preds: The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right hemicolectomy due to a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the cecum, with the tumor measuring 5.3 cm and extending into the muscularis propria but not through it. The surgical margins are negative for cancer, and there is no evidence of metastatic disease in the examined lymph nodes (0/32). Additionally, the apical lymph node shows no signs of metastasis, and the appendix is unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (Grade II) of the cervix, classified as AJCC Stage IB1, with a tumor thickness of 3 mm out of a total of 14 mm, and no evidence of lymphovascular invasion. The radical hysterectomy specimen shows no tumor in the uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes, vagina, or lymph nodes examined, confirming that the cancer is localized to the cervix. The microscopic examination reveals a solid appearance of the tumor with intermediate to high-grade nuclei and abundant mitotic activity, but it does not extend into the corpus of the uterus.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from the para-aortic and pelvic regions are negative for metastatic adenocarcinoma. However, a high-grade FIGO grade 3 endometrial adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation was identified in the uterus, invading 0.8 cm into the myometrium, with lymphovascular space invasion present. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are not involved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma of the left ovary, with metastatic implants found in the right ovary, fallopian tubes, serosal surface of the uterus, and omentum. Additionally, benign uterine leiomyomas and proliferative endometrium were noted, along with benign endo- and exocervical mucosa. Cytological analysis of peritoneal fluid was positive for serous carcinoma, confirming the presence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a unifocal papillary carcinoma of the thyroid gland, measuring 1 x 1 x 0.5 cm, located on the right side. The tumor exhibits invasion into the capsule or vessels and is characterized by trabecular or follicular structures with cuboidal epithelial cells that maintain polarity. There is a notable presence of inflammatory cells, but there is no extrathyroidal extension, and no special stains or markers were noted.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated, invasive, and ulcerated adenocarcinoma of the stomach (cardia) measuring 5.0 x 4.0 x 1.5 cm, with infiltration extending to the serosa and evidence of lymphatic and perineural invasion. Out of 27 dissected lymph nodes, 3 were found to be compromised by neoplasia, while surgical margins, greater omentum, and esophageal margins were free of neoplastic involvement. The pathological staging is classified as pT4 pN2, indicating advanced disease with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in the liver following an extended left hemihepatectomy, with a tumor size of 5.0x4.0x3.4 cm and a microtrabecular histologic type. The tumor exhibits partial capsule formation, 30% necrosis, and is classified as AJCC stage pT2, with no evidence of vascular invasion, satellite nodules, or intrahepatic metastasis. Additionally, cirrhosis is present, but there are no significant abnormalities noted in the gallbladder following cholecystectomy.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla are negative for carcinoma, while the left breast mastectomy reveals invasive ductal carcinoma with mucinous features measuring at least 3 cm, along with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The tumor is multifocal, located in the upper outer quadrant, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the right breast tissue shows benign changes, and the Oncotype DX assay indicates a recurrence score of 21, suggesting a 14% average rate of distant recurrence at 10 years.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an invasive adenocarcinoma located in the sigmoid colon, measuring 7.6 cm, with low-grade histologic differentiation and invasion through the muscularis propria into the subserosal adipose tissue. The surgical margins are clear of invasive carcinoma, with no metastatic carcinoma found in the examined lymph nodes (0/13). Additionally, the report notes the presence of lymphovascular invasion, while the spleen shows benign parenchyma with subcapsular hemorrhage.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary, with evidence of metastatic serous carcinoma in the right-sided pelvic peritoneum and one right para-aortic lymph node. The uterus, cervix, and left ovary show mild chronic cervicitis, inactive endometrium, adenomyosis, and a leiomyoma, but no tumors are present in these tissues. Additionally, rare atypical cells suggestive of carcinoma were found in the peri-ureteral tissue, while the majority of other specimens, including lymph nodes and various peritoneal sites, showed no evidence of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a neck dissection and a hemimandibulectomy, revealing a well-differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma in the right mandible measuring 4.5 cm, with cortical bone invasion but no perineural or vascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes from various levels of the neck dissection were negative for tumor, and margins from the right buccal, floor of mouth, and retromolar areas were also negative for malignancy. Additionally, a fragment from the right submandibular ganglion showed atypical cells suspicious for carcinoma, but definitive tumor presence was not confirmed in the surrounding tissues.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has endometrial adenocarcinoma of the well-differentiated (FIGO grade I) type, with a tumor size of 3.5 x 2.0 x 1.0 cm and minimal myometrial invasion. Both the right and left tubes and ovaries show acute salpingitis but are free of tumor, while the uterus and cervix exhibit adenomyosis and the presence of the endometrial carcinoma. Resection margins are clear, and there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous adenocarcinoma with focal clear cell adenocarcinoma in the endometrium, showing superficial invasion into the myometrium. Additionally, metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in both the left and right ovaries, while the cervix and fallopian tubes showed no evidence of malignancy. All examined lymph nodes were free of tumor, and the overall pathologic stage of the tumor is classified as T3a/NO/Mx.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower wedge resection of the lung revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.5 cm, with surgical margins uninvolved and no evidence of direct extension or vascular invasion. The right lower lobe lobectomy showed no residual malignancy, and two lymph nodes from this specimen were negative for metastatic disease. However, the level 12 lymph nodes demonstrated evidence of metastasis, while the level 7, level 9, and level 11 lymph nodes showed no evidence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the right tongue following a partial glossectomy, with a tumor size of 1.6 cm and a thickness of 9 mm. All examined margins and lymph nodes (25 total) were negative for malignancy, and perineural invasion was present. The tumor is classified as pT1 with no regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the right lung upper lobe, with solid, acinar, and lepidic patterns, and a tumor size of 1.6 cm, with negative margins and no pleural invasion. Additionally, a lymph node excised from level 10R is described as hyalinized and negative for neoplasm. Further studies are planned to determine the origin of the adenocarcinoma, with results to be reported later.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, papillary type (type 1), with a tumor size of 7.9 cm and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2. There is no evidence of tumor invasion into surrounding structures, including the ureter, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement. Additional findings include severe atrophy and cystic changes in the non-neoplastic kidney, with the AJCC staging classified as pT2a pNx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mucinous adenocarcinoma of the breast, classified as grade 2, with a tumor size measuring 3.5 x 3 cm. Examination of ten lymph nodes revealed no evidence of metastasis, and there is no venous invasion noted. The tumor is categorized as a T2 lesion, with margins and additional treatment effects not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, grade 3, measuring 3.5 cm, with ductal carcinoma in situ present but accounting for less than 5% of the tumor, and margins are negative but close at 1 mm from the posterior margin. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma was found in 2 of 14 axillary lymph nodes, with the largest metastasis measuring 3.4 cm and showing extracapsular extension. Overall, the findings suggest an aggressive breast cancer with lymph node involvement, necessitating further clinical management.

The pathology report describes a left kidney with a 5.5 cm tumor nodule that is a papillary renal cell carcinoma (type 2) with sarcomatoid features, invading the renal collecting system but not extending into perinephric fat. Histologically, the tumor is classified as grade 4 with some areas of grade 3, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. The report suggests the possibility of a hereditary syndrome related to the tumor, recommending further clinical evaluation and genetic testing for confirmation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left adrenalectomy and splenectomy, revealing a tumor measuring 7 x 5.5 x 5 cm and weighing 155 g. The diagnosis is adrenocortical carcinoma, classified as Grade 2, with a Weiss score of 5 and a Hough score of 1.89. The KI67 proliferation index was not evaluable, and the Van Slooten score was recorded at 12.3.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma consistent with primary peritoneal serous adenocarcinoma, with significant involvement of the omentum and minimal surface involvement of the right ovary. The report also notes the presence of a serous cystadenoma in the right ovary and small foci of adenocarcinoma in the left ovarian biopsy. An immunohistochemical stain for Her2neu was performed and returned negative, indicating no immunoreactivity for this oncopeptide.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic moderately to poorly differentiated papillary adenocarcinoma, primarily originating from the ovary, with extensive infiltration into the omentum, both ovaries, and multiple other sites including the bladder, cul-de-sac, and rectosigmoid region. The findings reveal that various tissues, including the spleen and liver, are almost completely replaced by papillary adenocarcinoma, with additional evidence of severe dysplasia and intraepithelial carcinoma in the fallopian tube. Overall, the report suggests widespread metastatic disease with significant tumor burden across multiple organs.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in both a tru-cut breast biopsy and a larger right breast specimen, with the tumor measuring 1.5 x 2.8 x 1.0 cm and located in the upper outer quadrant. The tumor is classified as NSABP histologic grade 3 and moderately differentiated, with vascular invasion present and the tumor margin being only 0.2 cm from the deep surgical margin. Additionally, six out of fifteen examined lymph nodes show evidence of metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a total gastrectomy specimen revealing an ulcerated poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma (diffuse type) of the gastric antrum, measuring 5 cm and invading all layers of the gastric wall, as well as surrounding fatty tissue and serosa. There is extensive metastatic involvement in 34 out of 40 perigastric lymph nodes and multiple nodular metastases in the greater omentum, while the resection margins are tumor-free. The tumor is staged as pT3, pN3, reflecting significant local and regional spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma of the right breast, measuring 4.0 cm, with Nottingham grade 2 and lymphovascular space invasion, while the left breast shows benign findings including fibroadinoma and columnar cell changes. Two out of eighteen lymph nodes examined were positive for metastatic carcinoma, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 1.6 cm and no extracapsular extension identified. The invasive tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER-2, with negative resection margins.

The pathology report indicates that all sentinel and non-sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla are negative for metastases. The wide excision of the left breast mass reveals invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 1.8 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ and negative surgical margins, except for a low-grade focus of DCIS at the inferior margin. The Oncotype DX assay shows a recurrence score of 0, suggesting a low risk of distant recurrence.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic serous papillary adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, pelvic sidewall, and cul de sac. Both the left and right fallopian tubes and ovaries show poorly differentiated serous papillary adenocarcinoma with extension to the peritubal tissue. Overall, the findings suggest widespread metastatic disease consistent with advanced serous papillary adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, confirmed through multiple samples from the right temporal region. Additional studies revealed cellular tumors without necrosis in various pieces, with some showing mild hypercellularity and unremarkable gray matter. Immunohistochemical analysis suggests a negative MGMT status and partial loss of PTEN, which may indicate a relatively unfavorable prognosis for the patient.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type, measuring 4.5 cm, with infiltration into the perirectal fatty tissue and metastasis to four regional lymph nodes. The circumferential, colon, and mesenteric resection margins are all tumor-free. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN2 (4/42) with a grade of G2, and it shows lymphovascular invasion (L1) but no perineural invasion (V0), indicating a locally resectable tumor (R0).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, uterus, and appendiceal tissue, with evidence of extensive lymphovascular invasion and metastasis to one lymph node. The primary tumor is characterized as undifferentiated carcinoma arising from well to moderately differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma, with invasion through the myometrium and into the serosal surface. The overall pathologic stage of the tumor is classified as T3/N1/MX (Stage IIIC), indicating advanced disease with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma, classified as grade 2 according to the World Health Organization (WHO) grading system. The tumor is located in the temporal lobe of a male patient. This finding suggests a low-grade glioma, which typically has a better prognosis compared to higher-grade tumors.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, involving the pancreatic head and body, with invasion into the ampulla of Vater, duodenal wall, and peripancreatic soft tissue. The tumor has a positive margin status (R1) and shows perineural invasion, with 8 out of 24 regional lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma, leading to a pathologic stage of IIB. Additional findings include chronic cholecystitis and fibrous luminal obliteration of the appendiceal tip, with no distant metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two foci of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 3.8 cm and 1.0 cm, respectively, with the tumor confined to the kidney and margins free of invasive carcinoma. Histological examination shows a Fuhrman nuclear grade of G2, and no lymphovascular invasion or necrosis was identified. Immunohistochemical studies support the diagnosis, and the pathological staging is classified as pT1aNX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in segments II and III of the liver, characterized by a large mass measuring 20.0 x 11.0 x 7.0 cm, with negative surgical margins. Additionally, a small excised nodule from segment VI of the liver is identified as an old sclerosed hemangioma. A biopsy from the left abdominal wall shows fibrin, inflammation, and reactive mesothelial cells, but is negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of a right lower lobe nodule confirmed a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma, which is poorly differentiated and high-grade. The tumor measures 22x20x1.5 cm, shows visceral pleural invasion, but no lymphovascular invasion, and is confined to the lung with a negative lymph node status (0/13 nodes). The tumor extends to the pleural surface, and immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, conventional type, located in the left thyroid lobe, measuring 1.8 cm, with no evidence of multifocality, extrathyroidal extension, or lymphovascular invasion. The resection margins are negative, and no tumor was found in the examined lymph node. Additionally, a frozen section analysis suggested the presence of a follicular adenoma with a tiny incidental papillary microcarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, measuring 2.5 cm, with a Nottingham score of 6/9 and no lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, there is ductal carcinoma in situ comprising 25% of the tumor volume, and all surgical margins are free of carcinoma, with the closest margin being 1 mm away. Sentinel lymph node analysis shows one of two nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma with extracapsular extension, while the other nodes are benign.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, which has extended into the muscular wall and shows focal squamous differentiation. All examined lymph nodes (33 total) and margins from the urinary bladder, prostate, and ureters are free of tumor, suggesting no lymphatic spread. The tumor is classified as pT3a, N0, MX according to the TNM staging system.

The pathology report indicates that multiple excised specimens from the deep right tongue base, left hard palate, deep skull base, left nasopharynx, and other areas are negative for tumor. However, a composite subtotal glossectomy and hemimandibulectomy specimen revealed a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity, with a tumor size of 7.0 cm and evidence of invasion into adjacent structures. Additionally, there is metastatic squamous cell carcinoma present in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, with extracapsular extension noted in some nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the omentum shows metastatic moderately differentiated papillary serous carcinoma, with a tumor grade of FIGO grade 2 and a high mitotic rate. The uterus and bilateral adnexa reveal focal changes suggestive of HPV effect, inactive endometrium with cystic change, and the presence of leiomyoma, while both ovaries are affected by papillary serous carcinoma. Additionally, the uterine tubes are unremarkable, and the overall staging is classified as pTNM stage T3c.

The pathology report indicates that the right axillary sentinel lymph node shows no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, with a total of 14 lymph nodes examined and none showing metastasis. The breast total mastectomy reveals an infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 3, with a tumor size of 35 mm and no lymphovascular invasion, while the margins are widely clear of invasive and in situ components. Additional findings suggest reactive lymphoid changes in the axillary lymph nodes, with immunohistochemical studies supporting a diagnosis of dermatopathic lymphadenitis rather than a lymphoproliferative disorder.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with sarcomatoid features, classified as Fuhrman Nuclear Grade IV and measuring 12.2 cm, with local invasion into the renal capsule and renal pelvis, as well as vena cava invasion. The resection of the vena caval thrombus showed tumor thrombus attached to the venous wall, while the proximal vena cava wall was negative for tumor involvement. All examined lymph nodes from various regions were found to be free of cancerous involvement.

The pathology report indicates that a right hemicolectomy specimen revealed an intramucosal well-differentiated adenocarcinoma arising from a tubulovillous adenoma in the cecum, measuring approximately 0.3 cm. Surgical resection margins are negative for tumor, and no tumor was identified in the appendix, with all 24 examined lymph nodes negative for metastases. The tumor is classified as pTis N0 Mx, indicating a complete resection with no evidence of invasive carcinoma beyond the lamina propria.

The pathology report indicates that malignant adenocarcinoma cells were identified in peritoneal washings from a patient with serous endometrial cancer. A hysterectomy revealed a grade 3 papillary serous carcinoma measuring 11.0 x 8.5 cm, with significant myometrial invasion and lymphovascular space invasion, but surgical margins were free of tumor. Lymph node dissections from both the right and left pelvic regions, as well as biopsies from the diaphragm and omentum, showed no evidence of neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary type II renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with the tumor measuring 2.8 cm and limited to the kidney without evidence of malignancy at the surgical margins. The pathologic stage is classified as pT1a NX MX, indicating a tumor confined to the kidney and no regional lymph node assessment possible. Key findings include a histologic grade predominantly III, absence of sarcomatoid features, and no evidence of perineural or vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis in the gallbladder. Additionally, a nephrectomy of the left kidney identified a 4.3 x 2.5 x 1.4 cm clear cell renal cell carcinoma, classified as pT1 with negative surgical margins and no evidence of lymphovascular invasion. The report confirms that the tumor is confined to the kidney without any additional lesions or lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the right leg mass is diagnosed as a high-grade undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma, measuring 8 x 6 x 3 cm, with 20% necrosis and evidence of vascular invasion. Immunohistochemical staining shows the tumor is negative for melanoma markers and other specific lineages, supporting the classification as undifferentiated sarcoma. The surgical margins are negative, with the closest margin being 1 mm from the tumor, and there is a superficial ulcer present on the skin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, in multiple biopsies from the right temporal region of the brain, with 5% tumor necrosis and 90% tumor cellularity. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis showed a normal EGFR and chromosome 7 signal pattern, with an EGFR gene to Cep 7 signal ratio of 1.1, suggesting no significant amplification of the EGFR gene. Immunohistochemical findings revealed up to 20% MGMT positivity, retained PTEN expression in 80% of tumor cells, and high levels of phosphorylated MAPK, which may indicate resistance to radiation therapy.

The pathology report indicates that the excised right neck mass is diagnosed as a diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, non-cleaved type, with a germinal center B-cell phenotype. The specimen was thoroughly examined and processed for various diagnostic studies, confirming the B-cell nature of the tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive markers consistent with B-cell lymphoma, supporting the final diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the liver nodule shows a minimally atypical epithelioid cell proliferation, likely representing a benign process, with no evidence of carcinoma. The right colon specimen reveals an invasive, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with focal mucinous features, which invades into the subserosal tissue, but surgical margins are free of tumor, and all examined lymph nodes are negative for carcinoma. Additional immunohistochemical analysis shows positive results for MLH1, MSH2, and MSH6, while PMS2 is negative, with microsatellite instability testing pending.

The pathology report indicates that a segmental resection of the colon at the splenic flexure revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, which invades through the bowel wall but shows no metastasis in the examined regional lymph nodes. Additionally, biopsies from the left lobe of the liver demonstrate granulomatous inflammation, negative for organisms, and a pelvic peritoneal nodule shows fat necrosis with fibrosis and calcification. The tumor margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear) cell type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4 and a tumor size of 12.0 cm, which extends into the perirenal adipose tissue and invades a blood vessel in the renal hilum. There is no evidence of renal vein invasion, and the vascular, ureteral, and soft tissue margins of resection are free of tumor, with the adrenal gland also showing no tumor presence. A portion of the left 12th rib was examined and found to have no gross abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy due to endometrioid adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 1, which is invasive to a depth of 0.3 cm with focal involvement of the lower uterine segment. There is no evidence of malignancy in the ovaries, peri-adnexal tissue, or lymph nodes examined, with a total of 30 lymph nodes showing no signs of metastasis. The overall pathologic stage of the tumor is classified as T1b/NO/MO (Stage IB).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the keratinizing type in the cervix, with focal lymphovascular space invasion noted. Additionally, severe dysplasia (CIN 3) is present, and the tumor extends to the edges of the tissue samples. The patient is a woman with a history of cervical bleeding, and the findings are based on the examination of cervical biopsy slides.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a tubular adenoma with low-grade intra-epithelial neoplasia in one specimen and a well-differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma of the sigmoid, which has arisen from the adenoma and shows submucosal infiltration. Additionally, there is evidence of chronic appendicitis characterized by lumen obliteration due to scar tissue, along with acute inflammatory changes and complications such as wall perforation and hemorrhage. Overall, the report describes a complex pathology involving both neoplastic and inflammatory processes, with no evidence of malignancy in the other examined segments.

The pathology report indicates that the right paratracheal lymph nodes showed no pathological diagnosis, while the parathyroid specimen revealed an adenoma consistent with diffuse hyperplasia. The right thyroid lobe and isthmus contained multifocal papillary carcinoma, with the largest tumor measuring 3.7 cm and no evidence of extrathyroidal extension or lymph node metastasis. Overall, the findings suggest a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid and a parathyroid adenoma, with no malignancy detected in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive, high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which extends into the prostatic stroma, along with prostatic adenocarcinoma classified as Gleason score 7 (4+3). Prognostic markers show an unfavorable profile with three altered biomarkers, suggesting an increased risk of recurrence. All examined lymph nodes (27 total) were negative for tumor, and resection margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 3, with a tumor size of 3.8 cm and associated high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising less than 10% of the tumor volume. One of the two sentinel lymph nodes examined showed metastatic carcinoma measuring 1.2 cm, accounting for approximately 40% of the lymph node volume, while the lumpectomy margins were negative for tumor. The overall staging is classified as IIB, with lymphovascular invasion present and receptor status showing 0% positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors, and a Ki-67 proliferative index of 70%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of thymoma, WHO type B2, following a sternotomy for a malignant neoplasm of the thymus, with the tumor confined to the mediastinum and no evidence of invasive growth. A benign lymph node was found adjacent to the thymus, and the tumor was completely excised, although it was noted that tumor cells were present near the surgical margin. Clinical follow-up is recommended to monitor for potential recurrence.

The pathology report indicates a right inferior parathyroid biopsy showing cellular parathyroid tissue. A total thyroidectomy revealed a unifocal papillary carcinoma, tall cell variant, measuring 2.5 cm, with local extension into the thyroid capsule and metastasis in 2 of 7 lymph nodes. Additionally, five separate papillary microcarcinomas were identified within the thyroid, and the margins of the primary tumor are uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates a left hemicolectomy specimen revealing a moderately differentiated, invasive mucous adenocarcinoma of the colon (G2), with permeation through all wall layers (pT3). The resection margins are free of cancer, and there are no affected lymph nodes (pN0), along with the presence of an additional tubular adenoma in the mucosal region. Additionally, diverticulum formations were noted throughout the intestine.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive transitional cell (urothelial) carcinoma, classified as grade III. The tumor was located in the bladder, measuring 4 cm, and was staged as pathological T3 with no evidence of metastasis (clinical M0). The procedure performed was a radical cystoprostatectomy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) in brain tissue obtained from a craniotomy, characterized by malignant astrocytic neoplasm with significant cytologic pleomorphism and necrosis. Additional genetic analysis revealed multiple abnormalities, including polysomy of chromosome 7 and loss of PTEN, which are associated with a poorer prognosis. The tumor exhibits a high proliferation index and various immunohistochemical markers, indicating aggressive behavior and potential treatment challenges.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma in a breast specimen obtained from a radical mastectomy, with a tumor size of 2.3 x 2.3 x 2 cm. Out of 10 examined lymph nodes, 2 showed evidence of metastasis. The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic counts.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the left mandibular mucosa, measuring 2.5 cm, with evidence of perineural invasion and focal invasion into the mandibular bone and underlying salivary gland tissue. The tumor is located close to several surgical margins, but all margins are reported as negative for carcinoma, and no carcinoma was identified in the 29 lymph nodes examined from the left neck dissection. The final pathological stage is classified as pT4a N0 Mx according to AJCC guidelines.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, involving both the right and left lobes of the prostate, with established extracapsular extension. The cancer comprises approximately 20% of the examined prostate volume, and perineural invasion is noted, but all surgical margins are free of carcinoma and no neoplasia is found in the examined lymph nodes. The final pathologic staging is pT3a N0 MX, indicating locally advanced prostate cancer without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a low-grade astrocytoma in the right temporal lobe, characterized by a MIB-1 proliferation index of 1.5%, with no mitotic figures or necrosis observed. Additionally, a separate specimen shows features of a high-grade glioma, possibly glioblastoma multiforme, with a significantly higher MIB-1 proliferation index of 98%, indicating increased cellularity and necrosis. The findings suggest a diffusely infiltrating glioma with varying histological grades, necessitating correlation with clinical and imaging data for final diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe cell type, with a nuclear grade of II/I, found in a right radical nephrectomy specimen. The tumor measures 6.8 cm, is confined within the renal capsule, and shows vascular invasion, but all surgical margins are free of tumor. The adrenal gland and hilar lymph nodes are unremarkable, with no metastatic involvement in the examined lymph node.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder, with a cystic duct lymph node showing no malignancy. The Whipple resection of the head of the pancreas revealed invasive moderate to poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma, with tumor invasion into surrounding tissues and involvement of 16 out of 19 dissected lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as pT3, indicating it extends beyond the pancreas, with lymphovascular and perineural invasion present.

The pathology report indicates that a female patient with a history of toxic goiter underwent a total thyroidectomy, revealing a tall cell variant of papillary carcinoma that spans the entire thyroid and measures at least 7 cm, with extensive extrathyroidal extension into surrounding tissues. Additionally, metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma was identified in all examined lymph nodes, including the delphian and left paratracheal nodes, with no extranodal extension noted. The report also mentions benign findings in the pretracheal and left supramediastinal tissues, with one parathyroid gland involved by the carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the pericaval and hepatic artery lymph nodes, as well as the bile duct and pancreas margins, are negative for metastatic malignancy. However, a ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, moderately differentiated (G2), was identified in the head of the pancreas, measuring 2.8 cm and invading the duodenal wall, with one regional lymph node involved (pN1). The tumor is staged as pT3, indicating it extends beyond the pancreas but does not involve major vascular structures.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant melanoma of the skin, characterized by superficial ulceration and a Breslow thickness of 1 cm. The tumor measures 4 x 3.5 cm and is located on the hip, with no evidence of venous invasion or specified lymphatic involvement. Margins and additional pathologic findings were not detailed in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 cholangiocarcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a mass measuring 2.4 x 2.3 x 2.0 cm that involves the right extrahepatic common hepatic bile duct and extends into surrounding liver and soft tissues. Surgical margins are negative for malignancy, and all examined hepatoduodenal lymph nodes are benign. Additionally, the distal bile duct margin is also negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that biopsies from both the right and left distal ureters show benign tissue with no evidence of carcinoma or dysplasia. In contrast, the radical cystoprostatectomy specimen reveals an invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma measuring 4.7 cm, primarily affecting the anterior bladder wall, but with all surgical margins and lymph nodes free of metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings include acute and chronic inflammation in the bladder and prostate, along with reactive urothelial atypia and focal intestinal metaplasia.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from the right posterior bladder wall tumor shows invasive urothelial carcinoma, classified as high grade. The tumor exhibits both papillary and flat growth patterns and has invaded the muscularis propria, although no vascular invasion was identified. Additionally, the non-neoplastic mucosa displays features of proliferative cystitis, including Brunn's nests and cystitis glandularis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma located in liver lobes 5, 7, and 8, with a maximum tumor size of 6x4x4 cm. Microscopic examination reveals trabecular patterns of tumor cells with irregularly large, hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant cytoplasm, invading the fibrous stroma. The tumor margins are uninvolved, and there is no specified information regarding lymph nodes, venous invasion, or neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower lobe neoplasm is an invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.5 cm, with evidence of pleural and angiolymphatic invasion, and metastatic adenocarcinoma found in two lymph nodes. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and the cancer is staged as T2 N1 MX. Additional biopsies of lymph nodes and pleura revealed benign reactive lymph nodes and benign fibroadipose tissue, with no tumor detected in those samples.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with a tumor diameter of 3.0 cm. The tumor is classified as not otherwise specified (NOS), grade III, and is staged as pT2LOVORO. This suggests a significant level of malignancy and potential for aggressive behavior.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of type 2 papillary renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 8.5 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade 2. There is no evidence of sarcomatoid features or capsular invasion, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement. The AJCC staging is classified as pT2 pNx, reflecting the tumor's characteristics and extent at the time of the report.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of endometrial cancer, specifically endometrioid adenocarcinoma, NOS, with a well-differentiated histologic grade (FIGO 1) and a maximum tumor size of 1.0 cm. There is no evidence of invasion, and the tumor involves 10% of both the anterior and posterior endomyometrium, with a background of complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. The FIGO stage is classified as IA, and no lymph nodes were examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma with focal squamous differentiation, involving the endometrium and lower uterine segment, with myometrial invasion of 33% but no serosal or cervical involvement. Lymphovascular space invasion is present, but all examined regional lymph nodes (21 total) show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The final AJCC pathologic stage is amended to pT1a, pN0, pMx, reflecting the depth of invasion and absence of lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total thyroidectomy due to a right thyroid mass, which was diagnosed as papillary thyroid carcinoma measuring 2.3 x 2.2 x 1.5 cm, with no evidence of lymphatic or capsular invasion. The left thyroid lobe showed no pathological changes. The tumor is classified as pT2 Nx Mx, indicating it is confined to the thyroid and not multifocal, with no lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the splenic flexure of the colon, with invasion through the muscularis propria. Surgical margins are uninvolved, but metastatic carcinoma is present in 7 out of 13 examined pericolonic lymph nodes. Additional testing for K-ras is requested, and no distant metastasis could be evaluated from this specimen.

The pathology report indicates that a 1.5x1x1 cm excised skin tumor is diagnosed as a moderately differentiated malignant melanoma with ulcerated and pigmented features. There are no specified details regarding satellite nodules, lymph nodes, lymphatic or venous invasion, or margins. Additional pathologic findings and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment are also not provided.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two colorectal adenocarcinomas in the left hemicolon, both moderately differentiated, with one tumor located 3.5 cm from the resection margin and the other 18 cm away. Both tumors exhibit invasive characteristics and are associated with severe dysplasia in adenomatous lesions. The resection margins are tumor-free, and all 36 examined local lymph nodes show no evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal carcinoma (G3) following a left nephrectomy, with a maximum tumor size of 5.5 cm and extension into the renal sinus fat, classified as pT3a. There is extensive invasion of large veins, but the adrenal gland and surgical margins are uninvolved by the tumor. No regional lymph nodes were identified, and distant metastasis is not assessed, with the report noting the presence of ganglia as an additional finding.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right hepatic lobectomy, revealing multiple foci of hepatocellular carcinoma, with the largest tumor measuring 8 cm and three satellite nodules nearby. The tumor is moderately to focally poorly differentiated, with no macroscopic vascular invasion identified, and the closest surgical margin is 1.7 cm from the tumor. Additionally, an abdominal wall excision showed fibrosis, hemorrhage, and granulation tissue without any malignancy noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma of the tongue, which involves deep soft tissue and shows angiolymphatic and perineural invasion, with one of 32 left neck lymph nodes being metastatic. Biopsies of the distal facial margin nerve and proximal neurovascular bundle revealed no tumor present, as did the submandibular gland. Surgical margins from the resection are negative for invasive tumor, suggesting complete removal of the primary tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 3, identified as a mass measuring 6.0 x 3.5 x 2.2 cm, with invasion into the myometrium and lymphovascular space invasion, but negative margins and no involvement of the endocervix. Multiple pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes were examined, with a total of 37 nodes showing no evidence of tumor involvement. Additionally, there are multiple intramural leiomyomas present in the myometrium, and the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates that a 1.8 cm poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the left upper lobe of the lung, with all surgical margins free of tumor and no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion. Six lymph nodes were examined, and none showed malignancy. The patient underwent a limited left thoracotomy with upper lobectomy, and the frozen section diagnosis confirmed the presence of carcinoma while ensuring the bronchial surgical margin was clear of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the tissue from the left orbit is consistent with recurrent melanoma, specifically showing spindled B morphology, with minimal necrosis present. The tumor is viable and has invaded focal background fibrous tissue, aligning with the patient's prior history of uveal melanoma. The gross description reveals multiple soft tissue fragments without discernible normal tissue, and the report confirms local recurrence of the tumor.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 2.1 cm, well-differentiated histologic grade, and no identified mitotic activity or necrosis. The tumor is partially encapsulated, with no evidence of blood vessel invasion, extrathyroid extension, or multicentricity, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue shows nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies of the left kidney show benign renal parenchyma, while the radical nephrectomy reveals multifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma with the largest tumor measuring 2.5 cm, and multiple angiomyolipomata. The tumor is confined to the kidney without invasion into surrounding tissues or involvement of surgical margins. Clinical investigation for a genetic disorder, such as tuberous sclerosis, is recommended due to the unusual association of multiple angiomyolipomas with renal carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multiple instances of urothelial carcinoma in situ and invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma, with the most invasive lesion located in the left anterior wall of the bladder, extending into perivesical fat. Lymph node dissection revealed benign lymph nodes in most regions, but metastatic carcinoma was identified in 2 of 3 perivesical lymph nodes. Surgical margins were positive for tumor at the left ureteral margin, and there is evidence of vascular and perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately-differentiated adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon and rectum, with invasion into but not through the muscularis propria (pT2). The surgical margins are negative for cancer, but metastatic carcinoma is identified in 2 out of 28 examined lymph nodes. Additionally, one apical lymph node biopsy was negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a left upper lobectomy revealing a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 40 mm, with invasion into the parietal pleura but no vascular invasion initially noted. Metastatic adenocarcinoma is present in one of the peribronchial lymph nodes and lymph node No. 5, with evidence of perineural and intraneural invasion in the surrounding tissue. The final pathological stage is classified as T3 N2, and supplementary elastic stains confirm unequivocal vascular invasion by the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a 6 x 8 cm left renal mass was diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a greatest diameter of 5.7 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion, renal vein invasion, or angiolymphatic invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney and measures less than or equal to 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical prostatectomy, revealing adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4, involving approximately 10% of the examined tissue and focally extending to the resection margin. The tumor is classified as pT2c, indicating involvement of both lobes, with perineural invasion noted but no lymph nodes sampled. The report highlights that the tumor extends to the resection margin at a focal distance of 1.1 mm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV, following a laparoscopic nephrectomy of the right kidney. The tumor measures 4.5 cm in greatest diameter, is solid in growth pattern, confined within the renal capsule, and shows no invasion of the renal vein, with all surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, the non-neoplastic kidney exhibits glomerulosclerosis and interstitial inflammation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of glioblastoma in multiple excised frontal brain lesions, characterized by varying degrees of solid and infiltrative growth patterns. The lesions exhibit features of high-grade malignancy, including nuclear anaplasia, brisk mitotic activity, and areas of necrosis. Overall, the findings confirm a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, with extensive infiltration of the cerebral cortex and white matter.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph node shows reactive sinus histiocytosis and is negative for carcinoma, while the right breast excision reveals benign tissue with usual ductal hyperplasia and no carcinoma. However, the right breast lumpectomy identifies invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 2, measuring 2.2 cm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ, also grade 2, with cribriform type and central necrosis. Margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma or DCIS, and no regional lymph node metastasis is identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated, large-cell, slightly keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma located in the right middle lobe, with evidence of metastasis to hilar lymph nodes. The tumor has caused significant obstruction of the middle lobe bronchus and has spread to the mucosal surface, but the resection margins to the main and upper lobe bronchus are free of dysplastic changes. Additionally, there is slight chronic retention pneumonia peripheral to the tumor, and other lymph nodes examined show reactive lesions without evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder, which is invading the detrusor muscle and shows vascular space invasion, with surgical margins free of carcinoma. No tumors were identified in the right and left ureters, urethra, or various lymph nodes examined, indicating no metastatic spread. Additionally, findings in the gallbladder reveal chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis, with no significant pathologic changes noted in the uterus, ovaries, and fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma in the bladder and prostate, with multicentric foci of invasive carcinoma and evidence of vascular and perineural invasion, classified as pT3b. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and no in situ carcinoma is identified, while the non-neoplastic mucosa shows chronic cystitis and other abnormalities. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes, ureters, and the left vas deferens are negative for metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in one of four lymph nodes from the right neck level I, while all other examined lymph nodes from various levels are negative for tumor. Additionally, a moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the anterior floor of mouth specimen, measuring 2.0 cm with perineural invasion, but negative margins were noted. The report concludes that the tumor is classified as pT1 with one positive lymph node (pN1) and no distant metastasis (pM0).

The pathology report indicates the presence of an extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma, characterized by a large, encapsulated tumor with an alveolar pattern and significant cellularity, along with focal necrosis and hemorrhage. Microscopic examination revealed no tumor in the lymph node, while electron microscopy confirmed the diagnosis by showing numerous secretory granules in the tumor cells. The tumor exhibited focal capsular invasion but no vascular invasion, and no adrenal tissue was identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated large cell squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, with tumor extension into adjacent structures and minimal pleural involvement. There is significant parenchymal necrosis due to disrupted blood flow from the tumor, along with reactive changes in the lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as stage IB, with no evidence of lymph node metastasis or infiltration into the bronchus or vascular structures.

The pathology report describes a 2.2 cm reddish, inhomogeneous tumor in the left adrenal gland, characterized by a trabecular architecture and medium-sized pleomorphic cells. The tumor is surrounded by a thin fibrous capsule, which is partially destroyed, indicating invasion into adjacent adipose tissue, and is associated with a hematoma that complicates complete resection. The final diagnosis is pheochromocytoma, with no evidence of necrosis, vessel invasion, or atypical mitotic activity.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 7.5 cm ulcerated moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach located in the cardia region, with invasion into the perigastric fat and extension to the esophageal wall. There are enlarged lymph nodes in the fatty tissue and omentum, but no evidence of metastatic disease in the examined lymph nodes. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is no venous invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, moderately differentiated rectal carcinoma, classified as adenocarcinoma grade 2. The tumor has penetrated all layers of the rectal wall, categorized as pT3, and shows lymphovascular invasion (L1, v1). This suggests a more advanced stage of cancer with potential for spread beyond the primary site.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the diaphragm, left ovary, left fallopian tube, uterus, right ovary, rectal tumor, and extensive metastatic involvement in various lymph nodes and the omentum. The findings reveal significant tumor invasion, with metastatic high-grade serous carcinoma identified in 27 out of 20 examined lymph nodes, and the largest metastatic focus in the omentum measuring 3.7 cm. The final staging is classified as pT3c/N1/M0 (Stage IIIC), indicating advanced disease with extensive regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Type A Thymoma, measuring 5.0 x 5.0 x 4.0 cm, classified as pT2 with no regional lymph node involvement (0/4). It is categorized as Masaoka stage II.2, with focal infiltration of mediastinal fat tissue and immunohistochemistry showing positive KL1 staining in epithelial cells, while CD1a, CD5, and CD117 are negative, with some CD1a-positive immature T-lymphocytes present among the epithelial cells.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a Whipple procedure revealing well-differentiated invasive ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, measuring 3.1 cm, with invasion into peripancreatic soft tissue and positive lymph nodes indicating metastasis. Specifically, ten out of nineteen lymph nodes from the peripancreatic area and four out of four lymph nodes from the left renal vein area tested positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the surgical margins were negative. Additionally, the gallbladder showed mild chronic cholecystitis, but no neoplastic changes were noted.

The pathology report indicates that the excisional biopsy of the right temporal lobe reveals a diagnosis of glioblastoma, characterized by extensive infiltration, nuclear anaplasia, and necrosis with pseudopalisading. Immunohistochemical analysis shows a high proliferation index of 60% and positive methylation of the MGMT promoter, suggesting potential responsiveness to alkylating agent therapy. The findings confirm a high-grade astrocytic neoplasm consistent with glioblastoma, supported by the presence of overexpressed p53 protein in the neoplastic cells.

The pathology report indicates that two lymph nodes excised from the phrenic area are negative for tumor involvement. A thymectomy revealed a 2.8 cm encapsulated type B2 thymoma, with negative resection margins and evidence of lymphoid hyperplasia in the non-neoplastic thymus. Additionally, nine lymph nodes examined were also negative for tumor, and there was no evidence of nerve involvement at the left phrenic nerve margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant melanoma, characterized by pigmented and ulcerated lesions composed of nevus-like and spindle-like cells, with a Clark level of V and a Breslow depth of 1 cm. Examination of three lymph nodes revealed metastasis in one inguinal lymph node, while the tumor was excised from the skin of the foot, measuring 2 x 1 x 3.5 cm. The margins of the excised tissue are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4 (score = 7), showing focal extraprostatic extension and positive margins at the left apex, as well as involvement of both seminal vesicles. The anterior bladder neck biopsy revealed benign muscle and fibroadipose tissue with no evidence of carcinoma. The tumor is classified as pT3bNXMX, indicating advanced disease with extensive involvement of the prostate and seminal vesicles, and there is also evidence of perineural infiltration and prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a high-grade liposarcoma with areas of necrosis in a specimen obtained from a radical resection involving the right retroperitoneum, right colon, right kidney, and right adrenal gland. The tumor measures 39.5 x 24.5 x 13.0 cm and exhibits a dedifferentiated component with a malignant fibrous histiocytoma-like growth pattern, and it is noted to be adherent to the kidney capsule and involving the colonic subserosa. Additionally, the normal psoas muscle specimen shows involvement by a well-differentiated liposarcoma.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated tubule-villous adenocarcinoma originating from the cardia of the stomach, which is focally invasive to the subserosa adipose tissue and extends to the distal esophagus, with a largest tumor size of 6.5 cm. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, but perineural invasion is present, and surgical margins are uninvolved by neoplasia. Additionally, all 28 examined lymph nodes from both the lesser and greater curvature are uninvolved by neoplasia, and the esophageal margin is also uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates a tumor located in the mediastinum, identified as a Type AB Thymoma. The tumor measures 6.0 x 5.5 cm. This finding suggests a neoplastic process originating from thymic tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast excision revealed an invasive ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, measuring 2.1 x 1.7 x 1.5 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and focal necrosis, and is 0.3 cm from the posterior margin. Among the sentinel lymph nodes examined, one showed micrometastatic carcinoma, while the other two were negative for carcinoma. Estrogen and progesterone receptors were positive, while HER2 testing was equivocal, with further evaluation pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing established extracapsular extension. The carcinoma occupies 20% of the examined prostate volume, with a maximum nodular dimension of 1.9 cm, and there is focal involvement at the right posterior distal urethral margin. Bilateral seminal vesicles are free of carcinoma, but perineural invasion is present, and the pathological TNM stage is pT3a Nx Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma, specifically a dominant follicular variant measuring 1.2 cm, along with additional smaller papillary microcarcinomas in the left hemithyroidectomy specimen. The tumor is encapsulated with no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion, and the margins are uninvolved by carcinoma. Pathologic staging is classified as pT1b, indicating the tumor is limited to the thyroid and measures more than 1 cm but not more than 2 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a B3 thymoma, characterized by a primary mass measuring 32x14 mm and multiple distinct nodules, with the largest infiltrating adjacent mediastinal tissue. The neoplasia is partially encapsulated, and additional small thymoma nodules were identified, but no invasive tendency was noted. Reactive lymph nodes were found in the surrounding adipose tissue, and the overall diagnosis is classified as Stage IIA according to the Masaoka-Koga system.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor measuring 4.2 x 3.6 x 1.1 cm that invades 0.6 cm into the myometrium, while the cervix and lower uterine segment remain uninvolved. The left ovary shows endosalpingiosis, while the right ovary and both fallopian tubes are unremarkable. All examined pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement, and the report includes excised skin and subcutaneous tissue from the abdomen.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon with neuroendocrine differentiation, classified as G3. The tumor shows extensive necrosis, significant peritumorous chronic inflammation, and infiltration into the colon wall and surrounding fatty tissue, with evidence of lymphatic spread and one regional lymph node metastasis. The tumor staging is pT3, pN2, MX, L1, with clear margins from the resection and accompanying chronic appendicitis.

The pathology report describes a right adrenal mass resection weighing 555 g and measuring 14.5 x 11.5 x 6.5 cm, characterized by a light brown, irregular external surface and friable, multilobulated internal tissue with yellow nodules and areas of hemorrhage. The diagnosis is adrenocortical carcinoma with a high nuclear grade, diffuse architectural pattern, and evidence of venous invasion, but no capsular invasion detected. The largest diameter of the tumor is 14 cm, with a mitotic count of greater than 5 in 50 high power fields and areas of necrosis present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with the tumor measuring 2x2x1.8 cm. The bronchial margins of resection are free of tumor, and two peribronchial lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT1N0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly to moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma involving the mandible, with the tumor abutting the anterior margin and being within 2 mm of the posterior margin. Additionally, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was identified in 4 out of 16 lymph nodes from the left neck dissection, with one lymph node grossly positive for the tumor. No tumor was present in the examined salivary glands or other soft tissue specimens from the floor of the mouth and surrounding areas.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis in the gallbladder. A left nephrectomy identified a renal cell carcinoma of clear-cell type, measuring 5.1 cm, confined to the kidney without evidence of metastasis or lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, an accessory spleen was noted in the spleen and tail of the pancreas specimen, with no abnormalities found in the pancreatic tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately well-differentiated adenocarcinoma of the left lung's lower lobe, measuring 3 cm, with focal bronchioloalveolar features. The carcinoma approaches but does not involve the pleura, and all margins of resection are negative for tumor. Additionally, one lymph node from each of the excised levels (5, 7, and 9) is negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the left sentinel lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement, with one lymph node examined from the first biopsy and eleven from the second, all showing no malignancy. A segmental mastectomy of the left breast revealed an infiltrating duct carcinoma measuring 0.8 x 0.7 x 0.6 cm, with a Nottingham score of 7/9 and no lymphovascular invasion, alongside ductal carcinoma in situ of the cribriform type. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive, weakly progesterone receptor positive, and HER-2/neu negative, with negative surgical margins and associated fibrocystic changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed invasive adenocarcinoma and mucinous type bronchial-alveolar adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe lung specimen, measuring 5.2 cm, with well to moderately differentiated histologic grade and uninvolved surgical margins. All examined lymph nodes (stations 7, 11, and 12) were negative for carcinoma, indicating no lymphatic spread. The tumor shows positive staining for CK7 and CK20, supporting the diagnosis, with no evidence of visceral pleura invasion or lymphatic invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates that the left lower lobectomy revealed poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.8 cm with visceral pleural invasion, while the bronchial and vascular margins were free of tumor. Among the lymph nodes examined, three out of five at station 12 and three out of four at station 11 showed metastatic carcinoma, while the other lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma. The tumor was characterized by positive immunohistochemical staining for p63 and CK5/6, supporting the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade muscle invasive urothelial cell carcinoma affecting most of the bladder wall, classified as T3aG3 NO M0. The tumor measures 5.5 cm in diameter, and all 18 examined lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor involvement. The anatomic site is identified as the bladder wall, not otherwise specified (NOS).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, predominantly clear cell type, with focal sarcomatoid differentiation and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 out of 4, measuring 10.0 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion but free surgical margins. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic clear cell carcinoma in the right parietal brain tumor and poorly differentiated malignant neoplasm in the right lung biopsy, suggestive of renal cell carcinoma metastasis. Other findings include positive malignant cells in a lymph node biopsy, tubular adenomas in colon polyps, and benign findings in a urine sample.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in the uterus, measuring 10.0 x 9.0 x 8.5 cm, with the tumor confined to the myometrium and no lymphovascular invasion identified. Surgical margins are uninvolved, and the endometrium shows no evidence of malignancy, with a pTNM stage of pT1bNO (FIGO IB). All excised lymph nodes and omentum are negative for metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse glioma in a Caucasian male, with the tumor located in the left temporal region of the brain. The tumor tissue was processed and analyzed, revealing a high percentage of astrocytic cells. Additionally, a blood sample was collected for further evaluation, but no abnormalities were noted in the blood analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade uterine leiomyosarcoma measuring 5 cm, with a suspicious focus for lymphovascular invasion, alongside findings of uterine leiomyoma, proliferative endometrium with endometritis, and cervicitis. Biopsies of lymph nodes from both the left and right pelvis showed no evidence of tumor in six examined nodes, while the omentum exhibited extensive acute inflammation without discrete lesions. Additional findings included a hemorrhagic corpus luteum cyst in the right ovary and paratubal cysts in the right fallopian tube, with the left ovary and fallopian tube showing no significant abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant mixed Mllerian tumor (carcinosarcoma) arising from an endometrial tumor polyp, with significant invasion into the cervical stroma and myometrium, as well as lymphovascular invasion. Metastatic carcinoma is present in one left parametrial lymph node and one high right para-aortic lymph node, while other lymph nodes examined show no tumor involvement. The report also notes the presence of uterine leiomyomata and various benign findings in the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from various regions (right external iliac, right obturator, right internal iliac, left obturator, and left internal iliac) were examined, and no tumors were found in any of them. The prostate and seminal vesicles showed the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3 + 4), with tumor foci located in both the peripheral and transition zones of the prostate, and focal marginal involvement cannot be unequivocally excluded. Additionally, perineural invasion was present, but no extraprostatic extension or lymphovascular invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Type AB thymoma, with the tumor measuring 5.0 x 4.5 x 3.5 cm and showing no extension through the capsule, classified as Stage 1. All examined regional lymph nodes were negative for tumor, and the margins of the thymus resection were uninvolved by tumor. Additional findings included focal cystic changes in the tumor and the presence of involuted thymic tissue, with no evidence of distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 3 endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with extensive lymphatic invasion and metastasis to multiple lymph nodes, including the right paraaortic, right pelvic, left pelvic, and cephalad IMA nodes. Additionally, a mucinous neoplasm of borderline malignancy was identified in the appendix, along with a small focus of metastatic endometrioid adenocarcinoma. The left and right adnexa, as well as the omentum and renal nodes, showed no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM), grade IV, located in the left parietal region, with significant histological features including pleomorphic astrocytes, numerous mitoses, microvascular proliferation, and extensive necrosis. The tumor was assessed through both frozen section and formalin-fixed specimens, with findings consistent across evaluations. The report emphasizes the presence of malignancy and has been personally interpreted by the signatory.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma extensively involving the left hemiglossectomy specimen, measuring approximately 4.0 cm, with the deep margin of resection being involved by tumor. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was identified in 2 of 22 right neck lymph nodes and 3 of 25 left neck lymph nodes, with the largest metastasis measuring 2.0 cm on the right and 1.0 cm on the left, both exhibiting extracapsular extension. Other biopsies from various sites, including the vallecular lesion and margins, showed no evidence of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 35 mm, with confirmed invasion of the visceral pleura and disruption of the pleural surface. Vascular invasion is noted, but there is no evidence of lymphatic or perineural invasion, and the surgical resection margin is clear of malignancy. The surrounding lung tissue shows signs of organizing obstructive pneumonitis, with no tumor identified in the additional nodules observed.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a micropapillary type adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe (LLL) of the lung, with a tumor size of 3.90 cm. The tumor is classified as stage II, with pathological T2 and N1, and no evidence of metastasis (M0). The differentiation of the tumor is noted as grade II.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma with focal squamous differentiation, affecting the bladder, prostate, seminal vesicles, urachus, and urethra, with a pathologic stage of pT3 due to invasion of perivesical soft tissue. The tumor exhibits a flat non-invasive component and an infiltrating invasive component, with identified perineural invasion but no vascular invasion or extravesical tumor extension. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and the prostate shows benign changes with granulomatous inflammation, while the bladder mucosa displays chronic cystitis.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from the right testis shows an immature teratoma with a histologic grade of III. There is evidence of infiltration into the spermatic cord, tunica albuginea, epididymis, and tunica vaginalis, along with neural, lymphatic, and sanguineous vascular invasion. Additionally, the spermatic cord margin is compromised, and the margin of the tunica vaginalis is minimal.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes excised from various locations (inferior pulmonary ligament, retroesophageal, hilar, subcarinal, and paratracheal) were all negative for malignancy. In contrast, a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.8 cm was identified in the right lung, with evidence of visceral pleura invasion and lymph-vascular invasion, but the bronchial margin was uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. The pathologic staging classified the primary tumor as pT2a and regional lymph nodes as pN1, with one involved lymph node out of ten examined.

The pathology report indicates that the distal left and right ureters are negative for neoplasm, while the additional prostatic tissue shows benign glandular tissue with areas of squamous metaplasia but no invasive malignancy. A radical cystoprostatectomy revealed infiltrating high-grade urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation, measuring 5.5 cm, extending through the bladder muscular wall to the inked radial margin, and marked necrosis was present. Both left and right lymph node dissections were negative for malignancy, and the prostate and seminal vesicles also showed no signs of cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, characterized by extensive necrosis and hemorrhage, with a tumor size of 9 x 9 x 6 cm and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2/4. The adrenal gland was examined and found to be negative for tumor involvement, and no lymphatic invasion was detected. The tumor is classified as pT2a, with no tumor seen at the specimen margins, suggesting it is limited to the kidney tissue examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive keratinizing squamous carcinoma of the larynx, classified as G2, pT2, with carcinoma in situ also present. The tumor measures 2.5 x 2.5 cm and infiltrates the supraglottal region and anterior commissure, but there are no signs of vascular, nerve, or cartilage invasion. Surgical incision lines are free of cancer invasion, and further analysis will be conducted on the full material.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as Nottingham grade 2, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm and lymphovascular space invasion present. Two lymph nodes from the left axillary sentinel biopsy showed carcinoma deposits, while two additional lymph nodes were negative for neoplasm. The surgical margins are negative for neoplasm, with the closest margin being 1.5 mm from the tumor, and the tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, as well as HER2/NEU at a level of 2+.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma of the esophagus, measuring 5.7 cm, with lymphatic invasion present but negative margins. Additionally, one lymph node from the left thoracic inlet is positive for metastatic carcinoma, while two retroportal lymph nodes are negative for neoplasm. The report also notes chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder and highlights the presence of high-grade dysplasia in the distal esophagus, with changes suspicious for invasive cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma of the right breast, with a tumor size of 3.0 x 1.4 x 1.8 cm and evidence of metastases in the axillary lymph nodes. Histological examination shows a moderate grade (NHG2) carcinoma with estrogen and progesterone receptors present in over 75% of the neoplastic cell nuclei, while HER2 testing returned a negative result. Additional findings include lesions consistent with fibrocystic mastopathy and infiltration of lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 3.5 cm, with invasion into the visceral pleura and lymphovascular invasion present. Out of 37 examined lymph nodes, one peribronchial lymph node was positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes from various levels were negative for metastasis. The bronchial and vascular margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, suggesting a localized tumor without extensive spread.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the cervix reveals invasive and ulcerated squamous cell carcinoma. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. This suggests that the cancer has penetrated the tissue but has not spread through the lymphatic or blood vessels.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the fundus of the stomach, measuring 8 x 6 x 1.7 cm, which is diagnosed as diffuse type adenocarcinoma. There is evidence of metastasis with 3 out of 11 lymph nodes positive for cancer. Additional details regarding invasion and margins were not specified, and there is no indication of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right kidney mass diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the chromophobe type, measuring 11 cm and exhibiting local invasion into the renal sinus fat, but with no renal vein invasion and free surgical margins. The non-neoplastic kidney shows signs of chronic interstitial inflammation, fibrosis, and glomerular sclerosis. Additionally, the excised right precaval and paracaval lymph nodes were not involved with cancer, as only one node was examined and found to be negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated papillary adenocarcinoma in the left lower lung, with a tumor size of 2.7 x 2.5 x 2.5 cm.
