All five examined lymph nodes show evidence of metastasis. Details regarding tumor extent, lymphatic and venous invasion, and margins are not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma, micropapillary predominant, measuring 3.5 cm, in the left upper lobe of the lung, with clear resection margins and no regional lymph node metastasis (0/3 benign lymph nodes). Molecular studies revealed no mutations in the KRAS or EGFR genes, and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) testing showed no rearrangement involving the ALK gene. Additional findings included emphysema, and the tumor was classified as poorly differentiated (G3) with lymph-vascular invasion present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, papillary type, with a Fuhrman grade of 2 and a tumor size of 2.4 cm. The tumor invades the renal capsule but shows minimal invasion into perirenal adipose tissue, with negative findings for carcinoma in Gerota's fascia, renal vein, ureter, and lymphatic vessels. The surgical margins are clear, with the tumor located 2 mm from the renal parenchymal margin, and the staging is classified as pT1a, pNx, pMx.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an angioinvasive adrenal cortical carcinoma measuring 12.5 cm, which has invaded the vena cava and shows involvement of a vascular margin, but there is no evidence of direct invasion into the kidney, gallbladder, or liver, nor any distant metastases. Additional findings include mild to moderate arteriosclerosis in the kidney and mildly active steatohepatitis in the liver, with no pathological diagnosis for the lymph nodes, gallbladder, or surgical waste. The tumor exhibits high-grade features, necrosis, and vascular invasion, with immunohistochemical staining consistent with adrenal cortical carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type, located 2.5 cm from the aboral resection margin and measuring 2.5 cm in diameter, with deep infiltration into the tunica muscularis propria. There are no tumor cells found in local lymph nodes, the colon, or the resection margins, indicating clear margins. The tumor is staged as pT2, pNO (0/26), pMX; G2, LO, V0, R0.

The pathology report confirms the diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in both the intercostal biopsy and the right paraspinal radical resection specimens. The tumor in the paraspinal resection measures 6.6 cm and involves skeletal muscle and fibroadipose tissue, with less than 5% necrosis and close proximity to surgical margins. The findings are consistent with the clinical diagnosis and were verified through personal examination of the slides.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 6.5 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as poorly differentiated (G-3), with invasion into the perigastric fat and metastasis to all six examined lymph nodes. There are also metastatic nodes in the omentum and two white spots on the spleen, although the surgical margins are free of tumor. The report notes that while the original staging suggested distant metastasis (M1), there is no supporting evidence in the patient's history.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of IV and a tumor size of 6.3 cm, extending into the renal pelvis but without renal vein invasion. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney shows chronic interstitial inflammation. Additionally, the excised perinephric fat contains benign fibroadipose tissue, with no lymph nodes identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an advanced mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colon, characterized by penetration through all parietal layers and vascular infiltrates (G3, pT3, L1, V1). The resection margins of the mucosa are regular, while the radial resection margin is free of cancer, showing mature fatty connective tissue. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes (0 out of 14) are free of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical prostatectomy, revealing invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7, involving both lobes of the prostate and approximately 30% of the examined volume, with established extracapsular extension and bilateral seminal vesicle invasion. All examined lymph nodes (23 total) were negative for carcinoma, and all surgical margins were free of tumor. The report also notes multifocal perineural invasion and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, with a clinical history of elevated PSA levels.

The pathology report describes a left adrenal gland tumor measuring 80x50x50 mm, identified as a pheochromocytoma with significant fibrotization and invasion into the fibrous adrenal capsule, but no infiltration beyond the capsule. The tumor exhibits high cellularity, nuclear pleomorphism, and atypical mitotic figures, with a proliferation activity of 1-2%. Additionally, large foci of Feyrter's metaplasia were noted in the periadrenal fat tissue, indicating a complex pathological process.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma with glandular differentiation, arising from a transurethral resection of a bladder tumor. The tumor has invaded the muscularis propria but shows no evidence of venous or lymphatic invasion. Staging reveals the primary tumor classified as pT2, with lymph nodes not assessed and distant metastasis unable to be evaluated.

The pathology report indicates the presence of three foci of carcinoma in an ablated breast sample, with the first tumor being a poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 2.8 cm and exhibiting focal intraductal components. The tumor-free dorsal resection margin suggests complete removal of the tumor at that site. The tumor is classified as NOS and mucinous carcinoma, grade III, with a staging of pT2(mult)NOLOVORX.

The pathology report indicates a 5x5 cm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the posterior wall of the stomach. The tumor has invaded the muscularis propria, but lymph nodes are negative for metastasis, and both proximal and distal margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additional details regarding omental margins and invasions are not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with a single tumor measuring 2.3 x 1.9 cm, exhibiting Edmondson grades II and III differentiation, and no evidence of necrosis or vascular invasion. The liver shows signs of cirrhosis and chronic hepatitis due to HBV, while the gallbladder specimen reveals mild chronic cholecystitis without stones or polyps. Surgical margins are clear with a 0.5 cm margin, and there are no signs of intrahepatic metastasis or multicentric occurrence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left anterior chest wall melanoma with residual melanoma present and all margins negative, along with changes at the previous biopsy site. In the left axillary lymph node contents, four out of eleven lymph nodes tested positive for melanoma, with the largest node measuring 45 mm and exhibiting extracapsular invasion. Additionally, two lymph nodes from the level 3 left axillary lymph node excision were found to be negative for melanoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade I, with focal superficial myoinvasion in the endometrium, while the cervix shows acute and chronic cervicitis but is negative for malignancy. The bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are also negative for malignancy, with endosalpingiosis noted in the left ovary, and lymph node dissections from the left pelvic and periaortic regions show no malignancy. Overall, the findings suggest early-stage endometrial cancer with no evidence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 55 mm moderately differentiated invasive ductal breast carcinoma in left-sided ablated breast tissue, with complete circumferential invasion of lymph vessels and no intraductal tumor component. The tumor has a minimum basal margin of 3 mm and is associated with fibrocystic changes, proliferating mastopathy, ductal hyperplasia, and sclerotic intraductal papillomas, while the epidermis and isolated samples of pectoral muscle are tumor-free. The tumor classification is M-8500/3, G 2, pT3, pL1, pN1a (1/13), pMx, and is staged as III A with R0 margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed subtype adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring approximately 5.0 cm in diameter, with infiltration of the visceral pleura and several tumor nodules present in the same lobe. The tumor classification is pT4, pNO (0/24), pMx, G2, although it would be classified as pT3 according to the current TNM classification. Additionally, EGFR mutation analysis was performed and returned negative results.

The pathology report describes a left adrenal gland specimen weighing 236g, containing a well-capsulated, multi-nodular tumor mass measuring 4.5x3.5x9 cm, which exhibits central necrosis. Microscopic examination confirms the diagnosis of malignant pheochromocytoma, with a PASS score of 12 indicating significant malignancy features such as necrosis, high cellularity, and invasion into surrounding tissues. Additionally, there is no evidence of disease in two small lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates that the omentectomy showed scattered adhesions with no tumor identified. The left salpingo-oophorectomy revealed a high-grade papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma confined to the ovary, measuring 17 cm, with no angiolymphatic invasion or surface capsular tumor growth. The hysterectomy with right salpingo-oophorectomy showed grade 1 endometrioid adenocarcinoma with inner half myometrial invasion, multiple uterine leiomyomata, and a single metastatic nodule of serous tumor in the right ovary, while peritoneal washings were negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) with various cellular differentiations, including giant cell and granular cell types, from a cystic lesion in the left frontal lobe of the brain. Immunohistochemical staining shows positive results for glial antigens and negative results for epithelial and melanoma-related antigens. The specimens included a small cystic mass and larger tumor fragments, all of which were processed for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma, specifically the dominant oncocytic follicular variant, measuring 2.0 cm in the right hemithyroidectomy specimen, along with chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. The tumor is encapsulated with minimal capsular invasion, and no lymph-vascular or perineural invasion is identified, with clear margins. Additionally, multiple papillary microcarcinomas, each measuring 0.1 cm, were noted, and there is no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with extensive lymphovascular space invasion, but all resection margins are free of tumor. The uterus, endometrium, myometrium, and adnexal structures show no evidence of malignancy, and a total of 27 lymph nodes examined are also free of metastatic disease. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IB, indicating it is confined to the uterus but larger than 5 mm, with no regional or distant metastases detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of recurrent or residual glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) in both a portion of an enhancing nodule and a right temporal lobectomy specimen. Microscopic examination reveals characteristics of high-grade astrocytoma, including nuclear pleomorphism, increased mitoses, vascular proliferation, and necrosis, with more pronounced features in the temporal lobectomy specimen. The gross descriptions of both specimens show irregular, hemorrhagic tissue with areas of necrosis and cyst formation, consistent with the diagnosis of malignant glioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma invading the mandible, with perineural involvement and infiltration into skeletal muscle, measuring 2.6 x 2.2 x 2.1 cm. The resection margins, including the new right lingual margin, are free of carcinoma, although the tumor extends to the right lingual surgical resection margin. A supplemental report is pending following the decalcification of the mandible.

The pathology report indicates a wedge resection of the liver revealing a 3 cm hepatocellular carcinoma, moderately to poorly differentiated, with negative surgical margins and no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion. Additionally, the specimen shows chronic hepatitis with fibrosis and focal fatty changes. Over 85% of the tumor is necrotic, and there is a chronic inflammatory infiltrate present in the portal tracts.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma (Grade 1, Stage IA) in the uterus, cervix, tubes, and ovaries, with no myometrial invasion or lymphovascular invasion identified. All examined lymph nodes from the left pelvic, left aortic, right pelvic, right common, and right caval regions were negative for metastasis. The report describes a nodular lesion in the endocervical canal and a papillary mass in the endometrial cavity, with microscopic findings supporting the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the excised right calf mass is diagnosed as malignant melanoma, specifically a nodular, polypoid type with a thickness of 7.4 cm and classified as pT4b. The tumor exhibits ulceration, lymphovascular invasion, and microsatellitosis, with a mitotic rate of 10/mm, while margins are free at a distance of 2 mm from the peripheral margin. Additionally, a satellite nodule was identified, but no precursor lesions or perineural invasion were noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7 in the left lobe and 3+5=8 in the right lobe, with a serum PSA level of 8.6 ng/ml and clinical stage CT2C. A radical prostatectomy revealed extensive bilateral tumor involvement, with established extraprostatic extension and perineural invasion, while one of five right pelvic lymph nodes showed a small focus of metastatic carcinoma. All surgical margins were free of neoplasia, and the final pathologic staging is T3a, N1, Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, measuring 3.3 cm, with a Fuhrman grade of 3, and shows lymphovascular invasion without renal capsule invasion. The surgical specimen from a right nephrectomy reveals negative vascular and ureteral margins, and the non-neoplastic kidney parenchyma shows minimal chronic changes likely related to age, with findings suggestive of thin glomerular basement membranes. Cytogenetic analysis identified a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 3, which is characteristic of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated, partially mucinous colorectal adenocarcinoma located 11.5 cm aborally to Bauhin's valve, with a tumor length of 3.5 cm that invades all layers of the intestinal wall and extends to the mesocolic fatty tissue. The tumor is staged as pT3, pN1 (2/24), with clear resection margins and no involvement of the greater omentum. Additionally, the appendix shows post-inflammatory fibrosis without evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, in the right upper pole of the kidney, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of acinar adenocarcinoma with a ductal component in the prostate, graded with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5). There is evidence of extra-prostatic extension, but no seminal vesicle invasion or lymphovascular and perineural invasion noted, with 20% of the prostate involved by carcinoma. Lymph node involvement shows one out of seven nodes on the left side is metastatic, while all eight nodes on the right are free of metastasis, leading to a pathological staging of pT3a, pN1, pMX.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a wide local excision of the right breast, revealing an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 1.7 cm, with negative surgical margins and associated ductal carcinoma in situ of the cribriform type. Four sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla were examined, all of which were negative for metastases. Additional tests showed the tumor to be estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor positive, and HER2 negative, with a recurrence score of 19.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 7.3 cm invasive moderately-differentiated adenocarcinoma located at the gastroesophageal junction, extending into the adventitia, with eight out of twenty lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement. The tumor is characterized by a centrally ulcerated mass with raised and rolled borders, and the margins of the resection are reported as free of cancer. There is no indication of preoperative chemotherapy or radiation therapy treatment.

The pathology report indicates that the lateral and medial margins show no evidence of tumor, while the paraspinal tumor is diagnosed as a neuroendocrine neoplasm consistent with extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma (paraganglioma), with negative margins. Tumor cells exhibit strong diffuse staining for chromogranin and synaptophysin, supporting the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma, presumed to be primary rather than metastatic. The report confirms that the laboratory is certified to perform high complexity clinical laboratory testing, and the immunohistochemical tests used for diagnosis have not been cleared or approved by the FDA.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an infiltrating astrocytoma in the hippocampus, characterized by mildly to moderately cellular regions alongside areas of high-grade astrocytoma. The tumor exhibits subpial condensation and has a MIB-1 labeling index of 17.2%, indicating a significant proliferation rate. The final diagnosis is anaplastic astrocytoma, classified as WHO grade III.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the right maxilla, with the tumor measuring 2.6 cm and eroding through the maxillary bone. Multiple surgical margins, including the deep, posterior, lingual nerve, superior, and medial margins, were found to be positive for carcinoma, while the anterior and lateral margins were negative. The report also notes extensive lymphovascular invasion and focal perineural invasion, with a minimum pathologic stage of pT4a, pNx, pMx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mucocellular adenocarcinoma of the stomach (G3, pT2, pN1) following a total organ resection. The tumor shows infiltration of the entire gastric wall and evidence of vascular invasion, with metastases identified in 2 out of 16 examined lymph nodes. The incision margins are free of neoplastic lesions.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a well-differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the pancreatic head, measuring 3.0 cm, with metastatic carcinoma found in 2 of 20 lymph nodes. The bile duct and pancreatic neck margins are negative for tumor, and there is no evidence of vascular or perineural invasion. Additionally, a benign ovarian cyst was identified in the left ovary, while the left fallopian tube and ovary were histologically unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, measuring 2.0 cm with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of II/IV, and showing focal extension into the perinephric fat. All surgical resection margins are free of tumor, but there is evidence of focal lymphovascular invasion, and the tumor is staged as T3a Nx Mx. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, with a low Ki67 proliferative index of 1%.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total thyroidectomy, revealing an encapsulated follicular carcinoma with foci of transcapsular invasion (2.5 cm) in the right lobe, along with two foci of papillary microcarcinoma (0.2 cm and 0.8 cm) in both lobes. Molecular testing showed no mutations in BRAF, NRAS, HRAS, or KRAS genes, and the FISH test was negative for RET/PTC rearrangement, suggesting a lower likelihood of aggressive behavior associated with these mutations. Additionally, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis was noted, but there was no evidence of angiolymphatic or extrathyroidal invasion, and the surgical margins were free of carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that a tumor type has been identified and the specimen was originally sent to the IGC Biospecimen Core Resource (BCR). The report includes instructions for completing the TCGA Missing Pathology Report Form, as well as details regarding the histology and site codes for the sample. However, specific diagnostic information about the case or patient is not provided in this report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma with nested features in the bladder, which is extensively invasive into the muscularis propria and suspicious for lymphovascular invasion. The tumor specimen measures 4.0 x 3.5 x 2.5 cm and shows signs of ulceration, necrosis, inflammation, and reactive stromal changes, suggesting a history of prior resection. The clinical history notes that the patient has a diagnosis of bladder cancer.

The pathology report indicates a resected colon sample with a centrally ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 4.8 cm, which has infiltrated the pericolic fatty tissue and shows two local lymph node metastases. The resection margins are tumor-free, and there are also individual tubular adenomas with moderate dysplasia present in the colon mucous membrane. The tumor is staged as pT2, pNO (0/27), pMX; G2, with no lymphovascular or perineural invasion and clear resection margins.

The pathology report indicates that a segmental resection of the sigmoid colon revealed an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that extends into the serosal fat, with all surgical margins free of tumor and no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in 22 examined lymph nodes. Additionally, there is a focus of foreign body reaction and granulation tissue adjacent to the tumor, likely related to a previous perforation or acute diverticulitis. The appendix, examined as an incidental finding, showed no significant histopathologic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver, characterized as well differentiated with a trabecular histologic type, and a safety margin of 0.5 cm with no evidence of invasion or metastasis. The gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis, and a biopsy of the pericystic lymph node reveals no tumor present. The specimen was obtained through partial hepatectomy and cholecystectomy, with a large tumor mass measuring 16.5 x 12.0 cm noted in the liver.

The pathology report indicates a right hemicolectomy specimen from the cecum, with a tumor measuring 6.5 x 7 x 5 cm. The tumor is classified as a moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma, extending to the subserosa. There are no specified details regarding lymph nodes, margins, or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast (NHG3, pT2, pNO) following a histopathological examination of the resected breast and axillary tissues. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed no estrogen or progesterone receptors, and a negative HER2 reaction in the invasive cancerous cells. The tumor measured 2.5 x 2.3 x 2.0 cm and was associated with fibrous mastopathy and adenosis in the surrounding glandular tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma at the base of the tongue, with metastatic involvement in three out of twenty-three lymph nodes from the right neck. Additionally, a total laryngectomy revealed moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with perineural invasion and a pathologic stage of pT3 N2b, while no tumor was found in the left neck lymph nodes. A separate finding of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma was noted in one lymph node from the left neck, with margins free of tumor in the excised tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional clear cell renal carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 8.1 cm and Fuhrman Nuclear Grade III/IV, showing local invasion into renal sinus fat and renal vein involvement. The excised lymph nodes were benign, with no evidence of metastasis, and the right adrenal gland was also found to be benign. The overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is pT3a, indicating invasion into surrounding tissues but not beyond Gerota's fascia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma involving the small intestine and sigmoid colon, characterized by a lymphomatous infiltrate of large lymphoid cells. The tumor mass measures 15 x 14 x 9 cm and exhibits a pale pink appearance, with a high proliferation fraction of over 90% and strong expression of anti-apoptotic molecules. Immunohistochemical analysis confirms the B-cell lineage of the neoplastic cells, with features consistent with the germinal center B-cell type, while excluding Burkitt lymphoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma involving the endocervical canal, lower uterine segment, and posterior vaginal cuff, with lymphovascular invasion noted. The tumor measures 1.1 cm and shows direct extension into multiple tissues, including the uterus and parametrial soft tissue, with metastatic carcinoma identified in one of four excised lymph nodes. Additionally, benign simple cysts were found in both ovaries and benign paratubal cysts in the fallopian tubes, while three lymph nodes from the left obturator and five from the right external showed no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that all examined lymph nodes from both the right and left sides, totaling thirty-five, are negative for tumor involvement. However, a cervical biopsy revealed the presence of large cell keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma with stromal invasion. The mucicarmine stain performed on the specimens was negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma, moderately differentiated, located in segment 5 of the liver, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm and free surgical margins. The gallbladder specimen shows cholelithiasis with no significant abnormalities noted. Additionally, there is evidence of chronic active hepatitis in the liver tissue, but no vascular or lymphatic invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total thyroidectomy due to a uni-nodular goiter, revealing a diagnosis of encapsulated follicular variant papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right lobe measuring 1.4 cm, along with an additional focus of papillary microcarcinoma in the left lobe measuring less than 0.1 cm. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or extrathyroidal extension, and all surgical margins are negative for carcinoma. Additionally, four benign lymph nodes were identified during the lymph node dissection, and the case is staged as pT1bNO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous adenocarcinoma, measuring 3.2 cm, in multiple specimens including the omental tumor mass, stomach, right and left tubes and ovaries, cul de sac tumors, and appendix. The tumor distribution suggests a primary peritoneal serous carcinoma, with grade 2 of 3 involvement noted in the right tube and ovary, and peritubal adhesions present. Additional findings in the uterus and cervix include squamous metaplasia, inactive endometrium, endometrial polyps, leiomyomata, and adenomyosis, but no malignancy was identified in these structures.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has left breast cancer, specifically invasive ductal carcinoma, with a poorly differentiated component and high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in one of the sentinel lymph nodes and one of six axillary lymph nodes examined, but no extranodal extension was observed. The additional anterior margin of the left breast showed no residual tumor, and the surrounding tissue revealed areas of DCIS and rare foci of infiltrating duct carcinoma.

The final pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with basaloid features in the right floor of the mouth, measuring 2.4 cm, with positive anterior, deep, and posterior resection margins. Additionally, two out of forty lymph nodes examined from a selective neck dissection show metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while other tissue samples from the neck and margins are negative for tumor. The overall TNM staging is pT2 N2b Mx, indicating a locally advanced tumor with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast tissue shows focal usual ductal hyperplasia and lactational changes, with no evidence of malignancy, while the left breast tissue reveals a well-differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 1.9 cm, with negative margins and no lymphatic invasion. The left axillary sentinel lymph node is negative for tumor, and additional findings include benign breast tissue in the left lower inner quadrant. The HER2 status has been amended to negative, confirming no amplification, and the estrogen and progesterone receptors are positive.

The pathology report indicates that no metastatic carcinoma was found in the four excised bilateral pelvic lymph nodes (0/4). The prostate specimen revealed a prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7/10, involving less than 5% of the prostate gland volume, and no extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle involvement was identified. The surgical margins were mostly negative for tumor, with the tumor focally abutting the left anterior inked capsule.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 3, measuring 2.8 cm, with negative margins following a left segmental mastectomy. Sentinel lymph node biopsies revealed no evidence of malignancy in three examined lymph nodes (0/2 and 0/1). Additional biopsies from surrounding breast tissue were negative for malignancy or atypia, and there was evidence of fibrocystic changes and ductal hyperplasia in the non-tumorous breast tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, classified as T1b with lymph node involvement (N1) and no distant metastasis (M0). The tumor measures approximately 2.9 cm, and there is evidence of possible lymphovascular invasion, although all resection margins are clear. A total of 23 lymph nodes were positive for cancer, with one node sampled during the procedure.

The pathology report indicates a subtotal gastrectomy specimen with a poorly differentiated diffuse type adenocarcinoma, measuring 30mm, which extends through the muscularis propria to the serosal margin. The proximal and distal resection margins are free of tumor, but metastatic adenocarcinoma is present in ten out of thirty-six examined lymph nodes. Additionally, there is evidence of perineural and intraneural invasion, along with a background of acute and chronic inflammation and the presence of Helicobacter pylori.

The pathology report indicates the presence of muscle-invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with high-grade features and extensive perivesical soft tissue invasion, as well as metastatic carcinoma identified in 4 out of 6 perivesical lymph nodes. Additionally, a separate focus of adenocarcinoma was found in the prostate, classified as Gleason score 7, but it was confined to the prostate without vascular invasion. The excised segments of the left and right distal ureters were reported as benign.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic ductal carcinoma, papillary type, in the right axillary sentinel lymph node, with extracasular spread measuring 0.3 cm. A modified radical mastectomy revealed invasive ductal carcinoma, also of the papillary type, with a maximum tumor size of 3 cm and Nottingham grade 2, alongside ductal carcinoma in situ accounting for 5% of the tumor mass. All surgical margins are free of invasive and in situ carcinoma, with one of sixteen examined axillary lymph nodes showing metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 6.0 cm, with a composition of 40% clear cells and 60% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3. The tumor is invasive into the renal vein and perinephric adipose tissue but does not invade the renal pelvis, and the margins of resection are free of tumor. The adrenal gland is unremarkable with no tumor present.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary serous carcinoma in both the left ovary and right ovary, with the left ovary showing a significant degree of involvement and a grade of 3/3. Additionally, there is a small deposit of adenocarcinoma confined to the endometrium and metastatic adenocarcinoma identified in the parametrial soft tissues and omentum. The report also notes that lymphovascular invasion is absent in the ovarian specimens, and no pathologic alterations were found in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a wedge resection of the liver revealing a solitary 2.4 x 2.2 cm mass diagnosed as Grade II hepatocellular carcinoma with a trabecular pattern. The tumor is confined to the liver, with all margins negative except for the posterior margin, which is indeterminate due to encroachment. The background shows micronodular cirrhosis, and there is no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion, with a cancer stage of pT1, pNX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma, favoring adenocarcinoma, from a right upper lobe transbronchial biopsy. Bronchial brushings and sputum specimens were inconclusive and did not show malignancy, while bronchial washings revealed no malignancy, only blood and acute inflammation. Additionally, a lobectomy of the right upper lobe confirmed poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma with squamous features, and there was evidence of tumor involvement in the chest wall, but lymph nodes were negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, with a tumor size of approximately 3.2 x 2.5 x 2.0 cm, extending into the ampulla and duodenal wall. The tumor is classified as moderately differentiated (G2) and shows perineural invasion, but all surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, with the closest invasive carcinoma being 4 mm from the uncinate margin. Pathologic staging reveals the tumor as pT3 due to its extension beyond the pancreas and pN1 indicating regional lymph node metastases, with 4 out of 17 examined nodes involved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade III, with invasion limited to half of the myometrium and a maximum thickness of 10 mm. No cervical invasion or lymph node involvement was identified, and the adnexae were unremarkable. Additional findings include atrophy and complex hyperplasia without atypia in the endometrium, and leiomyoma in the myometrium, while biopsies of lymph nodes and omentum revealed only mature adipose tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant epithelioid mesothelioma, extensively involving the pleura and infiltrating adjacent structures such as the pericardium, diaphragm, and lung parenchyma, with lymphovascular invasion present. Multiple lymph nodes were biopsied, revealing metastatic mesothelioma in several, with varying degrees of involvement, while the bone marrow and attached skeletal muscle were negative for metastatic tumor. The report concludes with a pathologic staging of pT3 N2 MX, highlighting the aggressive nature of the disease and the need for clinical correlation regarding the completeness of resection.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma (3.5 cm) in the bladder, with invasion into the detrusor muscle and perivesical fat, but surgical margins are free of tumor. Examination of lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions shows no evidence of carcinoma, and additional findings include a leiomyoma with degeneration in a right pelvic cyst. Other structures, including the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries, are free of tumor, with the cervix showing multiple nabothian cysts.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma in a resected rectosigmoid sample, measuring 6 cm, with infiltration into the pericolic fatty tissue and 30 regional lymph node metastases. The tumor-free resection margins include a minimum distance of 1 cm from the circumferential margin and a tumor-free mesenteric margin. Additionally, there is evidence of necrosis in peritoneal fatty tissue, and the tumor is classified as stage pT3 pN2 (31/45) pMX; G2, L1, V0, RX.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma in the resected section of the sigmoid colon, measuring 4.5 cm in diameter and extending up to 5 cm to one resection margin. The tumor shows invasive spread through all layers of the intestinal wall to the adjacent mesocolic fatty tissue and subserosa. The tumor is staged as pT3, with no regional lymph node involvement (0/22), and is classified as G2 with a complete resection (RO).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma involving the uterus, with direct extension into the lower uterine segment and extensive lymphovascular space invasion. Metastatic disease is confirmed in multiple lymph nodes, with one node showing extracapsular extension, while the ovaries and fallopian tubes show no histopathologic abnormalities. The tumor is staged as T2b/N1/MX, indicating significant local invasion and regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has infiltrating duct carcinoma in the left breast, with two lesions and lymphovascular invasion, and two out of two lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor positive, and strongly HER-2/neu positive, with surgical margins negative for carcinoma but very close to the excision margin. Additionally, the right breast tissue shows focal atypical ductal hyperplasia and other benign changes, with no significant malignancy detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of spindle cell thymoma, classified as Type A according to WHO standards, following a thymectomy procedure. The tumor measures 3 cm in greatest diameter, is completely encapsulated, and shows no invasion into surrounding tissues, with negative resection margins. The tumor is staged as pT1N0M0 (stage I), correlating with the clinical history of a mediastinal mass.

The pathology report indicates that the left neck specimen shows a mandibular gland with fibrosis and inflammation, and two lymph nodes without tumor presence. A composite resection of the left mandible and base of the tongue reveals a poorly differentiated keratinizing squamous carcinoma of the tongue, measuring 1.5 cm in thickness, with lymphatic and vascular invasion, but the margins of the lesion are free of tumor. Additionally, there is a microscopic focus of atypical epithelial cells suggestive of squamous carcinoma at the anterior margin, while other margins and the medial pharyngeal wall show no tumor present.

The pathology report indicates that the bronchial margin from the completion lobectomy shows no evidence of malignancy, and the bronchovascular margins are also free of tumor. A diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma is made from the left upper lobe wedge and chest wall, with the tumor invading the chest wall but no osseous invasion identified. Additionally, lymph node biopsies from levels 10, 11, and 9 show no evidence of malignancy, and other findings include chronic bronchitis and emphysema.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma located in the pre-pylorus of the stomach, characterized by an ulcerated and necrotic mucosa. The tumor measures 4 x 3 x 1 cm and shows invasion into the serosa, with 3 out of 5 adjacent lymph nodes positive for metastasis. Microscopic examination reveals hyperchromatic nuclei, irregularly enlarged nucleoli, and lymphocytic invasion in the stroma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right modified radical mastectomy due to multifocal invasive lobular carcinoma, with the largest tumor focus measuring 3 cm and classified as pT2, Nottingham grade 2. Additionally, the left breast tissue showed intraductal papilloma with atypical hyperplasia and small foci of lobular carcinoma in situ, but no evidence of invasive carcinoma was found in the examined lymph nodes. Surgical margins were free of invasive carcinoma, with the closest margin measuring approximately 1 mm.

The pathology report indicates that the left axilla sentinel lymph nodes showed no tumor involvement (0/3), while the right medial breast excision revealed usual ductal hyperplasia, sclerosing adenosis, and calcifications without tumor. The right breast partial mastectomy confirmed the presence of a 2.2 cm invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 3, along with high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with necrosis, but all margins were negative for invasive tumor and DCIS. Immunohistochemical tests for estrogen and progesterone receptors, as well as HER2/neu, were negative, indicating a lack of hormone receptor expression and HER2 overexpression in the invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a tubular adenocarcinoma (G2) in a segment of the large intestine, specifically at the rectosigmoid junction. The tumor measures 3.7 x 4.5 x 1.2 cm and surrounds 90% of the intestinal circumference, with clear margins at the incision lines. The diagnosis is classified as Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2, pT3, pNO, RO, indicating a locally advanced cancer without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left thyroid lobe, measuring 3.5 cm, with minimal extrathyroidal extension into surrounding soft tissues and skeletal muscle, but with free surgical margins. The right thyroid lobe contains benign thyroid tissue, while one of two examined central compartment lymph nodes shows metastatic involvement by the carcinoma, without extranodal extension. Overall, the tumor is classified as well-differentiated (G1) and unifocal, with one lymph node involved out of four examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO Grade 1 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with a tumor size of 3.1 x 2.1 cm and a maximum depth of invasion of 2.6 cm into the myometrium. The report also notes the presence of endometriosis and extensive adenomyosis, with no evidence of malignancy found in the examined lymph nodes (0/13 from the left pelvic nodes and 0/12 from the right pelvic nodes). Overall, the tumor is confined to the endometrium, and the specimen margins are not involved.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) of the right breast, classified as histological grade III, measuring 3.5 cm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) constituting less than 25% of the tumor mass. Both sentinel lymph nodes examined were benign with no evidence of metastatic tumor, and the lymph node status was 0/15 positive. Immunohistochemical studies showed positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2/neu was reported as negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating papillary (chromophil) renal cell carcinoma, oncocytic variant, in the left kidney, with extensive degenerative changes and necrosis. The tumor has invaded the perinephric adipose tissue and is classified as pTNM stage T3a NX MX, stage III, but there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or involvement of lymph nodes. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, suggesting complete resection of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade urothelial cell carcinoma in the bladder, with a tumor size of 2.9 x 2.5 x 1.2 cm that invades through the detrusor muscle into perivesical fat, but the surgical margins are negative for malignancy. Additionally, prostatic adenocarcinoma is identified with a Gleason score of 7, and there is no evidence of lymph node metastasis in the examined pelvic lymph nodes. The distal ureter margins are also negative for malignancy, confirming no tumor presence in those areas.

The pathology report indicates that the enucleated left eye contains a tumor nodule measuring 16 mm, diagnosed as uveal melanoma composed of epithelioid cells with severe atypia and moderate mitotic activity. The tumor shows infiltration into the ciliary body and sclera, with a focal extra-scleral nodule measuring 3 mm, while the optic nerve and its meningeal sheaths are free of tumor involvement. Approximately 60% of the tumor cells are pigmented with melanin, and the overall tumor thickness is 10 mm at its median part.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma in both the left and right breasts, with modified Black's nuclear grade 3 (poorly differentiated) and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) also identified in both specimens. The invasive carcinoma in the left breast measures 1.2 cm and is 2.2 cm from the closest margin, while the right breast invasive carcinoma measures 1.4 cm and has focal lymphovascular invasion, with DCIS present 0.35 cm from the lateral anterior margin. All excised sentinel lymph nodes from both sides show no evidence of tumor, and immunohistochemical analysis reveals low estrogen receptor positivity and negative results for progesterone receptor and HER-2/neu overexpression.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, showing extensive involvement of both lobes of the prostate, extraprostatic extension, and positive surgical margins. Additionally, one of three left pelvic lymph nodes is positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, while no tumors were found in the right pelvic lymph nodes. The overall pathologic stage is IV, indicating advanced disease with significant local and regional spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma primarily originating from the right ovary, with tumor deposits present on the surface and significant involvement of the right fallopian tube. Metastatic serous adenocarcinoma is also noted in the uterine serosa and rectosigmoid colon, with no evidence of malignancy found in the left ovary or fallopian tube, and all examined lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. The final staging is classified as T3c/NX/MO, indicating extensive peritoneal metastasis without distant spread.

The pathology report indicates the presence of grade 3 papillary serous adenocarcinoma involving both ovaries, with extension to the surface of the tumor mass and the adjacent fallopian tubes, as well as metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in multiple sites including the uterine serosa, recto-sigmoid area, and left external iliac lymph node. The omental biopsy shows adipose tissue with focal chronic inflammation and mesothelial hyperplasia, but no suspicious nodules were identified. Overall, the findings suggest advanced-stage ovarian cancer with extensive metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma from a specimen labeled "interaortocaval tumor," measuring 5.5 x 4 x 3.5 cm, with surgical margins free of tumor. One lymph node was examined, and no tumor was identified, while no adrenal tissue was found in the specimen. The tumor was described as a single piece of soft, red/purple tissue with a homogeneous, dark purple cut surface.

The pathology report indicates that the portahepatic lymph node is reactive with no tumor present, while the retroperitoneal mass is diagnosed as a paraganglioma, supported by immunohistochemical findings. Additionally, another lymph node showed artifact with no tumor detected. The tumor extends to the inked margin, and the immunohistochemical profile aligns with the diagnosis of paraganglioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in the liver segments, with a tumor measuring 10.8 x 10 x 8 cm that involves the capsule, although the surgical margin is free of tumor by 0.3 cm. Additionally, a 0.6 cm hemangioma is noted near the tumor. The gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis with multiple cholesterol polyps, but no stones are present.

The pathology report indicates that the right adrenal gland specimen shows a pheochromocytoma measuring 3 x 2.8 x 2.6 cm, weighing 29 grams, and is confined to the adrenal gland with free margins of resection. There is no evidence of blood vessel or lymph vessel invasion, and marked nuclear atypia is noted, but necrosis is absent. Immunohistochemical studies reveal positive staining for p27Kip1 and S100 in tumor cells, with an average of 13 labeled tumor cells per 20x field for Ki-67/Mib1.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left frontal gliosarcoma, characterized by neoplastic glial proliferation with nuclear anaplasia, frequent mitoses, and extensive necrosis. Additionally, a small area of infiltrative glioma was identified in the marginal tissue of the superior gyrus. The MGMT promoter methylation status was negative, suggesting that the patient may not benefit from therapy with alkylating agents.

The pathology report indicates a resected colon sample with an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of colorectal type, located 3.5 cm from the aboral resection margin and infiltrating the pericolic fatty tissue. There are five local lymph node metastases, but the resection margins are tumor-free, with the tumor being 0.2 cm from the circumferential resection margin. The tumor is staged as pT4, pN2 (5/34), pM1, with a grade of G2 and clinically classified as R2.

The histopathological examination of a partial organ resection from the left breast reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma, partially mucinous, measuring 1.7 cm in the largest dimension. The tumor is classified as NHG2, indicating moderate differentiation, with normal tissue margins observed. Additionally, the specimen shows signs of fibrous mastopathy and lipomatosis in the surrounding tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 8.5 cm in the left kidney, with involvement of the renal vein and a separate 0.9 cm nodular tumor focus near a large vessel in the renal hilum. The tumor exhibits a high mitotic rate and features such as coagulative necrosis and diffuse atypia, while the left adrenal gland is reported as benign. Although tumor is present at the renal vein margin, it is described as free-floating and not attached to the vessel wall, suggesting it may not represent a true positive margin, warranting clinical correlation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma (Fuhrman nuclear grade 2) in the left kidney, with a multifocal tumor measuring 2.5 cm and a positive surgical margin at the cauterized parenchymal margin, classified as pathologic stage I. Additionally, the report describes prostatic adenocarcinoma (Gleason score 3 + 4 = 7) involving both lobes of the prostate, with extraprostatic extension and a positive surgical margin at the left bladder neck, classified as pathologic stage III. No lymphovascular invasion was identified in either tumor, and regional lymph nodes were negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma of the glottis, involving the right true vocal cord, with surgical margins free of tumor. In the right modified radical neck dissection, one out of ten lymph nodes showed metastatic squamous carcinoma with extracapsular extension, specifically in the upper posterior cervical zone. Additional biopsies of the pharyngeal and tongue margins revealed no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma in the stomach, measuring 4.0 cm and infiltrating the serosa and adjacent adipose tissue, with lymphatic infiltration noted. The proximal surgical margin is compromised, while the distal margin and other examined sites, including the distal esophagus and thoracic esophagus, show no neoplastic involvement. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma is identified in 8 out of 26 lymph nodes, leading to a pathological staging of pT4a pN3a.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right nephrectomy due to a right kidney lesion, which was confirmed to be a conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma with Fuhrman nuclear grade III/IV, measuring 4.5 cm. Fluorescent in-situ hybridization analysis revealed monosomy of chromosome 17 in 35% of the tumor cells, consistent with the diagnosis. The final diagnosis confirmed no residual tumor in the renal parenchyma, with all surgical margins free of tumor and no evidence of invasion or significant pathologic abnormalities in the non-neoplastic kidney.

The pathology report indicates that the left partial mastectomy revealed poorly differentiated infiltrating duct carcinoma, nuclear grade III, with a maximum dimension of 2.4 cm, and duct carcinoma in situ present near the margins. In the left axillary lymph node dissection, metastatic carcinoma was identified in 5 out of 28 lymph nodes examined. Additionally, the left breast superficial and inferior margin showed fragments of benign fatty tissue and a 1 mm focus of infiltrating duct carcinoma, with its relationship to the margin being indeterminate.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in several lymph nodes and soft tissues of the right and left neck, with specific findings of metastatic carcinoma in lymphovascular spaces of the right oral labia and at the margins of re-excised tissues. Additionally, a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the anterior mandible, which involved the full thickness of the tissue sections and showed perineural and lymphovascular invasion, although the margins were reported as free of tumor. Overall, the report highlights significant metastatic disease in the neck and oral regions, necessitating further evaluation and management.

The pathology report indicates that the left temporal tumor is a well-differentiated astrocytoma, classified as WHO Grade II, with a MIB-1 labeling index of 3.6% and a focal area showing increased proliferation at 7.1%. The microscopic examination reveals a moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm with mild atypia, no mitotic activity, and no signs of microvascular proliferation or necrosis. Additionally, less than 10% of the specimen shows features of infiltrating low-grade glioma, but there is no definitive evidence of oligodendroglioma differentiation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4 + 4 = 8, and the cancer has extensively infiltrated both lobes of the prostate, with multifocal extraprostatic extension and perineural invasion. One of the nine examined right pelvic lymph nodes shows a microscopic focus of metastatic carcinoma, while all nine left pelvic lymph nodes are benign. The final diagnosis includes T3b, N1, MX staging, with focal tumor involvement at the right vas deferens resection margin.

The pathology report indicates a tumor in the right lower lobe of the lung measuring 3.5 x 2.0 x 2.2 cm. The diagnosis is Squamous Cell Carcinoma, basaloid type, classified as pT2a, with no regional lymph node involvement (0/38), and the metastatic status is unknown (pMx). The tumor is graded as G3, indicating a high level of differentiation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade pleomorphic myxofibrosarcoma in a soft tissue mass from the right thigh, measuring 17.5 cm, with close surgical margins of 0.1 cm and evidence of perineural invasion. Additionally, one of two excised lymph nodes shows involvement by metastatic sarcoma with extracapsular extension. The tumor exhibits significant pleomorphism, a high mitotic rate, and approximately 30% necrosis, leading to a pathologic stage of T2 N1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 out of 4, measuring 6.8 cm. Approximately 5% of the tumor is necrotic, and it involves the adipose tissue of the renal sinus, but there is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or invasion of perinephric adipose tissue. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and the pathologic TNM staging is pT3a Nx Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of primary endometrial cancer, specifically endometrioid adenocarcinoma, with a FIGO grade of 3 and deep myometrial invasion. The tumor is located in the anterior endometrial cavity and extends to the lower uterine segment, but there is no cervical or adnexal involvement, and lymphovascular space invasion is present with no regional lymph node metastasis identified. Additional findings include adenomyosis and an endometrial polyp, with pending results for estrogen and progesterone receptor immunohistochemistry.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the right posterior false vocal cord shows at least squamous cell carcinoma in situ, with focal suspicion for invasive squamous carcinoma, although no definite invasive carcinoma is identified. The biopsy of the left arytenoid reveals in situ squamous cell carcinoma accompanied by severe chronic inflammation, with no invasive carcinoma detected. The patient presented with dysphagia and underwent a triple panendoscopy for evaluation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of FIGO grade 3 endometrial serous adenocarcinoma, which forms a mass in the uterus and invades the myometrium and endocervix, with lymphovascular space invasion noted. Multiple lymph nodes from both the left and right pelvic regions, as well as para-aortic lymph nodes, show positive results for metastatic serous adenocarcinoma, while the omentum and gonadal vessels are negative for neoplasm. Additional biopsies from the ileal serosa and anterior vaginal mucosa reveal benign fibroadipose tissue and squamous mucosa, respectively, with no tumors detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a large, predominantly T2 hyperintense mass in the right posterior parietal lobe, measuring approximately 7 cm, which is diagnosed as an anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III). Microscopic examination reveals a highly cellular malignant glial neoplasm with marked nuclear pleomorphism and increased mitotic activity, along with subarachnoid accumulations of tumor cells. Additional genetic analysis shows polysomy of chromosomes 7 and 10, loss of 9p21, and a high proliferation index, suggesting a more aggressive tumor behavior.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 2 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus and cervix, with myometrial invasion and cervical involvement. The tumor is 6 mm from the deep cervical stromal margin, and there are changes suspicious for lymphovascular space invasion, although no malignancy was found in the examined lymph nodes. Hormone receptor status shows the tumor is estrogen receptor positive and weakly progesterone receptor positive, with an AJCC pathologic stage of pT2b pNO pMx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of carcinosarcoma (malignant mullerian mixed tumor) of the endometrium with myometrial invasion measuring 8 mm and lymphovascular invasion identified. All examined sentinel lymph nodes and additional lymph nodes were benign with no evidence of metastatic tumor, and the omentum showed benign fibroadipose tissue. The tumor exhibits a high proliferative index of over 90% as determined by Ki-67 labeling, with no immunohistochemical support for neuroendocrine differentiation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional clear cell type, with focal sarcomatoid features and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of IV. The tumor measures 9.5 cm, extends through the renal capsule, invades the renal vein, but all surgical margins are free of neoplasm, and no tumor was found in the examined lymph nodes. The adrenal gland is unaffected, and additional findings include arteriosclerosis and glomerulosclerosis in the non-neoplastic kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 2 endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, characterized by an 8.2 x 4.5 x 1.4 cm mass that invades the myometrium and extends 1.4 cm into the endocervix, with evidence of lymphovascular space invasion. Multiple leiomyomata are present in the myometrium, but the vaginal cuff margin and parametrium are negative for tumor, and the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes show no involvement. All examined lymph nodes, including those from the pelvic and para-aortic regions, are negative for tumor, indicating no lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon, measuring 4.0 cm, with invasion through the muscularis propria into pericolonic adipose tissue and involvement of the serosal surface, but without lymphovascular invasion. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in three out of twelve lymph nodes, while both proximal and distal resection margins are free of carcinoma. The AJCC staging is T4 N1 Mx, and the clinical context involves a history of colon cancer with a left ureteral stricture, leading to a palliative sigmoid colectomy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right renal mass diagnosed as conventional (clear cell) renal cell carcinoma with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 1.8 cm, with no local or renal vein invasion identified. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable. Additionally, the paracaval lymph nodes examined showed no involvement of cancer, confirming a pT1 staging for the renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bilateral papillary serous adenocarcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with FIGO grade 3 tumors measuring 4.5 x 4 x 2 cm and 8 x 7.5 x 3 cm, respectively, and positive serosal involvement. Additionally, metastatic papillary serous adenocarcinoma is identified in the omentum. The report confirms the diagnosis through immunostaining, which is consistent with primary serous carcinoma of the ovary.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a male with a history of achalasia, underwent a transhiatal esophagectomy, revealing a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma that is transmurally invasive and extends to the deep resection margin, classified as T3 N0 Mx. The cervical esophageal margin was free of invasive carcinoma, showing only squamous hyperplasia, and all examined lymph nodes were negative for neoplasm. The report confirms chronic inflammation and lack of ganglion cells consistent with achalasia, with no evidence of malignancy in the lymph nodes excised.

The pathology report indicates the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma, fibrolamellar variant, in the left lobe of the liver, with a tumor size of 10.0 cm and no evidence of perforation or vascular invasion. Among the examined lymph nodes, one periaortic lymph node is positive for metastatic disease, while the other lymph nodes are free of metastasis. The surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, with a distance of 1.3 cm from the closest margin.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant melanoma in a skin flap measuring 6 x 4.5 cm, with a brown spot of 2.5 cm in diameter and free surgical margins. Microscopic examination reveals superficial ulceration and a Breslow's depth of 2.5 mm, with no evidence of venous invasion. The tumor is characterized as pigmented and ulcerated, with no additional pathologic findings noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, located in the right lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 1.9 cm and unifocality. The tumor is classified as pT1, indicating it is less than 2 cm and confined to the thyroid, with uninvolved margins and no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. Additionally, there are findings of nodular hyperplasia and an unremarkable parathyroid tissue attached to the excised specimen.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately to poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma in the rectosigmoid colon, with a tumor size of 4.0 cm in length, 3.5 cm in width, and a maximum thickness of 1.5 cm. The tumor has invaded the superficial muscularis, with vascular invasion identified, but no serosal involvement or perineural invasion noted, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The pathological staging is pT2, with no lymph node involvement (pN0) as all 16 examined nodes were benign.

The pathology report indicates that no malignancy was found in the right and left pelvic lymph nodes, with a total of 15 nodes examined (0/2 and 0/13 respectively). The prostate specimen revealed multifocal adenocarcinoma, Gleason grade 3+4 (7/10), comprising approximately 25% of the gland, with focal angiolymphatic and perineural invasion present, but no extraprosthetic extension or seminal vesicle involvement. The pathological staging is classified as T2c, with all surgical margins negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a right frontal brain tumor diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV. The tumor exhibits characteristics such as neoplastic astrocytes, infiltration of the cortex, and areas of necrosis, but lacks definitive vascular endothelial proliferation. The specimen size is noted as 9 x 5.9 x 3 cm, with representative sections submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates that the left buccal mucosa shows squamous mucosa with acute and chronic inflammation, ulceration, and mild atypia, but no high-grade dysplasia or malignancy was found. A well-differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the left mandible, measuring 8.9 cm with bone invasion and perineural invasion, while one lymph node contained metastatic carcinoma. The surgical margins for the excised tissues were negative for carcinoma, and the overall lymph node status showed a total of 44 examined, with one node containing metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a left renal mass diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, measuring 3.5 x 3.0 x 3.0 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2/4. The tumor is confined to the kidney without evidence of transcapsular, renal vein, or vena caval invasion, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement. Additional findings include focal glomerulosclerosis and nephrocalcinosis, with the overall stage classified as pT1a, Nx, Mx.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing multifocal extracapsular extension. A total of 35 lymph nodes were examined, with no evidence of neoplasia found in any of them. The surgical margins are free of carcinoma, and there is evidence of perineural invasion, but no angiolymphatic invasion or seminal vesicle invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, gemistocytic type, with a MIB-1 labeling index of 2.0%. Microscopic examination reveals a diffusely infiltrative and moderately hypercellular astrocytic neoplasm, predominantly composed of gemistocytes, with moderate atypia and scattered markedly atypical cells. Notably, there are no mitoses, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis observed in the examined sections.

The pathology report indicates that the bronchial mucosa and multiple lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement. However, a lobectomy of the right upper lobe reveals infiltrating poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma, specifically large cell undifferentiated carcinoma with focal squamous features, measuring 5.6 cm. The carcinoma does not involve the pleural surface, and all margins and regional lymph nodes are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a liver biopsy revealing a nonspecific fibrotic nodule with calcification and no evidence of neoplasm, while peritoneal biopsies show metastatic poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma consistent with a pancreatic primary. A distal pancreatectomy specimen confirms invasive poorly-differentiated pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma measuring 9 x 8 x 3.2 cm, with positive margins and evidence of perineural and angiolymphatic invasion, classified as stage IV (pT3N0M1). Additionally, two of three accessory splenic nodules were positive for adenocarcinoma, while two peripancreatic lymph nodes were negative for neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the rectus abdominus measuring 3.5 x 3 x 1 cm, characterized as an exophytic adenocarcinoma that is moderately differentiated. The tumor extends into the perirectal tissues, with no lymph node metastasis detected (0/1 positive). Margins and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, with one of twelve lymph nodes in the left neck and five of sixteen lymph nodes in the right paratracheal and mediastinal regions showing tumor involvement. The total thyroidectomy revealed a 2.0 cm papillary thyroid carcinoma located in the isthmus, with extrathyroidal extension but no lymphovascular invasion, and negative resection margins. Additionally, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis was noted in the background thyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 2.5 cm, with well to moderately differentiated histologic features. No regional lymph node metastasis was identified in the examined lymph nodes, and the tumor margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, with no evidence of direct extension or vascular invasion. Additional findings include a central scar associated with the adenocarcinoma and sinus histiocytosis with anthracosis in the paraesophageal lymph node.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive well to moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 7 cm, involving the left posterolateral tongue, pharynx, and soft palate, with tumor extension to the right/midline lingual specimen margin. Lymph node examination revealed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in two out of 89 lymph nodes, with focal extranodal extension noted in one of the affected nodes. Immunohistochemical analysis for EGFR showed moderate to strong labeling in nearly all tumor cells, confirming the diagnosis remains unchanged.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 4 x 4 x 1.2 cm ulcerous tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma in the rectum-sigmoid boundary, with significant infiltration into surrounding tissues and metastases in regional lymph nodes. The tumor surrounds 80% of the intestinal circumference, with a minimum surgical margin of 6 cm, and the incision lines are free of neoplastic lesions. The histopathological diagnosis classifies the cancer as Dukes C, with a grade of G2, indicating a moderate level of differentiation.

The pathology report indicates a high-grade uterine leiomyosarcoma measuring 9 cm, with evidence of vascular space invasion and penetration of the uterine wall, but the serosa and parametrial edges are free of tumor. Histological examination reveals coagulative necrosis, severe nuclear atypia, and a high mitotic rate. All examined lymph nodes and omental tissue are benign, with no evidence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma, acinar type, with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, involving both lobes of the prostate and confined to the gland without extraprostatic extension. The tumor has a maximum diameter of 0.8 cm and comprises approximately 5% of the examined prostate volume, with all surgical margins free of neoplasia and no evidence of perineural or angiolymphatic invasion. Additionally, multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) is noted, and the pathological stage is classified as pT2c NX MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the pancreatic head, with a tumor size of 3.5 x 3.0 x 2.8 cm and evidence of invasion into peripancreatic soft tissue and the duodenal wall. Surgical margins are free of tumor, but metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in lymph nodes, confirming the spread of the disease. Additionally, chronic inflammation was noted in the common bile duct and chronic cholecystitis with cholesterolosis in the gallbladder.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing mild chronic cholecystitis and one reactive lymph node with no tumor present. A Whipple procedure was performed, identifying a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma of the pancreas measuring 3.1 cm, which invades peripancreatic soft tissue and the muscularis propria of the duodenum, with one of twenty lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. The tumor is staged as IIB, with negative surgical margins and evidence of lymphovascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a high-grade spindle and pleomorphic sarcoma in the right leg mass, consistent with malignant fibrous histiocytoma or undifferentiated high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma, measuring 9 x 6 x 4 cm, with 15% necrosis and involvement of the dermis, subcutis, and fascia. The tumor extends to the deep margin of resection and is located 0.1 cm from the lateral resection margin, but does not involve the attached periosteum or bone, with all other margins being negative. The lateral fascial margin shows benign fibro-adipose tissue, and immunostains reveal the tumor cells are negative for several markers, indicating a malignant process.

The pathology report indicates the presence of Barrett's esophagus with low-grade and focal high-grade dysplasia, but no invasive carcinoma was found in that biopsy. However, a separate biopsy of a tumor in the esophagus confirmed the diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. Additional biopsies from the stomach and distal esophagus showed non-tumorous changes, including mild chronic inflammation and reactive epithelial changes, with no evidence of Helicobacter pylori or intestinal metaplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of epithelioid cell melanoma located on the trunk of a male patient. The tumor measures 2.5 cm in diameter and 1.2 cm in height, with a Breslow thickness of 15 mm and classified as Clark level V. The melanoma is staged as II A, T4, N0, M0, indicating no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 10.0 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 and evidence of vascular-lymphatic invasion, although the tumor is confined to the kidney with resection margins free of tumor. Additionally, metastatic papillary renal cell carcinoma is present in all three examined regional lymph nodes and in matted para-aortic lymph nodes, with small foci of tumor noted within vascular-lymphatic spaces in the surrounding adipose tissue. The adrenal gland shows no evidence of tumor involvement, and the tumor's characteristics are consistent with type 2 papillary renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated gastric adenocarcinoma (G-3) with ulceration and invasion into the subserosa and surrounding fatty tissue. Out of 15 examined lymph nodes, 8 showed evidence of metastasis, while there was no venous invasion noted. The tumor measures 7.5 cm and the surgical margins are uninvolved, suggesting complete resection of the primary tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the brain biopsy reveals a diagnosis of glioblastoma, characterized by high cellular density, nuclear pleomorphism, and vascular proliferation with necrosis. The tumor shows a high proliferative index of more than 40% as measured by MIB-1 staining. The astrocytic origin of the tumor cells is confirmed by positive GFAP staining.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, grade 2, measuring 5.5 cm, confined to the right kidney with no tumor present at the vascular and ureteral margins. Additionally, two pericaval lymph nodes were examined and found to be free of tumor, while a left adrenal myelolipoma measuring 7.5 cm was identified. The report includes detailed descriptions of the specimens and sections submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two invasive carcinomas: endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, classified as FIGO grade 3, and cervical adenoid basal carcinoma, which is deeply invasive but confined to the cervix. The endometrioid carcinoma shows stromal invasion into the cervix, while the adenoid basal carcinoma measures 1.4 cm in greatest horizontal dimension and is also associated with high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL/CIN 3). Both tumors exhibit distinct histological features and immunostaining profiles, confirming their classification as separate primary malignancies.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.5 x 1.5 x 1.5 cm, with no visceral or lymphovascular invasion identified. The tumor is unifocal and approaches the stapled parenchymal margin to within less than 0.1 cm, but the surgical margins are otherwise clear, with no metastatic carcinoma found in the examined lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of primary pulmonary adenocarcinoma, excluding the possibility of metastasis from the patient's prior renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma in both the right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes, with additional metastatic disease found in the uterine serosa and omentum. The uterus shows atrophic endometrium, leiomyomas, adenomyosis, and endometriosis in the fallopian tube.
