Overall, the findings are consistent with advanced ovarian cancer with multiple metastatic sites.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 5.5 cm pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland, characterized by tumor cells arranged in well-defined nests with a finely granular cytoplasm and round to oval nuclei. Immunohistochemical staining shows positive results for synaptophysin in the tumor cells and S-100 in the sustentacular cells, while the surrounding adrenal cortical tissue appears unremarkable. The specimen was obtained during an adrenalectomy procedure, and no margins were required for the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a left orchidectomy was performed, revealing a nonseminoma tumor with a diameter of 4 cm. The tumor is confined to the testis and shows evidence of angioinvasion, but there is no invasion into the rete testis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of abnormal cells consistent with malignancy. Further analysis reveals the tumor is invasive and has characteristics suggestive of a specific type of cancer. Recommendations for additional diagnostic imaging and treatment options are provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, poorly differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma with partial neuroendocrine differentiation (G3). The tumor has penetrated all wall layers (pT3) and shows vascular invasion (L1, V1), with five out of fifteen lymph nodes affected by metastases. Resection margins are free of cancer, and there is also evidence of chronic appendicitis and a free ligature area.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of thymoma, predominantly epithelioid, with a maximum tumor dimension of 6 cm and microscopic extension beyond the capsule. The tumor is noted to come within 0.5 mm of the resection margin but is not present at the inked margin, and no lymphovascular invasion is identified. Microscopic examination reveals neoplastic cells with mild pleomorphism and areas of necrosis, surrounded by a fibrous capsule and interspersed with benign thymic remnants.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the skin measuring 2 x 1.5 x 0.4 cm, characterized as an ulcerated and raised nodular melanoma. The tumor is classified at IV level and is 6.0 mm deep, but details regarding lymph nodes, invasion, margins, and additional findings are not specified. Overall, the report highlights the presence of a significant melanoma requiring further evaluation and management.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has bilateral infiltrating ductal carcinoma, with the right breast tumor measuring 2.2 x 2.0 x 1.5 cm and the left breast tumor measuring 2.2 x 1.8 x 1.8 cm, both classified as Grade II. The right breast mastectomy margins are negative for tumor, while the left breast tumor abuts the deep margin with focal vascular invasion and associated ductal carcinoma in situ. Sentinel lymph nodes from both axillae show no evidence of malignancy, and additional breast tissue excisions are unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right thyroid lobectomy and mediastinal lymph node biopsy due to a right thyroid mass and suspected lymphoma or sarcoidosis. The findings confirmed a follicular variant of papillary carcinoma in the right thyroid lobe, with margins free of neoplasm, while the mediastinal lymph nodes showed non-necrotizing granulomas and were negative for neoplasm. Additionally, the left thyroid lobe exhibited lymphocytic thyroiditis, and the Delphian lymph nodes were also negative for neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic infiltrating glioma (WHO Grade III) in a left frontal tumor, characterized by increased mitotic activity and variable cytologic features. Immunohistochemical analysis showed strong p53 labeling and a moderate MIB-1 labeling index, with molecular studies negative for 1p/19q loss. The report includes multiple specimens and addenda, with no definitive professional opinion provided by the reviewing pathologist due to their absence during the case evaluation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the left tongue, measuring 4.0 cm, with the tumor extending to within 1 mm of the deep margin, while all other margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in three lymph nodes, with focal extranodal extension noted, and a total of 51 lymph nodes examined. The report confirms that there is no distant metastasis assessed, and perineural invasion is absent, while vascular invasion is present.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type, with a tumor size of 6.0 cm and a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV, showing local invasion into the renal sinus fat and multiple muscular branches of the renal vein. Surgical margins are positive for tumor presence, with a clearance of 0.4 cm from the resection margin, and the tumor is staged as pT3b due to its extension into the renal vein. The pericaval lymph nodes examined showed no involvement of cancer, with a total of 9 nodes assessed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left temporal anaplastic oligodendroglioma, grade III, characterized by a hypercellular and diffusely infiltrating glial neoplasm with moderate nuclear atypia and numerous mitotic figures. The MIB-1 labeling index is 34.7%, suggesting a high proliferation rate, while a minority of cells show positivity for p53, and the tumor is negative for IDH1. Additionally, there are features of microvascular laceration and occasional foci of necrosis, but no cystic differentiation is observed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma in the left retroperitoneum, measuring 27.5 cm, with significant necrosis and involvement of surrounding structures including the left kidney, ureter, and descending colon. Surgical margins were mostly negative for tumor, except for the adipose tissue surface, and the tumor exhibited a high mitotic rate of 65 mitoses per 10 high power fields. Immunohistochemical staining suggests the tumor does not fit the criteria for well-differentiated liposarcoma, leading to its classification as a pleomorphic high-grade sarcoma, NOS.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of primary liver cancer, specifically a mix of cholangiocarcinoma and hepatocellular carcinoma with poorly differentiated ductal characteristics. The gross examination reveals a gray mass with necrotic areas in the left lobe of the liver, but there is no infiltration of the liver capsule. Additionally, lymphatic nodes show no signs of tumor growth.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a bilateral simple mastectomy due to invasive lobular carcinoma in the left breast, with the tumor measuring 7.0 cm and showing nuclear grade II/III characteristics. Sentinel lymph node biopsies from both sides revealed no evidence of metastatic disease, supported by negative immunohistochemical staining. The right mastectomy showed fibrocystic changes and non-atypical intraductal epithelial hyperplasia, with no malignancy detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, with a predominant mass measuring 11 x 10 x 8 cm and a satellite nodule present. The surgical margins are clear of tumor, with the closest margin being 0.5 cm. Additionally, the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis without stones, and the excised pericholedochal lymph node is negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe wedge biopsy reveals a well to moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 1.5 cm, with negative margins and no vascular invasion. The lymph node level 5 shows no evidence of malignancy. The tumor is classified as pTNM Stage T1 N0, and immunohistochemical staining supports a lung primary origin.

The pathology report indicates a biopsy of a left parieto-occipital brain mass diagnosed as a Grade 4 fibrillary astrocytoma, classified as glioblastoma according to WHO standards. The tissue samples measured 3.2 x 2.2 x 0.3 cm and 5.2 x 2.4 x 0.7 cm. A preliminary frozen section suggested the presence of an astrocytoma, favoring a small cell type of at least intermediate grade, pending final typing and grading.

The pathology report describes a mildly to moderately hypercellular infiltrating glial neoplasm with characteristics of low-grade oligodendroglioma grade II. The neoplastic cells exhibit round, enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos, with notable gemistocytic cells present. There is a myxoid to macrocystic background, and no microvascular proliferation or necrosis is observed, along with a rare mitotic figure.

The pathology report describes a surgical resection of a left frontal brain lesion, revealing an infiltrative oligodendroglioma classified as grade II. Histological analysis shows relatively monomorphic neoplastic glial cells with a rich vascular network and areas of dystrophic calcifications, but no significant atypia or necrosis. Genetic analysis indicates isolated codeletion of 19q, confirming the diagnosis of diffuse oligodendroglioma.

The pathology report indicates histomorphology consistent with diffuse astrocytoma, characterized by a proliferation index of 2%. There is noted increased nuclear pleomorphism, suggesting a borderline case. The final diagnosis is astrocytoma, classified as WHO grade II.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical prostatectomy, revealing prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+4=8, involving approximately 35% of the sampled prostate tissue, but with negative margins and no extraprostatic extension. Additionally, all ten lymph nodes dissected from the right and left external iliac and obturator regions were found to be benign and negative for malignancy. The overall pathologic staging is pT2c, NO, indicating localized prostate cancer without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a trans-scleral resection of a choroidal melanoma of mixed cell type, characterized by a predominantly spindle cell composition with a minor epithelioid component. Histological examination reveals tumor extension into the sclera, with the lateral resection margins free of tumor, while molecular genetic analysis shows normal chromosome 1, essentially normal chromosome 3, gains in chromosome 6p, and borderline gains in chromosome 8q. Further investigations will correlate these molecular findings with clinical and morphological data to assess metastatic risk.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metaplastic carcinoma of the breast, spindle cell type, Nottingham grade II, with an invasive tumor measuring 3.8 cm and negative lymphovascular space invasion. The tumor is located in the central area of the left breast, with negative surgical margins, although a focus of invasive carcinoma is less than 1.0 mm from the anterior margin. Hormone receptor testing shows the tumor is negative for estrogen receptors and weakly positive for progesterone receptors, with no HER-2 overexpression detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme with an oligodendroglioma component (WHO Grade IV) from a left brain mass. The tumor exhibits high cellularity, mitoses, vascular proliferation, and necrosis, with a Ki-67 labeling index of 20-30% and P53 reactivity in about 20% of tumor cell nuclei. Chromosomal analysis revealed no deletions of 1p or 19q in the tumor tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma in the stomach, measuring 7.5 cm, with ulceration and invasion into the mucosa, muscularis mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria, and adjacent adipose tissue. Lymphatic vascular invasion is present, and 4 out of 15 dissected lymph nodes are involved by neoplasia, primarily located at the lesser curvature. Both proximal and distal margins, as well as the great omentum and other examined sites, are uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma, high grade, arising from a large retroperitoneal mass measuring 25 cm, which involves the left kidney, spleen, distal pancreas, and colon, with well-differentiated liposarcoma features noted in the pancreas. The tumor shows extensive necrosis and high-grade non-lipogenic elements invading the renal cortex, while colonic margins are free of tumor. Immunohistochemical staining reveals positive CD10 and negative results for other markers, confirming the diagnosis based on personal examination of the slides.

The pathology report indicates that the left occipital tumor has been diagnosed as glioblastoma, WHO grade IV, characterized by high cellularity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis. The tumor exhibits a mitotic rate of 5 per 10 high-power fields and shows positive immunohistochemical results for p53 and MGMT, with approximately 90% of the tumor being MGMT positive. FISH analysis revealed negative results for 1p/19q codeletion and PTEN deletion, while showing positive polysomy for chromosomes 1, 7, and 19, consistent with glioblastoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, with a tumor size of 1.2 x 1.1 x 0.8 cm and metastases identified in axillary lymph nodes (No VI/XIV). Histological examination shows a high mitotic rate and associated lesions of mastopathia fibrosa et cystica and lipomatosis. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals over 75% of neoplastic cell nuclei expressing estrogen receptors, no progesterone receptors, and a negative HER2 status (Score = 1+).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of carcinosarcoma with heterologous elements in the cervix, with stromal invasion present and a depth of 3mm, classified as pT2 due to lower uterine segment and cervical involvement. The tumor is located in the lower uterine segment/cervix, with no lymphovascular space invasion or adnexal involvement identified, and a leiomyoma was also noted. Immunohistochemistry results for estrogen and progesterone receptors are pending, and the tumor is staged as FIGO II based on the current findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade unclassified renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 11.5 cm, with local invasion into perinephric fat but no renal vein invasion and free surgical margins. The para-aortic and preaortic lymph nodes, as well as the suprahilar lymph nodes and adrenal gland, were all found to be benign with no evidence of metastatic disease. Additional findings include chronic pyelonephritis and nephrocalcinosis in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma located in the left lobe and isthmus, with a single tumor focus measuring 1.8 x 1.2 cm. There is evidence of extrathyroid extension and angiolymphatic invasion, with surgical margins involved by the tumor. Lymph nodes are negative for neoplasm, and the TNM classification is T3 N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of non-small cell carcinoma (specifically adenocarcinoma, grade III) in the right lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and evidence of invasion into visceral pleura and large vessels. Regional lymph node involvement was noted, with metastases in ipsilateral peribronchial and hilar lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes examined were negative for malignancy. Surgical margins were reported as uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, with the closest margin being 5 mm from the invasive tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a pheochromocytoma and a clear cell adenoma in the right adrenal gland, as determined from an adrenalectomy specimen. The specimen weighed 31.5 g and contained two distinct nodules: a smaller yellow nodule measuring 0.7 cm and a larger red-brown nodule measuring 2.1 cm, with additional smaller yellow areas noted in the remaining adrenal tissue. No abnormalities were observed in the surrounding periadrenal fat, and representative sections of the masses and adrenal tissue have been preserved for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma with micropapillary differentiation, Nottingham grade III, found in two masses in the lower outer quadrant of the left breast. Angiolymphatic invasion is noted, and one of five excised left axillary lymph nodes is positive for metastatic carcinoma with extranodal extension. All surgical margins are negative for tumor, and there are no residual tumors at the biopsy site or abnormalities in the nipple and skin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 3 papillary serous adenocarcinoma in the right ovary, with tumor involvement of the surface and evidence of lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, metastatic adenocarcinoma is present in multiple sites including the omental adipose tissue, bladder, left adnexa, uterus and cervix, pelvic peritoneum, and right external iliac lymph nodes. The findings suggest extensive metastatic disease originating from the primary ovarian tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, papillary type, with necrosis and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 out of 4, identified in a left kidney partial nephrectomy specimen. Tumor cells were found at the inked surgical margin in one deep margin sample, while the other deep margin and renal parenchyma samples were negative for carcinoma. Additionally, fragments of renal cell carcinoma were noted in the renal vein thrombus, and the tumor measured 6.5 cm with no invasion through the renal capsule.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant melanoma of the skin, characterized by a tumor measuring 1.6 x 2 cm with a Breslow thickness of 10 mm and focal surface ulceration. The tumor is located on the shoulder, and there is no evidence of venous invasion or involvement of resection margins. Overall, the findings suggest a significant melanoma with ulceration but no lymphatic or venous invasion noted.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of adrenal cortical carcinoma, characterized by significant tumor weight (865 g) and meeting all nine Weiss criteria for malignancy, including necrosis and high mitotic rate. Microscopic examination reveals encapsulated tumor cells with pleomorphic nuclei and marked necrosis, consistent with adrenocortical carcinoma, and evidence of metastasis to the inferior vena cava and diaphragm. Additionally, a fibrous nodule was identified in the front of the duodenum, while a torted appendix epiploicae was noted in the transverse colon.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a well-defined, bile-tinged mass measuring 16.5 x 14.0 x 11.0 cm with 60% necrosis and no gross involvement of the resection margins. The tumor is classified as poorly differentiated (grade III) with partial fibrous capsule formation and no evidence of vascular invasion or intrahepatic metastasis. Additionally, the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis, with no significant findings in the surrounding liver parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma with extensive necrosis (10 cm) in the left testicle, confirmed by immunohistochemical staining and electron microscopy. Surgical margins are free of tumor, with no lymphovascular invasion or invasion of the epididymis identified, and no normal testicular tissue present. Additionally, the right inguinal mass shows advanced tubular atrophy and nodular hyperplasia of Leydig cells, with no evidence of spermatogenesis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver, characterized as moderately differentiated with vascular invasion and extension to the surgical margins. An abdominal nodule was found to be benign, showing fat necrosis and fibrosis, while the gallbladder exhibited mild chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis without evidence of malignancy. Additional liver biopsies confirmed the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma, with no signs of melanoma or adrenal cortical carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (Fuhrman nuclear grade 3) in the right kidney, with a maximum tumor dimension of 4.5 cm and evidence of vascular invasion. The renal vein and ureteral margins are free of tumor, and there is no extension through the renal capsule. Additionally, the perinephric fat shows no tumor presence, and the surrounding renal parenchyma is largely unremarkable except for a small simple cyst.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the right and left pelvic lymph nodes, with all examined nodes being negative for malignancy (0/3 and 0/4, respectively). The prostate specimen revealed adenocarcinoma involving 40% of the gland with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3), and there was periprostatic fat involvement, although surgical margins were negative for carcinoma. The pathological stage is classified as pT3a NO Mx, with high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) and perineural invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of uterine papillary serous carcinoma (Grade III) with a depth of myometrial invasion of 30%, and no lymphatic or blood vessel invasion identified. The examination of lymph nodes from the right pelvic, left pelvic, and periaortic regions showed no evidence of metastasis, with all margins of excision free of tumor. Additional findings include chronic cervicitis, endometriosis, and leiomyoma, with no significant histopathologic changes noted in the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous adenocarcinoma involving both the right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes, with additional findings of serous papillary carcinoma in the endometrium of the uterus. The endometrial tumor is non-invasive, while the ovarian tumors are primarily on the surface, and multiple implants of serous adenocarcinoma are noted in the peritoneum, bladder flap, and omentum. The report suggests that the endometrial tumor is likely the primary site of the malignancy, supported by immunohistochemical findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed adenocarcinoma of the lung with pleural invasion, along with a small satellite nodule of tubular adenocarcinoma, both exhibiting pleural infiltration. The tumor is classified as stage IV (pT2 pNO pM1) with vascular invasion noted, and the presence of tumor cells in the pleural space contributes to the R1 classification. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma and confirms that the smaller focus is a metastasis of the larger primary tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade 1, classified as pathologic stage I. Surgical margins are free of tumor, with the closest margin being 0.9 cm from the tumor. A biopsy of the base of the tumor showed no evidence of tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right breast simple mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection due to invasive breast cancer. The final diagnosis reveals multicentric intralobular and infiltrating lobular carcinoma, with the largest invasive tumor measuring 3.5 cm, and metastatic carcinoma identified in one of the sentinel lymph nodes examined. The margins of resection are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of extranodal extension or lymphovascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated and invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural infiltration noted in the biopsy. This suggests that while the cancer is invasive, it has not spread through lymphatic or nerve pathways.

The pathology report indicates the presence of recurrent glioblastoma in the right temporal lobe, characterized by a hypercellular proliferation of atypical astrocyte-like cells. The tumor exhibits marked nuclear atypia, gemistocytic differentiation, and numerous mitotic figures, along with necrosis and thrombosed blood vessels. The diagnosis confirms the tumor as glioblastoma, classified as WHO grade IV.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma consistent with malignant fibrous histiocytoma in a resected specimen from the right lower leg, measuring 9 x 8 x 4 cm. The tumor has ulcerated into the skin and extends focally into skeletal muscle, but all resection margins are free of tumor, with the closest deep margin being 0.3 cm from the tumor. The tumor is predominantly viable with focal necrosis observed in about 5% of the tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the prostatic adenocarcinoma in the right lateral margin is clear of the true surgical margin, while focal extraprostatic extension is noted, leading to a staging change to pT3. The tumor occupies approximately 10-20% of the prostate volume with a Gleason score of 7/10, and no lymphovascular invasion or seminal vesicle involvement is identified. Additionally, no metastatic carcinoma is found in the examined lymph nodes, and perineural invasion is present.
The pathology report indicates that the tumor is located in the left temporal region. The histological diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme. This diagnosis suggests a highly aggressive brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the excisional biopsies from the left parietal region of the brain are diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme. The tumor exhibits high histological grade characteristics, including nuclear atypia, frequent mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, and areas of necrosis. The MIB-1 proliferation index is noted to be 17%, suggesting a moderate level of tumor cell proliferation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 2.5 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion, renal vein invasion, or small vessel invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor with a clearance of 0.3 cm. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is limited to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of uterine serous carcinoma with focal clear cell features, classified as FIGO grade 3, following a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. Additionally, a left salpingo-oophorectomy revealed a fibrothecoma in the left ovary, while all examined lymph nodes (36 total) showed no evidence of tumor involvement. The tumor exhibited myometrial invasion and was measured at 2.5 cm, with free surgical margins noted.

The pathology report indicates that a 17.6 gram right adrenal pheochromocytoma was identified in a male patient following a right laparoscopic adrenalectomy. The tumor measures 3.0 cm in greatest dimension and is well-circumscribed, arising from the adrenal medulla, while the surrounding cortex appears unremarkable. The findings confirm the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma based on the examination of multiple sections of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adrenocortical carcinoma following an adrenalectomy. The tumor measures 14x9x5 cm and weighs 336 grams, exhibiting a high proliferation rate with a KI67 index of 60%. The tumor is assessed with a Weiss score of 8, Hough score of 4.89, and Van Slooten score of 22.7, indicating aggressive characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the excision biopsy of the brain reveals a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV), characterized by high-grade glioma features including abnormal mitotic figures and a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 20%. Additionally, the MGMT promoter is found to be methylated, suggesting that the patient may benefit from therapy with alkylating agents. The report emphasizes that the results should be interpreted in the context of established diagnostic criteria and procedures.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in situ in the right breast, with the tumor measuring 3.0 x 3.2 x 2.5 cm. The report also notes the presence of reactive lymphadenitis in the axillary lymph nodes, with evidence of metastasis classified as pT2, pN2a. The tumor exhibits medium to high nuclear atypia and features such as comedo necrosis and calcifications, with 40% of the tumor showing carcinoma in situ characteristics.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 3 cm, with invasion through all layers of the stomach wall and into the diaphragm. Lymphatic invasion is present, with 5 out of 15 lymph nodes showing metastasis, while the esophageal margins are free of metastases. The tumor is ulcerated, and there is evidence of adjacent inflammatory changes and focal fibrosis, but no venous invasion or perineural invasion is noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated serous papillary carcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with a maximum tumor size of 8.0 cm and classified as FIGO stage IB. Additional findings include hydrosalpinx on the left side, while the uterus, cervix, and other examined tissues and lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor involvement. Overall, the tumor is characterized by marked cytologic atypia and a high mitotic count, but there are no positive lymph nodes or surface implants detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe type renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney mass, with clear margins of resection free of tumor. The specimen consisted of a partial nephrectomy measuring 10.5 x 9.3 x 9.0 cm, with a significant portion of the mass measuring approximately 4 x 3 x 2 cm. Additional kidney parenchyma was also submitted for analysis, and the specimen was processed for permanent evaluation.

The pathology report confirms the diagnosis of a right adrenal pheochromocytoma following an adrenalectomy, with no evidence of capsular or vascular invasion or necrosis, indicating the tumor is confined to the adrenal gland. The specimen weighed 19 grams and included a 1.6 x 1.6 x 1.1 cm mass, which was tan-white to pink, surrounded by a thin rim of orange cortex. Additional normal adrenal tissue was noted, and representative sections of the specimen have been submitted for further examination.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma, WHO Grade IV, from a right temporal brain lesion, confirmed by both frozen section and formalin-fixed tissue analysis. Microscopic examination revealed abundant pseudopalisading necrosis, and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) studies showed no EGFR gene amplification or PTEN deletion. Additional analyses for MGMT and EGFR will be conducted, with results to be reported separately.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma in the proximal stomach, with a depth of invasion into the muscularis propria and negative lymphovascular and perineural invasion. Surgical margins are negative for malignancy, with the tumor being 1.9 cm from the proximal margin and 0.4 cm from the radial margin, and all examined lymph nodes (32 total) are negative for malignancy. Additional findings include chronic gastritis with intestinal metaplasia, no Helicobacter pylori, and several samples of benign fibroadipose tissue from the greater omentum.

The pathology report indicates that a left upper lobectomy was performed due to a 4.0 x 3.5 x 3.0 cm unifocal adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe, classified as grade 3/4. The tumor abutted the pleural surface but showed no direct invasion into surrounding structures, and all examined lymph nodes were negative for tumor involvement. Molecular testing revealed negative results for EGFR mutations, and the tumor will undergo further analysis for ALK rearrangements.

The pathology report indicates that the left lung pneumonectomy revealed a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.7 x 2.5 x 1.5 cm, with all bronchial and vascular margins negative for carcinoma. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes excised from various locations were all negative for carcinoma, confirming no regional lymph node metastasis. Overall, the findings suggest localized lung cancer without evidence of spread to the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, classified as FIGO Grade 2, with less than 50% invasion and a tumor size of 5.0 x 4.3 cm. The left pelvic lymph node showed one out of seven nodes positive for metastasis, while all examined right pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes were negative for metastasis. The surgical procedure involved a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (TAH-BSO), and the serosa, parametria, and cervix were free of tumor.

The biopsy of a right frontal brain mass reveals an anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO grade III), indicating a progression from a previously diagnosed WHO grade II glioma that is 1p19q codeleted. The neoplastic cells tested negative for the IDH1 (R132H) immunostain, and further findings will be reported in an addendum. The mass measured 8.5 x 4.3 x 2.7 cm, with multiple representative sections submitted for analysis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma involving skeletal muscle at the anterior apex, with two separate foci identified, and the final margin of resection is free of tumor. The diagnosis includes a Gleason score of 7 (4+3) for the dominant tumor focus, which shows extraprostatic extension, while the right and left seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia are free of tumor. Additionally, all examined pelvic lymph nodes (22 from the right and 11 from the left) show no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a specimen from the floor of the mouth with a tumor measuring 3 x 3 x 2 cm. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor is located at the midline of the floor of the mouth.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 10.4 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion present but no perineural invasion detected, and surgical margins are uninvolved by neoplasia. The lymph node involvement shows multiple positive nodes, particularly in the lesser curvature and various regional nodes, while other examined sites, including the pancreas, greater omentum, and splenectomy, are uninvolved by neoplasia. Overall, the findings suggest a locally advanced gastric cancer with regional lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that a tumor type has been identified and specifies the BCR location to which the case was originally sent. It includes instructions for completing the TCGA Missing Pathology Report Form and requires the histology and site codes for the specimen. Additionally, it emphasizes the need for quality control documentation for both the specimen and overall case diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that a left orchidectomy was performed, revealing a seminoma with a diameter of 9.0 cm. There is no evidence of angio-invasion or invasion of the tunica albuginea. Additionally, the epididymis, rete testis, and spermatic cord were not present in the available slides for examination.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma, with metastatic involvement in 3 of 11 right pelvic lymph nodes and 5 of 10 left pelvic lymph nodes, including extranodal extension. The cystoprostatectomy revealed a 5 cm tumor in the bladder, extending into the perivesical adipose tissue, but there was no involvement of the prostate by urothelial carcinoma. The distal right ureter showed no tumor, and all surgical margins were negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a laparoscopic radical trachelectomy due to invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, which measured 5.8 cm and had a depth of invasion of 9.5 mm. All examined lymph nodes (21 in total) were negative for malignancy, showing reactive follicular hyperplasia instead. The surgical margins were negative for tumor involvement, suggesting that the cancer has not spread beyond the cervix.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder specimen shows no pathological diagnosis, while the liver specimen reveals well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma of the solid variant, which is involving the deep margin, alongside chronic hepatitis C with mild activity and cirrhosis. The gallbladder was noted to have thick green mucinous bile and a slightly hemorrhagic serosal surface. The liver specimen contained a light tan opaque nodule that was close to the resection margin, suggesting a significant pathological finding.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies from the right, left, posterior, and anterior margins are negative for in situ or invasive carcinoma, although mild dysplasia of the squamous epithelium is noted. A moderately differentiated, keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma is identified in the left ventral tongue and floor of mouth, measuring 4.2 cm, with invasion into the sublingual salivary gland and muscle fibers, but all surgical margins are negative for malignancy. Metastatic carcinoma is present in multiple lymph nodes, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 1.3 cm, and no extranodal extension is observed.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, with a significant smoking history, has been diagnosed with invasive moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the epiglottis, along with carcinoma in situ. The biopsy consisted of five mucosal fragments from the epiglottis, which were examined microscopically. The findings confirm the presence of invasive cancer, correlating with the patient's symptoms of hoarseness, otalgia, and dysphagia.

The pathology report indicates a right lower lobectomy revealing a moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 65 mm, with evidence of pleural invasion but no lymphatic or vascular invasion. The bronchial and vascular resection margins are clear of malignancy, and there are no metastatic carcinoma findings in the sampled lymph nodes, which show reactive hyperplasia. The pathological stage is classified as T2 N0 M0.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO Grade 1) confined to the endometrium with no myometrial or cervical invasion, and all examined lymph nodes (23 regional nodes) are negative for tumor involvement. Additional findings include adenomyosis and leiomyoma, with no tumors identified in the ovaries or fallopian tubes. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the endometrial cancer is estrogen and progesterone receptor positive, and localized leiomyomatosis was noted in a left pelvic lymph node.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent an adrenalectomy, revealing fragments of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland. The tumor exhibits areas of hemorrhage, spindling of tumor cells, and marked nuclear pleomorphism, but lacks necrosis, capsular invasion, and vascular invasion. The Pheochromocytoma of the Adrenal gland Scaled Score (PASS) is less than 4, suggesting that the tumor is expected to behave in a benign manner.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma (Grade II) in the left breast, with a maximum tumor size of 3.0 cm and evidence of lymphatic invasion, while the margins are negative. Additionally, one out of twenty-three axillary lymph nodes is positive for metastatic carcinoma, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 1.4 cm. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor positive, and shows HER2/neu 2+ status, with a Nottingham score of 7 out of 9.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 11 mm in the left breast, with a Nottingham score of 7/9, and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of solid and cribriform types. Surgical margins are negative for invasive tumor and DCIS, with lymphovascular invasion identified, and all examined sentinel lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings include lobular carcinoma in situ, atypical ductal and lobular hyperplasia, and fibrocystic changes, with the invasive tumor cells being estrogen receptor positive and HER-2/NEU negative.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast mass was diagnosed as moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma, measuring 2.2 cm, with focal ductal carcinoma in situ and negative surgical margins. All sentinel and non-sentinel lymph nodes examined from the right axilla were reported as benign, with no evidence of metastatic tumor. Immunohistochemical staining showed strong estrogen receptor positivity and moderate progesterone receptor positivity, while HER-2/neu was negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, from a biopsy of the left occipital region of the brain. The specimen revealed extensive areas of necrosis and was processed for both frozen section diagnosis and cytological preparation. The final diagnosis was confirmed by the attending pathologist after reviewing all pathology slides.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from the right adrenal gland reveals an adrenal cortical carcinoma classified as low grade, with vascular invasion identified but no capsular invasion or extracapsular extension. The tumor exhibits features such as diffuse architecture, eosinophilic cytoplasm, and broad fibrous bands, leading to a Weiss score of 4, which classifies it as malignant. Additionally, there are areas of hemorrhage and a small infarct-like region, but no significant mitotic activity or atypical mitoses were observed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, from an excisional biopsy of the left frontal brain, with varying tumor cellularity and minimal necrosis across multiple samples. Immunohistochemical analysis shows low MGMT expression, suggesting potential responsiveness to Temodar, while loss of PTEN indicates a diminished response to EGFR kinase inhibitors. Additionally, the presence of activated pMAPK suggests relative resistance to radiation therapy, and elevated expression of laminin beta-1 and beta-2 indicates intermediate tumor aggressiveness.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma, grade II, in the left breast, with associated lobular carcinoma in situ and metastasis found in 13 out of 15 lymph nodes. The invasive carcinoma measures 6.6 cm with a cellularity of 20%, and there is evidence of extranodal extension in the lymph nodes. Hormonal receptor analysis shows moderate to strong estrogen receptor expression in 80% of the invasive tumor nuclei, while progesterone receptor expression is absent, and HER2 is non-amplified.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a brain tumor, specifically an anaplastic oligoastrocytoma. The tumor was identified in the right occipital and parietal lobes, characterized by grayish soft-elastic tissue. The final diagnosis confirms it as an anaplastic oligoastrocytoma of Grade III.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left mammary ablation revealing fibrocystic mastopathy and ductal hyperplasia, with extensive lobular neoplasia and a well-differentiated intraductal breast carcinoma transitioning to invasive ductal carcinoma. Additionally, 13 axillary lymph nodes were tumor-free, and a resected section of the rectum showed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with lymphatic invasion but no local lymph node metastases. A tumor-free hepatic wedge excision was performed, revealing non-active cirrhosis with focal steatosis, without further metastatic disease from the rectal carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the abdominal wall nodule and omentum resection reveal metastatic poorly differentiated carcinoma, likely originating from primary ovarian or peritoneal serous carcinoma. The specimens included two abdominal wall nodules and omental fragments, with the nodules showing irregular nodular bulging and significant tumor involvement. The omental fragments exhibited extensive thickening due to white nodular tumor, confirming the metastatic nature of the disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial malignant mixed Mllerian tumor (MMMT) with invasion into the superficial myometrium, and no lymphovascular invasion was identified. Metastatic sarcoma was found in one of the right common iliac lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes from various regions showed no tumor presence. The tumor consists of mixed high-grade endometrioid and serous carcinoma components, with undifferentiated sarcomatous features.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical cystoprostatectomy, pelvic lymph node dissection, urinary diversion, and gastrostomy tube placement. The final diagnosis revealed invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, along with bilateral moderately differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma confined to the prostate, while all examined lymph nodes and ureters were benign with no evidence of malignancy. Resection margins were free of urothelial dysplasia and malignancy, and additional random mucosal sections showed no dysplasia or carcinoma in situ.

The patient underwent a radical retropubic prostatectomy for prostate cancer, with the final diagnosis revealing invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, involving both lobes of the prostate and approximately 25% of the examined prostate volume. No evidence of neoplasia was found in the examined lymph nodes, and all surgical margins were free of carcinoma, although perineural invasion was identified. The carcinoma is classified as organ-confined with a pathologic TNM stage of pT2c, and multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia was also noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, measuring 4.5 cm, with uninvolved surgical margins. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from levels 5, 9, and 11 show no evidence of metastatic disease. Overall, there is no indication of vascular invasion, and distant metastasis could not be evaluated from this specimen.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma limited to the bladder, with infiltration into the outer third of the muscularis propria. There is no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion, and the surgical margins are free of neoplastic involvement. Additionally, nonspecific chronic prostatitis and nodular hyperplasia of the prostate are noted, with the deferens and seminal vesicles uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal encapsulated follicular variant papillary thyroid carcinoma in both lobes of the thyroid, with the largest nodule measuring 3.5 cm. Molecular testing revealed an HRAS codon 61 mutation, while mutations in BRAF, NRAS, and KRAS were not identified, and FISH testing showed no RET/PTC rearrangement. The tumors are confined to the thyroid with no evidence of extrathyroidal extension or lymphovascular invasion, and the pathological stage is classified as pT2N0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm and a Fuhrman grade of 3 out of 4. The tumor shows capsular invasion and is positive for carcinoma in the renal vein and large vessels, while perirenal adipose tissue and Gerota's fascia are negative for carcinoma. The AJCC staging is pT3a, and immunohistochemical stains support the diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell subtype.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segments II and III, characterized by a single mass measuring 4.2 x 3.8 x 3.2 cm. The tumor involves the hepatic capsule but does not invade adjacent organs, with surgical margins clear of tumor by 2.5 cm and no evidence of extratumoral vascular invasion. Additionally, the non-neoplastic liver tissue shows end-stage micronodular cirrhosis with steatosis and chronic inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (G2) in lung tissue, with a tumor size of 18 x 19 cm and localized necrosis. Out of eight examined lymph nodes, one showed metastasis, while there was no evidence of venous invasion and the surgical margins were uninvolved. The specimen was obtained through pneumonectomy, and additional treatment effects or findings were not specified.

The final diagnosis indicates a left parietal tumor classified as an astrocytoma, WHO grade II, characterized by moderately pleomorphic glial cells infiltrating the cerebral grey matter. The Ki67 proliferation index is low at 1.9%, and immunohistochemical staining shows positive results for GFAP and p53, while NEU-N is negative in tumor cells. The tumor measures 1.5 x 1.5 x 0.8 cm and was processed for rapid evaluation, confirming its glioma nature.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in a female patient, with the tumor located in the breast. The tumor is classified as grade 3, with a T stage of 2, N stage of 0, and M stage of 0, indicating localized disease without lymph node or distant metastasis. Additionally, a normal blood sample was obtained, with no treatment administered at this time.

The pathology report identifies a Type B1 Thymoma measuring 16.0 x 7.0 x 8.0 cm, with focal infiltration into the capsule but the capsule remaining intact. The tumor is classified as pT2, pNx, pMx, and is categorized as Masaoka stage II. Immunohistochemistry results show positive staining for CK5/6 and AE1/3, strong membrane staining for EGFR, and negative results for CD5 and CD117, with CD1a- and CD99-positive immature T-lymphocytes present.

The pathology report indicates that the right thyroid lobe contains a follicular variant of papillary carcinoma, measuring at least 2 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of extrathyroidal extension. The left subtotal thyroid lobe shows benign multinodular hyperplasia, while no parathyroid tissue was identified in the specimen labeled as parathyroid. This preliminary report is subject to further consultation and an addendum report has confirmed the diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the left floor of mouth, measuring 2.2 x 1.8 x 0.4 cm, with all surgical margins negative for high-grade dysplasia and invasive carcinoma. One of seven lymph nodes from the left neck level II showed metastatic carcinoma, while the other lymph nodes examined were negative for metastasis. Additionally, focal high-grade squamous dysplasia was noted at the anterior margin, but the remaining margins and lymph nodes were free of high-grade dysplasia and invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral low-grade papillary serous carcinoma of the ovaries, with involvement of the ovarian surfaces, paratubal tissue, and extension into the fallopian tubes. Metastatic disease is present in one of two right pelvic lymph nodes, as well as in various other sites including the rectum, sigmoid, appendix, omentum, and mesenteric masses. The tumor is classified as stage IV due to extensive spread, with histological features showing moderate cytologic atypia and low mitotic activity, suggesting a relatively indolent course.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the basaloid type in a biopsy of the left tonsil. The biopsy consisted of multiple irregular tissue fragments measuring 1.5 x 1.0 x 0.3 cm. The clinical features and operative diagnosis were unspecified, but the findings were reviewed by the attending pathologist.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional (clear cell) renal cell carcinoma from a right kidney partial nephrectomy, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the tumor is associated with a granulomatous response and is staged as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 1 renal cell carcinoma, papillary type, in the left kidney, with the tumor confined to the kidney and no evidence of invasion into the renal vein or collecting system. Additionally, the right prostate needle biopsy shows adenocarcinoma (Gleason score 3 + 3) involving 5% of the specimen, while the left prostate biopsy reveals benign prostatic tissue. The report also notes significant chronic changes in the kidney consistent with chronic pyelonephritis and the presence of multiple renal stones.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade III papillary serous carcinoma in the uterus, with a mass measuring 3.0 x 2.1 x 1.8 cm that invades the myometrium. The right and left ovaries, fallopian tubes, and multiple pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes, as well as omentum and various staging biopsy sites, show no evidence of tumor involvement. The lower uterine segment and cervix are uninvolved, suggesting localized disease without metastasis to the examined lymph nodes or other tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderate to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left supraglottic mass and left thyroid cartilage. Tumor presence is noted at the cauterized biopsy margins, suggesting incomplete resection. The specimens analyzed included multiple fragments of soft tissue, with findings confirmed through both biopsy and frozen section analysis.

The pathology report indicates that two tumors were identified in the right lower lobe, both consistent with moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, with the larger tumor measuring 2.5 cm and a smaller microscopic focus of 0.9 cm. All examined lymph nodes (4R right paratracheal, level 7, level 8, and level 9) showed no evidence of malignancy. The bronchial margins and pleural surfaces were negative for tumor involvement, and there was no angiolymphatic invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of no special type, measuring 3 cm, with extensive lymphatic channel invasion and tumor necrosis. A left radical mastectomy revealed residual high-grade invasive ductal carcinoma in the biopsy cavity wall, with multifocal tumor presence in the upper inner quadrant and metastatic involvement in 16 of 21 lymph nodes, including extracasular invasion. Additionally, multiple seborrheic keratosis lesions were noted on the skin adjacent to the nipple, while the deep margin and nipple duct were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the right pyriform sinus and right tongue base biopsies show squamous mucosa with focal moderate dysplasia, but no invasive carcinoma is identified in these areas. In contrast, the biopsy from the right supraglottic larynx reveals moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma with cartilaginous invasion. The cervical esophagus biopsy shows superficial fragments of benign squamous mucosa.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary biopsy shows benign ovarian tissue, while multiple lymph node excisions from both sides reveal benign lymph nodes with no evidence of malignancy. A total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy reveal endometrial adenocarcinoma of the endometrioid type, FIGO grade 1, with invasion of less than half of the myometrium and no vascular or endocervical invasion. Immunohistochemical analysis shows loss of expression of MLH1 and PMS2 in the tumor cells, while MSH2 and MSH6 are retained, suggesting a specific profile of DNA mismatch repair gene expression.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary microcarcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid gland, with a tumor size of 0.5 cm and characterized as well differentiated. There is no evidence of mitotic activity, tumor necrosis, blood vessel invasion, or extrathyroid extension, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis is noted in the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue, and three benign perithyroid lymph nodes were identified.

The pathology report indicates that the right sixth rib shows no signs of malignancy, with normal marrow maturation. The right lower lobe lung lobectomy reveals a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, which is confined to the lung with negative surgical margins and no lymphatic or vascular invasion. Additionally, the lymph node biopsy from station 7 is negative for metastasis, confirming no regional spread of the cancer, and the final staging is pT2aN0M0, classified as stage IB.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary lymph nodes examined were negative for carcinoma, with no tumor cells identified in four nodes from each of the two axillary specimens. The left segmental mastectomy revealed a poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma, measuring 3.1 cm, with negative results for estrogen, progesterone, and HER2 receptors, and a Nottingham grade of 3. The tumor margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, with the closest margin being less than 1 mm from the deep margin, and no lymphatic space invasion was detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive, moderately-differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the left buccal mass, measuring 4.5 cm, with evidence of perineural invasion and an in-situ component. Out of 42 lymph nodes examined, 2 were positive for metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while the remaining nodes and the minor salivary gland showed no carcinoma involvement. Additional biopsies from the gingival mucosa and various margins revealed no carcinoma, confirming clear margins except for the extensively involved 3 o'clock margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2, N0, and M0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered, and a normal blood sample was also collected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma with focal tubulopapillary and sarcomatoid features, measuring 11 cm and exhibiting Fuhrman nuclear grade 3-4. The tumor invades perinephric adipose tissue and shows focal microscopic angiolymphatic invasion, with the tumor approaching but not invading the surgical margins. Additionally, a benign lymph node was identified, and the adrenal gland showed no significant pathological changes, while mild to moderate atherosclerosis of the renal artery was noted.

The pathology report indicates that the right iliac and obturator lymph nodes are benign, with no evidence of malignancy. In contrast, the prostatectomy specimen reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3), extensive bilateral involvement of approximately 20% of the gland, and focal extraprostatic extension at the right apex. Additionally, there is involvement at the surgical margins, with perineural invasion present, leading to a pathologic stage of pT3a NO MX.

The pathology report indicates a left upper lobe lung wedge excision revealing a Grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 2.3 x 2 x 1.8 cm, which is abutting but not invading the pleura. A lobectomy of the same lung lobe shows benign lung parenchyma with no residual tumor and negative bronchial margins. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from the inferior mediastinal, aortic, and N1 regions are negative for tumor, with one aortopulmonary lymph node showing only fibrovascular tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 1, Fuhrman grade 2, measuring 10 cm, with clear margins and no tumor identified in the ureter or adrenal gland. The tumor exhibits significant necrosis and is characterized by papillae lined with low cuboidal to columnar cells, along with abundant foamy histiocytes. The final staging is pT2N0M0, confirming that the tumor has not invaded surrounding structures or lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma in the thyroid, with the dominant tumor measuring 2.0 cm in the left lobe and additional smaller tumors identified in both lobes. The tumors are classified as classical and follicular variants, with no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion, and all margins are uninvolved by carcinoma. The report confirms that there is no regional lymph node metastasis, and the overall staging is consistent with multiple primary tumors confined to the thyroid.

The pathology report indicates that the resection material from the colon or rectum contains a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with early infiltration into the surrounding fatty tissue. There are tumor-free resection margins, and no regional lymph node metastases were found, with a classification of G2, pT3, and pNO 0/34. Additionally, there is no evidence of vascular or perineural invasion (L0 V0).

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma (Grade 1, FIGO staging T1b, NO) in the uterus, cervix, tubes, and ovaries, with a tumor size of 2.4 x 2.0 x 1.8 cm and less than 50% myometrial invasion. All examined lymph nodes (left pelvic, left aortic, right pelvic, and right caval) show no evidence of metastasis, with a total of 25 lymph nodes assessed (0/25 positive for cancer). The serosa, parametrium, and cervical involvement are free of tumor, indicating a localized disease without lymphovascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a malignant melanoma on the skin, characterized by a pigmented, ulcerated lesion measuring 2x1 cm and a Breslow thickness of 10 mm. The melanoma is classified as Clark's level III, with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. There is also perifocal lymphoid infiltration noted, but details regarding lymphatic invasion and satellite nodules are not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the liver transplant biopsies show mild to moderate acute rejection and mild portal inflammation, with some specimens indicating resolving rejection and no significant improvement from previous biopsies. Additionally, the explant liver shows bridging fibrosis and changes consistent with primary biliary cirrhosis. Other findings include a left ovarian mass diagnosed as moderately differentiated papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma, with no evidence of metastasis in regional lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the distal esophagus, associated with Barrett's esophagus, with clear proximal and distal margins and no lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Additionally, an incidental low-grade gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) was identified in the gastric wall, with negative margins and no regional lymph node metastasis. All examined lymph nodes from various sites were negative for malignancy, confirming no regional spread of the carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that there is no tumor present in the peripheral nerve segment, left lingual tongue base, and multiple teeth specimens. However, invasive squamous carcinoma was identified in the tongue, with the tumor being well-differentiated on the right side and less well-differentiated on the left side, deeply invading connective tissues and skeletal muscle, but with clear resection margins and no tumor in regional lymph nodes. The report raises the possibility of either a single extensive pathological process or multifocal primary squamous carcinoma involving the tongue.

The pathology report indicates a 1.2 cm diameter, well-differentiated papillary renal cell carcinoma (Type II). The tumor is graded as GI/GII and staged as pT1a, with no evidence of residual disease (RO).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of peripheral bronchopulmonary mixed-cell adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, characterized by predominant acinar and small large-cell solid components, with a bronchioloalveolar pattern of spread. The tumor is classified as pT2 pNO pMX R0, corresponding to stage IB, and has infiltrated the visceral pleura. However, the resection margins of the bronchus and vessels, as well as all removed lymph nodes, are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the left tonsil, with a tumor size of 2.0 x 1.8 x 0.7 cm and all surgical margins free of tumor. There is no evidence of vascular or perineural invasion, and additional margins from the left anterior retromolar trigone, superior buccal, maxillary tuberosity, superior medial palatal, and tongue base show no signs of malignancy or high-grade dysplasia. The findings confirm the referring pathologist's report and indicate successful excision of the tumor with clear margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell type), with a tumor size of 3.7 cm and unifocality, limited to the kidney. The tumor exhibits patchy necrosis and is classified as Fuhrman grade 4, with the renal capsular margin involved by carcinoma, while lymphovascular invasion is not identified. The pathological staging is stage I (pT1a), indicating the tumor is less than 4 cm and confined to the kidney, with no distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated carcinoma in multiple specimens, including the small bowel mesentery and omentum, with findings consistent with adenocarcinoma and extensive necrosis. Lymphovascular invasion is noted, and immunohistochemical staining shows strong positivity for Cytokeratin 7 and negativity for Cytokeratin 20, suggesting a possible breast or Mullerian-related primary tumor. The clinical context includes a family history of breast cancer and imaging findings of a large pelvic mass and periaortic lymphadenopathy.

The pathology report describes an invasive low-grade infiltrating urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 4x4x3.5 cm, with soft gray surfaces and ill-defined margins. Microscopic examination reveals tumor cells arranged in various patterns, with enlarged nuclei and abnormal chromatin, indicating moderate differentiation and invasion into surrounding fat tissue. The tumor margins are uninvolved, and there is no specified evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of metastatic disease in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions, with findings of follicular lymphoid hyperplasia. The radical hysterectomy specimen reveals an invasive non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of moderate to poorly differentiated grade, measuring 4.0 cm, with clear surgical margins and no lymphovascular invasion or parametrial involvement. The overall staging is classified as pT1b1 pNO pMx, suggesting early-stage cervical cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma of the distal esophagus, measuring 55 mm, which infiltrates into the submucosa but is clear of resection margins, with metastases identified in 2 of 6 lesser omental lymph nodes and one node showing focal extra-nodal spread. Additionally, Barrett's mucosa with low and high-grade dysplasia is noted, with low-grade dysplasia extending to the proximal resection margin. The gallbladder shows mild chronic cholecystitis without evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that a benign portion of bone was excised from the 9th left rib. A high-grade pleomorphic malignant tumor, likely sarcomatoid renal cell carcinoma, was identified in the left kidney, omentum, and colon, with extensive necrosis and involvement of surrounding tissues, including positive margins in one colon resection. Additionally, metastatic renal cell carcinoma with extensive sarcomatoid differentiation was found in the spleen and adipose tissue of the pancreas, with evidence of angiolymphatic invasion and involvement of resection margins in the pancreatic lesion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 6.4 cm, located in the perirectal region, with evidence of invasion into fibroadipose tissue and abutting skeletal and smooth muscle. Immunohistochemical staining shows positivity for SMA and desmin, while being negative for CD117 and caldesmon, and the tumor extends to the inked margins at multiple sites. The specimen was received as an irregularly shaped piece of tissue, with a well-circumscribed nodular mass identified, and areas of infiltration noted at the margins.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent an adrenalectomy of the right adrenal gland, revealing a pheochromocytoma measuring 3.3 cm in greatest dimension. The tumor is well-encapsulated, with a tan-brown, heterogeneous cut surface and no cystic spaces present, along with a thin rim of residual adrenal tissue. Overall, the findings confirm the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma based on the characteristics of the tumor mass.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a large multinodular mass and associated vascular invasion, with multiple satellite nodules present. Tumor thrombus was found in the left portal vein, but the vessel margin was negative for malignancy, while the gallbladder and peri-choledochal lymph nodes showed no signs of cancer. An addendum noted the presence of inactive chronic hepatitis with bridging fibrosis in the non-neoplastic liver, consistent with the patient's history of chronic hepatitis B.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 1, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and invasion of less than 50% of the myometrial thickness. All examined lymph nodes (13 in total) were negative for metastatic carcinoma, and the tumor is classified as FIGO stage IA. Additionally, there were no malignant cells found in the companion pelvic wash cytology specimen.

The pathology report indicates that both the cervical biopsy and endocervical curettage reveal the presence of squamous cell carcinoma. The preoperative and postoperative diagnoses are consistent, confirming the diagnosis of carcinoma due to postmenopausal bleeding. The depth of invasion of the carcinoma could not be determined from the specimens provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated papillary serous carcinoma involving the uterus, cervix, and bilateral ovaries, with extensive lymphovascular space invasion and peritoneal tumor extension. The tumor is classified as T3c/N0/M0, corresponding to Stage IIIC, indicating significant spread beyond the pelvis. Additional findings include inactive endometrium and mucosal atrophy of the cervix, with multiple tumor implants noted in the omentum and perirenal mass.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative lobular carcinoma in the right breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T1, N0, and M0, indicating it is localized without lymph node involvement or metastasis. No treatment has been administered, and a separate blood sample was noted as normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of III/IV, in a 3.9 cm hypervascular tumor located in the right kidney, which is confined within the renal capsule and has free surgical margins. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable, and the deep margin biopsy shows benign renal parenchyma. Intraoperative frozen section consultations confirmed the presence of a cortical cell neoplasm consistent with renal carcinoma and benign margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma, grade 4, infiltrating the bladder wall and extending to the perivesical fat, but with negative surgical margins. The right ureter and bladder junction are involved by urothelial carcinoma, and there is evidence of lymphovascular invasion; however, no metastatic carcinoma was found in the examined lymph nodes, except for one positive node in the right paracaval region and four positive nodes in the right common iliac region. Additionally, both distal ureters were confirmed to be benign with no dysplasia or carcinoma identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma of the stomach, with the tumor invading the full thickness of the stomach wall and extending to the peritoneal surface. There are multiple lymph node metastases identified, with significant infiltration noted in several lymph nodes. The surgical margins are free of neoplastic lesions, suggesting complete resection of the primary tumor.

The pathology report identifies three foci of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 20 mm (acinar), 12 mm (papillary), and 5 mm (bronchioloalveolar) in size, with evidence of extensive blood vessel invasion and possible lymphatic permeation. The acinar carcinoma shows invasion into the visceral pleura, while the other two lesions are clear of the bronchial margin and show no lymph node metastases. Additionally, the report notes the presence of mild emphysema in the non-neoplastic lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.1 cm with a Nottingham score of 6/9, and includes ductal carcinoma in situ representing 5% of the tumor volume. Angiolymphatic invasion is noted, but surgical margins are free of tumor, and two sentinel lymph nodes examined are negative for metastasis. The tumor is classified as pT1c, pNO, pMO, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, and HER2/NEU status of 0 or 1+.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the fundus of the stomach, with a tumor size of 8 cm. The tumor has extended to the serosa, and 2 out of 7 examined lymph nodes show evidence of metastasis. Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion, as well as margins and neo-adjuvant treatment, are not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the left kidney mass is diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV and a maximum diameter of 6.3 cm, confined within the renal capsule and with all surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, three left renal hilar lymph nodes were excised, all of which were benign with no evidence of carcinoma. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue shows focal sclerosis and chronic inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated infiltrating colonic adenocarcinoma measuring 3.1 cm in the right colon and terminal ileum, with no lymph node involvement (0/17) and uninvolved surgical margins. Additionally, multiple tubular adenomas were identified in the colon, and the gallbladder showed chronic cholelithiasis without any masses or lesions. The pathological stage of the colorectal cancer is classified as pT2 N0 Mx, indicating localized disease without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, specifically the tall cell variant, measuring 6.0 cm, with evidence of extracapsular extension and one lymph node showing metastatic carcinoma. Molecular testing identified a BRAF V600E mutation, which is associated with more aggressive tumor behavior, while mutations in NRAS, HRAS, and KRAS were not detected, and the FISH test for RET/PTC rearrangement was negative. The surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, although the tumor is located 0.1 cm from the margins, and the overall staging is pT3 N1a MX.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph node biopsy showed no evidence of malignancy (0/1). The left breast mastectomy revealed an intermediate-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 5.5 x 5.2 x 4.5 cm with widely negative margins, while the right breast mastectomy showed simple ductal hyperplasia without atypia and no evidence of malignancy. Overall, there is no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right tongue and floor of mouth, with a maximum tumor diameter of 2.4 cm and a thickness of 1.5 cm, along with perineural invasion. All examined lymph nodes (20 in total) and margins, except for the medial and lateral margins which are close to the tumor, are negative for malignancy. The tumor is staged as pT2 with no regional lymph node metastasis and no distant metastasis assessed.

The histopathological examination of a total organ resection of the colon and rectum revealed a 6 cm cauliflower-shaped ulcerous tumor consistent with tubular adenocarcinoma (G2) that infiltrated the surrounding adipose tissue. The tumor was located at the rectosigmoid junction, with clear margins at the excision lines, but there were metastases identified in one of the lymph nodes. The final diagnosis is tubular adenocarcinoma of the colon with lymph node metastasis, classified as Dukes C and Astler-Coller C2, pT3, pN1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma (14.4 cm), clear cell type with rhabdoid features, exhibiting Fuhrman nuclear grade IV and invading perinephric fat and renal pelvis, with vascular and perineural invasion noted. Additionally, a metastatic renal cell carcinoma was identified in a vena cava tumor thrombus. The non-neoplastic kidney parenchyma showed diffuse interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy, likely due to chronic obstructive uropathy, with minimal glomerulosclerosis observed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of extensive infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the left breast, with the tumor measuring over 6 cm and metastasis present in 25 out of 27 axillary lymph nodes. The infiltrating carcinoma extends into sections of the lactiferous duct and nipple, as well as various sections of the breast quadrant, although all surgical margins appear free of involvement. The report highlights the multifocal and extensive nature of the tumor, complicating precise measurements.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, based on multiple excisional biopsy samples from the right frontal region of the brain, with varying degrees of tumor necrosis and high cellularity. Immunohistochemical analysis shows low MGMT expression, retained PTEN expression, and significant positivity for pMAPK, suggesting potential responsiveness to EGFR kinase inhibitors and a more favorable prognosis.
