The presence of elevated laminin beta-1 and decreased laminin beta-2 expression indicates a more aggressive tumor behavior, with implications for treatment and prognosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of predominantly poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate, characterized by perineural infiltration and lymphatic invasion, with a maximum tumor diameter of 2 cm and involvement of the right seminal vesicle. The tumor classification is pT3b, L1, V0, R1; pN0 (0/7), and the Gleason score is 4+3, indicating a moderately aggressive cancer. Additionally, the report notes the presence of fatty tissue with four tumor-free lymph nodes and three tumor-free lymph nodes, suggesting no regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that both sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla show no evidence of tumor (0/1 for each node). The wide local excision of the left breast reveals invasive and in-situ ductal carcinoma, classified as SBR Grade III, with a tumor size of 2.5 cm and extensive necrosis present. Hormone receptor status is pending, but FISH analysis shows no amplification of the HER2 gene, and the overall pathology stage is T2N1.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive grade 2 squamous cell carcinoma in the floor of the mouth, measuring 4.5 cm, with ulceration and infiltration into the muscular layer and osseous tissue. Thirteen lymph nodes from Level 3, seven from Level 2, and seven from Level 1 on the left side were uninvolved by metastatic carcinoma, while four out of ten lymph nodes from Level 2 on the right side showed metastatic involvement with capsular invasion. The posterior margin of the jaw is involved by the carcinoma, but other surgical margins are uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates that the uterus, bilateral ovaries, and fallopian tubes are benign, with findings of inactive endometrium and benign leiomyomata in the myometrium. In contrast, the rectum and sigmoid colon show moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that is invasive into perirectal fat (pT3), but with negative resection margins and no lymph node metastasis (0/33). The appendix is reported as benign with mucosal lymphoid hyperplasia, and no significant abnormalities were noted in the other specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell type), with a nuclear grade of III/IV, found in a 4.0 cm tumor located in the right kidney. The tumor is confined within the renal capsule, with no invasion of the renal vein or involvement of surgical margins. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast specimen shows in situ and infiltrating lobular carcinoma, with a nuclear grade of II/III and a low mitotic index, while the left breast specimen reveals diffuse proliferative fibrocystic changes with atypical duct and lobular hyperplasia but no invasive carcinoma. The tumor in the right breast measures 2.3 x 3.3 x 1.7 cm and is 0.6 cm from the deep margin, which is free of tumor by 5 mm. All examined lymph nodes from both axillae show no evidence of metastatic disease, confirmed by negative immunohistochemical staining.

The pathology report indicates a radical mastectomy specimen with a tumor size of 3.2 x 2.5 x 1.5 cm, identified as infiltrating ductal and lobular carcinoma. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/8 positive). The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tumor grading and other histologic features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6 (3+3), showing a minor Gleason 4 component and established extracapsular extension, particularly involving the right anterior and bladder neck. Perineural invasion is identified, but vascular invasion is not present, and the seminal vesicles are not involved. The surgical margins are positive for tumor at the bladder neck and anterior basal margin, with benign findings in the periprostatic fat and anterior rectal wall margin biopsy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma in the right parietal lobe, characterized by astrocytic neoplastic proliferation with nuclear anaplasia, necrosis, and microvascular proliferation. Special stains have been requested for further characterization, and the MGMT promoter analysis shows no evidence of methylation. The MIB-1 proliferation index is approximately 7%, suggesting a high histological grade of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the left renal vein margin excision revealed a benign vascular structure with no tumor present. The radical nephrectomy specimen showed a renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type with focal spindle cell/sarcomatoid features, classified as Fuhrman Nuclear Grade IV and measuring 9.5 cm, with local invasion into renal sinus fat and identified renal vein invasion. Surgical margins were free of tumor, the adrenal gland was not involved, and all examined lymph nodes (30) were negative for malignancy, resulting in a staging of pT3b.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrioid adenocarcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with the right ovary showing FIGO histologic grade II/III and involvement of the ovarian surface. Additional findings include endometriosis in various specimens, with some areas showing no malignant cells, while a microscopic deposit of endometrioid adenocarcinoma was noted in the left pelvic sidewall. Overall, the malignancy exhibits both low and high cytologic grades, with features typical of endometrioid carcinomas, including squamous metaplastic differentiation.

The pathology report indicates that the right medial ankle lesion is a benign skin excision with a thrombosed dermal vessel. The total thyroidectomy revealed a unifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right superior pole measuring 2.0 cm, with negative resection margins and no extrathyroidal extension, while two lymph nodes from the right paratracheal area were positive for metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma. The overall pathology stage is classified as pT1b, pN1a, pMX, and the specimen integrity was intact.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph node biopsy shows metastatic carcinoma in one lymph node, measuring 7.0 mm, with extranodal extension of 2.0 mm. The left breast mastectomy reveals invasive lobular carcinoma with low to intermediate grade features, measuring approximately 8.5 cm, and no definitive lymphovascular invasion is identified. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma is found in nine of twenty-one dissected lymph nodes, with the largest metastasis measuring 5.0 mm and focal extranodal extension present.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the stomach measuring 7 x 6 x 1.5 cm, which is ulcerated and classified as moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The tumor has extended to the serosa but shows no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph node. Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion, as well as margins and neo-adjuvant treatment, were not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the left thyroid nodule was diagnosed as a papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 2.0 cm in the left lobe, with well-differentiated histology and no evidence of capsular or vascular invasion. Additionally, two peri-thyroidal lymph nodes and one para-tracheal lymph node were excised, all of which were found to be benign. The report also notes the presence of chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis in the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma in the total thyroidectomy specimen, with the largest focus measuring 2.3 cm in the left lobe and a smaller 0.4 cm microcarcinoma in the isthmus, both confined to the thyroid without lymphovascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes (8 total) showed no evidence of tumor involvement, and there is also evidence of nodular thyroid hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. Additionally, parathyroid tissue excised from various locations showed hypercellularity but no malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear) cell type, with a Fuhrman's nuclear grade of 3 out of 4 and a tumor size of 4.2 cm, confined within the renal capsule. There is no evidence of invasion into the renal vein, and all surgical margins are free of neoplasm. Additionally, the non-neoplastic kidney shows focal glomerulosclerosis, and the tumor is classified as pT1b NX MX in the TNM staging system.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 4.5 cm, confined to the left upper pole of the kidney. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion. Additionally, benign urothelial mucosa with chronic inflammation and benign renal parenchyma were noted in the biopsy of the deep margin collecting system on sinus fat.

The pathology report indicates the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5), showing extensive extraprostatic extension and invasion into the right seminal vesicle and perivesicular soft tissue. Additionally, metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in one of six left pelvic lymph nodes and one of nine right pelvic lymph nodes, both with extranodal extension. The tumor extends to the cauterized margin of resection at the anterior bladder neck, with a focus measuring 2.5 x 2.0 cm in the prostate.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix and upper vagina. Both the left and right pelvic lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for metastasis. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma likely of cervical origin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.5 cm, with papillary features, and the tumor is adjacent to but does not invade the visceral pleura. All surgical margins, including bronchial, vascular, and stapled parenchymal margins, are negative for tumor, and the pathologic stage is classified as T1N0MX. Additionally, lymph node dissections from stations 5 and 7 show no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive urothelial carcinoma in the left distal ureter and bladder, with extensive invasion into surrounding tissues, including the prostatic stroma and seminal vesicles. The tumor in the bladder measures 10 cm and is classified as high grade, with a TNM stage of pT4a, pNo, pMX, while the left ureterovesical junction also shows invasive carcinoma. Additionally, incidental adenocarcinoma of the prostate is noted, with no extraprostatic extension and a Gleason score of 6/10.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive lobular carcinoma in the right breast, characterized by two dominant tumor masses measuring 4.0 cm and 1.0 cm, with invasion into the dermal skin and lymphovascular space, while the surgical margins are negative for tumor. Sentinel lymph node analysis revealed no malignancy in two examined nodes, but metastatic carcinoma was identified in two out of eight lymph nodes. The overall pathologic staging is classified as mpT4b, N1a, M-not applicable, with additional findings of Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS) and low expression of estrogen and progesterone receptors.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the mandible, with metastatic involvement in one level 2 lymph node and evidence of extranodal extension. Additionally, a small focus of follicular variant papillary carcinoma was identified in the total thyroidectomy specimen, measuring 1.7 cm. Other lymph nodes and tissues examined showed granulomatous inflammation, benign thyroid tissue, and no tumors in several lymph nodes and other structures.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 3.5 cm, with metastatic carcinoma found in 2 of 8 lymph nodes. Additionally, there is evidence of acute inflammation in fibroadipose tissue from the neck excision, and the margins of the tumor are uninvolved with no evidence of vascular invasion. The left central neck dissection also revealed metastatic papillary carcinoma in 2 of 7 lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (grade 2) in the left liver, measuring 4.3 x 4.1 x 4.0 cm, with negative resection margins and no evidence of vascular or microscopic invasion. Additionally, the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis, with two benign lymph nodes identified. The liver also exhibits established stage 4 cirrhosis, with minimal hemosiderosis noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma arising from the lower uterine segment, with 50% myometrial invasion and a tumor size of 4.5 cm in length and 4.0 cm in depth. The margins from the excised specimens are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and there is extensive lymph-vascular invasion, but no regional lymph node metastasis was found. Additional findings include benign fibrovascular tissue at the surgical margins, bilateral ovarian follicular cysts, and adenomyosis, with the cervical tumor identified as poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the lung with a tumor size of 3.2 cm, which is poorly differentiated and invades the visceral pleura, classified as Stage IV due to the presence of a pleural deposit. Multiple lymph node biopsies show no evidence of malignancy, but hyalinized granulomas are present, with no fungal or mycobacterial species identified. The report also notes arterial invasion and confirms that all surgical margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, characterized by 60% clear cells and 40% eosinophilic cells, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4 and a tumor size of 6.5 cm. The tumor is noted to be well-circumscribed and does not invade the perinephric adipose tissue or renal vein, although it bulges into the perinephric adipose tissue and is located within a vascular space in the renal sinus. Additionally, multiple simple renal cortical cysts are present, with the largest measuring up to 6 cm, and no lymph nodes were identified within the hilum of the kidney.

The pathology report indicates that both cervical biopsy specimens show invasive squamous cell carcinoma that is focally keratinizing and moderately to poorly differentiated, with ulceration and significant acute and chronic inflammation present. Lymphovascular invasion was not identified in either specimen. Immunohistochemical staining for p63 confirmed the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma and ruled out neuroendocrine small cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas, with a solid mass measuring 4.0 x 3.0 x 3.0 cm that causes a stricture of the distal common bile duct and extends into surrounding soft tissue and the duodenal wall. Surgical margins are mostly negative for tumor, except for the neck margin and a microfocus of carcinoma in the body margin, while multiple regional lymph nodes show metastatic involvement. The gallbladder appears unremarkable, and the overall classification is AJCC pT3N1.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, with multiple small papillary neoplasms identified in adjacent renal tissue. Additionally, an oncocytoma was found in a separate tumor mass, while no tumors were detected in the Gerota's fascia, perirenal fat, or perimass fat. The dominant tumors exhibit characteristics of type I papillary carcinoma, with capsular disruption noted in one mass, and all resection margins are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma, grade 3 of 4, with a main tumor mass measuring 12 cm and adjacent satellite nodules totaling 3 cm (pT3a). The tumor was present at the original superior resection margin of the right lobe, but the final resection margins from the additional lobe are negative for tumor. Lymphatic space invasion was identified, and the background hepatic parenchyma shows moderate steatohepatitis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in a right pericardial mass measuring 5 cm, characterized by necrosis and a mitotic rate of 2-10 mitoses per high power field. The tumor shows marked nuclear atypia and infiltrates adjacent fat, with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. Immunohistochemical staining reveals strong positivity for desmin and smooth muscle-specific actin, and the tumor extends to the resection margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant Mllerian mixed tumor (carcinosarcoma) of the endometrium, characterized by a FIGO grade 3 endometrioid carcinomatous component that invades the myometrium and serosa, with extensive necrosis and lymphovascular space invasion. The tumor involves over 90% of the endometrial surface and the endocervical mucosa, with pelvic washings positive for tumor cells, leading to a staging of pT3a, N0, Mx, corresponding to FIGO stage IIIA. All examined lymph nodes (15 total) are negative for metastatic carcinoma, and the adnexa are reported as benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type) in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm and local invasion into the renal sinus fat, classified as pT3b. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and no renal vein invasion or metastatic lymph nodes were identified. The adrenal gland and surrounding lymph nodes were found to be benign, with no lymph node tissue detected in the resected specimens.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a partial nephrectomy of the left kidney, revealing a 3.5 cm papillary renal cell carcinoma (Fuhrman grade 2) that is confined to the kidney with no vascular invasion and negative margins. Additionally, the left adrenal gland was examined and found to be unremarkable with no abnormalities noted. The tumor is classified as pT1a, and there are no signs of necrosis or sarcomatoid features.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO Grade III) in the uterus, with myometrial invasion and negative margins, while the lymph nodes examined (left external iliac, right external iliac, and para-aortic) showed no evidence of tumor involvement. Additionally, the right adnexa revealed follicular cysts and a hemorrhagic corpus luteum, while the left adnexa contained a follicular cyst, both without any tumors. The cyst Morgagni was identified as encapsulated fat necrosis consistent with appendiceal epiploica.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated grade 3 urothelial carcinoma (invasive bladder cancer) with extensive invasion through the bladder wall and into the peritoneum, classified as pT3b pN0 R1. The tumor measures 130 mm and is located primarily in the bladder, abutting but not invading the prostate, which shows minor nodular hyperplasia. One lymph node sampled shows reactive changes with no evidence of tumor, and the ureteric resection margin does not contain visible urothelium.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a mass measuring 12 x 11 x 8 cm, with no vascular invasion and surgical margins clear by 1 cm. Additionally, the gallbladder shows mild chronic cholecystitis, with no stones present. The tissue samples were submitted en bloc from the right lobe of the liver and gallbladder.

The pathology report describes a solid tumor located near the nipple, measuring 4x3x3.5 cm, characterized by firm consistency and an irregular border. Microscopic examination reveals large transformed lymphoid cells arranged in diffuse or alveolar patterns, consistent with a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which is poorly differentiated and shows invasion of benign breast tissue. No lymph node metastasis was detected in the examined axillary nodes, and additional immunohistochemical findings indicate the tumor is CD20 positive and CKAE1/AE3 negative.

The pathology report indicates that a right SCF skin biopsy showed an exudative inflammatory process without neoplasia. A total pharyngolaryngectomy revealed a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 6.0 cm, with infiltration of the bilateral vocal folds and arytenoid and thyroid cartilages, but no vascular or perineural invasion. Importantly, the epiglottis, pre-glottic fat, thyroid, surgical margins, and all examined lymph nodes were uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that all four sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla show no evidence of tumor involvement. The right breast mastectomy reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 2.7 cm, classified as SBR Grade 3, with negative margins and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Additionally, a scalp lesion was identified as a pilar cyst, and the additional axillary tail tissue showed no tumor or lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma (grade 3) in the bladder, which is invasive into the muscularis propria and involves prostatic ducts and acini, but shows no invasion into the prostatic stroma or lymphovascular invasion. The specimen consists of multiple fragments of soft tissue measuring 3.0 x 2.5 x 1.0 cm, which were submitted entirely for examination. The clinical history notes a prior diagnosis of bladder cancer.

The pathology report indicates that a cervical biopsy was performed, revealing mainly degenerative tissue with minute fragments of viable dysplastic squamous cells consistent with invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The specimen consisted of two tissue fragments measuring between 0.4 and 1.1 cm, which were entirely submitted for analysis. The findings suggest the presence of cervical cancer, specifically invasive squamous cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated intestinal type adenocarcinoma in the stomach, specifically located in the fundus, with a tumor size of 12 x 15 x 2.5 cm and ulcerated features. All 16 examined lymph nodes show evidence of metastasis, indicating extensive spread of the disease. There are no specified details regarding lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion, and the margins of the tumor are also not detailed.

The pathology report describes a hypercellular glial neoplasm that infiltrates both gray and white matter, characterized by moderate atypia and the presence of mitotic figures, with no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis. The tumor exhibits features consistent with an oligodendroglioma, including sheets of atypical cells resembling oligodendrocytes, prominent perinuclear halos, and microcalcifications. The final diagnosis is anaplastic oligodendroglioma Grade III, with a MIB-1 labeling index of up to 15.5% indicating a higher proliferation rate.

The pathology report indicates the presence of non-small cell carcinoma in the level 5 lymph node, confirming a diagnosis of lung cancer. The left upper lobe specimen shows a tumor measuring 3.5 x 2.5 x 2.5 cm, located near the pleura and close to the stapled margin. Additionally, two small fragments from level 7 lymph nodes were submitted for analysis, but no specific findings were detailed for these fragments.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an adeno-squamous cell carcinoma in the lung, classified as grade 3. The tumor is staged as T4 N0 M0, suggesting it is locally advanced without regional or distant metastasis. No treatment has been initiated at this time, and the specimen was obtained from a blood draw.

The final pathology report confirms the diagnosis of a thymoma classified as WHO type mixed A/B, with a maximum tumor dimension of 5.3 cm, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, benign multilocular thymic cysts and one benign lymph node were identified in the resected tissue. The frozen section diagnosis was consistent with the final diagnosis, and all examined margins were negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4 (total score 7), involving approximately 10% of the prostatic tissue and showing extraprostatic extension at the right base. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in one of eleven examined lymph nodes, measuring less than 1 mm, with no evidence of malignancy in the seminal vesicles. The report also notes the presence of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia in the non-neoplastic prostate tissue.

The histopathological examination of a total organ resection of the colon and rectum revealed a 6.1 x 7.4 x 3.4 cm tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma (G2) located at the rectosigmoid junction, with infiltration into the muscularis propria and mesorectal fat. The tumor surrounded 80% of the intestinal circumference, with clear margins at the excision lines, and there were metastases identified in lymph nodes (No II/XIII). Additionally, a 0.9 cm tubular adenoma with mild dysplasia was found outside the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason grade of 5+5, involving approximately 35% of the examined prostatic tissue and showing extraprostatic extension and positive surgical margins. The right and left pelvic lymph nodes were examined, with a total of ten nodes (four from the right and six from the left) found to be negative for carcinoma. The pathological staging is classified as pT3a, indicating extraprostatic extension or microscopic invasion of the bladder neck.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, oncocytic variant, measuring 2.7 cm, with associated follicular nodular disease and a 2.5 cm follicular adenoma in the thyroid. The left hemithyroidectomy specimen shows unifocal tumor growth with minimal capsular invasion and uninvolved margins, while no lymphovascular or perineural invasion is identified. Additionally, the parathyroid glands contain double adenomas, one of chief cell type and the other of clear cell variant, with no regional lymph nodes examined or involved.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right axillary sentinel lymph node with metastatic carcinoma in one lymph node, and a right breast mastectomy revealing invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 4.8 cm with a high-grade intraductal carcinoma component. The lymph nodes excised from the axilla showed no tumor in seven out of eight nodes, with one sentinel lymph node positive for carcinoma. The invasive ductal carcinoma is classified as grade 3, with negative margins and no lymphatic-vascular invasion, and immunohistochemical analysis shows the tumor is negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors, with indeterminate HER2 status.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, with a high proportion of necrosis ranging from 30% to 50% across multiple biopsy samples. Immunohistochemical analysis shows weak MGMT staining (15%), loss of PTEN, and absence of pMAPK, suggesting potential responsiveness to Temodar and radiation therapy. Additionally, the expression levels of laminin beta-1 and beta-2 indicate a more favorable prognosis, despite the aggressive nature of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous adenocarcinoma involving multiple sites, including the omentum and soft tissue nodules in the anterior cul-de-sac and adnexa, with extensive lymphovascular space invasion noted. The tumor is characterized as moderately to poorly differentiated, with no evidence of ovarian parenchyma in the examined specimens, suggesting a primary peritoneal neoplasm. The report highlights significant tumor involvement in the pelvic peritoneum and omentum, but regional lymph node metastases could not be evaluated.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of a solid mass in the left groin revealed a high-grade leiomyosarcoma, which is a type of cancer that invades surrounding tissues. The excised tumor showed evidence of tumor thrombus formation and involvement of neurovascular bundles, with the lateral deep margin testing positive for tumor presence. Additionally, three lymph nodes from the left iliac region were excised and found to be negative for tumor, suggesting no lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of choroidal melanoma of mixed epithelioid and spindled type, measuring 13 mm at the base, with evidence of vortex vein invasion and extraocular extension. The optic nerve and ciliary body are negative for tumor involvement, and the tumor shows mitotic activity at a rate of 1 per 10 high-power fields. The gross examination reveals an intact right globe with a notable choroidal tumor shadow corresponding to the melanoma.

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy of the right upper lobe of the lung revealed a poorly differentiated non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.1 x 1.7 x 1.8 cm, with all surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, no tumor was identified in the examined lymph nodes from stations 7 and 9, with a total of eight lymph nodes showing no evidence of malignancy. The findings suggest localized disease without regional or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive, moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 2.3 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and extending into periuterine soft tissue, but with clear margins. A total of 27 lymph nodes were examined from pelvic dissections, all showing no evidence of malignancy. The report confirms that the patient underwent a radical hysterectomy with bilateral salpingectomy, and there were no regional lymph node metastases detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant melanoma with a pigmented mass measuring 2x1.5 cm that has invaded the fatty tissue and exhibits ulceration. The tumor is classified as Clark's level IV and has a Breslow thickness of 15 mm, with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. The specimen was obtained from an excision of a skin lesion located on the trunk.

The pathology report describes a specimen from the left lateral segment of the liver, which reveals a well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 2.7 cm. The tumor is located within a background of micronodular cirrhosis and is noted to have uninvolved surgical margins with no vascular invasion identified. Regional lymph nodes were not submitted for evaluation, and distant metastasis could not be assessed from this specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of basaloid squamous cell carcinoma in the right tonsil, measuring 2.2 cm at its greatest extent, following a tonsillectomy. The tumor is classified as AJCC stage II (pT2, pNn/a) and shows no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, with the edges of the specimen negative for malignancy. Additional tissue was submitted for research purposes, and the findings were reviewed by the attending pathologist.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in one of thirteen left iliac lymph nodes, with no extranodal extension observed. In contrast, the right iliac lymph nodes showed no evidence of tumor in twenty-one nodes. Additionally, prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3) was identified, with tumor invasion into the right seminal vesicle and bladder neck, but resection margins were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma with squamous epithelial differentiation, measuring 4 cm in maximum diameter, and infiltrating to the submucosal boundary without significant invasion into surrounding fatty tissue. The remaining bladder mucosa exhibits chronic inflammation, and there is no evidence of dysplasia at the resection margins. The tumor classification is pT2b, G3, with no lymphovascular invasion (L0) or perineural invasion (V0), and the resection lines are tumor-free.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis with no evidence of malignancy. In contrast, the liver segment 5 reveals a moderately-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm, with resection margins free of tumor, alongside findings of cirrhosis. The patient has a history of cirrhosis secondary to alcohol ingestion, which is consistent with the liver findings.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right hypopharynx, with involvement of the right vocal cord and metastatic carcinoma found in two of nine lymph nodes from the left neck dissection and three of fifteen lymph nodes from the right neck dissection. The report also notes that the esophagus is involved by neoplasia, while the surgical margins are mostly uninvolved, although some are exiguous at 1.0 mm. Additionally, a follicular papillary carcinoma of the thyroid gland is identified, with a tumor size of 1.2 cm and uninvolved margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, specifically located in the antrum, with a tumor size of 9 cm and evidence of invasion through all wall layers and into the omentum. Out of fifteen examined lymph nodes, eleven showed metastases, and the surgical margins are involved with tumor elements. There is no evidence of venous invasion, but the tumor is characterized as diffusely infiltrating (linitis plastica).

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical cystoprostatectomy due to high-grade urothelial carcinoma with sarcomatoid change, which has invaded the muscularis propria and perivesical fat, measuring 4.0 cm in size. All examined lymph nodes (27 total) and surgical margins were negative for tumor, suggesting no lymphatic spread. Additionally, the prostate showed high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, but no tumor was found in the excised distal ureter.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of thymoma, specifically WHO type B3, with a greatest tumor dimension of 3.7 cm and multifocal microscopic invasion into the surrounding mediastinal fat, although the painted resection margins are negative for tumor. The tumor is classified as stage IIa due to the microscopic transcapsular invasion, and the histological examination reveals predominantly epithelial cells with some atypical features. Additionally, the report notes involutional changes in thymic tissue and a parathyroid gland without significant abnormalities.

The pathology report describes a mildly to moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm resembling atypical fibrillar and gemistocytic astrocytes, with significant perivascular lymphocytic inflammation. There is no evidence of oligodendroglioma or ganglion cell differentiation, and while no mitotic figures are identified, the atypical features classify the tumor as anaplastic grade 3. The MIB-1 immunohistochemistry shows a labeling index of 16.3%, indicating high proliferative activity consistent with the diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma grade 3.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two types of brain tumors: a low-grade glioma with microcystic change and a higher-grade oligodendroglioma with atypical features. The glioma shows a low proliferation index of 1%, while the oligodendroglioma has a proliferation index of 28%, suggesting a more aggressive nature. Overall, the findings suggest a diffusely infiltrating glioma with low mitotic activity and necrosis, but the presence of neovascularization and cellular areas in the oligodendroglioma may indicate potential for more aggressive behavior.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade III, based on biopsies from two different brain tumor specimens. Histological examination reveals a highly cellular and atypical astrocytic proliferation with a significant mitotic rate, but no necrosis or microvascular proliferation. Immunohistochemical analysis shows approximately 50% positivity for p53 and a proliferation index of 5 to 10%, while IDH-1 is negative, confirming the diagnosis of high-grade glioma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic serous adenocarcinoma in the omentum and bladder reflection, along with moderately differentiated serous papillary adenocarcinoma in both the right and left ovaries, extending to the respective peritubal tissues. Additionally, the uterus shows chronic cervicitis, inactive endometrium, leiomyomas, and metastatic papillary adenocarcinoma involving the serosal surface. Multiple sigmoid nodules and masses in the right pelvic sidewall and cul-de-sac are also identified as metastatic papillary serous adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 2 cm and extending into the outer muscularis propria, with negative margins and no lymphatic or vascular invasion. The cervix, uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes, and vaginal mucosa show no significant pathological abnormalities, and all examined pelvic lymph nodes (21 total) are negative for tumor. The overall staging is pT2bN0Mx, indicating localized bladder cancer without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a papillary thyroid carcinoma of the follicular variant, measuring approximately 5.7 cm, with tumor extension to the margins but no definite angiolymphatic invasion or extrathyroidal extension. Molecular testing revealed no mutations in BRAF, NRAS, HRAS, or KRAS, and the FISH test was negative for RET/PTC rearrangement, suggesting a lower likelihood of aggressive behavior. The final diagnosis confirms the presence of a unifocal tumor in the right lobe of the thyroid, with additional findings of a multinodular thyroid and no parathyroid glands identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive high-grade serous carcinoma in both ovaries, with extraovarian pelvic spread noted as a 6 cm deposit attached to the left fallopian tube, and a Silverberg grade of 3/3. The uterus and cervix show benign findings, including inactive endometrium, leiomyoma, and polyps, with no malignant cells detected in the pelvic wash. The tumor is staged as pT2a, Nx, Mx, indicating local invasion without lymphatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 1.3 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion and involvement of N1 and N2 lymph nodes, but all surgical margins are free of cancer. Molecular testing revealed no KRAS, EGFR exon 19 or 21 mutations, but identified EGFR amplification, while EML4/ALK rearrangement was not detected. The final pathologic stage is classified as T1 N2 Mx, and additional lymph node biopsies showed reactive changes with some positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colorectal carcinoma located in the colon, with invasive spread through all layers of the intestinal wall and into the mesocolic fatty tissue, while also noting the presence of three tubulovillous adenomas with varying degrees of dysplasia. The resection margins and lymph nodes were tumor-free, leading to a staging of pT3 pNO (0/54), L0, V0; G2, with an additional note of a fresh ulcerous defect in the cecum. Additionally, the gallbladder shows signs of moderate chronic cholecystitis, likely associated with gallstones.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, Fuhrman grade 2, in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm that is confined within the kidney and abuts the renal capsule. The tumor margins are negative for invasion, with no evidence of renal sinus invasion, and the pathologic stage is classified as pT1a. Additionally, there are findings of arteriolosclerosis in the non-tumor portion of the kidney, consistent with the patient's history of hypertension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma from a cervical biopsy. The specimen contained a significant amount of tumor tissue, with a strong positive p63 stain supporting the diagnosis, although the orientation of the sample did not allow for measurement of the depth of invasion. The attending pathologist confirmed the findings, and the case included various special studies to support the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically papillary type 2, measuring 5 cm in greatest dimension, with Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, confined to the right kidney. Additionally, there is a simple renal cyst measuring 3.0 cm in the upper pole and cystic calyceal dilation in the mid portion of the kidney, but the margins of resection are negative for carcinoma. The tumor does not invade surrounding tissues or extend beyond Gerota's fascia, and the uninvolved renal parenchyma appears grossly unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal type 1 papillary renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and evidence of perinephric fat invasion. There are four discrete soft tissue masses identified, with one showing focal invasion of the psoas muscle, and two lymph nodes involved with metastatic disease exhibiting extracapsular extension. The pathologic stage is classified as rpT4, pN1, with no cancer detected at the resection margin.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right neck dissection and total thyroidectomy, revealing metastatic papillary carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes across levels II, III, and IV, as well as in the right paratracheal neck dissection. The total thyroid examination showed a 2.2 cm papillary thyroid carcinoma with extension into adjacent parathyroid tissue and tumor present at the margin. Additionally, one lymph node in level II exhibited a psammoma body surrounded by giant cells, but no epithelial cells were identified, and cytokeratin staining was negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type located in the right flexure, measuring 4.5 cm, with minimal infiltration into the pericolic fatty tissue. All regional lymph nodes are tumor-free, and the resection margins from both the small intestine and colon are clear of tumor. Additionally, three tubular colon mucosa adenomas with mild to moderate dysplasia were identified, classified as low-grade intraepithelial neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that the left pelvic lymph nodes show no tumor presence, while the prostate gland exhibits adenocarcinoma with microscopic involvement at the bladder margin, specifically on both the right and left sides. The Gleason score is 6/10, and the tumor is classified as pT3a, pNO, pMX, with a positive inked margin at the bladder neck but clear margins elsewhere. Notably, there is no perineural invasion or tumor detected in the seminal vesicles.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 2 x 1 cm with a depth of invasion of 7 mm, and no lymphovascular invasion identified. Multiple lymph nodes excised from various locations were found to be benign and negative for tumor, confirming no metastatic spread. The report also notes the presence of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 3) and a leiomyoma in the uterus, with the overall staging classified as FIGO stage IB.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymph node dissection due to cervical carcinoma, specifically poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with a maximum tumor invasion depth of 12 mm and no involvement of surrounding tissues. All examined lymph nodes (31 in total) showed no evidence of malignancy, confirming the absence of metastasis. The final staging of the tumor is classified as FIGO stage IB, indicating it is confined to the uterus but larger than T1a2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC) in the right kidney, with the largest tumor nodule measuring 1.9 cm and classified as grade 3 on the Fuhrman scale. There is no evidence of tumor invasion into surrounding structures, including the renal vein, ureter, or perirenal adipose tissue, and all surgical margins are negative. Additional findings include chronic interstitial nephritis and arteriolonephrosclerosis, with the overall staging classified as pT1a pNx pMx.

The pathology report indicates a 7.5 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as poorly differentiated (G3), with invasion into adjacent fatty tissue and the omentum. Out of 15 examined lymph nodes, 9 showed evidence of metastasis, confirming the spread of cancer. There is no evidence of venous invasion, and the surgical margins are reported as uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a mixed germ cell tumor in the left testicle, comprising approximately 60% teratoma, 20% yolk sac tumor, 10% embryonal carcinoma, and 10% choriocarcinoma, with a tumor size of 6.6 cm. The tumor has not invaded surrounding structures such as the epididymis, tunica vaginalis, or spermatic cord, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, intratubular germ cell neoplasia is present, and mild chronic inflammation is noted, with AJCC staging classified as pT1 pNx.

The pathology report indicates that the periaortic lymph node is free of tumor, while the left kidney shows a renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 4, measuring 14.0 cm. The tumor has invaded the renal pelvis, renal sinus adipose tissue, and renal vein, but the ureter, hilar vascular, and soft tissue margins are free of tumor, as is the adrenal gland. The tumor comprises approximately 80% of the kidney and extends to perinephric fat, with the closest soft tissue margin being 0.2 cm away.

The pathology report indicates the presence of benign salivary gland tissue with chronic inflammation in the left lymph node, while the tongue exhibits changes consistent with verrucous hyperplasia and invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with perineural and angiolymphatic invasion. A focus of metastatic SCC was identified in one of sixty lymph nodes from the left neck dissection, with no extracapsular extension noted. Additionally, invasive moderately to poorly differentiated SCC was found in the left buccal mass and left maxillectomy specimen, with positive margins in certain areas, indicating a need for further clinical correlation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant mixed Mllerian tumor involving the uterus, with extensive infiltration into the lower uterine segment and full thickness of the myometrium, as well as metastatic involvement in the vagina and omentum. The cervix, ovaries, and fallopian tubes show no histopathologic abnormalities. The tumor is classified as T3b/IIIB, indicating vaginal involvement, with limited lymphovascular space invasion and regional lymph nodes not assessable.

The pathology report indicates liver metastasis from a rectal adenocarcinoma, classified as pN1. The primary tumor is an invasive rectal carcinoma (G2 to 3) with muscularis infiltration, blood vessel, and lymph vessel involvement, but with free resection margins and three lymph node metastases. The distance from the mesorectal fascia is over 1 cm, and the tumor classification is ICDO-DA M-8140/3, G2-3, pT2, L1, V1, pN1, pM1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 6.5 x 5.5 x 2.0 cm, with extension through the bladder wall and into surrounding tissues, along with lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, there is a unilateral prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3), confined to the prostate without capsular involvement. Two of the 36 examined lymph nodes showed metastatic urothelial carcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes and other examined tissues were free of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenalectomy and right nephrectomy were performed on a patient with an adrenal mass and Cushing's syndrome. The examination revealed a high-grade adrenal cortical carcinoma measuring 9.8 cm, which was adherent to but not invading the kidney and liver, with negative margins. Additionally, the kidney tissue examined was histologically unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right temporal lobe tumor diagnosed as a mixed oligoastrocytoma with atypical features, showing signs of anaplastic transformation and a proliferation index of 10%. The loss of heterozygosity on chromosome arms 1p and 19q was detected, which is characteristic of oligodendrogliomas, and the methylated MGMT promoter was also identified, suggesting potential responsiveness to alkylating agent therapy. Overall, the findings highlight a glial neoplastic proliferation with atypical nuclei and mitotic figures, but without necrosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left renal mass diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the chromophobe type, measuring 13.5 cm, which is confined within the renal capsule with no invasion of the renal vein, although there is vascular invasion within the renal sinus. Additionally, the para-aortic lymph node and hilar lymph nodes examined were benign, with no evidence of metastatic disease. The report confirms that all surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney shows signs of fibrosis and chronic inflammation.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary and fallopian tube are benign, while the left ovary contains a fibroma and residual ovarian tissue with physiological changes, alongside a benign fallopian tube. The total abdominal hysterectomy reveals endometrial adenocarcinoma of FIGO grade II, with significant myometrial invasion but no cervical or lymphovascular invasion, and pelvic washings negative for tumor cells. Lymph node dissections from various regions show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, and the excised hernia sac is consistent with mesothelium-lined fibroadipose tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with squamous differentiation and significant myometrial invasion, alongside complex and simple endometrial hyperplasia. No tumor was found in any of the examined lymph nodes, and the surgical margins were negative for tumor. Additional findings include chronic cystic cervicitis, intramural leiomyoma, and endometriosis in the ovaries, with a final FIGO stage of IB.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal bilateral and isthmic papillary carcinoma in the thyroid, with the dominant tumor measuring 4.2 cm in the left lobe and additional tumors present in the isthmus. The tumors exhibit varying degrees of encapsulation and invasion, with no extrathyroidal extension or vascular invasion noted. Additionally, there is underlying mild nodular hyperplasia and multiple papillary microcarcinomas identified within the thyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the HER2 FISH studies on the adenocarcinoma are negative, while the HER2 immunoperoxidase studies are equivocal with an INC score of 2+. The final diagnosis reveals a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma at the esophagogastric junction, measuring 2.0 cm, with evidence of invasion into the perigastric fat and two lymph nodes showing metastatic carcinoma. The margins are negative for malignancy, and there is no evidence of Barrett's esophagus, with additional findings of dysplasia in the gastric cardia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 5.5 x 3 x 2 cm and various histological patterns including papillary predominant, acinar, micropapillary, and lepidic. The parenchymal margin is negative for neoplasm, and additional assessments for pleural invasion and EGFR mutations are pending. Other findings include centrilobular emphysema and organizing pneumonia in the lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the right glottis and moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the supraglottic region, with involvement of adjacent structures and three out of forty-eight lymph nodes showing metastatic disease. Additionally, slight nodular thyroid hyperplasia was noted in both the left and right lobes of the thyroid, along with a 0.4 cm papillary thyroid microcarcinoma confined to the thyroid. Surgical margins were technically free of tumor, but the tumor was close to the preepiglottic soft tissue margin, and there was evidence of angiolymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade urothelial carcinoma with invasion into the perivesical soft tissues and involvement of the urethra, prostatic ducts, and seminal vesicles, classified as pT3b. The right distal ureter shows severe dysplasia, while both the left and right vas deferens are negative for tumor. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes, including those in the perivesical and external iliac regions, are negative for metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the sigmoid colon, measuring 3.5x3x3 cm, which is diagnosed as moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The tumor extends into the submucosa, and no lymph node metastasis was found, with 0 out of 3 lymph nodes positive for cancer. Details regarding tumor margins and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates a gastric resection specimen from the fundus, revealing a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 9 x 8 x 1 cm with ulceration. The tumor has invaded adjacent structures, specifically the lesser omentum, and one out of eight lymph nodes examined shows evidence of metastasis. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no specified evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates that both sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla are negative for metastases. A wide local excision of the left breast reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 2.2 cm, located 0.5 mm from the closest posterior margin, with negative results for tumor in the posterior margin specimen. Estrogen and progesterone receptor tests are pending, but HER2 is negative, and the tumor is classified as grade 3 with no vascular or lymphatic invasion identified.

The pathology report describes a moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm with a predominant astrocytic component and a small oligodendroglioma component, infiltrating both gray and white matter. The tumor shows mild atypia, no microvascular proliferation or necrosis, and a low mitotic activity, with a MIB-1 labeling index of 6.1%, indicating an intermediate level of proliferation. The final diagnosis is a low-grade oligoastrocytoma, classified as WHO grade II, with a recommendation for close follow-up.

The pathology report indicates that a cervical biopsy was performed, revealing invasive squamous cell carcinoma, specifically large cell, nonkeratinizing type. The specimen measured 0.9 x 0.6 x 0.3 cm and was entirely submitted for examination. The clinical history is associated with an ICD 9 code of 233.1, and the report includes relevant CPT and ICD9 codes for billing purposes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, left and right adnexa, and the uterus, with the left adnexa showing primary ovarian carcinoma, grade 3. The tumor exhibits extensive involvement of surrounding tissues, including lymphovascular invasion, and is characterized by high-grade features with associated psammoma bodies. Notably, the uterus and cervix show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, although the vaginal wall and parametrial soft tissues are involved.

The pathology report indicates a subtotal gastrectomy specimen from the fundus, revealing a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 0 x 0 x 8.5 cm with ulceration. The tumor extends to the subserosa, and 1 out of 15 lymph nodes shows metastasis, while venous invasion is absent and margins are uninvolved. There is no specified information regarding lymphatic invasion, perineural invasion, or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with Fuhrman nuclear grade 4, measuring 17.0 cm, and extending into the hilar and pericapsular adipose tissue as well as involving hilar and pericapsular vessels. The renal vein and ureteral margins are free of tumor, and the adrenal gland shows no evidence of tumor invasion, although it is compressed by the tumor. The specimen was obtained through radical nephrectomy, revealing a large, necrotic mass with various nodules, while the adjacent kidney parenchyma remains unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Type A/B Thymoma, measuring 13.0 x 11.0 x 7.0 cm, classified as pT1b, pNx, and Masaoka stage II.2. Immunohistochemical analysis shows that the epithelial cells are positive for CK5/6 and exhibit strong membrane staining for EGFR, while being negative for CD5 and CD117. Additionally, there are CD5-negative, CD1a-positive immature T-lymphocytes present in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 2 leiomyosarcoma in the uterus, measuring 10.1 cm, with vascular space invasion and serosal surface involvement. The cervix and both ovaries and fallopian tubes show no diagnostic abnormalities, while additional excised soft tissue specimens also reveal leiomyosarcoma. The overall pathologic stage is classified as T2b NX, indicating involvement of other pelvic tissues with regional lymph nodes not assessable.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a malignant infiltrate in the right parietal pleura, favoring a diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma of both epithelial and biphasic types. Microscopic examination reveals a surface micropapillary and infiltrating malignant tumor with characteristic features, including enlarged nuclei and a fibrotic pleura. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, showing strong positivity for calretinin and other markers consistent with malignant mesothelioma.

The pathology report indicates that the excised subcarinal, level 9, level 7, and level 6 lymph nodes show anthracosis without evidence of malignancy. In contrast, the left lower lobe lung excision reveals a unifocal, moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 6.0 x 5.5 x 5.0 cm, with no visceral pleural or lymphovascular invasion, and a surgical margin of 1.0 cm from the bronchial margin. The overall pTNM staging is pT2b N0, confirming the absence of metastatic disease in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with tumor invasion measuring 6 mm deep into the cervical tissue, while excision margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, benign findings include an endometrial polyp, leiomyomata, and adenomyosis in the uterus, with no evidence of malignancy in the examined lymph nodes and other structures. The left ovary shows endometriosis, but overall, there is no metastatic disease identified in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe and superior segment of the lower lobe, measuring 2.7 x 2.5 x 2.0 cm, with negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes (levels 2R, 4R, 7, and 10R) were negative for malignancy, and the pleural peel showed benign chronic inflammation. The final diagnosis classifies the tumor as moderately to poorly differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma, with a pathologic stage of pT2a pNO.

The pathology report indicates that the right axillary sentinel lymph node #1 shows a single keratin-positive cell suspicious for isolated tumor cells, while sentinel lymph node #2 shows no tumor present. The right breast total mastectomy reveals invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm with high nuclear grade and associated ductal carcinoma in situ, but the tumor does not approach surgical margins. Immunohistochemical analysis shows low estrogen receptor positivity (5%), negative progesterone receptor, and high Ki-67 proliferation index (approximately 50%).

The pathology report indicates that the excision biopsy of a temporal lobe tumor initially diagnosed as anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) was later upgraded to glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) due to the presence of greater pleomorphism and focal microvascular proliferation. The tumor exhibits a poorly preserved gemistocytic astrocytoma with moderately high pleomorphism, scattered mitotic figures, and a strong p53 positivity, while no allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q was detected. Additionally, the methylated MGMT promoter was found, suggesting potential benefit from alkylating agent therapy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse adenocarcinoma of the stomach, located in the fundus, with a tumor size of 11 x 9 x 1 cm and ulcerated features. The tumor has metastasized to 1 out of 3 examined lymph nodes, with adjacent structures, specifically the lesser omentum, involved. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment documented.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme from both a left frontal brain biopsy and excision. The tumor exhibits features such as high cellularity, necrosis, and microvascular proliferation, with some areas showing characteristics of a lower grade infiltrating astrocytoma. Immunohistochemical staining confirms the infiltrative nature of the tumor, with a proliferation rate of approximately 10-15% in the higher grade regions.

The pathology report describes a glioma with both astrocytic and oligodendroglial components, characterized by mild to moderate cytologic atypia and the presence of microgemistocytes. The oligodendroglial component shows tumor cells with round nuclei and perinuclear halo formation, while the astrocytic component consists of neoplastic glial cells with oval nuclei. The diagnosis is consistent with a low-grade oligoastrocytoma, supported by a MIB-1 labeling index of up to 2.4%.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has papillary thyroid carcinoma, with metastatic disease found in both examined prethyroid lymph nodes. The total thyroidectomy revealed a 3.3 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm tumor in the right lobe, while the left lobe and isthmus were negative for carcinoma. An addendum corrected the initial report to confirm two positive lymph nodes and updated the pTNM classification to T2 N1 Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma involving the ovaries, uterus, cervix, and bilateral fallopian tubes, with evidence of metastasis to pelvic lymph nodes and the liver. Multiple biopsies reveal metastatic adenocarcinoma in various tissues, including the peritoneum and lymph nodes, with significant tumor extension noted in the surrounding structures. The findings suggest a widespread malignancy with a high grade of tumor differentiation and extensive involvement of the pelvic region.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in several lymph nodes, with 7 out of 11 nodes examined in the right modified neck dissection showing metastatic disease. The total thyroidectomy revealed a well-differentiated infiltrative papillary carcinoma, predominantly of the follicular variant, measuring 2 cm, with focal blood vessel invasion and no identified tumor encapsulation. Other lymph nodes examined from various regions, including the right neck and mediastinum, were reported as benign, with no evidence of metastatic disease in those samples.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of tubular and partially mucinous adenocarcinoma of the stomach, with evidence of metastases in multiple lymph nodes. The tumor has penetrated the full thickness of the stomach wall and shows signs of vascular invasion, classified as G3, pT3, pN3a. Immunohistochemical examination for HER2 protein was negative in the invasive cancerous cells.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (13.5 cm) with Fuhrman grade IV, originating in the right lower pole of the kidney and extending into perirenal adipose tissue, with lymphovascular invasion noted. The surgical margins for the ureter, renal artery, and vein are negative for tumor, and immunohistochemical staining shows positive results for CD10 and RCC. Cytogenetic analysis reveals clonal aberrations, including loss of chromosome 3, which is characteristic of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive well to moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon, measuring 5.5 cm and invading through the muscularis propria into pericolonic adipose tissue, with proximity to the serosal surface. There is no perineural invasion, but 3 out of 14 regional lymph nodes are positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, resulting in a pathologic stage of pT3, N1, Mx. Surgical resection margins are negative for tumor involvement, and there is evidence of angiolymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 3.0 cm, with a satellite nodule of 1.0 cm, and lymphovascular invasion present. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 10 out of 24 examined lymph nodes, with the largest metastasis measuring 3.5 cm and evidence of extranodal extension. The tumor is classified as grade 3, with negative margins and positive HER2 status, while estrogen and progesterone receptors are both negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma with signet-ring cell differentiation in the right breast, measuring 5.8 cm, and associated with lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). Additionally, metastatic carcinoma was identified in 4 out of 6 examined axillary lymph nodes, with tumor extension into the surrounding soft tissue. The margins of resection are free of tumor, with lymphovascular invasion noted, and there are small skin ulcerations present.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the examined lymph nodes from the right obturator, left obturator/internal iliac, and left external iliac regions (0/9). The prostate specimen shows prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5), exhibiting multiple tumor foci, invasion into the seminal vesicles, and extension into extraprostatic tissue, with a positive margin of 4.0 mm at the anterior apical region. Additionally, vascular and lymphatic invasion is present, while non-dominant tumor foci are confined to the prostate with negative margins.

The pathology report indicates that a thymectomy was performed, revealing a cortical thymoma classified as B2 by the WHO, which is encapsulated and completely excised with free surgical margins. There is no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion, and the pericardium is present but not involved by the tumor. The tumor is characterized as pT1, Nx, Mx, and the surrounding thymus tissue does not show signs of lymphoid hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates that the primary site of concern is the cervix. The biopsy results confirm the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma. This diagnosis suggests that the cancer has penetrated deeper tissues of the cervix.

The pathology report indicates that a portion of the liver (segments V and VI) was resected, revealing a well-differentiated hepatocellular neoplasm, classified as encapsulated grade 1 hepatocellular carcinoma, measuring 12 x 11 x 7.5 cm. The surgical margins are free of tumor involvement. Additionally, the attached gallbladder showed signs of chronic cholecystitis without stones.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon with infiltration into the muscularis and vessels, classified as p T 2, L1, V1. There are free resection margins and no lymph node involvement (p N 0), indicating a successful removal of the tumor. The tumor classification is ICDO-DA M-8140/3, G2, consistent with R 0 status.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous adenocarcinoma, grade III, primarily involving the right ovary and fallopian tube, with additional metastatic disease identified in pelvic peritoneal nodules, right hepatic peritoneum, right periaortic lymph node, epiploic nodule, and portohepatic nodule. The left ovary showed a smaller serous adenocarcinoma, while the uterus and cervix exhibited benign changes with no evidence of malignancy. Overall, the findings suggest advanced serous adenocarcinoma with multiple metastatic sites.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma involving the left ovary, with a tumor size of 15.0 cm, and evidence of invasion into the pelvic soft tissue. Metastatic disease is confirmed in a rectosigmoid nodule, while no carcinoma is identified in the examined lymph nodes or omentum. The final staging is provisional due to insufficient data, but the primary tumor is classified as T2b, IIB, indicating extension to pelvic soft tissue without regional lymph node metastases.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, characterized as invasive with a tumor size of 6 cm, and high-grade prostatic adenocarcinoma with invasion into bilateral seminal vesicles and positive margins. No carcinoma was detected in the left and right distal ureters or in the examined pelvic lymph nodes. The report also notes associated lesions, including urothelial carcinoma in situ, and provides detailed histological findings and TNM staging for both cancers.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 2.0 cm, with a Nottingham grade of 1 and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising approximately 5% of the tumor volume. Two out of four examined lymph nodes showed metastatic carcinoma, with one node exhibiting extravasation, while the other sentinel lymph node was negative for metastasis. Additional findings include various benign breast changes, and the surgical margins are free of invasive carcinoma, with the closest margin being 0.6 cm away from the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of unifocal classical variant papillary thyroid carcinoma, measuring 2.5 cm, with complete tumor capsule and focal capsular invasion, but negative margins. There is evidence of focal lymphovascular invasion, while perineural invasion and extrathyroidal extension are not present. The pathologic staging is pT2N0MX (Stage I), with no regional lymph node metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lung, with a tumor measuring 9.0 cm that spans both the upper and lower lobes, and shows angiolymphatic invasion. One of the lymph nodes examined (4R) is positive for metastatic carcinoma, while others, including the subcarinal and additional paratracheal lymph nodes, show no malignancy. The bronchial margin is negative for invasive carcinoma, and the report notes mild to moderate dysplasia in the respiratory mucosa at the bronchial margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma in the resected rectosigmoid colon, with invasive spread through all intestinal wall layers and into adjacent periproctal soft tissue. The tumor is staged as pT3, pN1, L1, V0, with metastases found in 2 of 47 lymph nodes, while the resection margins and isolated colon sections are tumor-free. The report highlights the presence of carcinomatous lymphangiosis at the tumor margin, with a distance of 0.5 cm to the resection margin of the periproctal soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder and portal lymph nodes are benign with no significant abnormalities or carcinoma identified. However, a partial hepatectomy of the liver revealed a moderately differentiated cholangiocarcinoma, measuring 3.5 cm, with clear margins and no evidence of vascular, perineural, or capsular invasion. Additionally, the background liver shows macrovesicular steatosis and grade 1 steatohepatitis, but no significant fibrosis or cirrhosis is noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, nuclear grade 2, with a tumor size of 6.0 cm, which is confined to the right kidney and has free surgical margins. Additionally, a tiny non-malignant renomedullary interstitial cell tumor measuring 2 mm was identified, but there was no evidence of tumor in the hilar lymph node examined. Overall, the tumor did not invade surrounding structures, and the surgical margins were negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report describes a surgical resection of brain tissue from the left insula region, revealing a diffuse oligoastrocytoma, grade II. Microscopic examination shows infiltration by both oligodendroglial and astrocytic cell populations, with features such as neuronal satellitosis and vacuolation of the neuropil, but no significant mitotic activity or necrosis. The report emphasizes the need for correlation with neuroimaging studies to assess for potential higher-grade areas not represented in the histological sample.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma involving the endometrium, with invasion into the myometrium and lymphatic invasion present, along with detached tumor clusters in the right fallopian tube. Additional findings include atrophic non-carcinomatous endometrium, myometrial leiomyomas, bilateral small ovarian serous adenofibromas, and a focus of endometriosis on the left ovary, while the cervix is negative for tumor. Pelvic washing results were positive for malignant cells, and an omental biopsy was negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear) cell type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 out of 4 and a tumor size of 6.8 cm. The neoplasm extends through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia, with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, and all surgical margins are free of cancer. The tumor is classified as pT3a NX MX in the TNM staging system, with a histologic grade of G3.

The pathology report indicates that the right axillary sentinel lymph node biopsy revealed metastatic lobular carcinoma in 1 of 3 lymph nodes, measuring 8 mm, with no extranodal tumor present. The right breast mastectomy showed infiltrating lobular carcinoma with a tumor size of 2.2 cm, negative resection margins, and associated lobular carcinoma in situ. Additionally, the tumor was found to be estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor positive, and HER-2 equivocal, with further testing sent for confirmation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous carcinoma, grade 2, in the epiglottis and squamous carcinoma in the fibroconnective tissue of the right jugular branch, with evidence of metastatic squamous carcinoma in 4 out of 18 cervical lymph nodes. The right pyriform shows squamous mucosa with mild atypia, while the superior pharyngeal margin and other lymph nodes are free of tumor. The laryngectomy specimen reveals extensive tumor involvement but with resection margins that are free of invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the liver, measuring 4.8 x 4.0 x 3.5 cm, with the tumor confined to the liver and a negative resection margin. Microscopic small vessel invasion is present, while there is no evidence of large vessel invasion or regional lymph node involvement. Additionally, the liver shows chronic hepatitis C changes with minimal activity and cirrhosis, and the gallbladder reveals chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 4.5 cm, with subpleural extension but no invasion of the visceral pleura. The surgical margins, including vascular and bronchial margins, are negative for tumor, and three examined lymph nodes are also negative for tumor, resulting in a pathologic stage of T2N0M0. While the tumor is likely a primary lung carcinoma, the possibility of it being a lung metastasis cannot be completely ruled out based on morphological assessment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a thymoma, classified as WHO type AB, with a maximum tumor dimension of 5.0 cm and evidence of microscopic transcapsular invasion, corresponding to Masaoka-Koga stage IIA. The thymic tissue also shows age-appropriate involutional changes, while two examined inferior cervical lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. Overall, the tumor appears to be completely encapsulated with no regional lymph node metastases identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 2, measuring 9.0 cm, with metastasis found in 2 of 18 examined axillary lymph nodes, while resection margins are clear. The tumor exhibits a single focus of invasion and shows lymphovascular invasion, but no necrosis or lobular carcinoma in situ is identified. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals positive estrogen receptors (99%) and negative progesterone receptors (<1%), with HER-2/neu scoring negative (1+).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 3.3 cm, but without local or renal vein invasion, and with free surgical margins. Additionally, a biopsy of the right kidney revealed mild diabetic nephropathy, mild diabetic glomerulopathy, and focal segmental and global glomerulosclerosis, suggesting secondary forms of kidney damage related to advanced vascular sclerosis. The report also notes the presence of chronic interstitial inflammation and arteriosclerosis, with no significant glomerular lesions identified.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an oligodendroglioma, classified as WHO grade II, located in the left parietal lobe, confirmed through biopsy, excision, and ultrasonic surgical aspiration.
