The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated serous carcinoma involving the omentum, bilateral ovaries, and right fallopian tube, with additional findings of atrophic endometrium and leiomyomata in the uterus. Multiple biopsies reveal carcinomatous implants with lymphovascular invasion in various sites, including the rectosigmoid colon, pelvic tumor, and perirectal tissue, indicating extensive metastatic spread. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage III and TNM stage pT3NXMX, with strong p53 staining suggesting an ovarian primary origin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, with the tumor measuring 5.0 cm and extending into adjacent soft tissue and the deep margin of resection. Metastatic disease is identified in 3 of 16 lymph nodes from bilateral neck dissections, with extracapsular extension noted in the largest affected lymph node. The remaining surgical margins of resection are negative for tumor, although the inferior tracheal margin is focally involved.

The pathology report indicates the presence of epithelioid malignant mesothelioma in multiple specimens taken from the right pleura, including both parietal and visceral pleura. Microscopic examination reveals a malignant tumor composed of epithelioid cells with solid and tubopapillary architecture, demonstrating invasion into surrounding tissues. No sarcomatoid component was identified, consistent with the previously diagnosed condition.

The pathology report describes a segment of the large intestine with a cauliflower-shaped tumor measuring 4.7 x 9.3 x 1.2 cm, which is classified as a G3 mucinous adenocarcinoma that infiltrates the muscularis propria and pericolonic fat. The tumor surrounds the entire circumference of the intestine and is accompanied by polyps with moderate to high-grade dysplasia. The intestinal ends are free of neoplastic lesions, and there is reactive lymphadenitis noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 5.0 x 3.5 x 2.0 cm, with infiltration touching the muscularis propria. Surgical margins, including the right ureteral margin, are compromised by neoplasia, while lymph nodes dissected from both sides are free of neoplastic involvement. Additionally, the right and left seminal vesicles show no signs of neoplasia, but the prostate is compromised by the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma with extensive vascular invasion following a total laryngectomy and partial pharyngectomy, with tumor involvement in the epiglottic and paraglottic spaces and close proximity to the excision margins. Additionally, nodular goiter was identified in both the right and left thyroid specimens, while the skin of the neck showed no evidence of tumor. The report notes that the vascular margins are considered positive for tumor invasion, despite being less than 1 mm from the margin of excision.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the prostate, with no extraprosthetic extension observed. The tumor is primarily located in the peripheral zone of the prostate, with a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7/10, and shows focal lymphatic invasion and extensive perineural invasion. The tumor is staged as pT2c, pNX, pMX, and no tumor is present in the seminal vesicles or at the specimen margins.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon (G2) that has penetrated all layers of the bowel wall (pT3) and shows lymph vessel invasion, with lymph node metastases (pN2). The report also notes that there are free anastomosis rings and no residual tumor was found in the examined preparations, indicating clear resection margins. The tumor classification is recorded as ICDO-DA-M 8140/3, G2, pT3, pN2, L1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of uveal melanoma in the left globe, characterized by mixed epithelioid and spindled types, measuring approximately 20 mm by 10 mm, with involvement of the choroid and ciliary body, and focal extension onto the iris. There is choroidal invasion present, but no definitive invasion of the canal of Schlemm, and the optic nerve and vortex veins are negative for tumor. Additionally, a fine needle aspiration biopsy was performed for further diagnostic testing, with background changes noted in the retina and lens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma, epithelial type, based on the examination of a right parietal pleural biopsy. Macroscopically, the specimen consists of multiple pieces of fibrous and membranous tissue with hemorrhagic areas. Microscopically, the findings reveal malignant cells in a fibrotic background, with specific immunohistochemical markers supporting the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 10 cm in diameter, with ulceration and no evidence of invasion into the muscularis propria. All 15 examined lymph nodes were negative for metastasis, and there was no lymphatic or venous invasion noted. The surgical margins were uninvolved, and the tumor was located in the fundus of the stomach.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated endophytic squamous cell carcinoma in the left partial glossectomy specimen, measuring 1 cm and invading to a depth of 0.5 cm, with all surgical margins free of tumor involvement. No metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the sentinel lymph nodes or other examined lymph nodes, and there was no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. The final AJCC pathologic stage is classified as T1, N0, indicating early-stage disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right tongue, measuring 3.1 cm, with negative surgical margins. Additionally, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was found in 8 out of 42 lymph nodes from the left levels 1-4 and in 3 out of 6 lymph nodes from the right level 1, while skeletal muscle and other lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. The tumor is classified as AJCC stage IVA (pT2pN2pM n/a), with the largest metastasis measuring 2.8 cm and no extranodal extension noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation at the gastroesophageal junction, measuring 2.2 cm, which invades the muscularis propria but does not show lymphovascular space invasion. All examined lymph nodes, totaling twenty-five, are negative for metastatic carcinoma, and the surgical margins are also negative for carcinoma. The final pathological tumor stage is classified as pT3 N0, indicating advanced local disease without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report describes an amelanotic melanoma of the skin, measuring 7.5x5 cm with a tumor diameter of up to 2 cm and a Breslow thickness of 10 mm, classified as Clark's level V. There is superficial ulceration present, and out of six examined lymph nodes, two showed metastases. The case is staged as pT4bN2bM0 according to the 7th edition of the TNM classification.

The pathology report indicates a left eye enucleation due to a 12 mm uveal melanoma originating from the ciliary processes, with infiltration into the choroid but sparing the sclera. The optic nerve is free of tumor involvement throughout its entire course, including the cut end. Microscopic examination reveals moderate nuclear atypia and some pigmented cells, with no evidence of endolymphatic embolus.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a halfway differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right middle lobe of the lung, which infiltrates the segmental bronchus and compresses the segmental artery. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma is identified in one of five para-segmental pulmonary artery lymph nodes, while the bronchial stump shows no tumor but has metastasis in one of two parabronchial lymph nodes. Additionally, the subcarinal lymph nodes are negative for tumor, and a rib section is noted to be on decalcification.

The pathology report indicates a left breast simple mastectomy revealing infiltrating Nottingham grade III ductal carcinoma, measuring 2.6 x 2.4 x 2.0 cm, with no angiolymphatic invasion or significant ductal carcinoma in situ. Additionally, a separate 1.2 x 1.0 x 1.0 cm hyalinized fibroadenoma was found, and all three left axillary sentinel lymph nodes were negative for tumor. Her-2/NEU testing has been ordered on the paraffin embedded tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total thyroidectomy due to a multinodular goiter, revealing two foci of papillary thyroid carcinoma: a 3.0 cm encapsulated follicular variant in the left lobe and a microcarcinoma in the right lobe, both confined to the thyroid without invasion. The report also notes the presence of multinodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, with no tumor found in the examined lymph nodes. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT2, with clear margins and no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates a final diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (3.0 cm) in the left mandible, with no tumor present in the examined lymph nodes (44 nodes total) and all surgical margins being free of tumor. The tumor is classified as pT4a, indicating advanced local disease, but there is no evidence of lymphatic or perineural invasion. Additionally, the report notes extensive caries in the extracted teeth, which were not subjected to microscopic examination.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal breast carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 3.4 cm, with a minimum dorsal margin of 0.1 cm. There is evidence of carcinomatous lymphangitis and two metastatic axillary lymph nodes out of 20 examined. Follow-up resection samples were free of carcinoma, and the tumor classification is M-8500/3, G 3, pT 3, pN la (2/20), M X, R 0, L 1, V0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver, characterized by a large multinodular mass measuring 8.8 x 7.5 x 6.8 cm, with close proximity to the surgical resection margin. The tumor exhibits poor differentiation (Grade IV) and shows evidence of capsular infiltration and vascular invasion, but no serosal or bile duct invasion. Additionally, there is direct tumor extension into the gallbladder, while the lymph node biopsy shows no evidence of tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with extensive invasion into surrounding structures including the uterus, cervix, and ureters, as well as significant perineural and lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, a high-grade serous carcinoma of Mllerian origin was identified, primarily affecting the right fallopian tube and involving multiple lymph nodes. Surgical margins were free of tumor, but metastatic disease was found in one lymph node from the right pelvic dissection and two from the left pelvic dissection.

The pathology report indicates that the left frontal brain tumor biopsy reveals a diagnosis of gliosarcoma (WHO Grade IV), characterized by a pleomorphic epithelioid neoplasm with prominent nucleoli and areas of necrosis. The tumor exhibits a Ki-67 labeling index of 30 to 40% and is diffusely positive for p53, with immunohistochemical staining showing positivity for GFAP, vimentin, and S100. Additionally, methylation testing of the MGMT promoter is positive, suggesting potential benefit from therapy with alkylating agents.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the esophagogastric junction, measuring 2.2 cm, which invades the submucosa and is associated with Barrett's mucosa, but shows no angiolymphatic invasion and all surgical margins are uninvolved. Additionally, multiple lymph node biopsies from various locations, including the paraesophageal region and perigastric area, were negative for carcinoma, with a total of 39 lymph nodes examined and none involved. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT1b N0, indicating early-stage cancer with no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated primary cervical adenosquamous carcinoma, measuring 5.0 cm in diameter with a depth of stromal invasion of 13.0 mm, classified as pT1b2 NO Mx. There are foci of adenocarcinoma in situ adjacent to the invasive carcinoma, with evidence of lymphovascular space invasion, but no vaginal or uterine corpus extension, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, no malignancy was identified in the left and right ovaries, fallopian tubes, or multiple lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 12 x 7 x 2 cm, with ulceration and involvement of adjacent structures, specifically the lesser and greater omentum. Out of 19 examined lymph nodes, 2 showed evidence of metastasis. Details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion, as well as margins and neo-adjuvant treatment, were not specified.

The pathology report indicates multiple findings, including a diagnosis of fibrous adhesion in the omental adhesion and chronic inflammation with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the hernia sac and omental specimens. The left and right fallopian tubes and ovaries show atrophic changes, chronic salpingitis, and reactive changes, while the uterus reveals a high-grade adenosquamous carcinoma with myometrial invasion of less than 50%. Lymph node examinations show extensive fibrosis and calcifications, but no evidence of metastatic carcinoma was found in any of the lymph nodes sampled.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, conventional type, located in the left lobe of the thyroid, measuring 1.9 cm, with extrathyroidal extension into soft tissue but no lymphovascular invasion. The resection margins are negative, and no tumor was found in the examined lymph node (0/1). Additionally, the left inferior parathyroid tissue was identified with no tumor present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of encapsulated follicular variant papillary thyroid carcinoma, measuring 3.6 cm, located in the left lobe of the thyroid, with no evidence of tumor capsule invasion, angiolymphatic invasion, or extrathyroidal extension. The resection margins are free of tumor, and one perithyroidal lymph node examined was also free of tumor, resulting in a pathologic stage of pT2 N0. Additionally, a BRAF V600E mutation was identified, which is associated with more aggressive behavior in papillary thyroid carcinoma, while no other significant mutations were detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of tubulopapillary and partially mucinous adenocarcinoma (G3) of the colon, specifically located in the caecum. The tumor shows infiltration into the muscularis propria with a minimum side margin of 0.6 cm, and the excision lines are free of neoplastic lesions. Additionally, there are small polyps identified, including a minor dysplastic adenoma and a hyperplastic polyp.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma in a lung specimen obtained from a pulmonectomy, with a tumor size of 10 x 10 x 8 cm. The tumor extends to the visceral pleura, and all four examined lymph nodes show evidence of metastasis. Additional details regarding histologic grade, lymphatic and venous invasion, margins, and neo-adjuvant treatment are not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, with a largest tumor size of 4.5 cm and multifocality, including two additional type 1 tumors and ten tubulo-papillary adenomas. The tumor is confined to the renal parenchyma, with a Fuhrman grade of 3 out of 4, and shows no evidence of invasion into perinephric fat, renal sinus, or renal vein. Additionally, chronic pyelonephritis and patchy interstitial fibrosis were noted in the nonneoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive conventional clear cell carcinoma, Fuhrman grade 3, in the right kidney, with tumor invasion into the renal vein. Initially, there was concern about tumor presence at the renal vein margin, but further discussion concluded that the margin is negative for tumor. The adrenal gland is reported as benign and uninvolved by tumor, with no regional lymph nodes identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear) cell type with sarcomatoid features and large rhabdoid-type cells exhibiting bizarre atypia, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 4. The tumor measures 10.5 cm, extends through the renal capsule with multiple satellite nodules, and shows angiolymphatic invasion, but all surgical margins are free of neoplasm and there is no renal vein invasion. The tumor is staged as pT3 NX MX, and the non-neoplastic kidney is unremarkable, with unusual histological findings noted in the comment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of biphasic synovial sarcoma located in the left flank, measuring 7.1 cm, involving both soft tissue and skeletal muscle, with no apparent tumor necrosis. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and the tumor exhibits an immunostaining pattern consistent with synovial sarcoma. Molecular studies for the SYT-SSX fusion transcript associated with the tumor will be performed and reported separately.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma involving the left buccal mucosa, mandible, and skin, with a tumor mass measuring 6.6 cm and all surgical margins free of tumor. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was found in 2 of 5 lymph nodes at level 2, 2 of 11 lymph nodes at level 3, and 3 of 4 lymph nodes at level 1a, while level 4 and right level 1b lymph nodes were negative for metastasis. Special immunoperoxidase stains for p16 were negative, suggesting no association with HPV.

The pathology report confirms the presence of parathyroid tissue without tumor and identifies a 3.5 cm papillary carcinoma of the thyroid in the left lobe, which is confined to the thyroid with free resection margins. Additionally, three lymph nodes associated with the isthmus show metastatic carcinoma, while the right lobe of the thyroid contains an adenomatoid nodule and a ruptured sebaceous cyst is noted in the right neck. Chronic inflammation is observed in the isthmus, and further immunoperoxidase studies were performed on the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade renal cell carcinoma, unclassified type, with a tumor size of 4.2 cm and local invasion into the renal sinus fat, but no renal vein invasion identified. The biopsies from the mesentery and Gerota's fascia revealed benign fibrofatty tissue, while three out of eight examined lymph nodes showed metastatic deposits, with the largest measuring 1 cm. The tumor is staged as pT3, indicating it extends into major veins or invades surrounding tissues but remains confined within Gerota's fascia.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the fundus of the stomach, measuring 5 x 4 x 1.5 cm. The tumor has metastasized to 7 out of 15 examined lymph nodes, with adjacent involvement of the greater omentum, but the surgical margins are uninvolved. There is no specified evidence of lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion, and no additional pathologic findings or comments are provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, from a partial nephrectomy of the left lower pole kidney. The tumor measures 1.5 cm in greatest diameter, extends through the renal capsule but is confined within Gerota's fascia, and shows a Fuhrman nuclear grade of II/IV, with no renal vein invasion identified and surgical margins free of tumor. The staging is classified as pT1, indicating the tumor is limited to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Testicular Seminoma, characterized by a tumor measuring 8.5 x 7.5 cm that extensively involves the testicle. Histological examination reveals solid tumor areas with round and oval cells, notable for their bright nuclei and moderate cytoplasm, along with a lymphocyte infiltrate in the surrounding connective tissue. The tumor shows evidence of vascular involvement but does not infiltrate the testicular capsule or the plane of resection at the funiculus.

The pathology report indicates that a left orchidectomy was performed, revealing a seminoma with a diameter of 4 cm. The tumor is confined to the testis in the available slides, with evidence of angio-invasion but no invasion into the rete testis. Overall, the findings suggest a localized seminoma with some vascular involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the right thyroid, follicular variant, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm that infiltrates surrounding soft tissue and involves both anterior and posterior margins. Additionally, four out of six lymph nodes examined showed metastatic papillary carcinoma, while lymph nodes from levels II, III, and V were free of tumor. The total thyroidectomy specimen and associated lymph nodes were submitted for analysis, confirming the presence of malignancy in specific nodes while others remained tumor-free.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed subtype adenocarcinoma in the left lung, specifically in the lower lobe, measuring 2.0 x 2.0 x 2.5 cm. The tumor shows infiltration of the visceral pleura and evidence of lymphangiosis carcinomatosa. Staging reveals pT2, pN2 (21/33 lymph nodes involved), pM1 (metastasis to the pericardium), and a grade of G3.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma in the right temporal lobe, characterized by extensive infiltration and necrosis, with a MIB-1 proliferation index of 22%. The tumor exhibits anaplastic features, including nuclear atypia and mitotic activity, and shows a predominantly astrocytic phenotype with possible oligodendroglial components. Additionally, molecular testing revealed a negative MGMT promoter methylation status and no allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, suggesting a high-grade glioma without typical oligodendroglioma characteristics.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma, grade 2, in the left lung, measuring 12 cm, with extension into perihilar mediastinal fibroadipose tissue and lymphatic permeation. Three out of eight perihilar lymph nodes and three out of fourteen subcarinal lymph nodes show metastatic tumor involvement, while resection margins are free of tumor. The overall staging is T4N2PL3, indicating advanced disease with significant lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that two regional lymph nodes were biopsied and found to be negative for tumor. A nephrectomy of the right kidney revealed a 5.7 cm clear cell renal cell carcinoma, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade II, which is confined to the kidney with negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, the non-neoplastic renal parenchyma shows changes consistent with early diabetic nephropathy, including diffuse mesangial expansion and severe vascular scarring.

The pathology report indicates a final diagnosis of an infiltrating glioma in the left parietal occipital region, consistent with the patient's previously biopsied anaplastic astrocytoma. The specimens submitted for analysis included multiple segments of soft tissue, with one specimen measuring 0.5 x 0.3 x 0.1 cm and another measuring 3.5 x 2.3 x 1.0 cm. Histopathological examination confirmed the presence of an infiltrating glioma.

The pathology report indicates that a right partial nephrectomy specimen weighing 16 grams contains a well-circumscribed clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 3.1 cm, which is unifocal and limited to the kidney. The tumor is 2 mm from the parenchymal resection margin, with no evidence of venous or adrenal involvement, and the adjacent kidney parenchyma shows no significant abnormalities. The final diagnosis is clear cell renal cell carcinoma, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 1, with a pTNM stage of pT1a NX.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma involving the head of the pancreas and the wall of the duodenum, with tumor size measuring 3.8 cm. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in one lymph node associated with the superior mesenteric artery, and invasive adenocarcinoma was also present in the portal vein resection. Additionally, benign fatty tissue with focal hemorrhage was noted in the omentum, and two benign reactive lymph nodes were identified in the node of importance.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of solitary hepatocellular carcinoma confined to segment 7 of the liver, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and a histologic grade of 1/4. There is no evidence of lymph-vascular invasion or satellite lesions, and the tumor is classified as pT1, with cirrhosis and hepatitis present at a grade of 2/4. The tumor extends to 0.7 cm from the resection margin, and the UNOS HCC stage is determined to be stage 2.

The pathology report indicates that multiple excised tissues and lymph nodes from the right neck and pharynx were examined, with no malignancy detected in the majority of samples, including two lymph nodes from level II, the right pharyngeal superior margin, the right inferior constrictor margin, and the right submandibular gland. However, a synovial sarcoma was identified in the right pharynx, characterized by a monophasic pattern and graded as FNCLCC Grade 3 based on differentiation, mitotic activity, and necrosis scores. Overall, the findings suggest a localized malignancy in the pharynx while the surrounding lymph nodes and other excised tissues were negative for cancer.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of high-grade monophasic synovial sarcoma in the right popliteal space, with a tumor size of 7.1 x 6.9 x 5.3 cm and areas of necrosis estimated at 20%. All surgical margins (proximal, distal, medial, lateral, and deep) were reported as benign, indicating no tumor presence at these sites. A benign lymph node was also identified, and the findings are consistent with the initial cytology diagnosis of sarcoma.

The pathology report indicates that one of the four excised sentinel lymph nodes is involved by metastatic carcinoma, while the other three are negative for carcinoma. The right breast lumpectomy reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma, grade III, measuring 2.0 cm, with negative surgical margins and evidence of blood vessel and lymphatic invasion. Immunohistochemical studies show the tumor is negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors, and non-amplified for Her2/neu, with a pTNM classification of pT1c, N1(sn), MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma, a type of soft tissue sarcoma, from a resected left retroperitoneal mass measuring approximately 9.2 cm. The tumor is classified as Grade II according to the FNCLCC grading system, with 40-50% necrosis observed. Pathological staging shows T2, with no evidence of regional lymph node involvement (N) and no distant metastasis (M0).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in the left retroperitoneum, with the tumor measuring 4 x 3.1 x 2.8 cm and showing focal areas of necrosis. The tumor is located very close to the inked margin of resection, at a distance of 0.1 cm. A mitotic count revealed up to 11 mitotic figures per 10 high power fields, consistent with the diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma.

The histopathology report indicates the presence of a large B-cell lymphoma with both diffuse and follicular components, classified as WHO Grade 3A, in a right thyroid mass. The lymphoma exhibits a patternless infiltrate of medium-to-large cells, with significant immunoreactivity for CD20 and CD10, and a proliferation fraction of approximately 70-80% as indicated by Ki-67 labeling. Additional findings include atrophic thyroid follicles and lymphocytic thyroiditis, while markers for Burkitt's lymphoma and mantle cell lymphoma are negative, ruling out those diagnoses.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive mucocellular and partially tubular adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as G3, with significant tumor invasion through the full thickness of the stomach wall and involvement of the peritoneum and omentum. Multiple lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma, with infiltration noted in several regional lymph nodes, including those associated with the lesser and greater curvature of the stomach and the spleen. The report confirms the presence of cancer metastases in the lymph nodes, indicating an advanced stage of the disease (pT2, pN3).

The pathology report indicates that the Level 10, Level 11, and Level 4 lymph nodes show benign hyperplasia, while the right upper lobe of the lung reveals a low-grade adenocarcinoma with mucinous and bronchoalveolar features, measuring 3.0 x 2.0 x 2.0 cm, and is confined to the lung without evidence of visceral pleural or lymphovascular invasion. There are no metastatic carcinoma cells found in any of the seven lymph nodes examined. The tumor is classified as pT1,NO, with a surgical margin distance of 2.5 cm from the bronchial and parenchymal margins, and less than 0.1 cm from the pleural surface.

The pathology report indicates that the distal pancreas specimen shows invasive poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma with perineural invasion and a positive radial resection margin, while the proximal and distal resection margins are uninvolved. Additionally, eight peripancreatic lymph nodes were negative for malignancy, and there is evidence of high-grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN). The gallbladder specimen reveals cholelithiasis and chronic cholecystitis, but is negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type with prominent sarcomatoid features, classified as Fuhrman Nuclear Grade IV and measuring 7.6 cm in greatest diameter. The tumor is staged as pT2, indicating it is greater than 7.0 cm but confined to the kidney, with no evidence of local invasion or renal vein involvement, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the excised para-aortic lymph nodes showed no involvement, with all four examined nodes being negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated large cell squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with significant infiltration into surrounding tissues and pleura, classified as pT4 pNO V1 RO, equivalent to stage IIIB. A smaller satellite tumor was also identified in the same lobe, while the resected pleura and surrounding soft tissue were free of tumor infiltration. Additionally, an intramuscular lipoma was noted, which showed no signs of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma multiforme in the right temporal lobe, characterized by pleomorphic neoplastic cells, high mitotic activity, and a proliferation index of 65%. There is evidence of necrosis and microvascular proliferation, with a suggestion of an oligodendroglial component. Additionally, tests for the EGFRvIII mutation and MGMT promoter methylation were negative, indicating no specific molecular alterations that could influence treatment options.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma located in the lower uterine segment, with a tumor size of 4.4 x 3.8 cm and a depth of myometrial invasion noted. Additionally, there is a 2.5 x 2.1 x 1 cm tumor implant in the cervix that penetrates 9 mm into the cervical wall. All examined lymph nodes and other structures, including the ovaries and fallopian tubes, are free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in both the right upper lobe and right lower lobe of the lung, with the tumors measuring 2.1 cm and 6.6 cm in greatest diameter, respectively. The lymph node examinations revealed multiple benign anthracotic lymph nodes, with no evidence of metastatic disease in the examined nodes. Additionally, the report notes that the mainstem bronchus is involved by in situ carcinoma, but the surgical margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of lung cancer, specifically a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the right upper lobe, measuring 4.0 cm, with invasion into the visceral pleura but not through it. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, revealing anthracosilicosis and mild reactive changes, with no metastatic carcinoma identified in any of the lymph nodes. The tumor is staged as pT2a N0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade oligodendroglioma (WHO grade II) from biopsies of a right frontal brain mass. The tumor exhibits focal high cellularity and increased proliferative activity, with mitotic figures and a Ki-67 labeling index suggesting early progression, although these findings do not warrant a grade III classification. Multiple brain mass specimens were received and processed for further evaluation, with preliminary interpretations indicating glioma.

The pathology report indicates that the descending colon specimen contains an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (pT3) that has invaded through the muscularis propria into pericolonic fat, with negative margins and no lymph node metastasis. However, the liver biopsy reveals metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with a colonic primary tumor. Overall, the findings suggest localized colon cancer with metastasis to the liver.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary carcinoma in both lobes of the thyroid, with the right lobe showing a papillary microcarcinoma measuring 0.1 cm and the left lobe containing three foci of papillary carcinoma, including one classical type (1.5 cm), one follicular variant (1.2 cm), and one microcarcinoma (<0.1 cm). All tumors are well differentiated, with no identified mitotic activity, necrosis, blood vessel invasion, or extrathyroid extension, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, both lobes exhibit nodular hyperplasia, and there is focal capsular invasion noted in the classical type from the left lobe.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, classified as FIGO grade 1 (well differentiated), with a tumor size of 4.5 x 4 cm and a depth of invasion of 1.3 cm into the myometrium. The cervix is positive for invasive carcinoma, while the remaining endometrium shows endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN), and all specimen margins are free of tumor. There is no evidence of malignancy in the right ovary and fallopian tubes, but the left ovary is absent, and the right ovary shows adhesions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in a right cervical lymph node excision. Microscopic examination reveals a fragmented lymph node with a proliferation of large lymphomatous cells, which are positive for CD20 and exhibit an activated B-cell phenotype, while excluding other types of lymphoma such as Burkitt and mantle cell lymphoma. The Ki-67 labeling shows a proliferation fraction of approximately 70-80%, and there is no evidence of terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase positivity, further supporting the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the distal esophagus, measuring 7.0 cm, with invasion into the periadventitial tissue but no regional lymph node metastasis (0/26 lymph nodes examined). Both the final esophageal and gastric margins are negative for malignancy, with the closest invasive carcinoma margin being 1.0 mm from the adventitial margin. Additionally, chronic inactive gastritis was noted, but there was no evidence of H. pylori infection or other lesions in the noncancerous esophagus or stomach.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral, multifocal prostate adenocarcinoma following a radical prostatectomy, with the index tumor located in the left mid/base and exhibiting a Gleason score of 4+5=9. There is evidence of extraprostatic extension at the left base (up to 7 mm), right apex (5 mm), and left apex (1 mm), with positive pathological margins noted at the right apex (2 mm) and left apex (0.5 mm). Additionally, separate multifocal transition zone adenocarcinoma is present, with Gleason scores of 3+4(40%)=7, 3+4(5%)=7, and 3+3=6, while no lymphovascular invasion is identified and seminal vesicles are clear.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 6.2 cm in the right upper lobe, which penetrates the visceral pleura but has free margins and no regional lymph node metastasis (0/4 lymph nodes). Additional biopsies of various lymph nodes and lung parenchyma show no malignancy, with findings of bronchioloalveolar hyperplasia in some lung samples. The overall pathologic staging is pT2, NO, MX, indicating a tumor greater than 3 cm with no evidence of regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph node biopsy from the left breast shows no metastasis in the examined lymph nodes. The left breast lumpectomy reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 2, measuring 1.5 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of vascular invasion. Additional findings include positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, negative HER2 status, and the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ comprising less than 20% of the tumor.

The amended pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, specifically favoring type 2 papillary carcinoma with oncocytic features, measuring 2.9 cm. The neoplasm is limited to the kidney with no definitive extracapsular extension, but it is present focally at the resection margins. Additionally, there is a microscopic detached fragment of carcinoma in the overlying fat, and clinical follow-up is recommended due to the involvement of the margins.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a mucinous adenocarcinoma in the stomach, classified as T2b and Borrmann type I, which is characterized by a protruded, polypoid, exophytic configuration. Multiple nodules of the tumor are observed within the perigastric fat, with lymph node involvement classified as N3 and no distant metastasis (M0). The tumor was resected, and the histological grade is noted as Il.

The pathology report indicates a resected section of the rectum containing a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that has infiltrated the perimuscular fatty tissue. The tumor-free oral and aboral resection margins suggest complete removal of the primary tumor. Additionally, there is a solitary regional lymph node metastasis, classified as G2, pT3, with a locally R0 and pN1 staging.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, measuring 27 mm, with pleural invasion but clear margins from the bronchial resection. Metastatic carcinoma is identified in the hilar lymph nodes, while the No. 10 lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy. Additionally, the non-neoplastic lung exhibits emphysema and fibrosis with a usual interstitial pneumonia-like pattern.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade I endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor measuring 4.8 x 3.5 x 1.8 cm that invades 0.4 cm into the myometrium and is associated with complex hyperplasia with atypia. The tumor is confined to the uterus and does not involve the endocervix or lymphovascular spaces, with negative margins and no involvement of the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes. Additionally, multiple pelvic lymph nodes excised from both sides are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent excision of the right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes, revealing small benign cysts and corpora albicantia, with no definitive fallopian tubes identified. A hysterectomy was performed, and the diagnosis confirmed endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, grade 2, measuring 5.5 x 5.0 x 4.5 cm, with focal myometrial invasion but no cervical involvement or lymphovascular invasion. All excised lymph nodes from various regions were negative for metastatic disease, and the surgical margins were uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma of the right ovary with extensive necrosis and paratubal tumor deposits in the fallopian tube. Additionally, there are findings of chronic cystic cervicitis, serosal adhesions with metastatic adenocarcinoma in the uterus and left adnexa, and metastatic papillary serous adenocarcinoma on the surface of the left ovary. Metastatic adenocarcinoma is also present in the sigmoid biopsy and omentum, while the appendix appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that all sentinel lymph nodes (1-5) from the right axilla are negative for tumor involvement. In the right breast, two foci of invasive ductal carcinoma were identified, with the larger focus measuring 2.2 x 1.9 x 1.5 cm and classified as SBR grade III, alongside ductal carcinoma in situ with high nuclear grade. Additional tissue samples from the right breast were found to be benign adipose tissue, and the surgical margins were negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right upper lobectomy, revealing poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.7 cm, with one of four examined peribronchial/hilar lymph nodes positive for carcinoma by direct extension. The remaining lymph nodes from stations 10, 11, 4, and 7 were negative for carcinoma. The tumor was staged as pT2a with lymphovascular invasion present, but all surgical margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a right insular tumor diagnosed as an astrocytoma with mitotic activity, characterized by moderately pleomorphic fibrillary astrocytes and rare mitotic figures in both specimens. The proliferation index, determined by Ki67 staining, is greater than 5% in small foci, suggesting the tumor may be a WHO grade II astrocytoma undergoing transformation to a higher grade. Clinical correlation is recommended due to the atypical features observed, and the report emphasizes that no high-grade features were identified on the frozen section.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, classified as Stage IB2, with a tumor size of 4.7 x 2.5 cm and evidence of lymphatic/vascular invasion. The excised parametrial soft tissue showed no evidence of carcinoma, and all examined lymph nodes (22 total) were negative for metastatic disease. Additionally, severe squamous dysplasia (VAIN-3) was present at the margin of resection in the vaginal mucosa, but there was no invasive carcinoma involvement in the uterus or parametria.

The pathology report indicates extensive involvement of the omentum by high-grade serous carcinoma, likely originating from the peritoneum, ovaries, fallopian tubes, or endometrium. Additionally, washings from the specimen tested positive for malignant cells. The omental tissue weighed 158 g and displayed multiple solid areas, with the largest measuring up to 7 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of extensive infiltration of high-grade papillary serous adenocarcinoma originating from the ovaries, with significant involvement of the omentum and serosal surfaces of the uterus. Both ovaries are affected, with lymphovascular space invasion noted, while the right fallopian tube remains uninvolved. Additional findings include a negative cervix and endometrial polyp, with the tumor classified as pTNM stage T2c.

The pathology report describes a right lower lobe lobectomy specimen containing a 48 mm poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, which is located 15 mm from the bronchial resection margin and shows possible invasion into the visceral pleura. There is no evidence of blood vessel, lymphatic, or perineural invasion, and no lymph node metastases are present, classifying the tumor as T2N0. The adjacent non-neoplastic lung tissue appears normal with minor emphysema and carbon dust deposition.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated gastric adenocarcinoma with extensive lymphovascular invasion, showing that the tumor has infiltrated the full thickness of the stomach wall and is narrowly excised at the proximal margin. There are at least 55 metastatic deposits identified in regional lymph nodes, while the right hemicolectomy specimen appears normal. A peritoneal biopsy shows no tumor presence, and the overall staging is classified as AJCC Stage IV (T2, N3, MX).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with a tumor measuring 3.0 cm and a Nottingham grade of 3, along with one positive sentinel lymph node showing metastatic carcinoma with extracasular extension. The left breast biopsy revealed ductal epithelial hyperplasia, while the surgical margins from the modified radical mastectomy were free of invasive carcinoma. Additionally, the tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, and HER2/NEU status is 2+.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the resected sigma colon, with infiltration into the perimuscular adipose tissue and several lymph node metastases. Additionally, there are findings of a hyperplastic polyp and several tubular adenomas with mild to moderate dysplasia. The resection margins are tumor-free, suggesting complete removal of the primary tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of type I papillary renal cell carcinoma, Grade 3, with a tumor size of 5.7 cm and unifocality. There is no evidence of capsular invasion or involvement of surrounding tissues, and all surgical margins are negative. The AJCC staging is pT1b, pNx, and additional findings include glomerulosclerosis and chronic interstitial inflammation in the non-neoplastic kidney.

The pathology report indicates that all excised lymph nodes from levels 5, 7, and 9L show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, confirming the frozen section diagnoses. The left lung pneumonectomy reveals a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, measuring 4.5 cm, with visceral pleural invasion and lymphovascular space invasion, but the tumor is confined to the lung. Additionally, one of the six lymph nodes examined contains metastatic carcinoma with extracapsular extension, and the tumor is staged as pT2aN1MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a right parietal brain tumor classified as an oligodendroglioma, grade II. Microscopic evaluation shows a diffusely infiltrating glioma with mild to moderate cytologic atypia, but no mitotic figures, necrosis, or microvascular proliferation are observed. The histologic features are consistent with a low-grade oligoastrocytoma, and a final diagnosis will be confirmed after reviewing special stains.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two distinct lesions in the right adrenal gland: an adrenal cortical adenoma measuring 1.8 cm and a paraganglioma measuring 2.2 cm located in the adjacent adipose tissue. Histological examination reveals the adrenal adenoma is composed of clear cells resembling zona fasciculata cells, with no signs of malignancy, while the paraganglioma shows nests of bland cells with positive immunostaining for Synaptophysin and Chromogranin. Both lesions exhibit no evidence of increased mitoses, necrosis, or invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right hemiglossectomy specimen, with the tumor invading to a depth of 3 cm and extending to the inked deep margin, while the posterior margin is clear. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma is identified in one of three lymph nodes at Level 1a, one of nine lymph nodes at Level 2a, and one of nine lymph nodes at Level 3, with the largest metastatic tumor measuring approximately 0.5 cm. The overall AJCC pathologic stage is classified as T2, N2.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right axillary sentinel lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma identified in one of two lymph nodes, while the second lymph node and additional sentinel lymph nodes show no tumor. The right breast partial mastectomy reveals an invasive micropapillary carcinoma measuring 2.1 cm, along with atypical lobular hyperplasia and a fibroadenoma, with negative resection margins and no lymphatic or perineural invasion. Immunohistochemical tests show positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2/neu testing is negative, and the overall staging is pT2N1aMX.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast mastectomy revealed moderately-differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with a Nottingham score of 7 and no lymphovascular invasion, while margins were negative. The sentinel lymph nodes excised were all negative for malignancy, confirming no spread of cancer. The right breast mastectomy showed mild fibrocystic changes without any discrete masses or lymph nodes identified.

The pathology report indicates that a right radical nephrectomy specimen was received, revealing a unifocal chromophobe renal cell carcinoma measuring 13.8 x 11.7 x 9.1 cm, confined to the kidney without lymphovascular invasion. The tumor exhibits a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4/4, with areas of necrosis but free surgical margins. Additional immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, and clinical correlation is recommended.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma from a biopsy of a supraglottic lesion. The specimen consisted of three portions of soft, pink, and hemorrhagic mucosa measuring a total of 9.0 x 6.0 x 4.0 mm. A frozen section analysis confirmed the presence of squamous cell carcinoma in the submitted tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pleomorphic lobular carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 10.0 x 10.0 x 7.2 cm, with a Bloom-Richardson grade of II and evidence of lymphovascular invasion. A total of 12 lymph nodes were examined, with 3 nodes showing metastatic carcinoma and the presence of extracapsular extension. The surgical margins are clear of tumor by 2.5 cm, and the pTNM stage is classified as pT3 N2.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast prophylactic mastectomy revealed atypical ductal hyperplasia and other benign changes, with no carcinoma identified. In the left breast, invasive lobular carcinoma, grade 1, was diagnosed with a tumor size of 50 mm, and one of three axillary lymph nodes showed micrometastasis, resulting in a pathologic stage of IIB. All surgical margins were negative, and the tumor was positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors while negative for HER2/neu.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO stage 1C serous adenocarcinoma of the uterus, with a tumor size of 6 x 5.5 x 2 cm and evidence of lymphatic and vascular invasion. The remaining specimens, including the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and pelvic lymph nodes, showed no pathological findings or tumor presence. The report notes the presence of a calcified leiomyoma and adenomyosis in the myometrium, with negative margins and no tumor involvement in the cervix or serosa.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 1 endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor measuring 2.2 x 1.9 x 0.5 cm located on the posterior uterine wall, invading 0.4 cm into the myometrium, but not involving the endocervix or showing lymphovascular invasion. The right ovary is unremarkable with a paratubal cyst, while the left ovary and fallopian tube are also unremarkable, although there are hemorrhagic adhesions suggestive of endometriosis. Overall, the surgical margins are negative for tumor, and the findings are based on gross and microscopic examination of the specimens.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma in multiple specimens, including the omentum, transverse colon, right adnexa, small bowel, pelvic peritoneal mass, sigmoid and left adnexa, rectal mass, bladder, cul-de-sac mass, and spleen. The tumor shows extensive involvement of the adnexa and omentum, with focal invasion into the bowel muscularis propria and submucosa, as well as lymphovascular invasion. Clinical data suggest a significant tumor burden, with a CA125 level of 5000 and a history of ascites and pelvic mass.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of predominantly poorly differentiated bilateral multifocal adenocarcinoma of the prostate, classified as Gleason 4+3=7, with a maximum tumor diameter of 1.6 cm and evidence of infiltration into periprostatic fatty tissue. Surgical margins are tumor-free, and lymph node assessments show no evidence of metastasis in the sampled nodes. Additional findings include high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and myoglandular prostatic hyperplasia, with the tumor classified as pT3a, pNO (0/5), and R0, indicating complete excision.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a pigmented malignant melanoma located on the facial skin, measuring 1.5 x 1 x 2 cm with a Breslow thickness of 4 mm. There are satellite nodules present, but there is no evidence of venous invasion and the margins are uninvolved. Lymphatic invasion and lymph node involvement were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon, which invades through the full thickness of the bowel wall and into surrounding adipose tissue. The tumor is located 11 cm proximal to the distal margin, with negative margins and no vascular invasion identified. Additionally, there is a tumor deposit in the pericolonic fat, with twenty-one lymph nodes examined being negative for malignancy, classified as pN1c.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma involving both the right and left ovaries, with extensive lymphovascular space invasion and metastasis to multiple lymph nodes and other sites, including the rectosigmoid colon and omentum. Additionally, a benign Brenner tumor was identified in the right ovary, and the uterus showed high-grade serous carcinoma involvement in the myometrium and lymphovascular spaces, while the endometrium was atrophic with no evidence of malignancy. The overall staging is classified as T3/N1/MX, indicating significant disease spread beyond the pelvis with multiple metastatic sites.

The pathology report indicates that no metastatic carcinoma was found in the left para-aortic lymph nodes, both in the biopsy (0/1) and removal (0/6) samples. A left renal mass was identified as an eosinophilic variant of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, classified as grade 1, with a size of 6.0 cm and no evidence of extra-capsular invasion or lymphatic/venous involvement. The surgical margins were negative, and the tumor is staged as pT1b pNO, pending further clinical review.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph node biopsy is negative for malignancy, while the left breast excisional biopsy reveals invasive lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade 2, with negative margins. Additionally, lobular carcinoma in situ is present in the posterior lateral margin biopsy, but there is no evidence of invasive carcinoma. The tumor measures 1.7 cm, and there is no vessel invasion or calcification noted.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of endometrial cancer, specifically grade III endometrioid carcinoma, with extensive myometrial invasion and involvement of the cervix, but no other organ involvement or lymphovascular invasion. A total of 25 lymph nodes were examined, all showing reactive hyperplasia and negative for malignancy. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there are no signs of metastatic carcinoma in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the prostate following a radical prostatectomy, with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4) and approximately 5% of the gland volume affected by the tumor. There is no evidence of extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, lymphovascular invasion, or metastatic carcinoma in the examined lymph nodes. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and the pTNM stage is classified as pT2c N0.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant melanoma of the skin, characterized by superficial ulceration and a Breslow thickness of 10 mm. The tumor measures 5.5 x 1.5 cm and shows pigmented features, with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. Additionally, a second skin fragment reveals superficial melanoma of the malignant lentigo type.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason grade of 3+4 (total score of 7), involving 16% of the examined prostate tissue, with tumor presence in both the right and left lobes, apex, base, and right seminal vesicle. Microscopic examination reveals invasion into periprostatic adipose tissue and perineural invasion, but the resection margins are clear of tumor, and no definitive vascular or lymphatic invasion is identified. Additionally, one lymph node was examined and found to be negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, characterized by a subpleural mass measuring 3.0 x 2.0 x 1.4 cm that involves the visceral pleura but has a negative bronchial resection margin. Metastatic disease is present in two out of two left subaortic lymph nodes and in three out of ten intraparenchymal peribronchial lymph nodes, with evidence of extranodal extension. No tumor is found in multiple other lymph nodes examined, including those in the left subcarinal, left pulmonary ligament, and left hilar regions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of unifocal papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, with the tumor measuring 5.0 cm and exhibiting extrathyroidal extension. One out of four lymph nodes examined was positive for carcinoma, and the tumor is classified as pT3 and pN1a according to the AJCC staging system. Additionally, the tumor extends close to the resection margins, with less than 1.0 mm distance from invasive carcinoma to the nearest margin, and multifocal intrathyroidal psammoma bodies are noted, along with lymphocytic thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates that multiple biopsies from the buccal and soft tissue margins, as well as the nasal septum and pterygoid, show no evidence of tumor. However, a maxillectomy specimen reveals an invasive, well-differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring approximately 3.2 cm, with negative margins that are close to the tumor. Additionally, lymph node evaluations show no metastatic carcinoma in multiple nodes, with findings of benign reactive lymphoid hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma (G3) in the bladder, which has invaded the prostate and reached the perivesical fat, with surgical resection margins being clear. There is evidence of possible lymphovascular invasion, but no metastatic carcinoma was found in the examined lymph node. Additionally, a separate area of G2pTa transitional cell carcinoma and focal carcinoma in situ were noted in the bladder background.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a low-grade leiomyosarcoma in the proximal jejunum, characterized by a smooth muscle neoplasm measuring 2.7 cm, which invades the bowel wall and extends to the mucosal surface with minimal serosal involvement. The tumor exhibits a nodular and infiltrating growth pattern, with no necrosis or vascular invasion noted, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Immunohistochemical staining shows the tumor cells are positive for desmin and SMA, with a low estimated proliferative index of up to 10%.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph node biopsy revealed two negative lymph nodes (0/2), suggesting no lymphatic spread of cancer. The left breast excisional biopsy confirmed the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 3, measuring 3.0 cm, with close proximity to the medial and inferior margins (less than 1 mm). No vessel invasion or ductal carcinoma in situ was identified, and the overall grade of the tumor is 9/9, indicating a high level of aggressiveness.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma following a right hemihepatectomy, with a tumor size of 2.5x2.5x2.2 cm and a histologic grade of 3 for the worst differentiation and 2 for major differentiation. There is no evidence of satellite nodules, vascular invasion, or necrosis, and the surgical margins are clear with a safety margin of 0.8 cm. Additionally, cirrhosis is present but inactive, and there are mild findings of chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph nodes are negative for malignancy, while the left breast segmental mastectomy reveals an invasive mammary carcinoma of high histologic grade and high proliferative rate, measuring 4.2 cm. The carcinoma exhibits a circumscribed and expansile growth pattern, which may account for the absence of lymph node involvement, and the surgical margins are deemed adequate. Additionally, the posterior margin from the segmental mastectomy is negative for malignancy, with the closest margin being 1.5 mm.

The pathology report indicates a tumor in the left lower lobe of the lung measuring 3.3 x 3.2 x 2.9 cm, diagnosed as adenocarcinoma of mixed subtype, which includes partially papillary, micropapillary, acinar, and solid components. There is evidence of infiltration into the visceral pleura. The tumor is classified as pT2, with no regional lymph node involvement (0/11), and is graded as G3.

The pathology report indicates that the right kidney specimen shows renal cell carcinoma of the clear cell type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV, measuring 3 cm and extending through the renal capsule but confined within Gerota's fascia, with no invasion of the renal vein and all surgical margins free of tumor. The portion of the right 11th rib resection is reported as negative for tumor, with the specimen appearing grossly unremarkable. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue is also described as unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme in the left parietal lobe, characterized by a proliferation index of 20%, frequent mitosis, vascular hyperplasia, and significant areas of necrosis. Additionally, the MGMT promoter is found to be methylated, which may have implications for treatment options. The specimen consisted of multiple irregularly shaped tissue fragments, measuring 2.5 x 2.0 x 1.0 cm, fixed in formalin.

The pathology report indicates the presence of squamous cell carcinoma in the left tonsil, measuring 5.0 cm, with infiltration into adjacent salivary glands and skeletal muscle, and extensive involvement at surgical margins. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in four out of 35 dissected lymph nodes, with notable extracapsular extension in the level III and level IIA nodes. The submandibular gland and left lingual nerve showed no evidence of carcinoma, while atypical cells suspicious for carcinoma were found in the peristyloid tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma, grade 2, with invasion into the myometrium and involvement of endocervical glands, but no lymphovascular invasion was identified. The excised pannus and other examined tissues, including the right and left ovaries, fallopian tubes, and pelvic lymph nodes, showed no significant pathological changes or tumors. Overall, the findings suggest localized endometrial carcinoma without evidence of metastatic disease in the lymph nodes or other examined areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade renal cell carcinoma, unclassified type, with a tumor size of 9.2 cm that invades the renal pelvis and hilar fat, classified as pT3b due to extension into the renal vein. Multiple lymph nodes, particularly from the interaortocaval region, show matted positive metastatic carcinoma, while the right adrenal gland and some lymph nodes are negative for carcinoma. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the left adrenal tumor is diagnosed as adrenal cortical carcinoma, weighing 80g, with features including pleomorphic cells and a Weiss score of 4, indicating aggressive characteristics. Microscopic examination reveals areas of invasion into the extra-adrenal fat, although the bulk of the tumor is separated from the soft tissue resection margin by an intact capsule. Immunohistochemical analysis shows a high proliferative index and positive markers for calretinin, inhibin, and MelanA, while IGF2, S-100, and chromogranin are negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous papillary adenocarcinoma involving the uterus, bilateral fallopian tubes, and ovaries, with extensive infiltration into the uterine serosa and left ovary, as well as focal involvement of the right ovary and fallopian tube. Additional findings include infiltration of high-grade serous papillary carcinoma in the bladder peritoneum, omentum, cul-de-sac, sigmoid region, diaphragm, and left side wall, while two left pelvic lymph nodes were negative for tumor. The report also notes chronic cystic cervicitis and an endometrial polyp in the uterus, with the endometrium showing atrophic changes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the left and right ovaries, fallopian tubes, and uterus, with significant myometrial invasion and cervical involvement. Additionally, fibrous connective tissue biopsies from the left peritoneum and bladder show similar high-grade serous adenocarcinoma, suggesting metastatic disease from the uterine primary. A right hip subcutaneous mass was identified as cystic fat necrosis with calcification, with no tumor detected in that area.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe, measuring 8.0 cm, with associated visceral pleural and angiolymphatic invasion, but no lymph node involvement (N0). The surgical margins are free of invasive tumor, and there is mild emphysematous change noted in the lung tissue. Overall, the tumor is classified as pathologic stage T2N0MX, with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, both ovaries, and the uterus, with significant lymphovascular invasion and surface involvement noted. The tumors measured up to 11 cm and were associated with endometriosis, with the disease classified as FIGO stage IIIC. Additionally, the report highlights the presence of malignant cells in the mesoappendix and indicates a poorly differentiated tumor with marked cytologic atypia and a ruptured tumor capsule.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, tall cell variant, measuring 2.1 cm in the left lobe, with no extrathyroidal extension and negative margins. Molecular testing identified a BRAF V600E mutation, which is associated with more aggressive disease, while no mutations in NRAS, HRAS, KRAS, or RET/PTC rearrangements were found. Additionally, one out of four examined lymph nodes was positive for metastatic carcinoma, indicating regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.1 cm, with negative surgical resection margins and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Both sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla were negative for metastases. Estrogen and progesterone receptor tests showed positive results, with an Oncotype DX recurrence score of 22, suggesting a 14% risk of distant recurrence at 10 years.

The pathology report indicates that multiple margins from the right tonsil and medial tongue show no tumor presence, although chronic inflammation is noted in some areas. However, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma is identified in several lymph nodes, with a significant involvement in right level I, II, and III nodes, as well as in left level III nodes. The primary tumor, located on the ventral surface of the tongue, is classified as moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 3.3 cm, with lymphovascular and perineural invasion present, and margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with a nuclear grade of 1/IV, in the right kidney, measuring 5.5 cm and extending into the renal pelvis, but without invasion of the renal vein and with all surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, a paracaval nodule was excised, which contained benign lymph nodes, confirming no malignancy in that area. The non-neoplastic kidney showed a benign simple cortical cyst and an incidental angiomylipoma measuring 0.2 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, unclassified with papillary features, measuring 8.5 cm and exhibiting extensive local invasion, including renal vein invasion and involvement of periadrenal soft tissue. Biopsies of the caval wall and lymph nodes show detached atypical cells and significant metastatic involvement, with 8 out of 10 left perihilar lymph nodes and 13 out of 18 paraaortic lymph nodes being metastatic. The tumor is staged as pT3b, indicating gross extension into the renal vein or vena cava below the diaphragm, with surgical margins showing tumor presence at the renal vein margin.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right upper lobe lung mass diagnosed as non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) with poorly differentiated features and a maximum diameter of 3 cm, but no vascular or perineural invasion was identified. The excised lymph nodes from levels VII and XI were all benign, with no metastatic involvement. Additionally, the non-neoplastic lung tissue showed emphysematous changes and interstitial fibrosis, while the bronchial margin was free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the left sentinel lymph nodes are negative for malignancy, confirming they are benign. The left breast excision reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 3.3 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of vessel invasion or skin involvement. Additionally, there is a very focal presence of ductal carcinoma in situ, while the surrounding breast tissue shows fibrocystic changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV) with leptomeningeal invasion, characterized by high cellularity, brisk mitotic activity, and a MIB-1 proliferation index of 50%. Genetic testing revealed no evidence of methylated MGMT promoter and no EGFRVIII mutation detected, while partial deletions of chromosome arms 1p and 19q were noted. The tumor exhibits significant necrosis and microvascular proliferation, confirming its aggressive nature.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma, grade 3, in a 7.4 cm tumor from a partial hepatectomy of the liver segment 3, with negative margins and no capsule involvement. Lymphovascular space invasion is present, and the background liver shows steatosis affecting approximately 5% of the parenchyma. The AJCC pathologic stage is classified as pT2 pNx.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder specimen shows no significant pathologic abnormalities, while the liver specimen reveals a well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 8.0 x 7.2 x 5.8 cm, which is located 0.2 cm from the resection margin and shows no vascular invasion. The background liver exhibits moderate portal lymphocytic infiltration and bridging fibrosis consistent with chronic hepatitis B infection. Overall, the findings confirm the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma in the liver, alongside chronic hepatitis B changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated large cell carcinoma consistent with squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 2.3 cm in greatest diameter, with visceral pleural invasion noted but not penetrating it. The bronchial and vascular margins are clear of carcinoma, and there is evidence of reactive changes in the level 4 lymph nodes, with metastatic carcinoma identified. The tumor is staged as pT1bNO, and clinical correlation and follow-up are recommended.

The pathology report indicates that the liver biopsy shows features consistent with bile duct obstruction but no malignancy. The pancreatoduodenectomy reveals a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma of the pancreas with invasion into the duodenum and peripancreatic fat, but no carcinoma is found in the examined lymph nodes. Additionally, a gastrointestinal stromal tumor is identified in the small intestine, while the gallbladder shows no significant abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed subtype adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 10.0 x 8.0 x 7.0 cm, with infiltration into the visceral pleura. The tumor is classified as pT2, pN2 (10/35), pMx, and is graded as G3. Immunohistochemical analysis shows tumor cells positive for CK7, CK18, CEA, and partially positive for TTF1 and NSE, while negative for synaptophysin and CD56.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a 7 cm right medial frontal brain lesion diagnosed as an oligodendroglioma (WHO grade 2) with positive 1p and 19q codeletion, IDH1 mutation, and methylated MGMT promoter. Microscopic examination reveals slight to moderate infiltration by neoplastic glial cells, with a proliferation index of up to 6% in one center, suggesting low histological grade but potential for increased biological activity. Additionally, a cortical lesion was noted with hyperostotic lamellar bone, but the primary concern remains the brain tumor and its implications for treatment and follow-up.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous papillary adenocarcinoma, grade 3, in the omentum and separate tissue fragments from the pouch of Douglas, with focal lymphovascular invasion noted on the uterine serosal surface. Both ovaries are extensively involved with poorly differentiated papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma, grade 3, characterized by complex tubulopapillary glands and significant necrosis. The final diagnosis classifies the condition as FIGO stage III C ovarian cancer, with extensive surface involvement in both ovaries.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO Grade III, following the resection of a brain tumor from the right posterior frontal region. Histological examination reveals an infiltrating glioma characterized by significant nuclear pleomorphism, gemistocytic morphology, and a proliferation index of 10-15%, with evidence of mitotic activity. Immunohistochemical analysis shows strong positivity for GFAP and mutated IDH1, while P53 is reactive in over 50% of tumor cells, supporting the diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically of the papillary type, limited to the right kidney, with a tumor size of 2.5 cm and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2/4. There is no evidence of lymphatic invasion or tumor at the resection margins, and the TNM stage is classified as pT1a. Additionally, the report notes the presence of simple cortical cysts and advanced chronic changes in the renal parenchyma, likely related to early diabetic glomerulosclerosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 6.5 x 5.7 x 4.5 cm, with no visceral pleural or lymphovascular invasion identified. Surgical margins are clear, with the tumor located 2.5 cm from the bronchial margin and 0.3 cm from the pleural surface, and all examined lymph nodes (8 total) are negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, there is an area of central scarring within the tumor, and the pTNM stage is classified as pT2b, N0.

The pathology report indicates that a partial nephrectomy was performed on a female patient with a left renal lesion, revealing a 1.8 cm papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 1, confined to the kidney with no necrosis or sarcomatoid features. The tumor is classified as pT1a, with negative margins and no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or distant metastasis. Additional findings include peritumoral chronic inflammation and no other tumors or tumor-like lesions present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4, involving approximately 15% of the prostate and confined within the prostatic capsule. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or seminal vesicle involvement, but perineural invasion and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia are noted. The AJCC staging is pT2c, and the surgical margins are uninvolved by tumor.

The pathology report describes a 4x4x1 cm ulcerated mass in the left heel skin, diagnosed as poorly differentiated malignant melanoma. Microscopic examination reveals necrotic and hyperplastic epidermis with spindle or oval tumor cells containing melanin, and evidence of invasion into the dermis or fat tissue. Additionally, one out of two examined left inguinal lymph nodes shows metastasis, with a Breslow tumor thickness of 8 mm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous carcinoma of the endometrium, with a tumor size of 7.5 cm and myometrial invasion less than half of the myometrium. There is evidence of stromal invasion in the inner third of the cervix, but no cervical mucosal involvement or lymphovascular space invasion was identified. Additionally, one of four left pelvic lymph nodes showed metastatic carcinoma, while all other lymph nodes examined were negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of a brain tumor in a 56-year-old woman reveals an astrocytoma classified as WHO grade 2, characterized by low proliferation and positive IDH1-R132H status. The tumor shows diffuse infiltration of the cerebral cortex with microcystic changes, but lacks mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis. Additionally, there is no evidence of allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, which is typically associated with oligodendrogliomas.
