Additionally, the rib marrow squeeze shows maturing trilineage hematopoiesis without evidence of tumor, and multiple lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. The report concludes with a classification of pT3 N0 Mx for the malignant mesothelioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive adenocarcinoma with mucinous features, moderately differentiated, measuring 4.0 cm, located in the right and transverse colon, and invading into the subserosa. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and there is evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, but no perineural invasion or malignancy identified in the examined lymph nodes (0/17). Additional findings include tubular adenomas away from the tumor and no abnormalities in the appendix.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, with metastatic disease identified in lymph nodes from levels 3 and 4, while levels 2 and 5 showed benign lymph nodes. The thyroid examination revealed multiple foci of well-differentiated papillary carcinoma, with the largest tumor focus measuring 1.6 cm located in the right lobe, and evidence of extrathyroidal extension into perithyroidal fibroadipose tissue. Overall, three out of seventeen lymph nodes examined showed metastatic involvement, with no extranodal extension identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of muscle invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, with evidence of metastasis in five out of nine examined left pelvic lymph nodes and involvement of the prostatic stroma. The tumor exhibits a diffuse growth pattern with focal micropapillary features and has invaded perivesical soft tissues, with surgical margins showing tumor presence at the urethral margin. Additional findings include benign tissues in various excised specimens, but significant invasive carcinoma is noted in periureteral and peri-urethral tissues.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated serous papillary carcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with tumor sizes of 18x15x9 cm and 13x8x5 cm, respectively. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic serous carcinoma in the uterus, sigmoid nodule, and peri-aortic lymph nodes, with one out of five left pelvic lymph nodes also positive for metastasis. The right fallopian tube shows no specific pathological changes, and the omentum is negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the left lung mass is diagnosed as poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 8.5 cm, with visceral pleural invasion and metastatic carcinoma found in four out of fourteen examined peribronchial lymph nodes. Biopsies from multiple lymph nodes (Levels 2R, 4R, and 5) show no evidence of metastasis. The surgical margins are clear, with the closest margin being 3.7 cm from the tumor, and additional findings include focally purulent chronic organizing pneumonia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic high-grade serous papillary adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, right colon, both fallopian tubes, both ovaries, uterus, bladder peritoneum, sigmoid, diaphragm, and supragastric regions. Tumor sizes vary, with the largest measuring 11.0 cm in the right ovary, and there is evidence of serosal and lymphovascular invasion, as well as one positive lymph node for metastatic adenocarcinoma. The overall staging is classified as pT3c N1 Mx, corresponding to FIGO stage IIIC, with histological features including papillary architecture and focal necrosis.

The pathology report indicates an invasive, poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the descending colon, classified as pT3, with penetration through all parietal layers and evidence of vascular infiltration (L1, V1). There are six lymph node metastases identified out of 14 examined (pN2, 6/14). The tumor is classified as G3, with an ICDO code of 8140/3.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 7, showing extensive perineural infiltration and multifocal extraprostatic growth, particularly at the base and seminal vesicles. There are lymph node metastases identified at the right internal iliac artery and left obturator fossa, with a maximum size of 3.0 cm, while other lymph nodes were tumor-free. The report confirms complete local resection of the tumor, but notes a minimal safety margin of 0.2 mm at the left rectolateral resection margin.

The pathology report indicates that two out of two lymph nodes from the left external iliac region show metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, with the largest lymph node measuring 4 cm and no evidence of extracapsular invasion. The remaining lymph nodes from various regions, including the left common iliac, periaortic, and all right-sided nodes, are negative for malignancy. Additionally, a hysterectomy specimen reveals a keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 4 cm, with a depth of invasion of 10 mm and clear margins from invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffusely infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in multiple margins of the tongue, with all resected margins testing positive for cancer. Lymph node dissection revealed extensive metastatic involvement, with several lymph nodes showing positive results for SCC and evidence of extracapsular extension. The case is classified as pathological AJCC stage T3, N2c, indicating advanced disease with significant lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of a left frontal brain tumor has been diagnosed as glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV), characterized by high cellularity, pleomorphism, and vascular proliferation with necrosis. Immunohistochemical studies show the tumor is positive for GFAP and p53, with a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 35%, while PCR testing for the EGFR variant III mutation returned negative. Additionally, the MGMT promoter methylation status is positive, suggesting potential benefit from therapy with alkylating agents.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 1) in the endometrium, with superficial invasion and no lymphovascular invasion, alongside metastatic adenocarcinoma in the right ovary and serosal surface of the right fallopian tube. The left ovary shows focal metastatic adenocarcinoma, while both pelvic lymph node dissections reveal no tumor involvement. Immunohistochemical results for estrogen and progesterone receptors are pending, but the findings suggest a primary endometrial tumor with metastases to the adnexa.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with myxoid changes, following a left laparoscopic nephrectomy. The tumor measures 5.0 cm, is confined within the renal capsule, and shows no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion, with all surgical margins free of neoplasm. The tumor is classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade II and staged as pT1b NX MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma with papillary features in the right breast, measuring 5.5 cm, and classified as Nottingham score 8/9, grade 3. The sentinel lymph node biopsy showed no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, and the margins of resection are free of neoplasm. Additional findings include ductal carcinoma in situ, atypical ductal hyperplasia, and various benign changes, with the tumor being ER negative, PR negative, and HER-2/NEU positive.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right hepatectomy due to a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 14.2 x 9.5 x 16.5 cm, with no evidence of cirrhosis and microscopic invasion present. Additionally, the gallbladder showed cholelithiasis with Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses, while the right colon and distal ileum exhibited ulceration and perforation with acute peritonitis. The tumor was confined to the liver with uninvolved margins, and there were no signs of lymph-vascular invasion or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade urothelial carcinoma with mixed histologic features, including extensive carcinoma in situ and invasive components affecting the bladder and both ureters. Metastatic urothelial carcinoma was identified in multiple lymph nodes, with all examined nodes from the right common iliac and right pelvic regions showing metastatic disease, while benign nodes were found in the left common iliac region. Surgical margins were positive for tumor at the left ureteral margin, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3 due to invasion of perivesical soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma confined within the right thyroid lobe, with the largest tumor nodule measuring 1 cm. There is no evidence of neoplasm in the left thyroid lobe, and four examined lymph nodes are benign with no tumor present. The tumor is staged as pT1a, with negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of an ulcerated cecal carcinoma, specifically a moderately differentiated, partially mucus-forming colorectal adenocarcinoma measuring 5.5 cm, with invasive spread into all layers of the intestinal wall and into the mesocolic fatty tissue and subserosa. The specimen also shows some tubular adenomas with moderate epithelial dysplasia, while the oral and aboral resection margins and greater omentum are tumor-free. The tumor is staged as pT3, pN2 (4/29), with a grade of G2, indicating the presence of metastases in four out of twenty-nine regional lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell carcinoma of the left renal kidney, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade III/IV, with the tumor confined to the kidney and negative margins for tumor involvement in surrounding tissues. Seven regional lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for tumor, supporting the absence of metastatic disease. Cytogenetic analysis revealed no detectable chromosomal abnormalities in the analyzed specimens, although this does not rule out the possibility of neoplastic proliferation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 3.0 cm and classified as Fuhrman grade 2, with evidence of invasion into the perinephric fat. The tumor is staged as pT3aNxMx, Stage III, with negative resection margins and no lymph node involvement identified. The specimen was obtained from a left laparoscopic radical nephrectomy, and the tumor was located in the mid kidney without gross invasion into the renal pelvis or intrarenal vessels.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in both the right and left paratracheal lymph nodes, with all examined lymph nodes showing evidence of metastatic disease. The total thyroidectomy revealed a papillary microcarcinoma located in the isthmus, measuring 0.8 cm, with no signs of vascular invasion or extrathyroid extension. Additionally, the right upper parathyroid tissue was unremarkable, and other lymph nodes examined were benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation, which has invaded the cervix and myometrium, and shows metastasis to the bladder, lymph nodes, peritoneum, and ileum. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IVB, with significant lymphovascular invasion and multiple metastatic sites identified, including one of eleven pelvic lymph nodes and one of five ileal lymph nodes. Additional findings include benign tissue in the omentum and appendix, with no evidence of serous endometrial carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrative poorly differentiated carcinoma in the cervix. An immunohistochemistry exam was requested to enhance the evaluation, and the findings are consistent with poorly differentiated endocervical mucinous adenocarcinoma. This suggests a diagnosis of a specific type of cervical cancer that is poorly differentiated.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, which measures 11.6 cm and shows lymphovascular invasion and extensive necrosis, with tumor extension through the liver capsule. Biopsies from Gerota's fascia and omentum show no evidence of malignancy, while additional biopsies from Gerota's fascia confirm the presence of poorly differentiated carcinoma. The findings are consistent with the patient's clinical history of a liver mass previously diagnosed as poorly differentiated carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman's grade of 3 out of 4, measuring 2.8 cm and exhibiting necrosis and hemorrhage. The tumor has invaded the renal cortex, medulla, and surrounding adipose tissue, with vascular invasion noted, including a tumor thrombus in a branch of the renal vein, although the main renal vein at the surgical margin is free of tumor. The report also notes that all surgical resection margins are clear of tumor, and there are no significant changes in the non-neoplastic kidney or the benign adrenal gland, with a pathological TNM stage of pT3b Nx M1, suggesting possible metastatic renal cell carcinoma to the lung.

The pathology report describes a lobectomy specimen from the left upper lung, revealing a poorly differentiated bronchiolo-alveolar adenocarcinoma measuring 2.5 x 1.5 x 3 cm. Details regarding tumor extent, other nodules, lymph nodes, and invasion are not specified. There are no comments or additional findings noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the left adrenal gland, with a tumor size of 3.4 cm and an estimated weight of 18 g. The specimen was disrupted during removal, complicating the assessment of surgical margins, but the tumor was not found to invade surrounding tissues or lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical staining revealed a low Ki-67 labeling index of <1%, suggesting a low proliferation rate of the tumor cells.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) in the right breast, measuring 1.1 cm, with negative surgical margins and no evidence of lymph node metastasis in the four examined sentinel lymph nodes. The tumor exhibits lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and geographic necrosis, classified as Scarff-Bloom-Richardson grade 3. Additionally, the estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) tests are negative, while the HER2 status is not amplified, indicating a HER2/CEP 17 ratio of 1.3.

The pathology report indicates a left lung mass diagnosed as moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, measuring 5.5 x 5.5 x 5.4 cm, with evidence of visceral pleural invasion but no lymphovascular space invasion. All examined lymph nodes (levels 5, 6, 9, and 10) were negative for metastatic carcinoma, confirming no spread to these nodes. The tumor is classified as stage pT2b N0, with surgical margins showing the tumor is 1.6 cm from the bronchial margin and 0.2 cm from the pleural surface.

The pathology report indicates that all three left axillary sentinel lymph nodes examined showed no evidence of tumor (0/3). The left breast mastectomy revealed an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, classified as grade 2, along with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of intermediate grade and gynecomastia. The invasive carcinoma is ER-positive, PR-negative, and HER2-positive, with clear resection margins and no lymphatic or perineural invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder and prostate, with two multifocal tumor masses measuring 3.4 cm and 1.2 cm, respectively, and evidence of angiolymphatic space invasion. Surgical margins for the ureters and urethra are negative for carcinoma, and all examined lymph nodes (8 from the left pelvic region and 6 from the right) are also negative for cancer. Additionally, carcinoma in situ is present within the prostatic ducts, but there is no prostatic stromal invasion identified, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3 pNO.

The final diagnosis indicates the presence of left renal cell carcinoma, papillary type II, measuring 4.3 cm, with a nuclear grade of III/IV, but no evidence of invasion into the renal capsule or surrounding structures. The specimens from the left kidney and posterior medial cyst wall show no malignancy, with the cyst wall exhibiting fibroadipose tissue and chronic inflammation. Surgical margins are free of malignancy, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable.

The final diagnosis indicates the presence of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the left oral cavity, measuring 2.5 cm and invading the mandible, with associated acute abscess formation. One of ten examined lymph nodes showed metastatic tumor involvement, but no extranodal spread was observed, and all surgical margins, including bone, were free of tumor. Additional biopsies from various sites in the oral cavity revealed no tumor presence, with marked acute and chronic inflammation noted in some areas.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of anaplastic squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus, characterized by a 1 cm thick gray tumor mass and ulcerative infiltration. Microscopic examination reveals heavy lymphoid infiltration and metastatic cells in the paraesophageal lymphatic node, while paragastric lymphatic nodes and greater omentum show no signs of metastasis. Surgical margins are clear, indicating that the tumor has not spread beyond the resected area.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the papillary type 2 (high grade), located in the right lower pole of the kidney, with a tumor size of 3.1 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable, and the tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon, measuring 4.9 cm, with invasion through the muscularis propria but negative resection margins and no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. The tumor is classified as T3 N1 MX according to the AJCC classification, with two out of thirteen regional lymph nodes showing positive involvement. Additional specimens from the proximal and distal margins, as well as the proximal and distal donuts, were all negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 10.5 cm tubular adenocarcinoma located in the anterior wall of the gastric body, with ulceration and spiculated invasion into multiple layers of the stomach wall and adjacent adipose tissue. Lymphatic vascular invasion is present, and 9 out of 24 dissected lymph nodes are involved, while neural and blood vascular invasions are not detected. Additionally, there is evidence of chronic inflammation and complete intestinal metaplasia in the non-neoplastic stomach tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the omentum did not identify any tumor, and all excised lymph nodes from the left and right paraaortic and pelvic regions were negative for metastatic disease. The hysterectomy specimen revealed an endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, classified as grade 3, with a size of 5.0 x 2.7 cm and focal lymphovascular space invasion, but no cervical involvement or metastasis to lymph nodes. The overall staging is pT1aNO (FIGO IA), and additional findings included myometrial leiomyomata and stromal hyperthecosis in the ovaries.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring up to 1.8 cm, with positive margins, particularly at the posterior margin, and very close anterior margin. Two out of three examined lymph nodes are involved with the tumor, indicating regional spread. Additionally, a hyperplastic nodule was found in the left thyroid lobe, while the thymus and parathyroid were unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the left testis was diagnosed with seminoma, which has invaded the tunica albuginea and the epididymis, with evidence of vascular invasion. The resection margins and scrotum are free of tumor. The specimen measured 14.0 x 10.0 x 8.0 cm, with the tumor fully replacing the testis and measuring 13.0 x 8.0 x 8.0 cm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two distinct adenocarcinomas in the right lung: a lepidic predominant adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe measuring 1.6 cm and a papillary predominant adenocarcinoma in the right middle lobe measuring 2.7 cm, both with free margins and no lymph node involvement. Genetic analysis revealed a positive L858R mutation in the EGFR gene in the right lower lobe sample, which is associated with responsiveness to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors, while the right middle lobe sample showed no mutations in the KRAS gene. The report emphasizes that mutation status may vary over time and should be interpreted in conjunction with other diagnostic tests for treatment decisions.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.8 cm in the right lateral tongue, with a depth of 1.5 cm and focal necrosis, while the posterior margin is focally positive for tumor. All examined lymph nodes from the right neck dissection (42 nodes total) are negative for carcinoma, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. Additional specimens from the tongue and floor of mouth margins show no evidence of carcinoma, with some margins demonstrating chronic inflammation and keratosis.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower lobe of the lung contains a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma measuring 62 mm, with visceral pleural invasion and satellite tumor nodules present. One of three peribronchial lymph nodes shows metastatic carcinoma, while two others are negative for malignancy, and the bronchial margin is clear of tumor. The overall pathologic stage of the lung cancer is classified as IIIA due to the presence of satellite nodules and regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pleomorphic sarcoma with features of malignant fibrous histiocytoma in a right posterior calf mass, measuring 6.8 cm in greatest dimension. The tumor shows focal presence at the anterior/deep margin and is classified as grade 3 with necrosis present in 5-10% of the tumor. No lymph-vascular invasion was identified, and there is no evidence of distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver, with a significant mass measuring 15.4 x 11.3 x 10.7 cm, and negative margins indicating no tumor at the closest margin. Additionally, the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis, while a lymph node from the left portal region is negative for tumor involvement. No necrosis or angiovascular invasion was identified in the liver specimen.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing cholelithiasis and chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder. In the right liver lobe, a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 11.4 cm was identified, with vascular invasion present but negative resection margins. Additionally, findings of liver cirrhosis and significant iron overload consistent with hemochromatosis were noted.

The pathology report indicates that the right pelvic and obturator lymph nodes are negative for malignancy, while one of the left obturator lymph nodes shows metastatic carcinoma. The uterus and cervix exhibit invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 7.8 cm, with lymphovascular invasion present and negative surgical margins. The tumor invades the cervix and lower uterine segment, with a depth of invasion of 1.1 cm in the cervix and approximately 2.0 cm in the lower uterine segment.

The pathology report describes a glial neoplasm characterized by mild hypercellularity and areas of confluent hypercellularity, with tumor cells exhibiting mildly atypical nuclei. A single mitosis was observed, and there is no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis. The final diagnosis is a low-grade oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade II) with a MIB-1 labeling index of 0.6%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a uterine malignant mixed Mllerian tumor, which invades 8.0 mm into the myometrium and shows lymphovascular invasion. No tumors were found in the cervix, bilateral ovaries, fallopian tubes, or multiple lymph nodes examined. The tumor is predominantly a high-grade carcinoma, consisting of undifferentiated and high-grade serous carcinoma, with a sarcomatous component that includes malignant cartilage.

The pathology report indicates that the right tonsil specimen shows a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.5 cm, with a positive deep margin for carcinoma. Among the examined lymph nodes, four out of seven from the right 2A region and one out of thirteen from the right level 3 region were positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the lymph nodes from right 2B and level 4 were negative. The overall pathologic staging is pT1 N2b Mx, with no evidence of extranodal extension or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the right inferior lymph node biopsy revealed benign thyroid tissue, while the total thyroidectomy specimen showed a unifocal papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 4.5 cm in the right lobe. The tumor is classified as pT3, indicating it is greater than 4 cm and limited to the thyroid, with uninvolved margins and no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. Regional lymph nodes and distant metastasis could not be assessed.

The pathology report describes a left adrenal tumor weighing 42 g, characterized as a pheochromocytoma with solid and alveolar structures, focal hemorrhages, and extensive hypolipoidosis in the surrounding tissue. The tumor exhibits high cellularity, atypical mitotic figures, and evidence of vascular and capsular invasion, indicating aggressive behavior. Immunohistochemical staining reveals frequent sustentacular cells, and the tumor shows significant nuclear pleomorphism and hyperchromasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in both the left lobe of the liver, with multiple nodules and the largest measuring 13.0 cm, and a right lobe segment VI nodule measuring 1.5 cm, both showing angiolymphatic invasion. The gallbladder specimen shows no histopathological abnormalities. The parenchymal margins for both the left lobe lobectomy and the right lobe segmentectomy are negative for tumor, confirming that the invasive carcinoma is confined to the liver.

The pathology report indicates the presence of grade 2 squamous cell carcinoma in the cervix, measuring 1.1 cm, with no involvement of surgical margins. There is no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes and parametrium, and a serous cyst was noted in the left uterine tube. Additionally, there is an absence of angiolymphatic and perineural infiltration.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the cervix revealed invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor is classified as histological grade 3, indicating a high level of differentiation. This finding suggests an aggressive form of cancer that may require prompt treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma (Gleason score 6) in a prostatectomy specimen from a male patient with prostate cancer, with tumor involvement primarily in the right lobe and evidence of perineural invasion. The tumor is classified as pT2a, indicating unilateral involvement of less than half of one lobe, with no extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additional findings include stromal hyperplasia, and the pathologic staging is provisional, pending further clinical information.

The pathology report indicates that a right neck dissection was performed, revealing one out of forty-nine lymph nodes positive for squamous cell carcinoma, specifically located in level I, with no extracapsular invasion. Additionally, a poorly differentiated basaloid squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the oral cavity, measuring 3.0 cm with positive lymphovascular invasion, but negative perineural invasion and negative margins, although it is close to the deep superolateral margin. The deep pterygoid margin and retro-antral fat were both negative for carcinoma, and an addendum noted focal invasion of the periosteum by squamous cell carcinoma, with bone margins remaining negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the left lower lobectomy specimen revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of mixed subtype measuring 4 cm, with negative bronchovascular margins and no regional lymph node metastasis. The biopsies from the lymph nodes at stations 7, 11, 12, and 5 showed fragments of anthracotic lymph nodes and adipose tissue, all negative for carcinoma. Molecular studies identified a positive L858R mutation in the EGFR gene, suggesting potential responsiveness to targeted therapies, while the KRAS gene analysis showed no mutations.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated infiltrating adenocarcinoma in the stomach at the incisura site. The specimen was analyzed, and the carcinoma cells were found to be negative for Her-2 expression. Further immunohistochemical and in situ hybridization tests were performed, and the laboratory is certified to conduct these high complexity tests.

The pathology report indicates that the excisional biopsies from the right temporal lobe reveal an anaplastic astrocytoma, characterized by infiltrative cellular proliferation of astrocytic cells with moderate nuclear anaplasia and occasional mitotic figures. The gross examination showed soft, pinkish-gray fragments, and microscopic analysis confirmed the presence of a neoplastic proliferation along with a blood clot. The tumor's proliferative index, assessed by immunostaining for MIB-1, is approximately 6%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 2.0 cm well to moderately differentiated polypoid adenocarcinoma in the left colon, with invasion into the submucosa and confirmed lymphovascular invasion. Thirteen lymph nodes were examined, and no tumor was identified in any of them, indicating a pathologic stage of pT1, N0, Mx. The resection margins are clear of invasive carcinoma, and there are no specific abnormalities noted in the uninvolved colon.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a maximum tumor size of 4.9 cm and a depth of invasion of 0.4 cm, but no parametrial involvement or lymphatic invasion. All examined lymph nodes from the pelvic and periaortic regions were negative for carcinoma, and the surgical margins were clear. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT1b2N0M0, corresponding to FIGO stage IB2, indicating no distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade carcinosarcoma in the endometrium, with the tumor forming a necrotic mass that fills the endometrial cavity and invades the lower uterine segment and cervical canal. The tumor has penetrated 2.5 cm into the myometrium and shows evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, along with focal superficial invasion of the cervical stroma. Additionally, a calcified subserosal leiomyoma is noted, and preliminary frozen section consultation suggested a high-grade carcinoma, likely serous, pending further classification on permanent sections.

The pathology report indicates that the pelvic lymph node dissection revealed six benign lymph nodes, and both the seminal vesicle and left lateral margin were also benign. The radical prostatectomy showed the presence of adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7/10, but no extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, or lymphovascular invasion was identified. Surgical margins were uninvolved, and the overall pTNM stage is pT2c NO, indicating localized prostate cancer without lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional type, with a tumor size of 9 cm and Fuhrman grade III, confined to the left kidney, while the adrenal gland shows no evidence of tumor. The left para-aortic lymph nodes were examined, and no tumor was found in the sixteen nodes sampled. Cytogenetic analysis revealed an abnormal mosaic male karyotype with a deletion on chromosome 3, characteristic of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which is extensively necrotic and infiltrating into the perivesical adipose tissue. Surgical margins are uninvolved but are close at the top left portion, measuring 1.9 mm, and there is evidence of angiolymphatic infiltration, while perineural infiltration is not detected. Additionally, metastases are present in both dissected lymph nodes, leading to a pathological staging of pT3b, pN2, pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of carcinomatosarcoma (malignant mixed Mllerian tumor) of the endometrium, with invasion greater than half of the myometrium and vascular invasion present, but no endocervical invasion. All examined lymph nodes from various regions, including para-aortic and iliac nodes, were found to be benign, with no evidence of metastatic tumor. Immunohistochemical staining for estrogen and progesterone receptors on the uterine tumor returned negative results.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total thyroidectomy, revealing two foci of encapsulated follicular variant papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left and right lobes, measuring 3.4 cm and 0.5 cm respectively. There is no evidence of tumor capsule invasion, angiolymphatic invasion, or extrathyroidal extension, and all resection margins are negative. Molecular testing results are pending, but initial analyses show no mutations in HRAS61 and KRAS 12/13, with BRAF and NRAS61 results being indeterminate due to poor DNA quality.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the right lung hilum, with a tumor size of 3.8 x 3.5 x 2.8 cm and extensive vascular invasion, although bronchial and vascular margins are free of tumor. Metastatic non-small cell carcinoma was identified in one of the level VII lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes examined were reported as benign or showed focal necrosis and calcifications without viable tumor. The report confirms that no mycobacterial or fungal organisms were detected in the examined specimens.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 45 mm, with invasion into but not through the visceral pleura and no evidence of blood vessel, lymphatic, or perineural invasion. A peribronchial lymph node shows metastasis of the adenocarcinoma, while the hilar lymph nodes exhibit only reactive changes with no malignancy detected. The surgical margins are clear of the tumor, and the overall classification is T2N1MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma located in the right hemicolectomy specimen, measuring 4 cm and invading the outer layers of the muscularis propria. The tumor is situated 1 cm aborally from Bauhin's valve, with clear oral and aboral resection margins and no tumor present in the large omentum. Additionally, twelve examined lymph nodes are tumor-free, leading to a staging of pT2 pNO (1/12), L0, V0; G2.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper parathyroid biopsy showed no pathological diagnosis, while the left hemithyroidectomy specimen revealed multifocal papillary carcinoma, dominant follicular variant, measuring 1.5 cm, arising from follicular nodular disease and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. The tumor is characterized by a unifocal transformation in the dominant lesion, with no evidence of capsular, lymph-vascular, or perineural invasion, and the margins are uninvolved by carcinoma. Additionally, there are findings of chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis and adenomatoid nodules, with ancillary studies showing specific immunohistochemical results for the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the left frontal lobe biopsy reveals a diagnosis of gemistocytic astrocytoma. Microscopic examination shows neoplastic astrocytic infiltration with hypercellular areas, predominantly gemistocytic astrocytes, and mild endothelial proliferation, but no necrosis or significant mitotic activity. The clinical history suggests a prior diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma with radiation treatment.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring approximately 2.2 cm in the left lower lobe of the lung, with evidence of focal lymphovascular invasion. The bronchial and vascular margins are clear of tumor involvement, and the remaining lung tissue shows moderate emphysema. Additionally, anthracosis is noted in the examined lymph nodes, but no metastatic tumor is identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of gastric adenocarcinoma mucocellulare with metastases to 13 out of 16 lymph nodes, classified as G3, pT2, and pN2. The tumor, measuring 3.2 x 5.5 x 1.4 cm, is located in the pyloric region and infiltrates deep into the muscular membrane, with incision lines free of neoplastic lesions. Additionally, HER2 testing showed a negative reaction in invasive cancerous cells (Score = 1+).

The pathology report indicates that the left tonsil specimen shows HPV-related infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.4 cm, with the tumor extending to the inked resection margin and areas suspicious for angiolymphatic invasion. The tumor is positive for p16 and HPV16. In contrast, the right tonsil specimen is negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), which is organ-confined and bilateral, with no evidence of carcinoma in the seminal vesicles or surgical margins. The pelvic lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for metastatic carcinoma, with no lymph node involvement. Additionally, benign fibromuscular tissue was noted in the margins and anterior prostatic fat, and there is evidence of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the right inferior segment lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 3.5 x 3.2 x 2.8 cm. The tumor does not involve the pleural surface, and the resection margins are negative for tumor, with a single intrapulmonary lymph node also showing no evidence of malignancy. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from the bronchus intermedius and mediastinal regions are negative for tumor, while adjacent lung parenchyma exhibits emphysematous changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma, measuring 11 cm, confined to the myometrium with evidence of myometrial blood vessel invasion and significant nuclear atypia. Additionally, there is a benign ovarian serous cystadenoma and mild chronic salpingitis noted in the right tube and ovary, while the lymph nodes examined are benign. The tumor is classified as FIGO Stage IB.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 4.8 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2-3/4, and evidence of tumor extension into perirenal adipose tissue and renal sinus, but not involving Gerota's fascia. Additionally, a renal cell carcinoma thrombus is present in a large renal vein, while the resection margins of the ureter and surrounding tissues are free of tumor. The right adrenal gland is benign with no evidence of malignancy, and a thrombus in the inferior vena cava is comprised of metastatic renal cell carcinoma similar to the primary tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left lung, with multiple tumor deposits in both the upper and lower lobes, the largest measuring 165 mm in diameter. The visceral pleura is focally involved, but there is no surface involvement, and the bronchial resection margin is clear, although the peri-hilar margin is closely approached. Additionally, one hilar lymph node shows direct extension of the tumor, while the remaining lymph nodes are free of malignancy, and the pathological stage is classified as T4 N1 M1.

The pathology report describes two excisional biopsies from bilateral breast tumors. The left tumor is diagnosed as invasive and intraductal carcinoma measuring 1.2 cm, with NSABP nuclear grade 2 and histologic grade 2, extending close to the margin but without vascular invasion. The right tumor is also invasive and intraductal carcinoma measuring 2.0 cm, with NSABP nuclear grade 2 and histologic grade 3, similarly extending near the margin and without vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderate to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with a maximal tumor diameter of 6.4 cm and evidence of residual carcinoma following wedge resection. A focus suspicious for lymphovascular invasion is noted, but visceral pleural involvement is not identified, and all bronchial and vascular resection margins are negative for tumor. Among the 14 sampled lymph nodes, one hilar lymph node shows micrometastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while the others are benign with no evidence of metastatic neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of gliosarcoma (glioblastoma multiforme with focal spindle cell differentiation, WHO grade IV) in the right parietal occipital lobe, characterized by prominent coagulative tumor necrosis and mild microvascular proliferation, along with significant leptomeningeal invasion. Additionally, the biopsy of the right parietal occipital dura revealed adherent malignant glioma. The specimens included a large tumor mass and smaller fragments, with histochemical and immunohistochemical analyses supporting the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) in the left breast, with the largest tumor dimension estimated at approximately 4.5 cm, and lymphovascular invasion is present. One of the sentinel lymph nodes (node #1) is positive for metastatic mammary carcinoma, while the other sentinel nodes and non-sentinel nodes are benign. Immunohistochemical staining shows strong estrogen receptor positivity (95%) and moderate progesterone receptor positivity (70%), with HER-2/neu testing negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of combined hepatocellular and cholangiocarcinoma in a liver segment, measuring 2.2 cm, with clear surgical margins and no evidence of vascular invasion or metastasis. Additionally, the gallbladder was found to have cholelithiasis with multiple stones, but no significant abnormalities were noted in its structure. The liver condition is associated with cirrhosis due to chronic hepatitis C infection.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, grade III of IV, confirmed through microscopic examination and immunohistochemical analysis, which showed a proliferation index averaging 9.5%. The tumor exhibits moderately pleomorphic and densely cellular astrocytes with few scattered mitoses, but no signs of endothelial proliferation or necrosis. Two specimens were analyzed, with one being a larger aggregate of soft tan-pink tissue and the other a smaller fragment, both submitted for further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type located in the rectosigmoid region, measuring 2.5 cm and infiltrating the muscularis propria with lymph vessel invasion. The resection margins are tumor-free, and all twelve examined regional lymph nodes are also free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT2, pNO (0/12), pMX; G2, L1, V0, RO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant mixed germ cell tumor in the left testis, primarily composed of embryonal carcinoma (approximately 95%) with a smaller component of yolk sac tumor (about 5%). The tumor shows lymphovascular invasion and extends into the rete testis, but does not involve the tunica albuginea, spermatic cord, or epididymis, with the spermatic cord margin being negative for tumor. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, and the tumor is classified as pT2 due to vascular invasion, while regional lymph nodes could not be assessed.

The pathology report indicates that the right axillary sentinel lymph node biopsy shows no tumor present (0/1). The right breast segmental mastectomy reveals invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 1.6 cm with intermediate nuclear grade, associated with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of intermediate grade, and no definite lymphovascular invasion identified. The tumor does not approach surgical margins, and there are focal areas of necrosis and fibrosis noted, with the clinical significance of these findings remaining unclear.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with a tumor size of 4 cm and extensive lymphovascular invasion. The Nottingham grade is 9/9, indicating a poorly differentiated tumor, and the margins are positive for cancer. Additionally, the tumor is negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors, as well as HER2, and there is a possibility of a metastatic process that cannot be entirely excluded.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left paratracheal lymph node and infiltrative papillary thyroid carcinoma in the trachea, with a dominant 6.6 cm multifocal papillary carcinoma in the left thyroid lobe exhibiting angioinvasion and focal dedifferentiation. Additionally, a 1.3 cm medullary carcinoma was identified in the right thyroid lobe, which shows positive staining for calcitonin and other markers. Surgical margins are involved by carcinoma in the left lobe, and the overall findings suggest extensive disease with multifocality and significant invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of predominantly squamous cell carcinoma with focal glandular differentiation in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 4.2 x 4.0 x 2.3 cm, and exhibiting moderate to poor differentiation. The tumor shows visceral pleural invasion and lymphovascular space invasion, but no metastatic carcinoma was found in the single lymph node examined. The surgical margins are clear, with the tumor being 7.0 cm from the bronchial margin and 4.0 cm from the parenchymal margin, although it invades the pleura.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a high-grade glioma, specifically a glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV), characterized by significant cytologic pleomorphism, mitotic activity, and necrosis, with evidence of subarachnoid infiltration. Genetic analysis reveals abnormalities including polysomy of chromosomes 7 and 9, amplification of EGFR, and loss of PTEN in a substantial proportion of tumor cells, which are associated with a poorer prognosis. Immunohistochemical findings show a high proliferation index and focal positivity for PDGFR-A and PDGFR-B, while MGMT is negative, further supporting the aggressive nature of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left upper outer quadrant of the breast, with a tumor size of 2.7 x 2.7 x 2.5 cm. Out of 8 examined lymph nodes, 1 showed positive metastasis, although details regarding extracasular invasion and margins were not specified. The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified parameters.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral ovarian serous papillary adenocarcinoma, Grade 2-3, with extensive metastasis to multiple sites including the omentum, rectal wall, bladder, descending colon, and mesenteric nodules. The report also notes the presence of leiomyomata in the uterus and squamous metaplasia in the cervix. Overall, the findings suggest a widespread metastatic disease originating from the ovarian carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 1, located in the cornu of the uterus, with a tumor size of 5 x 4.7 x 3 cm and a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 0.2 cm. There is no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion, and the adjacent non-neoplastic endometrium is quiescent. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes and the right ovary and both fallopian tubes are free of tumor, while the left ovary shows evidence of endometriosis.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of left breast cancer following a left segmental mastectomy and axillary dissection. The tumors are identified as infiltrating multifocal poorly differentiated duct carcinoma, with estrogen receptor positivity at 90% and progesterone receptor positivity at 60%, while HER-2/NEU is negative. Additionally, eleven lymph nodes from the left axilla were examined and found to be negative for metastatic carcinoma, although lymphovascular permeation was noted in the breast tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right upper inner quadrant of the breast, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm. Out of 10 examined lymph nodes, 4 showed positive metastasis. The tumor is classified as moderately differentiated, but specific details regarding tumor extent, margins, and Nottingham histologic score are not provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma (2.4 cm) with Fuhrman Grade II/IV, involving the mid and inferior pole of the right kidney, and showing tumor emboli at the renal vein margin. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with negative margins for ureteral and arterial involvement, and classified as pT3b Nx Mx according to AJCC guidelines. Cytogenetic analysis revealed clonal aberrations, including loss of the short arm of chromosome 3, which is characteristic of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 14x10 cm lipoma in the right chest wall, which is a benign soft tissue mass composed of mature adipose tissue. Additionally, a lobectomy of the right upper lobe revealed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring approximately 3.3 cm, with one of five peribronchial lymph nodes showing metastatic carcinoma. All other lymph nodes examined were negative for malignancy, and the bronchial margin was also clear of invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, characterized by a subpleural mass measuring 5 x 4.5 x 2.6 cm that extends into the pleura but does not penetrate it. The bronchial margin is negative for tumor, and multiple intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes are also negative for malignancy. Additionally, all examined mediastinal and N1 lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with a tumor size of 5.5 x 4.0 x 2.5 cm and infiltration into the muscularis propria, while lymphatic vascular invasion is present. There is no evidence of vascular invasion, perineural invasion, or neoplasia in the prostate and seminal vesicles, and all dissected lymph nodes from both the left and right iliac obturator regions are free of tumor. The adjacent bladder mucosa shows severe chronic cystitis, and the surgical margins are clear of neoplastic involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple microscopic foci of adenocarcinoma in the right middle lobe and a larger, moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe, measuring 7.5 x 5.5 x 3.8 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and multiple positive lymph nodes. Additionally, a hamartoma was identified in the right middle lobe, and there are foci of bronchioloalveolar carcinoma in the margins. The overall pTNM stage is pT3 N2, suggesting advanced disease with lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the sigmoid colon, measuring 2 cm in length and 1.5 cm in width, with invasion into subserosal adipose tissue. One regional lymph node showed metastasis out of 17 examined, leading to a staging of pT3 N1a according to AJCC 7th Edition criteria. The distal and proximal rings of the rectum and colon were found to be benign with no pathological diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated high-grade serous carcinoma involving both ovaries, with a tumor size of 25 cm and evidence of lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, the pelvic washings were positive for tumor, and invasive high-grade serous carcinoma was also found in the omentum and peritoneum, while pelvic lymph nodes and para-aortic lymph nodes were benign and negative for malignancy. Other findings included benign endometrial tissue, an endometrial polyp, and a leiomyoma in the uterus, with no significant abnormalities noted in the cervix.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma in three lymph nodes, with one positive node in the right pelvic dissection and two in the left, but no extranodal extension was observed. The radical prostatectomy revealed invasive poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9, involving both lobes of the prostate and approximately 40% of the examined volume, along with multifocal extraprostatic extension and invasion of the seminal vesicles. All surgical margins were free of carcinoma, and there was extensive perineural and lymphovascular invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma (grade 3) involving both bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes, with extensive deposits of serous carcinoma found in the omentum, pelvic tumor, and abdominal tumor specimens. The uterus shows benign findings, including a normal cervix and inactive endometrium, but there are reactive mesothelial foci suspicious for serous carcinoma. A right side lymph node is benign and negative for malignancy, and the patient is BRCA1 positive.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 cholangiocarcinoma in the liver, with a significant mass measuring 10.0 x 8.3 x 6.9 cm, and no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. The closest surgical resection margin is 0.2 cm, and a biopsy of a retrocholedochal lymph node shows no tumor involvement. Additionally, minimal chronic cholecystitis is noted, while the hepatic parenchyma appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from various regions, including the tracheobronchial and paratracheal areas, were examined and found to be anthracotic and negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, a lobectomy specimen from the right lower lobe revealed a well-differentiated bronchioloalveolar adenocarcinoma, measuring 12.5 cm, with no evidence of malignancy in the bronchial and vascular margins, and no lymph node involvement. The final diagnosis includes a pTNM stage of pT3 N0 Mx, indicating localized disease without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the right tonsil, with tumor extension to a cauterized deep surgical margin and a positive posterior lateral margin. Lymph node evaluation shows four out of eight positive right level 2A lymph nodes, while right level 2B and level 3 lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. The final diagnosis is T2, N2b, with no overt lymphovascular invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a type B2 thymoma in the thymus, classified as type 2 according to WHO criteria. The pre-vascular fat is reported to be free of neoplastic compromise. Immunohistochemical examination supports the diagnosis of type B2 thymoma based on its morphological features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (NHG3) in the left breast, with a tumor size of 6 x 4.5 x 2.5 cm and involvement of axillary lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical examination revealed no estrogen or progesterone receptors, and HER2 testing showed a score of 2+ with subsequent FISH analysis indicating no HER2 gene amplification but the presence of chromosome 17 polysomy. The findings suggest a high-grade malignancy with chronic lymphadenitis in the axillary lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in the right pelvic lymph nodes (2 out of 16) and left pelvic lymph nodes (3 out of 8). Additionally, prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5) is noted, showing multifocal extraprostatic extension and invasion of both seminal vesicles. The tumor occupies approximately 90% of the prostate and exhibits extensive lymphovascular invasion, with a focal extension of tumor to the bladder neck margin that cannot be excluded.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a minimally invasive type B2 thymoma, measuring 4 cm, with focal microscopic invasion into surrounding adipose tissue and margins that are close to but not transected. Additional biopsies from the right superior pole and diaphragm show hyperplastic thymus and fragments of bone and cartilage, respectively, with no evidence of tumor. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, and the overall pathologic staging is classified as Stage II according to the Masaoka system.

The pathology report indicates that the left parietal brain lesion is diagnosed as an anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade III, based on highly cellular tumor characteristics and a proliferation index of 20%. There are also features suggestive of an oligodendroglioma, prompting a recommendation for further molecular testing to exclude this diagnosis. The tumor shows no evidence of necrosis or endothelial proliferation, and the presence of prominent calcification and a fine vascular pattern was noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal carcinoma, grade IV, with extensive tumor necrosis and invasion into adipose tissue and the renal pelvis, although the carcinoma is confined by the capsule and margins are free of carcinoma. The left kidney also shows signs of early diffuse diabetic glomerulosclerosis, with minimal chronic changes and moderate arterial sclerosis. Additional studies are planned for further evaluation of the renal parenchyma and tumor characteristics.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, located in the middle and lower poles of the right kidney, measuring 8.4 x 7.9 x 3.4 cm. The tumor is confined to the kidney with no evidence of lymphovascular, transcapsular, or renal vein invasion, and all surgical margins are free of malignancy. The pTNM staging is pT2 NX MX, and there are no significant findings in the adrenal gland or lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade adrenocortical carcinoma measuring 17.1 cm, with significant capsular and vascular invasion, including invasion of the vena cava, and a necrosis rate of 75%. Surgical margins are reported as negative, but there is metastatic carcinoma found in one of two lymph nodes, and the tumor is classified as stage 4 (pT3 N1 M1). An incidental finding of a renomedullary interstitial cell tumor was also noted, while the resection of costochondral cartilage showed no lesions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm with Fuhrman nuclear grade II/IV, located within 0.1 cm of the inked capsule margin, but with no lymphovascular invasion and a free ureteral margin. Additionally, there is moderate arterial and arteriolar sclerosis with focal global glomerulosclerosis observed in the non-neoplastic kidney parenchyma, suggesting significant vascular scarring and potential nephron loss. Cytogenetic analysis could not be performed due to the absence of metaphases in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a da Vinci hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, revealing a moderately well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (Grade II/III) in the uterus with superficial myometrial invasion. All examined regional lymph nodes, including para-aortic and pelvic nodes, were free of metastatic tumor, and the right ovary contained a benign serous cyst. The report concludes that while the tumor exhibits some high-grade features, it does not meet the criteria for serous carcinoma, and the omentum showed no evidence of tumor.

The pathology report describes a hypercellular glial neoplasm with areas of small nuclei and rare mitotic figures, alongside regions with larger nuclei and increased mitotic activity. The presence of nonpalisading tumor necrosis and a calculated MIB-1 labeling index of 16.1% indicates a high-grade glioma. The final diagnosis is anaplastic oligodendroglioma classified as WHO grade III.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the cecal pouch, measuring 3.0 x 2.8 x 0.7 cm, with evidence of lymphovascular invasion but no perforation of the visceral peritoneum. The tumor extends through the muscularis propria into the subserosal adipose tissue, and one out of 17 examined lymph nodes shows metastatic carcinoma. Surgical margins are clear of carcinoma, and the final staging is pT3N1a.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma of the stomach, characterized by extensive ulceration and widespread infiltration into the surrounding soft tissue. There are thirty-nine regional lymph node metastases, with evidence of both invasive and lymphatic spread of the tumor, although the oral resection margin is carcinoma-free and the omentum is tumor-free. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN3 (39/40) pMX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the buccal mucosa, measuring 6.0 cm, with perineural invasion and involvement of the supero-anterior lip and buccal mucosal margins. Additionally, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was found in six out of forty-six lymph nodes from the right neck dissection, with extensive extracapsular extension noted. The mental nerve was positive for squamous cell carcinoma, while other examined tissues, including the inferior alveolar nerve and surgical waste, showed no pathological changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, with a tumor size of 2.4 x 2.1 x 1.5 cm and the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ comprising approximately 5% of the tumor volume. Angiolymphatic invasion is noted, but all surgical resection margins are negative for tumor, with a minimum tumor-free margin of 0.4 cm. Additionally, two out of three sentinel lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma with extranodal extension, while multiple other axillary lymph nodes are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as moderately differentiated (Nottingham Grade 2) with a tumor size of 1.9 cm and no evidence of necrosis or vascular invasion. Additionally, five out of sixteen axillary lymph nodes were positive for metastatic carcinoma, indicating lymph node involvement. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive and progesterone receptor negative, with a pathological stage of pT1c N2a Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of large-cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, characterized by extensive tumor growth and infiltration into adjacent lung tissue and bronchi, with several lymph node metastases identified. The tumor is classified as pT2 pN3 L1 V1 R1, indicating a stage III malignancy with significant local invasion and lymphatic spread. Additional findings include peripheral bronchiolectasia, fibrous remodeling zones, and tumor-associated inflammation, with evidence of anthracotic pigment deposits in both lung parenchyma and lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, classified as high grade and with a pathologic stage of pT2a, indicating invasion into the superficial half of the muscularis propria. Additionally, there is a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the prostate, with a Gleason score of 6, and both tumors are confined to their respective organs with no vascular or perineural invasion identified. All submitted lymph nodes and other tissues, including the ureters and vas deferens, were found to be benign, with surgical margins free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), located in the left lower lobe, with a tumor size of 9.5 cm and a grade of II. Pathological staging reveals T2, N2, and M0, indicating regional lymph node involvement with metastatic carcinoma found in 4 out of 9 examined lymph nodes. The tumor was resected, and the findings suggest a significant disease burden with potential implications for treatment and prognosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mucinous (colloid) adenocarcinoma of the transverse colon, characterized by a tumor size of 4.5 cm by 7 cm with moderate differentiation and invasion into the subserosa. Surgical margins are free of tumor, but there is evidence of vascular invasion and one metastatic lymph node out of 23 examined, with additional mesenteric tumor deposits present. Immunohistochemical staining shows retained expression of DNA mismatch repair proteins, suggesting the tumor's potential responsiveness to certain therapies.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma affecting multiple structures, including the mandibular ramus, temporomandibular joint, palate, oropharynx, tongue, laryngeal cartilage, and bilateral neck soft tissue. The tumor measures 19.0 x 12.0 x 6.0 cm, and no tumor was found in the representative margins examined. The mandibular condyle is undergoing further processing after decalcification for additional evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 11.5 cm located in the upper pole and limited to the kidney without evidence of necrosis or invasion into surrounding tissues. The tumor is classified as pT2b according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer Staging Manual, indicating it is greater than 10 cm but confined to the kidney, with no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. Margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and no significant findings were noted in the nonneoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates that a cervical biopsy was performed, revealing the presence of non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma invading fibromuscular connective tissue. The specimen measured 0.7 x 0.5 x 0.4 cm and was submitted entirely in one cassette. There are no copies sent to a primary or family physician, and the report is electronically signed.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in the right main bronchus, measuring 6 x 4.5 x 4 cm, with bronchial margins free of tumor. Reactive lymph nodes were identified in the 4R, level 7, and level 9 lymph nodes, with peribronchial lymph nodes showing positive involvement for carcinoma (3 out of 39). Additional findings include bronchopneumonia, extensive necrosis, and intrabronchial hemorrhage, with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or visceral pleural involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma, WHO grade II, following the resection of a brain tumor. The tumor specimens showed no deletions of 1p and 19q, which is considered a poor prognostic indicator, but the tumor was found to be mutated for IDH-1 and exhibited MGMT gene methylation. The findings suggest that the tumor may respond favorably to treatment with alkylating agents like temozolomide.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph node from the right axilla is negative for metastases, while the right breast specimen reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 1.2 cm with high nuclear grade and focal necrosis, involving the anterior surgical resection margin. The additional anterior margin specimen shows no tumor present, and the HER2 analysis is equivocal with no amplification detected. Overall, the findings suggest a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma with associated ductal carcinoma in situ, and the tumor is ER and PR positive.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma following a radical excision of a tumor from the right thigh, with no tumor detected at the margins. The tumor measured 3.2 x 2.4 x 2.2 cm and was well-circumscribed, coming close to the deep margin but remaining free of tumor at other margins. A new deep margin specimen was also examined, confirming no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 7.0 cm, with a composition of 60% clear cells and 40% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, and showing invasion into the renal sinus adipose tissue and renal pelvicalyceal system. The resection margins are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of tumor in the adrenal gland or the examined paracaval and interaortic caval lymph nodes. Additionally, the kidney parenchyma exhibits multifocal necrosis and hemorrhage within the renal tubules, but there is no invasion into the perinephric adipose tissue or renal vein.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Glioblastoma Multiforme (Malignant Astrocytoma - WHO Grade IV) located in the left frontal lobe of a male patient. The specimens received included hemorrhagic and red-tan tissue fragments, with the larger piece measuring 2.4 x 2.8 x 1.2 cm. Microscopic examination confirmed the presence of typical features associated with glioblastoma multiforme.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary serous adenocarcinoma involving both the right and left ovaries, with the right ovary measuring 17 cm and showing surface involvement, while the left ovary measures 7 cm with no surface involvement. Additionally, serous adenocarcinoma is present in the pelvic peritoneum and omentum, with the largest implants measuring 1.5 cm and 1 cm, respectively. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3b pNx, indicating advanced disease with peritoneal involvement but no lymph node assessment applicable.

The pathology report indicates the presence of dedifferentiated liposarcoma in multiple sites, including a 5 cm mass in the right retroperitoneum, an omental nodule, and a 1.9 cm lesion in the ileum, with all resection margins and lymph nodes negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, a left pelvic side wall deposit was identified as fibrovascular tissue with chronic inflammation and a foreign body giant cell reaction, but no tumor was found in that area. The report confirms the diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma based on the findings from the surgical pathology specimens.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower lobe neoplasm is an invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 6.5 cm, with additional satellite nodules and evidence of visceral pleural and angiolymphatic invasion. All surgical margins are free of tumor, but there is metastatic carcinoma present in the interlobar and anterior hilar lymph nodes, leading to a staging of T4 N1 Mx. Additional biopsies of lymph nodes and lung tissue show benign reactive changes with no carcinoma detected in several samples.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the rectosigmoid region, with a tumor size of 4.0 cm in length and invasion into the muscularis propria. No gross tumor perforation, serosal involvement, vascular invasion, or perineural invasion was identified, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes (21) showed no metastases, resulting in a pathologic stage of pT2 and pNO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, measuring 4.2 cm, confined to the left kidney with a Fuhrman nuclear grade II, and negative margins for tumor involvement. Four regional lymph nodes were biopsied, and no tumor was present in any of them, with no evidence of lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, the non-neoplastic kidney showed minor abnormalities, including mild focal glomerulosclerosis and arterial sclerosis, but no significant pathological changes were noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bilateral ovarian serous papillary carcinoma, Grade III, at Stage IIIC, with extensive infiltration of the ovarian parenchyma and metastatic deposits on the serosal surface of the uterus. The omentum also shows multiple metastatic deposits of serous carcinoma. The endometrium is inactive, and the cervix and parametrial tissues are free of tumor infiltration.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of an extra-adrenal sympathetic paraganglioma located near the right adrenal gland, with a maximum tumor size of 3.3 cm and negative margins. The tumor exhibits strong positivity for synaptophysin and chromogranin, confirming its neuroendocrine origin, while the adrenal gland itself is described as benign. Histological examination shows a low-grade neoplasm with typical zellballen morphology, and there are no definitive malignant features observed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, papillary type II, with a tumor size of 2.2 cm and a pathologic stage of pT1a NX MX. The deep margin of the resection shows no evidence of malignancy, and there is no perineural, angiolymphatic, or lymph-vascular invasion noted. The tumor is primarily limited to the kidney, with a histologic grade predominantly classified as III.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive non-keratinising squamous cell carcinoma (G3) in the larynx, with the excision line involved. The tumor measures 6 x 3.7 x 2.5 cm and appears whitish and lobular upon macroscopic examination. This finding is consistent with the clinical suspicion of cancer of the larynx and lower pharynx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of thymic carcinoma, classified as pT3, pNO (0/10), and pM1, with a Masaoka-Koga stage of IVb. The tumor measures 6.0 x 6.0 x 4.0 cm and shows focal infiltration into the lung parenchyma and pericardium. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals positive staining for CK5/6, KL1, EGFR, and some CD117, along with numerous CD5-positive T-lymphocytes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left mandibular mass, with evidence of necrosis and perineural invasion, and a size of 4.5 cm. One of fourteen lymph nodes examined showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma with extracapsular extension, while all resection margins were free of tumor. Additional findings included chronic sialadenitis in the submandibular gland and no tumor detected in other examined margins and tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant glioma, specifically a pleomorphic tumor classified as WHO grade III, located in the right frontal region of the brain. The tumor exhibits significant pleomorphism, brisk mitotic activity, and a high MIB-1 proliferation index of 35%, with histological features consistent with an anaplastic pleomorphic xanthoastrocytoma. Although the possibility of gliosarcoma was considered, the absence of specific characteristics such as necrosis and a clear sarcomatous pattern led to the conclusion that the tumor is more likely an anaplastic pleomorphic xanthoastrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 3 x 4 x 1.2 cm ulcerous tubular adenocarcinoma (G2) in the large intestine, which infiltrates the muscularis propria and surrounding adipose tissue. The tumor narrows the intestinal lumen and has a minimum side margin of 0.7 cm, with incision lines free of neoplastic lesions. Additionally, there are metastatic cancer cells found in 2 out of 13 regional lymph nodes, confirming the diagnosis of tubular adenocarcinoma of the rectum with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a tumor size of 5 x 4 x 2.5 cm and invasion extending greater than half of the myometrium. There were no positive lymph nodes found in the 14 examined, indicating no regional metastasis. Additional details regarding lymphatic and venous invasion, margins, and neo-adjuvant treatment were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a peripheral mixed bronchopulmonary adenocarcinoma, characterized by a predominantly tubular or acinar structure with mucin formation and a bronchioloalveolar growth pattern. The tumor is classified as stage IB (pT2 pNO pMX L1 V1 RX) and shows infiltration into the visceral pleura and extension to the basal resection margin. Immunohistological analysis supports the bronchopulmonary origin of the tumor, with positive markers for cytokeratin 7 and TTF-1, and negative for cytokeratin 20 and CDX-2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in a liver specimen obtained from a laparoscopic wedge resection. The tumor measures 1.5 x 1.2 x 1.0 cm, is encapsulated with no necrosis or hemorrhage, and shows focal capsular infiltration but no invasion of surgical margins or surrounding structures. The remaining liver parenchyma is noted to have cirrhosis, and the tumor is classified as poorly differentiated (IV) with major differentiation (III).

The pathology report indicates the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma in both the left partial hepatectomy and segmentectomy specimens, with the larger mass measuring 6.5 x 5.0 x 7.5 cm and showing marked necrosis. The tumor is classified as Edmondson-Steiner grade IV, with no evidence of vascular or serosal invasion, and the surgical margins are clear. Additionally, the gallbladder shows signs of chronic cholecystitis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.8 cm, with high nuclear grade and close proximity to the inferior surgical resection margin. Both sentinel lymph nodes excised were negative for metastases, and the additional lateral posterior margin showed no tumor presence. The Oncotype DX assay resulted in a recurrence score of 14, suggesting a low risk of distant recurrence at 10 years.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in one of the left pelvic lymph nodes, while the right pelvic lymph nodes are negative for carcinoma.
