The prostate examination reveals adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+4 (tertiary grade 5), involving approximately 11% of the gland, with extensive lymphovascular and extraprosthetic involvement but no involvement of surgical margins or seminal vesicles. The pathological staging is classified as pT3a N1 Mx, indicating locally advanced prostate cancer with lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional clear cell type, in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 5.3 cm and Fuhrman grade 2. The tumor is confined to the kidney without any extension into perirenal fat, lymphovascular invasion, or renal vein invasion, and both vascular and ureteral margins are negative. The adrenal gland appears benign, and the AJCC pathologic staging is classified as pT1b, NX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, classified as FIGO grade III, with myometrial invasion affecting 80% of the myometrium. Metastatic tumor was identified in one of three left pelvic lymph nodes, while the right pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes, as well as the omentum and peritoneal biopsies, were negative for malignancy. The overall staging is pT1b N1 (FIGO IIIC1), with prominent lymphovascular space invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates that a skin lesion excised from the trunk measures 3.2 x 2.8 x 4.5 cm and is diagnosed as malignant melanoma with ulcerated and pigmented features. There is no evidence of venous invasion, and the margins are uninvolved. Additional details regarding lymphatic invasion, satellite nodules, and neo-adjuvant treatment are not specified.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the right upper lobe, measuring approximately 47 mm, with evidence of blood vessel invasion but no lymphatic or perineural invasion. There is no convincing pleural invasion, and the bronchial resection margins are clear, although squamous metaplasia with severe dysplasia is noted at the right middle lobe bronchial margin. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes show reactive changes without evidence of malignancy, leading to a classification of T2N0MX for the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that all sampled left axillary lymph nodes (a total of 14) are negative for malignancy. The left total mastectomy reveals a unifocal invasive ductal carcinoma, apocrine type, measuring 1.6 cm, along with a significant component of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with scattered foci. The tumor is classified as Stage I, with negative margins and focal lymphovascular invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) in the right frontal region of the brain, characterized by malignant glial cell infiltration and dense cellularity. Microscopic examination revealed hyperchromatic, mildly pleomorphic nuclei, occasional mitoses, and focal subarachnoid accumulation, but no evidence of necrosis. Immunohistochemical findings supported the diagnosis with moderate perivascular reactivity noted for specific markers.

The histopathological examination of the left breast and axillary tissues reveals a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma. Immunohistochemical analysis shows that estrogen receptors are present in less than 10% of the neoplastic cell nuclei, with no progesterone receptors detected. Additionally, the HER2 protein exhibits a positive reaction in the invasive cancerous cells, scoring 3+.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.0 cm in the buccal mucosa, with no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion, and clear margins. Additional biopsies from various lip and alveolus sites, as well as lymph nodes from the left neck, showed no tumor presence, confirming that all examined margins are free of carcinoma. The pathological stage is classified as pT4a, with a total of 45 regional lymph nodes examined, all of which were negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the liver, characterized by a well-demarcated, expansile mass with areas of necrosis and no involvement of the resection margins. Additionally, there is evidence of periportal fibrosis with mild steatosis in the remaining liver parenchyma. The gallbladder shows signs of autolysis without any stones present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in a liver segment following a right partial hepatectomy, with a tumor size of 9.5 cm and a nuclear grade of 2 out of 3. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, and the surgical margins are negative at a distance of 0.4 cm. The background liver shows inactive cirrhosis consistent with a history of hepatitis C, and the final pathologic stage is classified as pT1NXM0, indicating no distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, characterized by 70% granular cell and 30% clear cell types, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 and a tumor size of 8.5 cm, showing focal lymphatic/vascular invasion but no perinephric adipose tissue extension or tumor in the adrenal gland or liver. Additionally, mild chronic inflammation and cholelithiasis were noted in the gallbladder, while two out of nine deep inter-aortocaval and right paracaval lymph nodes showed metastatic renal cell carcinoma, with the largest focus measuring 1.5 cm. The superficial inter-aortocaval and para-aortic lymph nodes were free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that a lymph node from Level VII is positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the excised lung tumor in the left upper lobe is diagnosed as a Grade II-III adenocarcinoma, measuring 1.9 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm, with no visceral pleural or lymphovascular invasion identified. The surgical margins are clear, with the tumor being 2.5 cm from the parenchymal margin and 0.1 cm from the pleural surface. Additionally, four lymph nodes from Levels V and VI were excised and found to be negative for metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma from a partial nephrectomy of the left kidney, with a tumor size of 2.6 cm and a histologic grade of 3 out of 4. There is no evidence of capsular invasion or lymphatic involvement, and both the perirenal adipose tissue and parenchymal renal margins are free of tumor. The AJCC staging is classified as pT1a, pNx, pMx, with the final staging subject to change based on further clinical review.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from various levels (4R, 2R, 4L, and Level 7) were biopsied and all were found to be benign. A lobectomy of the right upper lobe revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3 cm, with no involvement of the bronchial margins or visceral pleura, and no lymph node metastasis detected. The pathological staging is classified as pT2a, indicating a localized tumor without significant spread to lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes a left adrenal gland specimen that measures 7.5x6.5x4.5 cm and shows a yellow-red surface with hemorrhage and a central cystic area filled with friable material. Microscopic examination reveals normal adrenal tissue alongside a large scarred pseudocyst, with large polygonal cells exhibiting chromatin alterations and rare mitoses, as well as solid tumor formations with collagen-rich bands and focal necrosis. The final diagnosis is a regressive, pseudocystic pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma with mucinous features in the endometrium, showing invasion of 4 mm into the myometrium, with no lymphovascular space invasion identified. The tumor involves the endocervical mucosa and stroma, but all examined regional lymph nodes (21 total) are free of carcinoma. The overall pathologic stage of the tumor is classified as T2b/NO/MX, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) with a tall cell variant, primarily located in the left lobe of the thyroid, measuring 5.2 cm, and exhibiting partial encapsulation and invasion into surrounding fibroadipose tissue. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic papillary carcinoma in a left paratracheal lymph node, measuring 0.5 cm with a 0.25 cm metastatic focus, but no extranodal extension was observed. The surgical margins from the total thyroidectomy are free of tumor, and separate foci of papillary carcinoma, including follicular and microcarcinoma variants, were identified in the right lobe.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of gemistocytic astrocytoma, WHO grade II, with some regions exhibiting cellularity and nuclear atypia suggestive of grade III, although mitotic activity is low and the MIB-1 index remains within the grade II range. Multiple specimens from different tumor locations were analyzed, revealing low-grade glioma characteristics in the frozen sections. Overall, the findings suggest a low-grade brain tumor with some atypical features warranting further clinical evaluation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 3.5 x 3.5 x 2.5 cm, with the bronchial resection margin being free of tumor. All examined mediastinal lymph nodes (R4, L4, and level 7) and the Station 5 lymph node show fragments of benign lymph node tissue, with no evidence of tumor present. The report concludes that there is no direct extension of the tumor, and lymphovascular space invasion is absent, resulting in a pathological stage of pT2a pNO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of residual infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with a tumor size of 3.5 x 3.5 x 3.0 cm and histologic grade 3/3. Additionally, metastatic adenocarcinoma is present in 4 out of 16 axillary lymph nodes, with one node showing macroscopic positivity and extracapsular invasion. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of Paget's disease or dermal lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical cystoprostatectomy, revealing an invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma measuring 3.7 cm, which has infiltrated the muscularis propria but shows no lymph node metastasis in the examined 19 lymph nodes. Both the right and left distal ureters, as well as their margins, were negative for dysplasia or carcinoma. Additional findings include acute and chronic cystitis and inflammation consistent with previous resections, with no evidence of lymph-vascular invasion or microscopic tumor extension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 6.0 x 5.0 x 3.5 cm, with no evidence of visceral pleural or lymphovascular invasion. Surgical margins are clear, with the tumor being 4.5 cm from the bronchial margin and 6.0 cm from the parenchymal margin, and one peribronchial lymph node was negative for malignancy. Additionally, mutation analysis for EGFR and KRAS, as well as ALK gene rearrangements, is recommended for potential targeted therapy considerations.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon, measuring 3.5 cm, with invasion into the subserosa and perforation of the visceral peritoneum. One out of twenty-two lymph nodes examined showed metastatic adenocarcinoma, leading to a pathologic stage of pT4b N1 Mx. The proximal terminal ileal and distal colonic margins are free of tumor, and there is evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, but no perineural invasion is noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of soft-tissue and peritoneal metastases from a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, originating from an ulcerated cardiac adenocarcinoma measuring 4 cm. The tumor has infiltrated the perigastric soft tissue and shows sparse involvement of the diaphragm, with six regional lymph metastases identified. Additionally, the tumor extends to the oral resection margin, while the duodenal resection margin is tumor-free, and the omentum shows no evidence of tumor involvement, with a final tumor stage of pT4 pN1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 2 intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma in the left lobe of the liver, characterized by a large multinodular mass and a single satellite tumor, with negative margins for tumor at resection. The report also notes mild chronic cholecystitis and gallstones in the gallbladder, with negative findings in the pericystic duct lymph node. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from both the hepatoduodenal and para-aortic regions were examined and found to be negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, in the right breast, with a tumor size of 1.3 x 1.1 x 1.0 cm and negative surgical margins. There is no evidence of ductal carcinoma in situ or angiolymphatic invasion, and multiple sentinel lymph nodes, including one intramammary and one axillary, are negative for metastatic carcinoma. Non-neoplastic changes in the breast tissue are noted, and HER2/neu testing has been ordered.

The pathology report indicates a wedge resection of the right upper lobe revealing a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of lung measuring 1.5 cm, with multiple microscopic foci of bronchioalveolar carcinoma present, including at the resection margin. No tumor was identified in the examined regional lymph nodes, and there is no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. The tumor is staged as PT1 N0 MX, indicating localized disease without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, measuring 4.5 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of III/IV, and the tumor is confined to the kidney with negative margins. The regional lymph node specimen showed no significant pathologic changes, and no lymph nodes were identified. Additionally, the kidney parenchyma evaluation revealed mild diffuse mesangial sclerosis likely representing early diabetic glomerulosclerosis, along with moderate arterial sclerosis.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows no significant abnormalities following cholecystectomy. The left lobe of the liver reveals moderate to poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with extension into the portal vein and probable lymphovascular invasion, although surgical margins are free of cancer. Additionally, a true cut and wedge biopsy of the liver confirms the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma, with no cirrhosis observed in the adjacent liver tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic high-grade urothelial carcinoma, with one of ten right pelvic lymph nodes positive for tumor and evidence of extranodal extension. The urinary bladder shows invasive urothelial carcinoma extending through the muscularis propria into perivesical tissue and seminal vesicle, with a positive posterior margin. Additionally, the prostate exhibits prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, and the surgical margins are positive for tumor in both the bladder and prostate specimens.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a male with a diagnosis of mesothelioma, underwent a left thoracotomy and pleurectomy, with findings of malignant mesothelioma primarily in the pleura and diaphragm, along with extra nodular extension in lymph nodes. While benign bone and diaphragm muscle were noted without tumor presence, malignant mesothelioma was confirmed in multiple fragments of the pericardium and pleura, with focal vascular invasion. The final diagnosis includes epithelioid mesothelioma with a pathologic staging of pT2 N2 Mx, indicating regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma of the left ovary, measuring 6.5 x 4.1 cm, with tumor involvement in the serosa and fallopian tube. The uterus shows an endometrial polyp and leiomyomata, but is negative for carcinoma, as are the right ovary and fallopian tube, and the left pelvic lymph node. The omentum shows chronic inflammation but is also negative for carcinoma, confirming no metastatic disease in the examined lymph node and omentum.

The pathology report indicates a right lower inner quadrant mastectomy specimen with a grossly evident infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 2 x 1.5 x 2 cm. The tumor is classified as moderately differentiated, but specific details regarding tumor extent, lymph nodes, margins, and Nottingham Histologic Score components are not provided. Overall, the total Nottingham Score cannot be determined due to unspecified parameters.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma in a Caucasian male, with the tumor located in the right frontal lobe of the brain. The tumor specimen was processed as a primary tissue sample, and no additional treatment has been noted. Blood analysis was performed, but it returned normal results with no significant findings related to the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with WHO grade IV glioblastoma multiforme in multiple brain biopsy samples, including the left occipital region and a deep tumor site. The tumor exhibits high cellularity, significant nuclear pleomorphism, abundant mitoses, and areas of necrosis, along with extensive leptomeningeal involvement at the tumor margin. Immunohistochemical staining shows strong positivity for glial fibrillary acidic protein in many neoplastic astrocytes, confirming the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma, confirmed through biopsy of a left parieto-occipital enhancing tumor. The tumor exhibits characteristics of high-grade astrocytic neoplasm, including necrosis and a proliferation index of 12%, with positive MGMT promoter methylation detected. Additional special stains have been requested for further characterization of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph nodes from both the lobar (ST12R) and interlobar (ST11) biopsies show follicular lymphoid hyperplasia and are negative for malignancy. In contrast, the right lower lobe lobectomy reveals moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 7.7 cm, with visceral pleura invasion but negative surgical margins and no regional lymph node metastasis. Additional findings include mild centroacinar emphysema and focal non-specific pneumonitis in the remaining lung parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, characterized by 90% clear cells and 10% eosinophilic cells, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3. The tumor measures 13.5 cm and extends into the perinephric adipose tissue, invades the adrenal gland, and involves the renal vein, although the vascular, ureteral, and soft tissue margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the tumor exhibits areas of myxoid degeneration, hemorrhage, and necrosis, while the uninvolved kidney parenchyma appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the distal esophagus, with a maximum tumor size of 5.5 cm. Out of 22 examined lymph nodes, 5 were found to contain tumor involvement. The report notes that a radical resection was performed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade cutaneous leiomyosarcoma measuring 2.0 x 1.6 cm, located in the dermis and superficial subcutaneous tissue of the left ankle. The surgical margins are negative for sarcoma, suggesting complete excision of the tumor. The specimen was received as a wide excision, and the gross examination confirmed the presence of the lesion within the specified dimensions.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the mid third of the esophagus, measuring 7.5 cm, with evidence of angiolymphatic and perineural invasion, and metastasis to 7 out of 13 dissected lymph nodes. Additionally, there is a noted increase in volume of the parathyroid tissue, which may suggest hyperplasia or a parathyroid adenoma, depending on clinical correlation. Surgical margins of the esophagus are free of neoplasia, and there are findings of chronic gastritis with atrophy and intestinal metaplasia in gastric mucosa fragments.

The pathology report indicates that all examined lymph nodes from the left axilla are negative for tumor involvement. The left breast segmental mastectomy reveals an infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 1.1 cm with a Nottingham score of 6/9, along with ductal carcinoma in situ comprising 10% of the tumor volume. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and the tumor is characterized by positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, with HER2/NEU status of zero or 1+.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating moderately well-differentiated keratinizing squamous carcinoma in the right lung, measuring 2.5 cm and involving the surrounding area. The carcinoma has metastasized to 2 out of 18 peribronchial lymph nodes, while bronchial and pleural margins are negative for tumor. There is no evidence of an in situ component, suggesting a possible metastasis from a primary tongue carcinoma, although a primary lung carcinoma cannot be completely excluded.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple tumors in the right kidney, including renal cell carcinoma of the clear cell type with Furhman nuclear grade II in several specimens. Additionally, there are cysts with atypical cells and fibrous tissue noted in some of the excised tumors. The clinical history suggests a background of von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, which is associated with bilateral renal masses.

The pathology report indicates the presence of anthracosis and reactive changes in multiple lymph nodes from the right upper lobe, all of which are negative for malignancy. A poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma was identified in the right upper lobe, measuring 1.8 x 1.7 x 1.3 cm, with no evidence of visceral pleural or lymphovascular invasion, and a pTNM stage of pT1a, NO. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes showed no metastatic carcinoma, and further genomic studies have been requested for mutation analysis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5), showing multifocal extraprostatic extension and involvement of the left seminal vesicle, while the right seminal vesicle is negative for carcinoma. One out of eleven pelvic lymph nodes examined is positive for metastatic carcinoma, indicating regional spread of the disease. Surgical margins are reported as negative for invasive carcinoma, but there is evidence of perineural and venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, confined to the pancreas with perineural invasion present. Two out of nine examined lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma, while the resection margins are negative for malignancy. The tumor is classified as pT2, N1b, with no evidence of angiolymphatic or venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the specimens from the right parietal tumor are diagnosed as glioblastoma, a highly aggressive brain tumor. Microscopic examination reveals a hypercellular glial neoplasm with atypical astrocytes, prominent microvascular proliferation, and areas of tumor necrosis. Additionally, approximately 10-25% of the tumor cells show immunoreactivity for MGMT, suggesting a potential for targeted therapy.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the uterine cervix reveals the presence of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. This diagnosis suggests that the cancer has penetrated deeper tissues of the cervix. Further evaluation and management will be necessary to determine the extent of the disease and appropriate treatment options.

The lung biopsy reveals an infiltrating epithelioid neoplasm consistent with malignant mesothelioma. The tumor cells are positive for broad spectrum keratin, calretinin, and WT-1, while TTF-1 and CEA are negative. The findings suggest a diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma, epithelioid type.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with local invasion into perivesical soft tissues and vascular and perineural invasion identified, but surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, an adenocarcinoma of the prostate was found, confined to the prostate with a Gleason score of 7, and no metastatic disease was detected in the left pelvic lymph nodes. Both kidneys show changes consistent with end-stage renal disease, while other specimens, including the right ureter, left vas deferens, and left adrenal gland, were reported as benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast biopsy, classified as moderately differentiated (NSABP grade 2) with vascular invasion present. The subsequent mastectomy revealed no residual carcinoma, but benign proliferative changes were noted, along with metastatic carcinoma found in 4 of 7 axillary lymph nodes, with evidence of extracapsular spread. The largest metastatic lymph node measured 2.1 cm, and the skin and nipple showed no histologic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive carcinoma with a tumor diameter of 5.5 cm. The tumor classification is noted as NOS (not otherwise specified), grade III, and staged as pT3N3aL0V0R0. This suggests a locally advanced cancer with lymph node involvement but no evidence of distant metastasis or vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates that there is no malignancy identified in the peritoneal biopsy, omentum samples, and pelvic lymph nodes, while the left adnexa shows a benign ovary with serosal adhesions and an unremarkable fallopian tube. However, the hysterectomy specimen reveals primary endometrial adenocarcinoma of FIGO grade 1, with myometrial invasion present and lymphovascular invasion noted, indicating a potentially aggressive behavior despite its low architectural grade. Additional findings include benign leiomyomas and organizing hemorrhage in various tissues, with no cervical involvement or tumor at surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the stomach's antrum, classified as Bormann type III and intestinal type according to the Lauren classification, with a largest tumor size of 4.0 cm and evidence of ulceration. The tumor has invaded the muscularis propria and surrounding structures, including the duodenum and peripancreatic fat, with lymphatic invasion present and one out of eight examined lymph nodes involved by neoplasia. Both proximal and distal margins, as well as other examined structures such as the greater omentum, esophageal margin, and spleen, are uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the mid esophagus, with a tumor size of 6.2 cm and evidence of invasion into periesophageal fat tissue, as well as lymph-vascular and perineural invasion. The surgical margins are uninvolved by carcinoma, and out of 15 examined periesophageal lymph nodes, 3 are positive for neoplasia, while 1 out of 11 perigastric lymph nodes is also positive. Additionally, the gastric mucosa shows moderate chronic gastritis, but is uninvolved by carcinoma, and the esophageal segment without neoplasia appears normal.

The pathology report indicates that the left tonsil shows moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma. A biopsy of the floor of the mouth reveals squamous mucosa with focal fibrosis and chronic inflammation, but is negative for malignancy or dysplasia. The specimens submitted included fragments from the left tonsil and the right base of the tongue, with no normal tonsillar architecture present in the tonsil sample.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph node from the right axilla shows micrometastatic malignant melanoma, while the left axilla sentinel lymph node exhibits reactive hyperplasia with no tumor present. The melanoma excised from the back is classified as a superficial spreading type with a dominant vertical growth phase, measuring 5 cm in thickness and showing ulceration and vascular invasion. The overall pathologic stage is pT4b N3 Mx, indicating advanced melanoma with positive lymph nodes and involved surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, papillary variant, type I, measuring 3.0 cm, confined to the right kidney without lymphovascular or perineural invasion. The tumor is classified as pT1a, with indeterminate margins and no lymph nodes identified. Immunohistochemical studies support the diagnosis, but the fragmented nature of the specimen complicates the assessment of margin status.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of invasive endocervical adenocarcinoma, poorly differentiated, with a tumor depth of 3.6 mm and extensive lymphovascular space invasion, but no evidence of malignancy in the surrounding lymph nodes or other biopsied tissues. The tumor is classified as stage 1b1, with a maximum dimension of 4.0 cm, and the resection margins are negative for tumor. Overall, the findings suggest a localized cervical cancer without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a 2.4 cm moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe, with evidence of vascular and pleural invasion, resulting in a TNM staging of T2N0MX, stage 1B. The surgical margins, including vascular and bronchial margins, are free of tumor, and all examined lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. Additionally, there are mild emphysematous changes noted in the non-neoplastic lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 1.5 x 1.5 x 1.0 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of tumor in the examined sentinel lymph nodes (0/4). The tumor is classified as SBR Grade 2 and shows positive estrogen and progesterone receptor status. Additionally, HER2 testing results are negative, and there are no signs of vascular or lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with a tumor size of 3.3 cm and Fuhrman grade 3. The tumor is confined to the kidney with negative margins, classified as pathologic stage I, and no lymphovascular invasion was identified. The specimen was obtained through nephrectomy, and there is no evidence of regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (1.6 cm) in the right lower lobe, with the staple line margin free of tumor. All examined lymph nodes (stations 4, 7, and 9) are negative for carcinoma, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. Additional findings include emphysema, and the tumor is classified as pT1a with no evidence of visceral pleura invasion or lymph-vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma originating from the lung, with a maximum tumor size of 5.5 x 5.0 cm and unifocality. Immunohistochemical staining shows positive TTF-1 and negative results for p63, CK5/6, CK7, and CK20, supporting the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma rather than metastatic urothelial carcinoma. The report notes that all examined lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma, and further characterization of the tumor type is pending additional immunoevaluation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant lymphoma, specifically diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, affecting bilateral cervical lymph nodes measuring 1 to 1.5 cm. Microscopic examination reveals enlarged transformed lymphoid cells with irregular hyperchromatic nuclei and common mitotic figures. Tumor markers show positivity for CD20 and negativity for CD3.

The pathology report indicates that the tissue near the aorta and the nodule on the pleura are negative for neoplasia, while the left upper lobe biopsy shows fragments of squamous cell carcinoma without associated stroma, preventing assessment of invasion. The completion left pneumonectomy reveals a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.0 cm, with no invasion into the pleura and negative margins in the bronchial resection and lymph nodes. Overall, the findings suggest a complete resection of a T1N0 squamous cell carcinoma, which appears to be metachronous to a previously treated lung tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV, in a right renal tumor measuring 4.0 cm, which is confined within the renal capsule and has clear surgical margins. Additional findings include benign renal parenchyma at the deep margin, a benign simple cyst in the right kidney, and no identifiable lymph nodes in the paracaval tissue, which was composed of benign fibroconnective tissue. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable, and all surgical margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon, measuring up to 3 cm in diameter and extending 11 cm to the oral resection margin. The tumor invades all layers of the intestinal wall and extends into adjacent mesocolic fatty tissue, but both oral and aboral resection margins are tumor-free. The tumor is classified as pT3, G2, RO, indicating its stage and grade.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cystectomy due to a diagnosis of invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma with extensive squamous differentiation, characterized by a solitary 6.0 cm exophytic mass in the bladder. All examined lymph nodes (58 in total) and other excised tissues, including the right ureter and left fallopian tube, showed no evidence of tumor. Additionally, the uterus exhibited benign conditions such as adenomyosis and multiple leiomyomas, while the bilateral ovaries displayed physiologic changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically papillary type 1, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2 out of 4. The tumor measures 2.0 cm and shows a solid growth pattern, with no evidence of invasion through the renal capsule or into surrounding structures, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additional findings include mild chronic inflammation and focal glomerulosclerosis in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates a lobectomy specimen from the right upper lung, revealing a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.2 cm. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/6 positive). Additional details regarding tumor extent, invasion, and margins were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates a classic seminoma in the right testis, measuring 9.8 x 7.7 x 6.8 cm, with infiltration into the tunica albuginea, tunica vaginalis, and rete testis. The surgical margins, epididymis, and cord are uninvolved by neoplasia. Additionally, there is evidence of intratubular germ cell neoplasia present.

The pathology report indicates that a male patient underwent a biopsy and excision of a brain tumor, which was diagnosed as glioblastoma (GBM) based on the excision samples. The biopsy of the cerebral cortex was not diagnostic, while the excision samples showed neoplastic astrocytic proliferation with high mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, and areas of necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed a proliferation index of 40% and negative MGMT promoter methylation, consistent with a high-grade astrocytic neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast mastectomy revealed focal atypical ductal hyperplasia and other benign changes, with no evidence of malignancy. In contrast, the right breast mastectomy showed a unifocal invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 30 mm, classified as Stage IIB, with two out of eighteen lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. The report confirms that the surgical margins for the invasive lobular carcinoma are negative, and there is no extranodal involvement noted in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Type B3 Thymoma, measuring 6.0 x 6.0 x 4.5 cm, with infiltration into the mediastinal fat tissue and classified as pT3, pNO (0/1) according to the Masaoka staging system (III). Immunohistochemical analysis shows that the epithelial cells are positive for p63, CK5/6, and exhibit strong membrane staining for EGFR, while being negative for CD117, synaptophysin, and chromogranin A. The proliferation index, as indicated by Ki-67, is 30%, and there are CD5-negative, CD99-positive immature T-lymphocytes present.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the diffuse type arising at the gastro-oesophageal junction, with the tumor extending through the muscularis propria to the serosal surface. Metastatic tumor is identified in three of six lymph nodes, with two showing extra nodal spread, while the proximal and distal mucosal resection margins are clear of tumor. The remaining gastric and esophageal mucosa appears unremarkable, and no vascular or lymphatic invasion is noted.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the uterine cervix reveals infiltrative poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. This suggests an aggressive form of cancer that has invaded surrounding tissues. Further evaluation and management will be necessary to determine the extent of the disease and appropriate treatment options.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade urothelial carcinoma with invasion through the muscularis propria and extension into perivesical adipose tissue, along with multifocal high-grade prostatic adenocarcinoma confined to the right lobe of the prostate. Surgical margins are free of invasive carcinoma, and one perivesical lymph node shows a microscopic focus of metastatic urothelial carcinoma. The final pathologic staging for the urothelial carcinoma is T3b, N1, MX, and for the prostatic adenocarcinoma is T2a, N0, MX.

The pathology report indicates a cystoprostatectomy specimen revealing grade 3 transitional cell carcinoma that extends into the perivesical fat, with perineural and vascular invasion present. Two right obturator lymph nodes are positive for metastatic tumor, while four right external iliac nodes are negative. The ureteric, urethral, and soft tissue margins are clear, and there are no signs of carcinoma in situ in the background urothelium.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a bile duct adenoma and microhamartoma with subcapsular fibrosis in the liver, alongside a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with signet ring cell and neuroendocrine features located at the gastroesophageal junction, which has invaded the muscularis propria and shows angiolymphatic invasion. Surgical resection margins are negative for carcinoma, but one of three examined lymph nodes is positive for metastatic carcinoma, leading to a pathologic stage of pT2N3. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes dissected from various sites are reported as benign, with the exception of nine out of fourteen lymph nodes from the gastroesophageal fat being positive for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 7.5 x 9 cm, with invasion into the perigastric fat and ulceration present. A total of 15 lymph nodes were examined, all of which were negative for metastasis, and there was no evidence of venous invasion or involvement of surgical margins. The tumor is located in the fundus of the stomach, and there are no specified findings of lymphatic or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates that a total thyroidectomy was performed, revealing multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left lobe, with the largest tumor focus measuring 0.6 cm and showing partial capsular invasion, but no extrathyroidal extension or lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, three lymph nodes were examined, all of which were free of metastatic carcinoma, and other findings included Hashimoto's thyroiditis and a 6.0 cm follicular adenoma in the right side. The parathyroid tissue was not identified during the excision, corroborated by intraoperative consultation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of an extensively ulcerated, weakly differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma located in the antrum of the stomach, measuring 7.5 cm in maximum diameter, with infiltration into the surrounding soft tissue and evidence of lymphatic invasion. There is no evidence of tumor in the regional lymph nodes, with all 36 nodes examined being free of cancer. The resection margins, including the omental fatty tissue, are also free of tumor, and the cancer stage is classified as pT2b pNO (0/36) pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, classified as Fuhrman's nuclear grade 3, with the tumor measuring 5.5 cm and confined to the kidney without evidence of invasion into surrounding tissues. The tumor is composed of approximately 70% clear cells and 30% eosinophilic cells, with areas of marked hyalinization, and it abuts the renal sinus without invading the perinephric adipose tissue. Additionally, four small well-circumscribed nodules were identified within the renal medulla, but no tumor was found in the renal vein or calyces.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal papillary carcinoma in the right hemithyroid lobe, with a dominant tumor measuring 1.4 cm and a second smaller tumor of 0.4 cm, both exhibiting mixed classical and follicular variants. The tumors are partially encapsulated with minimal capsular invasion, and there is no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion, nor extrathyroidal extension. Margins are uninvolved by carcinoma, and additional findings include mild follicular nodular disease and focal nonspecific thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates that the left frontotemporal mass is diagnosed as an anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO grade III), characterized by diffuse infiltration of white and gray matter, moderate to high cellularity, and marked nuclear pleomorphism. Immunostaining shows an increased nuclear labeling rate for MIB-1, supporting the diagnosis of anaplastic change, with many nuclei positive for p53. Molecular studies for MGMT, IDH1, and 1p19q are currently in progress.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of stomach adenocarcinoma (G2, pT2, pNO) following a total organ resection of the pyloric part of the stomach. The tumor, measuring 3.2 x 2.9 x 0.8 cm, is located in the pyloric region and infiltrates the stomach wall and surrounding fat tissue. Examination of the incision lines and three lymph nodes shows no evidence of neoplastic lesions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma in the left testicle following a left radical orchiectomy. The tumor measures 5.0 x 4.0 x 2.0 cm and shows no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or intratubular germ cell neoplasm, with no extension into the tunica albuginea or epididymis. Pathologic staging is classified as T2CNXMX, and no lymph nodes were submitted for evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, measuring 2.7 cm, of the conventional type with 100% clear cells and Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, which is confined to the kidney with free margins and no invasion into surrounding tissues. Additionally, there is an adrenal cortical adenoma measuring 1.7 cm, but no metastatic renal cell carcinoma is present in the adrenal gland. The tumor is well-circumscribed and shows no other lesions in the kidney parenchyma, which is otherwise unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a right frontal lobe tumor characterized by a diffusely infiltrating glioma with variable cellularity, suggesting a preliminary diagnosis of a WHO Grade III astrocytoma, potentially mixed with oligodendroglioma. Macroscopically, the specimen shows significant cortical thickening and a cystic space filled with altered blood, while microscopically, the tumor exhibits a range of cellular features, including mild pleomorphism and a low proliferation index. Further genetic studies are pending to assess for specific deletions and amplifications that may influence the diagnosis and treatment plan.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma involving the mandibular bone, with vascular and perineural invasion noted. In the right neck dissection, metastatic squamous carcinoma was found in 2 out of 22 lymph nodes, while the left neck dissection showed no tumor in the nine lymph nodes examined. Resection margins from the anterior and tongue margins were free of tumor, suggesting complete removal of the primary tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland, with noted microscopic foci of vascular invasion, which raises concerns about the tumor's biological behavior. The specimen weighed 97 grams and contained a significant mass measuring 6.0 x 5.3 x 4.3 cm within the adrenal medulla, surrounded by a bright orange cortex. Close clinical follow-up is recommended due to the presence of vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated intestinal type adenocarcinoma located in the fundus of the stomach, measuring 9.5 x 8 x 1.2 cm and exhibiting ulceration. The tumor has metastasized to 6 out of 7 examined lymph nodes, with no specified lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion, and the surgical margins are uninvolved. There is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of thymic carcinoma, specifically a non-keratinizing squamous cell type, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm and evidence of multifocal invasion into mediastinal adipose tissue and pleura, while the resection margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, one of three lymph nodes examined is positive for metastatic carcinoma. The lung wedge resections show organizing phase diffuse alveolar damage, with features suggestive of possible progression to fibrosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma with extensive squamous differentiation, invasive into the muscularis propria, and no evidence of lymphovascular invasion. The tumor was described as multiple fragments of white-tan soft tissue, measuring a total of 4.0 x 4.0 x 2.5 cm. The clinical history notes a prior diagnosis of bladder carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4 + 5), showing focal extension into extraprostatic tissue, but with all resection margins free of tumor. Additionally, there is evidence of perineural invasion, while the bilateral pelvic lymph nodes were examined and found to be free of tumor (0/9). The seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia also showed no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of malignancy in the anterior bladder neck margin, left base of the prostate, left prostate apex, and in all examined pelvic lymph nodes. However, the prostatectomy specimen reveals the presence of acinar adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4 + 3, involving 20% of the prostate tissue and showing perineural and lymphovascular invasion, with positive margins at the bladder neck. The pathologic staging is pT2c pNO, indicating bilateral disease without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, confirmed through multiple biopsies from the right temporal region, with varying tumor cellularity percentages ranging from 60% to 95% and no necrosis observed. Immunohistochemical analysis shows strong positivity for p53, loss of PTEN, and low MGMT expression, suggesting a potential responsiveness to Temodar but a diminished response to EGFR kinase inhibitors. Additionally, the presence of high levels of EGFR amplification and polysomy indicates aggressive tumor characteristics, while the absence of significant activated MAPK suggests a likelihood of responsiveness to radiation therapy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of both astrocytic and oligodendroglial differentiation in the tissue sample. There is no evident mitotic activity, and the proliferation index is low at 2%. The final diagnosis is an oligoastrocytoma classified as WHO grade II.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of angioinvasive poorly differentiated thyroid carcinoma, arising from a follicular variant of papillary carcinoma, with a tumor size of 9.6 cm in the left hemithyroidectomy specimen. The tumor is classified as G3 (poorly differentiated) and is unifocal, with margins uninvolved by carcinoma, while lymphovascular invasion is present but limited to fewer than four vessels. No regional lymph node metastasis was identified in the examined lymph nodes from left levels 2 and 6, and there is no evidence of distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor mass measuring 14.0 x 10.0 x 6.0 cm that extends into the perinephric fat but does not involve the renal vein or collecting system. Metastatic lesions were identified in the right lower lobe of the lung, with two nodules measuring 1.0 cm and 0.8 cm, respectively, while retrocaval lymph nodes were negative for tumor involvement. An addendum notes that the tumor cells show 100% positivity for EGFR, suggesting it can be classified as an EGFR-expressing carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that both specimens from the left parietal brain lesion resection are diagnosed as glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV). The first specimen was evaluated via frozen section during surgery, confirming the diagnosis, while the second specimen was submitted for further analysis in formalin. The findings are consistent with a high-grade malignant brain tumor, necessitating further clinical management.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma (G3) of the larynx, classified as pT3. The tumor, measuring 4.5 x 2.5 x 1.2 cm, is located in the glottal region and has invaded surrounding areas, including the subglottal and supraglottal regions. Surgical margins are reported to be free of neoplastic lesions, with further analysis pending on paraffin specimens.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph node biopsy shows metastatic carcinoma originating from breast cancer, while the modified radical mastectomy reveals invasive lobular carcinoma that is poorly differentiated and multifocal, with extensive lymphatic permeation and involvement of the nipple. Additionally, lobular neoplasia and proliferative fibrocystic disease with atypia are noted, and metastatic carcinoma is present in 3 out of 12 axillary lymph nodes. The tumor is strongly positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, but shows no overexpression of Her-2/neu.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma in a right hemicolectomy specimen, measuring 6.5 cm and invading all layers of the intestinal wall to the subserosa. The tumor is staged as pT3, R0, G2, with clear resection margins and no evidence of tumor in the 44 dissected lymph nodes. The final staging is pT3 pNO (0/44) LO V0 R0, indicating no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in a female patient, with the tumor located in the breast and classified as grade 2. The cancer is staged as 1c with lymph node involvement classified as 1a and no distant metastasis (stage 0). Additionally, a normal blood sample was obtained, indicating no abnormalities in that specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma in the uterus, with a tumor measuring 7.0 x 4.1 x 0.4 cm that invades the myometrium and shows lymphovascular space invasion, but the margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from both para-aortic and pelvic regions are positive for metastatic carcinoma consistent with an endometrial primary, while the omentum is negative for tumor. The right ovary is atrophic, and high-grade serous carcinoma is also identified in the right fallopian tube and left adnexal soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder specimen shows no evidence of malignancy, with lymph nodes exhibiting reactive changes. In contrast, the liver specimen reveals moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with prominent vascular invasion and necrosis involving less than 10% of the tumor. The tumor is confined to the liver, with the parenchymal margin uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and additional findings include cirrhosis and fibrotic changes in the liver parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the distal third of the esophagus, with a maximum tumor size of 7.7 cm and a depth of infiltration of 1.2 cm, along with evidence of angiolymphatic and perineural invasion. Lymph nodes in the periesophageal and perigastric regions show involvement by neoplasia, with capsular transposition noted in both. Surgical margins from the esophagus and stomach are free of neoplasia, and there is an association with paracoccidioidomycosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant mesothelioma, specifically the tubulopapillary type, in the right lung and diaphragmatic tumor, with the lung parenchyma being free of tumor and bronchial margins negative for malignancy. Eleven lymph nodes from level VII, three from level VIII, and one from level IX were excised and all were negative for malignancy, while four lymph nodes from level IV also showed no malignancy. The report confirms the diagnosis through immunohistochemical studies, which showed positive markers for malignant mesothelioma.

The pathology report indicates a right renal mass diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma, with a tumor size of 5.2 cm and histologic grade G2. The tumor is confined to the kidney parenchyma, with surgical margins free of tumor, and no evidence of necrosis or lymph node involvement. Additional findings include focal glomerulosclerosis, arteriosclerosis, interstitial fibrosis, and chronic inflammation in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the descending/sigmoid colon, classified as grade G3, with evidence of ulceration and chronic inflammation. The tumor has infiltrated the parietal layers of the colon and has metastasized to 12 out of 18 local lymph nodes, along with signs of lymphangitis and vascular carcinosis. The resection margins are tumor-free, and the tumor is staged as pT3, pN2, MX, L1, V1, with the presence of diverticulosis in the sigmoid colon.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 2.2 cm, with well-differentiated histology and evidence of focal capsular and lymphovascular invasion. Two left para-tracheal lymph nodes were biopsied and found to be benign, with no evidence of metastatic disease. Additionally, the thyroid tissue shows chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and the surgical margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenalectomy was performed, revealing a tumor weighing 168g and measuring 8.3 x 7 x 4.5 cm. The diagnosis is adrenal cortical carcinoma with a Weiss score of 6. There is no evidence of lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed hepatocellular/cholangiocarcinoma in the left lobe of the liver, with the tumor extending to the surgical margins and invading large vessels. No carcinoma was found in the examined lymph nodes, and the tumor is classified as moderately differentiated with a maximum size of 12.1 cm and evidence of vascular invasion. The overall findings suggest a highly proliferative malignancy, with a histologic grade of pT3bNO according to AJCC staging.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous carcinoma of the endometrium, with extensive myometrial invasion (25 mm) and significant lymph-vascular space invasion, classified as Stage IIIC1. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 2 out of 10 examined pelvic lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes and bilateral fallopian tubes and ovaries showed no tumor involvement. The cervix was unremarkable with no dysplasia or tumor present, and immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade carcinoma with extensive necrosis and invasion into skeletal muscle in the left perihilar tissue, along with identified angiolymphatic emboli. The left renal vein cuff shows occlusion by high-grade, focally sarcomatoid carcinoma that invades through the vein wall, while the left kidney and associated tissues reveal a high-grade, partially cystic, partially sarcomatoid carcinoma with significant invasion and a large tumor thrombus in the renal vein. Overall, the findings suggest a diagnosis of advanced renal cell carcinoma with sarcomatoid features, extensive local invasion, and involvement of surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in a 2.8 x 2.6 x 2.4 cm solitary nodule located in the left lobe of the liver, with negative resection margins and the tumor confined to the liver. The background liver tissue shows established cirrhosis, and there is evidence of microvascular invasion, although major vascular invasion and lymphatic invasion are absent. Additional findings suggest the presence of steatohepatitis, and further clinical evaluation for Wilson's disease and alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is recommended.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor measuring 4.0 x 2.7 x 2.7 cm located in the fundus of the uterus, invading 0.2 cm into the myometrium, but not involving the endocervix or lymphovascular spaces. All examined pelvic lymph nodes from both the left and right sides are negative for tumor involvement, and the surgical margins are clear of cancer. The bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are unremarkable and uninvolved by the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade myxofibrosarcoma in a left buttock mass, measuring 6.5 x 5.8 x 4.8 cm, which is diffusely infiltrating subcutaneous adipose tissue and skeletal muscle. The tumor is predominantly viable with focal areas of necrosis, and surgical margins are free of tumor, with the nearest margin being 0.3 cm away. The specimen was received fresh and included an overlying ellipse of skin, with detailed measurements and descriptions provided for the surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the distal esophagus reveals moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, likely arising from preexisting Barrett's esophagus due to the presence of intestinal metaplasia. Microscopic examination shows malignant epithelial cells forming poorly differentiated glandular structures infiltrating the surrounding stroma, alongside fragments of benign squamous and glandular epithelium. The patient's history includes dysphagia and weight loss, which are pertinent to the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a right adrenal mass resected from a female patient, weighing 316 g and measuring 11 x 9 x 6.5 cm, characterized by a thick brown capsule and a multinodular cut surface with areas of hemorrhage. The diagnosis is adrenocortical carcinoma with a nuclear grade of 3, a Weiss score of 6, and evidence of sinusoidal invasion, but without capsular or venous invasion. The remaining adrenal parenchyma is intact, measuring 1.5 x 1.0 cm, and the periadrenal fatty tissue shows no signs of neoplastic infiltration.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, located in the upper pole of the left kidney, measuring 5.0 x 5.0 x 4.5 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2/4. The tumor is confined to the kidney with no evidence of lymphovascular, transcapsular, or renal vein invasion, and all surgical margins are negative. The pTNM staging is classified as T1bNXMX, and no lymph nodes were identified in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates that a specimen was sent to the Biospecimen Core Resource (BCR) for analysis, but it lacks specific details about the tumor type and histology code. The report emphasizes the need to complete the TCGA Missing Pathology Report Form due to the absence of a comprehensive pathology report. Additionally, it highlights the importance of providing accurate site and diagnosis codes for proper case documentation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a right adrenal tumor measuring 6.5x4.7 cm, characterized by a white and partly reddish appearance. Microscopic examination reveals cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and bizarre hyperchromatic nuclei, but no necrosis or atypical mitosis, with a Ki67 index of 1% and negative p53 staining. The final diagnosis is a pheochromocytoma of the right adrenal gland.

The pathology report indicates that a bladder tumor was identified, measuring 4.3 x 2.6 x 1.2 cm and weighing 6 grams. The diagnosis is invasive high-grade urothelial cell carcinoma, which has invaded the muscularis propria and shows evidence of perineural invasion. A portion of the tumor was submitted for further tissue procurement.

The pathology report indicates that a 4-year-old female underwent a total organ resection of the right breast, revealing a tumor measuring 3.2 x 1.8 x 2.8 cm, classified as invasive lobular carcinoma (NHG2). The tumor was located near the outer boundary of the breast and showed infiltration into the breast tissue, with no lesions observed in the nipple. The histopathological diagnosis confirms the presence of invasive lobular carcinoma of the right breast, categorized as pT2 with no nodal involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of mixed invasive ductal and lobular carcinoma in the right breast, graded Nottingham II, with a tumor size of 2.1 x 1.4 x 1.3 cm, and a separate ductal carcinoma in situ nodule measuring 0.6 x 0.6 x 0.5 cm. All surgical margins are negative for tumor, and seven right axillary sentinel lymph nodes show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The left breast shows mild proliferative changes with ductal hyperplasia without atypia, and further receptor analysis has been ordered.

The pathology report describes a 3.5x3.2 cm tumor in the left adrenal gland, characterized by a brown appearance with concentric reddish areas. Microscopic examination reveals a neoplasm of the adrenal medulla with specific cellular features and a mitotic rate of 2 per 10 high power fields, but no signs of vascular invasion or necrosis. The final diagnosis is a pheochromocytoma of the left adrenal gland.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from both the left and right pelvic regions are negative for tumor involvement, while the left distal ureter shows chronic inflammation and the right distal ureter contains fibrofatty tissue, both negative for tumor. However, the report identifies high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma with squamous and glandular differentiation in the urinary bladder and prostate, measuring at least 5 cm, with extensive invasion into surrounding tissues and one of fifteen examined lymph nodes involved. The tumor is staged as pT4a, pN1, pMX, with evidence of lymphatic and perineural invasion, and associated lesions of urothelial dysplasia and carcinoma in situ present in the bladder and prostate.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a liver specimen obtained from a laparoscopic segmentectomy of segment 6. The tumor measures 2.0 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm, is encapsulated, and shows a worst differentiation grade of III with a major differentiation grade of II, but there is no evidence of invasion into surrounding structures or vascular involvement. The remaining liver parenchyma shows portal inflammation and fibrosis, with minimal fatty change noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as Stage IIIC, with a tumor size of 10.5 cm and lymphovascular invasion present. Out of 14 examined lymph nodes, 10 were positive for metastatic carcinoma, while all surgical margins were free of the lesion, with the closest margin being 1.2 mm from the tumor. The surgical procedure performed was a modified radical mastectomy of the right breast, along with the insertion of a mediport.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe and superior segment of the right lower lobe, measuring 6.5 cm, with no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, all of which were negative for metastatic carcinoma, and remote granulomas with calcification were noted. The surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and the tumor is classified as pT2b, indicating it is more than 5 cm but less than 7 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, conventional type, located in the right thyroid lobe, measuring 2 cm with extrathyroidal extension but no lymphovascular invasion, and negative resection margins. Additionally, there are hypercellular parathyroid tissues noted in the right superior parathyroid gland and midline tissue, while the left thyroid lobe contains a colloid nodule. No tumor was found in the examined lymph node, and parathyroid tissue was negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in the Delphian nodes, right para-tracheal lymph nodes, and pre-tracheal tissue, with no extranodal extension identified. The total thyroidectomy revealed a well-differentiated papillary carcinoma, diffuse sclerosing variant, measuring 2.0 cm, with extensive blood vessel invasion and partial encapsulation. Additionally, the right lower parathyroid gland and right paratracheal tissue were found to be benign and unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma, with the tumor comprising approximately 5% of the total tissue volume and a Gleason score of 7/10. The specimen shows no evidence of extraprostatic extension or lymphovascular invasion, but there is a suspicious area along the left posterior lobe mid region that may indicate potential tumor extension beyond the surgical margins. The overall findings suggest careful clinical correlation is necessary to assess the surgical margins and any potential implications for treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of extensive superficially invasive well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO Grade I) in the uterus, with minimal myometrial invasion and no lymphovascular invasion, and a maximum tumor dimension of 12 cm. All examined lymph nodes (16 total) from various regions, including pelvic and para-aortic, were negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, mild chronic cervicitis was noted, and the ovaries and tubes appeared consistent with the patient's age.

The pathology report indicates that the left parietal mass and infiltrated brain specimens were diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV), with the left parietal mass showing focal oligodendroglial differentiation. The specimens consisted of multiple soft tissue fragments, with sizes ranging from 1.2 cm to 4.0 cm in aggregate. An intraoperative consultation confirmed the presence of a high-grade astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates that the left kidney specimen shows a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, with a tumor size of 3 cm and no evidence of capsular invasion or renal vein involvement. The left perinephric fat is composed of fibroadipose tissue and is negative for malignancy, while the left 12th rib specimen appears unremarkable. The overall pathological stage is classified as T1a NX MX, and the surgical margins are negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative lobular carcinoma in the right breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T1, N0, and M0, indicating it is localized without lymph node involvement or metastasis. No treatment has been administered, and a normal blood sample was also collected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligoastrocytoma (WHO grade III) from a right frontotemporal/insular brain mass. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positivity for IDH1-R132H mutation and p53 protein in rare cells, with a high Ki-67 labeling index. Further fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) studies for 1p19q deletion have been ordered for additional evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis in the gallbladder and hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver, with the tumor classified as Grade I and staged as pT1. The surgical margins, including the bile duct margin, are reported to be free of tumor, and there are small satellite tumors present. The tumor invades bile ducts but exhibits the morphological characteristics of hepatocellular carcinoma, with no evidence of cirrhosis noted.

The pathology report indicates a bladder tumor diagnosed as Grade 3 poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) with a pT2 classification, indicating invasion into the muscularis propria. The specimen consisted of 18g of firm and friable tissue, showing a mixed papillary and solid growth pattern. Additionally, carcinoma in situ was noted in the background urothelium, but there was no definite lymphovascular invasion observed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma in a partial resection of the right kidney, with a tumor size of 3 x 2.5 x 2.5 cm and a nuclear grade of 3. The tumor is unifocal, with no sarcomatoid features or necrosis, and it does not extend through the renal capsule or involve perinephric tissue, with negative surgical margins. Pathologic staging is classified as pT1a; pNX, and there is no evidence of lymph-vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, measuring 2.5 x 2.2 x 1.9 cm, with tumor involvement of the left true vocal cord, ventricle, anterior commissure, and invasion through the thyroid cartilage, but with negative surgical margins. A total of 81 lymph nodes were examined from various levels of the neck, all of which were negative for carcinoma. Additional findings include subcutaneous tissue inflammation with abscess and keratinaceous debris.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segments V and VI, characterized by a 6.5 x 6 x 5.5 cm mass that does not invade the hepatic capsule, with margins free of tumor by 2 cm. The non-neoplastic liver tissue is noted to be grossly non-cirrhotic. Additionally, the gallbladder shows cholesterolosis without any identified stones or malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, in multiple biopsies from the left frontal brain, with varying tumor necrosis percentages and high cellularity. Immunohistochemical analysis shows low MGMT expression, loss of PTEN, and high levels of phosphorylated MAPK, suggesting a potential response to Temodar but resistance to radiation therapy. Additionally, the presence of high EGFR amplification and polysomy indicates aggressive tumor behavior and may influence treatment decisions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary serous adenocarcinoma of the ovary, with evidence of similar high-grade carcinoma present in the fallopian tubes. Extensive necrosis and hemosiderin deposition consistent with hemorrhage are noted, particularly in the right ovary. The findings suggest a widespread malignancy originating from the ovaries, with multiple foci of carcinoma identified in both ovaries and on the surfaces of both fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 4.2 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is classified as pT1, indicating it is limited to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates that a right upper lobe lobectomy was performed due to a previously diagnosed squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 2.4 cm, which was moderately differentiated. All surgical margins and lymph nodes examined (7 in total) were free of tumor, with no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion. The final diagnosis confirms the presence of squamous cell carcinoma, but with clear surgical margins and no malignancy in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes (R4, right, level 10, and level 7) are negative for malignancy. In contrast, the right lower lobe resection reveals a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with no vascular invasion and negative margins. The overall pTNM stage is T2a N0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a tubulovillous adenoma of the colon mucosa with mild dysplasia. Additionally, it describes a right hemicolectomy specimen revealing a slightly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma classified as G3, with significant extracellular mucus accumulation and evidence of tumor infiltration into the colon wall and pericolic tissue, but with no tumor in the examined lymph nodes. The tumor staging is reported as pT3, pN0, with no residual tumor in the resection margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the body and tail of the pancreas, with a tumor size of 7.9 x 2.4 x 1.4 cm and evidence of invasion into peripancreatic fat tissue, as well as lymphovascular and perineural invasion. Surgical margins are free of tumor, but there is metastatic carcinoma identified in 1 out of 18 regional lymph nodes. The spleen and other examined lymph nodes show no pathological abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the left thyroid lobe and isthmus, characterized as well differentiated with a tumor size of 1.3 cm, no identified mitotic activity, necrosis, or blood vessel invasion, and free surgical margins. The right thyroid lobe shows nodular thyroid hyperplasia without any identified parathyroid glands. Additionally, mild nodular hyperplasia is noted in the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, nuclear grade III/IV, with a tumor measuring 5.5 cm that extends through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia, and no invasion of the renal vein is identified. Additionally, there is metastatic carcinoma in the adrenal gland measuring 10.5 cm, with vascular invasion present in the renal sinus. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney shows interstitial fibrosis and chronic inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma with both follicular and solid growth patterns, identified in two foci within the right lobe and isthmus, with sizes of 3.0 cm and 0.3 cm. The tumor is not encapsulated, shows vascular invasion, and has a focally positive anterior surgical margin, while extra-thyroidal extension is not identified. The AJCC pathologic stage is classified as pT2 pNx pMx, and the specimen has been revised to reflect that it is from the right lobe and isthmus rather than a total thyroidectomy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an invasive keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma located in the oral cavity, specifically in the left mandible, with a maximum tumor diameter of 3.9 cm and evidence of bone invasion. All examined lymph nodes (39 in total) and surgical margins are negative for metastatic carcinoma, suggesting no spread of cancer to these areas. Additionally, reactive squamous mucosa was noted in various margins, with carcinoma in situ present in the adjacent soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma, classified as grade 2. The TNM staging shows T2, N0, M0, indicating a primary tumor with no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been initiated at this time, and the specimen was obtained from a blood draw.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive lobular carcinoma with a tumor diameter of 2.5 cm and focal intraductal spread. There is evidence of lymph vessel invasion, classified as G III, oT2N3aL1V0RX. The findings suggest an aggressive tumor with potential for metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, specifically located in the body of the pancreas, with a tumor size of 4.5 x 3.5 x 3.0 cm and evidence of lymphovascular and perineural invasion. The tumor has extended into the peripancreatic soft tissue, but all surgical margins are free of tumor with a safety margin of 2.1 cm. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic carcinoma in 3 out of 11 examined peripancreatic lymph nodes, while the spleen and stomach biopsies show no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with areas of hemorrhage, necrosis, and focal sarcomatoid dedifferentiation, classified as Fuhrman's nuclear grade 4. The carcinoma invades perinephric adipose tissue and the renal pelvis, with evidence of carcinomatous angiolymphatic invasion, and it is present at the surgical resection margin. Additional excised tissues from the upper pole margin and peri-diaphragmatic area also show involvement by renal cell carcinoma, with degenerative changes noted in adjacent skeletal muscle.

The pathology report confirms the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in the Delphian node and one of the left low jugular nodes, with no extranodal extension identified. The total thyroidectomy revealed a classical type papillary carcinoma in the left lobe, measuring 4 cm, with well-differentiated histology and free surgical margins. Additionally, the left tracheal node and an additional left jugular node were found to contain benign fibroadipose tissue with no lymphoid tissue identified.
