The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid in the right lobe, measuring 1.5 cm, with the tumor confined to the thyroid gland and free margins. Additionally, metastatic papillary carcinoma was found in one of two perithyroidal lymph nodes. The total thyroidectomy specimen included the right lobe, isthmus, and left lobe, with the left lobe appearing unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 2.1 cm and a histologic grade of G3. Lymphovascular invasion is present, and 10 out of 17 lymph nodes examined show metastasis, with the bronchial and vascular margins being uninvolved. The report notes discordance with prior fine needle aspiration (FNA) results, suggesting incomplete sampling of affected lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 7 x 6 x 1.7 cm exophytic adenocarcinoma located in the sigmoid colon, which is moderately differentiated and extends into the muscularis propria. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes, with all 5 nodes being negative. The surgical margins are uninvolved, suggesting complete resection of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in two lymph nodes from the right neck, with one node showing extracasular extension and the largest metastasis measuring 2.2 cm. Additionally, a moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the right hemiglossectomy specimen, measuring 5 cm, with all surgical margins free of carcinoma and no perineural invasion noted. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3 N2b, and further studies have been ordered for additional evaluation.

The final diagnosis indicates a right temporal tumor excised, identified as a grade II astrocytoma according to the WHO classification. Immunohistochemistry for the proliferation antigen Ki67 shows less than 1% labeling of tumor cell nuclei, consistent with the expected proliferation index for a grade II astrocytoma. Microscopic examination reveals a diffusely infiltrative proliferation of moderately pleomorphic astrocytes without high-grade features such as necrosis or mitoses.

The pathology report indicates that a liver nodule excised showed no viable tumor cells but contained degenerated necrotic tissue with hemorrhage. An esophagogastrectomy revealed a poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma measuring 2.5 cm at the gastroesophageal junction, with extensive lymphovascular invasion and metastasis to 9 of 17 regional lymph nodes. Additional biopsies of the jejunal mesenteric lymph nodes confirmed metastatic adenocarcinoma, while other examined tissues from the small bowel and hernia sac were benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, grade 3, from a left partial nephrectomy specimen measuring 6 cm, with no direct tumor invasion beyond the kidney and absent sarcomatoid and lymphovascular invasion. All surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and the tumor is classified as pT1b with lymph nodes being unassessable. The non-neoplastic kidney shows no significant pathologic findings, and there is no evidence of distant metastasis.

The final diagnosis indicates a left frontal brain mass identified as an oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade II), with occasional mitotic figures present but no microvascular proliferation or necrosis observed. An addendum reveals that fluorescence in situ hybridization demonstrated loss of both chromosomes 1p and 19q. The specimen was received as an irregular fragment of soft tissue measuring 3.5 x 2.5 x 1 cm, and was processed for both intraoperative consultation and permanent analysis.

The pathology report indicates that the periportal lymph node, gallbladder, bile duct margin, pancreas margin, superior mesenteric lymph nodes, and omentum show no evidence of malignancy, while the Whipple's specimen reveals pancreatic adenocarcinoma that is well-differentiated and measures 4.6 cm. There is evidence of lymphovascular invasion and perineural invasion, with five positive lymph nodes identified out of those examined. The report also notes severe chronic pancreatitis and dysplasia along the pancreatic/common bile duct.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has pancreatic cancer, specifically a well-differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma measuring approximately 3.5 cm, with extensive invasion into surrounding tissues and involvement of the distal pancreatic margin. The gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis without malignancy, and one reactive lymph node from the common bile duct is negative for cancer. Additionally, five out of ten peripancreatic lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, leading to an AJCC staging of pT4N1Mx.

The pathology report indicates a 4 cm moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the upper lobe of the lung, with no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion and uninvolved margins. There were no positive lymph nodes out of 11 examined, suggesting no metastasis. The tumor is localized and has not specified additional tumor nodules or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates that the right frontal tumor resected is a high-grade mixed glioma, characterized by a classic oligodendroglial neoplasm with features of anaplastic oligodendroglioma and astroblastoma-like components. The corpus callosum resection shows no evidence of tumor. Additionally, the loss of heterozygosity at chromosome arms 1p and 19q was detected, while there was no evidence of methylation of the MGMT promoter.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical cystectomy with T-pouch to urethra, revealing a transitional cell carcinoma in the bladder that is grade 3/4 and invading through the muscularis propria into perivesical soft tissue, while the prostate shows prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6, without capsular involvement. All margins, including those of the ureters and apical urethra, are negative for tumor, and no malignancy is identified in a total of 77 examined lymph nodes. The final pathological staging is pT3bN0M0 for the bladder and pT1aN0M0 for the prostate.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated gastric adenocarcinoma (intestinal type) located in the distal stomach, with a maximum tumor size of 5.9 x 3.6 x 2.4 cm and invasion into subserosal soft tissues, but without visceral peritoneum involvement. All surgical margins are negative for tumor, and no malignancy is detected in the examined lymph nodes (0/13). Additional findings include chronic active gastritis and intestinal metaplasia, with the overall staging classified as pT3 pNO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of III/IV, in a right kidney mass measuring 4.1 cm. The tumor is confined within the renal capsule, and all surgical margins are free of tumor, with the non-neoplastic kidney appearing unremarkable. The frozen section diagnosis during intraoperative consultation confirmed a renal cortical neoplasm with negative margins for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder specimen shows cholecystitis with wall calcification, while the omental nodule is diagnosed as metastatic carcinoma. The uterus, cervix, ovaries, and fallopian tubes reveal endometrial adenocarcinoma with clear cell features, classified as FIGO grade III, with evidence of myometrial and endocervical invasion. Multiple lymph nodes, including left external iliac and left obturator, show significant metastatic carcinoma involvement, while several other lymph nodes and the omentum are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent right eye enucleation due to a choroidal melanoma, which is predominantly of the spindle cell type, measuring 12 mm in diameter and 10 mm in thickness. Microscopic examination confirmed the presence of deeply pigmented melanoma with minimal lymphocytic infiltration, no necrosis, and no evidence of tumor extension beyond the eye. Molecular genetic analysis revealed normal chromosome 1p, disomy 3, and normal chromosomes 6 and 8, suggesting the patient is at low risk for metastatic melanoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade myxofibrosarcoma in the right posterior thigh, with the tumor measuring 9.5 x 8 x 7 cm and involving subcutaneous tissue and the dermis. Focal areas of necrosis are present, but the resection margins are free of tumor, with the closest margin showing a 0.25 cm microscopic clearance. The specimen was obtained through a radical resection that included portions of skin and underlying muscle.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), located in the left lung, with a tumor size of 6 cm. The tumor is classified as Grade III and is staged as T2, N1, M0, indicating regional lymph node involvement without distant metastasis. The tumor is primarily located at the hilum and predominantly involves the upper lobe, without extension to the lower lobe.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated cervical squamous cell carcinoma, invasive to a depth of 14 mm, with multifocal lymphovascular space invasion but no parametrial invasion, and clear resection margins. The vaginal cuff, as well as multiple lymph nodes and fallopian tubes, show no evidence of malignancy. The final staging of the tumor is Stage IB1, with no regional or distant metastasis detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma, WHO grade II, in the right frontal region of the brain. The tumor exhibits characteristics of a low-grade glioma, including infiltrative growth, prominent perinuclear halos, and modest nuclear atypia, with infrequent mitotic figures. Additionally, sections of the tumor have been sent for 1p19q testing, with results pending from the Cytogenetics Laboratory.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of recto-sigmoid adenocarcinoma, with a tumor measuring 2.8 cm and classified as well-differentiated (G2). Surgical margins are negative, with the tumor located 5.8 cm from the distal margin, but lymphatic, vascular, and perineural invasion are present. Additionally, three out of thirty-eight examined regional lymph nodes show involvement, and a tubular adenoma is associated with the adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes were biopsied, all of which were negative for metastasis, confirming no malignancy in those samples. However, the left upper lobe with the superior segment of the lower lobe revealed an invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.0x3.5x3.0 cm, with negative bronchial margins and no angiolymphatic invasion. The overall staging is pT2N0Mx, indicating a localized tumor without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph node biopsies from the right side are negative for metastatic carcinoma, with no evidence of metastasis in 0/9, 0/18, and 0/2 lymph node fragments examined. A right lung pneumonectomy revealed a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, with lymphovascular invasion present and one of four lymph nodes showing metastatic carcinoma. The bronchial and vascular resection margins are negative for tumor, and the visceral pleura is uninvolved by the carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the porto-caval lymph node is involved with metastatic adenocarcinoma. The distal gastrectomy specimen shows a poorly differentiated, diffuse type adenocarcinoma of the distal stomach, approximately 40mm in size, which extends to the serosal surface and infiltrates adjacent omentum. Additionally, three out of seven regional lymph nodes are involved with metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma with multifocality, affecting the bladder, prostate, seminal vesicles, and both ureters, along with evidence of vascular and perineural invasion. Metastatic disease was identified in one of the right distal pelvic lymph nodes, while the left distal pelvic lymph nodes showed benign fibroadipose tissue. Additionally, carcinoma in situ was present at the resection margins of both distal ureters.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a biopsy of a laryngeal mass, revealing multiple findings across different biopsy sites. The final diagnosis includes keratosis with mild to moderate dysplasia, as well as the presence of Candida species, and notably, superficially invasive squamous cell carcinoma arising in a background of papillary keratosis with dysplasia. The report emphasizes the need for further clinical correlation and management based on these findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 1, identified as a 3.5 x 3.0 x 1.0 cm mass in the uterine fundus, with invasion into the myometrium but no involvement of the endocervix or lymphovascular invasion. The background endometrium shows complex hyperplasia with atypia, and the vaginal cuff margin is negative for tumor. Additionally, multiple pelvic lymph nodes excised are negative for tumor, and the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes show no diagnostic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a 4.5 cm moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the left upper lung, with involvement of the main bronchus. Out of 7 examined lymph nodes, 2 showed evidence of metastasis. There is no specified information regarding lymphatic or venous invasion, tumor margins, or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, in the right breast, with a tumor size of 8 x 7.5 x 5 cm and negative surgical margins. However, 27 out of 35 axillary lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, classified as AJCC pN3. The left breast shows benign proliferative fibrocystic changes with no diagnostic abnormalities in the nipple.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the posterior vaginal margin and the cervix, with tumor thickness measuring 8 mm and no vascular or perineural invasion identified. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, with all showing benign findings except for one lymph node with endosalpingiosis. Surgical margins from the radical hysterectomy are free of tumor, and incidental findings include adenomyosis in the myometrium and a serous cystadenoma in the right ovary.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal bilateral papillary thyroid carcinoma following a total thyroidectomy, with the largest tumor focus measuring 0.7 cm and minimal capsular invasion noted. Additionally, a pretracheal lymph node excision revealed no evidence of neoplasm. The tumor is classified as moderately differentiated (G2) and shows a classical variant in 60% of cases and a follicular variant in 40%.

The pathology report indicates the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in both segment 8 and segment 5 of the liver, with the tumors exhibiting Edmondson-Steiner grades II and III. The tumors are encapsulated, with no invasion into surgical resection margins, and the remaining liver parenchyma shows signs of cirrhosis. Additionally, the gallbladder was removed due to chronic cholecystitis and cholesterolosis.

The pathology report indicates a Whipple procedure specimen revealing a moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the head of the pancreas, measuring 3 x 3 x 2.7 cm, with possible invasion of the common bile duct and proximity to vascular margins. The common bile duct and pancreatic duct were found to be patent, and both the pancreatic neck margin and gastroduodenal lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. Out of seven lymph nodes examined, one showed evidence of metastasis, indicating regional spread of the cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma metastasizing to the liver, alongside an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon that shows infiltration of all parietal layers and vascular involvement. The colon cancer is classified as pT3, L1, V1, with free resection margins and no lymph node involvement (pN0). Additionally, two liver metastases were identified, confirming the presence of metastatic disease (pM1).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon, characterized by a large fungating ulcerated mass measuring approximately 9.0 cm, with invasion into the bowel wall and surrounding pericolic adipose tissue. Sixteen regional lymph nodes were examined and found to be free of metastatic tumor, and the resection margins are clear of tumor involvement. Additionally, there are chronic inflammatory changes noted on the serosal surfaces of the bowel and appendix, with the tumor exhibiting a variable histologic grade from well to undifferentiated.

The pathology report indicates that both biopsies from the right frontal lobe brain lesions are diagnosed as oligodendroglioma with a WHO grade of II. Molecular testing for various genetic markers, including EGFR, 1p/19q, MGMT promoter methylation, and IDH mutations, has been ordered and results will be reported separately. Immunohistochemical analysis shows approximately 60% of tumor cells are positive for P53, with a low proliferation index of less than 4% as indicated by MIB-1 staining.

The pathology report indicates a hemicolectomy specimen from the colon, revealing a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a tumor size of 9 x 8.5 x 8 cm. The tumor extends into the pericolonic tissues, but details regarding lymph nodes, margins, and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment are not specified. No additional pathologic findings or comments are provided in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma affecting both the left and right ovaries, with serosal involvement noted in both. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic serous adenocarcinoma in the left fallopian tube and omentum, as well as significant metastatic involvement in regional lymph nodes, with 11 out of 12 right external iliac nodes and 7 out of 8 para-aortic nodes showing metastasis. The overall staging is classified as FIGO Stage IIIC, indicating advanced disease with peritoneal metastasis and lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant epithelioid mesothelioma in the right pleura based on biopsy results. Immunohistochemical studies show the tumor is positive for cytokeratin (AE1/AE3), CK5/6, and focally positive for calretinin and WT1, while negative for mCEA, Ber-EP4, and TTF1. The specimen consisted of multiple fragments of soft tissue, and the findings have been reviewed intradepartmentally to support the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal breast carcinoma, classified as grade II, with evidence of angioinvasion and penetration into the retromamillary fibromuscular tissue, but without infiltration of the skin. The tumor measures 3.8 cm and shows multicentric manifestations of intraductal carcinoma, with 12 out of 17 lymph nodes involved, and is classified as pT2, pN3a, pM1, R0; G2. Resection margins are free of atypia, and there are no coarse calcifications noted.

The final diagnosis indicates the presence of an oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade II) in the medial frontal and right frontal tumors, with approximately 75% of the tumor exhibiting oligodendroglial features and mild cellular atypia, but no mitotic figures identified. The margin biopsy showed minimally hypercellular cerebral cortex without solid tumor, and the deep tumor was consistent with infiltrating glioma without obvious anaplasia. Immunohistochemistry results indicated positivity for the IDH1 R132H mutation, and interphase fluorescence in situ hybridization revealed losses of both 1p and 19q chromosomal regions.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the uterine cervix reveals moderately differentiated infiltrative squamous cell carcinoma. This suggests the presence of cancerous cells that are moderately well-formed and invasive in nature. Further evaluation and management will be necessary based on these findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast (NHG3, pT2, pNO) following a histopathological examination of the resected tissue. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed no estrogen receptors and less than 10% positivity for progesterone receptors, with a negative HER2 reaction in invasive cancerous cells. The tumor measured 3.2 x 2.0 x 3.0 cm and was associated with fibrocystic changes and hyperplasia in the surrounding glandular tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower lobe lung nodule is diagnosed as well-differentiated adenocarcinoma of the bronchoalveolar type, with a maximum tumor diameter of 1.5 cm and clear margins, showing no vascular invasion. The lymph nodes examined, including the inferior pulmonary ligament, tracheal, and subcarinal lymph nodes, show sinus histiocytosis with anthracosis but no evidence of metastatic tumor. Overall, there is no indication of distant metastasis at this time.

The pathology report indicates that a radical cystectomy was performed, revealing a diagnosis of invasive urothelial carcinoma in the urinary bladder, with a predominant micropapillary variant comprising 90% of the tumor. The tumor measured 7.5 cm and extended into the uterus, with lymph-vascular invasion present and focal positivity in the paravesical soft tissue margins, while the urethral and ureteral margins were negative for tumor. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma in situ was identified in four out of five pelvic lymph nodes, with the largest lymph node metastasis measuring 1.5 cm.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma (G3 TCC) of the bladder, which has invaded the perivesical soft tissue and is within 1 mm of the circumferential surgical resection margin. The right iliac lymph node shows evidence of metastatic carcinoma, while both proximal and distal ureteric resection margins are normal with no carcinoma in situ. Additionally, there are foci of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) in the right lobe of the prostate, but no evidence of adenocarcinoma is found.

The pathology report indicates that the right temporal brain tumor has been diagnosed as Glioblastoma multiforme, classified as an Astrocytoma WHO Grade IV. The tumor exhibits characteristics of malignancy, including multinucleated malignant astrocytic cells, hyperchromasia, and significant mitotic activity, along with areas of necrosis and neovascularity. Both specimens submitted for analysis confirm the presence of this aggressive brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a WHO B2 type thymoma, measuring 5.5 cm, with multifocal microscopic transcapsular invasion but no pleural or lymphovascular invasion identified, and negative resection margins. The tumor has been completely excised, and there are involutional changes in the thymic tissue, with one parathyroid gland showing no significant abnormalities. The overall findings suggest a modified Masaoka stage IIa thymoma, associated with the patient's clinical history of myasthenia gravis.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy from the brain revealed two findings: one specimen was non-diagnostic due to necrotic tissue, while the second specimen confirmed the presence of glioblastoma multiforme. The patient has a lesion in the right parietal lobe and exhibits lethargy along with an extensive mass lesion. Microscopic examination of the second specimen showed features characteristic of a high-grade malignant glioma, including nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic figures, and areas of necrosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segment VII, characterized by a dominant mass measuring 9.7 x 9.5 x 8.4 cm and at least 25 smaller tumor nodules. Additional findings include Grade 2-3 hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segments V and VIII, along with a cavernous hemangioma in segment V. The spleen biopsy shows benign tissue, and the gallbladder exhibits mild chronic cholecystitis and cholesterolosis, with a benign cystic duct lymph node.

The pathology report indicates a nephrectomy specimen containing two focal areas of highly differentiated Type 1 Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma, measuring 2.2 cm and 0.6 cm. The carcinoma is located near multiple papillary adenomas and shows evidence of chronic interstitial nephritis. The tumor is classified as pT1a, Grade G1, with an R-Classification of R1, and the ICD-O code is 8260/3.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lung lobe, measuring 3.7 x 3.2 x 2.5 cm, with invasion into the pleura but no vascular invasion or involvement of the bronchial margins. Multiple mediastinal and interlobar lymph nodes were examined, with no evidence of tumor in any of the lymph nodes, although one lymph node showed old calcified granulomas. Additional findings in the lung included emphysematous changes and atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, but no mycobacteria or fungi were detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a high-grade leiomyosarcoma in the infrarenal vena cava, with the tumor measuring 17 cm and affecting the left internal iliac vein margin, while the vena cava and right common iliac vein margins are free of tumor. A biopsy from the sacral promontory also confirmed the presence of sarcoma. Cytogenetic analysis was attempted but deemed inadequate, as no metaphases were found and the cells failed to grow in culture.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right tonsil, measuring 2.2 cm, with all resection margins negative for tumor. Additional excisions from the right neck revealed dense fibrous tissue with a foreign body giant cell reaction, benign fibroadipose tissue, and no significant histopathologic changes in the salivary gland and lymph nodes, all negative for tumor. The left tonsil and other excised tissues, including teeth, also showed no significant histopathologic changes or tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the head of the pancreas, with a tumor size of 35mm and staging classified as IIB. Tumor involvement is noted at the pancreatic neck margin (within 0.1mm) and the portal vein margin (0.2mm), with 2 out of 10 lymph nodes showing evidence of malignancy. Additional findings include a 12mm tubulovillous adenoma in the duodenum and a solitary necrotic nodule in the liver, with no malignancy detected in other examined lymph nodes and tissues.

The pathology report indicates that all examined lymph nodes (9 total) from both pelvic and periaortic regions are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The uterine specimen reveals endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 2, with significant myometrial invasion and lymphovascular space invasion, alongside complex atypical hyperplasia. The overall FIGO staging is IC, and the pelvic wash is negative for malignant cells.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO Grade IV, from a left frontal mass lesion, characterized by a hypercellular tumor with atypical glial cells, numerous mitoses, and areas of necrosis. The findings include endothelial proliferation and pseudopalisading necrosis, with a Ki67 proliferative index ranging from 25% to 40%. The initial biopsy showed predominantly necrosis with no viable tumor, while the excision confirmed the high-grade glioma diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with clear cell change in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 32 mm, with extensive lymphatic invasion but no direct invasion of the visceral pleura. Tumor involvement is noted in the peribronchial lymph nodes and other submitted lymph nodes, with no vascular invasion or perineural permeation observed. The pathological stage is classified as T2 N2, and additional findings include emphysema and respiratory bronchiolitis in the remaining lung parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bilateral acinar cell adenocarcinoma in the prostate, with a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7, and significant tumor involvement in the right seminal vesicle and questionable involvement in the left. Extracapsular extension and angiolymphatic invasion are noted, but all surgical margins and lymph nodes examined are free of tumor. The pathologic stage is classified as pT3b NO Mx, indicating advanced disease without lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of choroidal melanoma, spindle type, in the left globe, measuring 18 mm at the base, with no evidence of scleral invasion or tumor in the optic nerve or vortex veins. The tumor exhibits a low mitotic count of less than 1 per 10 high-power fields, and there are no extraocular lesions identified. The gross examination reveals a dark brown-black pigmented mass in the choroidal region, with the sclera beneath the tumor remaining intact.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right frontal brain tumor diagnosed as an oligodendroglioma, WHO Grade II, confirmed through both frozen and permanent sections. The tumor exhibits low-grade characteristics with no signs of mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis, and shows positive results for allelic loss on chromosome arm 1p and partial deletion on 19q, along with the detection of an IDH1 mutation. Additionally, the MGMT promoter methylation status is negative, suggesting that the patient may not benefit from therapy with alkylating agents.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 3, primarily originating from the left ovary, with extensive metastases and lymphovascular spread to multiple sites including the omentum, sigmoid colon, and pelvic side walls. The left thigh lipoma, right ovary, and fallopian tube specimens are free of tumor. The report highlights significant tumor involvement in the sigmoid colon, with one lateral resection margin testing positive for cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of melanoma in a Caucasian female, with the primary tumor located in the skin and graded as 4. There is also a sample of normal blood collected for comparison, but no significant findings were noted in that specimen. The report does not indicate any treatment or staging details for the melanoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma (7.1 cm, clear cell type, Fuhrman nuclear grade III/IV) confined to the left kidney, with negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, an adrenal cortical adenoma (2.0 cm) with myolipomatous metaplasia was identified in the left adrenal gland, while two regional lymph nodes were negative for tumor. The renal pathology evaluation revealed glomerulopathy with a membranous pattern of injury, suggestive of a paraprotein deposition disease, alongside moderate chronic changes in the kidney parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma (Grade 3) in the right breast, with a Nottingham histologic score of 8, and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (Grade II-III) and lobular carcinoma in situ. Three out of four sentinel lymph nodes showed isolated tumor cells, but no macrometastases were identified, indicating minimal lymph node involvement. The tumor measures 2.0 cm in greatest dimension, with lymphovascular invasion present, and margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional type, measuring 12.0 cm, with 70% clear cells and 30% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 4, and showing invasion into the renal vein and renal sinus adipose tissue. The resection margins are free of tumor, and no tumor is present in the adrenal gland. The tumor exhibits necrotic and cystic areas, with the renal sinus completely obliterated by the tumor, while the remaining renal parenchyma is unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma in a breast segment, with a tumor diameter of 3 cm and a focal intraductal component. The tumor is classified as not otherwise specified (NOS), grade II, and staged as pT2LOVORO. This suggests a moderate level of differentiation and a significant size of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a 3.5 cm poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located at the esophagogastric junction, with invasive tumor spread into all layers of the esophageal and gastric walls and into adjacent fatty tissue. There is minimal chronic gastritis present, with no evidence of Helicobacter pylori, and the resection margins are tumor-free. Out of 26 lymph nodes examined, three show metastases, leading to a staging of pT2b for gastric localization and pT3 pN1 for distal esophageal localization.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma with focal squamous differentiation in the urinary bladder, which invades the muscularis propria (detrusor muscle). The tumor is classified as high-grade and presents as a solid/nodular configuration, with no associated epithelial lesions identified. Additional findings include cautery artifact and necrosis, while lymph-vascular invasion remains indeterminate.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the chromophobe type, in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 3.2 cm and local invasion into the renal sinus fat, but no renal vein invasion or lymph node involvement was identified. Additionally, a retroperitoneal lipoma was excised, which showed mature adipose tissue without atypia, and multiple lymph nodes from various regions were examined, all of which were not involved with malignancy. The surgical margins from the nephroureterectomy were free of tumor, and the background renal tissue showed mild arteriosclerotic changes and benign cortical cysts.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant mixed Mllerian tumor (MMMT) with heterologous differentiation, extensively involving the lower uterine segment and invading the myometrium to a depth of 13 mm. Metastatic involvement of the tumor is identified in two out of six right pelvic lymph nodes, with extracasular extension, while the left pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy. The overall pathologic AJCC stage of the tumor is classified as Stage IIIC, indicating significant local and regional spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma arising from a well-differentiated liposarcoma, with the dedifferentiated component constituting 80% of the tumor and classified as a high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma. The tumor measures at least 8.0 cm and envelops the external iliac vessels, extending to the surgical margins, while the testis appears unremarkable and three benign lymph nodes were identified. The final left external iliac artery margin shows well-differentiated liposarcoma with cautery artifact, indicating involvement of the surgical margins by the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium with more than 50% myometrial invasion, and the tumor is located in the lower uterine segment. While the cervix and parametrium are negative for malignancy, one out of ten right pelvic lymph nodes shows metastatic adenocarcinoma, while all other lymph nodes and the omental biopsy are negative for malignancy. The final staging is pT1bN1Mx, reflecting the presence of the tumor and limited lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, measuring 5.5 x 4.5 x 4.5 cm, with parietal invasion and areas of necrosis. There is evidence of lymphatic invasion, but no metastases were found in the examined lymph nodes. The tumor is relatively well-defined and infiltrates the fibro-muscular parietal layer, with no evidence of tumor infiltration into the osseous tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the left hepatic ligament biopsy revealed a benign simple cyst and benign hepatic parenchyma, with no malignancy detected. The gallbladder and hepatic artery lymph node biopsies were also negative for malignancy, while the Whipple resection of the pancreas showed poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with extensive local invasion and metastasis to 11 of 21 peripancreatic lymph nodes, classified as stage IIB. The portal vein segment re-excision was negative for malignancy, confirming the absence of distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of residual intermediate-grade leiomyosarcoma in the right thigh following a wide excision. There are 12 mitoses per 10 high-power fields, but no necrosis is observed, and the resection margins are free of tumor. Additionally, there is evidence of scar tissue with skeletal muscle atrophy, fat necrosis, and a foreign body giant cell reaction at the previous surgical site.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two synchronous primary pulmonary adenocarcinomas in the left lower lobe, measuring 2.7 cm and 1.4 cm, with the larger tumor being poorly differentiated and the smaller tumor moderately differentiated. Both tumors are negative for lymphatic invasion, and all nineteen examined lymph nodes are benign, resulting in a pathologic stage of IA with clear margins (R0). Additionally, there is a single focus of large vessel invasion noted, but the pleura remains uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the sigmoid colon, measuring 3 cm in length and 4 cm in width, with invasion into the subserosal adipose tissue. Lymphovascular and perineural invasion are identified, with metastasis found in 3 out of 108 examined lymph nodes, leading to a staging of pT3 and N1b according to AJCC 7th Edition. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and additional findings include tubular adenomas and extensive melanosis coli in the non-neoplastic bowel.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a large, poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, with tumor extension to the pleura and involvement of nearby lymph nodes. The tumor measures up to 9 cm and shows signs of necrosis and chronic inflammation, but the bronchus resection margin and all examined lymph nodes are tumor-free. The TNM classification is pT2 pNO pMX V1 RX, indicating stage IB disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Type A Thymoma, measuring 4.0 x 3.6 x 1.5 cm, with focal infiltration of the capsule and surrounding fat tissue. The tumor is classified as pT2, pNx (0/5) and is staged as Masaoka II.2. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive staining for CK5/6 and KL1 in epithelial cells, while several other markers, including CD1a and CD5, are negative, with some immature T-lymphocytes present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant mixed mesodermal tumor (MMMT) involving the uterus, bilateral tubes, and ovaries, with extensive invasion into the endometrial cavity and surrounding structures, including the serosa and lymphovascular spaces. The tumor measures 16.0 x 15.0 x 10.0 cm and shows involvement of the left parametrium, omentum, and right ovary, with additional findings of surface involvement and dysplasia in the right fallopian tube. Additionally, fragments from a cervical vaginal tumor reveal infiltration by the same malignant mixed mesodermal tumor, with the margins of excision being unassessable due to fragmentation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon, classified as G2 and pT3. The tumor was resected with tumor-free margins, and there is infiltration into the perimuscular fatty tissue. Importantly, there are no local lymph node metastases, with a total of 34 lymph nodes examined showing no evidence of cancer spread (pN0).

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical hysterectomy due to cervical cancer, specifically a well-differentiated endocervical adenocarcinoma measuring 3.6 cm with a maximum depth of invasion of 7 mm, but with negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion. The right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes showed no evidence of malignancy, and all examined lymph nodes (17 total) were negative for cancer. The overall pathologic staging is pT1b1, indicating a clinically visible lesion less than 4 cm in greatest dimension, with no regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade (III) primary uterine adenocarcinoma, predominantly of the papillary serous type, with a small component of clear cell carcinoma, which partially replaces two large endometrial polyps and involves the endometrium and myometrium. There is evidence of lymphovascular invasion and a microscopic focus of metastatic carcinoma in the left parametrium, but the cervix and vaginal cuff are free of tumor, and no metastatic carcinoma is found in the ovaries or fallopian tubes. Additional findings include several smaller endometrial polyps, adenomyosis, and various benign changes in the cervix and ovaries, with reactive lymph nodes showing no evidence of metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive colonic adenocarcinoma measuring 3 cm in the sigmoid colon, with evidence of presumed angiolymphatic invasion. Two out of twelve regional lymph nodes examined show metastatic involvement, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 0.4 cm, while all surgical resection margins are reported as benign. Additionally, a small tubular adenoma is noted, and the tumor is staged as pT2 N1 MX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately invasive adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, with evidence of fat invasion and perineural and vascular invasion. The pancreatic resection margin is positive for carcinoma, while the bile duct margin and portal vein biopsy are negative for malignancy. Additionally, the gallbladder and bile duct margins are unremarkable, and there is no normal pancreatic tissue present in the biopsy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade myxofibrosarcoma in the right chest wall, measuring 5.5 x 4.7 x 3.0 cm, with approximately 90% of the tumor being myxoid and 5% necrotic, while the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, a hemangioma was completely excised from the skin of the right chest. The report confirms that no glandular breast parenchyma was identified in the examined specimens.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 8x7x6 cm, with one of four hilar lymph nodes showing metastasis. Additionally, the right middle lobe lesion is identified as a calcified necrotizing granuloma, with negative AFB and GMS stains. The final pathologic stage is amended to pT2N2Mx, reflecting the findings of lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 1.5 cm, with a Nottingham grade of 2 and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising 6% of the tumor volume. The tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, with a HER-2/neu score of 2+, but no amplification of the HER-2/neu gene was detected. Additionally, one of two examined sentinel lymph nodes was positive for metastatic carcinoma, indicating lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV, in the right kidney, where the tumor measures 7.5 cm and extends through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia, with evidence of renal vein invasion. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney shows patchy chronic inflammation. Additionally, the right para-caval lymph node biopsy reveals a benign lymph node with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade II astrocytoma located in the left temporal region of a male patient. This tumor is classified as a low-grade glioma according to the World Health Organization (WHO) grading system. Further clinical correlation and management are recommended based on this diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of locally advanced, poorly differentiated nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, primarily located in segment 2, with a TNM classification of pT4 pNO pMX R1, IIIB. The tumor has extended to the adherent part of the parietal pleura and surrounding soft tissue, with extensive necrosis and chronic inflammation noted in the pleural tissue. Although the resection margins of the bronchus, vessels, and excised lymph nodes are tumor-free, the presence of tumor at the resection surface of the pleura categorizes it as R1, indicating incomplete resection.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5). There is evidence of extra-prostatic extension and involved surgical margins, specifically on the anterior left side, but no seminal vesicle invasion was noted. The pathological staging is classified as pT3a, with no lymph nodes submitted for evaluation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), confined to the prostate, with negative margins and no seminal vesicle invasion. Multiple biopsies from various regions of the prostate showed fibromuscular tissue and nerve without any carcinoma identified, while 21 pelvic lymph nodes were negative for metastatic carcinoma. The report also notes the presence of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates a clinical diagnosis of a brain tumor. The gross examination revealed dense-elastic pieces of grayish-brownish brain tissue from the left temporal lobe. Microscopic analysis confirmed the presence of anaplastic astrocytoma, Grade III.

The pathology report indicates a right testicular mass diagnosed as a seminoma, with a tumor size of 5.5 x 4.5 x 3.5 cm, and no evidence of intratubular germ cell neoplasia. The tumor is confined to the testis and does not involve surrounding structures, with a negative spermatic cord margin. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT1aNXMX (Stage I), and lymphovascular invasion is not identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a pheochromocytoma in the left adrenal gland, characterized by a tumor with polygonal cells, hyperchromatic nuclei, and lymphatic invasion. The right adrenal gland shows normal adrenal tissue with no evidence of hyperplasia. Additionally, a separate report confirms a diagnosis of lymph node metastasis following initial surgery.

The pathology report indicates a high-grade urothelial carcinoma of the bladder measuring 6.2 cm, which is ulcerated and infiltrative, affecting all layers of the bladder and surrounding fat, but with no involvement of the prostate or other nearby structures. Additionally, there is a small acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate measuring 0.5 cm with a Gleason score of 6, and all surgical margins and lymph nodes examined are free of neoplastic involvement. The pathological staging is classified as pT3 for the bladder cancer, indicating advanced local disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a large, mixed, highly mucinous adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, predominantly of the bronchiolo-alveolar mucinous type, with additional acinar and solid components. The tumor is classified as pT2 pNO R0, corresponding to stage IB, and there is no infiltration of the visceral pleura. All resection margins and lymph nodes examined are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 5.0 cm invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma at the esophagogastric junction, with angiolymphatic invasion noted but no perineural invasion. Out of 35 examined lymph nodes, one was positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the remaining nodes were benign and negative for tumor. Surgical margins were free of tumor, and additional findings included Barrett's esophagus with low-grade dysplasia and chronic inflammation in gastric tissue.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions, with a total of 25 nodes showing no malignancy. The prostate examination reveals adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 3 = 6, involving both lobes and showing focal extracapsular extension, but all surgical margins and seminal vesicles are free of carcinoma. The tumor is classified as pT3a, with extensive perineural invasion noted and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia present.

The final diagnosis from the pathology report indicates the presence of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) in the temporal tip and enhancing lesions, with some areas resembling lower-grade astrocytomas and oligodendroglial differentiation. The report notes necrosis and vascular proliferation consistent with glioblastoma multiforme, while fluorescence in situ hybridization shows intact chromosomes 1p and 19q. Multiple specimens were submitted for analysis, revealing irregular brain tissue with varying characteristics, and the case has been reviewed and certified by the interpreting pathologist.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an anaplastic oligodendroglioma, WHO grade III, confirmed through multiple biopsies and a resection of the left temporal lobe. The tumor exhibits extensive infiltration, mitotic activity, and microvascular proliferation, with additional immunohistochemical tests planned to further characterize the tumor. An addendum reveals that the tumor cells are positive for IDH1 (R132H mutant form) and negative for P53, with a low proliferative index of 5%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder and prostate, with invasion through the muscularis propria into the perivesicular fat and evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. Both the left and right distal ureters, as well as the urethral margin and pelvic lymph nodes, show no evidence of malignancy or dysplasia, with negative margins of excision. The appendix is unremarkable, and the prostate is uninvolved by carcinoma, showing only nodular hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates that a specimen was sent to the Biospecimen Core Resource (BCR) from NCH for analysis. It requires the completion of the TCGA Missing Pathology Report Form due to the absence of a detailed pathology report. Additionally, it requests the tumor type and relevant ICD-0-3 histology and site codes for proper classification.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of ulcerated epithelioid melanoma from the right hand of a male patient. The melanoma is classified as Clark level III, with a Breslow thickness of 3 mm, categorized as Stage 2B, Grade 3, T3, N0, M0. The final diagnosis confirms the presence of epithelioid melanoma.

The pathology report indicates that all examined sentinel lymph nodes (three in total) are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The segmental mastectomy of the right breast reveals invasive moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma measuring 2.5 cm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ, with tumor margins close to the anterior margin of excision. Additionally, benign fibrocystic changes and mild to moderate ductal hyperplasia are noted in the tissue medial to the segmental mastectomy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast following a segmental mastectomy, with a tumor size of 1.7 cm and an intermediate histologic and nuclear grade (Nottingham score 5). Estrogen and progesterone receptors are both positive (95% staining), while HER-2/neu is negative. The surgical margins are free of cancer, and additional findings include lymphocytic infiltration, microcalcifications, and proliferative fibrocystic changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 10.0 cm, with a composition of 70% clear cells and 30% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, and confined to the kidney without invasion into surrounding tissues. The adrenal gland and right gonadal vein show no evidence of tumor presence, and the margins of resection are free of tumor. The tumor is noted to be close to Gerota's fascia and the renal sinus but does not exhibit unequivocal invasion into these areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 4 fibrillary astrocytoma, also known as glioblastoma multiforme, located in the right frontal lobe of the brain. The tumor was measured at various dimensions, with the largest being 5.5 x 4.7 x 1.8 cm. A preliminary frozen section consultation suggested the presence of an intermediate to high-grade glioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of giant cell glioblastoma, WHO grade IV, from multiple biopsies of the right temporal brain region, with tumor cellularity consistently reported at 95%. Tumor necrosis varied across samples, ranging from 0% to 10%. The high percentage of tumor cells immunostaining for MGMT suggests a potentially diminished response to Temodar treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) based on the examination of brain tissue samples, which show characteristics of a high-grade malignant astrocytic neoplasm with significant cytologic pleomorphism, necrosis, and microvascular proliferation. Additional findings from fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis reveal polysomy of chromosome 7 and EGFR, loss of chromosome 10 centromere, and PTEN allelic loss in a majority of tumor cells, indicating a poor prognosis. Immunohistochemical analysis shows a high proliferation index and loss of PTEN, further supporting the aggressive nature of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a left brain mass was examined, revealing a diagnosis of Glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) from both specimens submitted. The frozen section analysis confirmed the presence of malignant glioma, and the specimens consisted of multiple pieces of soft tissue. The report emphasizes that the examination and diagnosis were performed by a qualified pathologist.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma, specifically the clear cell variant, with 90% tumor content. The tumor is classified as TX for pathological T and NX for pathological N, with clinical M indicating metastasis (M1). The patient has recurrent slow-growing lesions, and the cause of death is noted as congestive heart failure (CHF).

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.5 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). One of the sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla showed micrometastases, while the other two sentinel lymph nodes were negative for metastases. Surgical margins were negative for invasive tumor, but DCIS was found within 1 mm of the anterior inferior margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral papillary serous adenocarcinoma involving both ovaries and fallopian tubes, with extensive metastatic spread to various soft tissue sites including the omentum, sigmoid mesentery, and pelvic region. The tumor is characterized as poorly differentiated with a high mitotic rate and significant lymphatic involvement, while the endometrium and cervix show no histopathologic abnormalities. The final AJCC/FIGO stage of the cancer is not evaluable due to the absence of regional lymph node examination.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of stomach adenocarcinoma (G3, pT2, pNO) following a total organ resection due to suspicion of cancer of the cardia. The tumor, measuring 12.8 x 11.7 x 2.9 cm, infiltrated the entire thickness of the stomach wall and surrounding fat tissue, but the excision margins, omentum, and lymph nodes were free of neoplastic lesions. Additionally, the spleen and pancreas were also found to be free of cancer.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenal tumor was excised and diagnosed as a pheochromocytoma, confirmed by positive staining for chromogranin and synaptophysin. The specimen measured 7.5 x 5.5 x 5.2 cm and contained a heterogeneous hemorrhagic mass, with additional normal adrenal tissue observed. The laboratory performing the tests is certified under CLIA, and the diagnostic methods used have not been FDA cleared or approved, but are deemed necessary for the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the left lobe of the thyroid contains a papillary thyroid carcinoma, follicular variant, with focal involvement of the inked margin and invasion into surrounding soft tissue, including thyroid cartilage. The right lobe of the thyroid and other excised tissues, including lymph nodes and paralaryngeal tissue, show no evidence of malignancy. Overall, the findings suggest a localized papillary thyroid carcinoma with no lymphatic or vascular invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cecum, measuring 4.5 x 3.2 cm, with invasion into the superficial muscularis propria. Surgical resection margins are negative for tumor, and all sixteen examined pericolic lymph nodes are also negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, two hyperplastic polyps were identified in the colon, and the vermiform appendix showed no evidence of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from the right temporal brain tumor is diagnosed as glioblastoma, characterized by a hypercellular glial neoplasm with atypical fibrillary astrocytes, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis. The tumor cells show patchy positivity for MGMT, with expression observed in more than 50% of the tumor cells. The overall cellularity of the tumor is estimated to be between 50-75%.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an extended moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, which has infiltrated the duodenal wall and is present in the resected loop of the small intestine, with involvement at the medial resection margin of the Whipple specimen. No lymph node metastasis was detected, and the gall bladder showed signs of acute abscessing cholecystitis without tumor presence. The report concludes with a TNM classification of pT4, pNO (0/21), and a grading of G2, indicating a positive but incomplete resection status (R1).

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the cecum, arising from a tubulovillous adenoma, with tumor infiltration into the muscularis layer and associated necrosis. There is significant chronic inflammation, including peritumoral inflammation, abscess formation, and chronic lymphadenitis in regional lymph nodes, but the resection margins are tumor-free. The tumor is classified as pT2, pN0, Mx, R0, with additional findings of chronic recurrent appendicitis and periappendicitis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional (clear cell) renal cell carcinoma from a partial nephrectomy of the right kidney, with a tumor size of 1.9 cm and a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor, although the clearance from the resection margin is 0.2 cm. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report describes three specimens from breast surgeries: a superficial margin re-excision of the left breast, a simple mastectomy of the right breast, and a simple mastectomy of the left breast. The left breast re-excision shows fibroadipose tissue with no evidence of neoplasm, while the right breast mastectomy reveals fibrocystic disease without malignancy. The left breast mastectomy, however, shows moderately differentiated intraductal and infiltrating duct carcinoma, measuring 4.5 cm, with suspicious foci for lymphatic invasion, but the margins are free of neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3). The tumor is confined to the prostate without extraprostatic extension, but there is metastasis in 1 out of 3 examined lymph nodes. The final classification is pT2N1, confirming the presence of cancer within the prostate and lymphatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma in the thyroid, with the dominant tumor being a follicular variant that is angioinvasive and widely invasive, measuring 5.4 cm, and showing focal dedifferentiation in less than 10% of the tumor. The report also notes the presence of additional smaller papillary microcarcinomas and confirms that there is no regional lymph node metastasis. Overall, the tumor is classified as pT3, indicating it is more than 4 cm in size but limited to the thyroid with minimal extrathyroidal extension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lateral liver, with a tumor mass measuring 4 x 3 x 3 cm. Surgical margins are clear of tumor by 5.0 cm, suggesting successful resection. Additionally, there is evidence of grade 1 chronic hepatitis and minimal periportal fibrosis, along with vascular invasion noted in the tumor sections.

The pathology report describes a 5x3x1 cm ulcerated mass located in the left heel skin, diagnosed as malignant melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 10 mm. Microscopic examination reveals necrotic epidermis and tumor cells arranged in sheets or nests, characterized by low nucleo-cytoplasmic ratios and the presence of melanin pigment. No metastasis was found in the examined lymph nodes, and the tumor is classified as poorly differentiated.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the urinary bladder, measuring 5.5 cm, with invasion into the perivesical adipose tissue but no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. Biopsies of the left and right distal ureters and pelvic lymph nodes show benign urothelial mucosa with no evidence of neoplasia, indicating no metastatic disease. The prostate exhibits high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia but no invasive carcinoma, and all surgical margins are free of invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma involving the left spermatic cord and left testis, characterized by two nodules measuring 4.5 x 3.5 x 2.0 cm and 3.5 x 2.8 x 1.5 cm, with evidence of vascular invasion and 15% necrosis. The tumor is noted to wrap around the spermatic cord and invade surrounding adipose tissue and skeletal muscle, while the spermatic cord margin is free of tumor, and the testis appears unremarkable. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of primary leiomyosarcoma, with no well-differentiated liposarcoma component identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, papillary type II, with a tumor size of 8.7 cm and extension into the pelvic fat, classified as pT3a NX MX. Surgical margins are free of malignancy, and there is no evidence of perineural or angiolymphatic invasion. The tumor exhibits a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of G3, with less than 10% necrosis and no sarcomatoid features identified.

The pathology report indicates that the right frontal tumor is diagnosed as anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade 3, with evidence of diffuse infiltration into both white and gray matter. Microscopic examination reveals areas of low-grade features alongside highly cellular regions with abnormal mitoses and marked nuclear pleomorphism, while the right frontal pole shows no tumor presence. Additional studies, including molecular testing, are ongoing to further characterize the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of FIGO grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, forming a mass in the lower uterine segment that invades the myometrial wall but does not extend to the uterine serosa. All examined lymph nodes, including those from the pelvic and para-aortic regions, as well as the gonadal vessels and omentum, are negative for malignancy. The report confirms that the ectocervical margin is negative for malignancy, with tumor infiltration noted in the cervical stroma beneath the transformation zone mucosa.

The pathology report indicates the presence of micrometastatic carcinoma in one of six examined lymph nodes from the right axilla, with a metastatic deposit size of 1.25 mm. The right lumpectomy reveals an invasive, poorly differentiated ductal carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and close proximity to the inferior margin. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the tumor cells are negative for ER, PR, and Her-2, suggesting a basal subtype of mammary carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left adrenalectomy, revealing a low-grade adrenocortical carcinoma with capsular invasion, but no vascular invasion was identified. The tumor measured 8 x 7 x 4 cm and appeared homogeneous and tan, arising from the adrenal cortex. Additional sections were examined to further assess the tumor characteristics, particularly regarding vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix (pT1b1) with a 2.3 x 1.4 x 0.5 cm mass primarily involving the posterior cervix, and metastatic involvement in the right common iliac lymph node. The right pelvic, precaval, right periaortic, left pelvic, and left upper common and periaortic lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. Surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, with the closest margin being 21 mm from the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma with focal sarcomatoid differentiation, which has invaded through the bladder wall and into the perivesical fat, measuring 5 cm in size. All examined lymph nodes (40 total) and distal ureter specimens were negative for tumor, and the distal urethra margin was also free of tumor. Additionally, the prostate showed high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and chronic active inflammation, but no invasive cancer was identified in the prostate.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of advanced gastric carcinoma, specifically a moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma of intestinal type, located in the lower third of the stomach with a size of 8.7x8.0 cm and a Borrmann type 2 gross appearance. The tumor invades the subserosa (pT3) but shows no metastasis in 27 examined regional lymph nodes, and the resection margins are free from carcinoma. Mild venous invasion is present, while lymphatic and perineural invasions are not identified.

The pathology report describes an invasive, low-grade infiltrating urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 2.5x2x2 cm, with soft, gray surfaces and ill-defined margins. Microscopic examination reveals hyperplastic transitional cells with moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm, enlarged nuclei, and irregular nuclear features, indicating tumor invasion into the superficial muscularis propria. The tumor is moderately differentiated, with no evidence of lymphatic invasion and uninvolved margins.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal Type I Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma, which is moderately differentiated. The tumor is classified as stage pT1a and is reported as completely resected (RO). The tumor grade is GII, with an ICD-0 code of 8260/3.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated, nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma located in the left lower pulmonary lobe, with a maximum size of 5.7 cm and associated necrosis. Lymph nodes show reactive lesions and anthracotic pigment deposits, with one subpleural node in S8 being metastatically involved, leading to a classification of pN1. Additionally, a pleural effusion was analyzed, revealing no malignant cells, only degeneratively changed mesothelial cells and an accumulation of leukocytes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a tumor size of 1x2x2 cm. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/9 positive). Additional details regarding tumor extent, lymphatic and venous invasion, margins, and neo-adjuvant treatment are not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated gastric adenocarcinoma in a remnant gastrectomy specimen, with tumor involvement in the pylorus and duodenum, measuring 5.4 cm in length and 2.5 cm in width. There is evidence of vascular and perineural invasion, but no regional lymph node metastasis was found in the examined lymph nodes, and all surgical margins are free of carcinoma. The tumor is staged as pT3, indicating it has penetrated the subserosal connective tissue without invading the peritoneum or adjacent structures.

The pathology report indicates that the right distal ureter margin biopsy is negative for tumor, while the left distal ureter margin shows focal urothelial atypia suspicious for carcinoma in situ. A radical cystoprostatectomy reveals invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with lymphovascular invasion and metastasis identified in some lymph nodes, while all surgical margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, a separate focus of prostatic urethral urothelial carcinoma is noted, with benign findings in other lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinomas: one in the colon with a maximum size of 3 cm, infiltrating pericolic fatty tissue and associated with seven regional lymph node metastases, and another at the cecum, arising from a tubular adenoma with high-grade dysplasia, which has not metastasized. The first tumor is staged as pT3 pN2 with local resection margins free of tumor, while the second tumor is staged as pT1 pN0, also with clear resection margins. Overall, the report highlights the presence of significant disease in the first tumor and a localized, non-metastatic tumor in the second.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary serous adenocarcinoma in the uterus with less than 50% myometrial invasion, alongside multiple leiomyomas, and lymphovascular invasion present. All examined lymph nodes from the para-aortic and pelvic regions, as well as the omentum biopsy, were negative for carcinoma. Additional findings include chronic cervicitis and a paratubal cyst in the left fallopian tube, with immunohistochemical studies showing negative estrogen and progesterone receptor staining, and positive P53 staining in the neoplastic cells.

The pathology report indicates a resection of the sigmoid colon showing diverticulosis and an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that has infiltrated the perimuscular fatty tissue. The resection margins are tumor-free, and all thirty-seven examined regional lymph nodes are also tumor-free, indicating no lymphatic spread. The tumor is classified as pT3 pN0 (0/37), with no vascular invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. Microscopic examination reveals sheets of enlarged, pleomorphic cells with abundant mitotic figures, apoptotic bodies, and areas of necrosis, along with focal keratinization. The patient is a woman with a history of high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) and severe dysplasia.

The pathology report indicates that the right medial margin of the tongue biopsy shows squamous mucosa with verruciform hyperplasia, while other margins and deep margins are benign with no evidence of dysplasia or carcinoma. A hemiglossectomy revealed a well-differentiated invasive keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.9 cm, with negative lymph nodes and no angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. The overall assessment suggests a pT1 pNO stage, with clear surgical margins and no significant abnormalities in the lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a paraaortic paraganglioma, a type of neuroendocrine tumor, measuring 6.0 cm, which was surgically resected. The tumor was well-encapsulated and showed a homogeneous fleshy pink-tan cut surface, with representative sections submitted for further analysis. Immunoperoxidase and in-situ hybridization tests were performed for diagnosis, although these methods have not been cleared or approved by the FDA.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated, invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. The biopsy specimen consisted of two fragments of tan-pink tissue measuring between 0.3 cm and 0.5 cm. The clinical context notes that the patient is a female with clinical stage III-b cervical cancer.

The pathology report describes a 55x45x35 mm pheochromocytoma tumor that is thinly encapsulated, grey-red in color, and exhibits focal hemorrhages. Microscopic examination confirms the diagnosis with features such as nuclear hyperchromasia, absence of necrosis, and weak to moderate positivity for S100 protein in tumor cells, while showing no invasion into surrounding tissues. The tumor is classified as PASS, indicating a low risk of aggressive behavior, with MIB-1 labeling index showing less than 1% positive cells.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor involvement, while the left breast biopsy reveals a 4 cm invasive ductal carcinoma (grade 2) with a positive anterior margin and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of low to intermediate nuclear grade. The invasive tumor has negative lymphatic and perineural invasion, and the resection margins for the invasive tumor are mostly negative except for the anterior margin. Overall, the lymph node status is negative, and the tumor staging is classified as pT2N0MX.

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy of the left upper lobe revealed a mixed acinar and bronchioloalveolar adenocarcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with moderate to poor differentiation. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in one of two resected lymph nodes, while the remaining lymph nodes and associated fibroadipose tissue were negative for tumor. Additionally, KRAS mutation analysis was positive, indicating a mutation in either codon 12 or 13 of the KRAS gene.

The pathology report describes two brain tumor specimens, both diagnosed as anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III). The first specimen is a 7 x 6.5 x 3 cm fragment exhibiting malignant glial neoplasm characteristics, with some areas suggesting oligodendroglial differentiation. The second specimen consists of two irregular fragments of soft pink tissue, also consistent with anaplastic astrocytoma, and no frank necrosis is observed in either sample.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the cervix, measuring 5 cm and invading 5 mm into the cervical tissue, with notable vascular space invasion. No tumors were identified in the uterus, vagina, parametrial tissues, or in any of the 22 examined regional lymph nodes, indicating no metastasis. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IB, suggesting it is confined to the uterus but larger than T1a2/IA2.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an adenocarcinoma arising at the gastroesophageal junction, with the tumor extending through the muscularis propria and being close to the surgical margins. One of four examined periesophageal lymph nodes shows metastatic involvement, and angiolymphatic invasion is noted. The TNM classification is T3 N1 Mx, indicating advanced local disease with lymph node involvement but unknown distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing established extracapsular extension. A radical prostatectomy was performed, and all examined surgical margins and lymph nodes were free of carcinoma, with extensive perineural invasion noted. The final pathologic stage is pT3a, with no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of melanoma in a primary skin tumor specimen from a Caucasian male. The tumor is classified as grade 4 with no evidence of regional lymph node (N0) or distant metastasis (M0), resulting in a TNM stage of T4 N0 M0. Additionally, a blood specimen was collected, which is reported as normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma (4.7 cm) of the uterus, classified as FIGO grade 3, with superficial myometrial invasion and extensive necrosis, while the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are benign. All examined lymph nodes (left pelvic, right pelvic, and periaortic) are reported as benign with no evidence of metastasis. Surgical margins and the uterine cervix are negative for involvement, and additional findings include complex hyperplasia and negative peritoneal cytology.

The pathology report indicates an excised skin tumor measuring 2.5x2x1 cm, diagnosed as a moderately differentiated nodular melanoma with an IV level of invasion. Lymphatic invasion is present, but details regarding lymph nodes, venous invasion, and margins are not specified. Additionally, there is a moderate inflammatory reaction noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bilateral prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 8/10, characterized by significant lymphovascular and perineural invasion, as well as extensive capsular penetration. The largest tumor nodule measures 4.5 x 3.0 x 2.0 cm, and there is a positive right posterior lateral margin, while four excised pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3aNOMX.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies of the right and left pelvic lymph nodes, as well as the periprostatic fat and bladder neck margin, showed no evidence of tumor. However, the prostate and seminal vesicles revealed multifocal prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+5=9, indicating aggressive cancer that invades the left seminal vesicle and has soft tissue extension on the left side. The surgical margins are reported to be free of tumor, suggesting successful removal of cancerous tissue from the margins.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a grade 3 mucinous adenocarcinoma of the stomach, characterized by infiltration of the entire gastric wall and involvement of the greater and lesser omentum.
