The tumor measures 10 x 11 x 2 cm, with the distal surgical margin showing tumor infiltration, while the proximal margin is free of cancer. Additionally, there are metastases identified in the lymph nodes (XI/XII), classified as pT3 and pN2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade I, with invasion limited to less than half of the myometrium and vascular invasion present. All examined lymph nodes from various regions, including external iliac, hypogastric, obturator, common iliac, and para-aortic, were found to be benign with no evidence of metastatic disease. Additional findings include endosalpingiosis in the right ovary and left fallopian tube, as well as adenomyosis and leiomyomas in the myometrium.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 1.8 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2. The tumor is classified as pT1, limited to the kidney, but has a positive margin status (R1) as it extends focally to the renal parenchymal margin, with no lymphovascular invasion identified. The overall pathologic stage is I, and there is no evidence of regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the left neck level II lymph node specimen showed no pathologic changes, and all biopsies from the oral cavity, including the left palate, left tongue base, and deep margin of the tongue, were negative for tumor. However, a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma was made from the left tongue, with a maximum tumor diameter of 4.9 cm, extensive perineural invasion, and the tumor being close to the deep medial soft tissue margin. Additionally, 25 lymph nodes from the left neck contents were negative for tumor, and the submandibular gland showed extensive atrophy consistent with prior radiotherapy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 2, with a mass measuring 2.5 x 2.1 x 1.0 cm and associated ductal carcinoma in situ. Angiovascular invasion is noted, but after re-excision, all margins are negative by at least 1.0 cm. Additionally, two out of five sentinel lymph nodes are positive for metastatic breast carcinoma, while seven other right axillary lymph nodes are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach with an intestinal pattern, measuring 8.6 cm, and showing angiolymphatic invasion, but no perineural invasion. Neoplastic involvement is noted in several lymph nodes, with 4 out of 19 and 3 out of 27 lymph nodes from the greater and lesser curvature respectively, as well as 2 out of 3 lymph nodes from chain 12A. The surgical margins and esophageal margin are uninvolved by neoplasia, and the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis.

The pathology report describes a surgical tumor specimen from the tongue, revealing a 3-cm superficially ulcerated, poorly differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma with minimal distances to resection margins. Microscopic examination shows extensive atypical squamous epithelium with irregular cell configurations and significant pleomorphism, surrounded by a desmoplastic stroma and a mixed inflammatory infiltrate, but no evidence of angioinvasion or perineural infiltration. Additionally, tumor-free tissue was identified with hyperparakeratosis and low-grade chronic inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate, with a maximum tumor spread of 2.6 cm and extensive perineural infiltration, as well as infiltration of the left seminal vesicle and surgical margins. The tumor classification is pT3b, Gleason score 5+4=9, with no evidence of vascular invasion or lymph node metastases found in the examined fatty tissue. Additional immunohistological studies are planned to further investigate chromatin expression and ensure comprehensive assessment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of unifocal papillary adenocarcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 0.8 cm, following a total thyroidectomy. All examined lymph nodes are negative for tumor, and the tumor is classified as pT1 with uninvolved margins and no evidence of vascular invasion. Additional findings include thyroiditis and a 0.7 cm adenomatoid nodule, along with intraparenchymal parathyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, Fuhrman grade 2, with a tumor measuring 12 cm in greatest diameter. There is no evidence of tumor invasion into the capsule or surrounding adipose tissue, and both the ureter and vascular margins are free of tumor. The adrenal gland is noted to be benign, and the provisional pathologic stage is pT2, NX, MX, indicating stage II disease.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in the pretracheal and superior mediastinal lymph nodes, with two out of three lymph nodes affected. The total thyroidectomy revealed four foci of well-differentiated papillary thyroid carcinoma, including follicular and microcarcinoma variants, with one microcarcinoma exhibiting tall cell features and some extra-thyroid invasion. Additionally, the Delphian node and right paratrachael node showed metastatic involvement, with no extranodal extension identified in the metastatic lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph node biopsies from both periaortic and pelvic regions show no evidence of malignancy, except for a small focus of metastatic adenocarcinoma in one of the right pelvic lymph nodes. The hysterectomy specimen reveals endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation, classified as FIGO stage IIIC1, with myometrial invasion and lymphovascular space invasion present. Additional findings include adenomyosis and leiomyomas in the myometrium, while the ovaries and fallopian tubes show no atypia or malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated Type II Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma. The tumor is classified as stage pT2 with no regional lymph node involvement (pNX) and no distant metastasis (pMX), and it is graded as GIII. The ICD-0 code for this diagnosis is 8260/3.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma grade 2 in the left breast, measuring 2.8 x 3.5 x 3.0 cm, with no vascular invasion noted. Additionally, four out of fourteen axillary lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma. The specimen included the left breast and left axillary contents, with the tumor located in the outer quadrants of the breast.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with invasion depth of 0.9 cm and clear margins following a radical hysterectomy. Additional findings include proliferative endometrium, adenomyosis, endosalpingiosis, and serosal surface adhesions, with one lymph node showing no evidence of malignancy. Multiple lymph nodes excised from both sides, including external iliac and obturator nodes, as well as periaortic nodes, also showed no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, in the right breast, measuring 2.2 x 1.6 x 1.6 cm, with no ductal carcinoma in situ or angiolymphatic invasion present. All surgical margins are negative for tumor, and five right axillary sentinel lymph nodes show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. Immunohistochemical staining has been performed, and Her-2/NEU testing is pending.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a male with a right pleural effusion, has been diagnosed with malignant mesothelioma of the biphasic type, comprising 20% epithelioid and 80% sarcomatoid components. Immunohistochemical staining supports this diagnosis, showing positive results for CK7, WT1 (focal), and calretinin (focal). Both frozen section and permanent diagnoses confirm the presence of mesothelioma in the right pleura biopsy specimens.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, classical variant, with extranodal extension in the right jugular lymph node and multiple lymph nodes in the right posterior triangle. The total thyroidectomy revealed multifocal papillary carcinoma, with the dominant tumor measuring 2.3 cm and a second tumor measuring 0.6 cm, both located in the right lobe. Additional findings include no pathological diagnosis in several parathyroid and thymus specimens, and the presence of two papillary microcarcinomas in the isthmus.

The pathology report indicates a left thigh tumor diagnosed as a pleomorphic, high-grade spindle and giant cell leiomyosarcoma measuring 15 cm, with the tumor margins being less than 1 mm from both the superficial and deep margins. Immunohistochemical studies confirm the diagnosis, showing strong positivity for smooth muscle actin and Vimentin. Cytogenetic analysis reveals a highly complex abnormal male karyotype with significant chromosomal rearrangements and double minutes present in the tumor cells.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma of the epithelioid subtype in the parietal pleura. Microscopic examination reveals malignant cells with distinct histological features, including large irregular nuclei and a background of fibrous stroma, along with positive immunohistochemical staining for CK5/6 and HBME1. The specimen consists of multiple irregular tissue pieces with firm thickened nodules, and no intracytoplasmic mucin was detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of astrocytic differentiation with detectable single mitoses and a proliferation rate of up to 7%. The tumor exhibits foci of increased cellularity and mitotic activity, leading to a classification of grade III according to WHO standards. The final diagnosis is anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade III.

The pathology report indicates that the right parietal brain lesion is diagnosed as Glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) based on both biopsy and excision specimens. The tumor exhibits dense cellularity, extensive necrosis, and a significant inflammatory response, with notable nuclear pleomorphism and a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 25%. Immunohistochemical staining shows strong positivity for GFAP, S100, and CD56 in the neoplastic cells, while the tumor is negative for pancytokeratin and cytokeratin AE1/AE3.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with the tumor measuring 7.2 cm and classified as grade G4. The tumor is confined to the kidney (pT2), with no evidence of invasion into the adrenal gland or surrounding tissues, and margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. There are no submitted lymph nodes for assessment, and distant metastasis cannot be evaluated.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma in the left ovary and metastatic papillary serous adenocarcinoma in the left fallopian tube and omentum. The right ovary and fallopian tube show no significant abnormalities, while the uterus exhibits cystic changes and leiomyomas. The tumor is classified as FIGO grade II and shows invasion of the mesovarium and adjacent fallopian tube, with metastatic involvement of the omentum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type, measuring 7 cm, located above the dentate line, with infiltration into the perirectal fatty tissue and one regional lymph node metastasis. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN1 (1/24) pMX, with a minimum distance of 0.6 cm from the circumferential resection margin, while the oral and aboral amputation margins are tumor-free. The report also notes that the mesenteric resection margin is tumor-free, and the tumor characteristics include G2, L1, V0, and locally R0.

The pathology report indicates that a right hemimandibulectomy was performed, revealing an invasive well-differentiated squamous carcinoma with free margins, suggesting no residual tumor at the surgical edges. The specimen measured 15.0 x 2.5 x 1.5 cm, with an associated ulcerated and necrotic lesion measuring 2.5 x 1.0 x 1.0 cm within the soft tissue. Decalcification of the mandibular bone showed involvement of the cortical bone by the carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, with oncocytic features in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 3 cm in greatest diameter. The tumor is well differentiated, completely encapsulated, and shows two foci of vascular invasion, but no capsular invasion or extrathyroid extension. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic thyroid exhibits nodular hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive mucinous adenocarcinoma (2.5 cm) in the right upper lobe of the lung, with clear margins and no residual tumor following a completion lobectomy. All examined lymph nodes (levels 4, 7, and 10) were negative for carcinoma, confirming no regional lymph node metastasis. Molecular studies revealed a positive KRAS mutation (p.G12C), while no EGFR mutations were detected, suggesting a poor prognosis and potential resistance to certain therapies.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach measuring 12 x 7 cm, with significant features including whole wall invasion, superficial ulceration, and the presence of signet ring cells. Out of 15 examined lymph nodes, 9 showed metastases, and there is evidence of perigastric fat invasion and perineural invasion. The tumor is located in the fundus of the stomach, and the margins are uninvolved with no venous invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates that both the right and left ureter biopsies are benign with no dysplasia or carcinoma. However, the cystoprostatectomy reveals invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation in the bladder (Stage T2) and invasive urothelial carcinoma in the prostatic urethra (Stage T1), with metastatic carcinoma found in three of four right external iliac lymph nodes. The left pelvic lymph nodes and other examined lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a left nephrectomy revealing a Grade 4 renal cell carcinoma with clear cell type and sarcomatoid features, forming a mass in the inferior pole of the kidney. The tumor measures 4.0 x 3.8 x 2.8 cm, extends into the pelvic fat, but does not involve the renal vein or collecting system, and surgical margins are negative for tumor. Coagulative tumor necrosis is present, and no renal hilar lymph nodes were identified, with the adrenal gland absent.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type) in the right lower pole tumor, measuring 4.7 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2 and tumor present at the margin of resection. The tumor is encapsulated and bulges into adjacent perinephric adipose tissue without gross infiltration, and there is no evidence of tumor in the perinephric fat or the 11th rib specimen. The findings suggest that while the tumor is at the inked margin, it does not invade surrounding adipose tissue or the renal sinus adipose tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma located in the bladder, with a tumor size of 6.3 x 5.1 cm and no evidence of carcinoma in 85 regional lymph nodes. Additionally, prostatic adenocarcinoma was identified with a Gleason score of 7, confined to the prostate but with a positive peripheral margin. Overall, the findings suggest significant malignancy in the bladder while the lymphatic spread appears absent.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two foci of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lung, with the hilar tumor measuring 3.1 cm and the apical tumor measuring 4.2 cm. There is extensive lymphovascular invasion, and four out of six sampled parabronchial lymph nodes are positive for metastatic squamous cell carcinoma. The bronchial and vascular margins are negative for carcinoma, and there is evidence of pleural invasion, but the overall specimen integrity is intact.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO Grade III endometrial adenocarcinoma of the indomestrioid type, with myometrial invasion measuring 9 mm and no cervical or vascular invasion identified. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from the left and right external iliac, left obturator, right obturator, and right common iliac regions were benign, with no evidence of metastatic disease. The abdominal pannus and omentum also showed unremarkable findings, with benign adipose tissue noted.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary contains a mature cystic teratoma with no evidence of adenocarcinoma, while the left uterus shows moderately differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (grade 2) involving 90% of the endometrial surface and penetrating 80% of the myometrial thickness. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from both pelvic and periaortic regions are free of tumor, confirming no lymphatic spread. The endometrial adenocarcinoma is classified as FIGO stage 1C, with associated findings of atypical complex hyperplasia and adenomyosis.

The pathology report indicates a left enucleated globe with a choroidal melanoma measuring 17.7 x 17.3 mm and a thickness of 8.1 mm, characterized as a mixed cell type with minimal epithelioid cell component. Microscopic examination reveals a partially pigmented melanoma with focal infiltration into the adjacent sclera, but no evidence of necrosis or extension through the optic nerve or vortex veins. The diagnosis confirms choroidal melanoma with focal scleral infiltration, and the tumor shows a low mitotic frequency and minimal lymphocytic infiltrate.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal breast carcinoma with a maximum diameter of 3 cm and a grade III malignancy, showing lymph vessel invasion and an invasive satellite node. The remaining breast tissue is in involution with no calcifications or ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) formation, and the nipple is tumor-free with wide safety margins. Tumor classification is pT2m pN2a (4/15), MX, R0; G3 (L1, V0).

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the cervix reveals poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma. This diagnosis suggests an aggressive form of cancer originating from the cervical tissue. Further evaluation and treatment options will be necessary to address the condition.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the liver's anterior segment showed no carcinoma, while a biopsy of the posterior segment was positive for adenocarcinoma, consistent with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma. A partial hepatectomy revealed a unifocal tumor measuring 6.2 cm with vascular invasion into portal vein branches and the vena cava, and positive margins for carcinoma were noted. Immunohistochemical staining supported the diagnosis of intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma, and the overall AJCC staging was pT2a pNO, with no evidence of malignancy in the gallbladder or lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of an ulcerated gastric carcinoma located in the middle of the stomach, characterized as a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the intestinal type, with a maximum diameter of 8 cm and invasive spread to the serosa and perigastric fatty tissue. The tumor is staged as pT2b pN2, with 14 out of 16 lymph nodes showing metastases. Additionally, there are findings of low to medium-grade chronic gastritis and intestinal metaplasia in the antrum, with no evidence of Helicobacter pylori.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a thymoma, classified as WHO type AB2, measuring 6.0 cm, with microscopic invasion of mediastinal fat but no invasion of pleura, pericardium, or lung. Additionally, a benign cyst was identified in the soft tissue resection from the right antro-lateral aspect of the aorta. The thymoma is staged as IIa, with uninvolved margins and absent vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with the tumor measuring 2.8 cm and extending to within 1 cm of the deep margin. The modified radical mastectomy specimen also revealed metastases in 6 out of 23 examined axillary lymph nodes, classified as pN2a. The histologic grade is Nottingham score 3/3, and additional immunohistochemical stains for hormone receptors and HER2 are pending.

The pathology report indicates that the excised 10R, 11R, 4R, #7, and 9R lymph nodes show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The right upper lobe lobectomy revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.5 cm, with no pleural involvement and all margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additionally, emphysema was noted in the surrounding lung tissue.

The pathology report describes a left adrenal tumor weighing 60g, consisting of two adjacent nodules, with the larger measuring 60x40x40 mm and the smaller 25x35x20 mm, both exhibiting grey-pink coloration and soft texture. Microscopic examination reveals pheochromocytoma with significant regressive changes in the larger nodule, while adrenal cortex remnants show pressure atrophy, and no infiltration into periadrenal tissue was observed. Immunohistochemical analysis indicates the presence of sustentacular cells, with low MIB-1 proliferation index, and the tumor exhibits characteristics such as high cellularity, necrosis, and vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, with two tumors graded 2 and one tumor graded 3 on a scale of 4. No evidence of capsular invasion or involvement of surrounding structures was found, and all surgical margins were free of tumor. The patient has three separate tumors, with sizes ranging from 9 mm to 2.7 cm, and the staging is classified as pT1a, pNx.

The pathology report indicates a tumor located in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 6.0 x 4.0 x 4.2 cm. The diagnosis is Squamous Cell Carcinoma, not otherwise specified (NOS), classified as pT2b, with no regional lymph node involvement (pNO 0/31) and an unknown distant metastasis status (pMx). The tumor is graded as G3, indicating a poorly differentiated carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, with components of solid, acinar, and bronchioloalveolar cell carcinoma, and evidence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in peribronchial lymph nodes. The tumor measures 3.5 x 2.8 x 2.5 cm, invades the visceral pleura, and shows no vascular invasion, while lymphatic invasion is pending. Additional findings include centrilobular emphysema, pulmonary hemosiderosis, and necrotizing granulomas in the lymph nodes, with negative results for neoplasm in other lymph node specimens.

The histopathological examination of a partial resection of the stomach revealed an invasive mucocellular adenocarcinoma (G3) located in the parapyloric region, measuring 3.3 x 4.6 x 0.7 cm, with partial infiltration of the stomach wall. The incision lines were free of neoplastic lesions, and there was reactive inflammation noted in lymph node No. XI. The report emphasizes the importance of contacting a doctor regarding the findings.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple well-differentiated liposarcomas in the right colon mesenteric nodules, with no high-grade or dedifferentiated areas noted. A larger dedifferentiated liposarcoma was identified in the right retroperitoneum, measuring 18 x 14 x 10.5 cm, with less than 10% tumor necrosis and focally positive resection margins. Additional findings include benign renal cysts and negative lymph nodes, with a Ki-67 proliferation index of approximately 25% in the larger nodule.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenosquamous carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, with evidence of metastatic disease in peribronchial lymph nodes and extensive vascular and lymphatic invasion. The tumor measures 3.6 x 3.4 x 2.9 cm and invades through the visceral pleura, classified as pathologic stage IIIA (T4 N1 MX). Additionally, lymph nodes excised from levels 5, 6, 7, 9, and 11 were negative for neoplasm, while a focus of metastatic non-small cell carcinoma was identified in the lymph nodes at level 10.

The final surgical pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multicentric invasive lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade 1-2, in the right breast, with the invasive carcinoma measuring approximately 8 cm in diameter and no tumor present in the two sampled axillary lymph nodes. Additionally, lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) of low nuclear grade is widespread throughout the right breast, and the surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement. The pathologic stage is classified as IIB, with a favorable receptor status showing high estrogen and progesterone receptor positivity.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 2.0 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising less than 25% of the tumor mass. Two sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla were found to have metastatic adenocarcinoma, with one node showing extravasation and the other being negative for this feature. Surgical margins were clear of malignancy, and the tumor was positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors while being negative for HER2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma, classified as WHO grade II, with a low MIB-1 Labeling Index of 4.9%. The tumor exhibits mildly to moderately hypercellular characteristics and is composed of cells with irregular nuclei and scant processes, but shows no signs of microvascular proliferation or necrosis. Close follow-up is recommended due to the borderline MIB-1 index, which raises concerns for potential recurrence or anaplastic progression.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 4.2 cm papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left lobe, characterized by multifocal capsular and extensive lymphovascular invasion, with seven out of eight left peritracheal lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement. Additional findings include reactive follicular hyperplasia in a right submandibular lymph node and normocellular parathyroid tissue with no malignancy. The overall AJCC pathologic stage is assessed as pT3 pN1a pMX, with surgical margins being negative but close to the posterior margin.

The pathology report indicates that biopsies from multiple lymph nodes (L4, R4, level 10, and subcarinal) are negative for malignancy. In contrast, the excised right lower and middle lobe of the lung reveals a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 9 cm, with one of seven hilar lymph nodes showing positive involvement. The resection margins and pleura are negative for tumor, but there is evidence of lymphatic space invasion and intrapulmonary spread of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were identified in any of the 29 lymph nodes examined from both peri-aortic and pelvic regions. The uterus showed the presence of a carcinosarcoma with mixed serous and endometrioid adenocarcinoma and undifferentiated sarcoma, classified as FIGO grade 3, with myometrial invasion of 0.9 cm. Additional findings included leiomyomata, adenomyosis, and vascular calcifications, with weak positive estrogen and progesterone receptor staining.

The pathology report indicates that a soft tissue mass in the left upper leg was diagnosed as myxofibrosarcoma/malignant fibrous histiocytoma, measuring 8.5 cm, with focal extension to the deep margin but all other surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, an excised extended periosteal margin revealed benign fibromuscular tissue. Microscopic examination confirmed the diagnosis, and the tumor is classified as T2b NX based on its size and regional lymph node assessment.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right temporal tumor diagnosed as glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) following an excision biopsy. The Ki-67 labeling index is approximately 8%, and the MGMT promoter methylation assay is negative, suggesting that the tumor may not respond to alkylating agent therapies. Microscopic examination reveals features such as vascular proliferation and pseudopalisading necrosis, with immunohistochemical stains showing the tumor is CD99 and NCAM positive, while p53 is negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 3.0 cm, showing no local invasion or renal vein invasion, and with surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, the excised para-aortic lymph nodes showed no metastatic involvement, and both cyst wall specimens were diagnosed as benign cortical cysts. The overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is pT1, indicating the tumor is confined to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 2) in the uterus, with a tumor size of 7.2 x 4.9 x 2.5 cm and a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 0.5 cm. There is no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion, and the cervix, serosa, and margins are free of tumor, with no malignancy found in the ovaries or fallopian tubes. The left and right pelvic lymph nodes were also negative for carcinoma, indicating no metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in a stomach tissue specimen obtained from a gastrectomy, with a tumor size of 6 x 6 x 1.5 cm. There is evidence of metastasis in 1 out of 4 examined lymph nodes, specifically in the intraabdominal region. Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion, as well as margins and neo-adjuvant treatment, were not specified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of parathyroid tissue in the right inferior parathyroid, with a diagnosis of parathyroid adenoma. Additionally, a total thyroidectomy revealed a 3.5 cm papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which is confined to the thyroid gland with clear margins of resection. The report confirms that the tumor does not extend beyond the thyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 3, with significant myometrial invasion and lymphovascular space invasion. There is no evidence of malignancy in the examined lymph nodes or other tissues, including the ovaries and fallopian tubes. The overall pathologic stage of the tumor is classified as T2b/NO/MO (Stage IIB).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) in the left breast, measuring 2.1 cm, with a Nottingham grade of 1 and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) constituting 10% of the tumor mass. All examined sentinel lymph nodes (four in total) are negative for carcinoma, and the resection margins are clear of invasive carcinoma or DCIS. The invasive tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER-2/NEU.

The pathology report indicates that a right orchidectomy was performed, revealing a nonseminoma tumor with a diameter of 3 cm. The tumor is confined to the testis and shows evidence of angioinvasion, but there is no invasion into the rete testis.

The pathology report indicates a subtotal gastrectomy specimen with a 9x7x1 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as moderately differentiated. The tumor extends to adjacent structures, specifically the greater omentum, but no lymph node metastasis was found (0/8 positive). The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there are no specified findings regarding lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma, moderately to poorly differentiated, in a cervical biopsy from a 51-year-old woman presenting with cervical and vaginal bleeding. Microscopic examination confirmed the diagnosis based on the tissue sample received. The specimen consisted of a single tissue fragment measuring 0.8 x 0.5 x 0.3 cm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with bronchioloalveolar features in multiple lung specimens, including the right lower lobe and anterior basilar right lower lobe, with sizes ranging from 0.7 cm to 1.6 cm. Additionally, bronchioloalveolar carcinoma is noted at the surgical margins of some specimens, while all examined lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy. The report concludes that the multifocal tumors are classified as stage pT3, with no regional lymph node metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast lumpectomy revealed a 2.5 cm invasive, poorly differentiated mammary carcinoma with high nuclear grade, and the tumor margins are free of invasive carcinoma. All examined sentinel lymph nodes (3 total) showed no evidence of carcinoma, with negative keratin immunostains. The tumor is classified as ER-negative, PR-negative, and HER2-negative, with further immunohistochemical subclassification pending.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated serous carcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with metastatic serous carcinoma found in the left fallopian tube, diaphragm, and serosal surface of the uterus. Additionally, there are signs of endometriosis and chronic inflammation in the right fallopian tube, but no evidence of carcinoma in the examined lymph nodes. The overall staging is classified as FIGO stage 3A, with multiple sites of metastasis identified in the abdomen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in a biopsy taken from the esophagus at 32 cm. The specimen consisted of three fragments of tan soft tissue measuring 0.3-0.4 cm, which were entirely submitted for examination. The diagnosis was confirmed based on a personal examination of the slides by the pathologist.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma (FIGO Grade 2) involving both left and right ovaries, with significant tumor size and serosal involvement. The cancer has metastasized to multiple sites, including the bladder peritoneum, uterus, omentum, and bowel, with extensive serosal spread noted. The report confirms that the left fallopian tube and rectal donut specimens are free of tumor, while the remaining tissues examined show evidence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 1.5 cm and classified as poorly differentiated (G3). Metastatic carcinoma was found in 6 out of 9 lymph nodes, with lymphatic invasion present but no vascular invasion or direct extension of the tumor. The surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and the neoplastic cells show specific immunostaining characteristics.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma in both the right and left ovaries, with significant lymphovascular invasion and extensive necrosis in the left ovary. The carcinoma has invaded the muscular layer of the colon, with positive surgical resection margins and extensive involvement of pericolonic tissue, while metastatic disease is noted in multiple pericolonic lymph nodes. Additionally, high-grade serous carcinoma is identified in the omentum, further confirming the aggressive nature of the disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma, grade 2, in the right breast, with a tumor size of at least 65 mm and a pathologic stage of IIIA. Surgical margins are negative, but five out of fourteen lymph nodes are positive for carcinoma, with identified extracasular extension. The tumor is estrogen and progesterone receptor positive, while HER2/neu is negative, and lobular carcinoma in situ is also present.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph node from the left axilla shows focal metastatic adenocarcinoma, measuring 0.8 cm, with no extranodal extension. The left breast segmental mastectomy reveals multifocal invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, with tumor sizes ranging from 0.2 cm to 1.6 cm, and ductal carcinoma in situ present, accounting for 30% of the total tumor volume. The tumor is ER positive, PR positive, and HER-2/NEU negative, with negative resection margins and identified lymphovascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma of the conventional type (clear and granular cell) in the left kidney, characterized by extensive involvement (14 cm) and areas of necrosis, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3/4. The carcinoma has invaded the renal capsule and perirenal adipose tissue, and there is a large occlusive thrombus in the renal vein, although the surgical margins are benign. Additionally, a left adjacent nodule was excised, showing similar carcinoma characteristics, also with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3/4, and appears to be completely excised.

The pathology report indicates that the omental biopsy shows fibroadipose tissue with fat necrosis, calcifications, and hemosiderin-laden macrophages. The right ileocolectomy specimen reveals a low-grade, moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma located in the cecum, measuring 9.3 cm, with invasion through the muscularis propria but negative resection margins and no identified lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Additionally, there is a marked peritumoral lymphoid response and residual adenoma present, with one out of eighteen regional lymph nodes positive for cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with involvement of the deep margin and proximity to the surgical margins in the oral cavity, specifically the floor of the mouth. Lymph node dissection revealed one metastatic carcinoma in 1 of 12 lymph nodes at level 3, while levels 1 and 2 showed no malignancy. The findings correspond to AJCC pathologic stage III, with the primary tumor classified as pT2 and regional lymph nodes as pN1.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated, non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 65 mm, with infiltration into the visceral pleura and evidence of angioinvasion. The bronchial resection margin and peribronchial lymph nodes are tumor-free, although they exhibit significant anthracotic pigment deposition. The tumor classification is M-8070/3, G3, pT 2, pV 1, pN 0, pM X, and it is staged as IB with a complete resection (R0).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated keratinizing invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with tumor invasion extending to a depth of 1.5 cm and extensive lymphovascular space invasion present. Additionally, there is severe dysplasia (CIN III) adjacent to the invasive carcinoma, and metastatic squamous cell carcinoma is identified in two of the examined lymph nodes. The report notes that the tumor also involves the lower uterine segment and the vagina, with significant lymphatic invasion but no distant metastases detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of urothelial carcinoma in the urinary bladder, with a histologic composition of 85% transitional cell, 10% sarcomatoid, and less than 5% squamous cell types. The tumor is classified as high grade and is infiltrative, invading the muscularis propria, but no lymph-vascular invasion was identified. The pathologic stage is at least pT2a, and there is extensive necrosis associated with the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a biopsy of the uterine cervix revealing poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. There are foci of vascular invasion noted in the specimen. This suggests a more aggressive tumor behavior and potential for metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma, classical type, in the left breast, measuring 1.6 cm, with a Nottingham grade of 2 and no lymphovascular invasion. The tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, and equivocal for HER-2/NEU, with further testing indicating no amplification of the HER-2/NEU gene. Additionally, all examined axillary lymph nodes (7 total) are negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of uterine serous carcinoma with invasion depth of 32 mm and extensive lymphovascular space invasion. Metastatic serous carcinoma was found in multiple lymph nodes, including one right pelvic and two of four right periaortic lymph nodes, while the cervix and right ovary were negative for tumor. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage T1B/N2/MX, indicating significant myometrial invasion and lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 8 (4+4), involving approximately 20% of the prostate and showing extracapsular extension into adipose tissue. Surgical margins are positive for tumor involvement, and no lymphovascular invasion is identified, with a total of 7 lymph nodes examined showing no evidence of tumor. The AJCC staging is pT3a, pNO, and the patient has received salvage radiation therapy following a local recurrence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme from an excised left occipital brain lesion, characterized by high-grade glioma features and extensive tumor necrosis. Microscopic examination reveals anaplastic tumor cells, microvascular proliferation, and the presence of polymorphonuclear neutrophils in necrotic areas. The MIB-1 proliferation index is noted to be 16%, indicating a moderate level of tumor cell proliferation in the more active regions.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of a right frontal lobe tumor in a female patient has been diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme. The tumor exhibits high cellularity, nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic activity, vascular changes, and significant necrosis. The MIB-1 proliferation index is approximately 25%, suggesting a high level of tumor growth.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located at the rectosigmoid junction, measuring 0 x 0 x 3.5 cm and exhibiting ulceration. Out of 12 lymph nodes examined, 1 showed evidence of metastasis, while the surgical margins were uninvolved. There is no information provided regarding neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathological findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, classified as Grade II, with tumor presence at the visceral pleural surface and no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis. A spindle cell carcinoid tumor was also identified in the completion lobectomy specimen, while other lymph nodes and biopsies showed no evidence of tumor involvement. The report highlights the presence of residual adenocarcinoma with surrounding obstructive/lipoid pneumonia and confirms that the bronchial margin is uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma with a poorly differentiated trabecular histologic type, arising in a cirrhotic liver. The tumor was well-defined, measuring 14.5 x 8.0 x 7.0 cm, and showed microvessel invasion, but the surgical resection margins were clear with a safety margin of 3.0 cm. Additionally, the gallbladder specimen showed autolysis, and further immunohistochemical stains are recommended to differentiate from other malignant tumors.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 3.5 cm invasive ductal breast carcinoma grade 3 located in the left breast at the 2 o'clock position, with minimal resection margins of 1 mm dorsally and 3 mm cranially. Additionally, there are small components of grade 3 ductal carcinoma in situ with comedo necrosis, and one out of eleven lymph nodes examined is positive for tumor involvement. The tumor classification is pT2, pN1, and R0, indicating a significant but localized disease with clear margins.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an advanced colonic adenocarcinoma in block A, characterized by severe necrosis, tubular formations, and significant nuclear atypia. The tumor has invaded all wall layers and vessels, classified as pT3, L1, V1, with no regional lymph node involvement (pN0). Granulation tissue is noted in the serosal region, and the tumor is classified as G2-3, consistent with a diagnosis of residual tumor (RO).

The pathology report indicates that the pleural biopsy shows benign mesothelial hyperplasia, while the left lower lobe lobectomy reveals moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 4.7 cm, with lymphovascular invasion present. Two out of three lymph nodes at level 7 are positive for metastatic carcinoma, while other lymph nodes examined are negative for carcinoma. The tumor is classified as pT2a and pN2, indicating regional lymph node involvement without distant metastasis.

The pathology report describes a mediastinal resection containing an invasive WHO type B2 thymoma measuring 6 cm in diameter, which has invaded the mediastinal fat tissue but not the pericardium. The tumor has incomplete resection margins, classified as R1, with the remaining surgical borders being free of tumor. Additionally, there is significant thymic atrophy, pronounced thymitis, and activated lymph nodes, with no evidence of thymic carcinoma, resulting in a tumor stage of IIB according to Masaoka-Koga/ITMIG classification.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) from multiple biopsies of left and right frontal tumors, as well as infiltrated white matter. The specimens included irregularly shaped soft tissue fragments from various locations in the frontal region, with sizes ranging from 1.3 cm to 11.0 cm in aggregate. The intraoperative consultation confirmed the presence of glioblastoma in the left frontal mass.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.7 cm, with margins appearing uninvolved by invasive carcinoma and a distance of 2 mm from the closest margin. The sentinel lymph node biopsy showed no metastasis in the examined lymph node, confirming a pathologic staging of pT1c and pN0(i-). Additionally, the tumor is negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors, with equivocal HER2 status, and the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) was noted, but it is not extensive.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant mesothelioma in multiple specimens, including the right chest wall mass, pleura, and pericardial tissue, with varying histological types (mixed epithelial and sarcomatoid) and significant tumor invasion into surrounding structures. Notably, the largest tumor nodules measure up to 5.5 cm and exhibit necrosis, with tumor involvement at multiple surgical margins. Other specimens, such as skin and rib, were negative for tumor, and a paratracheal lymph node was also negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a tumor size of 8x5x4 cm and stromal invasion ranging from 3.0 mm to 5.0 mm. There is no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion, and all 14 examined lymph nodes are negative for metastasis. Margins and additional pathologic findings were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, specifically gastric carcinoma of the diffuse type (signet ring cell carcinoma), located in the antrum and extending to the duodenal resection margin. The cancer has penetrated the peritoneum and shows metastases in six regional lymph nodes, as well as in the omentum and peritoneum. The staging is classified as pT4a R1 pN2 (6/39) pM1, indicating advanced disease with significant spread.

The pathology report indicates the presence of established fine nodular cirrhosis with slight fatty degeneration of hepatic cells, suggesting nutritional or alcohol-related liver damage. Additionally, a resected colon specimen reveals a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 6 cm, with infiltration into the submucosa but no involvement of local lymph nodes or resection margins. Two tubular adenomas with low-grade and high-grade dysplasia were also identified, with the tumor staged as pT1 pNO (0/22) pMX; G2, L0, V0, R0.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a deceased white individual, was diagnosed with colon adenocarcinoma located in the cecum. The cancer is classified as T3, N0, M0, corresponding to an overall stage of IIA. There is no indication of lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which has invaded through the muscularis propria and into the perivesical soft tissue, with multifocal tumor distribution. The left ureter shows carcinoma in situ, while all examined lymph nodes (25 total) are negative for tumor involvement. The report confirms no invasive carcinoma in the right ureter and provides detailed pathologic parameters consistent with the diagnosis of advanced bladder cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the right middle lobe lobectomy revealed a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, which invades the visceral pleura and shows lymphatic invasion, but the bronchial margin is negative for malignancy. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes were found to have metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, confirming regional spread of the disease. The level 11 lymph node biopsy showed no malignancy, suggesting that not all lymphatic involvement is affected.

The pathology report indicates that both the left and right ovarian masses are diagnosed as serous papillary cystadenocarcinoma, with the left mass measuring 11 cm and the right mass measuring 10 cm. Metastatic involvement is noted in the left pelvic lymph node (1/1), right pelvic lymph nodes (2/6), and para-aortic lymph nodes (3/5), along with metastatic disease in the omentum. The gastric mucosa examined shows no diagnostic abnormalities or evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the gastric antrum, measuring 4.3 cm, with no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural infiltration, and all surgical margins and lymph nodes are uninvolved by neoplasia. The adjacent mucosa shows moderate chronic gastritis and complete intestinal metaplasia, with a positive result for H. pylori. Additionally, the splenic artery lymph nodes, esophageal margin, enterectomy, and gallbladder show no signs of neoplasia, although the gallbladder exhibits nonspecific chronic cholecystitis.

The pathology report confirms the diagnosis of a left frontal brain tumor identified as glioblastoma multiforme, WHO Grade IV. Microscopic examination reveals pleomorphic glial cells, mitotic figures, abundant endothelial proliferation, and areas of tumor necrosis. The specimen was received in multiple fragments, with one portion analyzed via frozen section, consistent with a high-grade malignant glioma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a von Meyenburg's complex in the liver with moderate fatty infiltration. In the sigmoid colon, there is a tubulovillous adenoma measuring 1.8 cm with severe dysplasia, which transitions into a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma that invades the submucosa but has clear resection margins. The tumor is staged as pT1 pNO (0/17) L0 V0; G2 R0, with all examined lymph nodes showing no evidence of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 1. The tumor is staged as T2, N0, and M0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered, and a normal blood sample was also collected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an intermediate to high-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 32 cm in the mesentery, with associated ulceration, extensive necrosis, and perforation of the serosal surface. Additionally, a separate 14 cm leiomyosarcoma was identified in another mesenteric mass, while the left adrenal gland showed an uncapsulated adrenal cortical adenoma. The left kidney exhibited extensive acute tubular injury and moderate chronic changes, but no tumors were found in the kidney or omentum specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma in the right hemithyroidectomy specimen, with the dominant tumor measuring 5.1 cm and exhibiting locally invasive characteristics along with prominent cribriform architecture. Additionally, there are metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma findings in three perithyroidal lymph nodes, while no pathological diagnosis was made for the thymus. The report suggests that further investigation for a potential genetic predisposition may be warranted due to the unusual cribriform architecture observed.

The pathology report indicates a subtotal gastrectomy specimen from the stomach, revealing a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma tumor measuring 5 x 4 x 2.5 cm, which is ulcerated and extends to adjacent structures, including the lesser and greater omentums. Out of 8 examined lymph nodes, 3 are positive for metastasis. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no specified evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates that a total mastectomy was performed on the right breast, revealing two invasive mucinous carcinomas measuring 4.5 cm and 1.0 cm, both classified as grade I with low mitotic index, and the nipple and deep margin are free of neoplasm. Additionally, the right sentinel node was examined and found to be negative for tumor presence. The report also notes changes consistent with a biopsy site and the presence of proliferative fibrocystic disease with calcifications.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 3.5 x 3.5 x 2.9 cm, with a positive soft tissue margin adjacent to the bronchovascular margins. Six lymph nodes were examined, all of which were benign, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. The tumor is classified as pathologic stage IB, with no evidence of lymphovascular or visceral pleural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a pneumonectomy specimen from the lung, revealing a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3 x 2.5 x 2 cm. Details regarding tumor extent, lymph nodes, lymphatic and venous invasion, and margins are not specified. There is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the excised #8 lymph node is negative for malignancy, while the resected distal pancreas reveals poorly differentiated pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, with invasion into peripancreatic adipose tissue and positive perineural and lymphovascular space invasion. The tumor extends to the anterior and posterior edges of the pancreas, with six lymph nodes examined, five of which are positive for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, an intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm is present in the pancreatic tail, and the surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma infiltrating the corion and focally the detrusor muscle in the bladder, with free surgical margins. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic, sanguineous, or perineural invasions, and all examined lymph nodes are free of tumor. Additionally, the prostate, seminal vesicles, vas deferens, and urethral margins are all free of neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that all four sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla show no evidence of tumor or metastatic carcinoma. The left breast segmental mastectomy reveals a 3.0 cm invasive ductal carcinoma, classified as grade 3 (poorly differentiated), with no lymphatic or vascular invasion and widely free surgical margins. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the tumor is negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors, and HER-2/neu testing indicates no amplification of the gene.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 4.5 x 4 x 2.4 cm located at the upper pole and classified as Grade 2. The tumor is confined to the kidney, abutting the renal capsule without extending beyond it, and the surgical margins are negative for malignancy. The final pathologic stage is pT1bNXM0, indicating no lymph node or distant metastasis, and the background renal parenchyma shows no significant abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a malignant astrocytoma in the brain, characterized by a high proliferation index of 35% and significant cellularity, suggesting aggressive behavior similar to glioblastoma. Molecular testing revealed a positive MGMT promoter methylation status, which may indicate a potential benefit from alkylating agent therapy, while the EGFR variant III mutation was not detected. Additionally, allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q was identified, which is typically associated with oligodendrogliomas, but the overall diagnosis aligns more closely with a WHO grade III fibrillary astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an adrenal cortical carcinoma, measuring 13.5 x 9.5 x 8.5 cm, with evidence of infiltration into surrounding adipose tissue and multiple discrete peri-adrenal tumor nodules. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma consistent with the adrenal primary was found in the right lower lobe lung wedge resection and two other lung nodules, all located near the resection margins. The para-aortic lymph nodes were positive for malignancy, confirming the spread of the disease.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a male with mesothelioma, underwent a radical pleurectomy and photodynamic therapy. The final diagnosis revealed malignant mesothelioma of the epithelioid type in the apical chest mass, with no tumor detected in various other specimens including lymph nodes, parietal pleura, and rib tissue. Additionally, there were areas of suspicious mesothelial proliferation and inflammation in the pericardial fat and visceral pleura, but no definitive tumor was identified in those regions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type, measuring up to 3 cm, with infiltration into the pericolic fat but no regional lymph node metastases and clear resection margins. Additionally, there is evidence of moderate chronic fibrosing cholecystitis, chronic fibrosing pericholecystitis, and cholecystolithiasis. The tumor is staged as pT3, with no lymph node involvement (0/23), and classified as grade 2 (G2).

The pathology report indicates that both right axillary sentinel nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The right breast simple mastectomy reveals invasive ductal carcinoma (6 mm) with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (3.6 cm), both showing low to intermediate nuclear grades and negative excisional margins. Additional findings include benign conditions such as fibroadenoma and intraductal hyperplasia, with strong expression of estrogen and progesterone receptors in the invasive tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a diffuse infiltrating fibrillary astrocytoma (grade II) in the superficial biopsy, with a low MIB-1 labeling index of 2%. In contrast, the deeper biopsy reveals an anaplastic astrocytoma (grade III) with a significantly higher MIB-1 labeling index of 88%. The findings suggest a neoplastic proliferation of glial cells with varying degrees of malignancy and atypical features across the different specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma in the right liver, characterized by a large hepatic mass and multiple adjacent tumor nodules, with negative surgical margins. The pericholedochal lymph node is free of tumor, while the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis with numerous stones. Additional findings reveal non-cirrhotic hepatic parenchyma, no abnormal fibrosis, and no evidence of vascular invasion or hemosiderosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, with a tumor measuring 10.9 cm that is confined within the renal capsule but extends into the renal pelvis and invades the renal vein with tumor thromboembolus. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable, while the adrenal gland shows cortical nodular hyperplasia. The specimen was received as a nephrectomy with part of the right adrenal gland, and no lymph nodes were identified in the surrounding fatty tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 5.5 cm in the distal esophagus, with involvement of the submucosa at the gastroesophageal junction and metastatic spread to seven out of twenty-eight examined lymph nodes. Additionally, there is evidence of lymphovascular and perineural invasion, but the surgical margins are free of invasive carcinoma. Immunohistochemical analysis shows HER2 positivity, suggesting potential therapeutic implications.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing chronic cholecystitis, and excised lymph nodes from the peri-portal and perigastric regions were negative for metastatic disease. A Whipple procedure identified a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the pancreas measuring 2.8 x 2.2 x 1.7 cm, with invasion into the ampulla but no lymphovascular or perineural invasion, and surgical margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. The overall pTNM stage is pT3N1, and there are significant findings of severe chronic pancreatitis.

The pathology report indicates that all four sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla are negative for metastases, confirming no tumor presence in these nodes. The left breast mastectomy reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 1.7 cm, classified as SBR Grade 1, along with extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and negative surgical margins. Additionally, the Oncotype DX assay shows a recurrence score of 20, suggesting a 13% average rate of distant recurrence at 10 years.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma (FIGO Grade III) in the left ovary, with no residual ovarian tissue identified. Metastatic serous adenocarcinoma is present on the ovarian surface, as well as in the right upper quadrant peritoneum and mesentery, with a maximum dimension of tumor implants outside the true pelvis measuring 5 cm. The final staging is classified as at least FIGO Stage IIIC, indicating significant metastatic spread beyond the pelvis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 2.5 x 2 x 0.5 cm poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in lung tissue, with tumor extent involving the visceral pleura and additional tumor nodules present. Immunohistochemical staining shows positive results for CD15, CK7, and TTF1, while CK20 and CDX2 are negative. Specific details regarding lymph nodes, lymphatic and venous invasion, and surgical margins are not provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderate to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the right tongue, with extensive involvement of the tongue musculature and perineural invasion. The tumor is present at the mid medial soft tissue margin, and one of forty lymph nodes examined shows metastatic squamous cell carcinoma with extracapsular spread. The pathological stage is classified as pT3 N1 MX, indicating advanced disease with lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent an extrapleural pneumonectomy due to malignant mesothelioma, with extensive tumor involvement observed in the resected lung, pleura, and mediastinal fat. Microscopic examination revealed micrometastases in the bronchial and mediastinal lymph nodes, while the bronchial resection margin was clear of tumor. The thymic lymph node showed no evidence of malignancy, confirming the presence of mesothelioma primarily in the extrapleural and lymphatic tissues.

The pathology report describes a resected right superior pulmonary lobe containing a 45 mm necrotic, poorly differentiated, non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma with pleural infiltration and extensive hilar lymph node metastases. The bronchial resection margin is tumor-free, and the surrounding lung tissue shows significant anthracosis and structural changes. The diagnosis suggests difficulty in determining whether the carcinoma is a metastasis from the esophagus or a primary lung tumor, with a staging of III A if it is primary.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma (IDC) measuring 1.1 cm in the left breast, along with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). Micrometastatic carcinoma was identified in one sentinel lymph node, while another sentinel lymph node and a non-sentinel lymph node were benign. Immunohistochemical analysis showed strong estrogen receptor positivity, negative progesterone receptor, and negative HER2 status for the invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adrenal cortical carcinoma from a left adrenal mass, measuring 5.2 cm, with lymphovascular invasion present but no regional lymph node metastasis. The tumor exhibits strong positivity for calretinin, synaptophysin, and Melan A, with additional findings of tumor necrosis and degenerative changes. Margins are uninvolved by tumor, and the overall pathologic staging is consistent with pT1, indicating no extra-adrenal invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T4, N0, and M0, indicating advanced local disease without regional or distant metastasis. No treatment has been initiated, and a normal blood sample was also collected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, partially micropapillary, in the left breast, with a tumor size of 3.5 x 2.5 x 2.0 cm and evidence of carcinoma in situ. Immunohistochemical analysis shows over 75% positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors, along with a positive HER2 score of 3+. Additionally, there are metastases and micrometastases identified in 25 out of 28 examined axillary lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that multiple liver biopsies from segments 2, 3, and 7 show benign liver tissue with canalicular cholestasis and no carcinoma identified. A Whipple resection reveals a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the pancreatic head, measuring 4.5 cm, with invasion into the duodenal wall and peripancreatic soft tissues, and metastatic adenocarcinoma found in 2 out of 11 regional lymph nodes. Surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and the overall staging is pT3 pN1 pMx, indicating a locally advanced tumor with lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma classified as G3, with infiltration into fatty connective tissue and lymph vessels. The resection margins are clear, and the lymph nodes are free of cancer, with a pN0 classification. The tumor is classified as pT3, indicating significant local invasion, but there is no evidence of metastasis (MX).

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of a lymph node from the left upper lobe is negative for malignancy, while a lobectomy of the left lung reveals a moderately differentiated focally keratinizing squamous carcinoma measuring 4.8 x 2.0 x 2.0 cm, confined to the lung without pleural or lymphovascular invasion. The tumor is classified as T2N0, with a surgical margin of 3.5 cm from the bronchial margin and abutting the pleura. Additional lymph node biopsies from levels V/VI and VII are also negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in the right ovary and fallopian tube, with a tumor size of 10 x 6 x 5 cm and evidence of lymphovascular invasion. The left ovary also shows small high-grade serous adenocarcinoma, while the uterus, cervix, and left fallopian tube are unremarkable aside from atrophic endometrium and adenomyosis. All examined lymph nodes and other tissues, including the appendix and omentum, are negative for malignancy, confirming no metastatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast mastectomy revealed invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 3, measuring 4.5 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ, also grade 3, and negative margins of excision. The sentinel lymph node biopsy from the right axilla and four additional lymph nodes were negative for metastasis. The left breast mastectomy showed focal atypical ductal hyperplasia with negative margins, and no distant metastasis was identified.

The pathology report indicates that the 84-year-old male patient has high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, with tumor invasion into the perivesical soft tissues and evidence of vascular and perineural invasion. The excised pelvic lymph nodes from both sides were found to be benign, and the surgical margins from the cystoprostatectomy were free of tumor. Additionally, benign findings were noted in the excised distal ureters, while the prostate showed nodular hyperplasia and the seminal vesicles exhibited tumor involvement with emboli in lymphovascular spaces.

The pathology report indicates that both the omental biopsy and mesenteric nodules are diagnosed as large pleomorphic B-lineage lymphoma, most consistent with T-cell/histiocyte-rich large B-cell lymphoma. Immunohistochemical staining shows the lymphoma cells express B-lineage specific markers while being negative for CD15 and CD30, which helps differentiate it from other types of lymphoma. Flow cytometry reveals a predominance of CD3+ T cells with rare B cells, and conventional cytogenetics is pending for further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder. The liver analysis confirmed the presence of multifocal hepatocellular carcinoma, with a poorly differentiated tumor measuring 12.5 x 7.5 x 5.0 cm, and no evidence of malignancy at the surgical margins. Additional findings included severe steatosis in the liver parenchyma and identified vascular invasion, with the tumor staged as pT2 NX MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme in the left temporal lobe, with a proliferation index of 15%. The specimen consisted of multiple tissue fragments measuring 0.3 to 0.5 cm, and intraoperative consultation confirmed the presence of a glioma. Microscopic examination revealed high-grade glioma characteristics, with neoplastic astrocytes showing strong positivity for GFAP.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent multiple neck dissections, revealing metastatic squamous carcinoma in several lymph nodes, with extranodal extension present in some cases. Specifically, metastatic carcinoma was found in 1 of 5 lymph nodes in the right Level IB dissection, 5 of 14 in the right Level IIA, and 2 of 10 in the right Level IV, among others. Additionally, a near total glossectomy specimen showed well to moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma measuring 6.5 cm, with invasion depth of 3.5 cm and no perineural or vascular invasion noted.

The pathology report describes a partial nephrectomy of the left kidney, revealing a Grade 2 clear cell renal cell carcinoma. The tumor measures 2.8 x 2.2 x 2.0 cm and is located in the upper pole of the kidney, with no evidence of tumor necrosis or sarcomatoid differentiation. The tumor is confined to the kidney, indicating that it has not spread beyond the organ.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical prostatectomy revealing invasive poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+4 (total score of 8), affecting both lobes of the prostate and showing multifocal extraprostatic extension. All examined lymph nodes from the right and left pelvic regions (34 total) showed no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, and all surgical margins were free of tumor. Additionally, perineural invasion was identified, and multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia was present.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma, characterized by extensive vascular necrosis, tumor necrosis, and high mitotic activity in the right temporal lobe. The MGMT promoter is methylated, which may have implications for treatment options. Immunohistochemical analysis shows a high proliferation index of approximately 65% and about 2% of tumor cells expressing the p53 protein.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade myxofibrosarcoma in the right posterior medial thigh, measuring 5.1 x 4.9 x 4 cm, which is predominantly viable and diffusely involving skeletal muscle. The resection margins are free of tumor, although there is adjacent fat necrosis and a foreign body giant cell reaction consistent with a prior surgical site. The specimen was received fresh and included a significant portion of soft tissue, with no gross evidence of necrosis observed in the tumor mass.

The pathology report indicates the presence of paragangliomas in both an adrenal mass (4.4 cm) and a retroperitoneal lymph node (0.8 cm), with no adrenal or lymph node tissue identified in the specimens. The tumor cells are positive for chromogranin, synaptophysin, and NSE, and both lesions are encapsulated with no vascular invasion or necrosis noted. Additionally, two duodenal carcinoids were found, with evidence of infiltration into the muscularis propria and metastasis to peripancreatic lymph nodes, while other examined tissues, including the pancreas and bile duct, showed no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 4 squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, forming a 6 cm mass that extends through the pleura into the mediastinal fat, although the resection margins are free of cancer involvement. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes (5 of 6) in the intrapulmonary peribronchial region show metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while some inferior mediastinal lymph nodes are also involved. The left lingula lung parenchyma shows no diagnostic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with extensive myometrial invasion and lymphatic/vascular invasion present. Two of five right paraaortic lymph nodes were positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the left paraaortic nodes showed no evidence of malignancy. The tumor is classified as FIGO grade 3, with the serosa free of tumor and the ovaries negative for malignancy, although the left fallopian tube is suspicious for possible involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostate cancer, with a dominant nodule classified as prostate adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+3=7, and a secondary nodule with a Gleason score of 3+3=6. The tumor is organ-confined, involving the right posterolateral region and the anterior region, with no evidence of lymphatic invasion or metastasis in the examined lymph nodes. Surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, and there is present perineural invasion, but no extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle invasion.

The pathology report indicates that all four sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla are negative for tumor cells, confirming no lymphatic spread of cancer. The left breast mastectomy reveals a poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with negative margins and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Additionally, a superficial basal cell carcinoma was identified in the upper superior flap skin excision, while the right breast showed benign findings including a small fibroadenoma.

The pathology report indicates that a right lung pneumonectomy was performed, revealing poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with clear cell changes measuring 7 cm, but with no invasion of the visceral pleura and negative bronchial and vascular margins. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from levels 4, 7, and 9, as well as a portion of the sixth rib, showed no evidence of tumor involvement. Overall, the findings suggest localized lung cancer without metastasis to the sampled lymph nodes or rib.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from various locations (right and left para-aortic and pelvic regions) are negative for tumor involvement. A carcinosarcoma, primarily glandular (95% serous and 5% endometrioid), was identified in the uterus, confined to the endometrium without invasion into the endocervix, and with negative margins. Additionally, multiple biopsies from other sites, including the omentum and pelvic sidewalls, were also negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney partial nephrectomy revealing a renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 4.5 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is limited to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions, with a total of 9 lymph nodes examined (0/9). The prostate specimen revealed the presence of prostate adenocarcinoma, classified as Gleason grade 7 (4+3), with approximately 25% of the prostate involved and focal extracapsular extension noted. The surgical margins were free of tumor, and there were additional findings of benign prostatic hyperplasia and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that a composite resection of the left mandible and floor of mouth revealed a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 7.2 cm, with bone invasion present but no angiolymphatic or perineural invasion identified. All biopsies from various sites, including lymph nodes, showed no tumor presence, and the surgical margins were negative, with the closest margin being 0.1 cm from the tumor. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT4a pNO, and further clinical review may adjust this assessment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the right mandible, with a tumor size of 5.4 cm and a depth of invasion of 2.9 cm. Lymph-vascular and perineural invasion were identified, and two out of forty lymph nodes examined were positive for metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, with extranodal extension present.
