The surgical margins were involved by invasive carcinoma, specifically at the proximal bone margin, and moderate epithelial dysplasia was noted at several other margins.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary contains a benign mucinous cystadenoma, while the sigmoid and upper half of the rectum show a colonic adenocarcinoma that invades through the muscularis propria into perirectal soft tissue, but with negative margins and no malignancy in the examined lymph nodes. The appendix shows fibrous obliteration of the distal lumen. Overall, the findings suggest a localized rectal cancer without evidence of metastatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma, with two foci measuring 1.3 cm in the right lobe and 0.1 cm in the left lobe, and no extrathyroidal extension observed. Metastatic disease is present in three lymph nodes, with one node showing 0.1 cm of metastatic carcinoma, while the margins are uninvolved by carcinoma. Additionally, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis is noted as an accompanying finding.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a high-grade invasive papillary urothelial carcinoma in the right wall of the bladder, with tumor invasion into the muscularis propria. Prognostic marker analysis shows that two biomarkers (p27 and Ki-67) are altered, while p21, p53, and Cyclin E remain unaltered, resulting in a favorable prognosis due to the low number of altered biomarkers. The tumor was adequately sampled, and no lymph-vascular invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates a hemicolectomy specimen from the colon, revealing a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 6.5 x 4.5 x 4 cm. The tumor extends into the muscularis propria, but details regarding lymph nodes, margins, and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment are not specified. No additional pathologic findings or comments are provided in the report.

The pathology report indicates that a pheochromocytoma, measuring 2.3 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm, was identified in the left adrenal gland following an adrenalectomy. The tumor is confined to the adrenal gland with free margins, and there are no specific pathologic changes noted in the adrenal cortex. The specimen was examined microscopically, confirming the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in the right leg, measuring 9 cm, with the closest deep margin being 0.1 cm away and no involvement of the margin. Additional excised tissue revealed benign fibroadipose tissue and skeletal muscle at both lower and deep margins. Microscopic examination confirmed the diagnosis, showing spindle-shaped tumor cells with high mitotic activity and multifocal necrosis, while vascular invasion and inflammatory infiltrate were not identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) from a right frontal brain excision in a 1-year-old male patient. The tumor exhibits extensive infiltration, cellular anaplasia, frequent mitotic figures, and areas of necrosis, with a MIB-1 labeling index of 22%. The gross examination revealed a 4.5 x 3.0 x 2.0 cm fragment of gray-tan brain tissue with an ill-defined gritty area predominantly in the white matter.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes were examined, with the majority showing no tumor presence, except for hilar node #2, which contained metastatic adenocarcinoma. The left upper lobe lung specimen revealed an invasive adenocarcinoma, classified as histologic grade 2/4, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and no invasion of visceral pleura or large vessels. The final diagnosis includes a TNM stage of pT2a, pN1, and pMX, with positive findings in 2 of 2 peribronchial nodes out of a total of 12 examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the right parietal tumor and posterior brain lesion have been diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV). The frozen section evaluations revealed infiltrating glioma characteristics, including nuclear pleomorphism, necrosis, and increased mitotic activity. The specimens were submitted for further analysis, and the findings support the diagnosis of high-grade astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, classified as FIGO grade 1, with invasion into the inner half of the myometrium and no lymphovascular invasion detected. The cervix, ovaries, and uterine serosa show no evidence of malignancy, and all examined lymph nodes are benign, indicating no regional metastasis. Additional findings include complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia and a leiomyoma in the posterior wall of the uterus.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO Grade 3 endometrial carcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor size of 4.4 x 3.2 x 1.8 cm and myometrial invasion present, but less than half of the myometrial thickness is involved. All examined lymph nodes (32 in total) show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, and the surgical resection margins are negative. Additionally, the cervix and bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes show no specific diagnostic abnormalities, and pelvic washings were negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2, confined to the right kidney and measuring 8.0 cm in maximum dimension. The tumor shows no invasion into surrounding tissues, including the adrenal gland, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. The adjacent kidney parenchyma is unremarkable, and no lymph nodes were identified in the hilum of the kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of uterine leiomyosarcoma located at the posterior uterine fundus, measuring 18 x 18 x 12 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and extension through the uterine serosa. Additionally, there are multiple sites of metastatic leiomyosarcoma identified in the pelvic tumor, omentum, small bowel, appendix, and pelvic implant, with no tumor present in the cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes, or ovaries. The pathological staging is classified as Stage IIIB, indicating extensive local invasion and no regional lymph node metastases.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 5.3 cm, with a grade of 2 based on architectural, nuclear, and mitotic scores. The carcinoma involves the nipple but does not extend to the overlying epidermis or dermal lymphatics, and it has metastasized to all three examined sentinel lymph nodes, with evidence of extracapsular extension. The deep margin of excision is free of carcinoma, and the tumor is classified as T3N1MX according to the TNM staging system.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lymph nodes from both the left and right obturator are negative for metastasis, with no malignancy found in the apical margins or bladder neck. However, the radical prostatectomy specimen reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma with a high Gleason score of 9, extensive extraprostatic extension, and involvement of both seminal vesicles, along with multiple positive surgical margins. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3bN0Mx, indicating advanced prostate cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of tubulopapillary and partially mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colon, with a significant tumor measuring 5.4 x 6.9 x 1.8 cm that infiltrates the muscularis propria and surrounding mesenteric fat. There are metastases identified in lymph nodes, classified as No X/XIV, with evidence of cancerous infiltration in the lymph node capsule and surrounding adipose tissue. The tumor is classified as G3, Dukes C, and Astler-Coller C2, indicating an advanced stage of cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma from a right radical nephrectomy specimen, with the tumor measuring 3.0 cm and classified as pT1a, indicating it is confined to the kidney. Microscopic examination shows a low histologic grade (G1) with no evidence of venous invasion or involvement of regional lymph nodes, and the surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. The specimen was received fresh and included a well-circumscribed nodule that abuts the renal capsule but does not invade perinephric fat, with small cysts noted in the renal cortex.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive solid carcinoma, consistent with ductal breast carcinoma, with a maximum tumor diameter of 3.0 cm. The tumor has specific measurements for its margins, with the closest being 0.5 cm from the ventral margin. The tumor classification is NOS, G III, pT2 pN0(0/13), indicating no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with the tumor measuring 2.2 cm and penetrating the renal capsule into the perirenal fat, but not present at the surgical margins. The tumor is classified as Fuhrman grade II and staged as pT3aNX, with no lymph nodes identified. An addendum confirms that sections of uninvolved kidney show no specific pathologic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 4 squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, characterized by a 4.2 x 4.0 x 3.5 cm mass that has invaded the pleura and chest wall soft tissue. While the bronchial and chest wall resection margins are negative for malignancy, 2 out of 4 intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes and 2 out of 4 superior mediastinal lymph nodes show metastatic involvement. Other lymph nodes from the inferior mediastinum, left pulmonary artery, and left lower lobe lung are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid, measuring 3.5 cm, with extensive capsular invasion but no blood vessel invasion or extrathyroid extension. Additionally, lymph node dissection revealed metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in 7 out of 12 examined lymph nodes, with the largest metastatic node measuring 2.4 cm. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic thyroid shows nodular hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two polypoid lesions in the stomach, with the larger one measuring 8.5 cm and the smaller one 1.2 cm, both consistent with liposarcoma with de-differentiation. The report confirms that the margins are negative for malignancy, and additional findings include benign gastric tissue and fat necrosis in the omentum. An external consultation is pending for further evaluation of the gastric mass.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right floor of mouth and right lateral tongue, with a maximum tumor depth of 1.3 cm and perineural invasion noted. One lymph node from the level I facial region showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma with extranodal extension, while other lymph nodes and biopsies from various sites were negative for carcinoma or benign. Additionally, an intra-tongue metastasis was identified as a well to moderately differentiated mucoepidermoid carcinoma, with all surgical margins reported as negative for neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma (G1) in the transverse colon, which has infiltrated the stomach wall. The tumor measures 10 x 8 x 4 cm and surrounds the entire circumference of the intestine, with a minimum side margin of 0 cm. The diagnosis is classified as Dukes B and Astler-Coller B3, indicating advanced disease (pT4b; pNO).

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 2.5 cm, with no evidence of tumor at the bronchial and vascular margins. Multiple biopsies and lymph nodes from various levels were examined, all of which were negative for metastatic carcinoma. Overall, the findings suggest localized lung cancer without metastasis to the examined lymph nodes or other tissues.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left ureter biopsies show benign reactive urothelium with no evidence of urothelial carcinoma in situ or invasive carcinoma. In contrast, the bladder neck biopsy reveals benign fibromuscular tissue with focal reactive urothelium and no malignancy, while the anterior pelvic exenteration shows multifocal high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma measuring 2.1 cm, with extensive involvement of the detrusor muscle and perivesical adipose tissue, but all surgical margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, lymph node examinations from both the right and left pelvic regions show no evidence of malignancy in the seven nodes examined from each side.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right craniotomy for tumor resection, with all specimens analyzed confirming the presence of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) in multiple areas of the right temporal lobe. Three separate specimens were collected, all showing irregular fragments of soft, tan-pink, focally hemorrhagic tissue consistent with the diagnosis. The intraoperative consultation corroborated the findings of glioblastoma multiforme in both the right temporal brain lesion and the medial right temporal tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe, with the tumor measuring 6.8 cm and showing lymphovascular invasion, but the bronchial and vascular margins are free of tumor. One of four level 7 lymph nodes contains metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the other lymph nodes examined are negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, a benign mediastinal cyst and post-obstructive pneumonitis with pulmonary edema are noted, with no significant findings in the superior vein stump.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma (grade 4) in the bladder, with tumor extension into the perivesical tissue but free surgical margins and no lymphovascular invasion. The prostate shows bilateral prostatic adenocarcinoma (Gleason score 7) with perineural invasion, but all margins are free of tumor, and no metastatic carcinoma is identified in the examined lymph nodes. The final pathological staging is pT3aN0M0 for bladder cancer and pT2cN0M0 for prostate cancer.

The pathology report describes a surgical specimen from the floor of the mouth, revealing a 4 cm moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma with a central ulceration and a depth of infiltration measuring 8 mm. The tumor exhibits perineural sleeve infiltration but shows no evidence of angioinvasion, with resection margins indicating a minimum distance of 2 mm to depth and greater than 5 mm laterally. Additionally, tumor-free excised tissue was identified, and the report notes the presence of inflammatory changes in the surrounding salivary gland tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of squamous cell carcinoma in the lung, classified as grade 3. The tumor is staged as T3 N2 M0, suggesting local invasion and regional lymph node involvement without distant metastasis. No treatment has been initiated at this time, and the specimen was obtained through a blood draw.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated serous carcinoma of the right ovary, along with chronic salpingitis on the right side. Additional findings include chronic cervicitis, proliferative endometrium, and leiomyomas in the uterus, as well as metastatic serous carcinoma in multiple pelvic nodules and focal microscopic metastatic carcinoma in the omentum. The lymph node dissections revealed two negative left pelvic lymph nodes and three negative right periaortic lymph nodes, with the overall staging classified as FIGO stage IIIB.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multiple foci of well-differentiated papillary thyroid carcinoma, including one classical type and four microcarcinomas, with the largest tumor measuring 2.3 cm located in the right lobe of the thyroid. Metastatic disease was identified in lymph nodes from the right neck levels three and four, with six out of nineteen lymph nodes involved in level three and one out of fifteen in level four, while level two showed no metastatic involvement. The surgical margins were free of tumor, and no extrathyroid extension or blood vessel invasion was noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, with one lymph node from the right parotid positive for metastasis and a total thyroidectomy revealing a unifocal tumor measuring 8.2 cm, with eight out of twelve examined lymph nodes also positive for metastasis. Additional dissections of the right and left paratracheal neck and right radical neck revealed multiple lymph nodes with metastatic involvement, including extracapsular extension in some nodes. The tumor is classified as well-differentiated (G1) and exhibits minimal capsular invasion, with margins uninvolved by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies from multiple lymph nodes (stations 7, 4R, and 12) show no evidence of malignancy, while the right upper lobe lung resection reveals a poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma consistent with adenocarcinoma, measuring 3.2 cm, with negative margins and no pleural involvement. The final TNM staging is pT2aN0M0, corresponding to stage IB, indicating no regional or distant metastasis. A portion of the tumor and surrounding tissue has been preserved for potential future ancillary studies.

The pathology report indicates that the excision biopsy of the brain tumor reveals a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV), characterized by high-grade glial tumor features including elongated nuclei, frequent mitotic figures, and vascular proliferation. The tumor shows diffuse p53 immunopositivity and a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 80%, indicating a high proliferation rate. Additionally, the MGMT promoter is found to be methylated, suggesting that the patient may benefit from therapy with alkylating agents.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma in the larynx, with evidence of lymphatic and perineural invasion, as well as subglottic extension. A total laryngectomy was performed, and the margins of excision were free of tumor, with no tumor found in the examined lymph nodes. The report also notes the presence of squamous carcinoma in the thyroid cartilage associated with the total laryngectomy specimen.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) in the bladder, classified as Grade 3. The tumor exhibits a mixed papillary and solid growth pattern and has invaded the muscularis propria, categorizing it as pT2. No vascular channel invasion was identified, and the background urothelium remains non-dysplastic.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, with the left level 6 lymph node showing metastasis in one of one lymph nodes examined. A total thyroidectomy revealed a unifocal papillary carcinoma in the left lobe measuring 2.5 cm, with metastatic carcinoma found in one of four lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as pT2, indicating it is greater than 2 cm but less than 4 cm and limited to the thyroid, with uninvolved margins and indeterminate vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast mass is diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma, measuring 1.1 cm, with high nuclear grade and lymphovascular invasion present, and the anterior surgical margin is involved. Additionally, one of four sentinel lymph nodes shows micrometastatic carcinoma, with no extranodal extension. The Oncotype DX assay reveals a recurrence score of 44, suggesting a significant risk of distant recurrence at 10 years.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV, measuring 1.9 cm and confined within the renal capsule, with free surgical margins. The deep margin examined is composed of benign renal parenchyma, confirming no tumor presence. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable, and the findings are based on personal examination of the submitted specimens.

The pathology report indicates a 7.8 cm squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe, extending into the left lower lobe, with four additional tumor nodules present. There is no visceral pleural invasion, and all sampled lymph nodes are benign, suggesting no lymphatic spread. The report raises uncertainty about whether the tumor in the left lung and a previously identified tumor in the right upper lobe are independent primaries or metastases, recommending clinical correlation for staging.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type) measuring 6.0 cm with 30% necrosis and a Fuhrman grade of 3/4, along with a microscopic implant of carcinoma in the perinephric adipose tissue. There is no extension into Gerota's fascia or evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, and one lymph node was found to be free of tumor. Additionally, bronchial washing shows suspicious cells for metastatic renal cell carcinoma, but definitive categorization requires further immunohistochemical confirmation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating small cell undifferentiated carcinoma in the right middle lobe of the lung, measuring 3.2 cm, with evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. All examined lymph nodes and associated fibroadipose tissue are negative for tumor involvement. The case was presented at a quality assurance conference for further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma in the stomach (cardia) with a tumor size of 5.0 x 4.0 x 0.7 cm, showing lymphatic vascular invasion and involvement of the proximal surgical margin. Metastatic disease is noted in 9 out of 33 dissected lymph nodes, while the celiac trunk lymph node shows no neoplastic involvement. Additionally, the adjacent mucosa exhibits inactive chronic discrete gastritis, and the esophageal margin shows no neoplastic involvement, despite the expansion of the esophageal margin being involved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma with focal sarcomatoid features, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade IV. The tumor measures 7.0 cm and invades the adrenal gland, but there is no invasion of the renal vein or definite evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. All surgical margins are free of neoplasm, and the non-neoplastic kidney appears unremarkable, with the tumor staged as pT3a Nx Mx.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a hysterectomy and lymph node sampling, revealing endometrial carcinoma of the endometrioid type, FIGO grade III, with invasion into the cervix and lymphovascular space. Among the examined lymph nodes, one out of five right pelvic nodes tested positive for carcinoma, while the left pelvic nodes and other lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. The tumor measured 4.5 cm and invaded the outer half of the myometrium, extending into the soft tissue at the lower uterine segment but not reaching the surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the left breast, classified as Nottingham grade I, with a tumor size of 2.2 x 2.1 x 1.6 cm and negative surgical margins. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, but non-neoplastic fibrocystic changes are noted in the surrounding breast tissue. Additionally, one of the two sentinel lymph nodes shows multiple metastases, with the largest measuring 3.5 mm and focal extranodal extension present.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma involving both the left and right ovaries and fallopian tubes, with significant tumor sizes of at least 5.0 cm and 6.0 cm, respectively. Additionally, the uterus shows invasive serosal implants of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma, while the omentum and pelvic nodule also contain serous adenocarcinoma. The terminal ileum exhibits infiltration of serous adenocarcinoma with mucosal ulceration, and the appendix shows invasive serosal implants of the same carcinoma type.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast following a partial mastectomy, with a Nottingham combined histologic grade of 3 and a tumor size of 4.9 cm. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, in situ components, or carcinoma in the examined sentinel lymph node, and all surgical margins are reported as negative for invasive cancer. The AJCC pathologic stage is classified as pT2 pNO, and clinical correlation is advised regarding the anterior margin, which is noted to be 0.3 cm from the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) based on the examination of brain tissue samples. Microscopic analysis reveals a glial neoplasm with cellular pleomorphism and a proliferation rate of 10%, with evidence of tumor growth along blood vessels and in the subarachnoid region. Additional findings include abnormal genetic markers, specifically gains in EGFR and MET, and a detected mutation in the IDH1 gene, although the clinical significance of this mutation remains unclear.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, following a right nephrectomy, with a tumor size of 10.6 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade 4. The carcinoma shows focal invasion into the renal sinus fat but does not invade the renal vein or exhibit angiolymphatic invasion, and all surgical margins are free of neoplasm. The adrenal gland is uninvolved, and the tumor is staged as pT3a NX MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant mixed Mllerian tumor (carcinosarcoma) in the uterus, measuring 7.2 cm, with 18% invasion of the myometrial thickness and minimal endometrial surface involvement. The tumor is associated with a pre-existing submucosal leiomyoma, but there is no evidence of lymphovascular space invasion or tumor in the cervix and adnexae. Additional biopsies of the abdominal peritoneum and lymph nodes show no tumor presence, confirming a FIGO stage of IA with no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the rectum, classified as pT3 due to infiltration into the muscularis and surrounding fatty tissue. There are vascular infiltrates present, classified as L1 and V1, but no lymph node involvement (pNO 0 of 15). The tumor is locally resected with clear margins (R0).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a Type B1 thymoma, characterized as lymphocyte-rich with degenerative cystic changes and fibrosis, measuring 5.0 x 3.0 x 2.0 cm. The tumor shows focal extension into the capsule and involves the margins, classified as Stage IIa due to microscopic transcapsular invasion. Flow cytometry analysis reveals a predominance of immature T-lymphocytes consistent with thymocytes, suggesting a lymphocytic neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme based on a brain biopsy. Microscopic examination revealed high cellular density, cytological pleomorphism, mitotic figures, vascular proliferation with thrombosis, and areas of necrosis. The MIB-1 proliferation index was noted to be 30%, confirming the aggressive nature of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 2, with a tumor measuring 2.1 x 1.6 x 1.4 cm that invades 0.4 cm into the myometrium, but without evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. Additionally, a benign endometrial polyp with complex hyperplasia without atypia is present, along with background endometrium showing complex hyperplasia without atypia. All examined lymph nodes and gonadal vessels are negative for tumor, and no diagnostic abnormalities were found in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or cervix.

The pathology report indicates that the right temporal brain lesion is diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme, a highly aggressive brain tumor. Additionally, a thrombosed vein was identified within the tumor tissue. The specimens were examined microscopically, confirming the presence of glioblastoma multiforme with high proliferative activity.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) from a tissue sample taken from the adrenal gland. The report includes details on tumor size and histologic diagnosis, with a Weiss score provided for further classification. Lymph node status is indicated as negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma from a partial adrenalectomy of the right adrenal gland. The tumor cells tested positive for Synaptophysin, chromogranin, and S100, confirming the diagnosis. The specimen included a well-circumscribed nodule located in the medulla of the adrenal gland, with a gross description noting its orange-red color and soft consistency.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with a tumor diameter of 2.5 cm and discrete in situ spread. The carcinoma has infiltrated the corial connective tissue of the adjacent superficial skin without causing ulceration, and there is focal tumor spread within the lymph vessels. The tumor classification is noted as NOS, G III, pT2N1aL1V0R0.

The pathology report indicates that a right hemicolectomy was performed, revealing an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 6 cm, which arose in a tubulovillous adenoma and extends into the subserosal fat. The tumor is located at the hepatic flexure, with clear margins and evidence of venous invasion, while two out of 65 lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma with focal extranodal extension. Additional findings include two hyperplastic polyps, and the appendix is unremarkable with no tumor present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma with pleomorphic features from a right shoulder soft tissue mass, measuring 3.8 cm in greatest dimension. Microscopic examination revealed positive staining for smooth muscle actin and vimentin, with a Ki-67 proliferation index of approximately 60%, while desmin, S100, and CD34 were negative. The surgical margins are negative for sarcoma, and there is evidence of necrosis present in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a 41.2 g left adrenal specimen was obtained from a female patient during a laparoscopic left adrenalectomy, revealing two masses: a 2.2 cm pheochromocytoma and a 2.0 cm adrenal cortical adenoma, both of which were completely excised. The pheochromocytoma exhibited moderate cytoplasmic staining and a low proliferation index, with no evidence of significant invasion or atypical mitoses. Additional molecular testing for SDHB germline mutation is recommended due to negative SDHB staining in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates multiple biopsies from various sites, with most showing chronic inflammation and negative results for malignancy, except for the mandible, which revealed invasive moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.2 cm with perineural invasion. Additionally, 45 lymph nodes were examined and all were negative for malignancy. The overall diagnosis corresponds to AJCC stage IVA (pT4a, pN0, pMx).

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma in both breasts, with the left tumor measuring 1.3 cm and Nottingham grade 3, and the right tumor measuring 0.8 cm and Nottingham grade 2. The left axillary lymph node dissection revealed metastatic carcinoma in 2 out of 24 lymph nodes, while the right sentinel lymph node biopsy was negative for metastatic tumor. Both tumors are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER-2/neu, with clear surgical margins in both breast specimens.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, with twelve out of twenty lymph nodes involved in the right neck dissection. The total thyroidectomy revealed a unifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right lobe, measuring 2.5 cm, with evidence of capsular invasion and lymph-vascular invasion. Additionally, Hashimoto thyroiditis was noted, and a left neck mass was found to have a lymph node negative for metastatic tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma (multicentric), Nottingham grade 2, with the main tumor mass measuring 57 mm in diameter and lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) comprising less than 5% of the tumor volume. Metastatic carcinoma is present in both sentinel lymph nodes, with no extranodal extension observed, and the resection margins are negative for tumor. The pathologic stage is classified as IIIA, with lymphovascular invasion noted and estrogen receptors being positive.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma in the right colon, with tumor invasion extending to the fat subserosa and evidence of lymph-vascular invasion, but surgical margins are free of neoplasia. Three lymph nodes were examined, all of which were negative for neoplasia, and adjacent mucosa showed a villous adenoma with high-grade dysplasia and two polyps with low-grade dysplasia. The overall staging of the tumor is classified as pT3 pNO pMx according to the TNM 7th edition.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade poorly differentiated serous papillary carcinoma involving both the right and left ovaries, with evidence of lymphovascular invasion and positive malignant cells in pelvic cytology, classified as FIGO stage IV. The carcinoma has metastasized to the anterior bladder peritoneum, uterine serosa, adjacent myometrium, and multiple other sites including the sigmoid mesentery, right pelvic peritoneum, and diaphragm, with positive findings in both examined periaortic lymph nodes. The tumor exhibits significant histological features, including marked cytologic atypia and a high mitotic count, confirming its aggressive nature.

The pathology report indicates a right hemicolectomy specimen revealing a 4 cm moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma located in the middle of the colon, with invasive spread to the muscularis propria but not extending to the resection margins. Additionally, a 2 cm tubulovillous adenoma with severe dysplasia was found, along with other tubular adenomas exhibiting mild dysplasia in the colonic mucosa. All examined lymph nodes and resection margins were tumor-free, leading to a final staging of pT2 pNO (0/46); G2.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent an adrenalectomy, with a specimen measuring 17 X 10 X 8 cm. The diagnosis is adrenocortical carcinoma, characterized by a KI67 proliferation index of 10%. Additional scoring includes a Weiss score of 5, a Hough score of 3.13, and a Van Slooten score of 18, confirming the malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade poorly differentiated mixed epithelial adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with components of endometrioid and clear cell carcinoma, showing extensive necrosis and significant myometrial invasion. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage 1B, with no lymph node involvement as all examined nodes were free of tumor. Additional findings include superficial adenomyosis, an endometrial polyp, and chronic cystic cervicitis, with no tumors identified in the omentum or peritoneal biopsies.

The pathology report indicates that a radical cystectomy was performed, revealing a poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma (grade 4) in the bladder, measuring 4 cm, with invasion into perivesical fat and the peritoneum, along with lymphovascular invasion. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in six out of 71 examined lymph nodes, including three positive left pelvic lymph nodes and two positive right common iliac lymph nodes, while the surgical margins were negative for carcinoma. Overall, the pathological TNM stage is classified as pT3bN2MX, indicating advanced disease with lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a left orchidectomy revealing a seminoma with a diameter of 9.0 cm. There is evidence of angio-invasion, but no invasion of the rete testis or tunica albuginea, and the epididymis and surgical margin of the spermatic cord are free of tumor. Overall, the findings suggest a localized seminoma with some vascular involvement but no extensive spread.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left periaortic lymph node dissections, as well as the pelvic lymph node dissections, revealed benign hyperplastic lymph nodes with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The hysterectomy specimen showed a moderately to poorly differentiated endometrioid carcinoma of the endometrium, measuring 4.8 x 4.6 cm, with significant myometrial invasion and involvement of the cervix, but no metastasis to the lymph nodes was detected. The surgical margins were uninvolved by tumor, and the overall pTNM stage is classified as pT2, N0.

The pathology report indicates that two left axillary sentinel lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for metastatic disease. The left breast mass excised revealed invasive mucinous carcinoma, classified as Elston SBR grade 2, with the tumor being less than 1 mm from the deep margin and extremely close to the lateral margin. Additionally, the pectoralis fascia showed adipose tissue and skeletal muscle, with mucinous carcinoma present at the inked medial margin of resection, but no significant pathology was noted in the non-tumorous breast tissue.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes excised from various levels are negative for malignancy, with a total of ten lymph nodes showing no evidence of cancer. A wedge resection of the right upper lobe of the lung revealed a moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.8 cm, with negative margins and no pleural invasion. Additionally, a hyalinized plaque was noted in the lung, but no other tumors were identified in the remaining lung tissue examined.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an embryonal carcinoma in the right testis, measuring 1.8 cm, with the neoplasia confined to the testis and extensive areas of necrosis. There is no evidence of neural infiltration, lymphatic vascular invasion, or sanguineous vascular invasion. Additionally, the spermatic cord and epididymis are free of neoplastic involvement, and the surgical margins are clear of cancer.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe, measuring 2.0 cm, with metastases to two of three level 5 lymph nodes and evidence of visceral pleural invasion, while all surgical margins are free of cancer. The pathologic stage is classified as T2 N2 Mx. Additional findings include respiratory bronchiolitis with emphysematous changes and multifocal atypical adenomatous hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral papillary serous adenocarcinoma with extensive lymphovascular space invasion in both ovaries, as well as metastatic disease in the fallopian tubes, uterus, paracervical soft tissue, and omentum. The tumor is classified as poorly differentiated (G3) and shows significant invasion into surrounding tissues, with a final staging of FIGO IIIC due to macroscopic peritoneal metastasis. Additionally, an endometrial polyp was identified as an incidental finding, while the endometrium itself was inactive.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous carcinoma involving both ovaries, classified as FIGO IIIC grade 3, with associated endometriosis and multiple metastatic sites including the pelvic lymph node, sigmoid colon, appendix, ileum, and omentum. The tumor exhibits angiolymphatic invasion and uterine serosal implants, with a pathologic TNM stage of T3c N1 MX. Additionally, there are findings of mild cervical atrophy, erosion, nabothian cysts, proliferative endometrium, and adenomyosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a right adrenal pheochromocytoma measuring 4 cm, characterized by infarction and cystic degeneration, with no evidence of capsular or vascular invasion, and rare mitotic activity. Immunohistochemical analysis shows low Ki-67 labeling (approximately 1%) and positive staining for SDHB protein, suggesting the absence of SDH mutation. The specimen was noted to have a lacerated appearance with a significant hemorrhagic mass and a central cyst, with approximately 70% of the tumor sampled for analysis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade III, with significant myometrial invasion and vascular invasion, while the uterine serosa is negative for carcinoma. All examined lymph nodes from both sides, as well as additional excised tissues from the parametrium and paracolpos, were found to be benign, with no evidence of metastatic disease. Reactive changes were noted in the vaginal mucosa, likely related to prior vaginal packing, but no residual tumor was identified in the excised vaginal tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a brain tumor located in the right frontal parietal region, measuring 11.0 x 9.0 x 3.0 cm. Microscopic examination reveals infiltrating malignant glial cells, necrosis, vascular proliferation, and significant mitotic activity, consistent with a diagnosis of glioblastoma. The final diagnosis is confirmed as glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV).

The pathology report indicates extensive involvement of high-grade serous carcinoma in the omentum, bilateral ovaries, and the serosal surfaces of both fallopian tubes and uterus, with positive peritoneal washings for serous carcinoma. The findings suggest that the tumor originates from the ovaries rather than being a primary peritoneal serous carcinoma, as there is significant parenchymal involvement in both ovaries. Additionally, the uterus shows atrophic endometrium and benign leiomyomas, while the cervix appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of peripheral bronchopulmonary adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, characterized by a predominant acinar component and a smaller large-cell solid component, classified as stage IB (pT2, pN0, R0). The tumor is located at the junction of S1 and S2 and has infiltrated the retracted visceral pleura, which shows signs of fibrosis. Importantly, the resection margins of the bronchus and vessels, as well as all lymph nodes examined, are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 adenocarcinoma with signet ring cell features in the right upper lobe of the lung, with a mass measuring 2.5 x 2.4 x 2.4 cm that partially involves the stapled margin, but the pleura is uninvolved. A completion lobectomy revealed no residual tumor, and the bronchial margin was negative for malignancy, while multiple lymph nodes showed necrotizing granulomatous inflammation without evidence of tumor. Special stains performed on the lymph nodes for organisms were negative, confirming no infectious process.

The pathology report indicates that the left segmental mandibulectomy revealed a moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.8 cm, which involves the mandibular bone but has free margins from carcinoma at the bone edges. There is perineural invasion present, but no vascular invasion or tumor detected in the examined lymph nodes (37 nodes total). The medial, posterior retromolar, and buccal lateral margins were all reported as benign with no tumor seen.

The pathology report identifies a tumor classified as an atypical Type A thymoma, measuring a maximum of 12.5 cm, with infiltration into the lung and pericardium. The tumor is staged as pT3, pNx, pM1 (lung) and categorized as Masaoka-Koga stage IVb. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive markers for CK5/6, KL1, and p63 in epithelial cells, while other markers such as CD1a, CD3, and CD20 are negative, with some CD5- and CD117-positive T-lymphocytes present.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the peri-prostatic fat and the right anterior and posterior apex margins revealed benign tissue with no evidence of carcinoma. However, the radical prostatectomy specimen showed prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, which was confined to the prostate and had negative margins. There was no tumor identified in the seminal vesicles, and the overall staging was pT2cNO, indicating localized disease without extraprostatic extension.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive serrated adenocarcinoma of the colon, classified as grade G2, with muscular infiltration and vascular involvement (L1, V1), but with free mucosal margins. Additionally, a serrated adenoma without dysplasia was identified, along with evidence of chronic resorptive lymphadenitis in the lymph nodes. The tumor classification is pT2, with complete local excision and no lymph node metastasis (0 of 18).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma in the right tongue and mandible, with the tumor invading the mandible and extending into the subcutaneous tissue and deep dermis of the overlying skin, although resection margins are free of tumor. No evidence of metastatic disease was found in the left submandibular lymph nodes or in the twenty-two lymph nodes from the right neck dissection, and there was no lymphovascular or perineural invasion identified. The tumor measures 5.0 x 3.8 x 3.0 cm and is located within 3.0 mm of the medial/inferior soft tissue margin, with the closest margins remaining free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme in the left parietal region of the brain, with evidence of leptomeningeal extension and large areas of tumor necrosis. Microscopic examination reveals a high-grade glial neoplasm characterized by atypical glial cells, high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratios, and a Ki-67 proliferation index of approximately 12%-18%. The report confirms the astrocytic nature of the tumor cells through strong positivity for glial fibrillary acid protein.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an anaplastic oligodendroglioma in the left temporal lobe, characterized by a neoplastic proliferation of glial cells with brisk mitotic activity and a high proliferation index. Molecular testing revealed no evidence of the EGFR variant III mutation or methylation of the MGMT promoter, but there was a positive result for allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, suggestive of typical findings in oligodendrogliomas. Immunohistochemical analysis showed prominent gliofibrillogenesis and overexpression of the p53 protein in the neoplastic cells.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, grade IV, located in the left temporal region, characterized by a pleomorphic proliferation of astrocytic cells with abundant mitoses, endothelial proliferation, and necrosis. The frozen section diagnosis confirms the presence of glioblastoma with extensive necrosis, and additional tissue was requested for permanent sections. The specimen consisted of both fresh and formalin-fixed tissue, with the gross description noting irregular fragments of soft and rubbery tissue.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes (Level 7, Low 4R, High 4R, and Level 11) were removed, and no tumor was identified in these lymph node fragments. A lobectomy of the right upper lobe revealed a 3.5 cm invasive, moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma, with lymphovascular space invasion but no pleural or vascular involvement. The staging is classified as pT2a, pN1, with one peribronchial lymph node involved by metastatic carcinoma, and all surgical margins were negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a left adrenal pheochromocytoma with capsular invasion, and vascular invasion cannot be ruled out. Immunohistochemical staining shows the tumor cells are positive for chromogranin, synaptophysin, and S-100. The specimen is a large mass measuring 7.5 x 7 x 5 cm, with a hemorrhagic surface and a central cyst, and the margins are clear of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the resected colon and rectum are free of tumor at both the oral and aboral resection margins. It identifies an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that has infiltrated the lamina muscularis but shows no regional lymph node metastases. The tumor is classified as grade 2, with a pT2 staging and no lymphovascular invasion, based on the examination of 33 lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, eosinophilic type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3, measuring 4.5 cm and extending into the perinephric adipose tissue, although the surgical margins are free of tumor. A segment of the 11th rib was submitted for gross inspection only, and no tumors were found in the left adrenal gland or the seven examined left periaortic lymph nodes. The tumor exhibits characteristic eosinophilic granular cytoplasm and is consistent with chromophobe renal cell carcinoma based on immunohistochemical and electron microscopic findings.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two nodules in the right adrenal gland, measuring 6.2 cm and 3.1 cm, consistent with a pheochromocytoma. Both tumors are encapsulated, with the larger one exhibiting signs of fresh bleeding and focal necrosis, while the smaller tumor shows no necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis confirms the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma, and the surgical margins appear to be free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 8, involving 40% of the left lobe and 25% of the right lobe, with perineural invasion present but no seminal vesicle or extracapsular invasion. All examined lymph nodes (10 total) and the left seminal vesicle showed no evidence of tumor, and the surgical margins are free of invasive carcinoma. The overall pathologic staging is pT2c, indicating bilateral disease without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, predominantly nonkeratinizing, poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma at the right base of the tongue, with a depth of invasion of 0.5 cm and positive p16 immunohistochemical staining. Additionally, the soft tissue from the right neck lymph node shows skeletal muscle with scar tissue, acute and chronic inflammation, and a foreign body giant cell reaction, but is negative for neoplasm. The findings were confirmed by the signing staff pathologist who examined the slides.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of primary uterine adenocarcinoma, endometrioid-type, FIGO grade 2, with a minor component of high-grade serous carcinoma, primarily involving the uterine fundus and corpus, but with minimal myometrial invasion and no cervical involvement or metastatic disease in the ovaries or fallopian tubes. Additional findings include two uterine leiomyomas, multifocal adenomyosis, and a benign fibrous-walled cyst from an excised intraperitoneal mass, with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the examined lymph nodes. The report also notes various benign changes in the cervix and ovaries, and the surgical margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, consisting of a mixture of Type 1 and Type 2, with a nuclear grade of 2 out of 4 and a tumor size of 1.5 cm located in the upper pole of the right kidney. The tumor is unifocal, confined to the renal parenchyma with negative surgical margins, and shows no evidence of sarcomatoid features, necrosis, or lymph-vascular invasion. Pathologic staging is classified as pT1, NX, MX, and minimal nephrosclerosis is noted in the nonneoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, characterized by markedly pleomorphic and poorly differentiated areas, with a tumor size of 6.0 cm located at the right lateral and anterior walls. All examined ureteral and lymph node margins were negative for tumor, with a total of 16 lymph nodes showing no evidence of malignancy. Additionally, there is an incidental finding of adenocarcinoma in the prostate, classified with a Gleason score of 6, but without evidence of extraprostatic extension or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), which is confined to the prostate and involves both the right and left lobes, affecting less than 10% of the prostatic tissue. There is no involvement of surgical margins, seminal vesicles, or lymph nodes, and the pathological staging is classified as pT2c. Additionally, benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is noted as an incidental finding.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 8x7x4 cm and metastasis to one out of twenty-five peribronchial lymph nodes. All other examined lymph nodes and the fifth rib were negative for tumor involvement. The bronchial margins of resection were negative for tumor, and there was no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or visceral pleural involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the resected sections of the descending and sigmoid colon, with tumor-free resection margins. The tumor has infiltrated the lamina muscularis propria and shows several regional lymph node metastases. Additionally, there is significant perifocal inflammation and the tumor is encroaching on the peritoneum of the abdominal wall.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing perineural invasion and infiltration into peri-prostatic adipose tissue, particularly around the right seminal vesicle. There are positive surgical margins in six blocks, but the lymph nodes on both sides are tumor-free, indicating no metastasis. The tumor measures a maximum diameter of 48 mm and has a volume of approximately 30.2 ml, with additional findings of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and myoglandular hyperplasia in the remaining prostatic tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma of the larynx, involving the right supraglottic region, base of the right epiglottis, right false vocal cord, and focally the right true vocal cord. The tumor measures 1.5 x 1.3 x 0.7 cm and shows focal perineural and vascular channel invasion, but the resection margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the hyoid bone and thyroid cartilage are pending further evaluation after decalcification.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, confirmed through multiple excisional biopsies from the left temporal region, with varying percentages of tumor necrosis and high cellularity. Immunohistochemical analysis shows retained expression of PTEN and low levels of MGMT, suggesting potential responsiveness to EGFR kinase inhibitors and radiation therapy. The presence of aggressive tumor markers, such as up-regulated laminin beta 1 and beta 2, indicates a moderate to high aggressiveness of the tumor, which may impact prognosis and treatment options.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid carcinoma (Grade 3) in the uterus, with invasion exceeding half of the myometrium but no involvement of the endocervix or lower uterine segment. Examination of the pelvic lymph nodes revealed fat infiltration with no evidence of malignancy in 22 nodes. Additional findings include squamous metaplasia of the cervix, cystic atrophy of residual endometrium, and bilateral atrophy of the ovaries, with a final staging of pT1cN0.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation in the bladder, invading the deep half of the muscularis propria, but with surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, adenocarcinoma was identified in the prostate, classified as pT2a, with a Gleason score of 7, and no vascular or perineural invasion noted. All examined lymph nodes and ureter segments were reported as benign, with no evidence of extravesical tumor extension.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right middle lobe of the lung, with a maximum tumor diameter of 6.0 cm and evidence of pleural, lymphatic, and vascular invasion. Multiple lymph nodes, including subcarinal and level 3 nodes, were excised and found to be anthracotic but negative for tumor. Additionally, bronchial margins showed infiltration by carcinoma, with chronic inflammation and dysplasia noted in the bronchial mucosa.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 4.0 cm polypoid serous papillary carcinoma in the endometrium, with minimal myometrial invasion and lymphovascular invasion noted, while margins are free of tumor. Additionally, multiple implants of serous papillary carcinoma are identified in the sigmoid mesentery, omentum, and bladder, with no regional lymph node involvement observed. The overall staging is pT1a N0 M1, indicating localized endometrial cancer with distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in one left pelvic lymph node, while two additional left pelvic lymph nodes and eight right pelvic lymph nodes show no tumor. The prostate gland is diagnosed with prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 9 (5+4), with tumor extension into extraprostatic tissue and involvement at the margin of resection. The seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia are free of tumor, and further details regarding the pelvic lymph nodes can be found in the previous report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma arising within the left tonsil, with associated in situ carcinoma that focally involves a cauterized surgical margin. All surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, but lymphovascular invasion is identified. The tumor is classified as AJCC stage I (pT1, pNx).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma measuring 8.5 cm, which is confined to the endometrial cavity and invades less than 50% of the myometrium, with angiolymphatic invasion present. There is no evidence of carcinoma in the bilateral fallopian tubes and ovaries, and all examined lymph nodes (17 total) show no signs of metastasis. The surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, indicating that the tumor has not spread beyond the uterus.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal carcinoma, solid variant, with a histologic grade of 3 and a tumor size of 2.5 cm, showing no direct invasion beyond the kidney and absent lymphovascular invasion. All surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and the tumor is classified as pT1a according to AJCC staging. There are no significant pathologic findings in the non-neoplastic kidney, and lymph nodes could not be assessed.

The pathology report indicates that two tumor specimens were analyzed, both diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV astrocytoma). The first tumor specimen measured 0.5 x 0.3 x 0.3 cm, while the second tumor specimen was larger, measuring 1.8 x 1.2 x 0.8 cm. Both specimens were submitted for frozen section analysis, confirming the diagnosis of malignant glioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver, with a well-demarcated, multinodular mass measuring 4.0 x 3.0 x 3.0 cm, confined to the hepatic parenchyma and with clear surgical margins. The tumor is classified as Edmondson-Steiner grade IV with major differentiation III, exhibiting features such as capsular infiltration and septum formation, but without evidence of vascular or serosal invasion. Additionally, the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis, with three black stones identified.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive endocervical adenocarcinoma with mucinous features, moderately differentiated, located in the cervix, with a maximum tumor size of 3.5 cm and no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or parametrial involvement. All examined pelvic lymph nodes (22 in total) showed no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, and surgical margins were clear of invasive carcinoma. Additional findings included benign fibrofatty tissue in the common iliac lymph nodes and proliferative endometrium, with no significant abnormalities noted in the uterus.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple nodules of invasive mammary carcinoma in the right breast, specifically infiltrating lobular carcinoma and infiltrating ductal carcinoma, both classified as Nottingham grade I. The lobular carcinoma has metastasized to one of the right axillary sentinel lymph nodes, while the ductal carcinoma shows no evidence of metastasis in the lymph nodes. Additionally, extensive ductal carcinoma in situ is noted, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor, with HER2/neu protein overexpression observed in both tumor types, although no amplification for HER2/neu was demonstrated by fluorescence in situ hybridization.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mucinous adenocarcinoma located in the antrum of the stomach, with a tumor size of 5 cm. The tumor is classified as T2b, N1, M0, indicating it has invaded the muscularis propria and has regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. The macroscopic configuration of the tumor is described as type I (protruded) and Borrmann type III (ulcerated with infiltrative margins).

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure) revealing pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma measuring 2.8 x 2 x 1.7 cm, with invasion into the duodenal wall and two of eleven examined lymph nodes showing metastatic adenocarcinoma. All surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and there is evidence of lympho-vascular and perineural invasion. The final pathologic staging is pT3, N1, MX, indicating the tumor extends beyond the pancreas but without distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade metastatic papillary serous carcinoma in the omentum, bladder, and both ovaries, with psammomatous calcifications noted in the omentum. Additionally, adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, also of the papillary serous type, is identified, limited to the endometrium and involving endometrial polyps, with leiomyomata in the myometrium. The findings suggest extensive involvement of the reproductive organs and bladder by metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, ovaries, fallopian tubes, peritoneal implants, and various lymph nodes, with extensive tumor infiltration noted. The left ovary and tube show high-grade primary ovarian carcinoma with significant involvement of surrounding tissues, while the right ovary is virtually entirely replaced by tumor. The findings suggest a diagnosis of Stage IIIC papillary serous carcinoma, with extensive metastatic spread throughout the abdominal cavity and lymphatic system.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive poorly differentiated ductal carcinoma (grade III) in the left breast, measuring 5.0 cm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising less than 25% of the tumor mass. Metastatic carcinoma was found in two of the three sentinel lymph nodes examined, with one showing extranodal capsular extension, while the remaining lymph nodes in levels I, II, and III were benign or showed micrometastatic carcinoma. The tumor stage is classified as T2, pN1a, MX, corresponding to stage IIB.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating and intraductal carcinoma in the right breast, with significant vascular space involvement and an intermediate nuclear grade, measuring 6.0 cm. The report notes that 20% of the tumor volume is comprised of comedo-type intraductal carcinoma, and metastatic carcinoma is present in 6 out of 35 axillary lymph nodes, while surgical margins are free of tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive progesterone receptor staining (80%) and negative estrogen receptor staining (10%).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of biphasic malignant mesothelioma in the pericardial fat, pleura, and diaphragmatic pleura, with associated fibrous tissue changes. Biopsies of the level 4, level 7, and level 8 lymph nodes revealed anthracotic changes but were negative for metastases. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma, showing positive markers for cytokeratin and calretinin.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal adenocarcinoma with lobular features in the left breast, classified as Nottingham grade 3. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic ductal adenocarcinoma in the axillary lymph node. Estrogen/progesterone receptor, HER2/Neu, and EGFR analyses are pending for further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of primary mediastinal diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in the left cervical lymph node, characterized by an effaced lymph node architecture with sheets of large, pleomorphic neoplastic cells, some exhibiting Reed-Sternberg morphology. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the neoplastic cells are positive for several markers including CD20 and CD30, while being negative for CD10 and CD15, with a Ki67 proliferative index of 70-80%. Additionally, a moderate number of reactive T-cells are present, and the karyotype is normal.

The pathology report indicates a high histological grade glioma, specifically a mixed oligodendroglioma, from a left frontal brain excision. Microscopic examination reveals medium-sized neoplastic cells with hyperchromatic pleomorphic nuclei, significant mitotic activity, and areas of necrosis, with a MIB-1 labeling index of 22%. The findings suggest anaplastic features, and the tumor is characterized by a solid cellular glial proliferation with both oligodendroglial and astrocytic components.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 3 cm moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, accompanied by low-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The resection margins are clear of cancerous tissue, and two out of sixteen lymph nodes show metastases. The tumor classification is pT2, pN1a, with a grade of G2, and no lymphovascular invasion (L0) or perineural invasion (V0).

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a craniotomy for a large right frontal brain mass, which was diagnosed as glioblastoma. The tumor exhibits extensive infiltration, necrosis, and areas of hemorrhage, with a proliferation index of 6% and overexpression of p53 in about 25% of neoplastic nuclei. Additional special stains are being requested to further characterize the tumor, and the findings support the diagnosis of glioblastoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a left parietal occipital brain tumor, specifically a glioblastoma classified as grade IV according to the WHO scale. Microscopic examination reveals a densely cellular tumor with pleomorphic astrocytes, numerous mitoses, pseudopalisading necrosis, and microvascular proliferation, confirming the malignancy. The specimen was processed for both frozen section analysis and further histological examination, with additional immunohistochemistry studies noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which is invasive into the muscularis propria, but without evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Additionally, a biopsy of the left renal pelvis shows low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma, although invasion cannot be assessed due to the lack of lamina propria. Cytological evaluations from renal pelvis brushing and washing suggest suspicious findings for low-grade carcinoma, but the washing results are negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) in the brain tissue obtained from a craniotomy, characterized by cytologic pleomorphism, mitotic figures, microvascular changes, and pseudopalisading necrosis. The mass is predominantly located in the right temporal lobe, with some involvement of the inferior right parietal white matter, and shows evidence of a previous surgical resection. The report notes that the mass effect and effacement of the right basilar cisterns have not significantly changed compared to prior imaging studies.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with the left axillary sentinel lymph node showing metastasis and the right axillary sentinel lymph nodes also affected. The left breast mastectomy reveals invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 2.2 cm, while the right breast mastectomy shows invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 3.3 cm, both with negative surgical margins. Additional findings include extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) in the right breast, and the report notes positive estrogen and progesterone receptor status for the right breast tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma, measuring 3.0 cm, located in the cecum/ascending colon, with evidence of invasion through the muscularis propria into pericolonic adipose tissue. The tumor has negative proximal, distal, and radial resection margins, and no lymphovascular, venous, or perineural invasion is identified, although there is a suspicious focus of extramural venous invasion noted in an addendum. Additionally, there is one separate adenoma present, and the regional lymph nodes show no evidence of metastasis (0/30).

The pathology report indicates a right hemicolectomy specimen containing an invasive moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.9 x 3.2 x 0.5 cm, which invades the subserosa and has metastasized to one out of thirty-seven lymph nodes. Surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and additional findings include multiple tubular adenomas and a hyperplastic polyp at the ileocecal valve. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive expression of mismatch repair proteins (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2), indicating no abnormalities in mismatch repair protein expression.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated combined hepatocellular-cholangiocarcinoma located in segments 2 and 3 of the liver, with a largest tumor size of 3.8 cm and the presence of a satellite lesion. There is extensive microscopic small vessel/lymphatic invasion, but no macroscopic venous invasion or invasion of major branches of portal or hepatic veins. Additionally, the report notes cirrhosis with mild to moderate steatosis consistent with chronic hepatitis C, and the tumor is present at the cauterized inked resection margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal and lobular carcinoma in the right upper outer quadrant of the breast, with a tumor size of 1.8 x 1.6 x 1.6 cm. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/4 positive). The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tumor grading and characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, which extensively involves the stomach wall and has metastasized to 11 out of 15 examined lymph nodes. The esophagus shows no evidence of malignancy, and the small bowel segment is unremarkable with no diagnostic abnormalities. The tumor is staged as pT3 N2 Mx, indicating penetration through the serosa and significant lymph node involvement, with the prognosis pending further clinical evaluation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multicentric invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, with multiple tumor foci ranging from 0.3 cm to 1.8 cm in size, and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising less than 25% of the total tumor mass. Sentinel lymph node #1 is positive for metastatic carcinoma with extranodal extension, while sentinel lymph node #2 and non-sentinel lymph tissue are benign. The tumors exhibit moderate histologic and nuclear grades, with no involvement of surgical margins or skin, and the special studies show positive estrogen and progesterone receptor status, with negative HER2/neu.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma measuring 3.4 cm, exhibiting both papillary and clear cell features, with Furhman nuclear grade 3/4. Molecular analysis revealed trisomy of chromosomes 7 and 17, consistent with a papillary renal cell carcinoma phenotype, and the tumor is confined within the kidney capsule with free resection margins and no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. Additionally, the tumor shows prominent necrosis, while the surrounding non-neoplastic kidney is largely unremarkable, although there is noted glomerular sclerosis and interstitial inflammation in the peritumoral area.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in a female patient, with the tumor located in the breast and classified as grade 2. The staging reveals T2, N1, and M0, indicating a primary tumor with regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered at this time, and a separate blood sample was collected, which is reported as normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV, found in a right kidney partial nephrectomy specimen, measuring 2.0 cm and confined within the renal capsule without invasion of the renal vein. The tumor is located less than 1 mm from the surgical margin, and the non-neoplastic kidney shows patchy lymphocytic infiltrate. Additionally, a biopsy of the deep margin revealed benign fibroadipose tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinosarcoma in three examined lymph nodes from the right periaorta, with the tumor originating from an endometrial polyp and showing myometrial and endocervical invasion. Additionally, the total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy revealed carcinosarcoma of the endometrium with heterologous differentiation and adenomyosis in the myometrium. The omentum excision showed metastatic serous adenocarcinoma, while two examined lymph nodes were benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive well-differentiated squamous carcinoma in the right alveolectomy specimen, with focal invasion into bone but free margins of resection. The inferior anterior margin and buccal margin show mild to moderate dysplasia, while other examined tissues, including the nasal floor mucosa and maxillary sinus mucosa, show no tumor presence. Additionally, the right inferior turbinate specimen is pending decalcification, and the report confirms that previous diagnoses remain unchanged.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma in both ovaries, with metastasis involving the right peritubal soft tissue and extensive replacement of the omentum. Additionally, there is evidence of synchronous primary tumors in the endometrium, characterized by complex hyperplasia with atypia, but no definite myometrial invasion is identified. The cervix is free of endometrial carcinoma, although metastatic papillary serous adenocarcinoma is present in the deep paracervical soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent bilateral total mastectomies due to left invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 2.8 cm and right invasive ductal carcinoma with tubular features measuring 1.1 cm, both classified as Nottingham grade 1. No lymphovascular invasion was noted, and all examined lymph nodes were negative for neoplasm. The tumors were positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, with HER2/neu showing low expression, and surgical margins were clear of invasive cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma with extensive necrosis in multiple brain biopsy specimens from the medial temporal lobe, hippocampus, and posterior temporal lobe. Approximately 90% of the tissue is necrotic, with a MIB-1 proliferation index of 15% in more active areas, suggesting a high-grade astrocytic neoplasm. Additionally, the MGMT promoter methylation analysis shows a positive result in one block and a negative result in another, indicating variability in the methylation status of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that both sentinel lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The left breast mass is diagnosed as infiltrating ductal carcinoma, grade 2, measuring 1.5 cm, with negative margins and no vessel invasion. Additional biopsies from various locations in the breast show mild fibrocystic changes and are also negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe lung nodule is diagnosed as moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 1.9 cm, with lymphovascular invasion present but no perineural invasion. All examined lymph nodes (Level 5, 9, 11, and 12) and the 6th rib specimen were found to be benign, with no metastatic disease identified. Additionally, a separate focus of bronchioloalveolar carcinoma measuring 0.5 cm and multiple foci of atypical adenomatous hyperplasia were noted in the lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous cystadenomas in both the right and left ovarian cysts. A segmental resection of the left colon revealed an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 5 cm, with two out of seventeen lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma, but with negative margins. Additional findings included normal colonic mucosa in the distal and proximal donuts and endosalpingiosis in the small bowel nodule, with no malignancy detected.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right supraglottic region, measuring 4.8 cm, with evidence of invasion into surrounding tissues including the thyroid cartilage. A total of 54 lymph nodes were examined, all of which were benign, indicating no lymphatic spread of the cancer. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of perineural invasion, resulting in a pathologic stage of T4 N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates that the tissue over the prostate is composed of adipose tissue with no tumor present. The prostate gland shows adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6/10, located on both the left and right sides, but without extraprosthetic extension or involvement of the seminal vesicles or specimen margins. The tumor is classified as pT2c, pNX, pMX, and there is no evidence of perineural invasion.
