The pathology report indicates the presence of two distinct tumor masses in the left kidney: a high-grade renal cell carcinoma measuring 7.1 cm with features suggestive of a distal nephron origin, and a clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 2.6 cm that invades the renal capsule but is confined within Gerota's fascia. Both tumors have free surgical margins, and no local or lymph node invasion was identified in the examined specimens. The lymph nodes from the para-aortic and preaortic regions, as well as the adrenal gland, were found to be benign with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma in the stomach, with infiltration into the perigastric adipose tissue and classified as Bormann Type III. Surgical resection margins are uninvolved by neoplasia, but there is evidence of lymphatic embolization and metastasis in 1 of 12 resected lymph nodes, which shows extracapsular extension. All other examined lymph nodes and surrounding tissues, including the esophageal and duodenal margins, are uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 16.5 cm, with evidence of perineural and angiolymphatic invasion, and compromised proximal margins. Metastatic carcinoma was found in all dissected lymph nodes, with capsular transposition noted in both chain 5 and chain 3 lymph nodes. The final pathologic staging is pT3 pN3b, indicating advanced disease with significant lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of primary uterine adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with FIGO grade II and nuclear grade 2, showing extensive involvement of the endometrium and minimal invasion into the myometrium. The right fallopian tube also exhibits adenocarcinoma, with uncertainty whether it is a secondary involvement or a separate primary neoplasm, while the left fallopian tube and ovaries show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The vaginal margins are free of tumor, with only chronic inflammation and reactive changes noted.

The pathology report indicates a left inguinal lymph node biopsy revealing diffuse large B-cell lymphoma with focal plasmacytic differentiation. The lymph node is largely replaced by a proliferation of large neoplastic cells that are positive for several markers including CD20 and BCL6, while negative for others such as CD3 and CD10. The Ki67 proliferation index is approximately 60%, and no BCL2 gene rearrangement was detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with all examined nodes showing metastatic disease. The total thyroidectomy revealed a papillary microcarcinoma in the left lobe, measuring 0.8 cm, with no encapsulation and evidence of invasion into perithyroidal fibroadipose tissue. Additional benign thyroid and fibroadipose tissues were identified in other submitted specimens, with no significant abnormalities noted in the non-neoplastic thyroid or parathyroid glands.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lymph node at level 9R was negative for metastatic tumor, while the right upper lobe lobectomy revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.7 cm, with negative margins and no visceral pleura invasion. Additional lymph nodes excised from levels 7, 10R, and 4R were all negative for metastatic tumor, although some contained calcified granulomas and rare yeast forms consistent with Histoplasma capsulatum. The true proximal bronchial margin was also negative for malignancy, confirming the absence of invasive carcinoma at the margins.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with evidence of local invasion into perivesical soft tissues and metastasis to two out of three examined right distal pelvic lymph nodes. The left distal pelvic lymph node was benign, and the surgical margins from the bladder specimen were free of tumor. Additional findings include benign segments of the left and right distal ureters, with mild to moderate urothelial atypia noted in the right distal ureter.

The pathology report indicates that the left occipital tumor biopsy is diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme. The specimens received include multiple pieces of soft tissue, with the largest measuring 2.2 x 1.9 x 0.3 cm, and show hypercellularity, mitotic figures, new vessel formation, and areas of necrosis. The histological features confirm the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme for both the biopsy and the tumor specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the distal esophagus, associated with Barrett's epithelium. The tumor measures 5 cm in diameter, and out of 5 examined lymph nodes, 3 contain tumor involvement. The report notes that a radical resection was performed.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma, primarily located in the anterior uterine wall, with a tumor size of approximately 3.0 cm and a depth of myometrial invasion of 15 mm. Additional findings include focal positivity for p53 and MIB1 in the fallopian tubes, suggesting features consistent with serous tubal intraepithelial carcinoma, although no malignancy was identified in the fallopian tubes or ovaries. All examined lymph nodes and omentum were negative for malignancy, and the surgical margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with superficial invasion into the muscularis propria and carcinoma in situ at both ureteral orifices, while the surgical margins are free of tumor. The right and left distal pelvic lymph nodes, as well as the urethral margins and distal ureters, show benign findings, with no evidence of lymph node involvement. Additionally, a minute focus of adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6 is identified in the prostate, which is confined to one lobe and shows no vascular or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the histological and morphological findings are consistent with anaplastic astrocytoma, classified as WHO grade III. The diagnosis confirmed is anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade III. This suggests a malignant brain tumor with aggressive characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that two out of three left sentinel lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, with the largest metastasis measuring 1.2 cm and showing extracapsular extension. The left breast tissue biopsy reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma, grade 3, measuring 3.5 cm, with negative margins and the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ, grade 2. Additionally, there is no evidence of metastatic disease in nine other axillary lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, papillary type, with a tumor size of 6 cm. The tumor is classified as grade IV and is staged as T1b, with no regional lymph node involvement (NX) and no distant metastasis (M0). The sample was collected from the kidney and ureter during a resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two distinct tumors in the right kidney: a clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 2.5 cm with nuclear grade 3, extending into the fat of the renal sinus, and a separate papillary renal cell carcinoma measuring 2.8 cm with nuclear grade 2, both with uninvolved margins. The clear cell carcinoma is classified as pT3 due to its extension into the renal sinus fat, while the papillary carcinoma is classified as pT1, confined to the kidney. No vascular invasion or regional lymph nodes were identified, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue appeared unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the left ovary contains a serous carcinoma, classified as grade 3, with a size of 31 cm and a ruptured capsule, while the right ovary and fallopian tube show paratubal cysts without significant abnormalities. The uterus exhibits leiomyomas and the pelvic lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement, with incidental findings of lymphangioleiomyoma in the right pelvic lymph nodes. Additionally, biopsies from the bladder peritoneum and pelvic soft tissues reveal no tumors but show signs of acute and chronic inflammation, and the ascitic fluid and diaphragmatic washing are positive for adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a cervical biopsy. The tumor shows invasion into fibrotic stroma and exhibits focal necrosis. The report is based on the examination of the submitted slides by the pathologist.

The pathology report describes a moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm that infiltrates both gray and white matter, characterized by tumor cells with small, round nuclei and well-formed perinuclear halos, exhibiting little atypia. A small percentage of the nuclei are elongated with fibrillary processes, and there are no mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis observed. The diagnosis is a low-grade (grade II) oligoastrocytoma, predominantly oligodendroglioma, with a MIB-1 labeling index of 3.1%, indicating low-grade histologic features.

The pathology report indicates a resected sigma sample with a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (G2) exhibiting ulceration, necrosis, and peritumoral inflammation. The tumor has infiltrated the sigma wall to the subserous fatty tissue, but all examined lymph nodes (0/13) are tumor-free, and the resection margins are clear. The tumor is classified as pT3, pNO, MX, L1, R0, and there is also evidence of sigma diverticulosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well to moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma involving the gastroesophageal junction and proximal stomach, with a 1.5 cm extension into the distal esophagus, and negative resection margins. Out of 18 examined lymph nodes, 5 were found to contain metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while the common hepatic lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma. The tumor is staged as pT3 due to invasion of the adventitia, with lymphatic invasion present but no venous invasion detected.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes were examined from both the right and left neck dissections, with the majority showing no tumor presence, except for one lymph node in the right neck dissection at Level II "A," which contained metastatic squamous carcinoma with extracapsular extension. Additionally, a total glossectomy revealed invasive squamous carcinoma that was moderately to poorly differentiated, with negative margins for tumor. Overall, the findings suggest the presence of metastatic disease in the right neck while other examined tissues and lymph nodes were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, with a tumor size of 1.9 x 1.2 x 1.0 cm in the left breast, accompanied by a minor component of intermediate-grade ductal carcinoma in situ. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, with the nearest deep margin being 0.2 cm away from the tumor. Additionally, multiple left axillary sentinel lymph nodes are negative for tumor, confirming no lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right lower parathyroid biopsies showed no pathological diagnosis, while the total thyroidectomy revealed multifocal papillary carcinoma, specifically a dominant 1.8 cm follicular variant in the left lobe. Additionally, there was evidence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in one of three examined lymph nodes. The tumors were encapsulated with no signs of invasion or metastasis beyond the lymph nodes, and multiple additional papillary microcarcinomas were identified in both lobes of the thyroid.

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy of the left upper lobe of the lung revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 1.6 cm, with negative margins for malignancy at the bronchial and vascular resection margins. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes were examined, all of which were negative for malignancy, although some showed granulomas. Immunostaining confirmed the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma, and molecular studies indicated no mutations in the EGFR gene and no ALK gene rearrangement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous papillary adenocarcinoma in the right ovary, with the tumor measuring 13 x 6.9 x 6.5 cm and positive involvement of the right fallopian tube. Additionally, serous adenocarcinoma is present in the posterior vaginal peritoneum and nodules in the mesentery of the sigmoid colon and appendix, while the cervix and uterus show signs of adenomyosis and leiomyomata but are negative for carcinoma at the margins. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3a pNO pMX, indicating advanced disease with local spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of extensive prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7/10, showing neural invasion and involvement of the seminal vesicles and surrounding fatty tissue, with extraprostatic extension and focally involved peripheral margins. Three lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, a biopsy of the bladder neck revealed fibrofatty soft tissue that was negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with involvement of the peribronchial resection margin due to perineural spread, but no involvement of the pleura. The mediastinal lymph node biopsies show only reactive changes with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in any of the sampled nodes. Overall, the findings suggest localized lung cancer with no detected metastasis in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of choroidal melanoma of spindle cell type, characterized by a dome-shaped tumor measuring 10.5 mm in diameter and 7.3 mm in height, with moderate mitotic activity and minimal lymphocytic infiltration. Histological examination reveals a predominantly pigmented tumor with no evidence of scleral invasion or extraocular growth, and the optic nerve and examined vortex veins are free of tumor. Molecular genetic analysis shows normal chromosome 1, disomy 3, and gains in chromosomes 6 and 8q, which will be correlated with clinical and morphological data for assessing metastatic risk.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right frontal glioblastoma. Microscopic examination reveals a highly hypercellular and diffusely infiltrating astrocytic tumor with significant necrosis and microvascular proliferation, along with severe atypia in the tumor cells. Additionally, scattered mitotic figures are observed, indicating aggressive tumor behavior.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the chromophobe subtype, eosinophilic variant, with a histologic grade of 2 on the Fuhrman scale and a tumor size of 7.2 cm. The tumor is unifocal, with no evidence of extra-capsular invasion or involvement of surrounding structures, and all surgical margins are clear of tumor. The AJCC staging is pT2a pNx pMx, and there are no significant additional findings noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately-differentiated adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas, measuring 6 x 4.5 x 3.4 cm, with extensive perineural invasion and a positive retroperitoneal margin, while the pancreatic transection and common bile duct margins are negative for malignancy. Additionally, 21 regional lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for malignancy, leading to a final pathologic stage of pT3N0M0, classified as stage IIA. The gallbladder specimen showed mild lymphoplasmacytic chronic cholecystitis with cholesterolosis, but was negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 8 x 5 x 1.7 cm, with involvement of adjacent structures including the esophagus and lesser omentum. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/5 positive). The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no specified evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant melanoma with a poorly differentiated histologic grade, originating from a 3 x 3 x 1 cm ulcerated and pigmented skin tumor. There is evidence of metastasis, with 1 out of 10 lymph nodes (right inguinal) positive for cancer. The Breslow depth is measured at 10 mm, but details regarding margins, lymphatic, and venous invasion are not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy from the left supraclavicular lymph node is classified as Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma (DLBCL), characterized by positive markers CD20 and CD79a, and negative markers CD3, CD5, CD10, and Cyclin D1. The tumor exhibits a diffuse pattern with medium to large-sized cells and shows high Ki 67/MIB1 activity ranging from 80 to 90%. Additionally, there are areas of geographic necrosis noted, likely due to changes following a fine needle biopsy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma grade II in the uterus, with a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 1.4 cm and no lymphatic or vascular invasion noted. The right obturator lymph node showed metastatic carcinoma, while all other examined lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. Additionally, both the right and left ovaries contained benign simple cysts, and there was no evidence of malignancy in the fallopian tubes or other examined tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cecum, with the tumor invading through the muscularis propria into the pericolonic fat (pT3). The surgical margins are negative for tumor, but there is significant lymphatic invasion and metastatic adenocarcinoma identified in 11 out of 23 regional lymph nodes (pN2b). Additionally, an adenomatous polyp is noted adjacent to the tumor, while the appendix and remaining colonic mucosa appear histologically unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a Grade III poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 3 x 3 x 2.5 cm, with invasion into the stromal tissue and involvement of the corpus. There is evidence of lymphatic invasion, but lymph nodes were not examined, and no pelvic extension was noted. Margins and details regarding neo-adjuvant treatment are unspecified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma with squamous cell features located in the right posterior bladder wall, measuring 0.8 x 0.4 cm, which invades the detrusor muscle and extends into the prostatic stroma, with surgical margins free of tumor. Metastatic urothelial carcinoma was found in one of the right pelvic lymph nodes, while five other lymph nodes examined showed no evidence of neoplasia. Additional findings include focal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and background inflammation in both the bladder and prostate.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in a biopsy taken from the left supraglottis. The specimen measured 0.4 x 0.2 x 0.1 cm and was received fresh, submitted in a teabag. The findings are consistent with previous diagnoses, although specific clinical features and operative details are unspecified.

The pathology report indicates a renal tumor measuring 8x6x5 cm, characterized as papillary renal cell carcinoma of moderately differentiated histologic grade. Microscopic examination reveals elongated papillary structures lined by stratified cylindrical or cuboidal cells with irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei and evidence of mitoses. Additionally, there is metastasis to all examined lymph nodes (3/3 positive), and no neo-adjuvant treatment has been administered.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy due to well to moderately differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation, classified as FIGO grade 1-2, invading to a depth of 2 mm in the myometrium. No lymphovascular space invasion or carcinoma was identified in the examined lymph nodes, with a total of 29 nodes showing no evidence of metastasis. Additionally, mild adenomyosis and inflammation were noted, but the lower uterine segment and cervix were free of carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, with a tumor size of 12 cm and Fuhrman Grade 3 of 4. The tumor exhibits microscopic capsular invasion and extensive involvement of the renal vein, ureter, and renal sinus, while surgical margins for Gerota's fascia and renal artery are negative for malignancy. Additionally, there is evidence of perineural invasion and a small renal cortical adenoma, with the overall staging classified as pT3b pNX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (G2) in the ascending colon, with evidence of tumor infiltration into the pericolic fatty tissue and associated chronic inflammation. There is no evidence of metastatic spread, as all examined lymph nodes (0/16) and other resection margins are tumor-free. Additionally, the report notes the presence of chronic appendicitis and classifies the tumor stage as pT3, pNO, MX, L1, R0.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma in the bladder and prostatic urethra, with tumor invasion through the full thickness of the wall and involvement at the surgical margins. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in one of the left pelvic lymph nodes, while the right pelvic lymph nodes showed one positive out of four examined. Additional findings include focal urothelial atypia in the distal ureters, diverticulitis in the sigmoid colon, and no significant abnormalities in the appendix.

The pathology report indicates that the excised left frontal tumor is diagnosed as an oligodendroglioma (WHO grade II), characterized by a low-grade profile but with a locally elevated proliferation index of 8-10%, suggesting potential for future progression. Genetic analysis revealed losses of chromosomal regions 1p36 and 19q, which are consistent with the diagnosis of oligodendroglioma. Close follow-up is recommended due to the possibility of biological progression.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left segmental mastectomy due to a left breast mass, which was diagnosed as infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 1.8 by 1.5 by 1.0 cm, with poor histologic and intermediate nuclear grade. Additionally, there is a presence of ductal carcinoma in situ (comedo type) representing less than 2% of the tumor volume, along with fibrocystic changes and focal ductal epithelial hyperplasia, while surgical margins are free of tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive estrogen (95%) and progesterone (90%) receptor status, while HER-2/neu is negative.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the right breast, classified as poorly differentiated with a Nottingham score of 9 out of 9, and a tumor size of 5.6 cm. There is extensive lymphatic and venous invasion, with 9 out of 12 axillary lymph nodes positive for tumor, the largest metastatic focus measuring 1.5 cm. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive (20%), progesterone receptor negative, and HER2 negative, with the deep margin involved by the tumor, indicating a pathologic stage of pT3 N2a M# (AJCC Stage IIIA).

The pathology report describes a 4 x 4 x 3.5 cm bronchopulmonary neoplasm diagnosed as moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma without keratinization, exhibiting nuclear atypia and necrosis. There is evidence of lymphatic invasion, with one out of two regional lymph nodes showing metastasis. The tumor is well-defined with an anthracotic tattoo, and no neo-adjuvant treatment has been specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 5.4 cm and a histologic grade of 3 on the Fuhrman classification. The tumor is unifocal and appears confined to the kidney, with no evidence of extra-capsular invasion or involvement of surrounding structures, including major veins and lymph nodes. Additional findings include patchy chronic interstitial nephritis, fibrosis, and tubular atrophy, with the tumor staged as pT1b pNx pMx.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with papillary thyroid carcinoma located in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 4.5 x 2.5 x 2.7 cm, with low-grade characteristics and lymphatic invasion present, but no capsular invasion. The lymph nodes examined (2 total) were negative for metastatic carcinoma. The tumor is confined to the thyroid without multifocality or invasion into adjacent structures, and the surgical margins are negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade malignant fibrous histiocytoma in the left thigh, confirmed by both tru-cut biopsy and surgical resection. The tumor measures 12.9 x 8.6 x 9.3 cm, involves skeletal muscle and fibroadipose tissue, and shows areas of necrosis estimated at 20-30%. Surgical margins are free, but the tumor is located 0.15 cm from the deep resection margin, and immunohistochemical stains support the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 2.1 cm, with a histological grade of 2 based on the Elston modification of the Bloom-Richardson grading system. One lymph node out of ten examined showed metastatic carcinoma with extra-capsular extension, while no lymphovascular invasion or skin involvement was noted. Additional findings include fibrosis and hemorrhage at the biopsy site, with isolated micrometastases identified in the left axillary lymph node using immunohistochemistry.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma that has invaded the adjacent jejunum, kidney, and pancreas, with a tumor size of 7 cm and a pTNM stage of T4 N1. Metastatic carcinoma was found in two of thirteen examined pericolonic lymph nodes, while a single apical lymph node biopsy was negative for malignancy. The appendix showed no pathological diagnosis, and the spleen and other examined organs were unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as grade 3. The tumor is staged as T2, N0, and M0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered, and a normal blood sample was also collected.

The pathology report confirms the diagnosis of a choroidal melanoma of predominant spindle cell type in the right eye, with a largest diameter of 11.34 mm and a thickness of 7.6 mm, associated with exudative retinal detachment. Microscopic examination reveals a focally pigmented tumor with minimal lymphocytic infiltrate and no evidence of necrosis, while molecular genetic analysis indicates borderline losses on chromosome 1 and 3, along with gains on chromosomes 6 and 8. Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for Melan-A, BAP1, and HSP-27, suggesting a significant tumor presence with adequate clearance from surrounding structures.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the left adrenal gland following an adrenalectomy. The specimen consisted of a red-tan irregular-shaped soft tissue mass with multiple nodules, the largest measuring 11 x 5 x 2 cm, and showing areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Immunohistochemistry studies indicated strong staining for chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56, supporting the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left temporal brain lesion diagnosed as a diffuse astrocytoma, classified as WHO Grade 2. Molecular testing is pending, but initial findings show a low proliferative index and the presence of IDH1 R132H expression in the tumor cells. The frozen section diagnosis during intraoperative consultation suggested a glioma favoring astrocytoma, without evidence of frank anaplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon and upper rectum, with a tumor size of 8.5 x 7.4 x 6.3 cm that invades through the muscularis propria but does not extend through the serosal surface. The tumor is staged as pT3, with metastasis identified in 8 out of 15 regional lymph nodes (pN2b). The anastomotic rings show no pathological abnormalities, and additional findings include a tubular adenoma and serosal adhesions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with a tumor measuring 3 cm and classified as NSABP nuclear grade 3. The modified radical mastectomy specimen shows no residual tumor at the surgical margins, and all examined lymph nodes (16 total) are negative for metastatic disease. Additionally, a spindle cell component and focal intraductal carcinoma of comedo type are noted in the biopsy findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a high-grade spindle cell tumor, classified as a soft tissue sarcoma, located in the left thigh. The excised margins from the supralateral, vastus intermedius, and distal vastus lateralis regions showed no tumor involvement, while the main mass measured 12.0 cm and exhibited areas of necrosis. The tumor was found to be within 0.025 cm of the designated superficial margin, with other margins being widely free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of tubular adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as G3, pT3, pNO, with intestinal type according to the Lauren classification. The cancerous proliferation has reached the peritoneal surface, but surgical margins are free of neoplastic lesions, and there are signs of chronic inflammation and focal intestinal metaplasia in the mucosa outside the tumor. Reactive lymphadenitis is noted in multiple lymph nodes, while the adjacent omentum is free of cancerous lesions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade undifferentiated pleomorphic and spindle cell sarcoma in the right thigh soft tissue mass, measuring 12.4 cm, with evidence of necrosis and vascular invasion. The excised lymph node from the right groin was benign, and the margins from the proximal psoas muscle and other deep margins showed no tumor involvement. The tumor is noted to be close to the margins, with involvement of the proximal and deep inked specimen margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of colic adenocarcinoma characterized by solid and ductal cell elements, with notable loss of nuclear polarity and increased chromatin. The tumor has invaded approximately 1 cm into the surrounding fatty connective tissue, classified as pT3, and is staged as G2 with no regional lymph node involvement (pNO) and distant metastasis not assessed (MX). The report also notes the presence of lymphovascular invasion (L1, V1) and indicates a complete resection (R0).

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated invasive ductal adenocarcinoma measuring 2.0 cm in the tail of the pancreas, with superficial invasion into the peripancreatic fat and extensive perineural invasion. The tumor is located approximately 1 cm from the distal pancreatic margin, with all examined lymph nodes (0/9) negative for malignancy and margins free of tumor. Background findings include chronic pancreatitis, and the spleen and splenic vasculature are also negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the right inferior frontal lobe tumor biopsy yielded non-diagnostic material, while the resection specimens confirmed the presence of an oligodendroglioma, WHO Grade II. Additional assessments for 1p/19q and MGMT status are planned. The MIB-1 labeling index was noted to be low, not exceeding 4%.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right pelvic lymph nodes are negative for carcinoma, with no cancer detected in any of the examined lymph nodes (0/6 and 0/2, respectively). The prostate specimen shows prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4 + 4 = 8/10, involving approximately 15% of the examined tissue and exhibiting multifocal extraprosthetic extension, but with negative surgical margins and no seminal vesicle involvement. The pathological staging is classified as pT3a, N0, Mx, indicating locally advanced prostate cancer without lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph nodes are negative for metastases, while the left breast wide local excision reveals invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 2.1 cm, with tumor present at the anterior surgical resection margin. Additionally, the retroareolar tissue also shows invasive lobular carcinoma at the inked surgical resection margin. Estrogen and progesterone receptors are positive, while HER2 is negative, and the Oncotype DX assay shows a recurrence score of 29.

The pathology report indicates that a right upper lobectomy was performed due to lung cancer, revealing a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 7.7 cm, with invasion into the visceral pleura but negative bronchial margins. Lymphovascular invasion was noted, but multiple examined lymph nodes (including lymph nodes #10 and #7) were negative for tumor involvement. The overall diagnosis is T3 N0 Mx according to the AJCC Seventh Edition classification.

The pathology report indicates a tumor in the right lower lobe of the lung measuring 3.5 x 3.1 x 2.9 cm, diagnosed as mixed subtype adenocarcinoma, predominantly papillary and micropapillary with some solid components. There is infiltration of the visceral pleura, and the tumor classification is pT2, pN2 (37/39), pMx, G3. This suggests a moderately differentiated cancer with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma (grade 3) with squamous differentiation in the left wall of the bladder, which is invasive into the muscularis propria and shows lymphovascular invasion. The tumor exhibits extensive necrosis, inflammation, and reactive changes. The specimen consists of multiple fragments of pink-gray, friable tissue measuring a total of 4.0 x 4.0 x 3.5 cm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal bilateral papillary thyroid carcinoma, with a dominant invasive mixed classical and follicular variant measuring 1.9 cm in the isthmus, along with additional smaller papillary microcarcinomas. Metastatic disease is noted in multiple lymph nodes, with 8 out of 32 examined lymph nodes involved, including micrometastatic carcinoma in one lymph node. The report also describes various lymph nodes with no pathological diagnosis and additional findings such as simple epithelial cysts in the parathyroid glands.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) in the right breast, with the IDC being poorly differentiated and the DCIS showing high nuclear grade. Metastatic carcinoma was found in two of the sentinel lymph nodes, while the remaining lymph nodes were benign, and there was no extranodal extension of carcinoma. The report also notes that the invasive carcinoma is located in the lower inner and outer quadrants of the breast, with vascular invasion present but no involvement of surgical margins or skin.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from the right neck levels II, III, and IV, as well as various mucosal and margin specimens, are negative for malignancy. A squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated, was identified in the right posterior mandible, measuring 2.5 cm with no perineural or lymphovascular invasion, and all resection margins are free of tumor. Bone sections pending decalcification showed no evidence of bone invasion, and the medial mandible margin was also negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma, predominantly basaloid, located in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 3.5 x 3.0 x 4.5 cm. The tumor is classified as pT2a, with no lymph node involvement (0/35) and a high-grade (G3) designation. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positivity for p63, CK5/6, and some cells for CK14, while being negative for neuroendocrine markers and TTF1, with a proliferation rate of 40-60%.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph node biopsy is benign and negative for metastatic tumor. The rectosigmoid resection reveals a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that invades through the muscularis propria into the pericolonic fat, classified as pT3, with metastatic adenocarcinoma identified in 6 out of 16 lymph nodes. All resection margins are negative for tumor, and there are minimal changes noted in the diverticula.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two seborrheic keratoses and one lichenoid keratosis on the skin, with the latter completely excised. A biopsy of the right kidney revealed benign fibroconnective tissue with no malignancy, while a heminephrectomy confirmed a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, Fuhrman nuclear grade 2, with free surgical margins and no invasion. The right adrenal gland showed hemorrhage but was negative for malignancy, and overall, there was no evidence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a right renal mass diagnosed as a renal oncocytic neoplasm measuring 12 cm, which is confined to the renal parenchyma with no tumor seen in the adrenal gland or lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical staining suggests the tumor has low malignant potential, with differential diagnoses including low-grade chromophobe carcinoma and atypical oncocytoma. Cytogenetic analysis shows a normal male karyotype, indicating that the findings may reflect an overgrowth of normal tissue rather than a malignant tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the resection of the falciform ligament revealed benign fibroadipose tissue and was negative for malignancy. A pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple resection) identified a moderately differentiated invasive ductal adenocarcinoma in the pancreatic head, measuring 3.1 cm, with four out of thirty-three lymph nodes showing metastatic adenocarcinoma, resulting in a pathologic stage of pT3N1. All surgical margins were free of tumor involvement, and additional findings included chronic pancreatitis and chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma in the thyroid, with the dominant tumor measuring 6.5 cm located in the left lobe, and a secondary tumor of 0.4 cm in the right lobe. One out of five lymph nodes examined from the left neck dissection showed metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes were free of carcinoma. The tumors are classified as pT3 and pN1a, with no evidence of extrathyroidal extension or vascular invasion, and all surgical margins are uninvolved by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing chronic active cholecystitis with a significant increase in eosinophils. Additionally, a left nephrectomy showed renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear) cell type, classified as Fuhrman's nuclear grade II, with a tumor size of 5 cm, confined within the renal capsule and without evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. All surgical margins were free of neoplasm, and the non-neoplastic kidney appeared unremarkable, with the tumor staged as pT1b NX MX and histologically graded as G2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a bile duct hamartoma in a liver nodule, while a lymph node associated with the hepatic artery is negative for tumor. The distal pancreatectomy revealed an invasive, well-differentiated adenocarcinoma confined to the pancreas, measuring 6.8 x 4.0 x 2.6 cm, with extensive perineural invasion and one of 33 regional lymph nodes positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma. All surgical resection margins are negative for tumor, and the adjacent pancreatic tissue shows signs of chronic pancreatitis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma located in the left piriform sinus and pharynx, with a tumor size of 7.0 cm and a depth of invasion of 2.0 cm. The margins of the total laryngopharyngectomy specimen are negative for invasive carcinoma, although severe dysplasia is noted at the left pharyngeal margin. All examined lymph nodes from various neck dissections are negative for tumor involvement, and additional sections confirm no cartilage invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast mastectomy revealed benign breast tissue with fibrocystic changes, while the left breast mastectomy showed invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and evidence of necrosis and lymphatic invasion. One of the 22 lymph nodes examined was positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the left axillary lymph nodes showed one positive and twenty negative for metastatic disease. Additional findings included high-grade intraductal components and various benign changes in the breast tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, likely of ovarian origin, with extensive metastatic involvement in the pericolic fat, omentum, spleen, and transverse colon. The left ovary shows serous papillary adenocarcinoma, while the right ovary and pelvic wall also exhibit moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. Overall, the findings suggest a complex malignancy with multiple metastatic sites and features consistent with advanced-stage cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the right upper lobe lobectomy specimen shows a non-small cell carcinoma, specifically moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 3.0 x 2.5 x 1.5 cm, with areas of necrosis and negative margins. All examined lymph nodes (4R, Level 7, 4L, and Right Level 4) are negative for tumor involvement, indicating no lymphatic spread. The overall pathological staging is pT1, with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or visceral pleural involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.8 by 1.2 by 1.0 cm, with poor nuclear grade and extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (approximately 30% of the invasive tumor). The surgical margins, including skin, nipple, and deep margins, as well as five lymph nodes, are free of tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the tumor is HER2/neu positive (score 3+) and progesterone receptor positive (20%), while estrogen receptor is negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, with the largest focus of invasion measuring less than 0.5 cm and no visceral pleural or angiolymphatic invasion present. Additionally, a necrotizing granuloma was identified in the left upper lobe, and all examined lymph nodes were negative for malignancy, confirming no residual tumor. An addendum revealed the presence of fungal organisms consistent with Histoplasma species in the left upper lobe specimen.

The pathology report indicates that a segment 6 liver resection was performed due to hepatocellular carcinoma, with the tumor measuring 95mm x 75mm x 65mm and clear margins of at least 30mm. Histological examination confirms a well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with moderate nuclear atypia and small vessel invasion, but no necrosis, and the tumor has been completely excised. The gallbladder specimen was unremarkable with no evidence of stones or malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, located in the upper pole of the left kidney, measuring 10.7 x 7.6 x 1.7 cm, with a nuclear grade of 2/4. The tumor is confined to the kidney without invasion into major vessels or the adrenal gland, and all surgical margins are negative for neoplasm. Additional findings include chronic pyelonephritis, nephrocalcinosis, and vascular wall thickening consistent with arteriolonephrosclerosis, with the overall stage classified as pT2NXMX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated ulcerated colon carcinoma in the sigmoid colon, measuring 5 cm and invading all layers of the intestinal wall, with no tumor found within 3 cm of the resection margin. Additionally, a small specimen of submesothelial fibrosis was excised from the peritoneum. The tumor is staged as pT3 pNO (1/27), L0, V0, R0; G2, with all 27 examined mesocolic lymph nodes being tumor-free.

The pathology report describes a skin flap from the right leg of a female patient, with a clinical diagnosis of melanoma. Microscopic examination reveals an epithelioid pigmented melanoma measuring 11x9x2 cm, with a depth of 1 cm and a Breslow thickness of 5 mm, classified as Clark level IV, and showing ulceration. The final diagnosis is confirmed as epithelioid cell melanoma.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder specimen shows chronic cholecystitis, while the liver specimen reveals chronic hepatitis consistent with hepatitis B (grade 2, stage 2) and poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, with the resection margin being uninvolved. The liver also exhibits iron overload (3+), and the microscopic examination shows preserved lobular architecture with inflammatory cell infiltration and fibrosis. Overall, the findings suggest significant liver pathology related to chronic hepatitis and malignancy, alongside gallbladder inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a lung specimen obtained from a pulmonectomy, measuring 3 x 2 x 2 cm. Out of six examined lymph nodes, three showed evidence of metastasis. Additional details regarding tumor extent, other nodules, lymphatic and venous invasion, and margins were not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma with myogenic differentiation in a right leg mass measuring 13.5 cm, which involves deep soft tissue and skeletal muscle, with 60% of the tumor exhibiting necrosis. The resection margins are free of tumor, and immunohistochemical staining shows focal positivity for smooth muscle actin and desmin, suggesting myogenic differentiation. The specimen was well-circumscribed and included an unremarkable skin surface, with careful documentation of margins and necrotic areas.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a capillary hemangioma with sclerosis in a skin mole and a poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, grade 3, stage 1C, with extensive squamous differentiation and necrosis, invading 78% of the myometrial thickness. The tumor involves 60% of the endometrial surface and shows extensive lymphovascular space invasion, but the cervix and all examined lymph nodes are free of metastatic carcinoma. Hormone receptor immunohistochemistry reveals negative results for both estrogen and progesterone in the endometrial adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a left partial nephrectomy revealing a 2.4 cm papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 1, located in the upper pole of the kidney, with no sarcomatoid features or tumor necrosis identified. The tumor is classified as pT1a, indicating it is limited to the kidney and less than 4 cm in size, with focally extending margins to the cauterized inked parenchymal resection margin. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, and the nonneoplastic kidney shows chronic inflammation and dystrophic calcifications.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right modified radical mastectomy due to invasive ductal carcinoma, which is moderately differentiated with a nuclear grade of III. The tumor measures 3.5 x 3.3 x 3.1 cm and extends into the dermis, with over 90% of the tumor being invasive; however, the deep margin is free of tumor by 10 mm. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma is present in 4 out of 9 lymph nodes, while the medial skin of the right breast shows no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated, predominantly large-cell and partly clear-cell, nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, characterized by a large central lacuna. Additionally, there is evidence of tumor-related chronic inflammation, respiratory bronchiolitis, and emphysematous changes in the lung parenchyma, along with significant anthracotic pigment deposits in the lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as pT2 pN01 R0, stage 113, suggesting minimal invasion of the pleura and a potential primary focus in the lung.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) in a left frontal brain tumor following a craniotomy. The tumor exhibits characteristics such as high cellularity, mitotic activity, and extensive necrosis, with immunohistochemical studies supporting the diagnosis. Ancillary studies show weak positivity for p53, negativity for IDH-1, and a Ki-67 proliferation index of 40%.

The pathology report indicates that the left frontal brain biopsy and excision specimens are diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme. Two separate specimens were analyzed during intraoperative consultation, both confirming the presence of glioblastoma multiforme. The report includes details of the surgical procedure, which involved a left frontal craniotomy for tumor excision.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO Grade III endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, characterized by extensive myometrial invasion and vascular invasion, with no endocervical invasion noted. Additionally, a sigmoid nodule was identified as metastatic carcinoma consistent with the primary endometrial tumor. The left ovary showed a fibrothecoma, while the left fallopian tube was unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma (Grade 2) in the uterus, with a maximum depth of myometrial invasion measuring 3 mm and no evidence of cervical or lymphovascular invasion. Both sentinel lymph nodes from the right and left external iliac regions were examined and found to be benign, with no metastatic disease identified. The myometrium shows adenomyosis, while the endometrium and adnexa are unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 1.7 cm papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left thyroid lobe, with free margins and no evidence of carcinoma in the examined lymph nodes or other thyroid tissue. Additionally, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis is noted in both the left thyroid lobe and the right lobe. The overall staging is pT1, with no regional lymph node involvement and no distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 8 (4+4), showing tumor involvement in both the right and left prostate, with focal extraprostatic extension noted. All examined pelvic lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma, and there was perineural invasion present within the tumor. The report also highlights the presence of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and includes additional testing for DNA ploidy, which showed near diploid status.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of extensive urothelial carcinoma in situ and poorly differentiated papillary urothelial carcinomas, with invasive carcinoma extending through the bladder wall into perivesical soft tissue. Multiple foci of lymphovascular invasion were identified, and metastatic carcinoma was found in five of the 69 lymph nodes examined, while surgical margins were free of malignancy. Additional findings included benign lesions in the cervix, uterus, and ovaries, with no malignancy detected in the majority of the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, grade IV, located in the right frontal lobe. Microscopic examination reveals a pleomorphic and infiltrative tumor with biphasic characteristics, including small and larger astrocytic cells, along with mitoses, endothelial proliferation, and necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis shows strong positivity for GFAP in the tumor cells, confirming the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme.

The pathology report indicates that a partial colectomy of the rectosigmoid colon revealed a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.5 x 3.0 cm, with no lymphovascular invasion and negative surgical margins. Additionally, two previously unidentified lymph nodes were found, and all examined lymph nodes (13 in total) were negative for metastatic carcinoma. The final pTNM stage is classified as T3, and the colonic mucosa from the sigmoid colon rings showed no malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the left lung specimen shows invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with three out of fifteen lymph nodes positive for tumor involvement, and the overall staging is classified as Stage IIIA. The left rib specimen was grossly unremarkable, while the lymph node excisions revealed one node with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma and two out of three lymph nodes also showing metastasis. The tumor measures 8.0 x 7.0 x 6.0 cm, involves the main bronchus, and exhibits lymph-vascular invasion, but no visceral pleural invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, extending to the outer half of the muscularis propria, with additional foci of carcinoma in situ and no evidence of tumor in the prostatic urethra. The prostate shows a small focus of organ-confined microacinar adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6, and no extraprostatic invasion is noted. Metastatic urothelial carcinoma is identified in one of the left external iliac lymph nodes and in the left internal iliac node, but no metastasis is found in the right lymph nodes or left obturator nodes.

The pathology report indicates a left kidney mass diagnosed as a type 2 papillary renal cell carcinoma, measuring 2.4 cm with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with surgical margins negative at 0.55 cm from the tumor, and there is no evidence of blood or lymphatic vessel invasion. Additionally, mild arteriosclerosis is noted in the adjacent uninvolved kidney.

The pathology report indicates that the small bowel nodule and mesenteric node biopsies were negative for malignancy, while the gallbladder was unremarkable with no signs of cancer. However, the wedge resection of the right lobe of the liver revealed moderately differentiated cholangiocarcinoma, measuring 7.7 x 6.0 x 5.5 cm, with positive perineural invasion and close proximity to the liver resection margin. The immunohistochemical profile of the tumor supports the diagnosis of cholangiocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 3 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion, renal vein invasion, or small vessel angiolymphatic invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is limited to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma, primarily located in the left pyriform sinus, with extension into adjacent structures including the left aryepiglottic fold and subepithelial connective tissue of the left true vocal cord. The tumor has metastasized to 2 out of 26 cervical lymph nodes, while the tracheal, soft tissue, and other mucosal margins of resection are free of tumor. Additionally, there is no tumor present in the left thyroid lobe or hyoid bone, and further results regarding the tumor and underlying thyroid cartilage are pending decalcification.

The pathology report indicates that multiple skin margins and soft tissue fragments from the head and neck region show no evidence of malignancy. A buccal resection specimen reveals an invasive well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.0 cm, with negative margins and no perineural or lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, the right thyroid lobe contains multiple follicular colloid nodules consistent with goiter, with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that multiple excised lymph nodes and associated tissues are hyalinized and inactive, with granulomas present, but all samples are negative for tumor. Additionally, a portion of the excised rib is described as unremarkable. Overall, there is no evidence of malignancy in the examined tissues.

The pathology report indicates a subtotal resection of the stomach with a 4x4x3 cm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the fundus. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/11 positive), and the tumor extends into the muscularis propria. Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion, as well as margins and neo-adjuvant treatment, are not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, grade IV (WHO), based on both biopsy and excision of a left temporal brain mass. The findings include nuclear atypia, marked hypercellularity, tumor necrosis, and microvascular proliferation, with neoplastic cells positively staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein. The clinical history suggests a high-grade glioma, and the diagnosis was confirmed through gross and microscopic examinations by the attending pathologist.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multifocal multicentric invasive lobular carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 6.0 cm, with a Nottingham grade of 1. A total of 14 lymph nodes were examined, with 10 showing metastatic carcinoma, but no extravasation was identified. Additional findings include benign breast parenchyma and various changes in the left breast, including flat epithelial atypia and fibrocystic changes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of three separate tumors of clear cell renal cell carcinoma, all partially cystic, with a Fuhrman grade of 2 and a largest tumor size of 4.0 cm. There is no evidence of sarcomatoid features or invasion into surrounding structures, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement. Additional findings include moderate to severe arterionephrosclerosis, and the tumors are confined to the kidney without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated rectal carcinoma in a resected section of the colon, measuring up to 3 cm and extending 1.7 cm to the aboral resection margin. The tumor has invaded the muscularis propria but shows no involvement of the resection margins or local lymph nodes, with all 15 examined nodes being tumor-free. The tumor is staged as pT2 pN0 (0/15) L0, V0; G3 R0, indicating a localized cancer without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma in the temporal lobe, characterized by extensive infiltration of the cerebrum with features such as nuclear anaplasia, mitotic figures, and necrosis. The MIB-1 proliferation index is noted to be 20%, suggesting a moderate level of cellular proliferation within the tumor. Additionally, there are indications of an oligodendroglial component, although the predominant phenotype is astrocytic, specifically gemistocytic.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma (grade 3) involving both the right and left ovaries, with significant tumor presence on the ovarian surfaces and lymphovascular invasion noted. Biopsies from the right pelvic sidewall also confirmed the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma, and peritoneal cytology was positive for malignant cells. The uterus and cervix were found to be unremarkable, with no evidence of malignancy, while the omentum showed benign fibrofatty tissue without discrete lesions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of predominantly moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate, with a maximum tumor spread of 1.5 cm and left rectolateral predominance, but no evidence of vascular invasion or extraprostatic growth. The tumor classification is pT2c, pNo (0/2), L0, V0, with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, indicating approximately 40% Gleason 4. There is infiltration of the surgical margins in the left rectolateral and basal resection areas, with carcinoma cells extending to the labeled preparation margin and focal contact in the left apex region.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5 + 3 = 8, showing multifocal extracapsular extension and involvement of both the right and left lobes of the prostate, as well as extensive infiltration of the seminal vesicles. One of four lymph nodes examined showed a microscopic focus of metastatic prostatic adenocarcinoma measuring approximately 0.2 mm, while the other lymph nodes were negative for neoplasia. The final diagnosis includes a pathologic TNM stage of pT3b N1 MX, with recommendations for close clinical and serum PSA follow-up.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous adenocarcinoma involving multiple sites, including the omentum, ovaries, fallopian tubes, and appendix, with extensive tumor infiltration noted. The uterus and cervix show no significant histopathologic abnormalities, except for the presence of endometrial polyps. The findings suggest that the case should be classified as primary peritoneal carcinoma due to the extent of surface involvement without significant non-surface ovarian involvement.

The pathology report indicates a pneumonectomy specimen from the left lower lung, revealing a moderately differentiated bronchiolo-alveolar adenocarcinoma measuring 6 x 5 x 2 cm. Details regarding tumor extent, lymph nodes, lymphatic and venous invasion, margins, and evidence of neoadjuvant treatment are not specified. Additional pathologic findings are also not provided in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma with a Nottingham score of 9/9, characterized by a tumor size of 5.5 cm and extensive intratumoral lymphocytic infiltration. There is also the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ, accounting for 25% of the tumor mass, and angiolymphatic invasion has been identified. Additionally, 10 out of 21 lymph nodes examined showed metastatic carcinoma, with one exhibiting extracapsular spread, and all hormone receptor tests (estrogen, progesterone, and HER-2/neu) returned negative results.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma from the left tongue base/tonsil excision. The specimen consisted of several fragments of opaque, tan to red polypoid mucosal tissue measuring 2.1 x 0.9 x 0.2 cm in aggregate. The findings were reviewed by the attending pathologist, confirming the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a pheochromocytoma and an adrenal cortical adenoma in the left adrenal gland following an adrenalectomy. The specimen measured 14 x 7.5 x 5.4 cm and contained a 7.5 x 5.4 x 3.8 cm encapsulated soft tissue nodule, with minimal surrounding adipose tissue. Histological examination revealed a small amount of normal adrenal cortical tissue adjacent to the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated ductal breast carcinoma with invasive growth, identified during a left mastectomy preparation. The tumor has a dorsal margin of less than 0.1 cm, while the ventral margin is 0.5 cm, and other resection margins are greater than 1 cm. Additionally, all eleven examined lymph nodes are carcinoma-free, suggesting no lymphatic spread of the disease.

The pathology report indicates a left renal mass diagnosed as unclassified renal cell carcinoma with a high nuclear grade, measuring 6.5 cm, and an associated angiomyolipoma of 1 cm. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of local or renal vein invasion, with lymph nodes examined showing no involvement. Additional findings include mild arterionephrosclerosis and benign cortical cysts in the non-neoplastic kidney, while the adrenal gland and surrounding lymph nodes were also found to be benign.

The pathology report indicates an en bloc resection of the transverse colon, terminal ileum, right colon, mid jejunum, greater curvature of the stomach, and abdominal wall, revealing an invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 4.5 x 4.5 cm that invades adjacent structures but spares the gastric mucosa. There is associated acute suppurative and chronic inflammation with abscess formation, but all examined lymph nodes (0/25) and surgical margins are negative for carcinoma. Additional findings include focal squamous differentiation, chronic gastritis in the gastric mucosa, and acute serositis, with a final pathologic stage of pT4 N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates that two out of thirteen lymph nodes from a neck dissection are involved with squamous cell carcinoma, and a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 6.1 cm was excised from the right tongue, with less than 1 mm from the medial margin. Additionally, three lymph nodes from the right neck level 1 and a tongue base lesion were negative for malignancy, while perineural invasion was noted in the primary tumor. The findings correspond to AJCC pathologic stage IVA, indicating advanced disease with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the eosinophilic variant of conventional clear cell type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of III out of IV. The tumor measures 4.0 cm, is confined within the renal capsule, and shows no invasion of the renal vein or evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, with all surgical margins free of neoplasm. Additionally, the non-neoplastic kidney exhibits hyaline arteriolosclerosis, and there is an organizing hematoma in the subcapsular region, with a TNM stage of pT1a Nx Mx and a histologic grade of G3.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with significant involvement in the right neck posterior triangle, right jugular, and right paratracheal nodes. The total thyroidectomy specimen reveals bilateral multifocal papillary carcinoma, including a dominant 3.5 cm follicular variant with oncocytic change and a 2.1 cm widely invasive classical variant, alongside additional smaller microcarcinomas. No pathological diagnosis was made for the left lower parathyroid specimens, which were found to be within normal limits.

The pathology report indicates a resected colon sample from the sigmoid region containing an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The tumor has infiltrated the lamina muscularis propria but shows no evidence of local lymph node metastases. The resection margins are tumor-free, and the tumor is classified as G2, pT2, with no lymphovascular invasion or local recurrence.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma in the right colon, measuring 5.0 x 4.2 cm and invading into the muscularis propria (pT2), with no evidence of invasion into pericolonic fat or tumor at the serosal surface. All 26 dissected lymph nodes are negative for metastatic tumor (pNO), and additional findings include one tubular adenoma and one serrated adenoma. The proximal and distal margins are negative for tumor, with the closest margin being 20 cm from the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from the right frontal brain tumor is consistent with an anaplastic astrocytoma based on the frozen section diagnosis. However, the final diagnosis after microscopic examination reveals that the tumor is a glioblastoma, characterized by a hypercellular glial neoplasm with pleomorphic cells, hyperchromatic nuclei, and significant mitotic activity. Additional findings include microvascular proliferation, focal necrosis, and focal hemorrhage within the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, characterized by two separate nodules measuring 4.7 cm and 1.0 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2, and the tumor is confined to the kidney with negative margins. Additionally, there is an incidental finding of a papillary adenoma and evidence of immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, suggesting a membranous pattern of glomerular injury. Cytogenetic analysis revealed a loss of one chromosome 8 as the sole abnormality, which is not specifically associated with any particular tumor type.

The pathology report indicates that a mediastinal mass was resected, identified as a mixed type AB thymoma, with a size of 9 x 6.5 x up to 2.4 cm. The tumor was encapsulated, with no capsular invasion, tumor extension, or lymph-vascular invasion identified, and the margins were uninvolved by tumor. The final staging is classified as Stage I, with no evidence of distant metastasis or additional pathologic findings.

The histopathology report indicates features consistent with diffuse astrocytoma, but also shows focal increases in cellularity and mitotic activity with a proliferation index greater than 8%, suggesting anaplasia. The diagnosis is confirmed as anaplastic astrocytoma, classified as WHO grade III. This indicates a higher grade of malignancy compared to lower-grade astrocytomas.

The pathology report indicates that the left paratracheal lymph node biopsy is benign, and parathyroid tissue was identified in the biopsy. A total thyroidectomy revealed a 5.0 cm papillary thyroid carcinoma confined to the thyroid, with one parathyroid lymph node also negative for tumor. The report confirms a history of thyroid cancer and includes representative sections of the thyroid tumor for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the esophagus, classified as pT1b, with no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion, and negative surgical resection margins. Additionally, a focus of high-grade dysplasia was found 1.6 cm distally from the main tumor, which is associated with Barrett's esophagus. All examined lymph nodes (22 in total) showed no evidence of malignancy, confirming the absence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with one sentinel node showing metastasis in 1 out of 1, another in 3 out of 4, and a total of 6 out of 23 lymph nodes involved in the right axillary content. The right breast lumpectomy revealed a tumor mass measuring 2.3 cm, consisting of both in situ and invasive ductal carcinoma, with a Nottingham grade of 9/9 and free surgical margins. Additional findings include foci of vascular invasion and non-neoplastic changes in the surrounding breast tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5.0 cm in the left lower lobe, which invades the pleura but does not extend through it. All examined lymph nodes, including those at the bronchial and vascular resection margins, are negative for tumor, indicating no lymphatic or vascular invasion. The surgical margins are clear of tumor, and the non-neoplastic lung tissue shows signs of emphysema, with a final staging of T2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma in the left testis and cord following a radical orchiectomy. No tumor was identified in the vas deferens or tunica albuginea, and there was no definitive lymphovascular invasion or intratubular germ cell neoplasia noted. The report also describes atrophic testicular tissue with hyalinization of tubules, and malignant cells in blood vessels are likely due to carryover artifact, with negative results for HCG and CAM 5.2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in the left below-the-knee amputation specimen, with focal invasion of the fibula and evidence of vascular invasion. The tumor measures 10.0 cm and has caused destruction of the cortical bone at the fracture site, while tumor necrosis is noted to be less than 15%. Surgical margins of resection are reported to be free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a pneumonectomy specimen with a tumor size of 3 x 2.5 x 2 cm, diagnosed as poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. Out of 12 lymph nodes examined, 2 were positive for metastasis. Details regarding tumor extent, other tumor nodules, lymphatic and venous invasion, margins, and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment were not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, conventional type, located in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 4.0 cm, with no multifocality, extrathyroidal extension, or lymphovascular invasion, and negative resection margins. The background thyroid tissue shows chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and a right paratracheal lymph node was also negative for tumor. Overall, the findings suggest a localized thyroid cancer without evidence of spread to surrounding tissues or lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with the largest tumor measuring 1.2 cm and associated high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) extending over a 4 cm area. Lymphovascular invasion is noted, and one of thirty lymph nodes examined shows metastatic carcinoma measuring 7 mm, with no extranodal extension. Immunohistochemical studies reveal negative estrogen and progesterone receptor status, and HER-2/neu testing shows no amplification of the gene.

The pathology report indicates that the excised margins from the medial tongue, base of the tongue, and gingival margins are all benign squamous mucosa, with no evidence of high-grade dysplasia or invasive carcinoma. However, a composite resection of the floor of the mouth and tongue revealed moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 4.3 cm, with perineural invasion present, but all surgical margins were negative for carcinoma. Additionally, lymph node dissection showed metastatic carcinoma in three out of five lymph nodes from the left neck and one out of three from the right neck, with extranodal extension noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two distinct adenocarcinomas in the lung: a 1 cm solid predominant adenocarcinoma in the lingula and a 3.5 cm micropapillary predominant adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe, both with free margins and negative lymph nodes. Molecular studies revealed a KRAS mutation associated with poor prognosis in the adenocarcinoma, while no EGFR mutations were detected. Additional findings included emphysema, and the tumors are considered separate primary malignancies.

The pathology report indicates a final diagnosis of a 6.4 cm paraganglioma located in the periaortic region and left colon, with the segment of colon showing no significant histological changes. Examination of twelve lymph nodes revealed no evidence of malignancy (0/13). Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, showing atypical cells positive for synaptophysin, chromogranin, and Melanin A, while being negative for MITF, HMB45, and Cam 5.2.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in the left adnexa, left cul-de-sac, and high left para-aortic lymph node, with additional involvement in the left pelvic sidewall and ovary. Multiple biopsies and excisions of lymph nodes and other tissues revealed predominantly benign findings, including benign fibroadipose tissue and benign lymph nodes, with no evidence of malignancy in several specimens. Overall, the findings suggest a significant malignancy primarily localized to the ovarian and pelvic regions, with extensive sampling revealing mostly benign pathology elsewhere.

The pathology report indicates a thymoma measuring 12.0 x 8.0 x 7.0 cm with infiltration of the capsule. The diagnosis is classified as Type A/B Thymoma, with a staging of pT1, pNO (0/2), and pMx. According to the Masaoka staging system, this tumor is classified as Stage I.

The pathology report indicates that the enucleated left eye contains a choroidal melanoma characterized by fusiform cells and moderate pigment content, measuring 10 mm in size. There is no evidence of scleral involvement or extrascleral extension, and critical structures such as the ciliary processes, optic foramen, and optic nerve are free of tumor invasion. The mitotic index is low, and there is no necrosis present in the lesion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade poorly differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma (endometrioid type), classified as FIGO stage IIIB, with extensive invasion into the myometrium and involvement of the endocervix and parametrial tissue. The tumor measures 13 cm and shows 100% involvement of the endometrial surface, with positive margins at the left paracervical and parametrial tissue. However, all examined lymph nodes (26 in total) were negative for tumor, although extensive granulomatous inflammation was noted in these lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (11.3 cm) from a left radical nephrectomy, classified as Fuhrman Grade II/IV, with no evidence of invasion into the renal capsule or lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, a hilar mass lymph node (2.6 cm) showed sinus histiocytosis and follicular hyperplasia, but was negative for tumor, as were fifteen other small hilar lymph nodes. Cytogenetic analysis revealed characteristic chromosomal abnormalities associated with clear cell renal cell carcinoma, including an addition on chromosome 3.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a high-grade urothelial carcinoma with signet ring differentiation in the bladder, exhibiting extensive muscle invasion classified as at least pT2. There is also evidence of carcinoma in situ within the main specimen, while the left ureteric orifice biopsy shows no signs of invasive disease or carcinoma in situ. Overall, the findings suggest a significant bladder tumor with associated complications but no invasive cancer detected in the ureteric biopsy.

The pathology report indicates a bladder tumor consisting of 8g of firm tissue chippings. Microscopic examination reveals a Grade 3 poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma with a predominantly solid growth pattern and invasion of the muscularis propria (pT2), but no vascular channel invasion is identified. The background urothelium is flat and not dysplastic.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2, N0, and M0, indicating a primary tumor without regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered at this time, and a separate blood sample was collected, which is reported as normal.
