The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 10.6 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade 3 of 4, extending beyond the renal capsule into perinephric fat. The upper pole soft tissue margin is involved by carcinoma, while there is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. Additionally, a left adrenal gland examination reveals an adrenal cortical adenoma, which is not involved by the renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated, low-grade adenocarcinoma of the rectum, measuring 4.8 cm, with invasion into perirectal adipose tissue and focal extension to the radial soft tissue resection margin. The tumor is classified as T3 N1 MX, with metastatic adenocarcinoma identified in 2 out of 14 lymph nodes. The specimen was obtained through a low anterior resection procedure, and the tumor is located 1.5 cm from the distal resection margin and 16 cm from the proximal margin.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 8 cm and exhibiting ulceration. The tumor extends to the subserosa, with 9 out of 12 lymph nodes showing metastasis, and there is evidence of venous invasion. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no information provided regarding lymphatic or perineural invasion or neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, measuring 5.5 cm, with invasion into the inner half of the myometrium (approximately 35% of thickness) and involvement of the lower uterine segment, but not the endocervix. All examined lymph nodes (17 total) from various regions, including pelvic and paraaortic, were negative for tumor involvement, and there was no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. Additional findings include parakeratosis of the cervix, focal adenomyosis, and benign leiomyomata, with no tumors identified in the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated intestinal type adenocarcinoma in the lesser curvature of the stomach, with the tumor measuring 45mm and showing full-thickness involvement of the gastric wall. There is evidence of metastasis in 8 out of 11 lesser curvature lymph nodes and 1 out of 5 greater curvature nodes, along with extensive intestinal metaplasia and focal low-grade dysplasia in the non-neoplastic gastric mucosa. The proximal stomach shows similar findings of intestinal metaplasia and low-grade dysplasia, while the coeliac lymph node shows no tumor deposits.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of intestinal-type adenocarcinoma located in the fundus of the stomach for a Caucasian male patient. The tumor is classified as grade 3 with a TNM stage of T4, N0, M0, indicating advanced local disease without regional or distant metastasis. Additionally, a blood specimen was collected, which returned normal results, and no treatment has been specified.

The pathology report indicates that two sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla are negative for carcinoma. A segmental mastectomy of the left breast reveals an infiltrating mammary carcinoma measuring 1.9 cm, with mixed ductal and lobular phenotypes, classified as Nottingham grade 2/3, and accompanied by ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) that constitutes less than 5% of the tumor mass. Surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and the tumor is positive for estrogen receptors while negative for progesterone receptors.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left frontal brain tumor diagnosed as an oligodendroglioma, classified as WHO Grade II. Two biopsy specimens were submitted, both confirming the same tumor type and grade. Molecular testing for 1p/19q and immunohistochemistry for MIB-1 have been ordered and will be reported separately.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph node biopsies and dissections were performed, all of which were negative for neoplasm. However, a resection of the right lower lobe of the lung revealed a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 13 x 11.5 x 8.5 cm, with invasion through the visceral pleura to the diaphragm, but with negative margins and no lymphatic vascular invasion. The final pathologic staging is pT3N0M0, indicating a stage IIB lung cancer with no evidence of regional or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated Type I Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma. The tumor is classified as stage pT1b and is reported as resected with no residual tumor (RO). The tumor grade is GII, and it is coded with ICD-0-Code 8260/3.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 3) involving the lower uterine segment and upper two-thirds of the endocervix, with a tumor depth of 14 mm and evidence of lymphovascular space invasion. The resection margins are free of tumor, and no carcinoma was identified in the examined lymph nodes or other structures, including the vagina and ovaries. Additional findings include proliferative endometrium and leiomyomas, with no precursor lesions noted in the cervix, complicating the determination of the tumor's site of origin.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right adrenal cortical carcinoma with evidence of venous invasion and an associated intracaval thrombus, but the capsular margins are free of malignancy. Additional findings include benign fibroadipose tissue in the falciform ligament and near the right common bile duct, chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis in the gallbladder, and mild macrovesicular steatosis in the liver. The tumor is classified as pT4, and the modified Weiss score suggests malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal breast carcinoma measuring 3 cm, with small areas of necrosis and associated secondary inflammation. The tumor has varying margin distances, with the closest margin being 0.1 cm. The classification of the tumor is invasive ductal breast carcinoma, not otherwise specified (NOS), grade III, pT2 N0 (O/3sn) LOVORO.

The pathology report indicates that all four sentinel lymph nodes biopsied show no evidence of tumor (0/1 for each). The left breast mastectomy reveals an invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 3.0 cm, classified as modified Black's nuclear grade 1-2, with no lymphovascular invasion and clear margins. Immunohistochemical staining for metastatic carcinoma in the sentinel lymph nodes is negative.

The pathology report indicates a yolk sac tumor (95%) with associated foci of embryonal carcinoma (5%) in the left testis, measuring 8.5 x 7.0 x 6.0 cm. There are extensive necrotic areas and intense desmoplasia, but no evidence of perineural or angiolymphatic invasion, and the tunica albuginea, spermatic cord, and epididymis are uninvolved. The testicular parenchyma shows moderate atrophy, and the tumor is classified as pT1 in the pathologic staging.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated perihilar cholangiocarcinoma (extrahepatic) arising from the right hepatic duct. A hepatic resection specimen measuring 20x20x11.5 cm revealed a prominent whitish nodule of 12x12x12 cm, along with multiple satellite lesions. The findings suggest lymphatic vessel invasion and involvement of the gallbladder, classified as G2, pT3 according to UICC 2009 staging.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, Fuhrman grade IV, in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 6.5 x 6.5 x 2.3 cm that invades perinephric fatty tissue and renal sinus fat, with vascular and lymphatic invasion present. The renal artery and vein margins are free of tumor, and the adrenal gland shows no evidence of malignancy. Additionally, the gallbladder shows cholelithiasis and mild chronic cholecystitis.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph node #1 contains micrometastatic adenocarcinoma, while sentinel lymph nodes #2 and #3 are negative for malignancy. The left breast mastectomy reveals a well-differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm, along with multifocal ductal carcinoma in situ and atypical hyperplasia. Hormone receptor analysis shows positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, and HER2 testing is negative, with a pathologic stage of pT1c pNimi.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated intestinal type adenocarcinoma located in the fundus of the stomach, measuring 6 x 4 x 1.5 cm with an exophytic (polypoid) appearance. The tumor has extended to the serosa but shows no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/3 positive). There are no specified details regarding lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion, and margins and neo-adjuvant treatment information are also not provided.

The pathology report indicates that the spleen shows no significant pathologic abnormalities following splenectomy. A retroperitoneal mass was diagnosed as leiomyosarcoma, FNCLCC grade 2/3, measuring 18 x 15 x 13 cm, with surgical margins free of tumor and no angiolymphatic invasion. The additional posterior margin excision revealed pancreatic parenchyma and surrounding tissue that were negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, grade 2, with a tumor size of 2.5 x 2.3 cm located in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. Ten dissected lymph nodes show reactive changes, but none are positive for metastasis, indicating no lymph node involvement. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma, WHO grade II, characterized by an infiltrating glioma with a MIB-1 labeling index of 2.7%. Microscopic examination reveals a proliferation of tumor cells with round nuclei, mild to moderate nuclear pleomorphism, and prominent perinuclear halos, infiltrating the adjacent brain parenchyma. The tumor shows mild hypercellularity, occasional cytologic atypia, and up to one mitotic figure per 10 high power fields, with no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were identified in the excised lymph nodes from the right pelvic, left common iliac, left pelvic, and left common iliac regions. However, a high-grade endometrial adenocarcinoma (Grade III) was found in the total abdominal hysterectomy specimen, with microscopic foci of residual cancer and extensive lymphovascular space invasion, but no myometrial invasion or tumor at the surgical margins. The pathologic stage is classified as pT1a NO Mx FIGO IA, and additional findings include chronic cervicitis, adenomyosis, and leiomyomas, with bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes showing no malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing perineural invasion and infiltration into peri-prostatic adipose tissue. There is a positive surgical margin in six blocks, and tumor infiltration is noted in the right seminal vesicle and left deferent duct, while one lymph node metastasis was identified among the examined nodes. The tumor classification is pT3b, with a maximum diameter of 45 mm and a tumor volume of approximately 16.5 ml, alongside findings of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia in remaining prostatic tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located at the gastroesophageal junction, with the tumor measuring 6.5 cm x 5.0 cm and invading through the muscularis propria to the adventitia. There is evidence of lymph-vascular invasion, with 6 out of 25 examined lymph nodes showing metastatic carcinoma, and the tumor is less than 1 mm from the adventitial margin. Additionally, Her-2 immunostains show 3+ positive staining, suggesting potential for targeted therapy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid microcarcinoma (0.5 cm) of the oncocytic/Warthin-like variant, confined to the left lobe, with psammoma bodies present in lymphatics suggesting angiolymphatic invasion. Four isthmic lymph nodes were examined, and no tumor was found (0/4), with the tumor classified as pT1a and margins uninvolved by carcinoma. Additionally, nodular thyroid hyperplasia with a dominant oncocytic nodule and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis was noted, while molecular testing revealed no mutations in BRAF, NRAS, HRAS, KRAS, or RET/PTC rearrangements.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated invasive colorectal adenocarcinoma measuring 5.5 cm, located at the rectosigmoid junction with evidence of angiolymphatic invasion and metastasis to 10 of 12 regional lymph nodes. The surgical resection margins are benign, with carcinoma being 0.5 cm from the closest margin, and there is also metastatic colonic adenocarcinoma identified in the liver. Additionally, two small hyperplastic polyps were noted, and the appendix showed no histopathologic abnormalities or evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in Gerota's fascia, while the liver biopsy from Segment 5 shows no malignancy but reveals increased portal fibrosis and mild cholestasis. A partial hepatectomy of liver segments 1-4 and part of 8 confirms a poorly differentiated cholangiocarcinoma measuring 10 cm, with vascular and perineural invasion present, and close surgical margins. The gallbladder specimen is negative for malignancy, showing minimal chronic cholecystitis and acute serositis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of uterine leiomyosarcoma measuring 14.9 cm, with tumor emboli present in the vascular space of the right paratubal soft tissue and involvement of the right parametrial tissue. Additionally, there are findings of uterine leiomyomata, xanthogranulomatous salpingitis in the left fallopian tube, and a weakly proliferative endometrium. The tumor is classified as pathologic stage T2 Nx Mx, and the attending pathologist has reviewed all slides and materials for the final diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the excision biopsies from the right frontal brain tumor reveal an anaplastic oligodendroglioma, characterized by infiltrating glial tumor cells, frequent mitotic figures, and necrosis. The tumor exhibits distinct oligodendroglial features along with some astrocytic characteristics, and the MGMT promoter is found to be methylated, which may influence treatment options. Additionally, there is no detected allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, which is typically associated with oligodendrogliomas.

The pathology report indicates that the vaginal-cervical biopsy reveals moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. In contrast, the bladder biopsy shows marked chronic inflammation with reactive epithelial atypia, but no carcinoma is identified. The patient is a female with a history of squamous cell carcinoma of unknown primary origin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, with tumor invasion into the duodenal wall and peripancreatic soft tissue. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in four out of eighteen examined lymph nodes, and the tumor was staged as pT3 N1, indicating local extension beyond the pancreas without distant metastasis. The surgical margins were uninvolved by tumor, with a distance of 5 mm from the closest margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, papillary type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV, measuring 1.5 cm and extending through the renal capsule but confined within Gerota's fascia, classified as pT3a. The surgical margins are free of tumor, with the closest margin being 0.5 cm from the tumor. Additionally, a benign renal cyst was identified in the left lower pole, and immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that all excised margins from the upper and lower lips, as well as other oral cavity sites, are negative for tumor involvement. A squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity was identified, classified as moderately differentiated (G2), with a size of 7.5 cm and invasion into the skin of the face (pT4a). Additionally, there is evidence of metastasis in one ipsilateral lymph node, with extracapsular extension present, while 37 other lymph nodes examined were negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating well-differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 5.5 cm, with extension through the visceral pleura and metastatic carcinoma found in one of six lymph nodes. The bronchial and vascular margins are negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, a wedge resection of the right upper lobe shows a cavitary fibrotic cyst with branching hyphal fungal forms consistent with Aspergillus, and another infiltrating well-differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 1.5 cm, which is also negative for tumor at the bronchial margin.

The pathology report describes an invasive high-grade infiltrating urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 3.5 x 2.5 x 1 cm, with ill-defined margins and a soft, gray surface. Microscopic examination reveals hyperplastic tumor cells forming papillary structures, with enlarged nuclei exhibiting irregular shapes and abnormal chromatin patterns, indicating poorly differentiated characteristics. The tumor has invaded the muscularis propria, and there is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or lymphatic/venous invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates that all four sentinel lymph nodes from the right axillary region are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The right breast partial mastectomy reveals an invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 1.6 cm, with clear margins greater than 2 mm and associated findings of lobular intraepithelial neoplasia and atypical ductal hyperplasia. Immunohistochemical analysis shows strong expression of estrogen and progesterone receptors, with no amplification of the Her2/neu antigen.
The pathology report indicates a tumor located in the right temporal region. The histological diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme. Additional notes are not provided in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multiple lesions diagnosed as pleomorphic liposarcoma, affecting the omentum, pelvic mass, duodenum, small bowel, and a perirectal serosal nodule. The tumors exhibit varying sizes and characteristics, with some involving the walls of the duodenum and jejunum, but the margins of resection for the small bowel tumor are negative for tumor. The patient has a known history of high-grade liposarcoma with extensive involvement of various abdominal structures.

The pathology report indicates that all biopsied lymph nodes from levels V, XI, VII, 4L, XII, IX, and VIII show no evidence of malignancy. However, the left upper lobe lung resection reveals moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 3 cm, with focal vascular invasion and a negative bronchial resection margin. The left lower lobe biopsy shows emphysema and subpleural changes but is also negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of predominantly moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate, with a maximum tumor diameter of 1.2 cm and infiltration into the left-sided perivesicular fatty tissue. There is no evidence of tumor in the examined lymph nodes or seminal vesicles, and the surgical margins are tumor-free. The tumor classification is pT3a pN0 (0/8), with a Gleason score of 3+4 = 7, indicating a complete local resection.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a well to moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma at the gastroesophageal junction, measuring 2.5 cm, with focal invasion into the superficial submucosa and a background of high-grade dysplasia and intestinal metaplasia. All examined lymph nodes (27 in total) were benign, and the resection margins were negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, an incidental benign spindle cell tumorlet was identified as a schwannoma, pending further characterization.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic colonic adenocarcinoma in two liver wedge biopsies and a low-grade adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon, measuring 5 cm, which penetrates the visceral peritoneum. Surgical margins are clear, with the nearest margin being 8 cm from the tumor, but metastatic adenocarcinoma is found in 15 of 22 regional lymph nodes, indicating significant lymph node involvement. The overall pathologic staging is pT4a for the primary tumor, pN2b for regional lymph nodes, and pM1 for distant metastasis to the liver.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with the tumor measuring 7 cm and not penetrating the renal capsule. Both the vascular and ureteral margins are free of tumor, and no tumor is seen in the adrenal gland. The findings suggest that the tumor was an incidental finding during the examination of the right kidney.

The pathology report describes a moderately cellular neoplasm with perinuclear clearing, identified as an oligodendroglioma, WHO Grade II. The tumor shows minimal hypercellularity, infiltrates both gray and white matter, and exhibits perineural satellitosis, with no necrosis or vascular proliferation observed. The mitotic count is 0, and the MIB-1 labeling index is low at <0.1%, indicating minimal proliferation of the neoplastic cells.

The pathology report indicates that the medial margin of the palate is negative for tumor, while the right partial maxillectomy reveals a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.3 cm with no lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Additionally, the right partial glossectomy shows squamous cell carcinoma in-situ, with a maximum dimension of 0.6 cm and focally suspicious for superficial invasion, but all margins are negative for tumor. The deep margin of the tongue is also negative for tumor, and overall, the margins from the resected specimens are uninvolved by tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade adrenocortical carcinoma from a right adrenal gland resection, with a tumor size of 8.5 x 5.2 x 4.8 cm and negative surgical margins. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed focal p53 positivity and an increased Ki-67 labeling index, suggesting the potential for a focal high-grade component, although its clinical significance remains uncertain. Additionally, a simple cyst was identified in the right liver, with no lesions noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a tumor size of 3.0 x 2.5 x 1.2 cm and invasion into the lower uterine segment. Metastatic carcinoma was found in two out of two examined paracervical lymph nodes, while the right pelvic, right periaortic, and left periaortic lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma. The margins of excision were negative, and additional findings included secretory endometrium with polyps, adenomyosis, and leiomyoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 4.8 cm moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe, with visceral pleural invasion and a 2.1 cm satellite metastasis, classified as pathologic stage T3 N1. Two of the examined N1 lymph nodes showed metastatic involvement, while other lymph nodes biopsied exhibited reactive changes without evidence of malignancy. Additionally, the report notes severe emphysematous changes and smoker's-associated interstitial fibrosis in the lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the gastric antrum, classified as Type III according to Borman's classification, with a tumor size of 7.0 cm and evidence of ulceration. There is no evidence of neoplasia in the surrounding tissues, including the omentum and margins, and lymphatic or vascular invasion is not detected. The pathological staging is pT3 pN1, indicating tumor invasion into adjacent tissues with involvement of some lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type I, with a tumor size of 3.1 cm, confined to the right kidney and with negative surgical margins. The tumor is classified as Fuhrman grade 2, and there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or regional lymph node involvement. Additionally, the non-neoplastic kidney shows end-stage renal disease with significant chronic changes.

The pathology report describes a 7.4 cm yellowish tumor in the left adrenal gland, characterized by zellballen and trabecular architecture with enlarged nuclei and weakly eosinophilic cytoplasm. The tumor shows focal pigmentation, areas of bleeding, and capsule infiltration without destruction, along with vascular invasion, but no significant mitotic activity or necrosis. The final diagnosis is pheochromocytoma, supported by marked synaptophysin staining and a low proliferation index (Ki67 less than 5%).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma, WHO Grade IV, from specimens designated as "Left temporal malignant glioma" and "Left temporal glioblastoma." Microscopic examination reveals pleomorphic neoplastic glial cells with mitotic figures, tumor necrosis, and endothelial proliferation, along with positive immunohistochemical staining for GFAP and p53. The specimens were received fresh for frozen section and formalin-fixed, with the left temporal malignant glioma measuring 2.5 x 1.5 x 0.6 cm and the left temporal glioblastoma measuring 2 x 2 x 0.8 cm.

The pathology report indicates that both the right upper and left lower parathyroid biopsies showed no pathological diagnosis. The total thyroidectomy revealed multifocal papillary carcinoma of the dominant follicular variant, measuring 1.9 cm in the right lobe, along with severe chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis and mild nodular hyperplasia. The report confirms that the tumor margins are uninvolved by carcinoma, with no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion, and no regional lymph node metastasis was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated spindle cell carcinoma (sarcomatoid variant) of the right tongue, with a maximum tumor dimension of 3.2 cm and a thickness of 1.5 cm, but no perineural or lymphovascular invasion detected. The tumor is located 0.3 cm from the lateral and deep resection margins, while all other margins are negative for malignancy. Additionally, the floor of mouth, superior, and posterior margins show squamous mucosa negative for malignancy, and there are findings of epithelial dysplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with a Nottingham score of 8/9, and the presence of lymphovascular permeation. The tumor measures 8.3 cm and is associated with ductal carcinoma in situ, comprising less than 1% of the tumor volume, while one out of twenty-three axillary lymph nodes shows metastatic adenocarcinoma. Surgical margins, including the nipple and skin, are free of tumor, and the immunohistochemical profile shows positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, with HER-2/neu negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of lung cancer, specifically squamous cell carcinoma, classified as grade 3. The TNM staging shows T3, N0, and M0, indicating a locally advanced tumor without regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been initiated at this time, and the specimen was obtained from a primary lung tumor tissue sample.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, from multiple resected specimens, including the right posterior occipital tumor and additional samples labeled as "center" and "edge," all showing extensive necrosis. Tumor cells were positive for GFAP immunostain, and a significant number of tumor cells were also positive for the KI-67 immunostain, indicating high proliferation. Additionally, fragments of white matter were noted to have slight hypercellularity with rare atypical cells.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy from the gastroesophageal junction shows reactive squamous and gastric type mucosa, with no evidence of intestinal metaplasia. Additionally, the biopsy from the rectal mass reveals the presence of invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. Overall, the findings suggest a benign condition in the gastroesophageal junction and a malignant tumor in the rectum.

The final pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreatobiliary type, with an estimated tumor size of 2.0 cm, and the pancreatic neck margin is negative for invasive carcinoma. There is evidence of metastatic carcinoma in one of nine examined lymph nodes, along with vascular and perineural invasion present. The spleen shows no diagnostic abnormalities, and the tumor is confined to the pancreas with no prior treatment noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive mucinous carcinoma of the right breast, with cancer metastases identified in 1 out of 13 axillary lymph nodes. The tumor measures 5.5 x 4 x 4 cm and is classified as NHG2, pT3, pN1a. The right breast and axillary tissue were surgically removed, with no pathological lesions found in the nipple and evidence of glandular tissue atrophy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade II) from biopsies and removal of a tumor in the right temporal lobe of the brain. The report notes that further analyses for deletions of chromosomes 1p and 19q are pending. The specimens submitted included multiple fragments of soft tissue from the right temporal mass and deep temporal neoplasm, with detailed descriptions of their sizes and characteristics.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe cell type, in the left kidney, with the tumor measuring 5.2 cm and confined within the renal capsule, showing no invasion of the renal vein or involvement of surgical margins. The adrenal gland is unremarkable, and the non-neoplastic kidney exhibits chronic interstitial nephritis. Additionally, a para-aortic lymph node excision revealed one benign lymph node, confirming no metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating moderately differentiated duct carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 2.0 cm, with poor architectural grade and intermediate nuclear grade. Estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) tests are positive, while HER-2/neu testing is negative. Additionally, one out of nineteen axillary lymph nodes is positive for metastatic carcinoma, with resection margins free of tumor.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of left breast cancer, specifically moderately differentiated infiltrating lobular carcinoma measuring 6.6 cm, with foci of lobular carcinoma in situ. Both sentinel lymph nodes examined were found to be benign reactive regional lymph nodes, with one showing incidental microscopic micrometastases consisting of seven positive cells, while the other was negative for malignancy. All designated surgical margins from the left breast total mastectomy are free of tumor, indicating successful removal of cancerous tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the liver, with a single tumor measuring 11 cm located in the right hepatic lobe, exhibiting extensive vascular invasion and focal necrosis. The tumor is classified as grade 4 of 4, with negative parenchymal margins that are extremely close to the tumor, and no carcinoma identified in the additional liver segment excised. Background liver shows moderate macrovesicular steatosis and bridging fibrosis, with the overall pathologic stage assessed as pT2 pNX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, characterized by a central necrosis and an ill-defined intrapulmonary nodule measuring 2 x 2 x 1.1 cm. The pleura is not involved, and both the bronchial margin and one intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph node are negative for tumor. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from the superior and inferior mediastinum, as well as the right hilar region, are also negative for tumor, with focal organizing pneumonia observed in two separate nodules.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), located in the right lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of approximately 6.2 cm. The tumor is classified as Grade II and is staged as T2, N1, M0, indicating regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. The sample was obtained through a resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with endometrial adenocarcinoma, specifically of the endometrioid type, with a histologic grade of 2 and a tumor size of 2.5 cm. All examined lymph nodes from the left pelvic, left aortic, right pelvic, and right caval regions were negative for metastasis, confirming no spread of cancer to these areas. The tumor shows less than 50% invasion into the myometrium and direct extension into the cervical stroma, with no evidence of tumor in the ovaries or adnexa.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, with 5 out of 30 lymph nodes involved in the left lower neck dissection and 4 out of 4 lymph nodes involved in the left tracheoesophageal gutter node. The dominant tumor in the left lobe of the thyroid measures 2.1 cm and is classified as a widely invasive classical variant with psammomatous dissemination, although there is no evidence of vascular invasion. Additional findings include mild follicular nodular disease and mild reactive C-cell hyperplasia in the thyroid, with all margins uninvolved by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma located in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 7 x 3 x 2.2 cm, with evidence of angiolymphatic invasion and involvement of the parenchymal margin. Immunohistochemical staining shows the malignant cells are positive for cytokeratin 7, TTF-1, and Napsin-A, while being negative for cytokeratin 5/6, with one of two sampled peribronchial lymph nodes showing metastatic tumor. The tumor is classified as pT1b, pN1, pMX, with a significant size of the largest metastatic deposit being 1.3 cm.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a distal esophageal adenocarcinoma, with a 3.4 x 3.2 cm exophytic lesion at the gastroesophageal junction that extends into the muscularis propria. Six out of eighteen sampled lymph nodes are positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the resection margins are negative for cancer involvement. The TNM classification is T2 N1 MX, indicating the depth of invasion and lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO Grade 1) in the uterus, with a tumor size of 7 x 6 x 1.9 cm and a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 1 cm. The tumor involves the anterior wall of the uterus and fills the endometrial cavity but does not invade the cervix or serosal surface, and there is no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from both the left and right pelvic regions, as well as the ovaries and fallopian tubes, are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a right orchiectomy specimen was received, revealing a classic seminoma measuring 7.5 cm, with multiple necrotic nodules present. The tumor is confined to the testis, with no involvement of surrounding structures such as the spermatic cord or epididymis, and the surgical margins are negative. Additionally, the remaining testicular tissue shows fibrosis and chronic inflammation, with no residual normal tissue identified, resulting in a pathologic tumor stage of pT1NXMX (Stage IA).

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes excised from various levels of the mediastinum show no evidence of malignancy, with a total of 10 lymph nodes examined and all being negative for cancer. A moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 4.5 cm, with no tumor involvement in the pleura or surgical margins. Additionally, granulomas consistent with Histoplasma species were found in the lung and lymph node sections, while acid-fast bacilli (AFB) stains were negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, grade 3, with invasion into the inner half of the myometrium and positive involvement of the cervix, along with extensive lymphovascular space invasion. All examined lymph nodes from various regions (right pelvic, left external iliac, left obturator, and para-aortic) were negative for carcinoma, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. Additional findings include adenomyosis and leiomyoma, with the vaginal cuff negative for carcinoma and the right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes largely unremarkable except for chronic salpingitis in the left fallopian tube.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma with extensive necrosis in the left testis, measuring 13 x 8 x 7 cm, following a radical orchiectomy. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, and the tumor is confined to the testis with clear margins. The epididymis is not identified in the specimen, and the overall classification is pT1NXMX.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a partial nephrectomy of the left kidney, revealing a conventional (clear cell) renal cell carcinoma with a nuclear grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 3.9 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The non-neoplastic kidney shows mild focal interstitial fibrosis, and the tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (G2) in the cervix, measuring 8x4 cm, with invasion to the serosa and associated endometrial hyperplasia. Lymph nodes examined show no evidence of metastasis, with findings of lipomatosis and sinus histiocytosis, and margins are reported as uninvolved. The tumor is classified as stage T2a2 according to the AJCC 7th edition of TNM classification due to its size exceeding 4 cm.

The pathology report indicates that the anterior prostatic fat and left anterior apex biopsies show benign fibroadipose tissue and skeletal muscle with no evidence of prostate or tumor. The radical prostatectomy revealed prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, confined to the prostate, along with extensive high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (HGPIN), but no tumor was found in the seminal vesicles or lymph nodes. Additionally, there is evidence of lymphatic space invasion, but no extraprostatic extension, leading to a final staging of pT2cN0L1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (Borrmann type IV) located in the lower third of the stomach, with a tumor size of 4.0 x 3.5 cm and no gross serosal invasion. Microscopic examination reveals T3 depth of invasion, with lymphovascular and perineural invasion present, and metastasis identified in 1 out of 10 superior gastric lymph nodes. The final diagnosis is advanced gastric cancer with a pathologic stage of pT3N1Mx, and the presence of H. pylori is noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous carcinoma, grade III, in the right true vocal cord, with evidence of lymphatic invasion and tumor presence at the deep margin of resection and left anterior commissure. Additional findings include squamous carcinoma in the tissue overlying the arytenoid cartilage, while margins from the false cord, posterior commissure, and other areas show no tumor presence, except for dysplastic epithelium at the new anterior commissure margin. Overall, the report highlights significant malignancy with specific areas of concern and clear margins in several other regions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a tumor located in the left lower lung (LLL) with a size of 2.3 cm. The tumor is classified as stage II, specifically T2, with no evidence of metastasis (M0). The histological grade and differentiation details are not specified, but the report confirms the tumor's presence and staging.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the prostate following a radical prostatectomy, with a Gleason score of 4+5=9 and evidence of extraprosthetic extension. The periprostatic lymph node specimen showed no evidence of malignancy, and all examined pelvic lymph nodes were negative for cancer involvement. The surgical margins were clear of invasive carcinoma, and there was noted perineural invasion, while high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia was also present.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a hysterectomy revealing squamous metaplasia and weakly proliferative endometrium, along with multiple leiomyomata in the myometrium. A nephrectomy showed renal cell carcinoma of the chromophobe type with capsular invasion and positive lymphovascular space invasion, but no involvement of the adrenal gland or other margins. Additional findings included a follicular cyst in the left ovary and a corpus luteum in the right ovary, with no significant abnormalities in the fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a left lung tumor measuring 9.0 X 7.0 X 6.5 cm, diagnosed as Squamous Cell Carcinoma, not otherwise specified (NOS). There is infiltration of the visceral pleura, and the tumor is classified as pT2, pN1 with 3 out of 57 lymph nodes involved, and graded as G3. The metastatic status is classified as pMx, indicating that the presence of distant metastasis is unknown.

The pathology report indicates that the left adnexa shows benign findings, including an atrophic ovary and benign fallopian tube, while the right adnexa also reveals a benign atrophic ovary and fallopian tube. The uterus and cervix are diagnosed with high-grade endometrial adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade III), measuring 4 x 3 cm, with significant myometrial invasion and focal lymphovascular invasion, but no cervical involvement or tumor at surgical margins. All examined lymph nodes from both pelvic and para-aortic regions show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, and additional findings include a benign endometrial polyp and leiomyomas.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lung, measuring 70 mm, with significant lymphatic permeation but no blood vessel or perineural invasion. The tumor is located near the hilar resection margin and shows metastasis in the peribronchial, hilar, subcarinal, and upper medial sternal lymph nodes. The overall classification of the disease is T4N2M1, indicating advanced malignancy with lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 3 serous endometrial carcinoma, which extensively involves the endometrial cavity and myometrium, forming a significant exophytic mass. One of the 20 left pelvic lymph nodes shows a microscopic focus of metastatic serous carcinoma, while multiple right pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes are negative for tumor. The margins of the surgical specimen are negative for tumor, and additional findings include benign intramural leiomyomata and a benign appendix.

The pathology report indicates the diagnosis of a thymoma, WHO type A, from an excised anterior mediastinal mass measuring 2.2 x 2.2 x 1.5 cm, with microscopic invasion of the capsule but no tumor at the surgical margin. The adjacent thymus shows involutional changes, and immunohistochemical staining reveals tumor cells positive for AE1:AE3, with intermixed lymphocytes labeled for CD3 and TdT. The specimen was well-circumscribed and weighed 21 g, with a gross description of fleshy yellow solid tissue covered by a membrane.

The pathology report describes a 7x6x7 cm bronchopulmonary neoplasm identified as well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with areas of necrosis and keratinization. The tumor shows infiltration into the juxta-pleural pulmonary parenchyma but does not invade the pleura or lymph nodes, with no metastases found in the examined lymph node. The specimen was obtained from a lobectomy of the left upper lung lobe.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 4.3 cm and classified as Fuhrman grade 2. The tumor is unifocal and appears confined to the kidney, with no evidence of invasion into surrounding structures or lymphatic involvement, and all surgical margins are negative. Additionally, a small angiomyolipoma measuring 0.3 cm was identified, and the overall staging is pT1b, pNX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant lymphoma, specifically diffuse large cell type with a B-cell phenotype, from a left cervical level 5 lymph node biopsy. Flow cytometric analysis shows the lymphoma cells are positive for CD19, CD20, and CD22, with a Kappa/Lambda ratio of 59.9/0.23. Bone marrow biopsies from both iliac crests demonstrate orderly hematopoiesis and are negative for lymphoma, indicating no abnormal infiltrate.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes were biopsied and found to be anthracotic and free of carcinoma. A pneumonectomy revealed invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe, measuring 4.5 cm, with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or malignancy in the examined lymph nodes. Additionally, there were inflammatory changes and organizing pneumonia noted in the lung and pleura, but no malignancy was detected in the soft tissue, bone, or pleura samples.

The pathology report indicates that the final diagnosis for the left upper lobe lung wedge is invasive adenocarcinoma, classified as histologic grade 1/4, with a tumor size of 1.8 cm and unifocality. No tumor was detected in the examined lymph nodes, with a total of 14 nodes evaluated, and no significant vascular or pleural invasion was noted. The resection margins were clear of tumor, and the overall TNM stage is reported as pT1a, pN0, pMX.

The pathology report indicates that the left inferior parathyroid biopsy showed adipose tissue with no parathyroid parenchyma or tumor present. The total thyroidectomy revealed multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma with higher-grade insular areas, necrosis, and lymphovascular invasion, measuring 3.4 cm in the left lobe, but with negative resection margins. Additionally, the left level 3 lymph node was negative for tumor, and the left paratracheal soft tissue showed normal cellular parathyroid gland.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of gastric adenocarcinoma, specifically the intestinal type, with signs of vascular invasion and metastases to multiple lymph nodes. The tumor, located in the pyloric region, measures 5.5 x 4.5 x 1.5 cm and invades the muscularis propria and subserosa, but does not extend beyond the serosa. The surgical margins are free of neoplastic lesions, and the tumor is classified as G3, pT3, pN3a.

The pathology report indicates a bladder tumor diagnosed as transitional cell carcinoma (TCC), classified as grade 3 and showing muscle invasion (pT2). The specimen consisted of 7g of firm and friable tissue, with a mixed papillary and solid growth pattern. No vascular channel invasion was identified, and there was no flat urothelium present in the background.

The pathology report indicates that there is no tumor present in the left and right distal ureters and pelvic lymph nodes examined. However, transitional cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder and adenocarcinoma of the prostate were diagnosed, with the bladder tumor measuring approximately 2 cm and classified as high grade. The prostate adenocarcinoma shows no extraprosthetic extension, and no tumor was found at the specimen margins.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma originating from the salivary gland, with a maximum tumor size of 7.0 cm and involvement of the medial deep soft tissue margin. There is evidence of vascular, lymphatic, and perineural invasion, along with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma found in 1 of 2 lymph nodes. While the tumor invades the mandible, the bone margins of resection are free of neoplasm, and carcinoma in situ is noted in Wharton's duct.

The pathology report indicates that two right pelvic lymph nodes and four left pelvic lymph nodes were examined, with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma found in any of them (0/6). A radical prostatectomy revealed multifocal invasive poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, confined within the prostate capsule and accounting for approximately 8% of the tissue evaluated, with a maximum tumor dimension of 1.6 cm. Additionally, perineural invasion was identified, but all surgical margins were free of tumor, and no carcinoma was seen in the bilateral seminal vesicles.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason grade of 3+4, affecting both the right and left lobes, with 10% of the gland involved and focal extraprostatic extension present at the right apex. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is perineural invasion noted, but the seminal vesicles and lymph nodes (4 examined) show no evidence of malignancy. The tumor is classified as T3a/N0/MX, corresponding to Stage III prostate cancer.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 3.0x2.0x1.5 cm, with invasion into the muscular layer but no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. Both the left and right ureters show no neoplasia, and the surgical margins are clear of cancer. Additionally, lymphadenectomy results reveal that all examined lymph nodes (16 total) are uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma, specifically the tall cell variant, with the largest tumor measuring 2.8 cm and exhibiting extrathyroidal extension and perineural and angiolymphatic invasion. A microcarcinoma measuring 0.1 cm was also identified in the right lobe, but no tumor was found in the six examined lymph nodes. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT3, with involved margins noted at the left lobe.

The pathology report describes a right eye enucleation with a choroidal melanoma measuring 15 by 12 mm, located posteriorly and peripherally, close to the optic nerve but not invading it. The tumor superficially infiltrates the sclera without extrascleral extension, and there is no involvement of the ciliary body, iris, or anterior chamber. Overall, the optic nerve remains free of tumor throughout its course.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of thymoma, type AB, from a left anterior mediastinal mass measuring 16 x 14.5 x 9.2 cm, which shows focal invasion into surrounding adipose tissue but has free surgical margins. The portion of the left sixth rib examined shows unremarkable bony trabeculae and intact hematopoiesis, while the left anterior mediastinal lymph node contains benign fibroadipose and vascular tissue with no lymph nodes identified. Overall, the findings suggest a significant thymoma without evidence of metastatic disease in the examined rib or lymph node.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) in the right breast, with a primary tumor measuring 2.2 cm and a second smaller tumor associated with biopsy site changes. Sentinel lymph node #1 shows metastatic carcinoma, while sentinel lymph node #2 and the majority of axillary lymph nodes are negative for metastases, although four out of twenty-four lymph nodes in the axillary contents show metastatic carcinoma. Surgical margins from the lumpectomy are negative for tumor, and the tumor is classified as grade 3 with positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, but negative HER2 status.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type II, with Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, and focal invasion of the renal capsule following a radical nephrectomy of the right kidney. The tumor measures 5.3 cm and shows extension into perinephric tissue, but the surgical margins are free of invasive carcinoma. Additionally, there are significant chronic interstitial nephritis changes noted in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical prostatectomy due to prostatic adenocarcinoma, with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, involving approximately 4% of the examined gland and extending into the left seminal vesicle wall. There is focal extraprosthetic extension identified, and the left posterior margin is focally involved, with a positive margin measuring 0.6 mm. No lymph nodes were sampled, and there are no other significant pathologic findings noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, large intestine, and liver, with significant involvement of the left and right ovaries, both exhibiting grade 3 serous adenocarcinoma. The right ovary is nearly completely replaced by invasive carcinoma, while the left ovary shows extensive serosal surface involvement and free-floating carcinoma cells in the fallopian tube. Additional findings include various benign lesions and inflammatory changes, but the overall diagnosis highlights a widespread metastatic process primarily originating from serous carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the excisional biopsy of a right parietal brain tumor is diagnosed as glioblastoma, characterized by high mitotic activity, a proliferation index greater than 8%, and areas of tumor necrosis. Additionally, the MGMT promoter is found to be methylated, suggesting potential responsiveness to alkylating agent therapy, while no evidence of the EGFRvIII mutation is detected. The microscopic examination reveals significant vascular proliferation and a heavy infiltration of phagocytic cells within the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a colectomy specimen from the transverse colon, revealing a 2.5 x 4 x 3 cm mucinous adenocarcinoma that is moderately differentiated. The tumor extends into the pericolonic tissues, but details regarding lymph nodes and margins are not specified. There is no information provided about neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates a resection of the cervical esophagus revealing a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5.5x5x1 cm, with tumor extent involving the lamina propria or submucosa. There is evidence of metastasis in 1 out of 1 examined lymph node. Additional details regarding lymphatic and venous invasion, margins, and neo-adjuvant treatment are not specified.

The pathology report indicates that a cervical biopsy revealed squamous cell carcinoma with stromal invasion, specifically large cell nonkeratinizing type, graded as 2. There is also a prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate noted in the specimen. The biopsy specimen measured 0.6 x 0.5 x 0.4 cm and was entirely submitted for examination.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left papillary renal cell carcinoma, type II, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm and Fuhrman grade 2. There is no evidence of sarcomatoid features or capsular invasion, and all surgical margins are negative. The tumor is classified as pT1b, with additional findings of focal global glomerulosclerosis and mild interstitial nephritis in the non-neoplastic kidney.

The pathology report indicates a left adrenal pheochromocytoma measuring 9 cm, characterized by a necrotic and hemorrhagic appearance. Microscopic examination reveals a cellular proliferation of large, polygonal eosinophilic cells with mild to moderate anisokaryosis, but no atypical mitoses, capsular invasion, or necrosis. The tumor exhibits high cellularity and a diffuse architecture, with abundant hemosiderin deposition.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade leiomyosarcoma in the abdominal mass, measuring 15.0 x 11.5 x 6.5 cm, with involvement of the colonic subserosa but uninvolved surgical margins and no necrosis identified. The tumor exhibits moderate to severe nuclear atypia and a low mitotic activity of 2 mitotic figures per 50 high power fields, with immunohistochemical staining suggesting a possible gynecologic origin. Additionally, the umbilical hernia specimen shows benign fibroadipose tissue with reactive changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver, specifically located in segment 2, with a single tumor measuring 3.0 x 2.8 x 2.2 cm and classified as well differentiated (grade II). There is no evidence of tumor necrosis, hemorrhage, or invasion into surrounding structures, with the closest surgical margin being less than 0.2 cm from the tumor mass. Additionally, the patient has chronic hepatitis due to HBV, but there is no evidence of cirrhosis or other significant liver diseases.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach's antrum, measuring 7.5 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion present but no perineural invasion detected. The adjacent mucosa shows low-grade epithelial dysplasia and intestinal metaplasia, while surgical margins and multiple lymph nodes are uninvolved by neoplasia. Overall, there is no evidence of metastatic disease in the examined lymph nodes or surrounding tissues.

The pathology report indicates that the left parietal brain lesion is diagnosed as a poorly differentiated malignant neoplasm, specifically glioblastoma multiforme. The microscopic examination reveals pleomorphic, anaplastic cells with significant necrosis and abnormal mitotic figures, while special stains show focal positivity for GFAP, neurofilament, and desmin. Additionally, the dura mater biopsy shows attached poorly differentiated malignant neoplasm, and the possibility of a malignant melanoma cannot be ruled out.

The pathology report indicates that a subtotal esophagectomy and cholecystectomy were performed, revealing a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the esophagus, measuring 5 x 3 cm, with infiltration into the muscle layer but no vascular or perineural invasion. The surgical margins are clear, with no metastasis found in the examined lymph nodes (0/9). Additionally, chronic calculous cholecystitis was noted in the gallbladder.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (Grade 3) involving the uterus, cervix, and right adnexa, with extensive lymphovascular invasion and cervical involvement. All examined lymph nodes and left parametrial tissue were free of metastatic tumor, and the posterior vaginal margin showed focal erosion but was also free of tumor. The tumor has been staged as T2b, N0, indicating local invasion without lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of oligodendroglial differentiation with noted mitotic activity. There is a focal proliferation rate of 20%. The diagnosis is anaplastic oligodendroglioma, classified as WHO grade III.

The pathology report describes a liver tissue sample from segments VI and V, weighing 255.0 grams. The diagnosis indicates the presence of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma forming a mass measuring 3.6 x 2.1 x 2.1 cm, with uninvolved surgical resection margins. Additionally, a reticulin stain reveals a loss of reticulin framework in the carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 3) of the endometrium, with a tumor size of 6.0 cm and 67% myometrial invasion, but no cervical involvement. All examined lymph nodes (left pelvic, right pelvic, left periaortic, and right periaortic) were negative for metastatic carcinoma. The surgical procedure performed was a total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, with negative surgical margins and no other significant endometrial pathology noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classic seminoma in the right testis, measuring 6.2 cm, with involvement of the rete testis but no lymphovascular invasion. The spermatic cord and margins are free of tumor involvement, and intratubular germ cell neoplasia is also present. Serum tumor marker studies are within normal limits, and the tumor is classified as pT1, indicating it is limited to the testis and epididymis without vascular or lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma, with the largest lesion measuring 3.1 cm. Three out of four examined lymph nodes showed microscopic metastases, while there was no capsular invasion noted. Additional findings include chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, and the tumor was found at the surgical margin of resection.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of an esophageal mass with squamous cell carcinoma in situ, along with foci that are suspicious for invasive carcinoma. The examination was conducted on three slides received from the Surgical Pathology Division. The findings have been reviewed and confirmed by a qualified physician.

The pathology report indicates that the left eye underwent enucleation due to a malignant ciliochoroidal melanoma, characterized as a mixed cell type with both epithelioid and spindle cells. The tumor measured 8.1 mm in height and 11.5 mm in basal diameter, with involvement of the sclera, choroid, and ciliary body, but no melanoma was found at the margins. Additional findings included a high mitotic rate, mild pigmentation, and the presence of tumor infiltrating lymphocytes, along with retinal detachment and hemorrhage.

The pathology report indicates the presence of oligodendroglial differentiation with single mitoses observed. There is a proliferation rate of up to 6%. The diagnosis is oligodendroglioma, classified as WHO grade II.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the right and left obturator lymph nodes, with a total of five lymph nodes examined (0/3 and 0/2, respectively). The prostate examination revealed prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3), confined to the prostate, and the margins of resection were free of tumor. Additionally, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) was noted, while the seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia showed no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the right retroperitoneum following a radical resection, with a tumor size of 20.0 x 15.5 x 14.5 cm. Approximately 20-25% of the tumor volume is necrotic, and a small component of well-differentiated liposarcoma is also present. The tumor is noted to be focally at the inked surgical margin, suggesting potential involvement at the resection boundary.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two hepatocellular carcinomas in the liver, with the larger tumor in segment 8 measuring 6.8x5.8x4.5 cm and classified as pT3, showing poor differentiation and evidence of vascular invasion, while the smaller tumor in segment 7 measures 1.5x1.4x1.3 cm with better differentiation and no vascular invasion. Both tumors exhibit distinct histologic types, with the larger tumor being multinodular confluent and the smaller one having a solid pattern, and there is active cirrhosis present in the liver. Surgical margins are clear for both tumors, indicating no residual cancer at the edges of the resected tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma involving the posterior margin of the bladder, with a tumor size of 3.0 cm and invasion into the perivesical fat. All examined lymph nodes (24 total) and distal ureter specimens were negative for tumor, suggesting no lymphatic spread. Additional findings include leiomyomata uteri with focal osseous metaplasia and adenomyoma, while bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes showed age-related changes without evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in all examined lymph nodes, with one sentinel lymph node showing a metastatic focus greater than 2.0 cm and multiple non-sentinel lymph nodes also affected. The right breast biopsy reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma with a size of 3.7 cm, multifocality, and the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ comprising approximately 20% of the tumor volume, along with lymphovascular invasion. The overall pathologic stage is assessed as pT2(m) pN3a, indicating significant disease involvement.

The final diagnosis indicates the presence of a glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) in the brain tumor specimens, including tumor core and edge biopsies. Additionally, the normal appearing brain tissue shows infiltration by a minimal amount of atypical Ki-67 positive cells, suggesting possible malignant glioma infiltration. The immunohistochemical analysis reveals that approximately 2-3% of the evaluated cells are labeled with Ki-67, indicating a low level of proliferation.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast mass is diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated, with a histologic grade of III/III and measuring 4.5 cm, but no in situ component or vascular invasion is noted. All sentinel and non-sentinel lymph nodes examined from the left axilla are reported as benign, with no evidence of metastatic tumor. Immunohistochemical staining shows negative results for HER2 and the estrogen receptor, while the progesterone receptor is also negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma, with the largest tumor measuring 3.3 cm and extending close to the parenchymal margin of resection. Additionally, cirrhosis is noted in the liver biopsy, but no carcinoma was identified in that specimen. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of cholangiocarcinoma, with the malignant cells showing positivity for bile ductular markers.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower lobe lobectomy revealed poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion and three peribronchial lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. The excised lymph nodes from right level 2, level 4, and level 7 were all negative for metastatic carcinoma. The bronchial and vascular margins were negative for carcinoma, suggesting that the invasive cancer has not spread beyond the lung lobe.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a marked adenocarcinoma of the colon, characterized by tubular tumor cell arrangements and a tendency to invade surrounding fatty tissue and lymph nodes. There are seven conglomerate metastases with extensive necrosis, but the resection margins are reported as free of tumor involvement. The tumor classification is noted as G2 to 3, pT3, L1, V1, pN2, with a locally R0 status.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.0 cm, with the tumor extending up to but not through the pleura. The frozen section diagnosis of large cell carcinoma was confirmed, and the margins are reported as free of tumor. No lymph nodes were resected during the procedure, and areas of dense fibrosis associated with the tumor were noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 4.5 cm, with evidence of vascular and visceral pleural invasion. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 3 of 5 examined peribronchial lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes (4R, level 5, and level 7) were negative for metastasis. Surgical margins were uninvolved, and the tumor is classified as poorly differentiated (G3) with a pathologic staging of pT2a and pN1.

The pathology report indicates that all excised margins from the anterior and posterior mandible, as well as the buccal mucosa, are negative for tumor involvement. However, a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (G2) was made from a 4.5 cm tumor in the oral cavity, which has invaded through the cortical bone and metastasized to multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes. Additionally, a nodular basal cell carcinoma was identified in the forehead skin, but its margins are uninvolved by tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with mucinous features located in the cecum, measuring 5 cm in length and 8 cm in width, with invasion into subserosal adipose tissue but no gross perforation or lymphovascular invasion identified. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and no regional lymph node metastasis was found among the 28 examined lymph nodes. Additionally, the omentum specimen revealed benign mature adipose tissue with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a brain tumor, specifically a diffuse astrocytoma. The tumor is located in the left frontal lobe and exhibits a soft, brownish structure with both gray and white matter involvement. The tumor is classified as Grade III with a Ki 67 proliferative activity of less than 10%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well to moderately to poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, with a tumor size of 4.0 cm and evidence of vascular invasion. The gallbladder shows mild chronic cholecystitis, and the surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, although a satellite nodule is noted to be within 1 mm of the margin. The tumor is classified as pT2, indicating a solitary tumor with vascular invasion, and no distant metastases were identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3, measuring 6.0 cm, and confined to the left kidney with free surgical margins. The tumor exhibits areas of hemorrhage and necrosis but does not invade surrounding tissues or extend to Gerota's fascia. Additionally, a simple cortical cyst is present, and seven unremarkable lymph nodes were identified in the hilum of the kidney.

The pathology report indicates that the liver biopsy shows mild mixed portal inflammation and fibrosis, but is negative for malignancy. The left tube and ovary reveal a dermoid cyst and endosalpingiosis, also negative for malignancy, while the peritoneal mass biopsy shows a hyalinized nodule with dystrophic calcification, again negative for malignancy. However, the pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple's resection) confirms the presence of moderately differentiated invasive pancreatic adenocarcinoma, measuring 5.0 cm, with negative surgical margins and no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the right parietal lobe of the brain revealed no solid tumor in the initial samples, but subsequent analysis confirmed the presence of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) in the excised tumor tissue. Multiple tissue samples were collected for intraoperative consultation, with varying sizes and descriptions, all indicating the presence of abnormal tissue. The final diagnosis highlights the aggressive nature of the glioblastoma multiforme identified in the right parietal region.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an Anaplastic Astrocytoma, WHO grade III, in the left temporal lobe, characterized by increased cellularity and mitotic activity. Immunohistochemical analysis shows strong positivity for IDH-1 and approximately 25% positivity for p53, with a MIB-1 labeling index of about 8%. The specimen was received in two parts, with both portions confirming the diagnosis of an infiltrating astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast wide local excision revealed invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 2.2 cm, with negative surgical margins and a modified Scarff Bloom Richardson grade of 3. Among the sentinel lymph nodes, one (sentinel lymph node #4) was positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the other four sentinel lymph nodes and eight additional axillary lymph nodes were negative for metastases. The tumor is estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) positive, and HER2 negative, with a pathological staging of pT2 N1a.

The pathology report indicates that a radical resection was performed on a left thigh mass, diagnosed pre-operatively as a left thigh sarcoma, which was confirmed to be a leiomyosarcoma measuring 6.5 cm. The tumor is classified as high grade with a mitotic rate of 12 per 10 high-power fields, and the margins are negative for sarcoma, with the closest margin being 0.1 cm away. No necrosis was identified, and additional pathologic findings or assessments of regional lymph nodes and distant metastasis were not applicable.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, revealing metastatic serous adenocarcinoma in multiple sites including both ovaries, the uterus, and various soft tissues. Additionally, findings include acute and chronic cervicitis, inactive endometrium, benign polyps, adenomyosis, and leiomyomas. The final staging is classified as AJCC/UICC/FIGO Stage IIIC, indicating significant peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, measuring 2.3 cm, with a Nottingham score of 6/9 and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising 5% of the tumor volume. One sentinel lymph node was positive for micrometastatic carcinoma, measuring 1 mm, while another sentinel lymph node and a non-sentinel lymph node were benign with no tumor detected. The tumor is ER-positive, PR-positive, and HER2/NEU-negative, with surgical margins involved by the invasive component.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade I endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with an exophytic mass measuring 2.8 x 2.5 x 1.9 cm in the anterior uterine wall, invading 0.2 cm into the myometrium. The tumor is associated with complex hyperplasia with atypia and is not involving the endocervix, with no lymphovascular invasion detected. Additionally, multiple pelvic lymph nodes from both sides are negative for tumor involvement, and there are also two intramural leiomyomata present in the uterus.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Anaplastic Oligoastrocytoma, characterized by a hypercellular glial neoplasm that infiltrates both gray and white matter with distinct regional patterns. The tumor exhibits a mix of gemistocytes and astrocytoma phenotypes, with mild to marked atypia and rare mitotic activity. Focal tumor necrosis is present, but microvascular proliferation is not observed, and the MIB-1 labeling index is 5.2%.

The pathology report indicates that a radical orchiectomy was performed on the left testis, revealing a unifocal classic seminoma measuring 4.0 cm, which is confined to the testis without invasion into surrounding structures. The spermatic cord margin is free of tumor, and there is no evidence of lymph-vascular invasion. Additional findings include intratubular germ cell neoplasia and testicular microlithiasis.

The pathology report indicates a normal, tumor-free gall bladder and two tumor-free perivesicular lymph nodes. Additionally, it describes a resected segment of the sigmoid colon containing a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that has penetrated all layers of the wall and the peritoneum, with one regional lymph node showing metastasis. The findings suggest a diagnosis of pT4, L1, V0, pN1 with a solitary lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple renal cell carcinomas of the conventional (clear cell) type, with varying sizes and Fuhrman nuclear grades, including one tumor measuring 10.2 cm with extensive necrosis and sarcomatoid features. The tumors in the right kidney are staged as pT1a and pT1b, while the left kidney tumor is staged as pT3a, with some foci suspicious for angiolymphatic invasion. Additionally, a benign cyst was identified, and all surgical margins for the tumors were free of neoplasia, except for one tumor that extends to the inked capsular resection margin.

The pathology report indicates that the cervical biopsy reveals a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma, specifically a villoglandular papillary adenocarcinoma with intestinal-type differentiation. The tumor exhibits areas of complex cribriform architecture, comprising about 10-15% of the lesional tissue, although definitive stromal invasion is not identified due to the absence of normal stroma in the biopsy. The diagnosis is supported by the examination of the slides and is concurred by another physician.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in an anterior mediastinal/thymic mass, with a paratracheal lymph node showing reactive hyperplasia. The neoplastic cells are negative for pancytokeratin AEI/3, which helps exclude thymomas, carcinomas, carcinoids, and non-germinomatous germ cell tumors. The report confirms that the diagnosis remains unchanged despite an addendum regarding an omitted immunohistochemical result.

The pathology report indicates that two biopsies from the left frontal lobe show WHO grade IV glioblastoma multiforme, characterized by a highly cellular astrocytic neoplasm with mitoses, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis. In contrast, the resection of the left frontal lobe did not reveal any tumor, showing only gray and white matter with foci of hemorrhage consistent with surgical effects. Immunohistochemical analysis confirmed the presence of neoplastic astrocytes, and additional testing for MIB-1 showed a labeling index of 20.06%.

The pathology report indicates that a right renal mass was diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 1.5 cm, showing no local or renal vein invasion, and free surgical margins. Additionally, the excised paracaval lymph nodes were found to be uninvolved, with two nodes examined. The report notes marked glomerulosclerosis and chronic pyelonephritis in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue, and the tumor exhibits features associated with impaired renal function.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bilateral invasive grade 3 ductal carcinoma in the left and right breasts, with the left tumor measuring 1.8 cm and the right tumor measuring 4 cm, both associated with high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and extensive tumor necrosis. One of two left axillary lymph nodes is positive for metastatic carcinoma, while two of twelve right axillary lymph nodes show metastasis with extranodal extension. Margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, and additional findings include neurofibromatosis and proliferative fibrocystic changes.
