The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade uterine leiomyosarcoma, with tumors measuring 10x6x5.5 cm and 18x9x9 cm, both of which extend to the uterine serosa and involve the cervix. Focal angiolymphatic invasion is noted, while the ovaries and fallopian tubes show no significant pathologic changes, and the omentum is benign. The pathologic stage is classified as T1b NX MX, reflecting the extent of the disease.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 3x3x3 cm enlarged intra-abdominal lymph node with a soft, yellowish-gray surface, replaced by a diffuse pattern of tumor cells. Microscopic examination reveals malignant lymphoma, specifically diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, characterized by small and large transformed lymphoid cells with irregular hyperchromatic nuclei and common mitotic figures. The tumor is poorly differentiated, with positive CD20 and negative CD3 markers, indicating a B-cell origin.

The pathology report indicates a resected colon (rectosigmoid) containing an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that has infiltrated the perimuscular fatty tissue, but with tumor-free resection margins and no local lymph node metastases. Additionally, two tubular adenomas with moderate dysplasia were identified. The splenectomy preparation shows recent capsule and parenchymal defects, likely due to an iatrogenic injury.

The pathology report indicates that the tumor is located in the right parietal region of the brain. The histological diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme. This diagnosis suggests a highly aggressive and malignant brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 3. The tumor is staged as T1c, N0, and M0, indicating it is a primary tumor with no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered at this time.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant mixed Mllerian tumor (carcinosarcoma) involving the endometrium, cervix, and vaginal margin, with extensive lymphovascular permeation and metastasis to multiple lymph nodes, classified as FIGO stage IIIC. The tumor has infiltrated approximately 70% of the endometrial surface and has full-thickness penetration into the serosa and right parametrium. Additional findings include endometrial polyps, adenomyosis, multiple leiomyomas, and endometriosis in the left ovary, with no tumor detected in the ovaries or fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 3.0 x 1.5 cm, with a grade of II and no evidence of pleural or lymphovascular invasion, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Two lymph node biopsies from levels 10 and 7 were negative for neoplasm, and a lobectomy of the right upper lobe showed emphysematous changes but no residual neoplasm. The overall staging is pT1, N0, M0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that all examined pelvic lymph nodes from both the left and right sides are benign, with no evidence of malignancy. In the prostate, there are multiple foci of prostatic adenocarcinoma with varying Gleason scores, the most significant being a Gleason score of 4+4=8, with established extraprostatic extension and perineural invasion, but all surgical margins are free of tumor. The overall pathologic stage is T3a, with less than 5% of the prostate gland volume involved by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 6.0 cm in the left thyroid lobe, with margins that are grossly free of tumor. No parathyroid tissue was identified in the specimens evaluated for both the left inferior and right parathyroid, while the right thyroid lobe showed no tumor present. Additionally, the left paratracheal dissection revealed fibroadipose tissue without any lesions or lymph nodes identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in a breast tissue specimen obtained from a mastectomy, with a tumor size of 2 x 1.5 x 1.5 cm. One out of twelve lymph nodes examined showed positive metastasis, indicating the presence of cancer spread. The tumor is classified as moderately differentiated, but specific details regarding histologic grading and Nottingham scores are not provided.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear) cell type, following a left laparoscopic nephrectomy. The tumor measures 7.2 cm, is classified as Fuhrman's nuclear grade 3 of 4, and exhibits invasion into the renal vein, although all surgical margins are free of neoplasm. The tumor is staged as pT3b, with no regional lymph nodes examined and no lymphatic invasion present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma in the uterus, measuring 1.7 cm, with invasion to a depth of 3 mm and very focal lymphovascular space invasion. No carcinoma was identified in the vagina, parametrial soft tissue, or any of the examined lymph nodes, totaling 17 nodes with no malignancy detected. Additionally, the endometrium, myometrium, right ovary, and right fallopian tube showed no histopathologic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse astrocytoma (WHO grade 2) in the right frontal mass, with features suggesting early anaplastic change. Scattered astrocytoma cells are present within the tumor cyst wall and adjacent white matter, but no mitotic activity, vascular proliferation, or necrosis is observed. Molecular testing shows methylation of the MGMT gene, which may indicate a favorable response to alkylating agents like temozolomide.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme in the left frontal lobe biopsy, characterized by high-grade glioma that infiltrates normal brain tissue with pleomorphic neoplastic cells and areas of necrosis. Additionally, there is evidence of reactive gliosis in the white matter adjacent to the tumor. The MIB-1 labeling index for the tumor is reported at 10%, suggesting a moderate level of cellular proliferation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in the liver specimen, measuring 8.0 x 6.0 x 5.6 cm, with the tumor approaching within 0.5 cm of the surgical margin, which is free of malignancy. Additionally, the vermiform appendix shows benign findings with no evidence of appendicitis or malignancy. The background liver exhibits chronic portal inflammation without signs of cirrhosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing minimal chronic cholecystitis without dysplasia, and a total gastrectomy showing invasive signet ring cell carcinoma with a 13.8 cm ulcerating mass in the stomach, which has invaded adjacent jejunal mucosa and perigastric adipose tissue. The tumor is staged as pT4b, with significant lymphovascular and perineural invasion, and metastasis identified in 15 of 25 regional lymph nodes, leading to a final staging of IIIC. Margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, and additional findings include chronic active gastritis and intestinal metaplasia in the gastric mucosa.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with extensively invasive papillary serous adenocarcinoma affecting the right ovary and fallopian tube, with additional involvement in the left fallopian tube and multiple foci in the endometrium. Metastatic disease is present in several lymph nodes, including the right obturator, left external iliac, right external iliac, and para-aortic lymph nodes, while three left obturator lymph nodes are free of carcinoma. The findings suggest the possibility of synchronous primary sites due to the extensive involvement of the right ovary and discrete lesions in the fallopian tubes and endometrium.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast excision revealed an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 1.6 cm, with the tumor located 0.2 cm from the inferior surgical margin, and no tumor was found in the additional margin specimens. The sentinel lymph node was negative for metastases, confirming no spread to the lymphatic system. The tumor is classified as Grade 3, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative HER2 status.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a male with a history of adenocarcinoma and GERD, has been diagnosed with invasive adenocarcinoma at the esophagogastric junction, with a perforation and associated fibrinopurulent exudate. The tumor has penetrated through the muscularis into the adventitia, with a maximum depth of invasion noted, and four out of nine lymph nodes examined were positive for metastatic carcinoma. The TNM classification is T3 N1 MX, and there are no involved surgical margins at the proximal and distal resection sites.

The pathology report indicates that both sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla are benign with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The right breast segmental mastectomy reveals invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 2.7 cm, classified as well-differentiated with no lymphatic or vascular invasion, alongside a low-grade intraductal carcinoma (DCIS) comprising approximately 5% of the tumor. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and additional excisions of breast tissue show benign changes with no malignancy detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell variant, located in the lower pole of the left kidney, with focal microscopic invasion of the peripelvic fat and evidence of vascular and lymphatic invasion, classified as stage T3N1MX. The renal vein margins and adrenal gland are free of tumor. Additionally, a nodal mass excised showed metastatic renal cell carcinoma, while the inferior aortic node excision revealed no tumor present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in a male patient, with a tumor grade of 2 and a TNM stage of 1. There is no evidence of metastasis (M0) or regional lymph node involvement (N0). The report notes that no treatment has been initiated at this time.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a grade 3 poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) with necrosis, classified as pT2, and carcinoma in situ (CIS) in the bladder. The report also notes that while some tissue samples showed heavy inflammatory infiltrate, there was no evidence of invasive TCC in the multiple tissue planes examined. Overall, the findings confirm a diagnosis of transitional cell carcinoma G3 pT2 with associated carcinoma in situ.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right hemicolectomy revealing moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cecum, measuring 3.0 x 4.7 x 0.8 cm, with invasion into the subserosa (pT3) and evidence of vascular invasion, but no gross perforation or serosal involvement. Additionally, multiple tubular adenomas were identified, and out of 48 examined lymph nodes, 3 showed metastases (pn1). The omentum specimen was reported as benign adipose tissue with no abnormalities detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the lower lip, with extensive bone invasion and perineural and angiolymphatic invasion present. Additionally, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was found in two of four left neck lymph nodes, while the right neck lymph nodes showed one of three nodes with metastatic involvement, but no extracapsular spread. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT4a N2c, with involved margins noted in the left mandible and adjacent deep soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma located in the antrum of the stomach, measuring 10 x 8 x 3 cm, with an enlarged ulcerated tumor invading the serosa. The tumor exhibits a high mitotic index, hyperchromatic and irregularly enlarged nuclei, and scant eosinophilic cytoplasm, with prominent lymphocyte infiltration in the stroma. Additionally, metastasis is confirmed in both examined lymph nodes, indicating lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing perineural invasion, with a maximum tumor diameter of 45 mm and positive surgical margins. Additionally, there are lymph node metastases, with one metastasis on the right side and five on the left side, indicating a pN1 classification. The report also notes tumor infiltration into the seminal vesicles and peri-prostatic adipose tissue, with no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion detected.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower lobe lung biopsy shows benign bronchial mucosa, while the resection of the third rib reveals diffuse malignant mesothelioma of the epithelioid type in the soft tissue, with unremarkable bone and bone marrow. Additionally, the pleural resection demonstrates the same type of malignant mesothelioma extending into the adjacent lung parenchyma, along with a pleural hyaline plaque. Fluorescence in situ hybridization studies show no significant p16 (9p21) deletion, which is relevant for the diagnosis and prognosis of malignant mesotheliomas.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis with no evidence of malignancy, while two liver nodules from the left lobe exhibit focal scars but are also free of malignancy. However, a partial resection of the right lobe of the liver reveals a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, measuring 3.3 x 2.5 x 1.5 cm, confined to the hepatic parenchyma with no vascular or perineural invasion. Additionally, a portal lymph node was examined and found to be free of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a 7.5 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma located in the sigmoid colon, classified as moderately differentiated. There is evidence of tumor extension into pericolonic tissues, with 3 out of 12 lymph nodes showing metastasis. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no information provided regarding neo-adjuvant treatment or additional findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically the chromophobe subtype, with a histologic grade of 2 and a tumor size of 5.5 cm. There is no evidence of sarcomatoid features or extra-capsular invasion, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement. The tumor is classified as pT1b pNx pMx according to AJCC staging, and the specimen was well-circumscribed with no multicentricity observed.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, revealing a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma with invasion into the inner half of the myometrium, but no cervical involvement or lymphovascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes from the right and left para-aortic, right pelvic, and left pelvic regions, as well as the omentum biopsy, were negative for carcinoma. The tumor was classified as pT1b (IB) with no regional lymph node metastasis, and the surgical margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing chronic cholecystitis and cholesterosis, along with a reactive lymph node. A left lobectomy of the liver showed a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 13 cm with microvascular invasion, while all surgical margins were free of tumor. Additionally, granulomatous hepatitis was noted in both liver specimens, with a subcapsular sclerosed hemangioma identified in the right lobe.

The pathology report indicates that parathyroid tissue was examined with no tumor present. A total thyroidectomy revealed a 2 cm encapsulated papillary thyroid carcinoma, follicular variant, in the right lobe, along with a diffuse nodular goiter. There is no definitive evidence of lymphatic invasion associated with the tumor.

The pathology report describes a histopathological examination of a 32 cm segment of the sigmoid colon and rectum, which contains two tumors diagnosed as bifocal adenocarcinoma tubulopapillare partim mucinosum (G3). The first tumor, measuring 5 x 3 x 2.5 cm, infiltrates the intestinal wall and surrounding fat tissue, while the second tumor, measuring 2.5 x 3 x 1 cm, also penetrates the intestinal wall but has a larger side margin. The report indicates that the minimum side margin for the first tumor is 1.1 cm, and the intestine ends are free of neoplastic lesions, with a diagnosis of Dukes B and Astler-Coller B2 classification.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderate to high-grade leiomyosarcoma, measuring 8.5 cm, confined to the uterus (pT1b), with negative margins and no vascular invasion. All 24 regional lymph nodes examined from various sites were negative for metastasis. Additional findings included unremarkable ovaries and fallopian tubes, a cervix without dysplasia, and endometrial cystic atrophy with a polyp.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma in the right thyroid lobectomy specimen, measuring 3.2 cm, with metastatic carcinoma found in 6 of 14 lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as pT2, indicating it is greater than 2 cm but less than 4 cm and limited to the thyroid, with pN1b status due to metastasis to cervical or mediastinal nodes. The left thyroid lobectomy showed no tumor, with all four lymph nodes negative for malignancy, while five of nine lymph nodes from the central compartment dissection were positive for metastatic papillary carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a colectomy specimen from the sigmoid colon, revealing a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 5 x 4 x 1 cm. The tumor has extended into the pericolonic tissues, and all six examined lymph nodes show evidence of metastasis. Details regarding tumor margins and any neo-adjuvant treatment are not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the cervical biopsy reveals moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma with full thickness dysplasia extending into the endocervical glands and small irregular nests invading the underlying stroma. However, the endocervical curettage shows only benign endocervical and endometrial tissue, with no dysplasia or carcinoma identified. There is no evidence of lymphovascular space invasion noted in the biopsy.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in multiple biopsies from the right base of the tongue, left inferior pharyngeal margin, right superior pharyngeal margin, and various lymph nodes, except for one lymph node in the left Level 2A and 3, which showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm. The primary tumor, identified as moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, is located in the right glottis and surrounding areas, measuring 2.7 cm, with invasion into the cricoid cartilage but no extranodal extension. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3 pN1.

The pathology report indicates that four periaortic lymph nodes were examined, all of which were negative for malignancy, although one lymph node showed prominent non-caseating granulomatous inflammation, raising suspicion for sarcoidosis. The left kidney specimen revealed a multi-focal renal cell carcinoma, specifically the eosinophilic variant of chromophobe carcinoma, with a tumor size of 7.0 cm and a Fuhrman grade of 3, but no definitive capsular invasion was identified. Additionally, an angiomyolipoma measuring 1.0 cm was noted, and all surgical margins and major vessels were negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the sigmoid colon, measuring 4.4 cm in length and 3.7 cm in width, with invasion into the muscularis propria but no evidence of vascular or perineural invasion. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and no regional lymph node metastases were identified among the 17 examined nodes. Additionally, multiple hyperplastic polyps were noted away from the carcinoma, and a preexisting tubulovillous polyp was found at the carcinoma site.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast tissue shows macromastia with scattered foci of atypical lobular hyperplasia, while the right breast simple mastectomy reveals moderately differentiated intraductal and infiltrating duct carcinoma, with multifocal invasive components and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The largest invasive focus measures 7 mm, and the tumor is noted to be multifocal with DCIS present in 15 of 20 blocks examined. Additionally, the sentinel lymph node biopsy from the right axilla shows metastatic breast carcinoma in a focus measuring 0.17 mm, with isolated tumor cells also identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an oligoastrocytoma, predominantly oligodendroglioma, classified as low grade (WHO grade II). The MIB-1 labeling index is 5.0%, reflecting an intermediate level of proliferative activity consistent with low-grade histologic features. Microscopic examination reveals a mildly to moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm with a predominance of microgemistocytes and no evidence of mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the uterus and cervix. Microscopic examination confirmed the diagnosis based on the analysis of the provided slides. The report does not include any patient history or additional clinical information.

The pathology report indicates a lumpectomy specimen from the right upper outer quadrant of the breast, revealing a grossly evident infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 1.4 x 0 x 1.8 cm, which is moderately differentiated. Out of 10 examined lymph nodes, 1 showed positive metastasis, while the surgical margins are reported as uninvolved. The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic counts.

The pathology report indicates a unifocal clear cell renal carcinoma located in the lower pole of the right kidney, measuring 5.5 cm in greatest dimension, with a predominant histologic grade of II and a focal area of grade IV. The tumor is classified as pT1b, indicating it is more than 4 cm but not more than 7 cm in size and limited to the kidney, with uninvolved surgical margins and no evidence of invasion into the adrenal gland or large vessels. Additional findings include a renal cortical cyst and focal mild chronic interstitial inflammation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical cystectomy with urinary diversion, revealing a high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which has infiltrated through the muscularis propria into the peritoneum, along with evidence of lymphovascular invasion. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in five out of 74 lymph nodes examined, specifically in the right obturator/hypogastric lymph nodes and the right presciatic lymph nodes, while the remaining lymph nodes showed no evidence of malignancy. The ureters and other reproductive organs, including the uterus and ovaries, were found to be benign with no dysplasia or carcinoma identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with significant tumor involvement in the cervix, vaginal cuff, and paracervical soft tissues, including transmural invasion and lymphatic and vascular invasion. One of nine excised right pelvic lymph nodes shows metastatic carcinoma, while the left pelvic and periaortic lymph nodes are negative for metastatic disease. The uterine corpus and fundus are free of carcinoma, and additional findings include benign endometrial changes and a uterine leiomyoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade oligoastrocytoma, predominantly oligodendroglial (WHO grade II), from a left frontal brain mass. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive GFAP in reactive astrocytes and neoplastic cells, a positive IDH1-R132H mutation, variable p53 expression, and a low Ki-67 labeling index. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) studies for 1p19q deletion have been ordered for further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated, large-cell, focally keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma located in the right lower lobe of the lung, classified as stage IB. The tumor has invaded small to medium-sized blood vessels, but the visceral pleura, bronchial resection margins, and all examined lymph nodes are free of tumor. Additionally, there are findings of chronic fibrosing interstitial pneumonia and anthracotic pigment deposits in the lymph nodes, with no asbestos bodies identified in the examined sections.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed-type adenocarcinoma in the right middle lobe of the lung, measuring 2.1 x 1.2 x 0.5 cm, with no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion and negative margins. Additionally, four peribronchiolar lymph nodes were identified as benign with anthracosis, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as pT1b N0 M0, Stage IA. The intraoperative diagnosis confirmed the presence of adenocarcinoma with a negative bronchial margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 6.7 cm and a histologic grade of 2. There is evidence of extra-capsular invasion and involvement of a renal vein tributary, but surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement. The AJCC staging is classified as pT3 pNx pMx, indicating advanced local disease without lymph node or distant metastasis identified at this time.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy, revealing invasive ductal carcinoma (6.5 cm, grade II) with associated high nuclear grade ductal carcinoma in situ and focal Paget's disease of the nipple. Both sentinel lymph nodes and non-sentinel lymph nodes were negative for tumor involvement, and the excisional biopsy margins were free of tumor. The invasive carcinoma showed strong expression of estrogen and progesterone receptors, with HER2 status pending.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma involving the bladder, with a significant lesion measuring 5 x 3 cm and invasion into the muscularis propria. Three out of nine right pelvic lymph nodes tested positive for metastatic carcinoma, while all seven left pelvic lymph nodes were negative for tumor. The overall staging is pT2b, N2, MX, indicating advanced disease with lymphatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a glossotonsillar mass, with evidence of metastatic moderate to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a right neck lymph node, although 31 other lymph nodes were negative for metastasis. Additionally, an excised tongue mass showed salivary gland parenchyma mixed with skeletal muscle, which was negative for malignancy. Immunohistochemical studies revealed tumor cells strongly positive for p16, and HPV studies are pending for further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor measuring 6.1 x 2.1 x 1.9 cm that invades 1.8 cm into the myometrium but does not involve the endocervix or lymphovascular spaces. Lymph node analysis reveals that two of the four examined para-aortic lymph nodes are positive for tumor, while presacral lymph nodes are negative. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, suggesting complete resection of the primary tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a low-grade, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with focal mucinous features in the right colon, measuring 4.5 cm and exhibiting ulcerative and diffusely infiltrative characteristics. The tumor invades through the muscularis propria into the serosa, but both proximal and distal resection margins are negative for tumor, with no lymphovascular, extramural venous, or perineural invasion identified. The AJCC classification is pT3a N0 Mx, with a total of 22 regional lymph nodes examined, all of which are negative for metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with mucinous differentiation in the right colon, measuring 10.8 cm and invading through the muscularis propria. Surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of metastasis in the 18 examined lymph nodes. The appendix shows no pathological diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, moderately differentiated, with a maximum depth of invasion of 12 mm and lymphovascular space invasion noted. All examined lymph nodes (totaling 18) were negative for malignancy, and surgical margins were clear of invasive carcinoma. Additionally, focal cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN III) was identified, but the endometrium and myometrium were negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO grade III) in the right parietal lobe, characterized by a proliferation of astrocytic cells with a MIB-1 proliferation index greater than 10%. The tumor shows diffuse infiltration into the brain parenchyma without significant nuclear anaplastic features, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis. Additionally, there is evidence of allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, which is typically associated with oligodendrogliomas, but the findings are consistent with an astrocytoma diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade muscle invasive urothelial cell carcinoma with carcinoma in situ (CIS), classified as T3aN0Mx. The tumor is located on the right dorsolateral bladder wall and measures 2.5 cm in diameter. All 18 examined lymph nodes were negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 3 cm, with evidence of vascular invasion but negative surgical margins. The liver specimen was obtained from a right posterior hepatectomy, and the gallbladder showed signs of cholelithiasis and chronic cholecystitis. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT2 NX MX, G-1, Stage II.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 6.0 cm, with a composition of 90% clear cells and 10% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, and showing invasion into the renal vein and renal sinus adipose tissue. A small renomedullary interstitial cell tumor measuring 0.4 cm was also identified, but the margins of resection were free of tumor, and the adrenal gland showed no evidence of malignancy. The report notes extensive vascular-lymphatic invasion by the renal cell carcinoma, with a tumor thrombus extending into the inferior vena cava, although the renal vein wall at the margin is free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme from a brain biopsy of the frontal lobe. The specimen measured 4.0 x 2.0 cm and exhibited features of high-grade astrocytoma, including coagulation necrosis, hypercellularity, and nuclear pleomorphism. The MIB-1 labeling index for the tumor cells was approximately 30%, suggesting a high proliferation rate.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 4 + 4 = 8, involving both lobes of the prostate and measuring 1.2 cm in greatest diameter, but is organ-confined with no evidence of extraprostatic extension. All examined lymph nodes, including those from the right and left pelvic regions, as well as the left perivesical area, show no evidence of neoplasia, and all surgical margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, perineural invasion is identified, and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is noted, with a pathologic TNM stage of pT2c NO MX.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent an extended right hemicolectomy due to hepatic flexure cancer, with the final diagnosis confirming moderately-differentiated adenocarcinoma that invades through the muscularis propria into the subserosa (pT3). The tumor has negative margins, with a distance of 5.7 cm from the distal margin, and no vascular invasion was identified. Additionally, all 34 examined regional lymph nodes were negative for cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma (Fuhrman grade 3/4) in the left kidney, with a tumor size comprising a cystic component of 19 cm and a solid component of 5 cm, exhibiting extracapsular invasion into perinephric tissue but no lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, the report notes a torsed appendage epiploica with infarction and a perihilar renal lymph node showing follicular hyperplasia, with no evidence of tumor in the lymph nodes or adrenal gland. The surgical procedure performed was a radical nephrectomy, and all margins were negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the cervix reveals a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The specimen consists of multiple soft tissue fragments, with the largest measuring 0.3 cm, and shows well-differentiated invasive carcinoma with areas of keratinization and a prominent eosinophilic infiltrate. This diagnosis is based on the personal examination of the slides by the pathologist.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated, partially mucus-producing colorectal adenocarcinoma in the resected section of the colon, measuring 2 cm in diameter and invading the muscularis propria. The tumor is staged as pT2, with no lymph node involvement (0/22 nodes tumor-free) and clear margins (R0). Additionally, there are findings of pseudodiverticula and peridiverticulitis with chronic scarring in the intestinal wall.

The pathology report indicates the presence of acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 9 (5+4), showing extensive extra-prostatic extension and seminal vesicle invasion. Surgical margins are involved by invasive carcinoma with a multifocal extent of 15 mm, and lymphovascular invasion is present. Additionally, metastasis is noted in 5 out of 10 right pelvic obturator lymph nodes and 6 out of 9 left pelvic obturator lymph nodes, leading to a pathological staging of pT3b, pN1, pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, tall cell variant, with significant findings including extrathyroidal extension, involvement of surgical margins, and venous invasion. Molecular testing revealed a BRAF V600E mutation, which is associated with more aggressive tumor behavior, while no mutations in NRAS, HRAS, or KRAS were identified, and FISH testing was negative for RET/PTC rearrangement. The final staging is pT3, N1b, with five out of six examined lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the right pelvic lymph nodes are free of tumor (0/8), while two out of six left pelvic lymph nodes show metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma with extranodal extension. The prostate exhibits multifocal prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (5+4), extensive extraprostatic extension, and invasion of both seminal vesicles and perivesicular soft tissue. Approximately 90% of the prostate gland is involved by cancer, with two distinct tumor foci identified, one of which is larger and more aggressive.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, with the largest tumor measuring 5.5 cm located in the isthmus and left lobe. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 8 out of 17 lymph nodes, classified as pN1a, with no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. The surgical margins are uninvolved, with invasive carcinoma located less than 1.0 mm from the nearest margin.

The pathology report indicates that the thymus specimen shows an encapsulated thymoma of type AB, measuring 8 cm, with negative but close resection margins and adjacent benign involuted thymic tissue. The cervical horn specimen reveals benign fibroadipose tissue and involuted thymic tissue. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis with specific markers, and no lymphovascular invasion or distant metastasis is noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as moderately differentiated (Nottingham Grade 2) with a tumor size of 3.0 cm and extensive lymphatic invasion, but negative margins. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in one sentinel lymph node and one non-sentinel lymph node, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 1.5 cm and evidence of extranodal extension in the sentinel node. Estrogen and progesterone receptors were positive, while HER2 was negative, and additional benign changes were noted in the breast tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe, measuring 7.2 x 5.6 x 4.5 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. All examined lymph nodes (33 in total) and the pleural biopsy were negative for malignancy. Additionally, there is evidence of squamous cell carcinoma in situ associated with the bronchus, and the non-neoplastic lung shows emphysematous changes and subpleural fibrosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 7.6 x 3.3 x 2.2 cm, with multifocal carcinoma in situ and no malignancy identified in the attached ureters or resection margins. The prostate shows unilateral adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), confined to the prostate without capsular involvement, and no malignancy in the seminal vesicles or prostatic urethra. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes (79 total) and the left kidney show no evidence of malignancy or significant histopathologic changes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic serous carcinoma in the pre-caval lymph node and in 8 out of 17 right common and external iliac lymph nodes. The uterus, cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes, and ovaries show extensive involvement of serous carcinoma, with myometrial invasion and lymphatic/vascular space involvement, while the omentum is negative for malignancy. The tumor is classified as poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma, with a greatest dimension of 2 cm and a depth of myometrial invasion of 10 mm.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has endometrioid adenocarcinoma with a FIGO grade of 3, showing myometrial invasion of 1.1 cm and involvement of the lower uterine segment, but no cervical or adnexal involvement. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in one of six right para-aortic lymph nodes, three of seven right pelvic lymph nodes, and one of nine left pelvic lymph nodes, while the left para-aortic lymph nodes showed no tumor. Additional findings include extensive lymphovascular space invasion and the presence of leiomyomas and Nabothian cysts in the cervix.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe lung contains a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, with visceral pleural invasion and lymph-vascular invasion present. Out of eleven examined lymph nodes, one lymph node showed metastatic carcinoma, while the others were free of malignancy. The tumor is staged as pT2a, N1, Mx, and ancillary studies for EGFR and KRAS mutations are pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma at the right base of the tongue, measuring at least 2.6 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion present and carcinoma extending to deep and lateral margins, while other margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, two out of thirty-three lymph nodes examined from the right neck dissection show metastatic squamous cell carcinoma with evidence of extracapsular spread. The anterior, lateral pharyngeal, deep base of tongue, and medial base of tongue margins were all reported as benign with no tumor present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, specifically papillary Type I, with incipient lesions present. The specimen, a partially encapsulated mass measuring 7.5 x 6 x 3.5 cm, was excised and showed a tan, soft cut surface with areas of red and yellow. Immunohistochemical staining for CK7 was negative, and the laboratory is certified under CLIA for high complexity testing.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade II squamous cell carcinoma located in the cervix, measuring 4 x 3.5 x 3.5 cm, with infiltration into the muscle propria. Microscopic examination reveals hyperplastic squamous cells replacing normal cells, with malignant cells exhibiting abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, enlarged nuclei, and evidence of mitotic figures. The tumor shows lymphatic invasion, but the surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no specification regarding lymph node involvement or neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report describes a liver tissue sample from segment VIII, weighing 85.0 grams. The diagnosis indicates the presence of Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma associated with micronodular cirrhosis, forming a mass measuring 4.8 x 4.5 x 4.0 cm. The margins of the resection are free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a modified radical mastectomy for left breast cancer, revealing a poorly differentiated infiltrating duct carcinoma measuring 4.0 cm, with one intramammary lymph node showing metastatic carcinoma. No metastatic disease was found in the 37 examined axillary lymph nodes, and the closest margin was 1 mm from the invasive tumor. The tumor is classified as nuclear grade III with a Nottingham score of 9, and the final staging is determined to be 2B.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) in the brain, characterized by significant cytologic pleomorphism, mitotic figures, and necrosis. Imaging revealed a mass in the right temporoparietal region, measuring 5.7 cm, with associated mass effect on the adjacent ventricle. Additional genetic analysis showed polysomy of chromosomes 7 and 10, along with allelic loss of PTEN, suggesting a poor prognosis due to the presence of multiple abnormal markers.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating gliomas in multiple biopsy sites, specifically in the posterior margin, lateral superior margin, and frontal lobe. Additionally, an anaplastic oligoastrocytoma (WHO Grade III) was identified in the tumor excision, with over 90% of the tumor showing features of a WHO Grade II oligoastrocytoma, but with focal areas of increased cellularity and pleomorphism. No tumor was identified in the posterior medial tumor biopsy, and the report includes detailed descriptions of the specimens submitted for analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to weakly differentiated intestinal type gastric adenocarcinoma, measuring 5.5 cm, located in the prepyloric gastric antrum and invading the proximal duodenum, with associated perigastric fat infiltration and marked lymphangitis. There are seven regional lymph node metastases identified, while the oral resection margin is tumor-free with mild to moderate chronic gastritis. The aboral resection margin is also tumor-free, lined with typical duodenal mucosa, and the remaining gastric mucosa shows similar gastritis along with focal polypoid hyperplasia and multifocal intestinal metaplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of three tumors excised from the right kidney of a patient with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome. Tumor #1 is identified as a renal cyst, while tumors #2 and #3 are both classified as clear cell renal cell carcinoma with Furhman nuclear grade 2, accompanied by chronic interstitial nephritis. The specimens were processed for permanent analysis, confirming the diagnoses.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma involving both ovaries, with lymphovascular space invasion noted in multiple specimens. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in a right pelvic lymph node, omental adipose tissue, and fibroadipose tissue from bowel and cul-de-sac excisions. The overall staging is pT3, pN1, pM1, corresponding to FIGO stage IV, indicating advanced disease with metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive adenocarcinoma of the colon (cecal carcinoma G3) with significant infiltration into surrounding fatty tissue and vascular involvement. Additionally, a tubular adenoma with focal severe dysplasia and a transition to a circumscribed adenocarcinoma (G2) was identified, which has infiltrated the submucosa. The resection margins are free of tumor, and all examined lymph nodes (0 of 17) are also free of metastasis, indicating a locally R0 status.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of WHO-II glioblastoma multiforme, grade 4, characterized by necrosis, endothelial proliferation, and marked pleomorphism with abundant giant cells. The specimen was obtained from a left temporal mass, and the diagnosis was confirmed through gross and microscopic examinations. Additional immunohistochemical analysis revealed a MIB-1 labeling index of 35.3%, a p53 score of 3, and a positive EGFR score.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a Grade 2 oligodendroglioma located in the right frontal lobe of the brain, characterized by moderate cellularity and scant mitotic activity. FISH studies reveal abnormal results consistent with deletions of chromosomal regions 1p and 19q, which are commonly associated with oligodendrogliomas. The report also notes the presence of an old biopsy site with marked reactive changes and describes the gross specimen as a substantial mass of brain tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, with a tumor size of 1.5 x 1.4 x 1.2 cm, and associated ductal carcinoma in situ comprising approximately 20% of the tumor. All resection margins and sentinel lymph nodes are free of tumor, indicating no evidence of metastatic disease. Immunohistochemical staining supports the findings from the histological examination.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, conventional clear cell type, with a tumor size of 6.8 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade 3. There is no evidence of sarcomatoid features or capsular invasion, and all surgical margins, including Gerota's fascia and renal vein, are negative for tumor involvement. An incidental finding of a small angiomyolipoma is noted, and the tumor is staged as pT1b pNx according to AJCC guidelines.

The pathology report indicates that all examined pelvic lymph nodes (15 right and 6 left) are free of tumor, with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The prostate shows two foci of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3), extending focally into extraprostatic tissue, but with all resection margins free of tumor. Additionally, there is high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) and perineural invasion present, while the seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 2.8 cm, with no evidence of malignancy in the left lobe or lymph nodes examined. The left lobe showed benign thyroid tissue, and the lymph nodes and surrounding tissues were free of cancer. The surgical margins are clear of carcinoma, suggesting complete resection of the malignant tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in a solitary 3.7 cm tumor located in the middle of the right kidney, with no sarcomatoid features identified. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with uninvolved margins and no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, resulting in a pathologic tumor stage of pT1a pNX. Additional findings include a benign cortical cyst and mild interstitial inflammation in the adjacent renal parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of a lesion in the right parietal lobe of the brain reveals a malignant glioma consistent with glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV). The tumor is characterized by dense cellularity, marked pleomorphism, and a high mitotic rate, although it lacks coagulative necrosis and microvascular proliferation. Immunohistochemical stains have confirmed the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade spindle cell sarcoma in the left groin, and dedifferentiated liposarcoma arising from well-differentiated sclerosing liposarcoma in both the right and left groin, with tumors measuring 8.0 cm and 12.0 cm respectively, both extending to the margins of resection. Additionally, the left groin dissection revealed low-grade well-differentiated sclerosing and lipoma-like liposarcoma encasing lymph nodes, with no malignant involvement in the 19 lymph nodes examined. Special stains were performed, showing positive results for smooth muscle actin and other markers, confirming the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the cervix reveals moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. This diagnosis suggests the presence of cancerous cells originating from the squamous epithelium of the cervix. Further evaluation and management will be necessary to determine the extent of the disease and appropriate treatment options.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with a histologic grade of 2 out of 3 and a gross tumor size of 1.6 cm. The surgical margins are negative, and there is less than 10% in-situ carcinoma present, characterized as solid and cribriform. Estrogen receptor activity is positive, while progesterone receptor activity is negative, with further analysis pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 9 cm and evidence of local invasion into the renal sinus fat and renal vein. The tumor is classified as Fuhrman Nuclear Grade III/IV, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the excised falciform ligament shows benign fibro-adipose tissue with no evidence of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma involving both the left and right ovaries and their associated structures, with evidence of metastatic disease in the left pelvic peritoneum, right pelvic peritoneum, and omentum. No angiolymphatic invasion was identified in the ovarian specimens, and the fallopian tubes showed normal epithelium on the left side, while the right side exhibited epithelial dysplasia. Additionally, lymph node excisions from the left para-aortic and left pelvic regions showed no tumor involvement, although metastatic serous carcinoma was found in the perinodal fibrous tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma involving the floor of the mouth, with tumor extension to the mandibular bone and perineural invasion present, but no vascular or lymphatic invasion identified. The final margins of resection are free of tumor, although metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was found in one right level I lymph node with extracapsular extension. Additional specimens from the left mental nerve, teeth, and other margins showed no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon, measuring 4 cm and extending to within 6.5 cm of the resection margin, with infiltrative spread into the surrounding mesocolic fatty tissue. Additionally, a small tubulovillous adenoma with moderate epithelial dysplasia is present in the mucous membrane of the colon. The resection margins are tumor-free, and all 22 examined mesocolic lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor involvement, resulting in a tumor stage of pT3 pNO (0/22) LOV0; G2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), located in the left upper lobe, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm. The tumor is classified as pathological T2, with no evidence of metastasis (M0), and carcinoma in situ was identified at the bronchial resection margin. The sample was obtained through a resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma in two liver segments, with segment #3 showing a grade II-III tumor measuring 7.0 x 6.0 x 5.0 cm, extensive tumor necrosis, and venous invasion, while segment 4A and 8 contains a smaller grade II-III tumor measuring 1.5 x 1.0 x 1.0 cm without lymphovascular invasion. The closest surgical margin for segment #3 is 0.5 cm, and for segment 4A and 8, it is within 2.0 mm. Additionally, the patient has underlying hepatic cirrhosis and chronic hepatitis B.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a left parietal brain tumor diagnosed as oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade II). Microscopic examination reveals a well-differentiated glial neoplasm with hyperchromatic astrocytes and oligodendroglial cells, but no signs of mitosis, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis. The Ki-67 labeling index is low at 1-2%, suggesting a low proliferation rate of the tumor cells.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal, bilateral adenocarcinoma of the prostate, with the index tumor located on the left side and a Gleason score of 4+5=9, showing direct invasion into the left seminal vesicle and 3 mm of extraprostatic extension. The right apical transition zone also contains a small organ-confined adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+3=6, but the pathological margins are clear. The overall pathological stage is pT3b, confirming the presence of significant disease with clear margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the inferior left breast, measuring 2.6 cm, with involvement of the superficial dermis and close surgical margins. Sentinel lymph node #1 shows metastatic carcinoma, while sentinel lymph node #2 and the remaining axillary lymph nodes are negative for metastases. The tumor is ER-positive and PR-positive, with equivocal HER2 results pending further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with a tumor measuring 4.3 cm in the right kidney, showing focal necrosis and confined to the kidney with no angiolymphatic invasion. The right distal ureter shows focal moderate dysplasia and inflammation, but no tumor is identified, and the renal pelvis is also free of tumor. Cytogenetic analysis was inadequate for further evaluation, as no metaphases were found.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe, measuring 22 mm, with no evidence of pleural invasion, blood vessel invasion, lymphatic permeation, or perineural invasion, and it is clear of the bronchial resection margin. Additionally, the lymph nodes show numerous non-necrotising sarcoidal granulomata, which may represent a reaction to the carcinoma rather than sarcoidosis, and no lymph node metastases are present. The right lower lobe contains a silicotic nodule with no evidence of malignancy, and mild emphysema is noted in the adjacent lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an intradermal nevus on the anterior neck and multiple lymph nodes that show no tumor presence. However, papillary carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm in diameter is identified in the left lobe of the thyroid, with focal extension to the inked margin of resection and evidence of extrathyroidal extension, but no vascular or lymphatic invasion. Additionally, there are adenomatous nodules in the right lobe of the thyroid and focal chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the ovaries, omentum, posterior cul-de-sac, and liver, with evidence of metastasis. The ovaries show small foci of tumor involvement, while the fallopian tubes and uterus exhibit no significant abnormalities. The report highlights extensive tumor infiltration in the omentum and surrounding soft tissues, confirming a widespread metastatic process.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade III endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma, with the tumor involving the uterine serosal surface, parametria, and bilateral ovaries, along with extensive angiolymphatic invasion. The tumor has been classified as pT3a, with positive involvement in 2 out of 3 examined lymph nodes, and a biopsy of the pelvic cul-de-sac also confirmed the presence of tumor. Margins are involved by invasive carcinoma, specifically at the posterior uterine serosal margin, and the omentum was negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a lymph node with reactive lesions and a diagnosis of moderately differentiated rectal carcinoma (G2) that has infiltrated the muscularis (pT2) with lymphovascular invasion (L1) and perineural invasion (V1). The tumor was completely excised with fine resection margins, and the lymph nodes were free of cancer (pNO). Overall, the findings suggest a localized tumor that has been successfully removed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderate to poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, measuring 6.8 x 5.0 cm, with invasion into the peridiaphragmatic soft tissue and vascular invasion present. The carcinoma is located 2 mm from the diaphragmatic margin and 8 mm from the parenchymal resection margin, with no evidence of cirrhosis noted in the uninvolved liver. Additionally, the gallbladder shows signs of cholesterolosis, but no other significant lesions were identified.

The histopathological examination of the right breast reveals invasive ductal carcinoma classified as NHG3, with a tumor size of 1.5 x 1.9 x 1.0 cm and a basal-like carcinoma morphology. Immunohistochemical analysis shows estrogen and progesterone receptors present in 10-75% of neoplastic cell nuclei, while HER2 testing indicates a negative reaction in invasive cancerous cells (Score = 1+). Additionally, chronic lymphadenitis and sinus histiocytosis were noted in the axillary lymph nodes, with no metastatic involvement detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of glioblastoma multiforme in excisional biopsies from unspecified brain sites, characterized by a highly cellular neoplastic proliferation with features of anaplasia, necrosis, and vascular proliferation. The MIB-1 labeling index was determined to be 11% in one specimen and 18-20% in another, reflecting a high mitotic activity consistent with the aggressive nature of the tumor. The findings suggest a recurrent or progressive glioblastoma multiforme in a male patient with a history of this malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the left lateral bladder wall, depth of tumor, and base of tumor specimens, with extensive necrosis and focal squamous differentiation noted in some areas. All specimens show local invasion into the muscularis propria, but no vascular invasion or in situ carcinoma is identified. The tumors are characterized by irregular tan-brown soft tissue fragments, with the left lateral wall measuring 15x0.5x0.2 cm, the depth of tumor measuring 13x0.5x0.4 cm, and the base of tumor measuring 12x0.5x0.5 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in situ in the right breast, with evidence of metastases in axillary lymph nodes. The tumor exhibits estrogen receptor positivity in over 75% of neoplastic cells and shows a HER2 score of 2+, with FISH verification recommended, although HER2 gene amplification was not found. Additional findings include foci of lobular carcinoma in situ and various benign breast lesions, with the tumor classified as NHG2, pT2, pN1a.

The pathology report indicates the presence of micrometastatic carcinoma in one of four sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla, while the second sentinel lymph node showed no tumor. In the left breast, two tumors were identified: a 1.4 cm invasive ductal carcinoma with mucinous features and signet ring cells, and a 0.7 cm invasive ductal carcinoma, both classified as SBR Grade 2. The tumors are multifocal, with negative margins in the lateral excision and the medial excision being 0.1 cm from the deep margin, and both tumors exhibit atypical ductal hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma from a primary tumor tissue sample taken from the right kidney. The tumor is classified as T1, N2, M0, with a cellular tumor percentage of 90%. There are no prior treatments or chemotherapy noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated nodular melanoma located in the skin of the trunk, measuring 1.8 cm in depth and classified as Clark's level IV. The tumor is ulcerated and pigmented, with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. Additional details regarding lymphatic invasion and satellite nodules were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of tubular and partially mucocellular adenocarcinoma of the cardia, with a tumor size of 4.6 x 4.3 x 0.9 cm and evidence of infiltration into the surrounding adipose tissue and esophageal wall. There are metastases present in lymph nodes (No VI/IX), and the excision margins are uncertain in some areas, although other margins are free of neoplastic lesions. Additionally, there are foci of gastric metaplasia with dysplastic features on the esophageal wall, which may have contributed to the cancer development.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic adenocarcinoma in Node 8 and poorly differentiated ductal carcinoma in the Whipple's specimen, with evidence of perineural and lymphatic invasion. The proximal bile duct margin shows inflammatory changes without neoplasia, while the periportal lymph node contains only fibroadipose tissue. Additionally, all five examined peripancreatic lymph nodes are involved with metastatic adenocarcinoma, and the tumor is classified as pT2, indicating it is limited to the pancreas and measures more than 2 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver, with a tumor size of 2.5 cm that is confined to the liver and shows no vascular invasion. The tumor is moderately differentiated (Grade II) and the surrounding liver tissue exhibits significant fibrosis, classified as ISHAK stage 4. Surgical margins are clear of invasive carcinoma, with the closest margin being 12 mm away from the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Type A/B Thymoma with a tumor diameter of 2.0 cm, classified as pT1 and Masaoka stage I. Immunohistochemical analysis shows that the epithelial cells are positive for CK5/6 and exhibit medium to strong membrane staining for EGFR, while being negative for several other markers. The Ki-67 proliferation index for the epithelial cells is 10-20%, while immature T-lymphocytes show a higher Ki-67 index of 60-80%.

The pathology report indicates a 9.5 x 4 x 1.2 cm exophytic adenocarcinoma of the stomach, which is poorly differentiated and extends to adjacent structures, specifically the lesser omentum. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/5 positive). Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion, as well as margins and neo-adjuvant treatment, were not specified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in both the rectum and cecum, with the rectal tumor measuring 2.4 cm and the cecal tumor measuring 5.8 cm, both having negative surgical margins. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in 14 of 43 lymph nodes from the rectal specimen and in 1 of 66 lymph nodes from the cecal specimen, with additional findings of multiple hyperplastic polyps and diverticula. Immunohistochemical analysis showed no abnormalities in mismatch repair protein expression for both tumors, and further testing for microsatellite instability has been ordered.

The pathology report indicates that all examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic lymphadenectomy show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma (0/16 and 0/13, respectively). A radical prostatectomy revealed invasive prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, involving both lobes of the prostate but confined within the capsule, with all surgical margins free of carcinoma. Additionally, multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) was identified, and perineural invasion was noted, with a final TNM stage of T2c N0 MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in a male patient, with a significant mass measuring 9.5 cm located in the right lobe of the liver, which was treated previously. The gallbladder was found to be unremarkable, and the margins of resection from the liver are reported to be free of tumor, with no evidence of vascular invasion or lymph node metastases. The liver is noted to be non-cirrhotic, and the tumor is classified as ypT1 NX MX.

The pathology report indicates that the left submandibular mass is infiltrated by diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, with involvement of fibrofatty connective tissue and lymph nodes, while mild chronic sialadenitis is also noted without any malignancy in the submandibular gland. The microscopic examination reveals poorly preserved tumor cells with pleomorphic nuclei and high proliferation index, confirming the diagnosis of lymphoma. Additionally, normal thymic tissue is present in the specimen, and immunostaining supports the diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a Leydig cell tumor in the left ovary, with no carcinoma identified in the associated structures. The uterus contains a well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma, measuring 2 x 1.8 x 1.1 cm, which is confined to the endometrium without myometrial invasion. Additionally, both left and right pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy, confirming the absence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of melanoma located on the skin of the left femur, classified as epithelial melanoma. The tumor is at Clark Level 4 with a Breslow thickness of 5 mm, measuring 4x5 mm in size, and is staged as II with no evidence of metastasis. The report notes that there is no normal tissue present in the sample, and the patient is undergoing neo-adjuvant immunotherapy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with invasion into the muscular wall and perivesical adipose tissue, as well as involvement of the prostatic urethra. Metastatic urothelial carcinoma was identified in several lymph nodes, specifically in the left pelvic and common lymph nodes, while other specimens, including the right distal ureter and right pelvic lymph nodes, were negative for neoplasm. The tumor is staged as pT4a due to invasion into the prostate and pN3 for metastasis in the common iliac lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of extensive bilateral prostate adenocarcinoma, with the index tumor located in the right peripheral zone and a Gleason score of 4+5=9, along with additional tumor foci in the left peripheral and transition zones. There is multifocal extraprostatic extension, including involvement of the seminal vesicles and positive pathological margins at the right apex and both bases. The pathological stage is classified as pT3b, and there is evidence of multifocal perineural and lymphovascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) from a biopsy of the left parietal lobe of the brain. Specimen A contains the bulk of the tumor, while Specimen B shows relatively normal neural tissue with infiltrating glioma cells. The report confirms that the case has been reviewed and interpreted by the responsible medical professionals.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in the right calf mass, measuring 4.1 x 3.1 x 2.0 cm, with tumor infiltration into skeletal muscle and deep subcutaneous tissue, and a mitotic rate of 20 per 10 high power fields. Surgical resection margins are reported as negative for malignancy, although the tumor is noted to be within 1 mm of the posterior margin. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, showing positivity for h-Caldesmon and focal positivity for HHF35, while being negative for SMA, desmin, S-100, HMB-45, and cytokeratin AE1/AE3.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a left frontal lobe brain tumor, specifically an anaplastic astrocytoma classified as WHO Grade III. Two specimens were analyzed, both confirming the presence of tumor cells, with one showing positive expression for the R132H mutant IDH1. Further molecular studies are planned to better characterize the tumor.

The pathology report indicates multiple biopsies revealing metastatic papillary carcinoma in several lymph nodes adjacent to the thyroid gland, including the right retroparotid and paratracheal regions, as well as the right superior thyroid pole. A hemithyroidectomy of the right superior thyroid pole confirmed the presence of papillary thyroid carcinoma, while the left thyroid lobe showed mild lymphocytic thyroiditis with no malignant tumor detected. Additionally, a left paratracheal mass exhibited sinus histiocytosis without evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the distal third of the esophagus, with infiltration into surrounding tissues. There are metastases identified in the surrounding tissues. The specimen was obtained through exploratory surgery, but specific details regarding tumor size, lymph nodes, and margins were not provided.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right breast lumpectomy and axillary dissection, revealing an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 1.9 cm with a modified SBR grade III, and a microscopic focus of metastatic carcinoma in the sentinel lymph node. Out of 14 axillary lymph nodes examined, one was positive for tumor with a 1 mm metastatic deposit, while the remaining nodes were free of tumor. The excisional biopsy margins were clear of tumor, and there was no evidence of blood vessel or lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in several lymph nodes, specifically noting that one out of two lymph nodes from the left level 10 and left level nine are positive for metastasis, along with the level seven lymph node. Additionally, a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the left lower lobe of the lung, measuring 3.8 x 1.8 x 1.6 cm, with vascular invasion present but no perineural invasion. Other lymph nodes examined were reported as benign, with a total of four lymph nodes showing no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma in a right kidney partial nephrectomy specimen weighing 14 grams, with a tumor size of 3.6 cm and a histologic grade of G2. The tumor is unifocal and limited to the kidney, with negative margins indicating no malignancy at the deep parenchymal margin, which is 1.0 cm from the tumor. There are no identified sarcomatoid features or angiolymphatic invasion, and the surgical pathology staging is classified as pT1a NX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma located in the right liver, characterized by a 10 cm whitish nodule at the resection margin. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positivity for CK7 and CK19, while CK20, CDX-2, and TTF1 are negative, supporting the diagnosis of intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma. Additionally, the liver tissue exhibits mild steatosis and fibrosis, and there is evidence of reactive lymphadenitis in the hepatic peduncle lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes a 9x7 cm section of the esophagus containing a 7 cm ulcerated squamous cell carcinoma, keratinizing type, classified as moderately differentiated (G-2) and extending to the adventitia (pT3). Examination of lymph nodes revealed no metastasis, with 0 out of 17 lymph nodes positive for cancer, and there was no evidence of venous invasion or involvement of surgical margins. Overall, the findings indicate a locally advanced esophageal cancer without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated mixed adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, classified as pT2 pNO R0, stage IB. The tumor exhibits a compact structure with predominantly tubulopapillary differentiation and a small bronchioloalveolar component at the margin, extending to but not infiltrating the pleura. Additionally, the carcinoma has invaded a peripheral bronchus, which is significantly distended and obstructed by a tumor plug.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the left breast, classified as Nottingham Grade II, with a tumor size of 2.3 cm and evidence of perineural invasion. Tumor cells were identified in the sentinel lymph node, while additional margins showed no residual tumor, although the tumor was present close to the lateral and posterior margins. Estrogen and progesterone receptors were positive, and HER2 was negative, with the overall pathologic stage classified as pT2 N0 (i+) Mx.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast wide local excision revealed a moderately differentiated invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 2.6 cm, with negative margins and the presence of lobular carcinoma in situ and focal atypical ductal hyperplasia. Both sentinel lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma, and additional breast tissue samples from the left and right breasts showed no evidence of malignancy, although some areas exhibited benign changes such as columnar cell change and usual ductal hyperplasia. The immunohistochemistry results support lobular differentiation, with the tumor being ER positive, PR positive, and HER2 negative.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary carcinoma in four out of twenty-two lymph nodes from a lateral neck dissection, with the largest node measuring 1.4 cm and no extranodal extension identified. A total thyroidectomy revealed a multifocal tall cell variant of papillary carcinoma in the right lobe, with the largest tumor measuring 2.5 cm and additional papillary microcarcinomas present, along with metastatic carcinoma found in 19 of 40 lymph nodes. The primary tumor is classified as pT3 with minimal extrathyroidal extension, and margins are uninvaded, although there is evidence of venous and lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of adenocarcinoma in the prostate, with a Gleason score of 8 (4+4) and evidence of extracapsular extension and invasion of the right seminal vesicle, while surgical margins are free of tumor. No metastatic disease was found in the examined lymph nodes, which were all reported as benign. Additional findings include perineural invasion and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, with a multicentric pattern of invasive carcinoma noted.

The pathology report indicates that the right parotid duct is negative for malignancy, while the right buccal resection reveals moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with a maximum dimension of 2.5 cm and perineural invasion present, but no lymphovascular invasion. All surgical margins, including the anterior, superior, inferior, and deep margins, are negative for malignancy, and a total of 23 lymph nodes examined from the right neck are also negative for malignancy. The overall pathologic staging is pT2, indicating a tumor size greater than 2 cm but not more than 4 cm, with no regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the cecum, with a tumor size of 8 cm by 6 cm and evidence of extensive tumor budding and lymphovascular invasion. Metastatic disease was identified in one of two lymph nodes examined from the base of the superior mesenteric artery, while the middle colic lymph node was benign. The tumor staging is classified as pT3, indicating invasion into pericolorectal tissues, with a lymph node stage of N2b due to metastasis in seven or more regional lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, tall cell variant, in the right thyroid lobe and isthmus, with a tumor size of 1.4 cm and no identified mitotic activity or necrosis. The tumor shows no blood vessel invasion or definite extrathyroidal extension, and the surgical margins are free of tumor, although microscopic foci of papillary microcarcinoma are present. Additionally, the non-neoplastic thyroid exhibits nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type, located in the cecum/ascending colon, measuring up to 7.5 cm, with circumscribed penetration of the serosa. All examined regional lymph nodes, as well as small and large intestinal resection margins, mesenteric resection margin, and omental fat tissue, are tumor-free, confirming no metastasis. The final tumor stage is classified as pT4 pN0 (0/21) pMX; G3; L1, V0, locally R0.

The pathology report indicates multiple specimens from various sites, all diagnosed with metastatic papillary serous adenocarcinoma, including significant metastatic foci in the right colon, transverse colon, cecum, mesenteric small bowel, and bladder. Additionally, both left and right adnexal specimens show moderately to poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma, with the left adnexa exhibiting no residual ovarian tissue and the right adnexa showing residual tissue with lymphovascular invasion. The uterus and cervix also demonstrate metastatic involvement, highlighting the extensive spread of the disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal invasive lobular carcinoma of the right breast, with a tumor size of 1.7 x 1.2 x 1.5 cm. Additionally, there are metastases present in the axillary lymph nodes, classified as NO IV/X. The histopathological findings show characteristics of classical lobular carcinoma with no mitotic activity observed.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the cervix revealed invasive squamous cell carcinoma, specifically the large cell keratinizing type, which is classified as moderately to poorly differentiated. The specimen measured 1.3 x 1 x 0.3 cm and was submitted entirely in one cassette for examination. The clinical history and coding information are also provided, indicating the diagnosis of cervical cancer.
