The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated intestinal type gastric adenocarcinoma located in the cardia/corpus area, characterized by extensive ulceration and infiltration into the perimuscular soft tissue. There are 17 regional lymph node metastases identified, with a tumor-free esophageal resection margin and a tumor-free duodenal resection margin. The tumor stage is classified as pT2b pN3 (17/31) pMX.
The pathology report indicates a unifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma located on the left side, with a tumor size measuring 2.5 x 3 cm. The extent of the tumor is not specified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated ovarian adenocarcinoma in the right ovary, with metastatic adenocarcinoma identified in soft tissue biopsies from the cul-de-sac, sigmoid, and diaphragm. The report also notes benign paratubal cysts in both fallopian tubes and no evidence of malignancy in multiple lymph nodes examined. Additionally, there are findings of acute and chronic inflammation in the uterus and other soft tissue samples, with a final staging classification of AJCC IIIA due to microscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma with lobular features in the right breast, characterized as moderately differentiated (Nottingham Grade 2) with a tumor size of 2.5 cm and extensive involvement of the surgical margin. Both sentinel lymph nodes examined showed no metastatic deposits, and additional breast tissue from the inferior flap exhibited no significant pathologic changes. The tumors are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER-2 is negative, and the report notes the presence of multicentricity.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach located in the antrum, measuring 4 x 0 x 6 cm, with invasion into the perigastric fat and subserosa. Out of 15 examined lymph nodes, 10 showed metastases, and there is evidence of lymphatic invasion, while venous invasion is absent. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there are no specified comments regarding neo-adjuvant treatment or additional findings.

The pathology report indicates a subtotal gastrectomy specimen with a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma tumor measuring 5x3x1.5 cm, which has extended to adjacent structures, specifically the lesser omentum. Out of three examined lymph nodes, one shows positive for metastasis. There are no specified details regarding lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion, and margins or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment are also not provided.

The pathology report indicates a resected colon and rectal sample containing an ulcerated, moderately differentiated (G2) adenocarcinoma. The tumor has infiltrated the perimuscular fatty tissue but shows no evidence of local lymph node metastases. The resection margins are tumor-free, classified as pT3 pNO 0/21 LO V0, R0.

The pathology report confirms the presence of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.2 cm in the left retromolar trigone and tonsil. Among the lymph nodes dissected, one out of seven in level II showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while the lymph nodes in levels I, III, and IV were negative for malignancy. The intraoperative margins from the other sites excised were negative for carcinoma, indicating no residual cancer in those areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a biopsy of the supraglottic larynx. The specimen measured 1.0 x 1.0 x 0.3 cm and was described as pink-tan tissue. The report was reviewed by an attending pathologist, confirming the findings.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, involving both lobes of the prostate and measuring a maximum diameter of 1.4 cm. The cancer is organ-confined with no evidence of extraprostatic extension, and all examined surgical margins and lymph nodes are free of carcinoma. Additionally, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and perineural invasion are noted, with a pathologic TNM stage of pT2c, pNO, and pMX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a mixed malignant Mllerian tumor in the uterus, associated with an endometrial polyp, but without myometrial or lymphatic vascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes and other structures, including the cervix, ovaries, and fallopian tubes, show no evidence of tumor. Additional molecular studies confirm the tumor is microsatellite stable with intact expression of mismatch repair proteins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma testis (pT2 NXMX) in the right testicle, characterized by a tumor measuring 7 x 5.5 x 4.5 cm with associated hemorrhaging and necrotic areas. Histological examination reveals solid clusters of tumor cells with distinct nuclei and abundant cytoplasm, along with lymphocyte clusters and occasional sinciciotrophoblast cells, while showing up to 5 mitotic figures per high-power field. The tumor infiltrates the tunica albuginea and vascular areas but does not invade the rete testis, epididymis, or funiculus.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic renal cell carcinoma, with involvement in 3 out of 50 examined lymph nodes, and a left kidney tumor identified as chromophobe renal cell carcinoma with a significant sarcomatoid component. The tumor measures 20 cm and shows extensive vascular invasion and extension into perinephric tissues, but the vascular and ureteral margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, chronic interstitial nephritis is noted in the nonneoplastic kidney tissue, with no other tumors detected.

The pathology report indicates a combined nevus (intradermal and blue nevus) on the upper back, and a nodular ulcerative basal cell carcinoma on the scalp with negative margins, although it is close to the right inferior margin. Additionally, two lymph nodes from the left posterior triangle are negative for malignancy, while a sentinel lymph node excision revealed benign fibroadipose tissue. A wide excision of malignant melanoma on the scalp shows a thickness of 7 mm, classified as Clark's level IV, with free margins and no lymphovascular or perineural invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates that multiple specimens from the right frontal lobe were analyzed, all diagnosed as oligodendroglioma, WHO Grade II. The tumors are diffusely infiltrating gliomas without enhancement on MRI, and molecular testing for 1p/19q status has been ordered. Intraoperative consultations confirmed the presence of glioma with no overtly high-grade features identified.

The pathology report indicates a right lower lobectomy revealing a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 75 mm, with characteristics of non-mucinous bronchioloalveolar carcinoma and adjacent satellite nodules. The tumor reaches the pleura but does not invade it, and there is no evidence of vascular, lymphatic, or perineural infiltration, with clear resection margins. Additionally, the hilar lymph nodes show no signs of metastatic adenocarcinoma, leading to a pathological stage of T4 N0.

The pathology report indicates that no metastatic carcinoma was found in the ten excised right pelvic lymph nodes (0/10). The radical prostatectomy revealed prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6/10, occupying approximately 30% of the right side of the prostate, but without extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle involvement. Additionally, there is suspicious lymphovascular space invasion and perineural invasion present, but surgical margins are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multicentric invasive lobular carcinoma, classical type, measuring 5.5 cm, with lobular carcinoma in situ also identified. The invasive carcinoma involves the nipple and extends to the cauterized anterior flap margin, with perineural invasion present but no vascular invasion noted. Lymph node examination shows no positive nodes in levels I and II, and the tumor is classified as stage T3, PNO (I+), MX, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptor staining and negative HER2 status.

The left upper lobectomy reveals a moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma that is both in situ and invasive, with angiolymphatic invasion but no visceral pleural invasion, and involvement of one out of twenty lymph nodes examined. The pathology stage is classified as T1 N1 MX, with all surgical margins free of cancer. Additional biopsies of various lymph nodes show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, except for one lymph node that contained metastatic squamous cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in multiple specimens, including lymph nodes from the right level 2B and right facial node, as well as in the right composite resection involving the mandible and adjacent soft tissue. The posterior soft tissue margin of the composite resection is positive for invasive carcinoma, while other margins and lymph nodes were either benign or uninvolved by carcinoma. The tumor is classified as moderately differentiated (G2) and is staged as pT3 with significant lymph node involvement (pN2b).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma (FIGO Grade 3) confined to the endometrium, arising from an endometrial polyp, with no myometrial invasion or cervical involvement. All examined lymph nodes (left pelvic, right pelvic, left para-aortic, right para-aortic) and the omentum showed no evidence of carcinoma, confirming negative results for metastatic disease. The tumor size was noted to be 3.5 cm, and the overall stage is classified as Stage IA.

The pathology report indicates that the right neck dissection levels IA, IB, II, and III, as well as various margins, showed no tumor presence in the lymph nodes and surrounding tissues, except for the posterior gingiva which revealed invasive squamous carcinoma. The right segmental mandibulectomy and floor of mouth resection confirmed the presence of poorly differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma measuring 3.0 cm, with invasion into the bone. Additionally, both anterior and posterior bone margins were reported negative for tumor following decalcification.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast of a female patient, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2, N0, and M0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered to date, and a normal blood sample was also collected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3), showing extensive extraprostatic extension and involvement of the left anterior and posterior quadrants. The tumor was found in four consecutive sections with a maximum diameter of 1.6 cm, and while the proximal basal margin was focally positive for tumor, all other surgical margins and lymph nodes were negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, focal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) and nodular hyperplasia were noted, with no tumor present in the seminal vesicles or posterior bladder neck margin.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from the left temporal lobe mass is diagnosed as Glioblastoma multiforme, classified as an Astrocytoma WHO grade IV. Microscopic examination reveals a malignant astrocytic neoplasm with a sheet-like growth pattern, hyperchromatic nuclei, and significant mitotic activity, along with areas of necrosis and neovascular proliferation. The tumor measures 2.5 x 1.5 x 0.4 cm and is entirely submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates that two pelvic lymph nodes were biopsied and found to be benign with no evidence of metastatic tumor. The radical prostatectomy revealed adenocarcinoma in both lobes of the prostate, with a Gleason score of 6/10, no extraprostatic extension, and all surgical margins free of carcinoma. Additionally, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) and benign prostatic hyperplasia were noted, with the overall pTNM stage classified as T2c NO Mx.

The pathology report indicates that both sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla are negative for tumor involvement. A wide excision of the right breast revealed a poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm, with clear margins and no lymphovascular invasion, alongside ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with lobular extension. Additionally, a right breast cyst was identified as a ruptured apocrine retention cyst, and hormone receptor status for the invasive carcinoma is pending.

The pathology report indicates that the excision biopsy of the brain tumor is diagnosed as a high-grade glioma consistent with glioblastoma (WHO grade IV). The tumor exhibits significant mitotic activity and extensive necrosis, with immunostaining showing GFAP positivity and a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 20 percent. The frozen section diagnosis was confirmed on permanent sections, and appropriate immunoreactivity was validated through positive and negative controls.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma with hybrid oncocytic and focal papillary features in the right kidney, following a partial nephrectomy, with the tumor measuring 4.5 cm and confined to the kidney. Surgical margins are free of malignancy, and the pathologic stage is classified as pT1b NX MX. Immunohistochemical tests support the diagnosis, and there are no signs of sarcomatoid features, perineural invasion, or lymphovascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in the right thigh's adductor compartment, with tumor necrosis and cystic hemorrhagic changes comprising 10-20% of the mass. The tumor measures 9.2 x 7.5 x 6.3 cm and is located 0.15 cm from the deep surgical margin, which is considered close but free of tumor. Overall, the surgical margins are clear of tumor involvement, suggesting a potentially favorable outcome following the radical resection.

The pathology report indicates a total laryngectomy specimen with a moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 6.2 x 5.1 x 5.8 cm, involving the supraglottic, glottic, and subglottic regions, as well as the true and false vocal cords bilaterally. The tumor shows invasion into the thyroid and cricoid cartilages, with positive margins at the left tracheal and anterior margins, while other margins are negative for tumor. Lymphovascular invasion is identified, and representative sections have been submitted for further studies.

The pathology report indicates that high-grade urothelial carcinoma with mixed transitional cell and adenocarcinoma types was identified in the urinary bladder, with deep invasion into the muscularis propria but no extension into adjacent fat. One of eleven left pelvic lymph nodes showed metastatic carcinoma, while all other margins and lymph nodes examined were free of tumor. Additionally, there was a small focus of carcinoma in situ in the urinary outflow tract and benign prostatic tissue was noted in the distal prostatic urethra.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes from both right and left modified neck dissections, with extracasular extension identified in one lymph node on the left side. A total thyroidectomy revealed bilateral papillary thyroid carcinoma with extra-thyroidal extension and lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, metastatic disease was found in seven of twelve lymph nodes from a bilateral paratracheal and upper mediastinal dissection, with extracasular extension present in some nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (G3) in a 6.4 cm tumor located in the right upper lobe, with direct invasion into the right lower lobe, chest wall, and rib. All surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, with a distance of 3.2 cm to the nearest margin, and all evaluated lymph nodes (8 in total) are benign. The tumor is staged as pT3 with no lymph node involvement (pNO).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, located in the left lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 1.2 cm and well-differentiated histologic grade. There is focal capsular invasion, but no evidence of mitotic activity, tumor necrosis, blood vessel invasion, or extrathyroid extension, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the non-neoplastic thyroid shows nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, with four benign lymph nodes identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically the papillary type (Type II), with a tumor size of 4.7 cm that extends through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of renal vein invasion; however, focal glomerulosclerosis and vascular changes consistent with hypertension are noted in the non-neoplastic kidney. A portion of benign congested spleen adherent to the kidney is present, but it is not involved by the tumor, and lymph nodes are not identified.

The pathology report indicates that the left adrenal gland contains a 17 cm adrenocortical carcinoma, which is characterized by a soft, semi-solid mass with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage, but shows no vascular invasion and has free margins. The spleen, omentum, perirenal lymph node, and retroperitoneal fat were all reported as having no significant abnormalities or neoplasms. The left kidney is unremarkable, and the perirenal lymph node was negative for neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a tumor size of 2.6x2.5x0.98 cm. There is evidence of lymphatic and venous invasion, and one out of six pelvic lymph nodes shows metastasis, while surgical margins are uninvolved. No information is provided regarding neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates the presence of focal residual adenocarcinoma in-situ of the endometrium, along with adenomatous hyperplasia and squamous metaplasia of the cervix. In the liver, a single hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 14 cm was identified, with vascular invasion but free margins, and the background liver showed signs of cirrhosis and steatohepatitis. Additionally, the excised lymph nodes were negative for neoplasm, and tubo-ovarian adhesions and follicular cysts were noted in the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates that the left adrenal gland excision revealed a low-grade adrenal cortical carcinoma measuring 7.8 cm and weighing 171 grams, with margins free of malignancy. Additionally, a separate excision of a lipoma from the back was noted. Microscopic examination confirmed the presence of eosinophilic cells with nuclear atypia and necrosis, typical of carcinoma, while the tumor was encapsulated with some vascular invasion observed.

The pathology report indicates a gastric resection specimen with an 11 x 9 x 2 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma that is poorly differentiated and extends to adjacent structures, specifically the greater omentum. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/3 positive). Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion, as well as margins and neo-adjuvant treatment, were not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with a tumor diameter of 2.5 cm and discrete intraductal components. There is no evidence of skin infiltration, and the carcinoma has been completely excised based on the tumor-free medial follow-up resection material. The tumor classification is noted as NOS, G III, pT2NOLOVORO according to the 6th edition criteria from 2003.

The pathology report indicates that the right colon and terminal ileum specimen reveals invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cecum, which has penetrated the serosal surface and shows significant lymphatic invasion, with metastasis found in 5 of 18 regional lymph nodes. The left inguinal hernia sac contains benign fibromembranous tissue with no evidence of malignancy, and the omentum is composed of benign fatty tissue without any metastatic tumor. Additionally, five adenomatous polyps were identified in the colon, with one showing intracolonic metastasis 7 cm distal to the primary tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the excised left ileal mass is diagnosed as diffuse large B-cell lymphoma of the anaplastic type, characterized by large, pleomorphic cells, a high mitotic rate, and significant necrosis. Immunohistochemical studies confirm a B-cell phenotype, with negative ALK staining. The patient is a female with a history of a left hemipelvis lesion, and the findings suggest a malignant non-small cell neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal, acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate, with cancerous foci present on both sides of the organ and infiltration into the periprostatic tissue. The tumor volume is approximately 7 cm, but the outer areas of the resected material are free of tumor, and follow-up resection of pelvic lymph nodes and seminal vesicles also shows no evidence of cancer. The tumor is staged as pT3a pNO with a Gleason score of 4+5.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade III endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with a tumor size of 6 cm and classified as T1c. There were no lymph nodes sampled, but 20 nodes were positive for cancer, while the clinical M status is M0, indicating no distant metastasis. The sample was collected from the uterus following a surgical resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an infiltrating glioma, specifically an anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III/IV), characterized by moderate nuclear atypia and a proliferation index of 23%. Multiple biopsies reveal astrocytoma with atypical features and extensive infiltration of glial cells throughout the brain tissue. The findings suggest a high-grade astrocytoma with focal areas of anaplastic transformation, but without definitive microvascular proliferation or necrosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, involving both the right and left lobes of the prostate, but confined within the organ and with no evidence of extraprostatic extension. The radical prostatectomy revealed that less than 5% of the examined prostate volume was involved by carcinoma, and all surgical margins and lymph nodes examined were free of neoplasia. The final diagnosis includes high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, with a pathologic TNM stage of pT2c, pNO, and pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 4 cm, with mixed histological patterns including micropapillary, acinar, and lepidic. Metastatic carcinoma is present in the right level 11 and level 7 lymph nodes, while the right level 4 lymph node shows no evidence of carcinoma. Molecular studies reveal a wild-type KRAS gene and a positive E746 A750del5 mutation in the EGFR gene, suggesting potential responsiveness to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapies.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma, WHO grade IV, from a biopsy and resection of a right frontal lobe brain tumor, characterized by high cellularity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis with pseudopalisading. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive p53 expression and MGMT positivity in 30% of the tumor, while FISH analysis revealed negative 1p/19q codeletion and positive polysomy for chromosomes 1, 7, and 19, along with monosomy for chromosome 10. The tumor exhibits weak positive staining for chromogranin and synaptophysin, suggesting foci of neural differentiation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in one of the sentinel lymph nodes, while the second sentinel node shows no malignancy. The right breast specimen reveals an invasive tubulolobular carcinoma with a low nuclear grade and clear resection margins, measuring 1 cm in the greatest dimension. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, and negative for Her2, with a Nottingham histologic score of Grade I.

The pathology report indicates that there is no tumor present in the left and right ureter margins, and both left and right pelvic lymph nodes show three benign nodes with no evidence of metastatic neoplasm. However, an invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma measuring 1.6 cm was identified in the urinary bladder, deeply invading the muscularis propria but with negative lymphovascular invasion and a negative perivesical soft tissue margin. The report also notes benign prostatic tissue and a negative incidental appendix, with additional tissue from the urethral margin pending microscopic evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma in the right ovary, with metastatic involvement observed in the left ovary, fallopian tubes, omentum, and right parametrium. The uterus shows chronic inflammation, an inactive endometrial pattern, and leiomyoma, but no malignancy was found in the examined lymph nodes. The overall staging is classified as T3c/NO/MX, indicating significant peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis.

The pathology report indicates extensive metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the omentum, right ovary, left ovary, and mesenteric nodules, with tumor sizes ranging from 2.4 cm to 3.5 cm. Additionally, an adenocarcinoid tumor was identified at the tip of the appendix, which is distinct from the metastatic carcinoma. The findings suggest a primary ovarian adenocarcinoma, likely of serous type, with positive immunohistochemical markers consistent with this diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma, with the largest focus measuring 1.5 cm and exhibiting angiolymphatic invasion and microscopic extrathyroidal extension. Molecular testing identified a BRAF mutation, while no mutations in NRAS, HRAS, KRAS, or RET/PTC rearrangements were found. Additionally, a Hrthle cell adenoma and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis were noted, with one lymph node examined showing no tumor involvement.

The autopsy report describes a middle-aged, moderately obese Caucasian female with notable findings including adrenal cortical carcinoma in the right adrenal gland with metastasis to the liver, and acute bronchopneumonia in the right lung. Additional observations include mild atherosclerosis in the aorta, cardiomegaly, and benign breast tissue with a complex sclerosing lesion. The report also notes the presence of adhesions in the bowel and a history of surgical procedures, including a hysterectomy and placement of a medication port.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral ovarian serous carcinoma, Grade III, with tumor involvement in the omentum, large bowel wall, and one mesenteric lymph node. The left ovary shows a multinodular tumor with serosal involvement, while the right ovary also contains serous carcinoma with associated cysts. Additionally, there are tumor deposits on the serosal surface of the bowel, indicating invasive disease.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon, measuring 2.5 cm, with infiltration into the pericolic fatty tissue and two regional lymph node metastases. The tumor-free resection margins suggest complete removal of the primary tumor. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN1 (2/13) pM1, indicating advanced disease with clinically evident liver metastases.

The pathology report describes a mildly hypercellular white matter with atypical cells and no mitotic figures, indicating a glial neoplasm. The tumor exhibits modest cellularity, a dense fibrillary stroma, and shows diffuse immunoreactivity for GFAP, confirming its astrocytic nature. The findings are consistent with a diagnosis of well-differentiated astrocytoma, grade II, characterized by low-grade and infiltrative features.

The corrected pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma with focal clear cell differentiation, which has invaded the posterior retroperitoneal soft tissue, while margins from the common bile duct, duodenum, stomach, and superior mesenteric artery are free of carcinoma. Metastatic carcinoma is present in 2 out of 25 examined lymph nodes, and additional findings include chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis. The pancreatic margin resection is negative for carcinoma and intraepithelial neoplasia, confirming no prior treatment was administered.

The pathology report indicates that a right upper lobectomy was performed, revealing a well to moderately differentiated mucin-secreting adenocarcinoma measuring 40 mm, with pleural invasion but no evidence of vascular, lymphatic, or perineural invasion. The bronchial resection margins are clear of malignancy, and the sampled lymph nodes show no signs of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The pathological stage is classified as T2 N0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 4 adenocarcinoma in the right middle and lower lobes of the lung, characterized by a well-circumscribed subpleural mass with angiolymphatic invasion but no visceral pleural invasion. Metastatic adenocarcinoma is present in multiple intrapulmonary and mediastinal lymph nodes, with extranodal extension noted through the major fissure. The bronchial margin is negative for tumor, and no tumor is identified in several other lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of primary endometrial adenocarcinoma, specifically endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation, classified as FIGO grade 1, with myometrial invasion limited to the inner half. There is no evidence of serosal, cervical, or adnexal involvement, although focal lymphovascular space invasion is present. Additional findings include benign simple cysts in both ovaries and chronic salpingitis in the right fallopian tube, with estrogen and progesterone receptors being negative.

The pathology report indicates a right radical mastectomy specimen with a lobular carcinoma measuring 5.2 cm, and all 22 examined axillary lymph nodes show positive metastasis. The report does not provide specific details on tumor grade, margins, or Nottingham histologic score. There is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment mentioned, and additional pathologic findings are not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the gastric cardia shows mild inactive chronic gastritis without intestinal metaplasia or Helicobacter pylori, and no tumors were identified. In the distal esophagus, there are fragments of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, but the depth of invasion is indeterminate, along with evidence of active chronic inflammation at the squamocolumnar junction. Additionally, HER-2/neu testing revealed no amplification of the HER-2/neu gene in the tumor cells, with a signal ratio of 1.36, indicating normal levels.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the urinary bladder, which has invaded the muscularis propria, perivesicular fat, and vaginal wall, along with carcinoma in situ in the bladder dome and posterior wall. All examined lymph nodes (16 total) and surgical margins from the ureters are free of tumor, suggesting no lymphatic spread. The tumor is classified as pT4a, N0, MX, indicating advanced local invasion without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Type A/B Thymoma, measuring 16.0 x 10.0 x 9.0 cm, with focal invasion through the capsule into surrounding fat tissue. The tumor is classified as pT2, pNx, pMx, and is categorized as Masaoka stage II.2. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive staining for CK5/6 and medium membrane staining for EGFR in epithelial cells, while immature T-lymphocytes are positive for CD1a and CD99, and B-lymphocytes show sparse positivity for CD20.

The pathology report indicates the presence of anaplastic astrocytoma, classified as WHO grade III, in both the left frontal mass and the left temporal cortex of the brain. The tumors exhibit fibrillary and gemistocytic characteristics. Preliminary frozen section consultations suggest the presence of glioma, with further classification and grading pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a left frontal oligoastrocytoma, classified as WHO Grade 3, with oligodendroglial dominance. Notable features include conspicuous nodularity and satellitosis, and previous 1p19q FISH studies show a deletion. The tumor measures 4.0 x 3.2 x 1.8 cm and was obtained from a left frontal craniotomy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, characterized by a centrally located mass measuring 4.5 x 3.2 x 3.2 cm, with uninvolved pleura and negative margins at the proximal tracheal and distal bronchial sites. Additionally, 3 out of 8 examined intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma, while lymph nodes from the superior mediastinal, inferior mediastinal, aortic, and left lower lobe bronchus are negative for tumor involvement. The distal lung segments exhibit post-obstructive organizing pneumonia, but the left lower lobe lung margin is also negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast lumpectomy revealed intermediate grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) measuring 2 mm, along with intraductal papilloma and fibrocystic changes, with the closest margin being less than 1 mm. The left breast lumpectomy specimens showed multifocal invasive lobular carcinoma, with the largest focus measuring at least 2.3 cm, and all examined sentinel lymph nodes were negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings included intraductal papillomas, florid ductal hyperplasia, and fibrocystic changes, with no atypical ductal lesions or lymphovascular invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a female with a history of invasive lobular carcinoma, underwent a left breast lumpectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsies. The final diagnosis reveals invasive lobular carcinoma in the lumpectomy specimen, with a size of 1.5 cm, and no evidence of malignancy in any of the four sentinel lymph nodes examined. Additionally, lobular carcinoma in-situ and atypical lobular hyperplasia were noted, with the tumor being classified as moderately differentiated and having a Nottingham histologic score of 6/9.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in situ in the right breast, with a tumor size of 2.1 x 1 x 1.5 cm. Immunohistochemical analysis shows over 75% positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 testing reveals a negative reaction in invasive carcinoma cells. Additionally, metastases were found in axillary lymph nodes, confirming the presence of cancer spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligoastrocytoma, WHO grade II, characterized by a mildly hypercellular glial neoplasm with some atypical hyperchromatic cells and perineuronal satellitosis, but without necrosis or microvascular proliferation. The MIB-1 labeling index is noted to be up to 5.1%, which is relatively high for a low-grade oligodendroglioma, raising concerns for potential recurrence or anaplastic progression. Close follow-up is recommended due to the elevated MIB-1 index despite the absence of significant anaplastic features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with invasion exceeding half of the muscle layer and involvement of the endocervix, measuring 2x3 cm. There is no evidence of venous invasion, and all examined lymph nodes (21 total) are negative for metastasis. Additional findings include a glandular-cystic endometrial polyp and fibrous bodies in both ovaries, with the fallopian tubes appearing normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a predominant Gleason grade of 7 (3+4) and a component of grade 8 (4+4), affecting 60% of the left lobe and 25% of the right lobe, with perineural invasion present but no extracapsular or seminal vesicle invasion. All examined lymph nodes (65 total) showed no evidence of tumor involvement, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. The tumor approaches the left surgical margin anteriorly, classified as pT2c for bilateral disease, with no distant metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenalectomy was performed on a tumor weighing 198g and measuring 8.5 x 7.5 x 6 cm, which contains oxyphilic cells and has a Weiss score of 5, consistent with carcinoma. The tumor is classified as having malignancy potential, but there are no lymph node metastases identified (0/30). Additionally, a hyperplastic nodule was noted on segment V of the liver, with no changes in the histology of the gallbladder following a previous cholecystectomy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma following a total thyroidectomy, with a tumor size of 2.3 cm located in the left lobe and showing multifocality. The tumor exhibits a papillary growth pattern, with negative surgical margins that are close to the tumor, and there is evidence of metastatic disease in the lymph nodes, with 5 out of 10 nodes affected. The AJCC staging is pT2 pNla pMx, indicating the extent of the disease and the presence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy and resection of brain tissue revealed an oligodendroglioma, with part of the tumor showing focal anaplastic transformation classified as WHO grade III. Immunohistochemical analysis demonstrated a proliferation index of 8% to 10% in the more active areas, supporting the diagnosis of high histological grade oligodendroglioma. The tumor exhibits characteristics of a glial neoplastic proliferation with no atypical features in one part, while the other part shows brisk mitotic activity and focal necrosis.

The pathology report indicates that both the right and left distal ureters are segments of benign ureter with no carcinoma detected. However, the radical cystoprostatectomy revealed invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma extensively involving the bladder wall and extending into the prostatic urethra, with metastasis found in three pelvic lymph nodes. The tumor is staged as pT3b N2 MX, indicating significant local invasion and regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative urothelial cell carcinoma of the bladder, classified as high malignant potential and moderately/poorly differentiated (G2/G3), with extensive invasion into the bladder wall, prostate, and perivesical fat, categorized as stage IV (stpT4). Metastatic involvement is noted in multiple lymph nodes, with three out of fourteen nodes showing metastasis of the urothelial carcinoma. The tumor exhibits areas of neuroendocrine differentiation and presents with ulceration and necrosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, specifically chromophobe type, measuring 18 cm with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of II-III, and extensive involvement of the renal parenchyma, though margins for the renal vein, ureter, and perinephric fat are negative for tumor. There is no definitive lymphovascular invasion identified, and the tumor exhibits characteristic cytological features along with focal pseudo-papillary architecture and numerous calcifications. Additionally, minimal chronic changes are noted in the non-neoplastic kidney, with mild glomerulosclerosis and tubular atrophy affecting less than 5% of the cortical parenchyma.

The pathology report describes a right adrenal tumor measuring 60x50x38 mm, identified as a pheochromocytoma, characterized by solid growth of large polygonal cells with focal hemorrhages and remnants of adrenal cortex. Histological examination revealed no invasion beyond the capsule, minimal proliferation activity, and some areas of necrosis, while immunohistochemical staining confirmed the presence of sustentacular cells. Overall, the findings indicate a benign pheochromocytoma with no evidence of malignancy or invasive characteristics.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly to moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right supraglottic region of the larynx, with deep invasion and extensive perineural and vascular invasion. Additionally, metastatic squamous carcinoma is identified in four lymph nodes with extranodal extension, and atypical cells suspicious for squamous cell carcinoma are noted at the lateral margin. However, the base of the tongue and lateral oropharynx on the right side show squamous mucosa negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a lumpectomy specimen from the right upper inner quadrant of the breast, revealing a grossly evident infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 1.5 x 0 x 2 cm, which is poorly differentiated. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/10 positive), and the surgical margins are uninvolved. The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic counts.

The pathology report indicates a final diagnosis of a thymoma (type A) measuring 1.6 cm, which was completely excised from a mediastinal mass. Additionally, a right upper lobe lobectomy revealed a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 8.3 cm, with all surgical margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma and no lymphovascular invasion present. Multiple lymph nodes examined from various stations showed no evidence of malignancy, confirming the absence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates the presence of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segments V and VI, characterized by a subcapsular nodule with negative surgical margins. The background liver is noted to be noncirrhotic, and cytochemical stains reveal a loss of normal reticulin architecture within the tumor. Additionally, the gallbladder shows signs of acute and chronic cholecystitis with multiple gallstones, one of which is located near a stricture in the cystic duct.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with a tumor size of 3.7 and 3.9 cm and a maximum depth of myometrial invasion estimated at 0.1-0.3 cm due to extensive adenomyosis. Both left and right pelvic lymph nodes were examined, with a total of 28 nodes found to be negative for malignancy. The cervix, serosa, and both ovaries were free of tumor, and the specimen margins were not involved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell type), with Fuhrman's nuclear grade 2, measuring 3.9 cm and confined to the right kidney. The tumor shows no invasion into surrounding tissues, and the vascular, ureteral, and soft tissue margins of resection are free of tumor. Additionally, there are incidental findings of a renal cortical adenoma and a renomedullary interstitial cell tumor, both of which are small in size.

The pathology report indicates that the right neurovascular margin is negative for carcinoma or prostatic glands, showing only fibromuscular tissue and nerve. The prostate and seminal vesicles reveal adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), involving 20-30% of the tissue, but without extraprostatic extension or tumor in the surgical margins. The bilateral lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma, with no evidence of cancer in the four examined nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the maxillary bone and attached soft tissue, measuring 4.5 cm, with carcinoma present at the deep soft tissue margin and no evidence of bone invasion. Additionally, two out of 24 lymph nodes from the right neck dissection show metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while other lymph nodes and margins examined show no evidence of carcinoma or dysplasia. The minimum pathologic stage is classified as pT3 N2 MX according to the AJCC 6th edition.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous endometrial adenocarcinoma measuring 3 x 3 cm, with significant myometrial invasion and extensive lymphovascular invasion, classified as pT3a N2 (FIGO stage IIIC2). Additionally, multiple lymph nodes, including those in the left pelvic and peri-aortic regions, show metastatic carcinoma involvement. The omentum specimens reveal micro-adhesions and focal mesothelial hyperplasia, with rare free-floating tumor cells noted in one sample.

The pathology report indicates that the right partial glossectomy and partial pharyngectomy specimen revealed two foci of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with a maximum depth of invasion of 0.7 cm, and the tumor is present at the buccal margin. All examined lymph nodes (74 in total) were negative for tumor, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. Additionally, mild to moderate dysplasia was noted at the anterior lateral tongue margin, but no invasive carcinoma was identified in the other excised tissues.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in one of the sentinel lymph nodes, with a tumoral deposit measuring 1mm, while the other two sentinel nodes are negative for carcinoma. The right breast mass is diagnosed as poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma, measuring 2.0 cm, with negative surgical margins and evidence of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present in five out of 15 slides examined. The tumor is classified as pT1c pN1mi, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, and a HER2 score of 3+.

The pathology report indicates a lumpectomy of the left upper inner quadrant revealing a 1.3 x 0 x 1.5 cm infiltrating ductal carcinoma, which is moderately differentiated. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/10 positive), and the surgical margins are uninvolved. The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic counts.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 1, with myometrial invasion of 1.5 cm, but no cervical or ovarian involvement. Immunohistochemical studies for p16 and p53 were not reactive, supporting the diagnosis of papilloma, and all examined lymph nodes showed no metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings include leiomyomata, chronic cervicitis, and a bladder lesion consistent with cystitis cystica-like inverted papilloma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of carcinosarcoma, homologous type, located in the posterior endometrium, with a histologic grade of 3 and myometrial invasion involving 33% of the wall thickness. Lymphovascular space invasion is present, and three out of twenty regional lymph nodes examined show evidence of metastatic malignancy. Additional findings include benign conditions in the cervix, ovaries, and myometrium, with no serosal, cervical, or adnexal involvement by the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a left pneumonectomy due to a 65 mm papillary adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe, which has crossed into the left upper lobe and is associated with a separate focus of adenocarcinoma. There is no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion, and all examined lymph nodes are free of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The pathological stage is classified as T2 N0 ?M1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe lung, measuring 1.6 x 1.3 x 1.1 cm, with no evidence of direct extension to the pleura or lymphovascular invasion. Among the mediastinal lymph nodes examined, one node (Level 7) was positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the other lymph nodes were negative for metastasis. The bronchial margin from the completion lobectomy was also negative for residual adenocarcinoma, indicating no remaining cancerous tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma in a right partial glossectomy specimen, measuring 2.2 cm with infiltrative borders and a close deep margin of less than 2 mm, but no perineural or vascular invasion. Additionally, metastatic squamous carcinoma was identified in one of the twelve lymph nodes examined from the right neck dissection, while all other lymph nodes and margins were negative for tumor presence. The report highlights the need for careful monitoring due to the close deep margin and the presence of metastasis in the lymph node.

The pathology report indicates a 6.7 cm ulcerated squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus, classified as G3 poorly differentiated. The tumor has invaded through the muscularis propria into the adventitia, with lymph-vascular invasion present but no perineural invasion identified. Surgical margins are clear of carcinoma, and all examined regional lymph nodes (8) are negative for neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic adenocarcinoma in the bladder peritoneum, consistent with an endometrial primary, and identifies FIGO grade III endometrial adenocarcinoma in the uterus, which has invaded the myometrium and involved both ovaries. The left ovary shows a larger metastatic mass, while the right ovary has a smaller focus of metastasis; however, the cervix and fallopian tubes are unremarkable. All examined pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes, as well as the omentum, are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of invasive, poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the left lateral tongue, measuring 3.8 cm with vascular invasion present and negative margins. Additionally, one of six lymph nodes from the left neck level II shows metastatic squamous cell carcinoma with focal extranodal extension, while the other lymph nodes examined are benign. The report indicates that the tumor has infiltrative borders and mild lymphocyte infiltration, with no perineural invasion detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade III, with more than 50% myometrial invasion and lymphovascular space invasion. All examined lymph nodes and adnexal structures were negative for endometrial adenocarcinoma, and the cervix showed no carcinoma involvement. The tumor size was noted as 4.5 cm, and the margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon, characterized by tubular tumor cell groups and infiltration of the muscularis, classified as pT2 with vascular infiltration (L1, V1). The resection margins are free of tumor, with separation by mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis. The tumor is classified as G2, with a final summary of pT2, L1, V1, and pN0.

The histopathological examination of a segment of the large intestine revealed a 4.5 x 3.5 cm ulcerous, cauliflower-shaped adenocarcinoma (G2) that invades the muscularis propria and surrounding adipose tissue, with a minimum margin of 2.3 cm. The tumor surrounds 90% of the intestinal circumference and is classified as Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2, pT3, pNo. The surgical margins and anastomosis rings are free of cancer invasion, indicating no residual neoplastic lesions at the incision lines.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the posterior hypopharyngeal wall biopsy. High-risk HPV testing and p16 immunohistochemistry results are pending, with initial findings suggesting negative results for HPV and p16 in the addendum. The specimen consisted of spongy friable soft tissue fragments measuring 3.5 x 1.9 x 0.5 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cecum, characterized by a circumferential exophytic ulcerated tumor measuring 5.5 x 4.0 x 3.0 cm, with full muscle wall thickness invasion and extension into pericolic fat, as well as metastasis to 50 out of 59 examined pericolic lymph nodes. Additionally, two polyps were identified, one being a tubulovillous adenoma and the other a polypoid adenocarcinoma with submucosal extension. The peritoneal biopsy also tested positive for adenocarcinoma, indicating metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately-differentiated endocrine carcinoma of the pancreas, with a tumor size of 5.0 x 5.0 x 3.0 cm, and evidence of angiolymphatic and peri-neural invasion. The new pancreatic margin is focally involved by the tumor, while the superior and inferior pancreatic margins are free of tumor. The spleen shows no diagnostic histologic abnormality, but closer follow-up for potential metastatic disease is recommended due to the tumor's characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe of the lung contains a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma that has invaded the pleura and shows vascular invasion, with a subpleural tumor measuring 30 mm. Additionally, the number 5 lymph node exhibits multiple foci of metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, confirming lymph node involvement. The overall pathological stage is classified as T2N2, indicating the extent of the tumor and lymph node metastases.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive well-differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor size of 5.2 cm and minimal invasion into the myometrium. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, and the cervix and bilateral adnexa are free of tumor, with the pelvic wash also negative for malignancy. The pathologic stage is classified as T1a, N0, Mx, corresponding to FIGO stage IA.

The pathology report indicates that the left pelvic lymph nodes showed no tumor presence (0/4), while the right pelvic lymph nodes revealed metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma in one of four nodes (1/4), with no extranodal extension. The cystoprostatectomy specimen demonstrated high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, with invasion into the muscularis propria and positive margins for prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 7 (4+3), along with extraprostatic extension. Additionally, the left distal ureter resection showed no tumor present, and overall, the findings suggest significant malignancy with both bladder and prostate involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of thymoma subtype B3, measuring 9 cm by 6 cm, with confirmed invasion of the pericardium and lung parenchyma. The tumor exhibits characteristics of malignancy, including atypical mitosis and necrosis, and there is evidence of lymph node involvement, classified as N2. According to the modified Masaoka classification, the disease is classified as IVb, indicating advanced stage with significant local invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade myxofibrosarcoma in the left anterior thigh, measuring 10 x 5.1 x 4.5 cm, with focal areas of necrosis present. The tumor is located within skeletal muscle and is well-circumscribed but lacks encapsulation, with surgical margins being free of tumor, although the tumor is within 1 mm of the proximal deep margin. The specimen was received fresh and included a portion of skeletal muscle with attached fatty tissue, and all soft tissue margins were negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4 + 5 = 9, demonstrating multifocal tumor involvement and extraprostatic extension into the surrounding fat. The tumor is noted to be close to the inked margins, with the left anterior margin being positive for tumor involvement. No invasion of the seminal vesicles is observed, and the distal apical urethral margin is also positive for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a total thyroidectomy was performed on a patient with papillary thyroid carcinoma. A 2.2 cm well-differentiated tumor was identified in the left lobe of the thyroid, which is in close proximity to the surgical margin. Additionally, metastatic papillary carcinoma was found in four out of seven examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of carcinosarcoma (malignant mixed Mllerian tumor) of the uterus, with approximately 90% of the endometrial cavity replaced by tumor masses, the largest measuring 6.5 cm. The tumor shows lymphatic and vascular invasion but does not invade the cervix, ovaries, or fallopian tubes, and is located 4 mm from the serosal surface of the uterus. Additionally, malignant surface glands consistent with the carcinomatous component of the carcinosarcoma were identified in the posterior upper vagina, while the posterior vaginal margins were negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe, measuring 3.4 cm, with angiolymphatic and visceral pleural invasion but no lymph node metastasis, classified as T2 N0 Mx. The report also notes that all surgical margins are free of cancer, and there is mild host lymphocytic response. Molecular testing revealed no KRAS or EGFR mutations, but identified EGFR amplification, which may have therapeutic implications for treatment.

The pathology report indicates the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the right posterior segment of the liver, with a largest mass measuring 6.0 cm and showing well-differentiated features (grade II). The surgical margins are clear with a safety margin of 0.3 cm, and there is evidence of microvessel invasion and multicentric occurrence, but no capsular or portal vein invasion. Additionally, the gallbladder shows signs of autolysis, cholesterol polyps, and cholelithiasis, while the pericystic lymph node biopsy reveals reactive hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated intestinal type adenocarcinoma located at the gastroesophageal junction, measuring 4.8 cm, with ulceration and spiculated invasion into adjacent adipose tissue. Neural infiltration and lymphatic vascular invasion are noted, while the proximal and distal margins, as well as the greater omentum, are free of neoplastic involvement. Metastasis is detected in lymph nodes associated with the left renal vein and artery, while other lymph nodes examined show varying degrees of involvement.

The pathology report indicates that a right temporal lobe mass was examined, with the biopsy showing mildly gliotic brain tissue and no definite tumor present. However, the excised specimens were diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme, a high-grade astrocytic neoplasm characterized by pleomorphic large cells, mitotic figures, and necrosis. The report highlights the presence of a significant tumor in the excised samples while noting the absence of malignancy in the biopsy.

The pathology report indicates a malignant squamous cell carcinoma, large cell non-keratinizing, located in the cervix, measuring 2x1.3x1 cm. Microscopic examination reveals an invasive tumor with large polygonal cells and a desmoplastic stroma containing thin-walled vascular channels. The invasive carcinoma is 3 mm from the closest deep resection margin, and the nuclear score is 3.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a brain tumor, specifically glioblastoma with areas of oligodendrocytic differentiation. The specimen consists of multiple irregularly shaped fragments of soft tissue, measuring 4.0 x 3.0 x 1.7 cm, and shows features such as vascular proliferation, atypia, and frequent mitoses. An addendum will provide information on the 1p19q mutation status, and molecular diagnostics have been ordered.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a deceased white individual, was diagnosed with colon adenocarcinoma, specifically located in the sigmoid colon. The cancer is classified as Stage IV, with T Stage 3, N Stage 1, and M Stage 1, indicating advanced disease with regional lymph node involvement and distant metastasis. The report does not provide a date for the initial diagnosis or normal procurement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma from a left colon colectomy specimen measuring 30 cm in length. The tumor, measuring 3.5 cm, invades through the muscularis propria into pericolonic soft tissue, but the margins of resection are negative for malignancy, and there is no evidence of malignancy in any of the twenty-nine examined pericolonic lymph nodes. The pTNM stage is classified as T3 N0, indicating local invasion without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated large-cell squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, classified as pT2, pN1, V1, R0, and stage IIB. The tumor shows focal invasion of the visceral pleura and micrometastasis in the hilus lymph node, while the residual upper lobe is free of tumor. Additional findings include small tumor necroses, inflammation, chronic pleuritis, and emphysematous changes in the lung parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm and local invasion into the renal sinus fat, classified as pT3b. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of renal vein invasion or lymph node involvement in the examined paracaval lymph nodes and right adrenal gland. The report has been amended from a partial nephrectomy to a radical nephrectomy, confirming the presence of the tumor and its characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that a right hemicolectomy specimen from a male patient with a history of colon carcinoma revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the cecum, measuring 4.5 cm in length and 4.0 cm in width, with invasion into the muscularis propria but no serosal involvement. A preexisting tubulovillous adenoma was identified at the carcinoma site, and vascular invasion was present, while surgical margins were free of tumor and no polyps were found away from the carcinoma. The pathological stage is classified as AJCC pT2, with 28 benign lymph nodes identified (0/28), indicating no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a high-grade glial neoplasm in the left frontal brain, with features consistent with anaplastic oligoastrocytoma and areas of necrosis. Molecular analysis shows gene methylation detected, 1p and 19q deletions, and PTEN IHC staining of 2+ in 50% of tumor cells, while EGFR was not detected. Surgical margins are positive for glial neoplasm, and further prognostic marker studies are pending.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 4.2 x 6.5 x 0.8 cm tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon, which has infiltrated the muscularis propria and surrounding mesenteric fat. The tumor surrounds 90% of the intestinal circumference, but the incision lines are free of neoplastic lesions. Additionally, there are metastatic cancer cells found in the lymph nodes, classified as Dukes C, with a histopathological diagnosis of adenocarcinoma tubulopapillare coli.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma in the left thigh mass, measuring 10.9 cm, with resection margins free of tumor, although the closest margin has a clearance of less than 1 mm. The proximal margins showed skeletal muscle with atrophy and chronic inflammation, but no tumor was detected in those areas. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis of high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma, with specific markers indicating the tumor's characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) of the right breast, poorly differentiated (SBR Grade 3), measuring at least 3 cm, with extensive lymphovascular invasion and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The axillary dissection revealed metastatic carcinoma in 2 out of 25 lymph nodes, with the largest metastasis measuring 4 cm, but no extracapsular extension was observed. The tumor is ER-negative, PR-negative, and HER2-positive, indicating a specific subtype of breast cancer that may influence treatment options.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligoastrocytoma (WHO Grade II) from specimens labeled as right parietal neoplasm and anterior central tumor. The posterior margin biopsy shows fragments of cerebral cortex and white matter with focal mild hypercellularity. Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization analysis demonstrates preservation of both chromosomes 1p and 19q, supporting the diagnosis of this glioma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade urothelial carcinoma invading the bladder and perivesical fat, with carcinoma in situ found in the left distal ureter. Additionally, two out of the thirty-eight lymph nodes examined were positive for metastatic urothelial carcinoma, while incidental prostatic adenocarcinoma was noted in the prostate without evidence of extraprostatic extension. The report concludes with a pTNM staging of pT3a, N2, MX for the bladder cancer and pT2a, N0, MX for the prostate cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the fundus of the stomach, with a tumor size of 9 x 8 x 1.5 cm and ulcerated features. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/5 positive), and the surgical margins are uninvolved. Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion, as well as evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment, were not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the left tonsil biopsy revealed invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with carcinoma in situ, measuring 1.6 cm, and involving the lateral and inferior surgical margins. Additionally, metastatic poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma was found in 4 out of 6 lymph nodes at Level IV and in 2 out of 14 lymph nodes at Level V, both with extracapsular extension. No tumor was detected in the anterior, posterior, superior, and inferior margins of the tonsil, nor in the uvula and other lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates that a cervical biopsy was performed, revealing squamous cell carcinoma, likely invasive, classified as large cell, nonkeratinizing, and graded as 2. The specimen consisted of irregular tissue fragments measuring 1.3 x 1.0 x 0.3 cm, which were entirely submitted for analysis. The report is signed electronically and includes relevant CPT and ICD9 codes for documentation.

The pathology report indicates that both specimens from the bladder tumor show invasive poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma, with involvement of the muscularis propria. The histologic grade is III, and there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion. The specimens were collected via transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) and are adequately submitted for evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a pneumonectomy specimen from the lung, revealing a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 10 x 10 x 4 cm. Details regarding tumor extent, other nodules, lymph nodes, invasion, margins, and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment are not specified. No additional pathologic findings or comments were provided.

The pathology report describes a left temporal brain tumor characterized as a mixed anaplastic oligodendroglioma-astrocytoma, with the predominant component being a grade III oligodendroglioma. Microscopic examination reveals malignant glial cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, mitotic activity, vascular proliferation, and focal calcification. There is no evidence of necrosis in the tumor tissue.

The pathology report indicates that both specimens submitted from the right temporal lobe mass are diagnosed as diffuse astrocytoma (WHO grade II), with MIB-1 reactivity being less than 3%. The tumors were described as gray tan friable soft tissue, with the first specimen measuring 0.8 cm and the second measuring 3.8 x 2.0 x 0.7 cm in aggregate. The intraoperative consultation confirmed the diagnosis of low-grade astrocytoma based on the frozen section examination.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left renal mass diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma, papillary type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2-3 out of 4, measuring 3.0 cm and showing no evidence of invasion through the renal capsule. Additionally, the left perinephric fat excision showed fibroadipose tissue with no signs of carcinoma, while the abdominal wall lesion was identified as benign verrucoid keratosis. The surgical margins for the renal mass were clear, with carcinoma present less than 1 mm from the resection margin.

The pathology report indicates a 16-cm large bowel resection specimen containing a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type, which has infiltrated the pericolic fatty tissue and metastasized to three regional lymph nodes. Both the large bowel and mesenteric resection margins are tumor-free. Additionally, there is an inflammatory portion of the urinary bladder fused with the large bowel and ductus deferens in the tumor area, with the tumor staged as pT3 pN1 (3/43) pMX; G2, LO V0, local R0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, papillary variant, type I, measuring 3.0 cm, with negative margins and no lymph nodes identified. The tumor is classified as pT1a, with no lymphovascular or perineural invasion noted, and the pathologic stage is I. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, and while the tumor extends to the parenchymal edge of the specimen, the margin status is considered negative based on the evaluation of the associated specimens.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated serous carcinoma (FIGO grade III) in the right ovary, measuring 13.0 cm, with metastatic involvement in the right fallopian tube and a focus of metastatic carcinoma in the omentum. The left ovary shows two microscopic foci of serous carcinoma, while all examined lymph nodes (48 total) are negative for metastatic tumor. Additional findings include benign conditions such as leiomyoma and adenomyosis in the uterus, with no significant abnormalities in the cervix or left fallopian tube.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3), involving 30% of the right lobe and 10% of the left lobe, with perineural invasion present but no capsular or seminal vesicle invasion. All examined lymph nodes (50 total) were free of tumor, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. The surgical margins of the prostatectomy specimen are clear of invasive carcinoma, and there is noted prostatic glandular atrophy.

The pathology report indicates that a colectomy of the sigmoid colon revealed a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma measuring 3.0 cm, which has penetrated through the muscularis propria into the perirectal fat, but with no angiolymphatic invasion and clear surgical margins. Additionally, three examined pericolonic lymph nodes were free of tumor, and the pathologic stage is classified as pT3 N0 M1. A liver biopsy confirmed metastatic moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, with the primary tumor originating from the colon and rectum.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast mastectomy revealed a poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 2.5 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of lymphovascular invasion. All sentinel lymph nodes examined (SLN #1, SLN #2, SLN #3, and SLN #4) showed no tumor cells, indicating a negative lymph node status (0/5). Additional special stains performed on the lymph node were negative for fungal or acid-fast organisms, consistent with the patient's history of non-necrotizing granulomas.

The pathology report indicates that both specimens of parietal pleura show extensive infiltration by epithelioid malignant mesothelioma. Specimen A consists of multiple thickened fibrous membranes with gelatinous areas, while Specimen B contains thickened fibrous pieces with adipose tissue. The findings are consistent with a diagnosis of mesothelioma, as noted in the clinical information.

The pathology report indicates that the bone marrow from the 10th rib shows maturing trilineage hematopoiesis with no evidence of malignancy. The right kidney specimen reveals a 10.0 cm chromophobe renal cell carcinoma with Fuhrman nuclear grade III/IV, showing lymphovascular invasion but not invading the renal capsule, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Three regional lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two adenocarcinomas located in the fundus of the stomach, both classified as grade II. The tumors are staged as T1b, indicating invasion into the submucosa. The samples were collected through resection procedures, and the size of the tumors is noted as 6 cm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segments 6 and 8, with tumor sizes of 1.7 cm and 1.5 x 1.4 x 1.3 cm, respectively. Both tumors are confined to the liver, with margins of resection free of invasive carcinoma, and the liver shows signs of chronic hepatitis C with mild activity transitioning to cirrhosis (modified ISHAK stage 3 of 4). Additional findings include hepatocellular dysplasia and no evidence of vascular invasion or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma based on biopsies from both the cervix and endometrium. Microscopic examination reveals large fragments of a high-grade papillary carcinoma with necrosis and inflammation, suggesting possible stromal invasion. The findings raise uncertainty about whether the tumor is primarily cervical or endometrial, although it leans more towards an endometrial origin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Grade III, in the right breast following a partial mastectomy, with a maximum tumor dimension of 6 cm and no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, although it abuts deep skeletal muscle. The examination of lymph nodes from the right axilla and sentinel nodes shows no evidence of malignancy. The tumor is staged as T3 N0 Mx, and surgical margins are negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with tumor involvement in both the right and left lobes, measuring up to 2 cm, and a Gleason score of 7/10. There is no evidence of extra prostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, or lymphovascular invasion, and the surgical margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, one lymph node was examined, which showed no metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic glioma, specifically a mixed astrocytoma and oligodendroglioma, from a biopsy of the right temporal lobe. Microscopic examination reveals a hypercellular tumor with mitotic figures and vascular proliferation, predominantly in the astrocytoma component, along with scattered calcifications and no evidence of tumor necrosis. The MIB-1 labeling index is approximately 15%, suggesting a moderate level of cellular proliferation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 2.5 x 2 x 1.8 cm, with a Bloom-Richardson grade of II and a lymph node status showing 1 out of 2 sentinel nodes and 1 out of 8 level I and II nodes containing metastatic carcinoma. Estrogen receptors are positive (95%), while progesterone receptors are negative (0%), and the Ki-67 proliferation marker is low (<10%). The Her2 gene amplification analysis was inconclusive due to unsuccessful hybridization, and further testing is recommended if additional tissue becomes available.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade III, in a left frontal tumor, characterized by pleomorphic glial cells and multiple mitotic figures. Additionally, atypical glial cells consistent with infiltrating astrocytoma were noted in the specimen. The Ki67 proliferation index was found to be 10%, supporting the diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, grade 2, with a solitary tumor measuring 3.5 cm, and no evidence of direct invasion, lymphovascular invasion, or renal vein involvement. All surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and there are no significant pathologic findings in the non-neoplastic kidney. The tumor is staged as pT1a, with lymph nodes not assessable and no distant metastasis present.

The final diagnosis indicates that the patient underwent a radical cystoprostatectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy, revealing a poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder, measuring 3.5 cm, with invasion into the bladder wall and perivesical fat, and lymphovascular space invasion present. The prostate showed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6, confined to the prostate gland without capsular involvement, and all examined lymph nodes were free of metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings included benign conditions in the ureters and no urothelial dysplasia or malignancy identified in the resection margins.

The pathology report indicates that the left kidney underwent a radical nephrectomy due to a renal cell carcinoma of the conventional type, classified as nuclear grade III/IV, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm. The tumor is solid, confined within the renal capsule, and shows no invasion of the renal vein, with all surgical margins free of tumor. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable, and the specimen weighed a total of 700 grams.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma located in the right upper lobe (RUL) of the lung, with a tumor size of 2.50 cm. The tumor is classified as stage I, with a pathologic classification of T2, N0, and M0, indicating no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. The histological grade is not specified, but the report confirms the tumor was resected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the right breast, with a maximum tumor size estimated at approximately 5 cm and a Nottingham prognostic index score of 7, classifying it as a grade II lesion. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in three out of seven lymph nodes, including one sentinel lymph node. Ancillary studies, including breast cancer marker studies, are pending to further evaluate the tumor characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in three of five lymph nodes in the right central neck, with evidence of extracapsular extension.
