The total thyroid examination reveals a 2.9 cm conventional type papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right lobe, with extrathyroidal extension into skeletal muscle, but no lymphovascular invasion and tumor abutting the resection margin. The right inferior parathyroid gland shows parathyroid tissue that is negative for tumor.

The pathology report describes a 6x4 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as poorly differentiated (G-3), with invasion into the perigastric fat. Lymph nodes along the lesser curvature are not clearly detected, while those along the greater curvature are suspicious for metastases, although no positive lymph nodes were identified in the examined samples. The omentum is noted to be hyperemic, and there is no evidence of venous invasion or positive margins.

The pathology report indicates the presence of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the esophagus, characterized by multifocal exophytic growth with invasion into the superficial layers of the muscularis mucosae (pT1a), but no evidence of lymph node involvement or angiolymphatic invasion. Additional biopsies from the bronchial mucosa and lymph nodes showed no tumors, while the gastric tissue exhibited changes consistent with proton pump inhibitor therapy. The resection margins were free of malignancy, and there were findings of Barrett's esophagus and high-grade dysplasia in the esophageal mucosa.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade papillary serous carcinoma extensively invading the omentum, both ovaries, and the left fallopian tube, with the right fallopian tube showing no tumor involvement. Additionally, the sigmoid serosa and mesentery are also invaded by the carcinoma, while the endometrium is negative for tumor but shows signs of weak proliferation and cystic hyperplasia. The report highlights the presence of multiple leiomyomata and foci of adenomyosis in the uterus, with the cul-de-sac also being negative for tumor.

The pathology report describes a large ovoid tumor identified as a pheochromocytoma, measuring 130x100x90 mm and weighing 640 g, with a fibrous capsule and areas of hemorrhage. Microscopic examination reveals a solidly alveolar structure composed of large, polygonal cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, but no evidence of vascular or capsular invasion was found. Immunohistochemical analysis shows negative staining for S100 protein and a low proliferation index (MIB1 <1%), indicating a relatively low aggressiveness of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a mixed oligoastrocytoma with focal anaplastic features (WHO grade III) in the left temporal lobe, following a partial resection of a lesion. Molecular testing revealed negative results for MGMT promoter methylation and allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, which are typically associated with oligodendrogliomas. Microscopic examination showed moderate infiltration by neoplastic cells, with some exhibiting mitotic activity and microvascular proliferation, but no tumor necrosis was observed.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary has a follicular cyst and mild hyperplasia, while the left ovary shows serosal adhesions; both fallopian tubes exhibit minimal chronic inflammation with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The uterus reveals poorly differentiated invasive cervical carcinoma with squamous cell features, extending into the lower uterine segment and involving lymphatic invasion, with one of four parametrial lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, several lymph nodes from the left pelvic region are positive for metastatic carcinoma, while other lymph nodes from various regions show reactive changes without evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade III) from a brain tumor resection in the right frontal region. The tumor exhibits areas of low-grade oligodendroglioma alongside foci of increased cellularity, mitoses, and vascular proliferation, with a Ki-67 labeling index of 7-12%. Additionally, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis revealed deletions of chromosomes 1p and 19q, which may correlate with improved survival and chemotherapy response in oligodendroglioma cases.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated carcinoma in the larynx, with a tumor measuring 2.3 cm and invading the pre-epiglottic space, but all surgical margins are negative for malignancy. Lymph node excisions reveal carcinoma involvement in 5 out of 43 lymph nodes, with one node showing extranodal extension, while other lymph nodes and margins from the hypopharynx and oropharynx are negative for malignancy. The findings correspond to AJCC stage IV A (pT3, N2c, M0) disease.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the pancreatic neck margin is negative for tumor, while a distal pancreatectomy, splenectomy, and partial omentectomy reveal an invasive grade 3 adenocarcinoma measuring 2.2 x 2.0 x 1.8 cm within the body of the pancreas, with extension into peripancreatic soft tissue and evidence of perineural invasion. The surgical margins, including the pancreatic neck, are negative for tumor, and multiple lymph nodes from the peripancreatic and omental regions are also negative for malignancy. Additionally, the distal pancreas shows signs of chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN-1A) is noted in the pancreatic ducts.

The pathology report indicates the presence of astrocytic differentiation with no detectable mitotic activity and a proliferation rate of 2%. The diagnosis is an astrocytoma classified as WHO grade II. This suggests a low-grade tumor with relatively low cellular activity.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma, classified as grade II according to the World Health Organization (WHO) grading system. The tumor is located in the right temporal region. The patient is female.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower lobe lung biopsy revealed moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.9 x 2.5 x 1.8 cm, with no vascular or perineural invasion and a free bronchial margin. Additionally, multiple mediastinal lymph nodes were excised, all of which were found to be benign, and a right pleural biopsy showed fibrous connective tissue. The non-neoplastic lung tissue exhibited a pleural scar and focal organizing pneumonia.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent enucleation of the right eye due to a large choroidal melanoma, specifically an amelanotic epithelioid cell melanoma, with a significant tumor size and involvement of the choroid and retina. Additional findings include iris neovascularization, retinal detachment, and no evidence of scleral involvement or vascular invasion. The tumor was staged as pT3a NX MX, and immunohistochemical tests confirmed the diagnosis of melanoma while ruling out carcinoma or metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of locally advanced, primarily peripheral bronchopulmonary mixed highly mucinous adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, classified as stage IIIB (pT4 pN2 V1 RX). The tumor has infiltrated the pleural layer and extended into the hilum, with involvement of parabronchial lymph nodes and a separate satellite focus in segment 3. While the resection margins for bronchus, vessels, and lymph nodes are tumor-free, the proximity of the tumor to the hilar resection margin remains uncertain.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the cecum, measuring 3.7 cm by 4.0 cm, with evidence of lymphovascular and perineural invasion, but no regional lymph node metastasis was found. The tumor has invaded through the muscularis propria into pericolorectal tissues, classified as pT3 according to AJCC staging. The small intestine segment submitted for examination showed no pathological diagnosis, and all surgical margins were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, microfollicular variant, located on the right side. The tumor measures 1 x 0.7 x 0.6 cm and has penetrated into the regional soft tissue. Additionally, the tumor is multifocal, indicating the presence of multiple tumor sites.

The pathology report indicates that the tumor is located in the left parietal region of the brain. The histological diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme. This diagnosis suggests a highly aggressive and malignant brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, with a tumor size of 1.5 x 1.2 x 1.0 cm, and ductal carcinoma in situ comprising 5-25% of the tumor volume. All surgical resection margins are negative for tumor, and multiple sentinel lymph nodes are also negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, the report notes the presence of proliferative fibrocystic changes in the non-neoplastic breast tissue and identifies a fibroadenoma at the biopsy site.

The pathology report indicates the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in segment 6 of the liver, with a tumor size of 2.1 x 2.0 cm and partial capsular infiltration, but no evidence of vascular invasion or metastasis. The tumor shows a differentiation grade of II, with a trabecular histologic type and associated fatty change. Additionally, the liver exhibits chronic hepatitis due to HBV and is classified as micronodular cirrhosis, while the gallbladder specimen shows autolysis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left lower lobe lobectomy specimen diagnosed with moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 1.2 cm, with no evidence of pleural invasion or involvement of surgical margins. All examined lymph nodes (levels IX, VIII, VII, XI, V, VI, X, and XIII) were negative for malignancy, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. The overall findings suggest a localized lung malignancy without evidence of spread to surrounding tissues or lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left frontal lobe oligodendroglioma, WHO grade II, confirmed through both frozen and permanent section analyses. The tumor specimens were received and examined, revealing characteristics consistent with a low-grade infiltrating glioma. Additionally, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis showed deletions of 1p and 19q, which suggests a favorable prognosis for the patient.

The pathology report describes a biopsy of a mediastinal anterior neoplasia in a female patient, measuring 12x10x5 cm. Histological analysis reveals neoplastic infiltration consistent with a poorly differentiated neuroendocrine carcinoma, characterized by positivity for CD117 and Synaptophysin, with a Ki67 growth fraction of 30-40%. The findings suggest a thymic origin for the neoplasia, classified as a neuroendocrine thymic carcinoma according to the 2004 WHO classification.

The liver needle biopsy reveals well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) classified as Edmondson-Steiner grade 1 out of 4. Special stains showed no significant changes, but reticulin staining indicated disruption of the reticulin framework. The specimen consisted of three cores of pale tan fragmented liver tissue, and the entire sample was submitted for analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a liver specimen obtained from a partial hepatectomy, with a well-defined mass measuring 4.7 cm and a safety margin of 2.0 cm. The liver also shows mild steatosis and stage 2 periportal fibrosis, while the gallbladder reveals chronic cholecystitis. Additionally, a regional lymph node biopsy shows reactive hyperplasia with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph node biopsy from the innominate vein is negative for malignancy. The thymus resection reveals a mixed thymoma (WHO type AB2) measuring 7.0 cm with focal microscopic invasion of the tumor capsule, classified as stage IIa. The tumor margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral fallopian adenocarcinoma with high-grade serous and endometrioid components, showing myometrial invasion of 3.0 mm and cervical invasion of 2.0 mm. There is evidence of lymphovascular invasion, but no tumor is present in the examined lymph nodes or other structures, including the ovaries and omentum. Additionally, a leiomyoma was noted in the left ovary, while the right ovary contained a small cyst.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 10.5 cm, but without local or renal vein invasion. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the adrenal gland is not involved, while the lymph nodes examined show no signs of metastasis. The tumor is staged as pT2, indicating it is greater than 7.0 cm and confined to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with an anaplastic oligoastrocytoma, characterized by extensive infiltration of neoplastic cells in the brain tissue, with a MIB-1 proliferation index of 22%. Genetic testing revealed a negative MGMT promoter methylation status and partial deletion of chromosome arm 1p, while no evidence of EGFRvIII mutation was detected. The findings suggest a mixed phenotype of oligodendroglial and astrocytic characteristics in the tumor, with brisk mitotic activity and moderate nuclear pleomorphism.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an anaplastic glioma located in the frontal lobes and corpus of a Caucasian male. The tumor specimen was processed as a frozen tissue block, with a significant tumor cell percentage of 80%. There is no indication of additional treatment or staging details provided in the report.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the fundus of the stomach, measuring 4 x 3.5 x 1.2 cm, which is diagnosed as an ulcerated intestinal type adenocarcinoma. The tumor has metastasized to 7 out of 8 examined lymph nodes, with no involvement of the surgical margins. Additional details regarding histologic grade, lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion were not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the right pelvic tumor was diagnosed as high-grade leiomyosarcoma, measuring 11.5 cm, with focal extension to the surgical margin and approximately 25% necrosis, but negative for angiolymphatic invasion. The right ovary and fallopian tube showed no significant pathologic changes and were negative for malignancy, while the uterus, cervix, and left ovary exhibited benign findings, including an intramural leiomyoma and mild chronic cervicitis. Overall, the report highlights the presence of a malignant tumor in the right pelvic region, while other specimens were found to be non-malignant.

The pathology report indicates a tumor in the right lower lobe of the lung measuring 5.1 x 4.2 x 3.3 cm, diagnosed as Squamous Cell Carcinoma (not otherwise specified), partially basaloid. The tumor is classified as pT2b, with no regional lymph node involvement (pNO 0/20), and the metastatic status is undetermined (pMx). The tumor is graded as G2, indicating moderate differentiation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous papillary adenocarcinoma in the left ovary, with a tumor size of 15 cm that has invaded surrounding tissues and shows multiple lymphovascular tumor emboli. The right ovary contains metastatic adenocarcinoma with numerous lymphovascular tumor emboli, alongside benign cysts, while lymph nodes from both the left and right obturator regions show significant metastatic involvement. Additional findings include mild chronic cervicitis, proliferative endometrium, and various benign changes in the cervix and omentum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the right breast, with a maximum tumor size estimated at approximately 4.5 cm and extensive involvement of all eighteen examined lymph nodes, including evidence of extranodal spread. Immunohistochemical evaluations show favorable estrogen receptor positivity at 66% and borderline Ki-67 proliferation index at 11%. The Nottingham Prognostic Index grade is II, and there is no lymphovascular invasion noted, with the closest surgical margin being 9 mm from the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a left renal mass diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma, Fuhrman grade 2, measuring 3.1 cm and minimally extending into the perirenal fat. All surgical margins are negative for tumor, suggesting complete resection of the cancerous tissue. There is no evidence of vascular invasion or significant pathology in the non-neoplastic kidney.

The pathology report describes a glial neoplasm, specifically an oligodendroglioma classified as low grade (WHO grade II), which diffusely infiltrates both gray and white matter with notable perineuronal satellitosis and subpial spread. Although the tumor shows little cytologic atypia and no mitotic figures, a high MIB-1 labeling index of 21% indicates a markedly proliferative nature, suggesting potential for more aggressive behavior. Close clinical follow-up is recommended due to the tumor's characteristics.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial carcinomas, specifically a carcinomatous tumor with heterologous elements, classified as FIGO grade 3, with a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 0.6 cm. Additionally, the omentum shows extensive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, with the maximum tumor size measuring 4.5 cm. The cervix and fallopian tubes are negative for carcinoma, while both ovaries are positive for poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two specimens from the right parietal lobe, both diagnosed as anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO Grade III. Although the majority of the tumor appears low-grade, areas with multiple mitotic figures suggest anaplastic transformation, with a proliferation index exceeding 10% as indicated by MIB-1 immunostaining. Molecular testing for EGFR, MGMT promoter methylation, and IDH and EGFR vIII has been ordered, with results pending in separate reports.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a year-old woman, has been diagnosed with moderately differentiated non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix following a cervical biopsy. The specimen showed multiple fragments of cervical tissue measuring 0.7 x 0.5 x 0.1 cm, with an intense stromal chronic inflammatory infiltrate. The diagnosis was confirmed by personal examination of the slides by the reporting physician.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of stomach adenocarcinoma, characterized as solid, partly tubular, and mucinous, with metastases found in 4 out of 14 lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as G2, pT2, pN2, and shows invasion into the muscular membrane of the lesser omentum, with affected vessels exhibiting embolism. Additionally, there is a strong positive HER2 protein expression in the invasive cancerous cells, scoring 3+.

The pathology report indicates that a specimen was sent to the Biospecimen Core Resource (BCR) for analysis, but it lacks specific details regarding the tumor type and histology code. Instructions for completing the TCGA Missing Pathology Report Form are provided, emphasizing the need for accurate data entry related to the specimen and patient diagnosis. Overall, the report highlights the absence of a complete pathology report and the necessity for further documentation.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lesions from the left temporal occipital region of the brain are diagnosed as low-grade oligoastrocytoma (WHO grade II). Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive staining for IDH-1 (R132H) and variable staining for GFAP, with low to moderate p53 staining and focal moderate Ki-67 staining, supporting the diagnosis. A fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) test for 1p/19q deletion is pending, and preliminary findings suggest a low-grade glioma, likely oligodendroglioma.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the left parieto-occipital lobe reveals an oligoastrocytoma classified as WHO grade II, characterized by predominantly oligodendroglial features and relatively uniform nuclei with sparse mitoses. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positivity for IDH1 and a MIB-1 labeling index of approximately 6%, with p53 staining observed in 20% of tumor cells. Additional fluorescence in situ hybridization for 1p19q is pending, and the case has been reviewed by the attending pathologist for final diagnosis confirmation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast tissue, with a tumor size of 2.4 x 1.5 cm and a nuclear grade of 3. There is no evidence of malignancy in the re-excised posterior and superior margins, while metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in 2 of 14 axillary lymph nodes, with the largest metastasis measuring 1.0 cm. Estrogen and progesterone receptor activities were negative, and HER2/neu overexpression was positive in approximately 50-75% of the tumor cells.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma of the rectum, classified as G2, with evidence of deep infiltration into the muscularis propria and signs of fatty tissue penetration. The tumor measures 5.2 x 5.3 x 1.2 cm and surrounds 80% of the intestinal circumference, with incision lines free of neoplastic lesions. Additionally, a low-grade tubulopapillary adenoma with moderate dysplasia was found near one end of the intestine.

The pathology report indicates that a cervical biopsy was performed, revealing the presence of large cell, non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma with stromal invasion. The specimen measured 1.0 x 0.5 x 0.2 cm and was submitted for analysis. This finding suggests a malignant process in the cervix that requires further clinical evaluation and management.

The pathology report indicates a lobectomy specimen from the lung, revealing a 3 x 2.5 x 2 cm moderately differentiated mucinous bronchiolo-alveolar carcinoma. The report does not specify tumor extent, other tumor nodules, lymph nodes, lymphatic or venous invasion, or margins. Additional pathologic findings and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment are also not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a moderately differentiated intestinal-type gastric adenocarcinoma, measuring 4 cm, located on the lesser curvature of the stomach with invasive characteristics extending through all gastric wall layers and into surrounding fatty tissue. There is evidence of mild to moderate chronic gastritis and Helicobacter pylori infection in the gastric mucosa, while the resection margins are tumor-free. Metastatic spread is noted in 3 out of 36 examined perigastric lymph nodes, resulting in a tumor stage of pT2b and pN1.

The pathology report describes a thymectomy specimen weighing 173 g, which includes a lobulated tumor measuring 8 x 7.5 x 4.3 cm, surrounded by a thick fibrous capsule and showing biphasic proliferation with epithelial and lymphocytic components. Histopathological examination confirms the diagnosis of a completely encapsulated thymoma, subtype AB, with no evidence of malignancy in the surrounding fat or lymph nodes. The resection is deemed complete, and the normal thymus shows discrete lymphoid hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a left adrenal mass identified as a pheochromocytoma, with no tumor seen at the inked surface. Immunohistochemical staining revealed patchy ganglion cells and areas of micronodular hyperplasia in the adrenal cortex. The specimen, measuring 8 x 5 x 4.5 cm and weighing 108 grams, was submitted for permanent processing following a left adrenalectomy.

The pathology report indicates that the excision biopsy of a left temporal tumor is consistent with recurrent or residual glioblastoma. Histological examination reveals necrosis, foamy macrophages, and vascular proliferation, along with pleomorphic atypical glial cells infiltrating the cortex, which show strong p53 positivity and a high MIB-1 labeling index of approximately 80 to 90%. The tumor specimen measured 2.5 x 1.7 x 1.0 cm and weighed 2.08 grams, with findings suggesting treatment effects and the presence of glioma cells.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes and a peribronchial biopsy from the right side are negative for carcinoma, confirming no evidence of cancer in these specimens. However, the right lung specimen reveals invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 9.2 cm, with involvement into the chest wall but negative margins for carcinoma in bronchial, soft tissue, and bone resections. The pathological staging is classified as pT3, with no lymph node involvement detected in the examined nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the left orchidectomy revealed a nonseminoma tumor with a composition of 90% mixed type (MT + IT), 5% embryonal carcinoma (EC), 5% yolk sac tumor (YST), and trophoblastic giant cells. The tumor measures 5.5 cm and is confined to the testis, with no evidence of angio-invasion or invasion of the rete testis. Overall, the findings suggest a localized nonseminomatous germ cell tumor without aggressive features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with nuclear grade III/IV, present in two separate foci measuring 5.0 cm and 0.8 cm, respectively, and extending through the renal capsule but confined within Gerota's fascia. The left kidney and portion of the adrenal gland show no invasion of the large renal vein, and all surgical margins are free of tumor, while the remaining adrenal gland and para-aortic lymph nodes are histologically benign. Additionally, the non-neoplastic kidney exhibits focal benign simple cortical cysts, and the overall findings suggest a localized renal cell carcinoma without evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a left temporal brain tumor, characterized as a low-grade (WHO grade II) diffuse glioma, likely a mixed oligoastrocytoma. Microscopic examination revealed hypercellularity with atypical cells, but no necrosis or mitotic figures were observed, and some tumor cells tested positive for p53. Cytogenetic analysis showed no loss of 1p or 19q, and EGFR amplification was not detected, making oligodendroglioma less likely.

The intraoperative examination of a lesion excised from the right breast revealed an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 3 cm in diameter. Immunohistochemical analysis showed no estrogen or progesterone receptors, and HER2 testing was negative. The final diagnosis will be confirmed after further analysis of paraffin specimens, but the tumor is noted to be reaching the incision line.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma located at the rectosigmoid junction, with a maximum tumor size of 3.5 cm and invasion into adjacent fatty tissue. Additionally, there are two adenomas present: a tubulovillous adenoma measuring 3 cm with severe dysplasia and a tubular adenoma measuring 0.8 cm also with severe dysplasia. The resection margins are tumor-free, and all examined regional lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total laryngectomy and bilateral neck dissection due to respiratory distress, revealing moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the larynx, measuring 3.5 cm, with no thyroid cartilage involvement and free surgical margins. Additionally, two of sixteen lymph nodes from the right neck dissection were positive for metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, while no tumors were found in the left neck lymph nodes or other biopsied sites, which showed mild dysplasia. Ancillary studies for HPV and EGFR were negative, and the final pathologic stage was classified as pT4N0.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous carcinoma in both the right and left ovaries, with extensive replacement of ovarian tissue and tumor on the surface of the ovaries. Metastatic disease is noted in the omental lymph node and the right gutter peritoneum, as well as in one of the para-aortic and one of the left pelvic lymph nodes, while the uterus and cervix show no significant abnormalities apart from inflammation. Overall, the diagnosis is consistent with advanced ovarian cancer (pT3C) with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of carcinomasarcoma of the endometrium (malignant mixed Mllerian tumor) following a total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, with no myometrial or endocervical invasion and no definite vascular invasion identified. All examined lymph nodes from various regions (right and left para-aortic, external iliac, and obturator) were found to be benign, and the omentum was negative for tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed no support for heterologous rhabdomyoblastic differentiation in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the tumor is located in the right temporal region. The histological diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme. This diagnosis suggests a highly aggressive and malignant brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade I endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with a tumor size of 7 x 4 x 0.7 cm and a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 0.7 cm. All examined lymph nodes, including sentinel and pelvic nodes, were negative for malignancy, and the margins of the hysterectomy specimen were also negative. The report confirms that the adjacent non-neoplastic endometrium shows atrophy, and there is a subserosal leiomyoma present, but no malignancy was found in the ovaries or fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of unifocal papillary carcinoma located in the left thyroid gland, with a tumor size of 0.7 x 0.7 x 0.7 cm. There is no evidence of extrathyroidal extension noted in the report. Additionally, no lymph nodes were examined during the evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, nuclear grade I/IV, in the left kidney, with a tumor measuring 3.0 cm that is confined within the renal capsule and has negative surgical margins. The deep margin sample shows benign renal parenchyma. The tumor exhibits an acinar growth pattern and is characterized by focal hemorrhages and a central tan-white area.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bilateral invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) and invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) with multiple metastatic lymph nodes identified in the right axilla, including significant extranodal extension. The right breast mastectomy revealed two tumors: one measuring 3.6 cm with a focal lobular growth pattern and another measuring 2.5 cm, both associated with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The lymph node status showed 13 out of 17 nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma, highlighting extensive disease spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a tumor size measuring 1 x 0.8 x 0.5 cm. The tumor extent is noted to be less than 4.0 cm, but details regarding lymph nodes, lymphatic invasion, venous invasion, and margins are not specified. There is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings mentioned in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 3.5 cm, with infiltration into the detrusor muscle but no evidence of neural or vascular invasion. Surgical margins are clear of neoplastic involvement, and there is also nodular benign prostatic hyperplasia and nonspecific chronic prostatitis noted in the prostate. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from both the left and right pelvic lymphadenectomies are free of neoplastic compromise.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 4.5 cm papillary adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, characterized by poor differentiation and evidence of pleural infiltration and blood vessel invasion. There are also hilar lymph node metastases present. The tumor is classified as stage III A, with a grade of 3, and the surgical resection achieved clear margins (R0).

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with three out of four Delphian lymph nodes and four out of five right para-esophageal lymph nodes testing positive for cancer. The total thyroidectomy specimen reveals a well-differentiated classical type papillary carcinoma in the right lobe, measuring 4.1 cm, with evidence of extrathyroidal extension and involvement of surgical margins. Additionally, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis is noted in the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue, and extensive psammoma bodies are observed.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen with a poorly differentiated signet ring cell carcinoma measuring 16.0 x 15.0 cm, exhibiting an exophytic (polypoid) configuration. The tumor has invaded the serosa and 4 out of 12 lymph nodes show evidence of metastasis. Margins and additional pathologic findings were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the fundus of the stomach, measuring 3.5 x 3 x 1 cm. The tumor has not metastasized to the examined lymph nodes, with 0 out of 4 nodes positive for cancer. The surgical margins are uninvolved, suggesting complete resection of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous papillary carcinoma of the endometrium, with the tumor invading the myometrium to a depth of 2 mm and no lymphovascular space involvement. Surgical staging revealed no malignancy in 24 examined lymph nodes, and the margins were negative for tumor involvement. Additional findings included benign conditions such as cervical atrophy and endometriosis, with the tumor measuring 3 x 2 cm located in the anterior and posterior endometrium.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with a tumor size of 3 x 2 cm and a depth of myometrial invasion of 2.5 mm. Surgical procedures included a laparoscopic-assisted vaginal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and lymphadenectomy, with all examined lymph nodes showing no malignancy (0/18). Additional findings included adenomyosis, leiomyomata uteri, and an endometrial polyp, with negative margins and no lymphovascular space involvement noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade papillary serous adenocarcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with the left tumor measuring 9.0 cm and showing surface involvement and focal lymphovascular invasion. The report also notes that the fallopian tubes are involved, and there are additional findings of endometrial polyps, adenomyosis, and chronic cervicitis in the uterus. Importantly, all examined lymph nodes and biopsies from various sites are negative for metastatic carcinoma, and the overall pathologic staging is classified as pT3b, pNO, pMX, corresponding to FIGO stage IIIB.

The pathology report indicates that the right kidney tumor was diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, measuring 2.5 cm, with surgical resection margins involved by carcinoma. The right renal tumor base showed no malignancy. Immunohistochemical staining results were positive for cytokeratin 7 and CD 10, supporting the diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right upper lobectomy, revealing a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 45 mm, with pleural invasion and focal involvement of mediastinal fat, but clear bronchial margins and no lymph node metastases. Two lymph nodes examined (No. 5 and a hilar lymph node) showed only reactive changes with no evidence of malignancy. The final classification is T4N0MX, indicating advanced local disease without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that a right pneumonectomy was performed, revealing a 6.4 cm moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lung, with extension into the hilar area and lymph-vascular invasion present. Examination of 32 regional lymph nodes showed one involved lymph node in the peribronchial region, while other lymph nodes from various stations were negative for tumor. Additional findings included emphysema, and the bronchial margin was uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, while the vascular margin showed involvement by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of choroidal melanoma, spindle type B, measuring 11 mm at the base, with superficial scleral invasion but no extraocular extension or optic nerve involvement. The tumor is described as amelanotic, exhibiting mitotic activity and associated retinal detachment and atrophy. The right globe was intact upon examination, with the tumor showing a mushrooming growth pattern and no significant involvement of the surrounding structures.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a classic seminoma in the left testis, measuring 0.9 x 0.7 x 0.7 cm. There is no evidence of vascular invasion, perineural invasion, or intratubular neoplasia, and the surrounding structures, including the rete testis and tunica albuginea, are uninvolved by neoplasia. Additionally, there is focal atrophy in the adjacent testicular parenchyma, but the margins are clear of neoplastic involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 8, involving both lobes and showing established extracapsular extension. The carcinoma affects approximately 30% of the examined prostate volume and extends to the surgical margins, while bilateral seminal vesicles are free of carcinoma. Ten benign lymph nodes were examined, with no evidence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical variant papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid gland, measuring 1.7 cm, with extrathyroidal extension into perithyroidal adipose tissue and skeletal muscle, but negative for perineural invasion. The right lobe and isthmus show multiple adenomatoid nodules consistent with multinodular goiter, and a hypercellular parathyroid gland, which is negative for malignancy. The central node tissue is identified as benign thymic tissue, with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in both segments 6 and 8 of the liver, with segment 6 showing a very close resection margin of 0.1 cm and segment 8 having a safer margin of 1.2 cm. Histologically, both tumors are classified as trabecular type with Edmondson-Steiner grades II and III, and there is evidence of cirrhosis in the remaining liver parenchyma. No portal vein invasion or other significant complications were noted, but multicentric occurrence of HCC is suggested.

The final diagnosis indicates an anaplastic oligoastrocytoma (WHO grade III) in the left temporal brain mass, with immunohistochemical analysis showing positive p53 expression and a moderate MIB-1 labeling index. Preliminary frozen section consultation suggested a low-grade glioma, while fluorescence in situ hybridization studies for 1p19q deletion are pending. The specimens received included multiple biopsies from the left temporal and anterior temporal brain masses, all submitted for permanent sections.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic adenocarcinoma, with eight out of twelve lymph nodes from the left lung showing metastasis, and additional involvement in the left hilar and tracheobronchial lymph nodes. The primary tumor in the left upper lobe is characterized as a moderately to poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma measuring 5.0 x 4.1 x 2.4 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and direct extension into two intraparenchymal lymph nodes. Molecular analysis for EGFR mutations revealed no mutations detected, although a polymorphism of uncertain clinical significance was noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 2, with 95% involvement of the endometrial surface and invasion of 0.3 cm into the myometrium. All examined lymph nodes (30 in total) were negative for metastatic tumor, and there was no evidence of lymphovascular invasion. The final pathologic stage is T1a, N0, Mx, corresponding to FIGO stage IA.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial cancer, specifically well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma, with a maximum tumor size of 4.5 cm and significant myometrial invasion. The cancer is staged as FIGO IIIA, with no lymph nodes showing metastasis out of 13 examined, although pelvic wash specimens were positive for malignant cells. The tumor exhibits 10% anterior and 30% posterior endometrial surface involvement, with a nuclear grade of 2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) in the left temporal lobe of the brain, based on biopsy and removal of the lesion. Specimen "A" shows infiltrating anaplastic astrocytoma, while the majority of sections from specimens labeled as gross tumor and enhancing white matter demonstrate glioblastoma multiforme. The report includes detailed descriptions of the submitted specimens, which were processed for both intraoperative diagnosis and final evaluation.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the cervix revealed invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor is classified as histological grade 2. This suggests a moderate level of differentiation in the cancer cells.

The pathology report indicates that all examined pelvic lymph nodes from both the right and left sides are benign, with no evidence of malignancy. A radical prostatectomy revealed prostatic adenocarcinoma, acinar type, with a Gleason score of 3 + 5 - 8, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing focal perineural invasion, but no extraprostatic extension or lymphatic invasion. The tumor comprises approximately 10% of the prostate volume, with a maximum diameter of 1.3 cm, and all surgical margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report describes an enucleated right eye specimen measuring 25 mm in diameter, containing a 16 by 13 mm melanoma located behind the ciliary body, with infiltration into the internal third of the sclera. Microscopic examination reveals the tumor is composed mainly of fusiform cells with nucleolated nuclei and shows mitotic activity, but no necrosis or microcalcification is present. The iris, anterior chamber, optic nerve, and meningeal sheaths are free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the excised portal tissue is benign fibroadipose tissue, while the liver segmental resection reveals moderately-differentiated cholangiocarcinoma with a tumor size of 7.3 cm and multiple foci. The tumor is confined to the hepatic parenchyma, with a distance of 1 mm from the closest surgical margin, and perineural invasion is present. Background liver parenchyma shows prominent chronic portal inflammation, likely due to mass effect from the tumor, and further clinical correlation is necessary for a definitive diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, measuring 6.4 cm, with Fuhrman nuclear grade IV and focal sarcomatoid differentiation, confined to the right kidney without vascular invasion. The tumor's margins are negative for tumor, and additional evaluations of non-neoplastic kidney tissue are pending. Cytogenetic analysis revealed interstitial deletions on chromosomes in two specimens, consistent with characteristics of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma testis (pT2 NXMX) in the left testicle, characterized by a tumor measuring 7x4.8x4.5 cm that infiltrates the tunica albuginea and partially affects the epididymis and rete testis. Histological examination reveals tumor cells with distinct nuclei and abundant cytoplasm, with immunohistochemical positivity for PLAP, and shows partial necrosis and inflammatory infiltrates surrounding the tumor. Additionally, there is no evidence of intratubular germ cell neoplasia (IGCNU), and a separate tissue sample contains only fat and connective tissue without tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of solid predominant adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 3.2 cm, with both bronchial and vascular margins free of tumor and no regional lymph node metastasis (0/11 nodes involved). Molecular studies revealed no mutations in the EGFR or KRAS genes, and the ALK gene was negative for rearrangement, suggesting a potentially favorable response to targeted therapies. The tumor is classified as poorly differentiated (G3) and staged as pT2a, indicating it is greater than 3 cm but less than 5 cm in size without visceral pleura invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse malignant mesothelioma, biphasic type, in the right pleura based on biopsy samples. The seventh rib excised was found to be unremarkable. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of mesothelioma, with positive results for calretinin and negative results for TTF-1 and CD34.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation, involving the inner 40% of the myometrium, while the cervix, fallopian tubes, and ovaries are free of tumor involvement. All examined lymph nodes from both pelvic and periaortic regions are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The report also notes the presence of leiomyomata in the uterus.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma following a radical prostatectomy, with malignancy identified in the left lobe accounting for less than 5% of the total prostate volume and a Gleason score of 6/10. There is no evidence of extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, lymphovascular invasion, or high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, and the surgical margins are uninvolved. The pTNM staging is classified as pT2a, NX, and no lymph nodes were received for evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, papillary type, with focal spindle cell (sarcomatoid) growth and extensive necrosis, measuring 10.0 cm in greatest diameter. The tumor extends through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia, with no invasion of the renal vein and all surgical margins free of tumor. The non-neoplastic kidney and adrenal gland are unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 2.1 cm, with extensive lymphatic permeation and a poor nuclear grade (grade 3), while all surgical resection margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the right axillary dissection revealed that 35 out of 39 lymph nodes were positive for metastatic infiltrating ductal carcinoma, with some showing extracapsular spread. The final pathologic staging is classified as T2 N2 MX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 1 to 2, in the uterus, with a tumor size of 2.5 x 1.5 x 1.0 cm that partially invades the myometrium and shows lymphovascular space invasion, but the margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, multiple intramural leiomyomata were identified, and both right and left pelvic lymph nodes were negative for tumor involvement. The ovaries and fallopian tubes were noted to be atrophic and unremarkable.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma measuring 8.0 cm, with extensive invasion into pericolic adipose tissue and the visceral peritoneal surface, as well as angiolymphatic invasion. Metastatic adenocarcinoma is identified in 10 out of 17 examined lymph nodes, and there is serosal involvement of the appendix. Molecular testing reveals a KRAS codon 12/13 mutation associated with resistance to cetuximab therapy, and no microsatellite instability is detected, indicating a microsatellite stable status.

The pathology report confirms the diagnosis of a right frontal brain tumor classified as WHO grade III anaplastic oligodendroglioma, with evidence of 1p and 19q deletions but no EGFR amplification detected. Microscopic examination revealed a diffuse oligodendroglioma with areas of increased cellularity, pleomorphism, and mitotic activity, consistent with the diagnosis. The posterior margin resection showed reactive changes without definitive glioma involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm and classified as Fuhrman grade 3. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic or capsular invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The AJCC pathologic staging is pT1b, NX, confirming the tumor's localized nature.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a cervical lymph node measuring 2 x 1.2 x 0.6 cm, which shows a whitish and homogeneous cut surface. Histological examination reveals a diagnosis of primary mediastinal diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, characterized by atypical large cells with immunoblastic and Reed-Sternberg morphology, extending into the surrounding adipose tissue. The neoplastic cells are positive for CD20, PAX5, and partially for CD30 and CD23, with a Ki67 proliferation index of 40%, while in situ hybridization for Epstein-Barr virus is negative.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segments II and III, characterized by a 3.2 x 2.8 x 2.2 cm mass that is well-circumscribed but unencapsulated, with no vascular invasion noted. Surgical resection margins are negative for tumor following a re-excision. Additionally, the surrounding liver tissue shows mild nonspecific portal inflammation, a solitary granulomatous reaction, and trace steatosis without significant fibrosis or active steatohepatitis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, classified as NHG3. The tumor measures 1.6 x 1.2 x 1.8 cm and shows no expression of estrogen or progesterone receptors, as well as a negative HER2 status. The specimen was obtained from a total organ resection of the left breast, which weighed 600 g and did not include axillary tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma in the right hemicolectomy specimen, with the tumor measuring 4.5 cm and invading all layers of the intestinal wall and surrounding fatty tissue. The report notes that the remainder of the colon shows a hyperplastic polyp, while the appendix exhibits post-inflammatory fibrosis, and all resection margins and the large omentum are tumor-free. Additionally, all fifteen examined mesocolic and mesenteric lymph nodes are free of tumor, leading to a staging of pT3 pNO (0/15) L0, V0; G2.

The pathology report indicates a biopsy of the right coronary ligament showing dense fibrous connective tissue, while a liver resection from segment 7 reveals a poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 3.0 cm, with negative margins and no vascular invasion. The carcinoma is noted to arise in the context of cirrhosis. No regional lymph nodes were submitted for evaluation, and distant metastasis could not be assessed from the specimen.

The pathology report indicates that the bladder neck is involved with cancer, and there is positive margin involvement at the left base with a focal distance of 1-10mm. Lymph node analysis shows positivity in 5 out of 9 left pelvic lymph nodes and none in the right, with pathological staging classified as pT3b, N1, Mx. Additional findings include acute and chronic inflammation, and the specimen includes various sections of the prostate and lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with the largest tumor measuring 4.2 cm and classified as Fuhrman grade 3. All surgical margins are negative for tumor infiltration, and the lymph nodes examined show no evidence of metastasis. The overall staging is pT1N0M0, indicating localized disease without regional or distant spread.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a transmurally invasive adenocarcinoma arising in Barrett's mucosa, with a maximum tumor depth of 1.3 cm and no positive lymph nodes identified. The resection margins are free of carcinoma, and perineurial invasion is noted. The TNM classification is T3 N0 Mx, indicating advanced local disease without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) based on the examination of brain tumor tissue, which shows significant morphologic atypia and infiltrative characteristics. Approximately 10-25% of the tumor cells demonstrate MGMT expression, which is relevant for treatment considerations. The microscopic findings include marked hypercellularity, pleomorphic nuclei, and prevalent mitotic figures, consistent with a high-grade malignant glial neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates that the right kidney allograft shows severe chronic allograft nephropathy with calcific graft atherosclerosis and mild to moderate acute rejection characterized by lymphoid hyperplasia. The right native kidney reveals a 4.0 cm renal cell carcinoma of granular and clear cell type, classified as Fuhrman's nuclear grade III, with no tumor at the surgical margins and no vascular invasion. Additionally, there is a separate low-grade renal cell neoplasm measuring 0.3 cm and evidence of end-stage renal disease with multiple cysts exhibiting focal hemorrhage.

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy of the left upper lobe revealed an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.9 cm, with negative bronchial and vascular margins and lymphovascular invasion present. All 11 hilar and several other regional lymph nodes were negative for metastatic carcinoma, suggesting no spread of cancer to these areas. The tumor is classified as pT1b, indicating it is confined to the lung without direct extension or large vessel invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) following a right adrenal resection, with the tumor measuring 7.1 x 5 x 4.8 cm. The tumor is classified as pT2 pN1, with 8 out of 9 lymph nodes involved, and a low proliferation index (KI67 1-2%). The surgical margins are clear (R0), indicating no residual tumor at the resection edges.

The pathology report indicates a 7.5 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma located at the rectosigmoid junction, classified as moderately differentiated. There is no evidence of metastasis in the 12 examined lymph nodes, and the surgical margins are uninvolved. Details regarding neo-adjuvant treatment and additional pathologic findings were not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows no pathological diagnosis, while the liver exhibits chronic hepatitis B with mild activity and severe fibrosis (Stage 3). Additionally, a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 3.0 cm was identified in the liver and has been completely excised, with no evidence of endothelial-tined space invasion. The liver mass is located close to the resection margin, but the remainder of the liver parenchyma appears grossly unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates the presence of oligodendrogliomas, grade II (WHO), in three areas of the right frontal brain: the posterior part, anterior portion, and cingulate gyrus. The report notes that fluorescence in situ hybridization revealed loss of chromosomal arms 1p and 19q, which is associated with a more favorable response to adjuvant therapy. The specimens were submitted for further analysis, confirming the diagnosis of low-grade glioma consistent with oligodendroglioma.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy from a descending colon polyp revealed invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, measuring 3.5 cm in length and 2.2 cm in width, with invasion into the muscularis propria. There was no evidence of lymphovascular, perineural invasion, or metastasis in the examined lymph nodes, and the surgical margins were free of tumor. Additionally, two tubular adenomas were identified away from the carcinoma, and the tumor is staged as pT2 with no regional lymph node metastasis (N0).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, measuring 9.5 cm, with a composition of 40% clear cells and 60% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 4. The tumor is invasive into the renal vein and renal sinus adipose tissue, but the margins of resection are free of tumor, and no tumor is present in the adrenal gland. Additionally, there are foci of rhabdoid cells and multifocal necrosis noted within the tumor, but no unequivocal sarcomatoid component is identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma in the primary lung tissue of a Caucasian male patient. The tumor was processed in an OCT block with a specimen weight of 200 mg, and no treatment has been administered. Additionally, a blood sample was collected, which is reported as normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma, with the tumor involving 85% of the prostate gland and a Gleason score of 8/10, indicating a high-grade malignancy. There is no extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle involvement, but lymphovascular space invasion is present, and adenocarcinoma is noted at the surgical margin. Additionally, one of the ten examined bilateral pelvic lymph nodes contains a small metastatic carcinoma confined to the subcapsular sinus, leading to a pTNM stage of pT2c, N1, MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade spindle cell sarcoma compatible with dedifferentiated liposarcoma in a mass measuring 18.2 cm located in the right retroperitoneum, which does not invade the right kidney or adrenal gland but extends close to the resection margin. Histological examination reveals spindle cells in a palisading pattern with areas of atypical cells and a high proliferation rate, while immunohistochemical staining shows positivity for CD34, CDK4, and MDM2, with focal staining being uncharacteristic for this entity. FISH studies are pending to confirm the diagnosis, which has been reviewed and agreed upon by another pathologist.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma, WHO grade IV, in a right temporal brain lesion, with additional findings of tumor necrosis and positive staining for GFAP and CD34. The MGMT gene promoter region is found to be unmethylated, which is associated with a lack of gene silencing and may impact treatment outcomes. Fluorescence in situ hybridization analysis reveals positive amplification of the EGFR gene in 96% of the analyzed cells, suggesting a potential target for therapy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma, WHO grade IV, from a right parietal tumor biopsy, characterized by high cellularity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis. The tumor exhibits significant genetic alterations, including polysomy of chromosomes 1, 7, and 19, and monosomy of chromosome 10, with MGMT positivity in approximately 50% of the tumor and detected gene methylation. Additional FISH and immunohistochemistry studies support the diagnosis and reveal further genetic insights into the tumor's characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left ureters are negative for carcinoma, while the cystoprostatectomy specimen reveals a high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma measuring 1.6 cm with negative margins and lymphatic invasion present. Additionally, there are findings of nephrogenic adenoma and granulomatous inflammation in the bladder, with all examined lymph nodes (20 total) being negative for carcinoma. The prostate shows no tumor but does exhibit granulomatous inflammation and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme from excisional biopsies of the right frontal brain. Microscopic examination reveals a highly cellular neoplastic proliferation with anaplastic features, extensive necrosis, and microvascular thrombosis. The MIB-1 labeling index is reported at 11%, suggesting a moderate level of cellular proliferation within the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an invasive urothelial carcinoma with sarcomatoid and anaplastic features located in the right lateral wall of the bladder. The tumor is classified as high grade and shows local invasion into the muscularis propria, although no vascular invasion was identified. The specimen consisted of multiple pieces of tan soft tissue, measuring a total of 3.0 x 2.0 x 0.7 cm, and was entirely submitted for examination.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lymph node from the external jugular vein and the 23 lymph nodes from the modified radical neck dissection are all negative for malignancy. However, the resection of the gingiva and floor of mouth revealed invasive moderately-differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 4.1 cm with a thickness of 1.3 cm, and extensive invasion into the mandible. The tumor is staged as cT4 cNO cM0 (pT4 pNO, Stage IVA), with negative margins and no evidence of vascular or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical nephrectomy for a left renal mass, which was diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma measuring 6 cm with sarcomatoid features present in 10% of the tumor. The tumor has invaded the renal sinus fat (pT3a) but has negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion was identified. Pathologic findings also noted chronic inflammation and sclerosed glomeruli in the nonneoplastic kidney, with no distant metastasis observed.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph node from the right breast is negative for metastatic carcinoma, while the right breast tissue reveals multifocal infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III/III, with tumor sizes of 1.0 cm, 0.5 cm, and 1.2 cm. The tumor exhibits necrosis and microcalcifications, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, and negative HER2 status. The pathologic stage is classified as pT1c, with invasive and in situ carcinoma present near the medial margin.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma, a high-grade astrocytic neoplasm, following the resection of a 3.0 cm mass in the right temporal lobe and additional lesions in the corpus callosum. The tumor exhibits features such as nuclear anaplasia, mitotic activity, and areas of necrosis, with a MIB-1 proliferation index of 25%, suggesting aggressive behavior. Additionally, the MGMT promoter is negative for methylation, which may have implications for treatment options.

The pathology report indicates that the left inguinal lymph node contains multiple tissue fragments and is diagnosed with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, characterized by a complete loss of normal architecture and a proliferation of atypical large centroblastic cells. Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for CD20, CD79a, CD10, bcl-6, and bcl-2, with a high Ki67 proliferation index exceeding 80%, indicating aggressive tumor behavior. Additionally, a rearrangement of the MYC gene was identified, suggesting a specific genetic alteration associated with this lymphoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma, Fuhrman grade III, located in the lower pole of the right kidney, with a tumor size of 5.3 x 4.9 x 2.5 cm and extensive areas of necrosis. There is no evidence of tumor invasion into the ureteral or vascular hilar margins, and both examined lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement. The pathological staging is pT1b N0, indicating localized disease without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right parietal tumor diagnosed as an astrocytoma based on both frozen section and additional tissue examination. The tumor is characterized by a gelatinous mass measuring 3.2 x 2.5 x 2.0 cm and a smaller piece of gray-white tissue measuring 0.3 x 0.3 x 0.4 cm. The Ki67 index shows low proliferation in some areas (<1%) and higher proliferation in focal areas (approximately 28%).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (Fuhrman grade IV) in the right kidney, with significant vascular invasion and extension into perinephric tissue, while the adrenal gland and margins of resection are free of tumor. One of four intraaortic lymph nodes shows atypical cells, but the pericaval lymph nodes are reactive with no tumor detected. The tumor measures 11.5 x 7.4 cm and is classified as pT3b, indicating advanced local disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma, a high-grade malignant neoplasm measuring 18 cm, involving the lower uterine segment and cervix, characterized by a high mitotic count and significant cytologic atypia. The tumor is estrogen and progesterone receptor positive, with evidence of smooth muscle differentiation and necrosis. Additionally, the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes show no tumors, with one ovary containing a hemorrhagic corpus luteum.

The pathology report indicates an excised skin lesion from the hip, measuring 2 x 0 x 2.5 cm, which is diagnosed as malignant melanoma with ulcerated and pigmented features. Breslow's depth is noted to be 5 mm, and the surgical margins are uninvolved. There is no evidence of venous invasion, while details regarding lymph nodes and other pathologic findings are not specified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple foci of papillary carcinoma in both the left and right ovaries and fallopian tubes, as well as a malignant mixed mullerian tumor in the uterus infiltrating the myometrium with extensive vascular invasion. Additionally, metastatic papillary serous carcinoma is identified in the right paraaortic lymph node, while the omentum biopsy shows no tumor present. The tumor is characterized by a significant composition of papillary serous carcinoma and rhabdomyosarcoma, with greater than 50% myometrial invasion and lymphovascular invasion noted.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of ulcerated nodular melanoma of the acral lentiginous type located on the left foot, with a maximum thickness of 22 mm and classified as Clark level IV. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and all examined sentinel lymph nodes (five in total) are negative for tumor cells, indicating no lymphatic spread. There is evidence of possible perineural invasion, but no angiolymphatic invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a brain mass in the left temporal lobe, with a frozen section diagnosis of malignant glioma. The final diagnosis for both submitted brain mass specimens is glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV astrocytoma). The specimens were processed for further analysis, with portions submitted for permanent processing and a tumor bank.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cecum, measuring 6 x 3 cm, with invasion into the adjacent liver parenchyma. Surgical margins from the bowel and liver tissue are free of tumor, but metastatic carcinoma is present in one of thirty-seven examined pericolic lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as pT4a, N1 Mx, indicating advanced local invasion and limited lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma in the total thyroidectomy specimen, with the largest tumor nodule measuring 1.0 cm and involvement of perithyroidal adipose tissue. Two lymph nodes were positive for metastatic papillary carcinoma, and additional lymph nodes from the right neck levels 2, 3, and 4 also showed metastasis, with a total of 13 out of 28 lymph nodes positive for carcinoma. The right parathyroid gland biopsy revealed benign parathyroid tissue, and the superficial level 4 tissue was negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 4.0 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is limited to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with Fuhrman nuclear grade III/IV and a tumor size of 3.2 cm. The tumor is confined within the renal capsule, with no evidence of invasion into the renal vein or lymphatic invasion, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. The pathological stage is classified as pT1a NX MX, and the non-neoplastic kidney shows no specific abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial cancer, specifically well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma, following a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. The tumor measures 3.5 cm with 40% involvement of both the anterior and posterior endomyometrium, and it has invaded less than half the thickness of the myometrium. Additionally, there is evidence of complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia and adenomyosis, with no lymph nodes examined, resulting in a pathologic staging of pT1b, pNX, and pMX, corresponding to FIGO stage IB.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of choroidal melanoma of spindle cell type in the right eye, with the tumor measuring 13.36 x 13.42 mm and involving the optic nerve. Histological examination reveals a dome-shaped tumor with retinal invasion and minimal lymphocytic infiltrate, while the optic nerve and examined vortex veins are free of tumor. Molecular genetic analysis shows normal chromosome 1, borderline losses of chromosome 3, and gains in chromosomes 6 and 8, which will aid in assessing metastatic risk.

The pathology report indicates that the left adrenal mass is diagnosed as a pheochromocytoma, measuring 8.0 x 4.5 x 4.0 cm, with evidence of capsular and lymphovascular invasion. The tumor shows moderate nuclear pleomorphism and a diffuse growth pattern, extending into adjacent adipose tissue, and is located less than 0.1 cm from the surgical margin. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals positive staining for chromogranin A and synaptophysin, while other markers such as cytokeratin 7 and 20 are negative.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions. A radical prostatectomy revealed prostatic adenocarcinoma, acinar type, with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, involving both lobes of the prostate and approximately 15% of the examined prostate volume, but it is organ-confined with no extraprostatic extension. Additionally, multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia was identified, and all surgical margins were free of tumor.

The final diagnosis indicates a diffusely infiltrative glioma in the left temporal mass, most consistent with a low-grade oligoastrocytoma (WHO grade II). The report notes the presence of a separate lesion in the right frontal hemisphere, which exhibits features of an anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO grade III), and further comparison of the two tumors is planned following the resection of the right frontal tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis, showing positive GFAP staining in tumor cells and variable p53 expression, with additional FISH studies for 1p19q deletion ordered.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade muscle invasive urothelial cell carcinoma classified as pT2bG3, located on the posterior wall of the right side of the bladder. The tumor measures 7x6x2.5 cm, and a total of 20 lymph nodes were examined, all of which showed no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the left frontal tumor specimens are consistent with an anaplastic oligodendroglioma, Grade III, characterized by a diffusely infiltrative glial neoplasm with mild to moderate cytologic atypia and a MIB-1 labeling index of 7.0%. The tumor exhibits irregular tan-white and hemorrhagic soft tissue fragments, with varying sizes across the specimens. No microvascular proliferation or necrosis was observed in the examined sections.

The pathology report indicates the presence of grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the distal third of the esophagus, with invasion to the serous layer and uninvolved margins, but no lymph-vascular or perineural invasion noted. Additionally, there is evidence of metastasis in 3 out of 25 lesser curvature lymph nodes, while other examined lymph nodes and segments of the stomach, colon, and omentum show no signs of neoplasia. The gastric segment shows moderate chronic gastritis, and the colonic segment shows chronic colitis, both uninvolved by cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast mastectomy specimen contains an infiltrating ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated (Nottingham Grade 3), measuring 3.5 cm, with negative margins and no lymph node involvement. Additional findings include the absence of estrogen and progesterone receptors, as well as HER2 negativity, with a pathologic stage of pT2 N0 MX. The skin flap excision shows unremarkable skin and subcutaneous tissue with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of a 4.3 cm invasive, poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the left main stem bronchus, extending into the left upper and lower lobes, with no visceral pleural invasion and clear surgical margins. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma is identified in five out of seventeen sampled N1 lymph nodes, while all N2 lymph nodes are benign, resulting in a pathologic stage of T2N1Mx. Fluorescence in-situ hybridization studies indicate low-level amplification of the Her2/Neu gene, while no amplification is observed for Cyclin-D1 and EGFR genes, suggesting potential implications for patient prognosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, with the tumor measuring 4.8 x 4.0 x 4.0 cm and confined to the renal parenchyma, showing no angiolymphatic invasion and free surgical margins. Immunohistochemical studies support the diagnosis, revealing tumor cells positive for CK7 and negative for EMA. Cytogenetic analysis shows a normal karyotype, suggesting that the observed results may reflect an overgrowth of normal interstitial tissue rather than tumor.

The pathology report indicates a colectomy specimen from the colon, revealing a 9 x 8 x 2 cm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The tumor has extended into the pericolonic tissues, with all 12 examined lymph nodes showing evidence of metastasis. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no information provided regarding neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates a tumor in the right upper lobe of the lung measuring 6.5 x 5.0 x 4.5 cm, diagnosed as predominantly acinar adenocarcinoma. There is infiltration of the visceral pleura, classified as pT2, with no regional lymph node involvement (0/14) and an unknown distant metastasis (pMx). The tumor is graded as G2, indicating moderate differentiation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left frontal brain tumor diagnosed as Glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV astrocytoma) based on multiple specimens analyzed. The frozen section diagnoses reveal a highly infiltrative glial neoplasm with areas of low to intermediate-grade histology, alongside regions exhibiting increased cellularity, pleomorphism, vascular proliferation, and necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis shows strong reactivity for GFAP and variable Ki-67 labeling indices, supporting the diagnosis of a malignant glioma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a Grade 2 large cell nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the cervical cone, with stromal invasion and vascular space invasion identified. The tumor measures at least 7.0 mm in depth and 10.0 mm in lateral extension, affecting all sections of the specimen. Additionally, the endocervical curettings revealed blood clot with scant fragments of squamous cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the right and left pelvic lymph nodes, with a total of 11 nodes examined (0/7 and 0/4, respectively). The prostate shows the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3), confined to the prostate and with free resection margins, while perineural invasion is noted and no lymphovascular invasion is identified. Additionally, there are four tumor foci within the prostate, with the largest measuring 1.4 x 0.5 cm, and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) is also present.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical prostatectomy due to prostate cancer, with a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 8, involving 30% of the left lobe and 10% of the right lobe, with perineural invasion present but no seminal vesicle involvement. A total of 34 lymph nodes were examined from various regions, and none showed evidence of tumor metastasis. The surgical margins are free from invasive carcinoma, but there are areas suspicious for vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, classified as NHG3, with a tumor size of 2.2 x 2.0 x 1.5 cm and associated lymphonodulitis in the axillary lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical analysis shows no estrogen receptors and low progesterone receptor expression (less than 10%), with a negative HER2 status (Score = 1+). The specimen was obtained from a modified radical mastectomy, and the tumor is located in the outer quadrants of the breast.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent an adrenalectomy, revealing a mass measuring 8 X 7 X 7 cm and weighing 212 grams. The final diagnosis is adrenocortical carcinoma, with a low KI67 index of 1% and a mitotic rate of less than 1 per 10 high power fields. The tumor was assessed using various scoring systems, resulting in a Weiss score of 5, Hough score of 3.37, and Van Slooten score of 17.8.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of locally advanced, mixed adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, characterized by a predominant large-cell component and a bronchioloalveolar growth pattern. The tumor is classified as pT4 pN3 L1 V1 R0, corresponding to stage IIIB, with evidence of invasion into small blood vessels and lymph nodes, as well as multiple lymph node metastases. However, the visceral pleura and resection margins are tumor-free, indicating no residual disease at those sites.

The pathology report indicates a mixed germ cell tumor in the left testis, primarily consisting of 95% embryonal carcinoma and 5% yolk sac tumor, measuring 4.5 cm.
