There is evidence of intratubular embryonal carcinoma, multiple foci of angiolymphatic vascular invasion, and infiltration of the rete testis, tunica albuginea, and focal infiltration at the base of the spermatic cord, with an intravascular neoplastic embolus present. The epididymis and tunica vaginalis are reported as uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder and lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy, with chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis noted. In contrast, the liver resection reveals a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma consistent with primary intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma, measuring 11.5 cm, with positive margins at the hepatic parenchymal margin. The report confirms no definitive lymphovascular or perineural invasion, and the overall AJCC pathologic stage is pT1 pNO.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 1.7 cm, with a histologic grade of III and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of high nuclear grade. Sentinel lymph node biopsies from both the left and right axillae revealed no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, with all examined lymph nodes being benign. Additional immunohistochemical staining results are pending, but initial findings suggest the invasive tumor cells exhibit complete membranous staining for HER-2, with equivocal results.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of malignant melanoma measuring 4.2 cm with focal superficial ulceration and inflammation on the left shoulder, with resection margins free of neoplasm but the deep margin being close at 0.1 cm. Sentinel lymph node biopsies from the left axilla revealed two benign lymph nodes, both negative for metastatic melanoma or malignancy. Additional examination of the deep margin and soft tissue also showed no evidence of malignant melanoma or melanocytic lesions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (5 + 4), involving 30% of the prostate gland and showing extraprostatic extension at the left apex and left base, as well as into the bladder neck. The carcinoma extends to the right distal apical resection margin, but all other margins, including the bladder neck and peripheral margins, are free of tumor. Additionally, five bilateral pelvic lymph nodes were examined, and none showed evidence of malignancy (0/5).

The pathology report indicates a resected colon sample from the rectum containing an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that has infiltrated the perimuscular fatty tissue. The tumor-free margins suggest complete resection, but there are several local lymph node metastases and left-sided adrenal metastases present. The tumor is classified as G2, pT3, L1, V1, pN2, with 7 out of 40 lymph nodes showing metastasis and evidence of distant metastasis (pM1).

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows signs of chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis, while the right lobe of the liver has been diagnosed with moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (grade II), measuring approximately 15 cm, with no vascular invasion noted. The tumor is confined to the liver, with resection margins being close but uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and there is evidence of portal vascular inflammation likely related to pre-operative embolization. Overall, the findings suggest a solitary liver tumor with no significant underlying liver disease or cirrhosis.

The pathology report indicates that a thymectomy specimen weighing 97 grams was examined, revealing a well-defined Type B2 thymoma measuring 3.5 x 3 x 2.5 cm, with no tumor extension or lymphovascular invasion identified. The tumor margins are uninvolved, with the closest margin being less than 1 mm from the tumor, and one intrathymic lymph node examined was negative for malignancy. The final pathologic staging is Stage I, and no distant metastases were detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 8.2 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of TII/IV, and approximately 60% of the tumor mass is viable, while margins are negative for tumor. The tumor is localized to the kidney, with no lymphovascular or venous invasion, and there are also findings of moderate diabetic glomerulosclerosis and advanced sclerosing changes in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue. Cytogenetic analysis revealed a normal karyotype with no detectable chromosomal abnormalities, although the limited study may not rule out mosaicism.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma, dominant follicular variant, measuring 2.2 cm in the right lobe of the thyroid, with a second smaller microcarcinoma of 0.1 cm also present in the same lobe. The tumor exhibits minimal capsular invasion, but there is no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion, and the margins are uninvolved by carcinoma. Overall, the morphological features suggest a low-risk papillary carcinoma, with no regional lymph node metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 5.3 cm and unifocality. The tumor shows extrathyroidal extension and involved margins, but there is no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis. Additionally, there is evidence of venous and lymphatic invasion, and nodular hyperplasia is noted as an additional finding.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically chromophobe-type with areas of high-grade sarcomatoid differentiation, with the tumor approaching but not penetrating the capsule, and free margins at vascular and ureteral sites. The adrenal gland shows no evidence of tumor, and the excised retroperitoneal lymph nodes are reactive with marked sinus histiocytosis, but also show no tumor involvement. The left kidney specimen was significantly enlarged, weighing 3,800 grams, with a large mass lesion occupying most of the tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a wide local excision of the right breast, revealing an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm with focal necrosis and negative surgical margins. Additionally, sentinel lymph node #1 showed micrometastatic carcinoma, while sentinel lymph node #2 was negative for metastases. The tumor is classified as SBR Grade 2, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative HER2 status.

The pathology report indicates the presence of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver, characterized by a single encapsulated tumor measuring 14.0 x 10.0 x 8.0 cm, with negative resection margins and no extra-tumoral vascular invasion. The gallbladder shows signs of acute and chronic serositis without gallstones, while lymph nodes from the common hepatic artery and retro choledochal regions are negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, the submitted soft tissue from the supra-duodenal region reveals benign fibroadipose tissue with no lymph node identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC) with a nuclear grade of IV and a tumor size of 9.5 cm, which extends through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of renal vein invasion or involvement of the adrenal gland; additionally, the examined lymph nodes from both para-aortic and suprahilar regions are free of tumor. The staging for the renal cell carcinoma is classified as pT3a, indicating local invasion but no distant spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, papillary type II, with a tumor size of 17.5 cm and a nuclear grade of III, but no evidence of invasion into surrounding structures or lymph nodes. The adrenal gland is reported as free of malignancy, and surgical margins are clear of cancer. The pathological stage is classified as pT2, indicating a localized tumor without significant spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 1 (of 4) renal cell carcinoma, papillary type, in a mass measuring 1.9 x 1.7 x 1.7 cm from the left kidney. The tumor is confined to the kidney with no evidence of coagulative necrosis or sarcomatoid differentiation, and the surgical margins are negative for tumor, indicating they are free by 0.2 cm. The report was revised to correct the tumor type from clear cell to papillary.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, tall cell variant, with the primary tumor located in the right lobe measuring 2.2 cm and exhibiting focal blood vessel invasion and extrathyroid extension. Additionally, there are multiple foci of papillary microcarcinoma in the left lobe, with the largest measuring 0.8 cm, and surgical margins are close to the microcarcinoma. The report notes the presence of nodular hyperplasia in non-neoplastic thyroid tissue and identifies two benign perithyroidal lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated, keratinizing invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 8.0 cm with a depth of invasion of 1.3 cm, and it is located 0.1 cm from the closest deep cervical margin and 1.0 cm from the vaginal cuff margin. No malignancy was found in the examined lymph nodes or adnexal structures, which included benign findings such as hemorrhagic corpus luteum cysts and leiomyomas. Additional findings included adenomyosis and benign secretory endometrium, with the tumor extensively replacing the cervix but not invading surrounding structures.

The pathology report indicates that the right pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor (0/6), while the left pelvic lymph nodes contain metastatic high-grade urothelial carcinoma in 4 of 5 nodes, with the largest metastasis measuring 1.4 cm. The cystoprostatectomy reveals invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 3.2 cm, with extensive angiolymphatic invasion, and prostate adenocarcinoma (Gleason score 8) involving both seminal vesicles and not confined to the prostatic capsule. Overall, the findings suggest advanced urothelial carcinoma with lymphatic spread and concurrent prostate cancer, necessitating further staging and management considerations.

The pathology report indicates the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver, characterized by two well-defined masses with the worst differentiation graded III/IV. The surgical margins are clear of tumor invasion, and the remaining liver parenchyma shows signs of cirrhosis and chronic hepatitis due to HBV. Additionally, the gallbladder exhibits chronic cholecystitis, and there is evidence of Clonorchis sinensis infestation in the submitted tissue samples.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast total mastectomy revealed infiltrating ductal carcinoma, with two distinct foci: one well-differentiated (2.0 cm) and another moderately differentiated (0.6 cm), alongside extensive ductal carcinoma in situ. Sentinel lymph node biopsies showed one node with isolated tumor cells, while the other nodes were negative for carcinoma. The tumors were positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, with equivocal HER2 expression in one focus and positive in another.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO grade III) in the brain, characterized by a neoplastic proliferation of malignant astrocytic cells with elongated hyperchromatic nuclei and moderate hypercellularity. The tumor exhibits mitotic activity but shows no evidence of vascular proliferation or necrosis. Two separate specimens were analyzed, both confirming the diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.0 cm, with surgical margins free of tumor. Two lymph nodes removed during the procedure showed no evidence of tumor (0/2). The report suggests that the lung tumor may represent a new primary lung cancer rather than metastatic disease from a prior laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma, as the tumors exhibit similar characteristics.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a lung specimen obtained from a pulmonectomy, measuring 3 x 2.5 x 2.5 cm. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes, with 0 out of 3 nodes positive for cancer. Additional details regarding tumor extent, invasion, and margins were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 4 cm and invading into the vaginal wall (pT4a), with vascular invasion noted. Both ureteral margins and lymph nodes from the left and right pelvic regions were negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings include areas of urothelial atypia and focal neuroendocrine differentiation within the tumor, with extensive necrosis observed.

The pathology report indicates that one of two right axillary sentinel lymph nodes tested positive for micrometastatic invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 0.98 mm. The right breast excisional biopsy revealed a 5.3 cm invasive lobular carcinoma, grade 2, with tumor involvement at the posterior and inferior margins, and less than 1 mm from the anterior margin, raising suspicion for lymphatic space invasion. Microscopic examination confirmed the presence of invasive lobular carcinoma with no ductal carcinoma in situ identified, and the report noted changes at the core biopsy site.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal (tubulo-lobular) carcinoma, SBR grade II, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and significant lymph node involvement, as 20 out of 29 lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma. The invasive carcinoma measures 4.5 cm, with DCIS present within the main mass, and there is evidence of necrosis and microcalcifications. Additionally, there is extranodal extension noted, and the tumor exhibits strong expression of estrogen and progesterone receptors, while Her2/neu is non-amplified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous carcinoma in the left tonsil, with a tumor size of approximately 2.7 cm and no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. While the deep superior margin biopsy confirmed the presence of carcinoma, other margins (deep inferior, superior, anterior, posterior) showed no invasive carcinoma, although focal dysplastic squamous epithelium was noted at the anterior margin. All surgical margins were assessed as positive for carcinoma, and the final staging is classified as pT2, pNx, pMx, suggesting further evaluation is needed for comprehensive staging.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately-differentiated squamous carcinoma in the anterior commissure and invasive squamous carcinoma in the right true vocal cord, with extensions into the supraglottic and subglottic regions, as well as invasion into the right paraglottic space. The tumor crosses the midline to involve the left anterior vocal cord, but no lymphatic or vascular invasion is identified, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, biopsies from the posterior wall of the esophagus and thyroid show no tumor present.

The pathology report indicates that both sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla are negative for tumor involvement based on histological examination. The right breast mastectomy reveals a well-differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 2.4 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ and no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion, and negative margins. The tumor is classified as AJCC stage pT2N0M0, and the findings correlate with the pre-operative diagnosis of ruling out ductal carcinoma in situ.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of colorectal type in the resected colon, measuring 2.5 cm and infiltrating the tunica muscularis propria. There are no tumor cells found in the lymph nodes or at the resection margins. The tumor is staged as pT2 pNO (0/21) pMX; G2, with no lymphovascular or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left parietal glioblastoma (WHO grade IV) with a high proliferation index of 33%, characterized by significant nuclear anaplasia, mitotic activity, and tumor necrosis. The MGMT promoter is methylated, suggesting potential responsiveness to alkylating agent therapy, while no evidence of the EGFRvIII mutation was detected. The tumor exhibits strong immunoreactivity for GFAP and p53, confirming its aggressive nature.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 3.2 cm with 40% invasion into the cervical wall, but with negative surgical margins. Sentinel lymph nodes and regional lymph nodes were examined, revealing no evidence of tumor in 37 lymph nodes, although isolated tumor cells were identified in one sentinel lymph node. Additional findings include a uterine leiomyoma and a right hydrosalpinx, with the overall AJCC pathologic stage reported as pT2a1 pNO (itc) pMX.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive moderately to poorly differentiated cholangiocarcinoma located in the distal common bile duct, measuring 4.3 x 3.1 x 0.8 cm, with extension into the pancreas and evidence of perineural invasion. All surgical resection margins, including the uncinate margin, are negative for tumor, with a minimum tumor-free margin of 1.0 cm. Additionally, multiple regional lymph nodes and the gallbladder are negative for metastatic tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 3.2 cm invasive, moderate-to-poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas, with invasion into the duodenal wall and surrounding fat, along with lymphovascular and perineural invasion. The tumor is located within 0.5 mm of the pancreatic margin and 1.0 mm of the vascular groove resection margin, with metastatic adenocarcinoma found in 2 out of 18 lymph nodes, resulting in a pathologic stage of pT3 N1 MX. Additionally, a cholecystectomy revealed chronic cholecystitis, and pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN 3) was noted as an additional finding.

The pathology report indicates that the left temporal lobe lesion is diagnosed as a glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV). Microscopic examination reveals a highly cellular neoplasm with significant atypia, including nuclear pleomorphism, necrosis, and microvascular proliferation. The tumor demonstrates diffuse infiltration into the brain parenchyma, confirming its aggressive nature.

The pathology report describes a mediastinal tumor characterized by lymphoepithelial proliferation with atypical epithelial cells and limited lymphocytes, with complete resection noted. Additionally, there is evidence of tumor infiltration in the lower left parietal pleura, while other sampled areas show no tumor infiltration. The final diagnosis is B3 thymoma at Stage IVA, with no invasion of the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma (advanced gastric cancer) located in the antrum of the stomach, with a tumor size of 8.5 x 7.5 x 1.5 cm and a depth of invasion classified as T3. The resection margins are negative for tumor, and there is no evidence of lymph node metastasis (0/81 lymph nodes examined). Additionally, a cystic lymphangioma was identified in the mesenteric cystic wall, but no tumor was present in the associated lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a lobectomy specimen from the lung, revealing a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 6 x 6 x 6 cm, with tumor extent involving the visceral pleura. Out of three examined lymph nodes, one shows positive metastasis. Additional details regarding lymphatic and venous invasion, margins, and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment were not specified.

The pathology report indicates a 5.1 x 3.2 x 2.6 cm tumor in the left lower lobe of the lung, diagnosed as Squamous Cell Carcinoma, not otherwise specified (NOS). There is infiltration of the visceral pleura, and the tumor is classified as pT2b, pN1 (with 2 out of 33 lymph nodes involved), and pMx, with a grade of G3. This suggests a moderately advanced stage of cancer with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, grade IV, located in the left frontal lobe, characterized by a pleomorphic proliferation of infiltrative astrocytic cells, abundant endothelial proliferation, extensive necrosis, and a brisk mitotic rate. Multiple specimens were noted, with some not received, but the findings consistently support the diagnosis of a high-grade malignant glioma. The report emphasizes the need for further tissue if clinically indicated due to the suspicious nature of the findings.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a left ovarian tumor diagnosed as predominantly serous papillary adenocarcinoma with foci of clear cell adenofibroma and focal mucinous adenocarcinoma. Additionally, there is an exophytic papillary transitional cell carcinoma of the renal pelvis in the left kidney, classified as grade 2 with no stromal invasion, along with cystitis glandularis. All examined lymph nodes and other tissues, including the left fallopian tube and omentum, were negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a 5x6x2.5 cm exophytic adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as well differentiated. The tumor extends into the submucosa, but details regarding lymph nodes, invasions, margins, and evidence of neoadjuvant treatment are not specified. No additional pathologic findings or comments were provided in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with anaplastic mixed glioma (oligoastrocytoma, WHO Grade III) based on the examination of two tumor specimens from a left temporal brain tumor. The tumor exhibits infiltrative characteristics with moderate nuclear pleomorphism, significant mitotic activity, and a Ki67 labeling index of 10-15%, while showing no deletions of chromosomes 1p or 19q. The findings suggest a predominantly diffuse anaplastic astrocytoma pattern, with some areas resembling oligodendroglioma, and further analysis of the tumor's genetic markers is pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the left and right ovaries, left and right fallopian tubes, uterus, and omentum, with extensive lymphovascular space invasion noted. The left fallopian tube shows invasive carcinoma with surrounding in situ carcinoma, while the right ovary exhibits surface involvement and a significant tumor burden. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma is present in one of three examined lymph nodes, highlighting the aggressive nature of the disease.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated, non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 28 mm in the left upper lobe of the lung, with subepithelial and intramural infiltration of a subsegmental bronchus, but without pleural infiltration or hemangioinvasion. The resection margins are tumor-free, and the examined lymph nodes show anthracotic pigment without any signs of tumor involvement. The overall classification of the tumor is M-8070/3, G3, pT 1, pN 0, pMX, stage IA.

The pathology report indicates that a total thyroidectomy was performed on a female patient diagnosed with papillary thyroid carcinoma, with the largest tumor measuring 1.7 cm located in the isthmus of the thyroid. The tumor shows no capsular or vascular invasion, and the surgical margins are negative for cancer. Additionally, five lymph nodes from the central neck were excised and found to be negative for carcinoma, with benign thymic tissue identified.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total laryngectomy and right hemi-thyroidectomy due to a moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.4 cm, with a depth of invasion of 2.0 cm. All examined lymph nodes (76 total) were negative for malignancy, and the surgical margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, although the right superior pharyngeal margin was very close to the tumor. Additional findings included hypercellular parathyroid tissue and no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade renal cell carcinoma (RCC) with tubulopapillary features, measuring 6.5 cm, and exhibiting local invasion into renal hilar fat and angiolymphatic invasion in the renal vein. The adrenal gland is involved by metastatic carcinoma, and out of 10 examined periaortic lymph nodes, 4 show metastatic disease with extranodal extension. The tumor is staged as pT3b, indicating significant local extension into the renal vein or vena cava.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from the left lung lobectomy are negative for tumor involvement. An anterior mediastinal mass is diagnosed as a type AB thymoma with microscopic transcapsular invasion and involved margins. Additionally, a 2.5 cm adenocarcinoma is identified in the left upper lobe, with a focus of metastatic carcinoma in one of the hilar lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma following an extended right hepatectomy, with a tumor measuring 7.6 x 6.3 x 4.5 cm and located very close to the resection margin. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic space invasion, and four perihilar lymph nodes examined are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The surrounding liver tissue shows only minimal changes.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen with a tumor measuring 7 x 6 x 2 cm, identified as moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. Out of 8 lymph nodes examined, 3 were positive for metastasis. Specific details regarding the extent of invasion and margins were not provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant germ cell tumor, predominantly embryonal carcinoma, in the right testicle, measuring 4.5 cm, with no invasion into surrounding structures and free surgical margins. There is evidence of lymphovascular invasion, and while there is a mildly elevated AFP level suggesting a possible yolk sac tumor component, it was not identified in the sampled sections. The tumor is staged as pT2, and further comprehensive review is recommended for final staging.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade III serous carcinoma involving an endometrial polyp, with additional findings of a submucosal leiomyoma and a mixture of serous and grade I endometrioid carcinoma in the endometrium. There is focal superficial invasion, but no lymphovascular space involvement, and the cervix is unremarkable. All biopsies from the omentum, lymph nodes, and various staging sites are negative for tumor, indicating no metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, tall cell variant, located in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 2.7 cm, with involvement of the thyroid capsule but no extension beyond the thyroid. Additionally, metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma is identified in one perithyroidal lymph node, and the pathologic stage is classified as T2N1MX. The total thyroidectomy specimen was examined, revealing a well-circumscribed tumor while the remaining thyroid tissue appeared normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive hepatocellular carcinoma in the right liver, with a tumor size of 12 cm that extends to the surgical margin and shows evidence of necrosis and capsular disruption. Additionally, the gallbladder shows cholesterolosis without evidence of gallstones, and two lymph nodes examined show no tumor involvement. Overall, the findings suggest a significant liver malignancy with potential complications related to tumor extension.

The pathology report indicates that the left pelvic lymph node biopsy shows no evidence of malignancy, as does the right pelvic lymph node biopsy, with a total of four lymph nodes examined and none involved. However, the prostatectomy reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3 (7/10), involving 90% of the prostate tissue and showing extraprostatic extension, including invasion of the seminal vesicles and involvement of the right distal urethral margin and bilateral lateral margins. The pathologic staging is pT3bN0M(not applicable), indicating seminal vesicle invasion and no regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma in the left ovary, with additional findings of metastatic carcinoma in the omentum and colon, as well as involvement of the cervix and endometrial polyp. The right ovary shows a serous cystadenoma and the right fallopian tube has obstructing papillary serous carcinoma. Overall, the findings suggest advanced-stage ovarian cancer with extensive peritoneal spread, classified as FIGO stage IIIC.

The pathology report indicates that a right orchidectomy was performed, revealing a seminoma with a diameter of 6 cm. There is evidence of lymphatic invasion and invasion of the rete testis. These findings suggest a more aggressive tumor behavior.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated, following a Whipple procedure, with the tumor measuring 4 x 3.5 x 2.5 cm and invading adjacent structures, including the duodenum. Additionally, there is evidence of low-grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia in the additional pancreatic margin, but no carcinoma or high-grade dysplasia is present. The report notes that the margins are free of tumor, with lymphatic and perineural invasion observed, and acute and chronic pancreatitis are also noted as additional findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with the largest tumor measuring 4 cm and classified as grade 2, showing angiolymphatic invasion. Out of 18 examined axillary lymph nodes, 7 were positive for metastatic carcinoma, with focal extracapsular extension noted, while surgical margins were negative. Additional findings include strong positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors, and a Ki-67 proliferation index of 24%, indicating a high level of tumor activity.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant mixed Mllerian tumor (MMMT) with heterologous chondroid elements and endometrioid-type epithelial components, invading more than 50% of the myometrial thickness, while the cervix remains uninvolved and surgical margins are free of tumor. All examined lymph nodes (left pelvic, right pelvic, and periaortic) and the omentum are negative for malignancy. The tumor is classified as FIGO grade II endometrioid carcinoma, with a pathological stage of pT1c NO Mx.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lung, measuring 10 cm, with no visceral pleura invasion and negative bronchial margins. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, with one lymph node showing metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while the others were negative for malignancy or exhibited benign features. The report confirms the diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma and provides detailed descriptions of the lymph nodes and lung tissues analyzed.

The pathology report describes a segment of the large intestine with a 5.5 cm cauliflower-shaped ulcerous tumor diagnosed as a tubulopapillary and partially mucinous adenocarcinoma (G3) located at the hepatic flexure. The tumor infiltrates the muscularis propria and pericolonic adipose tissue, with lymph node metastases identified in 3 out of 6 examined nodes. The surgical margins are clear of neoplastic lesions, and the adjacent omentum is free of cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a poorly differentiated invasive malignant tumor measuring 3.5 cm, characterized by focal in situ spread and significant angioinvasion. The tumor is classified as lobular carcinoma, not otherwise specified (NOS), grade III, with a staging of oT2N3aL1V1RX. The findings suggest a primary tumor with notable pathological features.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from the right adrenal gland shows extensive replacement by a neoplastic infiltrate, consistent with a primary adrenal cortical carcinoma, characterized by highly pleomorphic cells and areas of necrosis and hemorrhage. Immunohistochemical staining reveals some positive markers, but the overall findings suggest a malignant tumor rather than lymphoma or melanoma. Electron microscopy supports the diagnosis of adrenal cortical carcinoma, although the preservation quality limits definitive conclusions.

The pathology report confirms the presence of parathyroid tissue and diagnoses papillary thyroid carcinoma of the right lobe, measuring 1.5 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and negative resection margins. Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma is identified in four of seventeen lymph nodes, with the largest focus measuring 0.4 cm, and in three of eight lymph nodes from right levels 3, 4, and 5, with focal extracapsular extension. The background thyroid shows multinodular adenomatous goiter.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO grade III) with a MIB-1 labeling index of 8.6%, suggesting a high proliferation rate. The tumor exhibits diffuse infiltration, with varying degrees of hypercellularity and atypia, and numerous mitotic figures are observed. Notably, there is no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis in the examined sections.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous papillary adenocarcinoma of the uterus, with direct extension from the endometrium and stromal invasion, measuring 6 mm deep into the myometrium. There is no evidence of malignancy in the bilateral ovaries, fallopian tubes, or in any of the examined lymph nodes, totaling 37 nodes. The tumor is classified as high grade and is staged as T2b/NO/MO (Stage IIB).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial cancer, specifically a poorly differentiated mixed tumor with endometrioid and papillary serous features, measuring 6.6 x 4.5 x 0.9 cm, with myometrial invasion of 0.9 cm. Surgical margins are free of malignancy, and all examined lymph nodes (18 total) are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The final staging is pT2NO, indicating the tumor has invaded the myometrium but no lymph node involvement is present.

The pathology report indicates a unifocal papillary carcinoma measuring 1.5 x 1 x 1 cm located on the left side. The tumor is characterized by papillae with a fibrovascular stalk, covered by cuboidal epithelial cells that maintain polarity, and shows signs of fibrous tissue and lymphocyte invasion. The nuclei of the tumor cells are regular with finely dispersed chromatin and intranuclear grooves, but the report does not specify whether there is extension beyond the capsule.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with endometrioid, serous, and transitional features in the right adnexa, measuring 11.5 cm, and moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with serous and endometrioid features in the left adnexa, measuring 5.8 cm. Other findings include focal cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 1) in the uterus and various biopsies from the diaphragm, bladder flaps, cul-de-sac, pelvic sidewalls, lymph nodes, and omentum, all of which were negative for tumor. Overall, the report highlights significant malignancies in the adnexal regions while the majority of other sampled tissues show benign or non-tumorous changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), located in the right lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm. The tumor is classified as Grade II and is staged as T2b N1 M0, indicating regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. The sample was obtained through a resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 4 squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, with a 2.0 x 2.0 x 1.5 cm mass located 1.8 cm from the bronchial margin, which is negative for tumor. Additionally, the left hilar region shows Grade 4 non-small cell carcinoma with squamous features, while multiple lymph nodes from various regions are negative for neoplasm, although one intraparenchymal lymph node exhibits non-necrotizing granulomatous inflammation. Special stains for microorganisms will be reported separately in an addendum.

The pathology report indicates that the left adrenal resection specimen is diagnosed as a pheochromocytoma, characterized by a tan tumor mass with fibrous adhesion and cystic spaces. Microscopic examination reveals large polygonal cells arranged in nests, with features such as nuclear pleomorphism and areas of hemorrhage, but no lymphovascular invasion. Immunohistochemical staining confirms the diagnosis, showing strong positivity for synaptophysin and chromogranin, consistent with pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lung lobe mass is diagnosed as moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma, measuring 2.5 cm in greatest dimension, with no evidence of vascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes (a total of 9) are negative for metastatic carcinoma, confirming no regional lymph node involvement. The final pathologic TNM stage is classified as IA (T1 N0 Mx).

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a male, has been diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, classified as T4a N1 M0. The examination was conducted to assess the margins of the collected laryngeal tissue specimens. The findings confirm the presence of advanced laryngeal carcinoma without distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the left lower lobe segmentectomy contains well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with Clara cell features, which shows strong expression of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) but does not overexpress HER2/neu. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis reveals an increased copy number of the EGFR gene in 95% of tumor cells, with a ratio indicating potential gene amplification. The regional lymph nodes examined show no evidence of malignancy, and the overall pathology stage is classified as pT1 pN0 pMx.

The pathology report indicates that the left frontal tumor biopsy and excision both reveal an oligodendroglioma classified as WHO grade II. Molecular analysis shows no loss of the 1p36 and 19q loci, which is consistent with the characteristics of oligodendrogliomas. The microscopic examination confirms the presence of an infiltrating glial neoplasm with a low proliferation index of 3-4%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma in the right breast, classified as Nottingham grade II (of III), with a mass measuring 2.8 x 2.6 x 2 cm and no lymphovascular involvement or carcinoma in situ detected. The surgical margins are negative for tumor after re-excision, and the surrounding breast tissue shows duct ectasia and stromal fibrosis. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes, including the sentinel lymph node and three axillary lymph nodes, are negative for tumor, with positive staining for estrogen and progesterone receptors.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma in a biopsy and excision of a mass from the left temporal lobe, characterized by features such as nuclear anaplasia, mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis. The MIB-1 proliferation index is low at 5%, and the MGMT promoter is found to be methylated, suggesting potential benefit from alkylating agent therapy. The tumor infiltrates the surrounding cerebral tissue and shows high histological grade glioma characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the tissue anterior to the prostate and the pelvic lymph nodes show no tumor presence, while the prostate gland reveals adenocarcinoma with extraprostatic extension, classified as pT3a, with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3). There is evidence of lymphatic and perineural invasion, but no tumor is detected in the seminal vesicles or at the margins of the prostate, soft tissue, urethra, and bladder neck. The specimen was obtained through a radical prostatectomy, weighing 40 grams, and the tumor is noted to be present on both the right and left sides of the prostate.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a locally advanced, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the rectum, which is ulcerated and extends to within 2 mm of the perirectal resection margin. The tumor shows deep infiltration into the perimuscular fatty tissue and includes lymph and blood vessel involvement, with numerous regional lymph node metastases identified. The resection margins are tumor-free, classified as R0, with a pathological staging of pT3, L1, V1, and pN2 (20 out of 34 lymph nodes involved).

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a completion lobectomy of the right thyroid lobe, revealing an encapsulated papillary thyroid carcinoma of the follicular variant, measuring 3.0 cm, which is confined to the right lobe with no evidence of invasion into the tumor capsule or vascular invasion. The surgical margins are free of carcinoma, and there are incidental findings of C-cell hyperplasia. Molecular studies showed PAX8/PPARg rearrangement, and immunohistochemical stains were positive for Galectin-3 and PPAR gamma, confirming the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, specifically an infiltrating type classified as advanced gastric cancer. The tumor measures 5.3 x 4.0 x 0.5 cm and is located in the anterior wall of the proximal antrum, with lymphovascular invasion present and one out of thirteen examined lymph nodes showing metastatic carcinoma. The proximal and distal resection margins are negative for tumor, and there is no gross serosal invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a tumor size of 4.5 x 3.5 x 2 cm and moderate to poorly differentiated histologic grade. Two of the lymph nodes examined were positive for metastatic carcinoma, while other lymph nodes and the right uterine artery biopsy were negative for malignancy. The final staging is pT1b2N1 (FIGO IB2), and there are associated findings of endosalpingiosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated (grade III) serous carcinoma originating from the left ovary, with metastases identified in the uterine serosa, left infundibular ligament, omentum, sigmoid colon, ileum, and appendix. The report notes that the cervix, right ovary, and pelvic lymph nodes showed no significant abnormalities or tumor presence. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IIIc, with extensive necrosis and no lymphatic or vascular invasion detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma of the anterior floor of the mouth, with invasion into the mandible and extension into subcutaneous tissue and skin. The resection margins of the mandible are reported to be free of tumor, while severe squamous dysplasia and carcinoma in situ are noted at the right posterior tongue mucosal margin. Additionally, no tumor is present in the right submandibular lymph node, and the other mucosal and soft tissue margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with one lymph node showing a microscopic focus of carcinoma out of thirty examined. The left and right pelvic lymph nodes were negative for tumor involvement, and the uterus, bilateral tubes, and ovaries showed atrophic changes and leiomyomas without evidence of malignancy. The tumor is multifocal, with a depth of invasion into extravesicular soft tissue, classified as pT3a, N1, MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 7 (predominantly 3+4) and areas of 8 (4+4), involving 35% of the left lobe and 20% of the right lobe, with perineural invasion present but no extra-capsular or seminal vesicle invasion. A total of 34 lymph nodes were examined, with no evidence of metastasis found in any of them. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the patient underwent a radical prostatectomy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in the left kidney, left colon, and retroperitoneum, with the tumor measuring 8.0 x 7.5 x 7.5 cm and showing focal areas of necrosis and a high mitotic count. The adjacent colon and renal parenchyma are unremarkable, and margins for colonic, renal vascular, and ureter are negative for tumor. Additionally, an intra-abdominal blood clot was noted with no tumor present, and the splenic tissue showed reactive changes without evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade mullerian-derived adenocarcinoma (papillary serous type) in both the right and left ovaries, with metastasis observed in periureteral tissue and lymph nodes. Additionally, pelvic adhesions and omental tissue were examined, revealing predominantly mature adipose tissue and reactive changes, but no malignancy was found in those areas. Overall, the findings confirm a diagnosis of advanced ovarian cancer with metastatic involvement.

The pathology report describes a 4.2x3.2x0.4 cm tan tumor in the right adrenal gland, exhibiting central necrosis and close proximity to the resection margin, with laceration of the specimen noted. The tumor is consistent with a clinical diagnosis of pheochromocytoma, showing strong immunohistochemical staining for synaptophysin and weak staining for chromogranin, along with the identification of sustentacular cells by S100. The proliferation index is low, with a Ki67 value of less than 1%, confirming the final diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has right breast cancer with a diagnosis of invasive pleomorphic lobular carcinoma, grade III, and extensive angiolymphatic invasion. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in both the sentinel lymph nodes (2 out of 2) and in three of twenty-nine lymph nodes from the right axillary contents, with evidence of extracapsular extension. The margins from the lumpectomy and final inferior margin show residual carcinoma but are negative for tumor at the new margin.

The pathology report indicates the presence of numerous MIB-1 reactive cells throughout the tumor, with a calculated labeling index of 22.9% in the most proliferative areas. The diagnosis is anaplastic astrocytoma, classified as grade III. The MIB-1 index of 22.9% suggests a high level of cellular proliferation within the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a primary brain tumor diagnosed as an astrocytoma, specifically located in the left temporal and parietal lobes. The specimen was obtained from a Caucasian male and processed as an OCT block. There are no additional findings or treatments noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 5 cm, with uninvolved surgical margins and no evidence of direct extension or vascular invasion. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from various levels show no evidence of metastatic disease. Overall, the findings suggest localized lung cancer without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland, with no evidence of vascular invasion or necrosis, and the tumor measures a maximum dimension of 4 cm. The specimen is described as a red-tan soft tissue mass, weighing 54.07 grams, and shows normal adrenal tissue surrounding the tumor. The findings confirm the pre-operative diagnosis of pheochromocytoma, with representative sections submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma with extensive invasion into the muscularis propria from a bladder tumor biopsy. The specimen consisted of multiple fragments of tissue and blood clot, weighing a total of 26 grams and measuring 4.0 x 4.0 x 3.0 cm. The case was reviewed and verified by another attending pathologist, confirming the findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of stomach adenocarcinoma tubular (G2) with a tumor size of 4 x 3.7 x 1.9 cm, infiltrating the full thickness of the stomach wall and showing signs of massive vascular invasion. There are metastases in lymph nodes, specifically noted in lymphonodo No I, II, and VI, while the surgical margins and omentum are free of neoplastic lesions. Immunohistochemical examination for HER2 shows a negative reaction in invasive cancerous cells.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver, specifically in segments 5 and 6, with a tumor size of 6.5 x 5 x 4.2 cm and free surgical margins. Additionally, the gallbladder shows benign changes with mild chronic inflammation and no evidence of malignancy, while the diaphragmatic nodule consists of fibroadipose tissue with fat necrosis and also shows no malignancy. Overall, the findings suggest a localized liver tumor without evidence of cirrhosis or metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast excision revealed infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma, with a tumor size of 1.6 cm and evidence of in situ carcinoma occupying 10% of the tumor. Lymphatic and vascular invasion were noted, and while all surgical margins were technically free of malignancy, carcinoma was found to be close to the superior margin. Additionally, three out of twenty-one axillary lymph nodes were positive for metastatic carcinoma, with one lymph node showing extracapsular extension.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a modified radical mastectomy of the left breast due to left breast cancer with positive lymph nodes. The final diagnosis reveals multicentric in situ and infiltrating duct carcinomas, grade 3, with lymphatic invasion and metastatic carcinoma present in 2 of 7 axillary lymph nodes. The right breast tissue showed benign changes with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 2.7 cm, which is confined to the kidney without local or renal vein invasion. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable. Additionally, a biopsy of the deep surgical margin shows the presence of renal cell carcinoma on one surface, while the other surface is free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor measuring 4.4 x 3.9 x 1.2 cm located in the posterior uterine wall, invading 0.1 cm into the myometrium, but not involving the cervix or exhibiting lymphovascular invasion. Both right and left pelvic lymph node biopsies show no evidence of tumor involvement. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and the remaining reproductive structures are unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal carcinoma (Fuhrman grade 3) in a right kidney specimen, measuring 6.3 x 5 x 4 cm, with the tumor confined to the kidney and not extending through the capsule. The tumor is classified as pT1b, indicating it is between 4-7 cm in size and limited to the kidney, with no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion. Margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and regional lymph nodes and distant metastasis could not be assessed.

The pathology report indicates a moderately to poorly differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma of the distal esophagus, measuring 7.0 cm, with infiltration into the perigastric fat and adventitia, and compromised circumferential margins. There is evidence of lymphatic and perineural infiltration, along with metastatic adenocarcinoma found in 7 of the 13 dissected lymph nodes. The proximal and distal margins are uninvolved by neoplasia, and there are no peculiarities in the gastric and esophageal peri-tumoral mucosa.

The pathology report indicates a subtotal gastrectomy specimen with a 5x0x6 cm exophytic adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as poorly differentiated. All 15 examined lymph nodes show positive metastasis, with the tumor extending to the subserosa, while venous invasion is absent and margins are uninvolved. There is no specified information regarding lymphatic or perineural invasion, neo-adjuvant treatment, or additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two tumor nodules in the thyroid, diagnosed as papillary carcinoma with tall cell features, measuring 1.6 cm in the isthmus and 0.6 cm in the right lobe. All four examined Delphian lymph nodes are negative for tumor, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. The tumor is classified as pT1, with uninvolved margins and no evidence of vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the floor of the mouth, measuring 6.0 cm in greatest dimension, with lymphatic invasion noted and the anterior mucous margin involved by neoplasia. Among the dissected lymph nodes, 1 of 10 right Level IIB lymph nodes and 2 of 10 right Level IIA lymph nodes showed metastatic involvement, with the latter exhibiting capsular involvement. All other examined lymph nodes and salivary glands were uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows minimal chronic inflammation and contains one cystic lymph node with lipogranulomas. The right lobe of the liver is diagnosed with a solitary, well to moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 2.1 cm, confined to the liver with no lymphovascular invasion and classified as pT1, pNO, pMx. Additionally, there is moderate steatosis and mild portal inflammation in the adjacent liver tissue, but no evidence of cirrhosis or significant fibrosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO stage 3, with extensive myometrial and cervical involvement, as well as positive findings in both parametrial tissues and the right ovary. The surgical procedure included a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and while 26 regional lymph nodes were examined, none showed evidence of metastasis. Additional findings included focally erosive cervicitis and a positive serosal surface for malignancy, with no residual endometrial tissue for evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive tubular adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as moderately to poorly differentiated, with a tumor size of 6.6 cm and evidence of vascular and perineural invasion. The tumor has penetrated the subserosa but has not invaded the peritoneum, with metastasis identified in 6 out of 44 examined lymph nodes, leading to a staging of pT3 and pN2 according to AJCC 7th Edition. Additionally, the small bowel portion examined was unremarkable, and immunostaining revealed positive HER2 expression in approximately 30% of tumor cells.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of epithelial melanoma located on the abdominal wall, classified as Clark Level 5 and with a Breslow thickness of 16 mm. The tumor measures 15 mm by 12 mm, with a tumor-to-normal tissue ratio of 4:3, and no evidence of metastasis. The melanoma is staged as Stage III, and the patient is undergoing neoadjuvant immunotherapy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous adenocarcinoma of the left ovary and fallopian tube, with the tumor completely replacing the specimen and no lymphovascular invasion identified. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic serous adenocarcinoma in one of two examined left pelvic lymph nodes, while the omentum and other specimens, including the right ovary and fallopian tube, show no neoplastic changes. The overall staging is classified as pTNM T3c, N1, MX, corresponding to FIGO stage IIIC.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in a liver tumor resected from segment five, with minimal tumor necrosis and no evidence of malignancy in the gallbladder, which showed chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis. The tumor measures 7.3 cm and is solitary, confined to the liver with no vascular invasion, and the parenchymal margin is uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additional findings include chronic triaditis in the liver parenchyma, and the tumor cells tested positive for HepPar-1 while being negative for Alpha Fetoprotein, cytokeratin 7, and cytokeratin 20.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7, involving both lobes and the left seminal vesicle, with focal extraprostatic extension and perineural invasion. The carcinoma occupies 15% of the examined prostate volume, with focal involvement at surgical margins, while three examined lymph nodes are negative for carcinoma. Additional findings include benign prostatic hypertrophy, chronic prostatitis, and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, with a pathologic TNM stage of pT3b, pNO, and pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically the chromophobe subtype, with a histologic grade of 3 out of 4 and a tumor size of 5.0 cm, unifocal in nature. There is no evidence of capsular invasion or involvement of surrounding structures, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor. The AJCC staging is classified as pT1b, pNx, based on the findings at the time of the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic high-grade Mullerian-derived papillary serous carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the omentum, anterior abdominal wall, pelvic region, liver, appendix, ovaries, uterus, and rectosigmoid colon, with extensive infiltration noted in various tissues. The carcinoma exhibits characteristic features such as high nuclear grade, architectural patterns including papillations and gland formations, and evidence of necrosis and inflammation. Notably, the patient's prior left breast carcinoma does not resemble the current findings, suggesting a new primary malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive adenocarcinoma of the transverse colon, classified as moderately differentiated (grade 2 of 4), with a depth of invasion through the muscularis propria into the subserosa and pericolic soft tissue. All surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, with no lymphovascular or perineural invasion identified, and no metastasis found in the 25 examined regional lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical staining shows normal expression for microsatellite instability markers, suggesting that the tumor does not support a diagnosis of hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC).

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen with an ulcerating adenocarcinoma measuring 11 cm in diameter, classified as poorly differentiated. The tumor has invaded the liver, while two examined lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. Margins and other invasion details are not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a benign elastotic nodule in the falciform ligament and an invasive moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the pancreatic body, measuring 5.8 x 3.6 x 3.3 cm, which extends into the peripancreatic soft tissue but has negative surgical margins. Additionally, all examined regional lymph nodes, including a peripancreatic lymph node, are negative for tumor involvement, and the adjacent pancreatic tissue shows PanIN 1A changes. The final diagnosis is classified as AJCC pT3N0, indicating a locally advanced tumor without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) tumors in the left lobe of the liver, with sizes ranging from 1.2 cm to 1.8 cm and a distance of 1.8 cm to the resection margin. The tumors exhibit moderate differentiation (grade III) and show partial capsular formation with no evidence of portal vein or bile duct invasion. Additionally, there is chronic hepatitis due to HBV, but no cirrhosis or dysplastic nodules were noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma located at the apex of the urinary bladder, measuring 3.8 cm, with no carcinoma detected in the examined pelvic lymph nodes or distal ureters. The tumor is classified as pT2b, with a histologic grade of 3/3, and there is no lymphatic invasion observed. Additional findings include benign conditions such as atrophic ovaries, leiomyomas, and paratubal cysts, with no tumor present at the surgical margins.

The pathology report describes a 6x3x0.7 cm ulcerated and invasive squamous cell carcinoma located in the lower esophagus, which has caused narrowing of the esophagus. Microscopic examination reveals moderately differentiated malignant cells with keratinized pearls, enlarged nuclei, and common mitotic figures, indicating invasion into the surrounding fat tissue. Additionally, one out of one examined lymph nodes shows evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the fundus of the stomach, with a tumor size of 6 x 6 x 1 cm. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes, and the surgical margins are uninvolved. Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion were not specified, and there is no indication of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a significant tumor mass in the uterus and extensive necrosis due to prior ablative therapy. Metastatic endometrioid adenocarcinoma was identified in two external iliac lymph nodes, while multiple other lymph nodes were negative for tumor involvement. The bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes showed no diagnostic abnormalities, and the depth of myometrial invasion is estimated to be approximately 1-3 mm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver, characterized by a large, well-demarcated mass with extensive necrosis and no invasion of surgical margins. The tumor is classified as poorly differentiated (grade III) and is associated with chronic hepatitis due to hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Additionally, the gallbladder shows signs of chronic cholecystitis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant mixed Mllerian tumor (carcinosarcoma) arising from an endometrial polyp, with superficial myometrial invasion but no cervical involvement or lymphovascular invasion. The tumor extends to the lower uterine segment, while all examined lymph nodes and adnexal structures are free of tumor. Additional findings include adenomyosis, endometriosis, and a myometrial leiomyoma, with no evidence of malignancy in the cervix, fallopian tubes, ovaries, or omental biopsy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix, grade III, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm and evidence of metastasis in one of the right pelvic lymph nodes and the left parametrial lymph node. The surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and the endometrium shows secretory changes with superficial adenomyosis. Additionally, both ovaries exhibit hemorrhagic corpus luteal cysts, while the fallopian tubes show no pathological alterations.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive lobular carcinoma of the left breast, with a multifocal tumor measuring up to 3.2 cm and a histological grade of 2/3. Metastatic carcinoma was found in one of the left sentinel lymph nodes and one of the fifteen lymph nodes examined from the modified radical mastectomy, with no extracapsular extension noted. The right breast showed benign changes with no evidence of malignancy, and the overall staging is pN1 with no distant metastases (M0).

The pathology report indicates that the excision biopsies from the right temporal lobe and superior temporal regions reveal an anaplastic oligoastrocytoma (WHO Grade III), characterized by moderately pleomorphic astrocytic features and a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 7%. The biopsy from the right posterior parahippocampal gyrus shows no definite tumor, indicating normal temporal lobe tissue with hippocampal dentate gyrus. Additionally, the MGMT promoter methylation status is negative, suggesting that the patient may not benefit from therapy with alkylating agents.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 17 x 11.8 x 8 cm, invading perirenal and renal sinus adipose tissue. Metastatic carcinoma was found in seven out of seven perinephric lymph nodes, while two out of four peri-aortic lymph nodes also showed metastasis, with no tumor detected in the inter-aortic caval lymph nodes. The vascular and ureteral margins were negative for carcinoma, and the tumor was classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3.

The pathology report indicates a 7x6x5 cm poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the right middle lobe of the lung, characterized by ill-defined margins and central necrosis. Microscopic examination reveals malignant cells with moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm, enlarged nuclei, and common mitotic figures, with evidence of lymphatic invasion but no metastasis in the examined lymph nodes. The surgical margins are uninvolved, suggesting complete resection of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, right and left tubes and ovaries, and the uterus. The tumors exhibit significant invasion, with angiolymphatic invasion noted in the right and left tubes and ovaries, and the uterine tumor invading the outer one-third of the myometrium. The endometrium and endocervix are inactive with no tumor detected.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent resection of a left hemispheric brain tumor, which has been diagnosed as glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) in both specimens analyzed. The gross examination revealed multiple soft tissue fragments from the tumor, and intraoperative consultation confirmed the presence of an astrocytic neoplasm. Overall, the findings are consistent with a high-grade malignant brain tumor requiring further management.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the skin of the trunk, measuring 2.8x2x0.4 cm, diagnosed as nodular melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 4.0 mm. The tumor is multicentric, exhibiting a fourth level of invasion in the larger nodule and a second level of invasion in the smaller nodule, with satellite nodules present. Specific details regarding histologic grade, lymph nodes, lymphatic invasion, venous invasion, and margins were not provided.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an adenocarcinoma arising at the gastroesophageal (GE) junction, classified as T2 N1 Mx, with one out of five lymph nodes positive for cancer. The surgical margins for both the esophageal and gastric resections are free of tumor involvement. Additionally, hyperplastic thyroid tissue was identified in the left cervical mass, with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the celiac lymph node excision.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 5.8 cm that extends to the visceral pleura but does not invade it, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in two out of seven hilar lymph nodes, while no tumor was detected in other examined lymph nodes, which showed follicular hyperplasia and hyalinized granulomas. Additionally, there is extensive recent and old hemorrhage in the non-tumorous lung surrounding the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma with oxyphilic changes, measuring 2.7 x 2.2 x 2.0 cm, and exhibiting lymphatic invasion but no capsular invasion. All examined lymph nodes (total of 13) were negative for tumor, and additional findings include Hashimoto's thyroiditis. The tumor is confined to the thyroid and shows no evidence of multifocality or invasion into adjacent structures.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 13.7 cm and predominantly confined to the upper pole, with involvement of the perirenal soft tissue. The tumor has a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2/4, shows no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, and the adrenal gland is not involved. The TNM stage is classified as T3a N0 Mx, and three perihilar lymph nodes were negative for tumor, with mild chronic interstitial inflammation noted in the non-neoplastic kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma infiltrating the bladder wall and extending to the prostate. The left ureteral margin shows focal urothelial carcinoma in situ, while the right ureteral margin and seminal vesicles are uninvolved by neoplasia. All examined lymph nodes from both the left and right sides, including obturator and iliac nodes, show no evidence of neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a thymoma, specifically WHO type B2, with a greatest dimension of 5.5 cm and multifocal microscopic invasion into mediastinal fat, although invasion of the pericardium was not identified. The tumor is partially encapsulated and presents at a cauterized surgical margin, indicating a microscopically positive margin of resection. The overall staging is classified as Stage IIa, with residual thymic tissue showing minimal involutional changes.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph node #2 is positive for micrometastatic carcinoma, while the other sentinel lymph nodes from both axillae are negative for metastases. In the left breast, two foci of invasive ductal carcinoma were identified, with one being grade 3 and measuring 1.6 cm, while the right breast also showed two foci of invasive ductal carcinoma, with the largest measuring 1.1 cm and being grade 3. Both mastectomy specimens had negative surgical margins, and additional findings included ductal carcinoma in situ and various benign breast lesions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 4.2 cm. The tumor extends through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia, with no evidence of renal vein invasion or small vessel angiolymphatic invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, a benign cortical cyst is noted in the non-neoplastic kidney, and the adrenal gland and lymph nodes were not identified in the submitted specimens.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma in the stomach's pyloric region, measuring 2.8 cm, with invasion into the gastric wall, perigastric fat, and peritoneum, but proximal and distal margins are uninvolved by neoplasia. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in 2 out of 5 lymph nodes examined, while the duodenal margin and omentum are uninvolved by neoplasia. Other findings include chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder and moderate chronic gastritis in the non-tumor gastric mucosa.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma with extensive squamous differentiation, which is invasive into the anterior cervical wall and vagina, and shows perineural invasion, but no lymphovascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes (27 in total) and margins from the resection are free of tumor, and additional findings include atrophic endometrium and benign leiomyoma in the uterus, as well as unremarkable bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes. The tumor is classified as pT4a, N0, Mx according to the 7th edition TNM staging system.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of biphasic mesothelioma involving both the visceral and parietal pleura, with a predominant epithelioid component and minor spindle cell features. The tumor has invaded the diaphragm and pericardial fat, with isolated nodules in the lung suggesting metastatic disease, and most lymph nodes examined show tumor involvement. Surgical margins are positive for tumor, and there are no identified pleural plaques or asbestos bodies.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a right frontal brain tumor classified as an oligodendroglioma with focal anaplastic progression (grade III). The tumor exhibits moderate hypercellularity and atypical oligodendrocytes, with evidence of early anaplastic changes, including increased mitotic activity in certain areas. The inferior medial frontal lobe also shows a diffusely cellular oligodendroglioma, but with lower mitotic activity compared to the more anaplastic regions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of thymoma, WHO type B3, with a tumor measuring 7.0 cm that has invaded into adipose tissue but not into the lung or pleura. The tumor was resected along with a portion of the innominate vein and a wedge of the right upper lobe, with all resection margins being negative for tumor involvement. Pathologic staging is classified as Stage III due to macroscopic invasion into neighboring organs, but there is no evidence of vascular invasion or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right frontal glioblastoma with recent hemorrhage, characterized by a high proliferation index of 60% and significant mitotic activity. The tumor exhibits features such as microvascular proliferation and necrosis, with recent bleeding observed within the tumor and surrounding brain tissue. Additionally, testing revealed a positive EGFRVIII mutation and a negative MGMT promoter methylation status, which may influence treatment options.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe lung lobectomy revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with mucinous features, measuring 5.0 cm, and showing invasion of the visceral pleura, with metastatic carcinoma found in 1 of 11 lymph nodes. All excised lymph nodes from stations 5, 6, and 7 were negative for tumor. Additionally, both KRAS and EGFR mutation analyses showed no mutations detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Glioblastoma multiforme (Astrocytoma, WHO grade IV) in multiple specimens taken from the right temporal lobe, including a biopsy, excision, and CUSA contents. The specimens were described as soft tissue fragments of varying sizes, with the biopsy showing high-grade infiltrating glioma consistent with high-grade astrocytoma. The final diagnosis was confirmed by the attending pathologist after reviewing all pathology slides.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder specimen shows focal mild chronic inflammation, while the liver specimen from a right hepatic lobectomy reveals poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with multiple tumors measuring up to 12.0 x 11.0 x 9.0 cm. Immunohistochemical studies confirm the presence of tumor markers consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma, and there is no evidence of vascular invasion or lymph node involvement. The pathologic staging is provisional, reflecting multiple tumors greater than 5 cm, with uninvolved surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 2.5 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The non-neoplastic kidney shows mild chronic interstitial inflammation and fibrosis, and no adrenal gland or lymph nodes were identified in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the sigmoid colon, measuring 6.5 cm in length, with no evidence of tumor budding, lymphovascular invasion, or metastasis to lymph nodes. The tumor invades the muscularis propria and is staged as pT2, with surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, benign colonic tissue was found in both the proximal and distal rings, and immunohistochemical staining for DNA mismatch repair proteins was retained in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the left neck lymph nodes and thyroid tissue are negative for malignancy, while the left partial maxillectomy and left cheek specimen reveals moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with perineural invasion and close margins. The tumor measures 4.5 cm and is located in the buccal mucosa, with no evidence of lymphovascular invasion and negative findings in 14 examined lymph nodes. The final diagnosis classifies the tumor as pT3 based on size and lack of bone invasion, with further evaluation of bone margins pending.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive lobular carcinoma, grade 1, in the right breast, measuring 1.1 cm, with clear surgical margins. The axillary lymph nodes examined show no evidence of metastasis. The specimen includes a spiculated nodule in the breast and multiple axillary lymph nodes, but no gross lesions were found in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) in multiple specimens from the right frontal lobe of the brain, including both tumor biopsies and tissue from the inferior white matter. The gross examination revealed irregular soft tissue fragments with varying colors and sizes, consistent with the aggressive nature of glioblastoma. All submitted specimens were processed for further analysis, confirming the presence of this high-grade tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 2.4 cm and no evidence of visceral pleural invasion. Surgical margins are clear of carcinoma, with the tumor located less than 1 mm from the pleural margin, and no metastatic carcinoma identified in the examined lymph nodes. Additional findings include areas of subpleural fibrosis, interstitial fibrosis, and emphysematous changes in the surrounding lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates that a 2.9 cm poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma was found in the cervix of a female patient who underwent a hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was identified in 2 out of 15 left pelvic lymph nodes and in 1 out of 13 right pelvic lymph nodes. The tumor was staged as pT1a1N1, indicating early invasive carcinoma with regional lymph node involvement.
