The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of unclassifiable renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3-4, extensive necrosis, and a tumor size of 8.2 cm that extends into the renal sinus adipose tissue, but without renal vein invasion. Additionally, one lymph node shows metastatic renal cell carcinoma with extracapsular extension, while the adrenal gland is unremarkable with no evidence of carcinoma. The overall TNM stage is pT3a N1 MX, and all surgical margins are free of neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a tumor in the right upper lobe (RUL) with a size of 6.00 cm, classified as grade III. The staging reveals a pathological T2 classification with no evidence of nodal involvement (N) or distant metastasis (M), resulting in a stage III diagnosis. The histological examination confirms the tumor's characteristics, but further comments or details are not provided in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the left frontal brain tumor biopsy is diagnosed as an oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade II), characterized by low-grade glioma features with rare mitotic figures and no vascular proliferation. Genetic analysis shows allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, which is typical for oligodendrogliomas, and no evidence of methylated MGMT promoter was detected. The tumor cells exhibit diffuse p53 positivity and a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 4 to 5%, suggesting a low proliferation rate.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma in the left thyroid lobe, with a dominant tumor measuring 2.5 cm and an additional microcarcinoma of 0.1 cm. The tumor margins are uninvolved by carcinoma, and there is no evidence of capsular invasion, lymph-vascular invasion, or extrathyroidal extension. The specimen was obtained through a left hemithyroidectomy, and no regional lymph nodes were examined or involved.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has bilateral poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7, involving both lobes of the prostate and measuring a maximum of 1.6 cm. All examined lymph nodes (26 total) are free of neoplasia, and the carcinoma is organ-confined with no evidence of extracapsular extension or seminal vesicle invasion. Additionally, perineural invasion is noted, and multifocal high-grade prostatic intra-epithelial neoplasia is present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) in a patient with a right central brain tumor and recent intratumoral hemorrhage. The tumor exhibits features such as nuclear anaplasia, mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis with pseudopalisading, with a MIB-1 proliferation index of 9%. Gross examination revealed multiple soft tissue fragments, and immunohistochemical analysis showed scant gliofibrilogenesis and extensive neovascularization.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, showing extraprostatic extension and bilateral seminal vesicle invasion. The tumor extends to the cauterized margin along the left posterior lobe proximal region, and no metastatic carcinoma was identified in the four examined lymph nodes. The final staging is pT3bNO, and clinical correlation and follow-up are recommended.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type in the resected rectosigmoid colon, characterized by deep ulceration and extensive infiltration into the perirectal fatty tissue, with two local lymph node metastases. The tumor extends to the circumferential resection margin, while the mesenteric and colon resection margins are tumor-free. The tumor is staged as pT4, pN1 (2/17), pMX; G2, with lymphovascular invasion (L1), no perineural invasion (V0), and a positive resection margin (R2).

The pathology report indicates that the right tonsil shows moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, but the surgical margins are negative for malignancy. Additionally, 19 lymph nodes from the right neck levels 2 and 3, as well as 2 lymph nodes from the right perifacial area, were examined and found to be negative for malignancy. The findings suggest that the carcinoma is localized to the tonsil without evidence of spread to the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma with focal squamous differentiation in the bladder, along with evidence of metastatic urothelial carcinoma in one of the left distal pelvic lymph nodes. The right common iliac, left common iliac, right distal, and pre-sacral lymph nodes were found to be benign, with no carcinoma detected in the lymph nodes examined. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and additional findings include chronic cystitis and benign changes in the female genital organs.

The pathology report indicates that a right renal mass was excised and diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the chromophobe type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2. The mass measured 4 x 3.5 x 3 cm and exhibited a tan/red cut surface with areas of punctate hemorrhage. The specimen was processed for both research and pathology analysis, confirming the diagnosis.

The pathology report describes a biopsy of brain tissue revealing an anaplastic oligoastrocytoma, grade III, characterized by hypercellular areas, myxoid stroma, and microcystic degeneration. Histological examination shows atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, frequent mitoses, and evidence of microvascular proliferation, but no tumor necrosis was detected. Immunohistochemical studies indicate positive GFAP and VIMENTIN staining, with a high proliferation index (KI-67).

The pathology report indicates the presence of a high-grade infiltrating urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, characterized by a large, ulcerated, and necrotic tumor measuring 7x5x5 cm. Microscopic examination reveals poorly differentiated tumor cells with significant nuclear atypia and common mitotic activity, invading surrounding fat tissue. The tumor exhibits aggressive features, including irregular nuclear membranes and abnormal chromatin patterns, suggesting a serious malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that a left orchidectomy was performed, revealing a seminoma with a diameter of 1.5 cm. There is no evidence of angio-invasion, invasion of the tunica albuginea, or tumor in the epididymis or rete testis. Additionally, the surgical margin of the spermatic cord is free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated acinar type prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 8, and the tumor measures 0.5 x 1.0 x 1.3 cm. Nine lymph nodes were examined, all of which were negative for metastasis, and the surgical margins are intact. The clinical diagnosis is prostate cancer, classified as stage T2 N0 M0, II B.

The pathology report describes a mildly to moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm that infiltrates both gray and white matter, characterized by tumor cells with round to oval nuclei and prominent fibrillary cytoplasm. The findings indicate a classic oligodendroglioma phenotype, leading to the classification of the tumor as an oligoastrocytoma. The neoplasm is low grade with a minimal proliferation index of 1.7%, consistent with previous biopsy results.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with a significant non-invasive component consisting of low-grade papillary carcinoma, and the tumor has invaded the deep half of the muscularis propria. Additionally, there are incidental findings of adenocarcinoma in the prostate, with multicentric foci identified, but no involvement of the seminal vesicles or lymph nodes. All surgical margins are reported as free of tumor, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as pT2b for the bladder cancer and pT2a for the prostate cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the excised fifth rib shows benign bone and bone marrow with no signs of malignancy. The right lower lobe lobectomy reveals invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with lymphovascular and visceral pleural invasion, but negative margins and no malignancy in examined lymph nodes. Additional lymph nodes from various levels are also reported as anthracosilicotic and negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant mesothelioma in the left pleura, characterized by predominantly epithelioid and some sarcomatoid patterns, with evidence of infiltration by neoplastic cells displaying significant pleomorphism and apoptotic features. Macroscopically, the specimen shows irregular nodules and fibrous tissue, while microscopically, it reveals a mix of fibrous connective tissue, adipose tissue, and myxoid stroma, along with a chronic inflammatory infiltrate. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis, showing positive markers for the malignant cells, and the report notes a clinical history of asbestos exposure.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary serous adenocarcinoma with psammoma bodies in multiple sites, including the right and left adnexa, omentum, and soft tissue nodules, along with associated low malignant potential tumors. The report also notes chronic cervicitis, atrophic endometrium, and extensive adenomyosis in the uterus, as well as negative findings for malignancy in multiple lymph nodes. Overall, there is evidence of metastatic disease, particularly in soft tissue and omental sites, while lymph nodes remain free of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade III endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor measuring 3.6 x 2.5 x 2.2 cm that invades 1.7 cm into the myometrium, but does not involve the endocervix. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma consistent with the endometrial primary is identified in multiple pelvic lymph nodes on both the right and left sides. The report also notes the presence of multiple intramural leiomyomata in the uterus, while the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are atrophic and not involved.

The final diagnosis indicates high-grade endometrial carcinoma (endometrioid type, FIGO grade III) with myometrial invasion and lymphovascular invasion, along with cellular leiomyoma and chronic cervicitis. Metastatic carcinoma was found in multiple lymph nodes, with a total of 8 out of 26 lymph nodes showing metastasis. The adnexa (ovaries and fallopian tubes) were unremarkable with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 3 adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, characterized by a bronchocentric mass measuring 4.5 x 3.0 x 1.5 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion but no pleural involvement. Metastatic disease is present in a single left subaortic lymph node and in two out of six intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes, while other examined lymph nodes show no tumor involvement. The bronchial margin is clear of tumor, suggesting complete resection of the primary lung lesion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2 N1 M0, indicating a primary tumor with regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. Additionally, a normal blood sample was obtained, with no treatment administered at this time.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right middle and lower lobes of the lung, with a tumor mass measuring 30 mm and evidence of perineural and lymphatic permeation, but no blood vessel invasion or pleural invasion. The tumor is well clear of the bronchial resection margin, although it is present in soft tissue adjacent to the pulmonary artery, and there are peribronchial lymph node metastases. The lymph node specimen shows only reactive changes with no evidence of malignancy, and granulomatous inflammation distal to the carcinoma exhibits necrosis without identifiable microorganisms.

The pathology report indicates that the left level 9, level 5, level 6, and level 7 lymph nodes were all negative for malignancy. A lobectomy of the left lower lobe revealed a unifocal, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 1.8 cm, with negative margins and no visceral pleura invasion. The overall pathologic staging classified the primary tumor as pT1a, with no regional lymph node involvement and no distant metastasis.

The pathology report describes a moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm primarily composed of gemistocytes and fibrillary astrocytes, with moderate to marked atypia but no mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis indicates an astrocytic origin, with a MIB-1 labeling index of 6.2%, which is at the high end for a grade II astrocytoma but not indicative of anaplastic features. The final diagnosis is a well-differentiated astrocytoma (WHO grade II), necessitating close observation.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen with an exophytic adenocarcinoma measuring 12x7x5 cm, classified as poorly differentiated. Out of 8 examined lymph nodes, 4 showed positive metastasis. Details regarding the extent of invasion and margins were not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multicentric papillary thyroid carcinoma with classical, tall cell, and microcarcinoma variants, primarily located in the left lobe, right lobe, and isthmus of the thyroid. Metastatic disease was identified in one lymph node from the right superior mediastinal tissue, with psammoma bodies present, while the right para-tracheal tissue and Delphian lymph node biopsies were benign. The tumor exhibits extensive capsular invasion, focal extrathyroid extension, and the surgical margins are free of tumor, with chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis noted in the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 1 cm and negative margins for malignancy. Multiple lymph node biopsies from levels XI, VII, and X, as well as a fat pad biopsy, show no evidence of malignancy. Additionally, the report notes the presence of emphysema and subpleural elastosis in the non-tumorous lung tissue.

The pathology report describes a lung lobe specimen with a localized 8 cm grey-yellow tumor exhibiting focal necrosis, diagnosed as bronchioloalveolar adenocarcinoma, well differentiated. There is no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion, and all examined lymph nodes (0/6) are negative for metastasis, with uninvolved margins. Additional details regarding tumor extent and treatment effects are not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the skin excision from the right port site shows chronic inflammation and is negative for tumor. The resected right lung and pleura reveal mixed sarcomatoid and epithelioid malignant mesothelioma, which invades the visceral and parietal pleura, chest wall, diaphragm, and pericardium, with close margins noted at the resection site. All examined lymph nodes, including those from the R4, R8, Station 7, and A3 lymphadenectomies, are negative for tumor, although one lymph node contains an asbestos body, and immunostaining shows strong positivity for EGFR in the tumor's epithelioid components.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with sarcomatoid transformation, nuclear grade IV/IV, in the right kidney, measuring 5.7 cm and extending through the renal capsule but confined within Gerota's fascia. There is no invasion of the renal vein, and all surgical margins are free of tumor, while the non-neoplastic kidney shows patchy chronic interstitial nephritis. The retroperitoneal lymph nodes examined show no evidence of metastatic disease, with all five nodes being benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma of the endocervical type from a biopsy of the cervix. An immunohistochemistry examination was performed to enhance the evaluation, confirming the primary neoplasia as originating from the uterine cervix. Overall, the findings support the presence of cervical cancer.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a peritoneal nodule diagnosed as a leiomyoma, characterized by a well-circumscribed proliferation of spindled cells with positive desmin staining. Additionally, a cecal tumor measuring 7.2 x 6.9 x 4.5 cm is identified as adenocarcinoma with focal mucinous and signet ring cell features, classified as G2, and showing tumor penetration into subserosal fat with 11 out of 15 lymph nodes involved by metastatic carcinoma. The overall pathologic staging is pT3 pN2b MX, with no gross perforation or lymphovascular and perineural invasion detected.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical prostatectomy due to a diagnosis of prostate cancer, revealing high-grade prostatic adenocarcinoma with mucinous features and extensive perineural invasion. The cancer involved the right posterior surgical margin and showed multifocal extraprostatic extension, while both left and right pelvic lymph nodes were uninvolved. The Gleason score was determined to be 5+4=9, indicating a high-grade tumor, and the final TNM stage was classified as pT3bR1 pNO pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous carcinoma (FIGO grade III) involving the right ovary and fallopian tube, with evidence of metastasis to the omentum, small bowel mesentery, sigmoid colon, and cecum. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, and no tumor was identified in the right pelvic, right obturator, or left pelvic lymph nodes. Additional findings include metastatic adenocarcinoma in peritoneal washings and various biopsies showing metastatic serous carcinoma in different abdominal sites, while the left ovary showed no tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma of the stomach (antrum), measuring 7.5 cm, with infiltration into the serosa and adjacent adipose tissue, and evidence of lymphatic and perineural invasion. Metastatic involvement is noted in all examined lymph nodes from the lesser curvature and greater omentum, with extracapsular extension, and there are multiple neoplastic nodules present. The distal surgical margin is affected by neoplasia, while the esophageal margin is uninvolved, leading to a pathologic staging of pT4a.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, conventional type, located in the left lobe of the thyroid, measuring 2.5 cm, with extrathyroidal extension into skeletal muscle and lymphovascular invasion present. Additionally, metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma was identified in one lymph node without extracapsular extension. The background thyroid tissue shows chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, and the tumor is noted to be abutting the resection margins.

The pathology report indicates a lobectomy of the left lower lung, revealing a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2 x 3 x 2.5 cm. Details regarding tumor extent, other tumor nodules, lymph nodes, lymphatic and venous invasion, and margins are not specified. There is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of basaloid squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 1.4 cm, with negative resection margins. A second tumor of similar type was found in the right upper lobe, measuring 1.1 cm, also with negative margins and one peribronchial lymph node negative for malignancy. All examined lymph nodes and the 5th rib bone were negative for malignancy, suggesting that the tumors are likely separate primary cancers.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a high-grade diffuse astrocytoma, specifically an anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO grade 3), with negative results for IDH1 and IDH2 mutations, and no co-deletion of chromosomal arms 1p and 19q. The Ki-67/MIB-1 proliferation index is approximately 10%, and there are abnormal blood vessels with mitotic figures, raising concerns for a potential higher-grade glioma, such as glioblastoma. Additionally, the presence of a methylated MGMT promoter suggests that the patient may benefit from therapy with alkylating agents.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, revealing a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 3.0 cm, with lymphatic invasion present but uninvolved margins. Additionally, benign fibroadipose tissue was found in the left parametrium, and benign cysts were noted in the right ovary and fallopian tube, while the left ovary and fallopian tube showed no significant pathology. The lymph node dissection revealed a total of 15 benign lymph nodes with no evidence of metastasis, leading to a pathologic stage of IB1 for the cervical cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left lung adenocarcinoma, specifically a poorly differentiated tumor measuring 8.5 cm, with no invasion of the visceral pleura and free surgical margins. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in 5 of the 53 examined lymph nodes, including 2 of 15 in the Level 5 lymph nodes and 3 of 6 in the Level 11 lymph nodes. Additional findings include fibrous adhesion in the diaphragmatic specimen and emphysema in the lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma in the left breast, with a tumor size of 1.7 cm and no evidence of invasion into surrounding structures. Sentinel lymph nodes from both sides show reactive changes, with isolated tumor cells found in one right sentinel lymph node, while the right breast tissue reveals ductal carcinoma in situ and fibrocystic changes. Margins are clear of invasive carcinoma, and the overall pathologic staging is pT1c for the primary tumor and pNO for the regional lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bilateral papillary carcinoma, with tumor sizes measuring 2.5x2x1 cm on the right and 1.5x1x1 cm on the left. The tumors are multifocal, but there is no evidence of extrathyroidal extension. Overall, the findings suggest localized disease without spread beyond the thyroid.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive FIGO grade I endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor mass measuring 8.5 x 2.6 x 1.1 cm that invades 0.7 cm into the myometrium, while the cervix remains uninvolved. Additionally, there is a focus of endometriosis in the right ovary, but the left ovary and both fallopian tubes show no diagnostic abnormalities. Lymph node analysis reveals that multiple right pelvic lymph nodes are negative for tumor, while one left pelvic obturator lymph node is positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, with left para-aortic lymph nodes also being negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal infiltrating mixed ductal and lobular carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 6.0 x 5.5 x 2.5 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion and a component of lobular carcinoma in situ. All surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, but there is evidence of metastatic breast carcinoma in the sentinel lymph node and all examined axillary lymph nodes, with a total of 27 lymph nodes showing metastasis. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor positive, and HER-2/neu negative, with a Nottingham score of 6, indicating a moderate grade of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a tumor in the left kidney, measuring 5.5 cm, which is confined within the renal tissue without any invasion into surrounding structures or surgical margins. The kidney shows chronic nephritis and other changes, but no malignancy is present in the examined sections. Additional stains and evaluations are pending for further assessment of the lymph node and rib specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, follicular variant, located in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 1.3 cm, with no multifocality, extrathyroidal extension, or lymphovascular invasion present. The resection margins are negative, and there is no tumor found in the examined lymph nodes. The background thyroid tissue shows multinodular adenomatous goiter.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right distal ureters show unremarkable urothelium with no high-grade dysplasia or carcinoma identified. In contrast, the bladder and prostate specimens reveal high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation, invading perivesical tissue, but all surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from various regions are benign and negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that a 12.3 cm pheochromocytoma was identified in the right adrenal gland of a female patient, with the tumor confined to the adrenal gland. The specimen weighed 558.8 grams and exhibited a friable, orange-tan mass with solid and cystic components. Immunohistochemical staining showed strong positivity for chromogranin and SDHB, with a Ki67 proliferation index of less than 1%.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an intermediate grade leiomyosarcoma in the retroperitoneal soft tissue, measuring 11 cm, with free inked margins and focal necrosis. A biopsy of the liver lesion reveals a Von Meyenburg complex (bile duct hamartoma), while the appendix shows non-specific chronic inflammation. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma, with tumor cells positive for SMA, vimentin, and desmin.

The pathology report describes a brain lesion consisting of five irregular structures, with the largest measuring 5.5 x 4.0 x 2.0 cm, exhibiting a jelly-like, brown irregular lesion on its surface. Microscopic examination reveals a diffuse glial neoplasm with moderate cellularity, characterized by oligodendroglial features and areas of anaplastic change, leading to a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma with diffuse anaplastic foci, WHO grade II. Although there are no definitive criteria for grade III, the presence of nuclear atypia and a higher Ki-67 proliferation index in some areas suggest potential progression to a higher degree of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), located in the left lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 2 cm. The tumor is classified as Grade II and is staged as T1, with no evidence of regional lymph node involvement (N) or distant metastasis (M0). Additionally, there is a noted histological comment of focal obstructive pneumonitis associated with the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left breast invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, with the invasive tumor measuring 2.6 cm and associated ductal carcinoma in situ constituting 40% of the total tumor volume. All examined lymph nodes, including sentinel nodes, were negative for metastatic carcinoma, and the surgical margins were clear of carcinoma, with the invasive component 0.4 cm from the nearest margin. The tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, as well as HER2, indicating a specific receptor profile.

The pathology report indicates a mastectomy specimen with a tumor measuring 2.2 x 1.5 x 5 cm, diagnosed as infiltrating ductal carcinoma. Out of five examined lymph nodes, three showed positive metastasis. The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tumor characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the right orchidectomy revealed a nonseminoma tumor, composed of 95% embryonal carcinoma and 5% seminoma, with a diameter of 4.5 cm. There is no evidence of angio-invasion, but invasion of the rete testis is present. The tumor is confined to the testis.

The pathology report indicates that the left adrenal gland underwent an adrenalectomy, revealing a pheochromocytoma measuring 2.2 x 2 x 2 cm and weighing 41 grams, which is confined to the adrenal gland with free resection margins. There is no evidence of blood vessel or lymph vessel invasion, and the tumor exhibits mild nuclear atypia with low mitotic activity and no necrosis. The tumor is classified as primary stage pTl, with no regional lymph nodes received and no distant metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates a left renal tumor diagnosed as clear cell renal carcinoma, measuring 6.0 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of G2 and pT1b staging, showing evidence of venous invasion but uninvolved margins. The left adrenal gland and spleen specimens were found to be free of carcinoma, with the adrenal gland showing mild nodular cortical hyperplasia and the spleen exhibiting focal capsular disruption without tumor presence. Additional findings include cortical cysts in the kidney and moderate arterial and arteriolonephrosclerosis.

The pathology report indicates that a Whipple resection was performed due to a pancreatic mass, revealing well-differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma with high-grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN III) and significant lymphovascular and perineural invasion. Out of 11 examined lymph nodes, 7 showed metastatic adenocarcinoma, and the tumor was found to be within 1 mm of the bile duct margin. Additionally, the lymph node and pancreatic margin biopsies were negative for malignancy, indicating no cancer in those areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 4.0 cm, with tumor margins free of cancer and confined by the capsule. The tumor is classified as Fuhrman grade III, with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, and the pathological stage is T1, NX, MX. Additionally, a fragment of the adrenal gland shows no signs of malignancy, and the uninvolved kidney exhibits arteriolonephrosclerosis and an old infarct.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left adrenalectomy, revealing a mass measuring 12.5 x 10.5 x 7 cm and weighing 467 grams, diagnosed as adrenocortical carcinoma. The tumor has a KI67 proliferation index of 5-10% and is classified as pT2 pNx L1 V1 Pn0 R0, indicating local invasion but no lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. The tumor's Weiss score is 7, Hough score is 3.52, and Van Slooten score is 22.7, suggesting a significant malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade adrenocortical carcinoma, with the tumor measuring 15.5 x 14.5 x 13.5 cm and weighing 1060 grams. There is evidence of vascular invasion and extra-adrenal extension, with a positive vascular margin and negative peripheral margin. The tumor exhibits necrosis and a low mitotic rate, classified as stage T4 NX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the caudate lobe of the liver, measuring 3.0 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm, with the tumor confined to the liver and no evidence of invasion into large vessels or lymph nodes. The resection margin is tumor-free with a distance of 0.4 cm from the tumor, and the adjacent liver tissue shows mildly active steatohepatitis and bridging fibrosis. The tumor is classified as AJCC stage pT1 (7th edition).

The pathology report indicates that the right neck dissection levels 1A, 1B, 3, 4, and 5 showed no tumor presence in the lymph nodes, while the right partial glossectomy revealed moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma measuring 2.5 cm with infiltrative borders and negative margins. One of the eight lymph nodes examined in the right selective neck dissection level 4 showed metastatic carcinoma, measuring 1.3 cm, but without extracapsular extension. Overall, the findings suggest localized squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue with limited metastatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that multiple liver biopsies show no tumors but reveal cholestasis and small hyalinized granulomas in some segments. A pancreaticoduodenectomy specimen confirms the presence of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with invasion into peripancreatic soft tissues, duodenum, and ampulla, along with lymphatic invasion and involvement of regional lymph nodes. The report concludes with a pathologic stage assessment of pT3 pN1, indicating advanced disease with metastatic involvement in one lymph node.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 5.5 cm, but no local or renal vein invasion was identified, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Additional specimens from the 11th rib, perinephric fat, and hilar lymph nodes revealed benign chondro-osseous tissue, benign adipose tissue, and no involvement of lymph nodes, respectively. The overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is pT1, indicating the tumor is limited to the kidney and measures less than or equal to 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 3, in the left breast, with a tumor size of 2.3 x 2.2 x 2.0 cm and negative surgical margins. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in the left breast intramammary lymph node, while multiple left axillary sentinel and dissected lymph nodes are negative for tumor. HER-2/NEU testing has been ordered on the paraffin-embedded tissue for further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates that a right lung mass was diagnosed as moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 4.5 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion present and metastasis to three of fifteen peribronchial lymph nodes. No malignancy was identified in the examined lymph nodes from the right proximal paratracheal, left distal paratracheal, and subcarinal regions, as well as in the fifth rib specimen. The bronchial margins were negative for tumor involvement, and the non-neoplastic lung showed emphysematous changes.

The pathology report indicates a resected colon sample containing an ulcerated, highly differentiated adenocarcinoma of colorectal type, which has infiltrated the pericolic fatty tissue. There are no tumor cells found in the local lymph nodes, colonic resection margins, or mesenteric resection margin. Additionally, a small tubular adenoma with mild dysplasia is present in the colonic mucous membrane.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically the chromophobe subtype, with a histologic grade of 3 on a scale of 4. The tumor measures 5.1 cm, is unifocal, and shows no evidence of extra-capsular invasion or involvement of surgical margins, although the renal parenchymal margin is close at 1 mm. The AJCC staging is pT1b pNx pMx, and the report notes that the findings are subject to change pending further clinical review.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with mucinous features primarily located in the periampullary region, with tumor invasion into the pancreas and periampullary duodenal wall, as well as positive perineural and lymphatic channel invasion. The lymph nodes examined showed five out of fifteen positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the resection margins were free of invasive carcinoma. Additionally, an incidental well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumor was identified within the infiltrating adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC), grade 3, measuring 2.5 cm, with extensive lymphovascular invasion and involvement at the anterior margin. Additionally, two of three sentinel lymph nodes and three of seventeen axillary lymph nodes showed metastatic carcinoma, with the largest metastasis measuring 1.5 cm and exhibiting extranodal extension. The report also notes the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and atypical ductal hyperplasia in the margins, with negative results for estrogen and progesterone receptors.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a mildly to moderately hypercellular diffuse glioma, primarily affecting the gray matter, with mild to moderate atypia and no mitotic figures observed. The tumor exhibits secondary structures such as perineuronal satellitosis and subpial condensation, with a MIB-1 labeling index of greater than 5%, suggesting a need for close follow-up despite not meeting criteria for anaplastic grade 3. The final diagnosis is an oligodendroglioma classified as WHO grade II.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, specifically of the endometrioid type with focal clear cell features, classified as FIGO grade 2, and showing myometrial invasion of less than half with a maximum thickness of 5 mm. The lymph nodes examined (18 in total) were negative for metastatic carcinoma, and the remaining structures, including the ovaries and fallopian tubes, were unremarkable or showed benign changes. Additional findings included leiomyomas and adenomyosis in the myometrium, with no evidence of endocervical invasion.

The final diagnosis indicates the presence of papillary renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 3.1 cm, with no evidence of malignancy in the adrenal gland and free surgical margins. The tumor is classified as pT1a, indicating it is 4 cm or less in size and confined to the kidney, with a histologic grade of II-III and 5% tumor necrosis. Ancillary testing supports the diagnosis, and there is no evidence of perineural, angiolymphatic, or lymph-vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates that a malignant melanoma was excised from the skin on the shoulder, measuring 4.1 x 3.6 x 5.2 cm. Out of 10 examined lymph nodes, 3 were positive for metastasis, while there was no evidence of venous invasion and the margins were uninvolved. Additional details regarding satellite nodules, lymphatic invasion, and neo-adjuvant treatment were not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the excisional biopsies of sentinel lymph nodes #1 and #3 are negative for tumor, while sentinel lymph node #2 shows rare single cytokeratin positive cells without significant tumor groups. The right breast mastectomy reveals poorly differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 4.0 cm, with no ductal carcinoma in situ identified and no lymphovascular invasion present. Hormone receptor tests show negative estrogen and progesterone receptors, and HER2 is negative, with the tumor staged as pT2pNO (i+) MX.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the retroperitoneum, with a tumor size of 11.8 x 10.5 x 10.2 cm, which is present at the resection margin and shows areas of necrosis. Additionally, a benign fibroadipose tissue consistent with a hernia sac was identified in the abdominal wall specimen. The dedifferentiated component of the tumor predominantly resembles a high-grade malignant fibrous histiocytoma, with some areas showing low-grade myxofibrosarcoma-like growth and well-differentiated liposarcoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lung, with a primary tumor measuring 14 cm and classified as pT3. There is one positive lymph node out of twenty-nine examined, resulting in a pathologic stage of IIIA, while margins are negative for invasive carcinoma. Additionally, the pericardial tissue examined is negative for tumor involvement, and no lymphovascular invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade I endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, identified as a polypoid mass in the uterus, with minimal invasion into the myometrium and no lymphovascular space invasion. The left ovary shows a fibroma, while the right ovary and both fallopian tubes are unremarkable. The endocervix is uninvolved, and the cervix appears normal.

The pathology report indicates a 3.0 cm clear cell renal cortical carcinoma in the right kidney, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 2-3. The tumor is well circumscribed and confined to the kidney, with negative margins of resection and no evidence of vascular invasion. A single small cortical cyst is noted in the non-neoplastic kidney, and regional lymph nodes and distant metastasis cannot be assessed.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the left maxilla, with a depth of invasion of 0.5 cm, and the tumor is noted to invade the periosteum and superficial bone. Other examined margins, including the left buccal margin and various mucosal sites, show moderate dysplasia or are free of tumor. Additionally, a minute fragment of squamous carcinoma was identified in the maxillary sinus mucosa, but all margins are reported as free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has stage IV breast carcinoma, with a diagnosis of invasive carcinoma of the right breast, showing histologic grades II/III to III/III and measuring at least 10 cm. Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is also present, constituting less than or equal to 25% of the total tumor mass, with extensive necrosis and lobular involvement. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma is identified in both axillary lymph nodes and soft tissue, with vascular invasion and direct extension into the skin and skeletal muscle.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with rupture in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a large tumor measuring 11.0 x 9.0 x 8.0 cm, with evidence of necrosis and hemorrhage. The tumor shows portal vein invasion but no bile duct or hepatic vein invasion, and the surgical margins are clear. Additionally, the gallbladder was removed due to chronic cholecystitis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma (Grade 3) with a tumor size of 7.5 cm and greater than 50% myometrial invasion, along with cervical stromal extension. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in the left suprapubic mass and left common lymph nodes, while one of twelve left pelvic lymph nodes showed metastatic tumor involvement. Reactive lymphoid hyperplasia was noted in the deep left pelvic lymph nodes, and the left lower aortic lymph node also contained metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the bladder measuring 3 x 2.5 x 4 cm, diagnosed as moderately differentiated transitional cell carcinoma. The tumor extends into the muscularis propria, but there is no evidence of venous invasion, and the surgical margins are uninvolved. Details regarding lymph nodes and lymphatic invasion are not specified, and there is no mention of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation, measuring 5.1 cm, involving the endometrium and extending into the myometrium, with lower uterine segment and adnexal involvement but no cervical or serosal involvement. The tumor is classified as FIGO grade 2 and staged as pT3a pNO, with no lymphovascular space invasion and no metastatic carcinoma found in examined lymph nodes. Additional findings include an epithelial inclusion cyst in the right ovary and metastatic endometrioid adenocarcinoma in the right fallopian tube, with fragments of carcinoma also identified in the left fallopian tube.

The pathology report indicates the presence of acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5), showing extra-prostatic extension and seminal vesicle invasion. Surgical margins are involved by invasive carcinoma in multiple locations, and perineural invasion is present, while lymphovascular invasion is absent. The left pelvic lymph node examined showed no evidence of metastasis, and the pathological staging is classified as pT3b, pNO, pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme from a brain biopsy, with evidence of tumor involvement in the overlying dura mater. The microscopic examination reveals hypercellularity, marked vascular proliferation, frequent thrombosis, and extensive necrosis, with characteristics suggesting an oligodendroglioma component. Special stains for GFAP and reticulum were requested to further evaluate the tumor's characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, specifically a non-keratinizing type that is moderately to poorly differentiated (grade 2-3/3). The carcinoma involves all submitted tissue fragments, with one fragment showing an ulcerated surface and the tumor extending to peripheral and deep margins, but without evidence of lymphatic space involvement. The tumor measures approximately 1.2 x 0.3 cm, and there are no previous abnormal pap smear results available for review.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma, measuring 3.8 cm, located at the gastroesophageal junction, arising in a background of Barrett's mucosa with high-grade dysplasia and invading the submucosa. The surgical margins are negative for malignancy, and there is evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, but no perineural invasion is noted; all examined lymph nodes (20 total) are negative for malignancy. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT1bN0, and HER2 testing is negative.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the epiglottic mass, with surface ulceration, while biopsies from various other sites, including the left and right false vocal cords and pre-epiglottic spaces, show no tumor or only mild dysplasia. Additionally, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma is identified in 4 out of 27 lymph nodes on the left side, with no tumor found in 25 lymph nodes on the right side. Surgical margins from the epiglottis specimen cannot be assessed due to fragmentation, but all frozen section margins from the other biopsies are free of tumor.

The pathology report describes a 5 cm soft tan and necrotic tumor in the right adrenal gland, characterized histologically as a pleomorphic tumor with zellballen structures and the presence of giant cells. Immunohistochemical analysis shows diffuse staining for synaptophysin and chromogranin, with a proliferation index of 5% as indicated by Ki67. The final diagnosis is pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a partial nephrectomy for a left kidney tumor, which was diagnosed as clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 3.0 cm. The tumor is located 0.1-0.2 cm from the renal surgical margin, but there are no identified sarcomatoid features, necrosis, or vascular invasion. The histologic grade is classified as Fuhrman grade 2, and both the lymph adipose tissue and renal parenchymal margins are negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with glioblastoma multiforme in the right temporal lobe following surgical excision of a necrotizing brain lesion. Microscopic examination reveals a highly vascularized and anaplastic tumor with areas of coagulation necrosis, pleomorphic neoplastic cells, and atypical mitosis. Immunohistochemical staining shows a gliofibrillary index of 10-11%, confirming the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous carcinoma, moderately differentiated, with a tumor size of 6.7 cm, involving the deep and new deep margins, as well as the lateral, posterior, and superior margins of the specimen. Metastatic squamous carcinoma was identified in 3 of 17 lymph nodes, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 3.7 cm, and evidence of extracapsular soft tissue invasion was noted. Additionally, the carcinoma has invaded the bone of the maxilla and undermined the respiratory mucosa of the maxillary sinus, with extensive lymphovascular invasion present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade III endometrial cancer, specifically endometrioid carcinoma, with tumor extension into the superficial myometrium but no involvement of the endocervical canal or lower uterine segment. A total of 18 lymph nodes were examined, all of which were negative for metastatic carcinoma, and surgical margins were clear. Additional findings included focal endometriosis in the left ovary and uterine serosa, as well as adenomyosis and leiomyomata in the myometrium, with no other malignancies identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a choroidal melanoma in the right eye, characterized predominantly by fusiform cells and a low mitotic index. The tumor measures 10 mm and infiltrates the internal third of the sclera and the intraocular emergence of the optic nerve, but there is no extrascleral extension or involvement of the optic foramen, post laminar section, or meningeal sheaths. Additionally, the iris, ciliary body, and anterior chamber are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 2.5 cm clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade II. The tumor focally involves the inked capsular resection margin, but the parenchymal resection margin is negative for tumor. The overall staging is pT1a, indicating the tumor is confined to the kidney and measures 4 cm or less.

The pathology report indicates a clinical diagnosis of a brain tumor, with gross examination revealing gray-yellow pieces of the left frontal lobe. Microscopic analysis shows brain tissue consistent with diffuse astrocytoma, characterized by nuclear polymorphism and a Ki-67 proliferation index of up to 5%. The final diagnosis is diffuse astrocytoma, classified as Grade II.

The pathology report indicates the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4 (total score 9), showing extensive extraprostatic extension and invasion of the left seminal vesicle, while the right seminal vesicle is free of tumor. No tumor was found in any of the six examined lymph nodes, and there is focal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia present. The tumor exhibits characteristics of signet-ring cell-like adenocarcinoma and shows perineural infiltration, with a negative margin status for the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated astrocytoma, grade II, occurring in a background of cortical dysplasia. Microscopic examination reveals a mildly to moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm that infiltrates both white and gray matter, with features such as focal perineuronal satellitosis and a predominance of gemistocyte-like tumor cells. Atypia is noted to be mild to moderate, with no mitotic activity observed in the examined fields.

The pathology report indicates the excision of a 4.5 cm cardiac paraganglioma, which was confirmed as a tumor with a firm nodular structure and a weight of 21 grams. Microscopic examination revealed that the tumor cells were positive for chromogranin and negative for pancytokeratin, with no signs of necrosis or increased mitosis. The pre-operative and post-operative diagnoses were consistent, confirming the presence of a cardiac paraganglioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, tall cell variant, in a 1.4 cm tumor located in the right lobe of the thyroid, with evidence of invasion into perithyroidal fibroadipose tissue and positive surgical margins. The biopsies from the jugular node, right paratracheal lymph node, and Delphian node all revealed benign fibroadipose tissue, with no lymphoid tissue identified. Additional findings include marked stromal reaction and calcification of a non-psammoma type, while no mitotic activity or tumor necrosis was observed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme in a right frontal brain tumor biopsy. Microscopic examination reveals pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, areas of necrosis, and vascular proliferation, consistent with a malignant glioma. Special stains confirm the absence of sarcoma-like features, and the proliferation index is noted to be 15 to 20%.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic adenocarcinoma involving the appendix, right ovary, and mesenteric fat, with a primary diagnosis of FIGO grade III endometrial adenocarcinoma that invades the myometrium. The right ovary is entirely replaced by tumor, and there is lymphovascular invasion present, while the cervix and left ovary show no evidence of tumor. Immunohistochemical staining confirms the metastatic nature of the adenocarcinoma, with negative results for estrogen and progesterone receptors.

The pathology report indicates a 2.8 cm invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with angiolymphatic and visceral pleural invasion, but all sampled lymph nodes are benign and surgical resection margins are free of tumor. The pathologic stage is classified as T2N0MX. Additionally, there is evidence of chronic inflammation and submucosal scarring in the respiratory mucosa, along with background emphysematous changes in the lung.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary contains a mature cystic teratoma and the left ovary has a benign serous cystadenoma, both with associated benign findings in the fallopian tubes. The sigmoid colon and upper rectum show an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that invades the muscularis propria, but all resection margins and regional lymph nodes are negative for metastatic disease. Overall, there is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the examined specimens.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes from the left neck, with one positive node each in levels I, II, and III, while levels IV and the right neck dissection levels I, II, III, and IV show no tumor involvement. A partial glossectomy reveals a moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, with perineural and vascular invasion present, but negative margins for invasive carcinoma. Overall, the findings suggest a diagnosis of metastatic squamous carcinoma primarily originating from the tongue.

The pathology report indicates that the pancreatic duct margin shows squamous metaplasia and chronic inflammation with no evidence of malignancy, while the common duct margin also exhibits chronic inflammation without malignancy. However, the Whipple contents reveal the presence of ductal adenocarcinoma, classified as grade 2, with tumor invasion into the ampulla of Vater, duodenal wall, and peripancreatic soft tissue, and involved margins. Pathologic staging shows the primary tumor as pT3, with regional lymph node involvement (pN1) in 7 out of 26 examined nodes, and additional findings include pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia III and acute and chronic pancreatitis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with focal mucinous differentiation, classified as FIGO grade II, and shows significant myometrial invasion and lymphovascular space invasion. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, including right and left para-aortic, left obturator, and external iliac nodes, all of which were negative for malignancy. The tumor involves the lower uterine segment and has a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 9 mm, with no regional lymph node metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive high-grade mixed urothelial carcinoma and small cell carcinoma in the bladder, with metastasis found in four of eleven right pelvic lymph nodes. The report also notes the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma with focal extraprostatic extension, while the left pelvic lymph nodes and left distal ureter show no evidence of tumor. Overall, the findings suggest advanced disease with significant local invasion and lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates the excision of a 2 x 1.5 x 0.3 cm squamous cell carcinoma, keratinizing, located in the distal esophagus, with a histologic grade of moderately differentiated. The tumor extends into the muscularis propria, but there is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/7 positive). The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there are no specified findings regarding lymphatic or venous invasion or neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma of the uterus, classified as poorly differentiated (FIGO grade 3), with tumor invasion through the full thickness of the myometrium and serosal involvement. There is evidence of bilateral peritubal and ovarian metastatic involvement, but no metastatic carcinoma was identified in the examined lymph nodes. The final staging is pT3a, pNO, and FIGO stage IIIA, with negative margins at resection.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland, with the tumor measuring 6 x 6 x 3.8 cm and weighing 101 g. There is no evidence of invasion into extra-adrenal tissues, lymphovascular or blood vascular involvement, and no tumor necrosis was identified, suggesting a benign nature. The surgical margins are clear, and the adrenal gland away from the tumor shows no significant histologic abnormalities, with the tumor classified as AJCC Stage pT2 pNx pMx.

The pathology report indicates a lobectomy specimen from the right upper lung, revealing a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.2 x 2.5 x 3 cm. Details regarding tumor extent, other nodules, lymph nodes, and invasion are not specified. There is no information provided about margins or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated type 2 papillary renal cell carcinoma with significant necrosis, bleeding, and cholesterol crystal accumulation. The tumor is encapsulated but has extensions into the perirenal fat, while the ureter and surgical margins are free of tumor. The classification shows it as stage pT1b, grade G3, with local resection margins clear of residual tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right-sided multicentric, poorly differentiated invasive ductal breast carcinoma with multiple foci, the largest measuring 3 cm, and associated with high-grade intraductal carcinoma featuring comedo necrosis. The surrounding tissue shows signs of mastopathy, including sclerotic changes, papillomatous scleradenosis, microcalcifications, and cystic mastopathy, while the overlying skin and nipple are free of tumor involvement. The tumor classification is M-8500/3, G 3, pT2 (m), pN1a (2/25), pMX, stage IIB, with clear resection margins (R0).

The pathology report indicates the presence of a unifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma measuring 1.5 x 1.5 x 1.3 cm in the right lobe of the thyroid gland. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, extension beyond the thyroid gland, or involvement of the surgical margins. Additionally, one benign parathyroid gland was identified in association with the carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 9.3 cm poorly differentiated, focally keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the right lung, which has invaded the pleura and ribs, with direct extension into the chest wall. No malignancy was detected in any of the examined lymph nodes (0/12), and there is evidence of lymphatic invasion, although there is no vascular invasion noted. The tumor is classified as pT3, indicating significant local invasion, while distant metastasis could not be assessed.

The histopathological examination of a total organ resection of the rectum and sigmoid colon revealed a 3.3 x 3.4 x 0.7 cm ulcerous tubular adenocarcinoma (G2) that infiltrated the surrounding mesorectal adipose tissue. The tumor was found to surround 100% of the intestinal circumference, with clear margins at the incision lines, but there were metastases identified in regional lymph nodes. The final diagnosis is tubular adenocarcinoma of the rectum with regional lymph node metastases, classified as Dukes C and Astler-Coller C2.

The pathology report indicates that both left axillary sentinel lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma, while one right axillary sentinel lymph node shows isolated tumor cells. Infiltrating lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade I, is identified in both breasts, with the left breast tumor measuring 0.9 x 0.7 x 0.5 cm and the right breast tumor measuring 12.5 x 6.3 x 2.2 cm, both with negative surgical margins. Lobular carcinoma in situ is present in both breasts, and there is no evidence of ductal carcinoma in situ or angiolymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, with a tumor size of approximately 6 x 5.2 cm and limited to the liver without perineural invasion. The gallbladder shows mild chronic cholecystitis, and the margins of the liver resection are free of tumor, although angiolymphatic invasion is present. The pathological stage is classified as T2 NX MX, indicating the extent of the liver tumor without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma in the left breast, with a Nottingham combined histologic grade of 2 and a tumor size of 4.1 cm, showing no lymphovascular invasion or involvement of the nipple or skin. Two out of seven examined axillary lymph nodes were positive for metastatic carcinoma, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 0.7 cm and no extracapsular extension identified. The tumor is classified as pT2 pN1a, corresponding to AJCC stage IIB, and shows positive estrogen and progesterone receptor status, while HER2/neu is negative.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas, measuring 4.3 x 3.5 x 3.1 cm, with extension into surrounding soft tissue, the duodenal wall, and the bile duct, while both angiolymphatic and perineural invasion are absent. The uncinate margin is positive for invasive carcinoma, and multiple regional lymph nodes show metastatic adenocarcinoma, with a final classification of AJCC pT3N1. Other examined lymph nodes and margins are largely negative for tumor, and there is evidence of chronic pancreatitis and chronic cholecystitis in the adjacent tissues.

The pathology report indicates that a left adrenalectomy was performed, with the specimen measuring 10 x 8 x 8.5 cm and weighing 196 grams. The diagnosis is adrenocortical carcinoma, confirmed by reference pathology. The tumor has a Weiss score of 6, a Hough score of 3.9, and a Van Slooten score of 9, indicating a high-grade malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, eosinophilic type, with a nuclear grade of 2, measuring 2.2 cm, following a partial nephrectomy of the left lower pole. The tumor is classified as pT1a and is pathologically staged as I, with a focally positive renal parenchymal margin (R1) but no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Additional findings include patchy glomerulosclerosis and chronic inflammation in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma) from a left lower abdominal wall mass, measuring 6.4 cm. The tumor exhibits high-grade characteristics with more than 10 mitoses per 10 high power fields and 10% necrosis, while surgical margins are clear, with the closest margin showing a clearance of 0.2 cm. Histological examination reveals marked cytological atypia, nuclear pleomorphism, and numerous bizarre cells, consistent with the diagnosis of high-grade sarcoma.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left ureter biopsies show no neoplastic process, while the urinary bladder biopsy reveals poorly differentiated invasive urothelial carcinoma measuring 7.5 cm, with full thickness invasion of the bladder wall but no lymphovascular invasion or involvement of perivesical adipose tissue. Additional findings include benign conditions in the uterus, cervix, and right ovary, with no neoplastic processes identified in the pelvic lymph nodes. The tumor is staged as pTNM T2bN0 according to AJCC cancer staging criteria.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which is ulcerated and infiltrating into the detrusor muscle, measuring 9.5 cm. The cancer has compromised segments of both the right and left ureters and the prostate, but the perivesical fat and seminal vesicles are uninvolved, along with all examined obturator lymph nodes. Angiolymphatic and perineural invasion are present, but there is no evidence of neoplasia in the urethral stump or lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of primary endometrial cancer, specifically endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation, classified as FIGO grade 3. The tumor shows superficial myometrial invasion with no serosal, cervical, or adnexal involvement, and lymphovascular space invasion is focally present; however, all examined regional lymph nodes are negative for tumor. Additional findings include extensive adenomyosis, and the tumor is estrogen receptor positive and progesterone receptor negative, with an AJCC pathologic stage of pT1a pN0, corresponding to FIGO stage IA.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver, specifically in segment 4, with a well-defined mass measuring 1.8 x 1.6 x 1.5 cm and no evidence of vascular invasion or satellite nodules. The tumor is classified as Edmondson-Steiner grade IV, with partial capsule formation and capsular infiltration noted. Additionally, the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis and cholesterolosis, with no significant findings reported in the remaining liver parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (SBR Grade 2) in the left breast, measuring 1.5 cm, with a satellite tumor of 0.2 cm and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present. The sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla were negative for metastases, and the additional superior margin showed usual ductal hyperplasia without evidence of carcinoma. Estrogen and progesterone receptors are positive, while HER2 is not amplified, and the Oncotype DX recurrence score is 23, suggesting a moderate risk of distant recurrence.

The pathology report indicates that the cervical biopsy reveals invasive, poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, and the tumor measures 1.0 cm. The bladder biopsy shows squamous metaplasia without dysplasia and is negative for carcinoma, containing abundant blood clot and benign epithelial cells. There is no muscle tissue present in the bladder biopsy, consistent with the absence of muscularis propria.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies from the right lower parathyroid, right paratracheal node, and left lower parathyroid showed no pathological diagnosis, while the total thyroidectomy revealed a 1.1 cm papillary carcinoma of the oncocytic variant in the right lobe. The tumor is classified as pT1b, with no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, perineural invasion, or extrathyroidal extension, and the margins are uninvolved by carcinoma. Additionally, the parathyroid glands were reported to be within normal limits, and no regional lymph node metastasis was identified.

The pathology report indicates that both the right and left obturator lymph nodes show no malignancy, while the prostate biopsy reveals adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4). The tumor exhibits perineural extension but no vascular or lymphatic invasion, and all surgical margins are free of tumor involvement. The prostatectomy specimen shows multiple firm areas consistent with tumor presence, but lymph nodes were not involved by metastasis.

The pathology report describes a hypercellular neoplasm primarily composed of glial cells and large, atypical neurons, raising the possibility of ganglioglioma, but lacking definitive features such as eosinophilic granular bodies. The tumor exhibits a diffusely invasive architecture with dystrophic calcifications and a focally prominent angiocentric growth pattern, while showing variable MIB-1 activity indicative of both low and higher-grade proliferation. The final diagnosis is anaplastic astrocytoma grade III.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a right frontal brain tumor, with multiple specimens submitted for analysis. Microscopic examination reveals that all samples consist of well-differentiated oligodendroglioma, classified as WHO Grade II. The findings include neoplastic cells with specific nuclear characteristics and evidence of focal calcification and perineuronal satellitosis.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the fundus of the stomach, measuring 5 x 6 x 1.2 cm and exhibiting ulcerated, annular features. The tumor has extended to the serosa but shows no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/6 positive). Surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no specified evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma in both lobes of the thyroid, with a larger tumor measuring 3.8 cm in the right lobe and a smaller one in the left lobe measuring less than 0.1 cm. There is no definitive lymphovascular invasion identified, and the surgical margins are grossly free of tumor. The report includes a detailed gross description of the thyroidectomy specimen, noting the characteristics of the tumors and the surrounding tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, with the tumor measuring 3.2 x 2.5 x 1.9 cm and classified as NHG2. Immunohistochemical analysis shows over 75% positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 testing reveals a negative reaction in invasive cancerous cells. Additionally, metastases were identified in the axillary lymph nodes, confirming the presence of cancer spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO Grade III, in a left temporal tumor, characterized by moderately pleomorphic neoplastic astrocytes and the presence of mitotic figures. Immunohistochemical staining shows positive Ki67 in up to 10% of tumor cell nuclei, with no evidence of tumor necrosis or endothelial proliferation. Additional specimens were analyzed, confirming the presence of an astrocytic neoplasm consistent with anaplastic astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade II, affecting the pelvic mass, both ovaries, and showing serosal involvement in the fallopian tubes. The hysterectomy specimen reveals intralymphatic foci of metastatic serous adenocarcinoma, along with benign endocervical polyps and leiomyomata. Overall, the findings suggest a significant tumor burden in the pelvis and peritoneum, raising the possibility of a primary peritoneal origin with metastatic involvement of the ovaries.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bilateral papillary thyroid carcinoma, with a larger 2.5 cm tumor in the right lobe and a smaller 0.8 cm tumor in the left lobe, both confined within the thyroid capsule. There is evidence of lymphovascular invasion and metastasis to five of eight examined lymph nodes in the central compartment. Margins are uninvolved by carcinoma, and additional findings include hyperplastic nodules and normal parathyroid glands.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two foci of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with the dominant mass measuring 1.9 cm and a satellite focus measuring 0.6 cm, both showing no lymphovascular invasion. The tumor is classified as Nottingham grade 2, with a cribriform type ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) constituting 10% of the total tumor volume, and one sentinel lymph node is positive for metastatic tumor with focal extracapsular extension. Estrogen and progesterone receptors are positive, while HER2 is negative, and surgical margins are focally involved by the invasive component.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in the endometrium, with invasion into the outer half of the myometrium and evidence of lymphovascular invasion. While the cervix, tubes, and ovaries are mostly negative for tumor, a microscopic focus of serous intraepithelial carcinoma was found in the right tube, and peritoneal washings were positive for malignant cells consistent with serous carcinoma. Additionally, there is noted ovarian stromal hyperplasia, and the overall examination of the reproductive organs shows a distorted endometrium due to a significant papillary lesion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with tumor invasion exceeding half of the myometrium and a maximum thickness of 11 mm, but no endocervical or vascular invasion noted. Among the lymph nodes examined, two out of nine left external iliac and one out of four left para-aortic lymph nodes were positive for metastatic carcinoma, while all other lymph nodes were benign. Additionally, a left abdominal wall lipoma was identified as benign.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder and portal lymph node specimens are negative for malignancy, while the right liver specimen shows hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 7.3 x 6.0 x 5.8 cm, located 0.9 cm from the liver resection margin. Additionally, there are foreign body type reactions in numerous intrahepatic vessels, likely due to an embolic procedure, along with background liver changes including focal microsteatosis and portal lymphocytic inflammation. Clinical correlation is required to assess the significance of the inflammation and the overall findings.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast specimen shows two foci of invasive lobular carcinoma, both well-differentiated (Nottingham histologic grade 1), with one measuring 1.5 cm and the other 3.5 cm, and margins are widely free from invasive carcinoma. Additionally, micrometastasis is present in one of the sentinel lymph nodes, while another lymph node contains isolated tumor cells, and the third lymph node shows no evidence of tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals strong positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors, low Ki-67 proliferation index, and negative HER2 overexpression, with further evaluation pending for HER2 gene copy levels.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of ulcerated infiltrative poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with focal signet rings, classified as diffuse type adenocarcinoma of the stomach, following a partial gastrectomy. The tumor measures 2.6 x 2.5 cm and extends to the inked serosal margin of resection, with multiple foci of tumor present in the perigastric adipose tissue and omentum, and three out of 23 lymph nodes showing positivity, including one with extracapsular extension. The proximal margin of resection is negative, while the radial margin is positive, and the remaining stomach shows focal intestinal metaplasia and inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, with oncocytic features, arising in a parasitic nodule of the thyroid, measuring 5 cm in greatest diameter. The tumor is well-differentiated with mild to moderate mitotic activity, completely encapsulated, and shows no evidence of capsular or blood vessel invasion, nor extrathyroid extension, with surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, a separate focus of papillary microcarcinoma measuring 0.35 cm was identified in the right lobe, alongside non-neoplastic nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis in the remaining thyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive urothelial carcinoma of the anterior bladder wall, classified as high grade. The tumor exhibits a papillary growth pattern and has invaded the muscularis propria, although vascular invasion was not identified. The specimen was received in Hanks solution and consists of multiple portions of pink-tan shaggy rubbery tissue, with all tissues submitted for further examination.

The pathology report describes a 7x5x2 cm ulcerated tumor located in the antrum-pylorus of the stomach, characterized by a firm, myxoid gray surface. Microscopic examination reveals the tumor is a poorly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma with invasion into the serosa, featuring pools of extracellular mucin and malignant epithelial structures, including signet ring cells. The tumor exhibits hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei with prominent nucleoli and mitotic activity.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type, measuring up to 4.5 cm, with significant infiltration into surrounding pericolic fatty tissue and extensive lymphatic spread. There are thirty-two regional lymph node metastases identified, but the resection margins of the large intestine and mesentery are tumor-free. The tumor is classified as pT3 pN2 (32/40) pMX; G3; L1, V0, RX, indicating advanced disease with a high grade of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the left renal mass was diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 2.8 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located near the Bauhin's valve and cecum, with infiltration into the surrounding adipose tissue. The tumor-free margins suggest complete resection, but there are four regional lymph node metastases identified. The tumor is classified as pT3, indicating advanced local invasion, with a grade of G2 and a local R0 resection status.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right breast invasive poorly differentiated ductal carcinoma, measuring 2.4 cm, with no evidence of metastatic tumor in the sentinel and non-sentinel lymph nodes examined. The left breast shows atypical ductal hyperplasia without atypia, along with benign changes. Immunohistochemical staining reveals the invasive carcinoma to be ER-negative, PR-positive, and HER2-negative, with no involvement of surgical margins or skin by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.0 cm, with surgical margins that are uninvolved. There is evidence of venous and arterial invasion, but no lymphatic invasion or positive regional lymph nodes, as all nine examined lymph nodes are negative for metastasis. Additionally, granulomatous inflammation is noted in some lymph nodes, but no infectious organisms were detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of ciliochoroidal malignant melanoma in the right eye, confirmed through enucleation, with a tumor height of 18 mm and no scleral involvement.
