The tumor is classified as spindle cell melanoma (pG1) and shows a mitotic rate of 6 per 40 high power fields, with negative findings for vascular invasion and inflammatory cells. Cytogenetic analysis revealed no dividing cells, but FISH results were positive for gains in chromosome 3 and cmyc, indicating an unusual finding.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the left and right pelvic lymph nodes, with all examined nodes showing no evidence of malignancy. The prostate gland was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma, exhibiting unilateral extension into the extraprostatic soft tissue, with a Gleason score of 7/10 and perineural invasion present. The tumor was staged as pT3a, with no involvement of seminal vesicles or positive margins at the prostate, soft tissue, urethra, and bladder neck.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the urinary bladder, with extensive invasion into surrounding tissues and multiple lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement. Additionally, the left ovary shows stromal hyperplasia, while the right ovary and fallopian tube do not contain any tumor tissue. The peritoneal nodule contains microscopic metastatic foci of urothelial carcinoma, alongside benign ovarian epithelial cysts.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 3.0 cm. The tumor extends through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia, with no evidence of renal vein invasion and free surgical margins. The overall staging is classified as pT3a, indicating local invasion without metastasis beyond the perinephric tissues.

The pathology report indicates that the left simple mastectomy revealed intraductal apocrine ductal carcinoma with lobular cancerization and rare foci of invasion, alongside a separate mass of intraductal and infiltrating ductal carcinoma. Both sentinel lymph nodes were negative for tumor, and the excisional biopsy margins were free of tumor with no evidence of blood vessel or lymphatic invasion. The invasive carcinoma was classified as grade III, with no expression of estrogen or progesterone receptors, and Her2/neu antigen results are pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with focal spindle cell features and a nuclear grade of III/IV, measuring 8.0 cm in greatest diameter, and extending through the renal capsule but confined within Gerota's fascia. The report notes that there is no invasion of the renal vein, all surgical margins are free of tumor, and a small angiomylipoma was also identified. Additionally, nine paracaval lymph nodes were examined, all of which were benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma involving the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes, with extensive metastatic spread to the omentum, umbilicus, sigmoid colon, bladder peritoneum, and distal pancreas. The tumor is classified as poorly differentiated (G3) and shows significant serosal and soft tissue involvement, with no evidence of malignancy in the examined lymph nodes. The overall staging is T3c/NO/MX, indicating macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in the right posterior section of the liver, measuring 6.5x4.9x4.5 cm, with a trabecular/pseudoglandular histologic type and classic cell type. The tumor exhibits the worst differentiation (2/4) and shows evidence of vascular invasion, but no satellite nodules, tumor necrosis, or intrahepatic metastasis are present. Additionally, there is active cirrhosis associated with HBV, and the surgical margins are free with a safety margin of 3 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a high histological grade glioma (WHO Grade IV) in the left occipital lobe, characterized by extensive infiltration of glial cells with significant nuclear pleomorphism and anaplasia. The tumor exhibits features consistent with glioblastoma multiforme, including mitotic figures and microvascular proliferation, but no necrosis is noted. Additionally, the MIB-1 labeling index is reported at 21%, suggesting a moderate level of cellular proliferation within the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of lung cancer, specifically a 2.5 cm invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe, associated with visceral pleural and angiolymphatic invasion, while all sampled lymph nodes were benign and surgical margins were free of tumor. Additionally, a 0.6 cm typical carcinoid tumor was identified in the right middle lobe, along with numerous carcinoid tumorlets and neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia throughout the right lung lobes. Molecular testing revealed no mutations in KRAS or EGFR, and fluorescence in-situ hybridization studies indicated no EGFR amplification, suggesting a pathologic stage of T2N0Mx for the adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the left temporal mass biopsy reveals a glioblastoma with sarcomatous features, classified as a gliosarcoma, characterized by neoplastic proliferation of glial cells, extensive necrosis, and high mitotic activity. Immunohistochemical analysis shows a positive MGMT promoter methylation status, suggesting potential benefit from alkylating agent therapy. The findings highlight the aggressive nature of the tumor, with significant cellularity and vascularity, and the absence of neuronal elements.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated intestinal type adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 8 cm, with invasion into the subserosa and features of necrosis. Fifteen examined lymph nodes show no evidence of metastasis, and there is no venous invasion or involvement of margins. The tumor is ulcerated and adheres to the fatty tissue of the omentum, which exhibits fibrosis and hyperemia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in lymph nodes, with the left paratracheal tissue showing a 0.2 cm focus and the central lymph node showing a 0.5 cm focus. A total thyroidectomy revealed multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma involving both lobes, with the largest nodule measuring 1.7 cm and evidence of tumor extension to the cauterized margins. Additionally, a parathyroid adenoma was identified adjacent to the right thyroid lobe, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as IVA due to the extent of the disease.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade spindle cell neoplasms in both the omentum and mesentery, suggestive of dedifferentiated liposarcoma, with sizes of 17.5 cm and 36.5 cm respectively. Both specimens show similar characteristics, including 50% necrosis, 30% hemorrhage, and a mitotic rate of 3 per 10 high-power fields. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis, revealing a positive staining profile for CD99, MDM-2, and CDK4, although MDM2 and CDK4 staining is noted to be weak and focal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right mandible, with the tumor measuring 5.3 cm and invading the mandibular bone. All examined lymph nodes (64 in total) showed no evidence of malignancy, and the surgical margins were free of invasive carcinoma. Additional findings included focal severe squamous dysplasia in the right maxillary alveolus and chronic inflammation in the floor of the mouth margins, with no evidence of carcinoma in those areas.

The pathology report indicates a left upper lobectomy revealing a moderately and poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 35 mm, with no visceral pleural invasion and a clear bronchial resection margin. Focal vascular and lymphatic invasion is present within the tumor, but the peribronchial and hilar lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy. Additionally, the residual lung exhibits moderate to severe emphysema and areas of scarring and organizing pneumonia.

The pathology report indicates a unifocal papillary carcinoma located in the left thyroid gland, measuring 2.5 x 2 x 1 cm. There is no evidence of extrathyroidal extension. The thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level is reported at 0.8 mclU/ml.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Type II papillary renal cell carcinoma, nuclear grade 3, located in the left kidney and ureter, with a tumor size of 15 cm and limited to the kidney. The tumor exhibits necrosis and lymph-vascular invasion, but the margins appear uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, suggesting no capsular invasion despite capsular disruption noted grossly. Pathologic staging is pT2b pNX, and correlation with clinical findings is recommended due to the presence of necrotic tumor at the surface.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 9.5 cm and surgical margins free of tumor (R0). The tumor is classified as Grade 2 and staged as pT2a, with no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or regional lymph node involvement (pNX). The overall pathologic stage is II, and the findings in the non-neoplastic kidney are unremarkable.

The final diagnosis indicates a malignant fibrous histiocytoma (pleomorphic type) of the right retroperitoneum, measuring 17.0 x 11.0 x 5.5 cm, with resection margins free of tumor. The right kidney exhibited focal interstitial pyelonephritis, but no tumor was found in the right ureter, right adrenal gland, or liver tissues. Immunohistochemical stains were negative for S-100, NSE, and CD-68, and there was evidence of tumor extension to perinephric fat without involvement of the kidney itself.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of epithelioid cell melanoma from a skin flap taken from the right leg. The melanoma measures 4x3 cm with a thickness of 2 cm, exhibiting ulceration and classified as Stage III, T4, N2, MO. The Breslow depth is 20 mm, and the Clark level is IV.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma involving a lymph node and a total thyroidectomy specimen showing multifocal papillary carcinoma in the left lobe, measuring 4.0 cm. The tumor has invaded regional lymph nodes, with metastatic carcinoma found in 11 of 14 lymph nodes, and the primary tumor is classified as pT3 due to its size and minimal extrathyroidal extension. Additionally, the margins are involved by invasive carcinoma, and there is evidence of venous and lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an invasive poorly differentiated carcinoma consistent with a breast primary, affecting both the pectoralis muscle and the right breast, with a tumor size of 19 cm and a histologic grade of 9 (grade III). The invasive ductal carcinoma involves all quadrants of the breast and shows significant features such as skin ulceration, dermal lymphatic invasion, and involvement of the skeletal muscle, with invasive carcinoma identified at the deep margin. Ancillary studies for hormone receptor status have been ordered, and the pathologic tumor stage is classified as pT4d NX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma (Type 1) in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 8.0 x 8.0 x 5.0 cm and the presence of tumor necrosis. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with negative margins for renal vein, renal sinus, renal capsule, perinephric adipose tissue, and ureter, and no lymphovascular invasion or additional pathologic findings identified. The histologic grade is II, and the pathological stage is classified as pT2a pNX.

The pathology report indicates that a left adrenal gland was removed via laparoscopic adrenalectomy due to a pheochromocytoma weighing 109 grams. The tumor is well-circumscribed and encapsulated, with no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or residual adrenal tissue, and surgical margins are free of pheochromocytoma. The specimen shows a variegated orange/yellow to tan/brown cut surface, and representative sections have been submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma in a partial sigmoid colon resection, measuring 3.5 cm and invading all layers of the intestinal wall, with extension to adjacent mesocolic fatty tissue. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN1, with one out of 26 lymph nodes showing metastasis, while the resection margins are tumor-free. Additionally, the colon exhibits several pseudodiverticula and signs of chronic scarring due to peridiverticulitis.

The pathology report describes a lung tumor measuring 12 x 10 cm, identified as a moderately differentiated muciparous adenocarcinoma, which occupies approximately two-thirds of the lower lobe and is associated with necrosis and hemorrhage. Microscopic examination reveals tubular-papillary structures with moderate cellular pleomorphism, and the presence of lymphatic and venous invasion, while lymph nodes show metastasis in the paraesophageal node and reactive changes in others. The report indicates that the tumor has not invaded the surgical margins, and there is evidence of moderate interstitial fibrosis and emphysema in the pulmonary parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph node from the mesenteric root is tumor-free, and the resected transverse colon shows a locally advanced, poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma that has penetrated all layers of the wall and invaded surrounding tissues, but there are no regional lymph node metastases. The spleen is also tumor-free, although it has some iatrogenic defects to the capsule. Further analysis for hereditary predisposition to HNPCC (Lynch Syndrome) revealed no indications of such a condition.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 4.2 x 4.0 x 2.2 cm, with poor differentiation and significant tumor necrosis. The carcinoma has invaded the cervix and parametrial soft tissue, with lymphovascular invasion present, and one of three examined lymph nodes shows metastatic carcinoma. The surgical margins are negative, but the invasive carcinoma is very close to the anterior and posterior parametrial margins, and there is no definitive vaginal involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic squamous carcinoma in 1 of 3 lymph nodes from the submental triangle and in 1 of 5 lymph nodes from the left neck, with extranodal extension of the tumor present. Additionally, a marginal mandibulectomy specimen reveals deeply invasive keratinized squamous carcinoma, moderately differentiated, extending to the skin with perineural invasion, although the margins are free of tumor. All sections of bony mandibular tissue examined are free of carcinoma, and no tumor is present in the examined nerves or lip margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (NHG1, pT1c, pNO) in the right breast, with a tumor size of 1.2 x 10 x 1.0 cm located in the outer lower quadrant. Immunohistochemical analysis shows over 75% of neoplastic cells expressing estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 testing reveals a negative reaction in invasive cancerous cells. Additionally, chronic lymphadenitis with histiocytosis is noted in the axillary lymph nodes, and fibrocystic changes are observed in the glandular tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 2.5 cm poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, with evidence of angiolymphatic and visceral pleural invasion, and metastatic adenocarcinoma present in multiple lymph nodes. Molecular testing revealed no mutations in KRAS, EGFR, or EML4/ALK, which are significant for treatment implications. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the pathologic stage is classified as T3N2Mx.

The pathology report indicates a rectal resection specimen with fully developed diverticulosis and an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (G2) extending into the perirectal fat, classified as pT3. Tumor-free margins were noted, and the previously reported infiltration of the posterior bladder wall was not detected microscopically. Additionally, out of 30 lymph nodes examined, 18 showed metastatic infiltrates, resulting in a staging of pT3 pN2 (18/30).

The pathology report indicates a lumpectomy specimen from the left upper outer quadrant of the breast, revealing a 2.4 cm lobular carcinoma that is moderately differentiated. Out of 10 examined lymph nodes, 1 showed positive metastasis, while the surgical margins are reported as uninvolved. The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic counts.

The pathology report indicates that a 40 mm low-grade adrenal cortical carcinoma was found in the right adrenal gland, which was incidentally discovered during a laparoscopic right adrenalectomy. The tumor meets three of the Weiss criteria for malignancy but is confined to the adrenal gland with no evidence of invasion into adjacent tissues. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis, showing a low proliferative index and specific markers consistent with adrenal cortical origin.

The pathology report indicates a total thyroidectomy with a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma, well differentiated, located primarily in the right lobe with a size of 2.1 cm and partially encapsulated. There are also two foci of papillary microcarcinomas in the left lobe measuring 0.8 cm and 0.9 cm, with one of four perithyroidal lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the remaining thyroid tissue exhibits severe chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a high-grade muscle invasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, measuring 2.5 cm, which has invaded the muscularis propria but shows no lymphatic or vascular invasion. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and all examined lymph nodes (20 total) are negative for metastatic disease. Additional findings include atrophic endometrium, inclusion cysts in the ovaries, and no significant abnormalities in the uterus, cervix, or fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma with extensive metastatic involvement in multiple sites, including the right and left ovaries, fallopian tubes, omentum, sigmoid colon, and regional lymph nodes. The right ovary shows nearly total replacement by carcinoma, while the left ovary is subtotally replaced, with both fallopian tubes exhibiting secondary tumor involvement. Additionally, there is significant lymphovascular invasion noted throughout the involved tissues, suggesting aggressive disease progression.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated, partially mucinous colorectal adenocarcinoma located at the base of a tubulovillous adenoma with severe dysplasia, measuring 2 cm in diameter and extending up to 5 cm to the resection margin. There are also small remnants of tubular adenomas with mild to moderate dysplasia found 4 cm from the resection margin. The resection margins and 18 examined mesocolic lymph nodes are tumor-free, leading to a final tumor stage of pT1 pNO (0/18) LO V0 R0; G2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous carcinoma of the right oral tongue, with the tumor located approximately 1.0 mm from the deep resection margin and extensive perineural invasion noted. Metastatic squamous carcinoma was identified in 2 of 4 left level II neck lymph nodes and in 1 of 7 level III lymph nodes, with extranodal extension to adipose tissue present. The bilateral neck dissection revealed no tumor in 18 left level I axillary lymph nodes and other lymph nodes in the right neck regions, while the palatal and anterior mucosal margins showed no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph node biopsy from the ST11 interlobar region is negative for malignancy, while the right lower lobe lung resection reveals an invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with no pleural or vascular invasion identified, but lymphatic permeation present. The resection margins are negative for tumor, and two examined lobar lymph nodes are also negative for malignancy. Additionally, there is patchy non-specific chronic inflammation and organizing pneumonia noted in the lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of residual pleomorphic undifferentiated sarcoma in a re-excised soft tissue mass from the right thigh, with a largest tumor size of 9 mm and a grade of 3. The surgical margins are free of tumor, with the closest margin being 3 mm from the tumor at the superior aspect. The specimen shows a well-circumscribed and encapsulated growth pattern, with no lymph nodes present in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an Anaplastic Oligodendroglioma, WHO Grade III, in the left frontal lobe, characterized by infiltrating glioma with hyperchromatic nuclei and increased mitotic activity. Genetic analysis revealed co-deletions of chromosomes 1p and 19q, which are associated with a better prognosis and response to chemotherapy in oligodendroglial tumors. The tumor cells tested positive for mutated isocitrate dehydrogenase-1 (IDH1) and showed a Ki-67 labeling index of 15-20%, indicating increased proliferative activity.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent resection of a celiac artery paraganglioma, which exhibited multifocal extension to the specimen edges, focal vascular and capsular invasion, and high cellularity. Immunohistochemical analysis showed strong positivity for Chromogranin and synaptophysin, with negative cytoplasmic staining for SDHB, suggesting a potential germline mutation. The lymph node biopsy revealed fibroadipose tissue with no evidence of tumor or lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy from the left occipital subcortical region reveals a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, classified as grade IV astrocytoma. The specimen was examined microscopically, showing hypercellular glial proliferation with gemistocytic cells, enlarged nuclei, and areas of necrosis and vascular proliferation. The report includes multiple samples submitted for further analysis, confirming the presence of this aggressive brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates that there are no tumors present in the left and right pelvic lymph nodes, as well as in the anterior bladder neck tissue. However, prostatic adenocarcinoma was identified in the prostate, with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3), and the tumor is confined to the prostate with free margins of resection. Additionally, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) and perineural invasion were noted, but no vascular or lymphatic invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 7 cm, with neuroendocrine features and negative margins. No tumor was found in the examined lymph nodes from levels 5, 7, 9, and 11, as well as in the portion of the 6th rib. Immunohistochemical staining shows the tumor is negative for chromogranin and synaptophysin, and focally positive for CD56.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, classified as Grade III. The specimen consisted of small gray pieces from the right frontal lobe, measuring approximately 4x2x1.5 cm. The Ki67 proliferation index was noted to be 8%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as grade 3. The tumor is staged as T2 N0 M0, indicating a primary tumor with no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered, and a normal blood sample was also collected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated papillary serous carcinoma involving both ovaries, with a left ovarian mass measuring 5.0 cm and right ovarian mass measuring 3.0 cm, along with surface involvement and invasive characteristics. Multiple lymph node biopsies from various regions, including external iliac, obturator, common iliac, and periaortic nodes, were negative for tumor, indicating no lymphatic spread. The overall staging is pT3c, pNo, pMX, corresponding to FIGO stage IIIC, suggesting advanced ovarian cancer with peritoneal involvement but no lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper and middle lobes of the lung, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm. The neoplasm is confined to the pulmonary parenchyma, abutting the visceral pleura, but shows no lymphovascular invasion, and the bronchial and vascular margins are free of neoplasm. One peribronchial lymph node shows anthracosis without evidence of metastatic carcinoma, and the tumor is classified as AJCC stage pT2a, NO.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right renal mass diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 2.0 cm, but without local or renal vein invasion, and with free surgical margins. Additionally, the retroperitoneal lymph nodes were found to be free of carcinoma but involved by chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma. The overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is pT1, indicating the tumor is limited to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation in the bladder, which is invasive into the outer half of the muscularis propria, measuring 3.2 x 2.3 x 1.3 cm. All examined lymph nodes (25 total) from both left and right pelvic dissections show no evidence of tumor (0/25). Resection margins, including those of the ureters and soft tissue, are negative for tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with bronchioloalveolar features in the right upper lobe, measuring 4.2 cm, which abuts but does not invade the visceral pleura, with clear margins and one of seven perihilar lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement. The tumor is classified as T2, N1, MX in the TNM staging system, and the histopathologic grade is G1. Additionally, four peribronchial lymph nodes and seven periaortic/peri-azygos lymph nodes were examined and found to be benign, with no evidence of neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a wedge resection of the left lower lobe lung, revealing a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with no visceral pleural invasion and uninvolved margins at 1.6 cm from the tumor. The frozen section diagnosis was confirmed by permanent section analysis, and the tumor is classified as stage IB according to the AJCC 7th edition. Additional findings include tumor necrosis and thick-walled parenchymal blood vessels, with no lymph-vascular invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, in the right breast, with two masses and no angiolymphatic invasion, while the tumor does not involve the nipple or surrounding tissues, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor. Metastatic carcinoma is present in two of three right axillary non-sentinel lymph nodes, with one showing focal extracapsular extension, while sentinel lymph nodes are negative for metastasis. The left breast tissue examined shows benign changes with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left frontal brain tumor diagnosed as a mixed oligoastrocytoma (WHO II), characterized by a glial neoplastic proliferation with mixed oligodendroglial and astrocytic features, and rare mitotic figures. Additionally, the loss of heterozygosity on chromosome arms 1p and 19q was detected, which is typical for oligodendrogliomas, while no evidence of methylated MGMT promoter was found. The findings suggest a diffusely infiltrating tumor without anaplastic features, although increased cellularity and rare mitoses may indicate a heightened biological potential.

The pathology report indicates that the precaval lymph nodes are negative for malignancy, confirming no cancer spread (0/1). The right renal mass, measuring 2.9 cm, is diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, with a nuclear grade of 3, but shows no evidence of necrosis or vascular invasion, and the surgical margins are clear by at least 0.3 cm. The overall pathologic staging for the renal tumor is classified as pT1a.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive lobular carcinoma of the right outer breast, classified as poorly differentiated (Nottingham Grade 3) with a tumor size of 3.2 cm and positive margins. Additionally, 23 out of 23 examined axillary lymph nodes were positive for metastatic carcinoma, with evidence of extracapsular extension in multiple nodes. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor negative, and HER2 negative, with a pathologic stage of pT2 N3a.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left modified radical mastectomy due to left breast cancer, which was diagnosed as infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 4.0 by 3.5 by 3.0 cm, with a poor histologic grade and moderate nuclear grade. The tumor involved the subareolar and nipple lymphatics, as well as the dermis and dermal lymphatics, with an intraductal component comprising 10% of the tumor. Additionally, out of thirteen lymph nodes examined, twelve contained metastatic tumor with significant perinodal extension in six nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segment 7, measuring 3.5 cm, along with a 2 cm cavernous hemangioma. Additionally, there is evidence of chronic hepatitis B with mild steatosis and minimal portal inflammation. The tumor is confined to the liver with negative surgical margins, and there is no vascular invasion or multifocality noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of predominantly poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate, with significant perineural invasion and left rectolateral extraprostatic growth, measuring a maximum spread of 2.2 cm. There is evidence of micrometastasis in one of two lymph nodes, with a maximum spread of 1.9 mm, while the seminal vesicles are tumor-free. The tumor classification is pT3a, pNlmi (1/4), L0, V0, with a Gleason score of 4+3 = 7, indicating a predominance of Gleason pattern 4.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous carcinoma of the endometrium, which arises from an atrophic polyp and shows significant myometrial invasion and vascular invasion, while the surrounding endometrium exhibits complex atypical hyperplasia. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma is identified in several lymph nodes, including the left external iliac, left common iliac, left obturator, and left hypogastric lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes are reported as benign. The omentum and both ovaries and fallopian tubes are also noted to be benign.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, which has invaded both seminal vesicles and shows extensive extraprostatic extension. There are suspicious crushed cells at the bladder margin, but definitive diagnosis regarding malignancy cannot be established due to crush artifact. All examined pelvic lymph nodes (10 total) are negative for tumor involvement, suggesting no lymphatic spread of the cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, which invades into but not through the muscularis propria, with final surgical margins free of involvement. No carcinoma was identified in any of the examined lymph nodes, and the splenic nodule is consistent with an accessory spleen, showing no significant pathological abnormalities. Additionally, there is gastric atrophy with extensive intestinal metaplasia noted in the stomach.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, measuring 3.5 cm, with negative margins for malignancy. Metastatic carcinoma was found in three out of fourteen hilar lymph nodes, while additional lymph nodes excised from levels 5, 7, and 9 were negative for tumor. There is no evidence of pleural invasion or vascular invasion, and distant metastasis is not applicable.

The pathology report indicates that a brain tumor specimen, measuring 3.9 x 3.3 x 2.0 cm, was submitted for frozen section analysis, revealing a diagnosis of malignant glioma, suspected to be glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV astrocytoma). The tumor exhibits significant nuclear and cellular pleomorphism, mitotic activity, vascular endothelial proliferation, and areas of pseudopalisading necrosis. Immunohistochemical staining shows that most tumor cells are reactive for GFAP and reticulin, supporting the diagnosis of glioblastoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the abdominal wall, anterior abdominal peritoneum, small bowel, mesentery, both ovaries and fallopian tubes, cul-de-sac tumors, uterus, cervix, and omentum. The tumors exhibit extensive involvement and extension into surrounding tissues, particularly noted in the right fallopian tube and ovary. Additionally, there are areas of transitional cell carcinoma and other benign findings such as endometrial polyps and leiomyomas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of colonic adenocarcinoma in a segment of the sigmoid colon and upper rectum, with a tumor size of 3.2 cm and a grade of 2 out of 3. The carcinoma invades into the muscularis propria but does not penetrate through it, and the margins of resection are negative for malignancy. Additionally, there is no evidence of malignancy in any of the 30 examined pericolonic lymph nodes, resulting in a pTNM stage of T2 N0.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a dedifferentiated liposarcoma arising from a well-differentiated liposarcoma in the left retroperitoneum, which measures 31 x 20.5 x 7.5 cm and involves the subserosal colonic fat and the renal capsule. The intestinal resection margins are free of tumor, and the sigmoid colon specimen shows no tumor presence, with one benign lymph node identified. Overall, the findings suggest a malignant tumor with significant involvement of surrounding tissues but clear margins in the resected bowel.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes show no significant pathological abnormalities, while the uterus contains a high-grade papillary serous carcinoma measuring 3.2 x 2.7 cm with myometrial invasion and focal involvement of the cervix. All excised lymph nodes from various regions, including external iliac and obturator nodes, are negative for metastatic disease, and the omentum is also negative for malignancy. The overall pTNM stage is pT2, NO (FIGO: II), indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report describes a total organ resection of the stomach due to a clinical diagnosis of gastric cancer, revealing an 8 x 7.5 x 4 cm tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma that infiltrates the full thickness of the stomach wall and surrounding tissues. The tumor is classified as G2, pT2b, with neoplastic spread noted at the distal incision line, while the proximal line and omentum are free of cancerous infiltration. Immunohistochemical examination shows a positive reaction for HER2 protein in the invasive cancerous cells, indicating a score of 0.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma (GBM) in the brain, characterized by necrotic and viable tumor areas, with evidence of malignant glioma infiltration, necrosis, and microvascular proliferation. The MGMT promoter methylation test returned negative, indicating no evidence of methylation, which may have implications for treatment options. Microscopic examination revealed astrocytic proliferation and active cell cycling, with extensive phagocytic cell collections and rich vascularity.

The pathology report indicates that there is no tumor present in multiple lymph nodes biopsied, while metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in three of eighteen lymph nodes and one perigastric lymph node. The primary tumor, a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, is located at the gastroesophageal junction with evidence of angiolymphatic and perineural invasion, but the surgical margins are free of tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis for HER2 shows equivocal results, and FISH testing indicates no amplification of the HER2 gene.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma (Grade 3) in the uterus, with a tumor size of 6.0 cm and cervical involvement noted. All examined lymph nodes (18 left pelvic, 1 left aortic, 16 right pelvic, and 2 right caval) were negative for metastasis. Additionally, endosalpingiosis was identified in the right gutter implant, and adenomyosis was noted in the uterus.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation in the bladder, along with extensive vascular and perineural invasion, and involvement of the urethra and prostatic ducts. Multiple lymph nodes from the right and left common iliac and pelvic regions show metastatic disease, with extranodal extension identified in some nodes. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3, indicating invasion of perivesical soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical cystoprostatectomy with extended pelvic lymphadenectomy, revealing invasive moderate to poorly differentiated papillary transitional cell carcinoma in the bladder, with perineural and lymphovascular invasion, but no malignancy in the prostate or urethral margins. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in multiple lymph nodes, including all examined para-aortic, left common iliac, and right common iliac lymph nodes, among others. The final diagnosis includes a pathologic TNM stage of T3aN2MX, with a total of 97 out of 140 lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma, with multiple lymph nodes involved: one of seven right pelvic lymph nodes, one of one left pelvic lymph node, two of five additional right pelvic lymph nodes, and two of fourteen left pelvic lymph nodes showing metastasis. The bladder and prostate specimens reveal high-grade invasive papillary urothelial carcinoma and prostatic adenocarcinoma, with extensive vascular invasion and multifocal tumor distribution. The report also notes that the right distal ureter shows no evidence of tumor, and the prostatic adenocarcinoma is confined to the prostate with a Gleason score of 3+3.

The pathology report indicates that the axillary lymph node contains tissue fragments consistent with primary mediastinal diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, characterized by a diffuse growth pattern and anaplastic cell morphology. Immunophenotyping reveals that the neoplastic cells are positive for several markers including CD20 and BCL2, while being negative for CD10 and CD3. Additionally, the Ki-67 proliferative index is high at 90%, and in situ hybridization for Epstein-Barr virus RNA is negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated papillary adenocarcinoma of the lung, with a tumor size of 12x4x8 cm and localized extent. One of the examined lymph nodes showed metastasis, while venous invasion was absent and margins were uninvolved. The report also notes the presence of sinus histiocytosis in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that multiple excised lymph nodes from various levels showed no evidence of tumor, while a left upper lobe lung excision revealed a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 7.0 cm, with negative surgical margins and no lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, the adjacent lung parenchyma exhibited organizing pneumonia with BOOP-like features, but no tumor was identified in that area. The overall pathologic staging for the lung tumor is pT2bN0Mx, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3, measuring 10.5 cm, and confined to the kidney without evidence of invasion into surrounding structures. The tumor is present within vascular and lymphatic spaces in the renal sinus, but all resection margins, including ureteral, vascular, and soft tissue margins, are free of tumor, as well as the adrenal gland and perinephric lymph node. Additionally, ten retroperitoneal lymph nodes were examined, and no tumor was found in any of them.

The pathology report indicates that sixteen left pelvic lymph nodes were excised and found to be negative for metastatic disease, while one of twenty right pelvic lymph nodes was positive for metastatic carcinoma. The uterus and bilateral adnexa were removed, revealing a 5.5 x 4.0 cm non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a depth of invasion of 1.5 cm and focally present lymphovascular space invasion. Surgical margins were negative for tumor, and the overall pTNM stage is pT1b2 N1.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left partial nephrectomy revealing two foci of papillary renal cell carcinoma, measuring 5.0 cm and 2.2 cm, with tumor grades of 3 and 2, respectively. The adrenal gland and peri-nephric soft tissue showed no evidence of tumor involvement, and the resection margins were negative for cancer. The final staging of the tumors is pT1bNXMX, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon, characterized by extensive anaplastic areas and a high histopathological grade of G3 to G4. The tumor shows ulcerations, necrosis, and infiltration into the colon wall, reaching the subserous fatty connective tissue, along with evidence of carcinomatous lymphangiosis and moderate chronic lymphadenitis in tumor-free lymph nodes. The tumor staging is classified as pT3, pN2, MX, L1, R0, with clear margins and no tumor present in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the tumor is located in the left frontal region. The histological diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme. This diagnosis suggests a highly aggressive and malignant brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated infiltrating lobular carcinoma (Grade II/III) in the left breast, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and negative margins. The tumor exhibits positive estrogen receptors and weakly positive HER2/NEU, while the progesterone receptors are negative. Additional findings include lobular carcinoma in situ, florid usual ductal hyperplasia, and various benign changes, with no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma with features of carcinoma in situ, infiltrating the prevesical fat layer, but with tumor-free surgical margins. The uterus shows atrophic corpus endometrium without atypical figures, and both the endocervix and ectocervix are free of dysplasia. The tumor is classified as pT4a, with a grade of G3, and the R-classification indicates local resection margins are clear.

The pathology report indicates a left breast incisional biopsy revealing poorly differentiated carcinoma with extensive vascular invasion, and no in situ carcinoma present. The tumor exhibits features consistent with lobular carcinoma, but lacks an in situ component. Portions of the tissue have been submitted for estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4 and a tumor size of 16.0 cm, showing invasion into the renal vein but not into surrounding adipose tissue or Gerota's fascia. The AJCC staging is pT3a pN1, with metastatic renal cell carcinoma identified in one of fifteen lymph nodes examined. Surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement, and the tumor is described as unicentric and confined to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two tumors in the right kidney, both diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma with features of papillary RCC type 1, exhibiting solid and clear cell areas. Tumor #1 measures 1.1 x 1.1 cm, while Tumor #2 measures 2.5 x 2.2 cm, with both specimens submitted for further analysis. A supplemental report may follow after discussion of the case.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma in the omentum, along with bilateral papillary serous adenocarcinoma (FIGO Grade III) in both the right and left ovaries and tubes. The tumors in the right ovary and left ovary measured 4.5 x 3.7 x 2.0 cm and 5.0 x 3.8 x 3.2 cm, respectively, with both serosas involved and additional findings of metastatic tumor. The report concludes that the patient underwent a bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and omental biopsy, with a pathological stage of pT3c pNx pMX.

The pathology report indicates that the endometrial biopsy shows benign dyssynchronous secretory endometrium with no evidence of hyperplasia or carcinoma. The cervical and endocervical specimens demonstrate cellular changes within normal limits, with some inflammation and the presence of endocervical cells, while bladder washings and urine samples are reported as benign. Additionally, the left breast mastectomy reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in situ, with clear resection margins and no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, in the left kidney following a radical laparoscopic nephrectomy. The tumor measures 8.8 cm, has a Fuhrman grade of 2, and is confined to the kidney without extension into surrounding fat or evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and the uninvolved renal parenchyma is unremarkable, with a pathologic stage of T2NxMx.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total thyroidectomy due to a left thyroid nodule, which was found to be a well-encapsulated papillary thyroid carcinoma. Additionally, two lymph nodes from the left level VI were excised and found to be positive for metastatic carcinoma consistent with papillary thyroid carcinoma. The thyroid tissue also showed a background of lymphocytic thyroiditis, and the carcinoma was noted to be closely approaching the inked margin.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in the left and right pelvic peritoneum, as well as the right fallopian tube, while the left tube and ovary show no evidence of malignancy. The uterus contains a serous adenocarcinoma, classified as FIGO Grade 3, with vascular invasion and positive tumor extension to the serosal surface. The overall pathological stage is pT3a pNX pMX, indicating advanced disease with metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, in the left breast, measuring 1.9 x 1.8 x 1.2 cm, with a Nottingham score of 7/9. Additionally, there is a presence of ductal carcinoma in situ, comprising approximately 5-25% of the tumor volume, but no angiolymphatic invasion is noted. All surgical margins are negative for tumor, and multiple left axillary sentinel lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the left temporal tumor is diagnosed as a gemistocytic astrocytoma, WHO grade 2, characterized by neoplastic gemistocytes and a small component of grade 2 fibrillary astrocytoma. The tumor shows no mitoses or necrosis, and the Ki67 proliferation index is approximately 2%, suggesting a relatively low proliferation rate. Immunohistochemical studies confirm strong positivity for p53 and patchy weak staining for Bcl2, consistent with the diagnosis of gemistocytic astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a Whipple procedure for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, which is moderately to poorly differentiated and measures 2.5 cm, with involvement of the pancreatic surgical margin and peripancreatic soft tissue. Four out of ten examined lymph nodes show metastatic involvement, with focal extracapsular extension, while the common bile duct margin is free of tumor. Additionally, the gallbladder specimen shows mild acute and chronic inflammation but no malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast specimen shows invasive ductal carcinoma, grade III, measuring 4.3 cm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of high nuclear grade, with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the examined sentinel lymph nodes. All sentinel nodes and additional lymph nodes from the right axilla were found to be benign, with no positive lymph nodes identified. The tumor is located in the upper-outer quadrant of the breast, and there is no involvement of the nipple or surgical margins by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly-differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma measuring 4 cm, with invasion into the epiglottic cartilage and hyoid bone, and extending to the inked tissue edge in the right parapharyngeal area. Multiple lymph nodes from the submental triangle and right level 1 were examined, with no tumor detected in any of the three nodes from the submental triangle and two nodes from right level 1. Additionally, squamous carcinoma was found in the right deep parapharyngeal, right superior parapharyngeal, and right parapharyngeal regions, while mild dysplasia was noted in the left parapharyngeal area without invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma (type 1) in a right renal mass, with a tumor size of 2.1 cm and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of II. The tumor is unifocal, confined to the kidney, and shows no evidence of necrosis, sarcomatoid features, or lymphatic/vascular invasion, with negative margins except for a disrupted area noted during surgery. The overall staging is classified as Stage I, with immunohistochemical studies supporting the diagnosis.

The pathology report confirms the presence of papillary thyroid carcinoma, specifically the follicular variant, in the right lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 1.3 cm and focal invasion into peri-thyroid tissue, while the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, two separate foci of papillary microcarcinoma were identified in the left lobe, measuring 0.15 cm and 0.1 cm, with no evidence of vascular invasion or necrosis. The parathyroid biopsy revealed benign parathyroid tissue, and one benign lymph node was noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with anaplastic oligoastrocytoma (WHO Grade III) in both the medial temporal and posterior brain regions. The tumor exhibits moderately pleomorphic cells with perineuronal satellitosis, and molecular studies show negative results for 1p and 19q loss of heterozygosity, while the MGMT promoter is methylated. The Ki-67 labeling index is approximately 12%, suggesting a moderate level of proliferation within the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that both the right upper and left lower parathyroid biopsies showed no pathological diagnosis, while the total thyroidectomy revealed multifocal papillary carcinoma in the right thyroid lobe, with the dominant tumor measuring 4.7 cm. The report also identified a second tumor in the isthmus, classified as a microcarcinoma, with no evidence of capsular invasion or lymph-vascular invasion. Overall, the margins were uninvolved by carcinoma, and there was no evidence of extrathyroidal extension or regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary urothelial carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 2.6 cm. The tumor is classified as stage T3 and the nodal involvement is classified as NX, indicating that regional lymph nodes were not assessed. The report confirms that the tumor was resected.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has left breast invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 3.0 cm, with a low combined histologic grade and negative surgical margins. Sentinel lymph node biopsies revealed one node with macrometastatic carcinoma (9 mm) and another with micrometastatic carcinoma (1 mm), while an additional non-sentinel lymph node was negative for tumor. Overall, the findings suggest a pT2 N1a stage of breast cancer with no evidence of extensive disease in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right renal mass diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the conventional clear cell type, with a nuclear grade of III/IV, measuring 9.4 cm and confined within the renal capsule without invasion of the renal vein. Additionally, three paracaval lymph nodes were excised and found to be benign, and the right adrenal gland showed no evidence of tumor, appearing benign. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the surrounding kidney tissue shows chronic inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a tumor measuring 5.7 cm and classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 2. The carcinoma is confined to the kidney, with all surgical margins negative for carcinoma and no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. Additionally, there is chronic interstitial inflammation and glomerulosclerosis noted in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cecum with deep infiltration into the perimuscular fatty tissue, classified as G3, pT3. The resection margins are tumor-free, and a hyperplastic polyp was found in the ascending colon. Additionally, all 40 examined lymph nodes are microscopically tumor-free, leading to a final staging of pT3 pNO (0/40) LO V0 R0.

The pathology report indicates a well-differentiated Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma, Type I, measuring 3.6 cm in diameter. The tumor is confined to the kidney with no evidence of invasion into the surrounding parenchyma, classified as stage pT1a. The tumor is graded as GII, with no regional lymph node involvement (pNX) or distant metastasis (pMX).

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a thymectomy, revealing a thymoma classified as WHO type B2. The tumor was noted to breach the capsule, but there was no definitive invasion into the surrounding peri-thymic adipose tissue. The specimen consisted of a well-circumscribed lesion with a homogeneous pale tan cut surface, and adjacent uninvolved tissue was also examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the prostate, with a Gleason score of 6/10 and positive inked margins at the right posterior prostate. Examination of the pelvic lymph nodes revealed no tumor in any of the four nodes assessed, and there was no evidence of lymphatic invasion, although perineural invasion was present. The report suggests further clinical correlation is needed due to the presence of a disrupted positive margin, but no extraprosthetic invasion was observed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly-differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma in the right ovary, with evidence of hemorrhagic ischemic necrosis and metastatic adenocarcinoma in the right fallopian tube. The left ovary showed a serous cystadenofibroma without any tumor, while the appendix and small intestine exhibited acute inflammation and hemorrhagic adhesions, with the small intestine showing foci of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Overall, the findings suggest advanced ovarian cancer with peritoneal involvement, classified as FIGO stage IC.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a mucinous adenocarcinoma, signet ring cell type, located in the right colonic segment, with extensive invasion into the subserosal tissue and a tumor size of 7.0 x 7.0 x 5.0 cm. The circumferential margin is less than 0.05 cm from the tumor, but the surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and there is no evidence of malignancy in the examined pericolic lymph nodes (0/13). The pathologic staging is pT3N0Mx, indicating that the tumor invades through the muscularis propria into the subserosa, with no regional lymph node metastasis detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma and lobular carcinoma in situ of the left breast, with metastases identified in the axillary lymph nodes. The tumor measures 2.2 x 1.5 x 1.3 cm and is classified as NHG 2, with a pT2 and pN1a staging. Immunohistochemical examination shows a low proliferation index (5% Ki 67 positive) and negative E-cadherin expression in neoplastic cells.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO grade III) from a biopsy of the left frontal lobe. Immunohistochemical analysis showed strong overexpression of p53 protein and positivity for the mutant IDH1 (IDH1 R132H), indicating the presence of an IDH1 mutation. The preliminary frozen section consultation suggested an intermediate grade glioma, which aligns with the final diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates diffuse involvement of the omentum by high-grade serous carcinoma, characterized by numerous psammoma bodies, with no primary tumor mass identified in the uterus, cervix, or ovaries. The carcinoma shows myometrial invasion and is present on the serosal surfaces of the fallopian tubes, left ovary, bladder peritoneum, terminal ileum, and appendix, suggesting a likely diagnosis of high-grade primary peritoneal serous adenocarcinoma. The patient's clinical history includes elevated CA125 levels, omental caking, and carcinomatosis, leading to a comprehensive surgical procedure that included total hysterectomy and tumor debulking.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has cholangiocarcinoma, moderately differentiated (grade 2 of 4), with two masses in the left lobe of the liver, measuring up to 1.5 cm, and additional foci of infiltrating carcinoma. The tumor is confined to the hepatic parenchyma with negative margins and no evidence of major vessel or microscopic invasion. Additionally, the lymph nodes and left hepatic duct margin are negative for tumor, and the gallbladder shows benign chronic inflammation.

The pathology report indicates that the left temporal lobe biopsy reveals an anaplastic gemistocytic astrocytoma, characterized by a diffusely infiltrating tumor with hypercellularity, nuclear pleomorphism, and a mild degree of vascular endothelial hyperplasia. The tumor shows a mixed composition of gemistocytic and undifferentiated cells, with a proliferation index of approximately 12% as indicated by the MIB-1 immunostain. There is no evidence of necrosis, and the tumor cells are strongly positive for GFAP.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma, with metastatic involvement in all examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions, as well as extensive invasion through the uterus, cervix, and adnexa. The tumor primarily originates in the endometrium, with significant myometrial invasion and lymphovascular space invasion noted, leading to a staging of pT3a pN1 and FIGO Stage IIIC1. Additional findings include multiple leiomyomas and no ovarian surface involvement, although there is evidence of parenchymal invasion in one ovary.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of III and a maximum dimension of 3.6 cm, confined to the kidney without invasion through the renal capsule or involvement of the renal sinus. There is a probable non-occlusive carcinomatous thrombus in an interlobar renal vein, but all surgical margins are free of neoplasm. The patient also has a confirmed metastasis of renal cell carcinoma in the right humerus, leading to a pathologic stage of pT3 NX M1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, characterized by a tumor size of 4.1 x 3.5 x 1.5 cm and a Nottingham grade II (moderately differentiated). Lymphatic invasion is present, with two out of eighteen examined sentinel lymph nodes showing metastasis, and extranodal extension noted. Hormone receptor status reveals strong positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 is negative.

The pathology report indicates that the left kidney mass is diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, eosinophilic variant, measuring 2.6 cm, with surgical margins involved by cancer, while the right kidney mass is identified as an oncocytoma, measuring 1.4 cm, with negative surgical margins. Both resection beds from the left and right kidneys show mild chronic interstitial inflammation but no evidence of malignancy. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnoses, with the left kidney lesion positive for CD117 and CK7, and the right kidney lesion positive for CD117 but negative for vimentin and CK7.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of advanced gastric adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated, with serosal invasion and a tumor size of 10.0 x 6.0 x 1.6 cm located in the lower third of the stomach. Lymph node analysis revealed metastatic carcinoma in 4 out of 49 inferior gastric lymph nodes, while no tumor was found in the superior gastric lymph nodes or other regional lymph nodes examined. The pathological stage is classified as pT4bN2Mx, indicating extensive local invasion and regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional type, with a histologic grade of 2 out of 4 and a tumor size of 3.4 cm. There is no evidence of tumor invasion into surrounding structures, including the renal vein, ureter, or adjacent organs, and surgical margins are clear. Additionally, an incidental finding of a 0.2 cm papillary adenoma was noted, with no lymph nodes present in the examined tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 8.0 x 7.2 x 7.0 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade 2. The tumor is unifocal with microscopic capsular invasion and positive microscopic involvement of the renal vein and large vessels, while margins and lymphatic vessels are negative for tumor. The AJCC pathologic staging is pT3a pNx, and the report notes mild arteriolonephrosclerosis in the non-neoplastic kidney.

The pathology report indicates that a total organ resection of the stomach was performed on a female patient, with a diagnosis of gastric cancer. The microscopic examination revealed a tubular adenocarcinoma (G2, intestinal type) with metastases present in lymph nodes along both the lesser and greater curvature of the stomach. The final histopathological diagnosis confirms the presence of adenocarcinoma of the stomach with lymph node involvement (pT2, pN2).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 1.5 cm, showing no local or renal vein invasion, and free surgical margins. Additionally, a second specimen from the deep margin revealed benign renal parenchyma with marked chronic inflammation. The overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is pT1, indicating the tumor is confined to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (grade 1 of 4) in the liver, with a dominant mass measuring 14.5 x 10.5 x 10.0 cm and multiple satellite nodules, all confined to the liver and with negative resection margins. Additional smaller nodules of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma were identified in segments VI, VIII, and IVB, while segment VII showed no definitive lesion. The gallbladder showed mild chronic cholecystitis, and further staining is planned to confirm the findings related to the reticulin network and mucin presence.

The histopathological examination of a resected sigmoid colon revealed an 8 x 5 x 1.5 cm invasive tubular adenocarcinoma, which surrounds 55% of the intestinal circumference and invades the periintestinal tissue. The tumor is classified as G2, with a minimum side margin of 0.1 cm, and the incision lines are free of neoplastic lesions. The final diagnosis is tubular adenocarcinoma of the colon, categorized as Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2, pT3, pNO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma (Grade 2/3) primarily located in the left fundus and lower uterine segment of a didelphic uterus, with a maximum tumor size of approximately 6 x 4 x 1.2 cm and myometrial invasion of up to 1.5 cm. The cervix, ovaries, and fallopian tubes are negative for carcinoma, and all examined pelvic lymph nodes (17 total) are also negative for cancer. The report notes the presence of endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia and leiomyomata in the remaining myometrium, with no lymphatic or vascular invasion detected.

The pathology report indicates that several lymph nodes excised from various locations showed no significant pathologic change, except for one lymph node which exhibited lymphoid hyperplasia. An excisional biopsy of the right lower lobe of the lung revealed poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma that involved the pleura but did not extend to the pleural margin, with the bronchial margin being free of tumor. Additionally, one out of eight examined lymph nodes showed granuloma formation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, in the right kidney following a radical nephrectomy, with the tumor measuring 9.0 cm and exhibiting a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 out of 4. The carcinoma has invaded the renal vein and extends beyond it, with involved margins indicating residual tumor presence. Additionally, the non-neoplastic kidney shows signs of chronic interstitial inflammation, glomerulosclerosis, and arteriosclerosis, and the pathological staging is classified as pT3a.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows signs of chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis, with no evidence of malignancy. The right kidney specimen reveals a conventional clear cell renal carcinoma measuring 6.5 x 5.5 x 5.4 cm, with lymphovascular invasion present but no transcapsular or renal vein invasion identified. Surgical margins are free of malignancy, and the tumor is classified as pT1b Nx Mx.

The pathology report indicates a partial nephrectomy of the right kidney revealing a Grade 2 papillary renal cell carcinoma, measuring 3.1 x 3.0 x 2.8 cm, which is confined to the kidney with negative surgical margins. Additionally, an excisional biopsy of the right chest shows infiltrating Grade 3 carcinoma consistent with a breast primary, located within a previous biopsy site and involving the dermis and subcutaneous tissue, but with negative margins following re-excision. Coagulative tumor necrosis and sarcomatoid differentiation are absent in the kidney tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a mediastinal mass was diagnosed as a grade 2 leiomyosarcoma, measuring 9.5 cm, with necrosis present and margins involved by the tumor. The pleural biopsy showed fibroadipose tissue with muscle, which was negative for malignancy, while the right rib specimen was received for gross analysis only. The tumor exhibited significant nuclear pleomorphism and a mitotic count of 8 per 10 high-power fields, with no lymph-vascular invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a right frontal brain mass identified as oligodendroglioma, Grade 2 (WHO). The specimen analysis revealed low-intermediate grade infiltrating glioma, with additional findings showing loss of chromosomal arms 1p and 19q, which may suggest a more favorable response to adjuvant therapy. The report includes both gross and histologic descriptions of the brain mass, with samples submitted for further research studies.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has esophageal adenocarcinoma, with a tumor measuring 2.2 cm located at the gastroesophageal junction, which shows moderate differentiation and extends into the adventitia. Both the initial surgical margin and the true margin at the staple line are free of tumor, and all examined lymph nodes (13 in total) are negative for malignancy. The report also notes the presence of perineural invasion, while lymphovascular invasion is not observed, leading to a pathological staging of pT3 N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates a sigmoid colectomy specimen with an 8.5 x 4.5 x 1.5 cm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the sigmoid colon. The tumor has extended into the pericolonic tissues, but there is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/8 positive). Margins and additional pathologic findings were not specified, and there is no indication of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The final diagnosis from the radical cystectomy report indicates the presence of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma with significant glandular components, measuring 6 x 4 x 2.5 cm, which extends through the bladder wall into surrounding tissues. No urothelial dysplasia or malignancy was identified in the ureters, ovaries, cervix, or in any of the 65 lymph nodes examined, all of which were free of malignancy. The pathological TNM stage is reported as pTisT3bN0Mx, and additional sections for p53 assay are pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 5.4 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade 2. There is no evidence of sarcomatoid features or capsular invasion, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement. The tumor is classified as pT1b, indicating it is confined to the kidney without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report confirms the diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO IV) in a patient who underwent craniotomy for resection of a right parietooccipital tumor. The specimen shows features of astrocytic anaplasia, neoplastic mitotic activity, and areas of necrosis with microvascular pseudopalisading. Immunohistochemical analysis indicates a MIB-1 proliferation index of 16%, consistent with a high histological grade glioma.

The pathology report describes a bladder tumor that is a poorly differentiated carcinoma with a solid growth pattern, invading the muscularis propria and showing features of high-grade malignancy. There are laminated layers of keratin indicating squamous differentiation, along with large areas of necrosis, but no transitional urothelium or vascular invasion is identified. The tumor is classified as G3 pT2, and it remains uncertain whether it is a transitional carcinoma with squamous differentiation or a primary squamous carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that four excised pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of carcinoma. A radical prostatectomy reveals invasive prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, confined to the prostate without extraprostatic extension, and involving approximately 20% of the prostate volume. Additionally, there is perineural invasion present, but all surgical margins and bilateral seminal vesicles are free of tumor, with no lymph node involvement detected.

The pathology report describes a right adrenal pheochromocytoma, characterized by a 180-gram mass measuring 9.4 x 5.5 x 4.5 cm, with the mass itself measuring 7.2 x 6.9 x 3.5 cm. The cut surfaces of the mass are soft, spongy, and heterogeneous, displaying yellow to brown coloration with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. The adjacent adrenal gland shows a bright orange cortex and a brown medulla, confirming the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma based on the examination of the submitted sections.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, from an excisional biopsy of the left parietal brain region. Microscopic examination reveals a high-grade astrocytoma with features such as microvascular proliferation and necrosis, while immunostains show up-regulation of laminin beta 1 and down-regulation of laminin beta 2, suggesting a more aggressive tumor behavior. The report emphasizes the importance of clinical correlation and literature review in guiding therapy, as the test results have limitations in their predictive value for treatment outcomes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the omentum, originating from the uterus, with significant involvement of the cervical stroma and endometrium. The endometrial tumor is classified as FIGO stage 3A serous adenocarcinoma, with 60% surface involvement and 20% invasion into the myometrium, along with chronic cystic cervicitis and multiple leiomyomas. All examined lymph nodes are free of tumor, but peritoneal cytology is positive for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma located in the right colon or transverse colon, with a tumor size of 2.5 x 2.3 x 1.0 cm. The tumor invades into but does not penetrate the muscularis propria, and all surgical margins are uninvolved by carcinoma, with the closest margin being 3 cm away. No lymphovascular or peri-neural invasion is observed, and the small intestine is negative for tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates that the right axillary sentinel lymph node biopsy is negative for metastatic carcinoma. The right breast segmental mastectomy reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 2, measuring 1.8 cm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) constituting 15% of the total tumor volume, with negative surgical margins. Additionally, the invasive tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER-2/neu, while surrounding breast tissue shows benign changes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic mullerian-derived carcinoma in multiple specimens, including the omentum, ovaries, fallopian tubes, and various soft tissue sites. Both ovaries are significantly involved with grade III primary ovarian adenocarcinoma, and there is extensive lymphovascular invasion noted. Additionally, while some lymph nodes show reactive changes, one node is positive for metastatic carcinoma, confirming the widespread nature of the disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant melanoma of the skin, specifically the nodular type, with significant ulceration and a Breslow thickness of 75 mm. The tumor measures 2.2 x 1.7 x 7.5 cm and shows infiltration into fat tissue and muscles, along with moderate lymphocytic infiltration. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals HMB45 positivity in a few cells, while other markers are negative, and the proliferation index (Ki67) is 50%.

The intraoperative examination of a lesion in the right breast revealed invasive ductal carcinoma (carcinoma ductale invasivum) with a size of 2.5 x 1.5 cm and associated ductal carcinoma in situ, characterized by high nuclear atypia and comedo necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis showed no estrogen or progesterone receptors, and HER2 gene amplification was not found, although a FISH verification was recommended due to a score of 2+. The final diagnosis indicates invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast classified as G2, pT2, with normal tissue margins noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as Nottingham grade 3, with a tumor size of 2.7 cm and negative surgical margins. The right axillary sentinel lymph node biopsy showed no evidence of neoplasm, with 0 out of 1 lymph node positive for cancer. Additional findings include atypical ductal hyperplasia, fibrocystic changes, and fat necrosis in the breast tissue, with the tumor being positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER-2/neu.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 2 x 1.5 x 3 cm, with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. There is no lymph node metastasis, as all 24 examined nodes were negative. The tumor extent is less than 4.0 cm, and there is no specified evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left upper lobectomy due to moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with the tumor measuring 5.5 x 3.5 x 3.0 cm and negative bronchial margins. All examined lymph nodes (2R, 4R, 10L, and 11L) were negative for tumor involvement, and the anterior superior mediastinal margin also showed benign tissue without malignancy. The pathological staging is pT2, N0, Mx, indicating no lymph node involvement and no distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total hysterectomy revealing endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, measuring 2 cm with FIGO grade 1, and showing myometrial and cervical stromal invasion, but no lymphovascular space invasion. The tumor has a depth of invasion of 10 mm into the myometrium, which is 50% involved, and adenomyosis is also present. The fallopian tubes and ovaries showed no diagnostic alterations, and the overall pathologic staging is classified as pT2, with negative margins for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a gastrointestinal stromal tumor in the small intestine and metastatic urothelial carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with varying degrees of involvement. The radical cystectomy specimen reveals high-grade urothelial carcinoma with mixed histologic features, including micropapillary and signet ring cell types, and shows local invasion into perivesical soft tissues. Surgical margins are positive for tumor, and vascular and perineural invasion are identified, indicating an advanced stage of disease (pT3).

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated papillary serous carcinoma in both the right and left ovaries, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm in the left ovary and a high mitotic rate. Metastatic disease is noted in the small bowel, omentum, and outer mural lymphatics of the uterus, with a pTNM stage of T3c. The uterus shows no pathological diagnosis in the cervix and inactive endometrium, along with benign endometrial polyps and leiomyomas in the myometrium.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe, measuring 10 cm, with bronchial margins free of tumor and positive peribronchial lymph nodes (3 out of 14). All examined lymph nodes from various levels (4L, 2R, level 7, and level 11) were reactive and negative for tumor. The report also notes that the rib specimen showed no pathological abnormalities or tumor presence, and the pathological staging was updated to pT3 based on the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, 7th Edition.
