The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated invasive ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, measuring 2.3 cm, with extensive perineural invasion but negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion. The excised lymph nodes and bile duct margin were negative for malignancy, and the tumor is confined to the pancreas without regional lymph node metastasis. Overall, the findings suggest a localized pancreatic cancer with no evidence of spread to surrounding tissues or lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, characterized by a cavitary mass measuring 7.5 x 6.0 x 5.5 cm, which invades the visceral pleura but does not penetrate it. The bronchial margins and three intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes are free of malignancy, while three out of nine excised subcarinal lymph nodes show metastatic involvement. In contrast, the superior mediastinal lymph nodes are negative for tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right pelvic lymph nodes are negative for carcinoma, with no tumors identified in the examined lymph nodes. The prostate specimen shows adenocarcinoma involving multiple aspects of the prostate, with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), and evidence of extraprostatic fat involvement and a positive surgical margin at the left lateral base. Additional findings include benign prostatic hyperplasia and inflammation, with the pathological staging classified as pTNM T3a N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, in the right kidney, with a tumor mass measuring 9.3 x 7.5 x 6.5 cm that is confined to the kidney. A tumor thrombus is present in the renal vein, measuring 0.8 cm, but there is no coagulative tumor necrosis or sarcomatoid differentiation observed. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, and multiple lymph nodes from the intra-aortocaval and retrocaval regions are also negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 1, in a right kidney partial nephrectomy specimen, with the tumor measuring 1.7 cm and showing a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of G2. The deep margin of the specimen is reported as benign renal parenchyma, with no evidence of tumor necrosis or angiolymphatic invasion. Immunoperoxidase stains confirm the presence of tumor cells with specific markers, and the tumor is classified as pT1a, indicating it is confined to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation in both the left ovary and the uterus, classified as FIGO Grade 2, with the left ovarian tumor measuring 20.5 cm. The right ovary and fallopian tube are benign, and all examined lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement. Additional findings include benign conditions in the appendix and omentum, with no evidence of malignancy in other sampled tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 1 clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a 2.5 cm mass that is confined to the kidney and shows no involvement of the renal vein or collecting system. Additionally, the report notes that the surgical margins are negative and there is no evidence of tumor necrosis or sarcomatoid differentiation. The gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis with a small area of superficial ulceration and the presence of a pigmented gallstone.

The pathology report indicates that metastatic prostatic adenocarcinoma is present in one of two left external iliac lymph nodes and one of two left obturator/internal iliac lymph nodes, with tumor foci measuring 3.0 mm and 4.5 mm respectively, both exhibiting focal extranodal extension. The prostate shows a single focus of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5), extending into extraprostatic tissue and the left perivesicular soft tissue, but no invasion of the seminal vesicles is noted. The right external iliac and right obturator/internal iliac lymph nodes are free of tumor, and a supplemental report regarding the prostate and seminal vesicles is to follow.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated pancreatic adenocarcinoma measuring 2.8 cm, which invades the duodenal wall and is classified as pT3 N1, with one of 44 examined lymph nodes showing metastatic carcinoma. The bile duct and pancreas margins are negative for malignancy, and there is evidence of perineural and lymphovascular invasion. Additional findings include chronic pancreatitis, and the report confirms that other lymph nodes examined are negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 2-3 adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, characterized by a poorly-circumscribed mass measuring 12.5 x 6.0 x 4.1 cm, which extends to the visceral pleura but does not invade it. Metastatic adenocarcinoma is found in one left hilar lymph node, one subcarinal lymph node, and two left pulmonary ligament lymph nodes, while multiple other lymph nodes are negative for tumor. Angiolymphatic invasion is absent, and the bronchial margin is clear of tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant mesothelioma, predominantly of the epithelial type, with multiple tumor nodules ranging in size from 0.5 cm to 6.0 cm, involving the pleura, lung, and diaphragmatic muscle. Surgical margins from the resected specimens are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion. The tumor has been staged as pT2, pNX, pMX, and exhibits a tubulopapillary growth pattern with specific immunohistochemical markers confirming its malignant nature.

The pathology report indicates a left pelvic kidney tumor diagnosed as clear cell renal carcinoma, with a tumor size of 5.6 cm and classified as Fuhrman grade 2. The tumor is unifocal and limited to the kidney, with no evidence of regional lymph node or distant metastasis, and the surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additional findings show no vascular invasion and no other pathologic abnormalities identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma measuring 7.3 cm, which has invaded through the muscularis propria into perivesical adipose tissue and shows focal lymphovascular invasion. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in one of seventeen regional lymph nodes, specifically in the left obturator lymph node, while all surgical margins are negative for tumor. Additional findings include benign conditions in the uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes, and appendix, with no evidence of distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left adrenal gland pheochromocytoma measuring 15.0 cm, with negative surgical margins. The tumor exhibits capsular invasion and vascular invasion, with a Pheochromocytoma of the Adrenal gland Scaled Score (PASS) of 7, suggesting a potential for malignant behavior. Clinical follow-up is advised due to the tumor's aggressive features, including nuclear pleomorphism and mitotic activity.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right total mastectomy, revealing a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 3.4 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm, with clear margins and no lymphatic or vascular invasion. Three sentinel lymph nodes were examined, all identified as reactive with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The tumor is classified as AJCC stage pT2, pNO, and shows a modified Scarff-Bloom-Richardson grade of 2/3.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma in the stomach's antrum, measuring 7.0 cm, with ulceration and spiculated invasion into adjacent adipose tissue. There is evidence of neural and lymphatic vascular invasion, and metastasis is noted in multiple lymph nodes with capsular perforation. Proximal and distal margins are free of neoplastic involvement, and the great omentum and celiac trunk adipose tissue show no signs of neoplasia.

The pathology report confirms the presence of parathyroid tissue without any tumor and identifies papillary thyroid carcinoma, conventional type, located in the isthmus, measuring 1.6 cm, with lymphovascular invasion present but no extrathyroidal extension. Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma is found in 10 of 17 lymph nodes from the thyroid specimen and in additional lymph nodes from right level 4 and levels 4 and 5 B, all without extracapsular extension. The background thyroid shows chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma (G2) with infiltration through all wall layers (pT3) and vascular invasion (L1, V1). There is no evidence of lymph node involvement (pN0) with all 14 lymph nodes examined being free of cancer, and the resection margins are clear (R0). The tumor classification is consistent with ICDO-DA M-8140/3, G2, pT3, L1, V1, pN0, indicating a localized tumor without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse malignant mesothelioma, characterized by a tubulopapillary growth pattern, with extensive pleural and angiolymphatic infiltration, confirmed through immunostaining. Multiple biopsies from various sites, including the chest wall, diaphragm, and lymph nodes, reveal metastatic malignant mesothelioma, with some lymph nodes showing subcapsular aggregates of neoplastic cells. Additionally, cytogenetic analysis shows complete deletion of the p16 region, which is commonly associated with malignant mesothelioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma with early anaplastic transformation (WHO grade III) in the left frontal brain masses. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive results for IDH1 (R132H) mutation and scattered p53 positivity, with a Ki67 labeling index ranging from low to moderate. Further fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) studies for 1p19q deletion are pending for additional characterization of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma located in the posterior urinary bladder, measuring 3.0 cm, with extensive glandular differentiation and invasion into perivesical soft tissue. All examined pelvic lymph nodes, ureter margins, appendix, uterus, and cervix showed no evidence of malignancy, with lymphatic and perineural invasion noted. The tumor is classified as pT3a, with no lymph node involvement, and associated findings include moderate urothelial dysplasia and extensive surface ulceration.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 4.6 x 3.3 x 2.7 cm, with infiltration into the muscularis propria and perivesical adipose tissue, and evidence of perineural invasion, while surgical margins are free of neoplasia. Additionally, a microscopic focus of prostate adenocarcinoma (Gleason score 7) is noted in the right apex, without extraprostatic extension or evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion, and surgical margins are involved. The bladder cancer is staged as pT3a, indicating significant local invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver, characterized by a well-defined mass measuring 3.5 x 3.4 x 3.0 cm with a worst differentiation grade of III and partial capsular infiltration. The surgical margins are clear of tumor invasion, and there is no evidence of portal vein invasion or intrahepatic metastasis, although microvessel invasion is noted. Additionally, a high-grade dysplastic nodule is present, and the liver parenchyma shows signs of cirrhosis associated with HBV.

The pathology report indicates the presence of adenocarcinoma in both the left lower lobe and left upper lobe, with negative margins noted for both wedge resections. The left lower lobe specimen contained a well-circumscribed nodule measuring 1.7 cm, while the left upper lobe specimen had a nodule measuring 1.8 cm. Additional tissue samples from levels 5, 6, and 7 were also submitted for analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a poorly differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma located in the right hemicolectomy specimen, with invasive characteristics and metastasis to the mesocolic fatty tissue and small nodular peritoneal metastasis. The tumor is classified as pT3 pN2 (5/23) L1, V0, M1, indicating advanced disease with lymph node involvement and distant metastasis. Additionally, there is a tubulovillous adenoma with moderate dysplasia in the colon mucosa and evidence of chronic mechanical ileus in the ileum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the cecum, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm in length and 3.5 cm in width, showing invasion through the bowel wall and involvement of the serosa. Two out of 29 examined lymph nodes showed metastases, and there is evidence of perineural invasion, while surgical margins are free of tumor. Immunohistochemical staining for DNA mismatch repair proteins is retained in the tumor, suggesting intact mismatch repair capability.

The pathology report indicates that the spleen shows no significant pathologic changes and no evidence of malignancy. A tumor in the posterior gastric wall is diagnosed as leiomyosarcoma, measuring 9 x 4 cm, with involved surgical margins. Additional gastric polyps exhibit foveolar and parietal cell hyperplasia, but there is no evidence of malignancy in these specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma in an ablated breast sample, with a tumor diameter of 2.7 cm. The resection margin is tumor-free, suggesting complete removal of the tumor. The final classification of the tumor is NOS, grade II, pT2N0LOVORO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 1 papillary renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, characterized by a 7.2 x 6.0 x 5.2 cm mass in the upper pole with extension into the perirenal fat. The ureteral and soft tissue margins are clear of tumor involvement, and the collecting system is also uninvolved. Additionally, a right precaval lymph node excised during the procedure is negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a highly to moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon, likely arising from a pre-existing tubulovillous adenoma, with infiltration into the muscularis and evidence of lymph and blood vessel invasion. The tumor has free resection margins and free lymph nodes, classified as pN0. Additionally, the report notes chronic appendicitis with partial scarring and the presence of a characteristic Meckel's diverticulum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating apocrine carcinoma of the right breast, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm and a Nottingham grade of 2, suggesting moderate differentiation. One of the 18 examined axillary lymph nodes tested positive for tumor cells, while the margins of the excised tissue are negative for cancer. The tumor is classified as pathologic stage pT2 N0 (i+) MX, and both estrogen and progesterone receptors are negative, while HER2 is positive (3+).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left thyroid lobe, measuring 3.5 cm, with focal invasion into the extracapsular soft tissue, although surgical margins are free of tumor. Metastatic disease is present in one of one left paratracheal lymph node and one of seven pretracheal lymph nodes, while the right thyroid lobe shows benign tissue with chronic inflammation. Additional findings include areas of chronic thyroiditis, and there is minimal extrathyroidal extension noted in the tumor.

The pathology report describes a moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm that infiltrates both gray and white matter, characterized by tumor cells with perinuclear halos and gemistocytic cytoplasm. The tumor shows mild to moderate atypia, lacks mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis, with a MIB-1 labeling index of 4.4%. The diagnosis is consistent with low-grade oligodendroglioma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of residual FIGO grade 2 endometrial adenocarcinoma with mucinous differentiation, forming a mass in the left cornu and posterior aspect of the uterine fundus, with 1.2 cm invasion into the myometrium. No residual papillary serous component or lymphovascular space invasion is identified, and the surgical margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, the right ovary shows a peritoneal inclusion cyst, while the left ovary contains a serous cystadenoma, with both fallopian tubes appearing unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a right kidney mass diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma, papillary type 1, measuring 3.6 cm, with focal extension into perinephric adipose tissue but negative surgical margins and no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion. Additionally, an incidental finding of clear cell type renal cell carcinoma, Furhman grade 2, confined to the kidney, and multiple papillary adenomas were noted. The findings raise the possibility of hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma syndrome, suggesting further genetic evaluation may be warranted.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 3.0 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade 3. Immunoperoxidase studies indicate that the tumor cells are positive for keratin 7, supporting the diagnosis, and the tumor is confined to the kidney with clear margins. There is no evidence of invasion into surrounding tissues, and the remaining renal parenchyma appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 2.0 cm, with a Nottingham score of 7/9, and the tumor is located in the lower inner quadrant, extending to the lower outer quadrant. The Her-2/neu gene analysis shows borderline amplification, and the estrogen receptor is positive while the progesterone receptor is negative. All examined sentinel lymph nodes are negative for tumor, and the margins of the excised tissue are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV, in a 4.0 cm tumor confined within the renal capsule and with a free deep margin. Additionally, a small satellite tumor excised from the right kidney was found to be benign renal parenchyma. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue surrounding the tumor was unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 1.2 cm and no evidence of residual tumor or lymph node metastasis. Fluorescence In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) testing for ALK gene rearrangement was negative, and molecular studies showed no mutations in the KRAS or EGFR genes. The tumor is classified as moderately differentiated (G2) and is primarily acinar in type, with the bronchial and vascular margins free of invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of focally poorly differentiated acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate, measuring up to 1.9 cm, with perineural growth and focal infiltration into the periprostatic fatty connective tissue, but with tumor-free seminal vesicles and ducts. Two lymph nodes examined were free of malignancy, and there is no identifiable vascular invasion. The tumor classification is pT3a, pNO (0/2), with a Gleason score of 3+4 = 7, indicating a moderate risk of progression.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis, and a lymph node associated with the hepatic artery contains metastatic adenocarcinoma. A pancreatoduodenectomy reveals moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of pancreatic ductal origin, with invasion into the duodenum, common bile duct, and peripancreatic tissue, along with lymphatic and large vessel invasion. The tumor is classified as pT3, with metastasis found in one of 28 examined lymph nodes, and margins are reported as free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a right total mastectomy revealing infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, with a 2.1 x 1.4 x 1.1 cm mass and evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, while all surgical margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, three out of four right axillary sentinel lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, classified as pN1(5n), but no extranodal extension is present. The left total mastectomy shows ductal carcinoma in situ of micropapillary and cribriform types, with all surgical margins also negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma, measuring 6.5 cm, which has invaded the perivesical adipose tissue and extended into the vaginal wall and the external wall of the left ureter. There is evidence of angiolymphatic and perineural invasion, with 20 out of 48 lymph nodes showing metastasis. Immunohistochemical staining reveals moderate to strong positivity for p16, consistent with high-grade squamous dysplasia in the vaginal tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a man with headaches and altered mental status, has been diagnosed with glioblastoma (WHO grade 4) following biopsies of a large, cystic, necrotic, ring-enhancing tumor in the right frontal lobe. The tumor exhibits significant nuclear anaplasia, brisk mitotic activity with a proliferation index of 42%, and positive MGMT promoter methylation, suggesting a potential benefit from alkylating agent therapy. Additionally, the analysis shows negative results for 1p and 19q codeletion and IDH1-R132H mutation, which are important genetic markers in glioma classification.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of primary uterine adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with FIGO grade I and nuclear grade 2, showing extensive involvement of the uterine mucosa and superficial myometrial invasion, but no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the ovaries or fallopian tubes. The report also notes the presence of benign findings such as endometrial hyperplasia, polyps, and leiomyomas, as well as reactive lymph nodes without metastatic disease. Overall, the tumor stage is classified as pT1b, NO, with no tumor involvement in the cervix or parametrial tissues.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with invasive adenocarcinoma of the esophagus, arising in Barrett's mucosa, with invasion extending into the mid submucosa, but all resection margins are free of cancer. The examination of ten lymph nodes revealed no evidence of carcinoma. Additionally, the gallbladder was found to have cholelithiasis with multiple stones present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately-differentiated keratinizing invasive squamous cell carcinoma located in the right lateral floor of the mouth, measuring 5.3 cm and invading the anterior mandible and subcutaneous soft tissue. All surgical margins are negative for tumor, with the closest margins being 0.5 cm away from the tumor. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from various levels are negative for tumor involvement, and the tumor is staged as pT4a pNO.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenalectomy was performed, revealing a 760g tumor measuring 13.5 x 9.5 x 6 cm, diagnosed as adrenal cortical carcinoma with a Weiss score of 7. There is no evidence of tumor extension into the liver or kidney, and no lymph node metastases were found (0 out of 19 lymph nodes examined). Overall, the findings suggest a significant adrenal cortical carcinoma without local or regional spread.

The pathology report indicates that the left liver biopsy revealed a benign sclerotic lesion consistent with a hemangioma, while the gallbladder showed no evidence of malignancy. The Whipple resection identified moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, measuring 2.5 cm, with no regional lymph node metastasis. The tumor invades the ampulla of Vater and duodenal wall, but the surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade prostatic adenocarcinoma with a total Gleason score of 9, showing extensive involvement of approximately 90% of the prostate and bilateral invasion of the seminal vesicles. Surgical margins are compromised, with tumor extension noted to the apical, bladder neck, and multiple soft tissue margins, although no lymphovascular invasion or metastatic carcinoma was found in the examined lymph nodes. The report highlights significant perineural invasion and recommends clinical correlation with intraoperative findings.

The pathology report describes a left adrenal gland tumor consistent with Conn's syndrome, characterized by a nodular lesion measuring 25 x 30 mm that compresses adjacent normal tissue. Microscopic examination reveals a trabecular architectural pattern with cytological atypia and a mitotic rate of less than 6 per 50 high-power fields, leading to the conclusion of an "adrenal cortical neoplasm of indeterminate malignant potential." Electron microscopy findings support the presence of aldosterone-secreting tumor features, but the report emphasizes that predicting tumor behavior based on ultrastructural appearances is not reliable, recommending long-term clinical follow-up.

The pathology report indicates the presence of keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the larynx, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm and histological grade 2, involving various tissues including the right vocal cord and cartilage. Metastatic carcinoma is identified in three of sixteen lymph nodes on the right side and one of ten lymph nodes on the left side, with capsular involvement noted in some. The surgical margins and tracheal margin are uninvolved by neoplasia, and there is evidence of lymphatic invasion but no vascular or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with glioblastoma following a biopsy of an enhancing lesion in the left posterior temporal lobe. The tumor exhibits characteristics such as nuclear anaplasia, brisk mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis with pseudopalisading. Immunohistochemical analysis shows a MIB-1 proliferation index of 13% and no evidence of methylated MGMT promoter, which may influence treatment options.

The pathology report indicates a right hemicolectomy specimen revealing two tubular colon mucosal adenomas with moderate dysplasia and an ulcerated, poorly differentiated, partially mucinous adenocarcinoma in the caecum and ascending colon. The cancer has penetrated all layers of the wall and the peritoneum, with two regional lymph node metastases identified. The tumor is classified as G3, pT4 L1 V0 pN1 2/24, indicating advanced disease with lymphatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma on the dorsum of the tongue, with a maximum tumor diameter of 3.4 cm and positive perineural invasion, while the posterior and deep margins are positive for tumor. The right and left neck contents, including 37 lymph nodes, show no evidence of tumor involvement. Other specimens from the tongue margins and floor of the mouth are negative for malignancy, indicating no high-grade dysplasia or carcinoma in those areas.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive mucinous adenocarcinoma of the endocervical type, extensively involving both the superior and inferior cervix, with cauterized margins noted. Microscopic examination reveals moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma characterized by large nests of pleomorphic cells with abundant mucinous cytoplasm and a high mitotic rate, along with some signet ring features and foci of endometrioid differentiation. Detached fragments of adenocarcinoma are also present in the endocervical canal biopsy, confirming the extensive nature of the disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 1, measuring 12.1 cm in the largest dimension, with Fuhrman grade 3 and extensive necrosis, but no sarcomatoid transformation or lymphovascular invasion. The tumor is confined to the right kidney, with free surgical margins and no evidence of lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. An addendum notes that a TTF-1 immunohistochemistry stain performed on the tumor was negative, and the overall diagnosis remains unchanged.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC) of the right kidney, with a tumor size of 7.5 cm and a nuclear grade of II/IV, confined within the renal capsule and without invasion of the renal vein. Additionally, six paracaval lymph nodes were examined, all of which were benign with no evidence of metastatic disease. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue and the adrenal gland were unremarkable, and surgical margins were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of undifferentiated diffuse type adenocarcinoma with signet ring cell features located in the antrum of the stomach, measuring 3.0 x 4.0 cm. Surgical margins are intact, and all examined lymph nodes (11 total) are negative for metastasis. The tumor is classified as T2a N0 M0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic ductal adenocarcinoma in the #8 lymph node, while the portal lymph nodes are benign. A Whipple resection of the head of the pancreas reveals invasive moderately-differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma, with tumor extension into surrounding structures, including the duodenal wall and retroperitoneal soft tissue. The gallbladder shows acute and chronic cholecystitis but is negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma with sarcomatoid features, showing significant necrosis and a high nuclear grade (IV/IV), with local invasion beyond Gerota's fascia and into the renal pelvis and colon wall. The left colon segment resection was benign, and while one of the 17 examined para-aortic lymph nodes showed metastatic involvement, the adrenal gland and other lymph nodes were negative for tumor. The tumor size was noted to be 16.5 cm, with a staging of pT4 due to its extensive local invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 2.0 cm and negative margins. All examined lymph nodes from various regions, including the right and left distal paratracheal and level 7, were negative for tumor involvement. Additional findings include focal pleural fibrosis and atypical alveolar cell hyperplasia, with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or visceral pleural involvement.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the cervix reveals well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The carcinoma is invasive and presents with ulceration. This finding suggests a significant malignancy requiring further evaluation and management.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant mesothelioma in multiple sites, including a 3.5 cm tumor at port site #1 and metastatic involvement in lymph nodes. Additionally, there is evidence of malignant mesothelioma in the pleura and diaphragm, with the largest tumor nodule measuring 14.2 cm and showing lymphovascular invasion. Other examined tissues, including rib fragments and diaphragm, were negative for tumor, confirming the localized nature of the malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated endometrioid type endometrial adenocarcinoma, with the invasive tumor confined to an endometrial polyp measuring 3.3 cm and involving approximately 20% of the posterior uterine wall. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, and the cervix and adnexa show benign findings with no neoplasms identified. The overall staging is pT1a, with a FIGO stage of IA, and previous complex atypical hyperplasia is noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adrenocortical carcinoma following a left adrenalectomy, with a tumor size of 5.8 cm. The tumor exhibits a KI67 proliferation index of 20%, with focal areas reaching 30-40%. The Weiss score is 9, the Hough score is 4.89, and the Van Slooten score is 22.7, all suggesting a high-grade malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a retromolar lesion, measuring 4.1 cm with evidence of necrosis, lymphovascular invasion, and perineural invasion, as well as involvement of osseous tissue. Among the lymph nodes examined, two out of seven showed metastatic carcinoma with capsular involvement, while eighteen other lymph nodes were free of metastatic disease. The anterior margin of the excised specimen was uninvolved by neoplasia, but the deep margin was involved by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right obturator lymph nodes are reactive with no tumor seen in any of the examined nodes. The final diagnosis reveals adenocarcinoma of the prostate, with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7/10, and no extraprosthetic extension or lymphatic invasion detected. The tumor is primarily located in the right mid zone of the prostate, with clear margins except for a close anterior-superior margin.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right radical nephrectomy, revealing a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type) with a tumor size of 8.8 cm, limited to the kidney but with evidence of renal vein invasion. The surgical margins for soft tissue, renal vein, ureter, and renal artery were negative for tumor, and the AJCC classification is T3 Nx Mx. Additionally, the examination of the right retroperitoneal lymph nodes showed no tumor presence, and further evaluation of the non-neoplastic kidney tissue is pending.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes near the common hepatic artery and the celiac axis stump show no evidence of tumor, and all surgical margins from the celiac artery and pancreatic neck are negative for malignancy. However, a 5.0 cm invasive moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma was identified in the pancreatic body, extending beyond the pancreas into peripancreatic soft tissue, but without angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. The report concludes that all 16 regional lymph nodes examined are negative for metastatic tumor, and the findings are consistent with AJCC pT3 N0 classification.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a malignant melanoma in a skin lesion excised from the hip, measuring 1x0x1.5 cm with a Breslow thickness of 4.5 mm. The tumor is characterized as pigmented and ulcerated, with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. Additional details regarding lymphatic invasion and satellite nodules were not specified.

The pathology report indicates that six excised pelvic lymph nodes are negative for metastatic disease. The prostate excision reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma, with a Gleason score of 7/10, occupying approximately 15-20% of the prostate volume, but without extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle involvement. Surgical margins are uninvolved, and the pTNM stage is classified as pT2c, NO, with additional findings of nodular hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the mandible, measuring 4.6 cm, with evidence of perineural and lymphovascular invasion, but all surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma. Additionally, two of five lymph nodes from the left level II neck dissection show metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while other lymph nodes and margins from various excisions are negative for carcinoma and show chronic inflammation. The report highlights chronic granulomatous inflammation in several lymph nodes and emphasizes that no high-grade dysplasia or invasive carcinoma was found in the examined mucosal margins.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of brain tissue reveals a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, characterized by significant anaplasia and a high MIB-1 labeling index of 30-40%. The microscopic examination shows features such as severe nuclear pleomorphism, frequent mitotic figures, and areas of necrosis, with the tumor diffusely infiltrating the cerebral cortex. The specimen consisted of several small fragments of gelatinous tissue, and the immunoperoxidase stains confirmed the astroglial nature of the neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic high-grade carcinoma in the omentum, with high-grade endometrial endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 3), focal papillary serous carcinoma, and sarcomatoid carcinoma originating from an endometrial polyp with complex atypical hyperplasia. There is focal superficial myometrial invasion, but no evidence of lymphovascular space invasion, and the cervix and myometrium show no tumor presence. Additionally, the left ovary, right ovarian surface, and both mesosalpingeal areas are involved, while pelvic lymph nodes from both sides show no tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade infiltrating serous papillary adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, both ovaries, uterus, pelvic mass, sigmoid mass, and metastatic lesions in the liver and retroperitoneum. Psammoma bodies are noted in several specimens, suggesting a characteristic finding associated with this type of cancer. The report highlights extensive tumor invasion into surrounding tissues, particularly in the ovaries and uterus, indicating an aggressive disease process.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 55 mm, with lymphatic permeation but no evidence of blood vessel or perineural invasion. There are peribronchial lymph node metastases, and the tumor is clear of the bronchial resection margin, although there is a nodule of tumor in adjacent soft tissue that extends close to the hilar resection margin. The overall classification is T3N1MX, with no pleural invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately-differentiated adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon, with the tumor invading into but not through the muscularis propria. The specimen shows no vascular invasion and all sixteen examined lymph nodes are negative for cancer. Overall, the findings suggest localized cancer without evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma, Grade II, located in the right lobe of the liver, measuring 18.0 cm and unifocal in nature. The tumor is confined to the liver with no lymphovascular invasion and the surgical margins are negative. Additional findings include prominent atypia and disruption of reticulin fibers, with no evidence of fibrolamellar features.

The pathology report indicates a 4 x 6 x 4 cm well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the midline of the tongue. The margins of the tumor are not specified in the report. Overall, the diagnosis is consistent with a squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+4=8, confirmed by radical prostatectomy. Metastatic carcinoma was found in one of twenty examined right pelvic lymph nodes, and there is established extracapsular extension of the tumor. The tumor is multifocal, involving both lobes of the prostate, with a maximum diameter of 2.5 cm, while all surgical margins are free of carcinoma and the bilateral seminal vesicles show no evidence of cancer.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated serous papillary adenocarcinoma in both the left ovary and right ovary, with involvement of the ovarian stroma and serosa, as well as luminal carcinoma in the left fallopian tube. Additionally, multiple leiomyomas and chronic cervicitis were noted in the uterus, while all examined lymph nodes were free of tumor. The overall staging of the disease is classified as FIGO Stage IIC, indicating advanced local disease without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma, grade IV, from a left parietal brain mass excision. Microscopic examination reveals a moderately pleomorphic proliferation of astrocytes with numerous mitoses, microvascular proliferation, and areas of necrosis, confirming the malignancy. The report includes details on the specimen's gross description and histological analysis, with additional notes on immunohistochemistry testing methods.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, which extends into the perithyroid soft tissue and trachea, measuring 4.0 cm. No tumor was found in the examined lymph nodes from the right neck (0/1 and 0/3) and a total of 16 lymph nodes from the completion thyroidectomy and radical resection (0/16). The tumor shows superficial invasion of the trachea but does not involve the inner tracheal surface or the external margins of resection.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right ureter biopsies show no tumor, while the cystoprostatectomy reveals invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder and focal atypical glands in the prostate, with no tumor found in the seminal vesicles. Additionally, one of three pelvic lymph nodes contains metastatic urothelial carcinoma, while the other lymph nodes show no tumor. The overall staging is classified as pT3aN1Mx / Stage IV, indicating advanced disease with local invasion and lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 3 cm moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, with no visible invasion of lymph or blood vessels and excised with clear margins. Additionally, there is a multifocal intraductal non-high-grade carcinoma present, measuring up to 5 mm, which does not extend beyond the invasive tumor component. The tumor classification is M-8500/3, G 2, pT 2, pL 0, pV 0 (0/1), pNX, pMX, with an R0 status indicating complete resection.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma following a right lateral glossectomy, with a tumor size of 3 cm and a depth of invasion of 1.5 cm, showing focal perineural invasion but no vascular invasion. The margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, although the deep margin is close at less than 2 mm. Examination of lymph nodes from various levels of the right neck and deep tongue tissue revealed no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma with predominant follicular growth in both the left lobe (5.0 cm) and right lobe (1.8 cm) of the thyroid gland. The left lobe tumor shows extensive vascular invasion, while the right lobe tumor has multiple foci of capsular and vascular invasion, but both tumors lack extrathyroidal extension. The closest margin to the invasive carcinoma is less than 0.1 cm, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in a female patient, with the tumor located in the breast and classified as grade 2. The staging reveals T2, N0, and M0, indicating a primary tumor without regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered, and a normal blood sample was also collected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma of the conventional type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2, and a tumor size of 4.0 cm, confined to the kidney without any extravasation or lymphatic invasion. Additionally, a separate small papillary renal tubular epithelial neoplasm of low malignant potential was identified, along with focal global glomerulosclerosis affecting 5-10% of the non-neoplastic kidney. The overall TNM staging is pT1a Nx MX, with a histologic grade of G2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the right middle lobe of the lung, characterized by solid, acinar, and cribriform patterns, with a tumor size of 4.1 x 4 x 3.7 cm and no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. Margins from the right lower lobe and bronchial margins are negative for neoplasm, while atypical cells of uncertain significance are noted in the pulmonary arterial and pulmonary vein margins. Lymph nodes examined are negative for neoplasm, and the tumor will undergo further EGFR mutational analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a multinodular mass measuring 7.5 x 5.8 x 5 cm, with clear surgical margins and no evidence of vascular invasion. The spleen and pericholedochal lymph node show no abnormalities, with the lymph node being benign. Additionally, the gallbladder exhibits chronic cholecystitis without the presence of stones.

The pathology report indicates multiple biopsies from various sites, revealing predominantly benign findings, including squamous mucosa and salivary gland tissue, with no carcinoma identified in most specimens. However, one lymph node showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, and a right hemiglossectomy revealed a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the tongue, measuring 2.0 cm with no angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. The surgical margins were negative, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as pT1 pN1, with no evidence of extranodal extension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the cecum, measuring 6.5 cm in length and 10 cm in width, with invasion into the muscularis propria but no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and no regional lymph node metastasis was identified among the 33 examined lymph nodes. Additionally, the portion of omentum excised showed benign mature adipose tissue, and immunohistochemical staining for DNA mismatch repair proteins was retained in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade III endometrial adenocarcinoma (endometrioid type) in the uterus, with a tumor size of 2.8 x 2.0 x 1.4 cm that invades 0.2 cm into the myometrium, but does not involve the endocervix or lymphovascular spaces, and has negative margins. All examined lymph nodes, including those from the right and left pelvic regions, omentum, and gonadal vessels, are negative for tumor involvement, indicating no lymph node metastasis. The overall staging is classified as AJCC pT1N0, suggesting early-stage disease with no regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in one anterior mediastinal lymph node, with extension into the surrounding soft tissue. Additionally, a partial pneumonectomy of the left upper lobe lung revealed moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, with negative bronchial and vascular margins but extensive lymphatic invasion, and metastatic carcinoma in one lymph node. Lastly, an excised aortic arch lymph node showed metastatic poorly differentiated carcinoma in the soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2 N1 M0, indicating a primary tumor with regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered to date, and a normal blood sample was also collected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, cul-de-sac, pelvic tumors, and both ovaries, with the left ovary likely being the primary site. Additional findings include inactive endometrium, submucosal leiomyoma, adenomyosis, and endometriosis in the cul-de-sac. Peritoneal washings were positive for serous carcinoma, suggesting widespread disease.

The pathology report indicates that the right testis was diagnosed with seminoma, a type of germ cell tumor. The tumor does not invade the tunica albuginea or the epididymis, although intratubular germ cell neoplasia and vascular invasion are present. The resection margin is free of tumor, and the specimen included a well-circumscribed tumor measuring 2.5 x 2.0 x 2.0 cm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of pheochromocytomas in both the right and left adrenal glands following an adrenalectomy. Immunohistochemical analysis shows that the tumor cells are positive for NSE, Synaptophysin, Chromogranin, and CD56, while staining negative for Inhibin, with sustentacular cells highlighted by S100. The specimens were received fresh from the operating room, with detailed descriptions of the tumor masses and normal adrenal tissue included.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the right tongue, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and evidence of perineural invasion, but with clear surgical margins. Additionally, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was found in two out of thirty lymph nodes from the right neck dissection, with extensive extranodal extension involving the internal jugular vein and skeletal muscle. No tumor was present in the excised floor of mouth tissue or in the lymph nodes from the left neck, although mild chronic sialadenitis was noted in some lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade ductal adenocarcinoma of the head of the pancreas, measuring 5 cm, with invasion into the duodenal wall and peripancreatic soft tissue, but surgical margins are free of tumor with the nearest margin being 2 mm away. The common bile duct and pancreatic duct margins show no tumor presence, and all 10 regional lymph nodes examined are negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis without any tumor detected.

The pathology report indicates two tumors in the left kidney following a laparoscopic radical nephrectomy: a 7.5 cm conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma with Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, and a smaller 0.8 cm type 1 papillary renal cell carcinoma with Fuhrman nuclear grade 2. Both tumors were unifocal and did not show capsular invasion or involvement of surrounding structures, with negative surgical margins and no tumor detected in the examined lymph node. The overall AJCC staging is pT2a pNO for the clear cell carcinoma and pT1a pNO for the papillary carcinoma, with additional findings of arteriolonephrosclerosis in the non-neoplastic kidney.

The pathology report indicates a subtotal colectomy revealing an invasive, moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma that extends through the colon wall into the omental fat, with clear proximal, distal, and radial margins. Additionally, two out of thirty examined mesenteric lymph nodes show metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma, while the appendix and associated lymph nodes exhibit no significant pathological findings. An adenomatous polyp is also noted within the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma of the rectum, with a significant tumor measuring 5.3 x 4.9 x 10.0 cm found in the mucosa and surrounding 15% of the intestinal circumference. The tumor was resected along with a 23.6 cm length of the large intestine and associated mesorectal fat, with a minimal margin of 1.5 cm. Additionally, there are metastases present in regional lymph nodes, indicating the cancer has spread beyond the primary site.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade III endometrial adenocarcinoma, specifically serous adenocarcinoma, confined to a polyp in the endometrial cavity, measuring 4.4 x 2.6 x 0.7 cm, with negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion. Multiple lymph nodes from various regions, including pelvic and para-aortic areas, were examined and found to be negative for tumor involvement. Additional findings include benign leiomyomata in the myometrium and fat necrosis in the transverse mesentery, with all other examined tissues and lymph nodes showing no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenal gland was removed, weighing 17 grams. The final diagnosis is a pheochromocytoma, which measures 3.7 cm. This tumor is typically associated with excess catecholamine production and can lead to hypertension and other symptoms.

The pathology report indicates a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 5 x 4 x 3 cm. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/10 positive). Additional details regarding lymphatic and venous invasion, margins, and neo-adjuvant treatment are not specified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive gastric carcinoma of the intestinal type, classified as pT3, with infiltration into the muscularis and serosa. There are free resection margins in both the mucosal and ligature regions, as well as free lymph nodes and omental tissue. The tumor classification is ICDO-DA-M 8140/3, with pT3, L1, and pN0 status, confirming that the mucosal resection margins are tumor-free.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes (R4, L4, level 5, level 7, level 9, and level 10) were excised and all were negative for metastatic carcinoma. The left lower lobe lung excision revealed an invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5.5 cm, with tumor extending into the pleura but not identified at the outer surface. The margins of resection were negative for tumor, and no vessel invasion was noted.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of left frontal glioblastoma, WHO Grade IV, characterized by markedly pleomorphic cells, a high Ki67 proliferation index of approximately 80%, and the presence of necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive staining for GFAP and P53, while FISH analysis indicates no deletions of 1p and 19q, suggesting the absence of oligodendroglioma features. The findings support the diagnosis of a malignant high-grade glioma, specifically glioblastoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic papillary serous carcinoma found in the omental biopsy, which is associated with fibroadipose tissue. The specimen labeled "rectus muscle" was also submitted but does not indicate any malignancy. The clinical context suggests a pelvic mass with concerns for ovarian cancer, supported by the presence of ascites and omental cake.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as histologic grade 3 with poor nuclear grade and evidence of vascular invasion, with tumor necrosis comprising 30% of the tumor mass. The tumor measures 2.6 cm in greatest dimension, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, all 29 examined right axillary lymph nodes are free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma, grade B, from a biopsy of the temporal lobe. The tumor is characterized by diffusely infiltrating glial cells with a "fried egg" appearance, focal hypercellularity, and the presence of microgemistocytes, but shows no mitotic activity or vascular proliferation. The MIB-1 proliferation index is noted to be approximately 8-10%.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right middle lobe of the lung, measuring 1.7 x 1.7 x 1.6 cm, with no evidence of visceral pleural or lymphovascular invasion. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, all showing no histologic evidence of metastatic carcinoma, with one lymph node exhibiting prominent dense calcification. The tumor is confined to the pulmonary parenchyma, with surgical margins indicating a distance of 0.3 cm from the parenchymal margin and 1 mm from the pleural surface.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a liver specimen obtained from a partial hepatectomy, with a well-defined mass measuring 1.8 cm and no involvement of the surgical resection margins. The liver parenchyma shows signs of micronodular cirrhosis, and there is no evidence of serosal, portal vein, or microvessel invasion. Additionally, the gallbladder specimen reveals chronic cholecystitis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which is extensive and has invaded the bladder wall and surrounding tissues, classified as pT3bN0Mx. Both the right and left ureters, as well as the pelvic lymph nodes examined, show no evidence of malignancy, confirming benign findings. Additionally, bilateral prostatic adenocarcinoma is identified, confined to the prostate with a Gleason score of 6, and all resection margins are free of dysplasia and malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the floor of the mouth, with a tumor size of 5.9 x 5.9 x 4.1 cm, and evidence of invasion into surrounding soft tissues and bone. Surgical margins show positive involvement at the right mucosal margin, while the left mucosal margin is negative; lymph node dissection reveals metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in 5 out of 19 lymph nodes, with extracapsular extension noted. Additional findings include extensive tumor necrosis, lymphovascular and perineural invasion, and no dysplasia or malignancy identified in other biopsied tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, characterized as well differentiated with a maximum tumor size of 2.8 cm, and no evidence of capsular or blood vessel invasion. Additionally, four separate foci of papillary microcarcinoma were identified in both lobes, while the pretracheal tissue and right paratracheal lymph node were found to be benign. Surgical margins were clear of tumor, and the remaining thyroid tissue exhibited nodular hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive moderately to poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, measuring 2.8 cm, with perineural invasion and metastasis to 7 out of 22 regional lymph nodes. Liver biopsies show features consistent with bile outflow obstruction but no evidence of malignancy, and lymph nodes from the common hepatic artery and aortocaval groove also show no malignancy. The proximal duodenal margin is positive for subserosal ductal adenocarcinoma, while other margins are negative for malignancy, leading to a staging of pT3 N1 according to AJCC 7th edition.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating duct carcinoma (G2) in the left upper outer quadrant of the breast, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm. Out of ten examined lymph nodes, nine showed metastases, indicating significant spread of the cancer. The tumor margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with two separate tumor foci measuring 3.5 cm and 2.5 cm, and the surgical margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, two out of four sentinel lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma, while eight other lymph nodes examined show no tumor involvement. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals the presence of estrogen receptors in both tumor foci, with varying positivity for progesterone receptors and equivocal HER-2 status.

The pathology report indicates that the right pelvic lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma, with no evidence of malignancy in the three examined nodes. The uterus and associated structures show the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 3, with myometrial invasion noted but no lymphovascular invasion identified. Additional findings include uterine leiomyomata and paratubal cysts in the left fallopian tube, while both ovaries and the right fallopian tube show no histopathologic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland following an adrenalectomy, with no capsular or vascular invasion observed. Tumor cells tested positive for chromogranin and synaptophysin, supporting the diagnosis, while sustentacular cells were highlighted by S-100 immunostaining. The specimen weighed 21 grams and included a notable ovoid nodule measuring 2.5 x 2.0 x 2.0 cm, with the majority of the tissue processed for further examination.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, involving both lobes of the prostate and a maximum tumor diameter of 33 mm, with infiltration into peri-prostatic adipose tissue. The surgical margins are negative, and the seminal vesicles and deferent ducts are tumor-free. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from both sides are negative for tumor involvement, confirming no metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two adjacent but separate masses in the right upper lobe of the lung, both diagnosed as poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma, with one mass showing visceral pleural invasion. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in one of three hilar lymph nodes, while the other lymph nodes examined from levels 11, 2R, 4R, and level 7 were negative for malignancy. The bronchial and vascular resection margins are negative for malignancy, suggesting no residual tumor at these sites.

The pathology report indicates that all excised lymph nodes from both sides, as well as the omentum, are benign. However, the total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy revealed a high-grade serous adenocarcinoma with minimal cervical stromal invasion and no myometrial invasion or lymphovascular invasion identified. Previous findings of carcinosarcoma were reviewed, and no sarcomatous elements were found in the current material.

The pathology report indicates that a total thyroidectomy was performed due to a history of thyroid cancer. The left thyroid specimen revealed a unifocal papillary carcinoma measuring 4 cm with focal capsular invasion, while the right thyroid specimen showed no significant abnormalities. The surgical margins were negative for neoplasm, and the tumor was classified as pT2, pNx according to AJCC staging.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma primarily originating from the left ovary, with extensive metastatic involvement in the omentum, spleen, uterus, and large bowel, classified as Stage 3C. Microscopic examination reveals multiple metastatic deposits with evidence of invasion into surrounding tissues, including the spleen and uterine wall, while the terminal ileum and caecum show no signs of malignancy. Immunohistochemical analysis demonstrates strong positivity for ER, WT1, and p53, with negative PgR, supporting the diagnosis of serous papillary adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent an anterior exenteration with ileo conduit and gastrostomy tube placement, revealing a high-grade invasive papillary urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which infiltrates the muscularis propria but does not extend through it. All examined surgical margins and 45 lymph nodes were free of tumor, confirming no metastatic disease. Additionally, the ureters were diagnosed as benign with no urothelial dysplasia or malignancy identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade infiltrating urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 5 cm and invading the muscularis propria, with positive lymphovascular invasion but free surgical margins. Both right and left ureter margin biopsies were negative for malignancy, and two pelvic lymph nodes were also negative for metastasis. Additional findings include chronic cervicitis, proliferative endometrium, and a subserosal leiomyoma, with the appendix and ovaries appearing unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two foci of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 0.7 cm and 1.5 cm, with a Nottingham score of 6/9, and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising 10% of the tumor volume. Surgical margins are free of tumor, with lymphovascular space involvement not prominent, and all examined sentinel lymph nodes are negative for tumor. Additional findings include fibrocystic changes, atypical ductal epithelial hyperplasia, and a microscopic radial scar.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has extensive invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the uterus, likely of cervical origin, with involvement of the cervical transition zone and myometrium, as well as positive margins at the resection site. Additionally, a right oophorectomy revealed an ovarian cystadenofibroma with squamous cell carcinoma, raising concerns about possible direct extension from the uterus. Other examined tissues, including lymph nodes and additional cecum, were negative for malignancy, suggesting localized disease without distant spread.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder is benign with no significant abnormalities or carcinoma identified. In contrast, the liver shows a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma, grade 3, with a primary tumor measuring 11 cm and multiple satellite lesions, along with evidence of vascular and capsular invasion, but no lymph node involvement. Additionally, the ileum resection reveals benign findings with fibrous adhesions and no carcinoma detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, papillary type, with combined type 1 and type 2 characteristics, measuring 3.2 cm in greatest diameter. The tumor shows local invasion into the capsule but does not extend through it, and there is no evidence of renal vein invasion, with surgical margins being free of tumor. Immunohistochemical studies support the diagnosis, and the tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is limited to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma measuring 4.5 cm in the left upper lobe of the lung, with involvement of a large airway but no pleural invasion. Angiolymphatic invasion is present, while vascular and bronchial margins, as well as seven hilar lymph nodes, are negative for tumor. Additional lymph node biopsies from levels V, VI, and VIII also show no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic serous papillary adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the peritoneum, omentum, ovaries, uterus, rectosigmoid mass, and other pelvic and abdominal structures. The right ovary and left ovary both show poorly differentiated serous papillary adenocarcinoma, with tumor sizes of 5.1 cm and 5 cm respectively, and the disease has invaded the myometrium and serosa of the uterus. The overall pathological stage is classified as pT3c pNX pMX, indicating advanced disease with extensive metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma, not otherwise specified (NOS), with a grade of III, originating from an endometrial mass. The tumor size is significant, measuring approximately 5.3 x 2.5 cm in the anterior aspect and 5.0 x 5.4 cm in the posterior aspect, with a pathological T classification of T1c and N classification of N1, indicating lymph node involvement. A total of 5 lymph nodes were sampled, with 17 nodes positive for cancer, and there is no evidence of distant metastasis (M0).

The pathology report indicates that multiple biopsies from the uterus and cervix reveal moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with some samples showing invasive characteristics. There is no evidence of lymphovascular space invasion, and the depth of invasion cannot be assessed from the biopsies. The patient is a female with a history of high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HGSIL) on Pap smear and a large lesion on the anterior cervix.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 2.4 cm and features such as psammoma bodies and partial encapsulation. The Delphian lymph node and a total of fourteen other lymph nodes examined were found to be benign, with no evidence of blood vessel invasion or extrathyroid extension. Additionally, the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue exhibited nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, while the surgical margins were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 fibrillary and gemistocytic astrocytoma in the right frontal lobe, with evidence of moderate tumor infiltration at the posterior margin. FISH studies showed no deletions of chromosomal regions 1p or 19q, but approximately 45% of the cells exhibited gains of these chromosomes, suggesting potential tumor tetraploidy or aneuploidy. The tumor mass measures approximately 4.4 cm and the right frontal posterior margin is negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma invasive into the detrusor muscle of the urinary bladder, with extensive multifocal carcinoma in situ present throughout the bladder and ureters. A small focus of prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3 + 3 = 6, is confined to the right lobe of the prostate and involves less than 5% of the gland. All surgical margins and lymph nodes examined are free of malignancy, with no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an 11.5 cm ulcerated invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the stomach, classified as intestinal type according to Laurn's classification, with invasion into subserosal adipose tissue and evidence of angiolymphatic and perineural invasion. There is moderate chronic gastritis with intestinal metaplasia and high-grade dysplasia in the adjacent mucosa, but surgical margins are clear of neoplastic involvement. Out of 20 dissected lymph nodes, 6 are involved with neoplasia, indicating a significant metastatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated papillary keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 8 cm, with a depth of invasion of 0.7 cm, arising from the buccal mucosa to the tongue, and with uninvolved surgical margins. A comprehensive right neck dissection revealed no evidence of malignancy in 21 examined lymph nodes, and additional tissues, including the right buccal fat pad and sublingual gland, also showed no malignancy. The tumor erodes the mandibular cortex but does not invade the medullary component, and the overall pathologic staging is pT4, pN0, pM0, indicating no regional or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right frontal brain tumor diagnosed as anaplastic oligodendroglioma, classified as WHO Grade III. Two specimens were submitted, both confirming the same tumor type and grade, with positive immunostaining for the R132H mutant of IDH1. The report emphasizes that the tests performed are for clinical purposes and the laboratory is certified under CLIA'88 for high complexity testing.

The pathology report indicates the presence of chronically fibrosing cholecystitis and reactive hyperplasia in a local lymph node. It also identifies a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma with local lymph node metastases, located 1.5 cm from the resection margin, and shows tumor-free margins in the colon and mesocolon. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN2 (4/35) pMX, with characteristics including G2, L1, V0, and local R0.

The pathology report indicates that the tumor is located in the right fronto-temporal region. The histological diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme. This diagnosis suggests a highly aggressive and malignant brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates a 24-cm resection of the colon revealing a poorly differentiated, largely ulcerated colorectal adenocarcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with infiltration into the pericolic fatty tissue (pT3; G3), but with tumor-free resection margins. Additionally, three tubular adenomas with low- to moderate-grade dysplasia were found in the colonic mucosa. A follow-up analysis of 28 lymph nodes showed no evidence of tumor involvement, confirming a final tumor stage of pT3 pNO (0/28) pMX; G3.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma primarily originating from the right ovary, with extensive involvement of both ovaries, the fallopian tubes, uterus, omentum, and peritoneum, as well as multiple metastatic sites including the bladder and cecal nodules. The right ovarian tumor measures 13 cm and shows surface involvement, while the left ovary exhibits extensive tumor involvement, raising the possibility of a synchronous primary neoplasm. Overall, the findings suggest widespread metastatic disease with lymphovascular invasion and significant inflammatory changes in the affected tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade III, with gross invasion into the myometrium and a right ovarian implant also identified as endometrioid adenocarcinoma. The tumor measures 5 x 2.5 x 1.3 cm, with a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 1.2 cm, and there is no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion. Additional findings include benign serous cysts in the right ovary and paratubal cysts in both fallopian tubes, with the cervix free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma in the cecum, which has penetrated the full thickness of the bowel wall and extended to the appendix, with perineural and lymph-vascular invasion noted. The surgical margins are free of neoplastic involvement, and all 15 examined lymph nodes are negative for cancer. The tumor is classified as stage T3a pNO, indicating local invasion without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the left adrenal gland following an adrenalectomy. Immunohistochemical staining shows that the lesional cells are positive for S-100, NSE, Synaptophysin, and CD56, with some sections also displaying adrenal cortical tissue. The specimen weighed 57.5 grams and contained a significant nodule measuring 5.2 x 4.6 x 2.9 cm, consistent with the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report indicates that the right pelvic lymph nodes show no tumor, while the left pelvic lymph nodes contain metastatic carcinoma in one of seven nodes. The prostatectomy reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, extensive extraprostatic extension, and involvement of both seminal vesicles. Additional biopsies of the bladder neck and posterior urethra show no tumor, with unremarkable fibromuscular connective tissue present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated, invasive adenocarcinoma following a left hemicolectomy, with infiltration into the pericolic fatty tissue. Additionally, there is a tubulovillous adenoma exhibiting focal severe dysplasia. The tumor classification for the adenocarcinoma is G2, pT3, with no lymph node involvement (0/27), and no vascular or perineural invasion (LO V0 R0).

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma in the right temporal lobe, confirmed by biopsy and excision of the tumor. The lobectomy specimen showed no neoplastic features, while the posterior resection margin was free of neoplasm. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed a proliferation index of 14% and a negative result for the methylated MGMT promoter, consistent with the diagnosis of glioblastoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, well-differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a maximum tumor size of 6.5 cm and invasion into the myometrium. There is evidence of lymphovascular invasion and complex atypical hyperplasia, with metastatic carcinoma found in the fimbriae of the left fallopian tube, while the cervix and other examined lymph nodes are free of tumor. The final pathologic staging is classified as FIGO stage IIIA, with no lymph node metastasis detected in the examined samples.

The pathology report indicates the presence of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in a left inguinal lymph node, characterized by centroblastic morphology and a significant population of small reactive cells. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the tumor is positive for CD20, CD79a, CD10, BCL6, and CD23, with a high Ki-67 proliferation index of 75%, while it is negative for several other markers. Genetic studies reveal no BCL2 gene rearrangements, gains of the BCL-6 gene, and losses in the chromosome 1 region 1p36.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 10.0 cm, with 90% clear cells and 10% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, and invasive into the renal pelvis. The tumor has free margins of resection, with no evidence of invasion into surrounding adipose tissue or the renal vein, although multifocal tumor necrosis is present. Additionally, the non-neoplastic renal parenchyma shows signs of interstitial inflammation and hemorrhage in the renal tubules.

The pathology report indicates that the right lobe of the liver contains a Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma, forming a mass measuring 11.0 x 11.0 x 10.0 cm, with surgical margins that are widely free of cancer involvement. Additionally, the gallbladder shows mild acute and chronic cholecystitis, but no gallstones are present. The liver weighed 1020 grams and the gallbladder dimensions were recorded as 10.2 x 3.7 x 1.7 cm.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the rectum, classified as grade G2, with evidence of erosions and chronic inflammation surrounding the tumor. The cancer has infiltrated the rectal wall layers up to the submucosa but has not invaded the muscularis layer, and all examined lymph nodes are tumor-free (0/17). The tumor is staged as pT1, pNO (0/17), MX, R0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement or metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma with extranodal extension, specifically noting one involved lymph node out of four examined in the right neck dissection. The total thyroidectomy revealed a 1.5 cm classic variant of papillary carcinoma in the right lobe with positive resection margins, while the parathyroid glands were reported as within normal limits. Additional findings included multiple lymph nodes with no pathological diagnosis and evidence of adenomatoid nodules or nodular follicular disease.

The pathology report indicates that biopsies of the right upper and inferior parathyroid glands showed no pathological diagnosis, while the thyroid specimen revealed multifocal papillary carcinoma of the dominant follicular variant, measuring 2.2 cm, along with mild follicular nodular disease and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. The report also notes that the margins of the tumors are uninvolved by carcinoma, with minimal capsular invasion and no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion. Additionally, three regional lymph nodes were examined, and no metastasis was identified.
