The pathology report indicates that the left testicle underwent a radical orchiectomy, revealing a classical pure seminoma with intratubular germ cell neoplasia present. There is no evidence of invasion into the tunica albuginea, tunica vaginalis, or paratesticular structures, and all resection margins are negative for malignancy. The tumor occupies 70% of the testicle's volume, with no signs of vascular invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma in the right thigh, confirmed by both a Tru-cut biopsy and excision specimen. The tumor measures 19.7 cm and shows approximately 30% necrosis, with involvement of fibroadipose tissue and skeletal muscle, and is located very close to the inked margin. Immunostaining reveals focal positivity for HHF35 and a minority of cells for SMA and desmin, while there is no staining for S-100 protein or myogenin.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in a liver mass from segment VI, measuring 14.5 x 13.0 x 12.0 cm, with negative resection margins and no large vessel invasion. Additionally, a solid nodule of hepatocellular carcinoma was found in segment VII, located 0.2 cm from the surgical margin, alongside a separate cavernous hemangioma. The adjacent non-neoplastic liver tissue shows mild macrovesicular steatosis without significant inflammation or fibrosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of chronic pancreatitis with lymphoid aggregates at the pancreatic neck margin, which is negative for tumor. A ductal adenocarcinoma measuring 2.5 cm was identified in the pancreatic head, with metastatic carcinoma found in four out of twenty lymph nodes, and evidence of local extension to the duodenum, distal common bile duct, and ampulla. The tumor is classified as moderately differentiated (G2) and shows invasion into large venous vessels and perineural invasion, while the surgical margins are uninvolved, with the closest invasive carcinoma being less than 1 mm from the uncinate margin.

The pathology report indicates a partial gastrectomy specimen with an exophytic adenocarcinoma located in the body of the stomach, measuring 8.0 x 7.0 x 2.5 cm and classified as moderately differentiated. The tumor has invaded the serosa and shows metastasis in 1 of 8 examined lymph nodes. Margins and other invasion details were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the left ovary has a serous cystadenofibroma, with no significant pathology in the attached fallopian tube. The uterus and cervix show atrophic endometrium and an endocervical polyp, while the right ovary and fallopian tube are also unremarkable. In the right colon, a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma was identified, classified as pT3, with all margins and regional lymph nodes negative for metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, FIGO grade 2, with tumor invasion limited to half of the myometrium and a maximum thickness of 6 mm. There is evidence of vascular invasion, but no endocervical invasion is noted, and additional findings include adenomyosis and leiomyomas in the myometrium. Biopsies of various lymph nodes reveal only benign findings, with no evidence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, classified as histologic grade III, measuring 2.5 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and focal lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). Among the sentinel lymph nodes examined, one node showed metastatic carcinoma, while the others were benign, indicating limited spread of the cancer. Special studies revealed that the tumor is estrogen receptor positive (70% staining), progesterone receptor negative (3% staining), and HER2 negative.

The pathology report indicates that the left temporal lesion resected from the patient is diagnosed as a glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV). The tumor exhibits multiple morphologies, including both epithelioid and solid growth patterns, with strong immunohistochemical positivity for GFAP. Two specimens were analyzed, with one portion undergoing intraoperative consultation confirming the presence of a malignant neoplasm favoring glioblastoma.

The pathology report confirms the diagnosis of a right frontal brain tumor identified as glioblastoma, WHO Grade IV. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive staining for GFAP and p53, with a Ki67 proliferation index of 15%. The tumor exhibits pleomorphic neoplastic astrocytes, mitotic figures, necrosis, and endothelial proliferation, indicating aggressive behavior.

The pathology report indicates that the pleural biopsies reveal a diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma with a biphasic pattern, characterized by high-grade malignancy and invasion of the chest wall. Immunohistochemical staining supports this diagnosis, showing positive results for mesothelin, TTF1, WT1, AE1/3, and CK5, while other markers were negative. One of the biopsies did not contain any identifiable tissue, while the other two confirmed the presence of malignant neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Type B1 Thymoma, measuring 7.0 x 4.5 x 3.0 cm, with multifocal invasion through the capsule into mediastinal fat and lung tissue. The tumor is classified as pT3, pNO (0/6), and is staged as Masaoka III. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive markers for CK 5/6 and EGFR, with negative results for CD5 and CD117, along with the presence of immature and mature T-lymphocytes and sparse CD20-positive B-lymphocytes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated, measuring 4.8 cm, located at the head of the pancreas and extending into the duodenum, with lymph-vascular invasion present and a positive margin at the uncinate process. Additional biopsies of the common bile duct, pancreatic duct margin, and gallbladder show benign findings with no carcinoma identified. The overall staging is pT3 pNO, with no lymph node involvement noted among the 13 examined.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade Mullerian-derived adenocarcinoma with serous and anaplastic features in the omentum, mesentery, and both ovaries and fallopian tubes, with extensive involvement of surrounding soft tissues and regional lymphovascular spaces. Additionally, metastatic adenocarcinoma is noted in the uterus and anterior abdominal wall, while the cervix shows no evidence of carcinoma. The findings suggest a primary ovarian neoplasm due to invasive tumor presence, with a pathologic tumor stage assigned as nT3c.

The pathology report indicates that the right axillary sentinel node biopsy showed no evidence of tumor (0/1), while the right breast partial mastectomy revealed invasive lobular carcinoma, SBR grade II, measuring 3.2 cm, with focal necrosis and associated atypical changes. The excisional margins are free of tumor, with the closest invasive carcinoma margin being 1 mm away, and there is no evidence of blood vessel or lymphatic invasion. Immunohistochemical studies show the tumor is ER positive in 68% and PR positive in 66% of invasive tumor nuclei, with no amplification of Her2/neu.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.2 cm, with no evidence of visceral pleural or lymphovascular invasion. The tumor is unifocal and remains isolated within the lung parenchyma, with clear surgical margins and no metastatic disease found in the examined lymph node. The pTNM staging is classified as pT1b N0, indicating an early stage of lung cancer.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in multiple biopsies from the base of the tongue, specifically from both the left and right sides. The report includes findings from three specimens: two biopsies and one curettage, all confirming the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma. The frozen section analysis also corroborated the diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma from the left base of the tongue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left body of the mandible and floor of mouth, with a maximum tumor diameter of 4.5 cm and perineural invasion present, but no lymphovascular invasion. One left perifacial lymph node was positive for carcinoma with focal extracapsular extension, while 23 other lymph nodes from the left neck were negative for carcinoma. Surgical margins from the resection are negative for carcinoma, and an addendum report confirms invasion of cortical and medullary bone by the carcinoma, although bone margins remain negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy was performed on the right lower and middle lobes of the lung, revealing a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 6.0 cm, which focally involves the pleural surface. There is no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion, and all examined lymph nodes (10 total) are negative for metastatic malignancy. The pathological staging is classified as pT2a, pNO, pMX, with benign vascular and bronchial margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach (diffuse type) with signet ring cell characteristics, showing extensive ulceration and infiltration into surrounding fatty tissue. There are twenty-five regional lymph node metastases and evidence of carcinomatous lymphangitis, with tumor spread noted in the omentum and hilar fatty tissue of the spleen. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN3 (25/25) pM1, indicating advanced disease with significant metastatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left modified radical mastectomy due to invasive ductal carcinoma, which is poorly differentiated and classified as nuclear grade 3. The tumor measured 7 cm and exhibited lymphatic space invasion, with metastatic carcinoma found in 5 out of 18 examined axillary lymph nodes. The deep margin beneath the tumor showed skeletal muscle with no tumor identified, suggesting a clear margin at that site.

The pathology report indicates the presence of Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a well-circumscribed mass measuring 8 x 6 x 6 cm, with surgical margins free of tumor involvement at a distance of 2 mm. Additionally, mild chronic cholecystitis was noted in the gallbladder, and a single inflammatory lymph node was identified in the pericholedochal region. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of hepatoma, with some unclear reactivity for HMB-45 in the neoplastic cells.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade III, with significant myometrial invasion and lymphovascular space invasion, as well as cervical involvement. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, with five out of thirty-three showing positive results for endometrial adenocarcinoma, indicating regional lymph node metastasis. A liver biopsy revealed mild steatosis and fibrosis but was negative for endometrial adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that a left upper lobe lobectomy was performed due to left lung adenocarcinoma, with the tumor measuring 2.5 cm and classified as moderately to poorly differentiated. All examined lymph nodes (including anterior hilar, posterior hilar, lobar, interlobar, and lingular nodes) were negative for tumor involvement, and there was no evidence of vascular or visceral pleural invasion. The final diagnosis confirms the presence of adenocarcinoma confined to the lung, with clear margins and no significant complications noted.

The pathology report indicates multiple tumors in the left kidney, including two renal cell carcinomas of the chromophobe type and clear cell type, both classified as Furhman nuclear grade II, with one tumor approaching the inked margin. Additionally, there are benign smooth muscle tumors (leiomyomas) and evidence of oncocytosis in the renal parenchyma. The findings suggest a possibility of tuberous sclerosis due to the morphology of the renal tumors and smooth muscle proliferation.

The pathology report indicates that multiple levels of left selective neck dissection revealed no tumor presence in all examined lymph nodes (0/6, 0/10, 0/18, 0/9). A left partial glossectomy showed moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma measuring 3.4 cm with perineural invasion and severe dysplasia at the margins, but no tumor was found at the mucosal, posterior gingival, or posterior pharyngeal margins. Overall, the findings suggest a localized squamous cell carcinoma with clear margins in the dissected lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 1, which forms a mass in the uterus and invades 0.4 cm into the myometrium, with negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion. The gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis and an adenomyoma, while a benign cystic duct lymph node is also noted. All examined pelvic lymph nodes from both sides are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of predominantly moderately differentiated bilateral multifocal adenocarcinoma of the prostate, classified as pT3a with a maximum tumor diameter of 1.6 cm and a Gleason score of 3+4=7 (30% Gleason 4). Tumor infiltration was noted in the periprostatic fatty tissue and extensive multifocal involvement of perineural sheaths, but surgical margins were tumor-free, suggesting complete excision. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes were tumor-free, and immunohistochemical investigations showed no evidence of blood or lymph vessel invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a pancreatic endocrine neoplasm measuring 3.5 cm, which is well-differentiated and confined to the pancreas, with all surgical margins free of neoplasia and no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion. Additionally, biopsies of periduodenal and retroperitoneal lymph nodes were negative for malignancy, and the gallbladder showed no significant abnormalities. Overall, the findings suggest a localized pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor without metastatic disease.

The pathology report confirms the presence of a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lung, measuring 43 mm, with perineural permeation but no blood vessel or lymphatic invasion, and no pleural invasion identified. The tumor is located close to the hilar soft tissue margin (0.3 mm) and shows involvement of peribronchial lymph nodes, resulting in a classification of T3N1. Additionally, the non-neoplastic lung exhibits emphysema and mild respiratory bronchiolitis, with no evidence of microorganisms found in the lymph node granulomata.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO III) located in the right frontal lobe, which shows significant infiltration by neoplastic glial cells with nuclear anaplastic features and a high mitotic rate. Genetic testing revealed loss of heterozygosity on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, as well as a methylated MGMT promoter, suggesting a potential benefit from alkylating agent therapy. The tumor was excised, and the microscopic examination confirmed the diagnosis with notable cellular characteristics and a proliferation index of approximately 50%.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma, identified through an excisional biopsy of a 4.0 cm tumor in the left temporal lobe. The tumor exhibits features of anaplastic astrocytic proliferation, including microvascular proliferation, necrosis, and a proliferation index of 13%. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positivity for GFAP and a small fraction of neoplastic cells expressing mutant p53 protein, with no neuronal marker expression detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bifocal invasive ductal breast carcinoma grade II in ablated material from the right breast, with the larger tumor measuring 1.1 cm and the smaller one 0.8 cm. The carcinoma has been completely resected, with a minimum margin of 0.5 cm extending into healthy tissue. Tumor classification is pTlc (m), pN2a (7/25), MX, R0, G2 (L0, V0).

The pathology report indicates an amended diagnosis of invasive thymoma, WHO type B2, measuring 9.5 x 5 x 2.5 cm, which invades peri-thymic fat and is adherent to the parietal pleura, but surgical margins are free of tumor. Additional biopsies from the right lateral, inferior, superior, and left lateral margins, as well as the xiphoid, revealed benign fibroadipose tissue with cautery artifact. The report also notes that three lymph nodes were benign, and the normal thymus gland showed atrophy, with immunostains confirming the diagnosis.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV) from the left temporal primary tumor. Microscopic examination reveals pleomorphic glial cells, mitotic figures, tumor necrosis, and positive immunohistochemical staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), with a proliferation index of approximately 25% as indicated by Ki67 staining. The report includes both frozen and permanent section evaluations, supporting the diagnosis of this aggressive brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left level 3 lymph node and in one level 2 lymph node, with a primary tumor in the left hemithyroid measuring 1.8 cm and exhibiting an infiltrative pattern. The right hemithyroid was found to be benign, and the tumor was classified as well-differentiated with partial encapsulation and evidence of lymph-vascular invasion. The margins were uninvolved by carcinoma, and the overall pathologic staging was pT1b for the primary tumor and pN1b for the regional lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a Grade 3 oligoastrocytoma, astrocytic predominant, located in the left frontotemporal region of the brain. FISH studies showed no evidence of deletions on chromosomes 1p or 19q, but approximately 70% of the tumor cells exhibited 3-4 copies of these chromosomal regions, suggesting potential tumor tetraploidy or aneuploidy. The report emphasizes that these findings should be considered alongside existing clinical and pathological information, as the FISH test has not been FDA approved.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, with the right paratracheal lymph node showing metastasis in one of one lymph node, and the right neck dissection revealing metastasis in four of twelve lymph nodes. The total thyroidectomy shows conventional papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right lobe, measuring 5.0 cm, with extrathyroidal extension into soft tissue and lymphovascular invasion present, but resection margins are negative. Additionally, there is no extranodal extension noted in the metastatic lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, conventional type, following a total thyroidectomy, with the tumor located in the right lobe measuring 1.1 cm and showing no extrathyroidal extension or lymphovascular invasion. The background thyroid tissue reveals multinodular adenomatous goiter, and no tumor was present in the examined lymph node. The resection margins are negative, indicating complete removal of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary thyroid carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm in the right lobe of the thyroid, with focal involvement at the resection margins and a background of Hashimoto's thyroiditis and multinodular goiter. Additionally, two out of three pretracheal lymph nodes were positive for microscopic papillary thyroid carcinoma, indicating regional metastasis. The left lobe of the thyroid showed benign parenchyma with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and no distant metastasis was evaluated.

The pathology report indicates an invasive rectal carcinoma of medium-grade differentiation, classified as mucinous type (G2). It shows infiltration through all layers of the rectal wall (pT3) and evidence of lymph vessel invasion (L1), with one lymph node metastasis identified out of twelve examined (pN1). The resection margins in the mucosa and ligature area are reported as free of cancer.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade II, with myometrial invasion and involvement of the posterior and anterior uterine walls, but all resection margins are free of tumor. The lymph node dissection revealed five lymph nodes from the left para-aortic region with metastasis, while other lymph nodes examined from various regions showed no evidence of metastasis. Additionally, a small leiomyoma of the myometrium was noted, and the ovaries and fallopian tubes were free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple pheochromocytomas in the adrenal gland, with at least four distinct nodules measuring between 0.8 and 2.5 cm. Three nodules are entirely intra-adrenal, while one extends beyond the adrenal capsule, and there is no evidence of vascular invasion, necrosis, or significant mitotic activity. The findings suggest a possible hereditary tumor syndrome, likely MEN2, and further clinical correlation is recommended.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, with myometrial invasion into the outer half and lower uterine segment involvement, but no cervical or adnexal involvement. The tumor measures 12.5 cm and is classified as pT1b pNO, with negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion, as all examined lymph nodes (23 total) were free of tumor. Additional findings include benign leiomyomas and an endocervical polyp, with the overall AJCC pathologic stage assessed as IB, grade 3.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast lumpectomy revealed a moderately differentiated invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 2.1 cm, with negative resection margins and no evidence of carcinoma in the examined sentinel lymph nodes. Immunohistochemistry results show the tumor is estrogen receptor positive (>50%), progesterone receptor positive (10-50%), and HER2 negative. The final AJCC classification is pT2, pN0, with no distant metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 3, consistent with an ovarian origin, with tumor involvement in the omentum, right gutter, surface of the right ovary, left pelvic sidewall peritoneum, and rectosigmoid colon. The right and left fallopian tubes, as well as the "donut" specimen, were found to be free of tumor. Microscopic examination confirmed the presence of adenocarcinoma with psammoma bodies, suggesting a primary ovarian or peritoneal source.

The pathology report indicates a subtotal gastrectomy with extensive metaplasia due to multifocal atrophic gastritis linked to a prior H. pylori infection. It identifies an ulcerated poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the intestinal type in the antrum, which has infiltrated the subserosa but shows no regional lymph node metastases. The tumor is classified as pT2b with no lymph node involvement (pNO 0/27).

The pathology report indicates that the right breast mastectomy revealed nonproliferative breast parenchyma with dense stromal fibrosis, while the left breast mastectomy showed a 2.6 cm invasive lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade 1, with negative margins and no lymph node metastasis in the eight sentinel lymph nodes examined. The tumor was characterized by being ER positive, PR positive, and HER2 negative. Additional immunostaining confirmed the lobular nature of the carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive bifocal ductal carcinoma of the left breast, with two tumors measuring 2.8 cm and 0.5 cm, respectively. Immunohistochemical analysis shows over 75% estrogen receptor positivity and a negative HER2 reaction in the invasive cancerous cells. Additionally, metastases were found in axillary lymph nodes, specifically in node No. III/XIV, indicating a pN1a classification.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple tumors in the right kidney, with 14 tumors diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the clear cell type, all classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade II. Additionally, there are several atypical renal cysts and fibrous hyalinized tissue noted among the excised specimens. The report also includes a gross examination of the right 11th rib, which showed no tumors or lesions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma of the breast, measuring 2.5 cm, with metastases found in all 10 examined lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as moderately differentiated (G-2) and shows positive estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) expression, while Her-2/neu is negative. There is no evidence of venous invasion, and the surgical margins are uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus, with the tumor extending into the periesophageal soft tissue and involving the deep resection margin. There were no positive lymph nodes identified among the 14 examined, and the proximal and distal surgical margins were negative for malignancy. The TNM classification is T3 N0 Mx, indicating advanced local disease without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mesenteric fibromatosis in both a small bowel nodule biopsy and a segment of small bowel from a colectomy, with the fibromatosis extending into the muscularis propria and surrounding tissue but negative for malignancy in lymph nodes. Additionally, a partial nephrectomy revealed a unifocal chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, measuring 4.6 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of capsular or vascular invasion. The gallbladder specimen showed mild chronic cholecystitis, also negative for fibromatosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated stomach adenocarcinoma following a total organ resection, with metastases identified in 3 out of 17 adjacent lymph nodes and evidence of vascular invasion. The tumor, located in the pyloric region, measures 5.6 x 4.1 x 0.8 cm and shows invasion into the submucosa and shallow invasion of the gastric muscular membrane. The report also notes chronic inflammation and complete intestinal metaplasia in the surrounding tissue, with incision lines free of neoplastic lesions.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive adenocarcinoma in the left main bile duct and moderately differentiated cholangiocarcinoma in the liver, with tumor extension to the bile duct margin and significant perineural involvement. The right bile duct and extrahepatic bile duct biopsies show no significant abnormalities, while the gallbladder reveals chronic cholecystitis and two benign lymph nodes. Overall, the findings suggest a diagnosis of cholangiocarcinoma with a negative hepatic surgical margin, but a positive bile duct margin, indicating the need for further surgical evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the chromophobe type, with a tumor size of 13.0 cm that has invaded the renal vein but is confined within Gerota's fascia, classified as pT3b. Lymph node examinations from various regions (para-aortic, pre-aortic, interaortocaval, and suprahilar) show no involvement in most nodes, except for one metastatic node in the suprahilar region measuring 1.3 cm, with no perinodal extension identified. Additionally, a biopsy of the liver reveals metastatic renal cell carcinoma involving the liver parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a benign serous cystadenoma in the right ovary and fallopian tube, while the total abdominal hysterectomy and salpingo-oophorectomy reveal endometrial adenocarcinoma of the endometrioid type, FIGO grade III, with invasion limited to half of the myometrium. All examined lymph nodes from both sides, including external iliac, obturator, hypogastric, common iliac, and para-aortic regions, are reported as benign with no evidence of metastatic disease. Additional findings include cystic atrophy of the endometrium and leiomyomas in the myometrium, with no vascular or endocervical invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 1.7 x 1.5 x 1.1 cm, with lymphovascular invasion present but no visceral pleural invasion. The tumor is unifocal and limited to the pulmonary parenchyma, with a pTNM stage of pT1 N1, indicating metastasis in 2 out of 8 examined lymph nodes. Additionally, a molecular panel for lung cancer is pending, and the surgical margins are clear with sufficient distances from the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma (grade II WHO) located in the right frontal region of a male patient. This tumor is classified as a low-grade glioma. Further clinical correlation and management are recommended based on this diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, classified as grade III according to the World Health Organization (WHO) grading system. The tumor is localized in the right fronto-temporal region of the brain. The patient is male.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the endocervix measuring 4 x 3.5 x 3 cm, diagnosed as poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/7), and additional immunohistochemical findings include positivity for CA125, vimentin, CK7, and high molecular weight cytokeratin, with some nuclei expressing neurospecific enolase and other markers. Margins, lymphatic invasion, and venous invasion details were not specified in the report.

The pathology report describes a thymectomy specimen weighing 355 g, revealing a nodular lesion characterized by fleshy, beige homogeneous tissue with spindle cells and small lymphocytes. Histopathological examination indicates a thymoma of subtype AB, measuring 10 cm in length, with no evidence of capsular invasion, classified as Stage I. Immunohistochemical analysis shows expression of various cytokeratins and CD markers, confirming the diagnosis and indicating complete surgical resection.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of residual invasive adenocarcinoma of the left breast, specifically invasive ductal carcinoma with lobular features, following a modified radical mastectomy. The tumor measures 2.1 x 2 x 1.2 cm and is located near the axillary tail, with lymphatic/vascular invasion present and 10 out of 23 axillary lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and the report notes the presence of in-situ carcinoma and necrosis, with no evidence of multifocal tumor or DCIS extending outside the invasive mass.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma (3.2 cm, 1.8 cm thick) in the right buccal mass, with evidence of infiltrative borders, angiolymphatic and perineural invasion, but clear margins. Additional findings include a background of lichenoid dysplasia and no tumor present in the Stensen's duct, buccal fat, deep margin, or lymph nodes examined (36 nodes total). The final diagnosis is staged as pT2, with no evidence of metastasis in the lymph nodes.

The final pathologic diagnosis is a thymoma, WHO type AB, measuring 6.8 x 5.6 x 3.6 cm, with soft tissue and mesothelial margins free of tumor, although the tumor capsule is within 1 mm of the inked margin. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion, and the tumor cells are positive for cytokeratin and CD5, indicating a lymphocyte-rich neoplasm. Flow cytometry analysis shows a population of immature and mature T cells, with a significant expression of various T cell markers, suggesting further classification is needed.

The histopathological examination of a partial organ resection of the descending colon revealed two cauliflower tumors consistent with bifocal adenocarcinoma tubulopapillare (G1), which invade the muscular layer and surrounding fat tissue. The tumors are located 4 cm and 2.5 cm from the excision margins, with a minimum side margin of 3 cm, and the excision lines are free of neoplastic lesions. The final diagnosis is classified as Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2, pT3, pNO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, characterized by a subpleural mass measuring 2.0 x 2.0 x 0.9 cm, which does not involve the overlying visceral pleura. The surgical margins are negative for neoplasm, and no tumor is identified in multiple examined lymph nodes from various stations, including mediastinal and intrapulmonary regions. Overall, the findings suggest a localized tumor with no evidence of metastasis in the sampled lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma in the rectal resection, with infiltration into the muscularis propria and the presence of a tubular adenoma exhibiting profound dysplasia. There is also evidence of diverticulosis, but the resection margins and lymph nodes (28 examined) are tumor-free. The tumor classification is G2, pT2 NO LO V0 RO.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a sternotomy and resection of an anterior mediastinal mass, which was diagnosed as a type AB thymoma, measuring 4.4 cm, with invasion into the capsule but no transcapsular invasion and uninvolved margins. A specialized gene expression assay classified the thymoma as Class 1, suggesting a low risk of clinical metastasis within the next ten years. Additionally, one lymph node was examined and showed no significant pathologic changes, confirming no regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, specifically of the papillary type, with a tumor size of 3.8 cm and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2/4. The tumor is confined to the renal tissue examined, with no evidence of lymph node involvement or vascular invasion, and the surgical margins appear uninvolved. The evaluation of the surrounding non-neoplastic renal parenchyma shows compression and atrophy near the tumor, along with mild chronic changes and mild vascular sclerosis at the resection margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type with sarcomatoid features, classified as Fuhrman Nuclear Grade IV. The tumor, measuring 15 cm, shows local invasion into Gerota's fascia, renal sinus fat, and the renal vein, with direct extension into the adjacent pancreas and involvement of the adrenal gland, while the spleen remains uninvolved. Lymph node examination reveals no tumor involvement, and the surgical margins are focally positive for tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, grade III, in the left breast, measuring 1.7 cm, with a small component of high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present. The sentinel lymph node biopsy revealed four benign lymph nodes, with no evidence of metastatic disease. Surgical margins from the lumpectomy and additional excised breast tissue were all reported as benign, with no vascular invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated endometrial carcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 3, with tumor invasion into the myometrium to a depth of 6 mm and evidence of lymphovascular invasion, although the lower uterine segment and cervix are not involved. Multiple leiomyomas were noted, but the ovaries and fallopian tubes were negative for tumor, and all examined lymph nodes (38 total) showed no evidence of malignancy. The provisional pathologic stage assigned is T1b/N0/MX, indicating localized tumor without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report describes a 3x2x2 cm ulcerated tumor in the pylorus, identified as poorly differentiated diffuse type adenocarcinoma, which has invaded the serosa and muscle bundles. Microscopic examination reveals necrotic mucosa with signet-ring cells and hyperchromatic nuclei, along with evidence of lymphatic invasion and metastasis in 3 out of 5 regional lymph nodes. The overall diagnosis indicates a significant malignancy with aggressive features and local invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma (grade 3) in the bladder, which is invasive into the lamina propria and shows strong suspicion for focal invasion into the muscularis propria. The tumor involves small bundles of smooth muscle tissue, and while the findings are not definitive, they suggest potential invasion. A rebiopsy may be considered for further tumor staging if clinically indicated.

The pathology report describes a thymoma measuring 4 cm in diameter, classified as type AB, with minimal invasion of the capsule and complete surgical resection achieved. Microscopic examination reveals a lobulated tumor with a biphasic structure, consisting of epithelial cells and lymphocytes, and some infiltration into surrounding tissues. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the epithelial cells express cytokeratin and CD20, while the accompanying lymphocytes express CD5 and CD1a, indicating a grade IIa tumor according to the Masaoka classification.

The pathology report indicates that the right hemicolectomy specimen reveals a high-grade, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the cecum, which invades through the muscularis propria into the serosal surface, with negative resection margins and identified perineural invasion. Additionally, a liver biopsy shows a bile duct adenoma. Immunohistochemical analysis suggests a loss of MLH1 and PMS2 staining in the tumor, indicating a potential sporadic methylation silencing rather than a germline mutation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade urothelial carcinoma with metastasis in multiple lymph nodes, including two of six left pelvic lymph nodes and one of ten right pelvic lymph nodes. The radical cystoprostatectomy revealed invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder and surrounding tissues, with positive margins in the soft tissue and left periureteral fibroadipose tissue, while the prostate showed a Gleason score of 6 with no extraprostatic extension. Additionally, high-grade urothelial carcinoma was found in the excised periureteral tissues on both sides.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the rectus abdominus measuring 5 x 5 x 1 cm, which is histologically classified as moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The tumor is ulcerated and has metastasized to all 12 examined pararectal lymph nodes. Margins and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary and fallopian tube show no significant abnormalities, while the left ovary contains a follicular cyst and benign glandular rest. The uterus reveals a grade 2/3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma with 40% myometrial invasion, but clear margins and no evidence of lymph-vascular space invasion or malignancy in the examined lymph nodes. Additionally, psammoma bodies were identified in the omentum, but no malignancy was found in that specimen.

The pathology report indicates a malignant melanoma located in the skin of the right foot, measuring 5x4x2 cm, with features of ulceration, pigmentation, and necrosis. Microscopic examination reveals poorly differentiated tumor cells with low nucleo-cytoplasmic ratios, varying nuclear shapes and sizes, and evidence of invasion into fat tissue. Additionally, 2 out of 9 lymph nodes show metastasis, and the Breslow tumor thickness is noted to be 20 mm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of large cell, non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 4 x 3 x 3 cm, with a histologic grade of moderately differentiated. The report does not specify details regarding tumor extent, lymph nodes, invasion, or margins. There are no comments or additional findings noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal moderately differentiated invasive breast carcinoma, with the larger tumor measuring 5.3 cm and exhibiting focal signet-ring cell differentiation, while the smaller tumor measures 1.5 cm. There are foci of angioinvasion noted, and the left breast sample shows further invasive tumor components in the excision cavity. The dorsal resection margin is tumor-free, and the tumor classification is NOS, G II, pT3(mult)N2aL1V0R0.

The pathology report indicates that the left buccal mass is diagnosed as moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 5.0 cm in maximum diameter with a thickness of 1.5 cm, and shows perineural invasion but no lymphatic or vascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes from various levels of the neck (totaling 42) are negative for tumor involvement, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. The surgical margins are close to the tumor, with the nearest margin being 0.2 cm, but all margins are negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a pneumonectomy specimen from the left lower lung, revealing a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.5 x 2.5 x 3 cm. Details regarding tumor extent, other nodules, lymph nodes, and invasion are not specified. There is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from the right eye orbit was diagnosed with malignant choroidal melanoma, predominantly of the epithelioid cell type, following enucleation. The tumor measured 7.79 mm in basal diameter and 12.18 mm in height, with involvement of the choroid and intrascleral invasion, but did not extend into the optic nerve. Additional findings included a low mitotic rate, mild pigmentation, and retinal detachment, with no melanoma detected at the margins.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenal gland mass was resected, diagnosed as pheochromocytoma, a type of tumor arising from the adrenal medulla. The tumor measured 5.0 cm and was characterized by a well-circumscribed solid mass with hemorrhagic areas, surrounded by a thin fibrous capsule, and showed positive immunostaining for synaptophysin and chromogranin. Histological features suggest a low proliferative rate with no indicators of aggressive behavior, and the report emphasizes that histologic features are poor predictors of biological behavior in pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma from a left robotic partial nephrectomy specimen, measuring 2.5 x 2.5 cm, with the tumor confined to the renal parenchyma and no evidence of sarcomatoid features or lymph-vascular invasion. The surgical margins are involved by tumor along a 5 mm linear dimension, while the remaining margins are free of tumor, and there is mild interstitial nephritis in the adjacent non-neoplastic kidney tissue. The tumor cells show positive immunostaining for CK7 and racemase, supporting the diagnosis, with a cancer stage of pT1a, pNX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an adrenocortical carcinoma in the right adrenal mass, measuring 20 cm with a nuclear grade of 3 and a Weiss score of 3, but without evidence of necrosis or invasion into surrounding structures. Additionally, a liver biopsy revealed a hyperplastic regenerative nodule with specific immunohistochemical markers showing focal positivity for Melan A, Inhibin, and 35BH11, while other markers were negative. The renal parenchyma showed no signs of neoplastic infiltration.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions. A diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma, predominantly acinar type with a Gleason score of 4 + 4 = 8, was made, involving the left lobe of the prostate with focal extracapsular extension and perineural and angiolymphatic invasion, but all surgical margins and seminal vesicles are free of carcinoma. The tumor size is 1.8 cm, and the pathological staging is classified as pT3a, pNO, pMX, with high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia also identified.

The intraoperative examination of a lesion resected from the left breast revealed invasive ductal carcinoma (NHG2) with clear margins, indicating no immediate concern for residual cancer at the surgical boundaries. The tumor measures 9 x 7 x 4 cm and shows positive estrogen and progesterone receptors in over 75% of the neoplastic cell nuclei, while HER2 testing returned a negative result. Additionally, benign lesions were noted, and lymph nodes were free of neoplastic metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary and fallopian tube show no significant abnormalities, while the left ovary and fallopian tube contain paratubal cysts and cystic follicles. A radical hysterectomy revealed a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 6.5 x 5.0 x 2.0 cm, with stromal invasion extending 2.0 cm into the endocervical canal but no lymphovascular invasion, and negative surgical margins. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes were negative for metastatic disease, and other findings included benign endometrium with adenomyosis and a subserosal leiomyoma.

The pathology report indicates that no carcinoma was found in the right pelvic lymph nodes, with all four nodes being negative for cancer. The middle lobe of the prostate showed prostatic hyperplasia without carcinoma, while adenocarcinoma of the prostate was identified, primarily located in the peripheral zone, with a Gleason score of 7/10 and positive margins on the right side. Perineural invasion was present, but there was no evidence of lymphatic invasion or tumor in the seminal vesicles.

The pathology report indicates a left upper outer quadrant radical mastectomy specimen with a 3.5x3x3 cm infiltrating ductal carcinoma, which is poorly differentiated. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/6 positive). The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic counts.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma in a female patient, with the tumor located in the right thyroid lobe measuring 1.6 cm and exhibiting well-differentiated characteristics. Micrometastatic disease was identified in one of the lymph nodes, with a total of three lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement out of thirty examined, but no extranodal extension was noted. Additionally, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis was observed in the left thyroid lobe and isthmus, with all surgical margins free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the stomach shows an ulcer scar with active inflammation, fibrosis, and foveolar hyperplasia, but is negative for carcinoma. In contrast, the biopsy of the distal esophageal tumor reveals moderately to poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma with high-grade dysplasia. The clinical history includes esophageal cancer and Barrett esophagus.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in both ovaries, measuring 7 cm in the right ovary and 8 cm in the left ovary, with extensive metastatic spread to the fallopian tubes, uterus, sigmoid colon, and multiple lymph nodes. Additionally, metastatic serous carcinoma was found in the omentum, appendix, mesentery, and various lymph nodes, with a total of 11 out of 19 pelvic lymph nodes showing metastasis. The overall staging is classified as FIGO stage IIIC, indicating advanced disease with significant metastatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, measuring 9.5 cm, with invasion through the pleura and hilar soft tissue, but no lymphovascular invasion identified. Biopsies of multiple lymph nodes (levels 9, 10R, and 7) showed no evidence of malignancy, and the bronchial margin was also free of tumor. The overall pathological stage is classified as pT3/N0/MX, indicating Stage IIB lung cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the left frontal brain tumor biopsies are diagnosed as oligodendroglioma with atypical features, characterized by a proliferation index of 18% and low histological grade features, but with some signs of enhanced biological activity. Additionally, the MGMT promoter is found to be methylated, suggesting potential responsiveness to alkylating agent therapy, and there is evidence of allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, which is typical for oligodendrogliomas. The findings should be correlated with clinical and imaging data for comprehensive patient management.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme from excised brain tissue in the right occipital region. The tumor exhibits high histological grade features, including nuclear anaplasia, mitotic figures, and areas of necrosis with pseudopalisading. MIB-1 proliferation indices were measured at 12% and 14%, indicating a significant level of cellular proliferation within the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a total thyroidectomy in a male patient, revealing multifocal well-differentiated papillary carcinoma with a dominant tumor in the right lobe measuring 3.1 x 1.5 x 1.1 cm, and additional microcarcinomas in both lobes. There is no evidence of capsular invasion, lymphovascular invasion, perineural invasion, or extrathyroidal extension, with surgical margins uninvolved by carcinoma. Additionally, a hypercellular parathyroid gland was identified, but no malignancy was found in that tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a brain tumor diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV astrocytoma) in two submitted specimens. The frozen section analysis revealed malignant glioma with areas of gemistocytic histology, vascular endothelial proliferation, and necrosis, with strong immunoreactivity for GFAP and PTEN, while EGFRVIII was negative. The specimens were collected due to a clinical history of sudden onset and imaging findings of a right temporal brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 2.7 cm, with negative but close margins (< 1mm). A biopsy of the deep margin showed no evidence of carcinoma, and there was no vascular invasion identified. The regional lymph nodes were not submitted for evaluation, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue appeared unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the distal esophagus, measuring 3.5 cm, with focal invasion into the superficial muscularis propria and associated with Barrett's mucosa and high-grade dysplasia. Angiolymphatic invasion is present, but all surgical margins are negative for tumor, and two out of thirty-eight examined lymph nodes show metastatic adenocarcinoma. The pathologic stage is classified as pT2 N1, indicating the tumor's extent and lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the wide local excision of the vulva shows moderate to severe squamous dysplasia, with mild dysplasia noted at the margins. In the left axillary sentinel lymph nodes, two nodes were positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the remaining nodes were negative for metastases. The left breast mastectomy revealed three foci of invasive ductal carcinoma, with the largest measuring 1.8 cm, and all surgical margins were negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade uterine papillary serous carcinoma, with extensive involvement of the uterus, cervix, and bilateral adnexae, including myometrial invasion and lymphovascular space invasion. The omentum is also involved by serous carcinoma, with the largest tumor focus measuring 11.5 cm. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic serous carcinoma in both ovaries and the fallopian tubes, with surface involvement noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal invasive carcinoma of the left breast, with the largest tumor measuring 2.8 x 2.5 x 1.6 cm and a histologic grade of 3. There is also the presence of ductal in-situ carcinoma, necrosis, and the surgical margins, nipple, and skin are free of tumor. Estrogen receptor activity is positive, progesterone receptor activity is borderline, and there is no evidence of malignancy in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates multiple findings, including a benign omental implant and chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis in the gallbladder, but no tumors were identified in these specimens. Notably, an upper pancreatic neck excision revealed atypical glandular epithelium suspicious for well-differentiated adenocarcinoma, while a full resection of the duodenum and pancreas confirmed the presence of invasive adenocarcinoma arising from an intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm, with a tumor size of at least 4.5 cm and focal perineural invasion. Additionally, one out of nine examined lymph nodes contained metastatic carcinoma, leading to a pTNM stage of pT3 N1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma located at the junction of the cecum and ascending colon, measuring 6 cm, with invasive growth into surrounding tissues and metastasis in 2 of 10 lymph nodes. Additionally, there is evidence of fatty liver cirrhosis with complete cirrhotic remodeling in the liver parenchyma. A follow-up examination of 31 lymph nodes showed no tumor involvement, confirming a final lymph node status of pN1 (2/41).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in a biopsy of the distal esophagus. The tumor consists of multiple light gray and pink fragments of soft tissue, measuring a total of 0.8 x 0.3 x 0.3 cm. No distinctive Barrett mucosa was identified in the sample.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the cecal pouch of the right colon, measuring 4.6 x 3.0 cm, with evidence of lymphovascular invasion and focal perforation of the visceral peritoneum. A total of 17 lymph nodes were examined, with 11 showing metastatic carcinoma, leading to a staging of pT4aN2bVL. The appendix showed fibrous obliteration at the luminal tip, but no carcinoma was identified in that tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma of the stomach, characterized by extensive ulceration and infiltration into the tunica muscularis propria, but without invasion into the surrounding fatty tissue. Both the oral and aboral resection margins are tumor-free, with the oral margin showing unremarkable squamous epithelium and the aboral margin displaying normal small intestine mucosa. The tumor is staged as pT2a pNO (0/58) pMX, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the left tonsil, measuring at least 2.1 cm and extending to the excision margin, while no tumor was found in the left tongue base or the right tonsil. In situ hybridization for Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) is positive, suggesting a potential viral association with the carcinoma. The final diagnosis confirms the presence of moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left tonsil, with no definitive tumor identified in the other specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver, with a significant lesion measuring 3.0 x 2.7 x 4.0 cm and additional smaller nodules. The surgical margins are clear of tumor invasion, with a safety margin of 3.0 cm for the large mass and 0.2 cm for the small mass. The liver parenchyma is noted to be cirrhotic, and there is evidence of multicentric occurrence of the carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 9.7 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade 2-3. The tumor is confined to the kidney without vascular invasion, and the surgical margins are negative, indicating no residual cancer at the edges of the resected tissue. Additionally, the adrenal gland is uninvolved by metastasis, and no regional lymph nodes were sampled.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, identified as a polypoid mass confined to the endometrium without invasion into the endocervix or lymphovascular spaces. The tumor measures 3.0 x 2.3 x 1.0 cm, and the surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement, with no involvement of the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes. Additionally, multiple intramural leiomyomas are noted in the uterus, but they are not associated with the malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the excision of a subcutaneous mass diagnosed as an epidermal inclusion cyst. Additionally, a left nephrectomy revealed a 4.6 cm papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, grade 2, located in the upper pole of the kidney, with negative resection margins and no evidence of lymph node involvement. A simple renal cyst was also noted in the kidney, and the overall staging of the renal cell carcinoma is classified as pT1bNxMx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in segment 5 of the liver, with a tumor size of 3.3 x 3.1 x 3.0 cm and no evidence of necrosis or satellite nodules. The tumor exhibits moderate differentiation (worst differentiation III) and is encapsulated without invasion into surrounding structures or vessels. Additionally, the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis but no tumor presence.

The pathology report confirms the diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) from biopsies of a right temporal brain tumor, characterized by a densely cellular glioma with pleomorphic cells, frequent mitotic figures, vascular proliferation, and pseudopalisading necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis shows that the tumor cells are diffusely positive for GFAP, with a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 30%, indicating high proliferation. Additionally, the MGMT promoter methylation assay returned negative, suggesting that the tumor may not respond to alkylating agent therapy.

The pathology report describes a moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm characterized by diffuse infiltration and mild nuclear atypia, with no mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis observed. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the neoplastic cells are positive for IDH1 and negative for p53, with a low MIB-1 labeling index of 0.6%. The final diagnosis is a well-differentiated astrocytoma (grade II).

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the bladder neck and anterior prostatic fat revealed benign tissue with no tumors present. However, the radical prostatectomy specimen showed prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4 (9), extensive extraprostatic extension, and invasion of the bladder neck, with positive margins noted. Lymph node dissection results were negative for tumor involvement in 18 examined lymph nodes, although areas suspicious for lymphatic invasion were observed.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated serous carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the omentum, left and right ovaries, uterus, parametrial tissue, lymph nodes, gastrocolic ligament, spleen, and appendix. Concurrently, bilateral Brenner tumors were identified in the ovaries, and there is evidence of angiolymphatic invasion and metastatic spread to lymph nodes. The histological features suggest a primary peritoneal serous surface carcinoma, classified as grade 3 due to its poorly differentiated nature.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe nodule biopsy revealed poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 3.0 x 2.0 x 1.5 cm, with no vascular or perineural invasion identified, and the tumor involved the surface of the visceral pleura. The excised lymph nodes from levels V, X, and XI were negative for tumor, and a lobectomy of the left upper lobe showed no residual carcinoma, with bronchial margins free of tumor. Additionally, the non-neoplastic lung tissue exhibited chronic bronchitis, focal scarring, and parenchymal granulomas.

The pathology report indicates that all examined lymph nodes (24 total) from the left and right obturator and hypogastric regions show no evidence of tumor (0/24). The prostate diagnosis reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5), indicating aggressive cancer that has invaded the seminal vesicles and perivesicular soft tissue, with tumor extending to the cauterized margin of resection. Additionally, there is evidence of lymphovascular and perineural invasion, along with high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN).

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right intrapericardial pneumonectomy specimen, with a maximum tumor diameter of 6.3 cm and positive involvement of the visceral pleura and pericardium. Metastatic non-small cell carcinoma was identified in the Level 11 lymph node, while other lymph nodes and the diaphragmatic nodule showed no evidence of malignancy. The overall pathological stage is classified as pT3 pN1 pMX, indicating advanced local disease with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO IV) based on the biopsy of a left brain tumor, characterized by nuclear anaplasia, mitotic activity, and necrosis, with a MIB-1 proliferation index of 20%. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the presence of giant cells and some cells reactive with neuronal markers, suggesting a possible neuronal component that may indicate a less severe prognosis. Additionally, tests for the EGFR variant III mutation and methylated MGMT promoter were both negative, which may influence treatment options.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes were biopsied and all were found to be negative for neoplasm, with some showing anthracotic pigment and reactive changes. A lobectomy of the right lower lobe revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.0 x 2.0 x 1.6 cm, with focal pleural invasion but no lymphovascular space invasion. The final staging of the tumor is T2N0, confirming the presence of lung cancer as initially diagnosed.

The histopathological examination of the resected stomach reveals a grade 3 tubular adenocarcinoma that invades the full thickness of the stomach wall and has metastasized to multiple lymph nodes. The tumor shows significant infiltration into surrounding tissues, including vessels and perigastric fat, while the incision lines are free of neoplastic invasion. Immunohistochemical testing for HER2 shows a negative reaction in the invasive cancer cells.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, involving both the right and left sides of the prostate, with a maximum tumor size of 2.0 cm and approximately 8% of the prostate volume affected. The cancer is organ-confined with no evidence of extraprostatic extension, and all examined surgical margins and lymph nodes (13 total) are free of carcinoma. Additionally, multifocal perineural invasion is present, and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma (Grade 2) with a tumor size of 6.0 cm and greater than 50% myometrial invasion, along with cervical involvement. All examined lymph nodes from the left pelvic, left aortic, right pelvic, and right caval regions were negative for metastasis. Additionally, the umbilical hernia sac showed fibromembranous tissue consistent with a hernia, with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that a left adrenalectomy and left nephrectomy were performed, revealing a tumor measuring 14 x 13 cm with a Weiss score of 8, consistent with carcinoma of the adrenal gland exhibiting oxyphilic features. There is evidence of thrombus in the renal vein, but no lymph node metastasis was found. Additionally, peritoneal fluid analysis showed no malignant cells.

The pathology report indicates that a transhiatal esophagectomy was performed on a female patient with squamous cell esophageal cancer, revealing a 2.5 x 2.0 cm centrally ulcerated mass in the thoracic esophagus that invades the submucosa. Two out of eight examined lymph nodes were positive for metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while surgical margins were reported as negative for carcinoma. The final TNM classification is T1 N1 MX, indicating early-stage cancer with lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left pelvic lymph nodes, as well as the right ureter segment, show no evidence of tumor (0/4 and 0/8 lymph nodes, respectively). The bladder cystectomy reveals high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation, which is transmurally invasive into perivesical adipose tissue, alongside multifocal urothelial carcinoma in-situ, but no lymphovascular invasion is present. The ovaries show no significant pathology, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Focal Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma, Type I, classified as stage pT1b, with no regional lymph node involvement (pNX) and no distant metastasis (pMX). The tumor is graded as GII, suggesting a moderate level of differentiation. The report also notes the presence of residual tumor (R1) and includes the ICD-0 code 8260/3 for this type of cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with areas of necrosis present. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural infiltration. This suggests a localized tumor without spread to surrounding lymphatic or nerve structures.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in the celiac and left gastric lymph nodes, with a total of four out of twenty-eight lymph nodes examined showing involvement. Additionally, a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.9 cm was identified in the distal esophagus and proximal stomach, with evidence of lymphovascular and perineural invasion. The surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, and there is no prior treatment noted for the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of advanced mucinous carcinoma (Grade 3) that has infiltrated the surrounding fatty connective tissue and has an inflammatory connection to the uterus. The uterus itself appears normal for the patient's age, and there are no affected lymph nodes (pN0). Tumor classification details include pT3, L1, V1, and a total of 30 lymph nodes examined with no metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive mucinous carcinoma of the right breast (NHG3, pT4b, pNO) following a total organ resection of the right breast and axillary tissues. Immunohistochemical examination shows estrogen receptors present in over 75% of neoplastic cell nuclei, while progesterone receptors are found in less than 10%, with a HER2 score of 2+ and FISH verification recommended. The tumor measures 5.3 x 3.8 x 5.3 cm and exhibits infiltration into the breast tissue, with chronic lymphadenitis noted in the axillary lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 6 cm in the right upper lobe of the lung, with uninvolved margins. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in 1 of 4 level 10 lymph nodes and in 2 of 3 peribronchial lymph nodes, while level 7 and level R4 lymph nodes showed no evidence of metastasis. Overall, the findings suggest a localized lung adenocarcinoma with limited regional spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lung, with a tumor size of 2 x 1.2 x 0.7 cm. The tumor extends into the main bronchus, and 2 out of 6 examined lymph nodes show evidence of metastasis. There are no specified details regarding lymphatic or venous invasion, margins, or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates that one of the left axillary sentinel lymph nodes is positive for metastatic melanoma, while the other lymph nodes from both axillae are negative for metastatic tumor. The excised mid back melanoma shows residual malignant melanoma at a depth of 3.0 mm, classified as Clark's level IV, with all margins negative for malignancy. Additionally, the melanoma is noted to be associated with marked chronic inflammation and melanin-laden macrophages, and it is focally ulcerated.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a mildly hypercellular glial neoplasm infiltrating the gray and white matter, consistent with a diagnosis of well-differentiated astrocytoma. Atypical features are noted, but no mitotic figures are observed, and the proliferation index is low at 1.7%. Overall, the findings suggest a low-grade glioma with reactive astrocytes present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma involving both the right and left ovaries, with tumor invasion noted on the ovarian surfaces and surrounding soft tissues, as well as lymphatic-vascular space invasion. Additionally, metastatic serous adenocarcinoma is identified in the fallopian tubes, uterus, bladder mucosa, appendix, gastrocolic omentum, and rectal plaque. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IIIC due to extensive peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis, with insufficient data to assess regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the distal esophagus, which extends into the gastroesophageal junction and proximal stomach, with submucosal invasion noted. One perigastric lymph node out of 48 examined shows metastatic adenocarcinoma, while all other lymph nodes and surgical margins are negative for carcinoma. Additionally, intestinal metaplasia consistent with Barrett's esophagus is observed at the gastroesophageal junction.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma from a brain biopsy of the left pulvinar. Microscopic examination reveals a high-grade glioma characterized by hypercellularity, pleomorphism, mitotic figures, and microvascular endothelial hyperplasia, along with necrotic tissue fragments. The MIB-1 labeling index for the tumor cells is approximately 10%.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma, WHO grade 4, characterized by a diffusely infiltrative tumor in the right frontotemporal and insular regions of the brain, with positive immunostaining for mutant IDH1-R132H protein and a low positive methylated MGMT promoter status. The tumor exhibits brisk mitotic activity and microvascular proliferation, but no necrosis is observed. Additionally, there is no evidence of allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, which is typically associated with oligodendrogliomas.

The pathology report indicates that nine lymph nodes from the right periaortic region show no evidence of metastatic disease, with findings of follicular lymphoid hyperplasia. The hysterectomy specimen reveals a carcinosarcoma at the fundus of the uterus, classified as FIGO grade 3, with a significant serous carcinoma component and no lymphovascular invasion or regional lymph node involvement. Additional findings include physiologic changes in the ovaries and fallopian tubes, with no significant abnormalities noted in the lymph nodes from pelvic and periaortic dissections.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 cholangiocarcinoma in the right liver segments IV-VIII, characterized by a dominant mass measuring 11.5 x 9.2 x 8.6 cm and multiple smaller nodules, with evidence of focal angiolymphatic invasion. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, and biopsies from the left liver lobe, caudate region lymph node, and peritoneum show benign findings, while the gallbladder reveals chronic cholecystitis. Immunohistochemical studies confirm the neoplastic cells' profile consistent with cholangiocarcinoma, being positive for cytokeratin 7 and negative for other markers.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colon, which is transmurally invasive and extends into adjacent soft tissues, arising in the context of a tubular villous adenoma. The tumor measures 3.2 cm and has negative surgical margins, with no evidence of tumor in the 15 examined lymph nodes. Additionally, there are no significant pathologic findings in the appendix or terminal ileum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme with a small cell pattern from both a biopsy and excision of a right frontal brain lesion. The tumor exhibits strong GFAP staining and a high MIB-1 proliferative rate of 25-30%, with evidence of entrapped ganglion cells and axons. The specimens were collected during a right frontal craniotomy for tumor resection, and both samples were submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of type 2 papillary renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 6.5 cm, with Fuhrman's nuclear grade 3, and the tumor is confined to the kidney without invasion of surrounding structures. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic papillary renal cell carcinoma in one of three hilar lymph nodes, with the metastatic focus measuring less than 0.1 cm. The report also notes the presence of multiple renal cortical adenomas and simple cysts, as well as adrenal cortical hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma extensively involving the omentum, serosal surfaces of the appendix, uterus, both ovaries, and both fallopian tubes, with additional involvement in colonic and small bowel implants. The report also notes the presence of a Brenner tumor in the right ovary and multiple leiomyomas in the uterus, while the endometrium shows cystic atrophy but is free of carcinoma. Overall, the findings suggest a primary peritoneal papillary serous adenocarcinoma, with significant tumor burden in the peritoneal cavity and associated structures.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately to poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon, measuring 3.9 cm, with invasion into the subserosa and two of twenty-four lymph nodes showing metastatic carcinoma. The proximal, distal, and radial margins are negative for tumor, and there is suspicious angiolymphatic invasion but no perineural invasion identified. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive expression for MLH1, MSH2, and MSH6, but negative for PMS2, with further testing for microsatellite instability pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (grade 2) in the right breast, with a tumor size measuring 4.2 x 3.7 x 2.9 cm and extending to within 0.4 mm of the deep margin. The tumor is noted to invade the dermis and dermal lymphatics, but there is no evidence of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or lymph node involvement. Immunohistochemical studies show positive estrogen receptor expression and HER2/neu amplification, while the progesterone receptor is negative.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left thyroid lobe, characterized as well-differentiated with a size of 2.5 cm and focal extrathyroidal extension. Additionally, multiple foci of papillary microcarcinoma were identified in the right lobe, with sizes ranging from 0.2 cm to 0.5 cm, and psammoma bodies noted in the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue. Metastatic disease was confirmed in both examined lymph nodes from the left neck, with all lymph nodes showing evidence of metastatic papillary carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic high-grade adenocarcinoma, confirmed by frozen section, with involvement of the omentum and uterus, including the right ovary and parametrial tissue. The tumor measures approximately 1.0 cm and shows focal invasion into the myometrium, with no definitive lymphovascular invasion identified. The final diagnosis is consistent with serous carcinoma of endometrial origin, classified as pT3a NX (FIGO IIIA).

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a splenectomy, revealing scattered granulomas in the spleen with no evidence of microorganisms. A radical resection of a left retroperitoneal sarcoma, along with the left kidney, adrenal gland, and left colon, identified a dedifferentiated liposarcoma measuring 22 cm, with areas of necrosis and mitotic activity, but no tumor involvement in the kidney, adrenal gland, or colon. The end of the sigmoid colon resection showed no tumor presence, confirming the absence of malignancy in that segment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with a tumor diameter of 3.5 cm and a dorsal margin distance of 3 cm, while other margins are free of tumor. The tumor classification is noted as NOS, G II, pT2N3aLOV0R0. This suggests a moderate grade tumor with regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a well-differentiated pancreatic endocrine neoplasm measuring 3 cm, with a low mitotic count and no necrosis, and the pancreatic resection margin is free of tumor. There is a focus of PanIN 1-2 at the resection margin, along with uninvolved pancreatic parenchyma showing focal fibrosis, atrophy, and PanIN-3 changes. The spleen shows no significant pathological findings, and immunohistochemical staining confirms the neuroendocrine nature of the tumor with a proliferation index of less than 1%.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe of the lung contains a 6 cm invasive, poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with focal sarcomatoid features, but it does not involve the visceral pleural surface, and the margins of resection are free of tumor. Additionally, the level 5 lymph node and two peribronchial lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma. Overall, there is no evidence of direct extension, venous, arterial, or lymphatic invasion, and distant metastasis could not be assessed.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a high-grade adrenal cortical carcinoma in the right adrenal gland, characterized by necrosis and a high mitotic rate, with the tumor confined to the adrenal gland and no extraglandular extension. A biopsy of the left lobe of the liver shows benign hepatic parenchyma with steatosis, and is negative for carcinoma. The mass from the right adrenal gland weighed 200 grams and was covered by an intact pseudocapsule, with gross margins free of tumor.
