The tumor is confined to the uterine corpus, and no additional pathologic findings or distant metastasis were noted.

The pathology report indicates that a peritoneal implant from a retroperitoneal sarcoma has been diagnosed as a high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma. The tumor exhibits spindled morphology with prominent nucleoli and frequent mitoses, and it extends to the resection margins. The specimen was received unfixed and measured 4 x 3 x 1.2 cm, with representative sections submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse type adenocarcinoma located in the mid-antrum of the stomach, with a tumor size of 3.0 x 3.0 x 1.3 cm and evidence of lymphovascular invasion. Lymph node metastasis was present in 5 out of 43 examined nodes, leading to a pathologic stage of pT2N2Mx according to the AJCC 7th edition. Additionally, the gallbladder showed signs of cholelithiasis with autolysis, but no malignancy was identified in the gallbladder tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classic seminoma, measuring 2.4 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and involvement of the rete testis, but no invasion into the tunica vaginalis or epididymis. Additionally, there is evidence of intratubular germ cell neoplasia, focal Leydig cell hyperplasia, and a benign epididymal cyst measuring 1.6 cm. The spermatic cord margin is free of tumor, and the specimen was obtained from a right orchiectomy.

The pathology report indicates a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.3 cm in the left upper lobe of the lung, with free bronchial, vascular, and pleural margins, and no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in six examined lymph nodes. Fluorescent in-situ hybridization studies show amplification of the Her2/Neu and cyclin D1 genes, while the EGFR gene shows no amplification, suggesting potential implications for patient prognosis. Special stains for neuroendocrine markers were negative, reinforcing the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma despite the presence of neuroendocrine features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma (metaplastic carcinoma) in the right breast, characterized by a significant mass with skin ulceration and angiolymphatic invasion. A single intramammary lymph node is positive for metastatic carcinoma, while multiple excised right axillary lymph nodes show no evidence of metastatic disease. All surgical resection margins are negative for tumor, and further receptor analysis will be provided in an addendum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated squamous carcinoma in a right cheek lesion and moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma in a total glossectomy specimen, with the latter showing significant invasion and metastasis in multiple lymph nodes. The bilateral neck dissection revealed metastatic carcinoma in 11 of 50 lymph nodes, with varying degrees of extracapsular extension. The margins of the lesions were reported as free of tumor, suggesting complete excision of the primary tumors.

The pathology report indicates a right testicle radical orchiectomy revealing a mixed germ cell tumor, comprising 85% classic seminoma and 15% mature teratoma, measuring 7 cm in the largest dimension. The tumor invades the tunica albuginea but does not extend to the tunica vaginalis, with no evidence of perineural or lymphovascular invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Serum tumor markers show elevated hCG levels, while AFP and LDH are within normal limits, and the tumor is classified as pT1 with no known distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating duct carcinoma with signet ring features in the right breast, measuring 4.0 cm, following a right segmental mastectomy. The closest surgical margins are noted to be less than 1 mm, but the margins are otherwise free of tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis shows negative estrogen and progesterone receptor status, while HER-2/neu is positive with a score of 3+.

The histopathological examination of a segment of the large intestine revealed a 4 cm tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma (G2) infiltrating the muscular layer, with the tumor surrounding 50% of the intestinal circumference. The surgical margins are free of neoplastic lesions, and a diverticulum was noted outside the tumor. The diagnosis is consistent with Dukes B classification, indicating a localized cancer of the sigmoid colon.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal intraductal and infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast of a female patient. The tumor is graded 2/3 and is moderately differentiated, with extension to within 0.1 mm of the surgical margin. This suggests a need for careful consideration of further treatment options due to the proximity of the tumor to the margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a dominant mass measuring 14.5 x 8.7 x 6.8 cm and numerous satellite nodules, with all tumors confined to the liver and negative resection margins. There is no evidence of macroscopic or microscopic vascular invasion, and three perihepatic lymph nodes are also negative for tumor. Additionally, the gallbladder shows signs of chronic cholecystitis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has infiltrative duct carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 2.6 cm, with all surgical margins free of lesions. Two sentinel lymph nodes were examined, both showing reactive changes and no evidence of metastasis. The tumor is classified as Grade III with high mitotic activity and features of ductal carcinoma in situ present, comprising about 6% of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated serous carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the ileum, distal cecum, right ovary, uterus, left fallopian tube, diaphragm, omentum, and a tumor in the cul-de-sac, with extensive lymphovascular invasion noted in several areas. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, but all six examined mesenteric lymph nodes are positive for metastatic disease. Additional findings include chronic cervicitis, squamous metaplasia, and leiomyomas in the uterus, with the left ovary showing no tumor but some epithelial inclusions and surface adhesions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 2, which forms a polypoid mass invading 1.3 cm into the myometrium, with no lymphovascular invasion and the cervix uninvolved. The bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes show no diagnostic abnormalities, and all examined lymph nodes, including those in the pelvic and para-aortic regions, are negative for tumor. The surgical procedure involved a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes excised from various levels are negative for malignancy, with a total of 14 lymph nodes examined showing no evidence of cancer. However, a squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated and measuring 5.2 cm, was identified in the right upper lobe of the lung, with invasion into the visceral pleura. Surgical margins and a peribronchial lymph node were negative for malignancy, suggesting no regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 4.0 x 3.5 x 2.5 cm, with lymphovascular invasion but free margins. Additionally, a microscopic focus of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6 was identified in the prostate, alongside high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, while all examined lymph nodes showed no evidence of malignancy. The ureters and urethral margins were reported as benign, with no malignancy detected in the associated tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 3.5 cm, but without local or renal vein invasion. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney shows simple cortical cysts and chronic inflammation. Additionally, a separate specimen from the lateral lower pole cyst wall reveals benign renal tubules and fibrovascular tissue with hemosiderin-laden macrophages.

The pathology report describes a pancreaticoduodenectomy specimen revealing a 3.8 cm invasive pancreatic adenocarcinoma, grade 3, located in the head of the pancreas, with one of twelve lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement. The surgical margins are negative for malignancy, indicating no tumor at the margins, although the tumor is close to the portal vein groove. The overall staging is pT3 N1 Mx, suggesting locally advanced disease with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left breast invasive carcinoma, specifically a ductal adenocarcinoma with a maximum dimension of 2.4 cm, and a Nottingham grade of 5/9. Sentinel lymph node biopsies revealed metastatic carcinoma in two nodes, with one node showing a metastatic focus of 7 mm and evidence of extracapsular extension, while another node was benign. The surgical margins from the mastectomy are free of invasive and in situ carcinoma, and the tumor is positive for ER, PR, and HER-2/NEU.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 70 mm, with evidence of blood vessel permeation but no lymphatic or perineural invasion. Additionally, metastatic deposits are found in the peribronchial and right middle lobe lymph nodes, while the right upper lobe specimens show organizing pneumonia with a BOOP pattern and no malignancy. The carcinoma is noted to possibly invade the pleura, but it is clear of the bronchial resection margin.

The pathology report indicates that the right kidney partial nephrectomy revealed a unifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma, type II, measuring 2.9 cm, with a histologic grade of G3 and 10% tumor necrosis, but the surgical margins were free of malignancy. Additionally, benign renal parenchyma was found in the deep margin and benign adipose tissue in the additional cystic wall specimen. The tumor is classified as pT1a, with no evidence of regional lymph node or distant metastasis.

The left lower lobe wedge resection reveals a 2.5 cm invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with focal angiolymphatic invasion, but no visceral pleural invasion, and it involves one of five N1 lymph nodes, with all margins free. The pathologic stage is classified as T1, N1, MX. Additionally, there are findings of emphysematous change, multiple small carcinoid tumorlets, and a pulmonary hamartoma, with one lymph node showing metastatic adenocarcinoma and others free of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+5=8, characterized by a mixture of Gleason patterns 3, 4, and 5, with negative surgical margins and no tumor found in the seminal vesicles or lymph nodes. Additionally, benign fibroadipose tissue was identified in the anterior prostatic fat and benign fibroconnective tissue in the left lateral margin biopsy. The tumor shows perineural infiltration and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (HGPIN) is present focally, with an overall AJCC/UICC stage of pT2cNO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma, epithelial type, based on pleural biopsy specimens. The tumor cells were found to be positive for calretinin, WT-1, and CK5/6, supporting the diagnosis, while non-necrotizing granulomatous inflammation was also noted. Additional tests for microorganisms were negative, and the specimens were received in two parts for analysis.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma of the stomach (cardia) with an intestinal pattern, measuring 5.0 x 5.0 x 0.9 cm, and infiltrating up to the perigastric adipose tissue, but without evidence of vascular or perineural invasion. Six out of fifteen dissected lymph nodes are compromised by neoplasia, with capsular leakage noted, while adjacent mucosa shows chronic inactive gastritis with complete intestinal metaplasia. Surgical margins are free of neoplastic involvement, and other examined tissues, including the pancreas, spleen, and gallbladder, show no significant histological abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multifocal infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the mucinous type in the right breast, with a Nottingham score of 4 and no angiolymphatic invasion, and the surgical margins are free of carcinoma. The sentinel lymph node biopsy showed no malignancy, and the endocervical and endometrial curettage revealed only benign findings without atypia or carcinoma. Hormone receptor analysis from a previous biopsy shows the tumor to be estrogen and progesterone receptor positive, and HER-2/neu negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix based on a biopsy. Due to poor orientation of the specimen, the depth of invasion could not be accurately assessed, but there appears to be at least 5.0 mm of invasion. The specimen consisted of multiple tan-pink, rubbery portions of soft tissue, and representative sections have been submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme in the left temporal lobe of a male patient. Gross examination revealed a 3 x 1.5 x 1.5 cm brain tumor with an area of hemorrhage, while microscopic analysis showed characteristics of a high-grade glioma, including hypercellularity, pleomorphism, and necrosis. The MIB-1 stain indicated a tumor cell proliferation index of approximately 20%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive transitional cell carcinoma, grade 3-4, with full thickness invasion of the bladder wall and multifocal carcinoma in situ, along with metastatic transitional cell carcinoma identified in three out of 73 examined lymph nodes. The ureters and apical urethral margin were found to be benign with no evidence of malignancy. Additional findings included adenomyosis and a single intramural leiomyoma in the uterus, while the ovaries and fallopian tubes were unremarkable and free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of micrometastatic carcinoma in sentinel lymph node #1 of the right axilla, while sentinel lymph nodes #2 and #3 show no tumor. The right breast mastectomy reveals multicentric invasive ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, measuring 1.2 cm, with extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present at the anterior margin. Additional findings include no tumor in 13 axillary lymph nodes and the presence of DCIS at the inked aspect of additional breast tissue, with no evidence of carcinoma in the inferior margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a dominant mass and a small satellite nodule, with clear surgical margins and no vascular invasion. The hepatic capsule is free of tumor, and the tumor exhibits a pushing type of infiltration. Additionally, the gallbladder shows mild chronic cholecystitis, while the non-neoplastic liver demonstrates mild tumor effect without evidence of chronic or primary liver disease.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma (Grade 1) in the uterus and cervix, with a tumor size of 9.4 cm and less than 50% myometrial invasion. No lymphovascular invasion was identified, and all examined lymph nodes (26 total) were negative for metastasis. The right and left ovaries, as well as the cervix and serosa, showed no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive multifocal lobular carcinoma of the left breast, with significant metastasis to 19 out of 22 axillary lymph nodes. The tumor measures 6.2 x 3.6 x 4.8 cm and is classified as NHG2, with additional findings of ductal carcinoma in situ comprising 10% of the tumor. The report also notes signs of perilymphatic invasion and describes the macroscopic and microscopic characteristics of the removed tissues.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 7.8 x 6.2 x 4.6 cm, with visceral pleural invasion but no extension beyond the pleura. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes were examined, all of which showed no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, with findings consistent with reactive hyperplasia and chronic inflammation. The final diagnosis confirms the presence of the lung tumor and the absence of metastatic disease in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a right kidney specimen with a 3 x 3 x 2.8 cm encapsulated clear cell renal cell carcinoma, Fuhrman grade 3, located in the lower pole and limited to the kidney without invasion into surrounding structures. The tumor is 1 cm away from the ureter, and all examined margins are free of neoplasm. Additional findings include severe arteriosclerosis in the adjacent benign kidney, but minimal nephrosclerosis and atrophy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a benign seborrheic keratosis in the left frontal skin, which extends to the excisional margin. Multiple excisional biopsies from the left temporal region reveal glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, with varying degrees of tumor necrosis and high cellularity, suggesting aggressive behavior. Immunohistochemical analysis shows retained expression of PTEN and amplification of the EGFR gene, which may influence the tumor's response to targeted therapies.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme from an excisional biopsy of the temporal lobe of the brain. The tumor presents with significant cellular proliferation, nuclear anaplasia, and extensive necrosis, along with a notable proliferative index of approximately 10%. The patient has a clinical history of progressive left-sided weakness and headaches, with the tumor extending into the frontal lobe.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bile duct hamartoma in the right lobe of the liver, with negative findings for malignancy in the hepatic hilar lymph nodes, common hepatic duct margin, and pancreatic neck margin. However, a Whipple resection revealed invasive moderately differentiated grade 3 ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas, with angiolymphatic and perineural invasion, and positive margins at the portal vein groove. Additionally, three out of twenty-five regional lymph nodes were positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, leading to a classification of AJCC pT3N1.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an ulcerated rectal carcinoma in the rectosigmoid colon, classified as a moderately differentiated colorectal adenoma, measuring 3 cm and extending to within 4 cm of the resection margin. The tumor has invaded the periproctic fatty tissue, but both oral and aboral resection margins are tumor-free, with a minimum distance of 2 cm from the soft tissue margin. Additionally, 32 examined lymph nodes are free of tumor involvement, leading to a final tumor stage of pT3, pNO (0/32), and G2.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the left breast, Nottingham grade II, with a mass size of 4.7 x 2.2 x 1.5 cm, and lobular carcinoma in situ also noted; all surgical margins are negative for tumor. In the right breast, infiltrating ductal carcinoma, also Nottingham grade II, is present with extensive ductal carcinoma in situ, and multiple right axillary lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma, classified as AJCC pN2. Additionally, isolated tumor cells are detected in a left intramammary sentinel lymph node, while other lymph nodes in both breasts are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left ovary, with extensive metastatic involvement in multiple regional lymph nodes, while the right ovary and both fallopian tubes show no histopathologic abnormalities. Additionally, the uterus exhibits disordered proliferative endometrium and an endometrial polyp, but no carcinoma is identified, and the omentum is free of carcinoma. The report concludes that the primary tumor is classified as FIGO stage IIIc due to regional lymph node metastases.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a type B thymoma, measuring 9.0 cm, which microscopically invades the capsule and is present in the perithymic adipose tissue, although the surgical resection margin is free of tumor. Additionally, benign thymic tissue was identified in both the thymus and the AP window biopsy, with no tumor seen in those specimens. The tumor cells are positive for AE1:AE3, while the thymic lymphocytes show positivity for CD1A, CD99, and CD3.

The pathology report indicates that both the left and right ovaries show poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma, with evidence of tumor involvement on their surfaces. Additionally, there is metastatic adenocarcinoma present in the omentum and both the right iliac and left para-aortic lymph nodes. The final staging suggests advanced disease with peritoneal metastasis and regional lymph node involvement, classified as FIGO stage IIIC.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma (Grade I) in the uterus, with a tumor size of 5.0 x 4.5 cm and myometrial invasion of 0.4 cm, while all examined lymph nodes are negative for metastasis. Additionally, a mature cystic teratoma was identified in the right ovary and tube, and benign findings such as intramural leiomyomas and adenomyosis were noted. The overall staging is T1b, N0, Mx, suggesting localized disease without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that the right upper lobe of the lung contains a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.5 cm, which extends to the staple line. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes, including six level 10 lymph nodes, twelve R-4 lymph nodes, and three level 7 lymph nodes. Additionally, a residual adenocarcinoma measuring 1.5 cm is noted at the staple line of the right lobe of the lung, but the margins of resection are uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, with perineural and lymph-vascular invasion, and involvement of the common bile duct and duodenum. Three out of fifteen examined peripancreatic lymph nodes were positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the resection margins were mostly negative for invasive carcinoma, except for the vascular bed margin. Additionally, the gallbladder showed mild non-specific acute inflammation, and five lymph nodes from group A were negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderate-grade invasive keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm on the right lateral tongue, with a depth of invasion of 0.5 cm and negative margins. All examined lymph nodes from levels I to IV in the right neck were negative for carcinoma, indicating no lymphatic spread. The frozen section analysis confirmed the absence of carcinoma in the additional soft tissue samples taken from various sites.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma in the right breast, measuring at least 4.5 cm, with a Nottingham combined histologic grade of 2 out of 3 and clear surgical margins. Metastatic breast carcinoma was found in two out of two examined right axillary lymph nodes, while the sentinel lymph node and six level 3 axillary lymph nodes showed no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings include foci of lobular carcinoma in situ and duct carcinoma in situ, with the tumor being ER positive and HER2 positive.

The pathology report indicates that both the right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes show no significant pathologic abnormalities, while a radical hysterectomy revealed a Grade II endocervical adenocarcinoma measuring 3.3 x 3.0 x 1.5 cm with focal stromal invasion into the paracervical tissue. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, although the tumor extends to the vaginal cuff margin of resection, and one paracervical lymph node is negative for malignancy, with additional lymph nodes also showing no evidence of metastatic disease. Other findings include endometrial and myometrial tissues without malignancy, and a vaginal biopsy confirming adenocarcinoma within the deep wall.

The pathology report indicates the presence of epithelioid malignant mesothelioma in both specimens taken from the parietal pleura, characterized by thickened pleura infiltrated by a tumor with predominantly papillary architecture and moderate pleomorphism. Macroscopically, the specimens show irregular tumor masses with associated adipose tissue and necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis, revealing positivity for MNF116 and calretinin, with other markers showing variable expression.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with a predominant bronchiolo-alveolar carcinoma component in the left lower lobe, measuring approximately 50 x 60 x 45 mm, with no evidence of vascular or perineural invasion and no metastases to hilar lymph nodes. Although the pleura is closely abutted by the tumor, confirmatory stains show no definitive invasion. Additionally, a separate specimen from the back reveals a lipoma, characterized by lobulated mature adipose tissue with no signs of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma grade III with an elevated MIB-1 labeling index of 18.8%, suggesting early anaplastic progression despite the tumor being histologically low grade. Microscopic examination reveals a mildly to moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm that infiltrates both gray and white matter, with features such as perineural satellitosis and mildly atypical nuclei. Notably, there are no mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis observed in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of residual superficial spreading melanoma on the left shoulder with a Breslow depth of 12 mm and extensive ulceration, while all margins are widely free. Sentinel lymph node analysis revealed metastatic melanoma in two out of three nodes, with one node showing focal capsular involvement but no extracapsular extension. Additional excisions of margins showed no evidence of melanoma, and further testing for BRAF mutation is planned.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) in the right occipital lobe based on both frozen section and resection specimens. The specimens consisted of multiple pieces of white-tan tissue, with one specimen measuring 0.8 x 0.1 x 0.2 cm and the other measuring 2.0 x 1.4 x 0.5 cm in aggregate. Intraoperative consultation confirmed the presence of glioblastoma in the right occipital lesion.

The pathology report indicates a colonic resection specimen from the rectosigmoid junction, revealing a tubular adenoma with severe dysplasia that has transitioned to adenocarcinoma in situ, along with ulcerated moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma showing early infiltration into the perimuscular fat tissue. A total of 26 lymph nodes were examined, with 15 showing metastatic infiltrates from the adenocarcinoma, leading to a staging of T3 pN2 (15/26). The tumor-free oral and aboral margins suggest no residual disease at the resection edges.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, primarily located in the right lobe of the prostate, measuring 1.6 cm, and showing focal extracapsular extension. All examined surgical margins and lymph nodes (20 total) are free of carcinoma, with no evidence of neoplasia in the lymph nodes. Additionally, multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and benign prostatic hypertrophy with chronic inflammation are noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.1 cm, with a high nuclear grade and negative surgical margins. Additionally, one of the sentinel lymph nodes shows metastatic carcinoma with extranodal extension, while the remaining 34 axillary lymph nodes are negative for metastases. The tumor is ER and PR positive, HER2 negative, and the overall pathological staging is pT1c N1a.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, measuring 8.5 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4 and extensive necrosis, invading the renal vein, adrenal vein, and surrounding adipose tissues, but with no tumor present in the adrenal gland or lymph nodes. A thrombus associated with the carcinoma was also identified within the renal vein, while the para-aortic and retroaortic lymph nodes showed no evidence of tumor involvement. The report highlights the presence of foreign material and marked necrosis in the adjacent normal kidney tissue, with the tumor extending beyond the renal vein margin but not involving its wall.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly-differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing multifocal established extracapsular extension. The carcinoma accounts for approximately 20% of the examined prostate volume, with no evidence of neoplasia found in the examined lymph nodes (0/19). All surgical resection margins are free of carcinoma, and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is also identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a low-grade oligoastrocytoma (WHO Grade II) following the resection of a brain tumor. Histological examination reveals a cellular glioma with both astrocytic and oligodendroglial features, low mitotic activity, and strong p53 positivity in numerous tumor cells, along with molecular findings of 19q loss and intact 1p. The specimen consisted of multiple fragments of soft tissue, with a total aggregate size of 3.5 x 2.7 x 1.6 cm, submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a tumor in the gastric wall, measuring 5.5 cm, characterized by middle-sized lymphoid cells and some regions with large atypical cells, consistent with non-Hodgkin's marginal zone B-cell lymphoma. Immunohistochemical staining shows positive CD20 and negative markers for CD3, CD5, CD10, and CyclinD1, with a Ki67 proliferation index of 60%. No lymph node metastasis was found in the 15 sampled nodes, and the tumor is localized to the stomach's antrum.

The pathology report indicates a radical mastectomy specimen with a tumor size of 2.2 cm, identified as infiltrating ductal and lobular carcinoma. Out of nine lymph nodes examined, one showed evidence of metastasis. The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tumor grading and other histologic features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metaplastic carcinoma, matrix-producing type, Nottingham grade III, in the right breast, measuring 2.7 x 2.3 x 1.7 cm, with associated high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ and no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. All surgical margins from the right mastectomy are negative for tumor, and multiple sentinel lymph nodes from both the right and left axillae are negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, the left breast and skin flaps show benign findings without any diagnostic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates that the lung wedge specimen shows a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma, with a tumor size of 2.4 x 2.3 x 1.8 cm and grade II differentiation, while lymph node analysis reveals six out of six nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. Genetic testing shows a KRAS mutation (G12C) detected, while no EGFR mutations were found, suggesting potential resistance to EGFR-targeted therapies, and FISH analysis for ALK rearrangement was negative, indicating no translocation but a gain of the ALK region in 79% of cells. The findings highlight the importance of these mutations in guiding treatment decisions, particularly regarding the use of tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the lymph nodes from the 4R and Station 7 lymphadenectomies, as well as in the diaphragm and right liver biopsies. However, a biopsy of the right pleura revealed the presence of epithelioid malignant mesothelioma. The findings suggest a diagnosis of mesothelioma, with no evidence of tumor in the other examined tissues.

The pathology report indicates a left upper lobe wedge resection revealing a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 25 mm, with the tumor being clear of the pleura and surgical margins. There is no evidence of lymphatic, vascular, or perineural invasion, and the pathological stage is classified as T1. Additionally, the adjacent lung parenchyma shows signs of organizing pneumonia and acute bronchopneumonia, while the remaining lung exhibits severe emphysema and areas of fibroelastotic scarring.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade diffuse astrocytoma (WHO grade II) in the brain, specifically in the hippocampus and left temporal lobe. Immunoperoxidase studies show positive GFAP staining, low Ki-67 proliferative index, and negative IDH1-R132H and EMA, suggesting a relatively low level of aggressiveness. The lesion exhibits high cellularity in some areas, but mitotic activity is not evident.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma with extensive spindle cell differentiation, also referred to as gliosarcoma, affecting the left temporal lobe of the brain, as well as the leptomeninges, dura mater, and skull. Intraoperative consultations suggested the presence of meningioma, at least Grade 2, in the submitted specimens. The report includes details on the gross description of the tumor and associated tissues, with multiple samples processed for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates a resected colon sample containing an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3 cm, with extensive infiltration into pericolic fatty tissue and four regional lymph node metastases. The tumor has penetrated the overlying serosa but the resection margins are tumor-free. Additionally, two tubular adenomas with moderate dysplasia were identified, and the tumor is staged as pT4 pN2 (4/15) pM1, indicating clinically significant liver metastases.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 5.0 cm, with negative margins but lymphovascular invasion present. All examined lymph nodes (39 total) were negative for carcinoma, and there were no significant findings in the ovaries and fallopian tubes. The final staging is pT1b2a2, FIGO IIA2, with the tumor confined to the cervix and no parametrial involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing acute and chronic calculous cholecystitis without evidence of malignancy, and gallstones were confirmed. A resection of the left kidney and adrenal gland showed renal cell carcinoma with a maximum tumor dimension of 11 cm, confined by the capsule but with an occlusive carcinomatous thrombus in the renal vein, classified as pathologic stage T3b. Additionally, a fine needle aspiration biopsy of the left upper lung lobe revealed metastatic renal cell carcinoma, while a separate lung nodule biopsy showed no definitive evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse malignant mesothelioma, predominantly epithelioid type, affecting the left upper and lower lobes of the lung, with invasion into the visceral and parietal pleura and involvement of a level 11 lymph node. Additional findings include reactive changes in several lymph nodes, no evidence of malignancy in bone and soft tissue samples, and chronic pleuritis with hyaline pleural plaques. The report also notes tobacco-induced lung injury, specifically respiratory bronchiolitis and emphysematous changes, without evidence of asbestosis or significant asbestos-related findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 4.8 cm, with a histologic grade of 3. No tumor was found in the surrounding tissues, including the base margin, perinephric fat, and cyst wall, and the surgical resection margins were negative. The tumor is classified as stage pT1NXMX, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately to poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the pancreatic head, with invasion into peripancreatic soft tissue and involvement of three out of nine lymph nodes. Additionally, pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia III (PanIN III) and chronic pancreatitis are noted, along with acute and chronic cholecystitis. The margins from the bile duct excision are negative for carcinoma, but carcinoma is present at the retroperitoneal and vascular groove margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 4 renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, in the right kidney, with a significant tumor mass measuring 8.2 x 6.2 x 5.3 cm that invades the collecting system and perinephric fat, but the renal vein is free of tumor. Additionally, metastatic renal cell carcinoma is present in the left adrenal gland, and one paracaval lymph node is positive for metastasis, while the inter aortic caval lymph node is negative. The report also notes the presence of sarcomatoid differentiation in the tumor on permanent sections.

The pathology report indicates the presence of well-differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma in multiple specimens, including the left nasal intima, left infraorbital nerve, pterygoid tumor, and soft palate, with some specimens showing close proximity to surgical margins. Notably, there is no evidence of tumor invasion in the superior nasal cavity tissue or the hemimandibulectomy specimen. The report highlights that further assessment of bone invasion is pending for some specimens.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 8.5 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ and calcifications. One of the sentinel lymph nodes examined showed metastatic ductal carcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes and additional margins were negative for carcinoma. The tumor is moderately differentiated (Nottingham grade 2) and shows no lymphovascular invasion, with the closest margins being 1 mm posteriorly and 3 mm medially.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated, large-cell, nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma located in the left lower lobe of the lung, primarily in segment S10, with associated lymph node involvement classified as pT2 pN3 pMX, stage IIIB. Microscopic examination revealed extensive infiltration of atypical epithelial cells in the tumor and lymph nodes, with some nodes showing reactive lesions. Additionally, there is evidence of active chronic organizing pneumonia at the tumor margin and pleural adhesion, but the resection margins are tumor-free.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma, acinar type, with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 (total score 7), involving both sides of the prostate and showing a maximum tumor size of 2.3 cm. There is focal extraprosthetic extension at the left anterior apex, but the bilateral seminal vesicles and all examined surgical margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, multifocal perineural invasion is present, while no angiolymphatic invasion is identified, and the pathologic TNM stage is pT3a Nx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate, measuring 2.3 cm, with marked perineural growth but confined to the prostate without involvement of the seminal vesicles or ducts. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes and surrounding fatty connective tissue are tumor-free, indicating no malignancy in those areas. The tumor classification is pT2c, pNO (0/5), with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, suggesting a moderate risk of progression.

The pathology report indicates that a specimen was sent to the Biospecimen Core Resource (BCR) from NCH for analysis. It requires the completion of the TCGA Missing Pathology Report Form due to the absence of a detailed pathology report. Additionally, it requests the tumor type and relevant ICD-0-3 histology and site codes for proper classification.

The pathology report indicates that the pulmonary ligament node, PA window node, and hilar lymph nodes are all negative for malignancy, while the left upper lobe of the lung shows a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.0 cm. The tumor invades the visceral pleura but has no involvement of regional lymph nodes, with margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma and absent lymphovascular, venous, and arterial invasion. The overall classification is pT2pN0pMX, indicating a localized tumor without regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis assessed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the cervix, measuring 5.2 cm with a depth of invasion of 18 mm, and focal lymphovascular space invasion present. The resection margins from the radical hysterectomy are free of carcinoma, and no dysplasia or carcinoma is identified in the vagina, parametrial soft tissue, or endometrium, which also shows an endometrial polyp and early menstrual endometrium. Additional findings include adenomyosis and a microscopic leiomyoma in the myometrium, while the ovaries and fallopian tubes show no histopathologic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant mesothelioma with an epithelioid type and tubulopapillary features in multiple sites, including the pleura, fissure, pericardial tissue, and diaphragmatic sulcus. Additionally, metastatic malignant mesothelioma was found in the aortic and level 9 lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes and subcutaneous nodules showed no evidence of tumor. Reactive changes such as fibrosis and granulomas were noted at previous operation sites, but no tumors were identified in those areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous papillary adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, classified as pT3a, with evidence of invasion and metastasis to the right parametrium, uterine serosa, cul de sac peritoneum, and right uterosacral ligament, while lymph nodes were free of tumor. Additionally, there are findings of squamous metaplasia and follicular cervicitis in the cervix, with no pathological diagnosis noted in the appendix. The report highlights the presence of multiple areas of necrosis and hemorrhage within the tumor, which is characterized by marked cellular atypia and numerous mitotic figures.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the distal esophagus reveals an invasive moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. The tumor was composed of multiple fragments of soft tissue, and the entire specimen was submitted for analysis. Additionally, immunostaining for Her-2/neu showed that the tumor cells are immunonegative, scoring 0 out of 3.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two separate thymomas in the thymus gland: a right-sided WHO type AB thymoma measuring 5.2 cm with microscopic transcapsular invasion, and a left-sided WHO type A thymoma measuring 5 cm that is completely encapsulated. Both tumors have negative margins and show no evidence of invasion into adjacent structures or regional lymph node metastasis. Additionally, the left periphrenic node biopsy is reported as normal, confirming no regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the liver biopsy from segment 3 is normal with no evidence of malignancy, while the gallbladder resection shows mild chronic cholecystitis without cholelithiasis or dysplasia. However, the laparoscopic right hepatic lobectomy reveals a 12 cm intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma with 12 intrahepatic metastatic foci, classified as moderately differentiated and with negative margins. The final pathologic staging is pT2aNXM0, indicating no lymph node or distant metastasis, and the overall stage is II.

The microscopic examination reveals a moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm characterized by infiltrating glial cells with moderate cytologic atypia and focal microcystic changes. There is no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis, and the MIB-1 labeling index is 2.7%, indicating a low-grade glioma. The findings are consistent with a diagnosis of Oligodendroglioma Grade II.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm in diameter, located on the left side and unifocal in nature. The tumor exhibits papillae with a fine fibrovascular stalk and cuboidal epithelial cells, showing regular nuclei and some psammoma bodies, with evidence of hemorrhage and lymphocytic invasion. There is no extrathyroidal extension noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 3.4 cm, with one peribronchial lymph node showing metastatic involvement. Other lymph nodes excised from various levels showed no evidence of malignancy, except for the level IV-R lymph node, which was positive for metastatic squamous cell carcinoma. Additionally, there was extensive foreign body response noted in the soft tissue specimen, and the bronchial margins were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the excised fat and capsule overlying the tumor contained benign fibroadipose tissue with no tumor present. The left kidney tumor was diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 1, with a maximal Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3, measuring 2.2 x 1.9 x 0.8 cm, and is limited to the kidney with no vascular invasion identified. The tumor is focally present at the inked surface, and the final margin status is assessed in conjunction with the other parts of the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, with a primary tumor measuring 1.5 cm and two additional microscopic foci of carcinoma in the left lobe. The pretracheal and central cervical lymph nodes were negative for metastatic carcinoma, indicating no spread to these regions. The report also notes the presence of marked chronic thyroiditis and positive margins in the right lobe.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderate-sized tumor in the uterus and cervix, measuring 20 cm, which invades to a depth of 10 mm. There is no evidence of carcinoma in the uterus, vagina, or ovaries, and the margins are clear. Additionally, the left external lymph node shows no signs of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the left pelvic lymph nodes, while adenocarcinoma of the prostate was diagnosed with unilateral extension into the extraprostatic soft tissue. The tumor primarily affects the left peripheral zone, with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7/10, and the extent of tumor involvement is rated at 4/5. The surgical margins are positive on the left side of the prostate, while other margins are clear, and there is no evidence of lymphatic or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the cervix reveals the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma. This diagnosis suggests that cancer has penetrated deeper tissues of the cervix. Further evaluation and management will be necessary to determine the extent of the disease and appropriate treatment options.

The histopathological examination of the left breast and axillary tissues revealed invasive ductal carcinoma with a tumor size of 2.5 cm and metastases in 3 out of 23 axillary lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical analysis showed over 75% positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 testing indicated a score of 2+ with no gene amplification found upon FISH verification. The diagnosis is invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast (NHG2, pT2, pNIa) with axillary lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right hemithyroidectomy specimen, with a tumor size of 3.0 cm that extends through the thyroid capsule into surrounding skeletal muscle and shows lymphovascular invasion. Metastatic thyroid carcinoma is identified in one of the pre-laryngeal lymph nodes and in one of the right paratracheal lymph nodes, while the margins of resection are free of tumor, with the closest margin being less than 1 mm from invasive carcinoma. Additionally, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis is noted in both the left hemithyroidectomy and in fragments of thyroid tissue from the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a biopsy of the left supraglottic larynx. The tissue submitted consisted of two fragments of pale tan-pink soft tissue measuring a total of 1.0 x 1.0 x 0.4 cm. The report was reviewed by the attending pathologist, and a portion of the tissue was allocated for research purposes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left breast mastectomy revealing infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma, high nuclear grade, measuring 5.0 cm, with margins free of tumor. All three sentinel lymph nodes examined showed no malignancy, and the tumor was negative for estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and HER2, but positive for HLA-DR, suggesting a medullary subtype. Additional findings included florid adenosis and stromal fibrosis in the breast tissue, with no microcalcifications identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic endocervical adenocarcinoma with extensive necrosis in the left ovary, measuring 25 cm, and involvement of the left fallopian tube, while the uterus and right adnexa show well-differentiated endocervical adenocarcinoma with invasive features. Additional findings include cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 3), chronic cervicitis, multiple leiomyomas, and adenomyosis, with no lymphovascular invasion or regional lymph node involvement noted. The overall AJCC pathologic stage is pT1b1 pNx pM1, classified as FIGO Stage IVB, indicating advanced disease.

The pathology report indicates a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus, measuring 8.5 x 5.5 cm, located in the distal third and extending to the cardia, with no evidence of vascular or perineural invasion. All examined lymph nodes showed no metastasis, and both proximal and distal surgical margins are uninvolved by neoplasia. The report concludes with a staging of pT3 pNO, indicating advanced local disease without nodal involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has established cirrhosis of the liver with severe mixed micro- and macrovesicular steatosis affecting approximately 70% of the liver parenchyma, but no evidence of malignancy in the initial biopsies. However, a subsequent biopsy confirmed the presence of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe, with a tumor size of 2.7 cm and no vascular invasion identified. Additionally, there is a foreign body giant cell reaction in a wedge resection of liver tissue, but no viable tumor cells were found in that specimen.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the fundus of the stomach, measuring 12 x 10 x 1 cm. The tumor has metastasized to all examined lymph nodes (8/8) and extends to adjacent structures, including the esophagus and omentum, but the surgical margins are uninvolved. There are no specified details regarding lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion, and no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment is noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated keratinizing invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a maximum horizontal dimension of 5.2 cm and a depth of invasion of 0.9 cm, but no lymphovascular space invasion or tumor at the resection margins. Additional findings include chronic endometritis and no evidence of malignancy in the surrounding soft tissues, ovaries, fallopian tubes, vaginal margins, and lymph nodes examined. The final staging of the tumor is classified as T1b2/NO/MX, indicating a clinically visible lesion confined to the cervix without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma measuring 2.0 cm with focal extrathyroidal extension following a total thyroidectomy. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, and the resection margins are free of tumor. Additionally, a secondary 0.2 cm nodule was identified in the superior pole of the thyroid, but the surrounding parenchyma appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe biopsy and mediastinal lymph nodes showed no malignancy, while a left lung tumor was identified as poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 6.0 cm, with evidence of large vessel and pleural invasion. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma was found in all examined lymph nodes from Station 5, with one lymph node showing no malignancy. The bronchial margins were free of tumor, and the overall assessment classified the tumor as pT2, pN2, pMX.

The pathology report describes a left adrenal gland tumor weighing 219g, identified as a pheochromocytoma, characterized by extensive necrosis and hemorrhage. Immunohistochemical analysis shows strong positivity for chromogranin, with a low proliferation index (MIB1 3-5%), and no evidence of angioinvasion. The tumor exhibits features such as high cellularity, atypical mitotic figures, and capsular invasion, indicating aggressive behavior.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of primary endometrial cancer, specifically endometrioid adenocarcinoma, classified as FIGO grade 3, with myometrial invasion limited to the inner half and no lymphovascular space invasion identified. All examined lymph nodes (18 total) from both para-aortic and pelvic regions showed no evidence of tumor involvement. Additional findings include a benign endocervical polyp and leiomyomas, with the endometrial adenocarcinoma being estrogen and progesterone receptor positive.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen is a right globe enucleation revealing a choroidal melanoma of predominantly spindle cell type, measuring 12 mm in diameter and 10 mm in thickness, with no evidence of necrosis or extension beyond the eye. Microscopic examination shows prominent microvasculature and minimal lymphocytic infiltration, with a mitotic frequency of 8 per 40 high power fields. Molecular genetic analysis reveals loss of chromosome 1p, monosomy 3, normal chromosome 6, and gains in chromosome 8, categorizing the patient in a high-risk group for metastatic melanoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical variant papillary thyroid carcinoma following a total thyroidectomy, with the largest tumor nodule measuring 2.5 cm in the right lobe and additional nodules present in the isthmus and left lobe. The surgical margins are negative, with the tumor located 0.1 cm from the closest margin, and one out of four lymph nodes examined is positive for tumor involvement. The findings are consistent with a background of lymphocytic thyroiditis, specifically Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and the pathologic stage is classified as I.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with a tumor size of 6 cm, classified as grade II. The tumor is staged as T1, with no regional lymph node involvement (NX) and no distant metastasis (M0). Additionally, the report notes the presence of steatohepatitis with moderate activity and moderate macrovesicular fatty change, along with mild iron overload in the liver tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the left ureteral margins show marked chronic inflammation and denudation of the epithelium, but no malignancy is present, while the right ureteral margin is negative for tumor. The urinary bladder resection reveals invasive high-grade transitional cell carcinoma with a maximum tumor diameter of 1.5 cm, invading through the muscular propria into the perivesical soft tissue, and coming within 1.8 mm of the inked margin. Additionally, both right and left pelvic lymph nodes are benign with no evidence of metastatic neoplasm, and the appendix shows no signs of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the final diagnosis for the enucleated left eye is malignant melanoma, predominantly of the spindle cell type, with a tumor size of 1.5 cm in diameter and 1.4 cm in height, while the vortex vein biopsy shows no evidence of malignant melanoma. Cytogenetic analysis reveals an abnormal clone of cells with a translocation between chromosomes 3 and 6, although the significance of this finding is not known. Microscopic examination confirms the presence of a cohesive spindle cell proliferation with rare mitotic figures, and there is no involvement of the ciliary body, sclera, or optic nerve.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of primary uterine adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with squamous changes, classified as FIGO grade II, and showing superficial myometrial invasion. The tumor is localized to the posterior uterine structures with no evidence of cervical involvement or metastatic spread to the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or lymph nodes. Additional findings include multiple benign leiomyomas and various benign changes in the cervix and ovaries, with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the examined lymph nodes or soft tissues.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has endometrial adenocarcinoma of the endometrioid type, FIGO grade III, with superficial invasion into the myometrium and lymphovascular emboli present, but all surgical margins and lymph nodes are negative for tumor. Additionally, the drug resistance assay shows low to intermediate resistance for several chemotherapeutic agents, with extreme drug resistance noted for topotecan. The omentum was found to contain benign fibroadipose tissue, and no significant pathologic changes were observed in the bilateral tubes and ovaries.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lung, which has invaded the pleura and extended into the chest wall, measuring 7.5 cm, with the tumor margins being negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, multiple soft tissue biopsies revealed benign lymph nodes, some of which contained scattered hyalinized granulomas. The pathological stage of the lung cancer is classified as T3 N0 Mx, indicating local invasion without lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary serous adenocarcinoma involving the appendix and surrounding soft tissue, with extension into the muscularis. Both ovaries are extensively affected by poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma, with additional metastatic involvement noted in the omentum, uterine serosa, and peritubal soft tissue. The tumor is classified as T3c (FIGO IIIC), indicating macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis, while regional lymph nodes examined show no evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma with associated ductal carcinoma in situ in the right breast, characterized by a tumor size of 1.5 cm and the presence of micrometastases in the axillary lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed no estrogen receptors, while progesterone receptors were present in 75% of neoplastic cell nuclei, and HER2 showed a negative reaction (Score = 1+). The tumor is classified as NHG2, with a pathological staging of pT1c and pN1(mi).

The pathology report indicates the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma in both segment 3 and segment 7 of the liver, with the tumors exhibiting varying degrees of differentiation. The tumor in segment 3 measures 3.5 cm and shows vascular invasion, while the tumor in segment 7 measures 0.9 cm and does not show any vascular invasion. Both tumors have clear surgical resection margins, and the remaining liver parenchyma shows signs of cirrhosis and mixed steatosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated synovial sarcoma, Grade 3, identified in a 2x1x1 cm fibrous synovial tissue mass from the arm. The tumor mass is malignant, but surgical margins are clear, and all five examined lymph nodes are negative for disease. The final diagnosis confirms the presence of synovial sarcoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the left hypopharynx, with additional findings of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in one of ten lymph nodes from the right neck and significant involvement in the left neck lymph nodes, including angiolymphatic and perineural invasion. The total laryngectomy specimen revealed a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.1 cm, with no cartilage or thyroid gland involvement, but with a separate focus of carcinoma in situ on the epiglottis and severe dysplasia in the vocal cords. Overall, the pathological stage is classified as pT3 N2c, indicating advanced disease with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, with 12 out of 40 examined lymph nodes involved, including those from the right neck and right paratracheal regions. The total thyroidectomy specimen shows widely invasive bilateral papillary carcinoma, with the dominant tumor measuring 3.0 cm in the right lobe and exhibiting extrathyroidal extension and involved surgical margins. Additional findings include mild follicular nodular disease, focal thyroiditis, and infiltrating papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right parathyroid gland.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a right frontal brain tumor diagnosed as anaplastic oligodendroglioma, grade III, with evidence of malignancy and a proliferation index averaging 16%. FISH analysis confirmed deletions of 1p and 19q, which are characteristic of oligodendrogliomas, with 71% of cells showing these deletions. The report emphasizes the need for clinical and pathological correlation to fully understand the implications of these findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive adenocarcinoma, grade 1, with mucinous features in the right upper lobe lung, measuring 2.6 cm, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. One of five peribronchial lymph nodes is positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, while fragments of lymph node tissue from the right paratracheal and subcarinal regions are negative for tumor. The tumor is classified as stage pT1bN1, and immunohistochemical analysis supports a lung primary origin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Anaplastic Astrocytoma (grade III). Microscopic examination reveals a highly cellular glial neoplasm with moderately atypical fibrillary astrocytes and 11 mitotic figures observed in 10 high power fields, but without microvascular proliferation or necrosis. There is no evidence of oligodendroglioma differentiation in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of recurrent dedifferentiated liposarcoma with focal areas of well-differentiated/sclerosing liposarcoma, involving the small and large bowel, stomach, and associated structures, with extensive necrosis observed. The main tumor measures 15.1 x 8.3 x 6.5 cm, while a separate well-differentiated liposarcoma component adheres to the stomach, measuring 8.5 x 5.4 x 3.9 cm. Additionally, the proximal jejunum segment excised shows unremarkable mucosa with no tumor identified.

The pathology report indicates a slightly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cecum, classified as G3, with significant infiltration into all layers of the cecal wall and associated chronic inflammation. The tumor has invaded the base of the appendix and shows evidence of carcinomatous lymphangitis, but there are no metastatic lymph nodes or evidence of serous carcinoma. The tumor staging is pT3, pNO, MX, L1, R0, indicating localized disease without vascular carcinosis.

The pathology report indicates a 6.8 cm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, characterized by micropapillary growth and psammoma bodies, with a pathologic stage of T2 N1 MX. Three out of thirteen lymph nodes examined showed metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes were free of malignancy but exhibited focal psammomatous calcifications. Additionally, there are findings of smoker's bronchiolitis with emphysematous changes and subpleural scarring.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right hepatic lobectomy due to moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, with two foci measuring 7.2 cm and 0.7 cm, respectively. Light microscopy revealed lymphovascular space invasion, but the surgical margins were free of tumor. The gallbladder showed no specific pathologic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates the presence of large-cell and polymorphocellular adenocarcinoma with mucin inclusions in the left lung, classified as stage IIIB (pT4 pN2 pMX V1 R0). The primary tumor affects both the upper and lower lobes, causing central bronchus stenosis and infiltration of parabronchial lymph nodes, while a peripheral manifestation is noted in segment S6, which does not involve the visceral pleura. Additionally, there is evidence of lymph node metastasis, but the resection margins and lymph nodes from other samples are tumor-free.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the rectosigmoid region, measuring 1.5 cm in length and 1.3 cm in width, with invasion into the muscularis propria and lymphovascular invasion identified. Surgical margins are free of tumor, with metastasis found in 3 out of 31 examined lymph nodes, leading to a staging of pT2 and N1b. Immunohistochemical staining for DNA mismatch repair proteins shows retention in the tumor, suggesting intact mismatch repair capability.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland, which was confirmed through histological examination. The specimen measured 13.0 x 10.5 x 2.5 cm and contained a 4.0 x 3.0 x 3.0 cm mass with a disrupted capsule and a rough orange-yellow rim. The surrounding adrenal tissue appeared unremarkable, with a thin cortical rim and central medulla.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma with gemistocytic features, classified as WHO Grade III, based on biopsy samples from a left frontotemporal tumor. The tumor exhibits hypercellularity with atypical cells, high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratios, and is positive for p53 and IDH1 (R132H) mutant proteins, suggesting a genetically favorable subtype. There is no evidence of necrosis or microvascular proliferation, and the Ki-67 labeling index is noted to be 18%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 3.8 cm and no evidence of invasion into surrounding structures. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in one of the three examined lymph nodes (level 10), while the other lymph nodes (levels 9, 8R, 11R, and 7) were negative for tumor involvement. The surgical margins, including bronchial, parenchymal, and vascular margins, were all reported as uninvaded, and the final pTNM stage is pT2 N1 MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, poorly differentiated colon adenocarcinoma, classified as grade 3 and partially mucinous. The tumor has penetrated all layers of the colon wall (pT3) and there are free lymph nodes present. Additionally, the resection margins are clear of cancerous cells.

The pathology report indicates a malignant invasive ductal carcinoma located in the left breast, characterized by a variegated tumor with solid nests, cords, comedo, and tubular patterns. Microscopic examination reveals large cells with moderately pleomorphic hyperchromatic nuclei, amphophilic cytoplasm, and a desmoplastic stroma containing similar tumor cells and lymphocytes, with focal areas of necrosis. The invasive carcinoma is 5mm from the closest deep resection margin.

The pathology report describes a moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm with myxoid and microcystic architecture, primarily composed of fibrillary astrocytes, with mild atypia and no mitotic figures observed. The MIB-1 labeling index is 10.4%, indicating higher proliferation activity than expected for a grade II astrocytoma, suggesting potential early anaplastic progression. Despite the increased proliferation, the overall histologic features are consistent with a well-differentiated astrocytoma (WHO Grade II), warranting close clinical follow-up.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a tubulovillous adenoma with intramucosal adenocarcinoma in the appendix and partial cecum, with no invasive carcinoma identified and negative margins. Additionally, a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma was found in the liver, measuring 8.8 x 8.0 x 6.2 cm, with extensive vascular invasion and positive margins at the portal triad and surgical margin. Other soft tissue margins showed either no malignancy or foci of hepatocellular carcinoma, with the background liver exhibiting cirrhosis and mild steatosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 3.3 x 5.2 cm ulcerous adenocarcinoma in the ascending colon, with significant infiltration into the surrounding adipose tissue and associated polyps. Microscopic examination confirms the diagnosis of tubular and mucinous adenocarcinoma (G3), with metastases identified in lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as Dukes C, indicating advanced local disease with lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with the tumor being poorly differentiated and showing features suggestive of a lymphoepithelial-like carcinoma, which may have a better prognosis. Immunohistochemical staining results show positivity for CK 5/6, p63, and p16, while being negative for CEA and S100. The biopsy is fragmented, preventing assessment of the depth of invasion, and further classification is pending additional workup.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 3.2 cm, with negative margins and evidence of vascular invasion. Five hilar lymph nodes and additional lymph nodes from levels 10, 5, and 7 were examined, all of which were negative for metastatic carcinoma. The tumor is classified as pT2a, indicating it is limited to the lung without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that a 4.5 cm papillary renal cell carcinoma was identified in a right lower pole renal mass following a partial nephrectomy. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is classified as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left temporal brain lesion diagnosed as glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) based on both a frozen section and resection specimens. Two specimens were analyzed, with the first being fresh for intraoperative consultation and the second fixed in formalin, both showing similar characteristics of the tumor. The findings confirm the presence of a high-grade malignant brain tumor requiring further management.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated Type I Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma, with the largest tumor piece measuring 4.2 cm and a smaller piece measuring 0.1 cm. The kidney parenchyma shows high-grade interstitial fibrosis and ectatic vasculature at the borders. The tumor is classified as stage pT1b, grade GI, and is reported as completely resected (RO).

The pathology report indicates that the lingual nerve segment is negative for tumor, while the right partial glossectomy reveals well-differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma measuring 2.8 cm with perineural invasion present but no vascular invasion. All margins from the dorsal, anterior, ventral, and posterior tongue, as well as the floor of mouth, are negative for tumor, and all examined lymph nodes from the right neck dissection are also negative for tumor. Additionally, the tumor is negative for high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) genotypes.

The pathology report indicates a total thyroidectomy revealing a 1.4 cm encapsulated follicular variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right lobe, with angiolymphatic invasion but no capsular invasion. Additionally, a 2.0 cm follicular adenoma with focal oncocytic change was identified in the left lobe, along with nodular thyroid hyperplasia and mild chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. The margins are uninvolved by carcinoma, and there is no evidence of extrathyroidal extension or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right axillary sentinel lymph node positive for metastatic ductal carcinoma, measuring 0.9 cm with focal extracapsular extension. The modified radical mastectomy of the right breast revealed multicentric infiltrating ductal carcinoma with a Nottingham score of 6/9, extensive lymphovascular space involvement, and tumor aggregates measuring up to 14.3 cm, while the margins were free of tumor. Additionally, fourteen right axillary lymph nodes were examined and found negative for tumor, and the left breast showed benign fibrocystic changes with microcalcifications.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) from a right temporal brain lesion obtained during a craniotomy tumor resection. Two specimens were analyzed, with both frozen and formalin-fixed sections confirming the presence of the aggressive tumor. The report includes details of the specimen's size and characteristics, as well as the intraoperative consultation findings.

The pathology report indicates that the right upper lobe lobectomy revealed a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.0 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. The right middle lobe wedge resection and other specimens, including the fat pad and right lower lobe, showed no malignancy, with findings of fibrotic nodules and benign tissue. Overall, the primary concern is the adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe, while other specimens are benign.

The pathology report indicates that a left pneumonectomy was performed, revealing a moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 55 mm, which invades several hilar lymph nodes but is clear of the pleura and bronchial resection margin. The lower lobe shows no evidence of tumor, with only an area of hemorrhage noted, while the sampled lymph nodes exhibit reactive changes without signs of metastatic carcinoma. The final diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma, pathological stage T2 N1, with no malignancy found in the No. 5 lymph node.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent excision of the right ovary and fallopian tube, revealing a surface serous adenofibroma and additional cystic follicles, while the left ovary and fallopian tube showed an involuting and hemorrhagic corpus luteum. A radical hysterectomy was performed, confirming a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 1.7 cm with focal lymphovascular invasion, but negative surgical margins and no evidence of malignancy in the endometrium or myometrium. Lymph node excisions from various regions were all negative for metastatic disease, and a vaginal biopsy also returned negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with extensive multifocal lymphovascular invasion and carcinoma in situ with pagetoid spread noted in the cervix and urethra. The final diagnosis confirms that the invasive tumor does not involve the cervix or uterus, but the cervix shows carcinoma in situ, while the bilateral ureters are benign with no malignancy identified. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma was found in one of the left common iliac lymph nodes, with a total of two positive lymph nodes out of 87 examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 2.5 cm, with a histologic grade of II/III and a moderately differentiated nuclear grade. A non-comedo intraductal carcinoma component is present, comprising less than 10% of the tumor, and no tumor is identified at the deep surgical margin. Additionally, two out of seventeen lymph nodes are positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, while no vascular invasion is noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.9 cm, with a Nottingham grade of 2 and evidence of extensive ductal carcinoma in situ. Lymphovascular invasion is present, but surgical margins are clear, with the closest margin being 0.4 cm away from the tumor. Sentinel lymph node biopsies show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the examined nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a maximum depth of invasion of 88% and evidence of microscopic angiolymphatic invasion, but all surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the left ovary shows a serous cystadenoma, and 4 out of 13 lymph nodes from the left external iliac region are positive for metastatic tumor. Other lymph nodes and the appendix show no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) following the examination of a brain tumor resection from the left frontal lobe. Microscopic analysis revealed a highly cellular population of pleomorphic astrocytes consistent with a high-grade glioma, and an area initially interpreted as necrosis was found to be hemorrhage due to surgical trauma. The report confirms that no frank necrosis was observed in the permanent sections, supporting the diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 2.5 cm adrenal tumor diagnosed as a pheochromocytoma. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive staining for synaptophysin and chromogranin, with a low proliferation rate indicated by Ki67. The total score of 3 suggests a benign nature of the tumor, with no significant extension into surrounding tissues or nuclear pleomorphism.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with the largest tumor measuring 1.7 cm and a smaller tumor measuring 1.0 cm, both exhibiting Nottingham grade 2 characteristics.
