The sentinel lymph node excised from the right axilla is free of metastatic carcinoma, and all surgical margins are negative for carcinoma. Additionally, ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is present, comprising approximately 10% of the larger tumor and 20% of the smaller tumor, with both invasive tumors being positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER-2/NEU.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma in both lobes of the thyroid, with the largest tumor measuring 1.7 x 1.1 cm and evidence of focal extension into the surrounding soft tissue. Metastatic disease is confirmed in the left paratracheal lymph node (1/2) and both right paratracheal lymph nodes (2/2), while the pretracheal lymph node is negative for tumor. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis is also noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately-differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma at the left base of the tongue. The biopsy was performed following a laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, and esophagoscopy due to clinical features suggestive of a malignant neoplasm in the head and neck region. The submitted tissue specimen measured 2.0 x 2.0 x 0.3 cm and was described as pink-tan tissue mixed with blood clot.

The pathology report indicates that the patient is male and has a tumor located in the right frontal region. The diagnosis is anaplastic astrocytoma, classified as grade III according to the World Health Organization (WHO) grading system. This suggests a malignant brain tumor with a higher degree of aggressiveness.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lung lower lobe, with a tumor size of 2.3 cm and evidence of fibrosis. The carcinoma extends to within 1 mm of the staple line but does not invade the visceral pleura, and no residual carcinoma is identified in the subsequent lobectomy specimen or lymph nodes. The final staging is pT1b N0, suggesting localized disease without lymph node involvement, and clinical correlation and follow-up are recommended.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7/10, involving only the left lobe of the prostate and showing evidence of extracapsular extension. The surgical margins are positive at the left lateral margin, while the lymph nodes from both sides are negative for tumor involvement. Overall, the findings suggest localized prostate cancer with specific characteristics that may influence further management.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of gliosarcoma from a biopsy of the left parietal lobe. The tumor exhibits a biphasic pattern with both glial and sarcomatous components, and shows a proliferative index (MIB-1) of 30% to 40%. Microscopic examination reveals patchy areas of necrosis within the glial component of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the prostate contains three separate foci of prostatic adenocarcinoma, with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), and all tumor foci are confined to the prostate with resection margins free of tumor. Additionally, the left and right seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia show no evidence of malignancy. Other examined tissues, including lymph nodes and neurovascular bundles, also demonstrate no morphologic evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of epithelioid malignant mesothelioma in a pleural implant. The specimen consists of four fragments of soft tissue, with sizes ranging from 0.6 cm to 2.0 cm. No clinical history was provided with the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, located in the right lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 3.2 cm and unifocality. The tumor is classified as pT2, indicating it is greater than 2 cm but less than 4 cm and limited to the thyroid, with no regional lymph node metastasis and negative margins. Additionally, there is no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion, and one lymph node examined is also negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the left adrenal gland and kidney resection revealed a malignant pheochromocytoma measuring 9x8x3 cm, with lymphovascular invasion but negative surgical margins and no tumor in the kidney. The splenic biopsy showed a benign splenic mesothelial cyst, while one of twelve periaortic lymph nodes was found to have metastatic pheochromocytoma. The tumor exhibits significant pleomorphism and is characterized by a neuroendocrine immunoprofile consistent with pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme in the occipital lobe, characterized by high cellularity, nuclear hyperchromasia, pleomorphism, and necrosis. The tumor exhibits a MIB-1 labeling index of 50%, suggesting a high proliferation rate. The specimen consisted of a small tissue fragment and a larger right occipital mass, which displayed a variegated appearance with hemorrhagic soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of isolated tumor cells in one sentinel lymph node from the left axilla, while the second sentinel lymph node is benign. A total mastectomy of the left breast revealed invasive lobular carcinoma, classical type, measuring 2.8 cm, with associated lobular carcinoma in situ and lymphovascular invasion, but negative surgical margins. The invasive carcinoma is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, with equivocal HER-2 results pending further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates that one of the right axillary sentinel lymph nodes is positive for micrometastasis and isolated tumor cells, while the second sentinel lymph node is negative for tumor but contains isolated tumor cells in extralymphatic spaces. The right breast lumpectomy reveals a well-differentiated infiltrating mucinous carcinoma, measuring 4.0 cm, with positive margins and foci suspicious for lymphatic invasion, alongside a low-grade ductal carcinoma in situ. Estrogen and progesterone receptors are positive, while HER2 is negative, and the pathologic stage is classified as pT2N1mi.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobectomy specimen, with a maximum tumor diameter of 3.4 cm and positive invasion into the visceral pleura. Regional lymph node analysis revealed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in two of the lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes and bronchial margins showed no evidence of malignancy. The pathological stage is classified as pT4 pN2 pMx, indicating advanced disease with lymphatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast excision revealed an invasive ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated, measuring 3 cm, with negative margins but evidence of lymphovascular invasion and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Additionally, metastatic carcinoma was found in both sentinel lymph nodes and one of the axillary lymph nodes, with a total of 3 out of 24 lymph nodes showing metastasis. The HER2 analysis was positive, indicating a high level of expression in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of melanoma in a Caucasian female, with the primary tumor located in the skin. The specimen was processed as an OCT block, and no additional treatment or staging details were provided. A blood sample was also collected, which was reported as normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast of a female patient, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2 N2a M0, indicating a locally advanced cancer without distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered to date, and a normal blood sample was also collected.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 1.2 x 1.0 x 0.8 cm, and the carcinoma invades into but does not penetrate the visceral pleura. All lymph node biopsies (4R, Level 7, 4L, 2R, Level 5, and Level 6) are negative for malignancy, indicating no evidence of cancer spread to these nodes. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT2a PL1 pNO, suggesting localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma, with the tumor confined to the right lobe and comprising approximately 5% of the examined prostatic tissue, exhibiting a Gleason score of 7/10. There is no evidence of extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, or lymphovascular invasion, although extensive perineural invasion is noted. Surgical margins are mostly clear of malignancy, except for the right posterior section where the neoplasm extends to the inked margin, and all examined lymph nodes are free of metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the subglottis, measuring 2.0 cm, with surgical margins free of tumor following a total laryngectomy. The right lobe of the thyroid shows colloid nodules but no evidence of tumor. The laryngeal mass was described as a light-tan, ulcerated, and slightly indurated mass that does not extend to the underlying cartilage.

The pathology report indicates a 10.0 x 6.0 x 6.0 cm tumor in the right lung diagnosed as squamous cell carcinoma, not otherwise specified (NOS). The tumor shows infiltration into the bronchus and is classified as pT2, pN2 (with 3 out of 31 lymph nodes involved), and pMx, with a grade of G2. This suggests a moderately differentiated tumor with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies from the brain tumor are diagnosed as anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade III, with features of a gemistocytic astrocytoma and areas of higher-grade pleomorphic astrocytoma. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the tumor cells are positive for GFAP and p53, with a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 45%, while tests for IDH1 mutation, EGFRvIII mutation, and MGMT promoter methylation are all negative. Clinical correlation is recommended due to the small size of the tissue fragments, which may limit the ability to rule out a higher-grade lesion such as glioblastoma, WHO grade IV.

The pathology report indicates that the anterior prostatic fat biopsy shows benign vascular fibroadipose tissue, while the posterior bladder margin biopsy reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+4=8, showing signs of nerve involvement and potential lymphatic invasion. The prostatectomy specimen demonstrates high-grade prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, extensive extraprostatic extension, and bilateral seminal vesicle invasion, with positive margins at three different sites. Lymph node dissections from both the right and left pelvic regions show no evidence of tumor in a total of seven examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left thyroid lobe, measuring 4.4 x 4.0 x 2.2 cm, with no evidence of lymphatic or capsular invasion. Additionally, both thyroid lobes show Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and all examined lymph nodes (3 total) contain microscopic foci of metastatic carcinoma. The tumor is well-differentiated and confined to the thyroid without infiltration into adjacent structures.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 4 fibrillary astrocytoma, specifically glioblastoma multiforme, in the right frontal lobe following a mass resection. The preliminary frozen section consultation suggested a high-grade glioma, pending definitive diagnosis. The gross description details multiple tissue samples from the right frontal brain, with varying dimensions.

The pathology report indicates a fresh frozen sample from a surgical resection of a tumor located in the urinary bladder, measuring 3 cm. The histological examination reveals papillary urothelial carcinoma with an unknown grade (Grade X) and a pathological staging of T2a with N2 nodal involvement. There is bilateral disease present, and the clinical M status is classified as MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the left lower lung lobe, with a background of multifocal bronchioloalveolar carcinoma. The tumor measures 6.0x3.4x2.5 cm, shows angiolymphatic invasion, and has a positive visceral pleural margin, while the bronchial margin and peribronchial lymph nodes are negative for metastasis. Additionally, the 6th rib and lymph node excisions are negative for malignancy, and the final pathologic stage is pT2N0Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated neuro-endocrine carcinoma, classified as G3, with significant infiltration into the terminal ileum and serosa (pT4). There is extensive invasion of lymphatic and blood vessels (L1, V1), but the resection margins, mucosal membrane, ligature area, and lymph nodes are free of tumor (pN0). The tumor classification is recorded as ICDO-DA-M 8140/3.

The pathology report indicates that no metastatic carcinoma was found in the two excised bilateral pelvic lymph nodes (0/2). The radical prostatectomy revealed prostatic adenocarcinoma, comprising approximately 5% of the prostate volume, with a Gleason score of 6/10, and no evidence of extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, or lymphovascular invasion. The surgical margins were negative for tumor, although adenocarcinoma was noted to be less than 0.1 cm from the right apical margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe lung, measuring 4 cm, with extension to the pleural surface but not involving the visceral pleura, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor. Multiple anthracotic lymph nodes were identified in the intralobar and superior segmental nodes, all of which were negative for tumor and showed non-caseating granulomata. The pathological stage is classified as pT2a N0 Mx, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid, measuring 1.5 cm, which is well-differentiated with no identified mitotic activity, necrosis, or invasion. The right para-tracheal tissue and two lymph nodes examined were found to be benign. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and the remaining thyroid tissue shows nodular hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated adenocarcinoma (endometrioid type, FIGO grade 1) confined to the endometrium, with no evidence of invasion into the myometrium or lymphovascular invasion. Additional findings include benign cervical tissue, benign fallopian tubes and ovaries, and benign lymph nodes with no evidence of metastatic neoplasm. The AJCC pathologic stage is classified as T1a, N0, indicating early-stage uterine cancer.

The pathology report indicates a mastectomy specimen with a tumor measuring 4.3 x 3 x 3 cm, identified as infiltrating ductal and lobular carcinoma. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/9 positive). The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tumor grading and other histologic features.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a significant tumor in the right lung, measuring up to 9.5 cm, with extensive involvement of the pleura and surrounding structures, including invasion into the pulmonary vein and obstruction of bronchi. Multiple lymph nodes are affected, with lesions noted in subcarinal, paratracheal, and hilar regions, suggesting metastatic spread. The findings are consistent with advanced adenocarcinoma, with extensive local invasion and associated complications such as thrombus formation in the pulmonary artery.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph node biopsy showed vascularized fibroadipose tissue without histopathologic abnormality and no lymphoid tissue present. The gallbladder cholecystectomy revealed chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis, and a periductal lymph node was negative for metastatic malignancy. The liver biopsy showed moderate steatosis and cirrhosis (Stage IV fibrosis), while the partial hepatectomy confirmed a 7.0 cm hepatocellular carcinoma with the tumor extending to within 1 mm of the surgical margin, classified as pathologic stage pT1N1.

The pathology report indicates that the left kidney has a moderately to poorly differentiated renal cell carcinoma, measuring 11.5 cm, with invasion into surrounding adipose tissue and the proximal renal vein, and two hilar lymph nodes showing metastatic disease. The left adrenal gland and retroperitoneal lymph nodes are negative for tumor, while a biopsy of the right fibula reveals atypical cells consistent with metastatic renal cell carcinoma. Urine analyses show atypical urothelial cells suspicious for malignancy, but subsequent tests indicate no malignant cells present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, measuring 9.2 cm, with Fuhrman nuclear grade III, and evidence of tumor extension through the renal capsule into perirenal adipose tissue, although resection margins are negative for tumor. The AJCC classification is T3 Nx MX, and there is no lymphovascular invasion noted. Cytogenetic analysis revealed clonal aberrations, including loss of the short arm of chromosome 3, which is characteristic of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in 1 of 4 para-aortic lymph nodes and 1 of 4 left pelvic lymph nodes, with a total of 2 of 4 right pelvic lymph nodes also involved, while the primary tumor is identified as endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, classified as FIGO grade 2. The tumor shows myometrial invasion of the inner half with a depth of 0.8 cm and is associated with lymphovascular space invasion, but there is no serosal or cervical involvement. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive (80%) and progesterone receptor positive (90%), and the overall AJCC pathologic stage is pT1a pN2, corresponding to FIGO stage IIIC2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, confirmed across multiple biopsies from the right frontal brain region. Tumor cellularity varied among samples, with some showing as low as 10% and others as high as 95%, while necrosis was noted in one sample at 20%. Overall, the findings are consistent with a high-grade malignant brain tumor characterized by significant cellularity and minimal necrosis in most samples.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of lung cancer, specifically adenocarcinoma, located in the right lung, measuring 2.2 x 2.0 x 1.8 cm, with moderate to poorly differentiated characteristics and lymphovascular invasion, but no pleural invasion identified. Multiple lymph nodes (levels 7, 9, 10, and 4) were examined, showing reactive sinus histiocytosis and anthracosilicosis, with no metastatic carcinoma detected in any of the lymph nodes. The surgical margins were assessed, revealing the tumor was 2.8 cm from the bronchial margin and 0.2 cm from the parenchymal margin, with no carcinoma identified at the parenchymal margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of carcinosarcoma (malignant mixed Mllerian tumor) confined to an endometrial polyp, with predominantly carcinomatous areas, and focal uterine intraepithelial serous carcinoma. All examined lymph nodes and additional soft tissue specimens show no evidence of malignancy, confirming that the tumor has not metastasized. The overall staging is T1aN0Mx, indicating the tumor is limited to the endometrium without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of oligodendroglial differentiation with noted mitotic activity and a proliferation rate of 10%. The diagnosis is anaplastic oligodendroglioma, classified as WHO grade III. This suggests a malignant brain tumor with moderate to high aggressiveness.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant mesothelioma, mixed type, in the pericardium, pleura, and diaphragm, with histological examination revealing moderate nuclear atypia and infiltration into adjacent tissues. Other specimens, including skin and subcutaneous tissue from the anterior and posterior thoracoscopy sites, as well as multiple lymph nodes and the phrenic nerve, showed no evidence of malignancy. Additionally, a portion of the right rib and bone marrow also exhibited no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of large peripheral to central undifferentiated mixed large-cell and polymorphocellular adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, classified as pT2 pN1 R0, stage IIB. Histological examination reveals a predominance of large-cell and polymorphocellular components with a clear-cell appearance and potential neuroendocrine differentiation, along with minimal invasion of the visceral pleura and central lymph node metastases. Immunohistochemical analysis shows a high proportion of tumor cells positive for low molecular weight keratins and TTF1, confirming the classification of mixed-type adenocarcinoma of the lung.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, serous papillary type, FIGO grade 3, with invasion into the myometrium and involvement of the entire endometrial surface and endocervix. The omentum and pelvic lymph nodes examined were negative for malignancy, and there was evidence of lymphovascular invasion in the myometrium. The overall staging is pT2a, N0, MX, indicating localized disease without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates multiple biopsies from various paratracheal and lung regions, with findings of lymphohistiocytic tissue and lymph nodes that are predominantly negative for malignancy, except for two samples which show diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (IWF G1). The right upper lobe biopsy reveals respiratory mucosa with focal squamous metaplasia and chronic inflammation. Additionally, the bone marrow biopsy shows trilineage hematopoiesis with no evidence of lymphoma, despite the patient's history of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the fundus of the stomach, measuring 16 x 14 x 2 cm with exophytic features. The tumor has metastasized to 15 out of 30 examined lymph nodes, and it has invaded adjacent structures, specifically the omentum, while the surgical margins are uninvolved. There is no specified evidence of lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion, and no additional pathologic findings or comments are provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma with an oligodendroglioma component, classified as WHO grade IV, from a right parietal lesion. Microscopic examination reveals extensive necrosis, microvascular hyperplasia, and strong p53 positivity, with a MIB1 proliferation index of approximately 40%. Molecular studies show borderline deletion of chromosome 1p, positive deletion for chromosome 19q, and no amplification of the EGFR gene, supporting the diagnosis of a high-grade glioma.

The pathology report indicates that the bladder neck biopsy shows benign fibromuscular tissue and glands with extensive cautery artifact, while no tumors were found in the right pelvic lymph nodes. The prostatectomy revealed bilateral prostatic carcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+5=8, extensive extraprostatic extension, and involvement of the right seminal vesicle, but no tumor was identified at the excision margins. Overall, the findings suggest advanced prostate cancer with significant local invasion but no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or metastatic disease in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a tumor in the right upper lobe of the lung measuring 8.0 x 5.0 x 7.5 cm, diagnosed as basaloid squamous cell carcinoma. There is infiltration of the visceral pleura, and the tumor classification is pT2, pN2 (1/31), pMx, G3. This suggests a moderately differentiated cancer with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left frontal oligodendroglioma classified as WHO Grade II, characterized by microcystic changes and moderate hypercellularity without significant mitotic activity, vascular proliferation, or necrosis. Molecular studies reveal allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, along with the presence of MGMT promoter methylation, while no EGFR variant III mutation was detected. The findings suggest a favorable response to alkylating agent therapy due to the methylated MGMT promoter status.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph nodes and additional lymph node excised showed no malignancy, with two benign lymph nodes identified and one specimen containing only fibroadipose tissue. The left breast lumpectomy revealed infiltrating ductal carcinoma with neuroendocrine features, classified as poorly differentiated (Nottingham grade 3) and measuring 3.0 cm, with no tumor necrosis or lymphatic invasion detected. Estrogen and progesterone receptors were negative, while HER2 was positive, and the pathologic stage was determined to be pT2 N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right renal mass diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the chromophobe type, measuring 10.0 cm, with extension into the renal pelvis but no invasion of the renal vein, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, a paracaval lymph node biopsy revealed 15 benign lymph nodes, and a right adrenal gland resection showed an adrenocortical adenoma measuring 0.9 x 0.8 x 0.7 cm. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue exhibited focal glomerulosclerosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a significant 8.5 cm tumor and evidence of intralymphatic tumor emboli at the ureteral margin. Metastatic renal cell carcinoma was identified in multiple lymph nodes, including the inter-aortocaval and retrocaval lymph nodes, with a total of six out of nine lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement. Cytogenetic analysis revealed an abnormal mosaic karyotype with deletions associated with nonpapillary renal cell carcinoma, supporting the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the left obturator lymph node exhibits reactive changes with nodular architecture, small germinal centers, and increased histiocytes, consistent with a reactive lymph node process. The primary diagnosis from the hysterectomy specimen reveals high-grade endometrial carcinoma, specifically endometrioid adenocarcinoma and serous carcinoma, with no lymphovascular invasion and no carcinoma identified in the examined lymph nodes. Overall, the findings suggest a localized endometrial carcinoma without evidence of metastatic spread to the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma, likely squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 7 x 4 cm in the right lung, with positive involvement in 2 out of 17 peribronchial lymph nodes. The bronchial margin is free of tumor, and there is no visceral pleural involvement. All other examined lymph nodes from various levels are negative for carcinoma, indicating limited metastatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a right upper lobectomy revealing a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 27 mm, with invasion of the visceral pleura but clear margins from the bronchial resection. No vascular invasion or lymph node metastases were identified in the examined lymph nodes. The adjacent lung tissue shows features of emphysema, and the pathological stage is classified as T2N0M0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade renal cell carcinoma with extensive invasion into the surrounding adipose tissue and Gerota's fascia, along with evidence of lymphovascular invasion. The tumor is present at the margins of Gerota's fascia and renal vein, while the renal artery and ureter margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, there are chronic changes in the kidney parenchyma, likely age-related, with mild atrophy and interstitial fibrosis observed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T4, with no regional lymph node involvement (N0) and no distant metastasis (M0). Additionally, a normal blood sample was obtained, indicating no abnormalities in that specimen.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the distal esophagus, extending into the gastroesophageal junction and proximal stomach, with a tumor size of 3.0 cm and invasion into the adventitia. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in 1 out of 43 examined lymph nodes, specifically in the left gastric nodes, while all other lymph nodes and surgical margins were negative for carcinoma. The tumor exhibits lymph-vascular and perineural invasion, and there is no prior treatment noted.

The pathology report indicates a thymectomy specimen weighing 189 g, with a notable 8 cm x 7 cm x 5 cm nodule characterized as a B1 thymoma, which shows minimal infiltration and is well-capsulated. Histopathological examination reveals a lobulated tumor primarily composed of small lymphocytes and macrophages, with no invasion of the surgical resection margins. The tumor is classified as Masaoka stage II and WHO classification T2N0M0, indicating complete resection with no evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with papillary serous carcinoma of the endometrium, with extensive lymphovascular invasion and involvement of the cervix, ovaries, and fallopian tubes. Out of 19 lymph nodes examined, 12 were found to contain metastatic carcinoma, with the largest metastasis measuring 2.8 cm. The omentum and appendix were noted to be free of neoplasm, and the overall pathological stage is classified as T3a NX MX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of four tumors in the right kidney, all classified as renal cell carcinoma of the clear cell type, with three tumors graded as Fuhrman nuclear grade 2 and one tumor identified as a renal cyst lined by clear cells. Additionally, a portion of the right 11th rib was submitted for gross evaluation only. The clinical history notes that the patient has bilateral renal masses, and the specimens were obtained through partial nephrectomy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma, WHO grade III, from biopsies and excision of a right insular tumor in the frontal lobe of the brain. Molecular assays for 1p and 19q deletions are pending, with preliminary results showing no loss of 1p and loss of 19q. Histological examination reveals hypercellular neural parenchyma with increased mitotic figures, consistent with the diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma.

The final diagnosis indicates a low-grade (Grade I) leiomyosarcoma of the pelvic soft tissue, which is invading the muscle wall of the urinary bladder and focally into the prostate, with all surgical margins free of tumor. The tumor shows rare mitoses, no necrosis, and no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion, with a TNM stage of pTb NO MX. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from various regions are negative for malignancy, supporting the diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous adenocarcinoma with focal clear cell features in both ovaries, along with metastatic involvement in the right and left fallopian tubes, deep cervical soft tissue, omentum, and posterior cul-de-sac. All seven examined right periaortic lymph nodes showed metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming extensive disease spread. The tumor is classified as poorly differentiated (Grade 3) and is staged as T3c, IIIC, indicating macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left distal ureter segments are benign, confirmed by frozen section diagnosis. However, the bladder and prostate show invasive, high-grade urothelial carcinoma with extensive squamous differentiation, affecting approximately 80% of the bladder wall and involving adjacent structures, including the prostate and seminal vesicles, with extensive perineural invasion and multiple lymph node metastases. The tumor is ulcerated and necrotic, with significant inflammatory cell infiltrate, and there is evidence of carcinoma at the posterior serosal surface and right anterior prostatic capsular resection margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) in brain tissue, characterized by a malignant astrocytic neoplasm with features such as cellular pleomorphism, mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis, with tumor presence in the subarachnoid space. Cytogenetic analysis revealed significant abnormalities, including polysomy of chromosome 7, amplification of EGFR, loss of chromosome 10 centromere, and PTEN allelic loss, with all four markers showing abnormal results. Immunohistochemical analysis showed negative MGMT expression and positive EGFR expression in a majority of tumor cells, suggesting a poor prognosis associated with the presence of multiple genetic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (grade 2) in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.0 cm, with negative margins and lymphovascular and perineural invasion identified. Out of 22 regional lymph nodes examined, 6 were positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, leading to a pathologic stage of IIIA. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, showing positive results for TTF-1, Napsin-A, and MOC-31, while the visceral pleura was not involved by the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma with a prominent lobular component in the right breast, measuring 12 x 9.5 x 4 cm, and classified as histologic grade 3. The tumor is multifocal, present in all quadrants of the breast, with lymphatic and vascular invasion noted, and metastatic carcinoma found in five of ten examined lymph nodes, the largest being 2.4 cm. Estrogen and progesterone receptor assays show positive results, with further details pending in an addendum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the left lobe of the liver, following a left hemihepatectomy. The tumor is characterized as a well-defined multinodular mass with a complete fibrous capsule and no evidence of invasion at the surgical margins. Additionally, the remaining liver parenchyma shows signs of cirrhosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, grade 3, measuring 8.0 cm, confined to the right kidney following a laparoscopic nephrectomy. The tumor is unifocal, limited to the kidney without evidence of invasion into surrounding structures, lymphatic, or venous systems, and the surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additional findings include chronic inflammation, and the tumor exhibits histologic features characteristic of type-2 papillary renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with a tumor size of 3.8 x 3.5 x 1.3 cm and extensive lymphovascular invasion. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in one of thirteen left pelvic lymph nodes, one of two right external lymph nodes, and one of nine right obturator lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes examined showed no evidence of malignancy. The tumor is classified as FIGO grade 3, with a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 1.3 cm, and the cervix and serosa are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma of the right breast, characterized as pleomorphic with focal signet cells, and classified as Nottingham grade II. The tumor measures 2.5 cm and is associated with lobular carcinoma in situ, with two out of eleven lymph nodes positive for carcinoma. The invasive tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER2/NEU, with negative surgical margins for both in situ and invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has moderately differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, involving both lobes of the prostate and measuring 1.8 cm in maximum dimension, but is organ-confined with no evidence of extracapsular extension. All examined lymph nodes (26 total) are free of carcinoma, and the surgical margins are clear of tumor, although focal perineural invasion is noted. Additionally, benign prostatic hypertrophy and chronic prostatitis are present, and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is identified.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from the right parieto-occipital region is diagnosed as a Glioblastoma multiforme, classified as an Astrocytoma WHO Grade IV. Microscopic examination reveals a malignant astrocytic neoplasm with features such as pleomorphic malignant astrocytes, mitotic figures, and areas of necrosis. The final diagnosis confirms the presence of a highly aggressive brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multiple excised masses from the left kidney, all diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma, papillary type I, with some showing spindle and clear cell differentiation and incipient lesions present. A total of 17 tumors were identified, with varying sizes and characteristics, alongside a specimen of perinephric fat. The clinical history notes that the patient has a history of renal cell carcinoma and underwent a partial nephrectomy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with two distinct tumors: one measuring 0.4 cm classified as clear cell type with Fuhrman grade 1, and another measuring 4.3 cm with overlapping features of papillary renal cell carcinoma and mucinous tubular and spindle cell carcinoma, graded as 2. Both tumors are confined to the kidney with negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion identified. Fluorescence in situ hybridization analysis suggests chromosomal abnormalities consistent with a mucinous tubular and spindle cell carcinoma, although a papillary renal cell carcinoma cannot be excluded.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver, specifically in segment 3, following a left lateral sectionectomy. The tumor is characterized as a well-defined multinodular mass with a safety margin of 2.2 cm, and there is no evidence of invasion into surrounding structures or vessels. Additionally, the liver parenchyma shows signs of cirrhosis and mild steatosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma in both the right and left ovaries, with direct extension into the right fallopian tube and focal lymphovascular space invasion identified in the left ovary. There is no evidence of malignancy in the left fallopian tube or in any of the examined lymph nodes from both pelvic and periaortic regions. The final staging of the cancer is provisional due to insufficient data, but there is no regional lymph node metastasis detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial cancer, specifically a predominantly endometrioid adenocarcinoma that is moderately to poorly differentiated (FIGO grade 2-3), with invasion into the myometrium but not extending to the cervix or serosa. The left and right pelvic lymph nodes show reactive changes with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma identified in the examined nodes. Additionally, the right ovary is noted to have benign multi-cystic features suggestive of a mature cystic teratoma, while the left ovary also shows characteristics of a mature cystic teratoma, with no carcinoma detected in either adnexa.

The pathology report indicates that the left pelvic lymph nodes were excised and found to be negative for metastatic disease, while one of five right pelvic lymph nodes tested positive for metastatic carcinoma. A hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cervix, measuring 4.5 cm and extending into the lower uterine segment, with a pTNM stage of pT2a2N1 (FIGO IIIB). Additional findings included negative results for malignancy in the uterine artery biopsy and benign findings in the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive tubular carcinoma of the left breast, measuring 2.3 x 1.7 x 1.3 cm, with a histological grade of NHG1 and classified as pT2, pNO(sn). The tumor was found centrally over the nipple, and the surrounding glandular tissue exhibited fibrocystic changes and a fibroadenoma. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed estrogen and progesterone receptor positivity in 75% of neoplastic cells, while HER2 was negative, and Ki-67 showed 10% nuclear proliferation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade adrenocortical carcinoma, with a tumor size of 14.5 x 11 x 7.9 cm and a weight of 560 grams, exhibiting capsular and extensive vascular invasion. Surgical margins are reported as negative after reevaluation, and there is evidence of necrosis (20%) and a high mitotic rate (51/50 high power field). The tumor has extra-adrenal extension and the lymph node status is negative for carcinoma, with the overall stage classified as pT4 NX MX.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes (including #7, L-4, R-4, R-2, #10, and level 7) were excised and found to be negative for neoplasm. In contrast, the right upper lobe lobectomy revealed a mixed-type adenocarcinoma with solid, acinar, and bronchioloalveolar patterns, measuring 6.3 x 2.9 x 2.0 cm, with vascular invasion present and metastasis identified in one peribronchial lymph node. The tumor infiltrates through the visceral pleura, and further analysis for EGFR mutations is pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 1.9 cm, which shows no local or renal vein invasion. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable. Additionally, a biopsy of a satellite tumor revealed a tubulopapillary neoplasm consistent with a papillary adenoma.

The pathology report indicates that the left pelvic lymph nodes and tissue over the prostate show no tumor presence, while the prostate gland exhibits adenocarcinoma with unilateral extension into the extraprosthetic soft tissue. The tumor has a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7/10 and is classified as pT3a, pNo, pMX, with perineural invasion present but no tumor detected in the seminal vesicles or at the margins. The specimen was obtained through a radical prostatectomy, weighing 42 grams, and the tumor is located on the left side of the prostate.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two synchronous moderately differentiated adenocarcinomas in the colorectal region: one in the rectum and another in the sigmoid colon, both exhibiting invasive characteristics. Additionally, there is evidence of coarse nodular metastasis in a lymph node, with nine out of thirty-three lymph nodes showing extensive metastases from the colorectal carcinomas. The tumors are staged as pT2 L0, V0; G2 for the rectal carcinoma and pT3 L1 V0; G2 for the sigmoid colon carcinoma, with a pN2 classification indicating significant lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the liver biopsy shows triaditis, cholestasis, steatosis, and microabscesses, with no evidence of malignancy. However, a metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in the liver segment 7 biopsy, and a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma was found in the cecum, extending into the sigmoid colon and urinary bladder, with positive lymph nodes indicating metastasis. Additional findings include chronic Crohn's ileitis and unremarkable segments of the colon in other excised specimens, with no tumors detected in those areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of colorectal adenocarcinoma arising in conjunction with a tubulovillous adenoma with high-grade dysplasia, located in the cecal pouch, and is moderately differentiated. The tumor has invaded into but not through the muscularis propria, with negative lymphovascular and perineural invasion, and clear margins from the tumor to proximal, distal, and mesenteric margins. Additionally, 28 regional lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for malignancy, and the report notes the presence of a separate tubulovillous adenoma with focal high-grade dysplasia.

The pathology report indicates that biopsies from the right lower paratracheal, subcarinal, and right pulmonary ligament lymph nodes are negative for tumor. In contrast, the right lung pneumonectomy reveals an invasive grade 4 squamous cell carcinoma with a well-circumscribed, partially necrotic mass measuring 6.3 x 5.2 x 3.4 cm, with no visceral pleural invasion and a negative bronchial margin by 1.8 cm. The overall staging is pT2bN0 according to the AJCC 7th edition, and multiple intrapulmonary peribronchial nodes show no evidence of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a right radical nephrectomy revealing a Grade 3 clear cell renal cell carcinoma, measuring 10.0 x 9.0 x 6.0 cm, with extension into the perinephric fat but no involvement of the renal vein or collecting system. Additionally, there are 11 separate clear cell renal cell carcinoma nodules of Grade 1-2 scattered throughout the upper and mid portions of the kidney. The surgical margins are negative, and the adrenal gland appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma (Grade 2) with myometrial invasion and identified lymphovascular invasion, while endocervical invasion was not found. Sentinel lymph nodes from both the left and right obturator regions were examined and found to be benign, with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, the endometrium showed complex hyperplasia with atypia, and the adnexa were unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder, with a benign cystic duct lymph node. In the liver, a grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma is identified, characterized by a dominant mass measuring 6.8 x 5.9 x 4.1 cm and a small satellite mass, with the tumor confined to the liver and a negative resection margin. While there is no macroscopic large vessel invasion, microscopic large vessel invasion is present, and no regional lymph nodes are identified.

The pathology report indicates that three left sentinel lymph nodes were biopsied and found to be negative for tumor involvement. A segmental mastectomy revealed a 1.0 cm infiltrating duct carcinoma with a Nottingham score of 6, characterized by no lymphovascular invasion and a small component of ductal carcinoma in situ. The tumor is hormone receptor positive (estrogen and progesterone) and HER-2/neu negative, with negative surgical margins and additional findings of benign fibrocystic changes and a fibroadenoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with invasion into surrounding tissues and lymphovascular invasion, while the urethral and ureteral margins are negative for carcinoma. Additionally, a segment of the right colon shows mild changes consistent with prior biopsies, including a hyperplastic polyp and a submucosal lipoma, but no residual dysplasia or adenocarcinoma. Out of the examined lymph nodes, five out of twenty-three from the left pelvic region show metastatic involvement, while all right pelvic lymph nodes are negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the cervical biopsy revealed poorly differentiated non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. The specimen consisted of two fragments, with one likely containing squamous epithelium and the other being irregular in shape. The patient's history included post-coital bleeding and a prior Pap smear classified as Class IV, prompting the biopsy to rule out cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the sigmoid colon specimen shows a poorly differentiated invasive mucinous adenocarcinoma that has invaded through the muscularis propria into the pericolonic fat, with negative resection margins and evidence of metastasis in 7 of 20 lymph nodes. Additionally, metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma is identified in both the right abdominal wall tumor and the omentum. The report also notes the presence of diverticulosis in the colon.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated, in the cervix with a depth of invasion of approximately 1.0 cm, while all examined lymph nodes were negative for metastasis. Additional findings include benign fibrous tissue in the abdominal soft tissue, extensive adenomyosis, and endometriosis in the serosa. The surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, with the closest margin being 5 mm from the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma measuring 2.0 x 1.7 x 1.5 cm, which extends beyond the pancreas but does not involve major vascular structures or surgical margins. All examined regional lymph nodes (20) and a lymph node from the hepatic artery are negative for malignancy, suggesting no lymphatic spread. Additionally, the gallbladder shows no significant pathological changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, measuring approximately 3.2 x 2.4 cm, with evidence of perineural invasion and metastasis to one of twelve peripancreatic lymph nodes. Additionally, the report notes metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma infiltrating the posterior cervical wall, along with benign findings such as atrophic endometrium and uterine leiomyoma. The pancreatic margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, but there is focal extension of carcinoma to less than 1 mm of the peripancreatic soft tissue margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a liver specimen obtained from a partial hepatectomy, with a well-defined mass measuring 2.5 cm and showing significant hemorrhage and necrosis. The tumor is classified as Edmondson-Steiner grade III, with no evidence of vascular invasion or metastasis, and the surrounding liver parenchyma is noted to be cirrhotic. Additionally, the gallbladder specimen reveals chronic cholecystitis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the lower third of the esophagus, measuring up to 5 cm, with invasion into all wall layers and evidence of metastatic lymph nodes. There is noted venous invasion and perineural invasion, with all examined lymph nodes showing metastases. Surgical margins are free of tumor growth, suggesting complete resection of the primary tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in segment 5 of the liver, with a tumor size of 3.6 cm, classified as Grade 2 of 4, and showing over 95% viability without evidence of vascular, perineural, or capsular invasion. The surgical margins are negative for malignancy, with the tumor located 0.5 cm from the segment IV margin and 1.3 cm from the segment VI margin. Additionally, the liver parenchyma shows mild centrilobular cholestasis, and both segment 4 and gallbladder specimens are negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classic seminoma in the right testis, classified as pT1, with the tumor confined to the testis and no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is associated intratubular germ cell neoplasia. The final TNM staging is pT1NXMO, corresponding to stage I testicular cancer, with no distant metastasis observed.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes excised from levels VII, X, XI, XII, and IV showed no evidence of malignancy, while a right lower lobe lobectomy revealed a poorly-differentiated mixed-type adenocarcinoma measuring 1.5 cm, with no lymphovascular or pleural invasion and uninvolved resection margins. Additionally, a pulmonary chondroid hamartoma measuring 1.3 cm was identified, along with subpleural pulmonary fibrosis and other non-neoplastic changes. The overall staging of the tumor is classified as T1a/N0/M0, indicating Stage IA lung cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.0 cm in the right pyriform sinus, with resection margins free of tumor and no evidence of perineural or lymphovascular invasion. The right and left neck dissections showed no tumor present in a total of eleven lymph nodes examined (0/9 on the right and 0/2 on the left). Additionally, the thyroid gland showed no diagnostic abnormalities, and the tracheal margin exhibited focal areas of necrosing mucosa with marked acute inflammation.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the right and left pelvic lymph nodes. However, prostatic adenocarcinoma was diagnosed in the prostate, with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5), and the tumor extends into extraprostatic tissue, although the resection margins are free of tumor. Three separate foci of cancer were identified within the prostate, with the dominant focus measuring 2.0 x 1.8 cm and located in the right peripheral zone.

The pathology report indicates the presence of nonpapillary grade 3 urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with transmural invasion of the bladder wall and focal extension into perivesical adipose tissue, while the prostate shows microcystic adenomatous change without malignancy. All examined lymph nodes from various regions, as well as segments of the vas deferens and ureters, show no evidence of tumor. The resection margins of both ureters are also free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as moderately differentiated with a Nottingham score of 6/9 and a tumor size of 2.8 cm, with no tumor necrosis or vascular invasion identified. One of the two sentinel lymph nodes examined was positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the additional margins and lymph node were free of malignancy. Estrogen receptors were positive, progesterone receptors negative, and HER2/neu was positive, with the pathological stage reported as pT2 N1a MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma, WHO grade IV, from an excised brain mass in the right temporal lobe, with noted areas of divergent differentiation including features of gemistocytes and small-cell components. Immunohistochemical analysis shows diffuse positivity for GFAP and CD56, with a high Ki-67 labeling index, confirming the high-grade nature of the tumor. Additionally, PTEN immunohistochemistry results were negative, but the original diagnosis remains unchanged.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma in an ablated breast sample, with a tumor diameter of 10.5 cm and focal skin ulceration. A satellite node measuring 0.9 cm was also identified in the skin, while the dorsal resection margin is tumor-free. The tumor classification is NOS, G II, pT4b pN3a(11/22).

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 4x6 cm keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the esophagus, classified as well differentiated (G-1) and extending to the adventitia, with no evidence of venous invasion or positive lymph node metastasis. Additionally, chronic gastritis was noted in the stomach, and one examined paraesophageal lymph node showed follicular hyperplasia. The surgical margins are uninvolved, suggesting complete resection of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that 37 lymph nodes from the right and left pelvis were examined, all of which were negative for metastatic carcinoma. A radical prostatectomy revealed invasive prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing focal extracapsular extension, but with all surgical margins and seminal vesicles free of carcinoma. Additionally, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia was identified, and the tumor was classified as pT3a, with no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a pleomorphic cellular astrocytic tumor with mitotic activity and early vascular proliferation. The proliferation index is noted to be 25%, suggesting significant cellular activity. The diagnosis is consistent with an anaplastic astrocytoma, classified as WHO grade III, with potential for transition to glioblastoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma located in the left hepatic lobe, measuring 4x3.5x3 cm. Microscopic examination reveals trabecular and acinar patterns with irregularly large, hyperchromatic nuclei and evidence of infiltration into benign hepatic tissue. The tumor shows moderate cytoplasm and lymphocytic stroma invasion, with no specified details on lymph nodes or venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right medial tongue biopsy and a larger invasive moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma (4.2 cm) in the left partial glossectomy, with no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. All final resection margins are free of tumor, and the pathological stage is classified as T3 N0. Additionally, a dissection of 23 lymph nodes from the left neck revealed no tumor presence (0/23).

The pathology report indicates the presence of two separate foci of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with mucinous features, classified as FIGO grade II, and showing invasion into the myometrium and endocervical tissue. The lymph node examination revealed no metastatic involvement in the sampled nodes, with all lymph nodes identified as benign fibroadipose tissue. Additionally, the anterior cul-de-sac biopsy showed fibrous tissue with calcifications and focal endosalpingiosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma (bladder cancer) with deep invasion into the muscularis propria, but no involvement of the prostate or ureters. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, all of which were found to be benign, and surgical margins were free of tumor. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT2b, indicating muscle-invasive disease without extravesical extension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma with Fuhrman's nuclear grade 4 and extensive sarcomatoid dedifferentiation, measuring 18 cm, and invading the perinephric and renal sinus adipose tissue as well as the adrenal gland. The tumor involves the wall of the renal vein/inferior vena cava at the margin of resection, although the ureteral, renal artery, and soft tissue margins are free of tumor. Additionally, a simple renal cortical cyst measuring 2.2 cm was noted, with the sarcomatoid component comprising approximately 90-95% of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the left breast, classified as Nottingham grade I, with a tumor size of 6.5 x 5.2 x 3.5 cm and a Nottingham score of 5/9. Lobular carcinoma in situ is present in less than 5% of the tumor volume, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor, while one of the six examined axillary lymph nodes is positive for metastatic carcinoma. Additional immunohistochemical analysis for hormone receptors and Her-2/NEU has been ordered for further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 1) with 25% myometrial invasion and 15% endometrial surface involvement, alongside benign findings such as simple hyperplasia and leiomyomata. All examined lymph nodes (15 total) are negative for metastatic carcinoma, suggesting no lymphatic spread of the cancer. Additional findings include benign cysts in the ovaries and fallopian tubes, as well as chronic cervicitis in the cervix.

The pathology report indicates that a 70-year-old male with a history of reflux has been diagnosed with moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma arising from the gastroesophageal junction. The tumor measures 1.5 cm, invades the muscularis propria, and reaches the omental surface, but the distal gastric margin and four sampled lymph nodes are negative for neoplasm. The TNM classification is T2N0Mx, and the deep resection margin is involved.

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy of the right lower lobe revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.7 cm, with no evidence of lymphovascular or venous invasion, and the tumor is confined to the lung with uninvolved margins. One of the nine examined subcarinal lymph nodes showed metastatic poorly differentiated carcinoma, while the level 4 lymph nodes were benign. The pathologic stage is classified as pT2 pN2 pMX, indicating the extent of the tumor and lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower parathyroid biopsy showed no pathological diagnosis, while the right hemithyroidectomy revealed a 2.2 cm papillary carcinoma of the follicular variant with minimal capsular invasion and mild chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. The tumor is unifocal, encapsulated, and has uninvolved margins, with no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion. The report confirms that the findings have been reviewed and agreed upon by a consulting pathologist.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, with a tumor size of 2.4 x 2.0 x 1.6 cm and extensive ductal carcinoma in-situ present. Positive margins were noted in the wide local excision specimen, while the mastectomy specimen showed residual in-situ carcinoma adjacent to the biopsy cavity, but all surgical margins were negative for tumor. Sentinel lymph nodes were negative for metastatic carcinoma, and further receptor analysis has been ordered.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive urothelial carcinoma with high histologic grade and mixed glandular and basaloid/squamoid features in the left lateral bladder wall, with local invasion into the muscularis propria but no vascular invasion identified. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed staining heterogeneity, with strong positivity for p16 and focal synaptophysin, while the tumor was negative for several other markers, suggesting a predominant urothelial differentiation. The specimen consisted of multiple pieces of soft tissue measuring 2.5 x 2.5 x 1.5 cm, and all sections were submitted for further examination.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma in the left side of the mandible, with tumor involvement at the margins of excision. Additionally, there is metastatic squamous carcinoma identified in one of the lymph nodes at left level IIB, while the surrounding fibroadipose tissue shows no tumor. Bone specimens from the left inferior margin and horizontal and ascending ramus of the mandible were submitted for decalcification, with no tumor detected in these areas.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left lung, measuring 32 mm, with perineural permeation but no blood vessel invasion. Metastatic carcinoma is identified in the peribronchial lymph nodes and No. 5 lymph node, while other lymph nodes show reactive changes without malignancy. The tumor is clear of surgical margins and pleura, classified as T2N2MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly-differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in a right partial glossectomy specimen, measuring 1.6 cm in size with a depth of invasion of 1.2 cm, arising in a background of high-grade squamous intraepithelial neoplasia. The invasive carcinoma is located at least 0.3 cm from the deep margins and all margins are free of in-situ carcinoma, resulting in a minimum pathologic stage of pT1 NX MX. Additional biopsies from various regions of the tongue showed no evidence of in-situ or invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue, measuring 7.5 x 4.0 cm, with involvement of skeletal muscle and osseous tissue, and lymphatic and perineural invasion noted. Out of 25 lymph nodes examined, none were involved by metastatic carcinoma, while 4 out of 19 lymph nodes from the neck dissection showed metastatic involvement without capsular invasion. The deep margin of the tongue was involved by neoplasia, but other surgical margins and the tongue margin were uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph node #1 contains isolated tumor cells, while the right breast tissue shows moderately differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma with a tumor size of 3.4 cm, located close to the inferior-anterior margin. There is no definitive lymph-vascular invasion noted, and the tumor is staged as pT2, pNO (i+), Mx according to AJCC guidelines. Additional findings include fibrocystic changes in the breast tissue, with no significant pathological changes in the nipple.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated infiltrating adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid and upper rectum, with minimal extension into pericolonic fat and all surgical margins negative for tumor. One out of 48 examined lymph nodes shows metastatic disease, while the apical lymph node is negative for metastasis. The appendix shows no significant pathology.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of myxoid sarcoma, specifically featuring characteristics of myxofibrosarcoma and acral myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma, in a right pretibial mass. Positive margins were identified at the superomedial, inferomedial, and deep margins, indicating incomplete excision of the lesion. Complete excision of the mass is recommended due to the presence of the tumor at the inked tissue edges.

The pathology report indicates that a right breast mass was excised from a  year old white female, revealing an invasive papillary adenocarcinoma measuring 2.5 cm in greatest diameter. The tumor is characterized by well-formed papillary structures and infiltrative foci, with the margins of resection being free of tumor. The mass was located 0.8 cm from the deep surgical margin, and the specimen included a portion of breast tissue with skin and nipple.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Thymoma, type A, measuring 4.0 cm, with no evidence of capsular or lymphovascular invasion, and negative surgical margins. Immunohistochemistry results support the diagnosis, showing diffuse positivity for pan-cytokeratin AE1/AE3 and scattered Tdt-positive lymphocytes. The specimen was received fresh for frozen section consultation, and both the frozen section and permanent diagnoses confirmed the presence of Thymoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Glioblastoma, WHO grade IV, characterized by marked hypercellularity, scattered mitoses, nuclear anaplasia, prominent microvascular proliferation, nuclear pleomorphism, and focal necrosis. The tumor was examined through intraoperative consultation, confirming necrosis and atypical glial infiltrate consistent with Glioblastoma. Two tissue fragments were received for analysis, with one frozen section and additional formalin-fixed specimens processed for histological examination.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right radical nephrectomy, revealing a poorly differentiated carcinoma, likely papillary renal cell carcinoma, with a tumor size of 6.5 cm and evidence of invasion into perinephric fat, renal sinus fat, and the renal vein. Among the lymph nodes examined, one of eleven right paracaval lymph nodes was positive for metastasis, while all four interaortocaval lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. The tumor exhibits variable morphology, with areas resembling both papillary renal cell carcinoma and other types, but extensive sampling did not support a diagnosis of translocation carcinoma or invasive urothelial carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, classified as NHG3, with a tumor size of 6.0 x 6.0 x 3.5 cm and evidence of metastasis in the axillary lymph nodes. Microscopic examination revealed carcinoma with significant mitotic activity and lymph node infiltration. Immunohistochemical analysis showed estrogen receptors in 10-75% and progesterone receptors in over 75% of neoplastic cells, while HER2 was negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 2) in the uterus, with a tumor size of 3.8 x 3.5 cm and greater than 50% myometrial invasion, but no cervical involvement or regional lymph node metastasis. Lymphovascular invasion is present, and all examined lymph nodes (9 pelvic nodes and 0 para-aortic nodes) show no tumor involvement. Additional findings include benign leiomyomas in the uterus and no pathological changes in the ovaries or fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates that the pelvic lymph nodes and fibrolipomatous tissue are tumor-free. However, the prostate shows extensive infiltration by adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4, affecting both lobes and extending into the periprostatic tissue. The seminal vesicles are tumor-free, and the overall staging is pT3a G3 NO R1.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has moderately to poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma of the right colon, which arose from a tubulovillous adenoma with high-grade dysplasia and multiple foci of intramucosal carcinoma. DNA mismatch repair testing showed no deficiency in the proteins tested, suggesting intact DNA mismatch repair function and a low likelihood of the carcinoma being associated with Lynch syndrome. The tumor has invaded the muscularis propria, but no metastasis was found in the examined lymph nodes, and the resection margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated papillary adenocarcinoma (intestinal type) in the stomach's antrum and pylorus, measuring 11.0 x 4.0 x 2.65 cm, with infiltration into adjacent fat and gastric serosa but no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. All examined lymph nodes from both the lesser and greater curvature, as well as those associated with the celiac trunk and anterior hepatic artery, show no signs of neoplasia. Additionally, the report notes atrophic gastritis with extensive intestinal metaplasia in the adjacent gastric mucosa and cholelithiasis in the gallbladder, with all surgical margins and omentum uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report describes a Whipple specimen revealing a 5 x 3.5 x 2.2 cm ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas, which invades the duodenal mucosa and peripancreatic fat. Microscopic examination shows chronic pancreatitis in the pancreatic margin, with no carcinoma detected in the pancreatic duct margin. Out of 24 lymph nodes examined, 4 were positive for metastasis, indicating regional spread of the cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the histological and morphological findings are consistent with an anaplastic astrocytoma classified as WHO grade III. The diagnosis confirmed is anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade III. This suggests a malignant brain tumor with aggressive characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a brain tumor, specifically an anaplastic astrocytoma. The tumor is located in the right parietal lobe and is characterized as Grade III. The tissue examined microscopically confirms the diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right renal tumor diagnosed as conventional (clear cell) renal cell carcinoma with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and a size of 1.9 cm, with no evidence of local or renal vein invasion, and free surgical margins. Additionally, the excised paracaval lymph node was not involved, and only fibrofatty tissue was identified with no definite lymph nodes present. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a left nephrectomy and resection of a left adrenal mass, revealing an adrenocortical carcinoma with a largest diameter of 19 cm and a high nuclear grade of 4. The tumor exhibits features such as necrosis in approximately 20% of the mass, capsular and venous invasion, and a mitotic count of 28 in 10 high power fields, resulting in a WEISS score of 8. The renal parenchyma shows no evidence of neoplastic infiltration.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma involving both ovaries, fallopian tubes, and the uterine serosa, with lymphovascular space invasion noted. Additional findings include chronic cervicitis and atrophic endometrium, with the tumor staging classified as pT3c, pNX, pMX, corresponding to FIGO stage IIIC. The carcinoma was also identified in the omentum, right sidewall lesion, and cul-de-sac tumor, with a maximum tumor size of 4 cm and evidence of invasive surface implants.

The pathology report describes a moderately cellular neoplasm in the cerebellum that resembles atypical fibrillary astrocytes, with features including Rosenthal fibers, vascular hyalinization, and microcalcifications. The tumor exhibits a solid growth pattern and has an expanded interface with the adjacent cerebellum, but lacks atypical ganglion cells and eosinophilic granular bodies. The final diagnosis is a well-differentiated astrocytoma (Grade 2) located at the cerebellopontine angle.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder specimen shows evidence of cholelithiasis and chronic cholecystitis. The liver specimen reveals a solitary, well-circumscribed hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 4.5 x 4.0 x 2.6 cm, classified as Grade 2, with no invasive carcinoma at the parenchymal margins but identified microscopic small vessel invasion. Additionally, there is chronic hepatitis with cirrhosis present in the liver, while the right adrenal gland shows no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 4.5 cm, with focal papillary architecture and focal involvement of the pleural margin, but the bronchial margin is not involved. Biopsies from lymph nodes Station 7, R9, and R10 show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. Intraoperative consultation confirmed the absence of in situ or invasive carcinoma at the bronchial margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the omentum, right ovary, left adnexa, and small bowel mesenteric implant, with significant tumor sizes and evidence of metastasis. The report highlights that the right ovary measures 6.5 cm and the left adnexa tumor measures 10 cm, with lymphovascular space invasion noted. The overall staging is classified as pT3c, pNX, pMX, corresponding to FIGO stage IIIC.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of colorectal type in the resected colon, measuring 3.5 cm and infiltrating the tunica muscularis propria. There are no tumor cells found in the lymph nodes or at the resection margins, indicating clear margins. The tumor is staged as pT2, with no lymph node involvement (pNO 0/21) and no distant metastasis (pMX), classified as grade 2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 2.1 cm, with clear resection margins. Metastatic ductal carcinoma was found in 2 out of 26 examined lymph nodes, with evidence of extranodal extension, while no malignancy was detected in an additional five lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as Nottingham grade 3, and ancillary studies show negative estrogen and progesterone receptor status, with positive HER2/neu results.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral papillary serous adenocarcinoma (FIGO stage III) in both the right and left ovaries, with evidence of extensive metastatic spread to the omentum, small intestine, transverse colon, and pericolic lymph nodes. The tumors exhibit significant invasion into surrounding tissues, with some resection margins being free of tumor, while others show involvement. Additionally, biopsies from the left fallopian tube and umbilicus show no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of adrenocortical carcinoma, with a primary tumor measuring 15 X 9 X 7 cm and a secondary tumor in the vena cava measuring 13.5 X 5.5 X 5 cm. The tumor has a KI67 proliferation index of 10%, and the staging is pT2 pNx LO V1 Pn0 R0, indicating no vascular invasion and complete resection. Additional scoring includes a Weiss score of 7, Hough score of 3.29, and Van Slooten score of 13.7, suggesting a significant malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with a significant mass measuring approximately 6.5 cm in the upper inner quadrant and additional firmness noted in the lower outer quadrant. Histologically, the carcinoma is graded as grade 2 with a nuclear grade of 3, and all examined regional lymph nodes (19 total) are negative for cancer. Final surgical margins are reported as negative for cancer, indicating no residual disease at the edges of the excised tissue.

The pathology report indicates that a 9 x 4.5 cm distal portion of the thoracic esophagus was removed, revealing a 6.5 x 5 x 1.1 cm ulcerative adenocarcinoma at the gastroesophageal junction, which invades through the muscular layer and approaches the serosal surface. The tumor involved 80% of the esophagus and metastasized to 4 out of 19 lymph nodes, with no involvement of the surgical margins. The final diagnosis is a poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma classified as T3 N1 MX, with no Barrett's mucosa identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating medullary carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.3 by 1.2 by 1.0 cm, with margins free of tumor. Additionally, one of twenty-three right axillary lymph nodes showed metastatic carcinoma with extracapsular extension. Immunohistochemical testing for estrogen and progesterone receptors, as well as HER-2/Neu, returned negative results.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a high-grade pleomorphic liposarcoma arising in the right chest wall, measuring 8.1 x 4.5 x 4.3 cm, with focal erosion into the surrounding soft tissue but not involving the rib margins. The tumor exhibits strong positivity for CDK4 and MDM2, supporting the diagnosis of a well-differentiated sclerosing liposarcoma. The specimen includes excised chest wall tissue and ribs, with the tumor abutting the pleural surface and extending into the anterior soft tissue.
