The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO grade I) in a lesion located in the right frontal parietal temporal region of a female patient. The specimen, measuring 0.6 x 0.5 x 0.3 cm, shows an infiltrating glial tumor with predominantly astrocytic characteristics, numerous mitotic figures, and abundant microvascular proliferation, but no areas of necrosis. This finding is consistent with a malignant brain tumor, specifically glioblastoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, classified as grade III, with the tumor being close to the excisional margins. All four sentinel lymph nodes examined were negative for malignancy, indicating no lymphatic spread of cancer. Additionally, a fibroadenoma was identified in the retroareolar region of the right breast, and the margins from the segmental mastectomy and additional wall specimens were negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, identified in two nodules measuring 2.6 cm and 2.1 cm. The tumor is confined to the kidney and is located within 1 mm of the hilum, with no evidence of coagulative tumor necrosis or sarcomatoid differentiation. The tumor extends to within 1 mm of the surgical margin, which is reported as negative.

The pathology report indicates that the left kidney specimen shows a conventional type renal cell carcinoma, nuclear grade IV, with a tumor measuring 6.8 cm that extends through the renal capsule and invades the renal vein, but all surgical margins are free of tumor. The para-aortic lymph node is benign, and the right renal artery thrombus and intima show no evidence of tumor, while the spleen is also reported as benign. Overall, the findings suggest a significant renal malignancy with no metastatic spread to the examined lymph nodes or other tissues.

The pathology report indicates a biopsy of the duodenum and pancreas following a partial gastrectomy, revealing moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma measuring 2.5 cm with perineural infiltration present. There was no evidence of angiolymphatic vascular invasion, and all six examined lymph nodes were free of neoplasia. The pathological stage is classified as pT2, pNO, with a noted suspicion of foci of neuroendocrine differentiation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinosarcoma in the anterior abdominal wall and identifies a malignant mullerian mixed tumor in the uterus with components of small cell carcinoma and adenosarcoma, showing extensive lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, while some lymph nodes were benign, the sentinel left external iliac lymph node showed metastatic carcinosarcoma. Other specimens, including the small bowel and sigmoid adhesions, revealed acute inflammation with reactive changes, while the omentum and other lymph nodes were benign.

The pathology report indicates that the right brain tumor is diagnosed as a glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, characterized by high cellularity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis. Additional findings include evidence of infiltrating glioblastoma in the dura and features suggestive of focal primitive neuronal differentiation. Immunohistochemical studies show approximately 50% positivity for MGMT, with no gene methylation detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in 15 of 19 lymph nodes from the right neck dissection and in 3 of 37 lymph nodes from the left neck dissection, with extranodal extension noted on the right side. Additionally, invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma was found in the right larynx, with a maximum size of 4.0 cm and evidence of angiolymphatic and perineural invasion, while the left glottic tumor measured 1.0 cm and showed no invasion. No carcinoma was detected in the excised specimens from the left base of the tongue, left lateral pharynx, and right base of the tongue, with final margins reported as free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous papillary adenocarcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with extensive tumor replacement of ovarian tissue and involvement of the fallopian tubes and surrounding structures. Additionally, there are metastatic deposits of the same adenocarcinoma in the uterus, rectosigmoid region, diaphragm, and right vaginal area, while lymph nodes examined show no evidence of metastatic disease. The omental tissue exhibits benign mesothelial hyperplasia, and other findings include chronic salpingitis and benign changes in the appendix and gastrocolic ligament.

The pathology report describes a 10 cm encapsulated lesion from the left adrenal gland, characterized by a yellow appearance with brown inclusions, hemorrhage, and cystic transformation. Microscopic examination reveals normal adrenal tissue alongside polygonal cells with granular inclusions and atypical cells exhibiting pleomorphic patterns. The final diagnosis is a pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of WHO-II Glioblastoma multiforme, Grade 4, from a biopsy of the right occiput, characterized by a highly cellular astrocytic neoplasm with significant nuclear pleomorphism, endothelial proliferation, and necrosis. Additionally, a craniotomy specimen revealed necrotic tissue with no viable neoplasm present. The findings were confirmed through microscopic examination and will be further evaluated with an immunoperoxidase stain for Mib-1.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the distal esophagus, which extends into the proximal stomach, with invasion into the adventitia and involvement of 3 out of 17 examined lymph nodes. The resection margins for both the esophagus and stomach are negative for carcinoma, and there is evidence of intestinal metaplasia (Barrett's esophagus) in the residual glandular mucosa. Additionally, there are metastatic adenocarcinoma findings in lymph nodes from station 17 and station 8, while other lymph nodes examined are negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with Glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV astrocytoma) based on two specimens submitted for analysis. The frozen section diagnosis revealed a highly anaplastic tumor with necrosis and reactive changes, characterized by a pleomorphic population of cells that are GFAP-immunoreactive. The tumor exhibits significant mitotic activity and vascular hyperplasia, with associated necrosis and a pronounced inflammatory response, but tests for infectious agents were negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma (UCC) with deep invasion into the muscularis propria and carcinoma in situ present at the left ureteral margin, following a radical cystectomy and hysterectomy. Examination of lymph nodes from both the right and left distal pelvic dissection revealed benign findings, with a total of 30 lymph nodes examined. Additional findings include proliferative cystitis in the non-neoplastic mucosa and chronic inflammation in the cervix, while the remaining female genital organs appeared unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right frontal brain tumor diagnosed as a glioma with atypical features and a mixed anaplastic oligoastrocytoma, with a MIB-1 proliferation index of 38%. The tumor exhibits a moderately cellular neoplastic proliferation of glial cells with areas of necrosis and microvascular proliferation, classified as WHO grade III. Immunohistochemical analysis shows sparse gliofibrilogenesis, rich vascularity, and a small percentage of cells over-expressing the p53 antigen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, grade III of IV, located in the right frontal lobe of the brain. Microscopic examination reveals a highly cellular and pleomorphic proliferation of astrocytic cells with scattered mitoses, but no evidence of endothelial proliferation or necrosis. The specimen was received as a 1.5 x 1.3 cm aggregate of soft tan-pink tissue, and the findings are consistent with a high-grade glioma.

The pathology report indicates a wedge resection of the left upper lobe revealing a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.2 x 2.2 x 1.2 cm, with focal visceral pleural invasion. The margins of resection are negative for malignancy, and there is no definitive evidence of vascular invasion or regional lymph node involvement. The specimen also shows focal fibrosis and anthracotic pigment deposition on the pleural surface.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) from a biopsy of an intra-axial lesion in the left frontal lobe of the brain, with features consistent with the small cell variant. The specimens submitted included multiple soft tissue fragments, with sizes ranging from 0.8 cm to 4.4 cm, all of which were processed for further examination. An intraoperative consultation confirmed the presence of a high-grade glioma.

The pathology report indicates a 6.5 cm keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus, classified as well-differentiated (G-1), with superficial ulceration and invasion into the muscularis propria. Metastasis was found in two out of ten examined lymph nodes, specifically one paraesophageal and one along the a. gastrica sinistra. There is no evidence of venous invasion, and the surgical margins are uninvolved, suggesting complete resection of the primary tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma measuring 2.2 cm, located in the right transglottic region, following a total laryngectomy and bilateral neck dissections. No tumor was found in any of the 46 lymph nodes examined from both neck dissections, and the thyroid tissue was also negative for tumor. Additional results regarding bone and cartilage invasion are pending decalcification and will be reported separately.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two tumors in the right kidney, both diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the clear cell type with Furhman nuclear grade II. Additionally, a specimen of fibroadipose tissue from the area over the right renal tumor was also excised. The tumors were described as large, with one measuring approximately 3.5 cm and the other slightly smaller, and both were processed for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph node and the left axillary contents show no evidence of metastasis, with 0 out of 1 and 0 out of 7 lymph nodes affected, respectively. The left breast simple mastectomy reveals an infiltrating ductal carcinoma, grade 3, measuring 3.2 cm, with negative surgical margins that are close (less than 2 mm). Microscopic examination confirms the presence of invasive carcinoma without vessel invasion or ductal carcinoma in situ.

The pathology report indicates that the left lung contains a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.5 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm, with extensive necrosis and involvement of both upper and lower lobes. Six peribronchial lymph nodes were positive for metastatic carcinoma, while multiple other lymph nodes from levels 5, 7, 9, and 10 were reactive and negative for metastatic carcinoma. The bronchial margin is free of tumor, and the overall pathologic stage is pT2 N1 Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade spindle cell sarcoma, compatible with leiomyosarcoma, located in the right foot, specifically involving the 4th and 5th metatarsal bones, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm. The tumor extends into surrounding soft tissue but the surgical resection margins are free of tumor, and no necrosis is identified. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, showing focal positivity for SMA, caldesmon, CD34, and S-100, while being negative for AE1:AE3, CD-117, and desmin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the rectum, measuring 3.4 cm in length and width, with extensive tumor budding and invasion into perirectal soft tissue. Surgical margins are free of tumor, with one out of 19 examined lymph nodes showing metastasis, leading to a staging of pT3, N1 according to AJCC criteria. The proximal and distal margins from the excision specimens are benign with no pathological findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, partially mucinous type, in the left breast, with a tumor size of 5 x 3.5 x 5.5 cm and evidence of metastases in axillary lymph nodes. Histological examination shows a grade 2 tumor with a significant presence of estrogen receptors and a positive HER2 status. The findings suggest a pT3, pN1a classification, indicating advanced disease with lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type in the right kidney, measuring 10.4 x 7.0 x 5.0 cm, with Fuhrman nuclear grade 3 and invasion into the renal vein, although the resection margins are free of tumor. The right adrenal gland shows no evidence of tumor, with gross examination revealing unremarkable adrenal cortex and medulla. Additional sections of the kidney and tumor have been submitted for further analysis and research purposes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total thyroidectomy, revealing a diagnosis of papillary microcarcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 0.4 cm in the left lobe, with clear margins and no evidence of extrathyroidal extension or vascular invasion. Additionally, the report notes the presence of a nodular thyroid and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. Molecular testing showed no mutations in BRAF, NRAS, HRAS, or KRAS, and the FISH test was negative for RET/PTC rearrangement, suggesting a lower likelihood of aggressive disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately-differentiated adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon, which has invaded through the muscularis propria and into the subserosal fat, with negative margins and metastatic carcinoma found in 5 of 24 lymph nodes. The left and right ovaries and fallopian tubes show simple adnexal cysts and unremarkable findings, while the appendix is noted to have no specific pathologic abnormalities. Overall, the report highlights the presence of significant colorectal cancer with lymph node involvement, alongside benign findings in the reproductive organs.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a liver specimen obtained from a lobectomy, with a well-defined mass measuring 9.0 x 9.0 x 7.0 cm and showing 30% necrosis. The tumor exhibits moderate to poor differentiation and is classified as trabecular type, with no evidence of portal vein invasion or intrahepatic metastasis, although microvessel invasion is noted. Additionally, the gallbladder shows signs of chronic cholecystitis, while the remaining liver parenchyma is cirrhotic with chronic hepatitis due to HCV.

The patient underwent a left partial nephrectomy due to an incidental left renal mass, which was diagnosed as clear cell renal carcinoma with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2. The tumor measured 3.8 cm and was confined within the renal capsule, with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, and all surgical margins were negative for tumor. Additionally, the peritumoral adipose tissue showed benign fibroadipose tissue with focal hemorrhage, and no malignancy was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma following an abdominal perineal resection, with the tumor invading through the muscularis propria and into peri-rectal soft tissues. The margins are mostly negative, with the carcinoma being 1 mm from the right perirectal soft tissue margin, and no lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion identified. The regional lymph nodes examined showed no metastasis, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as ypT3 pNO.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy due to acute cholecystitis, with negative findings for carcinoma in both the pancreatic duct and bile duct margins. However, the Whipple resection revealed ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreatic head/uncinate process. Additional clinical information noted obstructive jaundice and biliary dilatation, with a lesion in the liver and lymphadenopathy in the iliac region.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of tubular invasive adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as partially mucinous (G3), with a pT3 and pN1 staging, and evidence of metastases in lymph nodes. The specimen shows significant wall thickening in the pyloric region, with cancer invasion through the entire wall thickness and into surrounding fat tissue and peritoneum. Additionally, there are tumor emboli present in blood vessels, while the incision lines in the cardia and intestine are free of neoplastic lesions, and chronic gastritis is noted in the stomach.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant melanoma with superficial ulceration, located on the trunk and measuring 1.2 x 0 x 1.5 cm. The Breslow's depth is noted to be 6 mm, and the tumor margins are uninvolved, with no evidence of venous invasion. Additional details regarding lymphatic invasion and satellite nodules are not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower lobe of the lung contains a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 1.8 cm, with some lepidic growth and suspicious features for vascular invasion. A reexcision of the staple line showed no evidence of malignancy, and the pleura was also negative for cancer. The tumor is classified as pTNM stage T1a, with carcinoma present near the staple line in the initial biopsy.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast shows invasive ductal carcinoma (SBR grade 2) and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with associated necrosis, with surgical margins free of tumor and 0 out of 14 lymph nodes positive for carcinoma. In the right breast, invasive ductal carcinoma (SBR grade 2) is present with extensive DCIS and positive anterior-inferior margins infiltrating attached skeletal muscle, while 0 out of 2 sentinel lymph nodes are positive for carcinoma. Both tumors exhibit strong estrogen and progesterone receptor positivity, and Her2/neu is non-amplified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, involving both the right and left lobes, with a maximum tumor diameter of 1.6 cm and approximately 10% of the prostate volume affected. All examined lymph nodes (24 total) show no evidence of neoplasia, and the carcinoma is organ-confined with clear surgical margins, indicating no extraprostatic extension or invasion of seminal vesicles. Additionally, multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is identified, and the pathological TNM stage is pT2c, pNO, pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type) in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 4.6 cm and a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV, extending into the muscular branches of the renal vein but with free surgical margins. Additional specimens from the right adrenal gland and 11th rib show benign findings, and no malignant lymph nodes were identified in the paraaortic region. The overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is classified as pT3b due to the tumor's extension into the renal vein.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a left adrenal pheochromocytoma and an extra-adrenal paraganglioma in the para-aortic suprahilar lymph node. Additionally, infiltrating neuroendocrine carcinoma was identified in the retroperitoneum and portal vein tissue, while a well-differentiated pancreatic neuroendocrine carcinoma measuring 5 cm was found in the head of the pancreas, with negative margins and no regional lymph node metastasis. The gallbladder and several lymph nodes showed no pathological diagnosis, and the report notes the presence of multiple benign cysts in the pancreas.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left simple mastectomy revealing moderately differentiated infiltrating duct carcinoma with a total Nottingham score of 6, and rare foci of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) at the tumor's periphery. Two sentinel lymph nodes were examined, both showing multifocal metastatic breast carcinoma, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 3 mm in one node and 2 mm in the other, but without evidence of extranodal extension. The margins of excision from the breast tissue are free of tumor, and the Her-2/neu status is negative.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive lobular carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 5.7 cm, with associated intramammary and axillary metastases, including extensive involvement of 12 out of 12 examined axillary lymph nodes. The tumor exhibits lymphovascular invasion and is characterized by strong positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while Her-2/Neu amplification is negative. The report notes extracapsular extension of the metastases and confirms that the surgical margins are free of invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a thymectomy due to a diagnosis of mixed lymphocyte epithelial thymoma, which was confirmed post-operatively. The final diagnosis reveals a mixed lymphocytic and epithelial thymoma with minimal invasion, characterized by an encapsulated lobulated mass and focal necrosis. The specimen showed no normal thymic tissue and the area of induration appeared to extend to the inked margin, suggesting a need for careful follow-up.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a well-differentiated pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma located in the head of the pancreas, measuring 3.5 x 3.2 x 3.0 cm, with invasion into the retroperitoneal adipose tissue, duodenal wall, and ampulla of Vater. The surgical margins for the proximal stomach, distal duodenum, common bile duct, and pancreas are free of carcinoma, although the retroperitoneal margin is suspicious for involvement due to cautery artifact. Additionally, metastatic adenocarcinoma is identified in two of thirteen examined lymph nodes, with evidence of lymphovascular and perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located at the base of the tongue, extending to the larynx and involving the anterior deep margin, while the mucosal and tracheal margins are free of tumor. Multiple lymph nodes from both the left and right neck are reported to be free of tumor, and the anterior soft tissue margin shows smooth muscle with no tumor present. The tumor is characterized by an ulcerated mass measuring 5.5 cm, with involvement of the epiglottis and surrounding structures, but sparing the glottic and infraglottic spaces.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma in the left ovary, with evidence of ovarian surface involvement and tumor extension into the left fallopian tube. Additionally, metastatic high-grade serous carcinoma is present in the bladder peritoneum and the omentum, while the uterus and right ovary show serous carcinoma involvement but the right ovary is unremarkable and negative for malignancy. Peritoneal washing is positive for malignant cells, confirming the presence of cancerous activity in the peritoneal cavity.

The pathology report indicates that all examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic dissections are negative for carcinoma. The radical prostatectomy specimen reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4 (total score 9), showing bilateral involvement, extraprostatic extension, and invasion into the right seminal vesicle, but with negative surgical margins. Additional findings include lymphovascular invasion and perineural infiltration, with a final staging of pT3bNO.

The pathology report indicates a 4 x 3 x 0.4 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma located at the cardia of the stomach, classified as poorly differentiated. The tumor has invaded the muscularis propria and has metastasized to all four examined lymph nodes. Additionally, there is evidence of invasion into the esophagus.

The pathology report indicates a 3.8 cm moderately differentiated papillary renal cell carcinoma with resection margins that are tumor-free. Additional findings include glomerulosclerosis, interstitial nephritis, and massive arteriosclerosis. The tumor is classified as pT1a, with lymph nodes and distant metastasis not assessed, and is graded as GII.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligoastrocytoma, classified as grade II according to the World Health Organization (WHO) grading system. The tumor is localized in the right parietal region of the brain. The patient is male.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in the right posterior section of the liver, measuring 3.1x2.7x2.5 cm, with a histologic grade of 3 for the worst differentiation and 2 for major differentiation. There is no evidence of satellite nodules, vascular invasion, or metastasis in the lymph nodes, and the surgical margins are clear with a safety margin of 1.0 cm. Additional findings include a lipoma in the small bowel mesentery and no abnormalities in the gallbladder.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has infiltrating adenocarcinoma of ductal type in the right breast, with a histologic grade of 3 and nuclear grade of 2 to 3. The tumor measures at least 6.0 cm and shows lymphatic/vascular invasion, with carcinoma extending to the surgical margin multifocally; one out of 23 lymph nodes examined is positive for carcinoma. Estrogen and progesterone receptor analyses are negative, and the proliferation index is high at 70%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, with the primary tumor located in the left lobe measuring 3.5 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm and a microscopic focus of 2 mm in the right lobe. There is evidence of metastatic involvement in all examined perithyroidal lymph nodes and a lymph node with cystic metastasis. The tumor is classified as low-grade, with no lymphatic or vascular invasion, and is confined to the thyroid.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed adenocarcinoma in the lower lobe of the lung, characterized by a predominant acinar component and a smaller large-cell solid component with bronchioloalveolar growth patterns. The tumor shows slight mucin formation and significant lymph vessel propagation, having infiltrated the visceral pleura and extended to the basal margin of the specimen. The tumor classification is pT2 pNX pMX L1 RX, with localization code C34.3 and morphology code M8255/3, pending verification by immunohistological analysis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade urothelial carcinoma with mixed histologic features, including keratinizing squamous and small cell/neuroendocrine components, primarily located in a bladder diverticulum. The tumor exhibits invasive growth into perivesical soft tissues, with identified vascular and perineural invasion, while surgical margins are free of tumor. Additional specimens from the right vas deferens and pelvic lymph nodes show benign findings, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3 due to invasion of perivesical soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lymph nodes from both the right and left paraaortic and pelvic regions are negative for malignancy. A radical hysterectomy revealed an endometrioid adenocarcinoma, Grade 3, confined to the inner half of the myometrium with no cervical involvement or lymphovascular invasion, and surgical margins are free of malignancy. Additionally, benign findings such as hyperplastic endometrial polyps and fibromyomata were noted, with the overall pTNM stage classified as pT1a, N0.

The pathology report indicates that biopsies from the right and left ureters show reactive endothelium with no evidence of dysplasia or carcinoma. A radical cystoprostatectomy revealed high-grade urothelial carcinoma with extensive squamous differentiation, invading perivesical adipose tissue, but surgical margins were free of carcinoma. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes dissected from various regions were negative for metastatic carcinoma, confirming no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive well-differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cervix, with margins of excision free of cancer. The tumor shows focal lymphovascular invasion and extends into the lower uterine segment, but there is no evidence of malignancy in the examined lymph nodes. Additional findings include focal endometriosis and acute inflammation in the left fallopian tube, with no significant abnormalities noted in the myometrium or other examined tissues.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma at the gastroesophageal junction, measuring 12.70 cm, with ulceration and invasion into the mucosa, muscularis mucosae, submucosa, muscularis propria, and adjacent adipose tissue. Neural infiltration and sanguineous vascular invasion are noted, with one out of twenty-three lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement. The pathological staging is classified as pT3 pN1, with all margins (proximal, distal, and esophageal) free of neoplastic involvement.

The pathology report indicates a 1 cm mucinous carcinoma of the breast, classified as moderately differentiated (G-2), with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. Two examined lymph nodes showed no metastasis, and immunohistochemical staining revealed high positivity for estrogen (98%) and progesterone receptors (95%), while Her-2/neu was negative. The tumor is categorized as T1, with a Ki67 proliferation index of 12%, suggesting a low growth rate.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in a right adrenal mass, with areas suggestive of divergent differentiation. Immunohistochemical studies showed positive results for Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and S-100, while being negative for C-Kit and NFTP. The specimen was a large nodular tissue mass, measuring 8.7 x 6.1 x 3.6 cm, with additional normal adrenal tissue present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of eosinophilic variant of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma in a right kidney partial nephrectomy specimen, with a tumor size of 3.8 cm and a histologic grade of Fuhrman 2. The tumor is unifocal and exhibits capsular invasion without penetrating the renal capsule or involving perirenal adipose tissue, with surgical margins being negative but close to the tumor. The AJCC staging is pT1a, and there are no significant pathologic abnormalities noted in the non-neoplastic kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 28 x 22 x 12 cm, with focal necrosis and a mitotic index of 28 mitoses per 10 high power fields, but with negative margins. Additional specimens from the left broad ligament, distal small bowel, and sigmoid colon revealed benign findings, including a benign ovary, fallopian tube, and segments of bowel. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma, with tumor cells positive for SMA and desmin, and negative for HMB-45.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of gastric adenocarcinoma located at the cardia of the stomach, with a tumor size of 6.0 cm and ulceration present, classified as tubular (intestinal type) with a histologic grade of 2. The tumor has infiltrated the mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria, and perivisceral fat, extending to the esophageal mucosa, but there is no evidence of neural, lymphatic, or blood vascular invasion. Surgical margins and all examined lymph nodes (27 total) are free of neoplastic involvement.

The pathology report indicates that a left hemiglossectomy revealed moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.7 cm, with perineural invasion and severe dysplasia at the lateral margin, but final margins were free of invasive carcinoma. Additionally, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was found in three of the examined lymph nodes, with one node showing extracapsular spread. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3 N2b, indicating advanced disease with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma in a left frontal brain tumor, characterized by high histological grade and significant cellular proliferation with a MIB-1 proliferation index of 40%. Microscopic examination reveals extensive infiltration, nuclear anaplasia, brisk mitotic activity, and areas of tumor necrosis with pseudopalisading. The findings are consistent with a small cell glioblastoma classified as WHO grade IV, and molecular testing results are pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the epiglottis, measuring 2.3 cm, with involvement of the anterior commissure, false vocal folds, and focal extension into the epiglottic cartilage, while most margins are negative for malignancy. Additionally, one of the 40 lymph nodes from the right neck dissection is involved with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while all other lymph nodes examined from the left neck and other margins are negative for malignancy. The findings correspond to AJCC 6th Edition Pathologic Stage III (pT3N1M0).

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated diffuse type adenocarcinoma of the stomach located at the cardia, measuring 6 cm and invading the subserosa. Ten examined lymph nodes showed no evidence of metastasis, and the surgical margins are uninvolved. The omentum appears normal, and there is no indication of lymphatic or venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left lung, specifically in the lingula and medial segment of the left lower lobe, with a tumor size of 2.4 x 1.9 x 1.4 cm. There is evidence of visceral pleural invasion and angiolymphatic invasion, with the tumor being less than 1 mm from the parenchymal resection margin. The report also notes that the specimen integrity was disrupted, and no regional lymph node involvement was assessed.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) in the left breast, characterized by multiple foci spanning approximately 6 cm, along with extensive lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). Among the sentinel lymph nodes examined from the left axilla, one node showed evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the form of microscopic clusters, while the other two nodes were benign. The right breast tissue revealed benign changes with focal atypical ductal hyperplasia, and no involvement of the nipple or vascular/perineural invasion was noted in the left breast carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, characterized by a mixture of clear and eosinophilic cells, with focal rhabdoid features and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4. The tumor measures 6.3 cm and extends into the renal sinus adipose tissue, with evidence of vascular and lymphatic invasion, although surgical margins, including the adrenal gland, are free of tumor. The specimen was part of a nephrectomy, and additional tumor and normal tissue samples were submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the urinary bladder, which has invaded through the muscularis propria and into the perivesical tissue, with a tumor size of 1.5 cm and ulceration. All examined lymph nodes (30 total) and other specimens, including the uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, and distal right ureter, showed no evidence of tumor. The final staging of the bladder cancer is pT3b, N0, MX, indicating significant local invasion but no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with associated extensive ulceration and lymphovascular invasion, classified as pT3bN2MX. Additionally, a focus of well-differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma was identified in the uterus, with no cervical or myometrial involvement, and all surgical margins were free of malignancy. Metastatic urothelial carcinoma was found in two of the 86 lymph nodes examined, while the ureters and other examined tissues were reported as benign with no dysplasia or malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated, slightly keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe, with a maximum tumor size of 3.6 cm and evidence of peripheral spread. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, revealing lesions with anthracotic pigment deposits, but all resection margins and excised lymph nodes were tumor-free. Additionally, there is moderate centrocinar pulmonary emphysema and a need for further investigations to assess asbestos exposure, as no asbestos bodies were found in the examined sections.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in Barrett's epithelium of the distal esophagus, with a tumor size of 4 cm in maximal diameter. Out of 13 examined lymph nodes, 2 are positive for tumor involvement. The report notes that a radical resection was performed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma from a left brain tumor specimen in a Caucasian male. The tumor is classified as grade 3, and no treatment has been administered at this time. Additional blood samples were taken for normal analysis, but no significant findings were reported.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes (levels 2, 4, 7, 10, and 11) were biopsied and all were negative for carcinoma. The left lower lobe lung resection revealed an invasive adenocarcinoma, well differentiated, measuring 4.0 x 3.8 x 2.2 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of pleural invasion or direct extension. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT2a pNO, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, appendix, uterus, bilateral ovaries, fallopian tubes, sigmoid tumor, and a right groin lymph node. The ovarian tumors exhibit extensive lymphovascular invasion, with the largest tumor measuring 15 cm and evidence of extravasation and surface involvement. The overall staging is classified as FIGO stage IIIC, indicating advanced disease with lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial serous adenocarcinoma with significant myometrial invasion (3.8 cm) and involvement of the cervix and left ovary, along with metastatic carcinoma found in all examined pelvic and periaortic lymph nodes. Additional findings include leiomyomata in the uterus and a fibrothecoma in the right ovary. The pathological staging is classified as pT3a, pN2 (FIGO IIIC2), indicating advanced disease with lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows no signs of calculi, inflammation, or malignancy, while the liver specimen reveals a solitary hepatocellular carcinoma, grade III/IV, measuring 2.5 cm, with clear resection margins and no vascular invasion. The liver parenchyma exhibits moderate steatosis, chronic hepatitis, and per portal fibrosis, but no cirrhosis is present. Additionally, a cholesterol polyp was identified in the gallbladder mucosa, with no dysplasia or significant inflammation noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, with tumor involvement in the anterior and posterior endometrium and extension to the endocervix. It is classified as FIGO grade 3, with a maximum depth of invasion of 1.1 cm and evidence of lymphatic invasion, while parametrial tissue and bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are uninvolved. The tumor is staged as pT2, pNO, and pM n/a according to the AJCC/UICC TNM 7th edition.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the transverse colon with infiltration into the perimuscular fatty tissue, classified as pT3. Among 21 lymph nodes examined, one shows metastatic involvement, leading to a staging of pT3 pN1 (4/21) L0 V0 R0. The resection margins are tumor-free, suggesting complete removal of the primary tumor.

The pathology report indicates that both the right and left sentinel lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. The left breast lumpectomy reveals papillary carcinoma in situ with surrounding ductal carcinoma in situ, while the right breast lumpectomy shows infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated, with associated lobular carcinoma in situ. The invasive carcinoma in the right breast is close to the surgical margins, with microcalcifications identified in both ductal carcinoma in situ and benign breast tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma originating from the lung, with evidence of malignant pleural effusion and invasion into the chest wall and skin. Multiple specimens were analyzed, confirming high-grade neoplasm in pleural tissue and chest wall fistulas, with the tumor exhibiting specific immunohistochemical markers consistent with lung adenocarcinoma. The final pTNM staging is T4 N0 Mx, indicating advanced local disease without regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 4.0 cm, with underlying focal chronic thyroiditis in the thyroid tissue. Additionally, metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma was identified in 4 out of 30 examined regional lymph nodes, specifically in the central compartment. No pathological diagnosis was made for the parathyroid and several lymph node specimens, indicating they were unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows no significant abnormalities, while the pancreaticoduodenectomy specimen reveals an intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm with high-grade dysplasia and a well-differentiated invasive ductal adenocarcinoma measuring 1.0 cm. The tumor is confined to the pancreas with no regional lymph node metastasis, and all surgical margins are free of malignancy. Additionally, there is evidence of chronic pancreatitis and perineural invasion present in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of polymorphocellular undifferentiated breast carcinoma, grade II, with a maximum tumor diameter of 2.8 cm, exhibiting infiltrative growth and marked chronic inflammation. There is evidence of lymph vessel invasion and metastasis to the axillary lymph nodes, extending beyond the capsule into surrounding soft tissue. The tumor is classified as G II, pT2pN1a(1/14), with negative estrogen and progesterone receptors and positive C-erb B-2 oncoprotein.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade III endometrial adenocarcinoma, measuring 3.5 x 2.0 x 0.8 cm, with mixed endometrial and clear cell types, invading 0.4 cm into the myometrium, but not involving the endocervix, and with negative margins. Additionally, the left ovary and fallopian tube show a 3.2 x 2.7 x 2.2 cm mass of adenocarcinoma, also FIGO grade III, with tumor implants present on the right ovary and uterine cul de sac, and a single right pelvic lymph node is positive for tumor. Other lymph nodes and tissues examined, including the left pelvic lymph nodes, omentum, and gonadal vessels, were negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in the liver, characterized by a nodular mass measuring 6.5x4 cm with moderate differentiation and an adenoid-trabecular structure. The gall bladder shows no signs of infiltration, and the wall is noted to be pale brown with a thickness of 0.2 cm. Additionally, there are no signs of tumor growth in the lymphatic nodes or adjacent tissues.

The pathology report indicates a right renal mass diagnosed as conventional (clear cell) renal carcinoma, measuring 3.0 x 3.7 x 2.1 cm, located at the upper to mid pole of the right kidney. The tumor is confined to the kidney with no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, transcapsular extension, or invasion into the renal vein or vena cava, and all surgical margins are negative. Additional findings include interstitial chronic inflammation, with a final TNM staging of pT1a, Nx, Mx.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the right and left pelvic lymph nodes, but prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+5=10 was identified in the prostate gland, with extraprostatic extension and involvement of multiple resection margins. The tumor is described as invading the capsule at several locations and showing perineural infiltration, while the seminal vesicles were free of tumor. Additionally, vascular invasion was noted, and the overall staging is classified as pT3aN0M0 with R1 margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with a tumor diameter of 2.2 cm and focal intraductal components. The tumor is classified as NOS, grade III, and staged as pT2N1aLOVORO. This classification suggests a moderate to high-grade malignancy with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of mixed epithelial type in both the left and right ovaries, with metastatic adenocarcinoma identified in the fallopian tubes, uterus, parovarian soft tissue, omentum, and periaortic lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IIIB, indicating macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis, and is characterized by solid nests of poorly differentiated cells with areas of papillary serous and endometrioid differentiation. Immunohistochemical staining for Her2neu and C-kit was negative, suggesting a lack of expression of these markers in the carcinoma cells.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph nodes examined were negative for neoplasm, while a segment of the right lower lobe of the lung revealed a mucinous adenocarcinoma with acinar predominance, measuring 7.5 x 6.4 x 4.7 cm, and showing lymphatic invasion but no vascular invasion. Additionally, there was evidence of organizing acute fibrinous pleuritis and extensive chronic bronchiolitis with rare non-necrotizing granulomas in the lung tissue. The tumor invades the visceral pleura but is not present at the pleural surface, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as p Stage IIIA (T3 N0 Mx).

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.2 x 1.4 x 0.9 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising 70% of the tumor volume. The tumor is classified as NHG1, with estrogen receptors present in 75% and progesterone receptors in 10% of the neoplastic cell nuclei, while HER2 testing shows a negative reaction. The breast tissue examined shows parenchymal atrophy, and there are no lesions in the nipple.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the right tonsil reveals invasive poorly-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The specimen measured 0.7 x 0.7 x 0.6 cm and was described as soft tissue with a white and light-tan appearance, including a small area of bright red. The biopsy was performed following a direct laryngoscopy due to a right oropharyngeal lesion.

The pathology report indicates a well-differentiated pancreatic endocrine tumor located in the distal pancreas, measuring 4 x 3.5 x 3.5 cm, with no tumor necrosis and a low mitotic rate. The tumor shows venous/lymphatic vessel invasion but no perineural invasion, and it is positive for low molecular weight cytokeratin and glucagon, while negative for insulin. The spleen shows no significant pathological changes, and regional lymph nodes are negative for tumor, with the overall pathologic stage classified as T2N0MX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in two out of six lymph nodes from a central compartment selective dissection, with no extranodal extension noted. A total thyroidectomy revealed multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma, with the largest focus measuring 1.2 cm and exhibiting extrathyroid extension, while margins were uninvolved by carcinoma. Additionally, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis was observed, and the pathologic stage is classified as pT3a N1.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma infiltrating bone in the right maxillectomy specimen, with deeply invasive characteristics. Additionally, metastatic squamous carcinoma was identified in 2 out of 10 lymph nodes from the right suprahyoid neck dissection, while other examined tissues, including the submandibular gland and various muscle samples, showed no tumor presence. The report also notes invasive squamous carcinoma in the pterygoid margin and connective tissue, with no tumor detected in several other areas examined.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrioid adenocarcinoma (Grade 1) in the uterus, with no myometrial or endocervical invasion and no lymphovascular invasion identified. Additionally, all excised lymph nodes from the sentinel and left iliac regions were reported as benign, with no evidence of metastatic disease. A benign endocervical polyp was also noted in the findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of undifferentiated carcinoma of the endometrium, with a tumor size of 10 cm and full thickness invasion through the myometrium to the serosal surface. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in one of ten left pelvic lymph nodes and one of seven right pelvic lymph nodes, while the cervix was free of tumor and no malignancy was found in the omentum or sigmoid mesentery. The tumor is classified as FIGO grade 3 of 3, indicating a poorly differentiated carcinoma with significant lymphatic and vascular invasion.

The supplemental pathology report indicates that decalcified sections of the anterior mandibular resection margin and the condyle of the right mandible are free of carcinoma, while the original diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma involving the right mandible and associated soft tissues remains unchanged. The report highlights perineural invasion and metastatic squamous carcinoma present in 14 of 24 lymph nodes, with the largest lymph node showing significant involvement. The tumor measures 8.5 x 8.5 x 8.0 cm and diffusely involves the right buccal space, mandible, and floor of mouth soft tissue, but final margins of excision for certain areas are free of tumor.

The pathology report describes a mildly hypercellular glial neoplasm, primarily composed of cells with round to oval nuclei, but lacking classic oligodendroglioma differentiation and showing scattered atypical cells. No mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis are observed, and the margins are negative for neoplastic infiltration. The final diagnosis is a low-grade oligoastrocytoma, predominantly oligodendroglioma, with some areas showing moderate proliferation that raises concern for early anaplastic progression, although the overall histologic features do not classify it as Grade III/anaplastic.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of predominantly undifferentiated bilateral adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, a maximum tumor diameter of 3.3 cm, and evidence of lymphatic invasion (L1) but no vascular invasion (V0). The tumor has infiltrated periprostatic fatty tissue and the left seminal vesicle, with multifocal involvement of perineural sheaths, while all examined lymph nodes (0/8) and colon resection material are tumor-free. Additional immunohistochemical studies are ongoing to further clarify the vascular status, with results to be presented in a follow-up report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary serous adenocarcinoma of the ovary, measuring 11 cm, with surface extension and associated atypical hyperplasia in the fallopian tubes. There are surface implants of the carcinoma in the ovary and invasive carcinoma found in the omental adipose tissue, but no lymphovascular invasion or metastatic tumor in the examined lymph nodes. Additional findings include disordered proliferative endometrium, adenomyosis, leiomyomata, and chronic inflammation with squamous metaplasia in the cervix.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a seroma capsule with fibrous tissue and chronic inflammation, but no tumor was found in that specimen. In the total thyroidectomy and tracheal resection, a papillary carcinoma of the thyroid was identified, involving the left lobe and invading the trachea, with tumor extension to the soft tissue margins but no lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Additionally, metastatic papillary carcinoma was found in one of two left paratracheal lymph nodes, with no extranodal extension noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 3, with myometrial involvement and lymphatic vascular space involvement, but no cervical or lymph node involvement was detected (0/27 lymph nodes negative). The surgical procedure included a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and the margins were free of tumor, with the omentum also showing no evidence of tumor. Additional findings included chronic inflammation of the cervix, focal atypical hyperplasia in the endometrium, and adenomyosis in the myometrium, with the left ovary showing atrophic changes and small cysts.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a grade II leiomyosarcoma in the mesentery associated with a segment of the sigmoid colon, with no lymphovascular invasion and tumor present at the circumferential margin. Additionally, a fatty tumor in the left buttock is identified as a lipoma, while the right and left fallopian tubes and ovaries show no significant pathological changes aside from benign cysts. The uterus exhibits a leiomyoma and endometrial stromal nodules, with the overall findings suggesting a normal karyotype for the sarcoma sample.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive serous adenocarcinoma primarily affecting the right fallopian tube and ovary, with the tumor measuring up to 3.5 cm in the tube and 3 cm in the ovary, classified as FIGO grade 3/3. Additionally, there are multiple metastatic foci of serous adenocarcinoma in the omentum, with the largest lesion measuring 10 cm, and peritoneal washing reveals malignant cells consistent with serous carcinoma. The overall staging is pT3c, Nx, Mx, corresponding to FIGO stage IIIc, suggesting a significant involvement of the fallopian tube with some carcinoma in situ, indicating a possible fallopian tube origin of the cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary and fallopian tube show atrophic changes with an ovarian fibroma and multiple paratubal cysts, while the left ovary also has atrophic changes with larger ovarian fibromata and paratubal cysts, with no evidence of malignancy in either side. The rectum reveals moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that has invaded through the muscularis propria into perirectal adipose tissue, but the resection margins are free of malignancy, and no tumor was found in the examined lymph nodes. Additionally, the right colon shows a similar moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with full-thickness invasion and free margins, while the gallbladder exhibits chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma (grade 3) with micropapillary features, comprising 15% of the tumor, and invasive into the muscularis propria, with lymphovascular invasion present. Additionally, prostatic tissue shows stromal nodular hyperplasia, which is negative for adenocarcinoma. The gross examination revealed multiple fragments of soft tissue from the bladder tumor, measuring a total of 8.0 x 7.5 x 4.5 cm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), affecting approximately 40% of the prostate gland and showing focal extraprosthetic extension at the right mid prostate. The bilateral seminal vesicles are negative for tumor involvement, but there is focal extension to the surgical resection margin of the right mid prostate. The pathological staging is classified as pT3a, with no lymph nodes sampled and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) noted as an additional finding.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, FIGO grade II, with a maximum depth of invasion of 6 mm and focal vascular space invasion. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in the right ovary, while the left ovary showed physiological changes without tumor. All examined lymph nodes from various regions were negative for tumor involvement, indicating no lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma of the clear cell type, measuring 10x8x6 cm, with ill-defined margins and invasion into the fibrous stroma. Microscopic examination reveals trabecular and acinar patterns, abundant clear or basophilic cytoplasm, irregularly large hyperchromatic nuclei, and the presence of mitoses and inflammatory cells. The tumor was found in a wedge resection of liver tissue, with uninvolved margins and no specified details on lymph nodes or venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) in both breasts, with the left breast showing a mixed mucinous type measuring 2.3 cm and a second focus of in situ and invasive carcinoma measuring 0.9 cm, while the right breast has IDC measuring 4.6 cm. Sentinel lymph node biopsies from the left axilla revealed metastatic carcinoma in one of four nodes, while all nodes from the right axilla were benign. Immunohistochemical analysis showed negative estrogen and progesterone receptors, with the left breast tumor being HER2 positive and the right breast tumor being HER2 negative.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the right adnexa with a large papillary serous carcinoma, and involvement of the uterus, colon, and diaphragm. Lymph node biopsies show positive results for metastatic adenocarcinoma in several nodes, while the left common iliac lymph node is negative for neoplasm. The overall pathological staging is pT3c pN1 pMX, indicating advanced disease with significant spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, classified as NHG2, with a tumor size of 1.6 x 1.2 x 1.8 cm and evidence of metastasis in the axillary lymph nodes. The immunohistochemical examination shows estrogen receptors present in 75% of the neoplastic cell nuclei and progesterone receptors in 10%, with a HER2 score of 2+, suggesting further verification is needed. The specimen was obtained from a right breast resection, and the tumor is located near the outer quadrants, with specific measurements provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma (grade III) in the uterus and cervix, with a tumor size of 6.5 x 6.5 x 3.0 cm and evidence of lymphovascular invasion. Staging reveals T1c, N1 (Stage IIIC), with metastasis identified in 1 of 3 right pelvic lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes and adnexa are free of tumor. Additional findings include adenomyosis, and no tumor was detected in the omentum, pelvic biopsies, or abdominal wall biopsies.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of lung cancer, specifically a well-differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma located in the left upper lobe, measuring 3.5 x 3.2 x 1.6 cm, with no evidence of visceral pleural invasion or lymphovascular space invasion. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, and all showed reactive changes with no metastatic carcinoma identified in any of the sampled nodes. Additional findings include emphysematous changes and subpleural fibrosis, suggesting the tumor is likely a primary lung neoplasm, although the possibility of a metastatic lesion cannot be completely ruled out.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe wedge biopsy revealed invasive, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.0 cm, while the subsequent lobectomy showed no residual carcinoma and negative bronchial margins. Both the right and left lymph node biopsies were negative for carcinoma, with a total of nine lymph nodes examined showing no malignancy. The overall pathological staging is pT1, N0, Mx, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the anterior lymph node and anterior apex show no tumor presence, while one of eleven left pelvic lymph nodes is positive for metastatic carcinoma. The prostate contains prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3) and shows invasion into the left seminal vesicle and focal extraprostatic extension, but the resection margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the right pelvic lymph nodes are negative for tumor, and there is high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia noted.

The pathology report indicates that the liver biopsy is negative for malignancy and shows no intrinsic liver disease. A subtotal gastrectomy reveals poorly differentiated diffuse type adenocarcinoma with metastasis in 14 out of 30 perigastric lymph nodes, classified as pathologic stage pT4aN3a. Additionally, a peripancreatic lymph node biopsy shows a benign peritoneal cyst, and the omentum is negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that no in situ or invasive carcinoma was identified in the urethra or lymph nodes, with a total of seven lymph nodes showing no malignancy. The cystoprostatectomy revealed a high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma measuring 8.5 cm, invading the lamina propria of the bladder and prostatic ducts, with associated urothelial carcinoma in situ. Surgical margins were negative for malignancy, and immunohistochemical stains confirmed the benign nature of prostatic glands.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the floor of the mouth, moderately differentiated with keratinization, and shows extensive perineural invasion with a maximum depth of invasion of 1.7 cm. In the right neck dissection, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was found in one of three lymph nodes at level II and in one lymph node at the mental triangle, with extra-capsular extension identified in five of forty-one lymph nodes overall. Resection margins were free of tumor, and the salivary gland and other excised tissues were unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the left kidney mass is diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, measuring 7.5 cm, with no definitive extrarenal extension and clear vascular and ureteral margins. The para-aortic lymph nodes were excised, and no tumor was found in any of the 33 lymph nodes examined. Cytogenetic analysis revealed an abnormal mosaic karyotype, with findings including missing the Y chromosome and an extra copy of chromosome 7 in some cells.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma (not otherwise specified) in the left upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 6.5 x 6.5 x 5.0 cm. There is no infiltration of the visceral pleura, and the tumor is classified as pT2b, pN1 (6/28), pMx, G3. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the tumor cells are positive for CK7 and have a Ki-67 proliferation index of 40%, while being negative for several other markers.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a large mass measuring 22.0 x 15.3 x 12.8 cm, with surgical margins free of tumor by at least 1.1 cm. Additionally, a large subcapsular hematoma was noted, while the pericholedochal lymph node was negative for tumor involvement. The gallbladder showed mild chronic cholecystitis with cholesterolosis and a benign cystic duct lymph node.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type located in the ascending colon, with extensive infiltration into the pericolic fatty tissue and two regional lymph node metastases. The resection margins of the large and small bowel, mesentery, appendix, and omental fat tissue are all tumor-free. Additionally, a small tubular adenoma with slight dysplasia was identified in the colonic mucosa, and the tumor staging is pT3 pN1 (2/28) pMX; G2, L0, V0 R0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade II, with invasive depth of 2.5 cm into the myometrium, but with clear parametrial resection margins and no evidence of malignancy in the bilateral fallopian tubes and ovaries. The cervix shows acute and chronic cervicitis with squamous metaplasia, but no malignancy is present, and all examined pelvic lymph nodes (28 total) are free of cancer. Additional findings include endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) and leiomyomas, with the primary tumor classified as pT1b and no distant metastasis detected.

The pathology report indicates that the liver biopsy revealed benign calcified hyaline nodules, while the subtotal gastrectomy showed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the stomach with intestinal metaplasia and marked chronic inflammation. The tumor measured 3.0 x 3.0 x 1.0 cm and invaded the subserosa, but there was no evidence of malignancy in the examined lymph nodes (0/15). The provisional pathologic staging is pT2b NO MX, indicating tumor invasion without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme based on the examination of multiple tissue fragments from a brain biopsy. Microscopic analysis reveals high-grade glioma features, including hypercellularity, cellular pleomorphism, and necrosis, consistent with glioblastoma. The MIB-1 proliferation index of the tumor cells is approximately 10%.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in two lymph nodes (R4 and R10) with a 4 mm focus, while one lymph node (high R4) and two others (P3 and Station 7) were negative for tumor involvement. A lobectomy of the right upper lung lobe revealed a 7.5 cm poorly differentiated adenosquamous carcinoma, with metastasis found in 3 of 9 examined lymph nodes. Additionally, no mutations were detected in the EGFR or KRAS genes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse malignant mesothelioma, mixed epithelioid and sarcomatous type, with significant invasion into surrounding structures, but no lymph node metastases were found, resulting in a pathologic stage of T3 N0 Mx. Additional biopsies from various sites, including the chest wall and lymph nodes, revealed no evidence of malignancy, with findings such as suture granulomas and reactive changes. The report also notes that the underlying lung tissue shows no signs of asbestosis, and bone samples from the right ribs demonstrate normal bone and marrow without malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated large-cell nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma located primarily in the right lower lobe of the lung, classified as stage IB. The examination revealed extensive tumor involvement with associated chronic inflammation and pleuritis, but no infiltration of the visceral pleura or tumor presence in the resection margins and lymph nodes. Although no asbestos bodies were identified, further investigations are recommended to assess potential asbestos exposure.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma with medullary-like features in the upper inner quadrant of the breast, classified as Nottingham grade III. The tumor measures 2.7 x 2.5 x 2.0 cm and shows no evidence of ductal carcinoma in situ or angiolymphatic invasion, with all surgical margins negative for tumor. Additionally, a sentinel lymph node biopsy from the left axilla is negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report describes a moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm characterized by round nuclei and a small population of fibrillary astrocytes, with little atypia and no mitotic figures. The tumor infiltrates both gray and white matter, showing a modest proliferative index of 2.2%, consistent with low-grade features. The final diagnosis is a low-grade oligoastrocytoma, with an oligodendroglioma predominance.

The pathology report indicates a lobectomy specimen from the lung, revealing a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with a tumor size of 6 x 6 x 6 cm. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes, with 0 out of 1 node positive. Additional details regarding tumor extent, invasion, and margins were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive keratinizing squamous carcinoma (G2) of the larynx, specifically affecting the left side and infiltrating the subglottic region, vessels, and nerve stems. The surgical specimen measured 9x7x5.5 cm and contained a tumor sized 2.2x2.3x0.9 cm. The report notes that the surgical incision lines are in contact with the cancer-invaded area, and a final diagnosis will be provided after further examination of the material.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the distal esophagus and proximal stomach, with a tumor size of 7.8 cm and evidence of invasion into the mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria, and adventitia. The circumferential margin is involved by invasive carcinoma, while the proximal and distal margins, as well as the margin of the stomach, are uninvolved. Out of eight regional lymph nodes examined, three were positive for neoplasia, while six lymph nodes from the hepatic artery were negative.

The pathology report indicates a resected colon (sigma) sample containing a tubular adenoma with moderate dysplasia and a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that has infiltrated the lamina muscularis propria. The resection margins are tumor-free, and there is no evidence of local lymph node metastasis. The tumor classification is G2, pT2, with no vascular invasion or residual tumor, as indicated by the findings (V0 R0 pNO 0/15).

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma, with the largest tumor measuring 3.2 cm in the left lobe and one of three lymph nodes involved with metastatic disease. No malignancy was identified in the biopsies of the parathyroid tissues or the lymph node from the right superior thyroid. The report also notes the presence of multinodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, with negative surgical margins and no evidence of extra-thyroidal extension or vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma involving the base of the tongue, epiglottis, supraglottic mucosa, and pre-epiglottic space, with a tumor size of 5 x 4.5 x 1.7 cm and invasion up to 1.7 cm. Metastatic squamous carcinoma was identified in 1 of 25 right neck lymph nodes and 2 of 20 left neck lymph nodes, with significant extranodal extension noted in some of the affected nodes. No tumor was found in the hyoid bone, right and left submandibular glands, or the new left lateral pharyngeal margin.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with malignant biphasic mesothelioma, primarily affecting the right pleura, pericardium, and diaphragm, with a maximum tumor thickness of 3.5 cm. No tumor was found in the examined lymph nodes, confirming the absence of regional lymph node metastasis (pN0). The tumor is classified as pT4, indicating locally advanced disease that is technically unresectable, with significant invasion into the pleura and diaphragm but no venous or lymphatic invasion detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous adenocarcinoma, grade 2, primarily affecting the right ovary and fallopian tube, with tumor involvement noted in the omentum and small bowel mesentery. The tumor is characterized by a size of approximately 1.1 cm in the fallopian tube and less than 1 mm penetration into the ovarian wall, with metastatic foci identified in various tissues. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3c pNX pM1, indicating advanced disease with uncertain primary location, predominantly peritoneal in nature.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma primarily located at the base of the tongue, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and extensive involvement of surrounding tissues, including the larynx. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was identified in 45 out of 91 lymph nodes, with significant extranodal extension noted. Additional biopsies from various sites, including the hypoglossal nerve and tonsils, were negative for tumor, while infiltrating squamous cells were found in the left base of the tongue mucosa.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, characterized by 90% clear cells and 10% eosinophilic cells, with a Fuhrman's nuclear grade of 3, and the tumor measures 9.5 cm in greatest dimension. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with clear margins and no invasion into surrounding structures, while the adrenal gland shows nodular cortical hyperplasia. Additionally, a possible hilar lymph node was noted, measuring 1.7 x 0.9 x 0.9 cm, and portions of the tumor have been submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of intestinal adenocarcinoma located in the stomach (antrum), with a tumor size of 7.5 cm and classified as grade III. The tumor has invaded the duodenum and involved the omentum, with a pathological classification of T4a and N3a, while clinical metastasis is noted as M0. Additionally, the tumor contains a mucinous component that comprises less than 50% of the total tumor.

The pathology report indicates that all three specimens (omentum, left ovary, and peritoneal deposit) contain viable poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma, with the omental tumor classified as metastatic FIGO grade 3, stage 3B. The left ovary shows tumor involvement reaching the capsule and into the ovarian ligament, while the peritoneal deposit measures 11 mm across and is surrounded by fibrotic tissue. Lymphatic invasion is present, but there is no evidence of vascular invasion in the examined specimens.
The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligoastrocytoma, classified as grade III according to the WHO. The tumor is located in the right frontal region. The patient is male.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right temporal lobe tumor diagnosed as a mixed oligoastrocytoma, anaplastic (WHO grade III), characterized by extensive cellular infiltration, brisk mitotic activity, and focal necrosis. Molecular testing revealed no evidence of EGFR variant III mutation, allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, or methylation of the MGMT promoter. An addendum suggests the possibility of a high-grade oligoastrocytoma transitioning to glioblastoma, grade IV, and recommends clinical correlation for treatment considerations.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of unclassified renal cell carcinoma, nuclear grade III/IV, in the left kidney, with a tumor measuring 11 cm that extends through the renal capsule but is confined within Gerota's fascia, and no invasion of the renal vein is identified. Additionally, a 1.7 cm adrenocortical adenoma is noted in the left adrenal gland, while all examined lymph nodes and retroperitoneal fat are benign. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the pleura and multiple lymph nodes excised are negative for malignancy. However, a lobectomy of the right upper lobe of the lung reveals moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 0.65 cm, which is close to the surgical staple line. The tumor is classified as pathologic stage pT1AN0MX, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in the left retroperitoneal mass, measuring 11.5 x 9 x 8.5 cm, with involvement of the renal vein and adjacent soft tissue. The tumor exhibits areas of necrosis and is present at the renal vein margin as an intraluminal tumor embolus, while the remaining renal parenchyma appears unremarkable except for a small fibrotic nodule. One benign lymph node was identified, and further immunohistochemical work-up is planned for the renal nodule to confirm its classification.

The pathology report indicates that the resected colon and rectum material contains an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that has infiltrated the perimuscular adipose tissue. There are tumor-free resection margins, and no regional lymph node metastases were found, with a classification of G2, pT3, and pNo. Additionally, there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion (L0) or perineural invasion (V0).

The pathology report indicates that multiple biopsies of the mental nerves and various lip and cheek margins showed no tumor presence, while squamous cell carcinoma in situ was identified in the right and left anterior lip margins, as well as in multiple tongue and base of tongue margins. A composite resection of the anterior floor of the mouth revealed invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with a maximum depth of invasion of 9.0 mm and focal lymphovascular invasion, although adjacent margins were free of tumor. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from neck dissections were negative for tumor, and the report notes the presence of soft tissue metastasis in a minor salivary gland.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in the right liver following a hemihepatectomy, with a tumor size of 20.5x16x11 cm and a multinodular confluent gross type. Histologically, the tumor exhibits trabecular and pseudoglandular types with classic and clear cell groups, showing a mixed differentiation grade of 2 and 3, along with evidence of vascular invasion, tumor necrosis, and serosal invasion. The surgical margins are clear with a safety margin of 0.1 cm, and the pathologic stage is classified as AJCC (pT3, pT4), with intrahepatic metastasis present but no evidence of chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, or dysplasia.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the left and right pelvic lymph nodes, with five and two lymph nodes respectively showing no evidence of malignancy. However, the prostate and seminal vesicles show prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (5+4), indicating aggressive cancer that involves both lobes of the prostate, with perineural and extracapsular invasion, and positive involvement of the seminal vesicles. The tumor occupies 80% of the examined tissue, and the final staging is pT3b N0 Mx, suggesting advanced local disease without lymphatic or distant metastasis.
