The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade oligodendroglioma (WHO grade II) with a MIB-1 labeling index of 13.4%, suggesting a highly proliferative neoplasm despite its low-grade histological features. The microscopic examination reveals a hypercellular glial neoplasm infiltrating both gray and white matter, with prominent intratumor hemorrhage and mildly atypical nuclei, but no significant mitotic activity or necrosis. Although a few mitotic figures were noted, their low frequency does not warrant a classification of anaplastic oligodendroglioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, with a tumor size of 6.0 cm and free margins of resection. Additionally, chronic interstitial nephritis was noted in the kidney parenchyma at both the medial and lateral inferior margins. The tumor is classified as pT1b, indicating it is more than 4 cm but not more than 7 cm in greatest dimension and limited to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, grade IV, in the right parietal lobe based on biopsy and resection specimens. The tumor exhibits highly pleomorphic and bizarre cells, with features such as microvascular proliferation, focal necrosis, and a high percentage of cells staining for GFAP, confirming the diagnosis. An addendum notes an MIB-1 immunohistochemical labeling index of 24.58%.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left side craniotomy for a brain tumor, with two specimens submitted for analysis. Both specimens were diagnosed as anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III), showing infiltrative characteristics and evidence of anaplastic transformation, with a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 9%. The tumor exhibits areas of increased cellularity and pleomorphism, along with a gemistocytic appearance of the tumor cells.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated mixed papillary serous and endometrioid adenocarcinoma in both the right and left ovaries, with lymphovascular permeation and tumor involvement in the meso-ovary and paraovarian adhesions. Additionally, there are metastatic adenocarcinoma deposits identified in the sigmoid, bladder, peritoneum, and abdominal wall, along with focal superficial involvement in the omentum. The uterus shows chronic cervicitis, inactive endometrium, and adenomyosis, with the uterine serosa also involved by tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the sigmoid and upper rectum specimen contains a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma that has penetrated to the surface of the visceral peritoneum (pT4a) and shows prominent metastatic involvement in 21 of 34 lymph nodes (pN2b). The resection margins are negative for tumor, but there is significant vascular invasion noted. The appendix is reported as unremarkable with no significant findings.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis without malignancy, and the bile duct and pancreatic margins are also negative for cancer. However, the Whipple specimen reveals moderate to poorly-differentiated invasive pancreatic duct carcinoma, measuring approximately 6.0 cm, with invasion into surrounding tissues and positive margins at the uncinate process and pancreaticoduodenal soft tissue. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma is identified in four out of eleven lymph nodes, while the para-aortic lymph node shows reactive tissue without malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of lung cancer, specifically adeno-squamous carcinoma, with a histological grade of 2. The TNM staging shows T2, N0, and M0, suggesting a localized tumor without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been initiated at this time, and the specimen was obtained from a primary lung tumor tissue sample.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated large-cell, nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma located in the left lower lobe (S6) of the lung, classified as stage IIIA. The tumor has obstructed the bronchus and infiltrated nearby lymph nodes, with evidence of pleural involvement and additional lymph node metastases. Resection margins for the bronchus and vessels are tumor-free, and no asbestos bodies were found, although further investigations regarding asbestos exposure are recommended.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast lumpectomy revealed residual poorly differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma with a tumor size of 2.5 x 2.0 x 1.5 cm, and involved surgical margins. The left axillary dissection showed metastatic carcinoma in 18 of 20 examined lymph nodes, with extensive extranodal extension and non-nodal metastases. Additionally, the left supraclavicular lymph node excision confirmed metastatic carcinoma in one examined lymph node.

The pathology report indicates that the occipital tumor biopsy is consistent with a high-grade glioma, favoring a diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade III), although a high-grade mixed oligoastrocytoma (WHO Grade IV) cannot be completely excluded. FISH studies showed no loss of 1p or 19q, and no EGFR amplification was detected, supporting the diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma. The tumor exhibits extensive necrosis, pleomorphic neoplastic cells, and a proliferation index of approximately 10-15%, with immunohistochemical positivity for GFAP and scattered positivity for p53.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a localized, highly differentiated papillary serous tumor of the peritoneum with no metastases. Additionally, it describes a total gastrectomy specimen revealing a 5 cm ulcerated, weakly differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma with extensive infiltration into surrounding tissues and 14 regional lymph node metastases. The tumor-free margins of the resection indicate no residual disease in the oral, duodenal, or omental tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left breast cancer, specifically infiltrating duct carcinoma measuring 1.4 cm, with associated cribriform ductal carcinoma in situ comprising 5% of the invasive tumor. The Nottingham score is 6, indicating a moderate grade, and one of the two examined sentinel lymph nodes is positive for metastatic carcinoma with extracasular extension. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor positive, and HER2/neu equivocal (2+), with negative surgical margins and no evidence of Paget's disease.

The pathology report indicates that a left breast segmental mastectomy was performed due to a left breast mass, revealing a moderately differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 3.2 cm with associated microcalcifications. The tumor shows positive estrogen receptor staining (90%) and negative progesterone receptor and HER-2/neu staining. The surgical margins are grossly positive for tumor within less than 1 mm of the inked superior and deep margins, while the new superior margin is benign.

The pathology report confirms the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a liver segmentectomy specimen, with a well-defined mass measuring 3.5 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm and a safety margin of 1.2 cm that is not involved. The tumor exhibits moderate differentiation (Grade II) and a trabecular histologic type, with no evidence of vascular invasion or intrahepatic metastasis. The remaining liver parenchyma shows cirrhosis associated with hepatitis C virus (HCV).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma originating from the right buccal mucosa, with a tumor size of 6.8 x 5 x 2.3 cm and a depth of invasion of 2.3 cm. Lymph-vascular and perineural invasion are present, and there is one positive lymph node for metastatic squamous cell carcinoma out of 43 examined, with surgical margins being uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. The tumor is staged as pT4a and pN1, with no distant metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy from the cervix reveals poorly differentiated and invasive squamous cell carcinoma. This suggests a malignant tumor with aggressive characteristics. Further evaluation and management will be necessary based on these findings.

The final pathologic diagnosis reveals a high-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 10.5 cm in the left thigh, with negative margins for malignancy confirmed in all examined areas. The tumor exhibits brisk mitotic activity and widespread necrosis, with immunohistochemical staining showing reactivity for vimentin, small muscle actin, and desmin, while being negative for S100 and pancytokeratin. Additionally, there is involvement of a centrally coursing arteriovenous complex by the mass, and the closest resection margin is 0.2 cm.

The pathology report identifies a paraganglioma in the neck, characterized by a proliferation of monotonous cells with round nuclei, prominent red nucleoli, and eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in small nests. There is one mitotic figure observed per 10 high-power fields, with bands of fibroelastic tissue and few entrapped nerve fibers present, but no necrosis is noted. The final diagnosis is confirmed as a paraganglioma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right thoracotomy pneumonectomy, revealing two separate foci of invasive adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe, with the larger tumor measuring 4.5 cm and the smaller 1.9 cm, both abutting the visceral pleura but not invading it. The bronchial margins and all examined lymph nodes were negative for metastatic tumor, confirming that the invasive carcinoma is confined within the lung parenchyma. Additionally, the right lower lobe showed a separate focus of invasive adenocarcinoma measuring 2.4 cm, with all surgical margins free of tumor, and no lymphovascular invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple left kidney tumors in a male patient diagnosed with Birt Hogg Dube syndrome, with a total of 42 specimens submitted for analysis. The tumors are characterized as renal cell carcinoma of the chromophobe type and various hybrid tumors predominantly of oncocytoma type. The specimens have been processed for permanent analysis, with detailed descriptions of their sizes and characteristics provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse astrocytoma from a primary tumor located in the temporal lobe of a Caucasian male. The specimen was processed as an OCT block, with a tumor cell percentage of 80%. There is no indication of treatment or staging provided in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 0.9 cm and evidence of extranodal extension in some nodes. The total thyroidectomy revealed two foci of classical papillary carcinoma in the right and left lobes, measuring 2.8 cm and 1.5 cm respectively, with vascular invasion and extrathyroidal extension noted. Overall, the surgical margins are free of tumor, and benign parathyroid tissue was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which has invaded the muscularis propria and perivesical fat, but with negative surgical margins and no lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7 was identified, confined to the right lobe with negative margins and no lymphovascular or perineural invasion. All examined lymph nodes from both sides and the distal ureters showed no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, and chronic inflammation was noted in the ureters.

The final diagnosis from the biopsy of the right larynx indicates the presence of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma with focal angiolymphatic invasion. The specimen was submitted for microscopic examination, which confirmed the diagnosis. The report does not provide information regarding the patient's prior malignancy, chemotherapy, radiation, or other medical history.

The pathology report identifies a tumor measuring 8.0 x 7.0 x 6.0 cm, diagnosed as Type A/B Thymoma. The tumor is classified as pT1 with no regional lymph node involvement (0/8). According to the Masaoka staging system, the tumor is classified as Stage I.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type with focal sarcomatoid features, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade III/IV, measuring 4.5 cm. The tumor is noted to abut the renal capsule without extending through it, and extensive necrosis is present, but there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, with negative margins for the ureter, renal artery, and renal vein. The AJCC classification is T1b Nx M1, and further evaluation of the non-neoplastic kidney will be reported in an addendum.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with a tumor size of 2.5 cm and a modified Bloom-Richardson grade of 3. One of the left sentinel lymph nodes showed metastatic carcinoma, while the second sentinel lymph node and ten other examined lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. Estrogen receptors were positive in 60% of the malignant cells, and progesterone receptors were positive in 10%, with HER2 status reported as not amplified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, grade 2, with a tumor size of 1.8 cm located in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. Out of ten examined lymph nodes, four showed metastases, while the tumor margins were uninvolved and there was no evidence of venous invasion. The report does not provide specific details on the Nottingham histologic score or any evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma following a partial hepatectomy of the left lateral segment of the liver, with a tumor size of 15 cm and a 2 cm satellite tumor. The tumor exhibits variable histologic grades, including well-differentiated and moderately differentiated components, but shows no vascular invasion or transcapsular invasion, with negative margins. The overall AJCC stage is classified as Stage IIIA, and the procedure was performed as a palliative measure to relieve gastric compression.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma (4.4 cm) at the right base of the tongue, with two out of twenty-four lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement, but no extranodal extension. Immunohistochemistry results show positive p16 and HPV status, suggesting a viral association with the tumor. All surgical margins are free of carcinoma, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3, N2b.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has residual high-grade leiomyosarcoma involving the inferior vena cava, characterized by two nodules measuring 3.7 cm and 2.9 cm, with mitotic activity greater than 10 per 10 high power fields and focal necrosis present. The gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis and cholesterosis, while both the iliac and paracaval lymph nodes are benign. The report was amended to clarify the diagnosis from recurrent to residual leiomyosarcoma based on additional clinical information.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated rectal carcinoma, classified as colic adenocarcinoma located in the rectal position. The tumor has infiltrated the muscularis layer (pT2) but shows no evidence of vascular infiltration (L0 V0) and has free lymph nodes. The tumor classification is ICDO-DA M-8140/3, with a grade of G2 and staging of pT2, L0, V0, pNO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the esophagus, with extensive necrosis and a maximum tumor size of 4.2 cm, located at the gastroesophageal junction. The tumor invades the muscularis propria, with one out of thirteen examined lymph nodes showing metastatic carcinoma, while the resection margins are negative for neoplasm. No intestinal metaplasia or vascular invasion is noted, and the presence of multiple possible lymph nodes is documented, with the status of distant metastasis remaining unknown.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in one sentinel lymph node from the left axilla, while the right axillary sentinel nodes are negative for malignancy. The left breast resection reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma classified as Elston SBR grade 1, and the right breast resection shows infiltrating ductal carcinoma classified as Elston SBR grade 2. Additionally, there is no evidence of malignancy in four lymph nodes from the left axilla.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade III endometrial carcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor size of 2.3 cm and myometrial invasion of less than half. There is evidence of metastatic carcinoma in one of the left pelvic lymph nodes, while the other lymph nodes examined showed no malignancy. Additionally, adenomyosis was noted, and there was no cervical involvement or lower uterine segment involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of choroidal melanoma in the right globe, measuring 14 mm at the base and exhibiting a spindled type with superficial scleral invasion, but no optic nerve invasion or extraocular extension. The tumor shows mitotic activity at a rate of 3 per 10 high-power fields, and the vortex vein is negative for tumor involvement. The enucleation specimen reveals a choroidal-based mass that is confined to the globe, with clear vitreous and no significant abnormalities in the sclera or anterior chamber.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from the left obturator, right external iliac, and right obturator regions show no tumor presence. The prostate and seminal vesicles contain prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5), exhibiting extraprostatic extension and invasion into the left seminal vesicle, while margins of resection are free of tumor. Additionally, fibromuscular tissue was identified in the bladder neck samples, with no prostatic tissue or tumor present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, with a Fuhrman grade of 3 out of 4, and a tumor size of 3.7 cm. The tumor is unifocal, with negative findings for capsular invasion and no sarcomatoid features identified, although the renal parenchymal margin is involved. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, showing the tumor is positive for CK7, CD10, E-Cadherin, and CD117, while negative for RCC and vimentin.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an anterior mediastinal mass diagnosed as an AB thymoma, which is partially encapsulated and shows focal infiltration into the atypical lung resection, with the pericardium free from neoplastic infiltration. The report also notes reactive lymph nodes in the aorto-pulmonary window and precaval regions, with no significant alterations in the cardio-phrenic adipous tissue. Staging of the thymoma is classified as Stage III according to the Masaoka system.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as Nottingham grade 7/9, with micro papillary features comprising about 10% of the tumor mass, and a size of 2.1 x 1.8 x 1.3 cm. Additionally, one of seventeen examined lymph nodes showed metastatic carcinoma with a size of 1.2 x 0.8 cm and evidence of extracapsular spread. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor positive, and HER2/neu negative, with clear surgical margins and no significant angiolymphatic invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 2, measuring 18 mm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) exhibiting solid and cribriform patterns with associated necrosis and calcifications. The resection margins are negative for tumor, with the invasive carcinoma located 15 mm from the nearest margin, and no tumor present in the six axillary sentinel lymph nodes sampled (0/6). The pathologic stage is classified as IA, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, and no overexpression of HER2/neu.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated, non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the resected left superior pulmonary lobe, measuring up to 95 mm, with invasion into the mediastinum and infiltration of adjacent thymus tissue. The report also notes the presence of anthracotic pigmentation in non-tumorous lymph nodes and significant pre-existing pulmonary emphysema, along with xanthomatous retention pneumonia likely related to nicotine use. All resection margins are tumor-free, confirming complete removal of the carcinoma, classified as stage III B.
The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma, classified as grade III according to the WHO. The tumor is located in the left frontal region. The patient is female.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 3.0 x 2.5 x 2.0 cm low-grade pancreatic duct adenocarcinoma located in the head of the pancreas, with evidence of invasion into adjacent structures including the duodenum and ampulla. The pancreatic duct margin showed no evidence of tumor, while three out of thirteen examined peripancreatic lymph nodes were involved with tumor. Additional findings included chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder and a benign common hepatic lymph node.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma with myxofibrosarcoma-like growth, predominantly in high-grade areas, measuring 12.6 x 11.4 x 6.5 cm, and involving subserosal fat, but with free resection margins and uninvolved bowel margins. A minor component of well-differentiated liposarcoma, sclerosing type, is also present, and the tumor shows predominantly viable tissue with focal areas of necrosis. Additionally, a separate specimen of scarred abdominal skin was examined, which showed a wrinkled white tan appearance.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the right thyroid lobe, measuring 3.0 cm, which is well-differentiated with no identified mitotic activity, necrosis, or vascular invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the left thyroid lobe shows nodular hyperplasia with no evidence of malignancy or parathyroid glands identified. A benign lymph node was noted in the right hemithyroidectomy specimen, with chronic inflammation present in the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in one fragmented lymph node and identifies a left upper lobe lung tumor as poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 4.0 cm, with metastasis found in 6 of 11 lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as pT2a and pN2, with uninvolved surgical margins and no evidence of large vessel invasion, while lymphatic invasion remains indeterminate. Molecular analysis for KRAS and EGFR mutations returned negative results, supporting the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, classified as NHG2, with a tumor size of 2.1 x 1.8 x 1.7 cm. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive estrogen and progesterone receptors in over 75% of neoplastic cell nuclei, and a HER2 score of 3+, indicating a strong positive reaction. Additionally, there is chronic lymphadenitis in the axillary lymph nodes, but no evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the breast, measuring up to 3 cm, with evidence of metastases in 8 out of 10 examined lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical staining shows a high estrogen receptor positivity (98%) and moderate progesterone receptor positivity (50%), while Her-2/neu is negative. The tumor is classified as T2 due to its size, and the margins are reported as uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma in the rectosigmoid colon, measuring 2 x 1.3 cm, with superficial invasion into the submucosa and associated with a villoglandular adenoma. One out of twenty-six lymph nodes examined showed metastatic carcinoma with focal extranodal extension, while both the proximal and distal margins were negative for carcinoma. The overall pathological staging is pT1 N1 Mx, indicating a complete resection with negative margins.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 7.4 cm, with ulceration and infiltration into the mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria, and mesenteric fat, but without neoplastic infiltration into the colon or lymph nodes. All examined lymph nodes (35 total) and the gastric margin are uninvolved by neoplasia, indicating no lymphatic or blood vascular invasion. The pathological staging is classified as pT4 pN0, suggesting advanced local disease without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a mucinous adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, measuring 8.5 cm, with well to moderately differentiated histologic grade. Metastatic carcinoma is identified in two out of six proximal bronchial lymph nodes and one out of three hilar lymph nodes, while several other lymph nodes examined show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The bronchial and vascular resection margins are negative for tumor, and there is evidence of small vessel lymphatic invasion, but no large vessel invasion is noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with the tumor invading the deep half of the muscularis propria and showing vascular and perineural invasion, but surgical margins are free of tumor. The prostate also shows adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6, confined to the prostate capsule and exhibiting perineural invasion, while the lymph nodes and ureters are benign. Overall, the findings suggest a significant malignancy in the bladder and prostate, but no metastatic disease was identified in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 1.2 cm, with a close surgical resection margin of 0.15 cm and associated ductal carcinoma in situ of the cribriform type. Micrometastases were identified in three of the four sentinel lymph nodes, with the largest measuring 2.0 mm, while one lymph node was negative for metastases. The tumor is classified as ER-positive, PR-positive, and HER2-negative, with a low to intermediate nuclear grade and a recurrence score of 7 from the Oncotype DX assay.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a lymph node dissection and robotic hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, revealing no tumor in any of the examined lymph nodes (24 total). The uterine specimen showed endometrioid adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 3, with superficial myometrial invasion and no cervical or adnexal involvement, leading to a staging of pT1b pNO pMx; FIGO stage IB. Hormone receptor status revealed strong positivity for both estrogen and progesterone receptors, with further details pending in an addendum.

The pathology report indicates that a 54-year-old female with a history of gastric stapling has been diagnosed with distal esophageal Barrett's carcinoma, leading to a transhiatal esophagectomy. The findings reveal an adenocarcinoma at the gastroesophageal junction, with invasion into the muscularis propria and metastasis identified in 2 out of 11 lymph nodes, while resection margins are negative for carcinoma. The TNM classification is T2 N1 Mx, confirming the presence of invasive adenocarcinoma without extranodal metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that a left breast and axillary tissue resection was performed due to a clinical diagnosis of left breast cancer. Microscopic examination revealed invasive ductal carcinoma with features of carcinoma in situ and chronic lymphadenitis in the axillary lymph nodes. The final histopathological diagnosis is invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, classified as NHG2, pT2, pNO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated neuroendocrine carcinoma of the pancreas, characterized by extensive local invasion, including infiltration of the posterior wall of the stomach and vessel involvement. There are lymph node metastases identified, with some lymph nodes remaining tumor-free, and evidence of lymphangiosis carcinomatosis. The tumor classification is pT3, pN1, with a grading of G1 and an R1 resection status due to residual tumor at the margins and vessel invasion.

The pathology report indicates a left breast radical mastectomy specimen with a 2.5 x 3.2 cm lobular carcinoma, classified as moderately differentiated. There is no evidence of metastasis in the 10 examined axillary lymph nodes, and the surgical margins are uninvolved. Additional details regarding tumor extent and specific histologic scoring are not provided, but the tumor is categorized as a T2 size.

The pathology report indicates a histopathological examination of a lesion resection from the tongue, revealing a diagnosis of carcinoma planoepitheliale partim keratodes, classified as grade 2 (G2). The specimen measured 5 x 4 x 2.5 cm, with a tumor size of 3.5 x 1.8 x 2.5 cm, and minimal normal tissue margins were noted. The diagnosis confirms a squamous and partially keratinized carcinoma of the skin, categorized as pT2.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a lobectomy of the right upper lobe, revealing an invasive keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma that is poorly differentiated, measuring 5.0 x 4.9 x 3.9 cm, with no angiolymphatic invasion and free resection margins. All examined lymph nodes (12 total) showed no evidence of malignancy, and additional findings included obstructive pneumonia and emphysema in the uninvolved lung. The final staging is pT2a, N0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes and tissue samples were examined, all of which were negative for malignancy, confirming no regional lymph node metastasis. The primary diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma of the distal esophagus, classified as pT2N0Mx, with the tumor invading the muscularis propria but all surgical margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additionally, a fundic gland polyp was noted in the stomach, and no significant pathology was found in the surgical waste.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor measuring 5.0 x 3.8 x 3.2 cm that invades 1.3 cm into the myometrium, but does not involve the endocervix or lymphovascular spaces, and has negative margins. All examined lymph nodes from both pelvic and peri-aortic regions (totaling 55 nodes) are negative for tumor involvement. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive estrogen receptor staining in 51-75% of tumor nuclei and progesterone receptor staining in 26-50% of tumor nuclei.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal breast carcinoma with a maximum diameter of 1.8 cm and classified as malignancy grade II, exhibiting angioinvasion and neural sheath infiltration at the tumor periphery. Additionally, there is a concomitant ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) also graded II, with less than 10% of the tumor being a procomponent. The tumor classification is G2 (L1, V0), pTlc, pNO (sn), MX, and R0, with a minimum safety margin of 1 cm.

The pathology report indicates that a wedge resection of the right middle lobe revealed a 1.1 cm papillary predominant adenocarcinoma, with no residual tumor found in the margins or lymph nodes examined. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) testing for ALK gene rearrangement showed no evidence of rearrangement, while 26% of cells exhibited extra copies of the ALK gene, which is common in non-small cell lung cancer but of unclear significance. Additionally, molecular studies for KRAS and EGFR mutations were negative, suggesting a potentially favorable prognosis regarding targeted therapies.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left adnexa are negative for tumors, but both ovaries show focal surface adhesions and ectatic segments of the fallopian tubes with chronic inflammation. The uterus and cervix reveal invasive moderately differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma, which involves the entire endometrial cavity and has invaded the myometrium and cervical stroma, with one lymph node showing metastatic carcinoma. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IIIC, with no lymphovascular invasion identified, and is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 1.8 cm moderately differentiated tubulolobular breast carcinoma in the left breast, with associated intraductal tumor propagation. The tumor has clear margins, measuring at least 5 mm at 12 o'clock and over 10 mm at 3 o'clock, with minimal involvement at 6 o'clock. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, and the tumor is classified as stage I with a grade of 2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade muscle invasive urothelial cell carcinoma with carcinoma in situ (CIS) present, classified as pT3bG3 NO. The tumor is located in the right bladder wall and measures 1.2 cm in diameter. All 16 examined lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the uterine cervix reveals moderately differentiated, invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The carcinoma is non-keratinizing in type. This diagnosis suggests a significant malignancy that requires further evaluation and management.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in a segmental resection of the sigmoid colon, with a tumor size of 6.3 cm and evidence of focal perineural invasion, but no lymph-vascular invasion detected. All thirteen examined lymph nodes were negative for neoplasm, and the surgical margins were clear of cancer. The AJCC pathologic stage is classified as pT3, N0, indicating local tumor invasion without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with additional involvement of the right tubal fimbria and metastatic spread to the uterine serosa and right pelvic sidewall nodule. The omentum is negative for tumor, and peritoneal fluid analysis confirms the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma. A microscopic focus of tumor on the left tubal serosa is noted, but its nature as a true implant or artifact remains uncertain.

The pathology report indicates that the left adrenal gland contains a 100mm adrenal cortical carcinoma, characterized by a multinodular structure with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage, but no evidence of vascular invasion. Microscopic examination reveals pleomorphic cells with a high mitotic rate and a Weiss score of 6, consistent with a diagnosis of adrenal cortical carcinoma. The tumor is staged as II (pT2, NX, MX) according to AJCC guidelines, and local excision appears to be complete.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed type adenocarcinoma (70% endometrioid FIGO grade 1 and 30% high-grade serous) involving the lower uterine segment, with direct invasion into the myometrium to a depth of 8 mm. There is focal lymphovascular invasion identified, but the endocervix is not involved by the tumor. The report notes incidental findings of leiomyomata, chronic inflammation, and a capillary hemangioma, while the bilateral fallopian tubes and ovaries show no histopathologic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a right total mastectomy revealing multiple invasive ductal carcinomas, with the largest measuring 1.3 cm and classified as Nottingham grade II. No metastatic carcinoma was found in any of the examined lymph nodes, and the surgical margins are negative for carcinoma. Additionally, ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) were identified, with the invasive tumor cells testing positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER-2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma involving both ovaries, with metastatic disease identified in the right and left fallopian tubes, omentum, small bowel nodule, and peritoneal plaque. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IIIC, indicating macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis, with a maximum dimension of tumor implants measuring 4.0 cm. The report highlights significant tumor involvement, including necrosis and lymphovascular invasion, and notes that the status of regional lymph nodes and distant tumor sites could not be assessed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing invasion into the right seminal vesicle and prostatic adipose tissue. There is one lymph node metastasis identified on the right side, with a total of 14 lymph nodes examined, of which 8 were tumor-free. The tumor classification is pT3b, with a maximum diameter of 33 mm and a tumor volume of approximately 7 ml.

The pathology report indicates that the two sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla are negative for metastases. The left breast mass is diagnosed as invasive lobular carcinoma, measuring 1.5 cm, with negative surgical margins. Additionally, the estrogen and progesterone receptors are positive, while HER2 testing is equivocal, suggesting further evaluation may be needed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade III, from a brain tumor located in the right frontal lobe, based on both biopsy and resection specimens. The tumor exhibits features such as nuclear pleomorphism, a high Ki-67 labeling index, and is positive for mutant IDH-1, suggesting aggressive behavior and potential progression to a higher grade. No necrosis or vascular proliferation was observed, and further genetic analysis is pending for additional insights into the tumor's characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left distal ureters, as well as the apical urethral margin, were diagnosed as benign with no dysplasia or carcinoma identified. However, the bladder was found to have a poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma with sarcomatoid features, infiltrating through the muscularis propria, and lymphovascular invasion was noted, although surgical margins were free of malignancy. Additionally, right prostatic adenocarcinoma was identified, confined to the prostate, with one out of 170 lymph nodes examined showing metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma in the total gastrectomy and splenectomy specimen, with the tumor invading the submucosa and one of thirty lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement. The surgical margins are clear of malignancy, and additional findings include moderate chronic gastritis and intestinal metaplasia. The gallbladder and surgical waste specimens are reported as within normal limits, with no dysplasia or malignancy detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the omentum, left ovary, right ovary, cul-de-sac nodule, and right diaphragm, with serous adenocarcinoma diagnosed in both ovaries. The tumors exhibit significant size, with the largest measuring up to 7.5 x 6.5 x 5.5 cm, and show positive serosal involvement in both ovaries. The overall pathological stage is classified as pT3c pNX pMX, indicating advanced disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma, specifically the epithelial type, with evidence of metastasis in multiple lymph nodes and tissues. Metastatic mesothelioma was found in various lymph nodes, including right level four (1/18), level seven (4/10), and level eight (1/1), as well as in the right pleura, diaphragm, and a pericardial nodule. The tumor exhibits invasive characteristics, coming within 1 mm of skeletal muscle margins, and shows a micropapillary predominant pattern.

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy of the left lower lobe revealed a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with a predominantly bronchioalveolar growth pattern, measuring 3.7 cm, and no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. All examined lymph nodes (13 in total) were negative for metastatic carcinoma, confirming no regional spread of the disease. The bronchial margin was uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, with a distance of 17 mm from the closest invasive carcinoma to the bronchial margin.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary shows no pathologic change, while the fallopian tube exhibits dilatation consistent with hematosalpinx, and both left ovary and tube are unremarkable except for a paratubal cyst and a corpus luteum. The radical hysterectomy reveals invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, grade II, with lymphovascular invasion and metastasis in two of seven examined lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes and the omentum are negative for neoplasm. Overall, the findings suggest a diagnosis of cervical cancer with regional lymph node involvement, but no evidence of neoplasm in the ovaries or omentum.

The pathology report indicates that the intraoperative consultation revealed a glioma in the left frontal neoplasm. Fluorescence in situ hybridization analysis showed a loss of both chromosomes 1p and 19q. The specimens consisted of multiple soft tissue fragments submitted for further examination, including frozen sections and permanent sections.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a 2.3 x 2.0 x 0.8 cm mass located at the right posterior of the uterine fundus, invading 0.4 cm of the myometrium. All examined lymph nodes, including those from the left and right pelvic regions as well as para-aortic nodes, are negative for tumor involvement, and the lower anterior cervix margin is also negative for tumor. The bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes show no diagnostic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates that the excisional biopsy of the left parietal lobe reveals a diagnosis of glioblastoma with a high MIB-1 proliferation index of 9%, characterized by nuclear anaplasia, mitotic figures, and focal tumor necrosis. Additionally, there are findings of infiltrating glioma in the adjacent cerebral cortex and white matter, with sparse neoplastic cell infiltration. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the presence of an astrocytic neoplastic proliferation, with notable gemistocytic features in the glioblastoma sample.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, with a size of 2.3 x 2.0 x 1.5 cm, confined to the left kidney and classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3. Additionally, there is an adrenal cortical adenoma measuring 4.9 x 4.5 x 3.1 cm, with no tumor involvement in the surrounding margins or lymph nodes. The kidney also shows multiple renal adenomas, renal cortical cysts, and areas of calcification and fibrosis, but no other significant lesions were identified.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast wide local excision revealed lobular carcinoma in situ and various benign breast lesions, while the left simple mastectomy confirmed the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 2, measuring 2.5 cm, with negative margins and extensive ductal carcinoma in situ. Sentinel lymph node biopsies from the left axilla showed micrometastatic carcinoma in one lymph node, while the others were negative for carcinoma. Immunohistochemical analysis demonstrated positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, and negative HER2 status, with a recurrence score of 9 indicating a low risk of distant recurrence.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer, with the final diagnosis revealing acinar type prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, involving both lobes but confined to the prostate without extraprostatic extension. All examined surgical margins and lymph nodes (14 total) were free of carcinoma, and less than 5% of the prostate volume was involved by the tumor. Additionally, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia was identified, along with background nodular hyperplasia and inflammation.

The pathology report describes an anterior mediastinum mass with contiguous lung involvement, characterized by a lymphoepithelial proliferation with lobulated architecture and polygonal large cells exhibiting cytonuclear atypia. The findings indicate an anaplastic type B3 thymoma, with necrosis less than 10% and negative margins, suggesting complete resection. The tumor is classified as stage IVA, with no evidence of lymph node invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 5.5 cm invasive, well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma that invades the mandibular bone, but all surgical margins are negative for tumor. Multiple lymph nodes from various neck dissections and other oral tissues show no evidence of malignancy, with the exception of osteonecrosis noted in the additional left mandibular bone and tissue. Overall, the findings suggest localized cancer with no metastatic spread to the examined lymph nodes or surrounding tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive mucinous adenocarcinoma arising in a tubulovillous adenoma located in the left colon, with the tumor measuring 9 x 6.5 cm and involving the subserosa. The surgical margins are free of tumor, but metastatic carcinoma is present in 2 out of 26 examined lymph nodes. Additional findings include two tubular adenomas and diverticulosis, with a recommendation for clinical-surgical correlation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with glioblastoma multiforme, specifically the small cell variant, following a biopsy of the left temporal lobe. The microscopic examination revealed a highly undifferentiated neoplasm characterized by diffuse infiltration, necrosis, and a high mitotic rate, with a significant presence of blood vessels and hemorrhage. Immunohistochemical staining confirmed the tumor's undifferentiated nature, showing a high labeling index of approximately 60%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive breast carcinoma with mixed differentiation, comprising both ductal and lobular components, measuring 1.5 cm and classified as malignancy grade II. There is no evidence of angioinvasion or coarse calcification, and the minimum width of the ventral safety margin is 0.5 cm. The tumor classification is pT1c, pN0, MX, R0, and G2, with adjacent breast parenchyma and skin showing no atypia.

The pathology report indicates that both the right and left ovaries show poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma with ovarian surface involvement. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma in the rectal tumor, parametrial soft tissue, omentum, and diaphragm, while the right periaortic lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy. The final staging is classified as T3c/N1/M0 (Stage IIIC), indicating advanced disease with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of epithelioid mesothelioma infiltrating the parietal pleura, right lung, and skeletal muscle, with angiolymphatic invasion noted and pleural margins involved by neoplasia. Additionally, metastasis of mesothelioma was found in all four dissected subcarinal lymph nodes, with capsular transposition, and in two out of three dissected esophageal lymph nodes, without capsular transposition. There is no evidence of perineural invasion, and the bronchial margin is uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that a left nephrectomy specimen was examined, revealing a 5.2 x 4.8 x 4.5 cm renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of 3/4 and evidence of lymphovascular space invasion. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with negative surgical margins and no evidence of transcapsular or renal vein invasion. Additionally, a 0.4 cm renal calculus and a microscopic healed renal infarct were noted, and the final staging is pT1b Nx Mx.

The pathology report indicates that the excised margins from the palate, floor of mouth, and buccal mucosa are negative for malignancy, while a moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.0 cm was identified in the left mandible, with invasion into bone and positive inferior surgical margins. Additionally, 4 out of 20 lymph nodes from the left neck levels 2, 3, and 4 were involved by metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, and 1 lymph node from level 1B was also positive for malignancy. The findings correspond to AJCC pathologic Stage IVA, indicating advanced disease with extracapsular extension present in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 2, with focal squamous differentiation and atypical complex hyperplasia, located on the anterior aspect of the endometrium. The tumor measures 3 cm and shows superficial myometrial invasion, but no lymph-vascular invasion or metastatic carcinoma was found in the examined lymph nodes. Additional findings include benign conditions such as an endometrial polyp and leiomyoma, with no evidence of malignancy in other biopsied tissues.

The pathology report indicates that a liver biopsy revealed a 6.5 cm hepatocellular carcinoma with a surgical margin of 0.59 cm. The liver tissue showed moderate periportal fibrosis but maintained its architectural integrity, and there was no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or Schistosoma mansoni eggs. The pathological staging is classified as pT1 according to the TNM 7th edition.

The pathology report indicates a biopsy of the uterine cervix revealing squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor is classified as histologic grade 3 and is invasive in nature. Additionally, the presence of necrotic areas is noted within the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that multiple biopsies from the right superficial tumor and right temporal lobe of the brain have been diagnosed as fibrillary astrocytoma (WHO Grade II), characterized by prominent microcyst formation and mild hypercellularity suggestive of infiltrating glioma. Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization analysis shows preservation of both chromosomes 1p and 19q. The report includes various specimens labeled from different parts of the tumor, all confirming the presence of the same low-grade glioma.

The pathology report indicates that a poorly differentiated non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the R9 lymph node, measuring 7.5 cm, with no evidence of lymphatic or arterial invasion, and marked tumor necrosis. The tumor invades the pleura but does not penetrate through it, and all surgical margins are clear of tumor involvement. A total of 20 lymph nodes were examined, with none showing metastatic disease, and the overall staging is classified as T2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), located in the left lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 4 cm. The tumor is classified as Grade II and has a pathological staging of T2, N1, with no evidence of metastasis (M0). The sample was obtained through a resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated intestinal type adenocarcinoma in the stomach, measuring 3.3 cm, with evidence of angiolymphatic and perineural invasion, but with uninvolved surgical margins. Additionally, all 18 dissected lymph nodes were free of neoplasia, and there is a non-neoplastic segment of the stomach showing chronic gastritis with intestinal metaplasia. The report also notes the presence of congested mature adipose tissue in the epiploon segment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a liver mass, with a well-defined lesion measuring 4.0 x 3.0 x 3.8 cm and a safety margin of 0.5 cm, showing no capsular or vascular invasion. The gallbladder specimen reveals chronic cholecystitis. Overall, there is no evidence of intrahepatic metastasis or multicentric occurrence of HCC.

The pathology report indicates that a wedge resection of the posterior segment of the right lung revealed infiltrating moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, with negative margins and no evidence of vascular invasion. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from various levels were examined, all of which were negative for metastatic disease. The right upper lobe showed no residual tumor following a prior wedge resection, with mild emphysematous changes noted in the lung parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately-differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma, which extends through the wall of the cecum into the serosal fat, with no direct invasion of the abdominal wall. The resection margins (proximal, distal, and radial) are free of tumor, and all 19 examined mesenteric lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, there is evidence of pericolonic abscess formation and inflammation, but the appendix shows no significant histopathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates that parathyroid tissue excised from the neck is negative for tumor in both samples. A total thyroidectomy revealed multifocal papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 2.5 cm, with metastasis found in 4 of 11 lymph nodes, the largest measuring 2.4 cm. The primary tumor shows minimal extrathyroidal extension, and there is evidence of lymphatic invasion, while surgical margins are uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which has invaded through the muscularis propria into the perivesical tissue, with a tumor size of 2.4 cm located in the posterior wall. All examined lymph nodes (19 total) and resection margins are negative for tumor, suggesting no lymphatic spread. Additionally, benign ovarian tissue was found adjacent to the bladder, and scar tissue was noted in the skin and subcutaneous tissue without any tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates that both frozen and permanent sections of a right temporal brain tumor were analyzed, revealing a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme. The microscopic examination showed a highly cellular glial neoplasm with atypical astrocytes, scattered mitotic figures, and evidence of microvascular proliferation. Additionally, the permanent section exhibited significant areas of tumor necrosis.

The pathology report indicates that a solid mass measuring 7.2 x 6.0 x 5.4 cm was identified in the pancreatic tail, diagnosed as undifferentiated carcinoma with a sarcomatoid component, extending beyond the pancreas into peripancreatic soft tissue. All surgical resection margins are negative for tumor, with a minimum tumor-free margin of 2.6 cm, but one of 22 regional lymph nodes is positive for metastatic carcinoma. Immunohistochemical studies support the diagnosis, and the tumor is classified as AJCC stage pT3N1.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multiple biopsies from the spinal cord and nerve roots, revealing a diagnosis of plexiform neurofibroma and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNST) in various specimens. The malignant tumors exhibit high-grade characteristics with pleomorphic cells and necrosis, particularly affecting the S1, S2, and S3 nerve roots, as well as a sacral mass. The findings are consistent with a malignant transformation of a plexiform neurofibroma, and the patient has a history of neurofibromatosis type I.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive papillary urothelial carcinoma confined to the renal pelvis and calices of the left kidney, with small foci invading the lamina propria. The tumor measures 3.7 cm and is associated with adjacent high-grade urothelial carcinoma in situ, but all surgical margins, including those of Gerota's fascia and vascular structures, are negative for invasive carcinoma. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or lymph nodes identified, and the background shows patchy chronic interstitial nephritis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has bilateral poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, involving approximately 60% of the prostate volume and showing extra-prostatic extension. The surgical procedure performed was a radical retropubic prostatectomy, and all examined lymph nodes (17 total) were free of tumor. The final diagnosis confirms the presence of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and extensive perineural invasion, with the pathological staging classified as pT3a NO MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 3 squamous carcinoma of the floor of the mouth, measuring 7 mm in thickness, with moderate to severe dysplasia noted at the lateral and inferior margins, while other margins are free of tumor. Metastatic squamous carcinoma is identified in 3 of 12 right cervical lymph nodes and in soft tissues at level 3, with no tumor present in the left cervical lymph nodes or right submandibular gland. Additionally, the report notes that the proximal and lingual margins are segments of nerve with no tumor present, and the left maxillary gland shows chronic inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 5.3 cm, with negative resection margins and no vascular invasion, classified as pT1 according to AJCC staging. The background liver tissue exhibits marked steatosis and congestion, but there is no significant fibrosis or cytoplasmic globules present in hepatocytes. Additional staining results, including trichrome and iron stains, support the absence of significant liver damage or iron accumulation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bifocal invasive carcinoma of the right breast, with two distinct tumors: one classified as invasive ductal carcinoma (NHG3, pT2) and the other as mixed invasive carcinoma (NHG2, pTlc). Immunohistochemical analysis shows no estrogen or progesterone receptors in the first tumor, while the second tumor exhibits estrogen and progesterone receptors in 10-75% of neoplastic cell nuclei, with both tumors showing a negative HER2 reaction. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma was found in the axillary lymph nodes, indicating a more advanced stage of disease.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a thymoma, classified as WHO Type A, measuring 3.5 x 3 x 1.5 cm, which is encapsulated and has free margins. Additionally, three excised mediastinal lymph nodes were found to be benign. The non-neoplastic thymus tissue is unremarkable, and there are focal areas of B1-B2 classification within the tumor, comprising less than 10% of its total volume.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse astrocytoma, WHO grade II, following a brain biopsy. The tumor exhibits infiltrative characteristics without significant mitotic figures or vascular proliferation, and the Ki-67 labeling index is approximately 3%. Additionally, the MGMT promoter methylation status is negative, suggesting that the tumor may not respond to alkylating agent therapy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated, nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma located in the left upper lobe of the lung, with a maximum tumor size of 5.2 cm and evidence of endobronchial growth. The tumor has infiltrated the visceral pleura and is classified as stage IB (pT2 pNO pMX R0), while all examined lymph nodes and resection margins are free of tumor. Additionally, there is evidence of active chronic retention pneumonia in the tumor environment and reactive lesions with anthracotic pigment deposits in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two distinct tumors: a meningioma classified as WHO grade I and a glioblastoma multiforme classified as WHO grade IV. The glioblastoma exhibits varying degrees of tumor necrosis across multiple samples, with some showing no necrosis and others showing up to 20% necrosis. Immunostaining results suggest a negative MGMT status, with a potential response to Temodar, while a high percentage of MAPK positivity may indicate resistance to radiation therapy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of transglottic invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.0 cm, moderately differentiated, with vascular invasion present but no perineural invasion. A total of 39 regional lymph nodes were examined, all of which were benign, and the surgical margins, including tracheal and anterior soft tissue margins, were free of carcinoma. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT4a, with no evidence of prior malignancy or chemoradiation therapy.

The pathology report indicates that the left orchidectomy revealed a nonseminoma tumor with embryonal carcinoma (85%) and seminoma (15%) components, measuring 3 cm in diameter. The tumor is confined to the testis, with no evidence of angio-invasion or invasion of the rete testis. Overall, the findings suggest a localized testicular tumor without aggressive features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 1.7 cm well-differentiated (G1) invasive ductal carcinoma in the upper medial segment of the left breast. The resection margins and skin are free of carcinoma, confirming that the tumor was completely excised. The tumor staging is pT1c, G1, pL0, pV0, pN0 (0/1, SLN), pR0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal carcinoma from a partial nephrectomy, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2 out of 4 and a tumor size of 3.8 cm, confined within the renal capsule and without evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue shows no significant abnormalities. Additionally, biopsies from deep margins and surrounding adipose tissue are unremarkable and negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, classified as NHG3, with a tumor size of 4.3 x 6.2 x 2.2 cm and evidence of metastases in lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical analysis shows over 75% positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 testing reveals a negative reaction. The report also notes skin retraction and the presence of fibrous mastopathy lesions in the glandular tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast biopsy revealed atypical ductal epithelial hyperplasia and complex papillary proliferative lesions, among other benign changes. The right breast segmental mastectomy showed invasive ductal carcinoma with lobular features, measuring 3.2 cm, and extensive lymphovascular invasion, with one lymph node showing metastatic carcinoma and extravasation. The tumor is classified as Nottingham grade 2/3, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, and negative HER2/NEU status.

The pathology report indicates a 2.5 cm invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the upper lobe of the right lung, with a focus of perineural invasion but no evidence of pleural or angiolymphatic invasion. All examined lymph nodes and resection margins are free of tumor, and the pathologic stage is classified as T1N0Mx. Additionally, there are findings of emphysematous change and respiratory bronchiolitis-associated interstitial lung disease, with an addendum confirming that the rib specimen is also free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the superior laryngeal nerve showed no tumor present, while the cricothyroid membrane nodule revealed metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma with psammoma bodies. The total thyroidectomy specimen confirmed papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left lobe, with tumor extension through the thyroid capsule into the surrounding connective tissue and involvement at the posterior soft tissue resection margin. Additionally, lymph nodes from the left paratracheal and superior mediastinal tissue showed metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, while other examined lymph nodes and tissues did not show any tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, grade III, consistent with a high-grade glioma, based on the examination of tumor tissue that shows pleomorphic and infiltrative astrocytes with numerous mitoses. The report notes that there is no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis, confirming the malignancy. Additionally, some specimens were not received for analysis, but the findings were reviewed and interpreted by the signatory of record.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated monophasic synovial sarcoma measuring 3.2 cm in the left kidney, with significant mitotic activity and focal lymphovascular invasion, but negative margins at the ureter, artery, and vein. Additionally, the renal pathology evaluation revealed mild IgA nephropathy and moderate chronic changes in the kidney, including focal glomerulosclerosis and tubular atrophy. The findings suggest a complex case involving both a malignant tumor and chronic renal pathology, with further evaluation of the non-neoplastic kidney pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the rectosigmoid region, measuring 4.0 cm in length, with extensive tumor budding and perineural invasion, but no gross tumor perforation. Lymph node examination revealed metastasis in 3 out of 27 nodes, leading to a staging of pT3 and N1b according to AJCC 7th Edition criteria. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and immunohistochemical staining for DNA mismatch repair proteins shows retained expression in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a tumor size of 4.8 cm and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of III/IV. The tumor extends through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia, with no evidence of renal vein invasion and clear surgical margins. The report also notes areas of geographic necrosis and mild arteriosclerosis in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 14.5 cm eosinophilic type of papillary renal carcinoma in the right kidney, classified as T2, NX, M0, with a Fuhrman grade III. Additionally, there is extensive chronic pyelonephritis noted in the tissue. The findings suggest a significant renal tumor alongside chronic inflammatory changes in the kidney.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the mandible, tongue, soft palate, and hard palate, with evidence of focal invasion and mucosal ulceration. The left base of the tongue shows fragments of necrotic tissue with dysplastic squamous tissue, while four lymph nodes and the submandibular gland show no tumor presence. Additionally, there are microscopic foci of carcinoma at the resection margins, and focal vascular invasion by the tumor is noted, although no clear lymphatic or perineural invasion is observed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, classified as moderately to poorly differentiated (FIGO grade II-III), with a tumor size of approximately 2 cm and focal invasion into the myometrium. No carcinoma was identified in the endocervix or uterine serosa, but lymphovascular space invasion was present, and the surgical margins were clear of carcinoma. Additionally, reactive changes such as endometriosis, adenomyosis, and endosalpingiosis were noted in the adnexa and lymph nodes, with no metastatic carcinoma found in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) located in the right frontotemporal region of the brain, with evidence of high infiltration in all examined specimens. Immunohistochemical studies show strong positivity for p53 and a Ki-67 labeling index of up to 10%, suggesting a higher proliferative activity. Additionally, chromosome analysis reveals no deletions of 1p or 19q, which may have implications for prognosis and treatment response.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right temporal oligodendroglioma, Grade II, with a Ki-67 proliferation index of 4.5%, suggesting a relatively favorable prognosis compared to higher indices. Additionally, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) results show positive deletions of 1p and 19q, which are commonly associated with oligodendrogliomas. The report notes that further analysis is pending for additional tissue specimens, and clinical correlation is recommended.

The pathology report indicates that an excisional biopsy of the left tonsil revealed infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma of the transitional type. The specimen measured 3.2 x 2.2 x 2.0 cm and was described as irregular and lobulated in appearance. The patient is participating in an IRB-approved research protocol, and various tests were performed, although they have not been cleared or approved by the FDA.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right colon, with the tumor measuring 7.0 x 5.5 x 1.2 cm and invading through the muscularis propria into the subserosal fat (pT3). The surgical margins are negative for cancer, but one out of twenty-nine examined lymph nodes shows metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings include an unremarkable small bowel and an appendix with serosal fat necrosis.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right pelvic lymph nodes are negative for neoplasm, with four and five nodes examined respectively. A radical hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy revealed a poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma (Grade III) in the cervix, measuring 7 x 5 cm, with invasion into the lower uterine segment and myometrium, but surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, both ovaries contained benign simple cysts, and the uterine artery biopsy showed no pathologic change, with the tumor staged as pT2a2, NO (FIGO: IIA2).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 cholangiocarcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, with a circumscribed mass measuring 3.6 x 2.9 x 2.8 cm and negative surgical margins. Additional findings include a bile duct adenoma in segment 3, benign liver parenchyma in biopsies from segments 3 and 4, and non-necrotizing granulomatous inflammation in the hepatic artery lymph nodes, with no evidence of tumor. The report suggests a granulomatous reaction related to the neoplasm and recommends further clinical correlation to rule out other granulomatous conditions.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the falciform ligament showed vascularized fibroadipose tissue with no malignancy, while a lymph node in the posterior portal area was also negative for metastatic malignancy. However, two lymph nodes from the hepatoduodenal area tested positive for metastatic malignancy, and the Whipple procedure revealed invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, measuring 4.7 cm, with negative surgical margins and two out of sixteen lymph nodes involved. Additional findings included chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN3), with the tumor extending beyond the pancreas but without involvement of major vascular structures.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy, revealing chronic endocervicitis, nabothian cysts, and an endometrial polyp with complex hyperplasia and focal high-grade anaplastic mullerian-derived adenocarcinoma, along with metastatic nodules. Both left and right ovaries and fallopian tubes showed high-grade mullerian-derived adenocarcinoma, and there were metastatic lesions identified in the omentum. Lymph nodes excised from the pelvic region were reactive but negative for malignancy, suggesting localized disease without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a biopsy of the supraglottic larynx. The specimen consisted of multiple irregularly shaped fragments measuring a total of 1.3 x 1.3 x 0.5 cm, which were entirely submitted for examination. The report was reviewed by the attending pathologist, confirming the findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the right breast, with the largest tumor size estimated at 2.8 cm and positive surgical margins. Additionally, there is multifocal lobular carcinoma in situ present, and immunohistochemical staining shows positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 is not amplified. The specimen was obtained via needle localization, and the findings were consistent with a BIRADS IV mammogram.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in two out of thirty-six right lymph nodes, with no tumor found in the left lymph nodes. A total laryngectomy revealed a poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.0 cm, with transglottic and subglottic extension and involvement of the thyroid cartilage, but no perineural invasion and free surgical margins. The final diagnosis includes a pathologic stage of pT4 N2B, indicating advanced disease with lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph node from the right axilla shows metastatic carcinoma consistent with primary breast carcinoma, with one out of one lymph node positive for tumor. The right breast mastectomy specimen reveals invasive ductal carcinoma, grade II, with two distinct tumor masses and negative margins, while the axillary contents show no tumor in 35 lymph nodes examined. The left breast reduction specimen is negative for any specific pathologic changes or tumors.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade monophasic synovial sarcoma in the left leg, specifically involving subcutaneous tissue, skeletal muscle, and encasing large nerve trunks, with invasion into the talus bone. The tumor measures 10.5 x 8.2 x 7.2 cm and is predominantly viable, although the bone and soft tissue margins are negative for tumor. The specimen was obtained from a left below-the-knee amputation, and the report confirms that the diagnosis is based on a personal examination of the slides.

The pathology report describes a right lower lobectomy specimen containing a 40 mm well-differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma with a lepidic growth pattern and focal central necrosis. The excision margins are clear of malignancy, and all ten examined lymph nodes from the 11R group are free of cancer. While the tumor is consistent with a primary lung cancer, the possibility of it being a metastatic tumor cannot be ruled out.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of prostate cancer following a radical retropubic prostatectomy, with the tumor classified as invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7, involving both lobes of the prostate and measuring 1.3 cm in greatest dimension. There is no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes, and all surgical margins are free of carcinoma, indicating that the cancer is organ-confined without extracapsular extension. Additionally, perineural invasion is identified, and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is present, with a pathologic TNM stage of pT2c, pNO, and pMX.

The pathology report indicates that a right partial nephrectomy was performed, revealing a unifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, with a greatest dimension of 4.8 cm and a Fuhrman grade of 3 out of 4. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with no evidence of cancer at the resection margin or involvement of surrounding structures. Pathologic staging is classified as pT1b, with no significant findings in the nonneoplastic kidney or hilar lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right modified radical mastectomy due to infiltrating ductal carcinoma, which was classified with a Nottingham score of 9/9 and measured 8.0 by 3.0 by 1.5 cm. The tumor exhibited lymphovascular permeation, with 10 out of 15 lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma, including three with extracapsular extension, while surgical margins were free of tumor. Estrogen receptors were borderline positive, progesterone receptors were negative, and HER-2/NEU testing showed strong complete membrane staining, indicating a positive result.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in a liver lobectomy specimen, with a tumor size of 6x5x5 cm. The tumor exhibits trabecular and acinar patterns, with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, irregularly large hyperchromatic nuclei, and evidence of necrosis and lymphocyte invasion. There is no specified invasion into lymph nodes or veins, and the tumor is described as a single entity with no noted invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the mid esophagus, measuring 7.0 cm, with infiltrative and ulcerated characteristics, and evidence of lymphatic and perineural invasion. Metastatic disease is present in 9 out of 27 examined lymph nodes, primarily located at the celiac trunk and middle third paraesophageal regions, while the proximal and distal surgical margins are free of neoplastic involvement. Additionally, there is no evidence of neoplastic involvement in the infracarinal lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates mild chronic inflammation and focal cholestasis in the gallbladder, while the liver biopsies reveal well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma and cirrhosis, with mild stainable iron in Kupffer cells. Additionally, a small dysplastic nodule in segment 7 of the liver suggests early evolving hepatocellular carcinoma, alongside findings consistent with chronic hepatitis. Overall, the liver is characterized by cirrhosis with mild steatosis and low-grade atypia, but no carcinoma is seen at the specimen margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed endometrioid and serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with a revised AJCC pathologic stage of pT1A and FIGO stage IA, reflecting a change in the assessment of tumor invasion and lymph node involvement. The tumor exhibits superficial myometrial invasion with no evidence of serosal, cervical, or adnexal involvement, and lymphovascular space invasion is present; however, all examined lymph nodes (total of 24) are negative for malignancy. Additional findings include endometriosis and serous inclusion glands in both ovaries, with the cervix showing chronic cervicitis and the myometrium containing leiomyomas and adenomyosis.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder excision revealed chronic cholecystitis, while the liver resection of segments 5 and 6 confirmed the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma, with the tumor measuring 9.0 x 7.0 x 5.0 cm and showing no involvement of surgical margins.
