The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with a tumor size of 4.0 cm and invasion into the muscularis propria, along with focal carcinoma in situ. Metastatic urothelial carcinoma was found in two of eight right pelvic lymph nodes, while no carcinoma was identified in the left pelvic lymph nodes or in the biopsies of both ureters. The uterus, cervix, bilateral ovaries, and fallopian tubes showed no significant pathologic abnormalities or carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that a right neck dissection revealed 28 lymph nodes with no evidence of tumor (0/28), and the submandibular salivary gland showed focal chronic inflammation and squamous metaplasia. A partial glossectomy identified a moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma of the tongue measuring 1.7 cm, with no perineural or lymphovascular invasion and uninvolved margins. Additionally, mild dysplasia was noted in the squamous mucosa of the glossal mandibular sulcus, while other examined tissues, including the anterior and dorsum of the tongue, showed no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the omentum, both ovaries, fallopian tubes, and uterus, with evidence of metastasis to lymph nodes. The tumor is characterized by a maximum dimension of 12.5 cm, marked cytologic atypia, and vascular invasion, with a FIGO stage of IIIC. Additionally, there are findings of leiomyomas, adenomyosis, and chronic cystic cervicitis in the uterus, but the primary concern is the extensive spread of the carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the right portal lymph node was examined and found to have no tumor present. The resection of a right retroperitoneal mass revealed a diagnosis of paraganglioma, specifically an extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma, with the tumor being very close to the inked surface in some areas. Immunoperoxidase and in-situ hybridization tests were performed for diagnosis, and the laboratory is certified under CLIA for high complexity testing.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma (chromophobe type) in the right kidney, with the tumor measuring over 7 cm and confined to the kidney without evidence of lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. The tumor margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and there is no venous invasion noted. Additionally, a nodular piece of fibrovascular tissue was found in the vena cava, but no lymph nodes were identified in the submitted samples.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with myometrial invasion limited to the inner half and no serosal, cervical, or adnexal involvement. Lymphovascular space invasion is present, but all examined regional lymph nodes (25 total) are free of tumor. The tumor is classified as AJCC pathologic stage pT1a pNO pMX and FIGO stage IA, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptor status.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows nonspecific chronic and acute inflammation with no evidence of malignancy, while the common bile duct and level 8 lymph nodes are reactive and also negative for cancer. In contrast, the Whipple specimen reveals invasive moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, with significant local invasion and positive lymph-vascular and perineural invasion, as well as metastasis in 7 out of 19 peripancreatic lymph nodes. The tumor extends beyond the pancreas, with involved margins at the uncinate process, and the distal resection margin of the pancreas is free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right upper lobe lung adenocarcinoma with a predominantly micropapillary pattern, measuring 6 x 5.1 x 4.1 cm, and showing lymphovascular invasion but no perineural or visceral pleural invasion. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma was found in all examined lymph nodes, with one lymph node being negative for carcinoma. The EGFR analysis was negative for detectable alterations, and the final diagnosis remains unchanged despite the addendum.

The pathology report indicates that a left total nephrectomy and adrenalecomy were performed on a male patient, revealing a 15.5 cm chromophobe type renal cell carcinoma. The tumor was confined to the kidney without evidence of local invasion, renal vein invasion, or involvement of the adrenal gland, and surgical margins were free of tumor. The staging of the renal cell carcinoma is classified as pT2, indicating a tumor greater than 7.0 cm limited to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, characterized by 80% involvement of the endometrial surface and approximately 85% invasion of the myometrium, classified as grade 3 and stage II. Multifocal lymphovascular invasion is noted, with the adenocarcinoma also invading the endocervical glands and cervical stroma, while bilateral ovaries and omentum are negative for tumor. Lymph node dissection results show no tumor in the examined lymph nodes, confirming a negative status for metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma involving both ovaries, with surface involvement and metastatic spread to the omentum and small bowel serosa. Free floating tumor clusters were identified in the fallopian tubes, and the uterus showed no significant abnormalities except for atrophic changes and a sessile endometrial polyp. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IIIC due to macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade III serous endometrial adenocarcinoma, characterized by a polypoid mass in the anterior uterine wall, with minimal invasion into the myometrium and negative margins. While one of twenty right pelvic lymph nodes tested positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, the remaining lymph nodes and other examined tissues, including the ovaries and fallopian tubes, were negative for tumor involvement. Overall, the findings suggest a localized tumor with limited metastatic spread, classified as AJCC pT2b N1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with tumor invasion into the perivesical soft tissues and no vascular or perineural invasion identified. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and all examined pelvic lymph nodes are not involved with cancer. Additional findings include chronic cystitis in the bladder mucosa and various benign conditions in the female genital organs, such as endometrial polyps and leiomyomas.

The pathology report indicates that all excised margins from the tongue (dorsal, ventral, posterior, and anterior surfaces) are negative for malignancy. However, a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.1 cm was identified in the right ventral tongue, with no lymphovascular or perineural invasion, and all surgical margins were negative for malignancy. Additionally, lymph node excisions from levels I, II, and III were all negative for malignancy, corresponding to AJCC pathologic stage I (pT1, pN0).

The pathology report describes a right adrenal tumor measuring 75x60x30 mm, identified as a pheochromocytoma, characterized by solid and alveolar growth patterns with focal hemorrhages and atrophied cells. Immunohistochemical analysis shows sporadic S100 protein positivity and a low proliferation index (MIB 1 <2%). The tumor exhibits features such as high cellularity, necrosis, and cellular monotony, but does not meet the criteria for angioinvasion or significant capsular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of mixed type, characterized by both diffuse and intestinal components, with evidence of infiltration into the surrounding fatty tissue and penetration of the serosa. There are five regional lymph node metastases identified, while the resection margins at the mucosal level are tumor-free. The tumor classification is noted as pT4 N1 (5/29) LO V0 RO, indicating advanced disease with lymphatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a grade 3 poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma in the bladder, classified as pT2 due to invasion of the muscularis propria. The tumor exhibits a mixed papillary and solid growth pattern, with no vascular channel invasion identified. Additionally, the base of the tumor shows extensive infiltration by high-grade urothelial carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, conventional type, located in the left lobe of the thyroid, measuring 1.0 cm, with no extrathyroidal extension or lymphovascular invasion, and negative resection margins. Additionally, metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma was found in one of six lymph nodes from the left side, while the right facial lymph node showed no tumor presence. A pleomorphic adenoma of the submandibular gland, measuring 2.0 cm, was also identified, with margins free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that all examined lymph nodes from the left neck dissections (Level 1, 2A, and 3) and the salivary gland were negative for tumor involvement. A composite resection revealed moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma measuring 3.2 cm with infiltrative borders and a depth of invasion of 0.8 cm, but no perineural or vascular invasion was noted. Additional sections from the mandible and medial pterygoid plate were also negative for carcinoma, confirming clear margins in the resected specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the distal esophagus, with a tumor size of 7.0 cm in diameter. There are 7 positive lymph nodes associated with the tumor. The report notes that the resection was irradical, suggesting incomplete removal of the cancerous tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 5.5 cm, which invades the renal sinus fat but does not involve the renal vein. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the adrenal gland and paracaval lymph nodes are not involved, with the lymph nodes showing no signs of malignancy. The overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is pT3a, indicating local invasion into the adrenal gland or perinephric tissues but not beyond Gerota's fascia.

The pathology report indicates that both left and right distal ureter biopsies are negative for carcinoma, confirming the frozen section diagnoses. In contrast, the cystoprostatectomy reveals a high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the urinary bladder, measuring 6.5 cm, with invasion into the peri-vesicle soft tissue and extensive perineural invasion, while one out of fifteen lymph nodes shows metastatic involvement. The appendix shows no pathological changes, and all other examined lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of squamous, non-keratinizing carcinoma located in the upper lobe of the left lung, classified as grade 3. The tumor has a TNM staging of T2 N2 M0, suggesting it is locally advanced but has not metastasized. The tumor cell percentage is reported at 72%, and there is no current treatment indicated.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, follicular variant, located in the left superior lobe of the thyroid, with a largest tumor size of 2.1 cm and multifocality present. There is no evidence of extrathyroidal extension or lymphovascular invasion, and the resection margins are negative, indicating complete removal of the tumor. No lymph nodes were present for examination, and the remaining thyroid tissue appears grossly unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that a left renal mass was diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the chromophobe type, with the tumor focally reaching the renal capsule but not infiltrating perinephric fat. Frozen section analyses of the left renal mass margins showed no tumor in both the renal cortex and medulla. The inked margins of resection are free of tumor, confirming a successful surgical excision.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 3) in the endometrium, with focal vascular space invasion, while the cervix shows chronic cervicitis with no tumor identified. The myometrium contains a leiomyoma, and both ovaries and fallopian tubes exhibit physiological changes without any tumors. Additionally, all examined pelvic lymph nodes (16 total) are negative for metastatic carcinoma, confirming no regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of epithelial melanoma located on the back, with a Clark Level of 4 and a Breslow thickness of 10 mm. The tumor measures 10 mm by 12 mm, and there is no evidence of metastasis or normal tissue present. The melanoma is classified as Stage II, and the patient is undergoing neo-adjuvant immunotherapy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma with transglottic involvement in the right side of the larynx, extending into adjacent soft tissues and exhibiting extensive lymphovascular invasion. Metastatic squamous carcinoma was identified in one of two right paratracheal lymph nodes, while the left paratracheal tissue and other examined areas, including the pyriform sinuses and base of the tongue, showed no evidence of malignancy. The tumor forms an ulcerated mass measuring 2.5 x 2.5 x 1.0 cm, with involvement of the right supraglottis, glottis, and subglottis, and lymphovascular invasion noted in multiple sections.

The pathology report indicates that all examined lymph nodes from the right and left neck levels, totaling 57 nodes, were negative for malignancy. However, a moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue was identified, measuring 7.5 cm, with perineural invasion present and surgical margins negative for malignancy, although the tumor extends to within 0.3 cm of the right surgical margin. The findings correspond to AJCC pathologic Stage IVA (pT4a, pN0, pM0), and HPV testing has been ordered.

The pathology report indicates that no carcinoma was detected in any of the examined lymph nodes, totaling 22 nodes with 0 positive for metastatic tumor. A left lower lobe invasive squamous carcinoma was identified, classified as histologic grade 2-3, with a tumor size of 6 cm and unifocality. The final TNM stage is pT2b, pNO, pMX, and no tumor was found at the resection margins.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen with a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 10.0 x 11.0 x 1.5 cm, which has invaded the serosa. Details regarding lymph nodes, margins, and invasion characteristics are not specified. No additional pathologic findings or comments were provided in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical prostatectomy, revealing prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3 (total 7), affecting both lobes of the prostate and approximately 10% of the gland. There is evidence of perineural invasion, but no involvement of the margins, seminal vesicles, or periprostatic fat. Additional findings include benign prostatic hyperplasia and basal cell hyperplasia, with no lymph nodes sampled for analysis.

The pathology report indicates that a right orchidectomy was performed, revealing a seminoma with a diameter of 9.0 cm. There is no evidence of angio-invasion, invasion of the rete testis, or invasion of the tunica albuginea. Overall, the findings suggest a localized seminoma without aggressive features.

The pathology report indicates that parathyroid tissue was excised from the left inferior parathyroid gland, and a total thyroidectomy was performed revealing multifocal papillary carcinoma in both lobes of the thyroid, with the largest tumor measuring 2.5 cm. All 12 examined lymph nodes were negative for tumor, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. The tumor is classified as pT2, with uninvolved margins and no evidence of vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated serous carcinoma in the left ovary and fallopian tube, with a tumor size of 8 x 8 x 7 cm and intact capsule, while no ovarian surface involvement was identified. The right ovary and fallopian tube showed atrophic changes with no malignancy detected, and all examined regional lymph nodes (14 total) were negative for metastatic carcinoma. The report suggests that the serous carcinoma likely originated in the ovary, with secondary involvement of the fallopian tube, although the possibility of a primary fallopian tube carcinoma cannot be entirely excluded.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of primary invasive ductal adenocarcinoma of the right breast, classified as Nottingham grade 3 with a total score of 9/9. The tumor measures 1.3 cm and all surgical margins are negative for neoplasm, with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. Additionally, two lymph nodes were examined, and no metastasis was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, tall cell variant, located in the left lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 4.0 cm and minimal extrathyroidal extension. The tumor is unifocal, with one lymph node examined showing no evidence of metastasis, but the margins are involved by invasive carcinoma. Additional findings include nodular hyperplasia, and there is evidence of venous and lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower lobe lobectomy revealed a moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, grade 2, measuring 4.5 cm, with associated necrosis, but all surgical margins and five peri-bronchial lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. Additionally, fragments of lymphoid tissue from level 11 and level 7 lymph nodes were also negative for malignancy. The overall staging of the lung cancer is classified as pT2bNO(PLO).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 5.5 cm, with pleural invasion but clear surgical margins in the bronchial and chest wall areas. No metastatic carcinoma was identified in the examined lymph nodes, and additional findings included patchy acute bronchopneumonia in the uninvolved lung. The tumor was noted to have a satellite nodule, but there was no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous adenocarcinoma in multiple specimens, including the omentum, mesenteric colon, and both adnexa, with tumor sizes ranging from 4 cm to 28 cm. The left adnexa shows grade 2 involvement with both ovaries and peritoneal metastases, while the uterus and cervix exhibit serosal tumor extension. Notably, there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, but the tumor has infiltrated the left fallopian tube and uterine serosa.

The pathology report indicates the presence of extensive, poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with tumor extension to nearby lymph nodes and the middle lobe, classified as stage IV. Microscopic examination reveals no evidence of tumor in the lymph nodes, but there are signs of interstitial fibrosis, emphysema, and chronic pleuritis in the surrounding lung tissue. Additionally, a separate small tumor focus was identified in the middle lobe, classified as a satellite nodule, with associated inflammation and unclear etiology for the observed interstitial pulmonary fibrosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade infiltrating urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 2 cm, with invasion into the lamina propria and inner muscularis propria, but with negative surgical margins and no evidence of perineural or lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, there is a Gleason score 6 adenocarcinoma of the prostate involving both lobes, also with negative margins and no invasion. The ureter specimens were negative for malignancy, and the appendix showed no significant abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the uterus, measuring 1.9 cm in length and invading to a depth of 0.6 cm, with no evidence of tumor in the bilateral parametrium or vaginal cuff margins. A total of 29 lymph nodes were examined from both pelvic sides, with no evidence of malignancy found in any of them. Additional findings include benign conditions such as leiomyomas and hemorrhagic luteinized cysts in the ovaries, with no distant metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates that the left clavicle shows no tumor present, while the left radical neck dissection and left hemimandibulectomy reveal well-differentiated squamous carcinoma of the buccal mucosa, which has invaded the submandibular gland and soft tissue, but the resection margins are free of tumor. Additionally, there is metastatic squamous carcinoma identified in 1 of 20 cervical lymph nodes, with the metastatic tumor measuring 2.0 cm and no evidence of extranodal extension. The report also notes that various muscle and soft tissue specimens show no tumor present, and both the mandibular bone and left clavicle are pending further analysis after decalcification.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 8, in the right kidney, with the tumor measuring 1.3 cm and confined within the renal capsule, showing no invasion of the renal vein. The surgical margin is clear of tumor, being 0.2 cm from the resection margin, and there is an incidental finding of a small papillary adenoma. The frozen section diagnosis confirmed the presence of a renal cortical neoplasm with a stitched margin free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions. The prostatectomy reveals the presence of adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7, involving both lobes of the prostate, but it is organ-confined with no evidence of extraprostatic extension or lymph node involvement. Additionally, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is identified, and all surgical margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical hysterectomy and lymph node dissection due to a diagnosis of cervical cancer, specifically poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.0 x 2.5 x 1.5 cm. All examined lymph nodes (15 in total) were negative for tumor involvement, and the surgical margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, with a distance of 0.6 cm from the closest margin. The final pathologic staging is pT1b, pN0, and pMX, with additional findings of inactive endometrium.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma in the right temporal lobe, classified as grade IV due to the presence of necrosis, mitoses, endothelial proliferation, and significant pleomorphism. The specimen was received in two parts, with one part showing highly anaplastic astrocytoma without necrosis in the frozen section, while the final diagnosis confirmed glioblastoma multiforme. The diagnosis was established through comprehensive gross and microscopic examinations, reviewed by the attending pathologist.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma (grade 3) in the bladder, which is extensively invasive into the lamina propria and muscularis mucosae, but there is no definitive evidence of invasion into the muscularis propria. The tumor specimen measures 6.3 x 5.0 x 1.8 cm and consists of soft, rubbery tissue fragments. The clinical history notes a prior diagnosis of bladder cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma consistent with colon cancer, with the primary tumor showing poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma and evidence of invasion into surrounding tissues. The liver biopsy confirmed metastasis, while the gallbladder showed chronic cholecystitis, and the right kidney exhibited multiple cysts without malignancy. The cancer is staged as T4 N1 M1, indicating advanced disease with lymph node involvement and metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T1, N0, and M0, indicating it is a primary tumor with no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered at this time, and a separate blood sample was collected, which is reported as normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma, WHO Grade IV, in a right parietal brain mass, characterized by pleomorphic glial cells, mitotic figures, and areas of necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive staining for GFAP and a Ki67 proliferation index of 28%. The tumor margins could not be assessed, and additional tissue may be requested if clinically indicated.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal carcinoma in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 5.2 x 4.5 cm located in the mid and lower pole, and it is confined to the kidney without capsule penetration. The tumor exhibits a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3/4 and shows lymphovascular space invasion, but there is no evidence of transcapsular, renal vein, or vena caval invasion. Surgical margins, including soft tissue and ureteral margins, are free of tumor, and the staging code is TINXEX.

The pathology report indicates that the right kidney tumor was diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of unclassified type, with a greatest diameter of 2.5 cm and no evidence of local or renal vein invasion. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable. The tumor exhibits low-grade features with mixed tubulopapillary and cystic architecture, characterized by abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and uniform nuclei.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) in the right breast, measuring 3.5 cm, with a modified Scarff Bloom Richardson grade of 3, and negative surgical margins. Additionally, 12 out of 22 lymph nodes from the right axillary contents are positive for metastatic carcinoma, with focal extranodal involvement noted. The report also identifies ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) as a minor component, with no tumor found in the right posterior margin.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the uterine cervix reveals the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The carcinoma is invasive, suggesting that it has penetrated deeper tissues. This finding is significant for diagnosis and potential treatment planning.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast excisional biopsy revealed ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), cribriform type, with necrosis and microcalcifications, and DCIS is present at the medial margin. The left breast modified radical mastectomy showed invasive lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade 3, measuring 3.3 cm, with extensive involvement of the nipple dermis and metastatic carcinoma found in 20 of 24 lymph nodes. Additionally, there was a focus of invasive carcinoma in the fibroadipose tissue of the left axillary tissue, interpreted as extranodal extension.

The pathology report indicates extensive multifocal bilateral adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 4+5=9, showing extraprostatic lymphovascular invasion and involvement of both seminal vesicles. The report notes widespread extraprostatic extension and multifocal positive pathological margins, while the pelvic lymph nodes examined show no evidence of metastatic malignancy. The final pathological stage is classified as pT3bN0, confirming the aggressive nature of the disease.

The pathology report indicates a total thyroidectomy revealing multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma, including both conventional and follicular variants, with the largest tumor measuring 4 cm in the left lobe and a microcarcinoma in the right lobe measuring up to 0.3 cm. There is extensive lymphovascular invasion and perithyroidal extension, although the inked margins are negative for tumor, being within 1 mm of the closest margin. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma was found in all examined lymph nodes from the left level 6, with a total of 5 out of 14 lymph nodes involved.

The pathology report indicates that the tissue over the prostate is composed of fatty tissue with no tumor present, while the prostate gland shows adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7/10, indicating moderate aggressiveness. The tumor is confined to the prostate without extraprosthetic extension, and perineural invasion is present, but there is no lymphatic invasion or tumor at the specimen margins. The dominant nodule measures at least 1.5 cm, and the overall tumor extent is classified as 3/5.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and a histologic grade of 2 (of 4). There is no evidence of capsular invasion or involvement of surrounding structures, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, a tiny incidental medullary spindle cell nodule consistent with a microscopic leiomyoma was noted, but no lymph nodes were present in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 3.5 cm well-differentiated invasive ductal breast carcinoma in the left ablated breast, with focal lymphovascular invasion and skin infiltration. Additionally, there is an intraductal non-high-grade carcinoma of equal size exhibiting comedo necrosis, with minimum basal margins of 0.8 cm and 0.6 cm. The tumor is classified as M-8500/3, G1, pT4b, pL1, pN1a (2/21), pMX, and is staged as IIIB with R0 resection margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 1, with a tumor measuring 2.0 x 2.0 x 1.0 cm that invades 0.5 cm into the myometrium. The background endometrium shows complex hyperplasia with atypia, but there is no lymphovascular invasion, and the cervix is uninvolved. Additionally, both ovaries exhibit cortical inclusion cysts, and all examined lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical prostatectomy, revealing prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 3 = 6, involving approximately 20% of the prostate tissue in both the right and left lobes. There is no evidence of extraprosthetic extension, angiolymphatic invasion, or perineural invasion, although the tumor microscopically involves the left posterior and lateral surgical margin with a positive margin distance of less than 0.5 mm. The right and left seminal vesicles and vas deferens were negative for tumor, and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) was also noted.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the right upper parathyroid showed no pathological diagnosis, while a right thyroid lobectomy revealed a unifocal papillary carcinoma, oncocytic variant, measuring 2.9 cm, with minimal capsular invasion and uninvolved margins. Additional findings included adenomatoid nodules and focal nonspecific thyroiditis. The specimen was intact, and no regional lymph nodes were examined or involved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of uveal melanoma in the left eye, characterized by predominantly epithelioid cells and a tumor size of 17 mm. The tumor infiltrates the internal half of the sclera but does not extend beyond it, and there are no signs of intra-vascular tumor embolisms. Additionally, the optic nerve and surrounding meningeal tissues are free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a basaloid type squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.5 x 3.6 x 2.3 cm, involving the floor of the mouth, gingiva, tongue, and jaw, with lymph-vascular invasion noted but no perineural invasion. All examined lymph nodes (48 total) and the submandibular gland are free of neoplasia, and the surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive tumor. Additionally, there are foci of carcinoma in situ and intense stromal desmoplasia present.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated, nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma located in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring up to 2.8 cm, with a TNM classification of pT1 pNO pMX R0, indicating stage IA. Additionally, there are marked focal centroacinar pulmonary emphysema and reactive lesions in the lymph nodes, which also show anthracotic pigment deposits. Importantly, the tumor has not invaded the visceral pleura, bronchus, vessels, or any excised lymph nodes, suggesting clear resection margins.

The final pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe lung specimen shows poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 7 cm, with invasion into adjacent ribs and intercostal soft tissue, but all surgical margins are negative for carcinoma. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes excised from various levels are negative for metastatic carcinoma, and reactive mesothelial cells are noted in the pleural clot. Overall, the findings suggest localized lung cancer without evidence of lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) following a right parietal craniotomy for a malignant glioma, with evidence of extensive necrosis and microvascular proliferation in the tumor. Imaging shows a decrease in the enhancing lesion size, but there remains a heterogeneous focus of enhancement in the right parietal lobe, along with significant surrounding edema. Cytogenetic analysis reveals polysomy in several chromosomes, indicating a poor prognosis, as the patient exhibits multiple abnormal markers associated with a higher hazard of short survival.

The pathology report indicates the presence of Grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma, which invades the outer half of the myometrium with a maximum depth of 16 mm, and shows no lymphovascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions, as well as the para-aortic and common iliac areas, were benign with no evidence of metastasis. Additionally, the report notes the involvement of the fallopian tubes by the carcinoma, with benign findings in the ovaries and cervix.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue, with a significant tumor size of 8.1 cm and evidence of perineural invasion. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was identified in two lymph nodes from the right neck and one from the left neck, while the majority of lymph nodes examined showed no tumor presence. Margins from the glossectomy were free of invasive carcinoma, but there were areas of carcinoma in situ and severe dysplasia noted in various biopsies.

The pathology report indicates the presence of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in the liver, with a small mass in segment III and multiple masses in segments VII and VIII, all with negative surgical margins and no vascular space involvement. Additionally, mild chronic cholecystitis was noted in the gallbladder, along with a single benign cystic duct lymph node. The adjacent liver parenchyma shows mild steatosis and mild portal lymphocytic infiltrates.

The final pathologic diagnosis from the right Da Vinci laparoscopic partial nephrectomy indicates a unifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 1, measuring 2.4 cm, with no sarcomatoid features or evidence of invasion into perinephric fat or renal sinus. The tumor is classified as Fuhrman grade 2 of 4, and there is no involvement of the resection margin or lymph nodes. The pathologic stage is pT1a, indicating a localized tumor confined to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates a resected segment of the colon (sigma) containing an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that has infiltrated the perimuscular fatty tissue and shows two local lymph node metastases. Additionally, there are two small tubular adenomas with mild dysplasia and a small leiomyoma in the lamina muscularis mucosa. The resection margins are tumor-free, and the cancer is classified as G2, pT3, L1, V0, R0, pN1 with 2 out of 30 lymph nodes involved.

The pathology report indicates an excised lung tumor measuring 3 x 3 x 3 cm, diagnosed as poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. The tumor has invaded the visceral pleura and shows metastasis in 1 out of 1 examined lymph node. Immunohistochemical staining is positive for CD15, CK7, TTF1, and CEA, while negative for CK20 and CDX2.

The pathology report indicates that three sentinel lymph nodes were examined, and no carcinoma was found in any of them, with keratin immunostains pending. A right breast mass was identified as infiltrating, poorly differentiated ductal carcinoma measuring 1.7 cm, positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, and negative for HER-2, with final staging as pT1C N0 (sn) Mx. Additionally, there was evidence of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present, and the margins of the excised tumor were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the left radical resection of a retroperitoneal sarcoma revealed a dedifferentiated liposarcoma measuring 25 x 15 x 8 cm, which focally involved the distal pancreas and approached the adrenal gland and kidney, but surgical margins were free of tumor, except for the peritoneal margin which was less than 1 mm. The report also notes the presence of a benign multiloculated renal cyst as an incidental finding, and additional biopsies of the gonadal vascular margin and lateral margin were free of tumor. The dedifferentiated component of the tumor exhibited marked nuclear pleomorphism and frequent mitotic activity, with evidence of tumor necrosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, involving both sides of the prostate and comprising 10% of the sampled tissue, but without extraprostatic extension or involvement of seminal vesicles and vas deferentia. The surgical margins are negative, and no lymphovascular or perineural invasion is identified, with the tumor staged as pT2c and classified as pathologic stage IIB. Additionally, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is noted, but no regional lymph nodes were identified in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, from a left lobectomy of the thyroid, with the largest tumor nodule measuring 4 cm. The tumor is unifocal and classified as pT2, indicating it is greater than 2 cm but less than or equal to 4 cm and confined to the thyroid. There is no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion, and no lymph nodes were submitted for assessment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 1 endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma with 60% myometrial invasion, and negative margins of excision following a hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. All examined lymph nodes (13 in total) from the right pelvic, left pelvic, and periaortic regions were negative for carcinoma. Additional findings included unremarkable ovaries and fallopian tubes, along with adenomyosis and leiomyoma.

The final pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a laparoscopic right radical nephrectomy, revealing a unifocal clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 3.8 cm, with a Fuhrman grade of 2 and no sarcomatoid features. Additionally, the right adrenal gland was involved by an adrenal cortical adenoma measuring 0.8 cm, while the liver biopsy confirmed the presence of a hemangioma with no abnormalities in the adjacent liver parenchyma. The overall pathologic stage for the kidney tumor is classified as pT1a, pNX, pM-N/A.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 5.2 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3, and the tumor is confined to the kidney without invasion into surrounding tissues. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and no tumor is present in the examined lymph node or adrenal gland tissue. The tumor exhibits extensive hemorrhage and is well-circumscribed, located in the mid-to-lower pole of the kidney.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent resection of a left liver lobe containing a well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 8.0 cm, characterized by a predominantly trabecular pattern. The tumor is well circumscribed with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage, and there are focal changes suggestive of lymphovascular invasion, but it does not involve the surgical margins. The adjacent liver tissue appears normal without significant fibrosis or steatosis.

The pathology report indicates that a total thyroidectomy was performed, revealing a classical type of papillary carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid, measuring 1.0 cm, with focal blood vessel invasion but no extrathyroid extension or necrosis. Additionally, the excised Delphian node was confirmed to be a benign lymph node. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the remaining thyroid tissue shows nodular hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates that nine excised pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of neoplasia. A radical prostatectomy reveals prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, involving both lobes, with a maximum nodular diameter of 2.0 cm, evidence of extracapsular extension, and involvement of bilateral seminal vesicles, but all surgical margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, extensive perineural invasion is noted, and the pathologic TNM stage is pT3b, pNO, pMX.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from the right adrenal gland was diagnosed as a pheochromocytoma following an adrenalectomy. There is no evidence of capsular or vascular invasion, tumor cell necrosis, or significant mitotic activity. The specimen was described as a disrupted portion of adrenal tissue with a thin orange-tan cortical rim and central soft tan-gray medullary tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with glioblastoma, a high-grade astrocytic tumor, following excisional biopsies from the right frontal lobe. The tumor exhibits significant nuclear anaplasia, mitotic activity, and a MIB-1 proliferation index of 25%, along with necrosis and microvascular proliferation. Additionally, testing for MGMT promoter methylation was negative, suggesting that the patient may not benefit from therapy with alkylating agents.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade II, with invasion limited to less than or equal to half of the myometrium. The report also notes that all examined lymph nodes and omentum are benign, with no evidence of vascular or endocervical invasion. Additional findings include benign squamous mucosa in the cervix and abnormalities such as adenomyosis and leiomyomas in the myometrium.

The pathology report indicates a subtotal gastrectomy specimen with a 5 x 5 x 1 cm tumor located in the stomach, diagnosed as moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/9 positive). Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion, as well as margins and neo-adjuvant treatment, were not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma, with metastatic involvement in six of twenty-three right pelvic lymph nodes and one of ten left pelvic lymph nodes. The tumor has invaded through the bladder wall into surrounding tissues, including the perivesical fat and prostate, with positive margins noted at the right periprostatic soft tissue. Overall, the findings suggest a significant disease burden with a pTNM classification of pT4a, N2, MX, R1.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in three out of thirty-seven lymph nodes from the left neck dissection, with evidence of extracapsular extension. A total laryngectomy and base of tongue resection revealed a moderately differentiated supraglottic invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5.4 cm, which involved multiple structures but had free surgical margins and no vascular invasion. The right neck dissection showed thirty-one benign lymph nodes, confirming no metastatic disease on that side.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation, affecting the bladder and invading into the muscularis propria, with multifocal lesions observed. The uterus, cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes, and bilateral ovaries showed no significant abnormalities, and all examined pelvic lymph nodes (47 total) and distal ureter specimens were negative for tumor involvement. The tumor is staged as pT2b, N0, MX according to the 7th edition TNM classification.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenalectomy was performed, revealing a tumor weighing 208g and measuring 9.3 x 8.7 x 5.5 cm. The diagnosis is consistent with adrenal cortical carcinoma, supported by a Weiss score of 6. Additionally, the report notes the presence of chronic cholecystitis and cholecystolithiasis, with a history of cholecystectomy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon, classified as pT3 N2 with infiltration into the pericolic fatty tissue. A total of eight lymph node metastases were identified out of 30 lymph nodes examined. The tumor is classified as G2, with the presence of vascular invasion noted.

The final pathology report indicates that the right middle lobe lung lobectomy revealed invasive adenocarcinoma, poorly differentiated, measuring 4.5 cm, with invasion into the visceral pleura but not through it. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in the 11R lymph node, while the 10R, 2R, and 4R lymph nodes showed no tumor presence, and the 7R lymph node contained invasive adenocarcinoma with some involvement of lung tissue. The bronchial margin was free of invasive carcinoma, and the tumor was classified as pT2a with regional lymph node involvement classified as pN1.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in multiple specimens, including the omentum, ovaries, and right fallopian tube, with significant tumor involvement and invasion into surrounding tissues. The uterus and cervix show no evidence of carcinoma, while the distal ileum and large bowel exhibit extensive tumor infiltration through the muscularis propria. Additionally, the anterior abdominal wall peritoneal biopsy confirms the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated keratinizing invasive squamous cell carcinoma following a partial pharyngectomy, total glossectomy, left mandibulectomy, and left neck dissection, with the tumor measuring 11.0 mm in thickness and margins free of tumor. There is evidence of perineural and vascular/lymphatic invasion, with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma identified in 8 of 30 lymph nodes and multiple metastatic deposits in fibroadipose tissue and skeletal muscle. Additionally, chronic inflammation is noted in the salivary gland, but no tumor is present in that tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell type), nuclear grade II/IV, in the left kidney, with a tumor measuring 2.1 cm that is confined within the renal capsule and shows no invasion of the renal vein. There is focal tumor necrosis and fat necrosis in the perinephric soft tissue, but all surgical margins are free of tumor. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable, and the specimen includes a segment of ureter and dilated proximal ureter.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of squamous carcinoma invading the thyroid cartilage following a total laryngectomy and bilateral lymph node dissection, with the tumor graded as 2 and involving the left pyriform sinus and aryepiglottic fold. There is evidence of perineural and lymphovascular invasion, with metastatic squamous carcinoma found in 7 of 25 left lymph nodes, including extranodal extension in several nodes. The resection margins are free of tumor, and no tumor was detected in the thyroid gland or other examined mucosal areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a right insular tumor consistent with a low-grade oligodendroglioma (WHO grade II), characterized by a MIB-1 labeling index of 3.0%. Microscopic examination reveals a mildly to moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm with round nuclei and mild atypia, along with a minority component resembling fibrillary or gemistocytic astrocytoma. No mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, necrosis, or neoplastic ganglion cell components were observed in the examined sections.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the alveolar ridge, with a tumor size of 5.0 cm. There is no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion, and all surgical margins are uninvolved by carcinoma, with no metastatic carcinoma found in the eleven lymph nodes examined. Additionally, while osseous tissue is involved by carcinoma, the osseous margin remains uninvolved, and there is no neoplasia in the salivary gland.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated transitional cell carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 3 x 2.5 x 5 cm, with tumor extent involving the superficial muscle (inner half). There is no evidence of venous invasion, and the surgical margins are uninvolved. Additional details regarding lymphatic invasion and lymph nodes are not specified, and there is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with 100% involvement of the endometrial surface and 10% penetration into the myometrium, classified as FIGO stage IA. There is no evidence of lymphovascular space involvement, and all examined lymph nodes (five in total) are negative for tumor. Additional findings include chronic cervicitis, superficial adenomyosis, and leiomyoma, with no prior malignancy or chemoradiation therapy reported.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of iridociliochoroidal melanoma in the right globe, characterized by mixed spindled and epithelioid cell types, with invasion into the ciliary body, iris, and anterior chamber, as well as scleral invasion and extraocular extension. The tumor measures 19 mm at the base and 12 mm in height, with a mitotic rate of 2 per 10 high power fields, and the optic nerve and vortex veins are negative for tumor involvement. The primary tumor is classified as pT4d, with regional lymph nodes and distant metastases classified as pNx and pMx, respectively.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma located in the left liver, measuring 22x17x15 cm, with soft, solid, gray-white characteristics. Microscopic examination reveals trabecular and acinar patterns, with tumor cells exhibiting irregularly large, hyperchromatic nuclei and evidence of necrosis and vascular invasion. The tumor margins are uninvolved, and there is no indication of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma located in the liver, characterized by a 9.2 cm whitish nodule. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positivity for CK7 and negativity for CK20, CDX2, and TTF1, supporting the diagnosis of cholangiocarcinoma. Additionally, the liver tissue exhibits mild steatosis and fibrosis, with reactive lymphadenitis observed in multiple examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that all three excision biopsy specimens from the right temporal, deep temporal, and posterior temporal regions are diagnosed as glioblastoma with an oligodendroglial component, classified as WHO Grade IV. The tumors exhibit high-grade features including mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, and geographic necrosis, with a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 30%. Additionally, the loss of heterozygosity assay shows positive allelic loss on chromosome arm 19q, while no methylation of the MGMT promoter or EGFRvIII mutation is detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 16.0 cm, with a composition of 50% clear cells and 50% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 4 and exhibiting invasive characteristics into surrounding tissues, including the renal vein. The adrenal gland shows no evidence of tumor, and the soft tissue margins are free of tumor. Additionally, tumor thrombi are present within the renal vein, indicating vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a thymoma measuring 5.0 x 4.0 x 4.5 cm, classified as Type A/B with a dominant Type B1 component. The tumor is staged as pT2 and classified under Masaoka stage II.1. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive staining for CK5/6 and EGFR in epithelial cells, along with positive markers for immature T-lymphocytes including CD1a, CD5, and CD99.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has right breast cancer, specifically poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma, with a tumor size of 47 mm and involvement of the lateral surgical margin. Sentinel lymph node analysis revealed one positive lymph node for metastatic cancer, while the other three nodes were reactive. Estrogen and progesterone receptor tests returned negative results, and the overall classification is T2 N1 MX, Stage IIB.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 5.5 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of II/IV, and evidence of invasion into the renal vein but no capsular or perirenal soft tissue invasion. The AJCC classification is T3b Nx MX, and the renal artery, ureter, and Gerota's fascia margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, the renal pathology evaluation revealed moderate to severe arterial and arteriolar sclerosis, tubular atrophy, and chronic changes in the kidney parenchyma, likely secondary to vascular disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, nuclear grade II/IV, in a left posterior mid-pole renal mass measuring 3.7 cm, which is confined within the renal capsule with all surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, the non-neoplastic kidney shows signs of chronic pyelonephritis, nephrosclerosis, and a papillary adenoma. The peri-nephric fat specimen is reported as benign adipose tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver, with a tumor size of 8.7 x 7.4 x 6.0 cm. The margins of resection are free of carcinoma, although there is evidence of vascular invasion. Regional and distant metastasis assessments are inconclusive, as indicated by pNx and pMx classifications.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the excised lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions. The prostate examination reveals adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, involving both lobes, with a maximum nodular diameter of 2 cm, and showing extraprostatic extension and involvement of the seminal vesicles. All surgical margins are free of carcinoma, and the pathological staging is classified as pT3b N0 MX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of adenocarcinoma in an esophageal ulcer biopsy, with areas of ulceration noted. Additionally, the biopsy from an esophageal polyp shows Barrett's esophagus with high-grade dysplasia. The findings suggest at least pT1a adenocarcinoma with no definitive submucosal invasion observed, and correlation with endoscopic findings is recommended.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated, partially mucinous colorectal adenocarcinoma in the rectosigmoid colon, with invasive tumor spread to adjacent periproctic fatty tissue and lymphatic involvement. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN2 (4/19) L0, V0; G2, with four lymph nodes showing metastases. Both oral and aboral resection margins are tumor-free, and there are signs of old necrotic lesions in the mesocolic fatty tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated, deeply invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm in a partial mandibulectomy specimen, with evidence of pleural and perineural invasion. No tumors were found in the left mental nerve, right and left ventral tongue margins, and several alveolar ridge margins, except for the left alveolar ridge margin, which showed invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Additionally, the left new alveolar ridge margin exhibited focal dysplasia without invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left breast invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 2, measuring 1.5 cm, with lymphovascular space invasion present, but negative surgical margins. Two sentinel lymph nodes were biopsied, both showing benign results with no evidence of malignancy. The tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER2/NEU, with a pathologic stage of pT1a and pNO.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two moderately differentiated adenocarcinomas located in the splenic flexure area of the right colon, with the largest tumor measuring 2.9 x 2.6 x 0.5 cm and showing partial invasion through the muscularis propria, while the smaller tumor does not invade this layer. No lymphovascular invasion or metastatic carcinoma was identified in the 12 lymph nodes examined, and the surgical margins are clear, with the closest margin being 0.4 cm from the largest tumor. Additionally, a separate tubular adenoma without high-grade dysplasia was noted, and the tumors are staged as pT2, N0 for the largest and pT1, N0 for the smallest.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma in the left ovary and metastatic high-grade serous carcinoma in the omentum, with the metastatic tumor measuring 2.7 cm. The right ovary and fallopian tube showed no histopathologic abnormalities. The final staging is classified as T3c/NX/MX, indicating macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the distal rectum, measuring 3.6 x 2.2 x 0.6 cm, with invasion into the muscularis propria and identified perineural and lymphovascular invasion. Surgical margins are clear, with no metastasis found in the examined lymph node, and no precursor lesions or dysplasia identified in the surrounding tissue. The tumor is staged as pT2 according to AJCC criteria, indicating it has invaded the muscularis propria but has not spread to lymph nodes or other tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lung, with the tumor measuring 6 cm and all surgical margins negative for neoplasm. Out of 31 examined lymph nodes, 3 were involved with carcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes from various levels were negative for malignancy. The tumor was classified as pT2b and pN1, with lymph-vascular invasion present but no visceral pleura invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma, moderately to poorly differentiated, in biopsies from the right oral pharynx. An immunohistochemical stain for P16 is positive, suggesting a potential association with HPV. Additionally, biopsies from the left tongue base are reported as normal and submitted for research purposes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated, Grade 3 transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder, which is invasive but has clear circumferential margins and no vascular invasion. Additionally, there are multiple foci of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 3 = 6 found at the urethral resection margin, along with high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia. Overall, the bladder carcinoma is classified as pT2 and is completely excised, while the prostate carcinoma is also classified as pT2.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the lung, measuring 5x3 cm, with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. Five examined lymph nodes showed no metastasis, and there is an abscess noted in the lung tissue. Additionally, the report describes anthracosis in the lymph nodes, and the tumor is classified as localized with indeterminate features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma, classified as grade 2. The TNM staging shows T2, N0, M0, indicating a primary tumor with no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No specific treatment has been initiated at this time.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a clear cell renal carcinoma in the right kidney, classified as Fuhrman Grade 3, with a tumor size of 16 cm that invades the renal vein and perinephric fat, but the surgical margins are uninvolved by carcinoma. Additionally, four benign aorto-caval lymph nodes were identified, and the pathology stage is reported as pT3b pN0 pMX. The adrenal gland was not involved, and the report has been amended to clarify that the tumor mass at the superior pole of the kidney does not represent metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that both sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. A segmental mastectomy of the left breast reveals invasive ductal carcinoma, well-differentiated (Grade 1), measuring 1.6 cm, along with focal intraductal carcinoma (DCIS, Grade 2) comprising less than 5% of the tumor, with clear surgical margins. Additional tests show the invasive carcinoma is negative for neuroendocrine markers and HER-2/neu gene amplification, with a low Ki-67 proliferation index of 10%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma in the colon and rectosigmoid region, with the tumor extending 3.5 cm from the resection margin and encircling the colon wall over a length of 6 cm. The invasive tumor has spread through all layers of the intestinal wall into the adjacent mesocolic fatty tissue, but both the oral and aboral resection margins are free of tumor. Additionally, all 33 examined mesocolic lymph nodes are tumor-free, and the tumor is staged as pT3 pNO (0/33) LO V0; G2.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of a right frontal brain mass reveals the presence of glioblastoma multiforme, characterized by marked nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic activity, and necrosis. Malignant cells were confirmed to be positive for GFAP and negative for pankeratin. The final diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme based on the microscopic examination of the tissue samples.

The pathology report indicates that a vaginal biopsy was performed, revealing the presence of carcinosarcoma, which is consistent with the patient's previous diagnosis of uterine carcinosarcoma. The specimen consisted of multiple pale tan tissue fragments measuring a total of 2 x 1.5 x 0.4 cm. The report has been reviewed and approved by the resident physician.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma of the colon with focal penetration into the muscularis and infiltration of pericolic fat, accompanied by necrosis and a moderate lymphocytic inflammatory response. Both the oral and aboral resection margins are tumor-free, and the lymph nodes show reactive hyperplasia without evidence of metastasis. Additionally, there are tubulovillous adenomas with slight dysplasia, and the omentum contains metastasis from a poorly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma, which is distinct from the primary colon adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma, WHO grade IV, in the right parietal region of the brain, with evidence of dural involvement. The tumor exhibits characteristics of a high-grade astrocytic tumor, including microvascular proliferation and necrosis. Additionally, focal psammoma-type microcalcifications suggest that the glioblastoma may have originated from a pre-existing slow-growing lesion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of colorectal adenocarcinoma in a colon resection specimen, characterized by extensive ulceration and infiltration into pericolic fatty tissue, with five regional lymph node metastases. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN2 (5/12) pM1, indicating advanced disease with clinical liver metastases, but the resection margins are tumor-free. Additionally, there is no evidence of inflammation or tissue heterotopy in the small intestine or Meckel's diverticulum.

The pathology report indicates that a left adrenal tumor was received, measuring 4.2 x 3.2 x 3.2 cm, with characteristics of a pheochromocytoma, including gray-tan and bright yellow foci, and areas of hemorrhagic tissue. The tumor was encapsulated and showed normal adrenal gland tissue densely adhered to its capsule. Both frozen section and permanent section analyses confirmed the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in the mandible, measuring 4.3 cm, with no bony involvement and close margins. In the right neck dissection, two out of 39 lymph nodes showed metastatic SCC with extracapsular extension, while the salivary gland and other lymph nodes examined showed no evidence of carcinoma. Additional margin biopsies from various sites also revealed no carcinoma, confirming the extent of the disease and the status of the surrounding tissues.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes excised from various locations are negative for malignancy, while a lobectomy of the right upper lobe reveals invasive adenocarcinoma of acinar type, measuring 3.2 x 3.1 x 2.1 cm, with negative surgical margins. Additionally, there are no signs of vascular or lymphatic invasion, and the pathologic stage is classified as pT2a pNO pMX Stage 1b. The report also notes the presence of emphysematous changes in the lung tissue and a separate nodule adjacent to the primary tumor, which is not malignant.

The pathology report indicates that one of four sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla contains isolated tumor cells, while the right breast needle localization wide excision reveals invasive lobular carcinoma measuring at least 3.5 cm, with tumor present at the anterior margin. The tumor is classified as SBR Grade 2, multifocal, and associated with lobular carcinoma in situ, with no tumor identified in the intramammary lymph node or skeletal muscle. The Oncotype DX assay shows a recurrence score of 29, suggesting a 19% average rate of distant recurrence at 10 years.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast tissue is negative for tumor, with focal calcifications present, while the left breast shows infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, forming a 4.7 x 4.0 x 2.7 cm mass, with negative margins and no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or ductal carcinoma in situ. All ten sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla are negative for tumor involvement. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals negative results for estrogen and progesterone receptors, as well as HER2/neu overexpression.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, characterized by a 4.5 x 4 x 3 cm mass that extends close to the bronchial margin and is associated with extensive in situ carcinoma. The tumor does not invade the pleura, but there is evidence of obstructive pneumonia in the adjacent lung tissue. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes, including intrapulmonary peribronchial and aortic nodes, show metastatic involvement by squamous cell carcinoma, while several other lymph nodes are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a resected colon sample from the rectosigmoid region containing an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The tumor has infiltrated the perimuscular fatty tissue but shows no evidence of local lymph node metastases. The resection margins are tumor-free, and the tumor is classified as G2, pT3, with a total of 29 lymph nodes examined, all negative for metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous adenocarcinoma in the right ovary, classified as FIGO grade 2 with substantial areas of grade 3, and the tumor measures 15.0 x 11.0 x 9.0 cm. Metastatic tumors were also identified in the omental nodule, left ovary, and cul de sac, while no tumor was found in the examined lymph nodes, uterus, or left fallopian tube. The overall path staging is classified as 3C FIGO, indicating advanced disease.

The pathology report describes a left adrenal gland tumor consistent with a pheochromocytoma, measuring approximately 4.5 x 5 x 4 cm, which is encapsulated and shows features such as cystic defects, hemorrhage, and calcification. Microscopic examination reveals polymorphic tumor cells with no mitotic activity, necrosis, or angio-invasion, indicating a low likelihood of malignancy. The tumor was completely excised with a minimum margin of 1 mm, although there is focal invasion into the surrounding adipose tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adrenocortical carcinoma with evidence of infiltration into the vena cava and a lung specimen showing bronchoalveolar carcinoma. The tumor measured 5.5 cm and exhibited a van Slooten index of 25.8 and a Weiss score of 4. Additionally, the lung specimen had a KI67 proliferation index of 3% and a Hough score of 2.44.

The pathology report indicates that a right radical nephrectomy was performed due to a right renal mass, which was diagnosed as clear cell carcinoma with papillary features, measuring 5.0 x 3.6 x 4.0 cm. The tumor is well-circumscribed, confined to the kidney, and shows no invasion into the renal capsule or renal veins, with a nuclear grade of II. Pathologic staging is T1, NX, M0, and the margins are not involved, indicating a localized tumor without evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 3.6 cm, found in a left hemithyroidectomy specimen, with mild nodular hyperplasia also noted. The tumor is unifocal, totally encapsulated, and shows no evidence of capsular invasion, lymph-vascular invasion, perineural invasion, or extrathyroidal extension, with uninvolved margins. Additionally, there are no regional lymph nodes examined or involved, and the specimen is intact with no signs of distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type) in the mid right kidney, measuring 7.0 cm, with a predominant Fuhrman nuclear grade of II/IV, confined within the renal capsule and exhibiting an occlusive tumor thrombus in the main renal vein. There is microscopic angiolymphatic invasion in a small peritumoral blood vessel, but all surgical resection margins are benign, and a benign perirenal lymph node was identified with non-necrotizing granulomas. Additionally, the right adrenal gland showed a benign adrenal cortical adenoma with no evidence of malignancy, and the interaortocaval lymph node excision revealed a benign lymph node and adipose tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade mixed carcinoma, consisting of high-grade serous carcinoma and grade 2 endometrioid carcinoma, in both the left and right ovaries, with tumor extension to the fallopian tubes. Additionally, metastatic high-grade mixed carcinoma is identified in the uterine serosa, outer myometrium, appendix, and omentum, along with a nodule in the cul-de-sac. The report also notes findings of endometriosis and adenomyosis in the affected areas.

The pathology report indicates that the left adrenal mass was diagnosed as a paraganglioma, measuring 3.5 cm, which infiltrates adjacent adipose tissue and extends to the resection margin, but shows no necrosis. The retroperitoneal masses were biopsied and found to be portions of benign ganglion with no evidence of neoplasm. The tumor cells exhibited strong positive staining for chromogranin and synaptophysin, with a low proliferative fraction.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 2) of the uterus, with a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 0.8 cm and no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion. The cervix, serosa, and margins are free of tumor, and multiple lymph nodes from various sites are negative for carcinoma. Additional findings include a benign hernia sac and unremarkable right and left tubes and ovaries.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix based on a biopsy specimen. Microscopic examination revealed sheets and nests of malignant cells with pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei, consistent with the diagnosis. The findings were confirmed by intradepartmental consultation and highlighted by immunohistochemical staining.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 2.4 cm conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, classified as Fuhrman's nuclear grade 4. The tumor is well-circumscribed and bulges into the perinephric adipose tissue but shows no evidence of invasion into the adipose tissue or lymphatic/vascular invasion. Surgical margins, including vascular and ureteral margins, are free of tumor, and the surrounding non-neoplastic kidney parenchyma appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma following a robotic prostatectomy, with a Gleason score of 3 + 3 and approximately 20% of the prostate involved by the tumor, which is confined within the prostatic capsule. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or involvement of the seminal vesicles, and the surgical margins are uninvolved by tumor. The AJCC staging is reported as pT2c, pNX, and additional findings include benign prostatic hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma located in the head of the pancreas, measuring 4.5 cm, with no evidence of lymph node metastases in the examined lymph nodes. Surgical margins are free of neoplasm, and there is no evidence of angiolymphatic or venous invasion. Additional findings include chronic pancreatitis and islet cell hyperplasia, with the gallbladder and other examined organs appearing unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical type papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, with a follicular variant, well differentiated, located primarily in the right lobe measuring 1.5 cm in diameter. The tumor shows no mitotic activity, necrosis, or blood vessel invasion, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, there is a single focus of papillary microcarcinoma in the left lobe, while the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue shows no abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colon, classified as grade 3 (G3), with invasion through all layers of the colon wall and vascular infiltration, categorized as pT3, L1, V1. The resection margins are free of tumor in both the mucosal and ligature regions, and there is evidence of chronic recurrent appendicitis with fecal impaction. The tumor classification is ICDO-DA-M G3, with no regional lymph node involvement (pNO 0/14).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, oncocytic variant, measuring 1.4 cm, from a right hemithyroidectomy specimen. The tumor is unifocal, totally encapsulated, with minimal capsular invasion, and no lymph-vascular or perineural invasion identified. Margins are uninvolved by carcinoma, and there are no additional pathologic findings or regional lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma with extranodal extension, affecting multiple lymph nodes in both the right and left neck, with a total of 27 out of 80 examined lymph nodes showing metastasis. The primary tumor, located in the right lobe of the thyroid, measures 1.2 cm and exhibits widely invasive characteristics with psammomatous dissemination, although no definitive vascular invasion is identified. Additionally, there are no pathological findings in the left jugulodigastric lymph node, right upper parathyroid, and thymus specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, with the tumor being unifocal and measuring 13.8 cm, limited to the kidney but extending into the renal sinus vein. The tumor is classified as pT2, with venous invasion present and margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additional findings include positive staining for PAX-2, C-kit, and CK7, while regional lymph nodes and distant metastasis could not be assessed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with bronchioloalveolar features in the upper lobe of the right lung, which has infiltrated into the pleura. Five hilar lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for tumor involvement, and the bronchial and vascular margins are also negative for tumor. The pathologic stage of the carcinoma is classified as pT2pN0pMX, corresponding to Stage I.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell adenocarcinoma in the right kidney, specifically located in the lower pole with a size of 3.7 x 3.0 cm. The tumor extends to the kidney capsule but does not penetrate through it, and there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or involvement of surgical margins. The nuclear grade is assessed as Fuhrman grade 2/4, and the adrenal gland was not resected during the nephrectomy.

The pathology report indicates that the right external iliac and obturator lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for malignancy, with no cancer detected in the two lymph nodes sampled. In contrast, the prostate excision revealed prostatic adenocarcinoma with a high Gleason score of 4+5=9, indicating a high-grade tumor primarily located in the right lobe and involving the right posterior lateral margin. The tumor was noted to involve approximately 40% of the prostate, with perineural invasion present, but no extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates that the pelvic lymph node dissection revealed four benign hyperplastic lymph nodes, while the radical prostatectomy showed the presence of adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7/10, involving both lobes of the prostate and exhibiting perineural invasion. There was no seminal vesicle involvement or lymphovascular space invasion, and the surgical margins were negative except for a close margin in the mid left posterior region. Additionally, severe chronic prostatitis was noted, and the pTNM stage was classified as pT3a, N0, Mx.

The pathology report indicates a tumor in the right lower lobe of the lung measuring 4.8 x 3.5 x 3.0 cm, diagnosed as adenocarcinoma with a mixed subtype that includes papillary, acinar, and solid components.
