There is no infiltration of the visceral pleura noted. The tumor classification is pT2, with lymph node involvement classified as pN1 (2 out of 54 nodes), and it is graded as G3.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with invasion into the muscularis propria and perivesical soft tissue, as well as urothelial carcinoma in situ. Metastatic urothelial carcinoma was found in three out of fourteen lymph nodes, with extranodal extension noted in both right and left pelvic lymph nodes. Additionally, the prostate showed prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6, but no evidence of extraprostatic extension or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the left retroperitoneum, with a well-differentiated liposarcoma component, measuring 21.0 cm, and extending to the renal capsule without involving the renal parenchyma or adrenal gland. The left kidney and adrenal gland were removed during a radical nephrectomy and adrenalectomy, and the resection margins were reported as uninvolved. Additionally, the spleen showed no significant pathological changes following splenectomy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated, large cell, nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, with significant tumor growth causing displacement of the bronchus and infiltration into surrounding tissues. The resection margins, including the bronchus and lymph nodes, are reported to be tumor-free, suggesting complete removal of the tumor. The final classification is pT1 pNO RO, stage IA, indicating an early stage of lung cancer with no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that a radical nephrectomy was performed on the left kidney, revealing a unifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma measuring 6 cm, with no evidence of lymph-vascular invasion and uninvolved surgical margins. The tumor is classified as pT1b, indicating it is limited to the kidney and measures more than 4 cm but not more than 7 cm in greatest dimension, with no regional lymph node metastasis identified. Additionally, nonneoplastic findings include glomerular sclerosis and chronic interstitial nephritis in the remaining kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma (WHO IV) characterized by nuclear anaplasia, significant mitotic activity, and a high proliferation index of 33%. The tumor shows extensive necrosis and infiltration into the surrounding brain tissue, with microscopic areas present in the leptomeningeal space. Additionally, tests for the EGFR variant III mutation and methylated MGMT promoter were both negative, suggesting a specific molecular profile of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of lung cancer, specifically adenocarcinoma, with a TNM staging of T3 N2 M0. The primary tumor tissue was obtained from the upper right lung, weighing 450 mg, and shows a cellular tumor percentage of 70%. There is no prior chemotherapy or hormonal treatment noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma following a total gastrectomy, with a maximum tumor diameter of 9 cm and infiltration into the perigastric fatty tissue and serosa. There are thirteen regional lymph node metastases identified, while both the oral and aboral resection margins are tumor-free. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN2 (14/58) pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, confined within the thyroid tissue with no evidence of extracapsular extension. The total thyroidectomy specimen shows a well-defined tumor in the left lobe, with no tumor present in the parathyroid tissue or lymph nodes examined. The surgical margins are clear of tumor involvement, and the tumor exhibits a friable and papillary nature.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right lobe, characterized as a dominant widely invasive mixed follicular and columnar cell variant with focal tall cell change, measuring 1.7 cm, alongside severe chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. The left lobe also contains a classical papillary carcinoma measuring 1.0 cm, with no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis. Additionally, the parathyroid and lymph nodes examined showed no pathological diagnosis, and the parathyroid glands were within normal limits.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the right tonsil revealed a fragment of non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. The specimen was received unfixed and underwent intraoperative consultation, confirming the presence of malignancy. Microscopic examination supported the diagnosis, and the laboratory is certified to perform high-complexity clinical testing.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), occupying 10-15% of the prostate volume, and no evidence of extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, or lymphovascular invasion. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, and no lymph nodes were present in the specimen. Additional biopsies of the left lateral and urethral margins showed no malignancy, although the urethral margin exhibited extensive cautery artifact.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, staged as pT3 pN1, stage IIB, with a tumor size of 2.5 cm located in the head of the pancreas. The tumor exhibits perineural invasion but no angiolymphatic invasion, and it has invaded peripancreatic soft tissues, with one out of 23 regional lymph nodes showing metastasis. Surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, with the closest margin being 0.1 cm from the invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pharyngeal and laryngeal carcinoma, with findings of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes from both the right and left neck, including evidence of extracapsular spread. The laryngopharyngectomy specimen revealed moderately differentiated infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma with invasion into surrounding structures, including the thyroid and cricoid cartilages, and perineural invasion was noted. The final pathological staging is pT4a, N2c, Mx, with clear margins on resection and no tumor identified at the esophageal margin.

The pathology report indicates a classic seminoma located in the left testis. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion, and the surgical margins are free of neoplasia. The immunohistochemistry findings support the diagnosis of seminoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous papillary adenocarcinoma in the endometrium, with invasion into the myometrium to a depth of 3 mm and involvement of the lower uterine segment, along with vascular space invasion. The left fallopian tube also shows evidence of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma, while the right fallopian tube and both ovaries are free of malignancy. All examined lymph nodes and the omentum show no evidence of malignancy, suggesting no metastatic spread beyond the primary tumor site.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a mixed germ cell tumor in the left testicle, comprising 50% seminoma, 45% mature teratoma, and 5% embryonal carcinoma, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm and unifocality. The tumor does not invade surrounding structures, including the epididymis, tunica vaginalis, spermatic cord, and paratesticular soft tissues, with negative surgical margins. The AJCC staging is pT1 pNx pMx, and further comprehensive review is recommended for final staging.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph node was negative for tumor involvement (0/1). In the left breast, two separate foci of invasive ductal carcinoma were identified, with the larger tumor measuring 2.2 cm and a Nottingham score of 6/9, while the smaller tumor measured 1.3 cm with a Nottingham score of 7/9; both tumors had free surgical margins. Additionally, there was perineural involvement present, and the report noted the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ comprising 10% of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the right adrenal gland was diagnosed with pheochromocytoma following an adrenalectomy, while the spleen, examined during a splenectomy, showed evidence of sarcoidosis without any tumors or metastatic pheochromocytoma. Special stains were performed, revealing no fungal organisms or mycobacteria, and clinical correlation is recommended to determine the etiology of the sarcoidosis. The report confirms that the specimens were processed according to established laboratory standards, although some diagnostic tests used have not been cleared or approved by the FDA.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of stomach adenocarcinoma, specifically a tubular and poorly differentiated type (G3, pT2, pN2), with evidence of vascular invasion and metastasis to lymph nodes (13 out of 18). The tumor, measuring 7.8x6.4x1.3 cm, is located in the pyloric region and infiltrates the entire thickness of the stomach wall and surrounding fat tissue. The excision margins are free of neoplastic lesions, suggesting complete removal of the primary tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 8 (4+4) and a tertiary pattern of 3, with 30% of the prostate involved by carcinoma. Seminal vesicle invasion and lymphovascular invasion are present, while surgical margins are free of invasive carcinoma. Lymph node involvement is noted with one metastasis in the right external iliac and one in the left paravesical, leading to a pathological staging of pT3b, pN1, pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma in the right supraglottic larynx, with tumor extension into the anterior commissure, left supraglottic larynx, and epiglottis, measuring 2.5 x 2.0 x 1.5 cm, while resection margins are free of tumor. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from both the right and left neck were examined, with no evidence of metastatic disease found in any of them. Focal severe dysplasia of the squamous epithelium was noted in the right posterior mucosal margin, but all other margins showed no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6 (3+3), characterized by a dominant tumor nodule measuring 1.5 cm and focal capsular penetration, along with a positive surgical margin at the right posterior apex. The pathologic stage is classified as pT3aN0M0, and five excised bilateral pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of metastasis. The report confirms the presence of multifocal lesions within the prostate, with a total involvement of approximately 6.2% of the gland.

The pathology report indicates two distinct findings from radical resections of chest wall masses. The right mass is diagnosed as a schwannoma with free margins and one benign lymph node, while the left mass is identified as a high-grade myxofibrosarcoma measuring 5.4 cm with approximately 20% necrosis and close margins. The report confirms that the findings are based on personal examination of the specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear) cell type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 out of 4. The tumor measures 13.5 cm, extends through the renal capsule into perirenal fat, and shows microscopic invasion of a branch of the renal vein, but all surgical margins are free of neoplasm. The TNM staging is pT3a NX MX, and the non-neoplastic kidney and adrenal gland are unremarkable, with no lymph nodes identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, classified as grade II, with a tumor size of approximately 5 cm and greater than 50% myometrial invasion. There is no involvement of the cervix or metastasis to regional lymph nodes, as all examined lymph nodes were free of cancer. Additional findings include non-neoplastic changes in the endometrium and ovaries, with no evidence of metastatic disease in the ovaries or fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type) with a nuclear grade of IV, measuring 10 cm, and showing direct extension into the liver and duodenum, classified as pT4. Vascular invasion is present, but all surgical margins are free of tumor, with no metastatic lymph nodes identified. Additionally, the gallbladder specimen is reported as benign.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of infiltrative duct carcinoma in the left breast, with a tumor measuring 13.6 cm and a Scarff-Bloom-Richardson grade of 3, indicating poorly differentiated cancer. There is multifocal angiolymphatic invasion and involvement of five positive lymph nodes, with the largest node measuring 1.6 cm and exhibiting significant tumor involvement. Surgical margins are reported as uninvolved, and there is a focal extension of the tumor into the epidermis without ulceration, classifying the cancer as stage IIIB.

The pathology report indicates that both left and right supraomohyoid neck dissections showed no tumor presence in the examined lymph nodes and submental glands. A well-differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma with verrucous features was identified in the floor of the mouth and anterior mandible, measuring 4.5 x 3.5 x 2.0 cm, with vascular invasion noted but clear margins. Additionally, the left posterior ridge exhibited focal parakeratosis and chronic inflammation, with no tumor detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 3 cm clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, classified as grade 2. The tumor is well-circumscribed and located at the junction of the renal parenchyma and renal sinus, with no evidence of vascular invasion or malignancy in the renal capsule, renal sinus, or hilar margins. The pTNM staging is T1a, and additional pieces of yellow soft tissue were also received for analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, confirmed through multiple excisional biopsies from the right parietal region of the brain, with varying degrees of tumor necrosis and high cellularity. Immunohistochemical analysis shows retained expression of PTEN and significant positivity for pMAPK, suggesting potential resistance to radiation therapy, while the presence of EGFR amplification indicates a possibility for responsiveness to targeted therapies. The report highlights the aggressive nature of the tumor, with elevated expression of laminin beta 1 and decreased expression of laminin beta 2, which may predict a worse prognosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 5.0 cm, with a composition of 20% clear cells and 80% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, and confined to the kidney without invasion into surrounding tissues. Additionally, a renal adenoma (0.1 cm) and a renal cortical cyst were noted, with resection margins free of tumor and no tumor present in the adrenal gland. The tumor exhibits areas of hemorrhage and necrosis but does not invade the renal sinus or renal vein.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 adenocarcinoma with mucinous features in the head of the pancreas, forming a diffusely infiltrative mass measuring 4.5 x 2.8 x 2.2 cm, which extends to peripancreatic soft tissue and the adjacent duodenal wall. The tumor involves the common bile duct and pancreatic duct, with angiolymphatic invasion noted, and multiple peripancreatic lymph nodes (7 out of 21) are positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the pancreatic body and common hepatic duct margins are negative for tumor. The uncinate margin is involved by tumor, indicating a more advanced stage of disease.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an astrocytic tumor characterized by increased cellularity and pleomorphism, with detectable mitotic activity. Focal proliferation is noted to be up to 10%. The final diagnosis is anaplastic astrocytoma, classified as WHO grade III.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left pelvic lymph nodes are benign, with no cancer involvement. The prostate resection reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+4=8, but the surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and there is no evidence of extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle invasion. The tumor involves approximately 33% of the prostatic tissue, and the pathologic staging is classified as pT2c with no regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that a left segmental mastectomy was performed due to a left breast mass, which was diagnosed as medullary carcinoma measuring 2.0 cm, with clear margins and no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. Additionally, twelve lymph nodes from the left axilla were examined and found to be free of tumor. The tumor exhibited poor nuclear grade and a lymphocytic component, with further evaluation of estrogen and progesterone receptors pending.

The pathology report indicates multiple sites of poorly differentiated papillary serous carcinoma, including the ovaries, fallopian tubes, bladder, cul-de-sac, sigmoid serosa, uterus, pelvic lymph node, appendix, and umbilicus, with evidence of metastasis in several areas. Additionally, there is mesothelial proliferation and focal fibrosis in the omentum, and findings of chronic cervicitis and intramural leiomyomata in the uterus. No tumors were identified in the omentum, but significant malignancy is present in the other examined tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in a stomach segment, specifically located at the pylorus, with a tumor size of 6 x 5.5 cm that has infiltrated the entire wall layers and is ulcerated. Fifteen dissected lymph nodes show reactive changes, but none are positive for metastasis, and there is no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there are no additional pathologic findings or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment noted.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen from the antrum with an ulcerating adenocarcinoma measuring 8 x 6 x 1.5 cm, classified as moderately differentiated. The extent of invasion, lymph node involvement, and margins are not specified in the report. No additional pathologic findings or comments were provided.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the cervix revealed invasive squamous cell carcinoma, classified as grade III. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. This suggests a more aggressive form of cancer without spread to lymphatic or blood vessels.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a high-grade urothelial carcinoma with micropapillary features in the urinary bladder, which has invaded through the muscularis propria into perivesicular adipose tissue, with associated mucosal ulceration and granulomatous inflammation. Metastatic carcinoma was found in four out of seventeen lymph nodes examined, specifically three in the left pelvic lymph nodes and one in the right pelvic lymph node, while biopsies of the ureters and prostate showed no carcinoma. The final diagnosis is classified as pT3aN2, indicating advanced bladder cancer with lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (G2) in the distal rectum with superficial infiltration into the perirectal fatty tissue, classified as pT3, and clear resection margins. A follow-up examination of 34 lymph nodes revealed three metastatic infiltrations of the adenocarcinoma and colon carcinoma. The final staging is pT3 pN1 (3/34).

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy of the right upper lobe revealed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with focal papillary features, measuring 4.3 cm, and the tumor invades the visceral pleura but has uninvolved margins. Biopsies of the right diaphragmatic nodule and multiple lymph nodes showed no evidence of malignancy, with the lymph nodes being negative for tumor and showing anthracosis. Overall, the findings suggest a localized lung adenocarcinoma with no metastatic involvement in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies of the distal right and left ureters, as well as multiple pelvic lymph nodes, are negative for neoplasm. However, a radical cystoprostatectomy revealed a 4.5 cm invasive high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma that invades the muscularis propria and perivesical fat, with lymphovascular invasion present, but all resection margins are negative for tumor. The prostate shows high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, but is not involved by the urothelial carcinoma, and no regional lymph node metastasis was found.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the right middle lobe following a lobectomy. The tumor measures 2.0 cm in greatest dimension. The specimen type is classified as a lobectomy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade malignant fibrous histiocytoma, pleomorphic and storiform type, from a radical resection of a right thigh sarcoma, measuring 6.3 x 5.6 x 4.5 cm. The tumor encases large nerve trunks and involves skeletal muscle, but all margins are free of tumor with minimal clearance. An addendum reveals that the lymphocytic infiltrate adjacent to the tumor is predominantly composed of CD3 positive T cells, suggesting a reactive process.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.7 cm in diameter, originating in the right supraglottis, with perineural invasion but no cartilage invasion or involvement of the left vocal cord. Lymph node dissection revealed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in one of the right neck level II lymph nodes and one of the right neck level IV lymph nodes, while all other examined lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. The surgical margins from the total laryngectomy are reported as free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the chromophobe type, with marked anaplastic features, and a tumor size of 12 cm that has invaded the renal vein and surrounding structures. Surgical excision of lymph nodes revealed metastatic involvement in three out of fifteen examined nodes, while the adrenal gland was found to be benign. The overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is classified as pT3b, indicating significant local invasion.

The pathology report indicates a subtotal gastrectomy specimen with an 8 x 0 x 10 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as moderately differentiated. The tumor extends into the muscularis propria, with no lymph node metastasis found in 15 examined nodes, although lymphatic invasion is present. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of venous invasion or specified perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of adenocarcinoma of the prostate with invasion into the bilateral seminal vesicles, with a Gleason score of 8/10 and positive margins in the surrounding soft tissues. No tumor was detected in the examined right and left pelvic lymph nodes, and the left peri-prostatic tissue showed a minute focus of carcinoma. The TNM staging is pT3b, pNo, pMX, with suspected lymphatic invasion and confirmed perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the right ventral tongue, with evidence of perineural invasion. The specimen consisted of two soft tissue fragments measuring a total of 1.0 cm x 0.3 cm x 0.3 cm, which were entirely submitted for examination. The report was reviewed by the attending pathologist, confirming the findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, FIGO grade 3, with significant myometrial invasion, lymphovascular space involvement, and extensive necrosis, but no carcinoma was found in the ovaries or fallopian tubes. All examined lymph nodes, totaling 30, were negative for carcinoma, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. The tumor was staged as pT1c, with uninvolved surgical margins and no distant metastasis assessed.

The pathology report indicates a total thyroidectomy specimen revealing multifocal papillary carcinoma in the right lobe, isthmus, and left lobe, with the largest tumor measuring 1.4 cm. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 6 out of 9 lymph nodes, classified as pN1a, while the primary tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is less than or equal to 2.0 cm and confined to the thyroid. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is an additional finding of nodular hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes (4R, 4L, level 7, 2R, and additional 4R) were biopsied, and all were negative for carcinoma, confirming no malignancy in these samples. A lobectomy of the right upper lobe revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.0 cm, with focal invasion into the visceral pleura, but the bronchial margins were negative for tumor. Additionally, no malignancy was identified in nine lymph nodes examined, and there were findings of hyalinized plaques in the parietal pleura.

The pathology report indicates that the right adrenal gland and cyst wall from the right kidney showed no tumors, while a resection of the right kidney revealed chromophobe renal cell carcinoma measuring 5.3 cm with marked hemorrhage and fibrosis. The radical nephrectomy showed chronic interstitial nephritis and moderate atherosclerosis, but no tumor was found in the renal parenchyma or at the ureteral and vascular margins. Additionally, no lymph nodes or tumors were identified in the paracaval lymph node specimen.

The pathology report indicates a left posterior temporal tumor diagnosed as oligodendroglioma, grade II, with a MIB-1 labeling index of 2.9%. The microscopic examination reveals a mildly hypercellular glial neoplasm with cells resembling mildly atypical oligodendrocytes, and no mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis are observed. The tumor is noted to diffusely infiltrate both the gray and white matter.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO Grade 3) with full-thickness invasion of the myometrium and a tumor size of 5.8 cm, accompanied by complex atypical hyperplasia in the adjacent non-neoplastic endometrium. The tumor is noted to be diffuse, exophytic, and friable, with lymphatic and vascular invasion present, but all examined lymph nodes from the left and right pelvic regions, as well as the right obturator and aortic nodes, are negative for malignancy. The report concludes that the specimen margins are not involved, and the cervix shows no diagnostic abnormalities.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of right lung cancer, specifically poorly differentiated large cell carcinoma with squamous differentiation, located in the right lower lobe. No metastatic carcinoma was identified in the examined lymph nodes, which showed signs of anthrasilicosis and mild reactive changes. The tumor is noted to be less than 1 mm from the pleural surface, with lymphovascular invasion present but no pleural invasion detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an infiltrating glioma with oligodendroglial features, characterized by both low-grade and anaplastic regions, suggesting progression. The tumor shows marked hypercellularity and nuclear atypia in some areas, while other regions retain classic low-grade features. The diagnosis is confirmed as anaplastic oligodendroglioma grade III, with elevated proliferative activity indicated by a MIB-1 labeling index of 24.5%.
The pathology report indicates a unifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma located on the right side, measuring 9.0 x 9.0 x 6.0 cm. The tumor has penetrated into the surrounding fat tissue.

The pathology report indicates a partial resection of the small intestine with reactive lesions and a poorly differentiated carcinoma (G3) located at the rectosigmoid junction, which has infiltrated blood and lymph vessels and shows lymph node metastasis (pN1). The lesion was completely removed, with a distance of at least 1 cm from the mesorectal fascia. Further clinical evaluation is needed to determine whether the carcinoma is classified as rectal or sigmoid colon cancer.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the stomach, specifically located in the fundus, with a tumor size of 9.5 x 6 x 1.5 cm and ulcerated features. There is evidence of metastasis, with 7 out of 13 lymph nodes positive for cancer. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no specified evidence of lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of adenocarcinoma confined to the right side of the prostate, with a Gleason score of 4+3 and 16% of the gland affected by the tumor. Extra-prostatic tissues and seminal vesicles on the right side are positive for tumor, while surgical margins at the apex are negative, and peripheral margins show tumor presence in two foci on the right side. Lymph nodes from both sides are negative for tumor involvement, resulting in a pathological stage of T3BNOMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with approximately 40% of the prostate involved, a Gleason score of 8/10, and focal extraprostatic extension into nerve tissue. Surgical margins are positive in the apical region and both lobes, while no lymphovascular invasion or seminal vesicle involvement is noted, and all examined pelvic lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The tumor is classified as pT3a, indicating locally advanced disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive lobular carcinoma in an ablated breast sample, with a tumor diameter of 8 cm. The dorsal resection margin is tumor-free, and the tumor classification for the right breast is lobular carcinoma, grade II, with a staging of pT3N0L0V0R1. This suggests that the cancer is invasive but has not spread to lymph nodes or distant sites, although there is involvement of the resection margin.

The pathology report includes three distinct cases. The first case is a benign early trichilemmoma excised from the right cheek, showing no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy. The second case reveals a malignant melanoma in a core biopsy from the right arm, confirmed by immunohistochemical staining, while the third case indicates infiltrating adenocarcinoma in more than 90% of prostate chips, classified as Gleason 4+4=8.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligoastrocytoma (WHO grade III) from biopsies of two right frontal brain masses. Immunohistochemical analysis shows moderate expression of p53 protein, positivity for the IDH1-R132H mutation, and a Ki-67 labeling index of 10-12%. Further fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) studies for 1p19q deletion have been ordered for additional genetic interpretation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic invasive serous carcinoma, with the primary tumor being a poorly differentiated, predominantly papillary serous carcinoma affecting both ovaries and fallopian tubes, as well as widespread metastasis to the omentum, bladder peritoneum, sigmoid region, and other abdominal tissues. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IV, with significant necrosis and high mitotic activity observed in the tumor cells. Additional biopsies from various sites revealed no evidence of tumor in several areas, but some showed necrobiotic granulomata and reactive mesothelial changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mucocellular adenocarcinoma of the stomach (diffuse type) with significant infiltration, classified as G3, pT4a, pN3a, and pMx. There are metastases present in 12 out of 16 adjacent lymph nodes, while the spleen and omentum are free of cancer. The tumor measures 5.0 x 4 x 2 cm and is associated with an ulcerated lesion in the gastric mucosa.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 1 endometrioid adenocarcinoma located in the corpus of the uterus, with minimal myometrial invasion and no lymphatic or vascular invasion. Additionally, both ovaries are diagnosed with mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts), while the cervix and fallopian tubes show no pathological findings. The overall pathological stage is classified as pT1A, indicating early-stage endometrial carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, specifically signet ring cell carcinoma, located in the prepyloric antrum with extensive infiltration into surrounding tissues. The tumor has metastasized to several regional lymph nodes, the omentum, and shows peritoneal spread, with involvement of the distal resection margin and one margin of the transverse colon resection. The staging is classified as pT4 L1 V0 R2 pN3 21/27 pM1, indicating advanced disease with significant metastatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that the splenectomy preparation is tumor-free but shows recent capsule and parenchymal defects. The resected colon and rectum contain a moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma arising from a pre-existing tubulovillous adenoma, with infiltration into the perimuscular fatty tissue but no regional lymph node metastases. The tumor is classified as G2, pT3, with no lymphovascular invasion and clear resection margins.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes from both the right and left neck dissections, with 1 of 10 nodes affected on the right side and 8 of 19 nodes affected on the left side. Additionally, a poorly differentiated non-keratinizing squamous carcinoma was identified in the right pyriform sinus, measuring 3.5 x 1.5 x 1.1 cm, with resection margins free of tumor. The report also notes inflammation and fibrosis in the vocal scar, but no tumor was found in the examined teeth.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation, classified as Grade III, from a 5 cm posterior endometrial mass in the uterus. The tumor is staged as T4 with N1, indicating lymph node involvement, as 12 out of 1 sampled node were positive for metastatic disease. Additionally, there are focal areas of well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma and evidence of metastatic adenocarcinoma of endometrial origin in the bladder flap.

The amended pathology report corrects the greatest dimension of the neoplasm from 3.0 cm to 7.5 cm, with no changes to the previously rendered diagnoses. The final diagnosis indicates a left partial nephrectomy revealing papillary renal cell carcinoma, type I, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2, confined within the renal capsule and free of malignancy at surgical margins. Additionally, the report confirms no evidence of malignancy in the perinephric adipose tissue and cauterized renal parenchyma from the right kidney biopsy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right thyroid lobe, with a tumor size of 1.1 cm and well-differentiated histologic grade. There is evidence of extrathyroid vascular invasion and invasion into perithyroid fibroadipose tissue, with the tumor being close to the anterior surgical margin (<1 mm). No tumor encapsulation, multicentricity, or adenomas were identified, and the non-neoplastic thyroid shows mild hyperplastic changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) following a partial hepatectomy of the liver. The tumor measures 3.3 x 2.0 x 2.8 cm and exhibits a trabecular histologic type with no evidence of invasion at the surgical margins, which have a safety margin of 1.5 cm. Additionally, mild steatosis is noted in the remaining liver parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with an oligodendroglioma, a type of brain tumor located in the frontal lobe. The tumor exhibits characteristics such as uniform round nuclei, slight pleomorphism, and a low proliferation index of about 2%, with no evidence of necrosis or significant microvascular proliferation. Immunohistochemical analysis shows scant gliofibrillogenesis and no overexpression of the p53 protein, while special staining reveals no distortion of the normal axonal pattern.

The pathology report indicates a 1.5x1x0.8 cm squamous cell carcinoma located in the cervix, classified as Grade II and infiltrating the inner half of the muscle propria. Microscopic examination reveals hyperplastic squamous cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, enlarged nuclei, and evidence of lymphocytic invasion in the stroma. The tumor is moderately differentiated, with mitotic figures present, and additional details regarding lymph nodes and margins are not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, specifically grade 3 endometrioid type with serous areas, occupying the entire endometrial cavity and measuring approximately 8.8 x 3.5 cm, with focal myometrial invasion. All examined lymph nodes from the pelvic and aortic regions showed no evidence of metastatic malignancy. Additional findings include lymphovascular space invasion and intense chronic endocervicitis, with no involvement of the cervix or other organs.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma, specifically the dominant oncocytic follicular variant measuring 2.1 cm, along with a follicular adenoma and degenerative changes in the thyroid. The left hemithyroidectomy specimen shows no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion, and all margins are uninvolved by carcinoma. Additionally, a second tumor, a microcarcinoma variant of papillary carcinoma, was identified in the isthmus, with no regional lymph node metastasis detected.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a recurrent brain tumor diagnosed as glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) based on biopsy samples from the right temporal region. Histological examination reveals a high-grade astrocytoma with features such as microvascular proliferation and pseudopalisading necrosis, while immunohistochemical studies show diffuse p53 immunoreactivity and a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 20%. Additionally, there is no evidence of EGFRvIII mutation or methylation of the MGMT promoter detected, which may have implications for treatment options.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal papillary carcinoma in the thyroid, with a dominant mixed classical and follicular variant, and involvement of surgical margins. Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma was identified in multiple lymph nodes, with 10 out of 83 examined showing metastasis, while the parathyroid glands appeared normal. The report highlights the complexity of the tumor's characteristics, including various histologic types and the presence of additional microcarcinomas, necessitating a total thyroidectomy and extensive neck dissection.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) in a female patient with a right temporal brain tumor, characterized by anaplastic proliferation of astrocytic cells, vascular proliferation, and pseudopalisading necrosis. Cytogenetic analysis revealed significant abnormalities, including polysomy of chromosome 7, amplification of EGFR, and loss of PTEN, among others, which are associated with a poorer prognosis. The immunohistochemical analysis showed a high proliferation index and various positive markers, further confirming the aggressive nature of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade poorly differentiated serous papillary carcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with the right ovary showing focal surface involvement and arising from a serous tumor of low malignant potential. Additionally, metastatic serous papillary carcinoma is identified in the sigmoid and posterior cul de sac, while multiple lymph node dissections reveal no tumor involvement in the examined nodes. Other findings include chronic cervicitis, atypical hyperplasia, adenomyosis, and benign fibroadipose tissue in various biopsies.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland following an adrenalectomy, with inked margins appearing free of tumor. The specimen measured 15 x 5 x 3 cm and contained a nodule measuring 3.5 x 3 cm, characterized by a hemorrhagic and friable cut surface. Normal adrenal tissue was present at the periphery, and the specimen was submitted for further surgical pathology evaluation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right hepatectomy and cholecystectomy, with the final diagnosis revealing moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the liver, measuring 6.0 cm and confined to the liver with uninvolved surgical margins. The gallbladder showed no significant pathological changes, and four examined portal lymph nodes were benign and negative for malignancy. Additionally, there were findings of steatosis and bridging fibrosis in the liver, classified as stage 2-3/4.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of an ulcerated gastric carcinoma, measuring 7.5 cm, that has invaded all layers of the gastric wall and extended to the transverse colon, forming a gastrocolic fistula, with one of nineteen lymph nodes showing metastasis. Additionally, there is evidence of chronic gastritis and Helicobacter pylori infection in the gastric mucosa, along with a biliary hamartoma in the liver. The tumor staging is classified as pT4 pN1, indicating advanced local disease with limited lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive melanoma, superficial spreading type, with a Breslow thickness of 10.0 mm and Clark level IV, showing both radial and vertical growth phases, along with ulceration and vascular invasion. Metastatic melanoma was found in two of ten lymph nodes from the right inguinal contents and in two of seven lymph nodes from the right iliac and obturator contents, with the largest deposits measuring 40.0 x 35.0 mm and 12.0 x 10.0 mm, respectively. Surgical margins from the excised tissue are free of malignancy, but there is evidence of extracapsular extension in the inguinal lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as NSABP and nuclear grade 3, histologic grade 3. The specimen consisted of two pieces of tissue, and the surgical margins were not evaluated as per the surgeon's instructions. This finding is in the context of a clinical history of recurrent left breast carcinoma with suspected involvement of the right breast.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the distal esophagus, with the tumor invading the muscularis propria and measuring 8.3 cm in greatest dimension. Four out of 19 examined lymph nodes show metastatic deposits, while both the proximal and distal margins are clear of invasive carcinoma, although the circumferential margin is close to the tumor at 1 mm. Additionally, high-grade dysplasia is noted at the final esophageal margin, but the tip of the stomach is negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 3 tubular and partially mucocellular invasive adenocarcinoma of the stomach (pT3, pN2), with evidence of metastases in multiple lymph nodes. The tumor exhibits significant wall infiltration and ulceration, with cancerous involvement extending into the peritoneum and surrounding fat tissue. Immunohistochemical examination shows HER2 protein expression, suggesting potential therapeutic implications.

The pathology report indicates that the prostate biopsies from various locations show no tumor or benign prostatic gland, except for one area with benign crushed prostatic gland. However, metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in one of two right external iliac lymph nodes, while no tumors were found in the other lymph nodes examined. The final diagnosis from the robot-assisted radical prostatectomy reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, extra-prostatic extension, and bilateral seminal vesicle invasion, classified as stage 4 (pT3bN1MX).

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the left lung, measuring 62 mm, with invasion across the oblique fissure into the lower lobe and evidence of blood vessel invasion. The lymph nodes examined (number 5 and number 7) show no malignancy, but there is involvement of a peribronchial lymph node. The tumor is clear of the bronchial resection margin, and the pathological stage is classified as T2N1MX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade I, identified in the uterus, with a mass measuring 10.7 x 7.8 x 2.1 cm that invades 0.6 cm into the myometrium, while all surgical margins are negative for tumor. The bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are histologically unremarkable, and multiple pelvic lymph nodes from both sides are negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, a separate specimen of skin and subcutaneous tissue from a panniculectomy was examined grossly, with no lesions identified.

The pathology report indicates a breast tumor measuring 3.5 x 3.3 cm, classified as infiltrating ductal and lobular carcinoma, with involvement of the skin and all ten examined lymph nodes showing metastases. The tumor is graded as moderately differentiated (G2) and is staged as T4c N3a M0, indicating extensive local invasion and lymph node involvement. The report notes that there is no evidence of venous invasion, but specific details regarding margins and additional pathologic findings are not provided.

The pathology report indicates that a lymph node biopsy was benign, while the gallbladder showed signs of chronic cholecystitis. A partial liver resection revealed a moderately-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 2.5 cm, with negative margins and no vascular invasion. The presence of hepatocellular carcinoma was confirmed through histological analysis and immunostaining, with no regional lymph nodes submitted for evaluation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a well-differentiated papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, located in the left lobe of the thyroid, measuring 2.0 cm with focal capsular invasion and no blood vessel invasion or extrathyroid extension. Additionally, there is a separate encapsulated, non-invasive focus of papillary microcarcinoma in the right lobe measuring 0.7 cm. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and all examined lymph nodes are benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell adenocarcinoma in the left kidney, specifically located in the upper pole, measuring 4.0 x 4.0 x 2.5 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2/4 and evidence of lymphovascular space invasion. The tumor is confined to the kidney with negative surgical margins and no evidence of transcapsular or renal vein invasion, while no lymph nodes were examined. The pTNM stage is classified as T1a NX MX, indicating a localized tumor without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the right upper arm, with a tumor size of 8 x 5.5 x 5 cm and less than 10% necrosis. The tumor involves multiple margins, with the medial margin being negative and the lateral margin measuring less than 1 mm. The tumor exhibits high-grade characteristics, including spindle and pleomorphic cells, brisk mitosis, and a rich vasculature within a myxoid stroma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma in the right breast, measuring approximately 70 mm, with positive lymph node involvement (11 out of 12 nodes) and classified as Stage IIIC. The tumor exhibits a unifocal growth pattern with a nuclear grade of I for the classical type and II-III for the pleomorphic type, while margins are negative for invasive carcinoma. Additionally, no tumor was found in the omentum, and there are signs of focal atypical lobular hyperplasia and other benign changes in the breast tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 6.2 cm, which has invaded the renal vein but is confined within Gerota's fascia. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and lymph nodes examined show no involvement, while the right adrenal gland is noted to be benign. The overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is classified as pT3, indicating local invasion into major veins or perinephric tissues.

The pathology report indicates that the specimens from the frontal brain tumors were diagnosed as a WHO grade IV small cell and fibrillary astrocytoma (glioblastoma multiforme), characterized by palisading necrosis. The frozen section analysis revealed a malignant astrocytoma of at least grade 3, with final classification confirmed upon examination of permanent sections. The report includes multiple tissue samples from different areas of the frontal brain, all consistent with high-grade glioma.

The biopsy of the right oropharynx reveals invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. An addendum will report the results of a p16 immunohistochemical stain, which shows strong diffuse positivity. The clinical indication for the biopsy was a right neck mass.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the omentum, bilateral ovaries, and colon, with evidence of tumor spread to fibroadipose tissue and lymphovascular spaces. The tumor was primarily located in the omentum and measured up to 7 cm in the right ovary, with a FIGO stage of IIIC, indicating advanced disease. Additional findings include atrophic endometrium and benign cervical and colonic mucosa, with no malignant cells detected in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph node biopsies (levels 5, 7, 9, and 11) show fragments of lymphoid tissue that are negative for malignancy. In contrast, the left lower lobe lobectomy reveals moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.8 x 2.7 x 2.1 cm, with no lymphovascular invasion and negative margins, classified as stage pT1N0Mx. The report confirms the absence of tumor in the examined lymph nodes, indicating no metastatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 2.2 cm, with negative surgical resection margins and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present within 0.15 cm from the inferior margin. All four sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla were examined and found to be negative for metastases. The tumor is classified as SBR Grade 1, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptor status, and a HER2 negative result, along with a recurrence score of 17 indicating a low risk of distant recurrence.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic high-grade papillary serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, right ovary, and left ovary, with significant tumor involvement in the fallopian tubes and uterus. Additionally, a malignant mixed mullerian tumor (MMMT) was identified in one specimen, comprising approximately 10% of the tumor mass. The Her/neu status of the tumor is negative (1+) as per the Hercep Test, and there are no changes in the previous diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that multiple tissue specimens from the right anterior, middle, lateral, and posterior muscles, as well as various mucosal and deep margins, were examined, and no tumors were identified in any of these samples. However, a right mandible mass was diagnosed as moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, which has invaded the underlying bone, with surgical margins free of tumor. All lymph nodes examined from the right neck levels 1, 2, and 3 were also free of tumor, and the overall AJCC staging is pT4, pNo, pMx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metaplastic squamous cell carcinoma of the breast, with a tumor size measuring 5.5 x 4 cm and classified as T3. Examination of ten lymph nodes revealed no metastasis, and the tumor showed negative immunohistochemical staining for ER, PR, and Her-2/neu, with a Ki-67 proliferation index of 30%. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a high-grade glioma, specifically an anaplastic oligodendroglioma, confirmed through excisional biopsy of recurrent brain tumors. The neoplasm exhibits significant cellularity, mitotic activity, and a proliferation index of 50%, suggesting aggressive behavior. Additionally, the tumor appears to be infiltrating the leptomeningeal space, indicating a potential for further spread.

The pathology report indicates that the right adnexa shows a small inclusion cyst in the ovary, while the left adnexa reveals metastatic adenocarcinoma in the ovary. The total abdominal hysterectomy specimen shows poorly-differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with extensive invasion into the myometrium and endometrial surface, classified as FIGO stage 3C. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, with a total of 8 out of 21 examined lymph nodes showing malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast mass, with a Nottingham combined histologic grade of 3 and evidence of lymphatic/vascular invasion. One of the sentinel lymph nodes (node #1) shows metastatic carcinoma, while the second sentinel node (node #2) is negative for malignancy. The surgical margins are close, with the tumor approaching within 0.2 cm of the anterior margin, and additional findings include in-situ carcinoma and microcalcifications associated with the invasive tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma of endocervical type in the cervix, measuring 4.0 cm in maximum extension and 1.5 cm in maximum depth of invasion, with foci of adenocarcinoma in situ noted in the posterior wall. The tumor infiltrates nearly all of the anterior cervical stromal thickness and is less than 1 mm from the circumferential anterior surgical margin, but no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural infiltration is observed. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from the right and left iliac obturator regions, as well as the isthmus, uterine corpus, vagina, and fallopian tubes, are free of neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal-lobular carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T3, N0, and M0, indicating a locally advanced primary tumor with no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered to date, and a separate blood sample was noted as normal.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast specimen shows invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) of histologic grade III, measuring 1.5 cm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of solid type, which constitutes less than or equal to 25% of the tumor mass. Both sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla were found to be benign with no evidence of metastatic tumor. The right breast specimen revealed benign breast tissue with fibrocystic changes, and additional immunohistochemical staining results for hormone receptors and HER2 will be reported in an addendum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with focal papillary features and a Fuhrman's nuclear grade of 2. The tumor measures 3.6 cm, is confined within the renal capsule, and shows no invasion of the renal vein or angiolymphatic invasion, with all surgical margins free of neoplasm. The non-neoplastic kidney and adrenal gland are unremarkable, and the tumor is classified as TNM stage oT1a NX MX with a histologic grade of G2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the left tonsil. The specimen received was a 5 x 3 x 2 mm piece of hemorrhagic soft tissue from the left tonsil. The findings were reviewed by the attending pathologist, confirming the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade 3, from a left frontal brain craniotomy, with a positive IDH1-R132S mutation and a Ki-67 proliferation index of approximately 10%. There is no evidence of co-deletion of chromosomal arms 1p and 19q, and the tumor shows areas of increased mitotic activity without microvascular proliferation or necrosis. Additionally, IDH2 mutation testing was negative, confirming the presence of the IDH1 mutation, which is associated with a better clinical outcome.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant mixed mullerian tumor (MMMT) of the endometrium, characterized by high-grade serous adenocarcinoma and high-grade endometrial stromal sarcoma, with a heterologous chondrosarcoma component, measuring 5.8 x 5.1 x 4.6 cm and invading more than half of the myometrium. The left adnexa shows intraluminal tufts of malignant cells in the fallopian tube, but no direct invasion, while the right adnexa is free from tumor. The cervix exhibits chronic cervicitis and leiomyoma, and the overall staging is pT1c Nx Mx based on the examined material.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive adenosquamous carcinoma, moderately differentiated, with a tumor size of 3.9 cm located in the cervix and extending into the lower uterine segment. Metastatic carcinoma was found in one of six left obturator lymph nodes and one of four right external iliac lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes examined were negative for malignancy. The surgical margins are free of carcinoma, and there is evidence of lymphovascular invasion, with a final staging of pT1b1 N1.

The pathology report describes a mildly hypercellular glial neoplasm that infiltrates both gray and white matter, characterized by small, round nuclei with occasional larger nuclei and fine fibrillary processes. A focal microgemistocytic pattern is observed, but there is no evidence of mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis. The final diagnosis is a low-grade oligoastrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive papillary transitional cell carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 10 cm, with extensive necrosis and lymphovascular invasion, while the resection margins are free of tumor. The left ureter shows mild hydroureter but no tumor, and the prostate exhibits benign hyperplasia without any malignancy. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes (13 total) are free of tumor, confirming no metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7/10, involving less than 10% of the total tissue volume and showing extensive perineural invasion, but no extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle involvement. The surgical margins are reported to be free of malignancy, with tumor extension noted to be less than 1 mm from the resection surface. Additionally, three examined bilateral pelvic lymph nodes were negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma with mucinous and medullary features located in the ascending colon, measuring 7.1 cm in length and 5.5 cm in width, with invasion into the subserosa. No preexisting polyps were identified at the carcinoma site, and the surgical margins are free of tumor, with no lymph node metastases found among the 27 examined. The pathologic stage is classified as pT3, pNO, indicating significant tumor invasion but no lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma in the right liver lobe, measuring 4x3.5x2.5 cm, with a trabecular histologic type and a mixed histologic grade of 2 and 3. There is evidence of vascular invasion and partial capsule formation, but no satellite nodules, tumor necrosis, or major vascular involvement were noted, and the surgical margins are clear. Additionally, a cavernous hemangioma and two bile duct cysts were identified, along with findings of chronic hepatitis associated with HBV, but cirrhosis and dysplasia were absent.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 2) in the endometrium, with tumor invasion into the outer half of the myometrial wall and focal lymphovascular space invasion. No tumor was found in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions. The overall AJCC pathologic staging is pT1c pNO pMx, corresponding to FIGO stage IB.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with tumor invasion into the superficial half of the muscularis propria and involvement of the left ureter, while the surgical margins are free of tumor. The report also notes that the pelvic lymph nodes examined from both sides are not involved, and additional findings include benign lesions in the round ligaments and ureters, as well as a focus of epithelial hyperplasia in the right fallopian tube. Further studies are being conducted to characterize a 2 mm nodule identified in the specimen, which is consistent with a primary mllerian-derived glandular lesion rather than metastatic urothelial carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that nine excised pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of neoplasia. A radical prostatectomy reveals prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, involving both lobes of the prostate, with established extracapsular extension and extensive perineural invasion, but no carcinoma in the seminal vesicles or surgical margins. The tumor is classified as pT3a, with multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia identified, and the overall tumor involvement is approximately 10% of the examined prostate volume.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mucinous adenocarcinoma with infiltration into the muscularis and vessels, classified as G3, pT2, L1, V1, with free resection margins and no lymph node involvement (locally R0, pNo, 0 of 12). Additionally, there is a free anastomosis ring noted. Fragments of a serrated adenoma are also present, exhibiting focally severe chromatin disorders suggestive of a high-risk type.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the right posterior lateral wall of the urinary bladder, measuring 4.6 x 3.0 x 1.1 cm, with invasion into the muscularis propria but not into perivesicular fat. The final margins of both the left and right ureters are negative for tumor, and one out of six right obturator lymph nodes shows metastatic urothelial carcinoma. Overall, the remaining lymph nodes and other examined tissues, including the ovaries and vaginal wall, are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a left renal mass diagnosed as conventional (clear cell) renal cell carcinoma, nuclear grade II/IV, measuring 3.5 cm and confined to the kidney without evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. Surgical resection margins are free of carcinoma, and the adrenal gland shows no diagnostic abnormalities. Cytogenetic analysis reveals a normal karyotype in the majority of cells, with some nonclonal changes noted, but the significance of these findings remains unclear.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a partial nephrectomy for a right renal mass, which was diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma type 2, measuring 1.3 cm and confined to the kidney with uninvolved margins and no lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, a separate resection of the transverse colon revealed high-grade mucinous adenocarcinoma that invaded the muscularis propria, with negative margins and no regional lymph node involvement. Both tumors were staged according to the AJCC 7th edition, with the renal tumor classified as pT1 and the colon tumor as pT2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma located in the floor of the mouth, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm and a depth of invasion of 2.0 cm, exhibiting perineural invasion but no lymphovascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes from levels 2a and 3, as well as the submandibular salivary gland and lymph nodes, were uninvolved by metastatic carcinoma. An addendum notes that osseous tissue is involved by neoplasia, although the osseous margin remains uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates that the left lower lobe tumor is diagnosed as moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, measuring 3.3 x 3.0 x 2.7 cm, with no pleural or lymphovascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes (14 in total) from various locations showed no evidence of metastatic carcinoma (0/14). The pTNM staging is reported as pT2 N0 Mx, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the left pelvic lymph nodes are negative for neoplasm, while the right pelvic lymph nodes show metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in one of five nodes examined. A biopsy of a right pelvic lymph node also confirms metastatic squamous cell carcinoma. Additionally, the report identifies invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix (Grade II) with a tumor size of 7 x 3 cm and extensive lymphovascular space invasion, but surgical margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with a glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) following an excision biopsy of a right frontal brain tumor. The tumor exhibits characteristics such as biphasic cellularity, frequent mitoses, vascular proliferation, and pseudopalisading necrosis, with a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 30%. Immunohistochemical staining for p53 is negative, and MGMT promoter methylation testing is pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 5.0 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion, renal vein invasion, or small vessel angiolymphatic invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of thymic carcinoma, specifically squamous cell carcinoma, with a tumor size of 7 cm and evidence of invasion into the tumor capsule and pericapsular connective tissue. No metastatic tumor was found in the examined hilar nodes or mediastinal fat, and the margins of the specimen are negative. Additionally, there are incidental findings of multiple benign microscopic thymomas in the residual thymic tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 5 x 4.5 cm ulcerating squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated, in the thoracic esophagus, with invasion into the muscularis propria. Out of 15 examined lymph nodes, 2 show metastasis, specifically in one paraesophageal and one paratracheal lymph node, while the remaining nodes exhibit follicular hyperplasia. There is no evidence of venous invasion, and the surgical margins are uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9/10, showing extraprostatic extension and involvement of the seminal vesicles. Among the examined lymph nodes, one right hypogastric lymph node and one left hypogastric lymph node showed metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes were free of malignancy. The report also notes the presence of lymph-vascular invasion and perineural invasion, with the right and left posterior resection margins involved by tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the excised right renal mass was diagnosed as chromophobe renal cell carcinoma measuring 3.8 cm, with no tumor involvement in the surrounding perinephric fat. The additional specimens from the base of the tumor and the fat over the tumor showed no evidence of tumor presence. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed that the tumor cells were positive for c-kit (CD117).

The pathology report indicates that the right breast lumpectomy revealed invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 4 cm, classified as Grade 3 with negative margins. The first and second sentinel lymph nodes examined showed two reactive lymph nodes and one reactive lymph node, respectively, with no evidence of metastasis. The overall pathologic staging is pT2 for the primary tumor and pNO for the regional lymph nodes, with no distant metastasis detected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a mildly hypercellular infiltrating glioma characterized by a proliferation of cells with round nuclei and mild cytologic atypia. There are no mitotic figures, intratumoral necrosis, or hemorrhage observed, and the MIB-1 labeling index is very low at <0.1%. The final diagnosis is oligodendroglioma grade II.

The pathology report indicates that both specimens from the right soft palate show invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with a noted papillary configuration in some areas. High-risk HPV 16/18 in-situ hybridization testing is positive, suggesting a potential association with the carcinoma. The gross examination reveals tan-white and pink-tan granular soft tissue aggregates, with sizes measuring approximately 2x2x0.5 cm and 2.7x2.5x1.3 cm, respectively.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7/10, showing extensive tumor involvement in both lobes of the prostate and right seminal vesicle, along with perineural invasion. No lymph nodes were identified in the specimen, and the surgical margins were positive at the apical/inferior and right prostate margins. The report also notes the presence of benign prostatic hyperplasia, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN), and chronic prostatitis, with a TNM stage of T3b NX MX.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma in the right hemiglossectomy specimen, with perineural invasion but no vascular or lymphatic invasion, and surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, a biopsy of the left alveolar ridge shows verrucous carcinoma, while the right oral tongue biopsy reveals papillomatosis with atypia and marked inflammation. Other specimens, including lymph nodes and the proximal right lingual node, show no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right frontal glioblastoma, characterized by a cellular tumor with less than 10% of cells showing immunoreactivity for MGMT, primarily in endothelial cells, while neoplastic cells are negative for MGMT expression. Microscopic examination reveals infiltrating astrocytoma with moderate cytologic atypia, numerous mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, and areas of necrosis exhibiting pseudopalisading. Overall, the findings are consistent with a high-grade glioma, specifically glioblastoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 7.2 cm, with a Fuhrman grade of G2. The tumor is unifocal, located in the mid kidney, extends into the renal capsule but does not invade perinephric fat, and surgical margins are free of tumor. There are no signs of necrosis, lymphovascular, or perineural invasion, and the tumor is classified as T3 with unknown lymph node and distant metastasis status.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of locally advanced, poorly differentiated, nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the left upper lobe of the lung, classified as pT4 pN1 V1 RX(R1?), stage III. The tumor exhibits endobronchial growth and has metastasized to local bronchopulmonary lymph nodes, with invasion into the mediastinum but not infiltrating the pericardium or major pulmonary vessels. Additional findings include tumor necrosis, inflammation, and pleural adhesions, with the resection margins of the main bronchus and other lymph nodes being tumor-free.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the left lung, with the tumor extending into the bronchus and surrounding tissues, and involvement of adjacent lymph nodes. One of the peribronchial lymph nodes and a separate lymph node (number 7) show metastatic carcinoma, while the bronchial resection margin is clear of tumor. Additionally, there is a possibility of residual microscopic tumor in the mediastinum based on histologic findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 1.1 cm, with extrathyroidal extension and tumor present at the anterior surgical margin. Additionally, a papillary microcarcinoma (0.7 cm) was identified in the left lobe, while the lymph nodes examined were benign with no evidence of metastatic disease. The non-neoplastic thyroid tissue shows nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.5 cm, with invasion depth of 0.7 cm, but no lymphovascular space invasion identified. Resection margins are free of carcinoma, and no carcinoma was found in the examined lymph nodes or other structures, including the vagina, uterus, and ovaries. Additional findings include para-ovarian and peritubal adhesions, as well as hydrosalpinx, but no dysplasia or carcinoma was noted in the radical hysterectomy specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, measuring 3 cm, with no involvement of the pleura or large stem bronchus. All examined lymph nodes, including those from level 10, the left upper lobe, and the subcarinal region, are negative for metastatic tumor. The resection margins are clear of tumor, and no lymphovascular invasion is identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple tumors in the right kidney, all diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the chromophobe type, with a total of ten tumors identified. Some of the tumors exhibit chromophomatosis, a condition characterized by the presence of chromophobe cells. The patient has a history of multifocal renal cell carcinoma and underwent a partial nephrectomy for these tumors.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, measuring 3.5 cm, classified as conventional (clear) cell type with a Fuhrman's nuclear grade of III out of IV. The tumor is confined within the renal capsule, with no evidence of invasion into the renal vein or angiolymphatic invasion, and all surgical margins are free of neoplasm. The non-neoplastic kidney shows simple cysts, and the tumor is staged as TNM Stage I: pT1a NX MX with a histologic grade of G3.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type with extensive sarcomatoid differentiation, classified as Fuhrman Nuclear Grade IV/IV, and measuring 10 cm in greatest diameter. The tumor shows local invasion into Gerota's fascia, renal pelvis, and renal sinus fat, with identified renal vein invasion and angiolymphatic invasion, while the surgical margins are positive for tumor presence. Examination of lymph nodes from the paracaval and hilum regions revealed no metastatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated, multifocal, bilateral adenocarcinoma of the prostate, classified as pT2c with a maximum tumor diameter of 1.6 cm and a Gleason score of 4+3=7. The tumor is limited to the organ with no evidence of invasion into blood or lymph vessels, and both lymph nodes examined were tumor-free. Additional findings include prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and myoglandular prostatic hyperplasia, with a tumor-free surgical margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Anaplastic Astrocytoma (grade III). Microscopic examination shows a moderate hypercellular proliferation of atypical fibrillary astrocytes that are diffusely invading the surrounding brain tissue, with scattered mitoses present. There is no evidence of necrosis or microvascular proliferation, although there is a focus of hemorrhage with degenerating parenchyma that cannot be definitively classified as spontaneous necrosis.

The patient has been diagnosed with breast cancer, confirmed by a right segmental mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy. The final diagnosis reveals infiltrating duct carcinoma measuring 1.4 cm with associated lymphovascular invasion, and one out of four lymph nodes shows micrometastatic carcinoma. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor positive, and HER-2/neu negative, with negative surgical margins noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 7.5 cm, with involvement of the mainstem bronchus but no visceral pleura invasion. Out of thirty regional lymph nodes examined, three were positive for metastatic carcinoma, leading to a pathologic stage of IIIA. The surgical margins are reported as negative (R0), indicating no invasive carcinoma at the margins.

The pathology report indicates that the left kidney contains a renal cell carcinoma with 80% clear cells and 20% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman's nuclear grade 2, measuring 5.5 cm, and is confined to the kidney with clear margins. The right adrenal gland shows an adrenal cortical adenoma measuring 2.9 cm, also with clear margins, while the distal esophagus and proximal stomach reveal a smooth muscle neoplasm consistent with leiomyoma, measuring 4.5 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of malignancy in the surrounding tissues or lymph nodes. Overall, the report suggests localized tumors in the kidney and adrenal gland, and a benign smooth muscle tumor in the esophagus and stomach, with no signs of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lung, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm and extensive involvement of the right upper lobe, lower lobe, and mainstem bronchus, along with perihilar nodal and soft tissue invasion. At least 9 out of 10 examined lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, with evidence of perineural and vascular invasion, and the bronchial margin is also positive for carcinoma. The report suggests significant tumor necrosis and recommends clinical correlation to assess potential involvement of adjacent mediastinal structures.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral serous papillary carcinoma of the ovaries, classified as FIGO Grade III, with evidence of vascular invasion and extensive metastasis to the fallopian tubes, omentum, diaphragm, urinary bladder, and appendix.
