The uterus and cervix show no histopathological abnormalities, while the endometrium exhibits cystic atrophy without evidence of malignancy. The final staging is classified as FIGO Stage IIIC, indicating macroscopic peritoneal metastasis and regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of bladder cancer, with the final diagnosis indicating invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma with micropapillary features, measuring at least 5.0 cm and invading the detrusor muscle and perivesicular adipose tissue. The right ureteral margin is benign, while the left ureteral margin shows focal urothelial atypia without evidence of carcinoma. Metastatic urothelial carcinoma is present in one of two right pelvic lymph nodes and in six of seven left pelvic lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left ureter biopsies are benign and negative for tumor, while a single left internal and external iliac lymph node shows metastatic urothelial carcinoma. The radical cystoprostatectomy reveals invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma with glandular, micropapillary, and sarcomatoid differentiation, measuring 4.0 cm and invading perivesical fat, alongside incidental prostatic adenocarcinoma confined to the organ. Additional lymph nodes examined are mostly benign, with one lymph node showing metastasis, and the surgical margins for both the bladder and prostate are negative for invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of choroidal melanoma of the spindled type in the right globe, measuring 12 mm at the base and 6 mm in height, with evidence of scleral invasion in a perivascular pattern. There is no extraocular extension, and the vortex veins and optic nerve are negative for tumor involvement. Mitoses are noted at a rate of 3 per 10 high power fields, and a right eye aspirate was deemed inadequate for further testing.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade III mixed serous and endometrioid carcinoma in the endometrium, characterized by a polypoid mass measuring 3.6 x 3.1 x 2.0 cm, with invasion into the myometrium but no angiolymphatic invasion. All examined lymph nodes, omentum, and staging biopsies from various sites are negative for tumor, indicating no evidence of metastatic disease. The uterus, cervix, ovaries, and fallopian tubes show no diagnostic abnormalities apart from the identified carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the left tonsil and multiple lymph nodes (7, 8, 9, 5, and levels 5 and 6) are negative for malignancy. However, several soft tissue samples, including those from the serratus muscle, second rib, intercostal muscle, and middle scalene muscle, show positive results for squamous cell carcinoma, with the lung excision also revealing a 4.5 cm squamous cell carcinoma. The report concludes that the patient has lung cancer with no evidence of malignancy in the examined lymph nodes and pleura.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade myxofibrosarcoma in the right axilla, with the tumor measuring 12.5 x 11.6 x 7.2 cm and showing significant myxoid changes and necrosis. Five lymph nodes were examined, all of which were benign and negative for metastatic tumor. The tumor is noted to be close to the lateral and axillary margins, with additional extension into subcutaneous tissue and dermis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated Papillary Serous Cystadenocarcinoma, FIGO stage IIIC, primarily affecting the left ovary and metastasizing to the posterior uterine corpus, rectum, and regional lymph nodes. The right ovary and fallopian tubes show no evidence of carcinoma, while benign leiomyomata are noted in the uterus. Additional findings include negative peritoneal washing and vaginal/cervical thin prep for intraepithelial lesions or malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon, classified as grade 2 to 3, with infiltration into all layers of the colon wall and vascular involvement. There are six lymph node metastases identified (6 out of 12, N2), suggesting significant spread of the disease. Additionally, there are findings of adenocarcinoma in the gallbladder and liver, indicating further dissemination of the colon cancer.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, small intestine, and both ovaries, with the largest tumor focus measuring 11.5 cm. The report also notes lymphovascular invasion and metastatic involvement of the uterine serosa, while the resection margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the uterus and cervix show no evidence of malignancy, with findings of atrophic endometrium and adenomyosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive lobular carcinoma of the right breast, measuring 2.5 cm, with associated lobular carcinoma in situ. Among the sentinel lymph nodes examined, one showed microscopic clusters of metastatic carcinoma, while the other three were benign. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor weakly positive, and HER2/neu positive, with no vascular invasion or involvement of surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.0 cm, located in the cecum, forming a polypoid and ulcerative mass that invades into but not through the muscularis propria. The resection margins are negative for tumor, with no identified lymphovascular or perineural invasion, and the regional lymph nodes show no evidence of metastasis. Additional findings include residual adenoma, multiple hyperplastic polyps, and a lipoma of the ileocecal valve, with mild peritumoral response noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of acinar predominant adenocarcinoma (3.5 cm) in the right upper lobe of the lung, with all examined lymph nodes (32 total) negative for carcinoma. The bronchial and vascular margins are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of visceral pleural invasion. Molecular studies revealed a positive KRAS mutation (p.G12V), while no EGFR mutations were detected, suggesting a poor prognosis and potential resistance to certain therapies.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical cystectomy, hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and other procedures, with the final diagnosis revealing multifocal invasive papillary urothelial carcinoma of the bladder and uterus, nuclear grade 3/4, invading deep muscle and the urethra and vagina, but with all surgical margins free of tumor. The right and left distal ureters were found to be benign with no urothelial dysplasia or carcinoma identified, and a total of 53 lymph nodes examined showed no tumor involvement. Additional findings included atrophic endometrium and chronic cervicitis, with no tumors identified in the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostate cancer, specifically prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, which is bilateral and organ-confined, primarily located in the apex of the prostate. Multiple biopsies from various margins and the seminal vesicles showed no evidence of carcinoma, and all surgical margins were negative for invasive carcinoma. Additionally, 19 pelvic lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for metastatic carcinoma, with the presence of perineural invasion noted.

The pathology report describes a large ulcerated tumor in the antrum of the stomach, measuring 3x4x1.5 cm, characterized by a firm, myxoid gray surface. Microscopic examination reveals the tumor is a poorly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma with significant invasion into the serosa, featuring hyperchromatic nuclei and the presence of mitoses. Additionally, one out of five examined lymph nodes shows evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left renal mass diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 3.5 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 2.0 cm, with a Nottingham score of 6/9 and extending to the inked posterior surgical margin. The tumor is positive for estrogen receptors and negative for progesterone receptors, with no HER-2/NEU amplification, while two sentinel lymph nodes examined are negative for metastatic tumor. Additionally, there are incidental findings of fibrocystic changes and a microscopic perlobular hemangioma, with no significant abnormalities noted in the skin or skeletal muscle.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, nuclear grade III/IV, in a left kidney tumor measuring 1.1 cm, which is confined within the renal capsule with no invasion of the renal vein and free surgical margins. Additionally, the excised adipose tissue over the tumor is identified as benign fibroadipose tissue. The findings were consistent between the intraoperative frozen section and the permanent diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a Grade 3 poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma in the bladder, classified as pT2 due to invasion of the muscularis propria. The specimen consisted of multiple tissue fragments, with extensive necrotic infiltrating tumor observed. No vascular channel invasion was identified, and the background urothelium appeared flat and non-dysplastic.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma with tall cell features, measuring 4.5 cm, located in the left lobe of the thyroid, which invades perithyroidal skeletal muscle and has involved margins. Additionally, three lymph nodes were found to have metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, with no extranodal spread observed. Molecular testing revealed a BRAF V600E mutation, while mutations in NRAS, HRAS, and KRAS were not identified, and the FISH test for RET/PTC rearrangement was negative.

The pathology report indicates that three lymph node biopsies from the left TB angle and interlobar regions are negative for carcinoma. However, the left lower lobe lung resection reveals an invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.0 cm, with venous invasion present and one of nine lymph nodes positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma. The tumor is staged as pT2N1, and the bronchial resection margin is negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that both the right and left pelvic lymph nodes are reactive with no evidence of malignancy (0/1). The prostate specimen shows prostatic adenocarcinoma in both lobes with a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7, invading the adipose tissue and bladder neck, with positive margins at the left and right base. The pathological staging is T4, N0, Mx, confirming the presence of cancer in the prostate while lymph nodes remain negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous papillary adenocarcinoma in both the right and left adnexa, with extensive serosal implants observed. Additionally, a significant omental tumor consistent with serous papillary adenocarcinoma of the peritoneum was identified, and the uterus showed extensive tumor implants but no cervical involvement. The overall diagnosis suggests a pathologic stage of pT3cNXMX, indicating advanced disease primarily affecting the peritoneum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, with a largest tumor mass measuring 3.0 x 3.0 x 3.0 cm and multifocality noted. The lymph nodes examined were benign, with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The tumor has been reclassified to pT3NO due to the presence of a satellite tumor, although no visceral pleural invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of encapsulated papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 4.0 cm and classified as unifocal. The tumor is staged as pT2, with uninvolved margins and no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. Additionally, nodular hyperplasia was noted, and no lymph nodes were submitted for assessment.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the palate, measuring 3.5 cm, with perineural invasion noted and involvement at the deep margin. One of the 33 lymph nodes examined from the right neck was also involved by squamous cell carcinoma, but there was no evidence of extracapsular extension. All other margins and lymph nodes were negative for malignancy, leading to a final staging of AJCC pathologic Stage III (pT2, pN1).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 3.5 x 3 x 1.8 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and extending through the muscularis propria into perivesical soft tissue, but with clear resection margins. Additionally, two of the 52 lymph nodes examined showed metastatic carcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes and ureters were diagnosed as benign with no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy. Other findings included chronic cervicitis and benign changes in the uterus and ovaries, with no significant lesions identified in those structures.

The pathology report indicates the presence of anaplastic oligodendroglioma, grade III, characterized by a high MIB-1 labeling index of 9.6% and a borderline mitotic count. Microscopic examination reveals a glial neoplasm with moderate nuclear atypia, prominent perinuclear halos, and occasional mitotic figures, but no necrosis or microvascular proliferation. The tumor infiltrates both white and grey matter, with background hemorrhage and scattered calcifications noted.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph nodes from the ST10L TB angle and subcarinal ST7 are negative for malignancy, while the left lung pneumonectomy reveals poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5.7 cm, with invasion into the pulmonary artery and extensive infiltration of the interlobar lymph node. The bronchial resection margin is negative for tumor, and there is evidence of blood and lymphatic vessel invasion, as well as obstructive pneumonia in the lower lobe. Overall, the tumor is classified as pT2 and pN1, indicating significant local extension and involvement of lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Type A/B Thymoma with a tumor diameter of 4.2 cm, classified as pT3, pNx, and Masaoka stage III due to infiltration into mediastinal fat tissue and lung parenchyma. Immunohistochemical analysis shows that the epithelial cells are positive for CK 5/6 and negative for CD1a, CD5, and CD117, with the presence of CD5-positive mature T-lymphocytes interspersed among the epithelial cells. This suggests a complex tumor composition with both epithelial and lymphocytic components.

The pathology report indicates that the right axillary sentinel lymph node shows no identifiable tumor, although isolated keratin-positive cells are present. The right breast excision reveals invasive ductal carcinoma with metaplastic features, measuring 2.3 cm, and the specimen margins are negative for malignancy. Additionally, lobular neoplasia and fibrocystic changes are noted, along with changes consistent with a prior biopsy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the left para-tracheal lymph node and thyroid gland, characterized as well differentiated with no identified mitotic activity or tumor necrosis. The primary tumor in the left lobe measures 1.2 cm, with microscopic foci of papillary microcarcinomas present in both lobes, and metastatic disease identified in 3 of 5 lymph nodes. Additionally, the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue shows nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left thyroid lobe, with a tumor size of 2.9 cm and well-differentiated histology. One prelaryngeal lymph node was positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the right paratracheal lymph nodes were negative for cancer, and three out of three left paratracheal lymph nodes showed metastatic involvement. Additional findings include microscopic foci of papillary microcarcinoma and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis in the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary serous carcinoma involving the omentum, uterus, cervix, bilateral adnexa, and both ovaries, with the tumor exhibiting a mixed histologic type of endometrioid and serous adenocarcinoma. The tumor is staged as pT2Nx, with no myometrial invasion and superficial stromal invasion noted in the cervix. Surgical margins are negative, and there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, although extensive tumor involvement is observed in the omentum and both fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates that the right pelvic lymph nodes show two benign hyperplastic lymph nodes, while the left pelvic lymph node also exhibits benign hyperplasia. The radial prostatectomy reveals the presence of adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7/10, involving both lobes of the prostate, with focal extra-capsular extension and evidence of lympho-vascular and perineural invasion. Surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and no metastatic carcinoma is found in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multifocal prostatic adenocarcinoma with a dominant nodule exhibiting a Gleason score of 4+3=7 and established extraprostatic extension. No evidence of neoplasia was found in the examined lymph nodes, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. The final diagnosis confirms prostate cancer with a pathologic stage of pT3a and multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia present.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the left frontal mass reveals a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV), characterized by a densely cellular tumor with vascular proliferation and necrosis. The tumor cells are positive for GFAP and p53, with a Ki-67 labeling index that is focally up to 60%. Additionally, the EGFR variant III mutation is detected, while no evidence of methylated MGMT promoter is found, suggesting a potential lack of benefit from alkylating agent therapy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma, measuring 1.7 cm, in the left testis following a left radical orchiectomy. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or invasion of the epididymis, and the tumor is confined to the testis with free margins. Additionally, the testicular tissue shows evidence of spermatogenesis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, right ovary, right fallopian tube, uterus, cervix, cul-de-sac, and sigmoid colon, with significant tumor involvement in these areas. The left ovary shows high-grade serous carcinoma, while the left fallopian tube is free of tumor. The report highlights extensive tumor infiltration, particularly in the sigmoid colon and uterine serosa, with some lymph nodes identified in the pericolonic adipose tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with significant myometrial invasion and endocervical invasion, along with vascular invasion noted. All examined lymph nodes and adnexae were found to be benign, and the omentum showed only benign adipose tissue. Additionally, the gallbladder specimen revealed chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the antrum of the stomach, measuring 5.0 cm, with ulceration and local invasion into adjacent fat tissue. The tumor is classified as intestinal type according to the Lauren classification and shows lymphatic invasion, with 2 out of 19 lymph nodes involved by neoplasia. Both proximal and distal margins, as well as neural invasion and blood vessel invasion, are uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated, nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma located in the upper lobe of the left lung, with tumor involvement extending to the pleura and multiple lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as pT2 pN2 V1 R0, indicating local invasion and regional lymph node metastasis, while the surrounding lung parenchyma shows signs of chronic pneumonia and emphysematous changes. Additionally, there are reactive changes in some lymph nodes, with evidence of significant tumor necrosis and pleural adhesion noted.

The pathology report indicates a pneumonectomy specimen from the right lower lung, revealing a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.5 x 3.5 x 3 cm. Out of 12 lymph nodes examined, 2 were positive for metastasis. Specific details regarding tumor extent, other nodules, lymphatic and venous invasion, and margins were not provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme with zones of oligodendroglial differentiation from two brain tumor specimens: one from the right parietal region and another from the right frontal region. The microscopic examination reveals highly anaplastic tumor cells with necrosis, pseudopalisading, and a high proliferation index, suggesting aggressive tumor behavior. Molecular genetic testing for 1p19q deletions is planned due to the presence of oligodendroglial differentiation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the distal esophagus and proximal stomach, with a tumor size of 5.0 cm. The tumor has invaded the muscularis propria but shows no lymph-vascular invasion, while perineural invasion is present, and all surgical margins are uninvolved by carcinoma. A total of 17 regional lymph nodes were examined, and none were positive for neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic low-grade papillary serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, right and left tubes and ovaries, bladder peritoneum, and pelvic lymph nodes. Additionally, there are findings of serous borderline neoplasm with microinvasion in the right tube and ovary, and an endometrial polyp in the uterus. The left pelvic lymph nodes showed no evidence of tumor, while one of seven right pelvic lymph nodes contained metastatic carcinoma.

The final pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the hypopharynx, which measures 4.8 x 3.1 x 3.0 cm and invades the right thyroid gland, with perineural invasion identified. All surgical margins from the esophagus, pharynx, and base of the tongue are negative for carcinoma, and one out of eleven lymph nodes examined shows metastatic carcinoma. The patient has a history of HIV and underwent a total laryngopharyngectomy with neck dissection, and the tumor is classified as pT4a with a single positive lymph node classified as pN1.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left frontal brain tumor diagnosed as glioblastoma (WHO grade IV) following an excision biopsy. The MGMT promoter methylation analysis was performed and found to be positive, indicating the presence of a methylated MGMT promoter. Microscopic examination revealed a high-grade astrocytic neoplasm with pleomorphic features, frequent mitotic figures, and extensive microvascular proliferation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with tumor size recorded as 0 cm and invasion extending greater than half of the myometrium. The surgical specimen included a hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, with uninvolved margins and absent venous invasion. Details regarding lymphatic invasion and lymph node involvement were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right nephrectomy and resection of an adrenal mass, revealing an adrenocortical carcinoma with a largest diameter of 12 cm. The tumor is characterized by a multilobulated, brownish-yellow mass with necrotic areas, capsular invasion, and venous invasion, along with a nuclear grade of 4 and a mitotic count of 3 in 50 high power fields. The surgical margins are stained with green Indian ink, and while the right kidney is attached to the mass, there are no signs of invasion into the kidney itself.

The pathology report indicates that a lymph node associated with the common hepatic artery is involved by adenocarcinoma, while the pancreatic neck and common hepatic duct margins are negative for tumor. A Whipple resection revealed a 3.2 x 3.0 x 2.0 cm invasive moderately to poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the pancreatic head, with angiolymphatic and perineural invasion present, and a positive uncinate margin for invasive carcinoma. Additionally, multiple regional lymph nodes, including the common hepatic artery lymph node, are positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, leading to a final classification of [AJCC pT3N1].

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial cancer, specifically a high-grade (G3) predominantly endometrioid carcinoma with some mucinous features, invading more than half of the myometrium. All examined lymph nodes (16 in total) were benign with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings include focal complex hyperplasia with atypia adjacent to the neoplasm and adenomyosis with leiomyomas in the myometrium, while other organs showed no pathological diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the right and left pelvic lymph nodes. The prostate shows a focus of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), extending focally to the inked margin of resection, while the seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia are free of tumor. Additionally, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) is noted in the prostate.

The pathology report indicates that a right frontal lobe biopsy from a female patient revealed a mixed oligoastrocytoma with atypical features, characterized by diffuse infiltration of the cerebral cortex and white matter, and a MIB-1 proliferation index of 4%. There are no overt signs of anaplasia, such as microvascular proliferation or necrosis, but the presence of proliferation centers and a few mitotic figures suggest potential aggressive behavior. Additionally, the MGMT promoter methylation test was negative, indicating no evidence of methylated MGMT promoter in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a high-grade spindle cell sarcoma consistent with CD117 positive leiomyosarcoma in a retroperitoneal mass associated with the left kidney, which the tumor surrounds but does not invade. The left kidney shows signs of chronic pyelonephritis, while the adrenal gland appears unremarkable. Biopsies of the intra aortocaval and para aortic lymph nodes reveal no evidence of tumor in either lymph node.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring up to 4.4 cm, with a minimum dorsal margin of 2.9 cm. Additionally, there is high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with comedo necrosis present in the tumor center, measuring about 0.2 cm. Sixteen right axillary lymph nodes were examined and found to be free of metastases, resulting in a classification of stage II A for the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman grade of 4, measuring 14 cm, and exhibiting extensive sarcomatoid dedifferentiation and focal necrosis. The carcinoma invades the peri-nephric adipose tissue on the lateral aspect of the kidney, but does not invade the medial aspect or renal sinus adipose tissue, with surgical margins on Gerota's fascia being free of tumor but close to the tumor. Additionally, there is evidence of angiolymphatic invasion with a tumor thrombus in a renal vein, while the non-neoplastic kidney shows no specific abnormalities, and the pathologic TNM staging is pT3b Nx Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO grade III), fibrillary type, from a resected right frontal brain mass. Immunohistochemical analysis shows overexpression of p53 in most tumor cells, a low to moderate Ki67/MIB1 proliferative index, and positivity for IDH1(R132H). Preliminary frozen section consultation suggested a low-grade glial neoplasm, but further evaluation on permanent sections is ongoing.

The pathology report indicates that six lymph nodes from both the right and left periaortic and pelvic regions were examined, with no evidence of tumor found in any of them. A radical hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy revealed endometrioid adenocarcinoma in the endometrium, classified as FIGO grade 3, with myometrial invasion of 1.5 cm and no serosal or lymphovascular space involvement. The tumor was estrogen receptor positive (80%) and progesterone receptor positive (85%), and the overall AJCC pathologic stage is pT1c pNO pMx, corresponding to FIGO stage IB.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a seminoma in the right testis, which measures 7.7 cm and compromises the entire testicular parenchyma. The rete testis is focally affected, but the epididymis and spermatic cord are uninvolved. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, perineural invasion, or necrosis, and the surgical margins are clear of neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the rectosigmoid region, measuring 6.8 cm in length and 8.5 cm in width, with invasion into subserosal adipose tissue but no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and no regional lymph node metastasis was identified among the 24 examined lymph nodes. Additional specimens from hernia contents, omentum, and surgical margins were all reported as benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligoastrocytoma, grade II, characterized by a mildly to moderately hypercellular infiltrating glial neoplasm with both oligodendroglioma and astrocytoma phenotypes, the former being predominant. The MIB-1 labeling index is low at 0.3%, suggesting minimal cellular proliferation. No mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis are observed in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 8.5 cm, with features suggestive of oncocytoma and chromophobe tumor, but without evidence of extracapsular extension or lymphovascular invasion. The right ureteral stent was examined but showed no significant findings, and the tumor exhibited focal positivity for certain markers, supporting the oncocytoma diagnosis. Cytogenetic analysis was attempted but deemed inadequate due to bacterial contamination of the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma (not otherwise specified) in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 6.0 x 5.5 x 4.5 cm, with infiltration into the visceral pleura. The tumor is classified as pT2, pNO (0/22), pMx, and graded as G3, with a Ki-67 proliferation index of 40-50%. Immunohistochemical analysis shows tumor cells positive for CK7 and CEA, with some positivity for TTF1 and Vimentin, while being negative for several other markers.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (G3) of the left breast, with a tumor size of 3.5 x 2.5 x 3.0 cm located in the upper inner quadrant. Immunohistochemical analysis shows no estrogen receptors and low progesterone receptor expression (less than 10%), with a negative HER2 reaction. Additionally, the report notes chronic lymphadenitis in the axillary lymph nodes and fibrous mastopathy in the glandular tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon and upper rectum, measuring 3.5 cm in length and 3.2 cm in width, with invasion into the submucosa and a preexisting tubulovillous adenoma at the site. Lymph node examination revealed metastases in 2 out of 52 nodes, leading to a pathologic stage of pT1 and pN1 according to AJCC classification. The liver biopsy showed non-specific reactive changes without evidence of malignancy, and both proximal and distal margins from the excision were benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well to moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right mandible, measuring 5.5 x 3.5 x 3.5 cm, which is deeply invasive and extends into the skeletal muscle of the floor of the mouth. The carcinoma is free of involvement at the inked soft tissue margins, with the closest margin being 0.3 cm away, and all examined lymph nodes from both the right and left neck levels show no evidence of carcinoma. Additionally, the right anterior and posterior buccal margins are free of carcinoma, and the final pathologic staging is pT4a, pNO, pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the superior division of the left upper lobe, with a tumor measuring 4.0 x 3.2 x 2.5 cm that extends close to the visceral pleura. Focal invasion into the visceral pleura is confirmed, while the bronchial resection margin is negative for tumor, and multiple lymph nodes from various stations show no tumor except for two para-aortic lymph nodes. An addendum will provide further details on pleural invasion assessment.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma, follicular variant, in the right lobe of the thyroid, with at least five foci and focal extrathyroidal extension to the resection margin, classified as pathologic stage T3 NX. In the left lobe, a single 1.5 cm papillary thyroid carcinoma, also of the follicular variant, is confined to the thyroid with clear resection margins and no angiolymphatic invasion. Molecular testing revealed an HRAS codon 61 mutation, while no mutations in BRAF, NRAS, KRAS, or RET/PTC rearrangements were identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4 (7/10), involving both lobes of the prostate and estimated to affect 10-15% of the gland, with focal presence at the left posterior capsule and perineural invasion identified. There is no evidence of extraprostatic extension or tumor involvement in the bilateral seminal vesicles. A positive margin was noted at the left posterior capsule, but it is suggested that this may not represent a true positive margin due to surgical factors during the procedure.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 3.5x3x1.5 cm keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the esophagus, classified as moderately differentiated. The tumor has invaded the adventitia, and all five examined lymph nodes are negative for metastasis. The surgical margins are involved, and there is no information provided regarding lymphatic or venous invasion or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid in the left thyroid lobe, with a tumor size of 6.5 cm and evidence of lymphovascular invasion. Multiple lymph nodes, including those in the left paratracheal region and central compartment, show metastatic involvement with papillary carcinoma, with a total of 12 out of 19 examined lymph nodes being positive for metastasis. Additionally, the right thyroid lobe shows signs of lymphocytic thyroiditis, and the margins of the resected tumor are uninvolved by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of adenocarcinoma, acinar type, grade III, in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 4 cm and invading the visceral pleura, with negative bronchial and vascular margins. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in two of four lymph nodes examined, while the right 6th rib and right upper lobe wedge resection showed no tumor. Additionally, lymph nodes at levels 4, 10, and 3 were free of tumor, leading to a final staging of pT2, N2, Mx.

The pathology report describes a right upper lobectomy specimen containing a 50 mm mass of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, with no visceral pleura involvement and free bronchial resection margins. Serial sectioning of the remaining lung tissue shows no other lesions, while lymph nodes exhibit necrosis and reactive changes without malignancy. Additionally, a right middle lobe nodule is noted, which also shows reactive changes in a lymph node with no evidence of cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 5.5 cm, confined within the liver capsule, with uninvolved resection margins. The tumor is solitary, located in liver segments 6 and 7, and shows no evidence of vascular invasion or additional pathologic findings. Additionally, there is noted iron overload (2+) in the liver tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade III) in the temporal lobe, with a background of low-grade (Grade II) oligodendroglioma, and a calculated MIB-1 labeling index of 12.5%. Microscopic examination reveals a variably cellular and infiltrating diffuse glioma characterized by a microgemistocytic phenotype, with mild to focally moderate atypia and rare mitoses in most areas, while the enhancing uncus shows marked hypercellularity and increased atypia with scattered mitoses. No microvascular proliferation or tumor necrosis is present in the majority of the specimen, although some areas exhibit notable hypercellularity and mitotic activity.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligoastrocytoma, classified as grade III according to the World Health Organization (WHO) grading system. The tumor is located in the left temporal region of the brain. The patient is male.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma, WHO grade III, located in the left frontal region of the brain, with a MIB-1 labeling index of 24.4% in the most proliferative areas. Microscopic examination reveals neoplastic cells resembling oligodendrocytes, characterized by moderate to marked cytologic atypia, microvascular proliferation, and areas of necrosis. The presence of numerous mitotic figures and histological features such as microcalcifications and branching thin-walled vessels further supports the diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 and a tumor size of 8 cm, which is confined to the kidney and encapsulated without evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. The adrenal gland is negative for tumor involvement, and all surgical margins are reported as negative. The tumor is classified as pT2 pNX pMX according to AJCC staging.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated (Grade 3) urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which has invaded through the muscle into the extravesical fat, with no evidence of lymphovascular invasion and a closest surgical margin of 11 mm. Additionally, the prostate shows extensive microacinar adenocarcinoma with perineural involvement but no extracapsular extension, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. A total of 21 lymph nodes were examined, with two nodes showing metastatic prostatic adenocarcinoma, leading to a final diagnosis of bladder urothelial carcinoma (pT3a pN0) and bilateral prostatic adenocarcinoma (pT2c pN1).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in a left retroperitoneal tumor measuring 7.2 cm, which involves the renal vein and perirenal fibroadipose tissue, with significant necrosis and hyalinization. The kidney shows marked intimal thickening of interlobular arteries and scattered sclerotic glomeruli, but both the kidney and renal vascular margins are free of tumor. Additionally, one benign renal hilar lymph node was identified.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lymph node from the left cervical neck is diagnosed with malignant lymphoma, specifically the diffuse large cell type (IWF G1). Additionally, bone marrow biopsies from both the right and left iliac crests show orderly hematopoiesis and are negative for lymphoma. Overall, the findings suggest a localized lymphoma in the cervical lymph node without evidence of bone marrow involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, specifically located at the fundus, with a tumor size of 5.2 x 3.6 x 2.1 cm and a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 0.7 cm. All examined lymph nodes from various dissections, including external iliac, obturator, pelvic, and aortic nodes, were negative for carcinoma, indicating no lymphatic spread. The cervix and ovaries were also negative for carcinoma, and the specimen margins were not involved, suggesting a localized tumor without evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a colonoscopy with biopsy due to rectal bleeding and a rectal mass. The final diagnosis reveals the presence of invasive adenocarcinoma, which is well-to-moderately differentiated, in the rectal mass. Additional clinical questions and prior medical history were not addressed in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous carcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with nuclear grade 3 and evidence of capsular invasion, while no definitive lymphatic invasion is identified. The uterus and cervix show benign findings, including proliferative endometrium and a uterine leiomyoma, with no malignancy detected in the omentum, ileum, liver, or appendix. Additionally, scattered malignant cells consistent with ovarian primary were found in one omental sample, suggesting possible metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, in the left kidney, with a nuclear grade of II/IV and focal areas of grade IV, measuring 5.0 cm, confined within the renal capsule, with identified vascular invasion but no renal vein invasion, and all surgical margins free of carcinoma. The left eleventh rib, left spermatic vein, and periaortic lymph nodes were found to be benign, with no evidence of malignancy in the nine examined lymph nodes. The report confirms that the adrenal gland was not identified in the kidney specimen, and the non-neoplastic kidney shows chronic inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a cystectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy performed due to bladder cancer, revealing a grade 3 transitional cell carcinoma with extensive squamous differentiation infiltrating the bladder wall and extending into perivesical fat. The tumor measures 60 x 55 x 20mm and shows focal necrosis, while the attached ovaries and fallopian tubes are histologically normal. Additionally, one of the four dissected lymph nodes shows metastatic tumor deposits, with a final staging of pT3a N2 Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland following a cortical sparing adrenalectomy. Histological examination reveals that the adrenal medulla is entirely replaced by neoplastic chromaffin cells forming two nodules, with some neoplastic cells present at the cauterized resection margin, but no evidence of capsular or vascular invasion. The presence of atypically large nests and focal spindling suggests potential for malignant behavior, warranting clinical correlation.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 5x4x4 cm, located in a lobe of the liver with ill-defined margins. Microscopic examination reveals trabecular and acinar patterns, with tumor cells exhibiting irregularly large, hyperchromatic nuclei and evidence of necrosis and vascular invasion. The tumor is characterized by moderate basophilic or vacuolated cytoplasm and the presence of mitoses, while the stroma shows marked fibrous changes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right renal mass diagnosed as chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, measuring 5.2 cm, which is confined within the renal capsule with no invasion of the renal vein and all surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, three paracaval lymph nodes were excised, and all were found to be benign. A simple cyst measuring 1 cm in diameter was also noted in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of colon adenocarcinoma located in the ascending colon. The tumor is classified as T3, N0, M0, corresponding to an overall stage of IIA. The patient is identified as white and not Hispanic or Latino, with no additional details on vital status or date of death provided.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows no significant pathologic abnormalities and no tumors were identified. In the left hepatic lobe, there are three discrete foci of moderately to poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, with the largest lesion measuring 4.9 cm, and no tumor was found at the surgical resection margins. The report confirms focal lymphatic invasion but no blood vessel invasion, and the non-neoplastic liver parenchyma shows minimal macrovesicular steatosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left adrenalectomy and regional lymph node dissection, with the specimen measuring 17 x 15 x 15 cm and weighing 820 grams. The diagnosis is adrenocortical carcinoma, with the lymph nodes being negative for tumor involvement. Additional findings include a KI67 proliferation index of 2%, a Weiss score of 5, a Hough score of 2.6, and a Van Slooten score of 19.7.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated papillary serous carcinoma in multiple specimens, including the omentum, gallbladder, transverse colon, both ovaries and fallopian tubes, and the bladder, suggesting a widespread malignancy. The uterus and cervix show no significant pathological changes, with only squamous metaplasia and proliferative endometrium noted. The findings are characteristic of primary peritoneal serous carcinoma, correlating with the clinical history of ascites and elevated CA125 levels.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a cavitated poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 58 mm, with visceral pleural invasion and involvement of the chest wall, but clear of the bronchial resection margin. There is evidence of blood vessel invasion, but no lymphatic or perineural invasion, and no lymph node metastases were found in the examined hilar and peri-oesophageal lymph nodes, which showed only reactive changes. A supplementary examination of the chest wall and ribs confirmed no residual malignancy in the chest wall tissues or rib bone.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 3, with a tumor size of 6.8 cm and extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present, including involvement at the inferior margin. No tumor was found in the two examined lymph nodes, resulting in a staging of pT3, pN0(i-)(sn), and an overall AJCC stage of IIB. The tumor exhibits features suggestive of neuroendocrine differentiation and is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, with a Ki-67 proliferation index of 25%.

The pathology report indicates that the left frontal lobe excision revealed an oligodendroglioma classified as WHO Grade II. MIB-1 labeling activity was low overall, with some regions showing higher activity, though their significance remains unclear. Cytogenetic and molecular studies for 1p/19q deletion and MGMT promoter methylation are pending and will be reported separately.

The pathology report indicates a colectomy specimen from the sigmoid colon, revealing a 5.2 x 2.2 cm infiltrative and ulcerated mucinous adenocarcinoma that is poorly differentiated. The tumor extends to the subserosa, with 13 out of 18 examined lymph nodes showing metastasis. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no specified evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium in a female patient, with a histologic grade of 3 and a tumor size of 5.0 cm, showing myometrial invasion of less than half the thickness. There is no evidence of tumor involvement in the lower uterine segment or cervix, and lymphovascular space invasion is not identified; however, one of eleven examined pelvic lymph nodes shows microscopic metastatic carcinoma. The overall cancer staging is T1a, N1, with no neoplasm found in the bilateral ovaries, fallopian tubes, or other examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that a segment V liver resection was performed, revealing a well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with a largest tumor mass measuring 5.5 cm and multiple adjacent satellite lesions. The tumor is confined to the liver with no lymph-vascular invasion identified, and the closest parenchymal margin is 1.5 cm away. The report also notes the presence of portal and periportal fibrosis, consistent with incomplete cirrhosis, and the case is staged as pT3b due to the involvement of a major branch of the portal vein or hepatic veins.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma of the stomach's cardia, measuring 6.5 cm, with infiltration into the distal esophagus and stomach wall, as well as evidence of lymphatic and perineural invasion. Multiple lymph nodes, including right and left paracardic, lesser curvature, and left gastric artery lymph nodes, show metastatic adenocarcinoma with capsular invasion, while the suprapyloric lymph node is uninvolved. The esophageal margin and omentum are also uninvolved by neoplasia, and the gallbladder shows cholelithiasis.

The pathology report indicates that multiple biopsies of the cerebral cortex were performed, revealing no solid tumor in the anterior lateral margin and posterior lateral margins, but showing focal hypercellularity. The tumor center biopsy identified a low-grade glioma (WHO Grade II), and immunohistochemistry confirmed the presence of tumor cells. Additionally, fluorescence in situ hybridization analysis indicated losses on chromosome 29, with further results pending in an addendum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.3 x 2.2 x 2.2 cm, with no invasion of the visceral pleura and benign margins. The hilar lymph node excision revealed a benign anthracotic lymph node with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The final staging is pT1bN0M0, classified as stage IA, indicating localized disease without regional or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma, with three identified foci in the right and left lobes, the largest measuring 1.6 cm, and minimal extrathyroidal extension noted in the left lobe. The right central neck lymph nodes were negative for malignancy, with two benign lymph nodes identified. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3 N0 Mx, and the margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically the chromophobe type, eosinophilic variant, with a histologic grade of 2 and a tumor size of 3.5 cm. The tumor is unifocal, confined to the kidney, and shows no evidence of capsular invasion or involvement of surrounding structures, with all surgical margins free of tumor. The AJCC staging is classified as pT1a, pNx, and the specimen was obtained through robotic partial nephrectomy.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left pelvic lymph nodes show no tumor presence, and the tissue anterior to the prostate is composed of mature adipose tissue with no tumor seen. The prostate gland is diagnosed with adenocarcinoma, classified as pT2c, with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7/10, indicating moderate severity and extent of tumor involvement in 30-50% of the examined tissue. There is no evidence of extraprostatic extension, lymphatic invasion, or tumor in the seminal vesicles, but perineural invasion is present.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary serous adenocarcinoma in both the right and left ovaries, with tumor involvement in the right fallopian tube and serosa. Additionally, metastatic serous adenocarcinoma is identified in the omentum and a right lower quadrant nodule, with vascular invasion present. The tumors are classified as FIGO grade 2/3, and the overall pathologic stage is pT3c pNX pMX.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis and cholesterolosis, along with one benign lymph node. The liver biopsy reveals moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, measuring 3.2 x 2.9 x 2.8 cm, with no vascular invasion and negative surgical margins. Additionally, the background liver exhibits mildly active chronic hepatitis C with bridging fibrosis and early cirrhosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, Furhmans nuclear grade 3, confined to the left kidney, measuring 18.0 x 16.0 x 8.5 cm, with lymphatic and vascular invasion present but free margins and no tumor in the adrenal gland or lymph nodes. The tumor shows extensive hemorrhage and necrosis but does not invade surrounding tissues or structures. Additionally, five para-aortic lymph nodes were examined, all of which were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma in both breasts, with the right breast tumor measuring 2.4 cm and the left breast tumor measuring 1.8 cm, both classified as SBR grade 2. The right breast excision shows involvement of the surgical margins, particularly at the superior and medial margins, while the left breast margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, lobular carcinoma in situ and ductal carcinoma in situ with central necrosis and microcalcifications are noted in the right breast specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma, a type of malignant tumor, collected from the uterus with a size of 13 cm. The tumor exhibits focal epithelioid differentiation and is classified as grade X. The sample was obtained through a resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma of the stomach, specifically located in the middle third of the posterior wall, with a tumor size of 2.5 x 2.4 cm and no gross serosal invasion. The tumor invades the submucosa (T1b) and shows lymphovascular invasion, but there is no evidence of lymph node metastasis, as all examined lymph nodes are negative for tumor presence. Special stains reveal no H. pylori infection, and the margins are clear, indicating early-stage cancer.

The pathology report indicates a right hemicolectomy specimen containing an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon. The tumor exhibits lymphatic vessel invasion and infiltration into the perimuscular fatty tissue, but there are no regional lymph node metastases. The resection margins are tumor-free, and the tumor is classified as G2, pT3, pNO 0/18, L1, V0, R0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma, a type of malignant tumor, collected from the uterus. The tumor measured 21 cm and was resected for examination. The histological analysis confirmed the presence of leiomyosarcoma, but no specific grading or differentiation details were provided.

The pathology report indicates the presence of micrometastatic carcinoma in one lymph node (0.35 mm) detected via immunohistochemistry, while the remaining lymph nodes showed no malignancy. The left simple mastectomy revealed an invasive poorly differentiated ductal carcinoma measuring 3.7 cm, with extensive in situ ductal carcinoma and negative margins for invasive carcinoma, although the deeper margin was focally positive for DCIS. The tumor is classified as ER-positive, PR-negative, and Her2-negative, with a Nottingham score of Grade III.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive, ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 5.0 x 4.5 x 4.0 cm, with invasion into the serosa, adjacent fat tissue, omentum, and colon, along with blood vessel, lymphatic, and perineural invasion. Five out of 33 examined perigastric lymph nodes were involved by neoplasia, while other lymph nodes and surgical margins were uninvolved. The adjacent mucosa showed inactive discrete chronic gastritis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, characterized by tumor papillae with a fine fibrovascular stalk and cuboidal epithelial cells. The tumor measures 2.5 x 2 x 1.8 cm and shows invasion into surrounding tissues, including skeletal muscle, while maintaining cellular polarity and regular nuclei. The report notes that the tumor is necrotic and fibrous, with unifocal presentation on the right side.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent segmental mastectomies of both breasts and axillary dissection due to a diagnosis of left breast cancer and abnormal mammogram findings. The final diagnosis reveals atypical ductal epithelial hyperplasia in the right breast and infiltrating ductal carcinoma with extensive lobular features in the left breast, with tumor margins being close but not extending to surgical margins. Additionally, four out of twenty-two axillary lymph nodes were positive for tumor, indicating lymphatic spread of the disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segments I, II, III, and IV, characterized by a large tumor mass that invades but does not penetrate the hepatic capsule and is close to the surgical margin. Vascular invasion is noted, with approximately 30% tumor necrosis, while the left portal lymph node is benign and the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis with a pigment stone and an adenomyoma. The non-neoplastic liver tissue reveals mild chronic inflammation but is otherwise unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, chromophil (papillary) type, located in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 6.5 cm. The tumor is classified as grade III and is staged as pathological T1b, with no regional lymph node involvement (NX) and no distant metastasis (M0). The sample was obtained through a resection procedure.

The pathology report describes a mildly to moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm resembling mildly atypical oligodendrocytes, with no mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis observed. The tumor infiltrates both gray and white matter and has a MIB-1 labeling index of 2.3%, indicating a modestly proliferative nature. The final diagnosis is a Low Grade Oligodendroglioma, WHO Grade II.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the left liver following a partial hepatectomy, with the tumor measuring 6.5 cm and classified as well differentiated (Grade I). The tumor is solitary, confined to the liver, with no evidence of vascular invasion, and the parenchymal margin is uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, being 15 mm away from the closest margin. Additional findings include a history of cirrhosis and fibrosis, and the regional lymph nodes could not be assessed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, with clear cell features, following a complete nephrectomy of the left kidney. The tumor measures 4.5 x 4.0 x 3.5 cm, invades the peri-renal adipose tissue, but does not involve Gerota's fascia, and all margins are negative. The tumor is classified as Fuhrman grade 3/4, with a pathologic stage of pT3a Nx Mx, and no vascular invasion is identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a low-grade glioma, specifically an oligodendroglioma grade II, located in the left temporal region of the brain. Microscopic examination reveals diffuse infiltration of the neocortex by a low-grade glial neoplasm characterized by distinct cell phenotypes, with a predominance of oligodendroglial features and evidence of 1p/19q co-deletion. The tumor exhibits low cellularity, rare mitotic figures, and lacks microvascular proliferation or necrosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with the largest metastatic deposits measuring up to 0.9 cm. The right lobe of the thyroid shows a 3 cm diffuse sclerosing variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma with extensive lymphovascular invasion and extrathyroidal extension, although the surgical margins are negative for carcinoma. Additional findings include multinodular hyperplasia and lymphocytic thyroiditis in the left lobe, with no evidence of carcinoma in the prelaryngeal tissue or parathyroid gland.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located at the right base of the tongue, with a primary site in the left glossotonsillar sulcus extending into the lingual tonsil, measuring 1.5 cm. Surgical margins are involved with tumor, and no angiolymphatic or perineural invasion, or carcinoma in situ, was identified; lymph nodes were not present in the specimen. Additional biopsies from various sites, including the tonsil and margins, showed no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7, involving both lobes of the prostate and demonstrating unilateral extra-prostatic extension on the left side. The tumor is present at the bladder base margin, but there is no invasion of the muscular wall of the seminal vesicle, and lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions are benign. Additional findings include high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, basal cell hyperplasia, and atrophy, with focal extra-prostatic spread and residual microscopic disease noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two distinct carcinomas in the right upper lobe of the lung: a smaller squamous cell carcinoma (pT1b) and a larger moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (pT2b), with the latter identified at the parenchymal margin after trimming the staple line. Additionally, multiple biopsies of lymphoid tissue reveal benign findings with significant anthracosis, and calcified hyalinized granulomata are noted in the lung tissue, but no fungal organisms or metastatic disease are identified in the lymph nodes. The report concludes that there is a marked fibro-inflammatory reaction surrounding the tumors, with all margins of resection being negative for tumor involvement except for the adenocarcinoma at the trimmed margin.

The pathology report indicates that a left hemiglossectomy specimen revealed a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.8 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of perineural or lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, one of twenty-two lymph nodes examined from the left neck dissection showed metastatic carcinoma, while all other margins and lymph nodes from both sides were free of malignancy. The tumor is classified as pT2 and pN1, indicating a primary tumor size greater than 2 cm but not more than 4 cm, with metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma (grade 3) in a bladder tumor, which is invasive into the muscularis propria. The tumor consists of multiple tan-pink irregular tissue fragments measuring a total of 3.0 x 2.5 x 1.5 cm. No clinical history was provided with the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous carcinoma in the right false cord and a grade 3 squamous carcinoma with lymphatic invasion in the laryngectomy specimen, affecting both the right and left supraglottic regions, but with free margins of resection. Additionally, the right thyroid lobectomy revealed multinodular goiter, and lymph nodes from the right parotid bulb and cervical regions showed no evidence of tumor. Overall, the report highlights significant malignancy in the laryngeal tissue while noting the absence of tumor in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen with an ulcerating adenocarcinoma measuring 9 x 8 x 2 cm, classified as poorly differentiated. There is evidence of metastasis to 8 out of 12 lymph nodes. Margins and other invasion details were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, characterized by a cavitated mass and extensive necrosis. The tumor is well clear of the bronchial resection margin and peribronchial lymph nodes, but there is evidence of vascular invasion and invasion into the overlying thickened pleura. The pathological stage is classified as T2 N0 Mx, confirming no lymph node metastases and clear surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast (NHG2, pT1c, pNO) following a histopathological examination of the resected left breast and axillary tissues. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed estrogen receptors present in 10-75% of neoplastic cell nuclei, no progesterone receptors, and a positive HER2 score of 3+ in invasive cancerous cells. The tumor measures 1.8 x 1.5 x 1.9 cm and is associated with chronic lymphadenitis and sinus histiocytosis in the axillary lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, with a solid mass measuring 2 x 1.2 x 1.2 cm, located 0.8 cm from the bronchial margin, which is histologically negative for tumor. Additionally, multiple intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes and various mediastinal lymph nodes are negative for tumor, although a hyalinized granuloma is noted in one of the lymph nodes. The remaining lung parenchyma shows signs of organizing pneumonia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right colon, with evidence of DNA mismatch repair deficiency, specifically loss of MLH1 and PMS2 gene expression. The tumor is classified as pT4a, pN2b, with lymphovascular invasion and metastasis to 9 out of 16 lymph nodes. Additionally, BRAF mutation analysis was negative, and the tumor's characteristics suggest a potential association with microsatellite instability, which may influence treatment options and prognosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5.3 cm, originating from the floor of the mouth and invading surrounding tissues, including connective tissue, salivary gland, and bone, with perineural invasion noted. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in five out of thirteen examined lymph nodes, with focal extracapsular extension, while multiple other lymph nodes and tissue samples showed no malignancy. The surgical margins for soft tissue are negative for invasive carcinoma, but bone margins are pending further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with an anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) following a right frontal craniotomy for a brain lesion. Microscopic examination revealed a malignant astrocytic neoplasm with significant cytologic pleomorphism and mitotic figures, while additional tests showed abnormalities in several chromosomal markers, including loss of PTEN status. The MGMT promoter methylation analysis was negative, suggesting that the tumor may have a poorer prognosis based on the identified genetic alterations.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a high-grade renal cell carcinoma with extensive papillary, cribriform, and solid features, measuring 3.6 cm and invading the renal sinus fat and renal vein. The tumor is most compatible with a distal nephron/collecting duct origin, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, lymph nodes examined showed no involvement, confirming the absence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma from a right partial nephrectomy, with a tumor size of 2.5 cm and a histologic grade of 1 on the Fuhrman classification. There is no evidence of sarcomatoid features, extra-capsular invasion, or involvement of venous or lymphatic structures, and the surgical margins are negative. The AJCC staging is pT1a pNx pMx, and the perirenal adipose tissue examined shows no carcinoma.

The pathology report describes an orchiectomy specimen weighing 832.1 grams, revealing a well-defined solid tumor measuring 7 x 6.5 x 3.5 cm, which constitutes 90% of the testicular volume and exhibits hemorrhagic and whitish areas. Histological examination confirms a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma with a high proliferative index, characterized by extensive necrosis and infiltration of large atypical immunoblastic cells throughout the testicular parenchyma. The neoplastic cells are positive for CD20, CD79a, BCL2, and MUM1, with a Ki67 proliferation index of 100%, indicating aggressive tumor behavior.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive, moderately-differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma with mucinous differentiation located in the right colon, extending through the muscularis into the pericolonic fat. The surgical margins (proximal, distal, and circumferential) are negative for tumor involvement, and 24 examined lymph nodes show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. Overall, the findings suggest a localized tumor without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with signet ring cells at the gastroesophageal junction, measuring 0.8 cm, with clear resection margins and no evidence of lymph node involvement. Multiple biopsies of lymph nodes and gastric tissue revealed anthracotic lymph nodes and adipose tissue without any pathological changes, confirming that 24 lymph nodes examined were free of tumor. Additionally, HER2 testing on the adenocarcinoma was negative, indicating no amplification of the HER2 gene.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the mid esophagus, measuring 2.2 cm, with tumor invasion through the submucosa and no lymph-vascular or perineural invasion identified. The surgical margins, including the esophageal and hepatogastric ligament margins, are uninvolved by carcinoma, but there is evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the mediastinal and subcarinal lymph nodes. Out of the examined lymph nodes, three out of twelve left paracardic lymph nodes and two out of eight celiac trunk lymph nodes were positive for neoplasia, indicating regional lymphatic spread of the disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma located 6 cm from Bauhin's valve, measuring 2 cm in diameter, with invasive spread to the submucosa. The resection margins, greater omentum, and 31 examined lymph nodes are all tumor-free, indicating no lymphatic spread. The tumor is staged as pT1, pNO (0/31), LO, V0; G2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a right breast sample with moderately differentiated invasive carcinoma, measuring at least 7 cm, and showing focal ductal components along with Paget's disease of the nipple. There is evidence of angioinvasion and ulceration of the carcinoma skin, but the dorsal margin is tumor-free. The tumor classification is noted as NOS, G II, pT4bN1aL1 1VORO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, in the right breast, with a tumor size of 3.1 x 2.3 x 2.1 cm and extensive angiolymphatic invasion. A single right axillary lymph node showed micrometastatic carcinoma, while multiple other lymph nodes were negative for tumor involvement, and all surgical margins were clear of cancer. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive (1-10% staining), progesterone receptor negative, and HER2/neu overexpression is negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right thyroid lobe, measuring 2.5 cm, with no extrathyroidal extension or lymphovascular invasion, and negative resection margins. Additionally, metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma was found in two of fifteen right paratracheal and upper mediastinal lymph nodes, as well as in one pretracheal lymph node. The left lobe of the thyroid and other examined tissues showed no evidence of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic adenocarcinoma involving the uterus, with additional findings of endometrial polyps and intramural leiomyoma, while the cervix shows no abnormalities. The left ovary reveals moderately differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma, and both ovaries and fallopian tubes exhibit metastatic adenocarcinoma, with involvement of peri-ovarian soft tissue and omentum. The report also notes one lymph node examined with no evidence of malignancy, and the overall staging suggests advanced disease with peritoneal metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the left tonsil shows invasive non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.1 cm, with the carcinoma extending to the superior tissue edge and being less than 0.1 cm from the deep tissue edge, while perineural invasion is absent. The right tonsil also contains invasive non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma, approximately 0.8 cm in size, but with free margins. Immunohistochemical staining for p16 is positive, suggesting a potential association with human papillomavirus.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of carcinosarcoma (malignant mesodermal mixed tumor) in the uterus, with the tumor measuring 3.5 cm and an additional aggregate of 6.5 x 5 x 2.5 cm, showing a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 0.4 cm. Microscopic examination revealed no tumor in the majority of lymph nodes, except for a nodular focus of carcinosarcoma in the anterior peritoneal lymph node. The remaining structures, including the cervix and appendix, showed no pathological abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classic seminoma in the right testicle, measuring 8.0 cm, with no invasion of the rete testis or lymphovascular structures, and extensive intratubular germ cell neoplasia (ITGCN) identified. The left testis biopsy shows normal seminiferous tubules with no pathological alterations or evidence of ITGCN or malignancy. The tumor is classified as pT1, stage IA, with negative margins and no distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon, with tumor-free resection margins and solitary regional lymph node metastases (pT2 pN1). The tumor has infiltrated the lamina and muscularis propria, classified as G2, with no evidence of vascular invasion. Additionally, the small intestine or Meckel's diverticulum shows no signs of inflammation or tissue heterotopy.

The pathology report indicates that multiple excised specimens from the posterior and anterior dorsum, anterior and posterior ventral tongue, and margins are all negative for tumor. However, a left partial glossectomy revealed a squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5.0 cm with a depth of invasion of 1.0 cm, classified as moderately differentiated (G2), but with uninvolved margins and no regional lymph node metastasis. Additionally, benign lymph nodes were identified in the left neck dissection, confirming no evidence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffusely infiltrative endocervical adenocarcinoma in the cervical mass, with no residual intact cervical mucosa and a tumor size of 4.5 by 3.0 cm. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and all examined lymph nodes from various regions are negative for metastatic disease. Additional findings include background areas suspicious for adenocarcinoma in situ and benign changes in the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left simple mastectomy due to invasive ductal carcinoma, with multiple tumor foci identified, including in situ and infiltrating carcinoma. The report details that the tumors were located at various sites within the breast tissue, with some lesions extending close to the superficial margin. Sentinel lymph node biopsies from the left axilla showed no evidence of metastatic disease, and the re-excised margins and core biopsy site revealed no residual tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated serous papillary adenocarcinoma originating from the right ovary, measuring 4.5 cm, with evidence of lymphovascular invasion and metastasis to the omentum and appendix. The tumor has also invaded the serosa of the uterus and shows focal extension into the outer third of the myometrium, while the endometrium remains inactive and free of carcinoma. The final staging is classified as AJCC/UICC/FIGO stage IIIC, indicating significant peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma in a left temporal tumor, characterized by high cellularity, marked cytologic atypia, and a MIB-1 proliferation index of up to 50%. There is no evidence of methylated MGMT promoter or EGFRvIII mutation detected, and a partial loss of chromosome arm 1p was observed, while no allelic loss on chromosome arm 19q was detected. The tumor exhibits brisk mitotic activity and some microvascular proliferation, with no significant necrosis noted in the examined sections.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the right thyroid lobe, with three foci identified and a tumor size of up to 4.6 cm, showing capsular invasion but no blood vessel invasion or extrathyroid extension. Additionally, one lymph node was examined, which contained metastatic disease consistent with papillary thyroid carcinoma. An additional papillary microcarcinoma with tall cell features measuring 0.6 cm was also identified in the isthmus.

The pathology report indicates that six lymph nodes from the right pelvis showed no carcinoma, while one of four lymph nodes from the left pelvis tested positive for metastatic carcinoma. The radical prostatectomy revealed prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+5=9, exhibiting extra-prostatic extension and involvement of the right seminal vesicle. The overall staging is pT3bN1, indicating advanced disease with lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple tumors in the right kidney, specifically six tumors diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the clear cell type, all with Fuhrman nuclear grade II. Additionally, there is one renal cyst identified among the tumors. The report also includes a specimen from the 11th rib, which showed no mass lesions and was kept for gross examination only.
