The pathology report indicates that the pleural fluid is highly cellular and shows features suspicious for malignant mesothelioma, with a differential diagnosis of atypical hyperplasia. Immunoperoxidase studies reveal positive markers consistent with malignant mesothelioma, including CK7, EMA, and calretinin, while CD15 and CEA are negative. The findings have been reviewed and confirmed by another pathologist, supporting the diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the left lateral tongue, with evidence of infiltrative growth and invasion into skeletal muscle, as well as perineural and lymphovascular invasion. The surgical margins from the glossectomy are negative for carcinoma, while one of seven lymph nodes examined shows metastatic carcinoma without extracapsular spread. Additional excisions from other areas of the tongue are negative for high-grade dysplasia and invasive carcinoma, confirming localized disease.

The pathology report indicates that a right mandibulectomy, glossectomy, and pharyngectomy were performed due to a 3.5 cm invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma at the base of the tongue, with a maximum depth of invasion of 1.5 cm and identified perineural invasion. Examination of the bone sections revealed no involvement by carcinoma, and while there were focal mild atypical changes at the margins, they were free of tumor. Overall, the closest deep margin is 1.8 cm away from the tumor, and no lymphovascular invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated, invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder and prostate, with the tumor invading the prostatic parenchyma and a maximum depth of invasion of 1.1 cm. There are also findings of carcinoma in situ in the inferior and anterior urethral margins, while the remaining margins and lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy. The final diagnosis includes a high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma with associated low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma, and no tumor was identified in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lymph nodes from levels 11 and 7 are negative for tumor, while the right lower lobe of the lung shows poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma, consistent with poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with negative margins and no evidence of vascular or pleural invasion. The regional lymph nodes, including hilar and peri-bronchial nodes, are also negative for malignancy, and there are no distant metastases identified. Additional findings include focal hyalinization in the lymph nodes, possibly reflecting old granulomas, and scattered chronic inflammation in the lung away from the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes were biopsied and found to be negative for metastatic carcinoma, while a lobectomy of the right upper lobe revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 7x6x5 cm, which invaded the chest wall and pleura but had negative surgical margins. The final pathologic staging is pT3N0M0, classified as stage IIB, indicating no regional or distant metastasis. Immunohistochemical testing confirmed the tumor's histology as adenocarcinoma, with no criteria met for EGFR or ALK testing.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma with mucinous features in the left breast, classified as Nottingham grade III, with a tumor size of 1.9 x 1.0 x 0.9 cm and associated ductal carcinoma in situ comprising 5-25% of the tumor volume. The medial margin is positive for ductal carcinoma in situ after re-excisions, but no residual invasive carcinoma is found in the simple mastectomy specimen, and the sentinel lymph node is negative for metastatic carcinoma. Immunohistochemical testing for Her-2/NEU has been ordered on the tissue samples.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenal gland mass, measuring 7.5 x 5.4 x 6.7 cm and weighing 225 grams, was identified as a pheochromocytoma, which is a type of tumor that can produce excess catecholamines. The mass was well encapsulated, partially cystic, and exhibited focal hemorrhage, with a thin strip of normal adrenal gland tissue present at the periphery. Importantly, the surgical margins were negative, suggesting complete resection of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the right axillary sentinel lymph node #1 shows no evidence of malignancy, while sentinel lymph node #2 is positive for metastatic carcinoma in both lymph nodes examined. The right breast tissue reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma with focal lobular features, classified as Nottingham grade 2, and the tumor measures 4 x 6 x 7 cm. Additionally, there is evidence of carcinoma in the lymphatics of the nipple, with a total of 11 lymph nodes examined, of which 3 are positive for metastases.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade III, with invasion into the myometrium and suspicious foci for lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, an adult granulosa cell tumor was identified in the right ovary, while all examined lymph nodes were reported as benign with no evidence of metastasis. The report concludes that the endometrial carcinoma is confined to the uterus, with no regional lymph node metastasis detected.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left pelvic lymph node dissections revealed a total of thirteen benign hyperplastic regional lymph nodes with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The radical prostatectomy identified a conventional adenocarcinoma, comprising approximately 10% of the prostate gland volume, with a Gleason score of 7/10 and perineuronal invasion noted near the surgical margin. Additional findings included benign prostatic hyperplasia and chronic prostatitis, with no seminal vesicle or lymphovascular space involvement detected.

The pathology report describes a left adrenalectomy specimen from a patient with adrenal cancer, revealing a 16 cm solid, well-circumscribed adrenal mass with approximately 40-50% necrosis. The mass is diagnosed as adrenal cortical carcinoma, oncocytic type, with minimal capsular invasion and no vascular invasion, and the resection margins are negative. The spleen, pancreas, and kidney appear grossly unremarkable and uninvolved by neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, specifically the tall cell variant, with a tumor size of 1.5 cm located in the right lobe of the thyroid. Metastatic disease was identified in one of the additional right paratracheal lymph nodes, while the other lymph nodes and the Delphian and pretracheal tissues were found to be benign. Surgical margins from the total thyroidectomy are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of blood vessel invasion or extranodal extension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left breast cancer, confirmed by a left total mastectomy and axillary dissection, revealing infiltrating poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma with a Nottingham score of 8/9. Two out of twenty-five lymph nodes showed metastatic poorly differentiated ductal carcinoma, while all surgical margins, nipple, and skin were free of tumor. Hormone receptor tests showed negative estrogen and progesterone receptors, with HER-2/neu weakly positive (score 2+), and further testing for HER-2/neu was ordered.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrioid adenocarcinoma in both the right ovary and the endometrium, with the ovarian tumor showing invasion into the myometrium. The right fallopian tube is negative for carcinoma, and the left ovary and fallopian tube show benign findings. Lymph nodes from the para-aortic, right obturator, and left iliac regions are all negative for carcinoma, suggesting no regional metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon, with the tumor extending into pericolonic fat but all surgical margins being negative for tumor. Six out of thirty-two regional lymph nodes show metastatic adenocarcinoma. The right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes show no significant pathology.

The pathology report indicates that a total thyroidectomy was performed, revealing a 1.7 cm follicular variant of papillary carcinoma in the left lobe, which is organ confined and completely resected, along with a 0.3 mm focus of papillary microcarcinoma. The right lobe shows multinodular goiter, and all three examined central cervical lymph nodes are negative for metastatic disease. The margins of resection are negative, and there is no evidence of vascular invasion or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the right adrenal gland specimen, obtained from an adrenalectomy, is diagnosed as a pheochromocytoma, a type of neuroendocrine tumor. The mass measures 5 x 4.5 x 3.5 cm and exhibits a largely hemorrhagic cut surface. Additionally, a portion of the right 12th rib was submitted, which consists of normal bone fragments.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular breast carcinoma with a maximum diameter of 2.5 cm and a malignancy grade of II. The tumor classification is pT2, with no regional lymph node involvement (0/1) and no distant metastasis (MX), achieving clear margins (R0). The tumor is classified as G2, with no lymphovascular invasion (L0, V0).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) from a biopsy and removal of a tumor in the right temporal lobe of the brain. The specimens consisted of irregular fragments of soft tissue, which were evaluated microscopically and confirmed as glioblastoma multiforme. The report includes details of the intraoperative consultation and the gross description of the submitted tissue samples.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary and fallopian tube, as well as left adnexal tissue and omentum, are negative for malignancy. The uterus shows a high-grade serous carcinoma measuring 4.8 x 4.0 x 3.0 cm with myometrial invasion of 1.5 cm, but no cervical involvement or lymphovascular invasion is identified. All examined lymph nodes from various regions are negative for metastatic disease, and the surgical margins are uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast shows fibrocystic changes, while the left breast reveals invasive, multifocal moderately differentiated ductal carcinoma with mucinous morphology, measuring a total of 4.4 cm. One left rotter lymph node is positive for metastatic carcinoma, with perinodal tumoral invasion, while no carcinoma is found in the examined right axillary nodes or the eighteen lymph nodes from the left axilla. The tumor is classified as pT2 N1a Mx, with positive estrogen receptor status and negative progesterone and Her2 receptor statuses.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma (Grade 2) in the uterus and cervix, with evidence of myometrial invasion exceeding 50%. All examined lymph nodes from both pelvic and aortic regions show no evidence of metastasis. The right and left tubes and ovaries are unremarkable, and additional findings include the presence of leiomyomata in the uterus.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right chest wall mass showing reactive changes and inflammation, with biopsies of lymph nodes revealing no tumor involvement. A pleural resection specimen demonstrates a malignant biphasic tumor consistent with biphasic mesothelioma, characterized by 90% sarcomatoid and 10% epithelioid components, with local invasion but no lymphatic or venous invasion. The tumor is classified as pT3, indicating it is locally advanced but potentially resectable, and genetic testing for synovial sarcoma was negative, supporting the diagnosis of mesothelioma.

The revised surgical pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2, and confirms that the vascular and ureteral margins are free of tumor. The tumor measures 4.0 cm, is unifocal, and is confined to the kidney without involvement of the capsule. The report was revised due to a computer software error that corrupted the original final report, ensuring that this document accurately reflects the findings.

The pathology report indicates that the right axilla sentinel lymph node biopsy revealed carcinoma in one sentinel node following a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, which was moderately differentiated with focal micropapillary features. The lumpectomy specimen also showed intraductal carcinoma and lobular neoplasia, while the axillary lymph node dissection revealed no evidence of carcinoma in the remaining 14 lymph nodes. Overall, the findings suggest a diagnosis of breast cancer with lymphatic involvement, but no additional metastatic disease in the axillary lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive well-differentiated squamous carcinoma involving the tongue and floor of mouth, with focal extension to the left anterolateral floor of mouth and perineural invasion present. The resection margins, except for the left lateral anterior mucosal margin, are free of tumor. Additionally, multiple teeth and fragments were noted, but only a gross diagnosis was provided for them.

The pathology report indicates that no malignancy was found in any of the examined sentinel lymph nodes, with all showing negative results for keratin immunostaining. The right breast specimen revealed an invasive ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated, measuring 2.8 cm, with clear resection margins and no lymphovascular invasion identified. Additionally, high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ was present, but margins were free of this component, and the overall pathologic staging is pT2 N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a modified radical mastectomy for invasive lobular carcinoma of the pleomorphic type in the right breast, with a maximum tumor dimension of 4 cm and evidence of perineural invasion. Additionally, all 27 examined lymph nodes from the right axillary node dissection showed metastatic carcinoma, with extension into the perinodal fat. The tumor exhibits a Nottingham score of 6, indicating a moderate level of differentiation and low mitotic activity.

The pathology report indicates the presence of benign lymph nodes in both the left and right pelvic regions, with a total of four benign lymph nodes excised. The prostate examination reveals adenocarcinoma classified as pT2c, pN0, with a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7/10, indicating a tumor size of approximately 2.0 cm and positive resection margins in the right anterior base region. Additionally, the bladder neck margin is reported as negative for malignancy, and there are noted non-neoplastic changes including nodular hyperplasia and acute prostatitis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in multiple cervical biopsies, specifically noting large cell nonkeratinizing and focally keratinizing types that are moderately differentiated. Additionally, a bladder biopsy shows benign urothelial mucosa with mild chronic cystitis and extensive epithelial denudement. The depth of invasion for the cervical carcinoma cannot be adequately evaluated, but it involves the full thickness of most biopsy specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated bilateral adenocarcinoma of the prostate, primarily located in the peripheral zone, with a Gleason score of 4+5=9 and a maximum tumor diameter of 33 mm, involving approximately 80% of the gland. There is evidence of tumor infiltration into surrounding tissues, extensive bilateral seminal vesicle involvement, and perineural infiltration, with lymph node metastases identified in the left obdurator fossa and right external lymph nodes. The final tumor classification is pT3b, with lymph vessel invasion noted but no blood vessel invasion, and the presence of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with Furhman nuclear grade II in the excised left kidney tumor. Additionally, the cyst wall and base of the cyst show denudation of the lining and fibrosis. The patient has a history of von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and presented with a solid renal mass.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), with a tumor size of approximately 4.3 cm. The tumor is classified as Grade III and is located in the left upper and lower lobes, with a pathological T classification of T2a and N classification of N1, while clinical M is noted as MO. The tumor has been resected, and further histological analysis confirms the presence of squamous carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that no carcinoma was identified in any of the examined lymph nodes (total 19 nodes), while the primary diagnosis is a Grade III endometrioid adenocarcinoma located in the endometrium, with superficial myometrial invasion. The tumor measures 5.0 x 4.0 x 2.0 cm and shows no involvement of the cervix, lower uterine segment, or adnexa, with clear margins and no lymphovascular space invasion. Immunohistochemical studies reveal moderate estrogen receptor positivity in 60-70% of tumor cells and low progesterone receptor positivity in 5% of tumor cells, supporting the diagnosis of grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the esophagus measuring 2.7x2x1.5 cm, diagnosed as moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. There is evidence of metastasis in 1 out of 3 examined lymph nodes, while the surgical margins are uninvolved. Additional details regarding lymphatic and venous invasion, as well as neo-adjuvant treatment, were not specified.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenal gland was surgically removed and examined, revealing a pheochromocytoma measuring 4.8 cm. The mass appeared encapsulated and was grossly free of surrounding tissue, with margins confirmed to be clear. The specimen was processed and analyzed by the signing staff pathologist, who confirmed the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that a brain tumor specimen was submitted for evaluation, with a clinical history of a brain mass in a patient with prostate cancer. The frozen section diagnosis revealed a malignant glioma, specifically glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV astrocytoma). The specimen has been processed for permanent analysis, confirming the diagnosis of glioblastoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma involving the entire bladder wall, with extension into surrounding perivesical soft tissue and multifocal areas of carcinoma in situ. The tumor has also invaded the left ureter and the posterior surgical margin, while multiple lymph nodes examined show no evidence of metastatic disease. Additional findings include cystitis cystica and cystitis glandularis, with all distal ureteral and urethral margins free of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of heterotopic pancreas with focal pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia type 1 in the perigastric lymph nodes, but no lymph node was identified. The right colon hemicolectomy specimen reveals a low-grade, moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma measuring 7.0 cm, with invasion through the subserosa to the serosal surface, but negative resection margins and no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Additionally, there is a mild peritumoral lymphoid response and residual adenoma, with regional lymph nodes showing 5 positive out of 31 examined, classified as T4 N2 MX according to AJCC staging.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of highly differentiated invasive gastric adenocarcinoma of the intestinal type, which has infiltrated all layers of the attached colon loop and the pancreatic capsule, with marked perineural growth. There is evidence of metastasis in a pericolic lymph node and three peripancreatic lymph nodes, although all resection margins and jointly resected hepatic and splenic parenchyma are tumor-free. The regional lymph nodes examined from various areas, including the stomach and hepatoduodenal region, were also found to be tumor-free.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) from a biopsy and partial removal of a lesion in the right parietal lobe of the brain. Immunostaining results show reactive lymphocytes with CD3 positivity and negative CD20 staining. The specimens submitted included multiple soft tissue fragments, with a total aggregate size of approximately 5.0 x 2.8 x 1.0 cm.

The pathology report describes a left adrenal pheochromocytoma measuring 3 cm, characterized by a well-defined, densely cellular tumor with a trabecular architecture and no signs of malignancy, such as mitotic figures or capsule infiltration. Histologically, the tumor cells exhibit basophilic cytoplasm and are positive for chromogranin, indicating neuroendocrine origin. The overall assessment indicates a benign tumor with a PASS score of 4, suggesting high cellularity and cellular monotony.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the cervix, measuring 3.6 cm, with invasion depth of 12 mm and focal lymphovascular space invasion, although resection margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, carcinoma in situ (CIN III) is noted adjacent to the tumor, while the parametrium, vagina, and endometrium show no carcinoma or dysplasia. Other findings include epithelial inclusion cysts in both ovaries and hydrosalpinx in the right fallopian tube, with mild chronic inflammation and squamous metaplasia also observed.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) in both breasts, with Nottingham grades of 3 for the left breast and 2 for the right breast, and a maximum tumor size of 2.0 cm. Sentinel lymph node biopsies from both axillae are negative for metastatic tumor involvement, and resection margins are clear of carcinoma. The tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER-2, with additional findings of atypical ductal hyperplasia and benign breast changes.

The pathology report indicates that a total thyroidectomy was performed, revealing a 1.0 cm papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, follicular variant, with two out of eight paratracheal lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. The pretracheal and right paratracheal lymph nodes were both benign, and the resection margins were negative for carcinoma. Additional findings included chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, and the overall pathologic stage was classified as pT1, N1a, Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, with a tumor size of 3.3 x 1.8 x 3.2 cm and metastases found in 3 out of 16 axillary lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as NHG2, with estrogen receptors present in 75% of the neoplastic cell nuclei and progesterone receptors in 10-75%, while HER2 testing returned a negative result. The report also notes fibrocystic changes in the glandular tissue and provides specific measurements and descriptions of the excised breast and axillary tissues.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left parietal mass lesion diagnosed as glioblastoma, characterized by a high proliferation index of 35% and significant mitotic activity. Microscopic examination reveals a highly cellular neoplasm with features such as tumor necrosis and microvascular proliferation. Molecular testing for the presence of an oligodendroglial component and EGFRvIII mutation is ongoing, with initial results showing no evidence of the mutation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma, pleomorphic type, measuring 2.0 cm, with poorly differentiated histology and positive margins at the posterior, lateral, and superior segments. Prognostic markers show positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, high Ki-67 proliferation index (40-50%), and negative HER-2/neu status, suggesting a favorable hormonal profile despite the aggressive tumor characteristics. Sentinel lymph nodes were negative for metastatic carcinoma, and additional findings included atypical lobular hyperplasia and benign changes in surrounding breast tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, with tumor sizes measuring 2.1 cm in the right lobe, 2.6 cm in the isthmus, and 0.4 cm in the left lobe, accompanied by extrathyroidal extension but negative surgical margins and lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, metastatic papillary carcinoma was identified in one of four right paratracheal lymph nodes, while the left paratracheal lymph nodes showed no pathological diagnosis. The tumor staging is classified as T3, N1a, MX, and is categorized as Stage I for a patient under 45 years old.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a HRAS mutation (p.Q61K) in the thyroid tissue, while mutations in BRAF, NRAS, and KRAS were not identified, and a FISH test for RET/PTC rearrangement is pending. The final diagnosis reveals a poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the larynx with extracapsular spread in one of the lymph nodes, alongside multifocal papillary thyroid microcarcinomas confined to the thyroid. Additional findings include positive surgical margins for squamous cell carcinoma and the presence of a keratinizing lymphoepithelial cyst and nodular hyperplasia in the thyroid.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph node from the cystic duct and the cystic duct stump excision are both negative for tumor. A fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma was identified in the liver, measuring 10.2 x 8.3 x 7.4 cm, but it is confined to the liver with negative surgical margins and no evidence of vascular or microscopic invasion. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from the hepatoduodenal ligament are also negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) from a left frontal lobe tumor removal, with noted focal oligodendroglial differentiation. An addendum is pending for analyses of lesions on chromosomes 1 and 19, and fluorescence in situ hybridization shows preservation of both chromosomes 1p. The specimen consisted of multiple segments of irregular, opaque white to tan-brown, soft cerebriform tissue, measuring 2.3 x 1.8 x 0.5 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma originating from the renal pelvis, with a tumor size of 26 cm and evidence of invasion into periadrenal adipose tissue, but not into the adrenal gland, spleen, or pancreas. The biopsies of the pancreas and adrenal artery margin show no pancreatic tissue and no evidence of malignancy, respectively. Regional lymph nodes are free of metastatic disease, and there are no distant metastases noted, although lymphovascular invasion is present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type with mucinous differentiation (FIGO grade 1), confined to the endometrium with no cervical, vaginal, or lymphovascular involvement. All examined lymph nodes (35 total) were free of metastatic tumor, and peritoneal cytology was negative for malignancy. Additional findings include moderate to severe squamous dysplasia (CIN II-III) in the cervix and myometrial adenomyosis and leiomyoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, in the left lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 2.2 cm and well-differentiated histologic grade. There is no evidence of mitotic activity, necrosis, capsular invasion, blood vessel invasion, or extrathyroid extension, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, the non-neoplastic thyroid shows nodular hyperplasia, and parathyroid glands were not identified in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma (Fuhrman Nuclear Grade III/IV) with a tumor size of 6.0 cm, which extends through the renal capsule but is confined within Gerota's fascia, and involves renal sinus fat without renal vein invasion. Additionally, a retrocaval lymph node excision revealed malignant lymphoma of the marginal zone type, with immunostaining results consistent with this diagnosis and no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The adrenal gland was not involved by the tumor, and there were multiple foci of cortical amyloidosis noted, but no amyloid deposition was found in the kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon, measuring 3 cm, with infiltration into pericolic fatty tissue and penetration of the serosa. There are three local lymph node metastases identified, but the resection margins are tumor-free. The tumor is staged as pT4, pN1 (3/21), pM1, with clinical metastases to the liver and lung.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma, specifically serous type mixed with clear cell components, with a grade of 3/3 and a depth of invasion of 14 mm into the myometrium. The tumor measures 3.5 cm and shows invasive characteristics with metastasis noted in the omentum and other pelvic tissues, leading to a staging of pT3b, pN1, pM1. Additionally, one lymph node was involved with micrometastasis, while no tumor was seen at the resection margins of the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma, a type of cancer, identified in a tumor sample collected from the uterus and ovary. The tumor measures 10 cm and is classified as pathological T2b, with no regional lymph node involvement (NX) and no distant metastasis (M0). The tumor's grade or differentiation is marked as X, indicating that specific grading information is not provided.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 9.5 cm pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland, with negative surgical margins and no evidence of lymphatic invasion. The residual adrenal gland shows no diagnostic abnormalities, and there are no histological features indicating malignancy. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma, with positive results for chromogranin and synaptophysin in the tumor cells.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 4 fibrillary astrocytoma in the bifrontal region, with extensive infiltration into the leptomeninges and dura, forming a significant mass. Additional biopsies from the right frontal lobe and left frontal cyst wall also show involvement by fibrillary astrocytoma, while benign brain parenchyma with isolated tumor cells is noted in another left frontal lobe biopsy. The report confirms the presence of neoplastic cells through immunohistochemical staining, which highlights the tumor's characteristics and supports the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, papillary type (types 1 and 2), located in the left kidney. The tumor measures 3 cm and is classified as Fuhrman grade 3/4, with a pathological T stage of T1a, NX for lymph nodes, and M0 indicating no distant metastasis. The tumor was resected, and the report reflects a moderate to high grade of differentiation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade pleomorphic leiomyosarcoma in the right buttock mass, measuring 8.0 cm, with involvement of superficial soft tissue and focal extension to underlying skeletal muscle, as well as ulceration of the skin surface. Multiple satellite nodules were observed adjacent to the main mass, but the resection margins were uninvolved, with the closest deep margin showing a clearance of 0.1 cm. Additional specimens from the new inferior medial margin and superior margin were negative for malignancy, although microscopic nodules of leiomyosarcoma were noted at the superior margin extending to the cauterized and inked margin.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an endometrioid adenocarcinoma in the anterior wall of the uterus, measuring 6 x 4.5 cm with minimal invasion into the myometrium. The tumor is classified as pT1b, with no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion, and all examined lymph nodes from both the left and right pelvic regions are free of tumor. The ovaries and fallopian tubes are also reported as free of any pathological diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a left upper lobectomy specimen containing a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 45 mm, which primarily fills the bronchial lumens and shows perineural invasion but no vascular or lymphatic invasion. The tumor abuts the bronchial resection margins, with no evidence of metastasis in the sampled peribronchial or hilar lymph nodes. The overall pathological stage is classified as T2 N0.

The pathology report indicates that the histological and morphological findings are consistent with anaplastic astrocytoma, classified as WHO grade III. The diagnosis confirmed is anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade III. This suggests a malignant brain tumor with aggressive characteristics.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a cervical tumor classified as a non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma, with a histological grade of 3/3 and a size of 8.0 x 2.6 cm, exhibiting diffuse stromal invasion. Surgical margins are uninvolved, and the tumor is confined to the cervical region without extension into the lower uterine segment, endometrium, or myometrium; however, one of the lymph nodes excised from the right common iliac region tested positive for metastatic carcinoma. The overall staging is pT1b1(N1 M0 IIIB), indicating localized disease with lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma affecting multiple sites, including the omentum, right ovary, uterus, cervix, left ovary, rectosigmoid colon, transverse colon, small bowel mesentery, and bladder peritoneum. The tumor exhibits extensive serosal and lymphovascular invasion, with a FIGO stage of IIIC and a TNM stage of pT3cNXM0. The report highlights the presence of multiple large masses, with the largest measuring up to 11.0 cm, and confirms extensive metastatic involvement in the pelvic and abdominal regions.

The pathology report indicates that a left orchidectomy was performed, revealing a nonseminomatous tumor with 100% embryonal carcinoma, measuring 2.5 cm in diameter. The tumor is confined to the testis, with evidence of angioinvasion but no invasion of the rete testis. The findings suggest a localized malignancy requiring further management.

The pathology report indicates that the ST9 inferior pulmonary ligament lymph node is reactive and negative for malignancy, while the subcarinal ST7 lymph node is positive for metastatic carcinoma. The thoracic esophagus and proximal stomach specimen reveals poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with sarcomatoid and rhabdoid features, invading into the periesophageal fat, and 7 out of 33 examined lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma. The final esophageal margin is negative for malignancy, but the radial margin is positive for carcinoma, indicating a pT3N1c stage of the disease.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the left and right external, internal, hypogastric, and obturator lymph nodes, with some reactive changes noted in one lymph node. The symphysis pubic bone shows nonspecific reactive changes with no tumor present, while the prostate contains two foci of prostatic adenocarcinoma, with the dominant focus exhibiting a Gleason score of 9 and extending into extraprostatic tissue. The margins of resection are free of tumor, and the seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia show no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, measuring 1.7 cm, with involvement of perithyroidal adipose tissue and a negative margin status. Out of eleven lymph nodes examined, four were positive for metastatic carcinoma, leading to a pathologic stage of III. Additionally, multiple adenomatoid nodules consistent with multinodular goiter were noted, and there was no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or extranodal extension.

The pathology report indicates that two left and two right pelvic lymph nodes were examined, with no tumor detected in any of them. The prostate specimen shows adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3), predominantly located in the peripheral zone, and positive margins were noted at the left anterior and right posterior areas. There is no evidence of lymphatic invasion, but perineural invasion is present, and the tumor is staged at least pT2c with a dominant nodule measuring 1.0 cm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrioid adenocarcinoma, grade 2, with extensive involvement of the cervical stroma and a depth of invasion of 76% through the myometrial wall. Metastatic carcinoma was found in one of the four right periaortic lymph nodes and one of the four left periaortic lymph nodes, while the right and left pelvic lymph nodes showed no evidence of metastasis. Additionally, a mature cystic teratoma was identified in the left ovary, while the right ovary and fallopian tubes showed no malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, with multiple lymph nodes involved, including two at level two and four at level three, showing varying degrees of extranodal extension. The total thyroidectomy revealed multiple foci of well-differentiated papillary carcinoma, with the largest tumor focus measuring 1.1 cm, and significant multicentricity noted. The surgical margins are free of tumor, but the tumor is very close to the inked margin, and there is evidence of extrathyroid extension into fibroadipose tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe, measuring 5.0 cm, with one of fifteen N1 lymph nodes positive for metastases, while N2 lymph nodes show no evidence of metastases. The tumor is staged as T2N1MX, with no visceral pleural or angiolymphatic invasion and all surgical margins free of cancer. Additionally, multiple lymph node biopsies show reactive changes without evidence of malignancy, and there are findings of respiratory bronchiolitis and benign carcinoid tumorlets.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial cell carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 5.0 cm, with full thickness infiltration of the bladder wall, ulceration, and perforation leading to fistula formation, but no neural infiltration or sanguineous vascular invasion. Metastasis is noted in one of the left iliac obturator lymph nodes, while the right iliac obturator lymph nodes are free of neoplastic involvement. Additionally, the appendix shows chronic nonspecific periappendicitis with no evidence of neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), involving both lobes of the prostate. The tumor volume is estimated at 5%, with positive surgical margins near the right apex and evidence of perineural invasion, but no extracapsular extension or lymphovascular space invasion was identified. Seminal vesicles were negative for carcinoma, and the pathological stage is classified as T2CNXMX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.8 cm, with intermediate nuclear grade and lymphovascular invasion noted. One of twelve lymph nodes examined showed metastatic carcinoma, with the largest metastasis measuring 2.0 cm, while the remaining lymph nodes and superficial margins from the breast excision were free of tumor. The tumor is less than 1 mm from the anterior margin and 5 mm from the deep margin, but final margins after re-excision are clear of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme from a brain biopsy of the left frontal lobe. The microscopic examination reveals a high-grade glioma characterized by hypercellularity, mitotic figures, and necrotic tissue. The MIB-1 proliferation index is noted to be 25%, indicating a significant level of tumor cell proliferation.

The pathology report describes an epitheloid malignant tumor that constitutes approximately 95% of the examined tissue, characterized by round to oval nuclei and a high nucleo/cytoplasmic ratio. The tumor exhibits a sheet-like growth pattern with a mitotic count of 8 mitoses per square millimeter and includes lymphocytic infiltrates and melanophages. The diagnosis indicates that the findings are consistent with a metastasis of melanoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 1 (of 4) renal cell carcinoma, specifically of the papillary type, in a mass measuring 1.9 x 1.7 x 1.7 cm from the left kidney. The tumor is confined to the kidney with no evidence of coagulative necrosis or sarcomatoid differentiation, and the surgical margins are negative for tumor, indicating they are free by 0.2 cm. This revised report corrects the original diagnosis, which mistakenly identified the tumor as clear cell type instead of papillary type.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 and a tumor size of 3.7 cm, which is confined to the kidney. There is focal granulomatous inflammation at the interface between the tumor and the surrounding renal tissue, but no microorganisms were identified. The tumor does not involve the ureteral or renal vein margins, and the remaining renal parenchyma appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) based on the presence of atypical glial cells that infiltrate the brain's gray and white matter, with a notable MIB-1 labeling index ranging from <0.5% to 9.2%. Most neoplastic cells are reactive for GFAP, while some larger cells are GFAP negative, and the tumor cells are negative for Neu-N, suggesting astrocytic lineage. Despite the absence of significant mitotic activity, the degree of atypia and the high MIB-1 labeling index support the diagnosis of a grade III tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of medullary carcinoma in the left breast, characterized by a well-circumscribed mass measuring 4.5 x 2.0 x 2.0 cm, with widely negative surgical margins. Additionally, five left axillary sentinel lymph nodes were excised and found to be negative for tumor involvement, with no blue dye identified. Immunohistochemical staining confirmed the findings from the hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) examination.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes from both the left and right neck, with extranodal extension noted in the right neck dissection. Additionally, a moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the supraglottic region of the larynx, extending into surrounding tissues, but surgical margins were reported as free of tumor. Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis was found in the right thyroid excision, while margins from the tongue base excisions showed no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the right lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size measuring 2.6 cm. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic or venous invasion, and all sampled lymph nodes (0 out of 9) are negative for metastasis. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and no additional pathologic findings are noted.

The pathology report indicates that the excised tissue from the right temporal lobe contains a Grade 3 oligoastrocytoma, while another sample from the same area is negative for tumor. FISH studies suggest a deletion of the 19q chromosomal region, consistent with findings in other glioma specimens, although the 1p region appears to be intact. The report includes a preliminary frozen section consultation that also identified a diffuse glioma, pending final typing and grading.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the upper lobe of the left lung, measuring 4.5 cm, with the overlying pleural surface free of neoplasm. Two out of six hilar lymph nodes were positive for metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while other lymph nodes from various regions were negative. The pathological AJCC stage is classified as T2a, N1.

The pathology report indicates the presence of four foci of well-differentiated papillary carcinoma in the thyroid, including one classical type, one follicular variant, and two microcarcinomas, with the largest tumor measuring 1.8 cm in the right lobe. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and no evidence of blood vessel invasion or extrathyroid extension is noted. Additionally, a pretracheal lymph node biopsy revealed one benign lymph node, confirming no carcinoma in that tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with unilateral poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma, with a Gleason score of 4+5=9, involving both the right and left lobes of the prostate. The cancer is organ-confined, with no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes, and all surgical margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, perineural invasion is noted, and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is present, but there is no angiolymphatic invasion or seminal vesicle involvement.

The pathology report indicates a right pulmonary tumor thrombus due to metastatic renal cell carcinoma with extensive necrosis. A radical nephrectomy of the right kidney revealed conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 9.0 cm, with Fuhrman nuclear grade 3-4, angiolymphatic invasion, and involvement of the vascular resection margin, classified as TNM stage T3b; NX; M1. The non-neoplastic kidney and adrenal gland showed no significant pathological changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) with myelolipomatous metaplasia following a left adrenalectomy. The tumor measured 10.5 x 8.5 x 5.5 cm and exhibited a proliferation rate of KI67 at 20%, confirming its malignant nature. The Weiss score was 2, and the report notes that myelolipomatous metaplasia is very unusual in malignant tumors.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 3.3 cm, with focal extension to the cauterized posterior resection margin. The tumor is classified as pT2, with regional lymph nodes and distant metastasis not assessed (pNX, pMX). Additionally, vascular invasion is present, and the specimen was collected following a total thyroidectomy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 5.5 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion, renal vein invasion, or metastatic lymph nodes, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is classified as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney and measures less than or equal to 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma, a type of testicular cancer, measuring 9.5 cm, with lymphovascular invasion noted but no invasion of the epididymis or tunica albuginea. The tumor is confined to the testis, with free margins and no evidence of spermatogenesis in the surrounding testicular tissue. Clinical correlation is recommended due to the possibility of vascular invasion at the noted sites.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate, classified as Gleason 3+3=6, with perineural infiltration and no evidence of extraprostatic growth or vascular invasion. The tumor measures a maximum of 2.5 cm and is located in both lobes of the prostate, with focal infiltration into the surrounding fatty connective tissue, but the seminal vesicles and ducts are tumor-free. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes are free of malignancy, confirming a diagnosis of pT3a, pN0 (0/4), with a Gleason score of 3+4=7.

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy of the right upper lobe revealed a 2.2 cm acinar predominant adenocarcinoma with visceral pleural invasion, but the bronchial and vascular margins were free of tumor. All examined lymph nodes (8 total) were negative for carcinoma, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. Molecular studies showed a positive KRAS mutation (p.G12C), which is associated with poor prognosis, while no EGFR mutations were detected.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen from the cardia region, revealing a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 7 x 8 cm. The report does not specify the extent of invasion, lymph node involvement, or margins. Additional pathologic findings and comments are also not provided.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the skin of an extremity, measuring 2 x 1.1 x 1.1 cm, characterized as an ulcerated, raised, and pigmented nodular melanoma. The tumor exhibits a 5th level of invasion according to Clark's classification, with a depth of 11 mm. There are no specified details regarding satellite nodules, lymphatic or venous invasion, margins, or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a total thyroidectomy specimen with a unifocal papillary carcinoma located in the right lobe, measuring 5.0 cm. The tumor is classified as pT3, indicating it is greater than 4 cm and limited to the thyroid, with evidence of venous and lymphatic invasion, but the margins are uninvolved with a distance of 1 mm from the nearest margin. There are no submitted lymph nodes for assessment, and distant metastasis cannot be evaluated.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with WHO grade IV glioblastoma multiforme in multiple brain biopsy samples, including the left occipital region and a deep tumor site. The tumor exhibits high cellularity, significant nuclear pleomorphism, abundant mitoses, and areas of necrosis, along with extensive leptomeningeal involvement at the tumor margin. Immunohistochemical staining shows strong positivity for glial fibrillary acidic protein in many neoplastic astrocytes, confirming the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from various levels were excised and all were negative for malignancy, with one lymph node showing sclerosing granuloma consistent with histoplasmosis. A lobectomy of the right upper lobe revealed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 3.8 cm, with all surgical margins negative for invasive carcinoma. Additionally, lymph-vascular invasion was noted, but no regional lymph nodes were involved, and there were no distant metastases identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the esophagus, with a tumor size of 3.7 cm and evidence of invasion into the adventitia. Three out of seventeen examined lymph nodes were positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the resection margins were narrowly free of cancer. The report notes that there was no preoperative treatment with chemotherapy or radiation therapy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and umbilicus, with evidence of metastasis. The tumors are characterized by infiltration into surrounding tissues, with specific findings of tumor clusters in the fallopian tube lumen and involvement of the uterine serosa. Additionally, there are benign findings such as inactive endometrium, adenomyosis, and nabothian cysts noted in the cervix.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Type A Thymoma with focal Type A/B characteristics, measuring 8.0 x 8.0 x 3.0 cm, and showing focal invasion through the capsule. The tumor is classified as pT2, pNO (0/7), and is staged as Masaoka II.1. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals positive staining for CK5/6 and strong membrane staining for EGFR, while the epithelial cells are negative for c-kit and CD5, with immature T-lymphocytes partially positive for CD5 and CD99, and sparse CD20-positive lymphocytes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right kidney renal cell carcinoma, measuring 9.7 cm, of the conventional (clear cell) type with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 out of 4. The tumor is confined within Gerota's fascia, with all surgical resection margins free of tumor and no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. Additionally, there is focal interstitial chronic inflammation in the non-neoplastic kidney, and the TNM pathologic stage is classified as p T2 NX MX with a histologic grade of G3.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically the chromophobe type, with a tumor size of 14 cm and local invasion into the renal pelvis, but no renal vein invasion was identified. The para-aortic and supra-hilar lymph nodes examined showed no involvement of cancer, and the left adrenal gland was found to be benign. Surgical margins were free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney exhibited mild chronic interstitial inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of exophytic invasive moderate to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lung, with a tumor size of 3.7 x 2.8 x 2.8 cm and metastasis to one out of ten peribronchial lymph nodes. All other examined lymph nodes and margins, including additional bronchial margins and pleural nodules, were negative for tumor involvement. The pathological staging is pT2, N1, Mx, with no visceral pleural involvement or satellite tumors identified.

The cervical biopsy reveals invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the large cell nonkeratinizing type, which is poorly differentiated. The specimen consisted of multiple fragments of pale tan tissue mixed with clotted blood, measuring a total of 0.7 x 0.5 x 0.2 cm. The report has been reviewed and approved by the pathologist.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the prostate, classified as pT4 pN1 L1 V1, G4, corresponding to stage IV. There is evidence of perineural growth, invasion of lymph and blood vessels, and bilateral infiltration of the seminal vesicles and bladder wall, along with lymph node metastasis. Additionally, tumor-free lymph nodes and fatty tissue were identified, but the preparation margins are noted to be extensively infiltrated with tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma in an ablated left breast sample, with a tumor diameter of 5.0 cm. The tumor classification is noted as NOS, grade II, and is staged as pT2N1aLOVORO. The presence of an intraductal component is also identified within the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary serous adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, ovaries, rectosigmoid colon, and pelvic lymph nodes. The right ovary shows poorly differentiated carcinoma with surface involvement, while the left ovary also has metastatic disease. The report confirms extensive lymphatic and vascular invasion, with a pathological stage of pT3C pN1 pMX, indicating advanced disease.

The pathology report describes a left temporal lobe tumor characterized as an astrocytic neoplasm with anaplastic features, exhibiting a pleomorphic glial structure and areas of low to high histological grade. The tumor shows a significant proliferation index and is in close contact with the leptomeninges, with evidence of chronic hemorrhage and hemosiderosis. Genetic testing indicates no methylation of the MGMT promoter and no allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, suggesting a complex diagnosis that may include features of a pleomorphic xanthoastrocytoma and superficial glioblastoma.

The pathology report describes a left kidney specimen with a unifocal clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 9.0 cm, which is confined to the kidney and does not invade surrounding structures or lymphatic vessels. The tumor is classified as pT2, indicating it is larger than 7 cm but limited to the kidney, with margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. The adrenal gland is present and uninvolved, and there are no additional pathologic findings noted.

The pathology report indicates that the rib marrow specimen shows maturing trilineage hematopoiesis with no tumor present. The right kidney specimen reveals a 7.5 cm clear cell renal cell carcinoma, nuclear grade IV, with extensive necrosis, perinephric fat involvement, renal vein invasion, and lymphovascular invasion, classified as T3b NX M1. Cytogenetic analysis shows a deletion on chromosome 3p, which is characteristic of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with glioblastoma multiforme, classified as an astrocytoma of WHO grade IV, based on the excised tissue from the right parietal region of the brain. The intraoperative diagnosis suggested a consistent finding of grade IV glioblastoma multiforme, with a possibility of an oligodendroglial component, but it remains a grade IV neoplasm regardless. The specimens were received in two parts, both showing soft tissue characteristics consistent with the diagnosis, and the final diagnosis was confirmed by the attending pathologist after reviewing all pathology slides.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 3, located primarily in the posterior corpus of the uterus, with a tumor size of 4.5 x 3.3 x 0 cm and no myometrial invasion. The examination revealed no lymphatic or vascular invasion, and the specimen margins, as well as the ovaries and fallopian tubes, showed no pathological diagnosis. The report concludes that the adjacent non-neoplastic endometrium exhibited polyps and atrophy, while the remaining myometrium and cervix were unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with evidence of lymphovascular space invasion. The diagnosis is supported by microscopic examination of the biopsy specimen, which consisted of multiple fragments of soft tissue. The patient is a 70-year-old woman who presented with postmenopausal bleeding and a cervical lesion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma involving multiple sites, including the ovaries, omentum, posterior cul-de-sac, and liver, with evidence of metastasis. The ovaries show small foci of tumor involvement, while the uterus and cervix exhibit no significant abnormalities. The report highlights extensive tumor infiltration in the omentum and surrounding soft tissues, confirming a widespread malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that a pancreaticoduodenectomy was performed, revealing a diagnosis of ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas measuring 3.0 cm, with tumor involvement at the ampulla of Vater and negative margins. All examined lymph nodes (14 in total) were negative for malignancy, and additional findings included chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN 3). The pathologic staging is classified as pT3NO, indicating the tumor extends beyond the pancreas without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe, with a subpleural mass measuring 3.8 x 3.0 x 1.8 cm that involves the visceral pleura, but the resection margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, the right middle lobe biopsy shows subpleural fibrosis and focal osseous metaplasia. No tumor is identified in multiple examined lymph nodes from the mediastinal and hilar/intrapulmonary regions.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with a prominent cribriform pattern and a maximum tumor size of 7 cm. The tumor is multifocal, located in the upper outer quadrant, and there is no evidence of in-situ carcinoma or lymphatic/vascular invasion, with negative surgical margins and no carcinoma identified in the sampled lymph nodes. Estrogen receptor activity is positive, while progesterone receptor activity is borderline, with further analysis pending.

The pathology report indicates the presence of squamous cell carcinoma in lung tissue. The report does not provide specific details regarding the grade or TNM staging, as this information is pending. Additionally, there is no treatment data available at this time, and a blood draw was performed as part of the evaluation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the intra-abdominal specimen, measuring 27 x 25 x 18 cm, with focal necrosis affecting approximately 25% of the mass and extension to the inked margin. Additionally, a mesenteric mass was identified as a liposarcoma, measuring 3.2 x 2.2 x 0.5 cm, which also extends to the inked surface. Both tumors were surgically resected, and the findings were confirmed through personal examination of the slides.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma following a subtotal distal gastrectomy, with the tumor invading subserosal connective tissue (pT3) and metastasis identified in 2 of 19 regional lymph nodes (pN1). The resection margins are negative for tumor, and there is a background of moderate acute and chronic gastritis with intestinal metaplasia, with no Helicobacter pylori detected. Additional biopsies from hepatic artery, portal vein, and splenic artery lymph nodes show no evidence of metastatic tumor, confirming benign adipose tissue in those samples.

The pathology report describes a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma located in the left lobe of the liver, measuring 8x9x6 cm, with ill-defined margins and areas of necrosis. Microscopic examination reveals trabecular patterns of tumor cells with irregularly large, hyperchromatic nuclei and prominent nucleoli, along with moderate basophilic cytoplasm. The tumor exhibits vascular invasion, but the surgical margins are uninvolved, and additional details regarding lymph nodes and venous invasion are not specified.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes from both the left and right pelvic regions. However, a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate was identified, with a Gleason score of 4 + 4 = 8, showing established extracapsular extension and perineural invasion, but no involvement of the seminal vesicles or surgical margins. The tumor is classified as pT3a, with approximately 10% of the prostate volume affected, and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is also noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the omentum, uterus, and both ovaries, with a diagnosis of mixed papillary serous and endometrioid adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade III. The report confirms extensive tumor involvement in the omentum and peritoneum, with additional findings of endometrial polyp and serosal endometriosis. The final staging is classified as T3c/N0/M0 (Stage IIIC), indicating significant peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis, while a biopsy of a lymph node reveals metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma. The Whipple's specimen demonstrates moderately differentiated infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma, measuring 3.5 cm, with focal extrapancreatic cancer adjacent to pyloric lymph nodes and involvement of 2 out of 17 lymph nodes. Additionally, pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PANIN 1B/2) is noted at the neck of the pancreas, and an incidental pancreatic hamartoma/heterotopia is found in the duodenal wall.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the intrahepatic bile ducts, diagnosed as primary hepatic cholangiocarcinoma, with multiple lesions identified in different liver segments, including one measuring 11.2 cm and showing extensive invasion into perihepatic fibroadipose tissue. The report notes that the carcinoma is less than 1 mm from the inked parenchymal margin in one lesion and that lymphovascular invasion is present, with one of eleven examined lymph nodes showing metastatic adenocarcinoma. Additionally, dysplasia of the intraductal biliary epithelium and multifocal intraductal biliary papillary carcinoma in situ are observed, suggesting a spectrum of intraductal biliary neoplasia associated with the invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a hemicolectomy specimen from the hepatic flexure, revealing a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 7 x 8 x 2 cm. The tumor has invaded the liver and all four examined intraabdominal lymph nodes show evidence of metastasis. Specific details regarding tumor margins and any neo-adjuvant treatment are not provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the lung with acinar, papillary, and bronchioloalveolar patterns, invasive into the visceral pleura, classified as pathologic stage IB (PT2 N0 Mx). The tumor measures 4.5 cm and is well to moderately differentiated, with the bronchial margin free of tumor and no observed vascular or lymphatic invasion. All examined lymph nodes from various stations are negative for carcinoma, and an additional finding of obstructive bronchitis is noted.

The pathology report indicates that the distal right and left ureters are benign and negative for dysplasia and malignancy. A radical cystoprostatectomy specimen reveals an invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, which invades the detrusor muscle and perivesical adipose tissue, but with negative margins and no lymphovascular or perineural invasion. All examined pelvic lymph nodes are negative for tumor presence, and there are scattered foci of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia in the prostate.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade urothelial carcinoma with extensive squamous differentiation, invading the muscularis propria of the bladder, but no tumor was found in the examined lymph nodes or margins. The tumor measures 7.0 x 3.5 x 3.0 cm and shows no lymphovascular invasion, with a significant inflammatory response noted in the surrounding adipose tissue. Additionally, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) was identified in the prostate, but no tumors were present in the seminal vesicles or vas deferens.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma infiltrating all layers of the bladder and extending to surrounding tissues, with carcinoma found in four out of seven right lymph nodes. Additionally, there is evidence of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate, confined to the organ, with a Gleason score of 9. The report notes that while the follow-up resection material was free of tumor and dysplasia, there was infiltration of the pelvic wall, resulting in an R1 status.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade serous carcinoma affecting both the right and left ovaries, with tumor extension to the ovarian surfaces and significant involvement of the omentum. Additionally, the right and left fallopian tubes show no histopathologic abnormalities, while the uterus exhibits mild chronic inflammation and a leiomyoma. The final staging of the cancer is classified as T3c/NX/MX, indicating advanced disease with peritoneal metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in a celiac lymph node, which measures 2.5 cm and extends beyond the lymph node capsule. Additionally, a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma was identified in the head of the pancreas, measuring 4.7 x 4.5 x 4.2 cm, with evidence of lymphovascular and perineural invasion, and involvement of the portal vein and common bile duct. Other findings include chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder and chronic pancreatitis in the pancreatic duct margin, with two out of four lymph nodes showing metastatic adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of ciliochoroidal melanoma of mixed cell type following a left globe enucleation, with the tumor measuring 13 mm in diameter and 9 mm in height. Histological examination reveals a predominantly amelanotic melanoma with spindle cells and minimal lymphocytic infiltrate, and no evidence of necrosis or extension beyond the choroid. Molecular genetic analysis shows normal chromosome 1p, disomy 3, and borderline gains in chromosome 6, suggesting a low risk for metastatic melanoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 3 cm, with a modified Scarff Bloom Richardson grade of 2 and negative surgical margins. The HER2 status was initially equivocal but later determined to be not amplified, with a HER2/CEP 17 ratio of 1.5, while estrogen and progesterone receptors were found to be positive. Additionally, one sentinel lymph node was positive for metastatic carcinoma, and the Oncotype DX assay indicated a recurrence score of 27, suggesting an 18% risk of distant recurrence at 10 years.

The pathology report indicates a 9 cm right renal mass diagnosed as unclassified renal cell carcinoma with clear cell and papillary features, exhibiting local invasion into the renal pelvis and renal vein, with tumor thrombus identified in the inferior vena cava. Surgical margins were clear of tumor cells, and the right adrenal gland and lymph nodes examined were free of malignancy. The tumor is staged as pT3b due to its extension into the renal vein, and no metastatic lymph nodes were found in the resected specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated serous papillary adenocarcinoma of the left ovary. The tumor has extended into the left paratubal tissue and involves the ovarian surface. This suggests an aggressive nature of the cancer with local invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, in the right kidney, with the tumor measuring 18 cm and confined within the renal capsule, showing no invasion of the renal vein and clear surgical margins. The adrenal gland appears unremarkable and uninvolved by the tumor, while the excised right paracaval lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy, with all eight nodes being benign. The overall findings suggest a localized tumor without metastatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma with basaloid features at the base of the tongue, measuring 1.7 cm, with complete excision and negative margins. Angiolymphatic invasion is present, and one of twenty lymph nodes from the left level 3 is involved with the carcinoma, while other lymph nodes from levels 2B, 4, and 5 are negative for neoplasm. The overall staging is AJCC stage T1, N1, reflecting the involvement of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left neck soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates a radical mastectomy specimen with a tumor measuring 1.8 x 1 x 1 cm, identified as infiltrating ductal and lobular carcinoma. All 7 examined lymph nodes show evidence of metastasis, indicating regional spread of the disease. The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tumor grading and characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, classified as FIGO grade 2, with a tumor size of 5.2 cm and no myometrial or cervical invasion. All examined lymph nodes from the left and right paraaortic and pelvic regions were benign, with no evidence of lymphovascular space invasion. Immunohistochemical staining for DNA mismatch repair proteins showed intact expression of MLH1, PMS2, MSH2, and MSH6, but the findings do not completely exclude the possibility of Lynch Syndrome.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, measuring 5.0 cm, with Fuhrman grade 2, confined to the right kidney and with negative margins. The non-neoplastic renal parenchyma shows minimal chronic changes consistent with age-related alterations, including minimal glomerulosclerosis and tubular atrophy. Cytogenetic analysis could not be performed due to the absence of metaphases from the specimen.

The pathology report indicates that three excised lymph nodes (Station 5, R11, and L8) and their associated fibroadipose tissues are all negative for tumor. Additionally, a lobectomy of the left upper lobe lung was performed, but no further details about the lung specimen are provided in the report. Overall, there is no evidence of tumor in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located at the gastroesophageal junction, measuring 8 x 6 cm, with ulceration and invasion into the subserosa and adjacent fatty tissue. Out of 15 examined lymph nodes, 2 show metastasis, while the omentum and surgical margins are free of tumor. There is no evidence of venous invasion, and the tumor has spread to the esophagus, but no additional treatment details are provided.

The pathology report indicates a left pneumonectomy specimen revealing a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 42 mm, with invasion of hilar fat and metastasis identified in a peribronchial lymph node. No vascular, lymphatic, pleural, or perineural invasion was observed. The pathological stage is classified as T3 N1, indicating significant local tumor advancement and regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligoastrocytoma (WHO Grade II) based on the microscopic examination of a brain tumor biopsy and resection. The MIB-1 labeling index is calculated at 2.3%, suggesting a low-grade tumor, characterized by infiltrative growth and a predominance of oligodendroglial features with some astrocytic components. There is no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis, and the tumor shows moderate hypercellularity with rare mitotic figures.

The pathology report describes a mildly hypercellular glial neoplasm that infiltrates both gray and white matter, characterized by tumor cells with mild atypia and rare perinuclear halos. There is evidence of focally prominent perineuronal satellitosis, but no mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis are observed. The final diagnosis is a well-differentiated astrocytoma (WHO grade II), supported by the presence of numerous P53 immunoreactive cells and a very low MIB-1 labeling index.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size greater than 3 cm and no evidence of vascular or perineural invasion. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, all of which were found to be benign, indicating no metastatic spread. The bronchial and pleural margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic lung shows emphysematous changes and fibrosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of melanoma in a Caucasian male, with the primary tumor located in the skin. The tumor has a TNM staging of T2 N0 M1, suggesting localized disease with no regional lymph node involvement but distant metastasis. A blood specimen was also collected, but no additional findings or treatments are specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive lobular breast carcinoma with a maximum tumor diameter of 2.7 cm and a malignancy grade of 2, along with an invasive satellite node and multicentric formations. There are small foci of resorptive inflammatory reactions in the skin and fatty tissue, but no evidence of carcinoma in the submitted cutaneous/subcutaneous tissue samples, and tumor-free resection margins were achieved. The overall classification suggests a regional R0 status, indicating no residual tumor at the margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade I endometrioid adenocarcinoma with extensive squamous differentiation, located in the lower anterior wall of the uterus, measuring 3.5 x 2.2 cm, with no evidence of myometrial invasion. The lymphatic and vascular invasion is absent, and all examined pelvic lymph nodes (15 total) are negative for carcinoma. The remaining structures, including the cervix, fallopian tubes, and ovaries, show no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic poorly differentiated carcinoma in the liver mass and liver metastases, while the left adrenal tumor is identified as poorly differentiated carcinoma consistent with adrenal cortical carcinoma, which has invaded the adrenal gland and extended along the renal cortex. The periaortic lymph nodes are benign, and poorly differentiated carcinoma is also noted in the tumor capsule attached to the diaphragm and in tissue along the aorta. Overall, the findings suggest advanced disease with multiple sites of metastasis and significant tumor involvement in the adrenal gland.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, with involvement in multiple lymph nodes, including complete effacement of lymph node architecture in one and focal extracapsular extension in another. The total thyroidectomy revealed a unifocal tumor in the left lobe measuring 4.5 cm, with focal extrathyroidal extension and carcinoma abutting the surgical margins. Overall, 5 out of 9 lymph nodes were involved by metastatic disease, and the AJCC pathologic stage is classified as pT3 pN1b.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma located in the right lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 3.5 x 3.0 x 2.1 cm and well-differentiated histologic features. Surgical margins are not involved, with the tumor being less than 1 mm from the inked margin, and there is minimal extension into perithyroid soft tissue. Additional findings include lymphocytic thyroiditis and nodular hyperplasia of the left lobe, with no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the left simple mastectomy revealed benign breast tissue with areas of stromal fibrosis and no evidence of malignancy. In contrast, the right simple mastectomy showed infiltrating lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, with a tumor size of 7.8 cm and negative sentinel lymph node for metastasis. The tumor was estrogen receptor positive (95%) and progesterone receptor positive (50%), with no lymphovascular invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in the right colon, cecum, and appendix, following a radical resection of a large retroperitoneal mass measuring 17 x 12 x 7 cm. The tumor is characterized by focal areas of necrosis and is covered by an intact thin membrane, with the surgical margins appearing free of tumor.
