Immunohistochemical analysis shows tumor cells positive for desmin and smooth muscle actin (SMA), supporting the diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of mixed papillary serous and endometrioid types in both ovaries, with evidence of metastatic disease in the fallopian tubes and omentum. The uterus shows no metastatic adenocarcinoma, containing only an endocervical polyp and proliferative endometrium, while lymph nodes examined show no evidence of malignancy. The final staging is classified as FIGO stage IIIB, indicating macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies from various margins and lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor, while the radical prostatectomy specimen reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4, indicating moderate differentiation and extraprostatic extension. The tumor is located in multiple areas of the prostate, with an estimated volume of 7 cc, and there is perineural infiltration present. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and all examined lymph nodes are also negative for metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the excised lymph nodes from both the right (0/5) and left (0/12) pelvic regions. A radical prostatectomy revealed prostatic adenocarcinoma, acinar type, with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, involving both sides of the prostate and showing extra-prostatic extension and bilateral seminal vesicle involvement, but all surgical margins are free of carcinoma. The tumor is classified as pT3b, with multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and extensive perineural invasion noted, while no angiolymphatic invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (5.6 cm) in the left kidney, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 2, with tumor extension into the renal vein but no invasion of the renal capsule or lymphovascular invasion. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, and the adrenal gland is also free of malignancy. Cytogenetic analysis reveals clonal aberrations, including loss of the short arm of chromosome 3, which is characteristic of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland, with the tumor measuring 4 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm and weighing 21 grams. The tumor is confined to the adrenal gland with minimal capsular invasion, and the margins of resection are free of tumor, with no evidence of blood or lymph vessel invasion. Immunohistochemical studies show strong positivity for chromogranin and moderate positivity for synaptophysin, while the tumor exhibits moderate nuclear atypia and a high mitotic activity score.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, characterized by a 3.4 x 2.7 x 1.6 cm polypoid mass in the posterior and right lateral wall of the endometrial cavity, with invasion into the myometrium. The cervix, ovaries, and fallopian tubes show no abnormalities, and all examined pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement. The report is based on both gross examination and frozen section histologic evaluation of the specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma of the stomach, specifically located in the distal third (antrum) with a tumor size of 4.8 x 3.3 x 1.2 cm and evidence of serosal invasion. The proximal and distal resection margins are uninvolved, while lymph node metastasis is present in the inferior gastric lymph nodes, with no tumor found in the superior gastric lymph nodes. The pathologic stage is classified as pT1bN1MX, indicating early-stage cancer with lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis assessed.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic moderately-differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma in the liver, measuring 3.4 cm with 20% necrosis, and located 0.5 cm from the resection margin. The large bowel specimen shows a 5.8 cm adenocarcinoma in the rectosigmoid region with significant lymphovascular and perineural invasion, and metastasis identified in 8 out of 39 examined lymph nodes, classified as pT4a and N2b. Additional specimens from the proximal and distal rings of the colon, as well as the ovaries and fallopian tubes, show no pathological findings.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma in the right ovary, which also involves the fallopian tube, and shows metastatic disease in the omentum and anterior abdominal wall. Additionally, minute foci of papillary serous carcinoma are noted in the left ovary, fallopian tube, and peri-adnexal soft tissue, alongside findings of hyperplastic endometrial polyp, simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, and adenomyosis in the uterus. The report highlights a history of ovarian carcinoma, suggesting a progression of the disease.

The pathology report indicates that the right upper lobectomy specimen contains an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.6 cm, which extends into the visceral pleural surface, but the bronchial and vascular margins are free of tumor. All sampled lymph nodes from levels XI, X, R II, R IV, and VII are negative for malignancy, indicating no regional metastasis. The report concludes with no evidence of distant metastasis, confirming the primary tumor's characteristics and the absence of invasion into large vessels or lymphatics.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of poorly differentiated endometrioid carcinoma of the endometrium, measuring 3.0 x 2.3 x 1.5 cm, with myometrial invasion of 0.3 cm and no cervical involvement or lymphovascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes (28 total) were benign, showing no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings include adenomyosis and endometriosis involving the serosa and right ovary, with the overall stage classified as pT1a, N0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 5 cm and no evidence of invasion into venous, arterial, lymphatic, or perineural structures. Surgical margins are clear of tumor involvement, and no metastatic carcinoma was identified in the examined lymph nodes. The AJCC staging is reported as pT2 pNO pMx, and further comprehensive review is recommended for final staging.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in a colonic resection specimen from the sigmoid colon, measuring 3 cm and extending 11 cm from the resection margin, with invasive tumor spread to the muscularis propria. Both oral and aboral margins are tumor-free, and all examined mesocolic lymph nodes (10 initially and 7 additional) are also tumor-free, resulting in a final lymph node status of pNO (0/17). The tumor is staged as pT2 pn0 (0/10) LO V0; G2.

The pathology report indicates the presence of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4, primarily located in the left lateral zone and infiltrating the organ capsule, while also showing small tumor foci in the right lobe. There is no evidence of tumor in the fatty tissue, pelvic lymph nodes, or seminal vesicles, and the tumor is confined to the prostate without infiltration into surrounding tissues. The overall staging is pT2c G2 NO R0, indicating localized disease.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an oligodendroglioma, WHO Grade II, confirmed through biopsy and resection of the right frontal lobe. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive IDH-1 staining and a low MIB-1 labeling index of approximately 3-4%. Additional testing for 1p19q chromosomal alterations is pending and will be reported separately.

The cervical biopsy reveals invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, consistent with the patient's history of cervical cancer. Additionally, consult slides show both invasive and in situ endocervical adenocarcinoma with mucinous features, characterized by specific histological patterns and immunohistochemical markers. The endometrial curettings are negative for malignancy, indicating no evidence of cancer in that tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a high-grade infiltrating urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 1x1x0.5 cm, with ill-defined margins and a soft, gray surface. Microscopic examination reveals hyperplastic transitional cells arranged in various patterns, with notable nuclear irregularities and common mitoses, indicating aggressive behavior. The tumor invades the superficial muscularis propria, but lymphatic invasion is absent and surgical margins are uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates that a left knee mass was resected from a female patient with a history of biopsy-proven leiomyosarcoma, revealing a moderate to high-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 8.0 x 6.5 x 4.0 cm. The tumor is partially encapsulated with 15% necrosis and exhibits spindle and pleomorphic cellular morphology, with a mitotic rate of 5-6 mitoses per 10 high-power fields. The surgical margins are reported as free of tumor, with the closest margins defined by a fibrous pseudocapsule.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a liver specimen obtained from a partial hepatectomy. The tumor is characterized as a well-defined multinodular mass with a safety margin of 1.3 cm, and there is no evidence of invasion into surrounding structures or intrahepatic metastasis. Additionally, the liver parenchyma shows signs of cirrhosis and mild steatosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, with a significant mass measuring 5.2 x 3.0 x 2.6 cm, and the presence of lobular carcinoma in situ comprising less than 5% of the tumor volume. Angiolymphatic invasion is noted, and while the final surgical margins from the mastectomy are negative for tumor, multiple right axillary lymph nodes (5 of 18) are positive for metastatic carcinoma, indicating a pN2 classification. Overall, the tumor does not involve the nipple, overlying skin, or underlying chest wall, but there is evidence of extranodal extension in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of adenocarcinoma in the resected right lower lobe (RLL) sample. The tumor is classified as T2, with no regional lymph node involvement (N) and no distant metastasis (M), suggesting an early stage of cancer. The histological examination confirms the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma with a size of 6.00 cm.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left para-aortic lymph nodes, as well as the right and left pelvic lymph nodes, were negative for carcinoma, with a total of 24 lymph nodes examined showing no malignancy. The hysterectomy specimen revealed a mixed serous and endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, classified as FIGO grade 3, with superficial invasion into the myometrium and no cervical or serosal involvement. Additionally, the right fallopian tube showed involvement by adenocarcinoma, while both ovaries were atrophic and free of carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with squamous metaplasia, measuring 5 cm and invading approximately 53% of the myometrial thickness. All examined lymph nodes (17 total) from the right pelvic, left pelvic, and left periaortic regions were negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, the omentum biopsy showed fibroadipose tissue negative for tumor, and the cervix, ovaries, and fallopian tubes were also negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus, measuring 3.2 cm, with invasion into the adventitia and involvement of the deep resection margin. Out of 23 examined lymph nodes, 2 were positive for metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while the cervical resection margin was negative for carcinoma. The report highlights the presence of a significant tumor burden and the need for further evaluation of distant metastasis, which remains unknown.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal and multicentric infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with the largest tumor measuring 2.5 cm and a Nottingham score of 6/9, suggesting a moderate grade of malignancy. One sentinel lymph node shows metastatic adenocarcinoma with extracapsular extension, while three other examined lymph nodes are free of tumor. Additional findings include ductal carcinoma in situ (cribriform type) comprising less than 1% of the tumor volume, and the surgical margins, nipple, and skin are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a malignant thymoma in the thymus gland, characterized by focal microscopic extension beyond the capsule into adjacent mediastinal connective tissue, measuring 5.5 cm in maximum dimension. The tumor is classified as a predominantly mixed cortical type (Type B2 according to the 1999 WHO classification), and there are involutional changes in the native thymus consistent with the patient's age. Additionally, the report notes that complete resection cannot be confirmed due to the tumor's proximity to the external margin of the specimen.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right limited neck dissection, right paratracheal lymph node dissection, and completion of thyroidectomy, revealing metastatic papillary carcinoma of the thyroid in twelve lymph nodes. The thyroid tissue was entirely involved by a papillary tumor, while no thyroid tissue was identified in the remaining specimens, which included parathyroid tissue, thymus, and skeletal muscle with suture granulomas. The entire specimen measured 7.0 x 3.8 x 1.4 cm, with the thyroid lobe measuring 5.0 x 3.3 x 1.9 cm, and representative sections have been submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endocervical adenocarcinoma arising near the cervical junction, with a tumor size of 2.5 cm and invasion depth of approximately 4 mm, while the vaginal cuff margins are free of tumor. Out of 33 examined lymph nodes, 1 right pelvic lymph node is positive for metastatic carcinoma, while other regional lymph nodes are negative for metastasis. The report also notes the presence of superficial adenomyosis and cystic changes in the ovaries, with no evidence of atypia or carcinoma in the endometrium.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma with metastatic spread to the left and right ovaries, fallopian tubes, appendix, omentum, and vaginal tissue, while the fallopian tube on the left side is negative for malignancy. The uterus shows a tumor measuring 5.5 by 3.5 cm with myometrial invasion and involvement of cervical stromal tissue, classified as pT3b, NX, M1 (FIGO IVB). Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of primary endometrial serous carcinoma with metastasis to the adnexa and other sites.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 1.7 cm, with no invasion of the pleura and negative margins for tumor in bronchial and vascular areas. Additionally, two hilar lymph nodes and two excised lymph nodes (R4 and R7) were found to be negative for tumor, confirming no metastatic spread. The overall pathologic stage is classified as T1NoMx, indicating an early stage of lung cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade myxofibrosarcoma from a right paraspinal mass, measuring 6.3 cm in greatest dimension. The tumor involves subcutaneous fibroadipose tissue and is located 0.07 cm from the deep margin, with other margins being free of tumor and no necrosis observed. The deep fascia is not involved by the sarcoma, and the specimen was received fresh with a well-circumscribed lobulated mass identified upon examination.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 3x4 cm ulcerated moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the thoracic esophagus, extending into the muscularis propria. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined paraesophageal lymph nodes, which show only follicular hyperplasia. The tumor margins are uninvolved, and there is no venous invasion or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant biphasic mesothelioma in the right pleura, with evidence of metastatic disease in several lymph nodes, including four out of twelve in level seven and one out of one in the right internal mammary lymph node. The report also notes that the right sixth rib and level four lymph nodes were benign, with some lymph nodes showing necrosis. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of mesothelioma, with no asbestos bodies detected in the lung parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma in the left breast, measuring up to 1.8 cm, with a Nottingham score of 6/9 and grade 2, along with extensive atypical lobular hyperplasia and lobular carcinoma in situ. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and lymphovascular space involvement is not observed, while one sentinel lymph node is negative for tumor and the other shows rare keratin-positive cells. Hormonal receptor analysis reveals estrogen and progesterone positivity, with HER-2/neu being negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm involving the right lobe, isthmus, and left lobe of the thyroid. The tumor exhibits angioinvasion, but all examined lymph nodes are negative for metastasis, and the surgical margins are uninvolved, although the invasive carcinoma is less than 1 mm from the nearest margin. Additional findings include nodular hyperplasia with cystic degeneration.

The pathology report indicates a bladder tumor diagnosed as transitional cell carcinoma, classified as grade 3 with a mixed growth pattern of solid and papillary components. The tumor shows invasion into the muscularis propria, categorized as pT2, and there is also evidence of carcinoma in situ in the surrounding urothelium. No vascular channel invasion was identified in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with the tumor measuring 8.5 cm and exhibiting extensive local invasion into surrounding structures, including perinephric fat and major blood vessels. Additionally, two pericaval lymph nodes were found to be positive for metastatic disease, with the largest metastatic deposit measuring 2.2 cm and showing extracapsular extension. The gallbladder was diagnosed with chronic calculous cholecystitis, but was negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma of the pancreas with a focal micropapillary component, measuring 2.3 x 2.2 x 2.0 cm, which extends into the peripancreatic soft tissue and shows perineural invasion. The margins from the bile duct, pancreatic neck, and retroperitoneal areas are negative for carcinoma, while eight out of twenty-three examined lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, there is a cystic component to the tumor, and the differential diagnosis includes possible colonization of a retention cyst or large duct by carcinoma versus intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN).

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly-differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9, involving both the right and left sides of the prostate, and showing focal extraprosthetic extension. A radical prostatectomy was performed, and all examined surgical margins and lymph nodes (21 total) were free of malignancy. The final diagnosis includes multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and perineural invasion, with a pathologic TNM stage of pT3a NO MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately-differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma of the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.5 cm, with necrosis and extension to the pleura, while bronchial and vascular margins are negative for tumor. Two out of four regional lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, and one lymph node from the apical window is also positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma. Additionally, the uninvolved lung shows signs of hemorrhage, extensive remodeling, subpleural scarring, and both acute and chronic inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligoastrocytoma, classified as grade 2 according to the World Health Organization (WHO) grading system. The tumor is located in the temporal lobe. The patient is female.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in a liver specimen obtained from a central hepatectomy, with the tumor being moderately to poorly differentiated (G2 to G3) and measuring 2.8 cm in greatest dimension, confined to the liver with no macroscopic venous invasion. Additionally, the gallbladder specimen shows chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis and cholesterolosis, with two lymph nodes examined being negative for carcinoma. The liver parenchyma also exhibits signs of chronic hepatitis consistent with a history of hepatitis C virus infection, along with mild fibrosis and no significant hemosiderosis.

The pathology report indicates that the liver lesion is a metastatic adenocarcinoma originating from a rectosigmoid colon tumor, while the para-aortic lymph node biopsy shows no evidence of malignancy. The rectosigmoid colon resection reveals a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma that invades through the muscularis propria into the subserosa, classified as pT3, with one of 37 lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement (pN1a). All resection margins are negative for tumor, and lymphatic invasion is noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, both ovaries, and the uterus, with a high FIGO grade of 3 for the ovarian tumors. Additionally, there are multiple metastatic lesions identified in the bladder peritoneum, cecum, ileum, and rectosigmoid colon, along with involvement of the right external iliac lymph nodes. The cervix is noted to be free of tumor, while the endometrium shows a proliferative state with an endometrial polyp.

The pathology report indicates that a left lower lobectomy was performed, revealing a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.7 cm with separate tumor nodules in the same lobe, and lymph-vascular invasion was present. No mutations in the EGFR gene were detected, classifying it as wild type, and all examined lymph nodes were benign with no evidence of metastatic involvement. The tumor was staged as pT1b, with clear margins from invasive carcinoma, and additional findings included emphysematous changes in the lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of choroidal melanoma of predominantly spindle cell type in the right eye, with a tumor size of 9mm in diameter and 8.5mm in height. Microscopic examination reveals minimal lymphocytic infiltrate, no tumor necrosis, and no extension through the sclera or optic nerve, with adequate clearance margins. Molecular genetic analysis shows borderline losses on chromosome 3 and gains on chromosome 6p, with further immunohistochemical confirmation of tumor cell expression of Melan-A and HSP 27.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a large mass with numerous satellite nodules and involvement of the hepatic capsule and surgical margins, along with evidence of vascular invasion. Additionally, there are metastatic Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma masses identified in the right adrenal gland, while the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis without tumor presence. Peritoneal biopsies and lymph nodes from the cystic duct and pericholedochal regions are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of early gastric carcinoma associated with a high-grade adenoma, with the carcinoma being a well-differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma located in the middle third of the stomach. The tumor measures 6.5x4.3 cm and invades the mucosa, but there is no evidence of lymph node metastasis or invasion into lymphatic, venous, or perineural structures. The surgical margins are clear of carcinoma, and additional findings include foveolar hyperplasia with pit dysplasia and a pre-existing high-grade tubular adenoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of locally advanced, poorly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma of the cecum, classified as grade 3. The cancer has invaded all layers of the bowel wall, penetrated the peritoneum, and spread to a loop of small intestine, with multiple regional lymph node metastases. Additionally, there is evidence of peritoneal or omental carcinosis, indicating advanced disease (pT4 L1 V0 pN2 9/10 pM1).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, partially micropapillary, of the left breast, with a tumor size of 11 x 7 x 3 cm and evidence of vascular invasion. Metastatic carcinoma was found in axillary lymph nodes, specifically in nodes No IV/XI, indicating a pN2a classification. The report also notes additional findings of fibrocystic changes and simple ductal hyperplasia in the breast tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant mixed Mllerian tumor of the endometrium, characterized by a dominant serous carcinomatous component that invades more than half of the myometrium, with diffuse vascular invasion present. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma was identified in multiple lymph nodes, including 1 out of 3 left external iliac nodes, 1 out of 1 left obturator node, 5 out of 5 right external iliac nodes, 2 out of 4 right obturator nodes, 3 out of 3 right peri-aortic nodes, and 2 out of 7 left peri-aortic nodes. The report also notes abnormalities such as atrophy in the endometrium and fallopian tubes, and leiomyomas with tumor emboli in the myometrium.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic poorly differentiated serous carcinoma in the omentum, bilateral ovaries, and right diaphragm, with significant tumor involvement in the uterus and rectum. The appendix shows fibrous obliteration of the lumen with periappendiceal metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma is identified in the left and right pelvic lymph nodes, while the right aortic lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the left hepatic artery and cystic artery lymph nodes, as well as the portal caval lymph node, show no evidence of tumor. However, the right lobe of the liver reveals two foci of moderately to poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, measuring 9 cm and 7 cm, with vascular invasion present and negative surgical margins. Additionally, the patient has chronic hepatitis B with fibrosis stage 2, and the overall AJCC stage is pT3aNO.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinosarcoma in the left paracolic gutter and sigmoid mesentery, along with a malignant mixed Mullerian tumor in the uterus, characterized by 80% glandular and 20% stromal differentiation, forming a lobulated mass without myometrial invasion but with lymphovascular space invasion. The tumor has spread to the anterior uterine serosa and left fallopian tube serosa, while multiple benign leiomyomata and endometriosis are also noted. All examined lymph nodes and gonadal vessels are negative for tumor involvement, and the cervix and appendix show no abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma in the thyroid, with the dominant tumor measuring 1.7 cm located in the isthmus, and a second smaller tumor in the left lobe measuring 0.6 cm. The report also notes the presence of a dominant follicular adenoma measuring 2.5 cm, which shows extensive degeneration and reactive atypia. No pathological diagnosis was made for the parathyroid and lymph nodes examined, and all margins of the tumors were uninvolved by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in a right paratracheal mass and multifocal papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 2 cm. There is evidence of metastatic carcinoma in 20 out of 85 lymph nodes, with significant invasion noted in the primary tumor and involved margins. Additionally, metastatic papillary carcinoma was found in 11 of 15 lymph nodes from the paratracheal soft tissue and in all 8 lymph nodes from the right neck contents.

The pathology report indicates the presence of three foci of invasive lobular carcinoma in the right breast, with sizes of 2.9 cm, 0.6 cm, and 0.2 cm, and extensive lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) noted. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 22 out of 33 axillary lymph nodes, with extranodal extension observed, and the largest metastasis measuring 1.4 cm. The tumor is classified as Nottingham grade 2, with positive estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and HER2 results, leading to a pathological staging of pT2 N3.

The pathology report indicates that a right upper lobe mass was diagnosed as invasive adenocarcinoma, with a tumor size of less than 1 cm and a larger mass measuring 5 cm, and the parenchymal margin was involved by carcinoma. Lymph node biopsies from levels 2R and 4R were negative for metastatic carcinoma, confirming no regional lymph node involvement. Additionally, the surgical margins were focally positive for tumor, indicating the presence of mucinous and non-mucinous adenocarcinoma in situ at the margin of the resected lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right colon invasive low-grade adenocarcinoma with mucinous differentiation, measuring 9 cm, which is associated with a tubulovillous adenoma of the cecum and extends into the visceral peritoneum. Additionally, a liver biopsy reveals metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with the colorectal primary, while 17 regional lymph nodes examined show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The tumor margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, with perineural invasion present, and further evaluation for KRAS mutation and mismatch repair defects is planned.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating poorly differentiated duct carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 4.7 by 2.5 by 2.0 cm, with involvement of all four quadrants and extension to the dermis of the nipple. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive estrogen receptor (50%), progesterone receptor (40%), and HER-2/NEU (70% of tumor cells) results. Additionally, six out of nineteen lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, and the margins of resection are negative for tumor, but the tumor is within 0.2 cm of the deep margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of tubular adenocarcinoma (G3) of the stomach, with evidence of infiltration into the muscularis propria and periventricular adipose tissue, as well as invasion of blood vessels. The tumor measures 7 x 6 x 0.5 cm and is located on the lesser curvature of the stomach, with surgical margins showing cancer invasion. Additionally, there are metastatic carcinoma findings in lymph nodes No VI/XIX, while the mucosa is free of cancer but shows signs of chronic inflammation and focal intestinal metaplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in a left level 2 cervical lymph node excision. Microscopic examination reveals a disruption of normal nodal architecture with a proliferation of medium-sized lymphoid cells, and immunohistochemical staining confirms the B-cell nature of the lymphoma while excluding other types such as Burkitt lymphoma and mantle cell lymphoma. The Ki-67 labeling index suggests a moderate proliferation rate of 70-80%, and no evidence of granulomas or metastatic disease is noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 3.3 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2. The tumor extends into the perinephric adipose tissue but does not invade beyond Gerota's fascia, and the surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement. The pathologic staging is classified as pT3a, with no lymphovascular invasion identified, and the adrenal gland is uninvolved by the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type with squamous differentiation, classified as FIGO grade II, with myometrial invasion of less than 50%. There is no cervical involvement or lymphovascular space invasion, and all examined lymph nodes (33 total) are negative for metastasis. The report also notes the presence of complex hyperplasia with atypia in the endometrium, but the surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has acute and chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis, along with a reactive lymph node in the cystic duct. Liver biopsies reveal atypical hepatocytes consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma in the context of steatohepatitis, with a dominant mass in segment IVb and a smaller nodule in segment IVa, both classified as grade 1-2. Additionally, a subcapsular lipoma and bile duct hamartomas are noted, while the resection margins are negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right parietal pleural biopsy showing malignant mesothelioma of epithelial type, likely related to asbestos exposure. Microscopic examination reveals markedly thickened pleura with an epithelioid malignant infiltrate, characterized by large irregular nuclei and poorly cohesive cells. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis, with positive markers for calretinin and CK5/6, while CK20 and TTF-1 are negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma with multifocality and local invasion into perivesical soft tissues, classified as pT3. Metastatic disease was identified in lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic dissections, with one out of six nodes on the right and three out of eight nodes on the left showing metastatic involvement. Surgical margins were free of tumor, and the female genital organs showed no pathological abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right tongue, with a maximum tumor diameter of 3.2 cm and extensive perineural invasion, but no lymphatic or vascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes from both the right and left neck levels were negative for tumor involvement, and the closest lateral margin to the tumor was 0.3 cm. An addendum revealed invasion of the cortical bone by squamous cell carcinoma, although the bone margins were negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon (G2) that has penetrated all layers of the bowel wall (pT3) and shows lymph vessel invasion, with lymph node metastases (pN2). The report also notes that the resection margins are free of residual tumor in the examined specimens. Tumor classification is provided as ICDO-DA-M 8140/3, confirming the diagnosis and staging.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, grade III, located in the left temporal parietal region of the brain. The tumor exhibits a moderately pleomorphic and infiltrative proliferation of astrocytes with a proliferation index of 7.2%, which is consistent with this grade of tumor. There are no signs of endothelial proliferation or necrosis, and the specimen was processed for further histological examination.

The pathology report indicates that a wedge biopsy of the apical segment of the right lower lobe shows subpleural fibrosis and chronic inflammation, but is negative for malignancy. A lobectomy of the right upper lobe reveals poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.7 cm, with extensive infiltration into peribronchial lymph nodes, while several lymph nodes, including the right low paratracheal and interlobar nodes, are positive for metastatic squamous cell carcinoma. The bronchial and tracheal resection margins are negative for tumor, and the remaining lung parenchyma shows moderate to marked emphysematous changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (intestinal type) located at the esophagogastric junction. The tumor has infiltrated the perimuscular fatty tissue and shows metastasis in three out of twenty-nine regional lymph nodes. The resection margins are tumor-free, classified as pT2b N1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma following a prostatectomy, with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, indicating a moderately aggressive tumor. The largest tumor focus measures 27 mm and is located in the right posterior region, with a second focus of 24 mm in the right anterior region, and there is no evidence of extraprostatic extension or cancer at the surgical margin. The pathologic stage is classified as pT2c, NX, MX, and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is also noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, with a histologic grade of 1 and a maximum tumor size of 4.5 cm, confined to the endometrium but extending into the cervix. There is no myometrial invasion or lymphovascular invasion identified, and all sampled lymph nodes are negative for cancer. The AJCC pathologic stage is classified as pT2, pN0, or stage II, indicating localized disease with cervical involvement but no spread to lymph nodes or other organs.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal invasive adenocarcinoma with a predominant bronchioloalveolar pattern in the right middle and lower lobes of the lung, with the middle lobe tumor measuring 2 cm and the lower lobe tumor measuring 15 cm. Both tumors show no visceral pleural invasion and have negative margins (R0), with a total of 16 regional lymph nodes examined, all negative for metastatic carcinoma. The middle lobe tumor is classified as pathologic stage IA, while the lower lobe tumor is classified as pathologic stage IIB, with additional findings of non-necrotizing granulomatous inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a 5.5 cm well-differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with bilateral disease and a pathological classification of T2, NOS. There were 8 positive lymph nodes sampled, and the right posterior vaginal margin is positive for invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The sample was collected fresh frozen following surgical resection, with a diagnosis made 11 days post-procedure.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 4.2 cm Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma, Type I, with minimal diffusion to the surgical border and no major infiltration of lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as pT1b, RO, with a grade of GII. The peri-renal fat layer is free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Diffuse Large Cell B-Cell Lymphoma, follicular center cell type, from a cerebellopontine angle mass biopsy and resection. Microscopic evaluation shows sheets of atypical cells with pleomorphic hyperchromatic nuclei, significant cytologic atypia, and numerous mitotic figures, along with foci of necrosis and apoptotic cells. The tumor cells are positive for CD45, CD20, CD10, MUM-1, and BCL6, while negative for CD3, CD43, CD30, and BCL2, with a final diagnosis pending further stains and consultation.

The pathology report indicates an extended right hemicolectomy specimen with a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located at the hepatic flexure, measuring 4.8 x 3.2 cm and extending through the colonic wall to within 0.1 cm of the serosal surface. The tumor shows high-grade characteristics and is classified as pT4a, with vascular invasion suspected, but both proximal and distal margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, no regional lymph node involvement was found (0/25), and other findings include an ileocecal valve lipoma and fibrous obliteration of the appendix tip.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of peripheral bronchopulmonary mucinous adenocarcinoma with significant bronchioloalveolar differentiation, localized in segment 10. The TNM classification is pT2 pNO pMX R0, indicating stage IB cancer, with no evidence of visceral pleural infiltration. Additionally, the resection margins and all removed lymph nodes are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a high-grade leiomyosarcoma of the inferior vena cava measuring 9 cm, with significant mitotic activity and tumor necrosis, but negative resection margins. The right kidney was found to be free of tumor, and the adrenal gland was uninvolved. The tumor invades the lumen of the vena cava, with proximity to the resection margins noted, but no gross extension beyond its pseudocapsule was observed.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen consists of the uterus and left fallopian tube, revealing an invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.4 x 3.0 cm, with infiltration into the stroma but not compromising the resection margins. Additionally, there is evidence of squamous cell carcinoma in situ, neoplastic lymphatic embolization, uterine leiomyomas, and endometriosis in the parametrium and left fallopian tube. The pathological staging is classified as pT1b1, pN1 according to the TNM 7th edition.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated endometrial carcinoma (grade 3) with extensive involvement of the endometrial cavity and invasion into the myometrium and cervix. The tumor was found to have spread to the peritoneal surface, but all examined lymph nodes from various regions were negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings include benign fibroadipose tissue in the omental biopsy and endosalpingiosis in the ovaries, with surgical margins free of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with a total of 16 out of 31 examined lymph nodes testing positive for cancer. The right thyroid lobe shows a 9.4 cm papillary thyroid carcinoma, classified as grade 2, with lymphatic invasion but no capsular invasion or infiltration into adjacent structures. Additionally, benign findings include a nodular goiter in the left thyroid lobe and benign lymph nodes with hemosiderin deposition in the right inferior neck.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a woman with a left temporal brain tumor, has been diagnosed with glioblastoma, WHO Grade IV, characterized by high mitotic activity and necrosis. Immunohistochemistry revealed strong reactivity for p53, and the mitotic index was approximately 45%. Additionally, the MGMT promoter was found to be methylated, which may suggest a potential benefit from alkylating agent therapy, while the PCR for the EGFR variant III mutation was negative.

The final diagnosis indicates the presence of an anaplastic oligoastrocytoma (WHO Grade III) in the right temporal lobe of the brain, characterized by high cellularity, mitotic activity, and both oligodendroglial and astrocytic differentiation, along with prominent microvascular proliferation and coagulative necrosis. Immunohistochemical staining for the IDH1 mutation was negative, and fluorescence in situ hybridization showed preservation of chromosomes 1p and 19q. The specimen consisted of multiple soft tissue fragments measuring 3 x 3 x 0.3 cm, submitted for both intraoperative consultation and permanent analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade myxofibrosarcoma in the right buttock following a radical resection, with the tumor measuring 14.5 x 6.3 x 8.0 cm and exhibiting a diffusely infiltrative growth pattern. There is an estimated 20-30% gross necrosis, but the surgical margins are free of tumor, although lymphovascular invasion is noted. Immunohistochemical stains for CDK4 and MDM2 are negative, and the tumor displays a variegated appearance with areas of low-grade myxoid and more cohesive undifferentiated morphology.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with Fuhrman's nuclear grade 4, measuring 15.0 cm, and exhibiting focal invasion into renal sinus fat and the renal vein. There is evidence of metastatic renal cell carcinoma in the wall of the distal ureter and in approximately twenty matted hilar lymph nodes, while the adrenal gland and some additional hilar lymph nodes show no tumor involvement. A lymph node below the bifurcation is also involved by metastatic renal cell carcinoma, and the tumor displays focally rhabdoid features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of melanoma in a female patient, with the tumor located in the skin and classified as a primary tumor. The melanoma is graded as 3 and staged as T4b N1 M0, indicating advanced local disease with regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. Additionally, a normal blood sample was obtained, which does not indicate any abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2 N1 M0, indicating a primary tumor with regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. Additionally, a normal blood sample was obtained, which is not related to the cancer diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast lumpectomy revealed infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 2, with a tumor size of 1.3 cm and no evidence of necrosis, vascular invasion, or microcalcifications. All examined sentinel and non-sentinel lymph nodes were negative for malignancy, confirming no lymphatic spread of the cancer. The tumor was estrogen and progesterone receptor positive, with a HER2/neu status of negative, and the pathological stage is classified as pT1c N0 (i-) MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, in the right lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 4.9 cm. The tumor is well differentiated, completely encapsulated, and shows no evidence of capsular invasion, blood vessel invasion, or extrathyroid extension. Additionally, the surgical margins are free of tumor, and a benign lymph node was identified among the examined nodes.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon, classified as G3, with evidence of necrosis, chronic inflammation, and ulcerations. The tumor has infiltrated the colon wall and pericolic fatty tissue, with nine out of nineteen regional lymph nodes showing metastasis. The tumor staging is pT3, pN2, MX, L1, R0, and the resection margins are tumor-free, alongside a diagnosis of chronic appendicitis.

The pathology report describes a hypercellular spindle cell neoplasm in a fibrous stroma, consistent with a malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, showing mild cytologic atypia and rare necrosis. The tumor exhibits variable mitotic activity and immunoreactivity for S-100, while being negative for EMA and CD-34, with patchy MIB-1 labeling. An exclusion of spindle cell melanoma is suggested, as the core cells are negative despite high background positivity for the melanoma cocktail antibody.

The pathology report indicates the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma in the prostate with a Gleason score of 3+3, showing bilateral involvement and extensive extraprostatic extension, particularly affecting the right seminal vesicle. The left seminal vesicle is free of carcinoma, and there is extensive perineural infiltration noted. The excision margins are clear of tumor, but very close in multiple areas, with the overall staging classified as pT3bNXMX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma in both ovaries and fallopian tubes, with additional findings of a paraovarian serous cystadenoma and stromal luteinization. The cancer has metastasized to the serosal surfaces of the uterus and omentum, suggesting a primary peritoneal carcinoma. Other findings include benign conditions such as follicular cervicitis and leiomyomata in the uterus, with no significant lesions noted in the uninvolved ovarian tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in the left lung, measuring 65 mm, with invasion into the medial and lateral pleural surfaces and the pulmonary vein. There is evidence of metastasis in one hilar lymph node, leading to a pathological staging of T4 N1. The bronchial resection margin is clear of malignancy, and the pulmonary vein stump shows no evidence of cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary has a serous cystadenoma, while the right fallopian tube shows no significant changes, and no malignancy is identified in these structures. The uterus reveals an endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation, classified as FIGO stage IA, limited to the endometrium without myometrial or cervical invasion, and all examined lymph nodes are free of carcinoma. Additional findings include benign endocervical polyps, adenomyosis in the myometrium, and endometriosis in the left ovary.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 3 cm and unifocality. The tumor is limited to the lung, with no lymphovascular invasion identified, and both bronchial and vascular margins are free of involvement. The AJCC pathologic stage is T1b, N0, and negative findings were noted in the peribronchial and intraparenchymal lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of choroidal melanoma of mixed cell type in the left enucleated eye, with a tumor size of 16.8 mm in diameter and 9 mm in height. Microscopic examination reveals a predominance of epithelioid cells (80%), mild lymphocytic infiltrate, and no evidence of tumor necrosis or involvement of the optic nerve or vortex veins. The tumor shows minimal extension into the inner sclera, and the resection margins are clear of tumor cells.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from an adrenalectomy measures 7 X 5 X 4.5 cm and weighs 127 grams. The diagnosis is adrenocortical carcinoma, with a KI67 proliferation index of 5%. The tumor was assessed using various scoring systems, resulting in a Weiss score of 4, a Hough score of 2.29, and a Van Slooten score of 9.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade I, with no definitive myometrial, endocervical, or vascular invasion identified, alongside complex hyperplasia with atypia in the endometrium. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes and the right distal IP ligament biopsy showed benign findings, with no evidence of malignancy in the lymph nodes. Other noted abnormalities include adenomyosis and an adenomyomatous polyp in the myometrium, as well as benign paratubal cysts on the right side.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the excised lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions, with a total of 18 nodes examined (0/18 positive). The prostate biopsy reveals adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, showing features of ductal adenocarcinoma, with established extracapsular extension and perineural invasion, but no involvement of the seminal vesicles or surgical margins. The tumor involves both lobes of the prostate, with a maximum dimension of 3.3 cm and accounts for 28% of the examined prostate volume, classified as pathologic stage pT3a, pNO, pMX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the apical segment of the right lower lobe, measuring 75 mm, with extensive endobronchial extension but no invasion of the visceral pleura. The bronchial resection margins are clear of tumor, although there is perineural permeation and involvement of a peribronchial lymph node. The pathological stage is classified as T2 N1, with additional findings of bronchiectasis and focal endogenous lipoid pneumonia in the adjacent lung parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates that a left adrenalectomy was performed on a female patient diagnosed with pheochromocytoma following cardiogenic shock. The specimen received was a 29.13 gram left adrenal gland with a 4.0 x 2.6 x 2.3 cm tan homogeneous nodule, showing no signs of hemorrhage or necrosis. The final diagnosis confirmed the presence of pheochromocytoma in the left adrenal gland.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adrenal cortical carcinoma from a left adrenal mass, which was clinically associated with Cushing's syndrome. Microscopic examination revealed a nodular and diffuse tumor with significant nuclear pleomorphism, frequent mitoses, and areas of necrosis, along with evidence of infiltration into surrounding tissues. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, showing positivity for synaptophysin and melan-A, consistent with adrenocortical tumor characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left pelvic lymph nodes are benign and negative for malignancy, while the total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy reveal high-grade serous carcinoma involving the endometrial cavity, myometrium, and both ovaries, with multifocal microscopic tumor deposits on the uterine serosa. Additionally, the omentum shows positive multifocal deposits of metastatic high-grade serous carcinoma. The findings suggest that the primary tumor likely originated in the uterus, with metastasis to the ovaries and omentum.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bilateral serous adenocarcinoma (psammomacarcinoma) with extensive metastases involving the omentum, cecum, right fallopian tube, uterus, left fallopian tube, and rectosigmoid region. The tumors exhibit a gritty and mucinous character, with significant tumor burden replacing the ovaries and other structures. Immunostaining for carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) shows heterogeneous expression in the tumor cells, with approximately 50% of the cells exhibiting some degree of staining.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an infiltrating low-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 3x2x2 cm, with ill-defined margins and invasion into the muscularis propria. Microscopic examination reveals hyperplastic transitional cells with moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm, enlarged nuclei with irregular shapes, and the presence of mitoses. The tumor is moderately differentiated, with uninvolved margins and no evidence of lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the excised right and left pelvic lymph nodes, as well as the anterior fat pad, are benign and negative for carcinoma. The prostatectomy revealed invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+3=6, involving both lobes but less than 5% of the prostate volume, with no extraprostatic extension and free surgical margins. Additionally, perineural invasion was identified, and multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia was noted, while the spermatic cord showed fragments of a lipoma.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph node is negative for malignancy, confirming no cancer spread in that node. The right breast biopsy reveals invasive ductal adenocarcinoma, graded as 2 out of 3, with a 1.6 cm invasive component and the presence of in-situ carcinoma. The surgical margins are close, with invasive carcinoma located less than 0.5 mm from the superior margin, and further receptor analysis is pending.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 3, with a primary tumor size of 7 cm and metastasis found in 13 out of 19 examined lymph nodes. Additionally, a left highest axillary lymph node showed metastatic carcinoma, while another excised lymph node showed no evidence of carcinoma. The surgical margins from the mastectomy are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and there is evidence of venous/lymphatic invasion present.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast measuring 3.8 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ and lymphatic-vascular invasion present. One of the sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla showed metastatic carcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes and breast tissue samples were free of carcinoma. Hormone receptor testing revealed positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2/neu was negative, and the overall staging is classified as pT2N1MX.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive squamous cell carcinoma located on the right tongue, with a maximum tumor diameter of 2.5 cm and a depth of invasion of 0.6 cm. One of the three examined lymph nodes from level 1A showed metastatic carcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes from levels 2, 3, 4, and 5 were negative for metastasis. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, and there is no evidence of extracapsular extension in the positive lymph node.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in a liver resection specimen from segment 3, with a tumor size of 8.5 cm and focal microvascular invasion. The tumor is unifocal, confined to the liver, and the surgical margins are negative, with the nearest margin being 1.5 cm from the tumor. Additional findings include micronodular cirrhosis, and the tumor is classified as pT2 NX, corresponding to AJCC stage II.

The pathology report indicates that the deep bilateral pelvic lymph node dissections revealed seven benign hyperplastic regional lymph nodes with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The radical prostatectomy showed the presence of adenocarcinoma, with a Gleason score of 7/10, involving only the right lobe of the prostate and no extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle involvement. Surgical margins were negative, and benign prostatic hyperplasia was also noted as a significant finding.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary serous adenocarcinoma involving the entire endometrium and lower uterine segment, with invasion into more than half of the myometrium and cervical stroma. Metastatic disease is identified in 2 of 17 regional lymph nodes, while other examined tissues, including the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and omentum, show no tumor involvement. The report highlights the tumor's poorly differentiated nature and notes the presence of adenomyosis and leiomyomata in the uterus.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2 out of 4. The neoplasm is confined to the kidney without any evidence of extracasular extension or angiolymphatic invasion, and all surgical margins are free of cancer. The tumor is classified as pT1b NX MX, indicating localized disease without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, measuring 2.5 cm, with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion and clear surgical margins. Additionally, benign lymph nodes were identified in both the common bile duct and pancreatic regions, showing lipogranulomatous reactions without tumor presence. The liver background exhibited mild mixed micro- and macrovesicular steatosis and mildly active steatohepatitis, suggesting potential underlying metabolic issues.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic adenocarcinoma with an E746 A750del5 mutation in Exon 19 of the EGFR gene, which is associated with a positive response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapies. The tumor is characterized as a mixed subtype adenocarcinoma, primarily papillary, with visceral pleural invasion and metastasis to one of nine examined lymph nodes. Additionally, KRAS mutation analysis revealed no mutations, suggesting a potentially better prognosis and responsiveness to targeted therapies.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the cervix, with a tumor size of 2 cm and a depth of invasion of 1 cm, while all examined lymph nodes (totaling 42) show no evidence of metastasis. The right and left tubes and ovaries reveal benign findings, including simple cysts and paratubal cysts. Additionally, there is evidence of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III with microinvasion and disordered proliferative endometrium noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the left and right internal/external iliac, hypogastric, and obturator lymph nodes. The prostate contains four foci of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), all confined to the prostate and with resection margins free of tumor. Additionally, there is high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN), but the seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia show no evidence of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of a left parietal brain tumor is diagnosed as gliosarcoma, characterized by a biphasic pattern and a MIB-1 proliferation index of 50%. The tumor is positive for GFAP and reticulum stains, while negative for cytokeratin. The specimens were received without fixative and included a 0.6 cm and a larger irregular portion of soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing perineural invasion, with a maximum tumor diameter of 57 mm and positive surgical margins in 23 tissue blocks. Additionally, there is one lymph node metastasis identified on the right side, while the left side shows two tumor-free lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as pT4, indicating advanced local disease, with significant infiltration into surrounding structures including seminal vesicles and deferent ducts.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade I endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, arising in a background of polypoid atypical hyperplasia, with the cancer limited to the endometrium and no myometrial invasion or lymph-vascular space involvement. The cervix is unremarkable, and both ovaries and fallopian tubes are described as unremarkable, with the ovaries being atrophic. Additionally, the appendix is also reported as unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the perinephric fat removal showed benign fibroadipose tissue with no signs of malignancy. The left renal mass was diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the conventional clear cell type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3, measuring 2.9 cm, and no evidence of capsular invasion or metastasis. Surgical margins were negative for tumor, and the overall AJCC Pathologic TNM Stage is pT1a pNx.

The pathology report indicates that the inferior mesenteric vein lymph node biopsy revealed benign fibroadipose tissue with no lymph node or tumor identified. In contrast, the left adrenal gland biopsy confirmed the presence of an adrenal pheochromocytoma measuring 3.8 x 2.9 x 2.7 cm, exhibiting atypical histologic features and vascular invasion, raising concerns for possible malignant behavior. Close clinical follow-up is recommended due to the tumor's aggressive characteristics, including capsular invasion and extension into peri-adrenal adipose tissue.

The pathology report indicates a left renal tumor diagnosed as conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma, measuring 4.2 cm with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV, and no evidence of local invasion or renal vein involvement. Additional specimens revealed benign cortical cysts and a muscle-predominant angiomyolipoma adjacent to one of the cysts. Surgical margins were free of tumor, and the overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left modified neck dissection and total thyroidectomy, revealing metastatic papillary carcinoma of the thyroid in 9 out of 37 lymph nodes, with tumor involvement in the soft tissues of the neck. The total thyroidectomy showed a papillary carcinoma in the left lobe, measuring 4.8 x 3.0 x 1.8 cm, with tumor extending to the inked margins of excision. Additionally, a follicular adenoma was identified in the right lobe of the thyroid.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon, with a tumor size of 8.2 cm located in the cecum, showing invasion through the muscularis propria into pericolonic adipose tissue but no evidence of perforation or lymphovascular invasion. The surgical margins are negative, and no metastases were found in the 16 examined regional lymph nodes. Additional findings include focal mucinous differentiation and loss of nuclear expression of MLH1, with further microsatellite instability testing pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), showing multicentric foci and established extracapsular extension at the left posterior base, while the seminal vesicles and bladder neck are not involved. The surgical margins are focally positive at the left posterior margin, and no vascular invasion is identified, although perineural invasion is present. The pelvic lymph nodes examined are benign, with no evidence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lymph node from the hepatic artery is negative for metastatic carcinoma. A pancreatic endocrine neoplasm, grade 2, was identified in the subtotal pancreatectomy and splenectomy specimen, measuring 3 x 2.5 cm, with free surgical margins and no regional lymph node metastasis. Additionally, the gallbladder showed chronic cholecystitis and cholesterolosis without evidence of dysplasia or malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate, with a maximum tumor diameter of 3.5 cm and extensive perineural infiltration, along with extraprostatic growth in the right rectolateral region. There is no evidence of vascular invasion, and all examined lymph nodes (7 total) are tumor-free. The tumor classification is pT3a, L0, V0, pNO (0/7), with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, and the tumor is close to the preparation margin but shows no direct contact.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies from multiple lymph nodes (stations 10, 11, 12, 10R, 4R, and 7) are negative for tumor, with some showing hyalinized granulomas. The right upper lobe lobectomy revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 1.5 cm, with no lymphovascular or pleural invasion, and clear surgical margins. Overall, there is no evidence of metastatic disease in the examined lymph nodes, resulting in a pathologic stage of pT1a/N0/Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade mullerian-derived adenocarcinoma, metastatic, with involvement in multiple sites including the ileum, right and left ovaries, appendix, sigmoid colon, and peritoneum. The tumor is classified as papillary serous type, nuclear grade III, and is staged as FIGO stage IV. Notably, the fallopian tubes are not involved, but there is extensive metastatic spread to surrounding tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland, with noted vascular invasion, which is a risk factor for malignancy. The specimen measured 7.5 x 5 x 2 cm and contained a soft, friable tumor mass arising from the adrenal medulla, alongside some normal adrenal tissue. No lymph nodes or secondary masses were observed in the surrounding periadrenal fat.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC) in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 3.3 cm and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion, and all surgical margins are negative. Light microscopic examination supports the diagnosis, showing strong reactivity for CD117 and focal staining for CK7, while other markers were negative, ruling out oncocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant fibrous histiocytoma measuring 12.8 x 3.5 x 2.5 cm in the subcutaneous soft tissue of the right posterior calf, with angiolymphatic invasion and the tumor extending to within less than 1 mm of the medial margin. Additional evaluations of the medial subcutaneous margin and medial tendon margin were negative for tumor. The deep margin from the case was also confirmed to be negative for tumor.

The pathology report describes a hypercellular glial neoplasm with both astrocytic and oligodendrocytic components, showing moderate cytologic atypia and diffuse infiltration into adjacent brain tissue. The presence of microvascular proliferation and early micronecrosis raises concerns for anaplastic progression, despite low mitotic activity suggesting a low-grade glioma. The final diagnosis is an oligoastrocytoma with early anaplastic progression, supported by a MIB-1 labeling index of 6.9%.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 6.2 cm moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the cervix, characterized by extensive lymphovascular space invasion and a maximum tumor invasion depth of 10 mm. No carcinoma was identified in the surrounding parametrial tissues or in any of the examined lymph nodes, indicating no regional metastasis. The tumor is classified as T1b (FIGO stage IB), suggesting it is confined to the uterus but larger than T1a2/IA2, with a provisional pathologic stage pending further clinical data.

The pathology report indicates that the resected 5th and 6th ribs are undergoing decalcification, with an addendum report to follow. The pleura from a left pleurectomy shows diffuse malignant mesothelioma, predominantly of the fibrosarcomatous type, associated with hyaline pleural plaques and chronic talc pleuritis. Immunostaining confirms the diagnosis, revealing positive markers such as nuclear Calretinin and WT-1, while negative for other markers, indicating the specific characteristics of the mesothelioma.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the right lower lobe pleura revealed benign fibrous and adipose tissue with no tumor identified. Multiple excised lymph nodes from various levels also showed no evidence of tumor, except for one lymph node that contained benign adipose and fibrovascular tissue without lymphoid tissue. A lobectomy of the right lower lobe confirmed the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.3 cm, with no lymphovascular invasion or tumor at the surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates a lobectomy specimen from the lung, revealing a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5 x 5 x 5 cm. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/4 positive), and details regarding tumor extent, margins, and invasion are not specified. Additional pathologic findings and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment are also not provided.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in three sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla, with one node showing involvement up to 7 mm and another up to 4 mm, confirmed by AE1/AE3 cytokeratin immunostaining. Additionally, the left total mastectomy specimen reveals infiltrating lobular carcinoma measuring 8.0 x 6.5 x 4.2 cm, with a Nottingham score of 6/9, and no lymphovascular invasion noted. The margins of resection are free of tumor, and the immunohistochemical analysis shows positive estrogen and progesterone receptor status, while HER-2/neu is equivocal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated serous papillary adenocarcinoma originating from the left ovary, classified as FIGO stage IIIC, with significant lymphovascular space involvement and multiple metastatic sites including the omentum and pelvic soft tissue. The maximum dimension of the metastatic tumor implants is noted to be 17 cm. Other examined tissues, including the right ovary, fallopian tubes, uterus, and appendix, showed no evidence of tumor, with some benign findings such as leiomyomata and chronic inflammation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in a right upper lobe lung mass, measuring 4.5 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm, with no evidence of visceral pleural or lymphovascular invasion. All excised lymph nodes (4 total) showed no metastatic carcinoma, and the tumor is classified as pT2a N0. The lung cancer molecular panel results are pending, and the tumor is positive for cytokeratin 7 and TTF, supporting the diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 1) in the uterus, with a tumor size of 3.4 x 1.4 x 0.5 cm and a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 0.9 cm. Additionally, there are findings of a 0.9 cm hilus cell tumor in the left ovary and a 1.2 cm mitotically active cellular fibroma in the right ovary, with no tumor detected in the pelvic lymph nodes. The report notes a few foci suspicious for lymphovascular invasion, but the specimen margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the fundus of the stomach, with a tumor size of 14 x 13 x 2 cm and ulcerated features. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/5 positive), and the surgical margins are uninvolved. Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion are not specified, and there is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe lung lobectomy, measuring 2 cm, with negative margins and no pleural or main stem bronchus involvement (pT1a). There is evidence of venous and lymphatic invasion, but all examined lymph nodes (7 total) are negative for metastatic tumor. Additionally, there is an area of intraparenchymal pulmonary hemorrhage noted, which is not related to the surgical procedure.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix, poorly differentiated, with a maximum stromal invasion thickness of 22 mm and focal in situ carcinoma present. All examined lymph nodes from both sides (left and right external iliac, left hypogastric, left obturator, right hypogastric, and right obturator) were benign, showing no evidence of metastatic disease. Surgical margins are free of tumor, but the carcinoma is noted to extend within 0.1 cm of the deep parametrial soft tissue margin and the ectocervical margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 2.0 x 1.8 cm and classified as well differentiated. There is evidence of visceral pleura involvement, but the bronchial and pleural margins are negative for malignancy, and no lymph node metastases were identified (0/6). The findings support a primary lung adenocarcinoma, with no treatment effects noted, and the staging is classified as pT1, N0.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen from the antrum, revealing a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with an ulcerating configuration measuring 7 x 6 x 2 cm. Out of 8 examined lymph nodes, 2 were positive for metastasis. Details regarding the extent of invasion and margins were not specified, and there were no additional pathologic findings noted.

The pathology report indicates extensive urothelial carcinoma in-situ involving the prostate, with focal invasive carcinoma noted in the prostatic stroma, as well as carcinoma in situ affecting the ejaculatory duct and seminal vesicles. All surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement, and no prostate adenocarcinoma is identified. The tumor is classified as high grade, with a size of 7 cm, and there is multifocal lymphovascular invasion present in the lymph nodes, leading to a staging of IV.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated esophageal adenocarcinoma arising in Barrett's mucosa at the gastroesophageal junction, measuring 3.5 cm and confined to the lamina propria. A total of eleven lymph nodes were examined, all of which were negative for neoplasm, and the surgical margins were reported as negative. Additionally, an incidental finding of an leiomyoma was noted, but there was no evidence of preoperative treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 fibrillary astrocytoma (WHO grade III) from a biopsy and excision of a left frontal brain mass. Immunohistochemical analysis shows strong and diffuse expression of p53 protein in neoplastic cells, along with a high MIB-1 labeling index, supporting the diagnosis of a diffuse glioma. The gross description includes multiple samples from the left frontal lobe, with findings consistent with an intermediate grade glioma.

The pathology report describes a 7x7x7 cm squamous cell carcinoma, grade II, located in the right upper lobe of the lung, characterized by soft, necrotic-gray tissue and ill-defined margins. Microscopic examination reveals malignant cells with moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm, enlarged nuclei, and common mitotic figures, indicating invasion into benign bronchial tissue and lymphatic invasion. Notably, all examined lymph nodes (paratracheal, subcarinal, and interlobar) show no evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of stage IV right breast cancer, confirmed post-operatively following a modified radical mastectomy. The tumor is characterized as infiltrating poorly differentiated duct carcinoma measuring 9.0 by 8.5 by 4.0 cm, with involvement of all four quadrants, the nipple, and the epidermis of ulcerated skin, while margins of resection are negative for tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive estrogen (50%) and progesterone (40%) receptor status, while HER-2/NEU is negative, and multiple matted lymph nodes exhibit extensive metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the left kidney tumor is diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma with mixed type I and II patterns, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, and measures 9 x 6 x 4.5 cm. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with no evidence of vascular or perinephric tissue invasion, and the surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additionally, the fat overlying the tumor and the tumor base biopsy show no malignancy, confirming the benign nature of those specimens.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the peritoneum and perigastric lymph node is negative for tumor. In the liver, a grade 3 cholangiocarcinoma was identified as a single mass measuring 11.0 x 10.3 x 6.6 cm, confined to the hepatic parenchyma with negative margins and no evidence of major vessel invasion or lymph node metastasis.
