Additionally, a bile duct hamartoma was noted in the surgical material.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade papillary renal cell carcinoma (type 1) in the right kidney, with a tumor measuring 4.4 cm that is confined to the kidney and shows no lymphovascular invasion or positive margins. Cytogenetic analysis reveals an abnormal karyotype with multiple numerical chromosome abnormalities, including extra copies of chromosomes 2, 3, 8, 16, 17, and 20, which are associated with papillary renal cell carcinoma. The uninvolved kidney tissue shows scattered globally sclerotic glomeruli, and no lymph nodes were identified in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segment 4, with a background of cirrhosis. The tumor measures 2.8 cm and is classified as AJCC Stage pT1, with no evidence of vascular invasion or regional lymph node involvement. The parenchymal margin is uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, with a distance of 5 mm from the closest margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor measuring 4.7 x 3.2 x 1.7 cm located in the posterior and right lateral uterine wall, invading 0.3 cm into the myometrium, but not involving the endocervix or showing lymphovascular invasion. All surgical resection margins are negative for tumor, and there is an intramural leiomyoma and evidence of endometriosis on the posterior uterine serosa and cul de sac. Additionally, multiple pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes excised are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left frontal lesion diagnosed as high-grade glioma, most consistent with anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade III), based on both biopsy and resection specimens. Microscopic examination revealed a pink-tan focally hemorrhagic brain tissue with no discrete nodules identified. Additionally, fluorescence in-situ hybridization (FISH) analysis showed deletions of both 1p and 19q, which suggests a favorable prognosis for the patient.

The pathology report indicates the presence of oligodendroglial features with single mitoses observed. There is a focal increase in proliferation, reaching up to 10%. The final diagnosis is oligodendroglioma, classified as WHO grade II.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (Nottingham grade 3) in the left breast, measuring 1.7 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising 40% of the tumor volume and lymphovascular invasion present. One out of twenty-eight examined lymph nodes is positive for carcinoma, with a metastatic size of 1.9 cm, while seven additional lymph nodes are negative for tumor. The surgical margins are negative for invasive tumor, and the invasive tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, with weak positivity for HER2/NEU.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating multifocal and multicentric ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 2.5 by 2.0 by 3.5 cm, with ductal carcinoma in situ comprising approximately 20% of the tumor volume. Estrogen and progesterone receptors are both positive, while HER-2/neu is weakly positive, with a Nottingham score of 6/9. Additionally, four out of six lymph nodes are positive for metastatic tumor, with two showing extracapsular spread, and all resection margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma (Grade III) in the left breast, measuring 3.0 cm, with extensive necrosis and minimal high-grade in-situ component. There is evidence of lymphovascular space invasion, and the tumor is located within 1 mm of the deep surgical margin. Hormonal receptor testing shows the tumor is negative for estrogen receptors and focally positive for progesterone receptors, with HER2/neu status being negative.

The pathology report indicates that the right axillary sentinel lymph nodes #1, #2, and #3 are negative for malignancy, while the right breast mastectomy reveals a mixed epithelial/mesenchymal metaplastic carcinoma (carcinosarcoma) with a histologic grade of 3 and a tumor size of 2.5 cm, along with a separate adenoid cystic carcinoma. The margins of the excised breast tissue are negative for invasive carcinoma, and the lymph nodes show no evidence of metastasis. Hormone receptor status shows the metaplastic carcinoma is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 is negative.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the gastric stump, measuring 1.5 cm, with neoplasia confined to the mucosa and lamina propria, and no evidence of vascular or perineural invasion. A smaller 0.5 cm fundic gland polyp with reactive changes was also noted, alongside active chronic moderate gastritis in the adjacent gastric mucosa. All 24 dissected perigastric lymph nodes were uninvolved by neoplasia, and the surgical margins, as well as the gallbladder and spleen, showed no signs of neoplastic infiltration.

The cervical biopsy reveals a diagnosis of large cell, non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma with stromal invasion, classified as grade II. There is no evidence of vascular space invasion noted in the report. The specimen consisted of two irregular portions of tissue submitted for analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the prostate, with a Gleason score of 7/10, and tumor presence limited to less than 5% of the distal right posterior segment. There is no evidence of extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, lymphovascular invasion, or high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia. Additionally, bilateral pelvic lymph nodes were excised and found to be negative for metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade pleomorphic undifferentiated sarcoma in a scalp mass, with positive immunostains for SMA and focal positivity for p63, while being negative for several other markers. The tumor measures 2.2 cm in greatest dimension and has positive deep margins, with a high mitotic rate of 44 per 10 high-power fields. No necrosis or lymph-vascular invasion was identified, and the tumor is classified as pT1a, indicating it is superficial and 5 cm or less in size.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the floor of the mouth, measuring 6.5 cm, with involvement of the mandibular bone and skin, and evidence of lymphatic invasion, but no perineural invasion. All surgical margins, including mucosal, cutaneous, and bony margins, are free of carcinoma, and no tumor was found in the examined lymph nodes. The pathological stage is classified as pT4a, with a total of 51 regional lymph nodes examined, all of which were benign.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the endocervix, measuring 6.5 x 4 x 1.5 cm, with extension to the exocervix but no evidence of venous invasion or positive lymph node metastasis. The endometrium shows hypoplasia with reactive metaplasia, while the ovaries and fallopian tubes appear normal. Overall, the tumor margins are uninvolved, and there are no indications of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates a 6 x 6 x 6 cm poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the lung, with tumor extension to the visceral pleura. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/6 positive). Additional findings include positive staining for CK7, CD15, and TTF-1, while CK10 and P63 are negative.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen from the antrum, revealing an ulcerating adenocarcinoma measuring 16 x 12 x 5 cm, classified as moderately differentiated. The extent of invasion, lymph node involvement, and margins are not specified in the report. No additional pathologic findings or comments were provided.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes from various levels of the neck, with a total of 8 out of 34 lymph nodes examined showing involvement. Additionally, a right hemiglossectomy revealed a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, with negative margins. No tumor was identified in several other lymph nodes examined, indicating a mixed involvement pattern.

The pathology report indicates that a left adrenalectomy was performed on a mass measuring 9 x 9.5 x 9.5 cm and weighing 404 grams. The diagnosis is adrenocortical carcinoma, classified as grade 2. This suggests a moderately differentiated tumor with potential for aggressive behavior.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast specimen shows infiltrating ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated (Nottingham grade 2), measuring 2.0 cm, with clear margins and no lymphovascular invasion identified. Additionally, ductal carcinoma in situ (high nuclear grade) is present in a small portion of the tissue, but margins are free of DCIS. All examined sentinel and non-sentinel lymph nodes show no evidence of carcinoma, with immunohistochemistry results pending for some nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, based on excisional biopsies from both the left frontal and left occipital regions of the brain. The report notes varying degrees of tumor necrosis and high cellularity across multiple samples, with significant immunohistochemical findings suggesting potential responsiveness to Temodar and EGFR kinase inhibitors. Additionally, the presence of activated pMAPK indicates a relative resistance to radiation therapy, highlighting the aggressive nature of the tumor and the complexity of its treatment.

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy of the left lower lobe revealed a well-differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma measuring 21 cm, with no evidence of tumor at the bronchial margin. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes (levels 5, 9, 10, and 11) showed no evidence of metastasis. The overall diagnosis confirms the presence of a lung lesion consistent with mucinous adenocarcinoma, while regional lymph nodes were uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates that all sentinel lymph nodes examined from the left axilla and left neck are negative for melanoma, with a total of six nodes assessed showing no evidence of metastasis. The melanoma excised from the left deltoid shoulder shows residual malignant melanoma with a maximum tumor thickness of 2.3 mm and is classified as pT3b, but the resection margins are negative for invasive melanoma. The overall pathologic staging reveals no regional lymph node involvement (pN0) and no distant metastasis (MX).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the oral cavity, with the tumor measuring 7.0 cm and involving the mandible, floor of mouth, and adjacent soft tissues, along with perineural invasion but no lymphatic or vascular invasion. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma is present in 18 of 34 right neck lymph nodes and 1 of 21 left neck lymph nodes, with extensive extranodal invasion noted in the right neck. Resection margins are negative for tumor, although they are close to the tumor, and an addendum report is pending regarding decalcified sections of the mandible.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma in the left partial glossectomy specimen, characterized by extensive perineural invasion and the presence of vascular and lymphatic invasion, with a tumor thickness of 1.3 cm and close proximity to the deep margin. All examined margins, including the superior, anterior tongue, inferior floor of mouth, and posterior tonsillar pillar, show squamous mucosa with no tumor present. The gross description notes a central ulcer within the specimen, but the mucosa and deep skeletal muscle margin are grossly uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma with a focal sarcomatoid pattern in the bladder, specifically located at the right and left trigone, measuring 7 cm in size. No carcinoma was detected in the left and right distal ureter margins or in the examined pelvic lymph nodes, with a total of 9 lymph nodes showing no involvement. The tumor is classified as pT3a, with lymphatic and blood vessel invasion observed, but no tumor was found at the surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates a 4.2 cm moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the mid third of the esophagus, with tumor invasion through the submucosa and no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion. Out of 13 regional lymph nodes examined, 2 were positive for neoplasia, while the periesophageal lymph node examined was negative. The surgical margins, including the esophageal margin, are uninvolved by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated infiltrating adenocarcinoma at the gastroesophageal junction in a male patient with a history of obesity and gastroesophageal reflux. The tumor has invaded through the entire esophageal wall into the adventitia, with a maximum depth of invasion of 2 cm, and six out of eleven lymph nodes are positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma. The esophageal and gastric resection margins are negative for malignancy, but the deep resection margin is involved.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with endometrial adenocarcinoma, specifically grade 1 endometrioid carcinoma, arising from an endometrial polyp with a size of 5.0 cm and no myometrial invasion. All examined lymph nodes (25 total) from both pelvic and periaortic regions were negative for metastasis, and peritoneal cytology was also negative. Additionally, multiple intramural leiomyomas were noted, and the overall staging is classified as pT1a pNO pMX, indicating stage IA if no metastasis is present.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 5.5 cm thymoma in the thymus gland, which shows minimal microscopic invasion into the adjacent extra-capsular connective tissue, but the external margins are clear of tumor involvement. The adjacent non-neoplastic thymus exhibits involutional changes consistent with the patient's age and no significant lymphoid hyperplasia. Overall, the examination suggests a complete resection of the thymoma, classified as predominantly mixed/cortical type according to WHO criteria.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 3.8 cm, with associated lobular carcinoma in situ comprising approximately 5% of the tumor mass. The sentinel lymph node from the left axilla showed no evidence of tumor, and all margins from the lumpectomy were negative for invasive carcinoma. Additional findings include fibrocystic changes in non-neoplastic breast tissue and a favorable Ki-67 proliferation index of less than 10%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma in the gastric stump resection, primarily of the intestinal type with some focal areas of the diffuse type, showing infiltration into the surrounding fatty tissue and lymphangitis. There are two lymph node metastases identified out of 15 examined, while five additional lymph nodes were tumor-free. The tumor classification is mucinous adenocarcinoma, staged as pT3 N1 (2/20) L1 V0 R0, indicating tumor invasion and lymph node involvement but clear resection margins.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a partial liver resection revealing moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with clear cell and giant cell features, measuring 3.5 cm, and the margins are negative for malignancy. Additionally, the gallbladder specimen showed a benign simple cyst with minimal chronic inflammation and no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy. The background liver is non-cirrhotic and without apparent fibrosis, and there is no lymphovascular invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 2.4 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a lobectomy specimen from the right upper lung, revealing a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3 x 2.5 x 2 cm. Details regarding tumor extent, other tumor nodules, lymph nodes, lymphatic and venous invasion, and margins are not specified. There is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated endocervical adenocarcinoma, with tumor invasion noted throughout the tissue section and at least 5 mm deep. Lymphovascular space invasion is present, but perineural invasion is not identified. Immunostaining results show that the tumor cells are positive for p16 and negative for vimentin and estrogen receptors, consistent with an endocervical primary.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a ciliochoroidal malignant melanoma of the right eye, measuring 15 mm in basal diameter and 7.5 mm in thickness, with invasion into the peripheral anterior chamber and trabecular meshwork. There is also evidence of partial retinal detachment and cataract formation associated with the tumor. The tumor is classified as T3b, NX, MO according to the TMN classification system.

The pathology report describes two segments of brain tissue weighing 11g, which show signs of a neuroepithelial neoplasm infiltrating the neocortex. Microscopic examination reveals characteristics consistent with oligodendroglioma grade II, including rounded nuclei with granular chromatin and clear cytoplasm, without atypical mitosis or necrosis. The diagnosis indicates an excision product from a lesion in the left insular region, classified as oligodendroglioma grade II according to WHO criteria.

The pathology report indicates that a portion of the 6th rib and multiple lymph nodes (L9, level 7, inferior pulmonary vein, and level 5) show no evidence of tumor. However, the left lung specimen reveals keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma grade II, measuring 2.5 cm, with negative margins and no involvement of peribronchial lymph nodes. The final diagnosis categorizes the lung cancer as PT2N0, indicating a localized tumor without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the right inferior parathyroid tissue confirmed the presence of parathyroid tissue. A total thyroidectomy revealed a 1.1 cm papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, follicular variant, located in the superior right lobe, which extends to the surgical margin but shows no lymphatic invasion. The tumor appears well-circumscribed, but adjacent soft tissue was not available for evaluation of potential extension beyond the thyroid.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) following a partial hepatectomy of the liver. The tumor is characterized by a well-defined mass with a trabecular histologic type and shows no evidence of invasion at the surgical margins, with a safety margin of 1.0 cm. Additionally, the liver exhibits steatohepatitis with mild steatosis and periportal fibrosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent an esophagectomy, revealing an 8.2 cm invasive adenocarcinoma at the esophagogastric junction, with lymph-vascular and perineural invasion present. Among the examined lymph nodes, one high paratracheal lymph node was positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the other lymph nodes showed no evidence of malignancy. Additionally, the gallbladder exhibited chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis but no malignancy was found in any of the specimens.

The pathology report indicates the presence of FIGO grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma in the uterus, with invasion through more than 50% of the myometrium and focal lymph-vascular invasion, but no invasion into the cervix. All examined lymph nodes from the left pelvic, right pelvic, and periaortic regions are negative for malignancy, and the fallopian tubes and ovaries also show no signs of cancer. Additionally, leiomyomas are noted in the uterus, but they are not malignant.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lymph node from the left neck shows diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, non-cleaved type, consistent with a non-GCB subtype. Flow cytometry analysis reveals a population of mature B-cells, suggesting an intermediate to high-grade B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder. Correlation with morphologic studies is necessary for definitive classification, and additional testing has been performed to support the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen from the body of the stomach, revealing an exophytic adenocarcinoma measuring 3.0x4.0x1.0 cm. The tumor is well differentiated and has invaded the muscularis propria. Details regarding lymph nodes, margins, and invasion are not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma involving both the right and left ovaries, with tumor infiltration into the ovarian parenchyma and surface, as well as metastatic involvement of the fallopian tubes and extensive metastatic disease in the omentum. The uterus shows evidence of metastatic serous carcinoma with significant lymphovascular invasion, while the endometrium is inactive and chronic inflammation is noted in the cervix. The final staging is classified as T3c/NX/MX, indicating advanced disease with peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma (early gastric cancer) located in the middle third of the stomach, with a tumor size of 3.8 x 2.5 x 2.0 cm and no evidence of serosal invasion. The tumor has been classified as pT1bN0Mx, indicating submucosal invasion without regional lymph node metastasis, as all examined lymph nodes (79 total) were negative for tumor involvement. Additional findings include chronic gastritis and intestinal metaplasia in the stomach, as well as low-grade dysplasia in tubular adenomas of the large intestine.

The pathology report indicates that one of the right axillary sentinel lymph nodes is free of tumor, while the second lymph node shows micrometastatic adenocarcinoma. The right total mastectomy reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 2.7 x 2.5 x 2.4 cm, with a Nottingham score of 9/9 and extensive lymphovascular invasion, alongside ductal carcinoma in situ comprising about 5% of the tumor volume. Resection margins, nipple, and skin are free of tumor, and immunohistochemical staining results are pending for further characterization.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in both right and left pelvic lymph nodes, with five of nine nodes on the right and three of eleven on the left showing metastatic foci, along with extranodal extension. Additionally, prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5) is reported, exhibiting extensive multifocal extraprostatic extension and invasion of the right seminal vesicle, with carcinoma extending to the margin of resection. The anterior bladder neck margin is also positive for poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, indicating significant disease involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the right pelvic lymph nodes are benign with no evidence of tumor, while the left pelvic lymph nodes contained only fibroadipose tissue with no lymph nodes or carcinoma identified. The prostate specimen shows prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7, involving both lobes and approximately 50% of the gland parenchyma, with perineural invasion noted. The pathological staging is T3a, N0, Mx, confirming the presence of cancer in the prostate but no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a high-grade urothelial carcinoma with sarcomatoid differentiation, extensively involving most tissue fragments. The tumor is characterized by multiple irregular fragments of white-tan soft tissue, measuring 2.0 x 2.0 x 0.8 cm in aggregate. Additionally, there is evidence of urothelial carcinoma in situ present.

The pathology report indicates that a 3.5 cm invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma was found in the rectosigmoid region, with infiltration into the subserosa and focal involvement of the radial margin by carcinoma. One out of thirteen lymph nodes examined was positive for carcinoma, while the proximal and distal margins were negative for cancer. The proximal and distal donut excisions showed benign colonic-type mucosa with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the breast tissue, measuring 1.5 cm, with a histologic grade of 2 and moderately differentiated nuclear grade, and invasive carcinoma is noted at the inked surgical margin. No tumor was identified in the examined axillary lymph nodes, which included one node from the apex and eighteen from the axillary dissection. The tumor exhibits large atypical cells with some cribriform intraductal components, but there is no evidence of vascular invasion or significant inflammatory response.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 5 cm in greatest diameter, with Fuhrman Grade I of IV. The tumor is focally adherent to the capsule but shows no invasion through the capsule or into blood vessels. The pathological stage is classified as pT1b, NX, MX, indicating Stage I disease.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the antrum of the stomach, characterized by an ulcerated and annular tumor. The tumor has metastasized to all 14 examined lymph nodes, with involvement of adjacent structures, specifically the lesser omentum. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates a tumor in the right lower lobe of the lung measuring 3.7 x 2.8 x 3.0 cm, diagnosed as mixed subtype adenocarcinoma with components of papillary, acinar, and mucinous types. There is evidence of infiltration into the parietal pleura, classified as pT3, with no regional lymph node involvement (0/42) and unknown distant metastasis (pMx). The tumor is graded as G2, indicating moderate differentiation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated leiomyosarcoma (Grade 3) in a uterine mass measuring 29.0 cm, with no involvement of the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes. The tumor exhibits lymph-vascular invasion and necrosis, with a mitotic rate of 16/10 high power fields. Additional findings include no tumor involvement in the appendix or right aortic lymph nodes, and the presence of tumor cells in blood coagulum adherent to the external surface of the appendix.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant melanoma of the skin located on the trunk, with a Breslow's depth of 5 mm. The tumor measures 0.7 x 0 x 1.2 cm and is pigmented, with uninvolved margins and no evidence of venous invasion. Additional details regarding satellite nodules, lymph nodes, and neo-adjuvant treatment were not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the lung following lobectomy, with surgical margins free of tumor and focal vascular invasion present. The bronchial margin is negative for tumor, and three bronchopulmonary nodes examined are also negative. Additionally, the rib lobectomy and the innominate lymph node biopsy show no evidence of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2 N1 M0, indicating a primary tumor with regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. Additionally, a normal blood sample was obtained, which does not indicate any abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly-differentiated thyroid carcinoma with a papillary component, measuring 2.7 cm, located in the isthmus, with no extrathyroidal extension or lymphovascular invasion, and negative margins. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in one lymph node out of one examined, and five out of eighteen lymph nodes show bilateral metastatic involvement. The report also notes extensive chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and hypercellular parathyroid tissue in the biopsies, with no tumors present in the parathyroid samples.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of large peripheral bronchopulmonary mixed adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, characterized by acinar and solid components with a partially bronchioloalveolar pattern of spread. Additionally, a small non-mucinous bronchioloalveolar carcinoma is noted peripherally in segment S6. The TNM classification is pT2(2) pNO pMX R0, indicating stage IB disease.

The pathology report indicates a lobectomy specimen from the lung, revealing a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 6.5 x 5.5 x 5.5 cm. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/6 positive), and details regarding tumor extent, margins, and invasion are unspecified. Additional comments suggest discrepancies in the classification, but the malignancy has been validated.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 3.0 cm, with associated extensive duct carcinoma in situ and a Nottingham histologic grading score of 7. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 2 out of 13 examined axillary lymph nodes, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 4 mm, and no extranodal extension was identified. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive estrogen and progesterone receptor status, while HER-2-NEU was negative, and the margins from the mastectomy were clear of invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, grade 3, measuring 11 cm in diameter, with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or extracapsular extension, and negative surgical margins. The tumor is confined to the kidney, affecting both the upper and lower poles, and shows areas of necrosis and hemorrhage. The patient underwent a laparoscopic nephrectomy, and no additional significant findings or lymph nodes were identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two colonic adenocarcinomas: a high-grade tumor measuring 6.4 cm in the cecum and a low-grade tumor measuring 7.8 cm in the ascending colon, both invading through the muscularis propria (pT3). Lymphovascular invasion is noted, with metastases identified in 2 out of 18 examined regional lymph nodes (pN1b), while the resection margins are free of carcinoma. Additional findings include two tubular adenomas, and no prior treatment was administered.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon following a right hemicolectomy. The tumor was found to have infiltrated the perimuscular fatty tissue but exhibited tumor-free resection margins and no evidence of local lymph node metastasis. The tumor is classified as grade 3 (G3), with a pathological stage of pT3 and no lymphovascular invasion (V0) or residual tumor (R0), and 0 out of 17 lymph nodes showing metastasis (pNO).

The pathology report describes a 9.5x7.5x3.5 cm thymoma located in the mediastinum, characterized as a WHO type B2 thymoma with some areas exhibiting type B1 features. Histological examination reveals a lobular tumor rich in epithelial and lymphoid cells, with moderate thymitis and infiltration of mediastinal fat, classified as Masaoka stage II. There is no discrepancy between the histology of the frozen section and the paraffin section.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a benign pheochromocytoma in the left adrenal gland, characterized by a finely encapsulated tumor with a honeycomb structure of large polygonal cells and a prominent vascular network. Two fragments of the tumor were analyzed, with the largest measuring 4 x 2.7 x 2 cm, and no evidence of vascular or capsule invasion, necrosis, or significant mitotic activity was observed. The findings suggest a well-differentiated tumor with a PASS score of 0, indicating a low risk of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the pelvic peritoneum, ovaries, fallopian tubes, cervix, and appendix, with evidence of metastasis. The tumors extensively replace ovarian parenchyma and invade surrounding structures, including the cervix and periappendiceal tissue. Additionally, benign endometrial polyps were noted in the uterus, but the myometrium and uterine serosa appeared unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic ductal carcinoma in one lymph node and residual infiltrating carcinoma in the right breast, with a tumor size of 6.4 x 5.2 x 2.5 cm. The carcinoma is classified as nuclear grade 3 and histologic grade 3, with evidence of lymphatic and vascular invasion, and direct invasion into the nipple and skin. Estrogen receptor activity is positive, while progesterone receptor activity is negative, and there is focal involvement of the lateral surgical margin by infiltrating carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lymph nodes from the lower paratracheal and subcarinal regions showed no significant pathologic changes, while the inferior pulmonary ligament lymph node exhibited follicular hyperplasia and the intrapulmonary lymph node contained a calcified fibrous nodule. A bilobectomy of the right middle and lower lung revealed poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 6 cm, with the bronchial margin free of tumor, and there were no significant changes in the right lobar/intralobar lymph node. Additionally, a biopsy of the right upper lobe showed mild emphysema with respiratory bronchiolitis, and the myocardium biopsy revealed fibrous adhesions.

The pathology report indicates a 3 cm adenocarcinoma located in the right upper lobe of the lung, characterized by angiolymphatic invasion but without visceral pleural invasion, and all examined lymph nodes are negative for carcinoma. The tumor is classified as pT1bN0, with a moderately differentiated histologic grade (G2) and a negative surgical margin of 2.5 cm. Molecular testing revealed a KRAS G12A mutation, while tests for EGFR mutations and ALK rearrangement were negative.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing chronic cholecystitis with cholesterolosis, and lymph nodes excised were negative for tumor. A partial hepatectomy of the right liver identified a grade 3 cholangiocarcinoma with a solid mass and a separate nodule, confined to the liver and extending to the resection margin, but without major vessel invasion or microscopic invasion. Additionally, a wedge biopsy of a segment II liver nodule showed a bile duct hamartoma.

The pathology report indicates that two lymph nodes from the superior mediastinum were resected and found to be negative for malignancy. The anterior mediastinal tumor and thymus gland were diagnosed with a type AB thymoma, measuring 6.4 cm, with evidence of microscopic transcapsular invasion and no lymph-vascular invasion or regional lymph node metastases. The tumor is classified as modified Masaoka stage IIa, and the margins are uninvolved by tumor, with additional findings of age-appropriate involutional changes and focal infarction/necrosis within the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm and multiple foci of invasive carcinoma present. The tumor has invaded the skin, including the dermis and epidermis, and is associated with Paget's disease of the nipple, while the margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Pathologic staging classifies the primary tumor as pT4b, with regional lymph nodes not identified (pNX).

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma of the stomach (cardia) with extensive mucinous differentiation and signet ring cells, measuring 10.5 x 6.8 cm, and infiltrating the wall into the perigastric adipose tissue. There is evidence of perineural and angiolymphatic invasion, with compromised gastric resection margins and metastasis found in multiple lymph nodes across different chains. The esophageal margin, accessory spleen, and fragments of pancreatic and omental tissues are free of neoplasia, indicating no tumor presence in those areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma with areas of necrosis, measuring 7 x 4.5 x 4 cm, following a radical resection of a caval tumor. The surgical margins are negative, but the tumor is close to the vein, with one adjacent lymph node involved by the tumor, while four additional lymph nodes show no evidence of disease. The report confirms that the diagnosis is based on a thorough examination of the submitted specimens.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two types of renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney: a conventional clear cell carcinoma (2.2 cm, nuclear grade II/IV) and a papillary type 1 carcinoma (1.1 cm). Both tumors are confined to the kidney with no evidence of local or renal vein invasion, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, two non-neoplastic "papillary tubular adenomas" were identified in the kidney, and the overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is pT1.

The pathology report indicates that the left eye enucleation specimen reveals a diagnosis of malignant melanoma, mixed cell type, with involvement of the ciliary body but no extrascleral extension. The tumor measures 1.4 x 1.3 x 0.9 cm and shows a mitotic rate of 6 mitoses per 10 high power fields, with light pigmentation and scattered intratumoral lymphocytes. Pathologic staging is classified as pT3b due to ciliary body involvement, and there is no evidence of vascular invasion or involvement of regional lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of squamous cell carcinoma in the deep paraspinal muscles and anterior scalene muscle, with the tumor in the floor of the mouth measuring 1.2 cm and moderately differentiated. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma is identified in multiple lymph nodes across various levels of the left neck, with extracapsular extension noted in some nodes. Other examined tissues, including the left inferior alveolus, various oral cavity sites, and several lymph nodes, were negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that two specimens from a right occipital brain lesion were analyzed following a craniotomy for a suspected brain tumor. Microscopic examination revealed features consistent with glioblastoma multiforme, characterized by astrocytic cells with marked atypia, numerous mitoses, vascular changes, and necrosis. The final diagnosis for both specimens is glioblastoma multiforme.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a mixed germ cell tumor consisting of 80% seminoma and 20% choriocarcinoma, with the tumor measuring 3 cm and exhibiting areas of necrosis and hemorrhage. The tumor is confined to the testes, with no invasion of the epididymis, although lymphovascular invasion is noted, and surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, there is evidence of intratubular germ cell neoplasia and atrophy in the seminiferous tubules, with spermatogenesis present.

The pathology report indicates a fresh frozen sample from an endometrial mass, diagnosed as endometrioid adenocarcinoma, not otherwise specified (NOS), with a grade of III. The tumor measures approximately 3.8 cm and is classified as pathological T1b, with no lymph nodes sampled but 21 nodes positive for cancer. The sample was collected 27 days prior to diagnosis following a surgical resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates that the right sentinel lymph nodes 1, 2, and 4 show no evidence of metastatic mammary carcinoma, while sentinel lymph node 3 contains a metastatic infiltrating duct carcinoma measuring 4.0 mm. The total mastectomy reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma with a Nottingham grade of 1, measuring 1.2 cm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ and lobular carcinoma in situ. Additionally, there is no lymphovascular space invasion, but the invasive carcinoma extends focally to the anterior margin, and atypical ductal and lobular hyperplasia are also noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) in the left breast, with a histologic grade of III and a size of 2.5 cm, alongside ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising less than 25% of the tumor mass. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in two out of three sentinel lymph nodes, while the remaining lymph nodes in levels I and II of the left axilla were benign. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive estrogen and progesterone receptor status, with negative HER2 results.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 4 astrocytoma in the right frontal lobe, characterized by fibrillary, gemistocytic, and small cell features. Immunoperoxidase studies revealed that 40-60% of the cells were positive for the MIB-1 antigen, supporting the diagnosis. Preliminary frozen section consultations confirmed the presence of glioma with astrocytic features in the biopsy, while additional excisions are pending permanent section analysis.

The pathology report indicates that the right upper lobe resection revealed moderately to poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma, with negative bronchial and pulmonary margins. The right middle lobe nodule showed elastosis and chronic inflammation, but was negative for malignancy. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from various levels showed no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with a tumor diameter of 8 cm. The distance to the dorsal resection margin is less than 0.1 cm, suggesting close proximity to the margin. The tumor classification is noted as NOS, G II, pT3LOVORX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of monophasic synovial sarcoma in the right distal thigh and popliteal region, with the tumor measuring 4.2 cm and exhibiting vascular invasion, a mitotic rate of 15/10 HPF, and approximately 5% necrosis. The tumor is noted to encase a 0.5 cm diameter artery, but the surgical margins are widely free of tumor. Additionally, the report confirms the diagnosis based on histological examination and immunohistochemical staining, with further molecular analysis for the SYT-SSX fusion transcript pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left breast cancer, confirmed through a left radical modified mastectomy, which revealed infiltrating duct and intraductal carcinoma with poor nuclear grade and associated microcalcifications. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and all examined axillary lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive estrogen receptor (70%) and progesterone receptor (90%) expression, while HER-2/NEU is negative.

The pathology report indicates that both the left and right pelvic lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement, with a total of six lymph nodes examined. The prostate specimen shows prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, limited to the prostate and involving less than 10% of the tissue, with perineural invasion but no angiolymphatic invasion or extraprosthetic extension. Additionally, the left and right seminal vesicles and vas deferens are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of type AB thymoma from an excised thymus, with negative resection margins and no malignancy found in three examined lymph nodes. The tumor is characterized by a heterogeneous composition, predominantly featuring spindled epithelial cells and immature lymphocytes, consistent with a type B2 thymoma. Additionally, the report notes that there is evidence of tumor invasion into the capsule and possible vascular involvement, classifying it as a Masaoka stage II lesion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the cardia of the stomach, measuring 6 x 6 x 1.2 cm. The tumor has metastasized to 5 out of 9 examined lymph nodes, with involvement of adjacent structures including the esophagus and lesser omentum. There are no specified details regarding lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion, and the margins of the specimen are not mentioned.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant mixed Mllerian tumor of the endometrium with rhabdomyoblastic and cartilaginous components, invading up to half of the myometrium with a maximum thickness of 3.5 mm. All examined lymph nodes from various regions, including para-aortic and iliac nodes, were found to be benign, with no evidence of metastatic disease. Additional findings include atrophy of the endometrium, leiomyomas in the myometrium, and paratubal cysts in the left fallopian tube, while other adnexal structures were unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with invasive moderately-differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, with perineural invasion and extrapancreatic extension, as well as pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) grade 3. The mesenteric nodule and lymph node examined were both negative for malignancy, and the gallbladder showed chronic cholecystitis. The tumor extends beyond the pancreas but does not involve major vascular structures, with all examined lymph nodes showing no evidence of metastasis.

The histopathological examination of the left breast reveals an invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 3.9 x 6.6 x 2.8 cm, with metastases found in 11 out of 13 axillary lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical analysis shows estrogen receptors in 75% and progesterone receptors in 10% of neoplastic cell nuclei, while HER2 testing indicates a score of 2+ with no gene amplification detected by FISH. The tumor is classified as NHG2, pT3, pN3a, indicating a moderate grade and advanced stage of cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diffusely infiltrating oligodendroglioma in the right temporal lobe, characterized by a low proliferation index of 3% and lacking anaplastic features, classified as WHO grade II. Genetic testing revealed positive allelic loss on chromosome arm 19q, while no loss was detected on chromosome 1p, which is consistent with typical findings in oligodendrogliomas. Additionally, there was no evidence of methylated MGMT promoter, suggesting that the patient may not benefit from alkylating agent therapy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of primary oligodendroglioma in a Caucasian male, with the tumor located in the left brain. The tumor tissue was processed in an OCT block, weighing 200 mg, and no treatment has been administered. Additionally, a blood sample was collected, which is reported as normal.

The pathology report indicates that a total thyroidectomy was performed due to a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, follicular variant, located in the right lobe, measuring 6.5 cm with focal capsular invasion but no vascular or extrathyroid extension. The Delphian lymph node excised during the procedure was found to be benign, with no evidence of malignancy. Surgical margins were clear of tumor, and the remaining thyroid tissue exhibited mild nodular hyperplasia.

The histopathological examination of the right breast reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma (NHG3) measuring 3.5 x 2.5 x 2.0 cm, with significant vascular invasion and metastases in axillary lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical analysis shows over 75% positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 gene amplification was not found. The diagnosis indicates a pT2, pN2a classification, highlighting the aggressive nature of the tumor and its spread to lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral papillary thyroid carcinoma with two foci measuring 4.5 cm and 0.4 cm, the largest being an encapsulated follicular variant located in the right lobe. The cancer is confined to the thyroid with no evidence of capsular or angiolymphatic invasion, and the pathological stage is classified as pT3, pN0. Additionally, the left superior parathyroid gland is slightly enlarged but shows normocellular characteristics, with no involvement of regional lymph nodes or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma at the right base of the tongue. Immunohistochemical studies reveal strong p16 positivity, while HPV testing shows the presence of HPV-16. The specimen was submitted for further analysis, and the findings were reviewed by the attending pathologist.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the cul de sac, left pelvic peritoneum, sigmoid tumor, and retrocecal area, with high-grade papillary serous carcinoma identified in the uterus and bilateral adnexa. Lymph nodes sampled from the right and left pelvic regions show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, although there are aggregates of carcinoma cells in perinodal fat. Additional findings include benign lesions such as leiomyomas and endometrial polyps, alongside various reactive changes in the endometrium and cervix.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma from a biopsy of the right occipital lobe, with a MIB-1 labeling index of approximately 20%. The gross examination revealed multiple tissue fragments measuring 0.8 to 0.6 cm, and microscopic analysis showed characteristics typical of a high-grade glioma, including hypercellularity, pleomorphism, mitotic figures, vascular hyperplasia, and significant necrosis. The intraoperative consultation confirmed the presence of a glioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma, measuring 9 cm, in the right testis following a right radical orchiectomy. There is evidence of lymphovascular invasion in small vessels, but no invasion of the epididymis, and the tumor is confined to the testis with free margins. Additionally, the testicular tissue shows tubular atrophy and lacks evidence of spermatogenesis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, with the largest tumor mass measuring 43mm and additional smaller lesions identified. The tumors were completely excised with a margin of at least 14mm from the surgical margin, and there is no evidence of capsular breach or peritoneal involvement. The background liver shows established bridging fibrosis and moderate macrovesicular steatosis, consistent with early cirrhosis.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph node is negative for metastatic carcinoma. The left breast tissue biopsy reveals the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma with a histologic grade of 3, but the margins are negative for malignancy. Additionally, there is focal ductal carcinoma in situ present, and no definitive vessel invasion is identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 5.4 x 4.0 x 1.4 cm invasive adenocarcinoma located at the gastroesophageal junction, with invasion into the muscularis propria. Out of 12 examined lymph nodes, 6 showed metastatic adenocarcinoma, but the resection margins were free of cancer. The frozen section analysis confirmed the diagnosis of carcinoma, and there is no evidence of distant metastasis noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), located in the right upper lobe, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm. The tumor is classified as Grade III and is staged as T3, with no evidence of metastasis (M0). The sample was obtained through a resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix, with a maximum stromal invasion thickness of 19 mm and evidence of focal lymphovascular space invasion. No tumor was identified in multiple lymph nodes sampled, and the surgical margins from the radical hysterectomy were free of cancer involvement. Additional findings include associated cervicitis, leiomyomata in the myometrium, and various benign changes in the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a resected ileocolic sample revealing an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of colorectal type, measuring 7 cm, with extensive involvement of the cecum and significant infiltration into surrounding fatty tissue. There are 14 local lymph node metastases identified, but the small and large intestine, mesenteric resection margin, and appendix are tumor-free. The tumor is staged as pT4 pN2 (14/28) pM1, indicating advanced disease with clinical liver metastases.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade II, with multiple microscopic foci of microinvasion and a maximum myometrial invasion thickness of 1.0 mm. All examined lymph nodes from various regions, including the left and right obturator, common iliac, and para-aortic nodes, were found to be benign with no evidence of metastatic disease. Additional findings include complex hyperplasia with atypia in the endometrium, adenomyosis, and leiomyomas in the myometrium, as well as an epithelial inclusion cyst in the right ovary.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation in one of six right pelvic lymph nodes, while the right distal ureter and left pelvic lymph nodes show no tumor. A cystoprostatectomy reveals high-grade urothelial carcinoma of the bladder with extensive squamous differentiation, invasive into the outer half of the muscularis propria, and multifocal carcinoma in situ. All resection margins are negative for tumor, and the prostate shows high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left upper outer quadrant of the breast, with a tumor size of 2.1 x 1.8 x 1.4 cm. The tumor is moderately differentiated (Grade II) with a Nottingham Histologic Score of 6-7, and one out of 17 sentinel lymph nodes shows positive for metastasis without extracapsular invasion. The surgical margins are uninvolved, suggesting complete resection of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.8 cm in the left upper lobe, with associated angiolymphatic invasion but no visceral pleural invasion. All sampled lymph nodes were found to be benign, and surgical margins were clear of invasive tumor. The pathologic stage is classified as T2aN0Mx, and additional genetic testing for EGFR and ALK rearrangements returned negative results.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated follicular variant papillary thyroid carcinoma, measuring 1.1 cm, located in the right lobe of the thyroid, with negative margins and no evidence of capsular or vascular invasion. Lymph node dissections from levels III and VI revealed no neoplastic involvement, with a total of 13 lymph nodes examined from the right side showing no positive nodes. The report confirms that the carcinoma is confined to the thyroid without extrathyroidal extension or lymph node metastases.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas, measuring 3 cm, with focal involvement of the uncinate margin and metastatic carcinoma found in 3 of 18 lymph nodes. The remaining surgical margins are negative for tumor, and there is no definitive lymphovascular invasion, although focal perineural invasion is noted. Additionally, chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis were identified in the gallbladder, with one unremarkable lymph node and no dysplasia.

The pathology report indicates a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, measuring 4 cm, located near the bronchus. Two subcarinal lymph nodes were examined, both of which were negative for metastasis, and there was no evidence of venous invasion or involvement of surgical margins. The tumor is classified as localized with indeterminate features, and there are no indications of prior neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.7 cm, with negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes, including sentinel and non-sentinel nodes, were negative for malignancy. Additionally, the tumor is strongly positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 is not amplified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right colon, with the tumor invading through the muscularis propria into the surrounding fat (pT3). Metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in 2 out of 28 examined lymph nodes (pN1b), while the resection margins were negative for carcinoma. Additionally, the appendix showed evidence of endometriosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right colon, measuring 11.8 cm, with neuroendocrine and signet ring cell features, and evidence of focal mucin production. The tumor has invaded through the muscularis propria and involved the visceral peritoneum, with lymphovascular invasion noted, while one out of thirty-two lymph nodes examined shows metastatic carcinoma. Resection margins are free of tumor, and additional findings include fibrous obliteration of the appendix and peri-appendiceal adhesions.

The pathology report indicates the presence of grade 3 adenocarcinoma in the right middle lobe and right lower lobe of the lung, with the right middle lobe showing a subpleural mass and pleural invasion, while the right lower lobe has an intraparenchymal mass. Both pleural biopsies and the diaphragm biopsy also reveal invasive grade 3 adenocarcinoma. However, the mediastinal lymph node excision shows no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) in the left cerebral region, characterized by a highly cellular and pleomorphic tumor with mitotic figures, vascular proliferation, and necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis shows that the tumor cells are diffusely GFAP positive, with a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 50%, indicating high proliferation. Additionally, the MGMT promoter methylation status is negative, suggesting that the tumor may not respond to alkylating agent therapy.

The pathology report indicates that the left kidney underwent a radical nephrectomy due to a unifocal renal cell carcinoma of the clear cell type, measuring 8.7 cm and classified as Fuhrman grade III, with no capsular extension or tumor at the surgical margins. Additionally, the 10th rib segment and thirteen regional lymph nodes were examined, both of which were negative for tumor involvement. Cytogenetic analysis revealed a normal karyotype with no detectable chromosomal abnormalities, although this does not rule out the possibility of neoplastic proliferation.

The final pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with mixed subtype in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 1.5 x 1.1 x 0.7 cm, with identified angiolymphatic invasion but no visceral pleural invasion. All examined lymph nodes (totaling 10) were negative for metastatic carcinoma, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. The surgical parenchymal margin is negative for carcinoma, suggesting complete resection of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a mixed germ cell tumor in the left testis, consisting of 50% immature teratoma, 25% endodermal sinus tumor, and 25% embryonal carcinoma. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion, and the spermatic cord and surgical margins are free of neoplasia. However, the rete testis is infiltrated by the neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that multiple excised specimens from the left tongue base, right posterior pharyngeal wall, nasopharyngeal margins, and soft palate are negative for tumor, except for the soft palate which shows ulcerated squamous mucosa with focal high-grade dysplasia. However, a poorly differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the nasopharynx, with metastasis found in 6 of 51 lymph nodes, including evidence of extranodal extension. The primary tumor invades the nasopharynx, with margins uninvolved and perineural invasion present.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the cervix reveals invasive, moderately differentiated, keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. The specimen consisted of irregular gray-white tissue fragments mixed with blood clot, measuring 3.5 x 1.5 x 0.4 cm. The diagnosis is confirmed through microscopic examination by the attending physician.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of grade 1 squamous cell carcinoma of the mid third of the esophagus, measuring 5.3 cm in length and 1.3 cm in depth, with ulceration and infiltration into the mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria, and adventitia. All surgical margins, including the esophageal margin, are free of neoplastic involvement, and no cancer was found in any of the 15 examined lymph nodes. The presence of a mild inflammatory infiltrate is noted, but the overall findings suggest a localized tumor without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were identified in the left and right ureter margins, and no metastatic carcinoma was found in the majority of lymph nodes examined, with the exception of one right external iliac lymph node showing a 1.5 mm metastatic urothelial carcinoma. The bladder specimen revealed a high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma measuring 7.5 cm, with angiolymphatic space invasion present, and it was noted that the ureters were not involved. The overall staging for the bladder primary is classified as pT2b pN1 pMx, with no evidence of carcinoma in the prostate or seminal vesicles.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, primarily located in the lower uterine segment and endocervical canal, with extensive invasion into the myometrial wall and involvement of the cervix. Additionally, endometrioid adenocarcinoma is identified in the posterior vagina, with tumor extension to the resection margins. Lymph node dissection reveals no malignancy in the sampled lymph nodes, and the tumor is staged as pT3b pNO pMX according to AJCC 7th Edition criteria.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with invasion through the muscularis propria into perivesical fat and lymphatic invasion present, while the ureters are involved at the uretero-vesicular junctions. Additionally, prostatic adenocarcinoma is identified in the right lobe with a Gleason score of 3+3, and the right distal urethral margin is positive for this adenocarcinoma. Metastatic urothelial carcinoma is present in the right pelvic lymph nodes (7 out of 10) and one left pelvic lymph node, with no metastatic prostatic adenocarcinoma found in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV, measuring 4.5 cm and extending through the renal capsule but confined within Gerota's fascia, with all surgical margins free of tumor. The adrenal gland shows focal nodular hyperplasia, and three para-aortic lymph nodes examined are benign with no evidence of malignancy. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable, and the renal vein is free of tumor invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a left temporal brain mass excised, identified as glioblastoma, grade IV (WHO scale). The Ki-67 proliferation index was assessed, showing an average of 6.5%, with significant endothelial proliferation and necrosis observed microscopically. The tumor is characterized by a moderately pleomorphic and infiltrative proliferation of astrocytes, with scattered mitoses noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, measuring 1.5 cm, located in the right lobe of the thyroid, with evidence of angiolymphatic invasion but confined to the thyroid without extrathyroidal extension. All examined lymph nodes (20 total) were negative for tumor involvement, and the pathological stage is classified as pT1b N0. Additional findings include chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis and nodular thyroid tissue, with margins uninvolved by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with tumor invasion into the outer half of the muscularis propria and a size of 3 cm. The right ureter shows high-grade invasive carcinoma at the distal end, while the left ureter and lymph nodes from both sides are free of tumor involvement. Surgical margins, including the urethral margin, are negative for dysplasia or carcinoma, and no lymphatic or vascular invasion is identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the right posterior section of the liver, characterized by a 7.5 x 6.6 x 5.1 cm encapsulated, multinodular mass with central necrosis, and a clear surgical resection margin. The tumor is classified as Edmondson-Steiner grade IV with focal capsular infiltration but shows no evidence of vascular or serosal invasion. The adrenal gland and gallbladder specimens show no tumor presence, with the gallbladder noted to be in a state of autolysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with focal signet ring cell morphology and mucinous differentiation at the gastroesophageal (GE) junction, with a maximal tumor diameter of 3.5 cm. The tumor has invaded through the gastroesophageal wall and has metastasized to five out of thirteen perigastric/paraesophageal lymph nodes, while the distal gastric margin is free of tumor. HER2 testing revealed no amplification, with a HER2 to chromosome 17 ratio of 1.2, indicating the tumor is not HER2 amplified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme from a right partial brain tumor biopsy. Microscopic examination reveals significant tumor necrosis, anaplastic astrocytes, and vascular proliferation, with a MIB-1 labeling index of approximately 10%. The findings suggest a highly aggressive tumor with areas of necrosis and inflammatory response.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional clear cell renal carcinoma (Fuhrman Nuclear Grade II/IV) in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 10.0 cm and no evidence of local or renal vein invasion, and surgical margins are free of tumor. The para-aortic lymph nodes were examined, and no involvement was found in the 10 nodes assessed. The tumor exhibits multifocal areas of fibrosis and osseous metaplasia, and the overall staging is pT2, indicating the tumor is limited to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 6.5 cm, with invasion into the whole wall and perigastric fat. Out of 15 examined lymph nodes, 2 showed metastases, and the tumor is characterized by ulceration and extensive necrosis in the omentum. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) in multiple specimens from the left frontal and temporal lobes, with some areas showing features of low-grade astrocytoma (WHO Grade II). Approximately 20% of the resected tumor exhibits high-grade characteristics, while the remaining 80% shows low-grade features. The findings suggest a progression from a previously excised low-grade astrocytoma to a more aggressive high-grade form.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland, characterized by a well-delineated mass measuring 3.4 x 3.2 x 3.0 cm with a solid yellow to yellow-orange cut surface. Microscopic examination reveals a solid nesting and trabecular architecture with round cells, and no evidence of degeneration, invasion, or lymphovascular involvement. Immunohistochemical staining confirms the diagnosis, showing positivity for chromogranin and tyrosine hydroxylase, while sustentacular cells are positive for S100 protein.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma following a total laryngectomy, bilateral neck dissection, and right hemithyroidectomy, with a tumor size of 3.2 cm and cartilage invasion present. No tumor was identified in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left neck dissections, totaling 42 nodes, and all additional tissue samples from the pharynx, base of the tongue, trachea, and mediastinal tissue were negative for tumor. The report also notes the presence of chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis in the right thyroid lobe and acute and chronic inflammation at the stoma site, but no evidence of malignancy in these areas.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from the common hepatic artery and hepatic hilar region are negative for tumor, while the pancreas shows low-grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) and invasive grade 3 ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas, which extends into surrounding tissues. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, but two out of twenty-four regional lymph nodes are positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma. Additionally, mild chronic cholecystitis is noted in the gallbladder, and there is evidence of angiolymphatic and perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, characterized by a subpleural mass measuring 3.5 x 3.2 x 3 cm, located 2 cm from the bronchial margin, with negative surgical margins. There is evidence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in 2 out of 10 intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes, but no extranodal extension is noted. Additionally, multiple excised lymph nodes from the superior and inferior mediastinum are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant epithelioid mesothelioma based on a pleural biopsy. Immunohistochemical studies show strong positive staining for WT-1, mesothelin, and keratin 5/6, supporting the diagnosis, while MOC-31 staining was negative. The gross description notes two pieces of tan-white tissue, with findings consistent with the clinical history of left pleural mesothelioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral poorly differentiated papillary serous carcinoma of the ovaries, classified as FIGO grade III, with tumor involvement of both ovarian surfaces and lymphovascular invasion in the right ovary. Metastatic papillary serous carcinoma is also identified in multiple sites, including the bladder, pelvic tumor, omentum, and rectum, with associated necrosis and psammomatous calcifications. Additional findings include atypical leiomyomas and hyperplastic endometrial changes in the uterus, with the overall staging of the tumor being FIGO stage III C T3c NX MX.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated mixed epithelial type adenocarcinoma (endometrioid and papillary serous) involving both the right and left ovaries, with extensive lymphovascular invasion and metastatic adenocarcinoma identified in the omentum. No carcinoma was found in any of the examined lymph nodes, and the tumors are classified as FIGO stage IIIB due to macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis. The report highlights the presence of synchronous primary tumors in both ovaries, with significant findings of extensive ovarian adhesions and chronic inflammation in the fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates that a right orchidectomy was performed, revealing a nonseminoma tumor with a diameter of 2.3 cm, which is entirely confined to the testis. Angio-invasion is present, but there is no invasion of the rete testis. The tumor is classified as embryonal carcinoma (EC 100%).

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a woman of unspecified age, has been diagnosed with moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in both the endocervix and cervix, with no lymphovascular space invasion identified. Microscopic examination confirmed the diagnosis based on the analysis of the biopsy slides. The report also notes compliance with federal regulations regarding the performance of diagnostic tests.

The pathology report indicates that the anterior floor of the mouth shows invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with the resection margins free of tumor. Additionally, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma is present in 3 of 6 level I lymph nodes and 1 of 2 level III lymph nodes, while other examined lymph nodes and margins show no tumor. The report also notes benign findings in the gingival labial margin, mucosal tongue margin, and deep tongue margin, with no tumor detected in those areas.

The pathology report indicates a left kidney radical nephrectomy revealing a unifocal clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 5.9 cm, with Fuhrman nuclear grade 2. The tumor is confined to the renal cortex and does not invade the renal capsule or surrounding structures, with margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additionally, mild to moderate arteriosclerosis is noted in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two moderately differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinomas in the stomach: one at the subcardial region with infiltration into the lamina muscularis propria (pT2a) and another in the antrum with invasion of the submucosa (pT1). Both tumors have tumor-free resection margins and show no regional lymph node metastases (pN0 0/13). The findings are associated with a background of multifocal atrophic pangastritis due to Helicobacter pylori infection, accompanied by intestinal metaplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated basaloid squamous cell carcinoma in the right pharynx, with a tumor size of 3.1 x 2.2 x 1.9 cm and evidence of invasion into the tonsil and skeletal muscle, along with venous invasion. Surgical margins are focally positive for carcinoma, with the deep margin and specific peripheral margins showing tumor extension within 1 mm. Lymph node dissection revealed metastatic carcinoma in 2 out of 27 lymph nodes, with no extracapsular extension noted.

The pathology report indicates a left pneumonectomy revealing poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 65 mm, with evidence of vascular and pleural invasion, and metastases in peribronchial lymph nodes. The bronchial resection margin is clear of invasive malignancy, although necrotic tumor is present in the bronchial lumen. The pathological stage is classified as T2 N1, and the remaining lung parenchyma is unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a small focus of invasive lobular carcinoma (0.6 mm) at the edge of the excised right axillary breast tissue, with surrounding adipose tissue and rare benign acini. Additionally, two sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla show micrometastasis, with one node having a single focus (0.6 mm) and the other containing multiple foci (largest 1.5 mm), but no extranodal extension was observed. The right breast mastectomy revealed a unifocal invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, classified as Stage IIB, with positive lymph nodes (2 out of 15) and focal positive margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with basal-like features in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 5.0 cm, with perineural invasion and involvement of the mainstem bronchus. Regional lymph nodes were examined, revealing metastatic carcinoma in 6 out of 9 peribronchial lymph nodes and 1 out of 1 parenchymal lymph node, while other lymph nodes sampled were benign. Additionally, the pericardium showed benign mesothelial-lined fibroadipose tissue with no tumor present.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a thymectomy, revealing a thymoma classified as WHO type B2, with microscopic invasion into adjacent adipose tissue. The tumor measures 8.5 cm and is well-circumscribed, but the margin is less than 0.2 mm from the inked edge, indicating close proximity to the surgical margin. Flow cytometric analysis shows a predominance of T cells, with a viability of 54%, confirming the tumor's epithelial nature and the presence of lymphocytic infiltration.

The pathology report indicates that both the right and left pelvic lymph nodes are negative for malignancy, with no cancer identified in three nodes from each side. The prostate specimen shows multifocal adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3, comprising approximately 20% of the gland, with evidence of extraprostatic extension into the bladder neck and extensive perineural invasion, but no seminal vesicle invasion or positive margins. The left apical margin also shows no malignancy, confirming clear surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade oligoastrocytoma (WHO grade II) from a resected right frontal brain mass. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive IDH1 (R132H) mutation in tumor cells, rare p53 positivity, and a low Ki-67 labeling index. Additional fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) studies for 1p19q deletion have been ordered for further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma involving both the left and right ovaries, with extensive metastatic spread to the uterus, cervix, bladder serosa, and omentum. The tumors exhibit mixed histological types, primarily endometrioid and high-grade papillary serous adenocarcinoma, with significant intravascular and serosal involvement. The final staging is classified as FIGO stage IIIC, indicating macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of liver and lymph node metastases from a poorly differentiated carcinoma, as well as invasive carcinoma in gastric resection material that infiltrates all layers of the stomach wall and extends to the serosa. The resection margins in the mucosal region of the gastric specimen are tumor-free. The tumor classification is noted as ICDO-DA M. 8140/3, with staging indicating pT3, pN2, L1, V1, and pM1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma from a left kidney tumor specimen, with a tumor cellularity of 90%.
