The TNM staging is classified as T2 N1 M0, suggesting a localized tumor with regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. There are no prior treatments noted, and the specimen was processed as frozen tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower lobe wedge biopsy revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with visceral pleural invasion, while the right upper lobe wedge biopsy showed a poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma. Both tumors were single foci, with the adenocarcinoma measuring 2.7 x 2.5 x 2.0 cm and the squamous carcinoma measuring 1.0 x 0.9 x 0.7 cm. Lymph node biopsies from levels 4 and 7 were negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that both specimens from the brain tumor are diagnosed as glioblastoma, classified as WHO grade IV. The tumor was identified in the frontal region and consisted of multiple irregularly-shaped soft tissue fragments. A craniotomy was performed for the evaluation of the brain mass.

The pathology report indicates a prostatic adenocarcinoma measuring 2x2x1.5 cm, characterized by ill-defined margins and invasion into the stroma and bladder wall. The tumor exhibits a Gleason score of 8, with features including hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and areas of necrosis and hemorrhage. Additional findings suggest bilateral involvement and extraprostatic extension, but details regarding lymphatic and venous invasion, as well as margins, are not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous carcinoma with adenoid and sarcomatoid features in a floor of mouth mass, measuring 5.5 cm, with invasion into muscle and bone, and evidence of vascular and perineural invasion, although margins of resection are free of tumor. Additionally, a left supraomohyoid neck dissection showed no tumor in ten lymph nodes, while a right modified neck dissection revealed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in one of three lymph nodes. The report also confirms that no tumor was present in various other examined tissues, including the mental skin and buccal mucosa.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy due to a pancreatic mass, with the diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma measuring 4.1 cm, which extends into the peripancreatic fat and involves the distal pancreatic resection margin. Additionally, chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis were noted in the gallbladder specimen, and there is evidence of perineural and lymphovascular invasion, with 16 out of 27 lymph nodes positive for carcinoma. The TNM classification is pT3 pN1, reflecting the advanced stage of the pancreatic cancer.

The pathology report indicates that both ovaries are replaced by high-grade serous carcinoma, with microscopic involvement of the mucosa of one fallopian tube, while the omentum and uterus show no evidence of malignancy. The tumor was received in multiple fragments, making it impossible to assess for rupture, and pelvic washings were positive for malignant cells. The findings suggest extensive involvement of the ovaries by the tumor, with a possibility of metastatic spread to the fallopian tube.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous papillary Mullerian-derived adenocarcinoma involving the right and left ovaries, uterine serosa, and bilateral parametrial/paraovarian tissues, with evidence of tumor spread to multiple sites including the omentum, lesser sac, and diaphragm. The adenocarcinoma exhibits features of nuclear pleomorphism and psammoma bodies, with focal lymphatic invasion, and it is suggested that the primary origin may be peritoneal rather than ovarian due to limited ovarian involvement. Additionally, the appendix shows rare clusters of malignant cells without invasion of the appendiceal wall, and there are findings of mild chronic cervicitis and cystic follicles in the ovaries.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a residual high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the excised mass from the right arm, measuring 5.0 cm, with negative margins for tumor. Additionally, a second specimen revealed benign adipose tissue with focal fibrosis and a foreign-body reaction, showing no evidence of malignancy. The report confirms that the findings are based on a thorough examination of the submitted specimens.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenalectomy was performed, revealing a tumor weighing 244g and measuring 8.2 x 7.5 x 6.5 cm. The diagnosis is adrenal cortical carcinoma with oncocytic features, characterized by a Weiss score of 5. This score suggests a high-grade malignancy.

The pathology report describes a cervico-medullary mass identified as a low-grade glial neoplasm, with differential diagnoses including pilocytic astrocytoma (WHO Grade 1) and diffuse fibrillary astrocytoma (WHO Grade 2). Microscopic examination revealed a moderately cellular tumor with minimal nuclear atypia and a proliferation index (Ki67) of 20-30%, while immunohistochemical stains were positive for GFAP and negative for IDH1. Further molecular testing may assist in confirming the diagnosis, with a neurofilament stain suggesting an infiltrative growth pattern consistent with diffuse astrocytoma WHO Grade 2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma in a resected portion of the rectosigmoid colon, with the tumor invading all layers of the intestinal wall and extending into adjacent periproctic fatty tissue. The tumor is located 4.5 cm from the aboral resection margin and occupies a length of 5.5 cm, but both oral and aboral resection margins, as well as the periproctic fatty tissue, are tumor-free. Additionally, all 32 examined regional lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor involvement, resulting in a final staging of pT3 pN0 (0/32) L0 V0; G2 R0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland following an adrenalectomy, with areas suspicious for vascular invasion. Immunohistochemical studies show positive staining for chromogranin and synaptophysin, focal positivity for P53, and negative staining for c-Kit, along with an intermediate proliferative index by MIB-1 staining. The specimen was processed and examined under CLIA certification, confirming the findings related to the tumor's characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies of the right and left distal ureters are benign and negative for neoplasia. However, a radical cystoprostatectomy revealed high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma located in the left lateral wall and trigone of the bladder, measuring 3.5 cm and infiltrating into the superficial detrusor muscle, with associated dysplasia in the ureteral ostia. All examined surgical margins are free of neoplasia, and no malignancy was found in the excised lymph nodes.

The histopathological examination of the right breast and axillary tissues reveals invasive ductal carcinoma (NHG3) with a tumor size of 3.2 x 2.3 x 2.6 cm, accompanied by numerous foci of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and significant vascular invasion. Metastases were identified in the axillary lymph nodes, indicating advanced disease (pT2, pN3a). Immunohistochemical analysis shows over 75% of neoplastic cells expressing estrogen receptors, 10-75% expressing progesterone receptors, and a HER2 score of 2+, with FISH verification recommended.

The pathology report indicates a right lung mass diagnosed as moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, measuring 9.5 x 8.5 x 6.5 cm, with evidence of lymphovascular invasion and extension into the visceral pleura but not through it. A total of 22 lymph nodes were examined, with 6 showing metastatic carcinoma, leading to a final staging of pT3N2. Additional lymph nodes were found to be negative for metastatic carcinoma, confirming the primary lung malignancy diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal breast carcinoma, classified as malignancy grade II, accompanied by high-grade comedo-type ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with isolated coarse calcifications. The tumor measures 2.5 cm in maximum diameter and has a narrow medial safety margin, with DCIS formations extending to within 0.5 cm of the dorsal resection line, although the dye-stained resection margins are free of atypia. The tumor classification is pT2, pNO sn (n=3), MX, R0; G2 (LO, V0).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of unifocal invasive ductal carcinoma (grade 3) in the left breast, measuring 2.5 cm, with evidence of necrosis and a Nottingham score of 9/9. Three out of 17 axillary lymph nodes were positive for metastatic carcinoma, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 1.2 cm, but there was no evidence of vascular invasion or involvement of the nipple or skin. Additionally, the tumor was negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors, and the pathological stage is classified as pT2 N1a.

The patient underwent a left modified radical mastectomy due to infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the breast, which was classified with a Nottingham score of 8/9 and measured 5.5 cm, extending into the dermis with extensive lymphovascular invasion. The surgical margins were free of neoplasm, but metastatic carcinoma was found in the intramammary lymph node and all examined axillary lymph nodes. Hormonal receptor analyses indicated that the tumor was negative for estrogen, progesterone, and Her-2/Neu.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma of the colon, characterized by a 7 x 5 cm ulcerous tumor infiltrating the entire thickness of the colon wall and extending to the first loop of the small intestine. The tumor has caused significant narrowing of the intestinal lumen and is associated with metastatic involvement of neighboring lymph nodes. Histologically, the cancer is classified as G2, with a staging of pT4b and pN2, indicating advanced disease with lymph node metastases.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal, synchronous carcinomas in the uterus, bilateral ovaries, and fallopian tubes, including a FIGO grade II endometrial adenocarcinoma and a FIGO grade III undifferentiated carcinoma on the anterior uterine serosa. The endometrial tumor shows superficial invasion into the myometrium, while a third focus of FIGO grade I endometrioid adenocarcinoma is identified in the right ovary. Immunohistochemical studies reveal defective DNA mismatch repair due to loss of MLH1 expression, suggesting a potential hereditary component to the malignancies.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of carcinosarcoma of the uterus, with a tumor size of 7 x 6.5 x 5 cm and a maximum depth of invasion of 1.2 cm into the myometrium. There is evidence of metastatic disease in the pelvic sidewall, bilateral ovaries, and omentum, with a noted 1 mm tumor metastasis in the cervix. The report also highlights that lymphatic and vascular invasion is negative, and the specimen margins are not involved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant mixed Mullerian tumor with heterologous differentiation, measuring 7.5 x 7.0 x 2.0 cm, which invades 2.0 cm into the myometrium but does not involve the endocervix or show lymphovascular invasion. The bilateral fallopian tubes exhibit severe epithelial atypia, while the ovaries appear unremarkable, and all examined lymph nodes from both pelvic and para-aortic regions are negative for tumor involvement. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and the overall classification is AJCC pT1bNO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligoastrocytoma, classified as grade II according to the World Health Organization (WHO) grading system. The tumor is localized in the left frontal region of the brain. The patient is female.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies from various sites, including skin, nerve, tongue, and oral mucosa, were negative for malignancy, while two lymph nodes from the level 1A dissection were also negative for malignancy. However, an excisional biopsy revealed moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.2 cm, with invasion into the mandible and involvement of two lymph nodes. The findings correspond to AJCC stage p4a, indicating advanced oropharyngeal carcinoma with negative surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to a cervical mass, which was diagnosed as invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. All examined lymph nodes (15 in total) were negative for metastatic carcinoma, and additional findings included a benign endocervical polyp and a benign fibroma in the left ovary. The tumor exhibited features of perineural and lymphovascular invasion, with a maximum stromal invasion thickness of 1.4 cm, and was classified as FIGO stage IB1.

The pathology report indicates that the resection material from the sigmoid/rectum shows tumor-free margins and non-inflamed diverticula, along with three tubular adenomas exhibiting severe dysplasia. Additionally, there is a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with infiltration into the perimuscular fatty tissue, but no regional lymph node metastases were found. The tumor classification is G2, pT3, L0, V0, R0, with no metastases in 16 examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the endometrium, endocervix, and cervix, with histologic examination revealing pleomorphic nuclei, a high mitotic rate, and extensive keratinization. The endometrial biopsy shows only superficial tumor involvement, while stromal invasion is present in the endocervical and cervical specimens. The patient, a postmenopausal woman, presents with symptoms of bleeding and a pelvic mass, suggesting advanced stage cervical cancer.

The pathology report indicates that both the right and left ureters were excised and found to be benign with no tumors identified. However, a cystectomy of the bladder revealed a poorly-differentiated urothelial carcinoma measuring 5.3 x 2.2 x 0.5 cm, which invades through the muscularis propria into surrounding adipose tissue and shows lymphovascular space invasion. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, and no metastatic carcinoma was found in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a lobectomy of the right upper lobe of the lung, which revealed a well-circumscribed squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.7 cm, classified as moderately to poorly differentiated. The tumor is confined to the lung with no evidence of invasion into surrounding structures, and all surgical margins are reported as uninvolved. Additionally, a biopsy of the apical segment lymph node showed no tumor involvement, confirming a negative result for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, eosinophilic type, with Fuhrman's nuclear grade 3, confined to the left kidney, measuring 12.0 cm, with clear ureteral and vascular margins and no tumor in the adrenal gland. Additionally, a retroperitoneal lymph node shows atypical follicular hyperplasia, with immunohistochemical studies pending for further evaluation. The report notes that the left kidney and adrenal gland were part of a radical nephrectomy specimen, and the lymph node was submitted for detailed examination.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma (type 1), Fuhrman nuclear grade 2, in a left renal mass measuring 2.2 cm, which is confined to the kidney but has a focally positive resection margin. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, and the tumor is staged as pT1a, indicating stage I. A biopsy of the base of the renal mass shows benign renal parenchyma with no malignancy detected.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenalectomy was performed, revealing an adrenal tumor measuring 3.5 cm and a periaortic-pericave paraganglioma measuring 5 cm, both exhibiting significant cellularity and capsular invasion. The adrenal tumor shows marked nuclear atypia and is composed of small cells arranged in nests, while the paraganglioma demonstrates invasion into adjacent fat and lymph nodes. The prognosis for both chromaffin tumors is considered reserved due to their aggressive features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 7.2 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of II and no evidence of tumor invasion beyond the kidney or in the regional lymph nodes. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with negative margins for renal vein, artery, and ureter, and no lymphovascular invasion detected. Additionally, minimal chronic changes in the kidney parenchyma are noted, likely age-related, with a very low percentage of glomerulosclerosis and mild vascular sclerosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a transmurally invasive adenocarcinoma at the gastroesophageal junction, with tumor invasion extending into the stomach and esophagus. Two out of thirty lymph nodes examined were positive for metastatic carcinoma, with evidence of extracapsular extension and perineural invasion, while all surgical margins were negative for neoplasm. Additional excised tissues, including retroperitoneal and omental samples, were negative for neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive transitional cell carcinoma (grade III/IV) in the urinary bladder, with extensive invasion into the perivesical soft tissue and peritoneum, along with multiple satellite tumor nodules. No high-grade urothelial atypia or malignancy was identified in the right and left distal ureters, apical urethral margin, or prostate, although focal prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN II and III) was noted. Metastatic carcinoma was found in a limited number of lymph nodes, specifically one of eleven right obturator lymph nodes, two of seven left common iliac lymph nodes, and three of four left external iliac lymph nodes, while other examined lymph nodes were free of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, characterized by chromophobe and sarcomatoid cell types, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4. The tumor measures 17.0 cm, extends through the renal capsule but is confined within Gerota's fascia, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. Immunostaining confirms the presence of the chromophobe component, but the overall diagnosis remains unchanged.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon with a partial mucinous component, classified as G3. The tumor has invaded the muscularis and vessels, with lymph node metastases identified in two out of twelve sections, corresponding to pN1. Resection margins are free of cancer, indicating a locally R0 classification.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of epithelial melanoma located on the left shoulder, classified as Clark Level 4 and with a Breslow thickness of 2 mm. The tumor measures 3 mm by 2 mm, with no evidence of metastasis and a staging of I. The report notes that there are no normal tissue samples present and mentions neo-adjuvant immunotherapy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) in the left breast, characterized as poorly differentiated with a histologic grade of III and measuring 1.9 cm, along with focal ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising less than 25% of the tumor. Among the sentinel lymph nodes examined, one node showed a microscopic cluster of tumor cells, while the other two nodes were benign with no evidence of metastatic tumor. Additionally, HER2 gene amplification testing revealed that the tumor is not amplified, with a HER2/CEP17 ratio of 1.4.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a benign fibrous walled cyst in the left kidney, alongside a unifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma measuring 3.0 cm, which has transgressed the renal capsule into perinephric adipose tissue by approximately 0.1 cm. The tumor is classified as Fuhrman grade 3/4, with no lymphovascular invasion or sarcomatoid features identified, and the surgical margins are uninvolved by carcinoma. Additional biopsies from the tumor base and margins revealed no neoplasm, confirming the tumor's limited extent and the absence of malignancy in those areas.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the soft tissue of the anterior tracheal wall, with extrathyroidal extension into skeletal muscle and positive resection margins. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma is identified in four of eight lymph nodes and five of fifteen lymph nodes from the left neck dissection, with evidence of extracapsular extension. Other examined tissues, including the esophageal muscularis and portions of the parathyroid gland, show no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a cavernous hemangioma in a mass located in front of the inferior vena cava (IVC) and a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in a liver segmentectomy, characterized by a single tumor measuring 4.3x4.2 cm with Edmondson grades II and III differentiation. The liver tumor shows no evidence of necrosis, invasion, or metastasis, but there is minimal chronic hepatitis and early cirrhosis present. Additionally, a gallbladder cholecystectomy revealed cholesterol polyps without any other significant liver disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade 1-2, in the right breast, with metastatic carcinoma found in twelve of thirteen axillary lymph nodes, including all three sentinel lymph nodes. The largest metastatic focus measures 1.1 cm, and there is evidence of extranodal extension in at least five lymph nodes. The lumpectomy margins are negative for tumor, and the overall pathologic stage is IIIC.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, with a histologic grade of FIGO 1-2 and myometrial invasion extending to the outer half. Serosal involvement and lymphovascular space invasion are present, with one out of eight pelvic lymph nodes showing metastatic adenocarcinoma. The tumor is classified as AJCC pathologic stage pT3a pN1 pMx, corresponding to FIGO stage IIIC1, and immunohistochemistry results for estrogen and progesterone receptors are pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive colonic adenocarcinoma of moderate differentiation (G2), with infiltration through all layers of the colon wall (pT3) and evidence of lymphatic and vascular invasion (L1, V1). Additionally, there are lymph node metastases (pN2) present, but the tumor has been completely removed from the resection margins. Other preparations show smooth muscle fibers and anastomosis rings associated with the carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in four lymph nodes from the left central compartment, alongside multifocal papillary carcinoma in the thyroid, with the dominant tumor measuring 4.1 cm in the right lobe and a smaller 0.9 cm tumor in the left lobe exhibiting focal hobnail cell change. The surgical margins of the left lobe tumor are involved by carcinoma, complicating the assessment of extrathyroidal extension. Additionally, severe chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis is noted, with no pathological findings in several examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) in all three brain tumor specimens examined. Microscopic examination reveals infiltrating glial neoplasm with features of both astrocytic and oligodendroglial differentiation, along with increased pleomorphism and mitotic activity. The Ki-67 proliferation index is noted to be 5%, suggesting a moderate level of tumor cell proliferation.

The pathology report indicates that two right and two left pelvic lymph nodes were examined, with no tumor present in either group. The prostate shows a single focus of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), confined to the prostate and with free resection margins, while the seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia are free of tumor. Additionally, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) was noted in the prostate.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a peritoneal nodule consisting of loose fibrous and adipose tissue, hyperplastic lymph nodes, and a significant perirenal mass consistent with pheochromocytoma measuring 10 x 5 x 5 cm, which is adjacent to but not invading the adrenal gland. Diagnostic features suggest potential malignancy due to the tumor size and perforation into the renal vein, with immunohistochemical studies supporting the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. Continued clinical evaluation for possible bone metastases is recommended due to the malignancy risk associated with the tumor.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of endometrial cancer, specifically endometrioid adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated (FIGO grade 2), with a maximum tumor size of 4.6 cm and 75% involvement of both the anterior and posterior endomyometrium. The tumor has invaded less than half the thickness of the myometrium, with negative margins and no lymph node involvement, indicating a pathologic stage of pT2a, pNO, and pMX, corresponding to FIGO stage IIA. Additionally, peritoneal washing was negative for malignant cells, and pre-neoplastic conditions such as simple and complex endometrial hyperplasia were noted.

The pathology report indicates that the omentum and soft tissue from the right pelvic side wall are negative for malignancy, while the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions show no evidence of tumor involvement. The uterus, cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes, and ovaries were assessed following a robotic-assisted total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, revealing the presence of serous carcinoma in the endometrium with myometrial invasion. The tumor is classified as pT1b, indicating it invades more than half of the myometrium, but there is no involvement of the cervix, ovaries, fallopian tubes, or lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, follicular variant, located in the left thyroid lobe, measuring 2.2 cm, with no multifocality or extrathyroidal extension. Lymphovascular invasion is present, but resection margins are negative, and no lymph nodes were identified in the specimen. The gross examination reveals a well-circumscribed nodule confined to the thyroid, with the isthmus appearing unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left pelvic lymph nodes were examined, with a total of 12 nodes from the right and 3 from the left, all showing no evidence of adenocarcinoma. The prostate specimen revealed prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason grade of 4+3, indicating a total score of 7, and the cancer is confined to the prostate without involvement of surrounding structures. The pathological staging is classified as T2c, with no lymph node metastasis detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated diffuse type adenocarcinoma located in the prepyloric region of the stomach, measuring 3 x 1 x 1.5 cm, with exophytic and infiltrative characteristics. The tumor invades deeply into the muscularis propria but does not penetrate through it, and there is no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Surgical margins are widely free of involvement, and all examined lymph nodes (5 total) show no metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 10.5 cm, with a composition of 50% clear cells and 50% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 4, and showing invasive characteristics into the renal vein and surrounding adipose tissue. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic conventional renal cell carcinoma in the left adrenal gland. The tumor in the right kidney extends into the renal vein but does not invade the wall of the vein, and no lymph nodes were identified in the surrounding area.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with the tumor measuring 8 cm and not involving the visceral pleural surface. All examined lymph nodes (level 10, R4, and level 7) are negative for metastatic carcinoma, confirming no regional spread. The margins of resection, including bronchial and vascular margins, are free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 5 cm, which extends subpleurally but does not invade the visceral pleura. All examined lymph nodes, including those from stations 7, R-11, R-10, and R-4, are negative for tumor involvement, and the surgical margins are also negative for tumor. The pathologic stage of the cancer is classified as T2N0MX.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left radical orchiectomy due to a testicular mass, which was diagnosed as a unifocal pure seminoma measuring 6.2 cm. The tumor was confined to the testis, with direct invasion of the rete testis, but did not involve the tunica vaginalis, spermatic cord, or lymph-vascular structures. The pathologic stage is classified as pT1, with no significant additional findings noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of soft tissue dedifferentiated liposarcoma located in the left femoral region, characterized by a large tumor mass measuring 20x15x8 cm with a nodular component. Histological analysis reveals a mixoid liposarcoma with a predominance of low-grade components, high mitotic activity, and infiltration into adjacent adipose tissue and vessels. The tumor is graded G-6 FNCLCC (6/8), indicating a significant degree of differentiation and aggressive behavior.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal adenocarcinoma of the right breast, with a Nottingham combined histologic grade of 3 out of 3. The report notes the presence of in-situ carcinoma classified as comedo type, with a nuclear grade of 3 out of 3, while lymphatic and vascular invasion were not identified. Estrogen and progesterone receptor, HER2/Neu, and EGFR analyses are pending and will be reported in an addendum.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph nodes at levels 7 and 9 show anthracosis with reactive changes, but both are negative for malignancy. In contrast, the wedge resection of the right lower lobe lung reveals poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 1.6 cm, with extensive necrosis and extending to within 0.1 mm of the pleural surface, although no lymphovascular invasion is identified. The surgical margins are free of malignancy, and the frozen section diagnosis is confirmed.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a man with a history of right frontal oligodendroglioma (WHO grade II), underwent a craniotomy for resection of a brain lesion, which was confirmed to be oligodendroglioma in multiple sections from various walls of the operative cavity. Although there are areas of increased cellularity and mild atypia, no definitive features of progression to a higher grade were identified, and only one mitotic figure was noted. The report suggests ongoing imaging surveillance due to the slow increase in size of the lesion, with no evidence of necrosis or microvascular proliferation detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adrenocortical carcinoma following a left nephrectomy and adrenal mass resection, with the adrenal mass measuring 6 cm and weighing 38 g. The tumor exhibits a nuclear grade of 3, with focal areas of necrosis and evidence of venous invasion, including a neoplastic thrombus within the renal vein. No metastasis was found in the four dissected lymph nodes, and the Weiss score is reported as 5.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in Barrett's epithelium of the distal esophagus, measuring 4.5 x 2.5 cm. Out of 13 examined lymph nodes, 9 are positive for tumor involvement. The report notes that the resection was irradical, suggesting incomplete removal of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a left kidney specimen with a tumor measuring 4 cm, diagnosed as clear cell type renal cell carcinoma, Fuhrman grade 3. There is no evidence of malignancy at the renal capsule, renal sinus, or hilar margins, and vascular invasion is absent. The tumor is classified as pTNM Stage T1a, indicating it is localized and has not spread beyond the kidney.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the right lobe of the liver, with a well-defined mass measuring 4.3 x 3.7 x 3.3 cm and no evidence of invasion at the resection margins. The liver parenchyma shows signs of cirrhosis, specifically micronodular changes, while the gallbladder reveals chronic cholecystitis. Overall, the surgical margins are clear, and there are no signs of satellite nodules or vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates that a leiomyosarcoma, measuring 3.5 x 3.3 x 1.4 cm and classified as intermediate to high grade, was excised from the posterior right thigh, with the closest deep margin being 0.2 cm away. Surgical margins for the tumor were negative, and additional proximal and distal margins were also negative for tumor presence. The gross examination revealed a firm tan nodule that did not appear to invade the fascia, confirming the successful removal of the tumor with clear margins.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of carcinoma of the floor of the mouth, specifically invasive acantholytic squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.2 cm, with extensive perineural invasion and involvement of the mandible. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, revealing metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in several nodes, with extracasular spread noted in some, while others were benign. All surgical margins, including those from the mandible and surrounding tissues, were free of tumor, and the pathological stage is classified as T4a N2c MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), located in the right upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm. The tumor is classified as Grade II and is staged as T2, with nodal involvement not specified (NOS) and clinical metastasis not assessed (MX). The sample was obtained through a resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with a glioblastoma, WHO grade 4, located in the right frontal lobe, following an excision biopsy. Molecular testing revealed a positive result for the EGFRvIII mutation and negative results for MGMT promoter methylation, while allelic loss was detected on chromosome arm 19q but not on 1p. The tumor exhibits a proliferation index of up to 23%, suggesting a high level of cellular activity.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma with focal squamous differentiation, invading the endometrium to a depth of 20.9 mm and involving the lower uterine segment. Lymphovascular space invasion is present, and metastatic adenocarcinoma is identified in 4 out of 6 examined lymph nodes, while others show no carcinoma. The overall pathologic stage of the tumor is classified as T1c/N1/MX, indicating significant local invasion and regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme with prominent spindle cell differentiation, classified as gliosarcoma (WHO Grade IV), from biopsies and removal of a right frontal lobe mass. Intraoperative consultations revealed findings consistent with tumefactive demyelination and glioblastoma. The specimens submitted included multiple aggregates of soft, tan-white to red-tan tissue, with varying sizes, confirming the presence of high-grade glioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of advanced gastric carcinoma, specifically a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the diffuse type, located in the upper third of the stomach with a size of 7.8x6.5 cm and invading the serosa (pT4a). There are 4 metastases identified in 64 regional lymph nodes (pN2), with mild perineural invasion noted, while the resection margins are free from carcinoma. Additional findings include prominent lymphoid stroma and foveolar hyperplasia with pit dysplasia, with no tumor found in biopsies of the stomach and omentum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in a female patient, with the tumor located in the breast and classified as grade 2. The staging reveals T2, N2b, and M0, indicating a locally advanced breast cancer without distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered at this time, and a separate blood sample was collected, which is reported as normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of choroidal melanoma in the right eye, characterized as mixed epithelioid and spindled, with a base measuring 18 mm and evidence of extraocular extension. The tumor invades the sclera and the canal of Schlemm, extending to the subconjunctival surface, but the optic nerve and vortex veins are negative for tumor involvement. The specimen for further diagnostic testing has been sent out, and the margins of the tumor are reported as negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, located in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 5 cm, with negative surgical resection margins and no evidence of vascular invasion. The left lobe shows squamous metaplasia, and one lymph node examined was negative for metastases. The pathological staging is classified as pT3 N0 Mx, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 7 x 7 x 0.5 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma of the intestinal type located in the fundus of the stomach, which is poorly differentiated. There is evidence of metastasis with 1 out of 7 lymph nodes positive, and the tumor has not invaded the margins. No neo-adjuvant treatment was specified, and additional pathologic findings were not provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade II, with invasion limited to less than half of the myometrium and no evidence of cervical or vascular invasion. Additionally, all lymph nodes examined from both sides, as well as the abdominal panniculectomy specimen, were reported as benign, with the left ovary showing evidence of endometriosis. The anterior cervical tissue resection revealed a benign fragment of cervical tissue.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of a lymph node associated with the hepatic artery is negative for tumor, as are the margins from the common hepatic duct and pancreatic neck excisions. However, a Whipple resection reveals an invasive moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas, measuring 4.5 x 4.0 x 2.6 cm, which extends into surrounding tissues but has negative surgical margins. Additionally, one of twenty regional lymph nodes is positive for metastatic ductal adenocarcinoma, resulting in an AJCC stage of pT3N1.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in the vaginal corion from a biopsy of the anterior lower third of the vagina. Additionally, a biopsy of the cervix reveals invasive squamous cell carcinoma with a histologic grade of 2. This suggests a diagnosis of cervical cancer with metastasis to the vagina.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 4 cm, with the tumor located 2.5 cm from the bronchial margin and not invading the visceral pleura. All surgical margins are negative for tumor, and lymph nodes from the right lower paratracheal and subcarinal regions are also negative for malignancy, while one lymph node at the posterior right tracheobronchial angle shows infiltrating poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma. The pathological stage is classified as pT2a N1 MX, indicating the presence of cancer in one of the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in the left retroperitoneum, with a tumor size of 4.2 x 3.8 x 2.5 cm. The tumor appears to be completely excised, with narrow margins measuring less than 0.1 cm from the inked edges, and two benign lymph nodes were identified with no evidence of malignancy. The specimen was described as a well-demarcated, tan-yellow rubbery nodule.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma of the stomach, specifically located in the antrum, with a tumor size of 8 x 7 x 5 cm and evidence of ulceration. The tumor has invaded the serosa and shows metastasis in 2 out of 4 examined lymph nodes. Histological features include hyperchromatic nuclei, irregularly enlarged cells, and a moderate mitotic index, with inflammatory cell invasion in the stroma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with tumors measuring 9 cm and significant involvement of the fallopian tubes and omentum. There is extensive tumor infiltration into the serosal surfaces and the appendix, but no carcinoma was identified in the examined lymph nodes. Additionally, the uterus shows inactive endometrium with an endometrial polyp and multiple leiomyomas, while metastatic adenocarcinoma is noted in the omentum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant melanoma of the skin with ulceration, measuring 12 mm in thickness and 24 mm in diameter, located on the right arm. The tumor exhibits small satellite lesions and has minimal healthy tissue margins, with the closest margin being 0.3 cm from the side and 0 cm from the base. Histological examination suggests a primary nodular type melanoma with no signs of regression and a significant proliferation in the subcutaneous tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma identified in the right upper lobe and lymph nodes at levels 7 and 12. The tumor size is approximately 1.7 cm, and there is evidence of capsular penetration and lymphatic invasion, although the surgical margins are negative for carcinoma. The report also notes a history of breast carcinoma in the patient, and immunohistochemical staining supports a pulmonary primary origin for the carcinoma, excluding breast as the primary source.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma located in the right frontal and temporal lobes of the brain. The tumor is classified as grade 3 and there is no evidence of metastasis or lymph node involvement. The patient is a Caucasian female, and no specific treatment details such as chemotherapy were provided.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated, non-mucinous pulmonary adenocarcinoma in the upper lobe of the lung, measuring up to 3.2 cm, classified as stage III A. Immunohistochemical analysis shows absence of cytokeratin 5, co-expression of cytokeratin 7 and 20, and significant nuclear expression of TTF-1, along with marked CEA expression. The proliferation marker Mib-1 indicates a moderately high proliferation rate, supporting the diagnosis of primary pulmonary adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with two tumor nodules measuring 5.5 cm and 1.0 cm, and evidence of perineural invasion. Multiple lymph nodes excised from various levels were mostly negative for malignancy, except for one lymph node at level IV, which was positive for metastatic carcinoma. The pathologic stage of the tumor is classified as pT3 (m) / N2, indicating significant local invasion and regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a 2.5 cm invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, classified as Grade III (poorly differentiated). The tumor is staged as T1b1 with involvement of lymph nodes, as 2 nodes were sampled and 20 were positive for cancer. There is no evidence of distant metastasis (M0).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of lepidic predominant adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe, measuring 2.6 cm, with all bronchial and vascular margins free of tumor and no regional lymph node metastasis detected (0/11 nodes positive). Molecular studies revealed a KRAS mutation (p.G12A), which is associated with poor prognosis, while no EGFR mutations were identified. Additional findings included lymph-vascular invasion and emphysema, with the tumor classified as pT1b according to the pTNM staging system.

The pathology report indicates that the right upper parathyroid biopsy showed no pathological diagnosis, while the total thyroidectomy revealed a 1.7 cm encapsulated follicular variant of papillary carcinoma in the left lobe, characterized by classical architecture and no evidence of capsular or vascular invasion. The tumor is classified as low risk, with uninvolved margins and no regional lymph node metastasis identified. Additional findings include mild follicular nodular disease in the thyroid and normal parathyroid glands, with no pathological diagnosis for the thymus and lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of astrocytoma, a type of glioma, located in the right frontal lobe of a Caucasian female patient. The tumor specimen was processed as a primary tissue sample, while a separate blood sample was noted as normal. No treatment has been administered for the tumor at this time.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma involving the right and left ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, sigmoid colon, and omentum, with evidence of tumor spread and fibrous adhesions. Microscopic examination confirms extensive tumor involvement, including macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis, with the largest tumor focus measuring 4.2 cm. The overall pathologic stage is classified as T3c/NX/MX, indicating advanced disease with significant metastatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma, with extensive involvement of the urinary bladder, prostate, and multiple pelvic lymph nodes, showing significant metastatic spread. Specifically, 22 out of 28 lymph nodes examined were positive for metastatic disease, with extranodal extension noted in several nodes, and the largest lymph node metastasis measuring 3.5 cm. The tumor has invaded through the bladder wall into surrounding tissues, including the prostatic stroma and bilateral seminal vesicles, with positive margins at the posterior perivesical soft tissue adjacent to the prostate.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a large right-sided adrenal tumor measuring 7.2 x 5.5 x 4.7 cm, diagnosed as high-grade adrenocortical carcinoma, with a trimmed weight of 140 grams. The tumor shows no capsular or vascular invasion, and surgical margins are negative, although there is 15% necrosis present. The right kidney is unremarkable with no abnormalities noted, and the overall stage of the tumor is classified as T2 NX MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) with a KI67 proliferation index of 5%. The tumor is confirmed to be located in the adrenal gland, and additional details regarding tumor size and lymph node status are noted. The Weiss score and other pathologic information are referenced but not detailed in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 4.2 cm, with a Nottingham grade of 3 and associated features such as comedonecrosis and microcalcifications. The surgical margins are free of cancer, with the closest margin being 0.1 cm away, and no lymphovascular invasion is identified. Additionally, sentinel lymph node biopsies show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, confirming the absence of spread to the lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes a left adrenal gland containing tumors, with the major tumor measuring 42x30x22 mm and exhibiting focal hemorrhages, alongside a smaller ochre yellow nodule. Microscopic examination reveals hyperplastic adrenal cortex, encapsulated proliferation, and a solid pheochromocytoma characterized by moderate to high cellularity and focal atypia, but without necrosis or vascular invasion. Immunohistochemical analysis shows strong positivity for chromogranin A and synaptophysin in the pheochromocytoma, while the MIB-1 activity is minimal, indicating low proliferation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated ulcerated squamous cell carcinoma in the mid third of the esophagus, measuring 3.3 x 1.5 cm, with infiltration into the muscularis propria and no detected vascular or perineural invasion. Metastasis was found in one periesophageal lymph node and one of 25 lymph nodes from the lesser curvature, while other examined lymph nodes showed no metastasis. The margins of the esophagogastrectomy specimen are free of neoplasia, and the overall pathological staging is pT2 pN2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of gastric adenocarcinoma from a tissue specimen taken from the fundus of the stomach. The tumor is classified as grade 1, with no specific TNM staging provided. Additionally, a blood specimen was analyzed, which returned normal results.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the distal esophagus and proximal stomach, with a tumor size of 7.2 cm that invades the adventitia and periesophageal adipose tissue. The resection margins are negative for carcinoma, but four out of eight examined lymph nodes show metastatic adenocarcinoma. Additionally, a new cervical esophageal margin excision is negative for carcinoma, confirming the findings from the frozen section analysis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total laryngectomy, partial pharyngectomy, and bilateral neck dissection, revealing invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right pyriform sinus, with surgical margins free of tumor. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was identified in 3 of 3 lymph nodes at right Level II and in 1 of 22 lymph nodes at right Level IV, both with extracapsular extension, while other lymph nodes examined showed no tumor present. Additionally, two lymph nodes from the left external jugular and one submental lymph node were also free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with a tumor diameter of 5 cm and focal intraductal spread. The dorsal resection margin is tumor-free, suggesting successful removal of cancerous tissue at that site. The tumor is classified as NOS, grade III, and staged as pT2N0L0V0R0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma (Fuhrman nuclear grade 3) in the left kidney, measuring 11.0 cm, with tumor thrombus present in the renal vein and focal invasion into perirenal adipose tissue. The adrenal gland shows no evidence of tumor, and three retroperitoneal lymph nodes are also free of tumor. Additional findings include renal parenchyma with cortical hemorrhages, interstitial nephritis, fibrosis, and simple cysts.

The pathology report indicates that a left-hand assisted laparoscopic nephrectomy was performed on a kidney with a 4 cm unifocal clear cell renal cell carcinoma, which is confined to the kidney without extension into the major renal vein. The remaining renal tissue shows signs of end-stage renal disease, characterized by marked glomerulosclerosis and tubular atrophy. The surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and the tumor is classified as pT1a, pNX according to the AJCC staging system.

The pathology report indicates that all three sentinel lymph nodes removed from the right axilla show no evidence of melanoma, with negative immunostains for Melan A and S100 protein. In contrast, the wide excision of skin from the right arm reveals a nodular melanoma with a Breslow depth of 6.3 cm, extensive ulceration, and a Clark level of V, but all margins are widely free of tumor. The overall staging is pT4b, pNO, pMx, and further comprehensive review is recommended for final staging determination.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe lung nodule is diagnosed as poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma, consistent with adenocarcinoma, with a tumor size of 2.7 x 2.0 x 1.2 cm and invasion to the visceral pleural surface. All examined lymph nodes (stations 7, 4L, 4R, level 6, and level 10) are negative for carcinoma, indicating no lymphatic spread. The stapled surgical margin of resection is also negative for carcinoma, and additional findings include emphysematous changes in the lung parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the distal pancreas, measuring 2.8 cm, with negative resection margins but evidence of lymphovascular and perineural invasion. The spleen is reported as within normal limits, while the gallbladder shows cholelithiasis and intestinal metaplasia without dysplasia. All examined lymph nodes (11 out of 11) are negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph nodes from the left and right sides show no evidence of carcinoma, while the left breast wire-guided partial mastectomy reveals a 1.2 cm adenoid cystic carcinoma, SBR Grade 1, along with benign findings such as microcalcifications and atypical ductal hyperplasia. The right breast mammoplasty shows an intraductal papilloma and sclerosing adenosis, with no carcinoma identified. Immunohistochemical studies support the diagnosis of adenoid cystic carcinoma, which is ER positive, PR negative, and HER2/neu negative, with negative margins and no lymphatic-vascular invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates that the excision biopsy of a right temporal tumor in a female patient is diagnosed as an oligodendroglioma, WHO grade II, characterized by infiltrating glioma with a predominance of oligodendroglial components and a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 7%. Genetic testing revealed negative loss of heterozygosity on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, along with a positive methylation status of the MGMT promoter, suggesting potential responsiveness to alkylating agent therapy. Additionally, an immunohistochemical analysis showed a positive result for the IDH1 R132H mutation, further supporting the diagnosis of an infiltrating glioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of predominantly poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma limited to the prostate, with a Gleason score of 4+3=7 and a maximum tumor diameter of 1.5 cm, showing multifocal involvement and perineural sheath involvement but no extraprostatic growth. The surgical margins are tumor-free, and there are no signs of tumor in the examined lymph nodes or soft tissue. Additional immunohistochemical studies confirm no evidence of vascular invasion, leading to a final classification of pT2c, L0, V0, and R0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma (Gleason score 5+4=9) involving both lobes of the prostate, with significant tumor infiltration into the seminal vesicles and peri-prostatic adipose tissue, as well as positive surgical margins. Lymph node analysis revealed two metastases in nine right-side lymph nodes, while the left side showed no tumor involvement. The tumor classification is pT3b, pN1, with a maximum tumor diameter of 45 mm and a tumor volume of approximately 41 ml.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adrenal cortical carcinoma in multiple sites, including the left adrenal gland, lymph nodes, and near the left renal and coeliac arteries. The Weiss score of the tumor is 9, with a high mitotic rate and a Ki-67 proliferative index of 30%, suggesting aggressive behavior. Notably, the left kidney and certain lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy, while the thoracic duct also appears free of cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the uterus, cervix, and bilateral tubes and ovaries, with the tumor measuring 3.7 x 3.4 x 3.2 cm and invading the cervical stroma to a depth of 19 mm. All surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, and while there are foci suspicious for lymphovascular invasion, the parametria are not involved, and perineural invasion is absent. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from various regions are benign and negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma located in sublobes VI and VII of the liver, measuring 7x7x5 cm. Microscopic examination reveals trabecular patterns of tumor cells with irregularly large, hyperchromatic nuclei and evidence of vascular invasion. The tumor is characterized by a fibrous stroma and has uninvolved margins, with no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bifocal tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma (G2) in the colon, with two tumors located in the right side of the transverse colon and the distal sigmoid colon. The tumors exhibit infiltration into the surrounding tissue, but the excision margins are clear of neoplastic infiltration. Additionally, five reactive lymph nodes were identified, and there is evidence of a minor dysplastic adenoma outside the tumors.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma (Type I) in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm, confined to the kidney without any angiolymphatic invasion or extension into surrounding fat. The tumor exhibits a histologic grade mostly at Fuhrman grade 2, with focal areas of grade 3, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. Additional findings include benign adipose tissue and mild non-neoplastic changes in the kidney, such as atherosclerosis and glomerulosclerosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in a wedge resection of the left upper lobe, measuring 2.6 x 2.4 x 1.7 cm, with the tumor abutting but not infiltrating the visceral pleura and a distance of 0.6 cm from the nearest resection margin. Multiple lymph node biopsies from levels 5, 6, 7, 9L, and 12L show benign anthracotic lymph nodes with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The final pathologic staging is T1bN0M0, indicating stage IA lung cancer with no residual adenocarcinoma identified in the lobectomy specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell clear carcinoma with an unclassified hybrid pattern, including papillary and eosinophilic components. The tumor is staged as pT2 NX MX, with no evidence of invasion into surrounding structures, including the renal vein, renal artery, ureter, or renal pelvis, and all surgical margins are free of neoplasm. The non-neoplastic kidney tissue is reported as unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast tissue biopsy revealed poorly-differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 1.8 cm, associated with ductal carcinoma in situ of nuclear grade III, with negative estrogen and progesterone receptor status. Both sentinel lymph nodes were negative for tumor, and one non-sentinel lymph node was benign. The surgical margins were negative for tumor, and there were no signs of Paget's disease or lactiferous duct involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade II squamous cell carcinoma located in the cervix, measuring 4x3x2 cm, with infiltration into the outer half of the muscle propria. Microscopic examination reveals hyperplastic squamous cells replacing normal cells, with malignant features including enlarged nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, along with lymphocytic invasion in the stroma. The report notes that the endocervical glands appear normal, and additional details regarding lymph nodes and margins are unspecified.

The amended pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma in the retroperitoneum, measuring 22 x 15 x 10 cm, with focal extension to the surgical margin and adherence to a segment of the inferior vena cava. The tumor exhibits 20% necrosis and presents as a multilobulated mass with areas of hemorrhage and myxoid changes. This report supersedes a previous diagnosis of a well-differentiated smooth muscle neoplasm, and the responsible clinician has been notified of the amendment.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 2.0 cm, with identified angiolymphatic invasion but no pleural invasion. All margins of resection are negative for carcinoma, and lymph nodes sampled show no evidence of metastatic disease, resulting in a staging of T1, N0, Mx. Additionally, multiple biopsies of lymph nodes reveal benign reactive lymphoid tissue with no carcinoma detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately to poorly differentiated nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 5.2 cm, with invasion into the endocervix and margins that are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Lymphovascular invasion is present focally, but all examined lymph nodes (18 in total) are negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings include a submucosal leiomyoma in the endometrium and benign conditions in both ovaries and fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, with the tumor measuring 5.3 x 3.9 x 3.1 cm and extending beyond the pancreas. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in regional lymph nodes, with a total of 3 out of 23 nodes showing metastasis, and tumor cells were also present in the posterior area of the gastric wall. All surgical margins from the radical distal pancreatectomy were free of tumor, and the spleen showed no pathological abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma (grade 3/4) in the urinary bladder, with evidence of invasion through the bladder wall and extensive lymphovascular invasion. The left distal ureter shows hydroureter with chronic inflammation and atypical hyperplasia, while the right distal ureter is reported as benign urothelium. Metastatic high-grade urothelial carcinoma is identified in 4 out of 28 left obturator/hypogastric lymph nodes, with no tumor seen in the right common iliac lymph nodes, urethral margin, or proximal ureters.

The pathology report indicates that both biopsy specimens from the cervix show poorly differentiated, invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The patient, a woman with vaginal bleeding and an exophytic cervical mass, underwent a cervical mass biopsy. Microscopic examination confirmed the diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in both samples.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5), showing multifocal extensive extraprostatic extension and invasion of both seminal vesicles and perivesicular soft tissue. Additionally, two of five left pelvic lymph nodes and one of six right pelvic lymph nodes tested positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with prostatic origin. The tumor exhibits perineural invasion and is present at the margin of resection, with no unequivocal vascular or lymphatic invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a colorectal adenocarcinoma with well to moderately differentiated features, classified as pT2, with no regional lymph node metastases. Additionally, there are findings of a tubular adenoma with mild dysplasia and a tubulovillous adenoma exhibiting focal severe dysplasia. The resection margins are tumor-free, suggesting complete removal of the cancerous tissue.

The pathology report indicates that both right axillary sentinel nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma, and the superior mastectomy flap shows benign fibroadipose tissue with focal fat necrosis. The right breast simple mastectomy reveals two foci of invasive ductal carcinoma (SBR Grade II) and associated ductal carcinoma in situ, with excision margins free of tumor. Additional findings include intraductal papilloma and various benign changes, while the axillary lymph nodes remain negative for metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2, N0, and M0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered, and a separate blood sample was noted as normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, with a bilobed mass measuring 2.7 x 2.4 x 2.0 cm, and extensive ductal carcinoma in situ present both within and outside the invasive component. There is evidence of angiolymphatic invasion and multiple positive lymph nodes for metastatic carcinoma, with a total of four positive nodes identified. Following a total mastectomy, no residual carcinoma was found, and surgical margins were negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, revealing high-grade endometrioid adenocarcinoma in the endometrium with a depth of myometrial invasion of 5 mm, but no cervical involvement or vascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes were benign, and the tumor was staged as pT1b (IB) with no evidence of distant metastasis. Additional findings included benign nabothian cysts, adenomyosis, and benign post-menopausal ovaries, with no invasive carcinoma at the margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of deeply invasive moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma (2.8 cm) following a left partial glossectomy, with no perineural or lymphovascular invasion and clear surgical margins. In the left supraomohyoid neck dissections, six lymph nodes from level I and one lymph node from level II showed no tumor presence, while one of sixteen lymph nodes from level III contained a microscopic focus of carcinoma. Additionally, a tooth specimen was submitted for gross examination only, with no significant findings reported.

The pathology report indicates that the left ureter and right ureter biopsies show no dysplasia or carcinoma, while the cystoprostatectomy reveals a high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the urinary bladder, with negative margins and no tumor found in any of the examined lymph nodes. The prostate shows nodular stromal hyperplasia and glandular atrophy without evidence of carcinoma. Overall, the findings suggest a significant bladder tumor with invasive characteristics, but no metastatic disease was identified in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, in the right lobe of the thyroid, with the largest tumor measuring 1.0 cm and an additional focus of 0.3 cm. Both examined lymph nodes are negative for tumor, and there is no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion, with uninvolved margins. Additional findings include nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2 N2 M0, indicating a locally advanced cancer without distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered to date, and a separate blood sample was collected, which is reported as normal.

The pathology report indicates that the fifth rib excision showed unremarkable bone and bone marrow with no evidence of malignancy. However, multiple lymph nodes and a lobectomy of the right lower lobe revealed metastatic adenocarcinoma, with the primary tumor identified as mucinous adenocarcinoma measuring 6.0 cm, involving the visceral pleura and showing extensive angiolymphatic invasion. Molecular testing identified a KRAS mutation, while no EGFR mutations were found, and the tumor was staged as T2, N2, MX, with significant extravasation of cancer cells noted in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of invasive moderately to poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, with tumor involvement in the pancreatic head and surrounding tissues, as well as one positive peripancreatic lymph node out of fourteen examined. The gallbladder shows mild acute inflammation, and all other examined sites, including the bile duct margin and lymph node group 8, are negative for malignancy. The resection margins are free of invasive carcinoma, with the closest margin being 0.1 cm from the invasive tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive lobular carcinoma in the right breast, with a tumor size of 7.5 cm and a histologic grade of 2. Metastatic carcinoma is present in multiple lymph nodes, with 12 out of 19 lymph nodes showing positive results, including the right axillary sentinel node and the highest apical node. The report also notes the presence of vessel invasion and extravasation, with no evidence of Paget's disease or ductal carcinoma in situ identified.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from the common hepatic artery and hepatic hilar region are negative for tumor, while the pancreas shows low-grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) and invasive grade 3 ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas, which extends into surrounding tissues. The tumor has been identified as 3.3 x 3.2 x 2.6 cm in size, with angiolymphatic and perineural invasion present, but all surgical resection margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, two out of twenty-four regional lymph nodes are positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, leading to a classification of AJCC pT3N1.

The pathology report indicates that multiple neck dissections (levels IA, IB, II, III, and IV) revealed no tumor presence in the examined lymph nodes, with benign findings in the submandibular and parotid glands. However, invasive squamous carcinoma was identified at the anterior periosteum of the mandible and in the mental soft tissue, with a poorly differentiated tumor measuring 4.5 cm located at the left base of the tongue, extending into surrounding tissues. The anterior mandible showed squamous carcinoma invading bone, but additional sections indicated negative margins for tumor invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma, grade B, in a brain biopsy from the temporal lobe, with a MIB-1 labeling index of approximately 8%. The tumor is characterized by infiltrative growth, microcystic changes, and the presence of microgemistocytic cells, along with areas of nuclear atypia and mitotic figures. No vascular endothelial hyperplasia or necrosis was observed in the examined tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the pretracheal lymph node biopsy is negative for tumor, while the total thyroidectomy reveals multifocal papillary carcinoma with the largest nodule measuring 3.0 cm in the left lobe. Metastatic carcinoma is present in two out of eight lymph nodes, with the primary tumor classified as pT2 and regional lymph nodes as pN1a. Margins are uninvolved, but there is evidence of venous and lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral prostate adenocarcinoma following a robotic radical prostatectomy, with the index tumor located in the right anterior transition zone and a Gleason score of 3+3=6, including a tertiary pattern of 4. There is evidence of multifocal perineural invasion and a positive pathological resection margin at the right apical/mid anterolateral area, with extraprostatic extension measuring 20mm. No lymphovascular invasion or seminal vesicle involvement was identified, and lymph node evaluation was not performed.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, in the left breast, characterized by multiple masses, with the largest measuring 3.2 x 2.7 x 2.3 cm. Additionally, there is a 10% component of ductal carcinoma in situ, cribriform type, and 6 out of 30 left axillary lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, including 2 matted lymph nodes. The skin, nipple, and deep margins are free of neoplasm, and HER2/neu testing has been ordered on the tissue samples.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the right temporal lobe of the brain has been diagnosed as anaplastic astrocytoma, a type of aggressive glioma. The microscopic examination revealed small neoplastic cells infiltrating the cerebral cortex and white matter, with some features suggestive of astrocytic differentiation. Additional immunohistochemical and electron microscopy analyses confirmed the diagnosis, showing that the neoplastic cells do not derive from lymphocytes, neuronal elements, or epithelial cells, with a subset expressing GFAP.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 2.5 cm and unifocal involvement. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 1 of 2 examined lymph nodes, and the primary tumor is classified as pT2, indicating it is greater than 2 cm but less than 4 cm and limited to the thyroid. The surgical margins are uninvolved, with a distance of 1 mm from the nearest invasive carcinoma, and there is no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast specimen shows multicentric in situ and invasive lobular carcinoma, nuclear grade II, with tumor nodules ranging from 2 mm to 35 mm, while the deep margin is free of neoplasm and lymphatic invasion is not identified. The right breast specimen reveals proliferative fibrocystic disease with no signs of atypia or malignancy. Both left sentinel nodes are negative for tumor, with one node showing a focus of perinodal fibrosis suggestive of a previous biopsy site.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant melanoma of the skin, measuring 5.5 mm in Breslow thickness, without superficial ulceration. The tumor is pigmented and located on the hip, with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. Additional findings include a black node on the skin flap, and the specimen was obtained through excision of a skin lesion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma arising from a well-differentiated liposarcoma in the retroperitoneum, with the dedifferentiated component predominating and exhibiting heterogeneous morphology. The tumor measures 19 x 16 x 14 cm, invades the renal capsule and renal parenchyma, and extends to the subserosa of the bowel, with areas of necrosis present. Surgical margins, including those of the bowel resection, renal vascular, and ureteral margins, are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with signet ring cells located in the stomach (cardia), measuring 15.0 x 10.0 x 1.0 cm, with infiltration into the peritoneum, perigastric fat, and esophageal adventitia, and involvement of the circumferential esophageal margin. Lymphadenectomy revealed metastatic adenocarcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with significant involvement in the lesser curvature (17/22), left gastric artery (16/20), and celiac trunk (10/11), among others. The report notes that the spleen and omentum are uninvolved by neoplasia, while some lymph nodes in other regions showed no evidence of cancer.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 6.0 cm, with multifocal characteristics and a Nottingham grade of 2. Two sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla tested positive for metastatic tumor, with one node showing extracasular extension, while eleven additional axillary lymph nodes were negative for metastasis. The invasive tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER2/NEU amplification.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph nodes excised from various levels are negative for neoplasm, while the left lower lobe lobectomy reveals invasive adenocarcinoma of the acinar type, along with atypical adenomatous hyperplasia and organizing acute fibrinous pneumonia. Additionally, necrotizing granulomas with calcification were found in the granuloma content, and the lymph nodes at level 12 and L11 also showed calcified hyalinized nodules without neoplastic changes. The tumor is staged as IB (T2a N0 Mx), with no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion, and all margins are reported as negative.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right distal ureters are dilated but negative for malignancy. The urinary bladder shows invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma measuring 2.5 cm, with invasion into the prostate and lymphovascular tumor emboli present, while the prostate has microscopic foci of adenocarcinoma with a low Gleason score. Additionally, two out of five lymph nodes from the left pelvic region show metastatic urothelial carcinoma, while no tumor was found in the right pelvic lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, non-germinal center type, in a cervical lymph node biopsy. Microscopic examination reveals a diffuse infiltrate of large cells with a starry sky appearance, and immunohistochemical analysis confirms B-cell lineage with high proliferation. The findings exclude other lymphoma types, such as plasmablastic lymphoma and pleomorphic variant mantle cell lymphoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade II) from biopsies of a left parietal lobe brain lesion. An addendum reveals the loss of both chromosomes 1p and 19q, which is significant for the characterization of the tumor. The specimens submitted included multiple fragments of soft tissue, with varying descriptions and sizes, consistent with a brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 3.0 cm, with a Nottingham score of 7/9 and grade 2, and margins of resection free of neoplasm. Lymphovascular invasion was identified, and two of the four sentinel lymph nodes examined were positive for metastatic carcinoma, with one showing 1.5 cm of metastasis and 3 mm of extracapsular extension. Additional findings include ductal carcinoma in situ, atypical ductal hyperplasia, and other benign changes, with the overall pathologic stage classified as T2 N1 MX.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right segmental mastectomy due to a diagnosis of right breast cancer, confirmed by a core biopsy. The final diagnosis reveals a mixed infiltrating duct and mucinous carcinoma measuring 3.0 by 2.2 by 1.7 cm, with good nuclear grade and negative surgical margins, although ductal carcinoma in situ is present at the periphery.
