Additionally, neuroendocrine markers were noted to be positive, supporting the presence of neuroendocrine features in the carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma measuring 20.6 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of II, which compresses but does not invade surrounding tissues. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, and margins from the renal artery, vein, and ureter are negative for tumor. Additional staining confirmed the chromophobe features, and the overall diagnosis remains unchanged.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy. The prostate examination reveals adenocarcinoma in the right lobe with a Gleason score of 6, indicating a low-grade tumor involving 5% of the prostate. There is no regional lymph node metastasis, and the margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, although perineural invasion is present.

The pathology report indicates that a 58-year-old male has been diagnosed with high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, which has invaded the perivesical soft tissues and shows multicentricity, with surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, there is evidence of adenocarcinoma in the prostate, classified as pT2b, with perineural invasion identified but no vascular invasion. All submitted lymph nodes from both pelvic sides were benign, and other biopsies from the ureters and abdominal wall showed benign findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma involving both the right and left ovaries, with tumor presence on the ovarian surfaces and metastatic spread to peritubal soft tissue and other sites. Additional findings include endometriosis, focal tubal intraepithelial neoplasia, and chronic inflammation in the cervix, along with multiple metastatic sites in the peritoneum, omentum, and lymph nodes. The overall staging is classified as T3c/N1/MX, suggesting extensive disease with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates mechanically altered liver tissue with a regressive cyst and dystrophic calcification, alongside subcapsular liver tissue exhibiting nodular hyperplasia and moderate steatosis. Additionally, a resected ileocolic sample reveals a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type, measuring 4 cm, with infiltration into the muscularis propria but no involvement of local lymph nodes or resection margins. The tumor is classified as pT2, pNO (0/23), pMX; G2, LO, V0, R, and there is evidence of previous appendicitis with complete obliteration of the appendix.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the cervix reveals moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma. This suggests the presence of cancerous cells that have invaded surrounding tissues. Further evaluation and treatment options should be considered based on this diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left upper pole of the thyroid, with evidence of multifocal residual carcinoma involving both thyroid lobes and tracheal cartilage. Metastatic disease is present in several lymph nodes, specifically three out of thirteen in level III and one out of five in level IV, with noted extracapsular extension. Additionally, there are margins involved with papillary thyroid carcinoma, indicating a more extensive disease process.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 3, with a tumor size of 2.7 cm and associated high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising less than 10% of the tumor volume. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and no cancer was found in the examined axillary lymph nodes (0/10). The pathologic stage is classified as IIA, with features suggestive of a basal-like phenotype and low estrogen receptor positivity.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) of the left breast, measuring 1.5 cm, with a Nottingham grade of 2 and evidence of lymphovascular space invasion. Additionally, there is ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present, constituting 20% of the tumor volume, and one of three examined sentinel lymph nodes is positive for metastatic carcinoma. The invasive tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER-2/NEU, with negative surgical margins noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse adenocarcinoma of the stomach, specifically located in the fundus. The tumor is graded as 3, with a TNM stage of T1, N0, M0, suggesting early-stage cancer with no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. A blood specimen was also analyzed, which returned normal results.

The pathology report indicates that the excised mass from the right buttock is diagnosed as undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma, measuring 20 cm in greatest dimension, with a histologic grade of 3 and a high mitotic rate. While the proximal margin and other margins were negative for malignancy, the proximal nerve margin was positive for sarcoma. The tumor was staged as pT2b, indicating it is more than 5 cm in size and deep, with no residual tumor identified and no lymph-vascular invasion present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of advanced serous carcinoma, with multiple sites of metastatic involvement including the omentum, ovaries, peritoneum, and lymph nodes. The final diagnosis includes grade 3 serous carcinoma from the bilateral oophorectomy and metastatic serous carcinoma in various excised tissues, including the uterus and peritoneum. The findings suggest a probable primary peritoneal origin of the cancer, with significant tumor burden and involvement of surrounding structures.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma in the mandible's periosteum, with resection margins free of tumor. Biopsies from the midline upper lip and left floor of mouth confirm squamous carcinoma, with the left upper lip showing grade 2 carcinoma and free margins. Additionally, there are findings of severe dysplasia and invasive carcinoma in the right buccal margins, with multiple re-excisions indicating focal high-grade dysplasia and carcinoma in situ.

The pathology report indicates that the left frontal brain tumor is diagnosed as glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV), characterized by a high-grade glial neoplasm with significant necrosis and microvascular proliferation. The tumor exhibits atypical astrocytic cells with marked nuclear atypia and infiltrates the surrounding brain tissue. Additionally, immunohistochemical studies reveal that approximately 10-25% of the tumor cells express MGMT.

The pathology report indicates a fragment of the uterine cervix showing histologic grade 2 invasive squamous cell carcinoma. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion detected. The findings suggest a moderately differentiated tumor without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the antrum of the stomach, measuring 8 x 6.5 x 1 cm, diagnosed as poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/5 positive), and the surgical margins are uninvolved. Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion were not specified, and there is no mention of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates that the right neck zone 4 lymph node and the tail of the right parotid gland show no evidence of tumor, while the right mandible contains poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5.5 cm, with close margins but no perineural or lymphovascular invasion. A total of 47 lymph nodes examined from the neck are negative for tumor, and decalcified sections confirm the invasion of bone by the carcinoma, although bone margins are negative for tumor. An addendum report is pending for further evaluation of the bone sections.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix, characterized as moderately to poorly differentiated with a tumor size of 2.0 x 2.0 cm and significant stromal invasion. All examined lymph nodes (6 in total) and the liver biopsy were negative for metastatic carcinoma, suggesting no spread of cancer to these areas. Surgical margins are clear of tumor, and additional findings include benign changes in the ovaries and fallopian tubes, with lymphovascular space invasion noted in the cervical tumor.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen from the antrum with an ulcerating adenocarcinoma measuring 8 x 8 x 1.5 cm. The tumor is classified as undifferentiated, but details regarding the extent of invasion, lymph nodes, and margins are not specified. There are no additional pathologic findings or comments provided in the report.

The pathology report confirms the presence of moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, with tumor size estimated to be greater than 2 cm and evidence of perineural invasion. Surgical margins from the Whipple resection, including bile duct and pancreatic neck margins, are negative for dysplasia or malignancy, and all examined lymph nodes are free of metastatic disease. Additional findings include background pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN-3) and chronic inflammation, with no lymphovascular invasion identified.

The pathology report describes a right frontal brain tumor characterized as a well-differentiated astrocytoma (WHO grade II) with mild to moderate hypercellularity and diffuse infiltration of gray and white matter. The tumor exhibits mild atypia, lacks mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis, while showing immunoreactivity for p53 and a low MIB-1 labeling index of 2.8%. Additionally, there are features suggestive of a fibrillary astrocytoma pattern with minor areas resembling classic oligodendroglioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 3, measuring 1.8 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present between two identified tumors in the right breast. The surgical margins are negative, with the invasive tumor located 0.15 cm from the posterior margin, and all three sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla are negative for metastases. The report also notes the presence of high nuclear grade DCIS with central necrosis and microcalcifications, and the tumor is ER positive, PR negative, and HER2 positive.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade mullerian type adenocarcinoma with serous features involving the right ovary, fallopian tube, and appendix, with extensive metastatic spread to multiple lymph nodes. The report also notes benign findings in the left ovary and uterus, while the omentum and bladder peritoneum show no evidence of malignancy. Overall, the findings suggest a significant malignancy with extensive regional lymph node involvement and peritoneal metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mucinous adenocarcinoma of the stomach (G3, pT2, pNO) following a total organ resection. The tumor measures 4.2 x 2.6 x 0.9 cm and invades the full thickness of the stomach wall, but the incision lines, omentum, vessels, and lymph nodes are free of neoplastic lesions. The specimen was examined macroscopically and microscopically, confirming the presence of gastric adenocarcinoma with a mixed type.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, involving both lobes of the prostate but remaining organ-confined without evidence of extracapsular extension. The tumor measures 1.3 cm in greatest nodular diameter and comprises less than half of the total prostate volume, with all examined surgical margins and bilateral seminal vesicles free of tumor. Additionally, no carcinoma was found in the seven lymph nodes examined, and there is evidence of focal perineural invasion and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma in the right testicle. The specimen measured 5x4x3 cm and exhibited multiple gray-white nodules, with histological examination revealing solid tumor cell clusters characterized by round and oval nuclei and abundant cytoplasm. Notably, the tumor does not involve the funiculus or rete testis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bilateral papillary serous carcinoma in both the right and left ovaries, with the right ovary showing microscopic tumor extension to its surface and the left ovary exhibiting a grossly visible tumor on its surface. The uterus, pelvic lymph nodes, and omentum showed no evidence of tumor involvement, while a biopsy of the sigmoid colon revealed fibrofatty tissue with serous adenocarcinoma. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IIA, with no lymphatic or vascular invasion identified, and the Her-2/neu test results were negative for overexpression.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant mesothelioma in both the left chest wall and left lingula, characterized by infiltrating malignant epithelioid neoplasm with luminal formation and areas of necrosis. The tumor shows a nodular and diffuse growth pattern, breaching the visceral pleura and extending into the pulmonary parenchyma. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, with positive results for calretinin and other markers, while mucin stains were negative.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two adenocarcinomas located in the proximal and distal ascending colon, with sizes of 4.2 cm and 4.0 cm, respectively, and a cecal tubulovillous adenoma. The tumors exhibit low-grade differentiation, invade through the muscularis propria, and show no lymphovascular or perineural invasion, with negative margins for malignancy. Additionally, two out of twenty-five regional lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, and the findings suggest intact mismatch repair gene function, making hereditary non-polyposis colon cancer unlikely.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left brain tumor diagnosed as glioblastoma, WHO grade IV, following a subtotal resection. The tumor, located in the left frontal lobe, measures up to 5 cm and exhibits high-grade characteristics with pleomorphic nuclei and vascular proliferation. No areas of necrosis were observed, and the findings suggest that the tumor may have originated from a lower-grade lesion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 5.4 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion, renal vein invasion, or angiolymphatic invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is classified as pT1, indicating it is limited to the kidney and does not extend beyond the capsule.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma in the bladder, which is muscle-invasive (pT3a) and has metastasized to some lymph nodes (N2). The bladder tumor measures 25 mm x 20 mm x 10 mm and infiltrates into the muscularis propria, while the surrounding structures, including the uterus, tubes, and ovaries, show no evidence of malignancy. Out of the examined lymph nodes, two show metastatic involvement, while others are free of cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has endometrial adenocarcinoma of the endometrioid type, which involves 60% of the endometrial surface and invades 6 mm of the myometrium, with a background of complex atypical hyperplasia. Additionally, there is a poorly differentiated adenosquamous carcinoma involving the cervix, with lymphovascular invasion present, and both tumors are classified as synchronous primary tumors. All examined lymph nodes and other excised tissues, including the omentum and appendix, are negative for metastatic tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has moderately differentiated serous carcinoma of the right ovary, with a tumor size of 12.2 cm. There is evidence of metastatic serous carcinoma in the uterus, right fallopian tube, omentum, left ovary, left fallopian tube, and a bladder flap tumor. The uterus shows no evidence of endometrial carcinoma, and two leiomyomas are noted in the myometrium.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, in the right breast, with a tumor size of 2.5 x 2.5 x 2 cm and negative surgical margins. The right sentinel axillary and axillary lymph nodes, as well as a biopsy of the right breast skin and adipose tissue, are all negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, the left breast shows proliferative fibrocystic changes and a 0.5 cm fibroadenoma, with neoplastic cells testing negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has undergone resection of a right frontal lobe tumor, which has been diagnosed as a diffuse astrocytoma, WHO Grade II. Microscopic examination reveals a moderately hypercellular tumor with no mitotic activity or necrosis, and immunohistochemical analysis shows positive p53 staining and negative IDH-1 mutation status. Additionally, the MGMT methylation assay results indicate that gene methylation was not detected, suggesting a potential resistance to alkylating agents like temozolomide.

The pathology report indicates a unifocal papillary carcinoma located in the left thyroid, measuring 5x3x3 cm. The tumor exhibits invasion of the capsule and is characterized by papillae with a fibrovascular stalk, covered by cuboidal epithelial cells that maintain polarity. There is no extrathyroidal extension noted, but there is evidence of lymphocyte and fibrous invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, FIGO grade I, with myometrial invasion measuring 5 mm and no vascular space invasion identified. All examined lymph nodes (23 in total) are negative for tumor, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. Additional findings include complex hyperplasia and adenomyosis, with no tumors identified in the ovaries or cervix.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade adrenocortical carcinoma measuring 8.5 x 8.5 x 6.2 cm, with capsular invasion present but no vascular invasion, and negative surgical margins. The tumor appears to have arisen from a pre-existing adrenocortical adenoma, and there is focal necrosis observed within the tumor. Additionally, a biopsy of the liver capsule was negative for neoplasm, and the left perirenal fat was identified as benign fibroadipose tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma, specifically the tall cell variant in the right lobe (1.3 cm) and multiple foci of follicular variant microcarcinomas in the left lobe, with lymphovascular invasion noted in both lobes. The surgical margins are uninvolved by carcinoma, and no regional lymph node metastasis was found in the examined lymph nodes. Additional findings include multinodular hyperplasia and mild lymphocytic thyroiditis, with no parathyroid gland identified in the specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of stomach adenocarcinoma, characterized as partly tubular, mucous, and solid, with evidence of metastases to regional lymph nodes and invasion of surrounding tissues. The tumor measures 8 x 5 x 2 cm and shows significant infiltration into the gastric wall and perigastric fat, while the proximal and distal margins are free of cancer. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals that the cancerous cells are cytokeratin 7-positive, and HER2 protein was also assessed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, characterized by a centrally necrotic mass measuring 6 x 6 x 5 cm, located 1.5 cm from the bronchial resection margin. The tumor has invaded the visceral pleura over an area of approximately 3 x 3 cm, but the bronchial margin is negative for tumor. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from the superior and inferior mediastinum, as well as N1 nodes, were excised and found to be negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of advanced gastric carcinoma, specifically a moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma with an intestinal type, located in the lower third of the stomach. The tumor measures 4.8x4.3 cm, invades the subserosa (pT3), and shows metastasis to 3 out of 86 regional lymph nodes (pN2), with mild lymphatic invasion and moderate perineural invasion. The resection margins are free from carcinoma, with safety margins of 3.4 cm distally and 6.0 cm proximally.

The pathology report indicates a left upper lobectomy revealing a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 45 mm, with no pleural invasion and clear bronchial resection margins. The report notes that the peribronchial, left hilar, and mediastinal lymph nodes show reactive changes without evidence of tumor involvement. Additionally, the adjacent lung parenchyma exhibits obstructive pneumonitis and emphysema, with a pathological stage of pT2a N0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 oligodendroglioma in the left frontal lobe of the brain, characterized by a low MIB-1 labeling index. FISH studies revealed abnormal ratios for 1p and 19q, consistent with deletions commonly associated with oligodendrogliomas. The findings support the diagnosis and suggest the presence of chromosomal abnormalities typical of this type of glioma.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma located in the rectosigmoid region, measuring 3.3 cm in diameter and extending 4 cm to the aboral resection margin. The tumor has invaded the inner layers of the muscularis propria, but both the oral and aboral resection margins are free of tumor. Additionally, all 34 examined local lymph nodes are tumor-free, resulting in a staging of pT2 pN0 (0/34) G2 R0.

The pathology report indicates that a left orchidectomy was performed, revealing a seminoma with a diameter of 7 cm. There is no evidence of angio-invasion or invasion of the rete testis. The findings suggest a localized tumor without aggressive features.

The pathology report indicates that the anterior tongue mucosa and other excised specimens are negative for tumor, except for the right base of the tongue, which shows infiltrating HPV-related squamous cell carcinoma measuring 6 cm. The carcinoma invades to a maximum depth of 1.3 cm and extends to the deep and lateral margins, closely approaching the medial margin. Overall, the findings suggest a localized malignancy at the right base of the tongue with no evidence of tumor in the other examined areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma, measuring 20.0 cm, with a grade of 3, and focal presence at the inked resection margin. Additionally, two lymph nodes were examined, with one showing tumor by direct extension but no evidence of discontinuous spread, resulting in a classification of N0. The tumor is staged as T2b/N0/MX/G3, indicating a high-grade sarcoma without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 1.8 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and a close anterior margin of less than 0.1 cm. Sentinel lymph nodes were examined, and all three nodes were reactive and negative for metastatic carcinoma. The tumor is classified as SBR Grade II, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, and a recurrence score of 7, suggesting a low risk of distant recurrence.

The pathology report indicates the presence of chronic inflammatory lesions with pseudocyst formation in the soft tissue, potentially identified as oil cysts. Additionally, it reveals poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type in the rectosigmoidal resection, measuring 4 cm and infiltrating pericolic fatty tissue, with two regional lymph node metastases. The tumor-free margins in the colon and mesentery suggest a tumor stage of pT3 pN1 (2/25) pMX; G3, L1, V0, R0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive adenocarcinoma of the rectosigmoid colon, moderately differentiated, with tumor invasion through the muscularis propria into subserosal tissue. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in 3 out of 17 examined lymph nodes, while the left iliac lymph node biopsy was benign and negative for metastatic carcinoma. The anastomotic rings showed no significant pathological alterations, and no malignancy was detected in that specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with a tumor diameter of 3.0 cm. The minimum distance to the dorsal margin is 0.3 cm, while other margins are free at 1 cm. The tumor classification is noted as NOS, G II, pT2N0(sn)LOVORO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a tumor size of 4x3x3 cm. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/13 positive). Additional details regarding lymphatic and venous invasion, margins, and neo-adjuvant treatment are not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of unifocal papillary carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 2.5 cm. The tumor is classified as pT2, meaning it is greater than 2 cm but less than 4 cm and is confined to the thyroid, with uninvolved margins and no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. Regional lymph nodes and distant metastasis could not be assessed, as none were submitted for evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, mixed type (90% endometrioid and 10% clear cell), FIGO grade 3, with a tumor measuring 3.6 x 2.9 x 2.0 cm located in the posterior uterine wall, invading 0.1 cm into the myometrium, but not involving the endocervix or lymphovascular spaces. All examined lymph nodes and peritoneal biopsies are negative for tumor involvement, and the surgical margins are clear of cancer. The bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are also not involved by the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrioid adenocarcinoma with extensive squamous differentiation in the uterus, classified as FIGO grade 2, with invasion into less than half of the myometrial thickness and lymphovascular invasion noted. Rare, scattered epithelial cells were identified in sentinel lymph nodes on immunohistochemical staining, but their significance remains uncertain, and no metastatic carcinoma was found in the examined lymph nodes. Additional sections from the cervix confirmed no endocervical involvement by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous keratinized carcinoma (G2) of the right side of the tongue, with a tumor size of 2.5 x 2.2 x 1 cm. The minimum margins of healthy tissue from the surgical specimen are 0.4 cm on the side and 0.5 cm at the base, with a peritumoral lymphocytic reaction noted. Additionally, a fragment of salivary gland tissue was examined, which showed no evidence of tumor invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, in the left lobe of the thyroid, measuring 3 cm and classified as unifocal. There is evidence of metastatic carcinoma in 7 out of 20 lymph nodes, with the primary tumor classified as pT2 and regional lymph nodes as pN1a, indicating significant spread. Additionally, the report notes involved margins by invasive carcinoma and the presence of lymphocytic thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive poorly differentiated mucinous signet ring cell adenocarcinoma in the transverse colon, which has extended through the colonic wall into the adjacent omentum. The proximal, distal, and radial margins of resection are free of tumor, but 13 out of 41 examined mesenteric lymph nodes show metastatic adenocarcinoma. Additionally, vascular invasion by the tumor is present, and the appendix shows no significant histopathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates that the bilateral supraomohyoid neck dissection revealed no tumors in the majority of lymph nodes, with a microscopic focus of thyroid carcinoma found in one of five midjugular lymph nodes. The left lingual nerve and left inferior alveolar nerve biopsies showed benign nerves with no tumors present. Additionally, the subtotal mandibulectomy identified invasive well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, but the margins of resection were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous adenocarcinoma in the right ovary, classified as FIGO grade 2, with a tumor size of 10 x 3 x 3 cm and staging of 2B. The left ovary also shows serous carcinoma, measuring 1.6 cm, alongside leiomyoma, while the uterus reveals multiple leiomyomata and a proliferative endometrium. Additional biopsies from the left pelvic sidewall and omentum show no tumor, but the posterior cul-de-sac biopsy confirms the presence of serous carcinoma with marked squamous differentiation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with moderate differentiation, characterized by a single tumor measuring 85mm, surrounded by a fibrous capsule, and showing evidence of lymphovascular invasion. The tumor is located 12mm from the resection margin, with no significant bile production or underlying liver fibrosis noted, although mild steatosis and chronic inflammation are present in the background liver. Additionally, the gallbladder specimen shows no evidence of malignancy, despite being heavily autolysed.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma in both the right and left ovaries, with tumor sizes of 3 cm and 4 cm, respectively, and involvement of the serosa. Additionally, numerous tumor nodules are noted in the omentum, and there is evidence of metastatic tumor spread to the uterus and right fallopian tube. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3c pNX pMX, indicating advanced disease with significant spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, Type 1, measuring 5.8 cm, following a partial nephrectomy of the right kidney. The tumor is graded as Fuhrman grade 2 and is located at the mid to inferior pole of the right kidney, with the closest surgical margin being less than 0.1 cm. There is no evidence of tumor in the surrounding renal parenchyma, perirenal fat, or lymph nodes, and the AJCC stage is classified as pT1bNXMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma from the excised right adrenal mass. The tumor is characterized by positive chromogranin staining and the presence of sustentacular cells as indicated by S-100 staining. The specimen measured 5 x 4.5 x 2.5 cm and exhibited soft, fleshy tissue with multiple hemorrhagic foci.

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy of the right lower lobe lung revealed an invasive grade 3 adenocarcinoma, measuring 5 x 4 x 3 cm, with negative bronchial margins and one positive intrapulmonary lymph node for metastatic adenocarcinoma. Additionally, a wedge excision of the right upper lobe showed necrotizing granuloma, while multiple lymph nodes from the inferior and superior mediastinum were involved with necrotizing granulomatous lymphadenitis but were negative for tumor. Special stains for microorganisms on the subcarinal lymph nodes were reported negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma arising in the context of an intraductal pancreatic mucinous neoplasm with severe dysplasia, classified as AJCC stage pT2 N0. The tumor, measuring 5.0 cm, is well-differentiated and confined to the pancreas, with negative resection margins and no lymph node metastasis identified (0/5 lymph nodes). Additionally, perineural invasion is present, and there is a noted high-grade dysplasia associated with the intraductal neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a benign paratubal cyst and a poorly differentiated non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 3.9 cm, with significant circumferential involvement and stromal invasion of 6 mm. There is no evidence of parametrial, lymphovascular, or perineural invasion, and all examined lymph nodes (22 total) are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The report concludes with an AJCC Pathologic Stage of pT2a1 pNO, pending further clinical review.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma in the right hemithyroid, specifically a dominant oncocytic mixed follicular and macrofollicular variant measuring 1.3 cm, alongside chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis and mild follicular nodular disease. The tumor is encapsulated with no evidence of capsular, lymph-vascular, or perineural invasion, and the margins are uninvolved by carcinoma. Additionally, a second smaller tumor measuring 0.4 cm is noted, with both tumors classified as pT1b, indicating they are confined to the thyroid.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right ovaries and fallopian tubes show benign findings, including corpora albicantia and serous cysts, with no significant abnormalities in the fallopian tubes. The uterus exhibits a mixed pattern carcinoma with predominantly serous components, classified as grade 3, measuring 9.5 x 7.5 cm, with myometrial invasion of 1.7 cm and no cervical involvement. Lymph node excisions reveal multiple positive nodes for metastatic carcinoma, indicating advanced disease with a pTNM stage of pT1b, N2 (FIGO: IIIC2).

The pathology report indicates histomorphological features consistent with diffuse astrocytoma, characterized by increased mitotic activity. The proliferation index is noted to be 7%. The final diagnosis is anaplastic astrocytoma, classified as WHO grade III.

The pathology report indicates the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma in the resected prostate, with a Gleason score of 6 (Grade 3 + 3) and approximately 25% of the prostatic gland involved. Surgical resection margins are negative for tumor, and there is no evidence of extraprostatic extension or tumor involvement in the bilateral seminal vesicles. Additional findings include benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and no lymph nodes were sampled during the procedure.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma of the right ovary, classified as FIGO stage 3C, with a tumor size of 4.2 x 3.2 x 1.9 cm and evidence of tumor on the surface of the serosa. Multiple metastatic sites were identified, including the left gutter tumor, cul-de-sac nodule, omentum, bladder sac peritoneum, and right pelvic lymph nodes, with five out of twelve lymph nodes showing positive for metastatic disease. Additional specimens, such as the right inguinal mass and left pelvic lymph nodes, were either free of tumor or contained psammoma bodies without tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 2, measuring 1.6 cm, with metastatic carcinoma found in both sentinel lymph nodes (2/2). The resection margins from the right total mastectomy are free of tumor, with the closest margin being 2.0 cm deep, and no malignancy detected in five additional lymph nodes examined (0/5). Predictive markers show the tumor is estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) positive, and HER2 is amplified, indicating a specific profile for targeted therapy considerations.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically papillary type 2 with Fuhrman's nuclear grade 4, measuring 4.5 x 4.0 x 3.0 cm, and showing invasion into the perirenal soft tissue along with lymphovascular invasion. There is evidence of metastasis to the perirenal soft tissue, but the margins of resection and the adrenal gland show no tumor presence. Additionally, four inter-aortocaval lymph nodes were examined, and no tumor was found in those samples.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus, with a tumor size of 3.8 x 3.2 x 0.7 cm and no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/8). The resection margins are free of carcinoma, and the cervical esophageal margin is unremarkable. Additionally, a small bowel nodule was identified as an incidental accessory spleen, which was negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that a partial mastectomy revealed an invasive ductal adenocarcinoma of the breast, measuring 2.0 cm, with a Nottingham combined histologic grade of 3 and no lymphatic or vascular invasion. One of three sentinel lymph nodes examined was positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes and other excised breast tissue margins showed no evidence of malignancy. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and further receptor analysis is pending.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma located in a lobe, measuring 6x6x4 cm with ill-defined margins and areas of necrosis. Microscopic examination reveals tumor cells arranged in trabecular, acinar, and tubular patterns, characterized by polygonal shapes, large hyperchromatic nuclei, and moderate basophilic cytoplasm. The tumor is focal and shows evidence of mitotic activity, with uninvolved margins and no indication of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a grade 2 adenocarcinoma of the endocervix, measuring 1.1 cm and invading 8 mm, with no vascular space invasion and negative margins. All examined lymph nodes (15 total) and additional vaginal margins show no evidence of tumor or dysplasia. Additional findings include benign endometrium, superficial adenomyosis, and focal squamous severe dysplasia in the cervix.

The pathology report indicates that the left sentinel lymph node biopsy shows metastatic carcinoma with a 1.5 mm micrometastasis, while the left breast mastectomy reveals a 3.0 cm invasive ductal carcinoma classified as Nottingham grade 3, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and lymphovascular invasion. The surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement, with the closest margin being 0.7 cm from the invasive component. Additionally, the tumor exhibits positive estrogen receptors and negative progesterone receptors, with one of eighteen examined axillary lymph nodes showing metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the peritoneal implant biopsy is negative for malignancy. The rectosigmoid colon resection reveals a mucinous adenocarcinoma, grade 2, with invasion into pericolonic soft tissue, but negative margins and no evidence of malignancy in 32 examined lymph nodes. Additionally, hyperplastic polyps are noted in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma, a type of malignant tumor, found in a pelvic mass and associated with tumor deposits in various tissues including the omentum and peri-enteric soft tissue. The tumor is poorly differentiated, measuring 16 cm, with a high mitotic rate and evidence of necrosis, classified as FNCLCC grade 3. No invasion into the colon, appendix, or ileum was identified, but multiple tumor nodules were present in the surrounding soft tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO Grade III endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with significant myometrial invasion and extensive vascular invasion, but no endocervical invasion. The excised lymph nodes from various regions, including para-aortic and iliac nodes, were all negative for carcinoma, indicating no lymphatic spread of the cancer. Additionally, the left ovary and fallopian tube were unremarkable, with the presence of a benign leiomyoma in the left tube ovary.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma from a right robotic partial nephrectomy, with a tumor size of 2.5 cm and Fuhrman grade 3. There is no evidence of capsular invasion or major vein involvement, and the surgical margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, a benign simple cyst measuring 1 cm was identified, and the staging is classified as pT1a pNx.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2 cm, with negative margins and no pleural involvement. All examined lymph nodes and the bronchial margin are negative for malignancy, confirming no regional metastasis. The pathologic stage is classified as pT1a, pN0, and pM0, indicating localized disease without lymph node or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a clinical diagnosis of a brain tumor, with gross examination revealing soft gray-whitish tissue from the right temporal lobe. Microscopic analysis confirms the presence of anaplastic oligodendroglioma, characterized by a Ki 67 proliferation index of up to 15%. The final diagnosis is anaplastic oligodendroglioma classified as Grade III.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately-differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right colon, specifically a tumor measuring 5.2 x 4.0 cm that invades into, but not through, the muscularis propria. The surgical margins are negative for cancer, and there is no evidence of vascular invasion or regional lymph node involvement, as all twelve examined lymph nodes are negative. Additional findings include an unremarkable appendix and ileum, with the appendix showing fibrous luminal obliteration.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated papillary serous carcinoma involving both the left and right ovaries and fallopian tubes, with extensive lymphovascular space invasion. Metastatic carcinoma is also present in the omentum, small intestine, and all examined mesenteric lymph nodes, indicating widespread disease. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IIIC, with significant peritoneal metastasis and a maximum dimension of tumor implants outside the true pelvis measuring 8.0 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade myxofibrosarcoma in the right medial thigh, which is diffusely infiltrating skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. The tumor measures 4.4 x 2.8 x 2.5 cm and extends to multiple inked surgical margins, indicating incomplete excision. The specimen also includes an elliptical segment of skin with a well-healed surgical scar, and the tumor shows a lobulated, light yellow cut surface without hemorrhage or necrosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the left upper lobe of the lung, with evidence of asbestos exposure. The tumor measures up to 4.8 cm and has infiltrated the visceral pleura, but the resection margins and all examined lymph nodes are free of tumor. Additionally, there is active chronic retention pneumonia at the tumor margin, and further investigations are recommended to assess the extent of asbestos exposure.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the right lateral tongue, with a depth of invasion measuring 1.3 cm and perineural invasion present, although margins are free of tumor. During the right selective neck dissection, one out of eight lymph nodes at level I showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while lymph nodes at levels II, III, and IV were negative for neoplasm. The findings confirm the presence of the carcinoma and its limited spread, necessitating further management.

The pathology report indicates the presence of anaplastic oligodendroglioma, characterized by hypercellular brain tissue with neoplastic cells showing cytoplasmic immunoreactivity for GFAP and a MIB-1 labeling index of 6.5%. The microscopic examination reveals sheets and irregular nodules of neoplastic cells with extensive necrosis, moderate atypia, and rare mitotic figures, alongside reactive small cells and macrophages containing hemosiderin. Overall, the histological features are consistent with the diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma, with evidence of diffuse infiltration in some areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Anaplastic Oligoastrocytoma, predominantly featuring astrocytoma characteristics, with a MIB-1 labeling index of 9.2%. The tumor is described as moderately hypercellular with significant cytologic atypia, including gemistocytic cells and fibrillary astrocytes, along with areas of perivascular lymphocytic cuffing and minor foci of classic oligodendroglioma. Scattered mitotic figures are also noted, suggesting active proliferation within the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with two foci measuring 1.2 cm and 1.8 cm, and micrometastatic mammary carcinoma (0.23 mm) identified in one of the left axillary sentinel lymph nodes. The second sentinel lymph node showed no evidence of malignancy, and all additional margins and tissues examined were negative for carcinoma. The final pathologic staging is pT2N(sn)1miM, indicating the presence of micrometastasis in the sentinel lymph nodes but no distant metastasis.

The pathology report describes a low-grade oligodendroglioma (grade II) characterized by a variably cellular tumor that infiltrates both gray and white matter, with notable perineural and perivascular satellitosis. The tumor cells exhibit mild to moderate atypia, with a low mitotic count and no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis, indicating a lack of anaplastic progression. Despite the overall low grade, the presence of scattered mitoses and a mildly elevated labeling index suggests the need for close follow-up.

The pathology report indicates the presence of acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5), showing focal extra-prostatic extension and invasion of the left seminal vesicle. Surgical margins are free of invasive carcinoma, and there is perineural invasion present, but lymphovascular invasion is absent. No lymph nodes were involved by metastasis, with a pathological staging of pT3b, pNO, pMX.

The pathology report indicates that the right neck dissections at various levels and the right paratracheal lymph nodes show no tumor presence. However, a total laryngectomy and thyroidectomy revealed a moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, with invasion into cartilage but no perineural or vascular invasion. The tumor margins are negative for carcinoma, suggesting that the tumor has not spread beyond the immediate area.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph nodes show no evidence of metastasis in the two examined nodes (0/2). The left breast excisional biopsy reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma, grade 3, measuring 2.5 cm, with close margins (0.5 mm) and associated ductal carcinoma in situ of comedo and solid subtypes, also grade 3, with necrosis. The report highlights that the invasive carcinoma has no vessel invasion, but the margins are positive for in situ carcinoma at the posterior margin.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has bilateral infiltrating ductal carcinoma, with the right breast tumor measuring 2.5 cm and classified as poorly differentiated (Nottingham Grade 3) with one sentinel lymph node positive for microscopic tumor involvement. The left breast tumor is larger at 5.0 cm, also poorly differentiated (Nottingham Grade 3), but with all examined lymph nodes negative for cancer. Hormone receptor analysis shows the right tumor is estrogen receptor positive (90%) and progesterone receptor positive (10%), while the left tumor is nearly 100% estrogen receptor positive, 40% progesterone receptor positive, and HER2 positive.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 2.2 cm, with extensive lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) also identified. Of the two sentinel lymph nodes examined, one showed rare cytokeratin-positive cells, while the other was benign, indicating no significant metastatic involvement. Surgical margins were negative for invasive carcinoma, although LCIS was present in the medial, superior, inferior, and lateral margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) from biopsies taken from the right temporal lobe of the brain. Microscopic examination revealed necrotic tissue consistent with glioblastoma, and multiple specimens were submitted for analysis, showing varying sizes and characteristics of the tumor. The gross description details the tumor's soft tissue fragments, with significant hemorrhagic features noted in the largest specimens.

The pathology report indicates that the right upper lobe lung resection revealed an invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 6.6 cm, with focal invasion of the visceral pleura and vascular invasion present, but all resection margins and lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. Additional biopsies from the chest wall margins and various lymph nodes showed fibroadipose tissue and lymph nodes that were also negative for malignancy. The overall diagnosis is consistent with pT2N0 squamous cell carcinoma, with associated findings of peritumoral infarct and mild emphysematous changes in the lung.

The pathology report indicates a left kidney tumor diagnosed as a 3 cm variant of papillary renal cell carcinoma, specifically a solid variant with nuclear grade 1. The tumor is limited to the kidney, with margins free of tumor and no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. Immunohistochemical studies support the diagnosis, and the tumor is associated with a better survival rate compared to classic clear renal cell carcinomas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, in the left breast, with a tumor size of 2.0 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm and focal high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ present. All surgical margins are negative for tumor, and a single isolated tumor cell cluster was found in one of the three left axillary sentinel lymph nodes, measuring 0.11 mm. Non-neoplastic changes in the breast tissue include fibrocystic changes, and a nonsentinel lymph node was negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lymph nodes from various levels are negative for malignancy, with one lymph node at level IX and one at level XI also showing no signs of cancer. The right upper lobe lobectomy revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.0 cm, with clear surgical margins and no pleural involvement. Additionally, multiple peribronchial lymph nodes were negative for malignancy, confirming no regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 1, in the uterus, with a 6 x 3.5 x 0.4 cm exophytic mass that shows no myometrial invasion. The peritoneal biopsy and both left and right pelvic lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. Overall, the tumor is classified as minimally invasive, with no vascular invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a 3.1 cm unifocal tumor located in the right lower lobe of the lung, with no evidence of invasion into adjacent structures or lymphovascular space. All surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, with the nearest margin being 3 cm from the tumor, and all sampled lymph nodes are benign. The tumor is staged as pT2a, and there are no additional significant findings noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segments IV through VIII, characterized by a multinodular mass with multiple satellite nodules and extensive extratumoral vascular invasion, while the hepatic capsule and surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, a bile duct hamartoma was identified in liver segment III, and a biopsy of the peritoneum revealed inflammatory adhesion with no evidence of tumor. The non-neoplastic liver tissue shows no signs of primary or chronic liver disease.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe (LUL) of the lung. The tumor is classified as stage III, specifically T2, with no regional lymph node involvement (N0) and no distant metastasis (M0). The tumor was resected, and the size is noted as 3.20 cm.

The pathology report indicates that two lymph nodes from level X and one from level VII and level V are negative for metastatic carcinoma, while the left upper lobe excision reveals a 5.5 cm invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with two out of eight hilar lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. The primary tumor is classified as pT2b, showing minimal extension into the pleura and vessel invasion present in a large vessel. Overall, the findings suggest localized lung cancer with some regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates that a 70-year-old female underwent a Whipple procedure for a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor, which was found to be well-differentiated and measured up to 1.3 cm in greatest dimension, with evidence of lymph node metastasis in five out of nine regional lymph nodes. The liver biopsy showed no viable tumor, and the margins of the pancreatic resection were free of tumor, although the tumor was close to the retroperitoneal resection margin. Additionally, focal acute pancreatitis was noted, but no perineural invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon, classified as rectal carcinoma G2, with extensive infiltration into the muscularis, corresponding to pT2. There is evidence of vascular infiltration (L1, V1), but the resection margins are free of tumor, including the deep resection margin and mucosal region, along with free lymph nodes and anastomosis ring. The tumor classification is ICDO-DA M 8140/3, G2, pT2 L1, V1, pNO (0/12).

The pathology report indicates that the abdominal tissue from the abdominoplasty is unremarkable, while the left adnexa shows endometriosis in the fallopian tube but no tumors in either ovary or tube. The right adnexa is similarly negative for tumors, and the total abdominal hysterectomy reveals a poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 3, measuring 5.5 cm with less than 50% myometrial invasion and no lymphovascular invasion. The report notes the patient's history of BRCA1 mutation and previous endometrioid adenocarcinoma, with negative pelvic wash specimens for malignant cells.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an invasive grade 3 adenocarcinoma consistent with cholangiocarcinoma in the liver, with a mass measuring 4.8 x 3.1 x 3.0 cm and extensive necrosis. Surgical margins, including the retroperitoneal margin, are negative for malignancy, indicating successful resection. Additionally, the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis and cholesterolosis with the presence of stones.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type located in the cecum, measuring 5.5 cm, with infiltration into the pericolic fatty tissue but no regional lymph node metastases. Both the small and large intestinal resection margins, as well as the mesenteric resection margin, are tumor-free. Additionally, two submucosal lipomas were found in the ascending colon, and the tumor is staged as pT3 pNO (0/27) pMX; G2, L0, V0, R0.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a CD5-positive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma involving the full thickness of the terminal ileum, ileocecal valve, and cecum, with no tumor present in five examined lymph nodes. FISH analysis was negative for the t(11;14) translocation, which, along with negative cyclin D1 immunohistochemical staining, excludes mantle cell lymphoma. The tumor exhibits a diffuse infiltrate of atypical lymphocytes and has a MIB-1 proliferative index of approximately 50%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe, with a tumor size of 3.3 cm and negative surgical margins (R0). A total of 25 lymph nodes were examined, and no tumor was identified in any of them (0/25), resulting in a pathologic stage of IB. Additional findings include the absence of lymphovascular and perineural invasion, and the presence of uninvolved lung with organizing pneumonia.

The pathology report describes a 5 cm gray dense-elastic tumor on the tongue, characterized as a Grade 1 keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma with ulceration. There is evidence of venous invasion, and the tumor is localized with absent margins. Additionally, fatty tissue from the left side shows hemorrhages, while six lymph nodes from the right side appear morphologically normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade malignant fibrous histiocytoma, pleomorphic and storiform type, following a radical excision of a sarcoma from the right proximal thigh, measuring 7.0 x 5.6 x 4.5 cm. The tumor was found to involve deep skeletal muscle with approximately 15% necrosis, but the surgical margins were widely free of tumor. Additionally, one benign lymph node was identified, and the surrounding skin was noted to be benign.

The pathology report indicates that all sentinel lymph nodes (7 total) are negative for metastases, confirming no tumor cells were found in these nodes. The right breast wide local excision revealed an invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 1.8 cm, with negative surgical margins and the presence of focal atypical ductal hyperplasia. Hormone receptor analysis showed positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 testing was equivocal, with further evaluation pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated, ulcerated urothelial carcinoma (pT3b pN1 R0) following a radical cystoprostatectomy, with the tumor extending into the perivesical fat and approaching the surgical margin on the right side. Two peri-bladder lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma, with one exhibiting extracapsular extension, while other examined lymph nodes and ureteric margins are free of metastatic disease. The prostate shows high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) but no evidence of adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with a tumor diameter of 1.8 cm. The tumor is classified as not otherwise specified (NOS), grade III, and staged as pT1Nla(sn)LOVORO. This suggests a localized cancer with aggressive characteristics.

The pathology report describes a 3x3x2 cm moderately sized tumor in the liver, characterized by firm, solid, yellow-white tissue with focal necrosis. Microscopic examination reveals poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with irregularly large, hyperchromatic nuclei, abundant eosinophilic or clear cytoplasm, and the presence of mitoses. The tumor exhibits trabecular, tubular, and acinar patterns, with evidence of necrosis and lymphocyte invasion.

The pathology report indicates that a mediastinal tumor was excised, and the morphological and immunohistochemical findings are consistent with a diagnosis of Type AB Thymoma according to WHO classification. The surgical margins are reported to be uninvolved by neoplasia. Overall, the findings suggest a successful excision of the tumor with no evidence of residual disease at the margins.

The pathology report indicates that the excision biopsy of a right frontal brain tumor has been diagnosed as glioblastoma, classified as WHO Grade IV. The tumor exhibits characteristics of a high-grade glioma, including pleomorphism, mitotic activity, vascular proliferation, and necrosis, with a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 30%. Additional studies are recommended for further analysis, particularly for 1p19q co-deletion status due to the presence of oligodendroglioma features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, with a tumor mass measuring 5.5 x 3.8 x 3.7 cm located in the inferior pole. The tumor is confined to the kidney and shows a tumor thrombus in the renal vein measuring 6 cm, but there is no involvement of the collecting system, and no sarcomatoid differentiation or coagulative necrosis is present. Surgical margins are negative, and multiple left periaortic lymph nodes are negative for tumor, indicating no lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that the left frontal brain tumor is diagnosed as a mixed oligoastrocytoma, classified as WHO grade 2, with no evidence of mitoses, vascular proliferation, or necrosis. Genetic testing revealed no loss of 1p or 19q chromosomal regions, and there was also no amplification of the EGFR gene. The tumor cells exhibited variable staining for GFAP, vimentin, and S100, with a low proliferation index of 2-3%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma of the left lung, exhibiting both squamous and high-grade spindle cell features, with involvement of the pleural surface. All surgical margins of resection are negative for tumor, and one hilar lymph node along with associated fibroadipose tissue is also negative for tumor. Additionally, two other lymph nodes (Station 5 and L11) and their associated fibroadipose tissues are negative for tumor, while the uninvolved lung parenchyma shows emphysematous changes.

The pathology report indicates that a 79-year-old male underwent a total nephrectomy of the left kidney, revealing a renal cell carcinoma of the papillary type (Type 2) with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 7.5 cm, which extends through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia. Additionally, metastatic involvement was found in six para-aortic lymph nodes, with the largest metastatic node measuring 3.5 cm and exhibiting perinodal extension. The adrenal gland was unremarkable, and surgical margins were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+3=6, showing bilateral involvement and a positive margin at the right apical region. The tumor has invaded the capsule but shows no extraprostatic extension or involvement of the seminal vesicles, with no perineural infiltration or prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia noted. The overall staging is classified as pT2cNXMX, and the estimated tumor volume is 2.4 cm.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast needle localization excision revealed atypical lobular hyperplasia and changes from a previous biopsy, while the right breast mastectomy showed multifocal invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 2.2 cm, with negative margins and associated ductal carcinoma in situ. Sentinel lymph node biopsies from the right axilla showed no tumor in either of the two lymph nodes examined. The Oncotype DX assay indicated a low recurrence score of 8, suggesting a low risk of distant recurrence over ten years.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) measuring 2.0 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising 60% of the tumor mass, both showing high nuclear grade and significant lymphovascular invasion. Surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, but the invasive component is close to the anterior margin, and one sentinel lymph node is negative for metastatic carcinoma. The invasive tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER-2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma in a retroperitoneal mass measuring 21.0 cm, with significant areas of necrosis and a malignant fibrous histiocytoma-like growth pattern. The tumor also contains focal low-grade areas of sclerosing liposarcoma with myxoid changes, and microscopic examination shows that the tumor extends to the inked surface. The specimen was large, lobulated, and weighed 1.5 kg, with approximately 60% necrotic tissue and various characteristics noted in the gross description.

The pathology report indicates that the right paratracheal and left paratracheal lymph nodes showed no pathological diagnosis, while the total thyroidectomy revealed a unifocal papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 5.4 cm, with focal thyroiditis present. The tumor is encapsulated with minimal capsular invasion, and no regional lymph node metastasis was identified among the nine examined. Additional findings include normal parathyroid glands and nonspecific focal thyroiditis, with the margins of the tumor uninvolved by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of an invasive intraductal tubulopapillary neoplasm in the head of the pancreas, measuring 6.5x5.0x5.0 cm, with lymphatic and perineural invasion present, but no blood vessel invasion. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and metastasis is noted in 7 out of 28 lymph nodes, leading to a pathologic stage of pT3N1. Additional biopsies for potential liver mass and peritoneal seeding showed mesothelial cell hyperplasia and atypical glands, but no tumor was present in the other sites examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 6.2 x 4.6 x 3 cm and Fuhrman's nuclear grade 3. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with negative margins and no evidence of vascular or perinephric tissue invasion. Additionally, adjacent renal parenchyma shows signs of acute and chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis and focal glomerulosclerosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 1.6 x 1.5 x 1.3 cm, classified as Nottingham grade I (of III) and AJCC pT1c, with ductular involvement but no angiolymphatic invasion. Surgical margins and right sentinel lymph nodes are negative for tumor, confirming successful excision. The carcinoma is positive for estrogen receptors and negative for progesterone receptors.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a left frontal brain tumor, diagnosed as at least anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO grade III) based on frozen section analysis, with final grading pending permanent sections. Microscopic examination reveals a malignant diffuse glioma with features suggesting mixed glioma, specifically an anaplastic oligoastrocytoma (WHO grade III). Further testing, including a FISH study for 1P/19Q deletion, is planned to provide additional diagnostic information.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade metastatic urothelial carcinoma, with matted lymph nodes in both the left and right pelvic regions showing extensive lymphovascular and extranodal invasion. A radical cystectomy revealed invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder and prostate, with additional metastatic involvement in the ileocecum and lymph nodes. The overall staging is pT4a, N2, M1, indicating advanced disease with multiple sites of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the left eye enucleation revealed a tumor consistent with uveal melanoma, predominantly composed of epithelioid cells with severe cytological atypia and significant necrosis and hemorrhage. The tumor measures 18 mm and infiltrates the sclera, but there is no extra-scleral extension, and the optic nerve, ciliary body, and anterior chamber are free of tumor involvement. Additionally, there is evidence of intra-scleral endovascular tumor embolism.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, with multiple foci of cancer and a Nottingham score of 8/9, indicating a high-grade tumor. Metastatic carcinoma was found in multiple sentinel lymph nodes, with one node measuring 1.3 cm and exhibiting extracapsular extension. Surgical margins are clear of tumor, and the tumor is positive for estrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, and HER-2/NEU.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade urothelial carcinoma (transitional cell carcinoma) located in the right posterior lateral wall of the bladder, measuring 2.5 x 2.0 x 1.2 cm, with perinodal invasion present and one of three examined pelvic lymph nodes showing metastatic carcinoma. The radical cystoprostatectomy revealed extensive invasion of the prostate by the urothelial carcinoma, while the seminal vesicles were negative for malignancy. The pathological staging is pT4, pN1, and the right kidney showed marked chronic nephritis with hydronephrosis, but no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report describes a lobectomy specimen from the lung, revealing a 6x7x6 cm bronchopulmonary neoplasm diagnosed as moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with keratinization. The tumor shows infiltration into interlobar and hilar lymph nodes, with 2 out of 6 lymph nodes positive for metastasis, while no metastases were found in the triangular ligament and subaortic lymph nodes. The tumor extends to the periphery but does not invade the pleura, and additional details regarding margins and vascular invasion are not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 1, in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 3.7 cm and Fuhrman grade 2. The tumor is unifocal and limited to the kidney, with no evidence of sarcomatoid features, perinephric fat invasion, or renal vein involvement. The deep margin excision is negative for tumor, and there is a potential area of renal capsule involvement that requires further microscopic confirmation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the left lung, characterized by a central mass measuring 4.5 x 3.0 x 3.0 cm arising from the left lower bronchus, with no pleural invasion noted. The bronchial lumen is occluded, leading to distal obstructive pneumonia, but the bronchial margin is negative for tumor. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from various regions, including superior mediastinal and aortic, are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a high-grade astrocytic neoplasm consistent with glioblastoma, WHO Grade IV, from the resection of a parietal tumor. The tumor exhibits heterogeneous morphology with infiltrating and discrete components, focal extension into the subarachnoid space, and features such as multifocal palisading necrosis and microvascular proliferation. Immunostaining shows positivity for GFAP, with scattered cells positive for KI-67, indicating a high proliferation index.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an incisional biopsy of the left breast revealing invasive pleomorphic lobular carcinoma, classified as nuclear grade 2 and histologic grade 3. The tumor measures 1.5 x 1.0 x 1.0 cm and extends to the surgical margin, with no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion or in-situ carcinoma. Estrogen and progesterone receptor activities are negative, and the tumor does not overexpress HER2/neu oncoprotein.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, papillary type 1, with two separate foci measuring 0.7 cm and 2.5 x 2 x 1.7 cm, both confined to the kidney and with free surgical margins. Additionally, there are multiple papillary adenomas and acquired cystic disease of the kidney noted, with a pathologic stage of pT1a NX MX. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, showing positive markers for the tumor and adenomas, while no evidence of vascular or lymphovascular invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 2, with a tumor size of 6 x 3.5 x 2 cm that diffusely involves the endometrial cavity and invades 1.2 cm into the myometrium. There is no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion, and all examined lymph nodes (9 from the left pelvic node and 8 from the right pelvic node) are free of tumor. The cervix, ovaries, fallopian tubes, and omentum show no pathological findings, and the specimen margins are not involved by tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma in the endometrium with superficial myometrial invasion and extension into the cervical stroma, but no evidence of nodal metastases. All examined lymph nodes from the right pelvic, left pelvic, right periaortic, and left periaortic regions show no malignancy. Additionally, an incidental appendectomy revealed a benign appendix, and there are findings of adenomyosis and leiomyomata in the uterus.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a history of right neck swelling, dysphagia, odynophagia, and bilateral otalgia, with fine needle aspiration confirming squamous cell carcinoma. Gross examination revealed soft tissue fragments from the left tongue base and left aryepiglottic fold, both measuring approximately 2.5 cm and 2.6 cm respectively. Microscopic diagnosis confirmed the presence of invasive basaloid squamous cell carcinoma in both biopsy sites.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma arising from carcinoma in situ, with invasion through the bladder wall into perivesicular fat, classified as pT3b pN2 R0. Metastatic carcinoma is identified in several lymph nodes, including one with extracapsular extension in the right obturator node and another in the left obturator node, while some nodes show no evidence of metastasis. The remaining reproductive organs, including the uterus, cervix, and ovaries, are reported as unremarkable, with only minor findings such as leiomyomas in the uterus.

The pathology report indicates that a left renal tumor, diagnosed as clear cell renal cell carcinoma (Fuhrman nuclear grade 3), was removed via partial nephrectomy, measuring 5.2 cm, with no evidence of capsular invasion or tumor in surrounding tissues. Additionally, two other specimens were analyzed, revealing a benign cortical cyst measuring 1.5 cm and fragments of a benign simple renal cyst, both showing no signs of malignancy. The overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is classified as T1b pNx, pending further clinical review.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in a total gastrectomy specimen, measuring 7 cm, with infiltration into the perigastric fatty tissue and limited penetration of the serosa. There are fourteen regional lymph node metastases identified, while the oral and aboral resection margins and omentum are tumor-free. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN2 (14/35) pMX.

The pathology report describes an enucleated right eye with a 20x15 mm uveal melanoma primarily composed of epithelioid and fusiform cells, with the latter being predominant. The tumor has invaded the sclera and presents an extra-scleral nodule measuring 6 mm, while there is focal extension to the ciliary body without infiltration of the iris. Importantly, the optic nerve and its meningeal sheaths are free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma located in the right gluteal subcutaneous tissue, with a tumor size of 10.0 cm and a necrosis extent of 30%. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, with the closest margin being 1.6 cm away from the tumor. No additional pathologic findings or regional lymph node involvement were noted, and no pre-resection therapy was administered.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the cardia of the stomach, which is ulcerated and infiltrating the serosa, with evidence of perineural and lymphatic infiltration. The adjacent gastric mucosa shows moderate chronic gastritis with lymphoid follicle formation, while the esophageal mucosa exhibits mild chronic inflammation. Surgical margins are free of neoplasia, but there is metastasis present in 1 of the 14 dissected lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, papillary type, located in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 3 cm and classified as T1a. The tumor is graded as Fuhrman grade 3, and there is also evidence of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6/10, which was resected during the same procedure. There are no regional lymph node involvement (NX) and no distant metastasis (M0) noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma and a separate focus of minimally invasive adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with the squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.8 x 1.7 x 1.3 cm and the adenocarcinoma measuring 1.5 x 1 x 0.8 cm. Lymph nodes excised from regions 10R and 11R were negative for neoplasm, and there was lymphatic invasion present in the squamous cell carcinoma but not in the adenocarcinoma. The bronchial, vascular, parenchymal, and pleura/soft tissue margins were all negative for carcinoma, and further EGFR mutation analysis is pending.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical nephrectomy due to a large right renal mass, which was diagnosed as chromophobe renal cell carcinoma measuring 9.7 cm, confined within the renal capsule with all surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, the excised right gonadal vein was found to be unremarkable and negative for tumor involvement. The tumor exhibited characteristics such as multinodularity and areas of cystic degeneration, with no adrenal gland identified in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a brain tumor in a female patient, specifically a diffuse astrocytoma. Microscopic examination reveals nuclear polymorphism and a Ki67 proliferation index greater than 5%. The final diagnosis is a diffuse astrocytoma that is classified as Grade II, with evidence of progression to Grade III.

The pathology report indicates that a left orchidectomy was performed, revealing a seminoma with a diameter of 6.5 cm. There is no evidence of angio-invasion, invasion of the rete testis, or invasion of the tunica albuginea. Additionally, the surgical margin of the spermatic cord is free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma measuring 5.0 cm, which extensively involves the bladder and has penetrated into surrounding tissues, including the uterus and perivesical fat. Metastatic carcinoma was found in two of three examined lymph nodes, with evidence of focal extracapsular extension. Although all surgical resection margins are free of neoplasia, invasive carcinoma and carcinoma in situ are close to the final urethral margin, indicating a significant risk of residual disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma, specifically leiomyosarcoma, located in the right posterior scapula, with a tumor size of 17.2 cm and approximately 30% necrosis. The tumor exhibits smooth muscle differentiation, is positive for desmin and common muscle actin, and shows focal infiltration into surrounding soft tissue and skeletal muscle, with margins appearing free but close in some areas. The specimen was received fresh and consists of a segment of adipose tissue, fascia, and skeletal muscle, with detailed measurements and descriptions of the tumor's characteristics.
