The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, in the right breast, measuring 1.2 x 1.1 x 0.9 cm, with negative surgical margins and no angiolymphatic invasion. The right axillary sentinel lymph nodes, including two excised nodes, are negative for tumor, and no blue dye was identified in these nodes. Additionally, six other right axillary lymph nodes are also negative for tumor, and HER2/neu protein overexpression is negative with a score of 0.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right parieto-occipital brain lesion diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) based on three separate specimens obtained during a craniotomy. All specimens, including those for intraoperative consultation, confirmed the presence of glioblastoma multiforme, with evidence of necrosis noted in one of the frozen sections. The findings are consistent across all samples, confirming the aggressive nature of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma arising from a background of well-differentiated liposarcoma, with the tumor measuring 10.6 cm and exhibiting high-grade spindle cell characteristics. The tumor shows significant necrosis (40%) and extends to the resection margin, with foci suspicious for vascular invasion. Additionally, the surrounding benign tissues, including the terminal ileum, appendix, and colon, are uninvolved by the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver segment 8, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and 20% necrosis, but no evidence of vascular or bile duct invasion. Additionally, chronic hepatitis with impending cirrhosis was noted in the liver, and chronic cholecystitis was diagnosed in the gallbladder. The report recommends further immunohistochemical and special staining studies for additional evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO Grade III endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with tumor invasion limited to half of the myometrium and no evidence of cervical or vascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes from various regions were reported as benign, with no metastatic disease identified. Immunohistochemical analysis suggests a loss of MSH6 protein, which may indicate microsatellite instability, warranting further genetic testing for confirmation.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast contains three separate foci of carcinoma: infiltrating duct carcinoma in the upper outer quadrant, tubulolobular carcinoma in the subareolar region, and a papillary lesion with associated invasive duct carcinoma in the lower outer quadrant. Additionally, two out of fifteen left axillary lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma. The right breast exhibits multifocal intraductal carcinoma and a healing biopsy site, with no evidence of malignancy in the skin or lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes a histopathological examination of a 12 cm segment of the colon, revealing a 6 cm ulcerous tumor consistent with tubular adenocarcinoma (G2) that circumferentially involves the intestinal wall and narrows the lumen. The tumor has infiltrated the muscularis propria and surrounding adipose tissue, but the incision margins are clear of neoplastic lesions. The final diagnosis is tubular adenocarcinoma of the colon, classified as Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2, pT3, pNO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma arising at the gastroesophageal junction, with a significant mass measuring 4.5 cm in width and 10.5 cm in circumference, which is infiltrative and expansile, and has involved four out of ten sampled lymph nodes. The surgical margins from the esophageal and gastric resections are negative for neoplasm, although the tumor closely approaches the inked resection margin. The TNM classification is T3 N1 Mx, indicating advanced local invasion with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma and chromophobe renal cell carcinoma in a left renal tumor, with the largest dimensions measuring 1.8 cm and 1.6 cm respectively. Both tumors are confined to the kidney, with margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and tumor necrosis is present in the papillary renal cell carcinoma. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis, and the tumors are staged as pT1 for both types.

The pathology report indicates that a right orchidectomy was performed, revealing a seminoma with a diameter of 6 cm. The tumor is confined to the testis, with no evidence of angio-invasion or invasion into the rete testis. Overall, the findings suggest a localized seminoma without aggressive features.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a partial nephrectomy of the left kidney, revealing a 6.2 cm papillary renal cell carcinoma (Fuhrman grade 2) with negative surgical margins. Additionally, findings included arteriosclerosis and a simple renal cyst, while the medial margin showed no tumor presence. The tumor is classified as pT1NXMX, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that a left colon hemicolectomy specimen reveals an invasive moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 6.0 cm, which invades through the muscularis propria into the subserosa. Surgical margins are free of tumor, but 8 out of 17 pericolonic lymph nodes show metastatic adenocarcinoma with focal extranodal extension. The tumor is classified as pT3c/d N2 MX, indicating significant local invasion and lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that both samples of brain tissue (AF1 and BF1) from the right temporal brain tumor are diagnosed as glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV), characterized by malignant astrocytic neoplasm with significant cytologic pleomorphism and necrosis. Additional genetic analysis reveals abnormalities including polysomy of chromosome 7, amplification of EGFR, and losses on chromosomes 10 and 9, which are associated with a poorer prognosis. The MGMT promoter methylation analysis shows no methylation, suggesting a potential resistance to certain therapies.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 1) with a tumor size of 4.5 cm, invading approximately 25% of the myometrium and involving 90% of the endometrial surfaces. Both right and left pelvic lymph nodes were negative for neoplasm, and the cervix, bilateral ovaries, and fallopian tubes showed no malignancy. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT1a pNX (FIGO stage IA), with a background of complex atypical endometrial hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade III) in multiple samples of brain tissue. The microscopic examination reveals a neoplastic proliferation of glial cells with areas of necrosis and infiltration into the surrounding cortex. The report confirms the diagnosis across all submitted specimens, highlighting the aggressive nature of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of malignant mesothelioma, epithelioid type, involving the parietal pleura and with metastasis in one of three examined lymph nodes. Other specimens, including the left sixth rib and various lymph nodes, were negative for malignancy, while the left lower lobe biopsy showed emphysematous changes without malignancy. The tumor is staged as pT1b N1 Mx, with lymphovascular invasion present, and is positive for calretinin and CK5/6.

The pathology report identifies a rare variant of undifferentiated thymic carcinoma characterized by a polycyclic lobular structure, multifocal necrosis, and a syncytial growth pattern with pleomorphic nuclei. Immunohistochemical analysis shows strong expression of CK19, EMA, CD5, and CD117, while immature T cells are absent. The EBER hybridization results were negative, confirming the diagnosis of undifferentiated thymic carcinoma without discrepancies between frozen and paraffin sections.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of breast cancer in a female patient, following a left total mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy. The left sentinel lymph node #1 shows several micrometastases, while sentinel lymph node #2 and a non-sentinel lymph node are negative for metastatic tumor. The left breast tumor is characterized as infiltrating ductal carcinoma with a Nottingham score of 7/9, and the resection margins are free of tumor, although the tumor is close to the inferior surgical margin.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor involvement. The radical prostatectomy specimen reveals prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4 (total score 9), indicating high-grade cancer with bilateral involvement, but negative surgical margins and no extraprostatic extension. Additionally, perineural infiltration is present, but there is no involvement of the seminal vesicles or high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in the left lingula segment of the lung, measuring 23 mm, with focal invasion of the adjacent visceral pleura but no tumor on the pleural surface. The bronchial resection margin is clear, and there are no signs of lymphatic or vascular invasion, although there is a focal change suspicious for perineural invasion. The submitted left hilar and left lower lobe lymph nodes show reactive changes without evidence of tumor involvement, and the pathological stage is classified as pT2a N0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a nodular mass measuring 20x12x10 cm with signs of necrosis and no infiltration of the liver capsule. The tumor exhibits varying degrees of differentiation and infiltrates the hepatic parenchyma and vessels, while the surgical margins are clear. The gallbladder shows signs of autolysis, and lymphatic nodes from the common hepatic artery area show no evidence of tumor growth.

The final diagnosis indicates the presence of a retroperitoneal dedifferentiated liposarcoma, with tumor sizes of 3.5 cm and 30.0 cm, exhibiting 58% and 30% tumor necrosis, respectively. Additionally, a transverse colon tumor measuring 8.0 cm is also identified as dedifferentiated liposarcoma, with a high-grade myxoid leiomyosarcoma component. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, showing positive markers for vimentin, desmin, and actin, while negative for smooth muscle myosin and other markers.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located at the infero-anterior margin of the near total glossectomy specimen, with a maximum tumor dimension of 6.5 cm and a thickness of 2.2 cm. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was identified in 9 out of 55 examined lymph nodes from bilateral neck dissections, with no extracapsular extension present. All other lymph nodes and oral cavity specimens were negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the left sentinel lymph node is negative for malignancy, while the left breast tissue shows infiltrating ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, with a maximum tumor dimension of 2.0 cm and associated ductal carcinoma in situ, nuclear grade 2. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive (80% nuclear staining) and progesterone receptor positive (90% nuclear staining), with HER2 showing weak positivity (2+) and not amplified by FISH. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, and microcalcifications are identified in both the ductal carcinoma in situ and infiltrating carcinoma components.

The pathology report indicates a sigmoid colon resection specimen containing an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that has infiltrated the lamina muscularis propria, classified as G2, pT2. A total of 34 lymph nodes were examined and found to be tumor-free, resulting in a staging of pT2 pNO (0/34). The resection margins were unremarkable, and the presence of bland diverticuli was noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic serous adenocarcinoma originating from the ovaries, with extensive involvement of the omentum, uterus, rectosigmoid colon, cecum, terminal ileum, right diaphragm, and Gerota's fascia. The left and right ovaries and fallopian tubes show significant tumor invasion, with positive findings for ovarian surface and pelvic implants, as well as vascular invasion. The overall pathological stage is classified as pT3c, indicating advanced disease with multiple metastatic sites.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right buccal mucosa, with evidence of perineural and lymphovascular invasion, although all surgical margins are free of invasive carcinoma. Additionally, one of three examined lymph nodes shows metastatic carcinoma with extranodal extension, while the remaining lymph nodes from levels II, III, and IV are negative for metastatic disease. Other margins from the excised tissue show varying degrees of dysplasia, but no invasive carcinoma is identified in those areas.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen with a tumor measuring 7x6x1 cm, identified as moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. Specific details regarding the extent of invasion, lymph nodes, and margins are not provided. No additional pathologic findings or comments are noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with discrete intraductal spread, measuring 1.9 cm in diameter. The tumor classification is noted as NOS, G II, pT1cN1aLOVORO. This suggests a localized cancer with some lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, from a left lower pole heminephrectomy specimen measuring 8.5 cm in greatest diameter. The tumor exhibits a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and shows local invasion through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia, with no renal vein invasion identified and surgical margins free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT2, indicating it is greater than 7.0 cm and limited to the kidney, with supporting immunohistochemical markers positive for CD10, Vimentin, EMA, and focally for E-cadherin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a dysplastic colon polyp and a colon mass, with the final diagnosis confirming the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the right colon, measuring 2.6 x 2.0 cm. No carcinoma was identified in the terminal ileum or appendix, and there was no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or metastasis in the examined lymph nodes. The tumor extends through the muscularis propria into the subserosal adipose tissue, with clear surgical margins noted.

The pathology report identifies two brain lesions: a large, necrotic meningioma (WHO grade I) and a glioblastoma (WHO grade IV) with a high proliferation index of 30-35%. The meningioma is extensively necrotic and previously embolized, while the glioblastoma shows significant infiltration into the cerebral cortex and adjacent white matter, with prominent nuclear anaplasia and necrosis. Additionally, the MGMT promoter is methylated, indicating potential responsiveness to alkylating agent therapy, and allelic loss on chromosome arm 19q is detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma, WHO Grade II, from a brain tumor located in the frontotemporal lobe of an elderly male patient. Histological examination reveals an infiltrating tumor with monomorphic ovoid nuclei and characteristic "chicken wire" vasculature, with no necrosis or significant mitotic activity observed. Immunohistochemical studies show positive reactivity for IDH1 and GFAP, while P53 is predominantly negative, and further analysis of 1p/19q chromosomal status is pending.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the right temporal lobe reveals a diagnosis of glioblastoma, characterized by extensive cellular atypia, mitotic activity, and zones of necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis shows a MIB1 proliferation index of 12%, supporting the diagnosis of glioblastoma with evidence of neoplastic astrocytic cells and a microvascular proliferation. The specimen consists of gray-tan brain tissue with areas of petechiae and discoloration, consistent with the aggressive nature of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 3, with a tumor size of 4 x 4 x 1.5 cm and myometrial invasion of 0.8 cm. All examined lymph nodes (5 right pelvic, 6 right periaortic, 7 left pelvic, and 7 left periaortic) showed no evidence of tumor. Corrections were made to the final diagnoses regarding the depth of myometrial invasion and the absence of tumor in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a modified radical mastectomy of the right breast, revealing a 5.0 x 5.0 x 2.8 cm infiltrating lobular carcinoma with multifocal disease present. There was no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion, and all 28 examined axillary lymph nodes were free of malignancy. Estrogen and progesterone receptor assays showed positive activity, with further details pending in an addendum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Type I Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma, measuring 7.5 cm, with infiltration into the peri-renal fat layer. The surgical margins, vasculature, and ureter are free of tumor, and the cancer is staged as pT3a, pNX, LO, vo, RO, with a grade of GII. The ICD-0 code for this diagnosis is 8260/3.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma following a radical prostatectomy, with a total Gleason score of 7/10 and focal extraprostatic extension noted. The tumor comprises approximately 10% of the gland volume, with lymphovascular invasion present, but surgical margins are uninvolved and no seminal vesicle involvement or lymph node metastasis was identified. The PTNM stage is classified as pT3a, NO, and three benign hyperplastic lymph nodes were examined with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional (clear cell) renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 5.5 cm and classified as Fuhrman's nuclear grade 2. There is evidence of microscopic perinephric adipose tissue involvement, but all surgical margins are negative for neoplasia, and no angiolymphatic invasion is identified, with a pathological TNM stage of pT3a Nx Mx. The right adrenal gland shows no significant pathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic high-grade serous carcinoma in multiple excised specimens, including lymph nodes, soft tissue, and various organs such as the gallbladder and omentum. Notably, isolated tumor cells were found in one lymph node, while other lymph nodes showed significant involvement with the carcinoma. Additionally, there were benign findings in some lymph nodes and segments of colon, but the overall diagnosis highlights extensive metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a right middle lobectomy revealing a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 57 mm, with evidence of vascular, lymphatic, perineural, and pericardial invasion, but no lymph node metastases. The tumor is located near the bronchial resection margin and adheres to the pericardium, although it does not invade the inner mesothelial surface. The pathological stage is classified as T3 N0.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a lobectomy of the right lower lobe, revealing a high-grade invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.8 cm, with metastasis found in four out of seven examined peribronchial and hilar lymph nodes. The lymph node biopsy from level seven showed no evidence of carcinoma in six sampled portions. The tumor was poorly differentiated, with no observed blood or lymphatic vessel invasion, and the surgical margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the right oral tongue and floor of mouth, with a tumor size of 4.2 cm by 3.8 cm and a depth of invasion of 0.9 cm. The carcinoma has invaded minor salivary gland tissue and shows evidence of angiolymphatic and perineural invasion, extending to within less than 1.0 mm of the inferior specimen margin, although no carcinoma is found at the inked margins. The remaining mucosa appears pale tan and slightly edematous, with a superficial area of ulceration noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with oligodendroglioma, exhibiting anaplastic foci in multiple tumor specimens. The findings reveal infiltrating characteristics of the tumor, with areas of vacuolar degeneration and increased cellular density, suggesting anaplastic transformation. Additionally, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis identified deletions of both chromosome 1p and 19q, which may correlate with improved survival and chemotherapy response in oligodendroglioma cases.

The pathology report indicates the presence of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6 (3+3) and a tertiary grade of 4, involving multiple foci within the prostate but not extending beyond the capsule or into the seminal vesicles or bladder neck. Examination of the right and left pelvic lymph nodes revealed benign lymph nodes, with no evidence of metastatic disease, and the peri-prostatic fat also showed benign adipose tissue. Overall, the tumor is classified as pT2b, indicating it is confined to the prostate and involves both lobes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive colonic adenocarcinoma located in the right colon and distal ileum, with a tumor size of 9.5 cm and evidence of tumor perforation. The margins of the resection are mostly negative for malignancy, except for the circumferential margin, which is involved by invasive carcinoma. The tumor is classified as high-grade, with lymphovascular invasion present, but no regional lymph node metastasis was identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with the dominant tumor measuring 7.0 cm and a smaller lesion measuring 0.8 cm. Both tumors are classified as grade 2 and grade 5, respectively, with no evidence of tumor necrosis, vascular invasion, or extension beyond the renal capsule. Surgical margins are negative for malignancy, and a benign 0.6 cm angiomyolipoma was also identified in the non-tumorous kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring approximately 55 mm in diameter, with invasion into the chest wall but clear soft tissue resection margins. There is no evidence of vascular, lymphatic, or perineural invasion, and the peribronchial lymph nodes show no signs of metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, a decalcified section of the rib reveals no periosteal or bony invasion by the carcinoma, confirming a pathological stage of T3 N0.

The pathology report describes an amelanotic melanoma measuring 4 cm with ulceration and lymphocytic infiltration, classified as Clark's level IV and with a Breslow's depth of 8 mm. The tumor has invaded the reticular dermis, but there is no evidence of venous invasion, and the margins are uninvolved. The melanoma is poorly differentiated and shows lymphatic invasion, indicating a more aggressive tumor behavior.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with mucinous and signet ring cell features located in the ascending colon, exhibiting extensive lymphovascular invasion and a depth of invasion through the muscularis propria into pericolic soft tissue. Twelve out of fourteen regional lymph nodes are positive for metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, with extracapsular extension noted. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN2b, and immunohistochemical staining shows a normal phenotype, ruling out hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes were examined, and no tumors were found in any of them. A minimally invasive adenocarcinoma was identified in the lingular segment of the left upper lobe, measuring 1.5 cm with an invasive component of 0.4 cm, and classified as histologic grade 3/4. The tumor is unifocal, with no evidence of visceral pleura invasion or lymphatic invasion, and the resection margins were clear of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with mucinous features located in the ascending colon, measuring 2.1 cm in length and 2.8 cm in width, with invasion into subserosal adipose tissue. There is evidence of lymphovascular invasion, but no regional lymph node metastasis was found among the 31 examined nodes. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the tumor is staged as pT3 according to the AJCC 7th Edition.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in the left liver lobe, measuring 2.2x2x1.5 cm, with a trabecular histologic type and a mixed cell type showing classic and clear cell features. The tumor exhibits a histologic grade of 3 for the worst differentiation and 2 for major differentiation, with extensive bile duct invasion and serosal invasion noted, but no vascular invasion or satellite nodules present. Additionally, there is evidence of inactive HBV-associated cirrhosis, and the surgical margins are clear with a safety margin of 1.2 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary urothelial cell carcinoma of the right renal pelvis, which has invaded through the muscularis propria. The distal ureteral margin of resection is free of tumor, and there are associated findings of benign cortical cysts and arteriolar nephrosclerosis. No vascular invasion is identified, and regional lymph nodes and distant metastasis cannot be assessed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma located in the right colon, characterized by a polypoid and ulcerated mass measuring 4.0 x 3.6 x 2.2 cm, with involvement of the mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis propria. The tumor is classified as FNCLCC grade 3/3, with less than 50% necrosis, and all surgical margins are free of tumor, with no evidence of malignancy in 36 examined regional lymph nodes. Additional findings include a tubular adenoma and fibrous obliteration of the appendiceal tip, but the pathologic stage is not applicable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with Edmondson-Steiner grade III differentiation, arising in a liver segment that also shows cirrhosis. The tumor measures 2.0 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm, is encapsulated with central necrosis, and has no invasion of the surgical resection margins, serosa, or portal vein, although lymphovascular invasion is present. The remaining liver parenchyma is noted to be cirrhotic, and additional fluid smears from the peritoneal and pleural areas show no significant pathological findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, Grade 1, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and less than 50% myometrial invasion. All examined lymph nodes from the left pelvic, left aortic, right pelvic, and right aortic regions were negative for metastasis. Additional findings include the presence of intramural leiomyomata, but no cervical involvement or lymphovascular invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal Warthin's tumor in the right parotid gland, with one lymph node showing metastatic squamous cell carcinoma and focal extracapsular invasion. Additionally, a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the oral cavity, specifically in the anterior floor of the mouth, with a maximum tumor dimension of 3.6 cm and negative margins, although there is evidence of bone invasion. The report concludes with the finding of positive carcinoma in the decalcified sections of the mandible, indicating extensive invasion into the bone.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of Grade III serous adenocarcinoma of the uterus, measuring 1.5 cm, with invasion into the myometrium and lymphovascular invasion, but no regional lymph node metastasis was found in the examined nodes. An omental nodule biopsy revealed adipose tissue with hemorrhage and focal fat necrosis, showing no evidence of malignancy, while all excised lymph nodes from both periaortic and pelvic regions were negative for malignancy. Additional findings included peritoneal inclusion cysts in the ovaries and paratubal cysts in the fallopian tubes, with the tumor exhibiting specific immunohistochemical markers consistent with serous carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the left lobe of the liver, with two tumors measuring 3.4 cm and 0.9 cm, respectively. The report notes that there is no evidence of satellite nodules, necrosis, or invasion of surrounding structures, and the surgical margins are free from tumor. Additionally, the liver shows signs of cirrhosis associated with hepatitis B virus (HBV).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, conventional type, located in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 3.6 cm, with no multifocality, extrathyroidal extension, or lymphovascular invasion present. The resection margins are negative, and there is mild chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis in the background, with no tumor found in the examined lymph node. The gross examination reveals a dominant nodule in the right lobe, while the isthmus and left lobe appear unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the left renal mass is diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma, measuring 11 cm, with no angiolymphatic invasion and free resection margins. The two portions of the 11th rib and the base of the mass show no tumor presence. Cytogenetic analysis reveals an abnormal karyotype consistent with papillary renal cell carcinoma, including trisomy for chromosomes 7 and 17.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO grade III) located in the left frontal region, characterized by positive 1p and 19q loss of heterozygosity and a methylated MGMT promoter. The tumor exhibits a proliferation index of 18%, with features of infiltrative glial neoplastic proliferation and no evidence of necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis shows negative IDH1-R132H staining, and the presence of microvascular proliferation is noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive adenocarcinoma arising in Barrett's mucosa, with the tumor extending into the superficial muscularis propria and involving 3 out of 15 lymph nodes. The resection margins for both the esophagus and proximal stomach are negative for neoplasm, and there is evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. Additionally, an incidental finding of an esophageal leiomyoma was noted, while the cervical esophageal margin and one excised lymph node were negative for neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left palate and maxillary bone, measuring 3.2 cm, with extensive perineural invasion and involvement of the anterior and posterior maxillary bone resection margins. Other excised soft tissue margins, including the superior medial margin, posterior superior deep margin, hard palate margin, and soft palate margin, were negative for malignancy. Additionally, 17 lymph nodes examined were also negative for malignancy, leading to a diagnosis of AJCC 7th Edition pathologic Stage IVB.

The pathology report indicates the presence of diffuse malignant mesothelioma, epithelioid type, with solid and tubulopapillary patterns, involving the chest wall, mediastinal pleura, diaphragmatic pleura, and lung parenchyma, with invasion into the pericardium but not extending to its inner surface. Additionally, there is a microscopic focus of metastatic mesothelioma identified in one of the lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes and tissues examined show no evidence of tumor. The report also notes acute and chronic inflammation at the port site and maturing hematopoiesis in the rib bone marrow, with no tumors detected in these areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma with a multinodular pattern, comprising well-differentiated (grade II) and poorly differentiated (grade IV) areas, and shows evidence of cirrhosis in the adjacent liver tissue. The gallbladder exhibits cholesterolosis with no signs of malignancy. Surgical margins are free of cancer, and there is no evidence of vascular invasion or angiolymphatic embolization.

The pathology report indicates that the excision biopsy of a right frontal brain tumor is diagnosed as an anaplastic oligoastrocytoma (WHO Grade III). The tumor exhibits moderate cellularity with features such as mucin-filled microcystic spaces, mild to moderate nuclear pleomorphism, and a mitotic count of 2 to 3 per ten high-power fields, along with positive MGMT promoter methylation and complete loss of heterozygosity for 1p/19q. Overall, the tumor shows a mixed oligodendroglial and astrocytic cytology, primarily leaning towards oligodendroglial characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the wedge biopsy of the left lower lobe of the lung reveals an invasive, poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with negative pleura and inked resection margins. Additionally, the level 9L lymph node excision shows no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, as it is negative for cancer. The pulmonary parenchyma also exhibits emphysematous changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma (5.5 cm) in the uterus, with extensive angiolymphatic invasion and a mitotic index greater than 20 per 10 high power fields. No malignancy was identified in the cervix, ovaries, fallopian tubes, or lymph nodes examined, and the endometrium showed ulceration due to the leiomyosarcoma. Immunohistochemical studies confirmed the diagnosis, with negative results for markers typically associated with other tumor types.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma arising from a background of well-differentiated liposarcoma in the left retroperitoneum, measuring 13.0 cm, with over 95% of the tumor being low-grade spindle cell sarcoma. Additionally, a segment of the sigmoid colon and the deep iliac vein were examined, revealing no significant pathological changes in the colon and well-differentiated liposarcoma in the iliac vein, with four benign lymph nodes identified. Both the distal and proximal margins of the colon were reported as benign, indicating no residual tumor at these sites.

The biopsy of the right lung is consistent with epithelioid malignant mesothelioma, as indicated by the immunohistochemical studies showing positivity for calretinin, WT-1, and D2-40, while being negative for CEA, CD15, MOC31, CK5/6, and mesothelin. The gross examination revealed multiple pink-red core biopsy fragments measuring between 0.1 cm and 0.4 cm. The clinical history noted a pleural-based mass, supporting the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland, with the tumor measuring 6.2 cm and the specimen size being 6.9 x 5.2 x 3.1 cm. The tumor is well-circumscribed, with no evidence of invasion into the capsule, extra-adrenal tissues, or lymphovascular structures, and the surgical margins are negative. Additionally, there were no lymph nodes involved, as only one lymph node was examined and found to be negative.

The pathology report indicates that both sentinel lymph nodes (1 and 2) are negative for malignancy based on routine and immunohistochemical stains. The left breast biopsy reveals multifocal infiltrating ductal carcinoma, with two tumor foci measuring 1.5 cm and 0.6 cm, and an in-situ component comprising 10% of the tumor. Surgical margins are noted to be 2.0 mm and 1.5 mm from the superior margin of the larger and smaller tumors, respectively, with no evidence of lymphovascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates that multiple biopsies from the right pelvic peritoneum, right pericolic tissue, left pericolic gutter, pelvic area, post peritoneum, and omentum are negative for tumor. However, a left ovary and fallopian tube salpingo-oophorectomy revealed a high-grade serous carcinoma measuring 7 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and involvement of the ovarian surface, classified as FIGO stage II A. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from both pelvic and periaortic regions are negative for metastatic tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as Nottingham grade III, with a tumor size of 1.7 x 1.6 x 1.2 cm and negative surgical margins after re-excision. Additionally, there is a presence of ductal carcinoma in situ comprising less than 5% of the tumor volume, and a single intramammary lymph node and one of two left axillary sentinel lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma. Estrogen and progesterone receptor analysis, along with Her-2/NEU testing, have been ordered for further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions. A radical prostatectomy revealed invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, involving both lobes of the prostate but confined within the organ without extraprostatic extension. Additionally, perineural invasion was identified, but all surgical margins and seminal vesicles were free of carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive tubulolobular carcinoma in both the right and left breasts, with tumor sizes of 1.1 cm and 0.9 cm respectively, and both tumors are classified as SBR Grade 1. Sentinel lymph nodes from both axillae show no evidence of tumor involvement, confirming a negative lymph node status. The tumors are ER and PR positive, HER2 negative, and the margins are involved in the right breast specimen while the left breast margins are negative.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary renal cell carcinoma in the inter-aortocaval and retrocaval lymph nodes, as well as in the right kidney, which shows significant tumor invasion into the renal vein. The right kidney tumor measures 8 cm and exhibits extensive lymphatic invasion, with a negative ureteral margin. Additionally, a thrombus associated with the renal cancer is noted, and cytogenetic analysis reveals a nonclonal abnormality in the karyotype.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in segment 7 of the liver, with the tumor measuring 4.0 x 3.7 x 3.3 cm and extending to the inked parenchymal margin. No evidence of malignancy was found in the cartilage specimen submitted for examination. Additional findings include micro and macrovesicular steatosis and bridging fibrosis, with no lymph nodes identified and no evidence of vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy of the left upper lobe revealed a moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5.0 cm, with no tumor found at the bronchial margins and no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. All examined lymph nodes, including those from various levels and the posterior pleura, were negative for metastases, confirming no spread of cancer to these areas. The overall pathological staging is pT2 N0 Mx, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 4 cm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of colorectal type located in the colon ascendens, with evidence of ulceration and infiltration into the surrounding adipose tissue. There are no tumor cells found in the lymph nodes, small and large intestine, resection margins, appendix, or omental adipose tissue. The tumor is staged as pT3, pNO (0/39), pMX; G2, with no lymphovascular or perineural invasion, indicating a local R0 resection.

The pathology report indicates the presence of extensive serous carcinoma in the uterus, cervix, and left ovary, with mixed endometrioid and serous carcinoma identified in the endomyometrium. Metastatic serous carcinoma is confirmed in multiple lymph nodes, including 29 of 32 paraaortic lymph nodes, 6 of 6 left pelvic lymph nodes, and 3 of 8 right pelvic lymph nodes, while the vaginal cuff biopsy and omentum show no evidence of malignancy. Overall, the findings suggest advanced uterine cancer with significant lymphovascular invasion and metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5.2 cm on the tongue, with tumor extension to the deep left lateral margin but no perineural invasion detected. All examined lymph nodes (71 total) showed no evidence of malignancy, and surgical margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additional tissues, including various nerves and other structures, also revealed no malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left parietal tumor diagnosed as gliosarcoma (WHO grade IV) following an excision biopsy. The MGMT promoter methylation analysis returned negative, indicating no evidence of methylated MGMT promoter detected. Microscopic examination revealed a complex neoplasm with pleomorphic atypical cells, frequent mitotic figures, and areas of necrosis, with various immunostains performed showing vimentin and GFAP positivity among the tumor cells.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated papillary adenocarcinoma in the stomach, measuring 7.8 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion but no perineural invasion, and surgical margins free of neoplasia. Metastatic involvement is noted in several lymph nodes, including the supra-pyloric, infra-pyloric, left gastric artery, common hepatic artery, and celiac trunk, while other examined sites are free of neoplasia. The findings suggest a significant metastatic spread of the cancer, particularly in the lymphatic system.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, characterized as mixed mucinous and NOS type with solid-papillary features, histologic grade III, measuring 2.3 cm, along with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in 4 out of 10 lymph nodes at level one, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 2.5 cm and evidence of extranodal extension. Immunohistochemical testing revealed HER2 negativity, and no involvement of the nipple by carcinoma was identified.

The pathology report describes a right frontal tumor identified as an anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO grade III), characterized by diffuse infiltration of both gray and white matter. The tumor exhibits mild to moderate atypia, with scattered mitotic figures and a high MIB-1 labeling index indicating a highly proliferative neoplasm. No microvascular proliferation or necrosis is observed in the examined sections.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma in the liver segments V and VI, characterized by a multilobulated mass measuring 6.8 x 6.6 x 5.8 cm. The tumor is noted to extend to within 0.3 cm of the surgical resection margin. This suggests a potential concern for residual disease following the resection.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left total mastectomy due to a 7.0 cm invasive lobular carcinoma, which is high nuclear grade, with negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion identified. Sentinel lymph node biopsies showed no malignancy in both nodes examined, and immunohistochemistry results confirmed the tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors while negative for HER2. Additional skin from the mastectomy showed no malignancy, and further receptor status evaluations are pending.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma in the endometrium, with a dominant tumor measuring 2.5 cm and myometrial invasion of 2.5 mm. All examined lymph nodes (34 in total) and additional specimens, including the omentum and abdominal scar, were negative for carcinoma. The report concludes with a diagnosis of radical hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and lymph node dissection, confirming the malignancy is localized to the uterus.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of highly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma in an ablated breast sample, with a tumor diameter of 9 cm and circumscribed intraductal components. The resection margin is tumor-free, suggesting complete removal of the tumor. The tumor classification is noted as NOS, G I, pT3NOLOVORO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma (G2) of the floor of the mouth, classified as pT4a, with evidence of infiltration into the mandible and surrounding tissues. The tumor measures 3 x 2.8 x 1 cm and has caused destruction of the mandibular bone, with a minimum margin of uninvolved tissue measuring 0.3 cm. Microscopic examination confirms the presence of carcinoma infiltrating skeletal muscles, but no vascular or nerve proliferation was observed.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the rectosigmoid junction, measuring 2.5 x 0.5 cm, which is diagnosed as poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/8 positive), and the surgical margins are uninvolved. Additional details regarding tumor features, neo-adjuvant treatment, or other pathologic findings were not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Thymoma, type A (epithelial-type) in multiple specimens, including a left chest mass, left anterior pulmonary mass, and left pericardial phrenic mass. Additionally, a left pericardial lymph node was identified as benign with no neoplasm, showing sinus histiocytosis and hemosiderin deposition. Flow cytometry analysis revealed a normal population of T lymphocytes with no evidence of abnormal T cell populations or sufficient B cells for clonality analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of choroidal melanoma of mixed cell type following a local resection of a tumor from the right eye. Histological examination reveals a pigmented tumor composed of spindle and epithelioid cells, with a moderately high mitotic rate and no evidence of tumor infiltration into the sclera or lateral margins. Molecular genetic analysis shows loss of chromosome 1, normal chromosome 3 with borderline loss of two loci, gain in chromosome 6p, and gain in chromosome 8, which will be correlated with clinical and morphological data for assessing metastatic risk.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the left and right ovaries, uterus, mesenteric nodules, omentum, small bowel, anterior abdominal wall peritoneum, sigmoid colon, and appendix. Notably, the left ovary and right ovary both show significant tumor involvement, with angiolymphatic invasion identified in the right ovary and extensive angiolymphatic invasion in the uterus. The report confirms that the carcinoma is present on the serosal surfaces of the affected organs, with no tumor detected in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary sentinel lymph node biopsy is negative for tumor involvement. The left breast segmental mastectomy reveals invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 3, measuring 1.8 cm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present outside the invasive component and at the inferior margin of resection. The invasive carcinoma is negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors and HER-2/NEU, with no lymphovascular invasion identified in the current specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 4.0 cm in the right lobe of the thyroid, with no evidence of lymph-vascular, perineural, or extrathyroidal invasion. The tumor is unifocal and partially encapsulated, with margins uninvolved by carcinoma, and the parathyroid glands are within normal limits. Consultation with another pathologist confirmed the diagnosis, and ancillary studies showed weak positivity for CK19, while HBME-1 and Galectin-3 were negative.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus, characterized by an infiltrative oval ulcerated tumor measuring 4x1.5 cm. The tumor infiltrates all layers of the esophageal wall, with clear surgical margins, while a paraesophageal lymph node shows evidence of metastatic cells. No metastasis is observed in the paragastric lymph nodes or greater omentum.

The pathology report indicates a bladder tumor consisting of friable tissue with a maximum dimension of 12 mm, classified as a grade 3 poorly differentiated transitional cell carcinoma with mixed papillary and solid growth patterns. The tumor shows signet ring cell and sarcomatoid differentiation, with extensive necrosis and invasion of the muscularis propria (pT2), but no vascular channel invasion is identified. A small amount of non-dysplastic flat urothelium is present in the background.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast biopsy shows infiltrating ductal carcinoma with a histologic grade of 2 and nuclear grade of 2, along with evidence of skeletal muscle invasion. Additionally, the left axillary lymph nodes contain nodules of carcinoma, although the lymph nodes themselves are not identified. This suggests a locally advanced breast cancer with potential lymphatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows mild chronic cholecystitis without atypia, while the liver specimens reveal a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 6.5 cm, which has been completely excised with a 0.5 cm margin. The carcinoma is invasive, extending to the liver capsule but without evidence of capsule breach or vascular invasion. Additionally, the adjacent liver parenchyma shows mild chronic inflammation and no significant fibrosis or cirrhosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated papillary adenocarcinoma in the lung, measuring 1.5x2x2 cm, with invasion into the alveolar spaces and involvement of the visceral pleura. The tumor exhibits irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli and shows the presence of mitoses, while the stroma contains inflammatory cell infiltration. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined mediastinal lymph node, with a finding of 0 out of 1 node positive for cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the right internal iliac and right obturator lymph nodes, as well as the left proximal external iliac, left pelvic, and left obturator lymph nodes, are all negative for carcinoma. The uterus shows endometrioid adenocarcinoma, grade 3, with invasion into the outer third of the myometrium and lymphovascular space invasion, while the cervix and fallopian tubes are negative for malignancy. The left ovary contains a serous cyst adenofibroma and cystic mesothelial adhesion, with no regional lymph node metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates that the right upper lobectomy specimen contains an irregularly shaped grey mass measuring 4 cm in diameter, consistent with bronchiolar-alveolar carcinoma, characterized by sheets of atypical epithelial cells. Additionally, the hilar lymph node specimen shows chronic inflammatory changes with no evidence of malignancy. Overall, the findings suggest a diagnosis of invasive neoplastic disease in the lung, while the lymph nodes appear reactive without signs of cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 2.0 cm and unifocality. There is evidence of metastatic carcinoma in 20 out of 27 lymph nodes, classified as pN1a, while the primary tumor is categorized as pT1b, indicating it is limited to the thyroid. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of venous or lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast mastectomy revealed moderately differentiated infiltrating lobular carcinoma with lobular carcinoma in situ, extending into the milk ducts and skin of the nipple, and involving the upper outer quadrant, while the right breast showed lobular carcinoma in situ with extensive lobular hyperplasia and atypical lobular hyperplasia. Estrogen receptors were negative, progesterone receptors were positive (80-90% of nuclear staining), and HER2/NEU was not amplified. The report also notes the presence of fibrocystic changes in the right breast, including cysts, fibrosis, and apocrine metaplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic serous carcinoma in the peritoneum and omentum, with a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma in the uterus and cervix, classified as FIGO grade 3 and stage IVA. The tumor shows extensive myometrial invasion and lymphovascular space invasion, with adnexal involvement noted in both ovaries. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals the tumor to be estrogen receptor positive and weakly progesterone receptor positive, supporting its classification as a primary endometrial origin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a benign renal cortical cyst in the left lower pole, with no evidence of malignant tumor. A partial nephrectomy of the left kidney revealed a unifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma, classified as nuclear grade 1, measuring 4.0 x 3.0 x 3.0 cm, with negative surgical margins and no lymph-vascular invasion. Additionally, six para-aortic lymph nodes were biopsied and found to be negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in a left adrenal tumor, measuring 6.5 cm and weighing 86.7 grams, with features of degeneration including hemorrhage and cystic change. Microscopic examination reveals a solid nesting architecture with polygonal cells, focal nuclear pleomorphism, and an incomplete capsule, but no evidence of capsular or extra-adrenal invasion. Resection margins are clear, and there is no lymphovascular involvement or other adrenal pathology noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe variant, measuring 6.6 cm, with Fuhrman nuclear grade 2-3/4, confined to the right kidney and with negative resection margins. The specimen shows no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, and cytogenetic findings support the diagnosis. Additionally, mild age-related arterial and arteriolar sclerosis is noted in the adjacent non-neoplastic kidney parenchyma, with preserved glomeruli and no significant pathological changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma, usual type, forming a hilar mass in the liver, measuring 4.8 x 4.3 x 3.2 cm, with no involvement of the gallbladder and free surgical margins. Angiolymphatic invasion is present within the tumor, but there is no extratumoral vascular invasion, and the adjacent liver parenchyma is non-cirrhotic. Additionally, the gallbladder shows signs of subacute and chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis, while biopsies of the omentum and a hepatic artery lymph node are negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right ureter biopsies show no significant pathologic abnormalities or tumors. A radical cystoprostatectomy revealed invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 3.0 cm and invading perivesicular fat, but with negative margins and no evidence of prostate involvement or lymph node metastasis. Additional specimens, including excisions of the bladder and Meckel's diverticulum, also showed no tumors, confirming the absence of malignancy in those areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade 2) from a biopsy of the right temporal lobe. The tumor is moderately cellular with mild nuclear pleomorphism, and there are no signs of vascular endothelial hyperplasia or tumor necrosis. The frozen section diagnosis of glioma was confirmed, and the specimen consisted of multiple fragments of tan-gray soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a primary tumor measuring 7.5 cm and a satellite focus of 3.5 cm, both classified as Fuhrman's nuclear grade 3 of 4. The tumors are confined to the kidney without invasion into surrounding tissues, and all surgical margins are free of neoplasia. Additionally, the adrenal gland shows a recent hematoma but no significant pathological findings, with the pathological TNM staging reported as pT2 Nx Mx.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive, moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left partial glossectomy and pharyngectomy specimen, with focal perineural invasion and all margins free of tumor. Additionally, metastatic moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma was found in one of two lymph nodes from the left modified neck dissection, while the thyroid and other examined tissues showed no tumor presence. Other findings include an epidermal inclusion cyst in the left cheek and a cyst of the mandible, both without tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right hepatectomy due to a poorly-differentiated malignant neoplasm, most consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma, with a tumor size of 12 cm and multiple tumors present in both lobes of the liver. The tumor is classified as grade 3 (poorly-differentiated) and is confined to the liver with negative margins and no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Additionally, the patient has chronic hepatitis consistent with hepatitis C, with moderate fibrosis and mild steatosis noted.

The pathology report indicates a laryngectomy specimen with a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the glottis, measuring 4 x 4 x 2 cm. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/14), and the tumor extends to the vocal cord. Margins are not specified, and there is no indication of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies from the right frontal and temporal lobe tumors are diagnosed as oligodendroglioma, WHO grade II, with some features suggesting a transition to grade III due to focal mitotic activity. The MGMT promoter is found to be methylated, which may indicate a potential benefit from alkylating agent therapy, while no allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q was detected. Overall, clinical correlation is recommended to assess the implications of the findings.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 2.5 cm non-keratinizing invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the supraglottic region of the larynx, with evidence of angiolymphatic invasion but no perineural invasion. One out of thirty-two lymph nodes from the left cervical dissection showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while all lymph nodes from the right side and the total laryngectomy margins were free of carcinoma. Additional testing revealed negative results for HPV and EGFR FISH studies, with the immunoperoxidase stain for EGFR being positive.

The pathology report indicates that the tumor is located in the left frontal region. The histological diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme. This diagnosis suggests a highly aggressive and malignant brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the left brain tumor resection is diagnosed as anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) with prominent gemistocytic features, nuclear pleomorphism, and increased mitotic activity. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the majority of tumor cells are positive for GFAP, with a Ki-67 proliferation index of approximately 10%, while no deletions of chromosomes 1p or 19q were identified. The findings suggest a diffusely infiltrating tumor with a significant perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate, and correlation with clinical and imaging findings is recommended.

The pathology report indicates that the right parathyroid excision revealed one lymph node and associated fibroadipose tissue, both negative for tumor. The total thyroidectomy specimen showed multifocal papillary carcinoma in the right lobe, measuring 2.5 cm, with metastatic carcinoma found in 3 of 11 lymph nodes, and evidence of vascular and lymphatic invasion. The margins of the tumor are uninvolved, and additional findings include nodular hyperplasia and focal lymphocytic thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates that the left eye enucleation revealed a ciliochoroidal melanoma of predominantly spindle cell type, measuring 12mm in length, 9mm in height, with no evidence of tumor extension through the sclera or optic nerve. Histological examination showed minimal lymphocytic infiltrate, no tumor necrosis, and breached Bruch's membrane, while immunohistochemical stains confirmed the presence of Melan-A and partial HSP-27 expression. Molecular genetic analysis indicated loss of chromosome 1p, monosomy 3, normal chromosome 6, and gains in chromosome 8, which will be correlated with clinical and morphological data for assessing metastatic risk.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic serous carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the left and right fallopian tubes, ovaries, and omentum, with significant myometrial and cervical invasion noted in the radical hysterectomy specimen. Several lymph nodes were examined, revealing metastatic carcinoma in some, while others were benign. Additionally, benign fibroadipose tissue was identified in the left pararectal implant and rectum, with no carcinoma detected in certain excised tissues.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of a cervical mass from a female patient revealed poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Microscopic examination confirmed this diagnosis, and the specimen consisted of two irregular gray-white tissue fragments. The report emphasizes that the findings are based on personal examination by the pathologist and that the case has been reviewed and concurred by another physician.

The pathology report indicates a 5.8 cm clear cell renal cortical carcinoma confined to the right kidney, classified as pT1b. The tumor is well-circumscribed and approaches the inked capsular surface, but all margins are negative for tumor. No evidence of vascular invasion or additional abnormalities is noted, and regional lymph nodes and distant metastasis cannot be assessed.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multifocal invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 3+3=6, involving both lobes and a maximum tumor size of 1.4 cm, but is organ-confined with no evidence of extracapsular extension. All examined lymph nodes (4 total) are free of neoplasia, and all surgical margins are clear of carcinoma. Additionally, there is a minor tertiary Gleason grade 4 component comprising 4% of the tumor volume, and perineural invasion is noted without any angiolymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma in the omentum, with significant tumor involvement in fibroadipose tissue. Both the right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes were examined, revealing no tumors in the right side, while the left ovary showed a 1.5 cm tumor consistent with ovarian primary cancer. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma, with specific markers indicating the tumor's characteristics.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right frontal tumor diagnosed as anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade III), confirmed through both frozen and permanent section analysis. The tumor exhibits features such as mildly pleomorphic glial cells, focal microvascular proliferation, areas of necrosis, and a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 25%. Molecular studies reveal loss of heterozygosity (LOH) for chromosome arms 1p and 19q, along with a positive methylation status of the MGMT promoter, suggesting potential responsiveness to alkylating agent therapy.

The pathology report indicates that the left superior laryngeal nerve, pharyngeal margin, esophageal margin, and various lymph nodes show no tumor presence. However, a total laryngopharyngectomy reveals invasive moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma, multifocal and predominantly involving the left pyriform sinus, with a depth of invasion of 0.5 cm and extensive lymphatic invasion. The main tumor measures 3.2 x 1.5 x 0.5 cm and is accompanied by additional areas of invasive squamous carcinoma in the left subglottic mucosa and submucosal deposits.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, measuring 9.7 cm, with Fuhrman nuclear grade 2, arising in the upper pole of the right kidney, and no evidence of lymphovascular invasion. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with negative margins on the renal artery, vein, and ureter, while the regional retroperitoneal lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor. An addendum notes that the non-neoplastic kidney parenchyma exhibits minimal chronic changes likely related to age, with no significant pathology detected.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right upper lobe lobectomy due to adenocarcinoma, which measured 2.8 cm and was moderately differentiated, with no evidence of invasion into surrounding structures or visceral pleura. All examined lymph nodes (4 from N1 and 8 from N2) were negative for metastatic tumor involvement. Additional findings included atypical adenomatous hyperplasia and mild emphysema, with a final pTNM stage of pT1 N0.

The pathology report indicates a right hemicolectomy specimen containing a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma infiltrating perimuscular fat (G3, pT3) and a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma infiltrating the submucosa (G2, pT1), both with tumor-free resection margins. Additionally, there is a history of a tubulovillous adenoma with severe dysplasia that was previously excised. All dissected lymph nodes (21 in total) were found to be tumor-free, leading to a conclusion of pNO (0/12) for the previously diagnosed double carcinoma of the right colon.

The pathology report indicates that multiple biopsies from the left cheek skin and mandible margins showed no carcinoma, while a larger en bloc resection revealed well-differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma with bone invasion and close but negative surgical margins. The tumor extends into the buccal mucosa and mandible, with the closest soft tissue margin being less than 1 mm. Lymph node evaluations from various levels of the left neck showed no metastatic carcinoma, and the overall AJCC staging is pT4a pNO pMx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, measuring 6.5 cm, confined to the left kidney and with negative margins of resection. The tumor is well-circumscribed and does not invade surrounding tissues, including the adrenal gland, which shows no tumor presence. Additional tissue samples have been submitted for research purposes, and the adjacent kidney parenchyma appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, with a maximum tumor dimension of 2.8 cm and invasion into the outer half of the myometrium, but no involvement of the cervix or lymphovascular space. The bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes showed no diagnostic pathology, and an omental biopsy revealed fibroadipose tissue without any malignancy. Overall, the tumor exhibits high-grade features with a solid growth pattern, and immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that both right axillary sentinel nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma, while the right breast mastectomy reveals invasive lobular carcinoma, SBR grade II, with associated lobular carcinoma in situ and atypical lobular hyperplasia. The invasive carcinoma is multicentric with clear margins, and there is evidence of suspicious blood vessel and lymphatic invasion, although the axillary lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. Additional findings include intraductal hyperplasia and apocrine metaplasia, with the nipple being focally involved by lobular carcinoma in situ.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma (pleomorphic type) in the right breast, with a tumor size measuring 3.9 cm and a modified Nottingham histologic grade of 2 out of 3. Surgical margins are free of tumor, with the nearest margin being 1 mm from the tumor. Ancillary studies show positive estrogen receptor status (100% of tumor cells) and equivocal HER-2 results.

The pathology report indicates a mixed germ cell tumor in the left testis, comprising 40% seminoma, 35% yolk sac tumor, 20% embryonal carcinoma, and 5% teratoma, with the tumor being confined to the testis and no lymphovascular invasion detected. The tumor measures 5.8 x 5.2 x 3.5 cm and is unifocal, with all surgical margins, including the spermatic cord, negative for malignancy. Serum tumor markers show elevated AFP and beta-HCG levels, and there is evidence of intratubular germ cell neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that a lesion excision was performed on a tumor of the lower lip, revealing a papillary tumor measuring 1.5 x 1.0 x 0.5 cm. Microscopic examination confirmed a diagnosis of Grade 2 keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma (carcinoma planoepitheliale keratodes) with minimal margins of normal tissue measuring 2 mm laterally and 1.5 mm at the bottom. The final histopathological diagnosis is invasive keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the skin, classified as pT1, with excision lines within healthy tissues.

The pathology report indicates a left lateral liver resection specimen diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma, with a tumor size of 5.3 x 5.2 x 4.8 cm and multiple nodules present. The tumor is classified as well-differentiated (G1) and is confined to the liver, with a 5 mm distance from the closest resection margin indicating no invasive carcinoma at the margins. There is no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion, and the pathologic staging is pT2 with regional lymph nodes not assessed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma involving multiple sites, including the omentum, pelvic sidewall, posterior cul-de-sac, and uterus with both ovaries and fallopian tubes. The tumor exhibits extensive lymphovascular permeation and has metastasized to various lymph nodes, with a final staging of pT3c, pN1, and pM1, corresponding to FIGO stage IV. Additional findings include acute and chronic cervicitis, endometrial changes, and the presence of a microscopic leiomyoma in the myometrium.

The pathology report indicates the presence of grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with myometrial invasion and focal lymphovascular space involvement, while the cervix, ovaries, and fallopian tubes are negative for carcinoma. The omentum and hernia sac biopsies also show no evidence of carcinoma, and all examined lymph nodes (para-aortic, left obturator, and right obturator) are negative for metastatic disease. Additional findings include adenomyosis in the uterus, with the tumor measuring 5.6 cm and limited to the endometrium or invading less than half of the myometrium.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the excised lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions (0/2 for each). The prostatectomy revealed prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 8 (4+4), showing significant tumor involvement in the right lobe (42%) and minor involvement in the left lobe (2%), with extracapsular extension and extensive perineural invasion noted. The surgical margins were focally positive, and the overall staging is classified as pT3a pNO, suggesting non-confined tumor with no lymph node metastasis detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid, measuring 1.2 cm, with well-differentiated histologic grade and no identified mitotic activity or tumor necrosis. Additionally, two foci of papillary microcarcinoma were found in the isthmus and right lobe, measuring 0.6 cm and 0.3 cm, respectively, with the largest exhibiting tall cell features. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic thyroid shows nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates that a right hemicolectomy specimen revealed an infiltrating moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma arising in a serrated adenoma, measuring 2.2 cm, with surgical margins that are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma was identified in three out of 44 lymph nodes examined. The report notes the presence of three hyperplastic polyps and indicates that further studies on microsatellite instability will be reported separately.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, with a tumor measuring 10 cm that is limited to the kidney and shows focal invasion into the capsule. The ureter and vascular margins are free of tumor, and immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of chromophobe carcinoma. Additionally, the excised renal hilar lymph nodes contain fibroadipose tissue with no evidence of tumor or lymphoid tissue.

The pathology report indicates that four lymph nodes from both #7 and #11R excisions are negative for metastatic carcinoma, as well as fourteen lymph nodes from the #4R excision. A lobectomy of the right lower lobe reveals a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with mixed subtype, measuring 4.0 cm, and showing visceral pleural invasion, but with negative bronchial and vascular margins. Additional lung specimens from the right upper lobe and right middle lobe are reported as benign, with no evidence of carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic non-small cell carcinoma in the pericardial reflection lymph node and identifies a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper and middle lobes of the lung, measuring 5.5 cm. The tumor is located within 0.2 cm of the bronchial margin, with evidence of vessel invasion and multifocal extension into the pleura, while several regional lymph nodes show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma except for one lymph node at level 5, which is positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma. Additional findings include two poorly differentiated adenocarcinomas in the left lung lobes, both with uninvolved surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma with endometrioid areas in both the right and left ovaries, with the right tumor measuring 12 cm and the left 6 cm. There is evidence of extensive invasive implants of the carcinoma in the bladder, omentum, and uterus, along with lymph-vascular invasion, while the fallopian tubes show no malignancy. The final staging is classified as FIGO stage IIIC, indicating macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis.

The pathology report indicates that a left breast mastectomy specimen revealed infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 2.5 x 2.0 x 2.5 cm, classified as histologic grade 3 and poorly differentiated. No carcinoma was identified in the surgical margins, and additional findings included fibrocystic changes such as focal moderate epithelial hyperplasia, small cysts, apocrine metaplasia, and fibrosis. An axillary dissection of 15 lymph nodes showed no evidence of carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive keratinizing squamous carcinoma of the larynx, specifically classified as carcinoma planoepitheliale keratodes invasivum (verrucosum), with a tumor size of 2.6 x 2.6 x 1.0 cm located in the glottis region and infiltrating adjacent areas. The surgical specimen measured 9 x 5.5 x 5 cm, and there were no signs of vascular or nerve invasion, although the surgical margins showed cancer invasion. Intraoperative examination did not reveal any neoplastic lesions, and further analysis of paraffin specimens is pending for a final diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the left tonsil biopsy is involved by moderately-differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor is noted to be present in lymphovascular spaces. The specimen submitted was a fragment of soft tissue measuring 1.5 x 1.0 x 0.3 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) in the left breast, measuring 6.5 cm, with high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) also present, and evidence of metastasis in the left axillary lymph nodes (3 out of 19 nodes positive). The tumor exhibits features of high nuclear grade and necrosis, with close margins noted at the anterior-superior resection site. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2/neu status is indeterminate, necessitating further testing.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a panniculectomy and a hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. The findings reveal a FIGO grade 2 endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, confined to the endometrium without involvement of the endocervix, alongside extensive adenomyosis in the myometrium. The bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes appear unremarkable with no diagnostic abnormalities noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe, measuring 27 mm, with evidence of blood vessel and perineural invasion but no lymphatic permeation or definite pleural invasion. Additionally, there is a deposit of poorly differentiated carcinoma identified within the hilar lymph nodes, indicating metastasis. The tumor shows focal neuroendocrine differentiation, particularly in the better differentiated squamous areas, and is classified as T1N1MX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in multiple specimens, including the right adnexa, left ovarian excrescences, cul de sac tissue, and both tubes and ovaries, with endometrial adenocarcinoma diagnosed in the uterus and cervix. The tumor is classified as Grade 3 endometrioid with squamous differentiation, measuring 5.5 cm, and shows extensive invasion through the myometrium to the serosa, with lymphovascular invasion present. Staging reveals T3a, N1, with metastasis identified in several pelvic lymph nodes and other sites, confirming advanced disease.

The pathology report indicates a left testicular mass measuring 9 x 5 x 4.5 cm, which is replaced by a multinodular seminoma.
