The tumor is confined to the testis and extends into the rete testis, but does not involve the tunica vaginalis or epididymis. Lymphovascular invasion is present in the spermatic cord, and the final pathologic diagnosis is Stage IB seminoma (T2NXM0S0).

The pathology report indicates that multiple excised margins from the left and right sides of the oral cavity, including the gingival, pterygoid, lingual nerve, pharyngeal, buccal, and labial margins, are negative for neoplasia. However, two lymph nodes from the left neck levels 2 and 3 show involvement by metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, with one exhibiting focal extracapsular extension. The resection of the floor of the mouth reveals a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with perineural invasion present and a close margin of 0.1 cm to the nearest soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the excisional biopsies from the right frontotemporal region of the brain reveal a diagnosis of glioblastoma, classified as a WHO grade IV glioma. The MIB-1 proliferation index is noted to be 35%, indicating a high level of cellular proliferation. Microscopic examination shows features of anaplasia, necrosis, and microvascular proliferation, consistent with the aggressive nature of glioblastoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated advanced gastric adenocarcinoma of the intestinal type, with infiltration through all wall layers and extensive lymphatic vessel penetration, classified as pT3. There are also lymph node metastases identified, along with infiltration of adjacent fatty connective tissue and the omental tissue. The report concludes that a clear margin of healthy tissue was removed during the operation, and further secondary resections of the pancreas are planned due to inflammatory changes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the floor of the mouth, measuring 4.9 cm in greatest dimension, with close margins of less than 0.1 cm. Thirteen lymph nodes from the right neck and eighteen from the left neck were examined, all of which were negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, the cheek margin showed carcinoma in situ, while all other margins were negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast has a poorly differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 6.0 cm, with no lymphovascular invasion and clear surgical margins. The sentinel lymph nodes from both axillae show no evidence of carcinoma, and immunohistochemistry results are pending. Additionally, the right breast has ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with intermediate grade, measuring 0.3 cm, and also shows negative margins.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe, measuring 5.0 cm, with visceral pleural and angiolymphatic invasion, but negative lymph nodes and clear surgical margins. Fluorescence in-situ hybridization studies indicate no EGFR amplification, with a ratio of 0.88, and a hyperploidy rate of 41% for chromosome 7. The tumor expresses CDX2 without TTF1, suggesting the need to exclude an extrathoracic primary site, particularly in the gastrointestinal tract.

The pathology report indicates a 1.4 x 1.2 cm infiltrating ductal carcinoma (G2) located in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast, with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. Ten dissected lymph nodes showed no metastasis, although they exhibited hyalinosis, sinus histiocytosis, and lipomatosis. The tumor is classified as T1, with a total Nottingham score that cannot be determined due to unspecified histologic features.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from both the left and right neck dissections are free of tumor, with one lymph node in the left neck containing a nonkeratinizing granuloma. A composite resection of the chin, jaw, floor of mouth, and tongue reveals a 6.5 cm invasive hybrid verrucous and conventional moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with a depth of invasion of 3.2 cm and negative margins. Additional studies show the tumor cells are strongly positive for p53 and negative for high-risk HPV, with the diagnosis confirmed as invasive squamous carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the posterior pharyngeal wall, measuring 2.2 cm, with carcinoma in situ present and surgical margins free of invasive carcinoma. Additional biopsies from the floor of the mouth and gingiva reveal invasive squamous cell carcinoma with some margins showing cautery artifact, while other biopsies show benign squamous mucosa and lymphoid tissue. The AJCC pathologic TNM stage is classified as pT2 pNx, and the assessment is subject to change pending further clinical review.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenosquamous carcinoma in the ascending colon, classified as grade G3, with evidence of ulceration and peritumorous chronic inflammation. The tumor has infiltrated the parietal layers of the colon and extended into the pericolic fatty tissue, but no cancer was found in the examined lymph nodes (0/12). The resection margins and surrounding omental fatty tissue are tumor-free, and the tumor staging is pT3, pNO, MX, L1, R0.

The pathology report indicates that the right lobe of the liver contains an invasive grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma, forming a significant mass with extension into the inferior vena cava. The tumor is located 5 mm from the nearest negative surgical margin, and one periportal lymph node is negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, the gallbladder shows evidence of chronic cholecystitis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an anaplastic oligodendroglioma, classified as a Grade IV tumor, following a craniotomy for a right temporal lobe tumor. Microscopic examination reveals a highly cellular neoplasm with significant nuclear anaplasia, frequent mitotic figures, and extensive areas of necrosis, along with a MIB-1 labeling index of 37%. The tumor exhibits characteristics consistent with both anaplastic oligodendroglioma and glioblastoma multiforme, highlighting its aggressive nature.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of colon cancer, specifically a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with a mucinous component, located 1.2 cm from the ileocecal valve, measuring 3.5 x 3.5 x 1.4 cm. The tumor has invaded through the muscularis propria into the subserosa and surrounding adipose tissue, with evidence of lymphovascular invasion and perforation of the visceral peritoneum, resulting in a staging of pT4a N2b. Out of 20 examined lymph nodes, 17 were found to contain metastatic carcinoma, and the appendix showed signs of a mucocele.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 72 mm, with possible pleural invasion but no evidence of vascular invasion or lymph node metastases. The bronchial resection margin is clear of tumor, and special stains are being performed to further assess pleural invasion. Reactive changes are noted in the examined lymph nodes, with no evidence of malignancy in those specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated papillary adenocarcinoma of the cervix, with a tumor size measuring 2.6 cm in greatest dimension and no evidence of carcinoma found in the examined lymph nodes (47 total). The surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, and there is no regional lymph node metastasis. Additional findings include foci of adenomyosis and multiple physiologic cysts in the ovaries, with no significant alterations in the bilateral tubes and ovaries.

The pathology report indicates a lumpectomy of the left upper outer quadrant revealing an infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 2 x 0 x 2.5 cm, which is moderately differentiated. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/10 positive), and the surgical margins are uninvolved. The total Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic counts.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 3, located in the fundus of the uterus, with a tumor size of 2.6 x 1.9 x 1.4 cm and invasion into the myometrium. All examined lymph nodes and additional biopsies from the omentum, small bowel mesentery, sigmoid colon mesentery, and peritoneum are negative for tumor involvement. A single intramural leiomyoma was noted in the myometrium, and the surgical margins are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6 (3+3), along with a minor component of Gleason pattern 4, affecting both the right and left anterior regions of the prostate. The tumor is confined to the prostate capsule (pT2b), with identified perineural invasion but no vascular invasion or involvement of the seminal vesicles or bladder neck. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is evidence of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and nodular hyperplasia in the non-neoplastic prostate tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the right renal mass is diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 4.0 cm, but without local or renal vein invasion, and with free surgical margins. Additional specimens from the right peritumoral fat, right lower pole cortex of the renal mass, and proximal right ureter show benign findings, including fibroadipose tissue and benign renal cortical parenchyma with focal glomerulosclerosis. The report has been amended to correct the specimen identification from "proximal right distal urethra" to "proximal right ureter."

The pathology report indicates that the right breast specimen shows invasive ductal carcinoma with a solid papillary architecture, histologic grade III, and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) constituting less than 25% of the tumor mass, with no involvement of surgical margins or lymph nodes. The sentinel and non-sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla are both benign, and additional special stains for hormone receptors show strong positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 is negative. The left breast segmental resection reveals duct hyperplasia without atypia and benign changes, with calcifications present in benign ducts.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, with a tumor size of 2.7 x 2.7 x 1.5 cm, classified as AJCC pT2. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, with the closest margin being 1.5 cm away from the tumor. Additionally, two left axillary sentinel lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement, confirming no lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated, keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the right tongue, measuring 1.2 cm with a maximum depth of invasion of 6 mm, and clear margins of resection. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic carcinoma in one sentinel lymph node, measuring 3.5 mm, with no extracapsular extension noted. The overall AJCC tumor classification is pT1, pN1(sn), and the stage is classified as Stage III.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an encapsulated thymoma, Type B2, measuring 1.7 cm, with microcyst formation, and no malignant lymph nodes were identified among the seven examined. Specialized laboratory testing classified the thymoma as Class 1, suggesting a low risk of clinical metastasis within the next ten years. The specimen consisted of two fragments of lobulated fibroadipose soft tissue, with the larger fragment showing a well-circumscribed, homogeneous nodule.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pulmonary adenocarcinoma in a right lower lobe lobectomy specimen, with a tumor size of 1.2 cm and histologic grade classified as moderately to poorly differentiated. All surgical margins are free of tumor, although there is focal invasion into the visceral pleura and a focus suggestive of lymphatic invasion, with no lymph node involvement noted among the seven examined. The report recommends further mutation analysis for EGFR and KRAS to guide potential targeted therapy options.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 91 mm, with invasion into both the visceral and parietal pleura, classified as Stage pT3N0. The bronchial resection margin is clear of invasive carcinoma, but there is focal extension to the hilar soft tissue margin, resulting in a residual tumor status of R1. No metastatic adenocarcinoma is found in the examined lymph nodes, and there are non-neoplastic findings of lipoid pneumonia and pulmonary edema adjacent to the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of predominantly poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate, primarily located in the anterior and right rectolateral peripheral zone, with a maximum tumor spread of 0.9 cm and focal perineural invasion, but no extraprostatic growth or vascular invasion. All examined lymph nodes are tumor-free, and the resection margins are clear, indicating a complete local resection. The remaining prostate tissue shows myoglandular hyperplasia, and the prostatic urethra is free of tumor and dysplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in the liver, measuring 5.0 cm, with negative resection margins and mild hepatic steatosis. Additionally, a high-grade, poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with mucinous differentiation was found in the sigmoid colon, also measuring 5.0 cm, with negative resection margins and no identified lymphovascular or perineural invasion. The proximal and distal donut specimens from the colon were negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma of the left breast, with a tumor size of 26mm and a histologic grade of III. All examined sentinel lymph nodes and non-sentinel tissue from the left axilla showed no carcinoma present, and surgical margins were clear of tumor. The tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 testing revealed no amplification, suggesting a lower risk of aggressive disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of follicular variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm in the right lobe following a total thyroidectomy. The left lobe contains adenomatous nodules, but no tumor was found in the examined lymph node (0/1). The right lobe is described as slightly enlarged and nodular, with multiple well-circumscribed nodules identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, both ovaries, and fallopian tubes, as well as in the small bowel, right diaphragm, transverse colon, and umbilicus. The carcinoma is characterized as poorly differentiated (grade 3) and shows extensive involvement of the peritoneal cavity without a dominant ovarian mass, raising considerations for primary peritoneal or fallopian tube carcinoma. Representative sections from each specimen have been submitted for further evaluation, confirming the diagnosis of serous carcinoma in the affected tissues.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of prostate cancer following a radical prostatectomy, with the tumor classified as a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7, predominantly involving the right lobe and showing extracapsular extension. Both examined pelvic lymph nodes were benign, and all surgical margins were free of carcinoma. The pathological staging indicates pT3a, with extensive perineural invasion and multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia identified, but no involvement of the seminal vesicles or evidence of angiolymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the right lateral pharyngeal wall and right tonsil are involved by poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with the tonsil measuring 3.2 cm and affecting the cauterized lateral resection margin. Additionally, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was found in one of 29 lymph nodes excised from the right neck, measuring 3.0 cm, while other lymph nodes and minor salivary gland tissues from various sites were negative for malignancy. Overall, the findings suggest a significant presence of carcinoma in the pharynx and tonsil, with limited metastatic involvement in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the histological and morphological findings are consistent with a diagnosis of diffuse astrocytoma, classified as WHO grade II. This type of tumor is characterized by low-grade malignancy. The report confirms the presence of diffuse astrocytoma without any higher-grade features.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive lobular carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 2.5 x 1.5 x 1.2 cm, with associated microcalcifications and a Nottingham grade of 2. Three sentinel lymph nodes were excised, all of which tested positive for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, atypical lobular hyperplasia was noted in the left nipple biopsy, but no invasive carcinoma was present in that sample.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive breast carcinoma in the left breast at the 3 o'clock position, classified as pT2 (28 mm) with no distant metastasis (pM0). The tumor is graded as grade 1 and shows associated extensive lobular neoplasia and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) grade 1, corresponding to pTis. Additionally, there is a report of a resection margin being involved (R1) ventrally.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions. A radical prostatectomy revealed invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 8, involving both lobes of the prostate but confined within the organ, with no evidence of extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle invasion. Additionally, perineural invasion was identified, but all surgical margins were free of carcinoma, and benign prostatic hypertrophy and chronic prostatitis were noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with anaplastic oligodendroglioma, a high-grade brain tumor. The microscopic examination reveals malignant oligodendroglial cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and areas of tumor degeneration and hemorrhage, but no vascular proliferation or pseudopalisading necrosis. The specimens were submitted in multiple blocks for further analysis, confirming the presence of this aggressive tumor type.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderate to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 5.5 cm, with the tumor confined to the pleural parenchyma and closely approaching but not involving the visceral pleura. Metastatic squamous carcinoma is present in one lymph node, while all surgical margins, including bronchial, vascular, and pleural, are negative for tumor. Additional specimens from lymph nodes and ribs are histologically unremarkable and negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report describes a 1208 g thymectomy specimen with a lobulated yellowish-white tumor, identified as a type AB thymoma, measuring 19 cm in its largest dimension and exhibiting extensive infiltration into the lung parenchyma. Microscopic examination reveals a proliferation of fusiform epithelial cells mixed with abundant lymphocytes, along with areas of necrosis and fibrosis, while the resection margins appear microscopically healthy. The associated lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy, and the tumor is classified as stage 3 according to the Masaoka staging system, indicating a complete surgical resection.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma (G3) of the larynx, with a tumor measuring 2.5 x 2.5 x 1.5 cm that invades surrounding structures. The excision margins at the root of the tongue and trachea are free of cancerous lesions, although the margin at the front right side is less than 0.1 cm. The tumor is classified as pT4a, indicating advanced local disease.

The pathology report indicates a fresh frozen tumor sample from the cervix, collected from a patient undergoing surgical resection for a 4 cm adenocarcinoma, not otherwise specified (NOS). The tumor is classified as T1b2 with unknown grade (Grade X) and shows bilateral disease involvement, with 12 positive lymph nodes out of 0 sampled. The clinical staging indicates no distant metastasis (M0).

The pathology report indicates that all three sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla are negative for tumor involvement. The left breast mastectomy reveals multifocal invasive ductal carcinoma, grade II, with the largest tumor focus measuring 6.1 x 4.5 cm, and negative surgical margins. Additionally, the right breast skin specimen is unremarkable and also negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive FIGO grade III endometrial adenocarcinoma, undifferentiated and endometrioid types, with a mass measuring 6.0 x 3.7 x 1.8 cm located in the anterior uterine wall, invading 1.8 cm into the myometrium. The tumor does not involve the endocervix, but there is focal squamous cell carcinoma in situ present in the cervix associated with squamous metaplasia. All examined lymph nodes, omentum, appendix, and peritoneal biopsies are negative for tumor, indicating no metastatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, in the lower pole of the right kidney following a partial nephrectomy. The tumor measures 3.0 cm, is classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 2, and is confined to the kidney without any evidence of extravasation or angiolymphatic invasion, with all surgical margins free of neoplasm. Additionally, the adjacent non-neoplastic kidney shows moderate arterial and glomerulosclerosis, while the tubules and interstitium remain well-preserved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in segment 6 of the liver, with a tumor size of 3.0 x 3.0 x 2.2 cm and a multinodular confluent gross type. The tumor exhibits microtrabecular histologic type with a histologic grade of 3 for worst differentiation and 2 for major differentiation, while there is no evidence of vascular invasion, tumor necrosis, or metastasis. Additional findings include the presence of active cirrhosis and a negative surgical margin of 2.1 cm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a tubular adenocarcinoma (G2) in the colon, with significant infiltration into surrounding adipose tissue and metastases found in the lymph nodes. Additionally, chronic appendicitis and a hemorrhagic corpus luteum in the ovary were noted, along with metastatic adenocarcinoma in the ovary. The incision lines were free of neoplastic lesions, suggesting that the cancer has spread beyond the primary site.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated gastric adenocarcinoma with metastases found in 13 out of 22 adjacent lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as G3, pT3, pN3, R1, and shows infiltration into the subserosa and fat tissue, with cancer present at the distal excision line. Inflammation is noted outside the tumor, with a total of 11 out of 16 lymph nodes involved in the metastatic process.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (NOS type, histologic grade III) in the left breast, measuring 6 cm, with no involvement of the nipple or surgical margins. Among the sentinel lymph nodes examined, one out of two was positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes from levels I, II, and III of the left axilla were benign. Additional findings include vascular invasion in the breast tissue, and the tumor was found to be estrogen receptor positive (90%) and progesterone receptor positive (40%), with HER2/neu negative status.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the stomach, with the tumor exhibiting ulceration and extending into the muscularis propria. There is evidence of metastasis, with one out of one lymph node positive for cancer. No information is provided regarding lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion, and margins and neo-adjuvant treatment details are not specified.

The pathology report indicates that a left orchidectomy was performed, revealing a seminoma with a diameter of 2 cm. The tumor is confined to the testis, with no evidence of angio-invasion or rete testis involvement in the available slides. The findings suggest a localized seminoma without any signs of spread beyond the testis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach (gastric cancer) with a tumor size of 9.5 x 6.5 x 3.1 cm, classified as G3, pT3, and intestinal type according to the Lauren classification. There is no evidence of metastases in the lymph nodes, although reactive lymphadenitis is noted in several nodes, and the surgical margins are clear of cancerous invasion. Immunohistochemical analysis shows a positive HER2 protein expression in the invasive cancer cells, indicating a score of 3+.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated mixed adenocarcinoma (G1) localized in the left upper lobe of the lung, primarily in segment S1. The tumor is classified as pT2a pNO L0 V0 R0, corresponding to stage IB, and exhibits a bronchioloalveolar pattern with mucin production and some pseudopapillary structures. Notably, the resection margins and lymph nodes are free of tumor, although there is initial infiltration observed in the partially resected material from segment S6.

The pathology report indicates that all examined lymph nodes from various levels on both the left and right sides, as well as soft tissue from the right level 3, are negative for malignancy. However, invasive moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 3.0 cm, was identified in the supraglottic larynx, extending through the epiglottis into the pre-epiglottic space, classified as AJCC stage III (pT3, N0, Mx). Additional margins from the laryngeal dissection, including the right arytenoid and paraglottic margins, were negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type) following a laparoscopic nephrectomy, with a tumor size of 5.3 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade II. The neoplasm is confined within the renal capsule, with no evidence of invasion into the renal vein or lymphatic vessels, and all surgical margins are free of cancer. The tumor is classified as pT1b, indicating localized disease without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma of the left ovary, with extensive surface and pelvic implants, classified as FIGO Stage IIIc. Additionally, metastatic papillary serous carcinoma is identified in the posterior cul-de-sac mass, tip of the appendix, uterus, omentum, and sigmoid colon, while the right ovary and fallopian tube, as well as the stump of the appendix, show no malignancy. The findings suggest a widespread metastatic process originating from the ovarian tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 1.2 cm, with no visceral pleural invasion and negative margins (R0). Nineteen regional lymph nodes were examined, all of which were negative for metastatic carcinoma, resulting in a pathologic stage of IA. Additional findings included hyalinized nodules in the lymph nodes consistent with old granulomas and emphysematous changes in the lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma of the colon, classified as G2, with infiltration into the muscularis and vessels, but with free resection margins and no lymph node involvement (pN0). Additionally, there are inflammatory reactive lesions in the epiploic appendix and a free anastomosis noted. The tumor is classified as pT2, L1, V1, and is locally R0, indicating complete resection.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast mastectomy showed benign mammary tissue with no malignancy, while the left breast specimen revealed invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 3, measuring 2.8 cm, along with high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ and lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma was found in four out of nine examined lymph nodes, while no malignancy was detected in the left level III axilla lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical analysis showed the tumor cells to be positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, with HER2 status pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with extensive myxoid changes and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of III out of IV. The tumor measures 3.8 cm, is confined within the renal capsule, and shows no invasion of the renal vein or evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, with all surgical margins free of neoplasm. The TNM stage is classified as pT1a NX MX, and the adjacent non-neoplastic kidney exhibits changes due to the proximity of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma originating from the pancreatic head, measuring 4.0 x 3.0 x 1.8 cm, with invasion into the duodenum and involvement of surgical margins at the portal vein groove and retroperitoneal area. Additionally, two out of ten regional lymph nodes are positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, leading to a final pathologic staging of pT3N1M0, classified as stage IIB. The gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis and cholesterolosis, but no distant metastasis is noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 4.3 cm with extensive lymphovascular space invasion, while the parametrium and resection margins are free of tumor. Metastatic squamous carcinoma is identified in multiple lymph nodes, with 3 out of 15 left pelvic lymph nodes, 1 out of 9 left common lymph nodes, 1 out of 14 left periaortic lymph nodes, and 1 out of 15 right pelvic lymph nodes showing metastasis. Additionally, the uterus shows secretory endometrium and adenomyosis, with no evidence of malignancy in those tissues.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive, moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in both the endocervix and endometrium, with no endometrial tissue identified. The diagnosis is based on microscopic examination of the provided slides. The patient is a postmenopausal woman presenting with bleeding.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a robotic-assisted laparoscopic partial nephrectomy for a right renal mass, which was diagnosed as multifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma, with at least six tumors identified. The largest tumor measured 6.0 cm, and all tumors were confined to the kidney with negative margins and no evidence of necrosis or lymphovascular invasion. The pathological staging is classified as pT1b(m) pNx, indicating multiple primary tumors limited to the kidney without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in several lymph nodes, specifically in the right neck dissection at levels II A, III, IV, and in the right paratracheal and superior parathyroid lymph nodes, with a total of 7 out of 25 lymph nodes showing metastasis. The total thyroid specimen reveals a 2.6 cm papillary thyroid carcinoma with areas of poor differentiation, extrathyroidal extension, lymphovascular invasion, and positive resection margins. Additionally, other lymph nodes and tissues examined showed no tumor presence, and the background thyroid exhibited chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, located at the junction of the cecum and ascending colon, with invasion into the muscularis propria. Additionally, there is a small solitary tubular adenoma with moderate dysplasia and a calcified focus likely representing a benign lymph node. The resection margins are tumor-free, and all 31 examined lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor involvement, resulting in a tumor stage of pT2 nNO (0/31) V0 L0; G2 RO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of carcinosarcoma in the uterus, with a tumor measuring 6.0 x 3.5 x 1.0 cm and superficial invasion of less than 2 mm into the myometrium. The cervix shows a non-invasive tumor nodule on the mucosa, while all examined lymph nodes from the left external iliac, left pelvic, and right pelvic regions are free of tumor. Additionally, there are no pathological findings in the right fallopian tube and ovary, and the left ovary and fallopian tube are unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast wide local excision revealed an invasive mixed (ductal/lobular) carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with focal ductal carcinoma in situ and no malignancy found in the medial margin. The sentinel lymph node from the left axilla was reactive with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The report also notes fibrocystic changes in the breast tissue and provides additional details on hormone receptor status, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative HER2.

The pathology report describes a malignant lymphoma, specifically diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, located in the jejunum, measuring 10x8x3 cm, with ulcerated and diffuse characteristics. Microscopic examination reveals large transformed lymphoid cells and multinucleated giant cells, with hyperchromatic nuclei and common mitotic figures, while immunohistochemical testing shows positivity for CD20 and negativity for CD3 and CKAE1/AE3. No lymph node involvement was noted, as all three examined mesenteric lymph nodes were negative.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder and omentum specimens are benign, with findings of cholesterolosis and fibroadipose tissue, respectively. The esophageal specimen reveals a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 5.3 cm, invading the muscularis propria, with two of six lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement, classified as pT2 N1. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and additional studies show negative HER2 status.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with a tumor size of 3.4 x 2.1 x 1.5 cm and invasion into the myometrium. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in 3 out of 10 lymph nodes sampled, while the cervix, ovaries, and fallopian tubes were free of tumor. The final pathological stage is classified as pT1b pN2 pMX, reflecting the extent of the disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating mammary carcinoma with lobular features in the left breast, classified as Grade III (poorly differentiated) with a tumor size of 3.5 cm. There is no evidence of lymph node metastases, as all three sampled nodes were negative, and the clinical staging shows M0, indicating no distant metastasis. The tumor is negative for estrogen receptors (ER), progesterone receptors (PR), and HER2, with a Scarff-Bloom-Richardson (SBR) score of 9.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma in the left adnexa, associated with a serous cystadenoma, with the tumor being unilateral and involving the serosal surface of the left ovary. Additionally, metastatic papillary serous carcinoma was found in the right sidewall and anterior cul-de-sac, while multiple lymph nodes were excised, with one lymph node on the right side showing metastatic adenocarcinoma. Other findings included benign conditions such as endometrial polyps, leiomyomata, and chronic inflammation in the cervix, with no tumor detected in the majority of lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the left kidney, with the tumor located in the upper pole and measuring up to 2.5 cm in maximal diameter, confined to the kidney without evidence of lymphovascular invasion or involvement of the adrenal gland. Surgical margins, including soft tissue, ureteral, and vascular margins, are negative for tumor, and the pTNM stage is classified as T1N0M0. Additional findings include pronounced arterial and arteriolonephrosclerosis in the non-neoplastic kidney, with further evaluation pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 3.5 cm, with a composition of 75% clear cells and 25% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3. The tumor is located near the hilum and invades a medium-sized blood vessel within the renal sinus, but there is no invasion into the renal sinus adipose tissue, perinephric adipose tissue, or renal vein. Eleven lymph nodes were examined and found to be free of tumor, and the adrenal gland showed cortical nodules without evidence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left lung squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 8.0 cm, with no evidence of tumor at the bronchial, vascular, or costal margins, and all examined lymph nodes negative for metastatic carcinoma. The rib specimens show unremarkable findings with hypercellular marrow, and the lung tissue exhibits emphysematous changes and chronic inflammation with fibrous adhesions to the chest wall. Overall, the tumor is classified as pT2N0Mx, indicating localized disease without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 5.8 cm in the sigmoid colon, characterized by a polypoid and fungating mass with ulceration and infiltration into the muscularis propria, but with negative resection margins and no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. The report also notes the absence of residual adenoma and identifies no tumor in the proximal and distal donut specimens. Associated findings include hyperplastic polyps and diverticulosis, with the tumor classified as pT2 N0 Mx according to AJCC guidelines.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas with transmural involvement of the duodenum and invasion of peripancreatic soft tissue, as well as the wall of the superior mesenteric vein. The tumor measures 3.0 cm, is unifocal, and has a histologic grade of 2-3/4, with three out of twenty-two examined peripancreatic lymph nodes positive for metastatic disease. The tumor is staged as pT3, pN1, and pMX, with margins being focally close to the inked soft tissue but negative for carcinoma in the pancreatic parenchyma, duodenum, and common bile duct margins.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the stomach, specifically in the body and antrum, with a largest tumor size of 9.0 cm and evidence of ulceration and local invasion to the serosa. Lymph node involvement is significant, with neoplasia found in multiple chains, including 16 out of 18 lymph nodes in the lesser curvature and various other chains, while some lymph nodes remain uninvolved. Neural, lymphatic, and blood vessel invasions are present, indicating an aggressive tumor behavior.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic papillary serous adenocarcinoma in multiple specimens, including the omentum, appendix, and various implants from the mesentery, small bowel, and other sites. Notably, the left ovary shows a 3.8 cm grade 3 papillary serous adenocarcinoma, while the right ovary and fallopian tube also exhibit metastatic disease. The uterus and cervix show no significant pathological changes, and the report highlights extensive metastatic involvement throughout the abdominal cavity.

The pathology report indicates a gastrectomy specimen from the cardia with an ulcerating tumor measuring 8 x 5 x 1 cm, diagnosed as poorly differentiated signet ring cell carcinoma. Out of 8 lymph nodes examined, 2 were positive for metastasis. Details regarding the extent of invasion and margins are not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 1, measuring 1.2 cm, located in the lower inner quadrant of the right breast, along with a malignant phyllodes tumor measuring 3.2 cm in the upper outer quadrant. The mastectomy margins are negative for tumor, and there is micrometastatic carcinoma identified in one of two sentinel lymph nodes. The overall staging is classified as Stage IB, with the invasive carcinoma being 0.5 cm from the deep margin and at least 1 cm from all other margins.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe lung, measuring 27 mm, with no evidence of blood vessel, lymphatic, or perineural invasion, and clear resection margins. The left hilar lymph nodes show only reactive changes with no signs of malignancy or metastases. Overall, the findings suggest a T1N0MX classification for the tumor, with additional granulomatous changes noted that may require further investigation.

The pathology report indicates a total gastrectomy specimen with a 7 x 0 x 7.5 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as poorly differentiated. The tumor extends to the subserosa, with no lymph node metastasis found in 15 examined nodes, although venous invasion is present. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there are no additional comments or specified findings regarding lymphatic or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma in the ascending colon, with significant tumor invasion into pericolic soft tissues and evidence of perineural and lymph-vascular invasion. A total of 11 lymph nodes were examined, with 10 showing involvement by the cancer. The tumor is classified as stage pT4c/d, pN2, and the surgical margins are free of neoplastic involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed serous carcinoma (50-60%) and moderately differentiated endometrioid carcinoma (40-50%) confined to the endometrium, with no lymphovascular space invasion identified. The cervix, bilateral ovaries, fallopian tubes, and multiple lymph nodes excised during the procedure were all negative for tumor. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT1aN0Mx, suggesting early-stage endometrial cancer without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma involving a 7 cm pedunculated polyp in the endometrial cavity, with invasion into the stalk and inner myometrium, characterized by a high mitotic count and vascular invasion. No carcinoma was identified in the examined lymph nodes, which showed reactive hyperplasia, and the bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy specimens revealed benign findings, including acute salpingitis and paratubal cysts. Additional findings included inflamed endometrium with complex hyperplasia and no neoplasm in the cervix or parametrium.

The pathology report indicates that the liver biopsy revealed a benign bile duct hamartoma with no signs of malignancy, while the gallbladder showed chronic cholecystitis and a congested cystic duct lymph node, also negative for malignancy. The Whipple's specimen confirmed the presence of invasive ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, with tumor extension to the ampulla and involvement of three out of 24 examined peripancreatic lymph nodes. Overall, the findings suggest a diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma with regional lymph node metastasis, while other specimens were benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, characterized by an 8 x 6 cm mass with extension into the perinephric fat. Coagulative tumor necrosis is noted, but the renal vein is free of involvement and surgical margins are negative. Additionally, no renal hilar lymph nodes or adrenal gland tissue are identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of small foci of metastatic carcinoma in the perinodal connective tissue of two sentinel lymph nodes, although no carcinoma is seen within the nodes themselves. The right breast tissue shows infiltrating mammary carcinoma measuring 3 x 3 x 2.8 cm, classified as grade II with no significant in situ carcinoma or angio invasion identified, and all surgical margins are free of carcinoma. The closest surgical margin is approximately 0.2 cm from the tumor, and additional genomic studies have been conducted on samples from the mass.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade invasive colonic adenocarcinoma located in the cecum and ileum, with a tumor size of 7.5 cm and no evidence of lymph node metastasis (0 out of 13 lymph nodes examined). Additionally, two adenomas were identified: a tubular adenoma measuring 0.7 cm and a tubulovillous adenoma measuring 1.7 cm. All surgical margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and there were no signs of vascular or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy from the lymph nodes and liver tissue reveals a well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 18.0 cm, with multiple smaller tumor nodules present, but no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or neoplastic invasion in the examined lymph nodes. The surgical margins are free of neoplastic invasion, and the adjacent liver parenchyma shows only mild changes due to the tumor mass effect. Immunohistochemical studies support the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma, with specific markers indicating the tumor type and ruling out the fibrolamellar variant.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the ascending colon, measuring 5.5 cm in length and 6.5 cm in width, with evidence of lymphovascular invasion and metastasis in one of the 24 examined lymph nodes. The tumor has invaded through the muscularis propria into pericolorectal tissues, classified as pT3, and the lymph node stage is N1. KRAS exon 2 mutation analysis returned negative, and additional polypoid lesions were identified, including two tubular adenomas and one hyperplastic polyp.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, classified as NHG2, pT2, pN3a, with evidence of metastases and micrometastases in the axillary lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical analysis shows over 75% of neoplastic cells expressing estrogen receptors, 10-75% expressing progesterone receptors, and a positive HER2 score of 3+. The tumor measures 4.5 x 3.5 x 3 cm and is located near the outer quadrants of the breast, with significant involvement of the axillary lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal carcinoma, measuring 6.0 cm, confined to the kidney with a Fuhrman grade of II. The tumor margins, including vascular, ureteral, and soft tissue, are negative for tumor invasion, and no lymphovascular invasion is identified. The remaining renal parenchyma shows no significant pathological changes, with mild to moderate chronic vascular injury noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically the papillary type, classified as Fuhrman grade 2, with the tumor measuring 1.5 cm and confined to the kidney. All resection margins, including those from the additional tumor and final margins, are negative for tumor involvement. No evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion was found, and the surrounding adipose tissue showed no signs of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from the right adrenal gland is consistent with a low-grade adrenal cortical carcinoma, characterized by pleomorphic epithelial cells and a mitotic rate of 6 per 50 high-power fields. There is no evidence of vascular or sinusoidal invasion, extra-adrenal spread, or necrosis, and the excision appears complete with clear margins. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis, showing a proliferation index of 8% and strong positivity for glucocorticoid receptors.

The pathology report indicates that there is no tumor present in the periprostatic lymph nodes, anterior apex, or both left and right pelvic lymph nodes. However, prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4 + 5) is identified in the prostate, with a focus measuring 3.5 x 1.5 cm, and there is a possibility of focal extension to the left apical margin. The seminal vesicles and segments of the vasa deferentia show no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the small bowel nodule and nodules on the stomach greater curvature are peritoneal inclusion cysts with no malignancy identified. Both the right and left ovaries contain benign Brenner's tumors, while the left fallopian tube has a paratubal cyst, and all lymph nodes examined show no evidence of malignancy. However, a partial gastrectomy revealed an invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a signet ring cell component, measuring 6.5 cm, with negative margins and evidence of angiolymphatic and perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a right renal mass diagnosed as clear cell renal carcinoma, with the largest tumor measuring 5.0 cm and classified as pT1b, meaning it is more than 4.0 cm but not more than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension and limited to the kidney. The tumor is unifocal, with no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion, and the surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. The histologic grade is Grade I, and there are no additional pathologic findings noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a median sternotomy thymectomy, with the final diagnosis being an invasive thymoma that is predominantly epithelial and shows lymphatic involvement. The specimen weighed 160 grams and contained a well-defined encapsulated mass measuring 5.5 x 5 x 2.5 cm, characterized by sheets of polygonal cells and evidence of extracapsular invasion. The tumor is noted to be close to the resection margin, raising concerns for potential residual disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in a mass located in the distal esophagus, with overlaying squamous mucosa. The specimen consists of multiple soft tissue fragments measuring 1 x 0.2 x 0.1 cm. The clinical history notes the presence of esophageal cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right mastectomy, revealing infiltrating lobular carcinoma measuring 5.2 cm, with focal lobular carcinoma in situ and ductal carcinoma in situ present. The deep margin is positive for tumor, but all 11 examined lymph nodes are negative for tumor, and there is no lymphovascular invasion noted. Additionally, the tumor shows HER2-neu amplification, which was not identified in the prior core biopsy.

The pathology report indicates that the excised right and left pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy, with all 57 examined lymph nodes being benign. However, the radical prostatectomy reveals extensive prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9, indicating a high-grade tumor that extensively involves both lobes of the prostate and shows extraprostatic extension and perineural invasion. Additionally, there is focal involvement of the surgical margin, but no lymph node metastasis was detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, Nottingham grade 1, measuring 0.7 cm, with no definite lymphovascular invasion identified. Additionally, there is ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of nuclear grade 1 and atypical ductal hyperplasia present, with negative surgical margins. The tumor is estrogen and progesterone receptor positive, and HER2/NEU is negative or low (0 or 1+).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the left lung, with a significant tumor size of 11.0 cm and negative margins for visceral pleura, bronchial, and vascular involvement. Among the lymph nodes examined, one out of twelve peribronchial lymph nodes and one out of one level 10 lymph node were positive for microscopic metastatic carcinoma, while the other lymph nodes from levels 5, 6, 7, and 9 were negative for tumor. The overall pathology stage of the tumor is classified as pT2 N1.

The pathology report indicates that a right temporal lobe lesion was diagnosed as a diffusely infiltrating astrocytoma at WHO grade II. Although two mitotic figures were observed, suggesting potential anaplasia, the MIB-1 labeling index was low, and many tumor cells expressed p53 and the R132H mutant IDH1. The specimens included both frozen and permanent sections, confirming the diagnosis of infiltrating astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an anaplastic astrocytoma, grade III of IV, in the left temporal lobe, confirmed through microscopic examination. The tumor exhibits moderately pleomorphic and infiltrative astrocytes with several mitoses, but lacks microvascular proliferation and necrosis. The specimen was received in multiple fragments for analysis, and the findings were personally interpreted by the signatory of record.

The pathology report indicates the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segments 5 and 6, with a primary tumor measuring 4.5 cm and three satellite lesions, all without vascular invasion and with negative margins. The liver background shows chronic hepatitis C with mild necroinflammatory activity and periportal fibrosis. Additionally, the gallbladder specimen reveals chronic cholecystitis but is negative for neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from various locations, including the paratracheal and subcarinal regions, were biopsied and found to be negative for malignancy. A lobectomy of the left upper lobe revealed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with invasion into the visceral pleura but negative resection margins and no lymphovascular invasion. The overall pathologic staging is classified as pT3NO, indicating the tumor's local invasion without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating poorly differentiated and mucinous adenocarcinoma with scattered signet ring cells at the esophagogastric junction, accompanied by high-grade columnar epithelial dysplasia and intramucosal adenocarcinoma. The tumor exhibits HER2 overexpression, with 10% of invasive tumor cells showing complete membrane staining, classified as a score of 1+. Additionally, there are non-specific reactive changes in the squamous epithelium and the presence of bacterial colonies.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 3.0 cm, with well-differentiated histologic grade and mild to moderate mitotic activity. Additionally, six papillary microcarcinomas were identified in both lobes and the isthmus, ranging from 0.08 to 0.6 cm in size, while the surgical margins were free of tumor and no blood vessel invasion or extrathyroid extension was noted. A separate finding of slightly hypercellular parathyroid tissue was also reported, confirming the presence of parathyroid tissue in the frozen section analysis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of squamous metaplasia and cystitis cystica in the bladder biopsy, while the cervical biopsy reveals invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The patient is a woman with a history of cervical cancer and irregular bleeding. The specimens were received in formalin and consisted of multiple fragments of mucosal tissue from both the bladder and cervix.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.5 cm in the right lower lobe of the lung, with negative margins at the visceral pleura, bronchial margin, and vascular margin. Additionally, two lymph nodes (station 7 and level 9) were biopsied and found to be negative for tumor involvement. The overall pathologic stage is classified as T1 N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (G2) in the liver, likely metastatic from colon adenocarcinoma. The tumor has infiltrated all parietal layers (pT3) and shows invasion of lymphatic and blood vessels (L1, V1), with four lymph node metastases (pN1). Resection margins are reported as free of tumor, and the tumor classification is ICDO-DA-M 8140/3.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated bilateral adenocarcinoma of the prostate, primarily located in the peripheral zone, with a maximum tumor diameter of 31 mm and a Gleason score of 4+3=7, including a tertiary grade 5. The tumor has infiltrated the periprostatic fatty tissue and seminal vesicles, but surgical margins are tumor-free, and no lymph or blood vessel invasion was detected in the immunohistological analysis. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes were tumor-free, confirming a final classification of pT3b, L0, V0, R0, and pN0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm, primarily located in the left lobe of the thyroid and extending into surrounding soft tissue and skeletal muscle. Additionally, two follicular adenomas and an adenomatoid colloid nodule were identified in the left and right lobes, respectively, with free margins of resection noted. The report also mentions the presence of papillary carcinoma involving the thyroid cartilage, with further sections pending for additional evaluation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has bilateral invasive lobular carcinoma, with 2 of 3 right axillary sentinel lymph nodes and 11 of 17 additional right axillary lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement. Both right and left breast mastectomy specimens contain invasive lobular carcinoma, but the margins are free of carcinoma, and there are fibrocystic changes present. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor positive, and shows normal HER-2/neu expression, with the largest metastasis measuring 1.1 cm and evidence of extracapsular extension.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multifocal adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 3+4 (total 7), comprising less than 10% of the gland, with no extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle invasion, and all margins are negative for malignancy. Additionally, biopsies of both left and right pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy in the examined nodes (0/5 on the left and 0/4 on the right). The pathological staging is classified as pT2c, N0, Mx, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as nuclear grade II, with associated fibrocystic changes. There is evidence of metastatic carcinoma in 10 out of 13 examined axillary lymph nodes, with one lymph node showing significant extracapsular extension. The main tumor measures 2.5 x 2.0 x 1.5 cm and the surgical margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that high-grade papillary serous carcinoma is present in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and omental cake, with a FIGO tumor grade of 3/3 and evidence of lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, numerous deposits of the carcinoma are found involving the uterine serosa and cul-de-sac, while the cervix appears unremarkable. Peritoneal fluid analysis is positive for malignant cells consistent with high-grade serous carcinoma, suggesting extensive disease involvement primarily in the ovaries and omentum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the lung with bronchioloalveolar and papillary features in the right lower lung following lobectomy. Additionally, there are panacinar emphysematous changes, intrapulmonary hemorrhage, and a single remote granuloma in a hilar lymph node. Importantly, three pulmonary lymph nodes and the bronchial and vascular margins are negative for tumor, and special stains for fungi and acid-fast bacilli are also negative.

The pathology report indicates that the resected prostate specimen weighs 46g and measures 5.5cm in width, with no gross lesions or nodules identified. The diagnosis reveals adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, involving both lobes but confined to the prostate capsule, with negative surgical resection margins and no tumor in the seminal vesicles or vas deferens. Additional findings include perineural invasion, but no lymph nodes were sampled, and the pathological staging is classified as pT2c.

The pathology report indicates that an enucleated right eye contained a 17x12 mm pigmented nodule consistent with uveal melanoma, characterized by predominantly epithelioid cells and severe cell atypia. There is focal tumor infiltration into the inner sclera, but no extra-scleral extension or involvement of the optic nerve and anterior chamber. The tumor exhibits low mitotic activity and a mild pigmented load.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear) cell type, with a Fuhrman's nuclear grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 7.0 cm. The carcinoma exhibits an acinar growth pattern with extensive intratumoral hemorrhage and has invaded the renal vein, but the ureteral and renal vascular margins are free of carcinoma. The tumor is classified as pT3b Nx Mx, indicating significant local extension, while the non-neoplastic kidney shows nephrosclerosis.

The final diagnosis for the left frontal tumor is oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade II), with further analysis for allelic loss on chromosomes 1p and 19q pending. The fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) results indicate that both chromosome 1p and 19q are intact, showing no evidence of allelic loss, which is associated with chemoresponsiveness and longer progression-free survival in gliomas. The tumor was assessed through intraoperative consultation and submitted for permanent evaluation, with multiple tissue fragments collected for analysis.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right pelvic lymph nodes are benign and negative for metastasis. The hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy specimen reveals a high-grade endometrial serous carcinoma, classified as FIGO grade 3, with superficial invasion of the myometrium and no lymphovascular invasion or extrauterine extension. Additionally, the non-carcinomatous endometrium shows atrophy, and the ovaries and fallopian tubes are histologically unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 cholangiocarcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, characterized by a lobulated mass measuring 8.9 x 6.8 x 5.5 cm, located 1.1 cm from the surgical margin. Additional findings include partially calcified fat necrosis in the peritoneum, no abnormalities in the gallbladder, a negative lymph node biopsy, and a fistula tract with abscess formation in the small bowel. The colon segmental resection revealed diverticulosis with multiple diverticula and associated diverticulitis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 5.5 cm, with Fuhrman nuclear grade III, found in the left kidney following a radical nephrectomy. The tumor invades into the perinephric fat but shows no vascular invasion, and the margins of the renal vein, ureter, and perinephric fat are free of tumor. Additionally, the adrenal gland is noted to be benign, and tumor cells exhibit specific immunohistochemical markers supporting the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph node dissections from the right pelvic, left pelvic, and right obturator nodes showed no evidence of malignancy, with a total of 21 lymph nodes examined and all negative for cancer. The uterus was diagnosed with serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, associated with an endometrial polyp, showing superficial invasion into the myometrium but no lymphovascular space involvement or cervical involvement. The ovaries and fallopian tubes were negative for carcinoma, and the tumor was classified as pT1a (IA), indicating it is limited to the endometrium or invades less than half of the myometrium.

The pathology report indicates that a lung nodule was diagnosed as a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the right upper lobe, measuring 2.0 x 1.5 x 1.5 cm, with no evidence of visceral pleural invasion or lymphovascular space invasion. Three peribronchial lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for malignancy, confirming no metastatic disease. Additionally, benign lymph nodes were identified at levels 9 and 11, with calcified granulomata present, and no acid-fast or fungal organisms detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade III squamous cell carcinoma located in the cervix, measuring 4x3x1.2 cm, with invasion into the outer half of the muscle propria. Microscopic examination reveals hyperplastic squamous cells replacing normal cells, with features of malignancy including enlarged nuclei and lymphocytic stromal invasion. Additionally, two out of three examined lymph nodes show evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of five foci of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the total thyroidectomy specimen, including one classical type and four microcarcinomas, with the largest focus located in the right lobe. The report confirms that the tumor is well-differentiated, with no identified mitotic activity or tumor necrosis, and it invades perithyroidal adipose tissue and the parathyroid gland on the left side. Additionally, the left paratracheal tissue and tissue near the left upper pole were found to be benign, with no malignant lymph nodes identified.

The pathology report describes a left eye enucleation revealing a large pigmented tumor measuring 18 mm by 12 mm, located at the postero-lateral part of the eyeball and adherent to the internal face of the sclera. Microscopic examination shows a melanoma characterized by fusiform cells with abundant melanin, infiltrating the internal layers of the sclera and the posterior part of the ciliary body, but not extending beyond the sclera or affecting the optic nerve. The report concludes that there is no extraocular infiltration, and the optic nerve remains unaffected throughout its course.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 2.1 cm, with negative surgical margins and no evidence of vascular invasion or metastasis. The liver is noted to be cirrhotic, specifically cryptogenic cirrhosis. Additionally, the gallbladder resection showed no significant abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 1.6 cm invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the right upper lobe of the lung, with no evidence of angiolymphatic or visceral pleural invasion, and clear surgical resection margins. Fluorescence in-situ hybridization studies reveal low-level amplification of Her2/Neu and significant amplification of cyclin-D1 and EGFR, which may correlate with poorer survival outcomes. All sampled lymph nodes are benign, and the pathologic stage is classified as T1 N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates a primary melanoma tumor from a 52-year-old Caucasian female, with a histological grade of 4 and a TNM stage of T4 N0 M0. The tumor tissue was processed as a frozen specimen, and the blood sample was also collected for analysis. There is no indication of prior chemotherapy treatment for the melanoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor located in the brachial plexus of the left arm, measuring 16.5 cm. The tumor exhibits strong vimentin expression and a MIB-1 labeling index of 15.7%, with a histologic grade of 3 and 50% necrosis present. The margins of the tumor cannot be assessed, and the microscopic extent is deep with a mitotic rate of 6 mitoses per 10 high power fields.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive, well-differentiated squamous carcinoma measuring 3.0 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm in the left hemimandible, with identified perineural invasion but no lymphovascular invasion. All examined margins, including the left mandibular nerve, tongue margin, buccal margin, and anterior tonsillar pillar margin, show no evidence of carcinoma, and sixteen upper and mid jugular lymph nodes, as well as four submandibular lymph nodes, are negative for metastatic disease. Additionally, the tonsil shows reactive follicular hyperplasia, and the surrounding bone is pending decalcification.

The pathology report indicates a left kidney specimen with a 5 cm mixed renal cell carcinoma, comprising approximately 50% clear cell and 50% papillary types, both classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 2. The tumor is confined to the kidney without extension beyond the renal capsule, and the resection margins, as well as the adrenal gland, are negative for tumor. Additionally, there are several benign cysts and chronic interstitial inflammation present in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in a central liver resection specimen, classified as AJCC Stage pT1, NX, MX, with no vascular invasion and clear margins. A biopsy from the left lateral segment showed mild steatosis and was negative for malignancy, while a perigastric lymph node was also negative for tumor. Additionally, a midbody stomach resection revealed a benign gastrointestinal stromal tumor with no mitotic activity identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligoastrocytoma (WHO Grade III) from a tumor resection of the right frontal lobe of the brain. The tumor was found to have intact 1p and 19q chromosomal regions, and the specimen was submitted for both frozen section analysis and routine histology. The clinical history noted a right frontal intracerebral mass, and the microscopic evaluation confirmed the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right kidney tumor diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma, measuring 9.2 cm and classified as Fuhrman grade 3, with invasion into the renal sinus but no penetration of the capsule. Additionally, a retrocaval lymph node was excised, revealing a tumor mass of 5.8 cm that appears to have replaced the lymph node, indicating metastasis. The adrenal gland showed no significant pathological abnormalities, and the resection margins were negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report describes a left frontal lobe tumor measuring 10x8x4 cm, characterized by a soft, brown-white surface and moderately defined margins. Microscopically, the tumor is identified as a grade II astrocytoma, exhibiting infiltrative growth with elongated, hyperchromatic nuclei, mitotic figures, and a fibrillar background, along with necrosis and lymphocytic invasion. The tumor demonstrates hyperplastic vasculature and is composed of gemistocytic groups interspersed with spindle cells.

The pathology report indicates a left renal tumor diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the clear cell type, measuring 4.0 cm in greatest diameter, located in the upper pole of the kidney. The tumor is confined to the kidney with no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, transcapsular invasion, or involvement of surgical margins. Additional findings include interstitial chronic inflammation, and the adrenal gland was not resected during the procedure.

The pathology report indicates a right hemicolectomy specimen with a 4.3 cm moderately differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma that invades through the muscularis propria into pericolonic soft tissue. The margins of resection are negative for malignancy, and there is no evidence of cancer in any of the 19 examined lymph nodes. Additional findings include benign serosal mesothelial cysts and fibrous obliteration of the distal appendiceal lumen.

The pathology report indicates the presence of anaplastic astrocytoma in multiple brain tumor samples labeled AF1, AF2, BF1, and an additional specimen. Microscopic examination reveals infiltrated brain tissue replaced by pleomorphic anaplastic astrocytes, with the presence of tumor giant cells and abnormal mitotic figures, but no necrosis. All samples submitted for analysis confirm the diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with mucinous features in the rectosigmoid region, measuring 7.0 cm, with evidence of perineural invasion and suspected lymphovascular invasion, and metastasis identified in 7 out of 24 examined lymph nodes. Additionally, a segment of the liver showed metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with colorectal primary, with a tumor nodule measuring 1.8 x 1.5 x 1.0 cm, while the endometrial curettings revealed scant benign atrophic endometrium. Other specimens from the ovaries and fallopian tubes showed benign findings, including adenofibroma and fibroma, with no significant abnormalities noted in the re-excised sigmoid colon margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon, characterized by infiltration into the perimuscular fatty tissue. The tumor-free margins suggest complete resection, but there are numerous regional lymph node metastases present. The tumor is classified as G3, pT3, with local invasion and lymphovascular invasion noted, resulting in a pN2 classification with 24 out of 29 lymph nodes involved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade III papillary serous carcinoma in the uterus, characterized by a polypoid mass, with no invasion identified. Additional findings include a benign endometrial polyp, leiomyomas, a corpus luteal cyst in the left ovary, and endometriotic cysts in the right ovary, while all lymph nodes and staging biopsies are negative for malignancy. The neoplastic cells are confirmed to be positive for p53 and negative for WT-1, supporting the initial diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma involving the floor of the mouth and mandibular bone, with the tumor measuring 4.2 x 4.5 x 4.5 cm. The resection margins are free of tumor, although the tumor is close to the deep and anterior margins. Additionally, there is metastatic squamous carcinoma identified in one of the left neck lymph nodes, while the remaining lymph nodes and salivary glands show no evidence of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of undifferentiated high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma, specifically pleomorphic malignant fibrous histiocytoma, in the right thigh, with the tumor measuring 14 cm and exhibiting approximately 50% necrosis. The tumor is noted to be close to the deep margin (0.15 cm) and lateral margin (0.5 cm), while other margins are widely clear. The specimen was obtained through radical resection, and the tumor involves fibroadipose tissue and skeletal muscle.

The pathology report indicates that the right anterior chest wall lesion is diagnosed as metastatic renal cell carcinoma with sarcomatoid features. The right radical nephrectomy reveals a papillary renal cell carcinoma with similar sarcomatoid characteristics, nuclear grade III, and a tumor size of 12 x 11.5 x 9 cm, which invades the renal capsule but not beyond it. The right soft muscle mass also shows metastatic carcinoma similar to the chest wall lesion, with surgical margins negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 5.5x5.5x4.4 cm, with extensive necrosis and negative surgical margins. Out of the examined lymph nodes, two of five peribronchial lymph nodes were positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the other lymph nodes from levels 2R, 4R, 7, 10, and 11 were negative for metastatic disease. The overall diagnosis includes a pathologic stage of pT2pN1Mx, with additional findings of mild emphysema and mucous plugging in the non-neoplastic lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 14 cm, with signet ring cells and evidence of vascular and perineural invasion, as well as metastasis to 11 out of 29 lymph nodes. There is no neoplasia found in the epiplon or the distal esophagus, which shows ectopic gastric mucosa. Additionally, the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis with cholesterolosis, while the proximal and distal margins of the tumor are uninvolved by neoplasia, although the distal margin is very close at 1.0 mm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma located in the body and neck of the pancreas, with a tumor size of 20 x 20 x 20 mm. There is evidence of extensive perineural invasion and lymphovascular invasion, with three out of eleven lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement. The tumor is staged as pT3, pN1, and classified as stage IIB, with close margins noted at the posterior soft tissue and portal vein.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with tumor invasion extending 21 mm into the myometrium and involvement of the lower uterine segment and cervix, along with extensive lymphovascular invasion. Additional findings include an 8 mm endometrial polyp, focal adenomyosis, and multiple leiomyomata, with the largest measuring 11 cm. The overall pathologic stage is classified as T3a/NX/M1 (Stage IVB), indicating distant metastasis, particularly to the omentum.

The pathology report indicates that a right kidney partial nephrectomy was performed, revealing a papillary renal cell carcinoma, type II, with a tumor size of 10.5 cm. There was no evidence of renal capsular invasion, and the margins of resection were free of malignancy, resulting in a pathologic stage of T2 NX MX. Additionally, a portion of the right rib was examined, which was grossly unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that two excised lymph nodes (R4 and Station 7) and associated fibroadipose tissue are negative for tumor involvement. A lobectomy of the left upper lobe reveals infiltrating moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 5 cm, with features of papillary adenocarcinoma and a peripheral bronchioloalveolar component, which abuts but does not invade the pleura. Focal vascular invasion is noted, but all margins, including bronchial and vascular, are negative for tumor, and there is evidence of typical pneumocyte hyperplasia in the surrounding lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right hemicolectomy, revealing an exophytic invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 5.5x3.5x1.0 cm, which arose from a tubulovillous adenoma in the transverse colon and invaded the full thickness of the muscle wall with extension to subserosal fat.
