One out of twenty-six pericolic lymph nodes was positive for metastasis, resulting in a staging of pT3 N1, while the proximal, distal, and radial margins of resection were free of tumor. Additionally, MLH1 and MSH2 protein expressions were present, and testing for microsatellite instability has been ordered.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma (4.5 cm) of the left buccal mucosa, with evidence of angiolymphatic and perineural invasion, and tumor involvement at the surgical margins. Additionally, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was found in multiple lymph nodes, with extracapsular spread noted in three of three lymph nodes at level 1 and two of three lymph nodes at levels 2 and 3. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3, N2b, indicating advanced local and regional disease.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast mastectomy revealed non-proliferative fibrocystic changes with no atypia or malignancy, while the right breast mastectomy confirmed the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 3, measuring 2.5 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and negative surgical margins. Additionally, two sentinel lymph nodes were removed, both of which were benign and negative for malignancy. The invasive tumor was estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor negative, and showed HER2/neu overexpression, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ of the comedo subtype comprising approximately 5% of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the right axillary sentinel lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor in five reactive lymph nodes, although lymphovascular invasion is noted in one node. The right breast lumpectomy reveals invasive ductal carcinoma, grade III, with associated high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ, and the margins of resection are negative for tumor. Additional findings include columnar cell changes, blunt duct adenosis, and apocrine metaplasia in the breast tissue, with negative hormone receptor status and no Her2/neu amplification.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 3.3 x 2.7 x 0.8 cm tubular adenocarcinoma (G2) located in the mucosa of the cecum, with infiltration into the surrounding adipose tissue. The tumor surrounds 50% of the intestinal circumference and is classified as Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2, pT3, pNO. The resection margins are free of neoplastic lesions, and there is no evidence of reactive lymphadenitis.

The final surgical pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes (7, 4R, 11R, 10R, and Level 7) were excised and all were negative for metastatic carcinoma. The right lung pneumonectomy revealed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with multiple nodules, measuring up to 5.5 cm, and no evidence of pleural or lymphovascular invasion. The tumor is staged as pT3 due to the presence of separate tumor nodules within the same lobe, and the bronchial and vascular margins of resection are negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the tumor is located in the right temporo-mesial region. The histological diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme. This diagnosis suggests a highly aggressive and malignant brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous carcinoma grade 3, measuring 3 cm in thickness, located in the pyriform sinus and involving adjacent structures, with evidence of lymphatic and perineural invasion. Metastatic squamous carcinoma was found in both examined lymph nodes, with extranodal extension noted. Additional findings include carcinoma in situ with areas suggestive of microinvasion in the right glossopharyngeal sulcus and moderate dysplasia in the new right inferior glossopharyngeal sulcus, while other margins and lymph nodes were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary thyroid carcinoma located in the right thyroid lobe, measuring 4.2 cm, with minimal extrathyroidal extension and negative resection margins. The left thyroid lobe shows benign changes with mild lymphocytic thyroiditis, and six right paratracheal lymph nodes were examined, all of which were negative for metastatic carcinoma. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3, pNO, pMX, and the specimen was intact with no lymphovascular invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 7.0 cm, located in the right renal vein and right kidney, with necrosis present and a negative vena caval resection margin. The kidney parenchyma shows mild chronic changes, including focal global glomerulosclerosis and moderate arterial sclerosis, consistent with age-related changes. One lymph node was examined and found to be negative for tumor, while a simple cyst in the kidney was also negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a moderately to poorly differentiated, invasive adenocarcinoma of the colon (rectal carcinoma) that has penetrated all wall layers and shows vascular infiltration, with lymph node metastases present (3 out of 19 nodes involved). The tumor classification is pT3, L1, V1, pN1, and the resection margins are free, indicating no residual tumor at the margins. The report summarizes the tumor classification as ICDO-DA M 8140/3, G2 to 3, consistent with R0 status.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing a fundal adenomyoma in the gallbladder and one benign lymph node, with no dysplasia or malignancy detected. The appendectomy showed no diagnostic alterations, while the total gastrectomy revealed a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma at the gastric cardia, measuring 2.9 cm, with positive lymphovascular invasion and two out of twenty-five lymph nodes positive for metastasis. The overall pathologic stage of the gastric adenocarcinoma is classified as IIB, with negative margins indicating no residual malignancy at the surgical resection sites.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes excised (#7, #8, #9, #10, #2, and #4) are negative for tumor, with one specimen showing benign adipose tissue. The right upper lobe lobectomy reveals a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, comprising 90% of the tumor, with a 10% component of adenocarcinoma, measuring 3.5 cm, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. The overall classification of the tumor is pT2aNO, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of esophageal adenocarcinoma measuring 3.3 cm, arising in Barrett's mucosa at the gastroesophageal junction, with invasion into the adventitia but free margins and no positive lymph nodes among the 12 examined. Additionally, the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis, with multiple stones present. The celiac lymph node examined was also negative for neoplasm.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of left breast invasive ductal carcinoma, with a maximum tumor size of 1.6 cm and Nottingham grade 1. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and sentinel lymph node biopsies show no metastatic carcinoma in the examined nodes. Hormone receptor testing indicates positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2/neu is negative, and there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of lung cancer, specifically a poorly differentiated adenosquamous carcinoma located in the left upper lobe, measuring 3.7 x 3.5 x 3.3 cm, with no evidence of visceral pleural invasion or lymphovascular space invasion. All examined lymph nodes (levels 5, 6, 7, and 9) were negative for metastatic carcinoma. The tumor is classified as pT2a N0, indicating it is confined to the lung parenchyma without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the pancreatic head, with a tumor size of 2.5 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm that extends to the duodenum and peripancreatic tissue. Surgical margins show a close radial margin (0.1 cm) but free distal pancreatic and proximal bile duct margins. Additionally, chronic cholecystitis was noted in the gallbladder, and lymphovascular and perineurial invasion were present, with direct tumor extension observed in 2 out of 4 examined peripancreatic lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions. A radical prostatectomy revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma involving both lobes of the prostate, with a maximum nodular diameter of 1.3 cm and approximately 15% of the prostate volume affected, but all surgical margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, perineural invasion is noted, and extensive high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is present, with a pathologic TNM stage of pT2c and no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2 N1 M0, indicating a primary tumor with regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. Additionally, a normal blood sample was obtained, which does not indicate any abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the anterior floor of the mouth, with perineural invasion present but no angiolymphatic or bone invasion. The tumor measures 2.5 cm and has clear margins, with a pathological stage of pT2 and no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes. Additional tests for HPV and p16 were negative, while EGFR immunostaining showed a positive result (3+).

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal papillary carcinoma, specifically the dominant follicular variant, measuring 1.3 cm in the right thyroid lobe, along with additional smaller tumors in both lobes. The report notes that the margins of the tumors are uninvolved by carcinoma, and there is no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion. Additionally, there are no pathological diagnoses for the parathyroid specimens and lymph nodes examined, with findings of mild reactive C-cell hyperplasia in the thyroid.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma in situ in the trachea with no invasive carcinoma identified, and multiple lymph node biopsies showing no metastatic carcinoma in 0/5, 0/7, 0/26, and 0/24 fragments from various lymph node stations. A right lung pneumonectomy revealed a moderate to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 5.0 cm, with satellite nodules present and evidence of metastasis in 3 out of 15 lymph nodes. The AJCC staging is reported as pT4 pN1 pMx, and further comprehensive review is recommended for final staging.

The pathology report indicates that the excised tissues from the tongue muscle, tongue base, oral mucosal margin, pharyngeal wall, and floor of mouth are all negative for malignancy. However, carcinoma was identified in multiple lymph nodes, specifically one of three nodes at left level 1 and one of one node at left level 2, with evidence of extranodal extension. Additionally, a moderate to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma was found in the tonsillar pillar/floor of mouth excision, with extensive perineural and lymphovascular invasion, corresponding to AJCC Pathologic Stage IVA.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of eight bilateral pelvic lymph nodes is negative for metastatic tumor, and the left lateral margin shows benign fibrovascular tissue with no malignancy. The radical prostatectomy reveals adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 8/10, involving both lobes but with no extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle involvement, and perineural invasion is present. Overall, the surgical margins are mostly negative, with the closest margin being 1.5 mm from the right posterior mid prostate margin, and additional findings include benign prostatic hyperplasia and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN).

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3 cm in the lung, with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. Additionally, a hamartoma was identified in a lymph node, while other lymph nodes showed signs of anthracosis and sinus histiocytosis, with no metastasis detected. The tumor is localized, and the overall findings suggest a localized malignancy without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right frontal glioblastoma, characterized by high proliferation, nuclear anaplasia, and necrosis, with a proliferation index of 30%. The tumor exhibits features of malignancy, including microvascular thrombosis and pseudopalisading necrosis, and the MGMT promoter is found to be methylated. The findings suggest a high-grade glioma, consistent with glioblastoma, and further characterization may be needed to differentiate it from other gliomas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with the largest tumor measuring 1.5 cm and extensive lymphovascular invasion present. Six out of sixteen examined axillary lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma, with the largest metastasis measuring 1.1 cm and exhibiting extracapsular extension. The tumors are classified as Nottingham grade 2, with a cribriform type ductal carcinoma in situ comprising approximately 5% of the tumor mass, and surgical margins are negative for invasive tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of a mass in the mid esophagus reveals invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Additionally, a biopsy from a site suspected of Barrett's esophagus shows the same type of adenocarcinoma along with high-grade columnar epithelial dysplasia, but no intestinal metaplasia or Helicobacter pylori was identified. Immunohistochemical staining for Her2-neu was negative, indicating no membranous staining of the invasive tumor cells.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, classified as FIGO grade 2, with invasion into the myometrium to a depth of 5 mm, but no vascular or endocervical invasion noted. Multiple biopsies from various sites, including lymph nodes and peritoneum, revealed benign fibroadipose tissue, with sentinel lymph nodes showing no evidence of metastatic tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis for DNA mismatch repair proteins demonstrated positivity for MSH2 and MSH6, while MLH1 and PMS2 were absent, suggesting a potential mismatch repair deficiency.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, in multiple biopsies from the right temporal lobe, with varying degrees of tumor necrosis and cellularity. Immunohistochemical analysis shows low MGMT expression, retained PTEN expression, and a significant presence of phosphorylated MAPK, suggesting potential resistance to radiation therapy but possible responsiveness to Temodar and EGFR kinase inhibitors. Additionally, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis reveals EGFR amplification, further informing the tumor's aggressive nature and potential treatment options.

The pathology report indicates multifocal invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) in the right breast, with four foci of invasive tumor and extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present, primarily in the upper inner quadrant. The largest mass measures 4.0 cm, and the surgical margins are negative, with a Nottingham score of 6 out of 9 indicating intermediate grade. Additionally, the right axillary lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma in 2 out of 16 nodes, with the largest metastasis measuring 0.8 cm and no extracapsular extension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated signet ring cell carcinoma in a stomach tissue specimen obtained from a gastrectomy, measuring 5 x 4.5 x 1 cm. There is evidence of metastasis in 3 out of 6 examined lymph nodes, specifically in the perigastric region. Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion, as well as margins and neo-adjuvant treatment, were not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with two separate foci measuring 2.8 cm and 1.3 cm, and a histologic grade of 3. Additionally, high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is present, with margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma at a distance of 4 mm and by DCIS at 1 mm. The left axillary dissection revealed metastatic carcinoma in one of four lymph nodes examined, with the largest metastatic deposit measuring 7 mm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left vocal fold, with a tumor size of 5.0 x 3.0 cm affecting multiple laryngeal structures and adjacent soft tissues. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was found in one of the left neck lymph nodes, while all right neck lymph nodes showed no evidence of neoplasia. Additionally, the left soft tissue margins were involved by neoplasia, while other surgical margins remained uninvolved.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two specimens: one showing edematous white matter with reactive features and the other diagnosed as glioblastoma (WHO Grade 4) from the right temporal tumor. The glioblastoma exhibits hypercellularity, moderate cytologic atypia, and robust microvascular proliferation, with numerous mitotic figures and areas of necrosis. The findings suggest a high-grade infiltrating glioma with significant malignancy, requiring further evaluation and management.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobe lung, measuring 6.5x6.5x5.5 cm, with associated squamous cell carcinoma in situ and invasion into the bronchus. One of eleven hilar lymph nodes showed metastatic carcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes and bronchial margins were negative for tumor. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT2N1Mx, with no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the cervix revealed invasive squamous cell carcinoma, specifically of the large cell nonkeratinizing type, which is moderately differentiated. The specimen was described as a pale pink-tan irregular tissue fragment measuring 0.7 x 0.5 x 0.4 cm, with a significant amount of adherent hemorrhagic material. The findings are consistent with a diagnosis of cervical cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cecum and proximal ascending colon, characterized by an exophytic circumferential ulcerated tumor measuring 8x4x1 cm, with full muscle wall thickness invasion and extension to subserosal fat. Six out of thirty-six pericolic lymph nodes were positive for metastasis, and the margins of resection were negative for tumor involvement, indicating an R0 resection. Additionally, a tubulovillous adenoma measuring 1.2 x 1.1 cm was identified, and EGFR expression was negative.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total thyroidectomy and examination of a right paratracheal lymph node, with no metastatic disease found in the lymph nodes. The thyroid specimen revealed a well-differentiated papillary microcarcinoma with tall cell features, measuring 0.7 cm, and a separate focus of 0.25 cm in the right lobe, with no evidence of tumor necrosis or extrathyroid extension. Surgical margins were free of tumor, and the remaining thyroid tissue exhibited mild nodular hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma in the right calf, measuring 18.8 cm, with a histologic grade of III and negative margins. Additionally, a right tibial nerve nodule shows pleomorphic sarcoma involving a segment of peripheral nerve, indicating regional neural invasion but no evidence of distant metastases. The tumor exhibits areas resembling low-grade myxofibrosarcoma and pleomorphic liposarcoma, but S100 immunostains are negative in these regions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant melanoma with a Breslow depth of 18 mm and Clark's level V, characterized by pigmented nevus-like and spindle-like cells without ulceration. Out of seven examined lymph nodes, four were found to be metastatic, classifying the disease as stage N3 according to the AJCC 7th Edition. The margins of the tumor are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 8, showing 45% involvement of the left lobe and 20% of the right lobe, along with focal extracapsular invasion and perineural invasion. No tumor was identified in the seminal vesicles or lymph nodes examined, and the surgical margins are free of disease. A small cluster of abnormal prostatic cells was noted, but definitive diagnosis was complicated by artifacts.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade III, with a significant tumor mass measuring 6.3 x 4.5 x 4.2 cm that invades the myometrium and involves the lower uterine segment and cervix. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the neoplastic cells are focally positive for estrogen receptor and vimentin, while negative for progesterone receptor and pCEA, with HPV in situ hybridization also negative. Metastatic carcinoma is identified in a single right obturator and a single left external iliac lymph node, while multiple other lymph nodes and biopsies from the gonadal vessels and mesenteric sites are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus, characterized by an ulcerative tumor measuring 4x5 cm that infiltrates all layers of the esophageal wall. The tumor causes a constriction of the esophagus by 1.5 cm, and metastasis is noted in one of the 11 paraesophageal lymph nodes and one of the 9 paracardial lymph nodes examined. The specimen includes a fragment of the esophagus and adjacent adipose tissue, with lymphatic nodes described as soft and measuring 1.5 cm in diameter.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma following a radical nephrectomy of the right kidney, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 out of 4. The tumor measures 10.2 cm and has invaded the renal sinus fat and extended through the renal capsule, but there is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, and all surgical margins are free of neoplasm. The non-neoplastic kidney shows chronic interstitial inflammation and glomerulosclerosis, with a TNM stage of pT3a NX MX.

The pathology report indicates that a female patient was admitted with a clinical suspicion of tongue cancer. Histopathological examination of the collected specimen from the oral cavity confirmed the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue. Surgical margins were marked for further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of primary peritoneal serous carcinoma with surface and parenchymal deposits in the right ovary, as well as paratubal soft tissue surface deposits in both fallopian tubes. The omentum shows extensive involvement by serous carcinoma, with the largest focus measuring over 2 cm, and the tumor is classified as poorly differentiated (G3). The final staging is T3c/NX/MX, indicating macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, with a tumor size of 3.1 x 1.5 x 1.7 cm and evidence of metastasis in the axillary lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical analysis shows estrogen receptors in 75% and progesterone receptors in 10% of neoplastic cells, with a positive HER2 score of 3+. The histopathological classification is NHG3, with a pT2 and pN1a staging.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 2.3 cm and unifocality. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 2 out of 5 lymph nodes, and the primary tumor is classified as pT2, indicating it is greater than 2 cm but less than 4 cm. The margins are focally involved by invasive carcinoma, while additional findings include an adenomatoid nodule in the right lobe.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated invasive and ulcerated adenocarcinoma of the intestinal type located in the cardia of the stomach, measuring 5.0 x 4.0 x 1.4 cm, with infiltration extending to the subserosa and evidence of lymphatic vascular invasion. Surgical margins, as well as all 19 dissected lymph nodes, are free of neoplastic involvement, although there is neoplastic infiltration in the adipose tissue. Adjacent gastric mucosa shows moderate chronic inactive gastritis, and the esophageal mucosa exhibits moderate chronic esophagitis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, in the right thyroid lobe, with a tumor size of 1.8 cm. The tumor is well-differentiated, completely encapsulated, and shows no signs of mitotic activity, necrosis, capsular invasion, blood vessel invasion, or extrathyroid extension. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and no abnormalities were identified in the non-neoplastic thyroid or parathyroid glands.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of thymic carcinoma, favoring poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with a maximum tumor dimension of 7.1 cm and focal areas of transcapsular penetration into adjacent mediastinal soft tissue, although margins of resection are clear. The biopsy of the aortic adventitia was negative for malignancy, and all examined peri-thymic lymph nodes (19 in total) were also negative for malignancy. Additionally, the native thymus showed age-appropriate involutional changes, and the right lung tissue exhibited no significant pathology.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the liver, specifically located in segment 8, with a tumor size of 2.9 x 2.2 x 2.8 cm and no evidence of satellite nodules or necrosis. There is partial fibrous capsule formation with capsular infiltration, but no invasion of surrounding structures such as the portal vein, bile ducts, or hepatic veins, and the surgical resection margin is clear by 0.5 cm. Additionally, the report notes chronic hepatitis B virus-related liver disease with micronodular cirrhosis, but no other significant liver pathologies were identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma of the right breast, measuring 5.5 cm, with a Nottingham score of 6, classified as grade 2. The tumor exhibits central subareolar location, with no lymph node metastasis found in the examined sentinel lymph nodes. Additionally, the tumor shows positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2/NEU status is negative or low (0 or 1+).

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a year-old woman, underwent a cervical biopsy which revealed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The diagnosis is based on the personal examination of the slides by the pathologist. The report includes one slide labeled for review, accompanied by a corresponding pathology report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) following a left adrenalectomy, with the tumor measuring 7 x 6.5 x 4.5 cm and weighing 115 g. The tumor is classified as pT3, with no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph node (0/1), and a Ki67 proliferation index of 20-30%. The Weiss score is 6, suggesting a high-grade malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7, involving both the right and left lobes of the prostate and accounting for 15% of the gland. Tumor involvement is noted at the inked right apical and anterior margins, with periprostatic fat involvement, while the bilateral seminal vesicles and bladder base show no tumor. The prostate margin excision shows no tumor, and the pathological staging is classified as T3a, with negative lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, specifically the tall cell variant, with multifocal involvement in both the right and left lobes of the thyroid, the largest nodule measuring 2.1 cm. There is evidence of extrathyroidal extension and involvement of the resection margin, but no angiolymphatic invasion was found, and all examined lymph nodes were free of tumor. The pathological stage is classified as pT3, with additional findings of nodular thyroid hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the tonsillar bed, measuring 3.5 cm, with moderate differentiation and invasion into underlying skeletal muscle, but no bony invasion or carcinoma in the submandibular salivary gland. Metastatic carcinoma was found in one of the 26 lymph nodes from the left neck dissection (level II), while no metastatic carcinoma was identified in the lymph nodes from levels IA, III, and V. The surgical margins are reported to be free of carcinoma, although the invasive carcinoma is noted to be close to the anterior and inferomedial resection margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, measuring 7.2 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of II, and no invasion of the renal capsule or vascular structures. The left kidney and adrenal gland were resected, revealing a benign renal cyst and negative margins for tumor. Cytogenetic analysis showed clonal aberrations, including a deletion of the short arm of chromosome 3, which is characteristic of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a radical mastectomy of the right lower outer quadrant with a grossly evident lobular carcinoma that is moderately differentiated. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/7), and the total Nottingham Histologic Score cannot be determined due to unspecified details. Additional findings and comments are not provided in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the lung tissue from the lingula, measuring 2 x 1.5 x 1.3 cm, with negative margins and no involvement of the visceral pleural surface. The examined lymph nodes (levels 5, 7, and 10) are negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additional findings include emphysematous bullae and a pleural-based fibrous scar with old hemorrhage.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of subcutaneous leiomyosarcoma in a right knee mass, measuring 2.6 x 2.1 x 0.7 cm, with a tumor grade of 2-3 and a mitotic count of up to 12 mitoses per 10 high-power fields. Focal tumor necrosis is present, but there is no angiolymphatic invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor, with the closest margin being 1.0 mm. The pathologic stage is classified as pT1a, pNx, pMx, and the attending pathologist has reviewed all materials and confirmed the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast underwent a simple mastectomy revealing fibrocystic changes, usual ductal hyperplasia, and benign microcalcifications, with no significant pathologic changes in the skin and nipple. The left breast showed infiltrating ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated, measuring 2.5 cm, with negative margins and evidence of isolated tumor cells in multiple sentinel lymph nodes. The tumor was classified as pT2 N0 (i+) MX, with negative estrogen and progesterone receptors, and negative HER2 status.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional (clear cell) renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 3.0 cm and a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV, but no evidence of local invasion or vascular involvement. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and additional biopsies from the left renal margin, left 11th rib, peri-nephric soft tissue, and hilar lymph node all show benign findings. The overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is pT1, indicating the tumor is confined to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in three sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla, with one node showing micrometastatic carcinoma and two nodes negative for metastasis. The breast tissue analysis reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 2.8 cm, classified as Nottingham grade 1, with no lymphovascular invasion and a focal extension to the posterior margin of resection. Additionally, 19 axillary lymph nodes examined during dissection were negative for metastatic carcinoma, confirming a pathologic stage of pT2, pN1, pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, with a tumor size of 8.4 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, but no tumor was found in the hilar fat or surrounding structures. The tumor shows no evidence of capsular invasion or involvement of the renal vein, ureter, or lymphatic vessels, and surgical margins are negative for tumor presence. The AJCC staging is pT2 pNx pMx, and the report notes that the findings are subject to change pending further clinical review.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 6.5 cm, with no involvement of the pleura or angiolymphatic invasion. All examined lymph nodes, including those from levels 10R, 11R, 7, and 4R, as well as the portion of the 6th rib, showed no evidence of tumor. The surgical margins are free of carcinoma, and the overall assessment is classified as pTNM T2 N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma involving multiple sites, including the right and left ovaries, fallopian tubes, and the cul-de-sac, with extensive ovarian involvement and lymphatic invasion. Additionally, metastatic high-grade serous carcinoma is noted in the bowel serosa and colonic fat, with transmural involvement of the right colon and omental involvement. The report also identifies a high-grade non-invasive serous carcinoma in an endometrial polyp, while the cervix appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a 6 x 6 x 1.5 cm exophytic adenocarcinoma located in the rectum, classified as moderately differentiated. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/8 positive), and the extent of the tumor involves the perirectal tissues. Margins and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a poorly differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 3 cm, with lymphovascular invasion identified. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the sentinel lymph node biopsy shows one positive lymph node for metastatic carcinoma. The overall classification of the cancer is Stage IIB, T2 N1 MX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in one sentinel lymph node with a single tumor deposit and extracasular extension. In the breast, invasive ductal carcinoma was identified with two foci measuring 3.2 cm and 1.5 cm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ comprising 1% of the tumor mass, and lymphovascular invasion noted. The tumor is ER/PR positive and HER-2/neu negative, with two out of nine lymph nodes involved and a pathologic stage of pN2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive basaloid squamous cell carcinoma originating from the left pyriform sinus, with tumor extension into adjacent structures but free resection margins. Out of 70 examined lymph nodes, four were found to be metastatic for the carcinoma, while the remaining nodes were free of tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive EGFR, and negative results for P16 and HPV, with no evidence of perineural invasion or extracapsular extension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal and lobular carcinoma, grade 2, with a tumor size of 1.8 x 1.5 cm located in the left upper outer quadrant of the breast. Out of ten dissected lymph nodes, five show evidence of metastasis, while the tumor exhibits no venous invasion and has uninvolved margins. The Nottingham histologic score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic counts.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of intermediate-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 3.5 cm in the distal pancreas, with clear margins and no lymph node involvement. The spleen and additional lymph nodes examined showed no significant abnormalities. Follow-up findings suggest the presence of metastatic disease in the liver, confirmed by fine needle aspiration, indicating a progression of the leiomyosarcoma.

The pathology report indicates that two blocks of left breast tissue were examined, revealing infiltrating lobular carcinoma grade II in one block, characterized by intermediate-sized tumor cells with moderate nuclear pleomorphism and mitotic figures, along with moderate chronic inflammation and focal necrosis. The other block showed benign breast tissue. The tumor nuclei make up approximately 70% of the total nuclei, according to the Modified Bloom and Richardson's grading system.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a unifocal adenocarcinoma measuring 2.5 cm in the left upper lobe of the lung, with a histologic grade of 2/4. No tumor was found in any of the examined lymph nodes, with a total of 11 nodes assessed and all negative for metastatic disease. The final TNM stage is reported as pT1b, pN0, pMX, and there are no tumors seen at the resection margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma located in the rectosigmoid region, with a tumor size of 3 cm in length and width, and a maximum thickness of 0.6 cm, showing invasion into the subserosa but no vascular or perineural invasion. Surgical margins are clear, with a pathologic stage of pT3 and pN1, indicating one metastatic lymph node out of 22 examined. Immunohistochemical staining for DNA mismatch repair proteins shows retention in the tumor, suggesting intact mismatch repair capability.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsy of the left true vocal cord reveals invasive moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. Additionally, the biopsy of the anterior tracheal lymph node shows no evidence of tumor (0/1). The addendum confirms that the carcinoma is negative for p16 and high-risk HPV.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of predominantly moderately differentiated bilateral adenocarcinoma of the prostate, confined to the organ with a Gleason score of 3+4=7 and a maximum tumor diameter of 2.4 cm, showing extraprostatic growth in the seminal vesicles and multifocal perineural involvement. Surgical margins are tumor-free, and there is no evidence of vascular invasion, with additional findings of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and myoglandular hyperplasia. Lymph node analysis reveals five tumor-free nodes, confirming a classification of pT2c, R0, and pNO (0/7).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 9 cm, with evidence of angiolymphatic invasion and focal dermal lymphatic involvement. The tumor is located within 1 mm of the deep margin, and all 16 examined lymph nodes are negative for malignancy, resulting in an AJCC stage of IIB (T3 N0 Mx). Additional findings include focal lobular carcinoma in situ, florid intraductal hyperplasia, and fibrocystic changes.

The pathology report indicates a specimen from a hepatectomy with a tumor measuring 7.5 cm, diagnosed as moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma. Additional findings include positive markers for CD10, Hepar, and AFP, although details regarding tumor extent, lymph nodes, venous invasion, and margins are not specified. There are no comments provided regarding neo-adjuvant treatment or other observations.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma located in the right hemicolectomy specimen, measuring 3 cm and exhibiting invasive growth through all layers of the intestinal wall. Additionally, a tubular adenoma with moderate dysplasia measuring 2.3 cm was found in the ascending colon, along with chronic appendicitis and periappendicitis related to the tumor's effect on the appendix. The tumor is staged as pT3, pNO, (0/40) LO vo; G2 RO, indicating significant local invasion and no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma, WHO Grade IV, from a specimen designated as "Right frontal glioma," measuring 2.0 cm in greatest dimension. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positive staining for GFAP and a Ki67 proliferation index of 48%, indicating a high level of cellular activity. The tumor exhibits pleomorphic glial cells, mitotic figures, and areas of necrosis, with small foci of endothelial proliferation noted microscopically.

The pathology report indicates a unifocal papillary carcinoma located in the left thyroid, measuring 1x0.7x0.7 cm. The tumor exhibits invasion of the capsule but shows no extrathyroidal extension. The tumor cells maintain polarity with regular nuclei and are described as fibrous.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the right retroperitoneal area, characterized by two masses with varying grades of differentiation and significant necrosis. The larger mass measures 22 x 22 x 11.5 cm, while the smaller mass is 5.2 x 4.1 x 4 cm, and the tumor does not invade surrounding organs such as the kidney or colon. Additionally, the report notes that the other submitted specimens, including a retroperitoneal nodule and lymph nodes, show reactive changes without evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report describes a 5x3x2 cm malignant tumor located in the right breast, identified as medullary adenocarcinoma. Microscopic examination reveals a necrotic and invasive tumor with pleomorphic hyperchromatic nuclei and a desmoplastic stroma containing lymphocytes. The tumor is staged as pT2, with a distance of 3 mm to the closest deep resection margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated HPV-associated squamous cell carcinoma located in the right hypopharynx, measuring 4.7 x 3.7 x 2.6 cm, with involvement of the right piriform sinus and right vocal cord. While the surgical margins from various biopsies are negative for invasive squamous cell carcinoma, three out of 71 lymph nodes examined show metastatic involvement, with the largest positive lymph node measuring 3.3 cm and exhibiting extracapsular extension. Overall, the tumor is classified as pT3 pN2b, indicating significant local disease without distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade astrocytoma in the right frontal lobe of the brain, consistent with glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV). Two lesions were biopsied, both showing characteristics of high-grade glioma with focal microvascular proliferation. The specimens were submitted for further analysis, revealing irregular soft tissue fragments with varying sizes and colors.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma (G-3) in the lung, measuring 7.5 x 6 cm, with focal necrosis and no evidence of venous invasion. Ten examined lymph nodes were negative for metastasis, and the surgical margins are uninvolved. The tumor is classified as pT3 according to the 7th edition of the TNM classification.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right frontal lobe oligodendroglioma, classified as WHO Grade II, based on the excised brain tissue specimens. Immunohistochemical studies show negative P53 and a low MIB-1 index not exceeding 3%. Further analysis for 1p/19q deletion will be conducted on the submitted material.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, in the left breast, with two masses identified and angiolymphatic invasion present. All surgical margins from the wide local excision are negative for tumor, with a minimum tumor-free margin of 1.0 cm. However, one out of twelve lymph nodes from the left mid/low axillary dissection is positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobe, measuring 3.7 cm, with visceral pleural and angiolymphatic invasion, and one N1 lymph node involved by metastatic carcinoma. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and the cancer is staged as T2 N1 MX. Additionally, reactive lymph nodes were identified with necrotizing granulomas and calcifications, suggesting possible Histoplasma infection, while EGFR FISH studies were positive and ALK FISH studies were negative.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right upper lobe lobectomy revealing a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.7 cm, with no angiolymphatic invasion or pleural involvement, and a negative bronchial margin. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in 1 out of 4 peribronchial lymph nodes, while no metastatic carcinoma was identified in the R4 and station 11 lymph nodes. Overall, the surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement, and the nontumorous lung shows anthracotic pigment.

The pathology report indicates the presence of spindle cell squamous cell carcinoma in the right retromolar trigone, measuring 2.5 cm, with extensive ulceration and perineural invasion, but negative margins at the superior, inferior, lateral, and medial edges. Additionally, metastatic spindle cell squamous cell carcinoma was found in one of the sentinel lymph nodes, with extranodal extension noted, while other examined lymph nodes and tissues were negative for carcinoma. The overall staging is classified as pT2, N2b, with a total of 38 lymph nodes examined, of which 3 were involved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 1 cm, which arises from the bronchial mucosa and does not penetrate the visceral pleura. The surgical margins, including bronchial, parenchymal, and vascular margins, are negative for tumor involvement, and lymphovascular invasion is not identified. Additionally, four anthracotic lymph nodes from the anterior interlobar region are negative for tumor, and the overall pathological stage is classified as pT1 N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating duct carcinoma, grade 2, with a tumor size of 2.7 x 2.5 cm located in the central breast. Ten examined lymph nodes showed no evidence of metastasis, and the surgical margins are uninvolved. The report notes focal fibrosis and lipomatosis in the lymph nodes, but there is no evidence of venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, with myometrial invasion and focal penetration of the serosa, but no cervical involvement or metastatic carcinoma in the examined lymph nodes. Additional findings include chronic inflammation and reactive changes in the omentum, organizing hematoma in the right cornu of the uterus, and benign changes in the left and right ovaries and fallopian tubes. The report also notes the presence of microinvasive cervical squamous cell carcinoma and extensive cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) III, with no evidence of lymphovascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, classified as Fuhrman grade 2, measuring 4.5 cm. The tumor is confined to the kidney with clear surgical margins, no evidence of invasion into surrounding tissues, and no angiolymphatic invasion. Additionally, there are three incidental papillary renal cortical neoplasms and findings of mild chronic interstitial nephritis and moderate sclerosis in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated solid carcinoma (G3) in the ascending colon, characterized by necrosis, ulceration, and peritumorous inflammation. The tumor has infiltrated the colon wall and extended into the surrounding fatty tissue, but all examined lymph nodes (0/12) and other tissue samples are tumor-free, with no signs of serous carcinosis. The tumor is classified as pT3, pNO (0/12), MX, L1, R0, indicating a significant local spread without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in segments IVB and V of the liver, characterized by a solitary 2.2 cm nodule with no vascular invasion and widely negative resection margins. Additionally, the background liver shows moderate chronic active hepatitis consistent with hepatitis C infection, along with bridging fibrosis. The gallbladder exhibits chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis, with findings supported by Masson trichrome staining.

The pathology report indicates that two pelvic lymph nodes were examined and found to be benign, with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The radical prostatectomy revealed the presence of conventional adenocarcinoma in the prostate, with a Gleason score of 7/10 and very focal extraprostatic extension, but no seminal vesicle or lymphovascular invasion. Surgical margins were uninvolved, and the overall pTNM stage is pT3a, NO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the left tongue. Both P16 immunostaining and in situ hybridization for high-risk HPV were negative. The specimen consisted of multiple fragments of soft tissue measuring 1.7 x 1.5 x 0.4 cm in aggregate.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma, epithelioid type, in the right pleura and level eight mediastinal lymph node, with no lymphoid tissue identified in the latter. Several mediastinal lymph nodes were examined, revealing benign lymph nodes with non-necrotizing granulomas, while one lymph node fragment showed metastatic malignant mesothelioma. Additionally, a portion of the right sixth rib exhibited benign bone and cellular marrow with focal marrow fibrosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in one of four lymph nodes from the left neck level I, with extranodal invasion noted, while the remaining lymph nodes from levels II, III, and IV were negative for tumor involvement. The left buccal tumor, measuring 4.4 cm, is diagnosed as moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with tumor present at the deep margin but negative for lymphovascular and perineural invasion. Overall, the margins from the resection of the oral cavity are largely negative for tumor, except for the deep margin which is very close to the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total laryngectomy due to laryngeal cancer, with findings of invasive non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.6 cm in the right pyriform sinus, exhibiting perineural invasion but with clear margins. Additionally, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was identified in multiple lymph nodes, with one node showing a psammoma body and no evidence of extracapsular extension. A small focus of papillary thyroid microcarcinoma was also noted in the right thyroid lobe, confined without vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the retroperitoneum and right kidney, with a tumor size of 29.0 cm. The tumor shows focal minimal invasion into the renal cortex and extensive areas of necrosis, estimated at 60%, while the well-differentiated component is close to the medial margin. Additional margins are free of tumor, and the adrenal gland and kidney parenchyma appear unremarkable with renal vessels free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in the left interlobar lymph node, with a size of 2.1 cm and classified as stage III (T1, N1, M0). Additionally, a wedge resection of the left lower lobe reveals squamous cell carcinoma with squamous cell carcinoma in-situ extending close to the resection margin. The findings suggest a significant concern for incomplete resection due to the proximity of the carcinoma to the margin.

The final diagnosis indicates a left occipital lobe tumor identified as glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV), characterized by focal microvascular proliferation and coagulative tumor necrosis. Additionally, a biopsy of a left parietal lesion revealed an infiltrating glioma. The report includes an amendment for editorial changes and notes that the specimens were submitted for interoperative diagnosis and further review.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, in the right kidney, with a tumor measuring 4.5 cm that is confined within the renal capsule and shows no invasion of the renal vein. Additionally, three paracaval lymph nodes were excised and found to be negative for carcinoma, while the gallbladder specimen revealed chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis. The non-neoplastic kidney showed benign cysts, with the largest measuring 4 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with a total of 9 lymph nodes examined and 4 showing metastatic disease. The primary tumor in the right lobe of the thyroid measures 2.2 cm and is classified as well-differentiated, with no evidence of extranodal extension or vascular invasion. Additionally, benign thyroid tissue with chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis was noted in some lymph nodes, and surgical margins from the total thyroidectomy were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 1.5 cm adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, characterized predominantly by lepidic growth with foci of invasive adenocarcinoma, and all examined lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma. Molecular studies revealed a positive KRAS mutation (p.G12C), while no EGFR mutations were detected. Additional findings included benign anthracotic lymph nodes and fibronodular granulomas in the lung tissue, with no evidence of carcinoma at the bronchovascular margins or in the rib specimen.

The cervical biopsy reveals invasive adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated, with no lymphovascular invasion identified, and suggests a possible component of endocervical adenocarcinoma in situ. The endometrial biopsy shows scant fragments of carcinoma and atrophic endometrium, correlating with the findings from the cervical biopsy. Immunohistochemical staining indicates strong positivity for p16 and pan-keratin, while neuroendocrine markers are negative, supporting the diagnosis of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the right middle lobe lung wedge resection showed no carcinoma, while the right upper lobe lobectomy revealed poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5.5 x 4.3 x 4.0 cm, which invades the pleura and chest wall but has clear margins. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from various levels were examined, with the majority showing benign findings, except for one lymph node that partially involved low-grade follicular lymphoma. The report concludes that there is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the omental biopsy reveals poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, most consistent with serous adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemical staining shows positive results for markers such as Cytokeratin 7, CA-125, and Wilms Tumor-1 antigen, supporting the diagnosis. The findings suggest a malignant neoplasm of ovarian origin, with no definitive papillary architecture observed in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from the right insular tumor is diagnosed as an oligodendroglioma, exhibiting features suggestive of anaplasia, classified between Grade 2 to 3 according to WHO 2007 criteria. Microscopic examination reveals a hypercellular infiltrative tumor with frequent mitoses, a small area of necrosis, and a Ki67 proliferative index of up to 10%. The report suggests further testing for loss of heterozygosity at 1p/19q due to concerns about potential progression to an anaplastic oligodendroglioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 8.5 cm, with invasion into the muscularis propria and perigastric fat. Out of 15 examined lymph nodes, 7 showed metastases, and there is evidence of perineural invasion. The tumor is ulcerated, and the surgical margins are uninvolved, with no venous invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, in the right parietal region, with varying degrees of necrosis and tumor cellularity across multiple biopsies. Immunohistochemical analysis suggests a potential diminished response to Temodar due to 30% MGMT positivity, while preserved PTEN expression may indicate responsiveness to EGFR kinase inhibitors. Additionally, the presence of activated pMAPK in a high percentage of tumor cells suggests relative resistance to radiation therapy, highlighting the aggressive nature of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.7 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion present but no perineural invasion. Surgical resection margins are free of carcinoma, and the pathologic stage is classified as pT2N3MX, with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma identified in one of four lymph nodes, exhibiting extracapsular extension. The report confirms that additional biopsies from the base of the tongue, right soft palate, and medial pharyngeal regions were benign, with no tumor detected in those areas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the distal esophagus, associated with Barrett's epithelium. The tumor measures 4x3.5 cm and has metastasized to 4 out of 8 examined lymph nodes. A radical resection was performed.

The pathology report indicates that the left lower parathyroid and right paratracheal lymph nodes showed no pathological diagnosis, while a total thyroidectomy specimen revealed a unifocal papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 1.3 cm in the left lobe. The tumor is encapsulated with widely invasive capsular invasion but no lymph-vascular or perineural invasion, and all examined regional lymph nodes were free of metastasis. The overall findings suggest a localized thyroid malignancy without evidence of distant spread or involvement of regional lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.1 cm, primarily located in the right tonsillar-retromolar trigone region and extensively involving the mandible, with foci of carcinoma at the anterior mandibular bone margin and lateral soft tissue margin. All other biopsies, including those from the soft palate, posterior tonsillar pillar, lymph nodes, and various margins, showed no evidence of tumor, with a total of 24 benign lymph nodes identified. The pathological stage is classified as pT4, with no angiolymphatic or perineural invasion observed.

The pathology report indicates that there is microscopic involvement of the margins in the left posterior region, with a linear distance of less than 1mm. Pathological staging reveals pT3b, N1, and Mx, with positive lymph nodes found on both the right (1 out of 5) and left (3 out of 5) sides. Additional findings include chronic inflammation and a resected prostate gland with nodular tan parenchyma.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenalectomy was performed, revealing an adrenal tumor weighing 254g and measuring 12 x 6 x 6.5 cm. The diagnosis is adrenal cortical carcinoma, with a Weiss score of 7, indicating a high-grade tumor. There is no evidence of lymph node metastasis, as all 32 lymph nodes examined were negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.8 cm, involving the right lateral gingiva, buccal mucosa, perimandibular soft tissue, and focally the mandibular bone, with two out of seven lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement and extracapsular spread. The margins of the mandibulectomy specimen are free of carcinoma, and there is no perineural invasion noted. Immunohistochemical studies show positive EGFR expression, while HPV and P16 are negative, and the pathological stage is classified as pT4a N2b.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, Nottingham grade 2, with a tumor size of 2.0 cm and involvement of the inferior margin. Metastatic carcinoma was found in all examined sentinel lymph nodes, with one node showing macrometastasis and two nodes showing micrometastasis. Additionally, benign fibrocystic changes were noted in the new inferior margin specimen, which was negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, specifically an infiltrating type located on the lesser curvature side of the distal antrum, with a tumor size of 4.8 x 3.6 x 1.1 cm. The tumor has invaded the muscularis propria (T2) and shows lymphovascular invasion, with lymph node metastasis present in 2 out of 63 examined nodes. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT2N1Mx, indicating advanced gastric cancer.

The pathology report indicates that a right breast lumpectomy revealed a 3.5 cm invasive grade 3 ductal carcinoma, associated with high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), with focal involvement of the deep margin but no angiolymphatic invasion. The sentinel lymph node excised from the right axilla was negative for metastatic carcinoma, and additional margins were also negative for carcinoma. The tumor is classified as pT2 with a Nottingham histologic grade of 3, and the hormonal receptor status shows negative estrogen receptors and weakly positive progesterone receptors.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenosquamous carcinoma of the endometrium, with a nuclear grade of 3, involving the entire endometrial cavity and penetrating up to 30% of the myometrium. The tumor extends circumferentially to the endocervical canal and shows lymphovascular involvement, while the pelvic wash cytology is negative for malignancy. Additional findings include adenomyosis and focal atypical epithelial hyperplasia in the left fallopian tube, with no positive lymph nodes identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive high-grade endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterine cervix, characterized by poorly differentiated features and vascular and perineural invasion, with a maximum stromal invasion thickness of 12 mm. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and no evidence of tumor multicentricity or in-situ carcinoma is found. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes and the cul-de-sac biopsy show benign findings, with no tumor detected in those specimens.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the left breast, measuring approximately 6.5 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and involvement of multiple surgical margins. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in two of three sentinel lymph nodes and one of one additional sentinel lymph node, with no extracapsular invasion noted. The tumor is classified as well-differentiated with a modified Bloom-Richardson score of 5/9, and the overall TNM pathologic stage is pT3 N1a MX.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen is from a prostate obtained through transurethral resection. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of prostatic usual acinar adenocarcinoma with a high Gleason score of 10 (5 + 5). The macroscopic description notes multiple irregular fragments of elastic and brownish tissue measuring 9.0 x 6.8 x 2.0 cm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma involving the spleen, left colon, left kidney, and retroperitoneal area, with tumor size measuring 33 x 20 x 15 cm and focal areas of necrosis. Additionally, multiple nodules of well-differentiated liposarcoma were found in the iliac vein and deep pelvic regions, with the largest measuring 5.0 cm, while the distal sigmoid colon and abdominal tissue showed acute serositis but were negative for malignancy. Overall, the report highlights significant sarcomatous involvement in various specimens, with clear margins in the renal and colonic areas.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 6 (3+3) and stage III classification (stpT3), characterized by perineural and perivascular infiltration but no invasion of the seminal vesicles. Additionally, six lymph nodes were examined, all of which were reactive and negative for metastasis. The tumor size was measured at 6 x 4.5 x 3 cm, and the surgical margins were uninvolved, with no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with a main tumor mass measuring 2.2 cm and associated satellite nodules, along with lymphovascular and perineural invasion. In the axillary sentinel lymph nodes, one node showed metastatic carcinoma measuring 1.5 mm, and seven out of thirteen lymph nodes were positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, with some exhibiting extracapsular extension. The tumor is classified as Nottingham grade 2, with negative surgical margins and positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, while being negative for HER-2/neu.

The pathology report indicates that both cervical biopsies taken from the 6 o'clock and 8 o'clock positions show invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the large cell nonkeratinizing type, which is poorly differentiated. The specimens were described as pink to pale tan tissue fragments, with one containing apparent mucoid material. Both biopsies were entirely submitted for examination and confirm the presence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that a right partial hepatectomy was performed on a male patient, revealing a single focus of poorly differentiated sarcomatous cholangiocarcinoma in the right liver lobe, measuring 8 x 5.5 x 6 cm. The tumor is confined to the hepatic parenchyma with negative margins and evidence of perineural invasion, but lymphovascular invasion was not definitively identified. Pathologic staging classified the tumor as pT1, with no regional lymph node assessment available and no distant metastasis detected.

The pathology report indicates the final diagnosis of an oligodendroglioma following the removal of a tumor. The tumor's morphological features are consistent with those observed in a previous resection of the patient. The submitted specimen consisted of multiple irregular, opaque tissue fragments measuring a total of 2.4 x 2.2 x 0.5 cm.

The pathology report describes a 6x5x5 cm oligodendroglioma located in the frontal lobe of the brain, characterized by increased cellularity, hyperchromatic nuclei, and the presence of mitotic figures. The tumor exhibits necrosis and invades surrounding benign brain tissue, with hyperplastic vasculature noted. The diagnosis is classified as a grade II oligodendroglioma, indicating a poorly differentiated tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the margins from the left anterior and base of the tongue excisions are negative for malignancy, while a radical resection of the mandible, tongue, and superior neck reveals an invasive, well-differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 8.5 cm, with perineural invasion but no definitive lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, one of six lymph nodes from the left neck levels 2-3 is involved with squamous cell carcinoma, while the other lymph nodes examined are negative for malignancy. The findings correspond to AJCC 6th edition pathologic stage I, V A (pT4aN1M n/a).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 1 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, with a tumor size of 4 x 2.5 cm and minimal invasion into the myometrium. The tumor extends to the lower uterine segment but does not involve the cervix, and there is no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion. Both ovaries and fallopian tubes are negative for carcinoma, and the specimen margins are not involved.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, specifically in the mediastinum and interlobar regions, as well as in the right middle and lower lobes of the lung, where the tumor measures 3 x 2.7 x 2.5 cm and shows vascular and perineural invasion. Additionally, benign fibroconnective tissue was found in the bronchus intermedius, and the bronchial margin was free of tumor involvement. Overall, one out of three lymph nodes examined was positive for metastatic carcinoma, while the bone specimens from the ribs showed benign findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of epithelioid melanoma from a surgical resection of pigmented skin on the right hand. The melanoma is characterized as mushroom-shaped with ulceration, classified as Clark level IV and Breslow thickness of 11 mm, corresponding to Stage IIC (T4, N0, M0). The final diagnosis confirms the presence of epithelioid melanoma.

The pathology report describes a left temporal and periventricular tumor characterized as an Anaplastic Astrocytoma (Grade III), showing moderately hypercellular and infiltrative astrocytic neoplasm with moderate to focally marked atypia. The MIB-1 labeling index is calculated at 13.8%, indicating a highly proliferative high-grade glial neoplasm. No tumor necrosis or microvascular proliferation is observed in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates that a near-total glossectomy specimen revealed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.6 cm, with perineural invasion and involvement at the left lateral margin, while all examined lymph nodes from both right and left neck levels were negative for malignancy. The report also notes that the right neck level I contained two lymph nodes that were negative for malignancy, and the left tongue base biopsy was negative for carcinoma. Overall, the findings suggest localized squamous cell carcinoma in the oral cavity with no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a fresh frozen sample from a 4.2 cm endometrial mass, diagnosed as endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation, classified as Grade III. The tumor is staged as T1b with no regional lymph node involvement (NX) and no distant metastasis (M0). The histological examination reveals up to 50% squamous/transitional differentiation confirmed by immunohistochemistry.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, specifically the chromophobe type, with a histologic grade of 3 out of 4. The tumor measures 4.5 x 4.2 x 3.5 cm and is unifocal, with no evidence of sarcomatoid features or significant invasion into surrounding tissues, although it is noted to be less than 1 mm from the renal capsule. Surgical margins and lymph nodes are negative for malignancy, and the overall AJCC stage is pT1b pNO.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, which has infiltrated through the muscularis propria and into the perivesical fat, but all resection margins are free of tumor. A total of 26 lymph nodes were examined from both pelvic sides, and none showed evidence of tumor involvement. The tumor is classified as pT3a, N0, MX, indicating extravesicular invasion without lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, with a subpleural mass that does not invade the pleura and clear resection margins. One of the five peribronchial lymph nodes examined contains metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the left mediastinal, left peribronchial nodes, left bronchial stump, and left hilar lymph node show no evidence of malignancy. Supplementary electron microscopy confirms the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma by revealing acini with microvilli and junctional complexes.

The pathology report indicates that out of the lymph nodes examined, one lymph node from Station R-10 showed metastatic carcinoma, while the other lymph nodes from Stations R-4, 7, and 11 were negative for tumor. A lobectomy of the right upper lobe revealed a 3.0 cm poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, with evidence of venous and lymphatic invasion, but the surgical margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. The report also notes that there are no distant metastases assessed, and the tumor has metastasized to one of the thirteen lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) located in the right lobe of the liver, measuring 12.5 x 9.0 x 15.0 cm, with no evidence of satellite nodules, necrosis, or vascular invasion. The surgical margins are clear, and there is a presence of chronic hepatitis due to HBV, but no cirrhosis or dysplastic nodules were noted. Additionally, the gallbladder was found to have chronic cholecystitis.

The pathology report indicates that a right thyroid lobectomy was performed due to a right thyroid nodule, which was found to contain a follicular variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma arising in a benign follicular nodule. The tumor is multifocal, well-differentiated (Grade 1), and totally encapsulated with uninvolved margins and no lymph-vascular invasion identified. Additional findings include Hrthle cell hyperplasia and the specimen was submitted for further consultation, with a pending addendum for additional details.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma with focal clear cell carcinoma in the left ovary and right fallopian tube, with the tumor measuring 6.0 cm. Additionally, the uterus shows extensive involvement of papillary serous carcinoma and clear cell carcinoma, with significant invasion into the myometrium and lymphovascular invasion, along with multiple leiomyomas affected by the carcinoma. Metastatic carcinoma is noted in several lymph nodes, with a total of 19 out of 28 lymph nodes involved across various sites.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a bronchoscopy and right upper lobe segmentectomy due to a pulmonary nodule, which was diagnosed as invasive well-differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 1.4 cm, with all surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, multiple lymph node biopsies revealed benign lymph node fragments, and no lymphovascular space permeation was observed. The final staging classified the tumor as pT1, pN0, and pMX, with underlying conditions including emphysema and parenchymal scarring.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated cervical adenosquamous carcinoma, which invades the cervical wall and is located less than 0.1 mm from the resection margins. All examined lymph nodes from the left pelvic, right pelvic, and para-aortic regions are negative for carcinoma, with no evidence of metastasis. Additional findings include endometrial polyps and endometriosis in the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a lobectomy of the left lower lobe of the lung, which revealed a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor measures 8.5 cm in greatest dimension. The specimen also included ribs 6 and 7.

The pathology report indicates that both the right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes show benign serous cystadenofibromas with multiloculated cysts and papillary excrescences, while the surfaces are uninvolved. The uterus contains a FIGO grade III endometrial adenocarcinoma, which invades the myometrium to a depth of 3.3 cm, with no angiolymphatic invasion noted. Additionally, multiple pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes on both sides are positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, indicating spread of the cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated invasive colonic adenocarcinoma measuring 6.5 cm, which has extended through the muscularis propria into the serosal adipose tissue, classified as pathologic stage T3N0MX, Dukes' B. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, and perineural invasion is present, but all surgical margins are free of cancer. Additionally, twelve pericolonic lymph nodes were examined, and no metastatic carcinoma was found; an EGFR immunohistochemical stain was negative, but further testing is pending.

The pathology report indicates a 7.5 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma located at the rectosigmoid junction, classified as moderately differentiated. The tumor has extended into the perirectal tissues, but all 12 examined lymph nodes and adjacent fatty tissue show no evidence of metastasis. The surgical margins are uninvolved, suggesting complete resection of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a recurrence of glioblastoma in the right parieto-occipital region, confirmed through both biopsy and resection specimens. The analysis reveals neoplastic proliferation of astrocytes with features such as nuclear anaplasia, mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis, along with a MIB-1 proliferation index of 19%. Immunohistochemistry shows sparse glial fibrillogenesis, and the presence of entrapped neurons suggests significant tumor infiltration.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2 N1 M1, indicating localized disease with regional lymph node involvement and no distant metastasis. Additionally, a normal blood sample was obtained, which does not indicate any abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating colonic adenocarcinoma, grade 2, measuring 11.2 cm, with invasion into pericolonic fat and five out of twenty-one lymph nodes positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma. The tumor is staged as T3 N2a MX according to the AJCC 7th Edition TNM classification. All resection margins are negative for carcinoma, and there is no evidence of perineural or lymphovascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a peripheral mixed bronchopulmonary adenocarcinoma with mucin formation, characterized by a tubulopapillary structure and a bronchioloalveolar growth pattern. The tumor has infiltrated the visceral pleura and extends to the basal row of metal clamps, with a TNM classification of pT2 pNX pMX RX. Immunohistological analysis confirms the diagnosis, showing positivity for cytokeratin 7 and TTF1, and negativity for CDX2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated, partially mucinous adenocarcinoma of the rectosigmoid colon, measuring 2.5 cm in diameter and extending 10 cm to the resection margin.
