The tumor has invaded all layers of the intestinal wall and spread to neighboring mesocolic fatty tissue, with metastases found in all 12 examined lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as stage pT3, pN2, with no evidence of malignancy in the remaining intestinal wall or at the resection margins.

The pathology report indicates that a 9.5 cm segment of the esophagus was removed from a male patient diagnosed with esophageal adenocarcinoma, which is associated with Barrett's mucosa. The tumor has infiltrated to the adventitia and involved three out of ten examined lymph nodes, but the resection margins are negative for neoplasm. The TNM classification is T3N1Mx, indicating advanced local disease with lymph node involvement but unknown distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of widely-invasive papillary thyroid carcinoma, measuring 3.1 cm, with unusual features including Warthin-like and hobnail cell changes, and cribriform-morular architecture, alongside severe chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. Metastatic disease is confirmed in 3 out of 16 examined lymph nodes, specifically in the right and left paratracheal regions. The report highlights the need for further clinical evaluation due to the unusual features observed in the tumor, which may suggest potential associations with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) syndrome.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right upper lobectomy, revealing a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.9 cm in the right upper lobe, with unifocality and no visceral pleura invasion. The bronchial margin and other examined margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and one of the 15 regional lymph nodes examined was involved. Additional findings included respiratory bronchiolitis, while other lymph nodes and the bronchial margin showed no significant pathologic changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of lung cancer, specifically moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with a prominent bronchoalveolar pattern, located in the right upper lobe. The examined lymph nodes from the right hilar, station 4R, and station 7 regions are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The tumor measures 2 cm and is confined to the lung with negative margins and no evidence of vessel invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the left axillary lymph nodes are negative for carcinoma, with immunohistochemistry for keratin also negative. The left breast mastectomy reveals invasive lobular carcinoma, moderately differentiated (Nottingham grade 2), measuring 2.0 cm, along with lobular carcinoma in situ present in 4 out of 12 slides; margins are negative for carcinoma and no lymphovascular invasion is noted. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, as well as HER-2 (3+), and exhibits unusual features consistent with pleomorphic lobular carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 4+4=8 and a tertiary pattern of 3, along with focal lymphovascular space invasion, but no extraprostatic extension. All sampled surgical margins, including the bladder neck and prostate apical margins, are free of carcinoma, and the bilateral seminal vesicles show no evidence of malignancy. Additionally, two lymph nodes examined from the bilateral pelvic dissection are negative for tumor, confirming no regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an esophageal mass with hypertrophic benign squamous epithelium that is undermined by invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The origin of the malignancy is unclear based on the submitted material. The specimen consists of multiple small soft tan-white tissues measuring approximately 0.3 cm in size.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated (FIGO Grade 3) endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with invasion into the myometrium to a depth of 1.13 cm and focal lymphovascular space invasion. The cervix, bilateral ovaries, and fallopian tubes are negative for tumor, and all examined lymph nodes (12 total) are also negative for metastasis. The tumor is classified as pT1cN0M0, indicating it invades more than half of the myometrium without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left laparoscopic radical nephrectomy, revealing multifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma type 1 (five tumors) and one clear cell renal cell carcinoma, with the largest tumor measuring 6.7 cm. No sarcomatoid features, perinephric fat invasion, renal sinus invasion, or renal vein involvement were identified, and the tumors were confined to the kidney with a Fuhrman grade of 2. The pathological stage is classified as pT1b, with no cancer found at the resection margin and no lymph nodes present.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder specimen shows chronic cholecystitis with cholesterosis, with no evidence of dysplasia or carcinoma. The liver segment resection reveals well to moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, associated with cirrhosis, and shows angiolymphatic invasion but no necrosis or perineural invasion. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma, with the tumor measuring 2.6 cm and a negative parenchymal margin for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe lung, measuring 2.5 cm, with no visceral pleural invasion and uninvolved bronchial margins. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in the left level 8 lymph node, while the left level 11 lymph node showed no evidence of metastasis. The overall pathologic staging is pT1b for the primary tumor and pN1 for the regional lymph nodes, with one of five examined lymph nodes involved.

The pathology report indicates a lobectomy specimen from the left lower lung, revealing a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 6 x 6 x 6 cm. There is evidence of metastasis in 2 out of 2 examined intrathoracic lymph nodes. Additional details regarding tumor extent, other nodules, lymphatic and venous invasion, and margins were not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell adenocarcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 7.5 cm and classified as Fuhrman grade III, with tumor extension into the renal vein but no extracapsular extension observed. The vascular and ureteral margins are negative for tumor, and the adrenal gland shows no evidence of malignancy. The final staging is pT3b Nx Mx, indicating advanced local disease without regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly to moderately differentiated, partly keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the lower lobe of the right lung, with significant lymphatic metastasis classified as stage IIIB. The tumor measures up to 4.8 cm and shows extensive involvement of surrounding lymph nodes and pleural structures, with evidence of angioinvasion not affecting small vessels. Additionally, there are findings of organized pneumonia, fibrous remodeling, and minimal dust deposits in the lung parenchyma, suggesting possible occupational exposure to asbestos.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing chronic cholecystitis, and a Whipple procedure showing a 2.4 cm grade 2 ductal adenocarcinoma in the pancreatic head, which invades retropancreatic soft tissue with lymph-vascular and perineural invasion. One lymph node was negative for carcinoma, while three out of twelve lymph nodes were directly invaded by the tumor. The surgical margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, with the closest margin being 0.5 mm from the invasive tumor.

The pathology report indicates that no metastatic carcinoma was found in the five excised pelvic lymph nodes (0/5). The radical prostatectomy revealed prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7/10, occupying approximately 1-3% of the prostate volume, with no extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle involvement identified. Additionally, perineural invasion was present, but surgical margins were negative for tumor, and the pTNM stage was classified as T2a N0.

The pathology report indicates that the right glossectomy specimen contains moderately to well-differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.7 x 1.4 x 1.5 cm, with a maximum depth of invasion of 1.5 cm and no perineural or vascular invasion. The right inferior margin shows invasive squamous carcinoma, while the right posterior margin exhibits mild dysplasia, and other margins are negative for malignancy. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from various levels are benign with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the left lateral segment of the liver, with the largest lesion measuring 4.1 cm and multifocality present. The tumor is noted to abut the hepatic capsule with focal disruption, raising concerns for potential extension beyond the capsule, and the surgical margins are positive for tumor. Additionally, mild steatosis and siderosis are observed in the non-neoplastic liver tissue, and further correlation with operative findings is recommended.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive mucinous (colloid) adenocarcinoma arising from an intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN) in the pancreatic head, with the invasive component measuring 30mm and clear of the neck margin. The tumor is moderately differentiated, staged as IIA, and no lymph node involvement was detected (0/14). Additionally, the IPMN extends to the neck margin, but the invasive adenocarcinoma is clear of all other margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, with a largest nodule measuring 7.5 cm and evidence of capsular invasion, while vascular invasion was not identified. Surgical margins are focally positive at the site of capsular disruption, but other margins are negative, and no carcinoma was found in the excised margins from segments 2 and 3 of the liver, diaphragm, or gallbladder. The AJCC staging is classified as pT3 pNx pMx, indicating advanced disease with significant tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the left lower lobe of the lung contains a moderately-to-poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a clear cell component, measuring 2.0 cm, and the tumor does not extend to the pleura or show evidence of blood or lymphatic vessel invasion. All examined lymph nodes from various sites (subcarinal, inferior pulmonary ligament, proximal bronchial, and ap window) are benign with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The bronchial and vascular resection margins are negative for tumor, and the final diagnosis confirms the presence of primary lung carcinoma without metastatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive serous carcinoma, grade 3/3, affecting both the right and left ovaries, with extensive involvement in the omentum and extra-ovarian extension. The peritoneal cytology also confirms the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma. The findings suggest a significant and aggressive malignancy with widespread dissemination.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated pancreatic adenocarcinoma in the distal pancreas, with the tumor extending into peripancreatic soft tissues and approaching the outer resection margin, although not definitively identified at that margin. One of twelve lymph nodes examined showed metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the spleen exhibited no specific diagnostic abnormalities. Additionally, there is evidence of perineural invasion by the carcinoma, and the presence of a branch duct-type intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN) is noted, though its relationship to the adenocarcinoma remains uncertain.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of melanoma in a female patient, with the tumor located in the skin and classified as a primary tumor. The melanoma is graded as 2, with a T stage of 4, N stage of 2, and M stage of 0, suggesting advanced local and regional involvement but no distant metastasis. Additionally, a normal blood sample was obtained, indicating no abnormalities in that specimen.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has an anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade III, confirmed through both biopsy and excision of a right parietal brain tumor. The tumor exhibits moderate pleomorphism with increased mitotic activity and a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 10%, which can reach up to 45% in certain areas. Additional testing revealed a positive result for the R132H IDH1 mutation, negative for the EGFRvIII mutation, and a positive allelic loss on chromosome arm 19q, while no methylation of the MGMT promoter was detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, based on multiple excisional biopsy samples from the right occipital region, with tumor cellularity ranging from 90% to 98% and no observed tumor necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed significant findings, including 80% of tumor cells positive for MGMT, loss of PTEN, and high expression of phosphorylated MAPK, suggesting a potential diminished response to therapies. Additionally, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis showed polysomy of chromosome 7 in 70% of nuclei, correlating with amplified EGFR signals, which may impact treatment options.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix based on a biopsy specimen. No lymphovascular space invasion was identified in the examined tissue. The specimen measured 0.8 cm and was received in formalin for analysis.

The pathology report indicates that the excisional biopsies from the right temporal lobe reveal a mixed oligoastrocytoma with a low proliferation index (MIB-1 at 2%), classified as WHO grade II/III. There is evidence of allelic loss on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, which is characteristic of oligodendrogliomas, and the presence of a methylated MGMT promoter, suggesting potential responsiveness to alkylating agent therapy. Overall, the tumor exhibits a glial neoplastic proliferation with a prominent astrocytic component but lacks significant cellular anaplastic features or necrosis.

The pathology report indicates that the excised Delphian lymph node and the left enlarged inferior parathyroid lymph node are both negative for tumor. A total thyroidectomy revealed multifocal papillary carcinoma in the right lobe, with the largest tumor measuring 1.8 centimeters, while all 18 examined lymph nodes were negative for metastasis. The report notes that the margins are involved by invasive carcinoma in the right thyroid lobe, but there is no evidence of vascular invasion or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the left occipital tumor has been diagnosed as a glioblastoma. Microscopic examination reveals a hypercellular glial neoplasm with atypical gemistocytic and fibrillary astrocytes, along with necrosis, microvascular proliferation, and perivascular lymphocytic inflammation. The findings are consistent with a high-grade glioma, specifically glioblastoma, based on the presence of mitotic figures and necrosis.

The pathology report indicates a 5x4x1.5 cm malignant melanoma located in the skin of the left buttock, characterized by an ulcerated and necrotic epidermis with sheets of spindle or oval tumor cells containing melanin. The tumor is poorly differentiated, with a Breslow depth of 15 mm, and one out of nine lymph nodes examined shows evidence of metastasis. Mitotic figures are common, and the tumor cells exhibit a low nucleo-cytoplasmic ratio with variable nuclear shapes and sizes.

The pathology report indicates a tumor located in the upper lobe of the right lung, measuring 6.00 cm. Histologically, it is classified as grade II with a staging of T2, N1, M0, indicating regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. The sample was collected through a resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of unifocal papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, with the largest tumor measuring 2.5 cm. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 2 out of 18 examined lymph nodes, and the primary tumor is classified as pT2, indicating it is greater than 2.0 cm but less than or equal to 4.0 cm and limited to the thyroid. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that a liver biopsy and re-resection were performed, revealing two separate nodules of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in a background of cirrhosis. The larger and smaller nodules were located subcapsularly, with clear surgical resection margins noted. Overall, the findings confirm the presence of carcinoma while highlighting the underlying liver cirrhosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed high-grade oligodendroglioma with astrocytic components, classified as WHO Grade III. The microscopic examination reveals increased cellularity, vacuolated cells, and a high mitotic count, with evidence of 1p and 19q deletions detected through FISH analysis. Overall, the findings suggest a significant tumor presence with specific genetic alterations, warranting further evaluation and management.

The pathology report indicates the presence of extensive bilateral adenocarcinoma in the prostate with a Gleason score of 4 + 5 = 9, showing significant tumor involvement (80-90%) and extraprostatic extension, particularly on the left side. The left peripheral margin is involved by tumor, while all examined lymph nodes (9 total) are free of metastasis. Additionally, there is no malignancy found in the bladder neck tissue, which shows benign changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately-differentiated non-small cell carcinoma with squamous features in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 1.8 cm. The margins of excision are negative, and there is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or direct extension of the tumor. All examined regional lymph nodes, including those from levels 5, 7, 9, 11, and 12, are negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions. A radical prostatectomy revealed invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing established extracapsular extension, but less than 5% of the prostate volume is affected. All surgical margins are free of carcinoma, and extensive perineural invasion is noted, while the bilateral seminal vesicles are free of cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with myogenic differentiation in the left thigh, classified as FNCLCC Grade 3/3. The tumor measures 11 cm in greatest dimension and shows 30% necrosis, with margins that are uninvolved by the sarcoma, located 4 mm from the closest margin. The specimen was obtained through wide excision, and no lymph nodes were examined or found to be positive for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, with a low-grade neuroendocrine component, following a Whipple procedure that included total pancreatectomy and cholecystectomy. The tumor, measuring 5.0 cm, shows extra-pancreatic extension and involves the pancreatic notch margin, with three out of seven peripancreatic lymph nodes positive for malignancy, resulting in a pathologic stage of IIB. Additional findings include high-grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN III) and chronic pancreatitis, while the portal lymph nodes examined were benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive rectal adenocarcinoma (G2) with tumor penetration through all layers of the rectal wall (pT3) and involvement of lymphatic vessels (L1). The resection margins are free of tumor (R0), and there are no affected lymph nodes (pN0, 0/17). Additionally, there is a portion of biopsy showing reactive changes in a lymph node.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating duct carcinoma in the left upper outer quadrant of the breast, with a tumor size of 3 x 5 cm. Out of ten examined lymph nodes, five showed evidence of metastasis. The tumor is moderately differentiated, with no venous invasion noted, and the margins of the specimen were not specified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a renal mass in the left kidney, diagnosed as clear cell renal cell carcinoma (Fuhrman nuclear grade III/IV), which is confined to the renal parenchyma with no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or tumor at the surgical margins. All other tissue samples, including cartilage from the left 11th rib, perirenal fat, and various lesions, showed no tumor presence. Additionally, the cytogenetic analysis was deemed inadequate due to bacterial contamination of the specimen.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes (R4, L4, level 10, level 5, subcarinal, and level 6) were examined and all were negative for malignancy. In contrast, the left lung specimen revealed multicentric, moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, with two lesions measuring 6 x 5 x 4 cm and 3 x 2 x 1.5 cm, respectively. Additionally, two out of six peribronchial lymph nodes contained metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the bronchial, vascular, and visceral pleural surfaces were free of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of parathyroid tissue in the superior parathyroid gland and identifies papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, with tumor-free margins. Additionally, metastatic papillary carcinoma was found in one lymph node from the right selective neck dissection, with a total of 20 lymph nodes examined. The report also describes multiple tumors in the thyroid, including a larger tumor in the right lower lobe and a smaller tumor in the left lower lobe, along with several lymph nodes that were assessed for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS), located in the left upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 3 cm. The tumor is classified as Grade II and is staged as T2, with no evidence of metastasis (M0). The sample was obtained through a resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates that the excised margins from the anterior and posterior floor of the mouth, as well as the anterior and posterior margins of the tongue, are negative for malignancy. However, a well-differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm was identified in the left tongue, with no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion, and all examined lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. The findings correspond to AJCC 6th edition pathologic stage I, and HPV testing revealed the tumor cells to be negative for HPV.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a high-grade glioma, specifically an anaplastic mixed oligoastrocytoma (WHO grade III), from a left temporal lobe tumor resection. Assays for 1p and 19q deletions were performed, with results showing no loss of the 19q locus and a loss of the 1p locus. Microscopic examination revealed an infiltrating cellular neoplasm with atypical glial elements, frequent mitotic figures, and a proliferation index of approximately 20-25%.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 1.5 cm, with a Nottingham score of 8/9, classified as grade 3. Surgical margins are clear of neoplasm and ductal carcinoma in situ is present in four of fifteen sections, but also free of in situ carcinoma by greater than 1.0 cm. Additionally, both the sentinel and non-sentinel lymph nodes examined are negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive bifocal ductal carcinoma and carcinoma in situ of the left breast, classified as NHG2. Immunohistochemical examination shows over 75% of neoplastic cell nuclei expressing estrogen receptors, 10-75% expressing progesterone receptors, and a negative HER2 reaction in invasive cancerous cells. Additionally, there is evidence of vascular invasion and parenchymal atrophy in the glandular tissue.

The pathology report indicates a 3.0 cm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with papillary differentiation located in a scar of the left upper division segment of the lung, with no evidence of visceral pleural or angiolymphatic invasion, and all sampled lymph nodes being benign. The surgical resection margins are free of tumor, and the pathologic stage is classified as T1N0Mx. Additionally, molecular studies reveal an EGFR exon 19 mutation, while no EGFR amplification or KRAS mutations were identified.

The pathology report indicates that a partial nephrectomy of a left renal mass revealed renal cell carcinoma, specifically the papillary type, Fuhrman grade 3, with a tumor size of 5.5 x 4.5 x 3.9 cm, confined to the kidney and with uninvolved surgical margins. Additionally, the peri-tumor fat biopsy showed no evidence of malignancy. The provisional pathologic staging is pT1b NX, indicating the tumor is more than 4 cm but not more than 7 cm in greatest dimension and limited to the kidney.

The pathology report indicates that the left distal ureter is markedly denuded but negative for neoplasm, while the right distal ureter and urethral margin are also negative for dysplasia and neoplasia. A radical cystoprostatectomy revealed invasive high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma with muscularis propria invasion, and a minute focus of adenocarcinoma in the prostate with a Gleason score of 6, both with negative surgical margins. Additionally, twelve pelvic lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for carcinoma.

The histopathological examination of a resected stomach specimen reveals a 9.8 x 6.4 x 2.8 cm invasive tubular adenocarcinoma (G2) located on the front wall, with neoplastic invasion through the entire wall thickness but not extending to the serous membrane. The tumor is classified as pT2, pNO, indicating moderate differentiation and no regional lymph node involvement. Reactive lymph nodes were identified in the periorificial, lesser curvature, and greater curvature regions, while no reactive lymph nodes were found in the peripyloric fat tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, left ovarian tumor, left ovary, fallopian tube, and cul-de-sac tumor, with carcinoma also involving the tubal serosa. Additionally, the uterus, right ovary, and fallopian tube show benign findings such as an endocervical polyp, atrophic endometrium with adenomyosis, and myometrial leiomyomata, with no tumors detected in these areas. Fragments of high-grade serous carcinoma were also found in the right perivaginal cyst wall.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium with extensive myometrial invasion and metastatic adenocarcinoma present in one right common iliac lymph node. The tumor measures 10.2 cm in greatest dimension and shows lymphatic and vascular invasion, while the cervix is involved at the endocervical mucosa but the cervical stroma is free of carcinoma. Additionally, benign Brenner tumors are noted in both ovaries, and the remaining structures, including the fallopian tubes, show no pathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary renal cell carcinoma. The tumor is classified as pT1a, suggesting it is small and confined to the kidney, with a grade of GII indicating moderate differentiation. This classification follows the TNM system for malignant tumors as per the 2002 version.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a nipple-sparing total mastectomy for right breast carcinoma, revealing a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma with lobular carcinoma in situ, and the invasive component is closely approaching the deep margin at 1.5 mm. Specimens from the right breast nipple margin and left breast showed benign findings, including fibrocystic disease and benign intraductal epithelial hyperplasia, with no malignancy detected in the nipple margin. Immunohistochemical assays showed positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, as well as HER2 overexpression, with a Ki-67 proliferation index indicating an unfavorable prognosis.

The pathology report indicates that a left adrenalectomy was performed, revealing a tumor weighing 96 grams and measuring 6.7 x 4.6 cm. The diagnosis is adrenal cortical carcinoma, characterized by a Weiss score of 7. This score suggests a high-grade malignancy with aggressive features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a malignant mixed Mllerian tumor (carcinosarcoma) of the endometrium with heterologous elements, showing significant myometrial invasion and vascular invasion, while no endocervical invasion was identified. Metastatic carcinosarcoma was found in several lymph nodes, including the right para-aortic and left external iliac lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes and biopsies from various sites showed benign findings. Additionally, there is marked reactive follicular hyperplasia in the right external iliac lymph node, with immunohistochemical studies confirming reactive changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in situ in the left breast, with the tumor measuring 2.8 x 2.1 x 1.5 cm and classified as NHG3. The examination revealed high nuclear atypia and comedo necrosis within the tumor, along with reactive lymphadenitis in the axillary lymph nodes. The findings suggest a significant presence of cancerous lesions, with a histopathological classification of pT2 and pNO.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated papillary serous carcinoma in the right tube and ovary, as well as focal papillary serous carcinoma in the left ovary and fallopian tube. Additionally, a tumor in the cul-de-sac was also identified as moderately differentiated papillary serous carcinoma. Other examined tissues, including the omentum and various biopsies from the pelvic region, showed no definitive tumors, with some areas exhibiting benign fibroadipose tissue or chronic cystic cervicitis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO Grade II) in the uterus, with a tumor size of 4.6 x 3.9 x 1.8 cm and a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 0.4 cm. All examined lymph nodes (right para-aortic, right pelvic, and left pelvic) are negative for malignancy, indicating no evidence of metastatic disease. Additional findings include adenomyosis and a leiomyoma in the remaining myometrium, with all other structures, including the cervix, ovaries, and fallopian tubes, showing no malignancy.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of prostate cancer, specifically conventional adenocarcinoma, with a Gleason score of 9/10 indicating high-grade malignancy. The tumor is present in both lobes of the prostate, accounting for approximately 30% of the total prostate volume, and shows extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, and lymphovascular space invasion. Additionally, one of two examined pelvic lymph nodes contains metastatic carcinoma, confirming the presence of advanced disease (pT3a, b, N1).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma in the thyroid, with the dominant tumor measuring 1.3 cm in the left lobe and exhibiting both classical and follicular variants. The report also notes mild follicular nodular disease and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, with no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion, and uninvolved margins. Additionally, three regional lymph nodes were examined, all of which showed no metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that a right kidney was surgically removed due to a renal mass, which was found to be a unifocal clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 7.5 cm in greatest dimension. The tumor is confined to the kidney with no evidence of necrosis, sarcomatoid features, or lymphovascular invasion, and the surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. The pathological staging is classified as pT2a, and the urology service has been informed of the malignancy diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral peripheral zone prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, characterized by multifocal lymphovascular and perineural invasion, extensive extraprostatic extension, and direct invasion of both seminal vesicles. The bladder neck biopsy also shows carcinoma with similar features, while all examined lymph nodes (7 total) are free of malignancy. The pathological stage is classified as T3bN0, indicating advanced disease with significant local extension but no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a female with a history of pelvic masses, has been diagnosed with high-grade serous carcinoma affecting multiple sites, including the omentum, left ovary, small bowel mesentery, right cul-de-sac, pelvic peritoneum, and gallbladder, among others. While there is no evidence of malignancy in some lymph nodes and certain other specimens, the carcinoma has extensively involved the right ovary, right fallopian tube, uterine serosal surface, and colonic serosal surface. The report concludes with a provisional pathologic staging of pT3cN0M0, indicating peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis.

The pathology report indicates that a right colectomy specimen was examined, revealing a low-grade adenocarcinoma of the transverse colon measuring 9 cm, which infiltrates the subserosa but does not extend to the serosal surface. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and no cancer was found in any of the 12 regional lymph nodes examined. The tumor is classified as pT3 with no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver, forming a lobulated mass measuring 9.6 x 9.5 x 9.3 cm, with extensive lymphovascular invasion and a tumor thrombus. The surgical margins are negative for tumor by less than 0.1 cm, and multiple regional lymph nodes, including those from the celiac and hepatic arteries, are also negative for tumor involvement. An in situ hybridization test for albumin is positive, supporting the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma.

The pathology report describes an enucleated right eye with a 10 mm uveal melanoma characterized by fusiform cells and sparse mitotic activity. The tumor invades the inner part of the sclera but shows no extrascleral extension, and both the anterior chamber and the optic nerve are free of tumor involvement. Overall, the findings indicate a localized melanoma without evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right lung squamous cell carcinoma, poorly differentiated, with a tumor size of 4.0 cm and no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. The resection of the right upper lobe showed a gray mass, but all examined lymph nodes (32 in total) were free of tumor, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. The margins of the resected lung tissue were also free of invasive carcinoma, leading to a final pTNM classification of T2 N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the uterine cervix revealed moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma. There is no evidence of vascular invasion. This suggests that the cancer has invaded the cervical tissue but has not spread to blood vessels.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of intermediate-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 7.6 cm, involving both the gastric mucosa and serosa, with a mitotic count of up to 21 per 10 high power fields and no tumor necrosis identified. The tumor is located 2.3 cm from the nearest resection margin, which is negative for tumor involvement, and a fundic gland polyp is also noted. The findings are consistent with the patient's history of gastric leiomyosarcoma and the clinical diagnosis of bleeding gastric leiomyosarcoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma, Type I. The tumor is classified as stage pT2, with no evidence of residual disease (RO), and is graded as GII. The ICD-0 code for this diagnosis is 8260/3.

The pathology report indicates that the brain mass biopsy reveals a diagnosis of glioblastoma, classified as an astrocytoma grade IV. Microscopic examination shows a highly cellular glial neoplasm with atypical fibrillary astrocytes, significant tumor necrosis, and microvascular proliferation. Immunohistochemical analysis shows that approximately 10-25% of the tumor cells are reactive for MGMT.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (Grade III) in the extended right lobe of the liver, measuring 15.2 x 13.5 x 13.2 cm, with negative surgical margins and evidence of focal microscopic vascular invasion. Additionally, the gallbladder was found to be unremarkable, with one benign lymph node that showed no evidence of malignancy. The adjacent liver tissue exhibited cholestasis and fibrosis, while distant liver samples showed no pathological abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the carotid sheath and post-tracheal wall mass, with a total thyroidectomy and right neck dissection revealing a 5.7 cm tumor in the right lobe and isthmus, exhibiting extrathyroidal extension and positive resection margins. Additionally, metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma was found in 7 out of 26 lymph nodes, although lymphovascular invasion was absent and there was no extracapsular extension. The right facial lymph node was negative for tumor, confirming no metastatic involvement in that location.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of primary squamous cell carcinoma of the lung in a Caucasian male. The tumor has a histological grade of 3 and is classified as T4 N2 M0 in the TNM staging system. No treatment has been administered at this time, and a blood specimen was also collected, which showed normal results.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive carcinoma in the soft tissue of the tooth socket #17 and in the tissue medial to the proximal mandible, while the retromolar trigone resection revealed poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm with negative margins and no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. All other examined tissues, including various regions of the buccal mucosa, hard palate, base of tongue, and lymph nodes, showed no malignancy. Overall, the findings suggest localized invasive carcinoma with no regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated papillary adenocarcinoma in lung tissue, with a tumor size of 4 x 3 x 6 cm. Out of 8 lymph nodes examined, 3 were positive for metastasis. Details regarding tumor extent, lymphatic and venous invasion, and margins were not specified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 4.7 x 4 x 1.2 cm ulcerous tumor in the mucosa of the large intestine, diagnosed as tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma (G1). The tumor has infiltrated the muscularis propria and pericolonic adipose tissue, with a minimum side margin of 5 cm and incision lines free of neoplastic lesions. The final diagnosis is classified as Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2, pT3, pNO, indicating a localized stage of the cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse astrocytoma, WHO grade 4, or glioblastoma in a right temporal tumor. The specimen shows significant infiltration by neoplasm, with areas of hemorrhagic soft tumor and prior evidence of anaplastic astrocytoma. The findings suggest a high-grade glioma, consistent with the patient's previous surgical history.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a glial neoplasm, specifically an anaplastic oligodendroglioma, which infiltrates both gray and white matter with moderate atypia and rare mitotic figures. The tumor exhibits a background of low-grade oligodendroglioma, with varying MIB-1 labeling indices ranging from less than 1% to 8.8%, indicating differing levels of proliferative activity in different regions. Overall, the findings suggest a complex tumor with both high-grade and low-grade characteristics.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in several sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla, with a total of 6 out of 28 lymph nodes showing metastasis, consistent with primary breast carcinoma. The left breast mastectomy revealed invasive ductal carcinoma, grade III, measuring 3.2 x 2.2 x 2.0 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ and negative margins. Hormone receptor status shows negative estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2/neu is positive (3+), and the pathologic stage is classified as pT2 N2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in a female patient, with the tumor located in the breast and classified as grade 2. The staging reveals T1c, N1a, and M0, indicating localized disease without distant metastasis. No treatment has been initiated, and a normal blood sample was also collected.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary thyroid carcinoma, classical type, located in the left lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 2.0 cm and focal capsular invasion. Six lymph nodes were examined, with all being benign except for one pre-tracheal lymph node that showed micrometastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma. Additionally, the thyroid tissue exhibited chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and surgical margins were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional clear cell type, with a maximum tumor size of 12.9 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade 2. The tumor is unifocal with focal microscopic capsular invasion and macroscopic invasion of the renal vein, while the adrenal gland and surrounding tissues show no evidence of tumor. The AJCC staging is pT3a pNx, reflecting the extent of the disease at the time of the report.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were found in the left and right pelvic lymph nodes, with a total of ten lymph nodes examined (0/10). The prostate shows prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3), exhibiting extraprostatic extension, while the margins of resection are free of tumor. Additionally, the posterior bladder neck contains adipose tissue with vessels and ganglion, but no tumor is present.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic serous carcinoma affecting multiple sites, including the right ovary (grade III, FIGO stage IIIC), left ovary, both fallopian tubes, omentum, peritoneum, and colon. The left peri-aortic lymph nodes showed no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, while one of five right peri-aortic lymph nodes and one of fourteen right pelvic lymph nodes contained metastatic carcinoma. Overall, the findings confirm widespread metastatic disease with a significant tumor burden in the abdominal cavity.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a recurrent malignant glioma, specifically a glioblastoma multiforme, in the right occipital region, with a high MIB-1 proliferation index of 80%. Additionally, a right temporal biopsy also confirmed the presence of glioblastoma multiforme, characterized by high cellular density and a MIB-1 proliferation index of approximately 30%. The microscopic examination revealed features of anaplasia, necrosis, and neovascularization in both specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a moderately differentiated, partially mucus-producing colorectal adenocarcinoma located in the right hemicolectomy specimen, measuring 4 cm and invading the muscularis propria. Additionally, there is a small tubular adenoma with moderate epithelial dysplasia in the colon mucous membrane, and mild fibrosis in the appendix wall. The tumor-free margins and lymph nodes (25 examined) suggest no evidence of metastatic disease, resulting in a tumor stage of pT2 pNO (0/25) LO V0; G2 RO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of epitheloid melanoma in a male patient. The specimen consists of a skin patch from the right hand, measuring 5.5 cm x 6 cm x 5 cm, and is classified as Grade 3. The final diagnosis confirms the presence of epitheloid melanoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma in the stomach with infiltration into the perigastric adipose tissue and satellite nodes, classified as Bormann Type III. Surgical resection margins are clear of neoplasia, and there is evidence of lymph node metastasis in 1 out of 7 resected nodes from the lesser curvature, while no metastasis was found in 5 nodes from the greater curvature. Additionally, chronic cholecystitis is noted in the gallbladder, and all other examined tissues are uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from various levels are negative for tumor involvement, while a segment of the left lower lobe lung shows moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 1.5 cm, with focal penetration into the visceral pleura. The surgical margins of resection are negative for tumor, and there is patchy mild non-specific chronic inflammation with scattered epithelioid granulomata noted in the lung tissue. The final diagnosis includes a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma consistent with a primary lung tumor, supported by immunophenotyping results.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a modified radical mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection due to two separate tumor nodules in the left breast, one being a poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) measuring 3.9 cm and the other predominantly ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with foci of IDC. The report notes extensive necrosis in the DCIS, high nuclear grade, and the presence of vascular invasion, but no involvement of surgical margins or skin by carcinoma. Additionally, all examined axillary lymph nodes were benign, with no positive nodes identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of thymoma, WHO type AB, with a greatest tumor dimension of 5.0 cm and focal microscopic invasion of mediastinal fat, located within 0.1 cm of the cauterized surface of the specimen. Additionally, a left hilar metastatic deposit consistent with metastatic thymoma was completely excised, with minimal surrounding thymic tissue showing involutional changes. The report notes that the surgical margins are uninvolved by tumor, and close follow-up is recommended due to the presence of atypical features of uncertain significance.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive serous papillary carcinoma in both the left ovary and right adnexa, with extension into the fallopian tube and evidence of metastasis in the omentum, appendix, and umbilical nodule. The uterus and cervix show a proliferative endometrium and a leiomyoma, while the cervix exhibits parakeratosis. Immunohistochemical staining reveals that the tumor cells do not express estrogen or progesterone receptors, nor do they show overexpression of HER-2/c-erbB-2.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary thyroid carcinoma in both the right and left thyroid lobes, with the right lobe tumor measuring 2.0 cm and the left lobe tumor measuring 3 mm. The right thyroid carcinoma shows minimal extrathyroidal extension and approaches within <1 mm of the cauterized margin, while the left lobe has negative resection margins. Additionally, two out of two right paratracheal lymph nodes are positive for metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3, pN1a, pMX.

The pathology report describes a paracaval lymph node measuring 2.5 x 2 x 1 cm, which has been diagnosed with highly proliferative diffuse large B-cell lymphoma that is histiocyte-rich. Immunohistochemical analysis shows strong positivity for CD20, BCL-2, and MUM-1, with a Ki-67 proliferation index of 60-95%, while no definite follicular lymphoma component is identified. The specimen was processed for lymphoma workup, including flow cytometry and gene rearrangement studies.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a right upper lung lobectomy specimen measuring 5 x 2 x 7.5 cm. Details regarding tumor extent, other tumor nodules, lymph nodes, lymphatic and venous invasion, and margins are not specified. There is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma of the stomach, located in the corpus, with exophytic growth and infiltration into the submucosa. There is no evidence of tumor in the regional lymph nodes, oral or aboral resection margins, or omentum. Additionally, there is significant mucosal edema and hyperplasia in the antrum, with a small lipid islet noted at the junction of the antrum and corpus, and the tumor is staged as pT1 pNO (0/30) pMX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in one of five lymph nodes associated with a pericaval mass, with the largest focus measuring 1.5 cm and exhibiting extracapsular extension. Additionally, a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, likely intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma, was identified in the liver with a size of 5.8 cm and multifocality, invading the perihepatic soft tissues and adrenal gland, but with negative margins. The gallbladder showed cholesterolosis without any carcinoma detected.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast re-excision showed no carcinoma, while the right total mastectomy revealed focal atypical ductal hyperplasia and benign changes, with no invasive or in situ carcinoma identified. In contrast, the left modified radical mastectomy confirmed the presence of multifocal infiltrating ductal carcinoma with micropapillary features, extensive lymphovascular invasion, and a high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ component. The tumor staging is classified as pT2 pN2a pMx, with four positive axillary lymph nodes identified out of fifteen examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated, large-cell, focally keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the left lung, classified as stage IIIA due to extensive local invasion and lymph node involvement. The tumor measures up to 4.8 cm and has spread to the distal part of the main bronchus and nearby lymph nodes, with no evidence of metastasis to distant sites. Additionally, there are signs of bronchiectasis and moderate pulmonary emphysema, but the resection margins and co-resected lymph nodes are tumor-free.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma in multiple specimens taken from the right frontal lobe, with consistent findings across all sections. Microscopic examination reveals a high-grade anaplastic glial tumor characterized by high cellularity, pronounced nuclear pleomorphism, brisk mitotic activity, and evidence of infiltration into the cerebral cortex. Immunostaining results show variable positivity for gliofibrillary acidic protein and a high Ki-67 proliferation index, suggesting aggressive tumor behavior.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) following a left nephrectomy and lymph node dissection, with the tumor measuring 11 x 10.5 x 9 cm and weighing 497 g. All examined lymph nodes (0/4) are free of tumor, and the tumor exhibits a high-grade profile with a KI67 index of 5-10%. The Weiss score is 2, and additional scoring metrics suggest a significant tumor presence, but lymphatic spread is not evident.

The pathology report indicates that multiple biopsies from the abdomen, colic gutter, omentum, pelvic sidewall, cul-de-sac, bladder peritoneum, and lymph nodes show fibroadipose tissue with no evidence of malignancy. A total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy revealed a 3.5 cm endometrioid adenocarcinoma (Grade 2) in the endometrium, with myometrial invasion present but no lymphovascular invasion or metastasis to regional lymph nodes. Additional findings include benign conditions such as adenomyosis, leiomyomata, and a benign Brenner's tumor in the right ovary, with all lymph nodes examined being negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with a tumor diameter of 1.9 cm, which includes focal intraductal components. The tumor classification is noted as NOS, G II, pT1cN1aL1V0R0. This classification suggests a tumor that is invasive but has specific characteristics regarding its size and lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, specifically mixed serous and endometrioid types, arising from an endometrial polyp measuring 2.0 x 1.0 cm, with vascular invasion identified only in the polyp. All examined lymph nodes from both the left and right external iliac, obturator, hypogastric, and para-aortic regions were found to be benign, with no evidence of metastatic disease. Additionally, benign leiomyomata were noted in the uterus, while the cervix, fallopian tubes, and ovaries were reported as benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of epithelial melanoma located on the right forearm, classified as Clark Level 2 and with a Breslow thickness of 1 mm. The tumor measures 1.5 x 2 mm, with no evidence of metastasis or normal tissue present. The melanoma is staged as Stage I, and the patient is undergoing neo-adjuvant immunotherapy.

The pathology report indicates that multiple biopsies and resections from the liver reveal the presence of poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, with nodules measuring up to 5.6 cm and involvement of soft tissue margins in one specimen. Two lymph node biopsies show no evidence of tumor, while a smaller biopsy from segment 3 of the liver also confirms poorly differentiated carcinoma. Immunostaining for AFP is positive in the liver tumors, supporting the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the left lower lobe contains a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.8 cm, with bronchial and vascular margins free of tumor and no pleural involvement. All examined lymph nodes (14 in total) show no evidence of tumor involvement, and the left 6th rib fragments also reveal no tumor. The overall pathologic staging is pT2, pNO, pMX, with uninvolved margins and no direct extension of the tumor identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2, N0, and M0, indicating a primary tumor with no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered at this time, and a separate blood sample was noted as normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with a tumor diameter of 3.5 cm. The tumor is classified as grade III and is staged as pT2N0L0V0R0, indicating no lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. The minimum distance from the tumor to the dorsal margin is 1 cm, while other margins remain free of cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic renal cell carcinoma (RCC) of the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of IV and a tumor size of 9.5 cm, which has invaded the renal vein and extended through the renal capsule but is confined within Gerota's fascia. The adrenal gland is involved by the tumor, while the examined lymph nodes from the suprahilar, pre-aortic, and para-aortic regions show no evidence of malignancy. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated serous carcinoma in both ovaries, with additional findings of focal peritubal carcinoma and extensive metastatic poorly differentiated carcinoma in the omentum and periappendiceal fat. The uterus shows inactive endometrium with a benign endometrial polyp and poorly differentiated carcinoma in the subserosal myometrium, along with chronic cervicitis in the cervix. Overall, the findings suggest advanced-stage ovarian cancer with significant metastatic spread, classified as FIGO stage IIIC.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multiple specimens revealing metastatic serous papillary carcinoma, primarily affecting the omentum, right ovary, fallopian tube, stomach, bladder peritoneum, uterus, left ovary, rectum, splenic flexure, left colon, and right paracolic nodule. The left ovary and fallopian tube show serous papillary carcinoma with superficial invasion, and the tumor has invaded the outer rectal wall and uterine and cervical serosa. Two small lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.2 cm, with no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion, and negative margins. Two peribronchiolar lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for carcinoma, as were lymph nodes from levels 10 and 11. Additionally, EGFR mutation analysis revealed no alterations, indicating a wild type genotype.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a male, has a well-differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.2 cm in the left mandible, with invasion into the mandibular bone and evidence of perineural invasion, while a microscopic focus of carcinoma is present at the posterior bony margin. All examined lymph nodes from both sides of the neck (totaling 53) are negative for carcinoma, and additional margins and biopsies from surrounding tissues also show no evidence of malignancy. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals strong positivity for EGFR in the carcinoma cells, and HPV studies are pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse malignant mesothelioma, epithelial type, with a focal tubulopapillary pattern, invading surrounding adipose tissue and skeletal muscles in multiple sites, including the right parietal pleura and soft tissue at an old chest tube site. There is also evidence of a focal foreign body giant cell reaction consistent with prior surgery in several specimens, and the pleural margin of resection is involved by mesothelioma. The tumor is staged as pT3 NX MX with a histologic grade of G2, and immunohistochemical stains support the diagnosis of mesothelioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary carcinoma, specifically the dominant oncocytic follicular variant, measuring 2.6 cm in the right lobe of the thyroid, with mild follicular nodular disease present. The tumor is partially encapsulated with minimal capsular invasion, and there is no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion, nor extrathyroidal extension. Additionally, a second smaller tumor, classified as a papillary carcinoma microcarcinoma variant, was identified, but no regional lymph node metastasis was found.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, characterized by a 2.5 cm subpleural mass that does not invade the pleural surface, with clear bronchial resection margins. Metastatic adenocarcinoma is present in one lymph node from the left upper lung and in three out of four intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes, as well as in three out of twenty-five subcarinal lymph nodes. No tumor is found in the left lower paratracheal or para-aortic lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a single hepatocellular carcinoma in the left liver lobe, measuring 4x3.5x3 cm, with Edmondson grades III and IV differentiation, and evidence of microvascular invasion, but no invasion of surrounding structures or metastasis to lymph nodes. Additionally, the gallbladder specimen shows chronic cholecystitis without any stones or polyps. The liver also exhibits chronic hepatitis due to HCV with minimal fibrosis, but no cirrhosis or dysplastic nodules are noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing focal extraprostatic extension and multifocal perineural invasion. The tumor comprises approximately 15% of the sampled prostate volume, with a maximum diameter of 2 cm, and all surgical margins are free of malignancy. Additionally, the examination of lymph nodes revealed no evidence of malignancy, confirming a pathologic stage of pT3a, pN0, and pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma of the left breast, with a tumor size of 2.7 x 1.4 x 2.8 cm and metastases found in axillary lymph nodes (No IX/XI). Immunohistochemical analysis shows over 75% of neoplastic cell nuclei expressing estrogen and progesterone receptors, while HER2 gene amplification was not found. The tumor is classified as NHG2, pTIc, pN2a, indicating a moderate grade of malignancy and the presence of cancer spread to lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in both the intra-abdominal wall node and omental nodule. Additionally, moderately differentiated serous papillary adenocarcinoma is identified in both the right and left ovaries, with serous papillary adenocarcinoma also involving the serosa of the fundus of the uterus. The fallopian tubes are unremarkable, and the endometrium is noted to be atrophic.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a high-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 30.0 cm in the retroperitoneal area, with 10% necrosis and close proximity to the soft tissue margin. A biopsy of the right lobe of the liver shows focal portal fibrosis without any tumor present. The kidney exhibits scattered sclerotic glomeruli and patchy interstitial fibrosis and chronic inflammation, but no tumor is identified in the renal tissue.

The pathology report indicates that sentinel lymph node #1 is positive for micrometastasis (largest deposit 0.6 mm), while sentinel lymph node #2 is negative for metastasis. The right breast tissue shows moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with a maximum size of 1.4 cm, and the superior-anterior margin is involved by the tumor, while other margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, there are findings of ductal carcinoma in situ and benign fibroadipose tissue in the deep margin excision.

The pathology report indicates the presence of adenocarcinoma in the right apex and right mid of the prostate, with a Gleason score of 4+4=8 and 3+3=6, respectively. The left apex, left mid, and both bases of the prostate showed benign findings. Overall, the diagnosis confirms multiple prostatic needle biopsies revealing right-sided adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly-differentiated mixed serous and endometrioid adenocarcinoma involving both ovaries and the omentum, with significant tumor infiltration into surrounding tissues. The tumor is classified as FIGO stage IIIC due to macroscopic peritoneal metastasis and involvement of the omentum, with a maximum dimension of tumor implants outside the true pelvis measuring 10 cm. The report notes that regional lymph node status and distant metastasis cannot be evaluated, and the final staging is provisional pending further clinical data.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bilateral high-grade papillary serous carcinoma involving both ovaries, with the left ovary measuring 8.0 cm and the right ovary measuring 7.0 cm, exhibiting surface exophytic growth and stromal invasion. There is evidence of extensive metastatic spread to the uterine serosa, surrounding soft tissue, and multiple sites including the spleen, omentum, and peritoneal cavity, with a final staging of pT3c, pNX, and pM1, corresponding to FIGO stage IIIC. No lymphovascular invasion was noted, but the tumor capsule was ruptured, indicating aggressive disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, with a tumor size of 2.3 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm located in the lower inner quadrant of the left breast, exhibiting vascular invasion and negative surgical margins. Two left axillary sentinel lymph nodes showed micrometastasis, while additional lymph nodes were negative for tumor involvement. Both estrogen and progesterone receptor tests returned negative results, indicating a lack of hormone receptor expression.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the cecum, with a tumor size of 3 cm by 3.4 cm and a maximal thickness of 1.1 cm, invading into the subserosal adipose tissue. There are 4 metastatic lymph nodes identified out of 17 examined, leading to a staging of pT3 and N2a according to the AJCC 7th Edition. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and no gross tumor perforation or dysplastic polyps were found in the non-neoplastic bowel.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous adenocarcinoma in multiple sites, including the ileal mesentery, small bowel serosa, and omentum, with significant involvement of the uterus and endocervix, but no myometrial invasion. The tumor is classified as FIGO grade III and is confined to a pedunculated endometrial polyp, with negative surgical margins and no lymphatic or vascular invasion noted in most lymph nodes, although some left para-aortic lymph nodes show focal metastatic involvement. Overall, the findings suggest an advanced stage of serous adenocarcinoma with extensive peritoneal involvement but limited spread to lymph nodes.

The final diagnosis indicates a left temporal lobe brain tumor classified as glioblastoma, WHO Grade IV. Microscopic examination reveals pleomorphic glial cells with mitotic figures and areas of pseudopalisading necrosis, while immunohistochemical staining shows positive results for GFAP and a Ki67 proliferation index greater than 30%. The tumor was received as multiple fragments of soft tissue, and the report includes details on the specimen processing and staining methods used.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma (Grade 3, FIGO) with a tumor size of 3.0 cm and greater than 50% invasion into the myometrium. All examined lymph nodes (totaling 18) from the left and right pelvic and aortic regions were negative for metastasis. The staging of the cancer is classified as T1c, N0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that a segmentectomy of the right lower lobe of the lung revealed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm, with clear bronchial and vascular margins, but metastatic carcinoma was found in one hilar lymph node. Additionally, two out of four lymph nodes from the station 12 biopsy showed metastatic carcinoma, while the excised 5th rib exhibited normal bone and bone marrow with trilineage hematopoiesis. The overall staging is pT1a for the primary tumor and pN1 for regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph node biopsies from the left side are benign with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. A wedge resection of the left lower lobe lung reveals moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with papillary features, measuring 2.5 x 2.2 x 1.6 cm, with clear margins and no visceral pleural invasion or lymphatic vascular invasion. The final pathologic stage is classified as IA, with no regional or distant metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates that the left lateral, anterior, posterior, deep, and alveolar margins of the tongue are all negative for malignancy, as well as the contents of the left neck, which included 29 lymph nodes that were also negative for tumor. However, a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the left tongue and floor of the mouth, measuring 2.8 cm with a thickness of 0.9 cm, but all surgical margins were negative for tumor involvement. The tumor is classified as pT2 with no evidence of vascular, lymphatic, or perineural invasion, and the left sublingual gland showed mild chronic sialadenitis without malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a year-old female, has been diagnosed with invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, which has not been previously treated. The tumor exhibits squamous differentiation and invades the muscularis propria, but there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or associated epithelial lesions. The AJCC staging classifies the tumor as pT2, with a significant presence of tumor nuclei and no necrosis noted in the samples.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 1.7 cm invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, associated with visceral pleural invasion, but without angiolymphatic invasion. All sampled lymph nodes were benign, and the surgical margins were free of tumor, resulting in a pathologic stage of T2N0Mx. Additionally, there is mild chronic inflammation in the respiratory mucosa of the nasopharynx, with no significant findings related to the nasopharyngeal mass.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right hemiglossectomy, revealing moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue measuring 3.6 cm with a thickness of 2.2 cm, and all surgical margins were negative for tumor. Among the lymph nodes examined, one lymph node from right neck level IIA and one from level III were positive for metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, with the latter showing extensive extracapsular extension. The remaining lymph nodes from various levels were negative for tumor, and there were no pathological changes in the submandibular gland or right sublingual gland.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which has infiltrated surrounding tissues including the uterus, cervix, and bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes, with extensive lymphovascular invasion noted. The tumor exhibits a discohesive growth pattern and is poorly differentiated, resembling lobular carcinoma of the breast, but immunohistochemical staining supports its urothelial origin. Surgical margins are positive for tumor involvement in the bladder, while the urethral margin is negative, and the tumor is classified as pT4a pNX, suggesting advanced local spread rather than metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a tumor in the right lower lobe of the lung measuring 8.5 x 6.5 x 5.0 cm, diagnosed as Squamous Cell Carcinoma with partial basaloid features. There is evidence of infiltration into the visceral pleura, and the tumor classification is pT2, pN2 (5/59), pMx, G3. This suggests a moderately differentiated carcinoma with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma from a biopsy of a right palate lesion in a male patient. The specimen consisted of multiple soft tissue fragments measuring 1.4 x 1.0 x 0.6 cm. HPV screening tests for high-risk types were negative, indicating that the carcinoma is not associated with HPV.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate cancer, specifically conventional adenocarcinoma, following a radical prostatectomy. The tumor comprises approximately 10% of the gland volume with a Gleason score of 7/10, and there is no evidence of extra prostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, or lymphovascular invasion. Surgical margins are uninvolved, and no lymph nodes were received for evaluation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma, WHO Grade II, from a left frontal opercular tumor, with a Ki67 proliferation index of 4.7%. The tumor exhibits characteristics such as infiltration into cerebral grey matter and positive immunohistochemical staining for GFAP in some cells, while p53 staining is negative. Molecular genetic studies reveal deletions of 1p and 19q, which are commonly associated with oligodendrogliomas, and further analysis is pending.

The pathology report indicates that the left renal mass is diagnosed as a papillary renal cell carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm in diameter, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2. The tumor is well-circumscribed and limited to the kidney, coming within 0.4 cm of the resection margin, but there is no evidence of invasion into blood or lymphatic vessels. Additionally, a biopsy of the base of the renal mass shows no malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the transverse colon, which has invaded through the muscular wall into the attached greater omentum (pT3) and has metastasized to 1 of 60 lymph nodes (pN1). The resection margins are negative, and there are serosal adhesions noted, along with the presence of extranodal tumor. The overall pathologic stage is classified as T3N1 IIIB, with no distant metastasis identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the urinary bladder, with tumor invasion into the muscularis propria and extensive tumor necrosis. Focal lymphovascular invasion by carcinoma is also noted. The specimen consists of multiple pieces of irregular tissue, measuring 6.0 x 5.3 x 2.4 cm, and the tumor is present throughout the specimen.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade papillary serous carcinoma in multiple sites, including both ovaries, the omentum, and various soft tissues, with tumor sizes ranging from 2.2 cm to 12 cm. The findings suggest extensive metastatic involvement, including direct extension to the fallopian tubes and peritoneum, with no significant abnormalities noted in the uterus or cervix. The final staging is classified as T3c/NX/MX, indicating advanced disease with peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.0 cm in the superior segment of the right lower lobe, with no vascular invasion and uninvolved margins. The endobronchial mass showed a few atypical cells, but no malignancy was found in the bronchial mucosa or lymph nodes examined. Additionally, the sections from the 6th rib showed no carcinoma, and the overall staging is pT1a, NO, MX.

The pathology report indicates that a radical resection of a right upper thigh mass, previously diagnosed as high-grade myxofibrosarcoma, was performed. The findings reveal exuberant granulation tissue and a foreign body giant cell reaction, but no residual sarcoma is identified in the resected specimen. The report confirms that the surgical margins are clear of any sarcoma, indicating a successful removal of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a segment of the esophagus and proximal stomach was examined following an esophagectomy and partial gastrectomy, revealing a 5.5 cm moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma that has infiltrated the muscular layer of the distal esophagus but has not extended to the stomach. Additionally, four out of fourteen dissected lymph nodes showed metastatic involvement, and there is evidence of high-grade dysplasia in the adjacent esophageal mucosa. The surgical margins are free of neoplasia, and the pathological staging is classified as pT2, pN1b, pMx.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, revealing a diagnosis of papillary serous adenocarcinoma confined to the endometrium, with no lymphovascular invasion or carcinoma identified in the examined lymph nodes. Additionally, there were findings of acute and chronic inflammation in the cervix and no histopathologic abnormalities in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or other examined tissues. The case was amended to correct computer interface issues, but the diagnosis remained unchanged.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (G2) located in the distal rectum, with superficial invasion into the lamina muscularis propria. The resection margins are tumor-free, and there is no evidence of regional lymph node metastases, as all 17 lymph nodes examined were negative. The tumor is classified as pT2, pNO, with no vascular invasion (V0) and no perineural invasion (RO).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with a tumor diameter of 4.0 cm. The tumor classification is noted as NOS, G II, pT2NOi+(sn)LOVORO. This suggests a moderate grade of cancer with specific staging and nodal involvement.

The pathology report indicates a lobectomy specimen from the left upper lung, revealing a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 1.5 x 1.5 cm. The report does not specify tumor extent, other tumor nodules, lymph nodes involvement, lymphatic or venous invasion, or margins. There are no comments or additional findings noted in the report.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a high-grade leiomyosarcoma in a pelvic mass measuring 19.0 x 18.8 x 15.2 cm, with necrosis and extension to the surgical margin. Additionally, an appendectomy revealed a mucinous cystadenoma with no carcinoma identified and an uninvolved surgical margin. The abdominal scar specimen showed only skin with a scar, with no significant findings reported.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive pleomorphic lobular carcinoma in the left breast, measuring 2.2 cm, with negative margins of excision. One sentinel lymph node was positive for metastatic carcinoma, while nine other lymph nodes from the left axilla were negative for malignancy. Additionally, a core biopsy of the left nipple showed no evidence of invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower lobe of the lung contains a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with evidence of arterial invasion but negative margins and no direct extension of the tumor. All examined lymph nodes, including those from levels II, VII, and R4, show no signs of metastatic disease, and the presence of anthracosis is noted in these lymph nodes. The overall findings suggest a primary lung tumor with localized invasion but no metastatic spread to the regional lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, characterized by 60% clear cells and 40% eosinophilic cells, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4. The tumor measures 9.0 cm and extends into the renal vein, but there is no unequivocal extension into perinephric adipose tissue, and the adrenal gland shows no evidence of tumor. The surgical margins, including vascular, ureteral, and soft tissue margins, are free of tumor.
