The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma located in the fundus of the stomach, with a tumor size of 6 x 4.5 x 1.5 cm. There is evidence of metastasis in 2 out of 7 examined lymph nodes, and the tumor extends to adjacent structures, specifically the lesser omentum. Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion, as well as margins and neo-adjuvant treatment, are not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right distal ureters, as well as multiple lymph nodes from both sides, are negative for tumor involvement. However, a high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma was identified in the posterior wall of the urinary bladder, measuring 3.5 cm with invasion into the outer one-third of the muscularis propria. The tumor is classified as pT2b, with no lymph node involvement noted, and there is associated urothelial dysplasia present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC) of the right kidney, with a tumor size of 9.0 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade II/IV, confined to the kidney without lymphovascular invasion. The right regional lymph node was negative for tumor, and the AJCC classification is T2 N0 Mx. Additionally, minimal chronic changes were noted in the non-neoplastic kidney parenchyma, with mild arterial and arteriolar sclerosis.

The pathology report indicates a malignant tumor identified as Serous Papillary Cystadenocarcinoma located in the ovary, measuring 3.5x2.2x1.8 cm. Microscopic examination reveals solid nests and papillary patterns of large cells with moderately pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei, and areas of cystic degeneration, along with focal necrosis and a desmoplastic stroma containing lymphocytes. Additionally, part of the deep resection margin is involved by the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 4.2 x 4.1 x 0.6 cm ulcerous adenocarcinoma (G2) in the cecum, with the tumor infiltrating surrounding tissues and affecting the ileocecal valve. There are metastases identified in 3 out of 6 lymph nodes, and the incision margins are free of neoplastic lesions. The overall diagnosis is adenocarcinoma tubulopapillare coli, classified as Dukes C, Astler-Coller C2, pT3, pN1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a liver specimen obtained from a segmentectomy. The tumor measures 6.3 x 5.0 x 3.5 cm and exhibits multinodular confluent characteristics, with the resection margin involved by the tumor. Microscopic examination reveals poorly differentiated HCC with trabecular and pseudoglandular histologic types, but no evidence of portal vein invasion or satellite nodules.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of bifocal poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with tumor diameters of 2.8 cm and 0.8 cm. The tumor classification is noted as NOS (not otherwise specified), grade III, and staged as pT2(mult)NOLOVORO. This suggests the presence of multiple tumors with significant differentiation and no lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of neoplasia in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions. A radical prostatectomy revealed invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing focal extracapsular extension, but all surgical margins and seminal vesicles are free of carcinoma. Additionally, benign prostatic hypertrophy and chronic prostatitis are noted, with high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia identified, and the pathological TNM stage is pT3a, pNO, pMX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, with a significant exophytic mass measuring 10.0 x 7.5 x 1.5 cm, and minimal invasion into the myometrium. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in the sigmoid nodule, while other specimens, including lymph nodes and the pannus, showed no evidence of malignancy. The overall pathological stage is classified as pT1b pNO pM1, indicating the presence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma (G2) of the sigmoid colon, characterized by a 4.3 x 4.4 cm ulcerous tumor that completely surrounds the intestinal circumference. The tumor is classified as pT3, with no neoplastic lesions found at the incision lines, and there is also a tubular adenoma with moderate dysplasia present. Additionally, the report notes the presence of diverticula and reactive lymphadenitis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in the omentum and pelvic peritoneum, as well as serosal involvement in the appendix. Both the right and left ovaries show papillary serous adenocarcinoma, with normal fallopian tubes. The uterus and cervix exhibit no pathological diagnosis, but the serosa shows serosal implants of adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous transitional cell carcinoma in the right ovary and fallopian tube, with a tumor size of 13.3 cm and evidence of metastasis to the uterine serosa and cul-de-sac. Additional findings include metastatic serous transitional cell carcinoma in the sigmoid implant and cul-de-sac nodule, while lymph node biopsies from the right common iliac, right pelvic, and left pelvic regions showed no carcinoma. The overall staging is classified as FIGO stage IIB, with no tumor identified in various other biopsies and washings.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder and a colloid carcinoma measuring 3.2 cm confined to the pancreas, with lymphovascular and perineural invasion present. The carcinoma has metastasized to seven out of nine examined lymph nodes, and the uncinate and vascular bed margins are positive for invasive carcinoma. Additionally, a benign fibrous nodule was found in the small bowel wall, and no malignancy was identified in the pancreatic margin biopsy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma of the right breast, with a tumor size of 4.2 x 2.4 x 1.4 cm and evidence of metastases in axillary lymph nodes. Histological examination shows classical lobular carcinoma with associated carcinoma in situ and lymph node involvement classified as pN3a. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals estrogen and progesterone receptor positivity in 75% of neoplastic cells, while HER2 shows a negative reaction.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, confined to the kidney parenchyma without evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. The non-neoplastic renal tissue shows focal chronic inflammation and glomerulosclerosis, while the surgical resection margins are free of neoplasm. The tumor is classified as TNM stage T1NXMX and has a histopathological grade of G2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, in a right kidney partial nephrectomy specimen, with a tumor size of 4.1 cm and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of II/IV. There is no evidence of local invasion, renal vein invasion, or angiolymphatic invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is classified as PT1, indicating it is limited to the kidney and measures less than 7 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, based on multiple biopsies from the left temporal region, with varying percentages of tumor necrosis and consistent high cellularity across samples. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals significant findings, including a high percentage of MGMT immunostaining and loss of PTEN, suggesting a potentially diminished response to certain therapies. Additionally, the report notes the presence of EGFR amplification, which may influence treatment options and prognosis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+5=9, involving both lobes of the prostate and showing extensive extraprosthetic extension and bilateral seminal vesicle invasion. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in 2 out of 21 lymph nodes examined, with evidence of extranodal extension. The surgical margins are free of carcinoma, and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is also present.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma, specifically the tall cell variant, located in the left lobe of the thyroid, with a size of 1.3 cm and evidence of invasion into perithyroid skeletal muscle. Additionally, micrometastatic papillary carcinoma was found in the left paratracheal lymph nodes, with no extranodal extension observed. The right paratracheal tissue and left lower parathyroid biopsy revealed benign fibroadipose tissue and a hypercellular parathyroid gland, respectively.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, favoring type 2, with a maximal Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 out of 4, and the tumor measures 5.6 x 5.0 x 4.0 cm, confined to the right kidney. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and no vascular invasion is identified, with a pathologic TNM stage of pT1b NX MX. Additional findings include interstitial inflammation and scattered sclerotic glomeruli in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue surrounding the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the right adrenal gland contains a composite pheochromocytoma with ganglioneuroma, while the left adrenal gland shows a clear cell adrenal cortical adenoma with degeneration, and no evidence of adrenal medullary hyperplasia. The right adrenal tumor is largely occupying the gland, making it difficult to assess underlying conditions, but there is no indication of familial syndromes such as MEN2. Immunohistochemical analysis suggests that the right adrenal tumor is not related to SDH mutations, as most of the tumor shows SDHB immunoreactivity.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right kidney renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, Fuhrman grade 4, measuring 13.2 cm, with spindle cell differentiation and invasion into the renal capsule but not through it. All surgical resection margins are free of carcinoma, and the adrenal gland shows no signs of neoplasia. Additionally, non-gyn cytology reveals no malignant cells present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a tumor located in the left upper lobe (LUL) of the lung, with a size of 3.4 cm. Histological examination reveals a grade 3 tumor, classified as T2, with no evidence of metastasis (M0). The tumor is staged as pathologic stage I, indicating an early stage of disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Anaplastic Oligodendroglioma (WHO grade III), supported by a MIB-1 Labeling Index of 19.2%, which is consistent with a high-grade glioma. Microscopic examination reveals a moderately cellular infiltrating glioma with moderate to marked nuclear atypia and prominent perinuclear halos, indicative of oligodendroglial differentiation. Although there is low mitotic activity and no necrosis or microvascular proliferation, the hypercellularity and nuclear atypia raise concerns for a high-grade tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of synovial sarcoma, monophasic subtype, in the right lower lobe of the lung, with the tumor measuring 20 cm in aggregate and showing 40% necrosis. The mediastinal lymph nodes examined were benign, with no evidence of tumor involvement. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, revealing positive results for vimentin and cytokeratin CAM 5.2, while TLE1 stain was negative.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma in the left lower extremity, measuring 5.0 cm, with involvement of the superolateral margin and proximity to the deep margin. Additional excisions of superior margins showed no tumor identified, and there was no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. The overall findings suggest a significant tumor presence with careful monitoring of surgical margins required for further management.

The pathology report indicates that the brain tumor is diagnosed as glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) based on the examination of multiple tissue samples. The microscopic analysis reveals a hypercellular glial neoplasm with features such as elongated nuclei, moderate cytologic atypia, and evidence of necrosis and microvascular proliferation. Additionally, less than 10% of the tumor cells express MGMT, which may have implications for treatment options.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.0 cm, with invasion into the visceral pleura and angiolymphatic invasion present. Four out of five peri-bronchial lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma, while the mediastinal lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. The bronchial margin is clear of tumor, and the overall pathological staging is pT2a, N1, Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive mammary carcinoma, Nottingham grade 3, measuring 2.0 cm, with free surgical margins and negative hormone receptor status (ER, PR) and Her2. Among the sentinel lymph nodes examined, one showed metastatic carcinoma (2.5 cm), while the others were negative for carcinoma. The overall classification is preliminary pT1c pN1a, with further evaluation pending for keratin staining results.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, showing bilateral involvement and extension to the surgical margins. The left posterior and anterior apical margins, as well as the right and left pelvic lymph nodes, were negative for tumor, while extensive extraprostatic extension and perineural infiltration were noted. The overall staging is classified as pT3aN0M0, indicating advanced local disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a uveal melanoma in the enucleated right eye, characterized by a tumor nodule measuring 15x15 mm primarily composed of epithelioid cells with moderate mitotic activity and mild pigmentation. The tumor shows focal infiltration into the inner third of the sclera but does not extend beyond it, and both the optic nerve and ciliary body are free of tumor involvement. Genetic studies and cryopreservation of tissue specimens were performed prior to fixation for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a laparoscopic right adrenalectomy due to a clinical diagnosis of pheochromocytoma, which was suspected based on the presence of a right adrenal mass. The excised adrenal gland weighed 8 grams and contained a 1.7 cm nodule that was uniformly tan and extended to the surgical margin. The final diagnosis confirmed the presence of pheochromocytoma confined to the adrenal gland.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically papillary type 1, with a Fuhrman grade of 2 out of 4. The tumor measures 4.3 cm, is confined to the kidney, and extends focally to the inked parenchymal resection margin, but there is no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion. The final pathologic stage is classified as pT1bNXM0, indicating no regional lymph node or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary carcinoma in two of five lymph nodes from a right neck level 3 dissection, while lymph nodes from levels 4 and 5 were negative for tumor. A total thyroidectomy revealed papillary carcinoma with a follicular component in the right lobe and a follicular adenoma in the left lobe. Additionally, a left paratracheal mass excision showed metastatic papillary carcinoma in the soft tissue, with three lymph nodes also negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostate cancer, specifically a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma involving 70-80% of the prostate gland, with a Gleason score of 9. The tumor shows extensive infiltration into both lobes of the prostate, with involvement of the seminal vesicles and positive surgical margins at the bladder neck and apical margins. Additionally, there is evidence of extraprostatic extension and perineural invasion, classifying the cancer as stage pT3bNx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating duct carcinoma in the left breast, measuring over 2.5 cm, with nuclear and architectural grade 2, and lymphovascular space involvement present. Additionally, ductal carcinoma in situ was noted, comprising 30% of the tumor volume, with eight out of thirteen lymph nodes showing metastatic carcinoma and extracapsular extension. Estrogen receptor status is positive, while progesterone receptor status is negative, and the surgical margins are free of lesions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma of the left breast, Nottingham grade 2, with the tumor measuring 11.0 cm and involving all four quadrants. There is focal positivity at the deep margin in the lower-inner quadrant, and 8 out of 17 lymph nodes are positive for metastatic lobular carcinoma, with evidence of extracapsular extension. The tumor is estrogen receptor positive, progesterone receptor negative, and HER-2/neu negative, indicating a specific receptor profile.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a left parietal mass consistent with oligodendroglioma, Grade II (WHO). The tumor exhibits infiltrative characteristics with areas of increased hypercellularity and vascular activity, but does not meet the criteria for anaplastic oligodendroglioma. A 1p/19q analysis is planned for further evaluation of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two foci of invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, both classified as Nottingham grade 2, with the larger tumor measuring 1.7 cm and the smaller 0.7 cm. Additionally, ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) was identified, constituting 5% of the total tumor mass, and lymphovascular space invasion was noted, although the surgical margins were negative for carcinoma. Sentinel lymph node biopsies revealed no metastatic carcinoma in three examined lymph nodes, and the invasive tumor cells were positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors while negative for HER-2.

The pathology report indicates a partial nephrectomy of the right kidney, revealing a Grade 2 clear cell renal cell carcinoma with a mass measuring 2.5 x 2.2 x 2.1 cm. The tumor is confined to the kidney, with no evidence of coagulative tumor necrosis or sarcomatoid differentiation. Surgical margins are negative by 0.1 cm, suggesting complete removal of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma from a left mastectomy specimen, with a tumor size of 6.0 cm and nuclear grade extending within 1 mm of the resection line. There is evidence of massive vascular permeation, including involvement of the nipple, and fibrocystic changes are noted. Additionally, three out of fifteen axillary lymph nodes are positive for metastatic tumor with capsular and extracapsular extension.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower lobe of the lung was resected, revealing a unifocal, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.4 cm, with invasion of the visceral pleura but clear margins from invasive carcinoma. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from the subcarinal and inferior pulmonary regions were examined, all of which were benign with no evidence of metastatic involvement. Emphysematous changes were noted in the uninvolved lung parenchyma, and no lymph-vascular invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates that multiple biopsies from the tongue and floor of the mouth show no dysplasia or invasive carcinoma, with the exception of a poorly differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma measuring 2.4 cm in diameter found in the floor of the mouth. Surgical margins are negative but close, with the closest margin being 0.1 cm, and associated squamous carcinoma in situ is noted. Additionally, lymph node dissections from various levels show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 5.0 x 2.0 x 1.0 cm, with associated carcinoma in situ and moderate to severe dysplasia at the left ureterovesical junction. All examined lymph nodes (111 total) were free of tumor, and the resection margins were clear of dysplasia and malignancy. Additional findings included benign ureters and prostatic tissue, with no high-grade atypia or malignancy identified in the urethral margins or surrounding tissues.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two separate adenocarcinomas in the right lung, one in the upper lobe measuring 1.5 cm and poorly differentiated, and another in the lower lobe measuring 0.7 cm and moderately differentiated. Both tumors exhibit angiolymphatic invasion and extend to the inked margins, but neither shows visceral pleural or perineural invasion. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of primary lung tumors, with differences in histologic patterns suggesting they are distinct primary adenocarcinomas.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (Grade II) in the uterus, with invasion into the myometrium measuring 1.9 cm, but no malignancy detected at the serosal surface or in the cervix and fallopian tubes. All lymph nodes examined, including external and common iliac, as well as periaortic nodes, showed benign fibroadipose tissue with no evidence of malignancy. Additional findings include mild cervicitis and the presence of leiomyomata, with the ovaries appearing normal.

The final diagnosis of the retroperitoneal mass resection is high-grade leiomyosarcoma, measuring 6.5 cm, with less than significant tumor necrosis and free surgical margins. Histological examination reveals spindle cell malignant neoplasm with severe cytological atypia, increased mitotic activity, and strong positivity for vimentin, desmin, actin, and smooth muscle myosin. The tumor cells are also positive for estrogen receptors but negative for progesterone receptors, supporting the diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma arising from an endometrial polyp, with the tumor invading the myometrium and involving the uterine serosa, along with lymphovascular invasion. The left ovary shows an endometrioma with focal hyperplasia, while the right ovary and fallopian tubes are unremarkable. Additional biopsies from the bladder peritoneum and omentum reveal involvement by high-grade serous carcinoma, but lymph nodes and other peritoneal sites are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the left hemiglossectomy specimen revealed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue, measuring 1.5 cm in maximum diameter and 0.8 cm in thickness, with negative margins and no evidence of perineural or lymphatic invasion. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from levels I to IV of the left neck (22 in total) were negative for tumor involvement. The overall findings suggest a localized tumor with no metastatic spread to the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right cerebral tumor diagnosed as gliosarcoma with ependymal differentiation, characterized by a high Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 75% and negative p53 staining. Genetic analysis revealed a negative MGMT promoter methylation status and evidence of 1p deletion, suggesting a potential overlap with anaplastic ependymoma. The tumor exhibits high-grade features, including scattered mitotic figures, necrosis, and areas of cartilaginous and osteoid differentiation.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the urinary bladder, with approximately 95% of the bladder mucosa involved by the tumor, measuring 12 cm in greatest dimension. Biopsies from the urethral margins and distal ureters, as well as lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions, were all negative for malignancy. Additional findings include urothelial dysplasia and acute and chronic prostatitis, with no evidence of lymph-vascular invasion or regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in multiple nodules from an omentectomy specimen, consistent with ovarian origin. Additionally, the right salpingo-oophorectomy specimen reveals grade 3 serous adenocarcinoma involving both the ovary and fallopian tube. Pelvic fluid analysis shows positive malignant cells, supporting the diagnosis of advanced ovarian cancer with peritoneal involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of encapsulated follicular variant papillary thyroid carcinoma, measuring 2.5 cm, confined to the isthmus with no evidence of capsular or angiolymphatic invasion. One isthmic lymph node was examined and found to be free of tumor. Additionally, the left inferior parathyroid gland was slightly enlarged but normocellular, with no significant findings related to vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has bilateral prostatic adenocarcinoma with varying Gleason scores, primarily 3+4=7, and the carcinoma is organ-confined with no evidence of extraprostatic extension or lymph node involvement. The tumor measures a maximum of 1.9 cm and involves 20% of the examined prostate volume, with perineural invasion noted but no angiolymphatic invasion. All surgical resection margins are free of carcinoma, and benign prostatic hypertrophy and chronic prostatitis are also present.

The pathology report indicates that a brain biopsy from a male patient with blurred vision and papilledema revealed an oligodendroglioma with a proliferation index of 2%. The tumor exhibits moderate cellularity, mild nuclear pleomorphism, and the presence of minigemistocytes, but no mitotic figures, vascular hyperplasia, or necrosis were observed. The gross examination described the tumor as semi-firm and yellowish-grey, with two fragments received for analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of thymoma, WHO type B2, with a maximum tumor dimension of 4.5 cm and extension into the surrounding thymic adipose tissue. The tumor is staged as IIb due to macroscopic capsular invasion, with focal tumor cells present at the painted margin and pleural invasion noted, while no regional lymph node metastasis was found. The residual thymus shows lymphoid follicle hyperplasia, consistent with the patient's clinical history of myasthenia gravis.

The pathology report indicates that the right-sided hemicolectomy preparation shows tumor-free resection margins. It reveals a tubular adenoma of the ascending colon with moderate dysplasia and a moderately differentiated polypous adenocarcinoma of the cecum, which has infiltrated the perimuscular fatty tissue and has several regional lymph node metastases. The findings classify the adenocarcinoma as G2, pT3, L1, V0, locally R0, and pN2 with 6 out of 33 lymph nodes involved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3 + 5 = 8, involving both lobes of the prostate and measuring 1.5 cm, but confined within the prostate capsule. There is evidence of perineural invasion, and multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) is also present; however, all surgical margins are free of carcinoma. Additionally, six pelvic lymph nodes were examined, and no metastatic carcinoma was found (0/6).

The pathology report indicates that the patient has undergone excision of multiple lymph nodes and a left upper lobe lung mass. All examined lymph nodes (totaling 13) showed no evidence of malignancy, while the left upper lobe revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with clear surgical margins and no lymphovascular invasion. Adjacent lung tissue exhibited emphysematous changes, and the bronchial margin was negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) in a left parietal neoplasm, characterized by high-grade malignant astrocytic features including cytologic pleomorphism and necrosis. Genetic analysis reveals significant abnormalities, including polysomy of chromosome 7, amplification of EGFR, and loss of PTEN, among others, which are associated with a poorer prognosis. The tumor exhibits a high proliferation index, with immunohistochemical findings supporting the aggressive nature of the neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of nodular fat necrosis in two peritoneal implants with no tumor identified, along with a focal foreign body giant cell reaction. A Whipple resection of the pancreatic head revealed moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 1.8 cm, with tumor extension limited to the pancreas and negative surgical margins and lymph nodes. Additionally, chronic gastritis was noted in the stomach with no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy, and the small bowel showed no significant histopathologic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a postoperative diagnosis of a lesion in the rectum, with findings of adenomatous tissue showing moderate dysplasia. A biopsy specimen from the rectum reveals infiltrating characteristics. The report suggests that 13% of the adenomatous tissue exhibits dysplastic changes.

The pathology report indicates that the right axillary sentinel lymph node #1 shows metastatic ductal carcinoma measuring 1.3 cm, while sentinel lymph nodes #2 and #3, as well as a non-sentinel lymph node, show no tumor involvement. The right breast lumpectomy reveals multifocal invasive ductal carcinoma (largest focus 1.3 cm) with associated high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) spanning 8 cm, and positive margins for DCIS at multiple sites. Additional findings include weak estrogen receptor expression, no progesterone receptor expression, and HER2/neu amplification, with a final pTNM classification of pT1c(m), N1(sn), MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a tumor size of 4.8 cm and direct extension into the uterine wall, parametrial, and upper vaginal tissues, while surgical margins are uninvolved. Metastatic carcinoma is identified in one of 23 right pelvic lymph nodes, with no carcinoma found in the left pelvic or periaortic lymph nodes. The overall staging is pT2b, pN1, and pMX, indicating localized disease with limited lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of a right chest wall mass reveals a malignant biphasic tumor consistent with mesothelioma. The specimen was a single unoriented soft tissue fragment measuring 0.8 x 0.6 x 0.4 cm, and the frozen section evaluation confirmed the presence of a malignant neoplasm. The clinical history notes a diagnosis of right lung mesothelioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix, measuring 2.5 cm, with a maximum stromal invasion thickness of 1.7 cm and vascular invasion present, but no evidence of multicentricity or vaginal extension. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and the endometrium is benign, with a leiomyoma noted in the myometrium. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from both sides are benign, with no metastatic disease identified.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with papillary renal cell carcinoma type 2, measuring 8.5 cm, which involves the renal sinus and perinephric fat, with four out of five hilar lymph nodes showing metastatic involvement. No tumor was found in the examined paracaval lymph nodes or the fat around the kidney, which was identified as benign adipose tissue. The surgical resection margins are free of carcinoma, and there is evidence of extracapsular extension.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two separate foci of invasive adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon, with the first tumor measuring 5.8 x 4.9 x 1.8 cm and classified as pT2, while the second tumor, located 2.4 cm distal, measures 2.5 x 1.0 x 1.0 cm and is classified as pT1 with documented submucosal invasion. One of eighteen lymph nodes examined shows metastatic carcinoma (pN1), but resection margins are negative for carcinoma. Additionally, the proximal and distal anastomotic rings show unremarkable colonic mucosa, negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that a 5.3 cm pheochromocytoma was identified in the right adrenal gland following resection, with the tumor completely removed and tight free cutting edges. Microscopic examination revealed a tumor composed of trabecular and alveolar cells, with no mitotic figures or evidence of vascular invasion, although there was focal growth into the capsule. Immunohistochemical analysis showed scattered positivity for chromogranin and sporadic positivity for S100, confirming the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma (Gleason score 4+5=9) involving both lobes of the prostate, with significant tumor infiltration into the left seminal vesicle and extensive perineural invasion. There is a positive surgical margin noted in one tissue block, and one lymph node metastasis was identified among the examined lymph nodes. The tumor classification is pT3b, pN1, with a maximum tumor diameter of 52 mm and a tumor volume of approximately 7.2 ml.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a bilateral pelvic lymph node dissection and a radical prostatectomy, with the lymph node analysis revealing four benign lymph nodes (0/4). The prostate specimen showed adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7/10, characterized by a primary pattern of 4, a secondary pattern of 3, and a tertiary pattern of 5, along with perineural invasion present but no extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle involvement. Surgical margins were uninvolved, and there was no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the right upper lobe of the lung has a unifocal adenocarcinoma, lepidic predominant type, measuring 1.3 cm, with negative bronchial and vascular margins, and no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or metastasis in the examined lymph nodes. Additionally, a pulmonary hamartoma was identified in the right lower lobe, which was completely excised. The overall staging of the primary tumor is classified as pT1a, indicating it is 2 cm or less in greatest dimension without invasive characteristics beyond the lobar bronchus.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in a liver mass, measuring 5.5 x 5.0 x 7.0 cm, with no evidence of invasion into surrounding structures or vascular involvement. The remaining liver parenchyma shows signs of cirrhosis, and the gallbladder exhibits chronic cholecystitis without any stones. Additionally, a biopsy of a pericystic lymph node revealed no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 1 endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid and villoglandular type, located in the posterior uterine wall, measuring 2.5 x 2.0 x 0.7 cm, with invasion into the myometrium and lymphovascular space invasion, but negative margins and no involvement of the endocervix. The left fallopian tube, right ovary, right fallopian tube, and left ovary show no diagnostic abnormalities, and multiple lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions are negative for tumor. The findings are confirmed through hematoxylin and eosin staining, with a final pathology classification of AJCC pT1aN0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma located in the head of the pancreas, measuring 2.0 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm, with evidence of perineural and lymphovascular invasion. The tumor has extended into the peripancreatic soft tissue and the muscle and submucosa of the small intestine, but all surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is no lymph node metastasis detected. Additionally, the gallbladder shows signs of chronic cholecystitis, but no tumor is present in the bile duct or lymph nodes examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma with pleomorphic features in the left breast, measuring 2 cm, and Nottingham grade 2. There is also pleomorphic lobular carcinoma in situ present, with margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma and sentinel lymph nodes showing no evidence of metastasis. Hormone receptor studies reveal positive estrogen receptor status (>90%) and negative progesterone receptor and HER2/neu status.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade serous carcinoma of the endometrium, with a tumor size of 4.9 by 4.8 cm and focal invasion through the entire myometrial wall, but no involvement of the cervix or lymphovascular spaces. Surgical margins are uninvolved except for the tumor extending to the inked serosal surface of the uterus without perforation. Additional findings include leiomyomata and no significant abnormalities in the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes, with a pTNM stage of pT1b NX (FIGO IB).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated papillary urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 3.5 cm and extending into the muscularis propria, with evidence of lymphovascular invasion. Both the right and left distal ureters, as well as multiple lymph nodes examined, showed no signs of malignancy or dysplasia. Additional findings included benign changes in the anterior vaginal wall, uterus, and right ovary, with no atypical or malignant elements identified in these structures.

The pathology report from a right thyroid lobectomy reveals a 0.5 cm incidental nodule that is worrisome for a follicular variant of papillary thyroid microcarcinoma, alongside nodular hyperplasia (multinodular goiter). The nodule exhibits nuclear changes characteristic of papillary thyroid carcinoma, but it is confined to the thyroid and appears to be completely excised. Additionally, a normocellular parathyroid gland was noted in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary serous carcinoma involving the omentum, stomach, lymph nodes, and small bowel, with a diagnosis of grade 3 papillary serous adenocarcinoma in the left adnexa. Multiple specimens were analyzed, confirming the metastatic nature of the carcinoma originating from the ovary. The margins of the small bowel resection are free of tumor, suggesting no residual disease at the resection site.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a left choroidal melanoma, predominantly of the spindle cell type, with a size of 17.5 mm in diameter and evidence of extrascleral infiltration. Microscopic examination reveals minimal lymphocytic infiltrate, no tumor necrosis, and a breach in Bruch's membrane, suggesting incomplete excision. The report concludes that there is inadequate clearance due to trans-scleral spread of the tumor.

The pathology report describes a moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm consisting of protoplasmic astrocytes, gemistocytes, microgemistocytes, and oligodendroglioma, with focal hypercellular clustering. Atypia is generally mild to moderate, with few scattered mitotic figures and evidence of microvascular proliferation, but no necrosis is observed. The diagnosis is an Anaplastic Oligoastrocytoma, Astrocytoma predominant, classified as WHO grade III.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in three out of twenty-eight lymph nodes from the left axillary contents, with evidence of extracapsular extension. In the left breast, a segmental mastectomy revealed infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 3.5 x 2.5 x 1.7 cm, with involvement of the posterior and inferior resection margins and lymphovascular invasion present. Additionally, there are findings of ductal carcinoma in situ, atypical ductal hyperplasia, and other benign changes, with positive estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative HER2/neu status.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma located in the head of the pancreas, measuring 3.5 cm, with evidence of invasion into peripancreatic soft tissues and the duodenal wall. Lymph node analysis shows metastasis in 4 out of 22 examined nodes, leading to an AJCC stage of IIB (T3 N1 M0). Additionally, the right lobe liver nodule and celiac lymph nodes were found to be negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 3 cm and moderate to poorly differentiated histologic grade. All examined regional lymph nodes (3 total) are negative for malignancy, and the tumor margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. The report suggests that molecular studies may be indicated for further evaluation.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder specimen shows cholelithiasis and chronic cholecystitis with no evidence of malignancy. In contrast, the right colon specimen reveals an ulcerated, invasive moderately to poorly differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma measuring 4 cm, with evidence of angiolymphatic invasion and metastasis in one of eighteen regional lymph nodes. The tumor is staged as pT3a/b, pN1, and pMX, with all surgical margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive keratinizing squamous carcinoma (G2) of the tongue, with a tumor size of 2.4 x 2 x 0.9 cm within a surgical segment measuring 3.5 x 3 x 1.5 cm. The report notes that there are minimum margins of healthy tissue of 0.4 cm and 0.6 cm from the sides and base of the specimen, respectively, and no evidence of vascular or nerve invasion. An intraoperative examination revealed no neoplastic lesions, with a final diagnosis pending further material development.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes from the right neck, with two out of nineteen nodes at levels 3 and 4 showing involvement, and one out of five nodes at level 1, with extranodal extension present in some. Additionally, an invasive keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the right glossectomy specimen, measuring 4.1 cm, with negative surgical margins and perineural invasion noted. Other examined tissues from the tongue, tonsil, and mouth were negative for carcinoma, and a total of 44 lymph nodes were examined, with four showing metastatic involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma, grade 1, in the right breast with multifocal tumors measuring up to 40 mm, and lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) present. One of two sentinel lymph nodes examined was positive for metastatic carcinoma, with the largest focus measuring 2.5 mm, but no extracapsular extension was identified. The left breast mastectomy showed benign findings including sclerosing adenosis and usual ductal hyperplasia, with no atypical hyperplasia or carcinoma detected.

The pathology report indicates that all examined lymph nodes (4R, 4L, and Station 7) are uninvolved with malignancy. However, biopsies from the pleura and parietal pleura reveal the presence of epithelioid malignant mesothelioma involving fibroadipose tissue. The report confirms the diagnosis of mesothelioma, consistent with the clinical history provided.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a large-cell solid carcinoma in the right lower lobe, classified as pT2 pN1 V1 RO, stage IIB, with evidence of tumor necrosis and chronic inflammation. The tumor has infiltrated surrounding structures, including medium-sized pulmonary arteries, and there are lymph node metastases in the hilar region. Immunohistochemical analysis suggests the possibility of undifferentiated squamous cell carcinoma, as indicated by the positive markers for CK7 and high molecular weight keratins, while being negative for TTF-1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma in the right testicle, with the tumor measuring 5.5x3.5x3 cm and showing signs of necrosis and hemorrhaging. Histological examination reveals solid clusters of round and oval bright cells with dark nuclei, surrounded by connective tissue with significant lymphocyte infiltration. Notably, the tumor does not involve the rete testis or the funiculus.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with cystic and myxoid changes, measuring 5.5 cm in greatest diameter. The tumor is classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 2 and extends to the renal sinus fat but is confined to the renal capsule, with no evidence of renal vein or angiolymphatic invasion. All surgical margins are free of neoplasm, and the non-neoplastic kidney shows chronic interstitial inflammation, with a TNM stage of pT3a NX MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 4.0 cm in the right tongue, with no lymphovascular invasion and all surgical margins free of tumor. A single subglossal lymph node was negative for metastatic carcinoma, and adjacent squamous mucosa showed mild dysplasia. Additional excised tissues from various tongue margins and the floor of the mouth were all negative for malignancy, as were 44 lymph nodes from a right neck dissection.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear) cell type, with a Fuhrman's nuclear grade of III out of IV and a tumor size of 6.0 cm. The neoplasm is confined within the renal capsule, with no evidence of invasion into the renal vein or angiolymphatic invasion, and all surgical margins are free of cancer. Additionally, the non-neoplastic kidney shows chronic inflammation, arterial sclerosis, and focal hyalinization of glomeruli, with a TNM stage of p T1b Nx MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4/4. The tumor is confined to the kidney without evidence of lymphovascular invasion, transcapsular invasion, or renal vein invasion, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor. The pTNM staging is classified as T1 NX MX, indicating stage I disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma in the stomach, specifically located in the fundus, with a tumor size of 9 x 7 x 6.5 cm and ulceration present. There is evidence of metastasis, with 8 out of 17 lymph nodes positive for cancer. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no specified evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has bilateral papillary serous adenocarcinoma involving both ovaries, with tumor sizes of 19.0 cm on the right and 9.5 cm on the left, while the ovarian capsules remain intact. The fallopian tubes are not identified in the specimens, and the omentum shows no evidence of malignancy. The report suggests synchronous tumors due to the intact capsules, but metastatic disease cannot be completely ruled out.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, grade 3, in the left temporal region of the brain. The tumor cells are negative for IDH1, with focal positivity for p53, and a MIB-1 labeling index of 13.3%, suggesting a high proliferation rate. Microscopic examination reveals a diffusely infiltrative neoplasm with mild to moderate atypia and hypercellularity, but no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma involving multiple structures, including the epiglottis and base of the tongue, with a depth of invasion of 3.0 cm and lymphatic invasion present. Metastatic squamous carcinoma was identified in 7 out of 48 right cervical lymph nodes and 4 out of 3 left cervical lymph nodes, with the largest metastasis measuring 4.0 cm. The resection margins were free of tumor, and no tumor was present in the thyroid or other examined tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 4 squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe, characterized by a 3.3 x 3.0 x 3.0 cm obstructive mass and associated obstructive pneumonia. While the initial margins showed focal carcinoma in situ, re-excision revealed no carcinoma in situ, and the anterior lateral margin was benign. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma was found in 2 of 6 intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes, but no tumor was identified in the mediastinal or other examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic papillary adenocarcinoma in the right lung, specifically in the upper lobe, with a tumor size of 3.5 x 3.0 x 2.0 cm and involvement of the bronchial margin. Additionally, metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in one of the right pulmonary lymph nodes and one of the two lower paratracheal lymph nodes, while the paraesophageal lymph node was negative for tumor. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT2N2MXG2, indicating moderately differentiated cancer with extensive lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostate cancer, specifically prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, and bilateral disease. The report notes that the cancer is focally present at the left anterior apical margin with a positive margin of less than 1 mm, while seminal vesicles and other surgical margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, two pelvic lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for metastatic carcinoma, and there is evidence of perineural invasion but no extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the right renal mass was diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma, conventional clear cell type, grade 2, measuring 3.3 cm, with the tumor confined to the kidney and the resection margin free of tumor. The analysis of the right perinephric fat showed no tumor present, and there was evidence of moderate arteriolonephrosclerosis in the non-neoplastic tissue. Cytogenetic analysis revealed an abnormal mosaic karyotype with significant numerical abnormalities, including the loss of chromosome 3 and gain of chromosome 5, which are consistent with clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a resected colon sample with a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 5.5 cm, which has infiltrated the muscularis propria but not beyond the pericolic fatty tissue. The tumor is staged as pT2 with no regional lymph node involvement (0/27) and no distant metastasis (pMX). Additionally, the tumor grade is G2, with no lymphovascular invasion (L0), no perineural invasion (V0), and clear margins (R0).

The pathology report indicates that both the left and right adrenal glands were diagnosed with pheochromocytoma, with no evidence of capsular or vascular invasion. Additionally, a total thyroidectomy revealed bilateral medullary thyroid carcinoma with one lymph node involved with metastatic carcinoma, while the parathyroid tissue showed signs of adenoma. The report also noted nodular C-cell hyperplasia and confirmed that lymph nodes from both left and right levels 3 and 4 were free of tumor.

The intraoperative examination of a lesion excised from the right breast revealed an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 1.1 cm in diameter, with estrogen and progesterone receptors present in over 75% of neoplastic cell nuclei, and a negative HER2 reaction. The margins were assessed, showing adequate distances from the tumor to surrounding tissues, including 0.8 cm to the base and 1.9 cm to the skin. Final results will be confirmed after analysis of paraffin specimens, but the preliminary diagnosis is invasive ductal carcinoma, NHG1, classified as pT1c.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma, predominantly featuring a high-grade fibrosarcoma/malignant fibrous histiocytoma-like appearance, arising from a right retroperitoneal mass and involving the right colon, terminal ileum, and right diaphragm. The tumor measures 24.5 x 18.0 x 11.0 cm, shows areas of necrosis estimated at 10%, and microscopically extends to the inked surface, although it is surrounded by a thin intact membrane. The bowel segment examined is unremarkable, and the tumor is adherent to the diaphragm skeletal muscle and bowel wall.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of carcinosarcoma involving the uterus, cervix, and lower uterine segments, with a tumor size of 6.5 x 6.4 x 4.5 cm and FIGO grade 3. The invasive serous carcinoma extends into the posterior upper endocervix and shows lymphovascular space invasion, with one regional lymph node positive for metastatic serous carcinoma. Additional findings include mild cervicitis, atrophic ovaries, and no malignancy identified in the adnexa, with the overall AJCC pathologic stage classified as pT2 pN1 and FIGO stage IIIC1.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the left lung, with a maximum tumor dimension of 9.5 cm, but no evidence of lymphatic, venous, or arterial invasion, and the surgical margins are uninvolved by tumor. All examined lymph nodes (total of 5) are negative for malignancy. Additionally, the non-neoplastic lung tissue shows signs of pneumonia with abscess formation.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe mass is a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, measuring 2.5 cm, confined to the lung without visceral pleural involvement, and with negative margins of resection. One of the seven peribronchial lymph nodes examined contains metastatic carcinoma, while the other lymph nodes sampled are negative for malignancy. Additional findings include subpleural fibrosis and focal emphysematous changes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower gingiva, with a tumor size of 3.0 cm and evidence of perineural invasion. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was identified in two lymph nodes from the right neck, with one lymph node showing extranodal extension. Surgical margins were positive for invasive carcinoma at the deep and lateral sides, while other margins were reported as benign or showing mild dysplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two tumors in the left kidney, with the lower pole tumor diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma, grade 2/4, measuring 3.5 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm, and showing no necrosis or lymphovascular invasion. The upper pole tumor is smaller, measuring 1.8 x 1.5 x 1.5 cm, and both tumors exhibit multifocality with extension into perinephric tissue but no involvement of renal sinus or collecting system. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma for the lower pole tumor, while no lymph nodes were identified in the hilar fat.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left simple mastectomy due to multicentric moderately differentiated intraductal and infiltrating duct carcinomas, with three tumors measuring 2.2 cm, 1.0 cm, and 1.0 cm, and one tumor involving the superficial margin. The first sentinel lymph node biopsy revealed an isolated focus of tumor cells, while the second and third sentinel nodes were negative for tumor. Additionally, the right breast tissue showed fibrocystic changes and atypical lobular hyperplasia, with an Oncotype score of 14 suggesting a low risk of distant recurrence.

The pathology report indicates a clinical diagnosis of a brain tumor, specifically a diffuse astrocytoma. The microscopic examination reveals moderate nuclear polymorphism with a Ki-67 proliferation index of up to 7%. The final diagnosis is confirmed as diffuse astrocytoma, classified as Grade II.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma following a total thyroidectomy, with a tumor size of 2.8 cm located at the right superior pole, exhibiting extra thyroidal extension and unencapsulated capsular invasion. Additionally, a lymph node excision from the right neck level 3 revealed metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma measuring 7 mm without extracapsular extension. The overall staging is classified as pT3 pN1b, with surgical margins being focally involved at 1 mm from the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the left adrenal gland contains a tumor diagnosed as pheochromocytoma, measuring 5.5 x 5 x 2.5 cm, with negative margins and focal capsular invasion. The periaortic lymph node excised is negative for tumor involvement. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis, showing positive results for chromogranin A and synaptophysin, while other markers were negative.

The pathology report indicates that the tumor is located in the right frontal pre-rolandic region. The histological diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme. This diagnosis suggests a highly aggressive and malignant brain tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colon, measuring 2.6 cm, which arises in association with an adenoma and shows focal invasion into the muscularis propria without lymphovascular invasion. Eight lymph nodes examined are negative for tumor, and the cancer is staged as AJCC T2 N0 Mx. The surgical resection margins are clear, with the tumor located 12 cm from the ileal margin and 17 cm from the colon margin.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the urinary bladder, measuring 4.2 cm and invading perivesical tissue, while the prostate shows benign prostatic tissue and no significant abnormalities in the seminal vesicles. Biopsies of both the right and left ureters show no evidence of carcinoma, and lymph node dissections from both the right and left pelvic regions reveal no tumor involvement in a total of 29 examined nodes. The overall staging of the bladder tumor is classified as pT3aN0M0, indicating muscle invasion without lymphatic or vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates that three of the right axillary sentinel lymph nodes contain rare cytokeratin positive cells, which do not resemble the patient's invasive tumor and are considered non-specific immunoreactivity, while the other four lymph nodes are negative for tumor. The right breast segmental mastectomy reveals invasive ductal carcinoma with extensive tumor necrosis, classified as high grade, measuring 2.5 cm, with margins widely free of tumor and no lymphovascular invasion identified. Additional findings include fibrocystic changes and an intraductal papilloma in the breast tissue, with the lateral margin also negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast lumpectomy revealed infiltrating (invasive) and intraductal carcinoma, comedo-type, with a Bloom-Richardson grade of 9, and tumor involvement at the margins. The new medial margin biopsy also showed high-grade intraductal carcinoma with tumor involvement at the margin, while the sentinel lymph node biopsy was positive for metastatic carcinoma. The axillary contents showed no evidence of malignancy, and HER2 analysis indicated weak positivity.

The pathology report indicates that there is no evidence of metastasis in the right axillary sentinel lymph nodes (0/4) and the left axillary sentinel lymph node (0/1). The right breast biopsy reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma, mixed grade 1 ductal and lobular carcinoma, measuring 2.3 cm, with invasive carcinoma very close to the lateral margin (0.9 mm). The left breast biopsy shows ductal carcinoma in situ (nuclear grade 2) and the superior margin of the left breast contains infiltrating carcinoma, mixed grade 1 ductal and lobular carcinoma, with the invasive carcinoma extending to the medial and inferior margins.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, primarily located in the anterior commissure and extending through the thyroid cartilage into pre-laryngeal soft tissue. The tumor measures 3.0 x 2.6 x 1.5 cm and shows extensive submucosal extension into both true and false vocal cords, but no tumor was found in the examined lymph nodes or other soft tissue margins. A supplemental report is pending for additional sections of bone that are currently undergoing decalcification.

The pathology report describes a right lower lobe lung mass from a 60-year-old man with a history of non-small cell carcinoma. The frozen section diagnosis indicates moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.5 cm, with negative resection margins but evidence of lymphovascular invasion. The tumor is limited to the lung and associated with a scar of the subpleura, and the tumor cells are morphologically similar to those in a previous left lower lung biopsy.

The pathology report describes a 10 cm soft gray to reddish tumor in the right adrenal gland, with a lighter-colored area measuring about 4 cm. Histological examination reveals a composition of zellballen, marked nuclear pleomorphism, and focal melanin pigmentation, along with areas showing ganglionic differentiation. The final diagnosis is pheochromocytoma, with no evidence of vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the distal esophagus, with a significant ulcerated mass near the gastroesophageal junction that invades through the muscularis propria and closely approaches the serosal surface. The tumor occupies 70% of the lumen circumference, and seven out of ten sampled lymph nodes are positive for carcinoma, while the surgical margins are free of cancer. The TNM classification is T3 N1 Mx, indicating advanced local disease with lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates extensive involvement of high-grade serous carcinoma in the omentum and right ovary, with significant infiltration into the fallopian tube and surrounding soft tissues. The peritoneal washings also tested positive for high-grade serous carcinoma, complicating the determination of the tumor's origin between the ovary and fallopian tube. The degree of ovarian involvement exceeds what is typically allowable for peritoneal serous carcinoma, suggesting advanced disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating moderately differentiated colon adenocarcinoma measuring 2.2 cm, which has invaded the subserosa but has uninvolved surgical margins. Sixteen lymph nodes were examined, all of which were benign (0/16), and additional findings included multiple hyperplastic polyps and a small tubular adenoma. The pathological stage is classified as pT3a N0 Mx, indicating a complete resection (R0) with no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right pelvic lymph nodes were examined, with no tumor identified in either set (0/4 and 0/2 lymph nodes, respectively). The prostate and seminal vesicles showed the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+3=6, affecting approximately 35% of the examined tissue, but without lymphovascular invasion or extraprostatic extension. The resection margins were negative for carcinoma, and no tumors were found in the seminal vesicles or vasa deferentia.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies from the brain tumor reveal an oligodendroglioma, WHO Grade II, with both astrocytic and oligodendroglial features. The Ki-67 labeling index is approximately 5%, and there is no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis, although rare mitotic figures suggest the possibility of a transition to a higher grade. Additionally, the MGMT promoter methylation status is negative, and there is partial deletion of chromosome arm 19q, while no loss of heterozygosity on chromosome arm 1p is detected.

The pathology report indicates that the left temporal tumor biopsy and excision reveal a low-grade glioma (WHO grade II). Fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH) analysis shows a deletion of the 19q locus but no loss of the 1p locus, consistent with an oligodendroglioma diagnosis. The tumor exhibits mild to moderate cellularity with a low proliferation index, and the findings were confirmed by a neuropathologist.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of unclassified renal cell carcinoma with high nuclear grade, measuring 12.2 cm, and exhibiting local invasion into renal sinus and hilar fat, as well as renal vein invasion. The right gonadal vein biopsy showed benign vascular tissue, while excised para caval and pre caval lymph nodes were not involved in the malignancy, and a ganglioneuroma was identified in the right renal lymph nodes. The tumor is staged as pT3b, indicating it extends into the renal vein and vena cava below the diaphragm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the terminal ileum and right colon, with the tumor invading through the full thickness of the bowel wall and into surrounding adipose tissue. All surgical margins are negative for malignancy, and thirty-three regional lymph nodes examined are also negative for cancer. The appendix is noted to be unremarkable with no specific diagnostic abnormalities.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of recurrent/residual glioblastoma (WHO Grade 4) in both the left temporal lobe and a left temporal mass, with evidence of necrosis. The tissue samples consist of multiple soft beige fragments, and prior surgery and therapy for glioblastoma are noted in the clinical history. The findings confirm the presence of infiltrating high-grade glioma and necrosis in the analyzed specimens.

The pathology report indicates that a specimen was sent to the Biospecimen Core Resource (BCR) from the NCH location. It requires the completion of the TCGA Missing Pathology Report Form due to the absence of a detailed pathology report. Additionally, it requests the tumor type, histology code, and site code for the sample, which are necessary for quality control and case diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, forming a mass measuring 13 x 10 x 5.0 cm, with clear surgical resection margins. Additionally, a separate fibrous nodule shows old granuloma and hepatocellular carcinoma, while the nonneoplastic liver exhibits no signs of cirrhosis. The attached gallbladder displays cholesterolosis, and both the pericholedochal and separately submitted choledochal lymph nodes show reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, negative for tumor, with special stains for acid-fast bacilli and fungi on the granuloma also returning negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma measuring 5.0 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of III/IV, and evidence of invasion into the renal vein and focal involvement of renal sinus fat. All surgical margins are free of tumor, but there is a metastatic deposit in the adrenal gland, leading to a pathologic stage of pT3b Nx M1. Additionally, a nodular deposit of renal cell carcinoma was found in a lymph node, but lymph node architecture was not identified, suggesting it may represent a soft tissue deposit rather than confirmed lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the bilateral pelvic lymph node dissection revealed three benign hyperplastic lymph nodes, while the radical prostatectomy showed conventional adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7/10, involving both lobes and approximately 20% of the gland volume, with focal extra-capsular extension noted. There was no seminal vesicle involvement or lymphovascular invasion, and all surgical margins were negative for cancer. The final staging is pT3aN0, MX, with additional findings of benign prostatic hyperplasia and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive breast carcinoma with two positive sentinel lymph nodes for metastatic carcinoma, the largest metastatic focus measuring 0.4 cm and exhibiting extracapsular extension. The primary tumor is a mixed ductal and lobular carcinoma, with the largest invasive component measuring 2.5 cm and a Nottingham grade of 3, indicating high-grade features. Additionally, 20 axillary lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for metastatic carcinoma, and the tumor is estrogen and progesterone receptor positive, with HER2/neu negative status.

The pathology report indicates that the biopsies from the pancreatic duct and uncinate process are negative for carcinoma, while a pancreaticoduodenectomy reveals well-differentiated adenocarcinoma involving the ampulla and extending into peripancreatic soft tissues. The tumor measures 2.2 cm, with extensive perineural invasion identified, and one of nine regional lymph nodes is positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma. The overall pathologic stage is assessed as pT3 pN1 pMx, with additional findings of mild acute and chronic serositis in the small bowel and mild chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive adenocarcinoma of the sigmoid colon, classified as grade 2 (G2), with tumor infiltration through all parietal layers (pT3). There is evidence of vascular infiltration (L1, V1) and the tumor has metastasized to six out of twelve lymph nodes (pN2). The resection margins are free of tumor, indicating a locally complete resection (R0).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a tumor size of 3 cm and Fuhrman Nuclear Grade II/IV. The tumor is confined to the kidney with no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. Additional submitted specimens from deep margins revealed benign blood vessels and renal parenchyma, confirming the tumor's limited extent.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast mastectomy revealed gynecomastia with no malignancy, while the right breast modified radical mastectomy showed invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 3, measuring 4.7 cm, with features of invasive micropapillary carcinoma and high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The carcinoma was found to be 0.2 cm from the deep margin and at least 2 cm from all other margins, with metastatic involvement in 3 of 17 examined axillary lymph nodes. The overall pathologic stage is IV, indicating distant metastasis to the iliac bone, and the tumor exhibits lymphovascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, classified as grade 2. The TNM staging shows no evidence of regional lymph node involvement (N0) or distant metastasis (M0). There is no current treatment specified, and the tumor specimen was obtained from a frozen tissue sample.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right glossectomy specimen, with a maximum tumor diameter of 5.5 cm and perineural invasion noted, while the medial and lateral pharyngeal margins are positive for tumor. Among the examined lymph nodes, one out of nine in the right neck level IIA shows metastatic involvement with extracapsular invasion, while all other lymph nodes from various levels are negative for tumor. The overall pathologic staging is pT3 for the primary tumor and pN2a for the lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the right and left distal ureters show benign urothelial mucosa with no evidence of urothelial carcinoma in situ or invasive carcinoma. However, the urinary bladder biopsy reveals high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma, measuring 10 cm, with invasion through the detrusor muscle and into perivesical adipose tissue, along with lymphatic tumor emboli and rare perineural invasion. Additionally, metastatic urothelial carcinoma is present in six of twelve right pelvic lymph nodes and two of five left pelvic lymph nodes, with no evidence of malignancy in the mesenteric lymph node excision.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 adenocarcinoma of the stomach, classified as pT2 and pNO, following a total organ resection. The tumor measures 9 x 5.5 x 1.4 cm and is located centrally within the stomach, with specific distances noted from the proximal and distal boundaries. Microscopic examination reveals a papillary cystic intestinal type adenocarcinoma that infiltrates the muscular membrane, while the incision lines, omentum, and lymph nodes are free of neoplastic lesions.

The pathology report indicates that the lymph node biopsy from station 7 is negative for tumor. In contrast, the pleural biopsy from the right side shows atypical mesothelial proliferation suggestive of malignant mesothelioma, with immunohistochemical studies supporting this diagnosis. The findings include positive staining for calretinin and keratin 5/6, while CEA and MOC-31 are negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of primary uterine adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, grade II, with associated squamous changes and tumor-associated necrosis. The endocervical curettage shows benign tissue with acute and chronic inflammation, reserve cell hyperplasia, and no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the examined pelvic lymph nodes. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is less than 50% myometrial invasion, with no lymphovascular invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated solid urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, characterized by infiltration into the bladder wall and surrounding fatty tissue (pT3a, G3). There is evidence of carcinomatous lymphangitis, but all surgical margins, including those of the bladder, ureter, vagina, uterus, ovaries, and fallopian tubes, are tumor-free. The tumor classification is confirmed as pT3b, L1, pNO (0/10), G3, R0, indicating advanced disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 0.3 cm papillary thyroid microcarcinoma, tall cell variant, confined to the left lobe, with evidence of metastatic cystic papillary thyroid carcinoma in a lymph node with extranodal extension. The pathologic stage is classified as pTia N1a, with lymphovascular invasion present but margins uninvolved by carcinoma. Molecular testing revealed a BRAF V600E mutation, which is associated with more aggressive tumor behavior, while no other significant mutations were identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 3.0 cm squamous cell carcinoma in the upper aerodigestive tract, specifically categorized as moderately differentiated (G2). The tumor is classified as pT2, indicating it measures more than 2 cm but not more than 4 cm, with no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis (pN0) and uninvolved margins. Additionally, HPV studies show the tumor to be negative for P16 and HPV 16.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid with extension into adjacent connective tissue, alongside Hashimoto's thyroiditis, with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the examined lymph node. Additionally, findings in the right breast include a giant fibroadenoma and fibrocystic changes, while the left breast shows fibroadenomatous hyperplasia and proliferative fibrocystic change. The parathyroid tissue is ruled out, and no malignancy is detected in the breast masses.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a well-differentiated papillary adenocarcinoma with bronchoalveolar features in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 4.5 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of lymphovascular invasion. Additionally, three excised hilar lymph nodes and one N1 lymph node were identified as benign anthracotic lymph nodes with no metastatic carcinoma. The final diagnosis stages the tumor as pT2, with no distant metastasis assessed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal lobular carcinoma with focal ductal features in the left breast, classified as Nottingham grade I, with two distinct tumor masses measuring 5.3 x 2.7 x 1.4 cm and 1.2 x 1.0 x 1.0 cm. There is no lymphovascular invasion, and the surgical margins are negative for tumor, with the closest margin being 0.8 cm away. However, multiple axillary lymph nodes show metastatic involvement, with focal extracapsular extension noted, and further testing for Her-2/NEU has been ordered.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, with multifocal tumor distribution and invasion into the lamina propria and inner muscularis propria, measuring up to 8.5 cm. All examined lymph nodes (28 total) were negative for tumor, and there were no tumors found in the prostate, seminal vesicles, vas deferens, or distal right ureter. The report also notes focal chronic and granulomatous inflammation consistent with treatment effects.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, located in the lower pole of the left kidney, measuring 2.7 cm in greatest diameter. The tumor is confined to the kidney with no evidence of transcapsular or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, the left adrenal gland shows no pathological findings.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left lower lobectomy, revealing moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 7.2 cm, with no lymphovascular or perineural invasion and all surgical margins negative for carcinoma. Additionally, multiple excised lymph nodes (11L, #7, anterior 11L, and #6) were found to be benign, with no evidence of carcinoma in any of the examined nodes. The carcinoma is localized to the lung, with a distance of 1.5 cm from the bronchial margin, and no pleural invasion was identified.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lymph nodes and associated fibroadipose tissue are negative for tumor. A lobectomy of the right upper lobe revealed a 4.5 cm poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma with no regional lymph node metastasis and uninvolved surgical margins. There is indeterminate lymphatic invasion, and distant metastasis could not be assessed.

The pathology report indicates the excision of a right paraganglioma and a right adrenal gland containing a pheochromocytoma, both of which were confirmed as paraganglioma and pheochromocytoma, respectively. The right adrenal specimen revealed a 2.5 cm pheochromocytoma that was completely excised, while the paraganglioma specimens included two nodules and four benign lymph nodes. The findings were reviewed and confirmed by multiple pathologists, ensuring the accuracy of the diagnoses.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a well-differentiated invasive ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, measuring 3.7 cm, with evidence of lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion, and involvement of the common bile duct and retroperitoneal margins. One lymph node (out of 21 examined) was found to be positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, while another lymph node was negative for malignancy.
