Additionally, the gallbladder showed chronic cholecystitis with cholesterolosis, and atypical cells suspicious for adenocarcinoma were noted in the pancreatic neck margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of angioinvasive follicular carcinoma, measuring 2.8 cm, located in the left lobe of the thyroid, with multifocal capsular invasion and margins involved by carcinoma. Molecular testing identified a HRAS codon 61 mutation, while mutations in BRAF, NRAS, and KRAS were not detected, and there was a loss of heterozygosity at chromosome 22q. The patient has metastatic disease, with involvement of the right femur, and the tumor is classified as pT2 NX M1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of small-cell urothelial carcinoma, comprising 90% of the tumor, which measures 4.5 cm and shows infiltration into perivesical fatty tissue and lymph vessels, with a lymph node metastasis present. The surgical resection margins are tumor-free, and there are multifocal areas of carcinoma in situ in the remaining urothelium. Immunohistochemical analysis supports the diagnosis, revealing positive markers for pan-cytokeratin AE1/AE3, synaptophysin, and NSE, while being negative for other markers, confirming the poorly differentiated nature of the carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, measuring 3.9 cm, located in the right upper lobe of the lung, with focal invasion of the visceral pleura and identified angiolymphatic invasion. Six out of twenty-five examined lymph nodes are positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, while multiple other lymph nodes are negative for metastatic disease. The overall pathologic stage is classified as T2, N1, MX, suggesting a primary lung tumor with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report describes a moderately differentiated papillary squamous cell carcinoma located in the left lower lobe of the lung, measuring 2 cm in diameter, with evidence of lymphatic invasion but no metastases found in the examined lymph nodes. The tumor exhibits characteristics such as nuclear atypia, isolated atypical mitoses, and areas of necrosis, with a fibrous-inflammatory stroma present. The report indicates that the tumor is obstructing the bronchus but does not specify the margins or any prior treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal breast carcinoma in the left breast, measuring up to 6 cm, with focal invasion of lymph vessels and extension to the base of the nipple and pectoral muscle. The tumor is classified as M-8500/3, grade 3, and is staged as pT3, pN2a (5/13), pMX, stage III A, with a complete resection (R0). There is no evidence of pagetoid tumor propagation or skin infiltration.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) located in segment 4 of the liver, with a tumor size of 1.2 x 1.3 x 1.1 cm and no evidence of necrosis, hemorrhage, or invasion of surrounding structures. The tumor exhibits moderate differentiation (Grade III) and is encapsulated, while the non-tumor liver tissue shows signs of chronic hepatitis due to HBV and mixed cirrhosis. Special stains reveal fibrotic changes, and immunohistochemistry confirms hepatocyte presence, supporting the diagnosis of HCC alongside cirrhosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive high-grade serous carcinoma of the endometrium, with tumor invasion into the myometrium and cervical epithelium, as well as involvement of an endometrial polyp. No carcinoma was identified in the bilateral ovaries, fallopian tubes, or in any of the examined lymph nodes and peritoneal biopsies. The overall pathologic stage of the tumor is classified as pT3a/NO/Mx, with positive results for mismatch repair proteins indicating potential microsatellite instability.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the right breast, Nottingham grade I, with a tumor size of 5.7 x 4.8 x 2.1 cm and angiolymphatic invasion present, but all surgical margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, a single right axillary sentinel lymph node is positive for metastatic carcinoma, with 14 out of 16 dissected axillary lymph nodes also showing metastasis. The left breast shows proliferative fibrocystic disease without atypia, and further testing for Her-2/NEU has been ordered.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the lateral segment of the liver, with a well-defined mass measuring 1.5 x 1.8 x 2.0 cm and clear surgical margins. Microscopic examination reveals moderately differentiated HCC with no evidence of vascular invasion or intrahepatic metastasis, alongside mild chronic hepatitis due to HCV. Additionally, the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 5+4=9, involving both lobes of the prostate, with extensive perineural invasion and infiltration into peri-prostatic adipose tissue. There are three lymph node metastases identified in the right side lymph nodes, while the left side lymph nodes are tumor-free. The report also notes a positive surgical margin at the right apex and focal tumor infiltration in the left neurovascular bundle.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe of the liver, with a tumor measuring 1.8 x 1.5 x 1.0 cm, located 0.6 cm from the cauterized margin. The surrounding liver tissue shows chronic hepatitis consistent with hepatitis B, classified as mildly active (grade 2 of 4) and accompanied by cirrhosis (stage 4/4). Additionally, the gallbladder exhibits benign mucosa with cholelithiasis, containing two cholesterol stones.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma primarily located in the bladder, with evidence of local invasion into perivesical soft tissues and involvement of both distal ureters. Metastatic disease is identified in one lymph node from the right common iliac and one from the right distal pelvic dissection, while other lymph nodes examined are benign. Surgical margins are positive for tumor at both ureteral margins, and the pathological stage is classified as pT3 due to invasion of perivesical soft tissue.

The pathology report indicates a well-differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung, measuring 75 mm, with no evidence of pleural invasion or vascular involvement, and clear margins at the bronchial resection. Metastatic deposits of adenocarcinoma are present in the hilar, lingular, and No. 11 lymph nodes, classified as T2N1M0. Additionally, there is evidence of centriacinar emphysema in the lung parenchyma away from the tumor, along with squamous metaplasia and severe dysplasia at the bronchial resection margin.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of rectal adenocarcinoma located in the rectosigmoid colon. The cancer is classified as T3, N0, M0, corresponding to an overall stage of IIA. The patient is identified as white and not Hispanic or Latino, with no additional details provided regarding vital status or date of death.

The pathology report indicates that a left nephrectomy was performed, revealing a 2.2 cm chromophobe type renal cell carcinoma limited to the kidney, with no vascular invasion detected. The ureteral and vascular margins are negative for tumor, and the background kidney shows no significant changes. The tumor is classified as pT1a NX MX, indicating it is at stage I.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in a male patient, with the tumor located in the left kidney. The tumor tissue sample weighed 330 mg and was processed as a frozen specimen. Histologically, the tumor shows a cellularity of 85%, with no data provided for TNM staging or prior chemotherapy details.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme in the left parietal lobe following excision of a brain tumor. The tumor exhibits significant necrosis, thrombosed vessels, and a proliferation of atypical multinucleated cells with bizarre nuclei. The MIB-1 labeling index is reported at 20 percent, indicating a high level of cellular proliferation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 3.4 x 3.0 x 2.3 cm, with extensive vascular and perineural invasion. Biopsies of the level XI and level VII lymph nodes revealed two benign lymph nodes and one metastatic carcinoma, respectively, while the AP window lymph node also showed metastatic involvement. The bronchial margin and pleura are free of tumor, and additional lung abnormalities include emphysematous changes and respiratory bronchiolitis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the right breast, classified as grade 2. The tumor is staged as T2 N1 M0, indicating a primary tumor with regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. Additionally, a normal blood sample was obtained, which is not related to the cancer diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the left ovary contains a mucinous cystadenoma, with no significant pathology in the attached fallopian tube. The rectal specimen reveals an infiltrating moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, which extends into the pericolonic soft tissue, with all surgical margins negative for tumor. Additionally, metastatic adenocarcinoma is present in three of twenty-four regional lymph nodes, along with foci of non-lymph node pericolonic soft tissue metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma located in the rectosigmoid region, measuring 2.5 cm in diameter and extending 1.5 cm to the aboral resection margin. The tumor is associated with a tubulovillous adenoma exhibiting severe epithelial dysplasia and has invaded the submucosal layer, but both oral and aboral resection margins are tumor-free. The tumor is staged as PT1 pN0 (0/18) L0, V0, G2 R0, with all eighteen examined lymph nodes showing no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the peritoneal and small bowel implants are both positive for adenocarcinoma, while the sigmoid colon shows a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma with full muscle wall thickness invasion and metastasis to one out of twenty-five lymph nodes. The tumor measures 5 x 3.5 x 1.6 cm and has negative margins, but there are tumor implants present in the pericolic fat. The rectal and colon donut specimens are negative for tumor, and the overall pathologic stage is pT3 N1 Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated solid transitional cell carcinoma originating from the bladder, with invasion into the prostate and evidence of regional lymph node metastases. The urethral and left ureteric surgical margins show carcinoma in situ, while the right external iliac node does not exhibit metastatic disease. Overall, the findings suggest a pT4 pN2 pMx classification with associated carcinoma in situ.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinomas in the prepyloric antrum of the stomach, with one measuring 3 cm and infiltrating the perigastric fatty tissue, and another measuring 1.5 cm with infiltration of the submucosa. Additionally, there are six regional lymph node metastases identified, while the esophageal and duodenal resection margins, as well as the omentum, are tumor-free. The tumor stage is classified as pT2b (2) pN1 (6/42) pMX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with 3 out of 3 left paratracheal nodes and 1 out of 6 left neck level four nodes showing metastasis. A total thyroidectomy revealed multifocal papillary carcinoma in the thyroid, with the largest tumor measuring 1.2 cm in the isthmus and additional tumors in the left lobe. The parathyroid biopsies showed no pathological diagnosis, and the overall findings suggest extensive regional lymph node involvement with a total of 17 out of 25 examined nodes affected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (Grade II) of the cervix, with a tumor size of approximately 2.7 cm. The tumor is classified as T1b and has spread to one of four sampled lymph nodes (N1), while also indicating distant metastasis (M1). The sample was collected fresh frozen during a surgical resection procedure, 28 days prior to diagnosis.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of malignant melanoma on the left scalp, which was found to be focally ulcerated and showed multiple foci of angiolymphatic invasion and cutaneous and dermal satellites, although the resection margins were free of tumor. Two sentinel lymph nodes were excised, revealing fibrous tissue and skeletal muscle without any evidence of tumor cells. Overall, the findings indicate a melanoma with local invasion but no metastatic spread to the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a recurrence of high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the left colon wall, encasing the left kidney and ureter, with the largest tumor nodule measuring 18.5 x 15.5 x 12.0 cm and showing significant necrosis. The small bowel resection revealed no evidence of malignancy, while the mesenteric nodule biopsy showed well-differentiated liposarcoma. The abdominal scar excision demonstrated a dermal scar with mild inflammation but no malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated tubular gastric adenocarcinoma of intestinal type, measuring 4.5 x 3.5 x 2.0 cm, involving the gastric body, cardia, esophagus, and infiltrating the liver and omentum with multiple tumoral implants. Lymphatic and perineural infiltration is present, and while the proximal margin is uninvolved, it is only 3 mm from the tumor, with hepatic and distal margins also uninvolved. Metastatic adenocarcinoma is found in 2 of 6 lymph nodes from the lesser curvature and 4 of 6 lymph nodes from the greater curvature.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent an adrenalectomy and nephrectomy, revealing a large tumor measuring 18 cm within a specimen that is 25 X 17 X 8.5 cm. The diagnosis is adrenocortical carcinoma, with a KI67 proliferation index of 10%. The tumor has a Weiss score of 7, a Hough score of 5.58, and a Van Slooten score of 22.7, suggesting a high-grade malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of adenocarcinoma of the prostate with invasion into the right seminal vesicle, while the extraprosthetic soft tissue is not involved. The tumor has a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7/10, with a tertiary pattern of Gleason grade 5/5, and the TNM stage is pT3b, pNX, pMX. No lymphatic or perineural invasion was observed, and the margins are mostly clear except for a focal positive shaved margin at the bladder neck.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional (clear cell) renal cell carcinoma with large areas of necrosis, classified as Fuhrman Nuclear Grade IV/IV, and measuring 13.0 cm in greatest diameter. The tumor extends through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia, involving renal hilar fat, while no renal vein invasion is identified, although muscular vein invasion in the renal sinus is noted. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and the adrenal gland is not involved, with the overall staging classified as pT3b due to gross extension into the renal veins.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of fibrofatty tissue from the right breast revealed invasive lobular carcinoma, grade 1. Immunohistochemical analysis showed the tumor to be negative for e-cadherin, with estrogen receptor positivity in 70% of the cells, progesterone receptor positivity in 20%, and HER2 negativity (score 1+). The findings suggest a low-grade invasive breast cancer with specific receptor characteristics that may influence treatment options.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of deeply invasive, moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma in a left buccal mucosal lesion, with the tumor abutting the deep margin. All surgical margins (superior, anterior, and inferior) are negative for carcinoma, while one out of twelve lymph nodes from the left neck dissection is positive for metastatic carcinoma. The report highlights the presence of a significant tumor measuring 4.0 x 2.5 x 1.5 cm, with a normal-appearing mucosa surrounding it.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (Furman grade 3-4) in the left kidney, measuring 3.2 cm, with all surgical margins and the renal vein free of carcinoma, and no extension beyond the renal capsule, classified as pT1a Nx Mx. Additionally, an adrenal cortical adenoma measuring 3.5 x 2.8 cm was identified, with no evidence of malignancy. Immunohistochemical staining confirms that the renal tumor and adrenal mass are separate entities, ruling out metastasis from the renal cell carcinoma to the adrenal gland.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma in both ovaries, with tumor sizes of 4.5 cm on the right and 3.8 cm on the left, as well as involvement of the posterior cul-de-sac and uterus, with significant lymphovascular space invasion. Additionally, metastatic high-grade serous carcinoma was found in one right external iliac lymph node and in the omentum, with evidence of extravasation. The overall diagnosis suggests advanced disease with a classification of T3c/N1/MX, indicating peritoneal metastasis and regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that multiple excised lymph nodes, including R4 and Station 5, are negative for tumor involvement. However, a lobectomy of the left upper lobe reveals infiltrating moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.8 cm, which extensively erodes the bronchial cartilage and invades the bronchial lumen and lung vasculature. Overall, while the lymph nodes are clear of cancer, the primary tumor in the lung shows significant local invasion.

The pathology report indicates a left radical nephrectomy revealing a renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type with focal sarcomatoid dedifferentiation, measuring 25 cm and exhibiting multifocal extracapsular extension into perirenal adipose tissue and direct invasion into the adrenal gland. The tumor is classified as pT4 with a predominant Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3, and there is a focal tumor embolus occluding a renal sinus vein, but no main renal vein tumor thrombus is identified. Additionally, benign gastric tissue and benign striated muscle with organizing hemorrhage were found in the excised portions of the stomach and psoas muscle, respectively, with no evidence of malignancy in those tissues.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right distal ureters are negative for malignancy, confirmed by frozen section analysis. The urinary bladder shows a high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma measuring 5.0 cm, with lymph-vascular invasion present, but all examined lymph nodes (28 total) are negative for metastatic disease. The prostate tissue is benign with patchy atrophy, and there are no additional significant pathologic findings noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated bilateral adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a maximum tumor diameter of 5.5 cm and a Gleason score of 4+5=9, showing extensive extraprostatic growth and multifocal infiltration of seminal vesicles and perineural sheaths. There is evidence of tumor involvement at the surgical margins and lymph vessel invasion, but no blood vessel invasion was found. Follow-up immunohistochemical studies confirmed no tumorous vessel invasion, leading to a final classification of pT3a, with no lymph node metastasis detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, with the resection margins free of tumor and no lesions in the surrounding renal parenchyma. The specimens submitted included the left renal mass, its margin, and adjacent fibrofatty tissue, all of which were processed for further examination. The operative findings were unremarkable, confirming the pre-operative diagnosis of a left renal mass.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the endocervical curettage specimen, with widespread invasion noted. There are also fragments of benign squamous and endocervical epithelium present, but no normal epithelium is identified. The depth of invasion cannot be determined, and the patient has a history of heavy vaginal bleeding and intrauterine device usage.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an undifferentiated carcinoma associated with moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma at the gastroesophageal junction, measuring 12.6 cm and infiltrating into the surrounding adipose tissue, with evidence of angiolymphatic vascular invasion. Surgical margins from the esophagus and greater omentum are free of neoplasia, but there are metastases found in six out of thirty-seven lymph nodes, with extranodal invasion noted in two. Overall, the tumor primarily resides in the stomach, extending to the esophagus, and requires further evaluation based on immunohistochemical studies.

The pathology report indicates a localized squamous non-keratinizing carcinoma of the lung, measuring 5x3 cm, classified as moderately differentiated (G2). Five bronchopulmonary lymph nodes showed reactive changes, but none were positive for metastasis, and there was no evidence of venous invasion or lymphatic invasion. The surgical margins are uninvolved, suggesting complete resection of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has undergone a radical prostatectomy, revealing the presence of adenocarcinoma in the prostate with a total Gleason score of 7/10, characterized by a primary pattern of 4 and a secondary pattern of 3. The tumor occupies approximately 5% of the gland volume, with no evidence of extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, lymphovascular invasion, or perineural invasion, and all surgical margins are reported as uninvolved. Additional findings include the presence of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN), and the pTNM stage is classified as pT2c, NX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade myxofibrosarcoma in a specimen obtained from a radical resection of a right groin mass, measuring 9.1 cm at its greatest dimension. The tumor involves subcutaneous fibroadipose tissue and shows approximately 10% necrosis, with the deep margin being 0.7 cm from the tumor. Other margins are widely clear, and the overlying skin is not involved.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver, characterized by a large intrahepatic mass measuring 13.0 x 13.0 x 7.5 cm with areas of necrosis. There is no evidence of vascular invasion, and the resection margins are negative for tumor, with the closest margin being 1.2 cm. The surrounding liver tissue is noted to be noncirrhotic.

The pathology report indicates a resected colon with a centrally ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, measuring 6 cm in length, with infiltration into perirectal fatty tissue and four local lymph node metastases, but with tumor-free resection margins. The report also notes tumor-free periureteral soft tissue with focal fibrosis and the appendix shows signs of previous healed appendicitis and mild periappendicitis. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN2 (4/19), pMX; G2, L1, V0, local R0.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal carcinoma from a tumor sample collected from the left kidney, measuring 4 cm in size. The tumor is classified as grade III, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3/4, and is staged as pathological T1a, with NX for lymph nodes and M0 indicating no distant metastasis. The procedure performed was a resection of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a wedge biopsy of the right lung upper lobe revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.0 x 2.0 x 1.3 cm, with the tumor extending to within 0.2 cm of the surgical margin. The completion lobectomy showed benign lung tissue with no residual carcinoma, and the bronchial margin was free of tumor. Additionally, two peribronchial lymph nodes and mediastinal lymph nodes were found to be benign, resulting in a pathologic stage of pT1a pNO.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with the tumor invading the superficial half of the muscularis propria and showing multicentricity. Surgical margins, including those from the urethra and ureters, are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of vascular or perineural invasion. Additional findings include benign nodular hyperplasia and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia in the prostate, while the seminal vesicles and lymph nodes are not involved.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with extensive residual carcinoma extending into the deep dermis, classified as histologic grade III and nuclear grade III. Additionally, lymph node examination revealed positive cancer involvement in both level II and level III nodes, while level I nodes were negative for cancer. All final surgical margins were reported as negative for cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with a non-invasive component identified as flat in situ carcinoma, and no evidence of lymph node involvement in the examined pelvic lymph nodes. The tumor invades the superficial half of the muscularis propria, with surgical margins free of tumor and no vascular or renal invasion noted. Additional findings include benign conditions in the perivesical tissue, prostate, seminal vesicles, and other excised structures, with the overall pathologic stage classified as pT2a.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a diagnosis of endometrial papillary serous carcinoma with superficial myometrial invasion, measuring 1.5 cm, and no lymph node involvement from the 17 examined. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic papillary serous carcinoma in the left adnexa involving the broad ligament, while the right adnexa and other sampled tissues show no malignancy. Overall, the report suggests a localized cancer with no significant spread to lymph nodes or other examined sites.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade (3/3) papillary serous adenocarcinoma in the left ovary, with extension to the ovarian surface and focal involvement of the fallopian tube, as well as metastatic nodules in the omentum and surface implants in the right ovary. No lymphatic or vascular invasion was observed, and the right pelvic sidewall lymph node was benign. Peritoneal washings were positive for high-grade papillary serous adenocarcinoma, suggesting metastatic spread from the primary ovarian tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of Grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma in segments II and III of the left lobe of the liver, characterized by a large multilobulated mass measuring 11 x 10 x 9.5 cm, along with a separate tumor mass of 1.3 x 1.2 x 1 cm. The hepatic parenchyma is noted to be noncirrhotic, and the surgical margins are clear, with the closest margin being 0.5 cm. Additionally, the biopsy from the right lobe of the liver shows benign liver tissue.

The pathology report confirms a diagnosis of seminoma following a right radical orchiectomy, with the tumor measuring 3.4 cm and showing multifocal involvement and vascular invasion, leading to a pathologic stage of pT2. All surgical margins are negative for tumor, and serum tumor markers are within normal limits. Immunohistochemistry results indicate positive staining for placental alkaline phosphatase and negative results for human chorionic gonadotropin, alpha-fetoprotein, CD30, and cytokeratins.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon with medullary features, measuring 7x5x1.2 cm, invading through the muscularis propria into the subserosa, but with free resection margins and no lymph node metastasis (0/23). Additionally, multiple tubular adenomas and hyperplastic polyps were identified in the ascending colon. The tumor is classified as pT3NO MX, indicating significant local invasion without lymphatic spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation, measuring 9 x 6 x 2.5 cm, which has invaded the anterior lower uterine segment and shows vascular space invasion. Surgical margins are negative, and no tumor is detected in the examined lymph nodes, indicating no lymphatic spread. The final staging is pT1aN0Mna, suggesting early-stage endometrial cancer with no evidence of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that the total gastrectomy specimen shows extensive infiltration by poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, characterized by a linitis plastica pattern, with full thickness wall infiltration and metastases in all examined lymph nodes. The tumor extends to the gastro-oesophageal junction but does not involve the surgical margins. Additionally, the right gastroepiploic lymph node also demonstrates metastatic adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional (clear cell) renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm and a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV. There is no evidence of local invasion, renal vein invasion, or lymph node involvement, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is confined to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated papillary non-mucinous adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe, measuring 50 mm and extending to the visceral pleura, which is tumor-free. The tumor classification is M-8140/3, G1, with a staging of pT2, pN0, pMX, and stage I B, indicating no lymph node involvement and no distant metastasis. The resection margins are clear of tumor, denoted as R0, with additional findings of subpleural scarring and pleural adhesions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mucinous adenocarcinoma at the rectosigmoid junction, characterized by a tumor infiltrating the full thickness of the intestine and surrounding 100% of its circumference. There are metastatic lymph nodes with significant infiltration, and the tumor is classified as G3, Dukes C, pT4, pN2b. The surgical margins are minimally clear of neoplastic lesions, with a minimum side margin of 3 cm.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (G2) in a resected sample of the rectosigmoid colon, with infiltration into the perimuscular fatty tissue. The tumor is classified as pT3, with lymphatic invasion (L1) and vascular invasion (V1), and the resection margins are tumor-free (R0). Additionally, there are lymph node metastases, with 20 out of 32 nodes involved (pN2).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse astrocytoma in a Caucasian female patient, with the tumor located in the right frontal region of the brain. The specimen was processed as a tissue block and weighed 200 mg, with no additional treatment specified. There are no findings related to blood analysis in this report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of bronchioloalveolar type in the right lung's lower lobe, measuring 4.9 cm, with high nuclear grade and no pleural involvement or metastasis to lymph nodes. The bronchial and vascular resection margins are free of malignancy, and there is no evidence of lymphovascular channel involvement. The cancer is staged as AJCC T2, N0, Mx, and the intraoperative consult confirmed no malignancy at the bronchial margin.

The pathology report indicates a segment of the rectosigmoid colon with a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that invades pericolonic fat and is minimally positive at the radial margin, with metastatic disease found in 2 of 52 lymph nodes. The proximal colon segment shows no significant pathology, while the distal donut excision also reveals no significant findings. Overall, the diagnosis confirms the presence of rectal cancer with lymphovascular invasion and metastatic involvement in the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with high-grade morphology and extensive necrosis, measuring 9.5 cm, and infiltrating into surrounding tissues including the renal vein. The tumor exhibits lymphovascular invasion and is classified as pT3b N1 Mx, with all surgical margins being negative. Additionally, a periaortic lymph node shows metastatic carcinoma, completely replacing the node.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of unifocal papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, with the largest tumor measuring 3.0 cm. There is no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis, and the tumor is classified as pT2, indicating it is greater than 2.0 cm but less than 4.0 cm and confined to the thyroid. Margins are uninvolved, with no signs of vascular or lymphatic invasion, and additional findings include mild lymphocytic thyroiditis and a small adenomatoid nodule.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a 5.0 cm moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, with metastasis to one of twelve examined N1 lymph nodes and evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, while all surgical margins are free of tumor. Fluorescence in situ hybridization studies show a ratio indicating a lack of amplification of the EGF-R gene, and no significant abnormalities were found in the bronchial mucosa or other lymph nodes examined. The final pathologic stage is classified as T2 N1 MX, with mild emphysematous changes noted in the lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated (Grade III), measuring 3.1 cm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising less than 25% of the tumor mass, with no involvement of surgical margins or nipple. Multiple sentinel lymph nodes were examined, with one node showing microscopic clusters of metastatic carcinoma (micrometastasis), while the others were benign. Hormonal receptor analysis revealed positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, and negative HER2/neu status.

The pathology report indicates that the delphian tissue is fibroadipose and negative for tumor. The total thyroid examination reveals the presence of papillary thyroid carcinoma with conventional and follicular patterns located in the right lobe, measuring 2.5 cm, with no multifocality, extrathyroidal extension, or lymphovascular invasion, and negative resection margins. The remaining thyroid tissue is unremarkable, and the right lobe contains a multinodular nodule confined to the thyroid.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right upper lobe adenocarcinoma, predominantly papillary, measuring 7.0 cm, with clear bronchial and vascular margins and no regional lymph node metastasis. Molecular testing for EGFR and KRAS mutations revealed no mutations, while FISH analysis showed no rearrangement involving the ALK gene, although extra copies of the ALK gene were noted in some cells. Overall, the lymph nodes examined were negative for carcinoma, and the findings suggest a moderately differentiated tumor without significant genetic alterations that would impact treatment decisions.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a tumor located in the left lower lung (LLL) with a size of 3.5 cm. The tumor is classified as stage III, specifically T2, with no evidence of metastasis (M0). Histological examination shows a grade of 3, indicating poor differentiation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligoastrocytoma, Grade II, in a female patient with a clinical diagnosis of a brain tumor. The gross examination revealed dense white tissue from the right frontal lobe. Microscopic analysis confirmed the presence of mitotic activity consistent with the Grade II classification.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right ureters show chronic inflammation but are negative for dysplasia. The bladder contains invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma, measuring 5.7 cm, with microscopic extension to the ureteral orifices and identified lymphovascular invasion, but no evidence of prostatic invasion or metastasis in pelvic lymph nodes. The appendix is reported as anatomically normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with a nuclear grade of II/IV, measuring 12.0 cm and extending through the renal capsule but confined within Gerota's fascia, with all surgical margins free of tumor. The excised lymph nodes from both the superhilar periaortic and para-aortic regions were negative for tumor involvement, although some lymph nodes showed granulomatous lymphadenitis with necrosis. Additionally, a benign vascular lesion identified in the perirenal adipose tissue was characterized as a hemangioma.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast tissue shows benign changes with multiple intraductal papillomas, while the left breast tissue is diagnosed with invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 3.4 cm, with negative margins and absent lymphovascular invasion. All three sentinel lymph nodes examined are positive for metastatic lobular carcinoma, with the largest deposit measuring 1.6 cm and showing superficial extranodal extension. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT2, pNX, pMX, indicating the presence of invasive cancer with nodal involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated papillary serous carcinoma in both ovaries, with the right ovarian tumor measuring 11 cm and the left measuring 4 cm, along with metastatic involvement in the uterus, omentum, and abdominal soft tissue. The uterus shows metastatic carcinoma with lymphovascular invasion, alongside benign endometrial polyps and leiomyoma. The final diagnosis confirms a pathologic stage of pT3c NX M1, indicating advanced disease with multiple sites of metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma (5.0 cm) in the right kidney, classified as Fuhrman grade 2, with negative margins. Additionally, the excised perinephric fat on the right side showed benign adipose tissue with no malignancy identified. The tumor was determined to be confined to the kidney prior to surgery, resulting in a pathologic staging of pT1b NX MX.

The pathology report indicates that no carcinoma was identified in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left peri-aortic and pelvic regions, with a total of 25 lymph nodes assessed showing no malignancy. The uterus exhibited an endometrioid adenocarcinoma, classified as FIGO Grade 2, with superficial invasion into the myometrium but no serosal, cervical, or adnexal involvement. Additional findings included an endocervical polyp, chronic inflammation, and stromal hyperthecosis in the ovaries, with no lymphovascular space invasion detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, characterized by a 6.3 x 5.2 x 4.4 cm mass and a separate 0.3 cm tumor nodule on the kidney surface. The renal vein is free of tumor involvement, and there is no evidence of tumor in the collecting system, coagulative necrosis, or sarcomatoid differentiation. Surgical margins are negative, and no renal hilar lymph nodes or adrenal gland tissue are identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the distal esophagus, with a tumor size of 3 cm. There are three negative lymph nodes, suggesting no lymphatic spread of the cancer. However, the report notes that the resection was irradical, indicating that the tumor may not have been completely removed.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7/10, characterized by a primary pattern of 3 and a secondary pattern of 4, and the tumor occupies 1 to 3% of the prostate volume. There is no evidence of extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, or lymphovascular invasion, and all surgical margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, no metastatic carcinoma was found in the examined pelvic lymph nodes, and perineural invasion is present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, measuring 1.5 x 1.2 x 1.0 cm, with associated high nuclear grade ductal carcinoma in-situ present outside the main tumor mass. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, and all surgical resection margins are negative for tumor. However, multiple left axillary lymph nodes (3 of 25) are positive for metastatic carcinoma with extranodal extension, and Her-2/NEU testing has been ordered on the tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial cancer, specifically a mixed adenocarcinoma with approximately 90% endometrioid and 10% clear cell components, classified as FIGO grade 3. The tumor is confined to the endometrium, measuring 2.5 x 2.3 x 0.8 cm, with no evidence of invasion into the myometrium or lymphovascular space, and the cervix is negative for tumor. Additionally, biopsies of the abdominal wall and omentum revealed benign findings, and pelvic washings were negative for malignant cells.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right upper lobectomy revealing a poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma measuring 2.3 cm, with negative surgical resection margins and no evidence of malignancy in 28 examined lymph nodes. Additional excised lymph nodes from various levels also showed no malignancy. The overall staging of the tumor is classified as T1b/N0/M0, corresponding to Stage IA lung cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma in the uterus, characterized by a 6.5 x 3.6 cm tumor that invades the myometrium and shows lymphatic and vascular invasion. The cervix and other examined structures, including the ovaries and fallopian tubes, are free of tumor, and all lymph nodes sampled (totaling 38) show no evidence of malignancy. An additional finding includes a well-circumscribed submucosal leiomyoma in the posterior endocervix, while immunohistochemical staining confirms the absence of neuroendocrine differentiation in the tumor cells.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a brain tumor, specifically diagnosed as a well-differentiated oligoastrocytoma (WHO Grade II) in two separate specimens. Microscopic examination reveals a densely cellular neoplasm with features such as round to irregular nuclei, microcysts, and extensive perineuronal satellitosis, but no evidence of necrosis or vascular proliferation. The tumor exhibits a gelatinous appearance and is characterized by thin delicate arcuating vessels.

The pathology report describes a segment of the large intestine with a 5.3 x 10 x 4.5 cm mucinous adenocarcinoma located 3 cm from the rectal edge, which infiltrates the muscularis propria and mesorectal fat. The tumor surrounds 100% of the intestinal circumference, with a minimum side margin of 2 cm, and the incision lines are free of neoplastic lesions. The final diagnosis is mucinous adenocarcinoma of the rectum classified as G3, Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2, pT3, pNo, R0.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a choroidal melanoma of mixed cell type in the left eye, characterized by a dome-shaped, non-pigmented tumor measuring 14mm in length, 13mm in height, and associated with exudative retinal detachment. Histological examination reveals retinal invasion, high mitotic activity (approximately 18/40 high power fields), and evidence of scleral invasion through the inferomedial vortex vein, while the optic nerve remains tumor-free. Molecular genetic analysis shows normal chromosomes 1 and 3, gains in chromosome 6p, losses in chromosome 6q and 8p, and gains in chromosome 8, which will aid in assessing metastatic risk.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of conventional renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, characterized by 10% clear cells and 90% eosinophilic cells, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4. The tumor measures 13.5 cm and extends into the perinephric adipose tissue, although the vascular, ureteral, and soft tissue margins are free of tumor. Notably, the tumor exhibits marked anaplasia and increased mitotic activity, but no sarcomatoid component is identified.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the right colon flexure, classified as grade G3, with evidence of ulceration and erosions. The tumor has infiltrated the parietal layers of the colon and surrounding fatty tissue, but all examined lymph nodes are tumor-free, indicating no lymphatic spread. The tumor is staged as pT3, pNO, MX, L1, R0, suggesting local advancement without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade clear cell carcinoma in the right ovary and endometrial carcinoma with both endometrioid and clear cell features in the uterus, confined to the endometrium. Additional specimens, including lymph nodes and omentum biopsies, were negative for metastatic carcinoma, suggesting no spread of cancer to these areas. Other findings included benign conditions in the fallopian tubes, cervix, and appendix, with various cysts and inflammatory changes noted in the adnexa and omentum.

The pathology report indicates that five left pelvic lymph nodes were examined and found to be negative for carcinoma. The prostate specimen revealed adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4, indicating a moderately aggressive cancer, and there is focal involvement of the right lateral surgical margin. Additionally, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and patchy chronic prostatitis were noted, with the pathological staging classified as T2+.

The pathology report identifies a retrocardiac paraganglioma, a neuroendocrine neoplasm measuring 1.3 cm, with notable nuclear pleomorphism observed on H&E stains. The tumor cells are positive for synaptophysin, indicating neuroendocrine differentiation. The biological behavior of the paraganglioma cannot be predicted solely based on histological findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC) with a Fuhrman nuclear grade II, primarily affecting the left kidney and extending into the renal vein and perirenal soft tissue. The largest tumor focus measures 7.5 cm, with lymphovascular invasion noted, while the renal artery and adrenal gland are negative for tumor involvement. Cytogenetic analysis revealed clonal aberrations, including a deletion on chromosome 3, which is characteristic of clear cell RCC, although no abnormalities were found in one of the specimens analyzed.

The pathology report indicates that a partial thyroidectomy was performed on a female patient, revealing a classical type of papillary carcinoma in the left thyroid lobe, measuring 2.3 cm, which is well-differentiated with no identified mitotic activity, necrosis, or vascular invasion. Additionally, a follicular type adenoma was identified away from the carcinoma, and the surgical margins were free of tumor. The report also notes the presence of nodular hyperplasia in the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma in the left breast, characterized by three masses measuring up to 2.0 cm, with perineural invasion and close proximity to surgical margins. Additionally, metastatic adenocarcinoma is present in one sentinel lymph node and three out of thirty-one axillary lymph nodes, with evidence of extranodal extension in some cases. No invasive carcinoma was found in the new anterior margins, although lobular carcinoma in situ was noted in a few foci.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 2.0 cm, with metastasis identified in 1 of 21 lymph nodes. The tumor shows no direct extension or vascular invasion, and the surgical margins are clear. Additional findings include benign lymphoid tissue in one lymph node and small hyalinized granulomas in a peribronchial lymph node, with the non-neoplastic lung parenchyma exhibiting changes consistent with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm and a histologic grade of 2 on the Fuhrman classification. There is no evidence of sarcomatoid features, extra-capsular invasion, or involvement of surgical margins. Additionally, a biopsy of the overlying fat revealed mature fat with no carcinoma identified, and the tumor is staged as T1b pNx pMx according to AJCC criteria.

The pathology report indicates a multifocal classic seminoma in the right testicle, with the largest tumor dimension measuring 2.6 cm and confined to the testis without lymphovascular invasion. All surgical margins, including the spermatic cord margin, are negative for seminoma, and the pathologic staging is pT1 with no evidence of regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. Additional findings include intratubular germ cell neoplasia and microlithiasis, with serum tumor markers showing elevated LD levels and normal beta-HCG and AFP levels.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma located in the lower pole of the left kidney, measuring 4.9 x 4.4 x 3.9 cm, with a nuclear grade of 3/4 and no evidence of invasion into surrounding tissues or lymphovascular spaces. The adrenal gland shows signs of cortical hyperplasia, but no metastatic carcinoma was identified. Additional findings include chronic pyelonephritis, glomerulosclerosis, benign retention cysts, and nephrocalcinosis, with all surgical margins being negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, characterized by a tumor measuring 6.2 x 4.3 x 7.8 cm, with infiltration into the skin and pectoral muscle. The cancer has metastasized to the axillary lymph nodes, classified as NHG3, pT4b, pN1a. Immunohistochemical analysis shows estrogen and progesterone receptors present in 10-75% of neoplastic cell nuclei, while HER2 testing returned a negative result.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 1.7 cm that is partially encapsulated and shows focal invasion into extrathyroidal adipose tissue. The left paratracheal lymph node examined was determined to be benign, with no evidence of metastatic disease. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is no identified blood vessel invasion or multicentricity.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated gastric carcinoma located in the prepyloric region of the stomach, with involvement of the pancreas. The tumor is classified as G3, pT3, pN1, and there are metastases found in 2 out of 8 adjacent lymph nodes. The tumor exhibits ulceration and infiltration into surrounding fat tissue, but the incision lines are free of neoplastic lesions.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left open adrenalectomy due to a left adrenal mass, which was found to be an adrenocortical carcinoma measuring 9 x 6.3 x 4.3 cm and weighing 105 grams. The tumor exhibits focal capsular invasion and necrosis, with a low mitotic rate of 8 per 50 fields, while vascular invasion is negative and surgical margins are close. The tumor is staged as pT2NxMx, and there is no evidence of extra-adrenal extension or lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that all skin margins and mandible biopsies are benign and negative for malignancy, except for the right mandible resection, which shows moderately-differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma with extensive mandibular invasion and positive lymph nodes. Additionally, there are areas of moderate dysplasia noted in the right tonsil margins, but no invasive carcinoma is present. The findings correspond to AJCC pathologic Stage IV A, indicating advanced disease with lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an infiltrating moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the upper rectum, classified as pT3, with metastatic disease found in 9 of 18 regional lymph nodes. The umbilical hernia sac showed adipose and fibromembranous tissue consistent with its origin, and was negative for tumor. The appendix was examined and found to have no significant pathology.

The pathology report indicates that the three sentinel lymph nodes from the left breast are negative for carcinoma, while the left breast mastectomy reveals a moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm, with negative margins and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Immunohistochemical analysis shows the tumor is estrogen receptor (ER) positive and progesterone receptor (PR) positive, with no amplification of the HER-2 gene. The overall pathological staging is pT2N0, indicating the tumor is invasive but has not spread to the lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from both the left and right external iliac, obturator, para-aortic, and common iliac regions were examined, with all lymph nodes showing no evidence of metastasis. However, a cervical biopsy revealed the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma, which is poorly differentiated and nonkeratinizing. Overall, while the lymph nodes are negative for cancer spread, the cervical tissue shows significant malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mucinous adenocarcinoma of the endocervical type in the cervix, classified as histologic grade 2, with infiltration extending 8.0 mm deep into the cervical wall. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of neoplasia in the right and left parametria, uterine tubes, or ovaries. Additionally, both right and left pelvic lymph nodes show no signs of neoplasia, with a total of 26 nodes examined (0/12 on the left and 0/14 on the right).

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma, primarily type II, with the largest tumor measuring 4.5 cm and classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3. Invasive carcinoma is noted to involve the renal parenchymal margins in two of the tumors, while the renal capsular margin appears uninvolved. Additional smaller tumors of varying grades and sizes were also identified, with no evidence of sarcomatoid features, tumor necrosis, or lymph-vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with Nottingham grades ranging from 2 to 3, and the largest tumor nodule measuring 1.5 cm. Additionally, ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of high nuclear grade is present, comprising less than 10% of the biopsy tissue volume, and there is evidence of metastatic carcinoma in three out of fifteen examined lymph nodes. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and the overall pathologic staging is classified as AJCC Stage IIA.

The pathology report indicates that the right ovary and fallopian tube are benign, with a paratubal cyst present. The left uterus, ovary, and fallopian tube show weakly proliferative endometrium, adenomyosis, and multiple leiomyomas, with the largest measuring 9 cm, while the cervix is benign with a cystic lesion. The left breast excision reveals invasive ductal carcinoma (grade 3) measuring 2.2 cm, with negative margins and no tumor found in the sentinel lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated large-cell nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma located in the left lower lobe of the lung, classified as stage III with lymphangioinvasion and metastases in the hilar lymph nodes. Additionally, numerous non-necrotizing epithelioid cell granulomata suggestive of sarcoidosis were observed, along with slight pulmonary emphysema and seborrheic keratosis of the skin. No asbestos bodies were found in the examined sections, but further investigations are recommended to assess potential asbestos exposure.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma arising in Barrett's esophagus, with invasion into the muscularis propria and negative margins. The specimen includes a segment of the distal esophagus and adherent cardiac stomach, showing areas of ulcerative esophagitis and gastric erosions. No positive lymph nodes were identified, and the TNM classification is T2 Nx Mx, suggesting localized disease without nodal involvement.

The pathology report indicates a right hemicolectomy specimen that shows tumor-free resection margins. It contains two tubular colonic mucosal adenomas with mild dysplasia and an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon that has infiltrated the perimuscular fatty tissue. Importantly, there are no regional lymph node metastases identified.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right pelvic lymph node dissections revealed a total of 27 benign lymph nodes. A radical hysterectomy specimen showed invasive non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix, measuring 3.3 cm, with moderate to poor differentiation and in situ carcinoma also identified. Surgical margins were involved with in situ carcinoma, but there was no evidence of vascular invasion or parametrial involvement, and the lymph nodes examined were benign.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder is normal with no pathological abnormalities following a cholecystectomy. The liver specimen shows moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, measuring 11.0 cm, with vascular invasion and a parenchymal margin that is uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, located 0.8 cm from the closest margin. Additionally, a tumor thrombus in the left hepatic vein is identified, also consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma and necrosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive non-keratinizing poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right tonsil, with tumor present at the deep and superior soft tissue margins. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was identified in 2 out of 18 level II lymph nodes, while the remaining lymph nodes from levels III and IV were negative for metastasis. The report also notes focal moderate squamous dysplasia at the inferior margin, but overall, the mucosal margins are negative for malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 4.4 cm and Fuhrman nuclear grade 2. The tumor is unifocal, and there is no evidence of capsular invasion or involvement of surrounding structures, with all surgical margins free of tumor. The AJCC staging is classified as pT1b, pNx, and the report notes that further clinical review may affect this staging.

The pathology report indicates that the left upper lobe of the lung contains two distinct types of carcinoma: a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with a predominantly lepidic growth pattern and a poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma. No visceral pleural invasion was identified in either tumor, but lymphovascular invasion is present, and the bronchovascular margins are negative for carcinoma. Additionally, lymph node biopsies from the mediastinum show benign findings, with one node containing adenocarcinoma similar to the lung lesions.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right upper lobectomy, revealing two separate poorly differentiated tumors: a 3.5 cm adenocarcinoma with a sarcomatoid component and a 3 cm poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, both classified as grade 3. All examined lymph nodes (10 in total) were negative for tumor involvement, although some contained calcified granulomas. The tumors exhibited visceral pleura invasion and lymph-vascular invasion was present in the squamous cell carcinoma, with the bronchial margin being uninvolved by invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right neck lymph nodes, with one out of eighteen nodes involved and no extracapsular spread. A subtotal glossectomy and mandibulectomy revealed a 5.0 cm invasive squamous cell carcinoma with extensive perineural and venous invasion, while the margins were free of tumor. Additionally, five out of twenty-one lymph nodes from the left neck dissection showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma with evidence of extracapsular extension.

The pathology report indicates that the left pelvic lymph nodes are free of tumor, while metastatic carcinoma is present in 1 of 5 right pelvic lymph nodes. A high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma, measuring 2 cm, is identified in the left trigone of the urinary bladder, with extensive squamous differentiation and no glandular differentiation noted. The tumor is staged as pT3b, pN1, and pMX, with lymphatic invasion observed and no tumor seen at the margins of the resected specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with lymphovascular invasion present and tumor invasion depth of at least 6 mm. Additionally, the report notes the presence of detached fragments of dysplastic squamous epithelium and benign endocervical tissue in the curettage sample, but the dysplasia cannot be graded due to the small and poorly oriented nature of the fragments. The patient is a woman with a history of low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion on a Pap smear.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant melanoma (spindle cell type) with superficial ulceration, located on the facial skin, measuring 1.2 x 0 x 2.5 cm. The Breslow's depth is noted to be 7 mm, and the tumor margins are uninvolved, with no evidence of venous invasion. Additional details regarding lymph nodes, satellite nodules, and histologic grade were not specified in the report.

The pathology report indicates that a left lower lobectomy was performed, revealing a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 2.9 cm in the left lower lobe, with no invasion of the visceral pleura and negative bronchial and vascular margins. Three excised lymph nodes (L9, L10, and L7) were found to be negative for metastatic carcinoma. The final diagnosis is consistent with the frozen section findings, and the tumor is classified as stage IA (pT1b pNO).

The pathology report indicates that both the right and left distal ureters are benign with no urothelial dysplasia or malignancy identified. However, a diagnosis of invasive urothelial carcinoma (grade 3-4) was made for a tumor located in the trigone of the bladder, with one of 11 examined lymph nodes showing metastatic carcinoma. The remaining specimens, including the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and various lymph nodes, were reported as benign with no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, histologic grade III, in the right breast, with the tumor measuring 5 cm and located 2 cm from the deep surgical margin. All 27 examined lymph nodes were negative for malignancy, and the operative margins were free of cancer. Benign proliferative changes such as blunt duct adenosis, intraductal hyperplasia, and fibrosis were noted, with no identifiable intraductal carcinoma present.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of unifocal papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 3 cm. The tumor is classified as pT2, indicating it is greater than 2 cm but less than 4 cm and is confined to the thyroid, with uninvolved margins and no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. Additionally, mild thyroiditis was noted, and no lymph nodes were submitted for assessment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma located in the right temporal lobe of a Caucasian female patient. The tumor tissue was processed as a primary specimen, and no additional treatment has been specified. A blood sample was also collected, which is reported as normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of advanced serous adenocarcinoma involving multiple sites, including both ovaries, fallopian tubes, omentum, uterus, cervix, appendix, and pelvic sidewall, with evidence of metastasis. The tumor is classified as poorly differentiated and has invaded surrounding structures, with positive findings in peritoneal and pleural fluids. Angiolymphatic invasion is present, and the overall staging is pT3c, indicating extensive disease progression.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 3.0 cm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the ascending colon, with no evidence of invasion into the muscularis propria or lymph-vascular invasion, and all examined lymph nodes were negative for metastatic disease. Additionally, a left kidney tumor was identified as a unifocal 7.0 cm papillary renal cell carcinoma, also with negative surgical margins and no signs of necrosis or extension into surrounding tissues. The report notes a separate inflammatory polyp in the colon and confirms that no further ancillary testing was performed.

The pathology report indicates that both axillary sentinel lymph nodes from the left side are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The left total mastectomy reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 2, measuring 2.5 cm, with lymphovascular invasion noted, but all surgical margins are negative. The right total mastectomy shows benign changes including fibrocystic changes and ductal epithelial hyperplasia, with no evidence of carcinoma in the skin margins of both breasts.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated, abundant mucus-forming adenocarcinoma in the resected colon and rectum, with infiltration into the perimuscular fatty tissue. The tumor-free margins suggest successful resection, with a distance of at least 1.6 cm from the tumor to the perirectal margin. Additionally, there is a recent ulcerous mucosal defect located orally to the carcinoma, possibly related to a previous endoscopic excision of an adenoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a composite resection of the anterior floor of the mouth and mandible due to invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, measuring 2.5 x 1.3 x 0.3 cm, with a depth of invasion of 0.3 cm and no angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. All surgical margins are free of tumor, with a distance of at least 0.5 cm from the closest margin, and a total of 23 lymph nodes were examined, all of which showed no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The final diagnosis is staged as pT2/N0/M0, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV) in the left parietal region of the brain following a craniotomy. Histological examination reveals characteristics of a high-grade diffuse astrocytoma, including pleomorphism, brisk mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, intravascular fibrin thrombi, and areas of tumor necrosis. The gross description notes the presence of dark-red tissue with hemorrhagic areas, measuring 6.0 x 3.0 x 2.0 cm, along with additional aggregates of hemorrhagic tissue submitted for further examination.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the uterine cervix revealed moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor is associated with intense desmoplasia. This finding suggests a significant stromal response to the malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 5.0 x 4.5 x 4.5 cm, with tumor invasion into the visceral peritoneum and evidence of venous and lymphatic space invasion. Additionally, there are cauterized fragments of the carcinoma found in the right diaphragm without evidence of tissue invasion, and an intravenous tumor embolus in the adipose tissue near the right adrenal gland, which was not identified. The background liver shows cirrhosis consistent with hepatitis B and a focal non-necrotizing granuloma, with special stains for infectious organisms returning negative results.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the left upper lobe, with a tumor size of 3.0 cm and evidence of invasion into the visceral pleura. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 2 of 17 examined lymph nodes, specifically in levels 10 and L4, while margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additional findings included respiratory bronchiolitis, and no distant metastasis could be assessed.

The pathology report indicates that both the biopsy and resection of the left occipital brain lesion reveal a diagnosis of diffuse astrocytoma, WHO grade II. The tumor exhibits astrocytic features with immunohistochemical evidence of R132H mutant IDH1 and low Mib-1 labeling index. Further analysis for 1p/19q status and molecular diagnostics for IDH and MGMT will be conducted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas, with chronic pancreatitis noted in the body of the pancreas. Additionally, metastatic adenocarcinoma is found in the hepatic artery lymph node and multiple periduodenal lymph nodes, with low-grade dysplasia observed at the bile duct margin. The tumor measures 6.1 x 4.5 x 2.0 cm, extends into surrounding soft tissue, and involves the duodenal mucosa, while the proximal and distal margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus, with tumor extension throughout the myometrium and involvement of the cervix, but no angiolymphatic invasion or tumor involvement in lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical staining showed normal expression of MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 proteins, suggesting intact DNA mismatch repair function and a low likelihood of Lynch syndrome. The AJCC pathologic stage is classified as T2, N0, and further testing for additional markers may be warranted based on clinical history.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple tumors in the left kidney, with four biopsies confirming papillary renal cell carcinoma, type I. Additionally, there are findings of cystic dilatation, chronic interstitial nephritis, and sclerotic changes in the renal parenchyma, with no tumor seen in some specimens. Immunohistochemical studies reveal tumor cells in the adjacent fat of one of the biopsies, suggesting potential invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the cervical biopsy reveals fragments of squamous cell carcinoma with a papillary architecture and fibrovascular cores, but no definitive invasion is identified. The specimen was received in formalin and consisted of two tan-gray tissue fragments. The clinical context includes a 6 cm cervical mass, and the findings were confirmed by an intradepartmental consultation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe, measuring 52 mm, with evidence of visceral pleural invasion and blood vessel and probable lymphatic invasion, but no perineural invasion or lymph node metastases. The bronchial resection margin is clear of tumor, and the surrounding lung tissue shows mild emphysema and patchy inflammation. Special stains confirm the invasion through the elastin layers of the visceral pleura, with no tumor present on the surface.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 3.7 cm squamous cell carcinoma located in the right lower lobe of the lung, with involvement of the visceral pleura but uninvolved bronchial and vascular margins. All examined lymph nodes (16 total) from various stations are negative for metastasis, and there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion. Additional findings include anthracotic lymph nodes and changes consistent with emphysema and atelectasis in the lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of bilateral breast carcinoma, with the right breast biopsy revealing poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma and the left breast tumor showing invasive and intraductal adenocarcinoma, both classified as NSABP histologic grade 3. The left breast tumor measures 1.3 cm and is located close to the superior margin, while the right axillary resection shows invasive and intraductal carcinoma measuring 4.5 cm, with no tumor identified in the examined lymph nodes. Overall, the margins of resection for both breast tumors are reported to be free of carcinoma, although vascular space invasion is noted in the left breast tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, measuring 7.8 cm with Fuhrman nuclear grade IV and extensive tumor necrosis, confined to the kidney without lymphovascular invasion. The tumor is located in the lower pole of the kidney, with surgical margins clear of involvement, and no tumor detected in the adrenal gland. An addendum notes that the non-neoplastic renal parenchyma shows no significant pathological changes, although there is focal moderate arterial sclerosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated serous carcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with extensive metastatic involvement in the omentum and multiple lymph nodes. The left fallopian tube shows no evidence of malignancy, while the uterus exhibits squamous metaplasia and an atrophic endometrial polyp. Overall, the findings suggest advanced-stage serous carcinoma with significant spread beyond the ovaries.

The pathology report indicates a well-differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas tail, measuring 4.5 x 2.6 x 2.7 cm, with limited focal invasion into peripancreatic fat and no lymph-vascular or perineural invasion identified. Surgical margins are free of tumor, with two periprancreatic lymph nodes and an additional 20 lymph nodes showing no evidence of metastatic disease. The cancer is staged as pT3, pNO, and additional findings include a benign spleen and no significant pathologic changes in the uninvolved pancreas.

The pathology report indicates that a left parametrial lymph node biopsy showed no evidence of malignancy, while a radical hysterectomy revealed invasive poorly differentiated cervical squamous carcinoma (pT1b2N1) with tumor extension into the lower uterine segment and lymphovascular and perineural invasion. Additionally, one lymph node from the left parametrial region was found to have metastatic carcinoma, but other examined lymph nodes (totaling 40) showed no malignancy. Other findings included inactive to atrophic endometrium, benign inclusion cysts in the left ovary and fallopian tube, and no significant alterations in the vaginal margin tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right colon, which has penetrated through the entire colonic wall and into the adjacent ileum (pT4b). Out of 13 examined lymph nodes, 2 are positive for metastatic carcinoma (pN1), while the resection margins are negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, there is evidence of prominent lymphatic and venous invasion, but no distant metastasis can be evaluated.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a grade 3 micropapillary transitional cell carcinoma in the bladder, characterized by an ulcerated tumor measuring 50 mm x 30 mm with invasion into the bladder wall and microscopic invasion of vesical fat. The tumor is confined to the posterior bladder wall and is 2 mm away from the deep posterior margin, with no evidence of invasion into the seminal vesicles or prostate. Additionally, the prostate shows hyperplasia without signs of prostatic adenocarcinoma, and the ureteric resections reveal no malignancy.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from a right adrenalectomy measures 7.5 x 7.5 x 5 cm and weighs 153 grams. The diagnosis is adrenocortical carcinoma, classified as malignant with a Weiss score of 3 and a Hough score of 1.31. The KI67 proliferation index is 2-3%, suggesting a borderline malignant potential.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, arising from severe squamous dysplasia (CIN3), with invasion through the entire tissue thickness of 5 mm. Microscopic examination reveals that the tumor exhibits significant cytologic atypia and a solid growth pattern, distinguishing it from clear cell carcinoma. The tumor's origin is further supported by its development in an area of squamous dysplasia.

The pathology report indicates that there is no tumor present in the left and right distal ureter margins, distal urethral margin, and pelvic lymph nodes examined. However, an invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma was identified in the dome of the urinary bladder, measuring 2.5 cm, with a histologic grade of 3/3 and a depth of invasion into the muscularis propria. Additionally, prostate adenocarcinoma was noted with a Gleason score of 3+4=7/10, but no extraprosthetic extension or tumor at the margins was observed.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated intestinal-type gastric adenocarcinoma measuring 6.0 cm in the anterior wall of the stomach, with perineural invasion but no angiolymphatic invasion detected. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes (34 total) and fragments of omentum show no signs of neoplasia. The gallbladder exhibits chronic cholecystitis with cholesterolosis, but there is no evidence of malignancy in the associated tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma in the left testicle. The tumor measures 3.5x2x2 cm and occupies two-thirds of the testicular parenchyma, characterized by solid clusters of round cells with distinct nuclei and surrounding lymphocyte clusters. Notably, the tumor does not involve the rete testis or the funiculus.

The pathology report describes a hypercellular glial neoplasm that infiltrates both gray and white matter, characterized by a range of neoplastic cells with moderate atypia and prominent perinuclear halos. There is no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis, but up to nine mitoses are observed in ten high power fields. The final diagnosis is anaplastic oligoastrocytoma, oligodendroglioma predominant, classified as grade III.

The pathology report indicates that the excised lymph nodes from level 7 and level 4R are negative for malignancy. The right upper lobe lobectomy revealed a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 5 x 5 x 3 cm, with involvement of the bronchial margin but no visceral pleural or lymphovascular invasion.
