The pathology report indicates that the left kidney specimen shows a diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma, type II, with a size of 7.5 x 6.3 x 6.1 cm, and features such as perinephric and renal sinus adipose tissue invasion, as well as lymphovascular invasion, although surgical margins are negative for carcinoma. Additionally, the left periaortic lymph nodes show significant metastatic involvement, with 9 out of 11 lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. The pathological staging is classified as pT3a N1, indicating advanced disease with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney and adrenal gland, characterized as 40% clear cell and 60% eosinophilic cells, with focal rhabdoid features and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4. The tumor measures 9.0 cm and has metastasized to the adrenal gland, but the resection margins are free of tumor. No evidence of spindle cell sarcomatoid carcinoma was found, and the tumor is described as high grade with significant hemorrhagic components.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in both the right groin lymph node and the mesenteric mass, with specific immunophenotypic characteristics noted. The left fallopian tube and ovary were found to be benign, while the right ovarian cyst was identified as a corpus luteum cyst. Additional testing, including flow cytometry and FISH analyses, is planned to further characterize the lymphoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in a cervical biopsy taken from the 10 o'clock position. Additionally, squamous carcinoma in-situ is present in the overlying epithelium, but there is no evidence of lymphovascular space invasion. The specimen consisted of four irregular grey-white tissue fragments measuring between 0.2 to 0.4 cm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in both the endometrium and cervix, with accompanying areas of invasion and necrosis. Additionally, high-grade squamous dysplasia (CIN 3) is noted in the endocervical curettage, although no definite invasion is observed in that area. The findings are based on the examination of biopsy and curettage specimens from a patient with a large cervical mass.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma in a female patient, with the tumor located in the breast and classified as grade 2. The staging reveals T2, N1a, and M0, indicating a primary tumor with regional lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis. No treatment has been administered to date, and a separate blood sample was noted as normal.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 3, with involvement of the lower uterine segment and superficial invasion into the myometrium. No lymphovascular invasion or malignancy was found in the examined lymph nodes, and other structures such as the cervix, ovaries, and fallopian tubes showed no histopathological abnormalities. The tumor invades to a depth of 3 mm, with a myometrial thickness of 14 mm, and the overall staging remains provisional pending further clinical data.

The pathology report indicates that the right axillary sentinel lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma (0/2). The right breast excisional biopsy reveals invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 2, measuring at least 2.5 cm, with involvement at the medial and posterior margins, and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), grade 2, present at the inferior margin. Additional findings include no vessel invasion or calcification, and immunostaining confirms the presence of invasive carcinoma at the margins while excluding lobular carcinoma in situ.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme in the left temporal region of the brain, confirmed through both frozen section and excised tissue analysis. Microscopic examination reveals extensive infiltration by neoplastic cells with notable pleomorphism, mitotic activity, and areas of necrosis. The MIB-1 proliferation index is reported at 9%, indicating a moderate level of cellular proliferation in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV) in multiple specimens, including a right parietal neoplasm, a right parietal tumor, and inferior white matter. The findings show microvascular proliferation and coagulative tumor necrosis. The specimens were received fresh and processed for examination, confirming the presence of the aggressive tumor type.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 3, primarily affecting the omentum and with metastatic involvement in both ovaries and fallopian tubes. The uterus shows serosal implants of serous adenocarcinoma but no significant myometrial or cervical pathology. The overall pathological stage is classified as pT3c, pNx, pMx, indicating advanced disease with lymphatic and vascular invasion present.

The pathology report indicates the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with focal squamous differentiation, classified as FIGO grade I, showing superficial myometrial invasion and no vascular space invasion. All examined regional lymph nodes (21 total) are negative for tumor, indicating no regional lymph node metastasis. Additionally, a serous cystadenoma is noted in the right ovary, and slight chronic cervicitis is observed in the cervix, with no tumor identified in the cervix or fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade II, with a polypoid mass in the uterus that invades the myometrium to a depth of 0.5 cm, while the cervix remains uninvolved. The right ovary and fallopian tube show diagnostic abnormalities, but the left ovary and fallopian tube are unremarkable. All examined pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung, with a tumor size of 2.3 x 2.0 x 1.3 cm. The pleura is uninvolved, and the tumor is located 4.5 cm from the bronchial margin, with negative margins in the bronchial resection and multiple intrapulmonary lymph nodes. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from the superior and inferior mediastinal, aortic, and N1 regions are also negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left adrenalectomy due to a pheochromocytoma, which consists of two adjacent masses measuring 6.9 cm and 3.0 cm, with no lymphovascular invasion detected. The report also notes that the periaortic tissue sample revealed ganglion and nerve without any tumor or lymph nodes identified. Given the patient's young age and history of medullary thyroid carcinoma, the presence of two distinct tumors is favored, suggesting a possible syndromic form.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a mucinous, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type, measuring up to 5 cm, with extensive infiltration into the pericolic fatty tissue and five regional lymph node metastases. The tumor-free resection margins suggest complete removal of the primary tumor, although there is a noted mucosal defect near one margin, likely related to previous polyp excision. The tumor is staged as pT3 pN2 (5/30) M1, indicating advanced disease with clinically evident liver metastases.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic serous adenocarcinoma in the omentum and both ovaries, with the right ovary measuring 4.5 x 4.3 x 2.9 cm and the left ovary measuring 4.5 x 3.2 x 2.5 cm, both classified as FIGO grade 3. The fallopian tubes are also involved with metastatic disease, and the omentum shows two separate tumor masses measuring 7.5 cm and 6.5 cm. The overall pathological stage is classified as pT3c pNX pMX, following a bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and omentectomy.

The pathology report indicates that a sample from the right base of the tongue was excised and diagnosed with invasive, poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The report is marked as unofficial and should not be filed in the patient chart. For official documentation, it is advised to contact medical records.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from both the right and left sides, including external iliac, common iliac, para-aortic, and obturator regions, were examined and found to be negative for tumor involvement. The uterus showed an endometrial polyp with partial replacement by serous carcinoma, which is confined to the polyp without myometrial invasion, and the myometrium also contained a leiomyoma. Overall, there is no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis, and the tumor is classified as pT1a (IA) according to FIGO staging.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland, with no convincing evidence of vascular or capsular invasion. Multiple small tumor fragments found on the periadrenal fat are likely contaminants from specimen handling rather than indicative of extracapsular invasion. Immunohistochemical staining confirmed the tumor cells' positivity for chromogranin and synaptophysin, supporting the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the left kidney resection revealed renal cell carcinoma of the chromophobe cell type, measuring 15.8 cm, which is confined within the renal capsule with no invasion of the renal vein and free surgical margins. The biopsy of the left 11th rib showed no gross abnormalities, and further microscopic examination is pending due to the need for decalcification. The left para-aortic lymph node biopsy revealed benign fibroadipose tissue, confirming no evidence of metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pure seminoma following a left radical orchiectomy, with a tumor size of 5.4 cm and no evidence of invasion into surrounding structures or lymphatic/venous involvement. All surgical margins are negative for tumor, and serum tumor markers are within normal limits. The tumor is classified as pT1, with lymph nodes not assessable, and additional findings include intratubular germ cell neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that the left breast excisional biopsy reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated (Nottingham Grade III), with a tumor size of 3.1 cm and negative margins. The sentinel lymph node analysis shows no malignancy in two lymph nodes, confirming the absence of metastatic disease. Hormonal receptor testing shows positive estrogen receptors and negative progesterone receptors, with HER2 being positive (3+), leading to a pathological stage of pT2 and an AJCC stage of IIA.

The pathology report describes a tumor located in the left lung sublobe IV, measuring 1.5 x 1.5 x 2 cm, with ill-defined margins and a firm, white-gray surface. Microscopic examination reveals poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, characterized by malignant cells with moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm and enlarged nuclei showing variability in size and shape. Lymphatic invasion is present, but details regarding tumor extent, other nodules, lymph nodes, and margins are not specified.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total nephrectomy due to a recurrence of papillary renal cell carcinoma, Type 2, with a nuclear grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 3.8 cm, which invades the renal hilar fat but shows no renal vein invasion. The excised paracaval lymph nodes and perinephric soft tissue revealed benign fibroadipose tissue with no lymph nodes identified, and the perinephric soft tissue showed fibrosis and fat necrosis without any tumor present. The surgical margins of the kidney specimen were free of tumor, and the overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is classified as pT3a.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a male with mesothelioma, underwent a pleurectomy and other procedures, with multiple specimens collected from various sites including the pleura, diaphragm, and lymph nodes. Microscopic examination revealed foci of invasive malignant mesothelioma in several specimens, including the visceral and parietal pleura, pericardial fat, and diaphragm, with evidence of lymphovascular invasion noted. Some specimens, such as the intercostal nodes and rib, showed no evidence of malignancy, while others indicated benign findings or previous biopsy sites without residual tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 5.2 cm, which extends through the renal capsule but remains confined within Gerota's fascia. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of renal vein or small vessel angiolymphatic invasion. Additionally, a biopsy of the left kidney shows benign renal medullary tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 5.2 cm and classified as Fuhrman grade 4. There is no evidence of sarcomatoid features or significant invasion into surrounding structures, although microscopic invasion of the renal sinus is noted. The surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and the overall staging is pT3a, pNx, pending further clinical review.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon, classified as G2 and pT3, with invasion through all wall layers and lymphatic vessel involvement (L1). There is no evidence of lymph node metastasis, as all 18 examined lymph nodes are free of cancer (pN0). The resection margins are clear of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, based on multiple biopsies from the left parietal region of the brain, all showing 95% tumor cellularity and varying degrees of tumor necrosis. The report notes that the low MGMT immunostaining result suggests a likelihood of responsiveness to Temodar, while the loss of PTEN indicates a diminished probability of response to EGFR kinase inhibitors. Overall, the findings highlight the aggressive nature of the tumor and its potential treatment implications.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows mild chronic cholecystitis, while the right kidney reveals a clear cell adenocarcinoma measuring 7.0 cm, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade II/IV, with the tumor confined to the kidney and free surgical margins. Cytogenetic analysis of the renal mass shows an abnormal karyotype with the loss of chromosomes 6 and 8, which is associated with various renal tumors. Overall, the findings suggest a significant renal malignancy alongside mild gallbladder inflammation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 3.6 cm, with lymphovascular invasion and involvement of three out of nine perihilar lymph nodes. Multiple biopsies from various lymph nodes revealed benign lymph nodes, some with anthracotic pigment deposits, and all were free of tumor. The surgical margins show a small cluster of tumor cells in a vessel, and the overall staging is classified as pT2a N1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive squamous carcinoma of the left side of the tongue, classified as partially keratinizing and ulcerating (G2). The surgical specimen measured 4.5 x 4 x 2 cm, with a tumor size of 3.5 x 2.0 x 0.8 cm, and all wire-marked margins were found to be free of neoplastic lesions. Intraoperative examination confirmed that no cancerous lesions were present within the marked margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation (FIGO Grade 3) in the endometrium, which invades the myometrium to a depth of 10 mm. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or regional lymph node metastasis, as all examined lymph nodes (24 total) are free of malignancy. Additional findings include a leiomyoma and focal granulomatous inflammation in the ovaries, but no malignancy is noted in the cervix, ovaries, or fallopian tubes.

The pathology report indicates that both the right and left obturator lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy, while the prostate biopsy reveals adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6 (Grade 3+3). The primary tumor is classified as pT2c, indicating bilateral disease, with no regional lymph node metastasis and absent extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle invasion, although perineural invasion is present. Tumor involvement extends to the inked capsular margin of the left lobe, but the bladder margin and apical margins are free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates a 1.2 x 1.3 cm infiltrating ductal carcinoma (G3) located in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast, with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. Ten dissected lymph nodes showed no metastasis, with findings of focal fibrosis and reactive hyperplasia. The tumor is classified as T1, and the Nottingham histologic score could not be determined due to unspecified details.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right pelvic lymph nodes, as well as the left common iliac lymph nodes, show no evidence of malignancy, with all lymph nodes being benign. The bladder, prostate, and seminal vesicles contain a high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma measuring 5.6 x 2.1 cm, with carcinoma in-situ present at the left ureter margin and no angiolymphatic invasion. The overall staging is pT3a, pNO, pMO, and the surgical margins are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a cholecystectomy revealing mild chronic cholecystitis, and a liver resection that identified a 9 cm hepatocellular carcinoma with vascular invasion and multiple satellite lesions, but negative margins. Additionally, a partial resection of the diaphragm showed skeletal muscle with fibrous adhesions and granulation tissue, which was negative for malignancy, and a segment of omentum revealed benign adipose tissue with focal fibrosis, also negative for malignancy. Overall, the findings suggest a significant liver tumor with associated chronic changes in the gallbladder and benign findings in the diaphragm and omentum.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 8/10, showing bilateral involvement and perineural invasion, but no lymphovascular or seminal vesicle invasion. The surgical margins are positive for carcinoma, indicating intracapsular invasion, while lymph node dissection revealed no metastatic malignancy in the three examined nodes. The tumor is classified as pT2c,NO, reflecting its local extent without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with classical papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) located in the left lobe, with a tumor size of 1.1 cm and multiple foci of papillary microcarcinoma present in both lobes. All examined lymph nodes and additional thyroid tissue specimens were found to be benign, with no evidence of vascular invasion or extrathyroid extension. Surgical margins are involved with tumor, and the remaining thyroid tissue exhibits nodular hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary serous adenocarcinoma of the endometrium arising within an endometrial polyp, with no myometrial, endocervical, or vascular invasion identified. The anterior vaginal wall biopsy shows benign squamous epithelium and fibromuscular tissue, while all examined lymph nodes and the omentum are reported as benign with no evidence of tumor. The myometrium shows leiomyomas, but the overall findings suggest no metastatic disease.

The pathology report indicates that a cervical biopsy was performed, revealing the presence of squamous cell carcinoma with stromal invasion, specifically large cell non-keratinizing type. The specimen consisted of five irregular portions of tissue, described as pink-tan to red-tan and friable, with sizes ranging from 0.4 to 0.7 cm. No clinical history was provided with the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in the right posterior section of the liver, measuring 3.2x2.3x3.0 cm, with a histologic grade of 3 for the worst differentiation and 2 for major differentiation. There is no evidence of satellite nodules, vascular invasion, or necrosis, and the surgical margins are clear with a safety margin of 0.6 cm. Additionally, the report notes the presence of inactive HBV-associated cirrhosis and identifies an epithelial cyst in the diaphragm suggestive of a ciliated foregut cyst.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the right tonsil reveals invasive non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma, which is moderately to poorly differentiated. Additionally, the core biopsy from the right level II lymph node shows scar tissue with a microscopic focus of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma. Further testing for HPV, P-16, and EGFR has been requested.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which extends through the bladder wall and involves the right ureterovesical junction, with a focus of vascular invasion noted. All examined lymph nodes (66 in total) show no evidence of malignancy, and the ureters and urethral margins are reported as benign with chronic inflammation and reactive changes. Additional findings include benign conditions in the uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes, and ovaries, with no dysplasia or malignancy identified in these structures.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left partial glossectomy due to invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue, measuring 1.9 cm with perineural invasion present, but with clear surgical margins. Additionally, one out of twenty-seven lymph nodes examined showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, while the remaining lymph nodes and margins were free of tumor. Immunohistochemical staining for P16 and HPV was negative, and the tumor was classified as pathologic stage pT1 N1.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma (cholangiocarcinoma) in the gallbladder, measuring 3.8 cm, with invasion into the muscle layer but free margins and no lymphovascular or perineural invasion identified. Additionally, there is evidence of chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis with perforation, but no tumor at the perforation site. The portal tissue resection shows non-specific inflammation without neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO Grade III endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with serosal involvement and extensive lymphovascular space invasion. Multiple lymph nodes, including the left obturator, right obturator, and paraaortic nodes, show positive metastatic carcinoma, while some pelvic nodes are negative for carcinoma. The right ovary is noted to have a serous cystadenoma, and the omentum is negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of right renal cell carcinoma, specifically clear cell (conventional) renal carcinoma, with a tumor size of 2.7 x 2.5 x 2.4 cm located at the lower pole of the kidney. The tumor is classified as pT1a, indicating it is limited to the kidney and does not involve the capsule, with uninvolved margins and no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. Additional findings include mild nonspecific chronic pyelitis, and the specimen was obtained through a radical nephrectomy.

The pathology report indicates that an anterior mediastinal mass was excised and diagnosed as a thymoma of the lymphocyte predominant type (thymoma type B1). The tumor measured 8.2 cm and exhibited focal transcapsular invasion, but the margins were uninvolved by tumor, with no lymphovascular invasion identified and no regional lymph nodes involved. The specimen was intact, and the pathologic staging is classified as Stage Ila, with no additional pathologic findings noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma measuring 9 x 7.5 x 0.4 cm, with invasion into perirectal adipose tissue, and 27 out of 72 lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. The margins of resection are negative for carcinoma, indicating a complete resection with no residual cancer at the margins. Additional findings include diverticulosis and evidence of venous and lymphatic invasion, with a pathological staging of pT3 N2 Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of malignant melanoma of the skin, nodular type, with significant ulceration and a Breslow thickness of 25 mm, classified as pT4b and pN3. The tumor measures 3.5 x 4 x 2.5 cm, with extensive invasion into adjacent tissues and numerous satellite nodules, along with signs of vascular invasion. Microscopic examination reveals over 10 mitoses per 1 mm, low-intensity lymphocytic invasion, and necrosis within the tumor, with margins measuring less than 0.1 cm.

The pathology report indicates a left renal mass diagnosed as a partial carcinoma, exhibiting features of both papillary (type 2) and clear cell types, measuring 1.7 cm in greatest dimension. The carcinoma is confined to the kidney with all surgical margins negative for carcinoma, and it has a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3 out of 4. Pathologic staging is classified as pT1a NX MX, with no lymphovascular invasion observed.

The pathology report indicates the presence of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with a tumor measuring 9.0 cm that is confined within the renal capsule but extends into the renal pelvis and involves adjacent adipose tissue. The right adrenal gland shows benign adrenal tissue, and the hilar lymph nodes are reported as benign with no evidence of metastatic disease. Additionally, tumor cell clusters are identified in small veins, but there is no invasion of the renal vein.

The pathology report indicates that the right thyroid lobe lobectomy revealed a unifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma, measuring 1.5 cm, with negative margins and no evidence of carcinoma in the two examined lymph nodes. Additional findings include a nodular goiter and chronic inflammation. The tumor is classified as pathologic stage pT1 NO MX, indicating early-stage thyroid cancer without lymphatic or venous invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in the right liver lobe following a hemihepatectomy, with a tumor size of 10.5 x 8.0 x 7.5 cm and a histologic grade of 2-3. There is no evidence of satellite nodules, vascular invasion, or necrosis, and the surgical margins are clear with a safety margin of 0.5 cm. Additional findings include chronic hepatitis B with moderate portal activity and fibrosis, but no cirrhosis or dysplasia was noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a high-grade infiltrating urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 2x1.5x1.2 cm, with invasion into the muscularis propria and evidence of venous invasion. Microscopic examination reveals poorly differentiated tumor cells with enlarged nuclei and abnormal chromatin patterns, and the tumor has not metastasized to the examined lymph nodes. The surgical margins are uninvolved, and there is focal extracapsular extension noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) in two separate brain tumor specimens labeled "AF1" and "B." Both specimens show infiltrated brain tissue replaced by pleomorphic cells with astrocytic features, including fibrillary cells and gemistocytes, with occasional mitotic figures but no necrosis or significant endothelial proliferation. The findings suggest a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, likely grade III, based on previous biopsy results.

The pathology report indicates the removal of a right abdominal testis, which was diagnosed as a seminoma measuring 6.5 cm in diameter. The tumor is confined to the testis in the available slides, but there is evidence of angio-invasion and invasion into the rete testis. This suggests a more aggressive behavior of the tumor despite being localized.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm located in the inner upper quadrant. There are metastases present in the axillary lymph nodes, classified as NHG3, pT2, pN1a. Immunohistochemical analysis shows no estrogen or progesterone receptors in the neoplastic cells, and HER2 testing is negative.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade I, in the left breast, measuring 4.8 x 2.7 x 1.9 cm, with all surgical margins clear of tumor. Additionally, lobular carcinoma in situ is present, and the AJCC staging is pT2NXMX. The right breast shows benign nonproliferative changes, and multiple lymph nodes from the left axilla are negative for tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, which has extended through the bladder wall and into adjacent adipose tissue, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm. Metastatic urothelial carcinoma was identified in one of the right common iliac lymph nodes, while other lymph nodes examined were negative for neoplasm. Additionally, atypical urothelium was noted in the right distal ureter, while the left distal ureter and urethral margin were negative for neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately-to-poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma in both the left and right ovaries, with metastasis observed in the fallopian tubes and multiple sites within the large intestine, including the transverse and sigmoid colon. The gross examination revealed significant infiltration and necrosis in the omentum and colon, with various specimens showing evidence of metastatic disease. Microscopic examination confirmed the diagnoses of metastatic papillary adenocarcinoma across the examined tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligoastrocytoma, WHO grade II, characterized by a hypercellular glial neoplasm that infiltrates the brain parenchyma. The tumor exhibits both astrocytoma and oligodendroglioma features, with mild atypia and a MIB-labeling index of 6.1%, suggesting intermediate proliferative activity. While the findings do not classify the tumor as anaplastic, they raise concerns for potential aggressive behavior.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, measuring 8.0 cm, with a composition of 90% clear cells and 10% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, and confined to the kidney without invasion into surrounding tissues. Additionally, there is a 1.3 cm metastatic renal cell carcinoma present in the adrenal gland, while one lymph node examined shows no tumor involvement. The margins of resection are free of tumor, and a renal cortical cyst is also noted in the kidney.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the fundus of the stomach, measuring 5 x 4 x 3 cm with an exophytic (polypoid) appearance. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/5 positive), and details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion are not specified. Margins and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment are also not provided in the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma, poorly differentiated (G3), with a tumor size of 2.3 cm located in the left upper lobe, and no definitive invasion of the visceral pleura. The bronchial and vascular margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, with isolated tumor cells extending to adjacent alveolar spaces. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes examined are negative for malignancy but show the presence of granulomas.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma in the thyroid, specifically located in the isthmus and left lobe, with a tumor size of 2.8 cm and unifocality. There is evidence of metastatic carcinoma in 3 out of 15 lymph nodes, and the tumor is classified as pT2 with regional lymph node metastasis (pN1A), while the surgical margins are uninvolved but close to the invasive carcinoma. Additionally, lymphocytic thyroiditis is noted, and there is evidence of both venous and lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a thyroidectomy due to a thyroid nodule, revealing a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left lobe, measuring 3.3 cm, with no extrathyroidal extension or vascular invasion. The right lobe showed benign thyroid tissue. The carcinoma is staged as T2, with the closest margin being 0.1 cm from the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the left thyroid lobe contains a well-differentiated papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 2.1 cm, with no evidence of capsular invasion, blood vessel invasion, or extrathyroid extension, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. All examined lymph nodes from the central compartment, left paratracheal region, and right thyroid lobe are reported as benign, with no malignancy detected. Additionally, the right thyroid lobe shows chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, while the left lobe exhibits nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade ovarian carcinoma with mixed components in the right ovary, while the left ovary shows metastatic high-grade carcinoma consistent with an ovarian primary, involving the fallopian tube. The uterus and cervix exhibit complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia and an endometrial polyp, but no tumors are present in the cervix or uterus. Additionally, metastatic high-grade carcinoma consistent with ovarian primary is noted in the cul-de-sac and omental biopsy, with no tumor found in the left pelvic lymph node.

The pathology report indicates that multiple axillary sentinel lymph nodes on the right side are positive for metastatic carcinoma, with the largest metastatic tumor measuring 6.0 mm and showing focal extracapsular extension. The breast tissue analysis reveals invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 2, measuring 4.0 cm, along with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) comprising 15% of the total tumor volume, and lymphovascular invasion is noted. Surgical margins are negative for carcinoma, and the invasive tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, while negative for HER-2.

The pathology report indicates that the excisional biopsy of the temporal lobe reveals a diagnosis of malignant glioma, specifically glioblastoma multiforme, characterized by extensive necrosis and atypical cells. The MIB-1 labeling index is noted to be 10%, suggesting a moderate level of cellular proliferation within the tumor. The findings suggest that the glioblastoma may have evolved from a prior gemistocytic astrocytoma, with significant vascular involvement and necrosis observed microscopically.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cecum, which extends into the muscularis propria but does not penetrate through it. All surgical margins are negative for tumor, and there is no evidence of lymphatic invasion, with all 24 examined lymph nodes showing no metastatic disease. Additionally, a 2 mm adenomatous polyp is noted in the right colon, while the terminal ileum and appendix show no significant pathology.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic high-grade serous carcinoma in multiple specimens, including the omentum and bladder peritoneum, as well as a malignant mixed Mllerian tumor (carcinosarcoma) in the uterus with superficial myometrial invasion and necrosis. The tumor in the uterus measures 11 cm and shows lymphovascular invasion, while additional findings include a uterine angiomyolipoma and positive peritoneal cytology. Overall, the diagnosis suggests advanced disease with significant metastatic spread.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two separate clear cell renal cell carcinomas in the left kidney, with sizes of 4.8 cm and 3.2 cm, both classified as nuclear grade III. Tumor invasion is noted to the renal capsule and perirenal adipose tissue, with the lower pole tumor involving the renal sinus, but neither tumor invades Gerota's fascia, renal vein, or ureter. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the overall AJCC staging is T3a, Ix, pM1, pending further clinical review.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma consistent with lymphoepithelioma-like carcinoma and prostatic adenocarcinoma, with a solitary tumor measuring 4.5 cm in the bladder and no carcinoma found in any of the examined lymph nodes (0/23). The prostatic adenocarcinoma has a Gleason score of 3+3 and shows no evidence of perineural invasion or extraprostatic extension. Additionally, a bladder diverticulum was noted, but all surgical margins and lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade serous carcinoma of the endometrium with deep myometrial invasion and evidence of lymphatic and venous invasion, along with an implant of carcinoma on the left ovary and detached fragments in the right fallopian tube. Both left and right pelvic lymph nodes were negative for malignancy, while peritoneal washings tested positive for high-grade serous carcinoma. Additionally, the uterus showed multiple leiomyomas and atrophic noncarcinomatous endometrium, with the cervix, right ovary, and left fallopian tube being negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a re-excision of the right lateral breast, revealing intermediate grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with no evidence of invasive carcinoma, and the surgical margins were multifocally positive for DCIS. Additionally, a stereotactic needle biopsy of the right breast showed infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma, classified as nuclear grade 2-3 and histologic grade 3, with a gross tumor size of 2.2 cm and an invasive component of 1.6 cm. Estrogen receptor activity was positive, progesterone receptor activity was negative, and HER2/neu analysis indicated no significant amplification of the HER2/neu gene.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right hemihepatectomy and cholecystectomy due to a preoperative diagnosis of liver carcinoma. The liver specimen revealed moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with vascular invasion, while the gallbladder showed autolysis of the mucosa, and the hepatoduodenal lymph nodes were negative for metastatic carcinoma. The resection margin of the liver was free of tumor, and the remaining hepatic tissue exhibited fatty dystrophy with minimal fibrosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a 15.5 cm chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, classified as Fuhrman grade IV, which is well-circumscribed and confined to the left kidney without invasion into the renal pelvis or surrounding structures. The regional lymph nodes examined showed no evidence of tumor involvement, and the tumor exhibits mixed features consistent with both chromophobe carcinoma and oncocytoma. Additionally, the non-tumoral kidney parenchyma shows mild focal global glomerulosclerosis and mild vascular changes, but no significant pathological findings were noted.

The pathology report describes a moderately hypercellular glial neoplasm that diffusely infiltrates both gray and white matter, characterized by tumor cells with mild atypia and no mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis indicates a predominance of p53-positive cells, supporting a diagnosis of well-differentiated astrocytoma rather than oligodendroglioma, with a low MIB-1 labeling index of 2.5%. The final diagnosis is a WHO grade II astrocytoma.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from both the right and left sides, including periaortic, pelvic iliac, external iliac, hypogastric, and obturator regions, were excised and all were negative for metastasis. Additionally, a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy revealed endometrial adenocarcinoma of the endometrioid type, FIGO grade 3, with myometrial invasion and vascular invasion present, but no endocervical involvement. The ovaries and fallopian tubes showed no significant histopathological changes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid, with a tumor size of 1.7 cm and characterized as well differentiated. There is no evidence of mitotic activity, tumor necrosis, blood vessel invasion, or extrathyroid extension, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, non-neoplastic thyroid tissue shows mild nodular hyperplasia, and parathyroid glands were not identified in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a 2.5 x 2.2 cm infiltrating ductal carcinoma (G2) located in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast, with no evidence of venous invasion and uninvolved margins. Ten dissected lymph nodes showed no metastasis (0/10 positive), although there was evidence of sinus histiocytosis and lipomatosis in the fatty tissue. The tumor is classified as a T2 size, and additional details regarding the Nottingham Histologic Score and treatment effects were not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, with a maximum tumor diameter of 7.5 cm, located in the right upper lobe and invading the hilar region, but with negative margins at the bronchial, vascular, parenchymal, and pleural levels. Intraoperative consultation revealed no tumor in the main stem bronchus or distal bronchial margins. Additionally, biopsies from regional lymph nodes (Levels 10, 7, and 11) showed no evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, measuring 6.0 cm, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of II/IV, and the tumor is confined to the renal parenchyma without evidence of invasion into surrounding structures. The renal vascular margin, ureteral margin, and perirenal margin are free of tumor, and no tumor was found in the adrenal gland. Cytogenetic analysis revealed an abnormal mosaic karyotype with a deletion on chromosome 3, which is consistent with findings in clear cell renal carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an anaplastic astrocytoma in the right temporal lobe, with multiple specimens submitted for analysis. Immunohistochemical studies show that the tumor cells are negative for the R132H mutant IDH and exhibit loss of PTEN expression. The frozen section diagnosis during intraoperative consultation favored a high-grade astrocytoma, which was confirmed in the permanent diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast partial mastectomy revealed two separate nodules of invasive duct carcinoma, with the larger nodule measuring 1.7 cm and poorly differentiated, while the second nodule is 1.2 cm and moderately differentiated. The first sentinel lymph node biopsy showed metastatic infiltrating duct carcinoma, while the second sentinel lymph node biopsy did not show evidence of metastatic disease. Margins were assessed, with the deep margin being free of tumor by at least 1 cm, but there were concerns regarding the presence of duct carcinoma in situ at various margins.

The pathology report indicates that no tumors were identified in the lymph nodes and soft tissue biopsies, with all tested sites negative for malignancy except for the larynx and base of tongue. Basaloid squamous cell carcinoma was diagnosed in both the right and left supraglottic larynx, as well as in the base of the tongue, with no definitive perineural or lymphovascular invasion noted. Overall, the findings suggest localized malignancy in the larynx and base of tongue, while other examined tissues were benign.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, with a maximal depth of invasion of 3.5 cm and evidence of vascular invasion, while the vaginal resection margin is free of tumor. Both the right and left parametrial lymph nodes were examined, and all lymph nodes from both sides were negative for metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, the report notes the presence of male twins in the uterine cavity.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma located in the head of the pancreas, measuring 4.5 cm, with invasion into peripancreatic soft tissue and one positive lymph node out of 46 examined. Surgical margins are free of malignancy, and there is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, although perineural invasion is present. The overall staging is pT3 pN1 pMx, corresponding to AJCC stage IIB.

The pathology report indicates that the right colon and retroperitoneal mass is diagnosed as a dedifferentiated liposarcoma, measuring 30 x 29 x 11 cm, with less than 10% necrosis and tumor extending to the inked soft tissue margins. The subcutaneous fat specimen was grossly unremarkable, while the uterine mass was identified as a leiomyoma with benign endometrium and a benign serosal cyst. Additionally, the right ovarian cyst was determined to be a corpus luteum cyst.

The pathology report identifies a Type A Thymoma measuring 4.0 x 2.5 x 2.0 cm, classified as pT2 with Masaoka stage II. There is focal infiltration of the mediastinal fat tissue observed. Immunohistochemistry shows the epithelial cells are positive for CK 5/6, with the presence of CD99-positive immature T-lymphocytes interspersed among the epithelial cells.

The pathology report indicates that a 61-year-old male underwent an Ivor Lewis esophagectomy due to a PET-positive mass, which was diagnosed as well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus, measuring 5.2 x 4.3 x 2.1 cm, with no lymph-vascular or perineural invasion identified. All surgical margins, including the proximal, distal, and circumferential margins, were negative for invasive carcinoma, although the tumor was located less than 0.1 cm from the circumferential margin. Additionally, granulomas consistent with a history of sarcoidosis were found in the stomach margin and lymph nodes, with no malignant lymph nodes identified among the 22 examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma, Follicular Variant in the left thyroid lobe, measuring 2.3 x 1.8 x 1.7 cm, with lymphatic invasion present but no capsular invasion. Additionally, three lymph nodes were examined and found to be benign, with no evidence of carcinoma. The right thyroid lobe and isthmus showed lymphocytic thyroiditis, and immunohistochemical staining was positive for TTF-1.

The pathology report indicates a final diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma, non-keratinizing type, from a biopsy of the right tonsil. Immunohistochemistry results show positive p16 staining and positive HPV detection via in situ hybridization. The specimen was adequately processed and examined, confirming the malignant nature of the tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 2.5 cm in the right upper lobe of the lung, with the carcinoma extending subpleurally but the parenchymal lung margin being negative for tumor. All examined lymph nodes (R4, R10, Station 7, and R11) are negative for tumor involvement. The pathologic stage of the tumor is classified as T1N0M0.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a radical prostatectomy, revealing adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4), involving 30% of the right lobe and 15% of the left lobe, with perineural invasion present but no extra-capsular or seminal vesicle invasion. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes (18 total) were free of tumor, and the margins of resection were tumor-free. Other tissue samples adjacent to the prostate showed benign fibrous and fibromuscular tissue without evidence of malignancy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, involving approximately 50% of the endometrial surface and invading about 35% of the myometrium, classified as FIGO stage 1A. There is evidence of focal lymphovascular invasion, but all examined lymph nodes (32 total) are negative for tumor involvement. Additional findings include atypical hyperplasia, an endometrial polyp, adenomyosis, and chronic cervicitis with reactive changes.

The pathology report describes a resection of the right lower lobe revealing a locally advanced, poorly differentiated adenosquamous carcinoma measuring at least 65 mm, with significant pleural infiltration and extensions into surrounding tissues. There are lymph node metastases exhibiting necrotic destruction and multifocal invasion of blood vessels, indicating aggressive disease. The assessment concludes that complete removal of the carcinoma is not definitive, classifying the tumor as stage III A.

The pathology report indicates the presence of adenocarcinoma of the prostate with focal microscopic extension into the right extraprosthetic soft tissue, classified as pT3a, with a Gleason score of 4 + 3 = 7/10. The right and left obturator lymph nodes and bladder neck were negative for tumor, and there was no tumor seen in the seminal vesicles or at the margins of the prostate. Perineural invasion was present, and a dominant nodule measuring at least 1.8 cm was identified within the prostate.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of serous adenocarcinoma of the right ovary, FIGO grade 3, with a tumor size of 12 x 9 x 5 cm and evidence of metastatic involvement in the serosa and left ovary. Additionally, one right paraaortic lymph node is entirely filled with cancer, while other examined specimens, including the left fallopian tube, uterus, and several lymph nodes, show no tumor involvement. The overall pathologic stage is classified as FIGO 3B, pT1B pN1 pMX.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the uterine cervix was performed. The findings reveal the presence of mucinous adenocarcinoma of the endocervical type. This diagnosis suggests a malignant tumor originating from the glandular cells of the cervix.

The pathology report indicates that the left adrenal mass is diagnosed as a high-grade adrenal cortical carcinoma, characterized by variable architecture and significant nuclear pleomorphism. The tumor exhibits numerous mitoses, including atypical forms, and shows prominent vascular space permeation with the formation of tumor thrombi. Local excision of the tumor appears to be complete, with residual atrophic adrenal cortex noted at one end.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma in the bladder and right distal ureter, both graded 4/4, with the bladder tumor measuring 3.5 x 2.7 x 1.6 cm and extending into the muscularis propria. No malignancy or dysplasia was identified in the uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes, or in any of the 70 lymph nodes examined. The final pathologic staging is bladder pT2bN0Mx and ureter pT3N0Mx, with additional testing for p53 status pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of ductal adenocarcinoma located in the pancreatic head, with a tumor size of approximately 3.4 cm. The tumor is classified as grade II and is staged as pathological T3, with no evidence of regional lymph node involvement (N) and no distant metastasis (M0). The sample was obtained through a resection procedure.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma from a partial nephrectomy of the left kidney, with a tumor size of 5.7 cm and Fuhrman grade 2. There is no evidence of sarcomatoid features or significant invasion into surrounding tissues, although the renal capsular margin is noted to be close to the tumor at less than 0.1 mm. The AJCC staging is pT1b, pNX, and the surgical margins are reported as negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen is from a left adrenalectomy and nephrectomy, measuring 9 X 8 X 4 cm and weighing 185.2 grams. The diagnosis is adrenocortical carcinoma, with a KI67 proliferation index of 30%. The tumor has a Weiss score of 5, a Hough score of 4.5, and a Van Slooten score of 14.7, suggesting a high-grade malignancy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, with extensive local invasion into perivesical soft tissues and vascular invasion identified. Metastatic disease is confirmed in one of the left pelvic lymph nodes and one of the right pelvic lymph nodes, while the majority of other lymph nodes and ureter specimens are benign. The overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3, indicating significant local tumor invasion without prostate involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder shows chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis, while the liver segment 5 contains well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with surgical margins free of tumor. Additionally, the liver biopsy reveals micronodular cirrhosis with severe macrovesicular steatosis and siderosis. The overall findings suggest a solitary tumor without vascular invasion and no evidence of malignancy in the gallbladder or liver biopsy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated Type I Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma with a solid growth component. The tumor is classified under the ICD-0 code 8260/3, indicating it is malignant. This suggests an aggressive form of kidney cancer that may require prompt and comprehensive treatment.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma located in the left liver, characterized by a 5 cm whitish nodule within a resected liver parenchyma measuring 17x10x4.7 cm. Immunohistochemical analysis shows positivity for CK7 and negativity for CK20 and TTF1, supporting the diagnosis of intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma. Additionally, the liver tissue exhibits mild steatosis, chronic inflammation, and mild to moderate fibrosis, along with reactive lymphadenitis in the hepatic and celiac lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in both the right and left adnexal masses, as well as in the cul-de-sac soft tissue. Additionally, an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the uterine cervix was identified, with vascular invasion and involvement of the paracervical soft tissue margins. Most lymph nodes examined were benign, except for one left obturator lymph node which showed metastatic adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type) in the right kidney, measuring 12.5 cm, with a Furman nuclear grade of 3 out of 4 and evidence of tumor extension beyond Gerota's fascia. The tumor also involves the renal vein resection margin, and the TNM pathologic stage is classified as pT4 NX M1, indicating advanced disease with metastasis. Additionally, a hepatic tumor excision reveals metastatic clear cell carcinoma consistent with a renal primary, accompanied by extensive tumor necrosis.

The pathology report indicates a tumor in the left upper lobe of the lung measuring 4.0 x 3.0 x 5.0 cm. The diagnosis is adenocarcinoma, predominantly of the papillary type with some acinar features, classified as pT2 and pN2 with 7 out of 30 lymph nodes involved. The tumor is graded as G2, indicating a moderate level of differentiation.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade IIb, with myometrial invasion extending to the serosa but no lymphovascular space invasion or cervical involvement. All examined lymph nodes and residual ovarian tissue are negative for carcinoma, and there are no signs of distant metastasis. The tumor is primarily located in the fundus of the uterus, measuring approximately 2.1 x 3.3 x 3.8 cm, with additional findings of endometriosis in the right fallopian tube.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the lower esophagus, measuring 3 x 2 x 1.5 cm, with evidence of invasion into surrounding fat tissue. Microscopic examination reveals ulceration, hyperplastic squamous cell layers, and malignant cells with notable nuclear atypia and frequent mitotic figures. Additionally, 5 out of 8 regional lymph nodes show metastasis, indicating lymphatic invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the left kidney, with a tumor size of 5.0 cm located on the posterior aspect of the mid kidney. The tumor is classified as pT1NXMX, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2/4, and shows no evidence of lymphovascular, transcapsular, or renal vein invasion, with negative surgical margins. No lymph nodes were identified, and the specimen has been submitted for genomic studies.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the larynx, specifically affecting the glottic, supraglottic, and right infraglottic sites, with a tumor size of 3.0 x 2.4 x 1.0 cm. The tumor has invaded surrounding structures including the thyroid, cricoid, and arytenoid cartilages, but there is no evidence of perineural, vascular, or lymphatic invasion, and surgical margins are clear of neoplasia. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes (15 from the neck dissection and 3 from the right recurrent dissection) are uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that all excised lymph nodes (totaling 10) from the right and left external iliac and obturator regions are negative for tumor involvement. The uterus and cervix show a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the endocervix, measuring 3.3 cm in lateral extension and invading to a depth of 0.6 cm, with no lymphovascular invasion or involvement of the ectocervix, vagina, or parametrial tissues. The final staging of the tumor is pT1b1/NO/MX, indicating early-stage cervical cancer without regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 7 x 6.5 cm, with invasion through the entire wall thickness and ulceration present. There is no evidence of venous invasion or lymph node metastasis, as all 10 examined lymph nodes are negative. The tumor is located in the antrum of the stomach, and the margins are uninvolved.

The pathology report describes a 3x4x1.5 cm ulcerated and invasive mass located on the 3rd and 4th toes, characterized by sheets of spindle or oval tumor cells with melanin granules, indicating a diagnosis of malignant melanoma. The tumor is poorly differentiated, with a Breslow thickness of 15 mm, and shows metastasis in 1 out of 5 examined lymph nodes. The microscopic findings reveal necrotic epidermis and common mitotic figures, suggesting aggressive behavior of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma in the left adrenal gland, measuring 2.8 cm. The specimen was received fresh and included a red-tan ovoid nodule, with additional tissue submitted for permanent processing. The report confirms that the pre-operative and post-operative diagnoses were consistent, and the laboratory is certified to perform the necessary testing.

The pathology report indicates that a left adrenal gland was removed from a female patient with a history of pheochromocytoma and hypertension. The specimen weighed 26 grams and contained a 3.7 cm encapsulated hemorrhagic tumor, consistent with pheochromocytoma, with no necrosis observed. The findings confirm the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma following the left laparoscopic adrenalectomy.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right leg above-knee amputation due to a high-grade pleomorphic leiomyosarcoma, measuring 12.0 cm, with necrosis but clear surgical margins. The tumor is adjacent to the fibula without invasion, and four examined popliteal lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. Additionally, biopsies of the sciatic and femoral nerves showed no evidence of malignancy in the nerve and adjacent fibroadipose tissue.

The pathology report indicates a biopsy of the uterine cervix revealing mucinous adenocarcinoma of the endocervical type, which is moderately differentiated. The tumor shows extensive necrosis. This finding suggests a significant level of tumor aggression and potential clinical implications.

The pathology report indicates that two sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla are free of metastatic carcinoma. A segmental mastectomy of the left breast reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 1.6 cm with tubular and cribriform features, classified as Nottingham grade 1, and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) constituting 20% of the tumor mass. The invasive tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER-2/neu, with negative surgical margins and no lymphovascular invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes from the right neck levels I, II, and III are negative for tumor involvement, and the submandibular gland shows no pathological changes. The oral cavity specimens reveal mild keratinizing dysplasia in several areas, but no high-grade dysplasia or invasive carcinoma, except for a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma found in the right mandibulectomy specimen, measuring 3.1 cm with a thickness of 2.1 cm, and negative margins. An addendum notes that decalcified sections of the mandible show invasion of alveolar bone by squamous cell carcinoma, although the bone margins are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a Type AB Thymoma located in the anterior mediastinum, measuring 10.8 x 8.0 x 5.2 cm. The surgical margins are uninvolved but described as exiguous. Immunohistochemistry findings support the diagnosis of thymoma based on the morphologic aspects observed.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated, nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma located in the left upper lobe of the lung, classified as pT2 pN1 pMX, stage IIB. The tumor measures approximately 4 cm and has caused obstruction of the upper lobe bronchus, with some metastasis to nearby hilar lymph nodes, while the resection margins and other examined lymph nodes are tumor-free. Additional findings include bronchiectasis, respiratory bronchiolitis, slight emphysema, and reactive lesions in the lymph nodes with anthracotic pigment deposits.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligoastrocytoma, classified as grade III according to the WHO. The tumor is located in the right parieto-occipital region of the brain. The patient is female.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma (5.7 cm) with bone involvement, originating from the floor of the mouth and extending to adjacent structures, but with negative surgical margins. There is evidence of perineural invasion and metastatic carcinoma found in one right level 1B lymph node out of ten examined, as well as one metastatic lymph node in the right level 4 resection with extranodal extension present. Additionally, abundant filamentous organisms consistent with Actinomyces were noted in the mandibular bone, associated with osteonecrosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic mullerian-derived carcinoma in multiple sites, including the omentum, both ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, appendix, and umbilicus, with significant lymphovascular invasion noted. The left ovary shows a high-grade primary ovarian carcinoma with mixed undifferentiated and serous features, while the right ovary may represent either a metastatic lesion or a second primary neoplasm. Additionally, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis reveals no HER-2 gene amplification, with a ratio of 1.4, indicating that the tumor is not HER-2 amplified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO grade 3 endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor mass located in the right fundus of the uterus, invading 0.7 cm into the myometrium, and involving both ovaries and fallopian tubes, as well as the posterior uterine serosa and cul de sac. Additionally, metastatic adenocarcinoma is identified in the sigmoid colon, omentum, and multiple nodular masses are present in these areas, indicating extensive spread of the disease. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and there is no lymphovascular space invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates that the brain tumor biopsy and resection are consistent with glioblastoma, classified as WHO Grade IV. Microscopic examination reveals a hypercellular glial neoplasm with atypical spindle-shaped astrocytes, marked mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, and areas of necrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis shows the neoplastic cells are diffusely positive for GFAP, confirming the diagnosis of glioblastoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 2.5 cm squamous cell carcinoma in the lung, with a tumor size of 1.8 x 2.5 cm and a histologic grade of moderately differentiated (G2). All examined lymph nodes (12/12) are negative for metastasis, and the surgical margins are free of tumor, indicating no residual disease. Additional findings include antracosis and sinus histiocytosis in the lymph nodes, but there is no evidence of venous invasion or treatment effect noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of esophageal adenocarcinoma located at the gastroesophageal junction, measuring 2.2 cm and invading the submucosa without involvement of the muscular wall or adventitia. The surgical specimen included a 19.7 cm segment of the distal esophagus and proximal stomach, with margins free of cancer, and no preoperative chemotherapy or radiation therapy was administered. Additionally, all nine examined lymph nodes were negative for malignancy, suggesting no lymphatic spread of the cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a right breast lumpectomy, revealing a 2.8 cm invasive lobular carcinoma with additional tiny foci of cancer present in the excised breast tissue. One of the sentinel lymph nodes (node #1) showed involvement by metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the second sentinel lymph node (node #2) was benign. The final margins of the excised tissue appear free of tumor, and the tumor is characterized as estrogen receptor positive and progesterone receptor positive.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right tonsil, measuring 3.5 cm, with a detached fragment of carcinoma present at the inferior mucosal edge. The margins are free of invasive carcinoma or high-grade dysplasia, and no angiolymphatic or perineural invasion was identified. Additionally, the tumor shows strong dot-like nuclear signals for HPV 16/18, and p16 immunoperoxidase staining is strongly positive.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, measuring 4.0 cm, with invasion into perivesical soft tissues (pT3b) and extensive carcinoma in situ along the prostatic urethra. Metastatic urothelial carcinoma was identified in one of seven right pelvic lymph nodes and one of four right hypogastric lymph nodes, while other specimens, including the vas deferens and distal ureters, showed benign findings. Surgical margins are free of carcinoma, and the non-neoplastic mucosa exhibits chronic cystitis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a malignant astrocytic tumor with rhabdoid features and leptomeningeal infiltration in the left parietal region of the brain, classified as a WHO grade IV neoplasm. The tumor exhibits significant mitotic activity, a proliferation index of 9%, and shows extensive areas of necrosis and hemorrhage. Additionally, testing for the EGFR variant III mutation and methylation of the MGMT promoter returned negative results, suggesting a distinct molecular profile for this tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a poorly differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma located in the right hemicolectomy specimen, with the tumor invading all layers of the intestinal wall and extending into the mesocolic fatty tissue. The tumor measures 8 cm and is situated 1.5 cm from Bauhin's valve, with no evidence of malignancy in the appendix, resection margins, or the large omentum. All 41 regional lymph nodes examined are tumor-free, resulting in a tumor stage of pT3 pNO (0/41) L0 V0 R0; G3.

The pathology report indicates that the left eye enucleation revealed a 15 mm choroidal melanoma characterized by fusiform cell morphology and a low mitotic index. The tumor is noted to infiltrate the internal third of the sclera but does not extend beyond it, with no involvement of the optic nerve, iris, ciliary body, or anterior chamber. Overall, the findings suggest a localized melanoma with no evidence of extraocular spread.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of seminoma in the right testicle, measuring 4.9 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion and involvement of the tunica albuginea and rete testis, but negative surgical margins. The final TNM staging is pT2NXM0, indicating no regional lymph node or distant metastasis, and the tumor is classified as stage I. The specimen was obtained through a radical orchiectomy, and the microscopic examination confirmed the presence of classic seminoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a robotic left partial nephrectomy for a 1.8 cm papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 2, located in the upper pole of the left kidney. The tumor is confined to the kidney with no evidence of necrosis or lymphovascular invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Pathologic staging is classified as pT1a, with 34 regional lymph nodes examined and none involved, indicating no regional metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated intestinal adenocarcinoma in the stomach, measuring 9.0 cm, with invasion into adjacent fat tissue and evidence of lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion. Surgical margins are clear of neoplasia, and there is mild peritumor inflammatory infiltrate, along with moderate pangastritis and incomplete intestinal metaplasia in the adjacent mucosa. Additionally, metastatic adenocarcinoma is identified in 5 out of 25 lymph nodes, primarily in the lesser curvature lymph nodes, while other examined lymph nodes and omentum are uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates that the right lower parathyroid biopsy showed no pathological diagnosis, while the right hemithyroidectomy revealed multifocal papillary carcinoma, specifically the dominant oncocytic follicular variant measuring 4.5 cm, along with focal mild reactive C-cell hyperplasia. The tumor is encapsulated with minimal capsular invasion and no evidence of lymph-vascular or perineural invasion, and no regional lymph node metastasis was identified. Additionally, the report notes the presence of thyroiditis and confirms the reactive nature of the C-cell hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, measuring 8.0 cm, with a composition of 80% clear cells and 20% eosinophilic cells, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3 and invasive into thick-walled blood vessels in the renal sinus. Additionally, there is evidence of metastatic renal cell carcinoma in the right adrenal gland, characterized by a well-circumscribed mass with areas of hemorrhage. The surgical margins of the resection are free of tumor, and there is no invasion into perinephric adipose tissue or the renal vein.

The pathology report indicates the presence of two renal cell carcinomas in the left kidney: one in the interpolar region and another in the lower pole, both classified as conventional clear cell type with nuclear grade II/IV, and confined within the renal capsule with free surgical margins. Additionally, fragments of multilocular cystic renal cell carcinoma were found in the cyst wall of the interpolar region, while the perinephric fat and other surrounding tissues were identified as benign fibroadipose tissue. Overall, the non-neoplastic kidney tissue is unremarkable, and there are no indications of tumor involvement in the surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates that the spleen and splenic flexure of the colon show no histologic abnormalities, and three lymph nodes were negative for neoplasm. However, the left adrenal gland, left kidney, and distal pancreas reveal a malignant pheochromocytoma measuring 20.0 cm, with invasion into surrounding tissues and lymphovascular invasion, although surgical margins and one lymph node were negative for neoplasm. Additionally, a retroperitoneal soft tissue excision showed benign adipose tissue with no evidence of neoplasm.

The pathology report indicates that the gallbladder resection showed no malignancy, while the partial hepatectomy of liver segment 5-8 revealed hepatocellular carcinoma, well differentiated, with a tumor size of 3.7 cm and no vascular invasion. Additionally, there is evidence of chronic hepatitis with severe steatosis consistent with alcoholic hepatitis and fibrosis stage III. The parenchymal margin is uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, but the bile duct margin and other margins could not be assessed.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a 12 cm clear cell renal cell carcinoma, nuclear grade IV, which has extended beyond the renal capsule and into lymphatics and vascular spaces, but all surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, two out of three retrocaval lymph nodes show metastatic renal cell carcinoma, while the aortocaval lymph nodes and adrenal gland are benign and uninvolved by tumor. The gallbladder is reported as benign with multiple stones and cholesterolosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed subtype adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.5 cm, with infiltration of the visceral pleura. The tumor is classified as pT2, pN2 (8/28), pMx, and is graded as G3. Additionally, EGFR mutation analysis revealed a positive mutation, specifically p.E746_A750del.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately differentiated serous cystadenocarcinoma in both the right and left ovaries, with vascular channel invasion noted in the right ovary. Additionally, multiple deposits of serous cystadenocarcinoma are identified in the peritoneal nodules, omentum, appendix, and spleen. Immunostaining for carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) shows insignificant expression in the tumor cells from both the ovary and omentum.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in one of twenty-two lymph nodes from the left neck, with the involved lymph node measuring 2.0 cm and located in level I, while the anterior lip margin and submandibular gland show no pathological changes. Additionally, a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma was identified in the marginal mandibulectomy specimen, with a maximum tumor diameter of 3.9 cm and a thickness of 1.6 cm, but no lymphovascular or perineural invasion was noted. An addendum report revealed superficial invasion of the cortex by squamous cell carcinoma in decalcified sections of bone, although the bone margins were negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive grade 2 squamous carcinoma primarily involving the floor of the mouth and contiguous tongue, with a maximum depth of invasion of 1.8 cm and evidence of peri-neural invasion. Twenty-nine regional lymph nodes from the right neck dissection and thirty-one from the floor of mouth examination show no tumor present, and the resection margins are free of tumor. Additional findings include unremarkable submandibular gland and mild chronic inflammation in the anterior tongue mucosa, with no tumor detected in other examined tissues.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of classical papillary carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid, measuring 1.2 cm, with focal capsular invasion and two additional foci of papillary microcarcinoma in both lobes. The Delphian lymph node, left lower parathyroid, and left paratracheal tissue were all found to be benign, and the surgical margins from the total thyroidectomy were free of tumor. Non-neoplastic findings include nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis in the remaining thyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 6.3 cm, involving the floor of the mouth, lateral oral tongue, and sublingual gland, with extensive vascular and perineural invasion. Additionally, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma was identified in 7 out of 108 regional lymph nodes, with evidence of extracapsular spread. Margins from the surgical resection are reported as uninvolved by tumor, but the anterior floor of mouth tissue edge is involved by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, WHO grade IV, from multiple biopsies of the right parietal brain region, with varying tumor cellularity percentages ranging from 80% to 95% and minimal tumor necrosis. The report suggests that the low percentage of MGMT immunostaining (5%) may indicate a likelihood of responsiveness to Temodar treatment. Additionally, the preserved expression of PTEN, along with the presence of the EGFRvIII mutation, suggests potential responsiveness to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right renal mass diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 2.5 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor, classifying the tumor as pT1. Additionally, the non-neoplastic kidney shows focal myoid metaplasia, and the perinephric adipose tissue is unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that two left axillary sentinel lymph nodes were biopsied and found to be negative for metastatic carcinoma. A segmental mastectomy of the left breast revealed an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 2.2 cm, classified as Nottingham grade 2, with less than 5% ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present. The surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma and DCIS, and the tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, with an equivocal HER-2/NEU score of 2+.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of FIGO II endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with a tumor measuring 2.9 x 2.1 x 0.7 cm, invading 0.4 cm into the myometrium, but not involving the endocervix or lymphovascular spaces. Surgical margins are negative for tumor, and multiple intramural leiomyomata are present, while the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes show no abnormalities. Additionally, all examined right and left pelvic lymph nodes (totaling 42) are negative for tumor involvement.
