The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive adenocarcinoma in the right colon, characterized as moderately to poorly differentiated and invading into pericolonic fat (pT3). The tumor measures 6.5 x 4.4 cm and shows lymphovascular space invasion, but all 25 examined lymph nodes are negative for metastatic disease (pNO). Additionally, an adenomatous polyp was identified in the specimen.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma (Nottingham grade 3) in the right breast, with a tumor size of 2.5 cm and a ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) component comprising approximately 10% of the total tumor volume. Two sentinel lymph nodes were examined, with one node positive for tumor metastasis measuring 0.7 cm, while the other node showed no involvement. The invasive tumor is negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors and has a HER2/NEU score of 1+.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left frontal brain tumor diagnosed as glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV astrocytoma) based on both biopsy and resection specimens. The frozen section analysis confirmed the presence of a malignant glioma, most likely glioblastoma. Two specimens were submitted for examination, both showing characteristics consistent with glioblastoma multiforme.

The pathology report indicates that the sigmoid colon specimen shows moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma invading through the full thickness of the bowel wall into surrounding adipose tissue, with negative margins and no malignancy in the examined lymph nodes. Additionally, a liver biopsy reveals a subcapsular nodule consistent with metastatic colonic adenocarcinoma. There are also multiple hyperplastic and adenomatous polyps identified in the colon away from the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a large, locally advanced, poorly differentiated nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, with significant infiltration into surrounding tissues, including the chest wall and bronchial structures. The tumor exhibits endobronchial growth and has associated lymphatic or hemangioma propagation, while the resection margins and lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor involvement. The overall classification is pT3 pNO L1 or V1, corresponding to stage IIB.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal bilateral papillary thyroid carcinoma, with the dominant tumor measuring 4.5 cm located in the right lobe, and additional smaller tumors identified in the isthmus and left lobe. The midline delphian node biopsy showed no pathological diagnosis, and there was no evidence of capsular invasion, extrathyroidal extension, or lymph node metastasis. The overall pathologic staging is pT3, indicating a tumor greater than 4 cm but limited to the thyroid with no regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 2, in both the left and right ovaries, with metastases identified in multiple sites including the umbilical hernia sac, small bowel, right diaphragm, omentum, and several other locations. The tumor exhibits a predominantly solid structure with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis, and a small subpopulation of tumor cells shows mild overexpression of the HER2/neu oncoprotein. The ventral hernia sac was noted to be free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the left frontal brain tumor is diagnosed as a glioblastoma, characterized by a hypercellular glial neoplasm with small gemistocytes and atypical fibrillary astrocytes. The presence of mitotic figures and areas of necrosis, including pseudopalisading, were noted in the microscopic examination. Additionally, fewer than 10% of the tumor cells showed immunoreactivity for MGMT, primarily in endothelial cells, confirming the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma, grade II, in the right breast lumpectomy specimen, measuring 3.0 cm, with tumor involvement at the lateral and anterior margins and a focus of atypical ductal hyperplasia near the superior margin. The sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, confirming the absence of tumor in both lymph nodes examined. Additionally, the final posterior and anterior/medial margins are free of tumor, with the overall staging classified as pT2 N0 Mx.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of predominantly moderately differentiated bilateral adenocarcinoma of the prostate, classified as Gleason 3+4=7 with a maximum tumor diameter of 1.6 cm, and no infiltration into periprostatic fatty tissue. There is evidence of tumor involvement in a few perineural sheaths, but no blood or lymph vessel invasion, and the surgical margins are tumor-free. Additionally, there are foci of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and signs of myoglandular prostatic hyperplasia, with lymph nodes showing no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 13.5 cm adenocarcinoma in the stomach, specifically a mucosecretor, mucocellular signet-ring carcinoma with diffuse Lauren subtype, which has invaded the serosa and shows focal neural invasion. All surgical margins and lymph nodes examined (0/54) are uninvolved by neoplasia, indicating no metastasis. Additional sites, including the gastro-hepatic ligament, peripancreatic peritoneum, and spleen, are also reported as uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma in the left lung of a Caucasian male patient. The tumor is classified as a primary lung cancer with a histological grade of 3 and a TNM stage of T2 N0 M0. No treatment has been administered at this time, and a blood specimen was also collected for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary renal cell carcinoma, solid variant, Furhman grade III, in the left renal mass and the deep margin, with the tumor being organ confined and measuring at least 3.2 cm. The perinephric fat shows benign fibroadipose tissue, while the completion nephrectomy of the left kidney reveals no definitive tumor, with negative surgical margins. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion, and the report notes that staging is challenging due to specimen disruption.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of a rectal mass was performed following a flexible sigmoidoscopy. The final diagnosis reveals the presence of invasive adenocarcinoma in the rectal tissue. Multiple tissue levels were examined to confirm this diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 68 mm in the left upper lobe, with vascular invasion but clear bronchial and pulmonary artery margins. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma is present in the peribronchial lymph nodes, and the pathological stage is classified as T2 N1. Additionally, there is evidence of focally necrotizing granulomatous inflammation suggestive of atypical Mycobacterial infection.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right paratracheal lymph node, with one lymph node examined and involved by tumor measuring 0.8 cm. The total thyroid specimen reveals a well-differentiated classical type papillary carcinoma in the right lobe, measuring 1.3 cm, with focal capsular invasion but no evidence of vascular or extrathyroid extension. Additional lymph nodes and midline neck tissue were found to be benign, and a papillary microcarcinoma was identified in the left lobe.

The histopathological examination of a resected segment of the sigmoid colon revealed a 5.6 x 6.3 x 1.7 cm tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma that infiltrates the surrounding adipose tissue. The tumor surrounds 100% of the intestinal circumference, but the incision lines are free of neoplastic lesions. The diagnosis is consistent with Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2, pT3, pNO classification for colon adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 40mm poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the head of the pancreas and uncinate process, with evidence of small vessel invasion and perineural invasion. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 2 out of 11 lymph nodes examined, while margins were clear with the closest invasive tumor being 1mm from the portal vein bed and 1.2mm from the periuncinate margin. The overall staging of the tumor is classified as pT3N1, corresponding to stage p2B.

The pathology report indicates a radical mastectomy specimen with a tumor size of 2.2 x 2.2 x 2 cm, identified as infiltrating ductal and lobular carcinoma. Out of 11 lymph nodes examined, 2 showed positive metastasis. The Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined due to unspecified details regarding tumor grading and other histologic features.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, measuring 7.5 cm, with evidence of vascular invasion and tumor necrosis. The tumor exhibits a mixed histologic grade, primarily grade 2 with areas of grade 4 nuclei, and is classified as pT2a with negative resection margins. No regional lymph nodes were submitted for evaluation, and the non-neoplastic kidney tissue appears unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates the presence of high-grade endometrioid adenocarcinoma involving the omentum and uterus, with the tumor located at the uterine fundus and measuring 3.5 cm, classified as FIGO grade 3. The cancer has invaded the outer half of the myometrium but shows no serosal, cervical, or adnexal involvement, while additional sites such as the pelvic gutter and bowel serosa are also affected. The overall AJCC pathologic stage is pT1b pNx pM1, corresponding to FIGO stage IVB, with no lymphovascular space invasion identified.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in two liver segments (I and VIII), with tumor sizes measuring 1.2 cm and 1.7 cm, respectively, and both lesions are free from neoplastic infiltration at the surgical margins. The adjacent hepatic parenchyma shows signs of mild lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate, baloniform degeneration, and severe fibrosis, likely related to B virus infection. Additionally, there is macrovesicular steatosis in about 10% of the neoplastic cells, but significant necrosis and vascular or lymphatic invasion were not detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located at the gastro-esophageal junction, with a tumor size of 4.5 cm. Out of 19 examined lymph nodes, 4 contain tumor involvement. The report notes that the resection was irradical, suggesting incomplete removal of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with the right inferior level and right anterior paratracheal mass both showing metastasis. The report describes a dominant tumor in the right thyroid lobe measuring 6.8 cm, characterized as a diffuse sclerosing variant with lymphovascular invasion but no extrathyroidal extension, while a second tumor in the left lobe measures 2.6 cm and shows minimal extrathyroidal extension. Overall, the findings suggest multifocal papillary thyroid carcinoma with regional lymph node involvement, classified as pT3, pN1a, and no distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type located 2 cm above the dentate line, measuring up to 3 cm in diameter, with extensive infiltration into the perirectal fatty tissue. All regional lymph nodes are tumor-free, and the resection margins are clear, with a minimum distance of 1.5 mm from the tumor to the circumferential resection margin. The tumor is staged as pT3 pNO (0/16) pMX; G2, with no lymphovascular or perineural invasion noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multifocal invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the distal esophagus and proximal stomach, with the largest focus being a basaloid variant measuring 0.6 cm and invading the mid submucosa. Immunohistochemical staining for p16 was negative, and all examined lymph nodes (3) were negative for neoplasm, confirming no distant metastasis. The resection margins are negative, and the diagnosis remains unchanged from previous evaluations.

The pathology report indicates that the right superior parathyroid tissue was identified, and the right thyroid lobe was diagnosed with unifocal papillary carcinoma measuring 1.2 cm. All six examined lymph nodes were negative for tumor, and the primary tumor is classified as pT1b with no regional lymph node metastasis and uninvolved margins. The report was amended to correct the tumor size from 3 cm to 1.2 cm due to a typographical error.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated infiltrating pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma in the neck, body, and tail of the pancreas, with a maximum diameter of 4.2 cm and evidence of invasion into peripancreatic fat and one of twenty examined lymph nodes. The spleen showed no pathological abnormalities, while a pedunculated mass from the posterior wall of the stomach was identified as a benign calcifying fibrous tumor. The tumor in the pancreas exhibits perineural invasion and is classified as pT3, indicating it extends beyond the pancreas without involvement of major vascular structures.

The pathology report indicates that the deep and superficial margins of the tongue excision are negative for tumor, while metastatic squamous cell carcinoma is identified in one of six lymph nodes from the left neck level 2 and one of seven lymph nodes from the right neck level 2. A total laryngectomy specimen reveals a 3.2 cm squamous cell carcinoma in the supraglottis, classified as moderately to poorly differentiated, with metastasis found in 2 of 48 lymph nodes and margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. The tumor invades the preepiglottis, and there is evidence of venous/lymphatic invasion, but no perineural invasion is noted.

The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma measuring 6.5 x 2.5 cm in the laryngeal pharyngectomy specimen, with metastatic carcinoma found in 4 of 29 lymph nodes. The esophageal margin shows focal mild dysplasia, while the superior laryngeal nerve and superior pharyngeal margin are free of tumor and severe dysplasia. Additionally, the report includes a gross examination of five unremarkable teeth, which does not contribute to the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates that multiple lymph nodes excised during surgery are negative for metastatic carcinoma, with one lymph node showing fragments of adenocarcinoma. A right upper lobe lobectomy revealed a mixed subtype adenocarcinoma measuring 6.3 cm, with perineural and visceral pleural invasion, but negative resection margins. Additionally, a skin excision showed seborrheic keratosis, and the overall findings suggest localized lung cancer with limited lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that a biopsy of the uterus and cervix reveals moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The diagnosis is confirmed through microscopic examination of the slides. The patient is a woman of unspecified age.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma arising in Barrett's mucosa, with the tumor invading the submucosa but not extending through the muscularis propria. The surgical margins are negative for malignancy, and all examined lymph nodes are negative for metastasis. The TNM classification is T1 N0 Mx, indicating early-stage esophageal cancer.

The pathology report indicates the presence of acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 8 (4+4) and evidence of extra-prostatic extension and seminal vesicle invasion. Surgical margins are involved by invasive carcinoma, and lymphovascular and perineural invasion are also noted. In the lymph nodes examined, one out of four left obturator nodes showed metastasis, while none of the right obturator nodes were involved.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with 10 out of 26 examined nodes showing metastasis, including significant involvement in the right neck levels II, III, and IV, as well as the central compartment. The thyroid gland exhibits multifocal papillary carcinoma, with the dominant tumor measuring 3.0 cm and showing widely invasive characteristics, while a smaller microcarcinoma is also noted in the left lobe. Additional findings include focal nonspecific thyroiditis and mild reactive C-cell hyperplasia, with all surgical margins remaining uninvolved by carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple renal tumors in the left kidney, with a total of eight tumors diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma of the chromophobe type and two tumors identified as clear cell renal cell carcinoma with Fuhrman nuclear grade II/III. The tumors were assessed through partial nephrectomy, revealing significant involvement of the left kidney with minimal normal parenchyma remaining. Immunoperoxidase and in-situ hybridization tests were utilized for diagnosis, although they have not been cleared or approved by the FDA.

The pathology report indicates the presence of squamous cell carcinoma with focal sarcomatoid features and necrosis in the hypopharynx, measuring 8.5 cm, with moderate to poorly differentiated histologic grade. Metastatic carcinoma was found in 2 out of 25 ipsilateral lymph nodes, specifically in level 2, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 4 cm and evidence of extranodal extension. Additionally, invasive carcinoma was noted to involve the inked right superior margin, with perineural invasion present and lymphocytic thyroiditis observed.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, clear cell subtype, with a tumor size of 6.2 cm and a histologic grade of 2 (Fuhrman classification). The tumor has invaded through the capsule into perirenal fat and shows vascular invasion in the renal vein, but surgical margins are not involved, and no carcinoma was identified in the adrenal gland. The AJCC staging is pT3a pNx pMx, reflecting the extent of the disease at the time of the report.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma with focal poorly differentiated areas in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 2.4 cm, with extrathyroidal extension into skeletal muscle and lymphovascular invasion present. One of four lateral paratracheal lymph nodes showed metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, while the medial paratracheal dissection revealed three lymph nodes negative for tumor. Additionally, the cricoid thyroid muscle was atrophic but negative for tumor, and parathyroid tissue was present in the right inferior parathyroid.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type in resected colon material, located 3 cm from the resection margin. The tumor has infiltrated the pericolic fatty tissue and shows circumscribed penetration of the serosa, with 23 local lymph node metastases identified. The tumor classification is pT4, pN2 (23/29), pMX; G3, L1, V1, R1, with tumor-free resection margins.

The pathology report indicates that the specimen from a right insular tumor is consistent with a low-grade astrocytoma (WHO Grade 2), characterized by mildly hypercellular glial tissue with mild nuclear atypia and the presence of microgemistocytes. Although the features suggest some characteristics of oligodendroglioma, no definitive diagnosis can be made, and further genetic testing for 1p/19q deletion is recommended. Ki67 staining shows a low proliferation index of approximately 2%, and there are no observed mitoses or necrosis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately to poorly differentiated pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma in the distal pancreas, measuring 4.2 x 3.1 cm, with invasion into peripancreatic adipose tissue and the vascular wall of the splenic vein. One out of seventeen peripapancreatic lymph nodes showed metastatic carcinoma, while both the proximal pancreatic and retroperitoneal margins were negative for tumor. Additionally, an epigastric hernia was excised, revealing no tumor in the adipose tissue containing lymphoid tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular breast carcinoma, classical variant (Grade II), with a tumor size of 3 cm and extensive skin infiltration but no ulceration. The tumor is classified as pT2pN0(0/10), positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, and negative for C-erb B-2 oncoprotein. Follow-up findings confirm that there is no metastatic infiltration or individual cell presence of the carcinoma in the excised axillary lymph node, affirming the pN0 status.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a partial nephrectomy for a right renal mass, which was diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma, Type 1, with extensive necrosis and hemorrhage, measuring 4.6 cm. The surgical margins were negative for tumor, and no regional lymph node metastasis was identified. Additional specimens from the right paracaval mass and right hilar lymph node showed no tumor presence, confirming the localized nature of the cancer.

The pathology report indicates a 2.5 cm mid esophageal tumor diagnosed as invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with invasion into the adventitia but free margins. There is no evidence of carcinoma in the examined lymph nodes, with a total of three benign nodes identified. The frozen section analysis confirmed the absence of carcinoma at the proximal and distal margins, and there is no indication of preoperative chemotherapy or radiation therapy.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive, moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, measuring up to 12 cm in diameter, with extensive infiltration into peripancreatic fatty tissue and the submucosa of the small intestine. There are six lymph node metastases identified out of 21 examined lymph nodes, and the resection margins at the dorsal side and truncus coeliacus are involved with tumor, indicating an R1 resection status. The tumor exhibits features of high-grade PanIN lesions and shows lymphovascular and perineural invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, characterized by keratinization and necrosis. Due to tissue fragmentation and lack of orientation, the depth of invasion could not be assessed. The specimen consisted of five irregular, slightly nodular fragments of red tissue obtained from a cervical biopsy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma, grade 3.4, measuring 8.2 cm, confined to the right kidney without invasion of surrounding tissues or lymphovascular involvement. The surgical margins, including the ureter and renal vessels, are negative for malignancy, and the adrenal gland shows no pathological findings.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, measuring 3.0 cm, which invades the muscularis propria but has negative surgical margins and no evidence of lymph node involvement (0/18). The tumor is staged as pT2, pNO, and classified as pathologic stage IB, with no lymphovascular invasion identified. Additional findings include chronic cholecystitis and a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) in the muscularis propria, with no Helicobacter organisms detected.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of choroidal melanoma, predominantly of the epithelioid type, with a base measuring 20 mm and focal choroidal invasion present. The tumor surrounds the optic nerve but shows no extraocular extension, and the vortex veins are negative for tumor involvement. Additionally, the tumor has eroded Bruch's membrane, with a mitotic rate of 2 per 10 high power fields.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 3, measuring 2.1 cm, with associated ductal carcinoma in situ constituting 5% of the tumor volume. The resection margins are negative for carcinoma, with the closest invasive carcinoma being 1.5 mm from the anterior margin, and no lymphovascular invasion noted. The tumor is hormone receptor positive (ER and PR) and weakly positive for HER2/NEU, with one sentinel lymph node biopsy showing no metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent an oesophagectomy due to oesophageal adenocarcinoma, which is moderately differentiated and has a depth of invasion classified as T3, extending beyond the muscularis propria but not involving the circumferential margin. Out of 24 examined lymph nodes, 12 were positive for metastatic disease, indicating lymphovascular and perineural invasion. The pathological staging is classified as TNM 6 T3 N1 Mx and TNM 7 T3 N3 Mx, with no evidence of invasive malignancy found in the splenic, subcarinal, and right crus lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, specifically the papillary type, with a tumor size of 5.8 cm and local invasion into the renal sinus fat, but no renal vein invasion. The left adrenal gland is not involved, and while one of the nine examined para-aortic lymph nodes shows metastasis, the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additional specimens from the distal left ureter and other lymph nodes are benign, confirming the presence of metastatic disease in the lymphatic system.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a salvage cystectomy with ileal conduit, revealing invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder, specifically a nuclear grade 3/4 tumor measuring 4 x 4 x 1.8 cm, with a separate focus of high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma. Both distal ureters were diagnosed with hydroureter and showed no evidence of urothelial dysplasia or malignancy, while all examined lymph nodes (13 total) were free of malignancy. The final pathological staging is pT3b, indicating stage III bladder cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total thyroidectomy due to a diagnosis of papillary thyroid cancer, revealing two foci of well-differentiated microcarcinoma in the left and right lobes of the thyroid. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes and the left lower parathyroid gland were found to be benign, with no evidence of tumor invasion or necrosis. The remaining thyroid tissue exhibited chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, and surgical margins were free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has two areas of invasive lobular carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 2.8 cm and 1.8 cm, with a total score of 6 out of 9, classified as Grade 2. Extensive lobular carcinoma in situ is also present, and while there is no evidence of angiolymphatic invasion or skin and nipple involvement, the deep margin of excision is involved by carcinoma. Additionally, one axillary lymph node shows metastatic carcinoma measuring 0.4 cm, with no extracapsular extension noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma located in the head of the pancreas, measuring 2.7 cm, with focal infiltration into peripancreatic fat. Surgical margins are negative for malignancy, and no regional lymph nodes (0/18) show evidence of metastasis, resulting in a pathologic stage of pT3 N0. Additionally, perineural invasion is present, while angiolymphatic invasion is absent, and there are findings of chronic pancreatitis.

The pathology report indicates that the omental mass excised consists of mature adipose tissue without atypia. The radical resection of the right kidney, right adrenal gland, and associated soft tissue mass reveals a dedifferentiated liposarcoma, which is a malignant tumor that has areas of necrosis, fibrosis, and calcification, with the dedifferentiated component comprising 30% of the tumor. The tumor encases the kidney and adrenal gland but does not invade them, and the surgical margins are clear of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, grade IV, based on a biopsy of a brain tumor. The tumor exhibits highly cellular neoplastic astrocytes, extensive microvascular proliferation, and areas of necrosis. The specimen consisted of five soft, irregularly shaped tissue fragments, and the diagnosis was confirmed through gross and microscopic examinations by the attending pathologist.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 7.3 cm and a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2. There is no evidence of tumor invasion into surrounding structures, including perirenal adipose tissue, Gerota's fascia, and the ureter, with surgical margins also negative for tumor. The AJCC staging is pT2a pNx, and the report notes mild to moderate arterionephrosclerosis in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue.

The pathology report indicates that a right adrenal mass was excised and diagnosed as a pheochromocytoma. The specimen measured 7 x 5 x 4 cm and was described as a soft, tan, well-circumscribed nodule with a homogeneous cut surface and no apparent hemorrhage. The tumor was processed for further examination, with representative sections submitted for permanent processing.

The pathology report indicates that the excised peritumor fat contains benign adipose tissue with no neoplastic process, and the biopsy of the posterior margin shows no tumor. The right kidney partial nephrectomy reveals a unifocal renal cell carcinoma of the papillary subtype, measuring 4.0 cm, with foci of transgression of the renal capsule and a nuclear grade of 2/4, but no lymphovascular invasion or sarcomatoid features. The tumor is staged as pTNM T3a, with tumor present at the inked capsular surface but not at the surgical margin.

The pathology report indicates the presence of multiple malignancies, including a clear cell adenocarcinoma in a sigmoid nodule and a malignant mixed Mllerian tumor of the endometrium with extensive lymphovascular invasion and cervical stromal involvement. The report also notes that the tumor has invaded the myometrium and serosa, with a pathological stage of pT3 pN2 Mx, and positive metastatic findings in several lymph nodes. Additional findings include adenocarcinomas in other excised nodules and omental tissue, with a total of three positive lymph nodes out of seven examined.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of mixed lymphoepithelial thymoma (type AB) with prominent cyst formation in the thymus gland, measuring approximately 4.2 x 3 cm. The tumor is located close to the inked margins of resection, but the margins are histologically clear, and the background tissue is unremarkable atrophic thymic tissue. Flow cytometry reveals a benign, T-cell dominant lymphoid population with no antigenic aberrancies, and the minority B-cell population is polyclonal.

The pathology report indicates that a 1.5 x 0 x 2 cm excised skin lesion from the trunk is diagnosed as malignant melanoma with ulcerated and pigmented features. The Breslow's depth is measured at 10 mm, and the margins are uninvolved, suggesting complete excision. There is no evidence of venous invasion, while details regarding lymphatic invasion and lymph nodes are not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma in the left kidney, with a tumor size of 14 cm and microscopic invasion into the perirenal adipose tissue, while the renal sinus, major veins, and ureter are not involved. The tumor is noted to extend to the adrenal gland and is classified as pT2b, with surgical margins being very close to the tumor. Additional testing revealed MDM2 gene amplification, suggesting potential lipocytic differentiation of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of high-grade renal cell carcinoma, specifically papillary type II, measuring 6.7 cm, with invasion into the perirenal fat and evidence of vein invasion. Additional specimens from the left kidney, hilum, diaphragm, and ureter showed no tumor in most tissues, except for the hilum which contained fatty tissue with high-grade carcinoma. Immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, with the tumor cells showing a specific staining profile consistent with this type of cancer.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma (not otherwise specified) in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 4.8 x 4.2 x 3.8 cm, classified as pT2a, with no regional lymph node involvement (0/23) and a grade of G3. Supplementary examination revealed a positive EGFR mutation, specifically p.L856R (c.2573T>G). The tumor dimensions and characteristics suggest a significant malignancy with specific genetic alterations.

The pathology report indicates that the right sentinel lymph node shows no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, confirming the frozen section diagnosis with negative pancytokeratin staining. The right breast mastectomy reveals multiple areas of invasive papillary carcinoma, with the largest area measuring 3 cm and a total score of 4 out of 9, indicating grade 1 carcinoma. Additional findings include in situ and invasive papillary carcinoma in other quadrants, with no skin or nipple involvement and clear deep margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the sigmoid colon, measuring 2.8 cm in length and 6.5 cm in width, with invasion into subserosal adipose tissue but no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and no regional lymph node metastasis was identified among the 21 examined lymph nodes. Additional specimens from the proximal and distal rings show colonic mucosa with hyperplastic features but no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the retroperitoneum and sigmoid colon, with the tumor measuring 17 cm and showing areas of necrosis (20%). The tumor invades retroperitoneal and pericolonic fat and extends focally to the inked surgical margins. The specimen was well-demarcated and encapsulated, with the sigmoid colon appearing grossly unremarkable.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a right frontal lobe mass diagnosed as an oligodendroglioma, classified as WHO grade II/III, with a low proliferation index of 2% to 4%. The tumor exhibits loss of heterozygosity on chromosome arms 1p and 19q, which is characteristic of oligodendrogliomas and suggests a favorable response to chemotherapy. Additionally, the presence of a methylated MGMT promoter was detected, indicating potential benefit from alkylating agent therapy.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, specifically the conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV and a tumor size of 2.5 cm. There is no evidence of local invasion or renal vein invasion, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT1, indicating it is limited to the kidney and measures less than 7.0 cm in greatest dimension.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent enucleation of the right eye, revealing a malignant melanoma of the spindle cell type, measuring 1.9 x 1.0 cm, with focal invasion into the sclera but no extrascleral extension or involvement of the optic nerve. The optic nerve margin was negative for tumor, and the tumor was primarily located in the choroid. The report complies with cancer staging protocols, confirming the diagnosis of uveal melanoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of low-grade invasive adenocarcinoma in the right colon, specifically a 3.8 x 2.6 x 0.8 cm tumor located at the cecum, which has penetrated into the muscularis propria but does not extend to the serosal surface. All surgical margins are free of tumor, and 23 examined lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy. Additionally, a submucosal lipoma and tattoo pigment were identified, with no prior treatment noted for the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of transitional cell carcinoma from a bladder tissue sample obtained through radical cystoprostatectomy. The tumor measures 8 cm, is classified as grade III, and is staged as pathological T4 with N1 involvement, while clinical M is M0. Histological examination reveals 90% tumor presence with no necrosis noted.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal papillary renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney, with three distinct masses measuring 1.5 cm, 3.8 cm, and 2.5 cm, all graded as histologic grade 3. There is no evidence of capsular invasion or perirenal adipose tissue invasion in any of the masses, but the renal parenchymal margin from the anterior mass is positive, while the posterior medial and posterior lateral masses have negative margins. The overall staging is prT1a, pNx, and the patient has a history of renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive, poorly differentiated sigmoid colon carcinoma (G3) with penetration through all parietal layers (pT3) and evidence of vascular infiltration (L1, V1). The resection margins in both the mucosa and deep circumferential areas are reported as free of tumor. The tumor classification is ICDO-DA M8140/3, with a nodal involvement of pN1 (2 of 13 positive lymph nodes), and it is locally classified as R0.

The pathology report indicates a left lower pole renal mass diagnosed as papillary renal cell carcinoma, Type II, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 2. The tumor measures 1.8 cm and is well-circumscribed, limited to the kidney without evidence of necrosis or lymph-vascular invasion, and the surgical margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Additional findings include chronic inflammation in the nonneoplastic kidney, and a representative portion of the tumor has been submitted for tissue banking.

The final pathologic diagnosis from the thymectomy is a thymoma classified as WHO histologic type B2, with clear margins indicating no residual tumor. A small amount of normal thymic tissue was found adjacent to the tumor, and three examined lymph nodes were benign (0/3). The specimen measured 14 x 9 x 3 cm, with a well-defined, predominantly homogeneous mass measuring 4.3 x 3.5 x 2.8 cm, and no necrosis was observed.

The pathology report indicates that the left and right pelvic lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy, with a total of five lymph nodes examined and all being negative. The prostate biopsy reveals poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9, indicating significant tumor involvement with extraprostatic extension and bilateral seminal vesicle invasion. The hernia sac specimen is reported as mesothelial lined fibrous tissue, consistent with a hernia sac, and no additional pathologic findings were noted.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a left adrenalectomy, revealing a well-differentiated adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) measuring 12x11x12 cm and weighing 641 g. The tumor is classified as grade 1, with a Weiss score of 3, and there is evidence of lymph node involvement (1 out of 1). The overall staging is T2N1Mx, indicating the tumor's size and lymph node status.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph nodes excised (1 and 2) show no evidence of carcinoma. The left breast partial mastectomy reveals invasive ductal carcinoma (2.1 cm, SBR grade 2), ductal carcinoma in situ (1 cm), lobular carcinoma in situ, and atypical ductal hyperplasia involving a fibroadenoma. Lymph node status is negative for carcinoma, and the tumor exhibits lymphatic-vascular invasion, with negative resection margins for the invasive tumor and ductal carcinoma in situ.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma, grade II, characterized by a moderately hypercellular and diffusely infiltrating glial neoplasm. The tumor exhibits moderate atypia with round nuclei and a labeling index of 4.2% for MIB-1 reactive cells, suggesting a low level of proliferation. Notably, there are no mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis observed in the examined sections.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO Grade III, with some areas exhibiting features of Grade II. Molecular studies revealed loss of heterozygosity on chromosome 19q, but not on 1p, ruling out the 1p/19q codeletion typically associated with oligodendrogliomas. The tumor exhibits significant cellularity, nuclear atypia, and mitotic activity consistent with a Grade III lesion, and various tissue samples were analyzed, all showing infiltrating glioma characteristics.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 3, with a maximum tumor size of 2.1 cm and superficial myometrial invasion, but no cervical involvement or lymph node metastasis. The report also notes the presence of a benign Brenner tumor in the right ovary and multiple leiomyomata in the myometrium, with all examined lymph nodes being negative for carcinoma. Overall, the findings suggest a localized malignancy with no evidence of metastatic spread at the time of evaluation.

The pathology report indicates that the sentinel lymph node from the right axilla is reactive with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The wide local excision of the right breast reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 2.3 cm, with negative margins and associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present at a low quantity. The Oncotype DX assay shows a low recurrence score of 10, suggesting a low risk of distant recurrence over ten years.

The pathology report indicates an excised tumor from the antrum of the stomach, measuring 7.5 x 6 x 1 cm, which is ulcerated and diagnosed as poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/11 positive). Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasion, as well as margins and neo-adjuvant treatment, were not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade III) from a biopsy of a right frontal lobe brain lesion. The tumor exhibits a high mitotic rate and focal microvascular proliferation, with further chromosome analysis pending. The specimens submitted included multiple fragments of soft tissue, with varying sizes and descriptions, confirming the presence of a high-grade glioma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, with a well-differentiated nuclear grade and a component of colloid carcinoma representing less than 25% of the tumor volume. Additionally, three out of fourteen axillary lymph nodes contain metastatic carcinoma, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 1.8 x 1.1 cm, but all surgical margins are free of tumor. The report also notes that there is no tumor present in the skin, nipple, or lactiferous duct.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has metastatic lobular carcinoma in the right axillary sentinel lymph nodes, with node #1 showing over 200 metastatic cells and node #2 showing fewer than 200 cells, while nodes #3 and #4 are negative for metastasis. The right breast mastectomy revealed both in situ and invasive lobular carcinoma, with the invasive component measuring up to 7 cm and classified as Bloom-Richardson grade II, with negative surgical margins and no angiolymphatic invasion. The overall pTNM staging is T3N1 (mi), and additional prognostic marker evaluations are pending.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous adenocarcinoma in the right ovary, measuring 5.5 x 5 x 4.2 cm, with involvement of the serosa and metastasis to the omentum. Additionally, extensive endometrioid adenocarcinoma is noted in the left ovary and extensive tumor involvement in the uterus, which also shows signs of adenomyosis. The right and left fallopian tubes are free of tumor, and the overall pathologic stage is classified as pT3c pNx pMX.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive moderately-differentiated adenocarcinoma of the gastroesophageal junction, characterized by a significant polypoid mass and invasion into surrounding tissues, with angiolymphatic space invasion and metastasis to two paraesophageal lymph nodes. Additionally, a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) was identified in the stomach, while other examined tissues, including anastomosis rings and additional gastric portions, were negative for malignancy. The final staging of the cancer is classified as pT3N1M0, indicating a stage IIIA disease with no distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left renal cell carcinoma, papillary type, with a tumor measuring 13.0 cm that extends through the renal capsule but is confined within Gerota's fascia, with all surgical margins free of tumor. The left and right fallopian tubes and ovaries are unremarkable, showing only paratubal cysts, while the spleen reveals hemorrhagic and non-caseating granulomas without any tumor involvement. This report is an amendment to a previous diagnosis, providing updated findings based on further examination of the specimens.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of type 2 papillary renal cell carcinoma with Fuhrman's nuclear grade 3, confined to the kidney and measuring 4.5 cm, with resection margins free of tumor. Additionally, a second specimen from the left partial nephrectomy shows renal parenchyma with focal glomerulosclerosis, and an adrenal biopsy reveals adrenal cortical tissue with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma. Overall, there are no changes in the diagnosis from the original report, and correlation with clinical findings is suggested.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 3) in the uterus, along with findings of immature squamous metaplasia, chronic inflammation, endocervical polyp, and endometriosis involving deep cervical soft tissue. No carcinoma was identified in any of the examined lymph nodes (28 total), and there were also benign findings such as leiomyoma and endosalpingiosis. The overall pathologic stage of the tumor is classified as T1a/N0/MX, suggesting it is limited to the endometrium without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic carcinoma in one of the left axillary sentinel lymph nodes, while the remaining lymph nodes excised showed no tumor involvement. Additionally, a total mastectomy revealed invasive ductal carcinoma, modified Black's nuclear grade 3, with two separate nodules measuring 1.8 cm and 0.5 cm, and negative resection margins. Lymphovascular invasion was identified, but ductal carcinoma in situ was present in less than 5% of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated basaloid type squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.5 cm in the right upper lobe, which invades the visceral pleura but not the pericardium, with all resection margins free of tumor. No malignancy was detected in any of the examined lymph nodes (0/7), and there is no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. The tumor is staged as pT2, pNO, pMX, indicating localized disease without regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of left kidney renal cell carcinoma, characterized by a tumor composed of 50% clear cells and 50% eosinophilic cells, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4, extending into perinephric and renal sinus adipose tissue, as well as the renal vein, and showing vascular lymphatic invasion. A biopsy of a left liver mass shows hepatic parenchyma with adjacent fibrosis but no definitive evidence of metastatic carcinoma, suggesting further evaluation may be necessary. Additionally, metastatic renal cell carcinoma is identified in the left adrenal gland, while the spleen and hilar lymph node show no tumor presence.

The pathology report indicates that a portion of the left lobe of the liver was resected and diagnosed with moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, measuring 4.5 x 4.4 cm, with minimal necrosis and no perineural or angiolymphatic invasion. Additionally, a portal hepatic lymph node was excised, showing reactive changes without evidence of malignancy. The overall pathological stage is classified as T1 N0 Mx, indicating localized disease without lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the distal esophagus, invading the muscularis propria, with metastatic adenocarcinoma identified in 2 out of 18 examined lymph nodes. Additionally, two lymph nodes exhibited features consistent with hyalinized granulomas, while the remaining lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma. The resection margins for the esophagus and proximal stomach were negative for carcinoma, suggesting no residual disease at the surgical margins.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of vasculo-invasive oncocytic papillary carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, measuring 6.1 cm, with capsular invasion absent and margins uninvolved by carcinoma. The tumor is classified as pT3, indicating it is larger than 4 cm but limited to the thyroid without regional lymph node metastasis, as no lymph nodes were involved. Additional findings show no distant metastasis can be assessed, and no other significant pathologic findings were identified.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a left renal mass diagnosed as chromophobe renal cell carcinoma, measuring 12.5 cm, with local invasion into the renal sinus fat but no renal vein invasion. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and examination of lymph nodes from the left periaortic and left hilar regions shows no evidence of metastasis. The overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is pT3a, indicating invasion into perinephric tissues but not beyond Gerota's fascia.

The pathology report indicates a 4.5 x 5 x 1.2 cm undifferentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, with tumor extension to the greater omentum. There is no evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes (0/4 positive). Additional details regarding lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion, as well as margins and neo-adjuvant treatment, were not specified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma, most consistent with squamous cell carcinoma, located in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 3.5 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm. All examined lymph nodes (totaling 11) and bronchial margins were negative for carcinoma, indicating no lymphatic spread. Additionally, the report notes the presence of interstitial fibrosis and organizing pneumonia in the adjacent lung tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the left breast, classified as Nottingham grade III, with a tumor size of 1.8 x 1.5 x 1.5 cm and evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, with a minimum tumor-free margin of 0.5 cm, but multiple lymph nodes (5 out of 14) in the left axilla are positive for metastatic carcinoma with extranodal extension. Non-neoplastic breast tissue shows nonproliferative fibrocystic changes, and there are changes consistent with a prior core biopsy site.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic classical variant papillary thyroid carcinoma in multiple lymph nodes, with 7 of 41 nodes involved in the right neck dissection and additional involvement in the right paratracheal and Delphian lymph nodes. The total thyroidectomy specimen reveals multifocal papillary carcinoma, predominantly a widely invasive classical variant with focal tall cell change, alongside a mixed follicular and classical variant papillary carcinoma. Additional findings include mild reactive C-cell hyperplasia and a simple epithelial cyst in the parathyroid gland, with no evidence of distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates that a specimen was sent to the Biospecimen Core Resource (BCR) from the NCH for analysis. It requires the completion of the TCGA Missing Pathology Report Form due to the absence of a detailed pathology report. Additionally, it requests specific tumor type and histology codes for proper classification and quality control.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of pure seminoma in the left testicle following a radical orchiectomy, with tumor extension into the epididymis, base of the spermatic cord, and peri-testicular adipose tissue. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, but lymphatic and vascular invasion is present, leading to a pathologic staging of pT3NXM0, classified as stage I. No distant metastasis is noted, and serum tumor markers were not available for assessment.

The pathology report indicates that both the left and right pelvic lymph nodes are negative for adenocarcinoma, with no evidence of tumor in three left lymph nodes and ten right lymph nodes. The prostate biopsy reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4 + 3, confined to the prostate and involving 5% of the tissue, with negative margins. Overall, the pathological staging is T2c, N0, Mx, and no other significant findings were identified.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive adenocarcinoma with mucinous features located in the cecum, moderately differentiated, with a depth of invasion through the muscularis propria into pericolic soft tissue. Lymphovascular and perineural invasion were not identified, and the tumor has negative margins with one regional lymph node showing metastasis out of 19 examined. Additional findings include focal abscess formation adjacent to the tumor, and enlarged lymph nodes that were reactive without evidence of lymphoma.

The pathology report indicates that the pre-laryngeal lymph node examined is benign, with no evidence of malignancy. The total thyroid specimen reveals a diagnosis of papillary thyroid microcarcinoma, well differentiated, located in the left lobe with a size of 0.9 cm, and shows no signs of vascular invasion or extrathyroid extension. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and there is evidence of nodular hyperplasia in the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 2 renal cell carcinoma, papillary cell type, in the right kidney, with a tumor mass measuring 2 x 1.8 x 1.8 cm. The tumor is confined to the kidney, showing no coagulative necrosis or sarcomatoid differentiation. Surgical margins are noted to be very focally positive.

The final diagnosis indicates a malignant small cell glioma in the medial temporal lobe, consistent with derivation from small cell glioblastoma multiforme, accompanied by extensive coagulative necrosis and perivenular inflammation. An addendum reveals that no EGFR alterations were detected in the tumor tissue, and fluorescence in situ hybridization showed loss of chromosome 1p while preserving chromosome 19q. Additionally, mild white matter hypercellularity was noted in the temporal tip, consistent with infiltrating glioma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of extensively ulcerated, poorly differentiated gastric adenocarcinoma measuring 6.5 cm, located in the cardia area and infiltrating the surrounding fatty tissue, with evidence of lymphangitis. There are no cancerous cells found in the regional lymph nodes, and both the oral and aboral resection margins are free of tumor involvement. The tumor is classified as pT2b, with no regional lymph node involvement (pNO) and unknown distant metastasis (pMX).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of glioblastoma in a left temporal mass. The specimen exhibits marked hypercellularity, atypical fibrillary astrocyte-like tumor cells, microvascular proliferation, and multifocal necrosis. Scattered mitotic figures are noted, confirming the aggressive nature of the tumor.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma in the right ovary, with metastatic involvement in the left ovary, fallopian tube, appendix, and omentum. The uterus shows mild inflammation and the presence of leiomyomas and adenomyosis, but no evidence of endometrial carcinoma. The tumor is classified as T3a, IIIC, indicating significant peritoneal metastasis beyond the true pelvis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in the lymph nodes, with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and multifocal involvement. Immunohistochemical staining shows positive reactions for CD45, CD20, and CD30 in some tumor cells, while CD3 is negative in the tumor cells. There is no evidence of venous invasion, and the margins are uninvolved, but there is extranodal involvement in the liver and spleen.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the liver, specifically in segment six, with a tumor size of approximately 19.0 centimeters and multiple nodular masses. The carcinoma is noted to be at the inked surgical resection margin, but there is no evidence of intravascular invasion or perineural invasion. Additionally, a biopsy of a left lateral segment nodule also confirmed the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a biopsy of a left frontal brain lesion diagnosed as a low-grade oligoastrocytoma (WHO grade II). Special stains show low labeling indices for MIB-1/Ki67 and p53, with a subset of tumor cells positive for GFAP. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) studies for 1p/19q deletions are pending on the paraffin sections.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with focal sarcomatoid features and significant necrosis, classified as Fuhrman Nuclear Grade IV. The tumor measures 7.5 cm and extends into the renal pelvis, but there is no evidence of renal vein invasion or small vessel angiolymphatic invasion, with surgical margins free of tumor. The tumor is staged as pT2, and immunohistochemical staining supports the diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 2.0 cm in segment 6 of the liver, with surrounding liver showing bridging fibrosis classified as stage 3. The tumor is solitary, without vascular invasion, and the parenchymal margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, with a distance of 12 mm from the closest margin. The report notes that regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed, and distant metastasis cannot be evaluated.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a mixed malignant mesodermal tumor (MMMT) in the uterus, characterized by high-grade serous carcinoma and rhabdomyosarcomatous differentiation, with invasion into the myometrium and lymphovascular space involvement. Additionally, metastatic carcinoma is identified in the bilateral ovaries, omentum, appendix, rectal serosa, and pelvic peritoneum, with positive involvement in regional lymph nodes. The overall pathologic stage of the tumor is classified as pT4/N1/M1, indicating advanced disease with distant metastasis.

The pathology report indicates the presence of squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, measuring 2.8 cm, with carcinoma in situ identified at the bronchial margin of the right middle lobe. Multiple lymph nodes examined were reactive, with no evidence of metastatic involvement. All surgical margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, although the bronchial margin was involved by carcinoma in situ.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma involving the left false vocal cords, left pyriform sinus, left epiglottis, and extending to the left aryepiglottic fold, with a tumor size of 5.5 cm and a depth of invasion of 2.0 cm. The surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma, although mild dysplasia is noted at the tracheal margin. Additionally, all examined lymph nodes from both neck dissections and the right paratracheal lymph nodes show no evidence of tumor involvement.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+5=9, characterized as multifocal and involving both lobes of the prostate, with a dominant nodule measuring 2.5 cm. The tumor exhibits extraprostatic extension and seminal vesicle invasion, while lymphovascular invasion is not identified, and the surgical margins are negative, with the closest margin at 0.07 cm. The pathologic tumor staging is classified as pT3b, indicating invasion of the seminal vesicle, and the overall pathologic stage is III.

The pathology report indicates a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate measuring 2.8 cm, with significant perineural growth and infiltration into the periprostatic connective tissue, but with tumor-free seminal vesicles and ducts. All examined lymph nodes are tumor-free, and carcinoma infiltrates are noted in both the peripheral and transitional zones, predominantly on the right side. The tumor classification is pT3a, pN0 (0/9), with a Gleason score of 4+4=8 and a tertiary Gleason score of 3, and further evaluation for possible neuroendocrine differentiation is pending.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of II/IV and a tumor size of 5.5 cm. There is direct invasion of the renal vein, but no evidence of invasion into the renal sinus or perinephric adipose tissue, and all surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, ureteritis cystica is present, and the adrenal gland was not identified, with a pathologic stage of pT3b NX MX.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with a tumor diameter of 3.5 cm and focal intraductal patterns of spread. The tumor classification is noted as NOS, grade III, with a staging of pT2N1aLOV0RX. This suggests a moderate to high-grade malignancy with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates that the right breast lumpectomy revealed invasive ductal carcinoma with a tumor size of 2.4 cm, while all examined sentinel lymph nodes (five in total) were benign, showing no evidence of metastasis. The tumor margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, with the closest margin measuring 1.3 cm. Additionally, the report noted the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ and lobular carcinoma in situ, with a histologic grade of 3 for the invasive ductal carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that all excised lymph nodes from various levels are negative for malignancy. However, a squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated, was identified in the right middle lobe of the lung, measuring 3.5 cm, with vascular invasion present but no pleural involvement. The bronchial margin was negative for carcinoma, and there is no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report describes a 3x2.5x2.2 cm invasive tumor located in the head of the pancreas, characterized as a moderately differentiated mucinous non-cystic adenocarcinoma. Microscopic examination reveals papillary and dilated glands with mucin, irregularly enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei, and evidence of invasion into surrounding fat and duodenal tissue. The tumor exhibits a desmoplastic stroma with lymphocytic infiltration and a notable mitotic index, indicating aggressive behavior.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a Da Vinci prostatectomy, with the final diagnosis confirming the presence of prostate adenocarcinoma, classified with a Gleason score of 6 (3 + 3). The tumor was multifocal, with the largest focus measuring 21 mm located in the right posterior lobe, and there was evidence of cancer being less than 1 mm from the right surgical margin. No extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle invasion was noted, and additional findings included nodular hyperplasia of glands and stroma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a 2.00 cm adenocarcinoma located in the right upper lobe (RUL) of the lung. The tumor is classified as T2, with no regional lymph node involvement (N0) and no distant metastasis (M0), suggesting an early stage of cancer. The histological differentiation is noted, and the sample was prepared for further analysis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of metastatic papillary serous carcinoma in multiple specimens, including the omentum, tumors adjacent to various organs, and the sigmoid colon. Additionally, the right adnexa mass shows moderately differentiated papillary serous carcinoma involving the ovarian hilum and surface, with tumor present in the fallopian tube lumen. The findings suggest a primary peritoneal carcinoma, consistent with the clinical diagnosis of ovarian cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the patient, a male with phase 2 distal esophageal adenocarcinoma, underwent an esophagectomy without prior radiation therapy. A 2.0 x 1.3 x 1.2 cm granular, ulcerative tumor was identified at the esophageal-gastric junction, with a maximum depth of invasion into the adventitia and one positive lymph node out of fifteen examined. The resection margins were negative for carcinoma, suggesting no residual cancer at the surgical edges.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma in the left occipital lobe, characterized by a proliferation of oligodendrocytes with varying degrees of cellularity and cytological atypia. The tumor exhibits high cellularity, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic activity, with some areas showing well-differentiated features, while others demonstrate significant anaplasia. Immunostaining reveals a variable nuclear labeling index, suggesting a high proliferation rate in the tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a radical hysterectomy specimen revealed an invasive well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, measuring 3 cm and involving approximately 50% of the cervical circumference, with lymphatic and vascular invasion present. All examined pelvic lymph nodes (16 total) were negative for carcinoma, confirming no lymph node metastasis. Additional findings included benign secretory endometrium, and the case was reviewed and confirmed by the pathologist.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right tongue resection, with a maximum tumor size of 2.7 cm and a thickness of 1.2 cm, but no perineural or lymphovascular invasion detected. All surgical margins, including the right posterior margin, floor of mouth mucosa margin, and deep tongue muscle, are free of tumor, and a total of 40 regional lymph nodes examined show no evidence of malignancy. Additionally, a p16 test performed on the tumor cells returned negative results.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has malignant mesothelioma of the right pleura, characterized as epithelioid type, with a maximum thickness of 1.7 cm and evidence of invasion into surrounding structures, including the diaphragm and mediastinal fat. Out of 24 examined lymph nodes, four were found to be positive for metastatic mesothelioma, while other lymph nodes sampled showed no tumor presence. The report concludes with a pathologic staging of pT3, N2, indicating locally advanced disease with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the oral cavity, specifically in the anterior floor of the mouth, with a tumor size of 4.0 cm and evidence of perineural and angiolymphatic invasion. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in 1 of 3 level I lymph nodes, while all other examined lymph nodes from the right neck, left neck, and left perifacial regions were negative for carcinoma. The margins from the composite resection, including the mandibular bone margins, were free of carcinoma, and the minimum pathologic stage is classified as pT4aN2.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the right breast, measuring 7.0 cm, with multifocality and a Nottingham score of 8/9, while the sentinel lymph node biopsy shows one positive lymph node for metastatic carcinoma with a size of 3.5 cm and extracasular extension. Additionally, eight out of ten axillary lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 2.0 cm and also exhibiting extracasular extension. The tumor is ER-positive, PR-positive, and HER-2/NEU negative, with no definitive lymphovascular invasion identified and all surgical margins free of invasive carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates a well-differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma located in the left upper lobe of the lung, measuring 43 mm, with lymphatic permeation but no blood vessel or perineural invasion, and no pleural invasion identified. Metastatic carcinoma is present in some peribronchial lymph nodes, while the No. 5 and No. 6 lymph nodes show only reactive changes without malignancy. The overall classification of the tumor is T2N1MX.

The pathology report indicates a 6 cm poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, with invasion into the muscularis propria and focal necrosis. Fifteen examined lymph nodes showed no evidence of metastasis, and there was no venous invasion noted. The tumor is ulcerated, and the specimen was obtained from a subtotal gastrectomy, with the tumor located in the fundus of the stomach.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of Grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung, characterized by a mass measuring 3.8 x 3.7 x 3.5 cm that invades the visceral pleura. All examined intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes and mediastinal lymph nodes are negative for tumor involvement. The bronchial margin is also negative for tumor, suggesting clear margins.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has a malignant glioma, specifically a high-grade glioblastoma, characterized by significant nuclear anaplasia, brisk mitotic activity, and extensive necrosis. The MIB-1 proliferation index ranges from 6% to 30%, and the MGMT promoter is found to be methylated, suggesting potential responsiveness to alkylating agent therapy. Additionally, there is no detected allelic loss on chromosome arm 1p, with partial deletion suggested on chromosome arm 19q.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous papillary carcinoma of the endometrium with significant myometrial invasion (approximately 83%) and lymphatic invasion, while the endocervical canal shows no definite tumor involvement. Metastasis is noted in one of four left pelvic lymph nodes and one of three right para-aortic lymph nodes, while the remaining lymph nodes and soft tissue samples are negative for malignancy. The tumor is classified as pT1c N1 MX according to the TNM staging system, indicating it is confined to the uterus with regional lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a benign fibrous-walled cyst in the lower pole of the right kidney, along with multiple small tubulopapillary adenomas, with no evidence of malignancy. In the upper pole of the right kidney, a papillary renal cell carcinoma was identified, classified as Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, measuring approximately 10 cm, with extensive necrosis and hemorrhage but negative surgical margins. The report confirms that the tumor is limited to the kidney and does not show lymph-vascular invasion.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the spermatic cord, with a well-differentiated component comprising less than 10% of the tumor. The tumor measures 13.5 cm and involves fibroadipose tissue, including the spermatic cord, but does not invade the testis, which appears unremarkable. The tumor is located 0.08 cm from an unspecified inked margin and is associated with a foreign body reaction to synthetic mesh.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a polypoid endometrioid type endometrial adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 2, with probable very superficial myometrial invasion and no vascular invasion. The cervix shows CIN-1 and CIN-2 lesions, while the ovaries and uterine tubes are free of pathological findings. Overall, the findings suggest a localized endometrial carcinoma with associated cervical dysplasia.

The pathology report indicates the presence of moderately differentiated intestinal-type adenocarcinoma in the gastric stump, with infiltration into the perigastric adipose tissue and the entire depth of the small intestine wall, as well as peritoneal and lymphatic involvement. The right paracardic lymph node showed metastatic adenocarcinoma, while other examined lymph nodes from the left paracardic, lesser curvature, and celiac trunk regions were uninvolved by neoplasia. The proximal and distal margins of the surgical specimen are free of neoplastic involvement, and the non-tumoral gastric mucosa exhibits signs of alkaline gastritis.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type) in the right kidney, with a tumor size of 6.9 cm and a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV, showing local invasion into the renal sinus muscular branches but no renal vein invasion. The excised lymph nodes from the precaval and paracaval regions were not involved, and the adrenal gland was found to be benign with multiple benign cortical nodules. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the overall staging for the renal cell carcinoma is pT3b.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a tumor in the small intestine, measuring 6x5x3 cm, with three associated mesenteric masses. Microscopic examination reveals ulceration of the mucosa and the presence of large transformed lymphoid cells, leading to a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Immunohistochemical results confirm the tumor's B-cell origin, with CD20 positivity and CD3 negativity, indicating extranodal involvement in the small intestine and mesenteric lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated endometrial carcinoma (FIGO grade 3) in the uterus, with myometrial invasion noted. All other examined tissues, including the omentum, right ovary, left ovary, and cervix specimens, were negative for malignancy. Non-cancer related findings include adenomyosis and leiomyomas in the uterus, with no vascular invasion or involvement of the uterine serosa.

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3.2 cm in the right upper lobe of the lung, which invades and ulcerates bronchial tissue, but all surgical margins are negative for tumor. Additionally, multiple lymph nodes from various levels (Level 10, R4, and Level 7) were examined and found to be negative for metastatic disease. Overall, the findings suggest localized lung cancer without evidence of metastasis in the examined lymph nodes.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has multifocal moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lateral segment of the liver, with negative surgical margins and associated cirrhosis. Additionally, a right hemicolectomy revealed an invasive adenocarcinoma in the colon, also with negative margins, and no significant abnormalities in the ileum or appendix. The report highlights the presence of vascular invasion in the liver tumor and suggests further genetic evaluation due to the loss of one mismatch repair protein in the colon tumor.

The pathology report indicates that a completion lobectomy of the left thyroid revealed an incidental finding of papillary microcarcinoma measuring 1 mm. This microcarcinoma was identified in the context of multinodular hyperplasia. The report emphasizes that the findings are unofficial and should not be filed in the patient chart until confirmed by medical records.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has been diagnosed with glioblastoma following excisional biopsies of brain tumors from the right temporal region. The tumor exhibits characteristics of high histological grade (WHO IV), including nuclear anaplasia, frequent mitoses, and microvascular proliferation, with a MIB-1 proliferation index of 28%. Immunohistochemical analysis shows overexpression of the p53 protein in more than 50% of the neoplastic cells, confirming the aggressive nature of the glioblastoma.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the cecum, measuring 9.2 cm, with tumor extension through the muscularis propria into the subserosal adipose tissue. No carcinoma was identified at the proximal, distal, or circumferential margins, and there was no evidence of lymphovascular or perineural invasion, with a total of 32 lymph nodes examined showing no metastatic carcinoma. The final staging is pT3NO, and additional findings include scattered lymphoid aggregates and hyperplastic polyps, with no carcinoma detected in the appendix.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of multifocal infiltrating duct carcinoma with lobular and clear cell features in the right breast, with tumors measuring up to 1.5 cm and close to the medial margin. One of fifteen axillary lymph nodes was positive for tumor with extra capsular extension. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive estrogen and progesterone receptor status, while HER-2/neu was negative.

The pathology report indicates that no neoplasia was found in the examined lymph nodes from both the right and left pelvic regions. A radical prostatectomy revealed invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4 + 4 = 8, involving both lobes of the prostate, with established extracapsular extension and focal involvement at the surgical margin. Additionally, there was extensive perineural invasion and focal angiolymphatic invasion, but the bilateral seminal vesicles were free of carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent extensive resection of soft tissue tumors, with the diagnosis of metastatic papillary serous carcinoma in the omental tumor and poorly differentiated papillary serous adenocarcinoma in both the right and left adnexa, showing surface involvement. The uterus and cervix were noted to have atrophic endometrium and leiomyoma, while cytology of peritoneal fluid revealed suspicious cells consistent with adenocarcinoma. Overall, the findings suggest advanced ovarian cancer with metastasis and associated endometriosis.

The pathology report indicates that a total thyroidectomy was performed on a female patient with a 2.9 cm nodule in the right thyroid lobe, which was diagnosed as classical papillary carcinoma, well differentiated. The tumor is partially encapsulated, with no identified mitotic activity, necrosis, blood vessel invasion, or extrathyroid extension, and the surgical margins are free of tumor. Additionally, a separate focus of papillary microcarcinoma measuring 0.2 cm was found in the left lobe, and the remaining thyroid tissue shows nodular hyperplasia.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason grade of 4+3, involving approximately 10% of the prostate volume and showing focal extraprostatic extension, but with negative surgical resection margins. Examination of the right and left pelvic lymph nodes revealed no evidence of metastases, with all nodes sampled being negative for cancer.
